column2: GENEVA, Aug. 21. -- A proposal that the League of Nations be supplemented by a "central consultative parliament," theoretically open to all League members, but practically confined to the democratic or Socialist States, was made here tonight by Herbert Morrison, British Labor leader.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Evidence intended to show that officers of a nation-wide detective agency sought to place spies in industrial plants and destroyed records in defiance of a Senate inquiry, after records had been subpoenaed, was unfolded today as the La Follette subcommittee on Labor and Education began hearings in its investigation into industrial espionage and civil liberties.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP). -- M.J. (Mike) McLaney of New Orleans strained a back muscle and then defaulted, sending stolid Carl Fischer of Detroit into the final round of the men's singles in the national public parks tennis tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Reports of an impending shakeup in the Federal Communications Commission, involving displacement of the special counsel and chief accountant who have been conducting the commission's inquiry into the affairs of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, were denied and denounced today by Commissioner Paul A. Walker, chairman of the telephone division.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP). -The Athletics won their third straight game today, coming from behind to beat the Senators, 3 to 2, as Horace Lisenbee defeated Buck Newsom in a pitchers' duel.
IRUN, Spain, Aug. 21. -- Hand-to-hand combat broke out on this battlefront tonight, substantiating reports that an attempt to end the Spanish civil war by mediation had proved futile.

Most of the excitement at the Stadium yesterday was not to be found in the ball game itself, in which the pace-setting Yankees took the measure of the Red Sox, 4 -- 1, before 6,000 spectators. In fact, it was not until the struggle was over and the clubs made their way to the dressing rooms that the bombshell exploded.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 21. -- Only one of the sixty-five pairs participating in the qualifying round of the Seawane Club's annual best-ball invitation tourney played par golf today. That distinction was achieved by Dr. Edward Kempf of St. George's and Arthur A. Brown of Brentwood, who carded a 72 to take medalist honors.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 21. -General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, Rebel commander, in a broadcast from Seville tonight, alleged the Spanish playwrights Jacinto Benavente, Serafin Alvarez Quintero and his brother, Joaquin, and the artist Ignacio Zuloaga had been murdered in Madrid.

SEATTLE, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The Seattle Times tonight published a purported Communist handbill supporting striking editorial employes of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, while the American Federation of Labor began an investigation of the Seattle Central Labor Council's action in listing the newspaper as "unfair."

Retail sales volume, while not showing as large a daily increase as was the case last week, held above the comparative 1935 week by a considerable margin, reports here yesterday indicated. The showing as between individual stores was spottier than has been the case in July, and the fact that there are two less business days in the month affects the comparative August figures.

The Summer theatre circuit will dip pretty close to Broadway this evening -- about as close at it has ever come, in fact -- when the San Carlo Opera Company and the Shuberts offer a revival of "Florodora" at the Randalls Island Stadium.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 21. -- While Mikhail Botwinnik of Russia, having drawn the bye, was idle today, Dr. Max Euwe of the Netherlands, chess champion of the world, regained the lead in the international masters' tournament at University College. Euwe played a short drawn match with Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia, lasting only nineteen moves.
ALLENTOWN, N.J., Aug. 21. -The Monmouth County (N.J.) Historical Society was making efforts today to obtain funds with which to purchase as a permanent museum the historic Imlay mansion here.

The right of oil companies to collect tax rebates on products sold to seven New York City departments was presented yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church when he heard argument in a suit by the Richfield Oil Corporation of New York against the city to collect $7,141 as a refund for gasoline taxes paid the Federal Government that the city refused to pay.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 21. -- Miss Peggy Boulton of Toronto, fiancee of James Graham Parsons, who is secretary to Joseph Clark Grew, American Ambassador at Tokyo, was the guest of honor this afternoon at a tea and reception given by his mother, Mrs. James Graham Parsons, at Bonnie Brae, Prospect Hill, Stockbridge.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 21. -- Carl H. Cook, Republican State Chiarman, said today, after talking with Governor Landon, that certification of the nomination of Governor Landon and Frank Knox for President and Vice President would be filed soon with Mrs. Alex Miller, Iowa Secretary of State.

With few exceptions Protestant pulpits in the city will be occupied tomorrow by visiting clergymen or assistants. Some of the visiting preachers are from overseas. Most of them are here under the auspices of the Committee on Interchange of Preachers and Speakers in America, Great Britain and France, which this Summer brought over more clergymen and sent more American clergymen to the British Isles than in any previous year.
BUFFALO, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Seneca Indians appealed to the Federal Government today for "protection" from a court order for public sale of forty-three acres on the Tonawanda reservation.

The Brown Book Company, publishers in Kansas City, Mo., say they have sold 1,300,000 copies of their anti-New Deal booklet, "Pay Day." The booklet, signed by a pseudonym, is composed of the letters of a Missouri farmer to his son in college and is devoted to showing up "New Deal fallacies."

Settlement of two more claims in the vast and tangled match interests left by Ivar Kreuger was sought yesterday in a petition filed with Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee, by the Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Corporation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Babe Herman ended his walkout and returned to the Reds today, but it made no difference to the Cubs, as they downed the Reds, 7 -- 2, making the game safe with a six-run uprising in the fifth.
In the Aug. 10 issue of your newspaper appeared a story on the close finish of the 100-meter men's freestyle swimming event at the Olympics.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Aug. 21. -- Rhythm, sailed by John Abberley and John Middlebrook of Pequot, became the first boat to win two races in the Star Class Atlantic Coast championship series today as she reclaimed the lead on points after relinquishing it for a day.

James J. Braddock will defend his heavyweight championship of the world against Max Schmeling next year. The titleholder's manager, Joe Gould, made this fact public last night when he announced that he had signed for Jersey Jim to oppose the German battler in the Madison Square Garden Bowl on June 3 or June 10, 1937.

The stock market broke out of its erstwhile narrow trading range yesterday and registered its sharpest decline since April 27. Leading stocks were off 1 to 3 points and a few high-priced issues dropped 8 to 10 points, with a few others filling in the gap with losses of 4 to 6 points.

One of Broadway's famous ticker-tape parades will welcome back home the United States delegation of athletes to the Olympics, which closed last Sunday in Berlin, it was announced here yesterday by Mayor La Guardia's committee to welcome the Olympic team.

Taken as a whole, this country of ours is in grave peril from now till election eve. Looked at State by State, the outlook is as cheerful as one could ask. All the forty-eight Commonwealths taken together, as we Republicans see it, are now on the edge of the abyss and the brink of destruction because of FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT'S leadership.

Winthrop G. Martin, young men's secretary of the New York State Y.M.C.A., will be one of the leaders of the fourteenth International Conference of the Men's Clubs of the Y.M.C.A., opening tomorrow at Silver Bay, Lake George, and continuing until next Saturday.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, received favorable reports yesterday from representatives of Michigan, Wyoming, Washington and Arizona who visited him at headquarters at the Hotel Biltmore.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- President Roosevelt's itinerary for his Western tour is as follows:

DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Roxie Lawson, who pitched to only one batter, was credited with the victory today as the Tigers scored four runs, including Goose Goslin's twenty-second homer, in the eighth inning to defeat the White Sox, 8 to 6.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 21. -- Mrs. Henry E. Coe gave a reception tonight at the Appletrees, her place in First Neck Lane. During the evening the hostess, in costume, presented readings with musical accompaniment of a group of old English ballads, which she calls "Mistress Tom D'Urfey," as a tribute to the wife of the author, Tom D'Urfey.

Our blessings are manifold. Even the condition of idleness may be turned to advantage. One need only reflect, and wonder at the benefits that have been thrust upon us. Peaceful contemplation, long the almost exclusive jewel of the East, is now ours.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Martin Moore, 22-year-old hall-boy, swore today that he was tortured into confessing he killed Helen Clevenger in her Battery Park Hotel room at 1 A.M. July 16 and produced witnesses to support his assertion that he was at a birthday party at the time.

MOBERLY, Mo., Aug. 21. -- Two coal miners -- one of them apparently little the worse for his three-day ordeal -- were rescued alive late today from a gas-filled tunnel in which four were imprisoned by a mine collapse Tuesday afternoon, but death had taken their companions.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- Two young women were introduced to society here tonight. They were I Miss Consuelo V. L. Villa, daughter of Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa of New York and this city, and Miss Sidney E. Cheston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Radcliffe Cheston of Radnor, Pa., who has been visiting Mr. and Mrs. George Eustis Paine at Lands End.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- By carding two sub-par rounds of 69 and 68, Paul Runyan successfully defended his Westchester open golf championship at the Metropolis Club today, finishing with a total of 280, nine strokes better than his nearest rival, Willie Macfarlane of Old Oaks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- Improvement in the shipping demand for hogs advanced the market here today and prices were steady to 15 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday. The top was up 10 cents to $11.60 and the day's average also rose 10 cents to $10.20. Fresh pork loins were quoted at 15 to 25 cents a pound wholesale, the same as yesterday.

I read your lines on Jack Sharkey's return in today's NEW YORK TIMES and looked with futility for some lament about this daring raid on the home for the aged. At a time when the former champion should be thinking of Dr. Townsend, rather than Joe Louis, can't we have a few critics of such frauds upon the public?

HOPEWELL, N.J., Aug. 21. -Charles Ward Hall, 59 years old, of Morrisville, Pa., a designer of flying boats and airplanes since 1916, who flew as early as 1909, was killed today when his plane crashed into a tree on Mount Rose, a wooded knoll between this town and Princeton.

Maritime labor leaders exchanged charges yesterday as the Regional Labor Board opened its hearing on the complaint of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association that wage contracts had been signed by its rival, the United Licensed Officers Association, with steamship companies whose men it did not properly represent.

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- The German Foreign Ministry, through the semi-official organ Diplomatische Korrespondenz, protest against the projected unveiling of a monument at Dinant, Belgium, next Sunday, to the memory of Belgian civilians killed in the World War, because the monument bears the phrase, "Furor teutonicus," in its inscription.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 21. -The women golfers of the Huntington Country Club, for the second time in a week, proved too strong today for the teams from the Crescent Athletic Club and the Northport Country Club in their three-event inter-club matches played yearly for possession of the large silver trophy donated in 1933 by Crescent members.

ALBANY, Aug. 21. -- Seven hundred and forty-one law students, mainly those who were graduated in June from the various law schools in the State, passed the bar examinations conducted June 29 and 30 last, the Board of Law Examiners reported today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 21. -- After winning both the medal and the tournament last year, T. Suffern Tailer Jr. today had to play an extra hole to gain a place in the first sixteen in the fifth annual Maidstone Club invitation golf tourney.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today the plea of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration several securities, all representing old issues which have been exchanged for new issues now listed and registered on the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The Bureau of Roads said today that New York State would receive about $3,390,000 from the Federal Government for grade-crossing elimination and protection during the fiscal year beginning in July.

The city of Rochester, N.Y., will consider tenders on Wednesday for a new issue of $1,000,000 of public welfare certificates of indebtedness. The certificates will be dated Sept. 1, 1936, and will mature on Feb. 1, 1937.

Wearing evening clothes and masquerading as peaceful visitors, 150 men and women Communists precipitated a riot last night on the Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen, the second of its kind in about a year, after passing out anti-Nazi handbills and parading through the liner yelling, "Hitler must be kept out of Spain."

Joseph M. Hyland, executive secretary of the Millinery Quality Guilds, Inc., explained "the fundamental principles" of that organization in testifying yesterday in the hearing of charges of restraint of trade brought by the Federal Trade Commission against this group of designers and manufacturers of women's hats.

THE local opening of "Tovarich" can now be listed for that week which begins on Oct. 12. "Tovarich," in case any one has forgotten, is the Robert E. Sherwood adaptation of Jacques Deval's play, one which won acclaim last season in London and, with its New York cast, is now practicing in the British provinces.
All yachtsmen, like the Gaul fondly remembered from our second-year Latin books, are divided into three parts. It depends a good deal on their women folk.

TWO weeks ago this westbound motorist asked the proprietor of a Main Street restaurant in a small manufacturing town in the Pennsylvania mountains what he heard about the election. The man had been affable about road advice, pleasantly frank, indeed, about what was good and not so good on his own menu.

Thomas Jefferson Ryan, who has filed petitions as a candidate for a Democratic nomination for judge of General Sessions, submitted to the Supreme Court yesterday an application for an injunction to restrain the Board of Elections from removing his name from the primary ballot.

A STAR CAST" is not only the latest, but also the most unusual addition to the stream of novels that has flowed from the pen of Naomi Royde-Smith. Its basic idea is so apt and so simple that one wonders why it has never been used before -- although, had Miss Smith not hit upon it in a happy moment, it might well have idled in the breadline of unemployed plots for years to come.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith today named the Rev. Thomas J. McDonnell of New York City national director of the Pontifical Society for the Propagation of the Faith, succeeding the Right Rev. William Quinn.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Melvin Crook of Upper Montclair, who became a motor boat driver while a Princeton undergraduate a few years ago and hasn't yet lost a race in his long, low, mahogany, beetle-shaped Betty V, proved to a huge regatta throng on the North Shrewsbury today that he and his extraordinary boat are getting better as time goes on.

The American Association of Port Authorities, whose membership includes port representatives of the United States and Canada, has undertaken a study of the importance of commerce to cities equipped to handle import and export commerce.

Japanese imports of cotton cloths produce alarming effects on the minds of some members of the cotton textile industry. Mr. DONALD COMER, president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association and also of the Avondale mills in Birmingham, Ala., has written an article for Liberty Magazine called "Japan Is at War With Us Now."

Would you wallow in gore? Than read this book and have your fill for once of slaughter. The Mr. Strang who gives the book its title is a man with a mission, and that mission is to wipe out the crooked parole racket, which he accomplishes by the simple expedient of killing off all the men who are connected with it -- perhaps not quite all, but enough.

The Continental Steel Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a net profit of $715,914 after depreciation, interest. Federal income taxes, and after giving effect to the new basis of inventory valuations. The profit is equivalent to $2.67 a share on 200,590 no-par common shares, excluding stock held in the treasury, after annual dividend requirements on 25,651 shares of $100 par 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 22. -- At the close of play tonight in the international chess masters' tournament, Mikhail Botwinnik of Russia led the field of fifteen competitors as a result of his victory in the eleventh round over Sir George Thomas, former British champion, in a hard-fought match lasting sixty-nine moves.

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., Aug. 22. -- The ninth annual team race for the Barclay Trophy among 15-foot Perrine Sneakboxes and the sixth annual team race for the Little Egg Harbor Yacht Club perpetual trophy were decided late today after being delayed by a heavy rainstorm and squalls. Seven other classes also competed.

IN a 350-acre park in Toronto, flanking Lake Ontario, Canada's annual national exhibition will open on Aug. 28. This display, the largest of its kind in the world, is an event of first importance, for it reflects the country's progress over more than a half century in science, industry, agriculture and the arts.

Despite late declines, a good part of the commodity futures group ended with net gains for the week ended on Friday, with the trading volume showing some improvement. Rubber and silk futures continued their declines, however, and coffee and copper turned weak.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y.,, Aug. 22. -- C. Everett Bacon of Montclair, N.J., regained his laurels in the Sagamore invitation golf tournament today but not without a struggle, going to the eighteenth hole to defeat Ira Mendelson of Albany, 1 up.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 22. -- Princess Aymon de Faucigny Lucinge of Paris, who is passing the Summer at the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods, gave a dinner party at the hotel tonight in honor of Bishop John Thompson Dallas of New Hampshire.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Rice brought the entertainments of tennis week here to a close tonight with their annual tennis ball at their home, Miramar.

THE assurance that the ghosts of all good Americans will come to Paris is a promise which all Frenchmen like to hear. In 1929 it gave the 500,000 Frenchmen who live from tourist trade the feeling that they would always be able to sell to the American, whether he was dead or alive.

A PITILESS searchlight is turned on the life of a large family in Katharine Ball Ripley's novel, "Crowded House." Usually fiction depicts brothers and sisters, when there are many of them, as having a truly idyllic time.

BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Aug. 22. -- Admiral Nicholas Horthy and Chancellor Adolf Hitler, both sworn foes of communism, had a confidential chat on the terrace of the Fuehrer's chalet here today. It was the first time the two men had faced each other and the visit lasted two hours.
STONE HARBOR, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Joe McNitt of the Raritan Yacht Club, Perth Amboy, N.J., with A.M. Grant as crew, won the first comet class race of the second annual Stone Harbor regatta today.
Rails down under the impetus of a spanking easterly breeze, twenty-one sturdy craft in the auxiliary and sailing divisions started yesterday in the City Island Yacht Club's annual overnight race.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Commissioner Peter G. Ten Eyck of the Milk Control Board heard the demands of up-State dairymen voiced in strong terms before 2,000 farmers here tonight, with a threat made of a milk holiday beginning Labor Day unless the farmers' demands were met.

THE music of Wagner held a predominant place in the concert programs given at the Lewisohn Stadium during the eight-week season just concluded, according to a compilation issued by the Stadium Concerts, Inc. Of a total of twenty-three Wagner performances the Prelude and Love Death from "Tristan und Isolde" was played four times by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

JUST completed but not yet opened to the public is John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s new archaeological musuem in Jerusalem. The finest building of its kind in the world, it represents an outstanding achievement in the difficult adaptation of modern architectural design to Oriental tradition.

Daniel Frohman, who gallantly forgets the ages of all his women friends "over 35," entertained at dinner last night for a party of girls. The occasion was his eighty-fifth birthday and it was celebrated in the memento-crammed studio atop the Lyceum Theatre in West Forty-fifth Street, which has been called New York's "pioneer penthouse."
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 22. -- It is expected that more Negroes will vote in South Carolina in November than at any election in the last forty years.

The police of Darien, Conn., who had been seeking Satoris Cunningham, 37-year-old Negro, for more than two and a half years on a $10, 000 gem theft charge, reported that they had him in custody yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Nearly half a million placements were reported last month by the Federal Employment Service, a 54 per cent increase over July, 1935, but a slight decrease from last month's total, due chiefly to continued reduction in the number receiving security wage employment on relief projects.
BOSTON, Aug. 20. -- Massachusetts last week scored three new political records.
BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Sanford Bates, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, urged today that all persons when released from prisons or reformatories be put on parole.

CUBA is sick and tired of turmoil and violence. She has had enough of political murders, bombings and kidnappings. She is equally disgusted with revolutionary terrorism and with "ley de fuga" (law of flight) killings by soldiers and police. Neither rebellion nor dictatorship is wanted.

There are so many detectives in this story and there is so little cooperation among them that the criminal who is apparently trying to exterminate the Kelsey family very nearly accomplishes his purpose. That he does not quite succeed is largely a matter of luck.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Vernon Kennedy registered his seventeenth triumph of the season today as the White Sox evened the current series with the Tigers by winning, 9 -- 3.

VIENNA, Aug. 22. -- The elaborate system of secrecy surrounding Admiral Nicholas Horthy's movements in Austria turned into something like wartime camouflage today when Austrian and Hungarian official circles strove to persuade foreign correspondents that "there will be no meeting between Horthy and Hitler in Berchtesgaden."

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Trade was appreciably better at both wholesale and retail by comparison with last week, and held well above last year's level. The retail trade record was helped by two suburban "dollar day" events which drew record crowds of bargain-minded shoppers and by a further expansion in the sales of the Loop department stores.

The Paint Store, Inc., opened last May in New Rochelle by T.J. Maloney, Inc., advertising agency, to test paint merchandising ideas, has proved a successful experiment, it was reported yesterday by Frank Gilday of the agency's merchandising staff.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Another strike was added to Minneapolis' list of labor troubles today as the shortage of packaged goods on retail grocers' shelves grew more pronounced with continuation of the walkout by truck drivers for wholesale grocery concerns.

Statements of earnings of twenty-seven leading public utility companies in the United States compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES for the twelve months ended on June 30 show that while gross earnings were 4.84 per cent larger than in the preceding year, net earnings after operating expenses, depreciation and all taxes were 5.15 per cent higher and net income available for stocks was up 9.39 per cent.

Seven persons were slightly injured at about 12:45 P.M. yesterday when a westbound Third Avenue trolley left its tracks at Westchester and Fteley Avenues, the Bronx, and crashed into a pillar of the Pelham Park elevated railway.

An illicit alcohol ring is suspected of operating in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, according to officials of the New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. A search for evidence of such a ring was begun yesterday following the capture in Jersey City by police late Friday night of a truck carrying more than 1,000 gallons of alcohol.

THROUGH the country high temperatures had a retarding effect on retail trade in the week, but important centers still reported substantial gains over last year. Industrial cities showed the best increases, which ranged up to 20 per cent.

MILLIONS of children are playing in squalid streets these blue-and-gold Summer days. But the average city dweller, long inured to the sight, has grown cynical. "The chances are that most of them could go to a playground if they really wanted to," he tells himself as he passes by.

With all thoughts of fighting again put off until next June, James J. Braddock will devote the immediate future to caring for the ailment that forced a postponement of his bout with Max Schmeling, whom he was scheduled to meet the end of next month.

GENEVA. -- Some Ford records have been beaten by Soviet workers, thanks to the Stakhanoff movement, Boris Markus, chief of the labor and employment section of the State Planning Commission, Moscow, says in the current International Labor Review, the ILO monthly.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Through the mud that has laid low champions from Kingfisher to Gallant Fox, Discovery today strode to the most decisive victory to be scored in a big American stake in many years.

THE American Revolution was only a little war, as wars go, for it lacked all the devastating equipment which makes a first-class war today. Without our modern refinements of destructive weapons there was greater reliance on stratagem for the swift movement of troops, for which a knowledge of the terrain was indispensable.
A woman's sleeplessness led to the arrest early yesterday of four youths on charges of stealing valuable fur coats and pelts from a loft building at 204 West Twenty-seventh Street.

The author has lived among the Vai tribe to which Sondo belonged and his picture of life in Liberia is authentic. The material is fresh and interesting, there is plenty of action and the story is told in a pleasantly simple and childlike fashion.

WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 22. -- A return to "the American way of life" with determination to win security and abundance without sacrifice of the freedom of the individual citizen was advocated today by Governor Landon in a speech at the village in which he was born forty-eight years ago.

About 6,500 men are now actively employed on naval construction work and in the shops at the navy yard in Brooklyn, officers said yesterday. This figure does not include about 1,700 others on the WPA payrolls.
The Socialist party announced yesterday that it would support both the proposed City Charter and the proposition for proportional representation in the coming election. The Socialist support was

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- While President Roosevelt will avoid active political campaigning until October, he is considering devoting that month to an intensive fighting campaign extending from New England to California and embracing what advisers regard as "soft spots" in the Middle West.

THERE had been two years of purity, and the cinema was experiencing that righteous glow that comes only to the reformed sinner. If the lurid past was viewed wistfully, there was realization of the healthy financial position of the industry, appreciation of the absence of discord within it and of the improved regard in which it was being held by the community.
Nearly eighteen years after the World War, Americans still are restoring to Belgium treasures she lost during the German invasion.

This city is to have another visit from a woman country newspaper correspondent from the Middle West. Mrs. Susan Frawley Eisele, this year's winner of the annual Country Home Magazine award for the best country newspaper correspondent, is due to arrive today. She comes from her husband's eighty-acre farm nine miles from Blue Earth, Minn.

The facilities of commercial organizations and trade associations have been heavily taxed during the past year because of the increase in government regulation of business, according to the annual report of the Merchants Association of New York, made public yesterday.

THE reformation of a parvenu family, due to the wholesome effects of losing their money in the depression, is the Pollyanna theme of Mr. Wylie's latest novel. In spite of its happy moral lesson, the book's atmosphere is gloomy.

MEXICO, D.F. IN the last two years the biggest attraction of this city's musical life was undoubtedly the annual season of the Orquesta Sinfonica de Mexico. The concerts of this orchestra gather in the beautiful and acoustically well-accommodated great hall of the Palace of Fine Arts the most distinguished music lovers of the Mexican capital.

SALZBURG. ACTUALLY, it ought to be "Die Meistersinger von Salzburg"! For Wagner's great comedie humaine is not only the most daring and ambitious thing Salzburg has ever attempted in the way of artistic enterprise (Reinhardt's "Faust," for all its length and bulk and open-air scenic stunts, does not hold a candle to it), but likewise, taken all in all, the most startlingly and sensationally successful.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson's special raiding squad not only continued its crusade today against gambling and vice, but also directed attention to enforcement of the State Liquor Law by raiding a club in the Central City District which allegedly sold liquor after the 2 A.M. closing hour.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- The elements today did to the Giants what few rival ball clubs have been able to do since July 15. An overnight rain followed by a cold, early morning drizzle put a temporary halt to one of the most amazing winning streaks in the modern history of baseball.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 22. -- More members of this year's graduating class at Princeton University have obtained employment than had their predecessors in the class of 1935 at this time last year, Richard W. Warfield, '30, director of the bureau of appointments and student employment, announced today.

The special quality that distinguishes R. Austin Freeman's stories from the general run of detective fiction is that they are completely logical and orderly without being in the least dull. Mr. Freeman has the rare faculty of injecting excitement into a pains-taking and, to all appearance, leisurely investigation.

PLEASURE cruises to the Lesser Antilles ports are now popular. Between July and November, the "Little West Indies" may be comfortably visited in a cruise of less than a month. The limited space on the comparatively few steamers which take in these islands was booked solid throughout the early and middle Summer, for the most part by school teachers and educators whose holidays expire about Labor Day.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 22. -- A warning of "strenuous objections" to a possible alliance between Japan and Germany was given today by French and British delegates to the Institute of Pacific Relations.

WITH the appearance week of licensed matrons in most of New York City's 70-odd movie houses, unaccompanied youngsters between 8 and 16 years had the novel experience of stepping up to the box office and buying their tickets without having to ask some indulgent adult to "Take me in mister, please."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- Eight New Yorkers qualified tonight together with one representative each from Washington, D.C.; Providence, R.I.; Portland, Ore., and Montreal, for the finals of the annual open championship of the American Chess Federation.

Accused of attacking a young woman who reported to the police that she had been forced into an automobile Friday night while she was walking along a Brooklyn street, five men were rounded up by detectives yesterday on charges of robbery and criminal assault.

NOW, when irises that have become too thick require replanting, and when newer sorts are being added to the garden, consideration may be given to their use as landscape material. Too often they are grown merely as "varieties" in a collection in the border.

As long as a wide variety of trades and professions continues to be open to women, Maysie Greig will find plenty of subjects for her facile pen. Give a girl a job and Miss Greig will provide the romance. In "Workaday Lady," Carol Carson -- not so beautiful, but very magnetic -- got an interesting position in a de luxe studio for commercial photography, Challoner's.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Aug. 22. -- John Cunniff, qualifying medalist, today reached the semi-finals of the first annual metropolitan public links championship at the Hendricks Field Club when he played splendid golf to win his first and second-round matches.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22. -- The two finalists in last year's competition went hurtling out of the annual Maidstone invitation golf tournament in short order today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22. -- San Franciscans who happened to pass along Sansome Street just off the now defunct Barbary Coast yesterday witnessed an unusual and colorful spectacle -- the annual payoff of the men who labor for gold in the canneries of the "Land of the Midnight Sun."

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 22. -- Martin Moore, Negro hallboy, was convicted today of slaying Helen Clevenger with a pistol in her Battery Park Hotel room here July 16 and was sentenced to die Oct. 2 in the State gas chamber.

E.W. HOWE of Kansas has been known for years as the author of "The Story of a Country Town." E.W. Howe's daughter, Mateel Howe Farnham, of New York and Connecticut, is also well known as a writer. But she, too, has her story, if not of a country town, at least of a country estate on the outskirts of a rural community.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Justice Department officials said today that the arrest of a large ring of men and women in Connecticut this week on white slavery charges was only the first of a series of "clean-ups."
I was greatly interested by Anne O'Hare McCormick's article in your issue of Aug. 2, because I found in it the impressions I had very keenly felt myself on my recent arrival in this country.

BEE-KEEPING to most of us suggests a phase of farming -- an industrial pursuit in which the insects are kept for honey just as cows are kept for milk. But while it may be only a part of the day's work to farmers, to others it is a source of endless entertainment and interest.

DR. WALLACE, who is Professor of History and Economics at Wofford College, has written an excellent and well proportioned chronicle of a State rich in historical interest. The low country was the scene of early colonization attempts by French and English, and the State, in pre-Revolutionary times, during the Revolution, and again in the Civil War, played a foremost part in national affairs.

Eight women and four men who participated in the Communist riot aboard the Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen Friday night were arraigned in West Side Court yesterday and paroled in custody of counsel until a hearing Thursday on charges of disorderly conduct.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- The finals of the sixth annual Sagamore tennis tournament are being held today on the Hotel Sagamore courts. Paul Martin of Troy, tri-counties champion, who has one leg on the trophy, will play Raymond Loucks of Schenectady for the men's singles title, the match having been postponed until today because of rain.

Optimistic reports on the Congressional situation in the East, including assurance that Republicans will win all three seats from Maine, will be taken to Governor Landon by Representative Robert Low Bacon of the First New York District, who will leave tonight for Erie, Pa., to join the Governor's party.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- Casting aside all considerations of political tactics and personal safety, the leaders of the Confessional opposition within the German Protestant Church have declared open warfare against what they consider to be an organized campaign to drive Christianity out of Germany and to replace it with a neo-paganism based on the myths of Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, cultural director of the Nazi party.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 22 t).-Alfred E. Smith Jr., son of the former Governor and Presidential candidate, replied today to his wife's petition for generous alimony and counsel fees pending their separation action in October by in-! sisting that figures revealed here in court regarding his law practice income were greatly exaggerated.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The appointment of Dr. C.T. Wang as Chinese Ambassador to the United States became known here today.
No other cruiser contest in Eastern waters has evoked as much genuine interest as the Captain Billhop race, which will be held in a counter-clockwise direction around Staten Island next Sunday.

TRENTON, Aug. 22. -- Assemblymen Emerson D. Fite and Maurice Fitz-Gerald of New York have been named to a committee to arrange for a public meeting to be held by the Interstate Commission on the Delaware River Basin on Oct. 2 and 3 at Buckwood Inn, Shawnee-on-the-Delaware, Pa.

LONDON has its first professional baseball league this Summer. Seven teams are playing every Saturday and Sunday under 100 per cent American rules, but in a setting which is 100 per cent English. And sizable crowds are attracted to the games.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Making full capital of a four-goal handicap, a well-mounted team of West Point officers galloped off with a 10-9 victory over the Westchester Country Club quartet today.

GLEN ROCK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- A party of four that will include Miss Helen Somerville of 99 Beech Road, this borough, will leave here Thursday for a bear hunting expedition in Canada. Bows and arrows will be used in the search for bear. Others in the party are Henry W. Schreiber of Norfolk, Conn., Boy Scout executive, Mrs. Schreiber and William Troeger of Cross Road, Saddle River Borough.

IN the world of the air, anniversaries pile up with great rapidity, keeping pace, in a sense, with the swift movement of flying itself. This month marks, however, one of especial interest. It is the twentiety anniversary of the founding of Aviation Magazine by Major Lester D. Gardner, who has, in the two decades which have intervened, built other sound institutions in the field to which he has devoted such untiring effort.

WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 22. -- On his way to his birthplace here Governor Landon was cheered today by crowds at six stops in Ohio, was told by party leaders that he was certain to carry the State, and in a speech at Canton lauded President McKinley as an American patriot and the type of statesman whom it would be well to follow.

Seven thousand supporters of the American League Against War and Fascism, many of whom carried huge posters expressing resentment against munitions-makers, dictators and all forms of undemocratic government, marched in the league's third annual "peace parade" yesterday afternoon from the lower East Side, through Yorkville, to Harlem, where there were addresses.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 21. -- A furor of indignation has followed Kentucky's recent third public hanging. The press has been deluged with letters from horrified subscribers, who cry that they will hereafter be ashamed to acknowledge their nativity away from home.

IN 1894 Mr. Lee was an engineer in a little mining settlement on the northeast frontier of India. It was there that he was initiated into the practice of taking drugs. A Hindu doctor gave him a shot of morphia for an attack of malaria, and then when this habit became fixed, gave him cocaine to counteract it.

The engagement of $685,000 gold in France for shipment to this country was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This lifted to $18,500,000 the total of gold taken in Paris for United States account since the current movement began on Aug. 7.

LOVE of the land which had been theirs for generations is a prime characteristic of the family whose story this is. More consciously than most Americans, Mrs. Peattie's Honeywells are aware of their roots. They are proud of old Adoniram, their ancestor, who came out to the Illinois prairie a century ago and planted his acres along the Indian portage trail.
The annual Fall edition of the Metropolitan Golf Association's handicap list has made its appearance and contains something over 2,000 names of golfers representing 158 clubs.

FISH AND CHIPS" shops, peculiarly British institutions, are appearing in New York. Several, on a modest scale, have put out their signs in Eighth Avenue and one is being opened, amid modernistic settings, in the East Forties.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- With the Giants idle because of rain, the Cardinals were able to increase their National League lead to a full game today when they nosed out the Pirates, 4 to 3.

Few comments of the European press on President ROOSEVELT'S Chautauqua address on war and peace got into the dispatches. Probably most of them were commonplace and pointless. But one significant editorial came from Germany. The Berlin Tageblatt resented what it called Mr. ROOSEVELT'S "dig at us."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Four languages, English, French, German and Spanish, may be heard simultaneously without interference through an electric interpreting system which will be used at the Third World Power Conference Sept. 7-12.

HAILED in Great Britain as a milestone in communication, in some respects more important than the introduction of the penny post nearly a century ago, are the trials now in progress with Canopus, the first of the new fleet of Imperial Airways flying boats.

HOLLYOOD. MOST of the time, Walter Wanger says, the good, the true and the noble are his inspiration and his guide. But pictures like "Shanghai" shake faith in these virtues. "Shanghai,'' which cost a mere $250,000 and drew considerable adverse comment from the critics, played two weeks at the New York Paramount and five weeks in London, making, of course, a barrel of money.

A STORY for little children which has the simple, unforced appeal of a fairy tale. The artist-author, who has lived in the country of which she writes, has caught in both text and illustrations the even tempo and gentle atmosphere of rural Mexico.
NOT often does a dedication throw so much light on a book as does the inscription on the flyleaf of "Light of the Years." Mrs. Crowell dedicates her poems with affection to her fellow-men.

Presenting figures showing that New York City has the highest automobile liability insurance rates, though it has the lowest motor death rate among cities of more than 500,000, Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday to establish a citizens' committee to obtain reduced rates.

CHANGES in the habits of people are changing the homes they live in. Apartment houses are replacing the single-family dwelling; garages are larger, kitchens smaller; bathrooms are more numerous. Just what the relationship is among these facts is, of course, debatable, but the sequence is clear.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Eastern Long Island's most elaborate supper club, the Montauk Island Club on Star Island, in the middle of landlocked Lake Montauk, was raided early this morning by Lieutenant J.A. Gaffney of Troop K and twenty other State troopers.

A TRIPLE memorial show is being held at the Artists Union for three of the deceased members -- I. Diener, E. Richardson and L. Santillo. In the publicity prepared for the occasion the untimely deaths of all three are charged to the capitalist system and its neglect of the artist during his life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- With two and a half times as many white men as women, Alaska still maintains something of the gold rush condition, when men outnumbered women nine to one. According to the Division of Territories and Island Possessions, no State in the Union has a comparable ratio.
WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 22. -- Uncles, aunts and cousins of Governor Landon on both his father's and mother's side turned out here today to do him honor.

MR. SANDBURG read his "Good Morning, America" as the Phi Beta Kappa poet at Harvard in 1928 and there he half promised what he now fulfills in "The People, Yes": a long, considerable poem mainly made out of the sayings of the people. Then he read to the students:

GRAND COULEE, Seminoe, Bonneville, the Tennessee Valley and other water-power systems -- we shall hear much of them during the campaign. Their cost runs into the hundreds of millions. The opponents of the President hold them up as striking examples of reckless extravagance and marshal statistics to prove that the Northwestern enterprises, for example, have been carried out in regions already over-electrified.

Conceding the point that they no longer are a match for the Yankees in the sprints, the Red Sox elected to try out the McCarthy men over a distance of ground as the two clashed in the second game of their series at the Stadium yesterday.

THE third annual Bennington Festival came to a brilliant conclusion with four performances in the State Armory in Bennington, Vt., Aug. 12-15, by Doris Humphrey, Charles Weldman, their concert company and the "workshop" group of the Bennington School of the Dance, of Bennington College.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 21. -- The last week has been the bloodiest in the number of Jews murdered by Arabs since the Palestine disturbances began four months ago. It has also been marked by the particularly barbarous nature of the attacks.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Aug. 22. -- In special session next week, the Alberta Legislature will begin to put through legislation providing for issuance of social credit dividends to Alberta people. They will not go to all citizens of Alberta, only to those who have signed the "covenants."

European countries and their nationals have more than $6,000,000,000 in cash and securities here which could be speedily utilized for the purchase of materials in event of an outbreak of war on the Continent, a canvass of their resources here yesterday revealed.

TO the Lombardy Tuesday afternoon, after a preview glimpse at Metro's "Romeo and Juliet," to meet Basil Rathbone and perhaps to extract a few opinions from that able and well-grounded Shakespearean. Found him well hemmed in on a love seat, chatting to two interested listeners, while Mrs. Rathbone, the Ouida Bergere of scenario writing note, moved about the intimate cocktail lounge talking of this and that with one guest or another.

HAVING dealt clearly and briliantly, in their earlier volume, with the elements of mechanics, physics, chemistry and biology, the noted authorities who wrote "Simple Science" have now set before the general public opportunities of wider knowledge in further fields.

POINT O'WOODS, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Sixty-seven yachts sailed today in the annual invitation regatta of the Point O'Woods Yacht Club, with Lloyd Emory in Sea Fever winning by a wide margin in the Star Class event.

Marshalling statistics of the improvement of business since March, 1933, Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, declares that the recovery has been achieved at a reasonable cost to the nation, in his book, "I'm for Roosevelt," published this week.

According to a report of the National Safety Council the State of New York has made a relatively better showing in the matter of traffic accidents. The reduction in accident deaths during the first six months as compared with the same period in 1935 is put at 13 per cent, and more than half of the difference was credited to New York City.

REBUFFED: According to the latest issue of The Army and Navy Journal, our naval men and our Ambassador to Spain, Claude G. Bowers, have had a spat. Mr. Bowers, says the Journal, upon the arrival of our ships to take away Americans stranded by the Spanish revolt, "went aboard the Coast Guard cutter Cayuga and, assuming the role of commander, began issuing orders.

POULTNEY, Vt., Aug. 22. -- The Historical Society of Poultney will begin reconstruction of the Colonial architecture of East Poultney, the restoration to be dedicated as a memorial to George Jones, founder of THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Rev. Frederick E. Wolf, president of the society, announced today.

THIS is an English novel which sets out to create and sustain a figure of the type European financier, post-war buccaneer model -- one of the minor Lowensteins, Kreugers, Hatrys et al. of international speculation. As such it is a very readable and wholy intelligent story which keeps to the main track and gives you an entertaining and convincing picture of Jerry Foyster's rapid rise and sudden fall.

ONE of J.B. Priestley's qualities for which he has not received the credit due to him is his courage A few years ago he was bold enough to defy a conventional taboo of the publishing and bookselling world -- one of the most daring things a professional author could possibly do.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary was speeding to New York last night with a world's record in her grasp and with nothing but weather conditions seeming able to hold her back.
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 21. -- With the season for intensive campaigning nearly at hand, the Democratic party in this State is in a condition which might be described as "when a feller needs a friend."

MARRIED women comprise the largest group in tune with educational broadcasts, according to a tabulation of the mail received by the Educational Radio Project, Office of Education, United States Department of Interior, which produces five informational network programs.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden was looking well and appeared to have not a worry in the world when he returned to his post this week after seventeen days on a badly needed holiday. To see him bound from a taxicab and stride through the door to the Foreign Office last Tuesday one would have imagined that the Ethiopian fiasco had never occurred and that the international horizon was cloudless.

Is the great fuss and bother over the matter of Japanese textile imports into the United States much ado about nothing? After all, the cotton manufacturing industry of America produces annually in excess of 7,000,000,000 yards of cloth, and to this giant volume current Japanese imports bear a ratio of only 1 per cent.

IN woodlands throughout the country Boy Scouts are blazing trails, much after the fashion of the pioneers of a bygone day. Older Scouts who are seasoned campers are detailed for this work, which requires a knowledge of woodcraft, considerable muscular effort and some training in charting a way through unmarked forests.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 21. -- The Lone Star State faces a most unusual, if not unprecedented, situation in regard to the casting of votes by her twenty-three electors for her favorite in the Roosevelt-Landon contest. Federal law requires that the electors of each State "meet and give their votes on the first Monday after the second Wednesday in December next following their appointment, at such place in each State as the Legislature shall direct."
DES MOINES, Aug. 22 (AP). -- A shortage of water at many points in the Midwest raised a new problem today for the drought conference between President Roosevelt and five Governors here Sept. 1.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Senators and the Athletics divided a twin bill today, the Senators taking the first game, 12 -- 8, and the Athletics the second by 7 -- 6.

Augusto Rosso, Italian Ambassador to the United States for the last three years, sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia to assume his new post as Ambassador to Russia. He expressed regret over leaving the United States.

The long-sought prosperity which so persistently eluded us during the days of President Hoover is in process of glorious realization under the Roosevelt administration. Business is on the upgrade everywhere.

Mrs. Clara Petzler, 74 years old, of 1,194 University Avenue, the Bronx, who was taken suddenly ill while driving through Everett, Mass., with her two daughters yesterday, was driven home under police escort for the entire 250-mile trip.

Reports that South Africa will follow the example set by Australia and curb imports from this country continue to alarm exporters here who are watching the agitation in progress in Africa much as they did that in Australia earlier in the year.

IF you want to know who they were -- that large company of jolly English folk who debarked from the liner Carinthia in the bright sunlight of last Tuesday morning and came pounding uptown in a veritable fleet of baggage-laden taxicabs -- just put the question casually to that singular but inevitable friend whose gramophone cabinet you know is stacked with disks of Gilbert and Sullivan music.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The State Department made public today the form letter it is sending to American munitions manufacturers who inquire concerning the government's attitude toward arms exports to Spain. It is based on the circular instruction recently sent to American consular officers in Spain advising them of the non-interference policy of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Lower taxes, suggested by Secretary Morgenthau in his open letter to President Roosevelt, probably cannot become a reality before 1939 or 1940, if the past and present state of Federal finances correctly foreshadow the future.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 22. -- Criminal court administration in Massachusetts, and more particularly in Boston, is just where it was fifty years ago, and the judiciary is largely responsible, according to Professors Sam Bass Warner and Henry B. Cabot of the Harvard Law School.

The struggle now going on between the Soviet Union and Germany to gain the upper hand in the Balkans brings into conflict two unlike styles of political scheming. Russia is trying to mend fences against Germany originally built up by France but lately neglected.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Good relief pitching by Ray Davis, plus homers by Lew Riggs and Babe Herman and a two-run pinch double by Gilly Campbell in the sixth gave Cincinnati a 6-4 triumph over the Cubs before 19,000 fans today. It was the fading National League champions' ninth defeat in their last thirteen games.
SANTA ROSA, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Cries of "The Vigilantes!" heard as a band of night riders acted in a farm labor strike a year ago, resounded in court today as victims told their stories.

Designed to "free art training from antiquated methods of instruction," a new educational unit has been organized in the Extension Division of Columbia University and will begin operation with the Fall term, it was announced yesterday.

The public affairs committee of the Socialist party of New York made public yesterday a letter to State Senator John J. McNaboe, requesting that the recently selected "committee to investigate communism in the New York Schools" hold only open hearings and that the Socialist party be permitted to have counsel present "for the protection of all who may testify."

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Miss Maria Vanherwerden of Lake Mohawk and Rahway, riding her 6-year-old brown gelding, Gambler, was awarded the Governor Harold G. Hoffman Trophy for horsemanship at the fourth annual Essex County Horse Show held on the D.L.B. Smith estate today.

GARDENERS who take an especial interest in clematis -- and their number seems to be increasing rapidly -- will read with advantage a comprehensive article in the July issue of the Journal of the New York Botanical Garden, by the clematis authority, J.E. Spingarn.

KAHOKA, Mo., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Mrs. Nellie Tipton Muench, who was forced to give up the "gift of God" baby she claimed as her own, was convicted today by a rural jury of criminal conspiracy to obtain the child unlawfully.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Lanova Corporation of New York City today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 200,000 shares of its common stock of $1 par value. The shares will be offered to the public in lots of 40,000, 6,000 and 10,000 at $7.50 each; a block of 22,000 at $15, and a block of 113,000, representing control, at $40 a share.

THE college girl's highly individual whims in dress are a major concern of New York's shopkeepers during the last weeks of Summer. Special displays of college clothes are being opened in New York department stores. These shops usually have on their staffs a woman, but recently graduated from some leading college, who is familiar with campus requirements.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 22. -- High Vatican officials branded as "atrocious mockery" tonight the appeal of the Rev. Father Juan Garcia Morales, a former Spanish Deputy, for Catholic aid on the side of the Madrid Socialist government.

NO answers could be simpler, or briefer, than those given by Miss Blitzsten to the following questions: Why be psychoanalyzed? How is psychoanalysis worked? What kind of person should one expect the analyst to be? and Whence comes psychoanalysis?

Rankers in New Jersey have been drawing up the details of a plan for a cooperative pension system through the New Jersey Bankers Association and expect to have it ready for operation by Sept. 1, it was disclosed yesterday in an account of the plan appearing in the weekly news bulletin of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21. -- On the face of primary election returns, Missouri is so overwhelmingly Democratic that only a forlorn hope remains for the Republicans. But there are elements in the situation which point to a closer race than the primary indicates, especially in the election of Governor.

"Florodora," a popular musical play of yesteryear, was the first of a series of Shubert productions presented last night on the newly erected mammoth stage in the stadium on Randalls Island by Fortune Gallo.

IN the craft of popular fiction Kathleen Norris has often demonstrated the advantage of pursuing a safe middle course. Not one time in ten does she surprise her readers; and doubtless she could be said never to disappoint the vast majority of them.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 21. -- What are the economic conditions in Manchester since the huge Amoskeag Mills, largest single textile manufacturing unit in the world, was ordered to liquidate? What has become of its 12,000 employes and how is the city of Manchester weathering the shock?

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21. -- California's slowly growing resentment against vigilante tactics that began after the San Jose lynching of 1933 and then waned during the general strike here, has now gathered force and found effective official expression.

Manufacturers of nationally advertised lines of food products see in the present firm price situation and the heavy demand for supplies throughout the country the greatest opportunity they have experienced in recent years to broaden sales volume.

In the covers of Fishers Island, N.Y., Oct. 23, 24 and 25, will be held the annual field-trial meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association, it is announced by Henry L. Ferguson, secretary of that organization. With the meeting opening on Friday, it is believed that three days will be ample for the running of the six stakes that have been arranged for springer and cocker spaniels.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Commissioner Ten Eyck told the farmers here tonight that they could get "a proper and fair return" for milk if they would take the situation in their own hands and decide unanimously to raise the price to dealers.

WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 22. -- Having taken the management of his personal campaign pretty much into his own hands, Governor Alf M. Landon, Republican nominee for President, has started it in the East with the capture of the forty-seven electoral votes of New York and the thirty-six electoral votes of Pennsylvania as his main and immediate objective.
NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 22. -- Two home runs, one by Ralph Boyle and the other by Ernie Koy, enabled the Newark Bears to break even with the Syracuse Chiefs in a double-header today.

PARIS, Aug. 12. -- A number of well-known Americans have recently gravitated from Paris to the cure resorts and music festivals of Central Europe. The other day Miss Anne Morgan and Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt took the Orient Express which King Edward VIII boarded at Calais.

Adversely affected by the heat wave, business moved at a slower pace in many sections of the country last week, although retail distribution continued to show gains over the figures for the corresponding period last year. There was less activity in most of the leading wholesale markets, as retailers generally have made heavy purchases in recent weeks to cover their Fall and Winter requirements.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The drought of 1936 is likely to be remembered for two reasons -- its heavy cost in losses and relief and the impetus it has given to the plans of the AAA and other governmental agencies for a long-term program on the nation's semi-arid Western farm lands.

Influenced by private reports of showers at two or three points in Northwest Texas and moderate hedge selling, prices on the Cotton Exchange sank yesterday into new low ground for the movement. The December touched 11 1/2 cents a pound, where a quantity of trade buying orders created resistance.

The share market rallied briskly yesterday and closed higher in light trading. The fairly active selling of Friday that resulted in a sharp setback in prices on that day was not repeated. On the contrary, many stocks began the day with overnight recoveries ranging from fractions to more than a point, and at the close of the two-hour session a representative list of issues had made gains ranging up to as much as 4 points.

YORK HARBOR, Me. -- Toward the end of August the York Harbor season is at its gayest and will continue so until after the Labor Day week-end. Entertaining continues day and evening, with ever-increasing pace. The Reading Room is the scene of a constant round of luncheons and dinner parties.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 22. -- An $18 automobile salvaged from a junkyard got out of control and overturned while descending a hill on the Berwick-Orangeville Highway just before midnight last night. Two young men were killed and three companions were injured.

IT sounds a little fantastic to credit Henry James with anything so humanly vulgar as a capacity for leering. Nevertheless the fact is that for thirty-five years he has leered steadily at Anglo-American criticism from 319 of his most important, most luminous and most neglected pages.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- Captain Wolfgang Fuerstner, creator of the Olympic Village, who committed suicide on Tuesday, was buried today with military honors.

HANOVER, N.H., Aug. 22. -- The names of 405 Dartmouth students, representing 17 per cent of the undergraduate body, are included in a report of distinctive scholastic accomplishment in the past academic year.

IN midsummer, particularly if the season has been hot and dry, there is likely to be a scarcity of garden flowers, making it difficult for a hostess to gather enough of them to decorate her rooms. Then it is that diminutive "arrangements" not only save the day but not infrequently create a charm which larger compositions lack.

From States furthest from New York winners in the C.I.T. Safety Foundation's safe-driver contest have started for the city, it became known yesterday. Winners in nearer States will start on schedules worked out to bring all the delegates here on Aug. 31 for a four-day conference on safe driving as understood by the average driver.

H.V. MORTON makes, here, an English journey. But it is not such a journey from place to place as were those of his well-known travel books, nor is it such a wide swing around the circle as Priestley's was, or Sir Philip Gibb's.

MORTARLESS walls, made and planted in a new way, have been meeting with enthusiastic success in American gardens. The idea is to provide a safe place for the more valuable members of the rock garden, as well as a fit setting for those choice plants which need a more isolated display.

QUEBEC, Aug. 22. -- Defeat of the Liberal party in the Province of Quebec last Monday after a thirty-nine-year reign was not so much a rebuke for the party as it was for the Taschereau "regime," in which former Premier Taschereau, his brother Antoine and Charles Lanctot, Assistant Attorney General, were prominent targets of attack.

Relief from the effects of harsh features of revenue measures, commonly referred to as "cushions," is generally provided for in the form of "credits" in the determination of taxable income. In calculating the amount of retained net income subject to the surtax on undistributed profits, it had been suggested that a corporation having at the beginning of its taxable year a deficit, or impairment of capital, should be permitted to take credit therefore.

FOR visitors now flocking to see the gigantic Boulder Dam and the artificial Lake Mead that stretches out for miles behind it, there, is another striking man-made spectacle close by. Reside the dam is Boulder City, new sober and bright, created a few years ago to house the dam workers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Governor Landon received a "full Presidential salute" when his special campaign train reached Cedar Rapids, Iowa, yesterday, but because of Democratic protests it was "fired" on the installment plan, the Republican National committee revealed today.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 21. -- Nothing that has happened since the Spanish-American War has aroused such keen personal interest in Latin America as the present civil war in Spain. To most Latin Americans a European war is a quarrel among neighbors which does not affect them personally and their interest therefore is largely academic.

Far too much emphasis is laid on domestic problems in connection with the approaching Presidential election, and we have relegated any serious consideration of our position and course of action in world affairs to the background.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 21. -- The "expansion" of the Tennessee Valley Authority exists only in the minds of the officials of the nineteen Southern utilities companies who are conducting a legal campaign to halt the New Deal's "yardstick-of-power" program, spokesmen of the Authority are saying here in their discussions of the latest move by private power interests to halt the Authority's work.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- Reversing the result of their last three meetings, Robert L. Riggs of Los Angeles defeated Frank Parker of Spring Lake today to win the Newport invitation tennis tournament and practically clinch a ranking in the first three in his initial season of play on turf courts.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Summer training of the members of the 107th Infantry, the old Seventh Regiment of New York City, ended at Camp Smith today with the showdown inspection of quarters, company streets and equipment.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 22. -- Legacies of nearly $6,000,000 held up for sixteen years became payable today with the death of Mrs. Roberta O'Neill, widow of Thomas O'Neill, founder of O'Neill Co., Inc., one of Baltimore's largest department stores. The chief of the three bequests was for the building of a new Catholic cathedral here.
WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 22. -- A half hour before Governor Landon's train arrived here at 2:15 P.M. the sun emerged brightly from an overcast sky, chasing away the rain clouds.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- Population surpluses and other problems of varied America's rural districts, including the drought area, cannot be solved without extensive emigration, according to findings in a study of population redistribution made public today by the University of Pennsylvania.

PAULSBORO, N.J., Aug. 22. -- A 75-year-old motorist lost control of his sedan on a main highway about a mile from here this morning, plunged up an embankment, across a fifty-foot lawn and into the living room of a small bungalow, injuring a woman and her 15-monthold daughter.

Mrs. Charles F. MacLean, widow of a former Supreme Court justice, who has lived in a mansion on Fifth Avenue between 130th and 131st Streets for half a century, has received the support of more than 100 residents of that neighborhood in resisting the effort of Park Commissioner Moses to condemn her land for a playground.

HOTEVILLA, Ariz., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Rattlesnakes, as the "little brothers" of the Hopi people, sped to the underground gods tonight bearing prayers for rain imparted by tribal priests in the ancient rites of the snake dance.

Employes of the rapid transit lines, including the city's Independent System, will appear before the Transit Commission in September to demand from the La Guardia administration a showdown on its labor policy toward subway workers if and when unification is achieved.

TWENTY-SIX years ago Dr. Robert R. Williams, who since has become chemical director of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, began to devote his spare time to the study and investigation of vitamin B1, generally known as the "nerve vitamin" because of its importance in keeping nerve tissue in a healthy state.

MOTORISTS are acclaiming the action of the War Department in approving the plans for a vehicular bridge and causeway over the Hudson River between Tarrytown and Nyack. After official action at Washington several days ago the Rockland-Westchester Crossing Authority, the promoter of the project, held a meeting to discuss ways and means of building the structure and to consider arrangements for making borings.

National titles as well as historic trophies will be at stake when more than 2,000 of the country's leading rifle and pistol shots from all sections of the country gather to take part in more than sixty matches which are to start tomorrow at Camp Perry, Ohio.

IT was surprising to hear "I Am the Fox," fourth of the Atlantic prize novels, referred to before publication as a picture of Iowa. It does come out of Iowa, and its episodes place, geographically, in Iowa. But it would be misleading indeed if, with the flush of regional novels, "I Am the Fox" were launched as another local-color item, a testament of the Bible Belt.

Two historic ships of the Japanese Navy, the old first-class cruisers Yakumo and Iwate -- veterans of the Russo-Japanese War and the World War -- will steam into New York early Tuesday morning for an eight-day visit.

TORONTO, Aug. 22. -- Two of the oldest gold mining areas in Canada, the Porcupine and the Kirkland Lake camps, are still the richest producers in the Dominion, the Department of Mines reported this week in a survey of the industry in 1935.

The volume of bonds called for redemption before maturity, which had shown a receding tendency in the week before last, was restricted further last week. Moreover, the announcements, except for one large foreign issue, did not include any important prepayments. They consisted principally of small lots of municipal and foreign bonds.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 22. -- Racing over a sloppy strip for the first time in his life, the Motor City Stable's Appealing captured the Roger Williams Handicap, at a mile for 3-year-olds and upward with $5,000 added, at Narrangansett Park today, winning from C.V. Whitney's Roustabout by a nose. Three lengths back came the favorite, J.W.Y Martin's Dark Hope.

DETROIT, Aug. 22. -- Senator Couzeus, under whose administration as Mayor Detroit approved municipal ownership of its street railway system, was appointed United States Senator in 1922 to succeed Truman H. Newberry, who resigned.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Braving chill winds and a threat of rain, there was a great outpouring tonight of horse-show enthusiasts on the grounds of the old Field Club for the final session of the annual North Shore exhibition. Important trophy competitions and the various championships were the magnets that kept enthusiasm at a high pitch and the rails lined with partisans.
OSBORNVILLE N.J., Aug. 22. -- Two persons were fatally injured and two others hurt critically near here today when a car in which they were riding crashed into a tree.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 22. -- Floyd B. Olson of Minnesota, the nation's only Farmer-Labor Governor, died here tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- A projected city of fantastic domes and towers began rising today from the surface of San Francisco Bay to house the $40,000,000 Golden Gate International Exposition of 1939.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 22. -- The twenty-third annual Greenwich Horse Show will be held on Sept. 12 on the John Sterling estate here.

VENICE. TOTI DAL MONTE took her first fling in drama the other day when she appeared as Lucieta in the Goldoni comedy "Le Baruffe Chiozzotte" (The Squabbles of Chioggia), in an elaborate open-air mounting in Campo San Cosmo in the Giudecca.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The American game of football is credited by scientists of the Carnegie Institution of Washington for the discovery of one of the most important archaeological sites of Central America.
TIENTSIN, China, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The reported stabbing of a Japanest citizen by a Chinese soldier at Fengtal was believed today to portend a new breach in Chino-Japanese relations.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Brig. Gen. Perry L. Miles, United States Army, will arrive here tomorrow night from his permanent station, Fort Ontario, N.Y., to relieve Colonel Alien J. Greer of command of the Ninety-eighth Division, Organized Reserves, composed of 250 reserve officers from New York State, during their annual two weeks' Summer training period.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Representative William Lemke, the Union party Presidential nominee, has received 431 requests from the New England States for speaking engagements, John Nystul, national campaign manager, said today. He added that it was physically impossible to fill them all, but that the Eastern tour would be arranged with a view to covering as many points as possible.

A legalistic problem, arising out of abrogation of the gold clause by Congress in June, 1933, which involves the validity of numerous bond issues floated since that time and which threatens to inject difficulties into the current large-scale refunding movement of corporations, recently has enveloped officials of the New York Stock Exchange, counsel for the Exchange and counsel for local security-issuing houses.

AN English girl with no knowledge of any foreign language is on a European railway train speeding homeward. There are a few other English people on the train, but those of them who are known to her look upon her with disapproval.

IN Geneva, where for two decades an elder generation has struggled against world chaos, representatives of youth from every corner of the world will assemble from Aug. 31 to Sept. 7. Their purpose will be the maintenance of peace and the preservation of liberty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- No evidence of any slackening in the quickened pace of industrial activity in the early weeks of Summer was found by the Department of Commerce through the middle of August, according to the department's weekly survey of domestic business conditions.

OLATHE, Kan. IT is a busy time out here in the Middle West. Every one is working hard to scrape enough out of the hot, dry soil, planted with wheat, corn and oats, to carry them through next Winter. Soon the roads will be heavy with a golden dust, kicked up by the stream of wagons hauling wheat to the elevators, and in a few weeks there will be a little money in people's pockets.
VIENNA, Aug. 22. -- The latest propaganda by the Austrian Nazis brings in the Bible.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. -- The unusually full program of social and artistic events now going on in Southampton and East Hampton promises to continue throughout the remainder of the season. The final weeks of the Summer give every indication of being lively, for the calendar lists the usual social functions as well as distinctive musical, dramatic and artistic activities.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 21. -- So far as success in early tests at the polls in the West is concerned, evil days have fallen on many candidates premising their chief claims to office on the Townsend plan. A variety of reasons probably are responsible for the Townsend decline.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- To clear up a misunderstanding as to the class of persons subject to registration as floor brokers under the Commodity Exchange Act, the Commodity Exchange Administration of the Department of Agriculture issued today the following statement:

MORE recreation for Americans and greater recreation areas in all parts of the country are contemplated in a new program evolved by the Department of the Interior, acting through the National Park Service in cooperation with the State governments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Within a few months the safety division of the Bureau of Mines will issue its millionth training certificate to a graduate of its first-aid classes. More than 963,000 persons have been trained in first-aid and mine-rescue methods, under the supervision of Federal experts.
