JERUSALEM, Aug. 22. -- This correspondent learned tonight on the most reliable authority that it now has been definitely decided to order a stoppage of Jewish immigration from the time of the arrival of the British Royal Commission, coming to investigate the Palestine disorders, until after all the work in connection with the investigations and recommendations of the commission has been completed.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Representative Thomas L. Blanton's twenty years in Congress were ended tonight when he conceded defeat in his bid for renomination in a run-off Democratic primary.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- A musical event of importance will take place at Pittsfield this afternoon, when the South Mountain String Quartet presents the seventh chamber concert in Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge's Temple of Music. Gunnar Johansen, pianist, and Professor Albert Sprague Coolidge of Harvard, viola player, and son of Mrs. Coolidge, will be the assisting artists.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Johnny Allen scored his fifteenth victory of the season today by shutting out the Browns with three hits. The Indians made nine safeties to win, 6 to 0. Only one Brown player reached third base.

HELIEVED and gratified, to use his own terms, after seeing the Warner production of his "Anthony Adverse," Hervey Allen departed Manhattan Thursday confident that the thousands of New Yorkers who have read his book will find the Warner Brothers' motion picture version, due at the Strand Wednesday, a satisfying reprise of an important part of his thousand and one or more pages of compelling adventure.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Charles Blair MacDonald gave a large reception this afternoon at White House, his place in the Shinnecoek Hills, for Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sterner of New York and Brick House, Richmond, Mass., who are his guests.

GLASGOW, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Fine victories kept Aberdeen, Rangers and Motherwell at the top of the Scottish Football League today. The Dons and Rangers were successful away from home, the former swamping St. Mirren, 4 -- 1, while Rangers made it 2 -- 0 at Falkirk. Motherwell, at home, overcame Clyde, 4 -- 1.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The dinner dance at the American Yacht Club here tonight attracted a large gathering.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The National Association of State Racing Commissioners adopted a resolution today urging formation of an organization of track operators "through which the problems of racing may be approached and its security maintained."

VIENNA -- The Austro-German agreement which took Europe by surprise in July has been in force for more than a month. Its causes and effects for Austria and for Europe are not yet fully clear, but are becoming perceptible.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Louis Wetherell, 20-year-old University of Southern California tennis star from Los Angeles, became singles champion of the nation's public parks today when he defeated Carl Fischer of Detroit, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 6-3, 6-3.

AN ambitious undertaking that should prove of interest to artists, libraries and the layman interested in American art, has been carried out by Porter Butts, Assistant Professor of Social Education in the University of Wisconsin. The results of his survey and research have been put together in a volume called "Art in Wisconsin," and the work comprises a history of the art of the State with consideration of the influence of the Middle Western frontier.

The contents of a number of old Spanish documents bearing on early American history have been saved, even though the originals may have been destroyed in the Spanish revolution, Miss Irene A. Wright, historian, revealed here after arrival from Lisbon, Portugal, last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The drought was explained here today by a serious-minded government weather expert as a case of "Mother Nature going round and round."

Floor coverings retailers continued to stock quantities of both rugs and carpets here last week, acting upon reports that price advances would be put into effect on short notice. Mill executives yesterday admitted that increases are contemplated in the near future, but declined to mention any specific dates.

BOMBAY UNIVERSITY has lately come in for much criticism for "slaughtering" candidates in this year's matriculation examination. Of the 24,000 who presented themselves 17,000 were declared unsuccessful and unfit to enter the university.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Stoller and George H. Bull, president of the Racing Association, entertained tonight at a dinner dance held at the Saratoga Golf Club for 100 members of the younger set and married set.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell, stormy petrel of the Red Sox, returned to Boston today firm in the belief that his $1,000 fine for quitting the mound against the Yankees yesterday was the result "of a huge mistake, in which I probably was most to blame."

International complications arising from the Spanish revolt multiplied ominously last week, the fifth week of civil war. German and British toes in particular were trod upon, and both Berlin and London took vigorous action.

Captain Harold L. Winslow sailed yesterday in command of the Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania on his first voyage as an intercoastal master. Captain Winslow was transferred from the liner President Harding in an exchange that took Captain James E. Roberts, a veteran of the intercoastal trade, back to the transatlantic service in which he obtained his early training.

Increased activity was shown in many wholesale merchandise lines last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Consumer buying has apparently started in earnest as indicated by reorders received for Fall dresses, coats, suits, handbags and piece goods.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The population of this Montgomery County village soared more than 300 per cent today as shotgun experts from all parts of the country converged for the thirty-seventh annual grand American trapshoot program.

WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 22. -- A crowd of about 75,000, as large as that which heard his acceptance speech at Topeka, greeted Governor Landon at West Middlesex this afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- London in August takes on the aspect of a strange city given over to sightseeing visitors, house decorators, preparations and rehearsals for new plays and cabaret shows for the beginning of the Winter season. Americans, resident here, follow the British habit of passing August in the North or on the Continent and at coastal resorts around England which are crowded with families.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 22. -- A youth was killed and two other men seriously injured near here today when a seaplane in which they were flying nose-dived into the Matedeconk River.

Three men arrested here on Friday as the supposed "strong-arm" members of an interstate vice combination were ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Vincent L. PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Standard Steel Spring Company notified employes today that its Coraopolis and Moon Township plants, near here, would close because of strike difficulties.

Share prices were lower on the week, due to the sharp decline on Friday when the list suffered its greatest setback in nearly four months. Still, with yesterday's brisk recovery, the drop in THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks on the week was held to 2.59 points. The week before there was a drop of 3.46 points.

ACCLAIMED in Europe as one of the foremost of living 'cellists, Gaspar Cassado is expected to prove himself one of the most important new artists of the ensuing season here. The Spanish 'cellist, a native of Barcelona, has toured widely in Europe and appeared there as soloist with the foremost orchestras.

RAPID CITY, S.D., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Concern over migration from the drought area was expressed today by Rexford G. Tugwell as the Great Plains committee studying the problem headed for Wyoming after promising consideration for remedial measures advanced here by the planning boards of seven Northwest States.

THE approach of another Fall season during which new car models will be introduced raises the question of what has been accomplished by the shift from the year-end to November in the announcement of manufacturers of their new products. Assurances come privately from executives high in the industry that they are committed not only this Fall but permanently to the advanced showings of new passenger cars.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- That drought and politics are inseparable is well known. Although it will not be the most important issue of the coming campaign, higher food prices are certain to be a factor in the next election.

LONDON, Aug. 1. For his hero he has chosen a man named Richardson, who has appeared in several novels, first as a simple police constable, and now in this story as Divisional Superintendent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- America's moral embargo against arms shipments to either side in Spain's civil war was bolstered today by a warning from an official of the United States Shipping Board that ship lines indebted to the government are obligated to comply.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Colonel E.R. Bradley of Lexington, Ky., finally hit the mark with his Bow and Arrow today.

ROME, Aug. 21. -- The pacification of Ethiopia, the basic task confronting Italy after the end of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, is the job to which General Graziani is now dedicating most of his time and care. It is estimated that 250,000 Italian soldiers are still in Africa despite the rainy season that prevents the penetration of troops into some parts of the flooded territory.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22. -- Mikhail Tomsky, whose alleged connection with the Trotskyist bloc was under investigation by Soviet authorities, committed suicide today at his country house at Bolshevo, near Moscow, it was announced here tonight.

In an optimistic mood after his conference at Hyde Park with President Roosevelt, James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, was back at party headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore yesterday preparing for another week of conferences with party leaders from several States.

The use of salt in treating highways is being tried experimentally in some Canadian Provinces and several sections of the United States, It is reported. Following experiments by the National Research Council of Canada, a government body, and at McGill University of Montreal, the use of salt for eliminating dust on gravel roads and reducing cracking of the surface has spread.

PARIS, Aug. 20. -- Fabric gloves are making a strong offensive to recapture the supremacy of the evening accessory mode. Mainbocher, Schiaparelli and others stress gloves that match evening gowns in trimming as well as material.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa. -- Disliking the prospect of an unofficial boycott of American goods by South African producers, United States importers who have offices here have stepped in to try to help sell South African deciduous fruit and wines to their country.

One of the keenest scrambles in the history of golf will take place Tuesday over the double layout of the Winged Foot Golf Club when a field of 206 players will attempt to qualify for the United States amateur championship, which will be played over the historic Garden City Golf Club course in September.
TOKYO, Aug. 22. -- Of thirty so-called national renovation policies prepared by government departments, the Cabinet yesterday gave provisional approval to twelve.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Drenching rain weakened the drought's grip on much of the farm belt today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- With a heavy sea running all day and a steady northeast breeze making the last leg of the triangular course a spinnaker run, a fleet of seventy-four boats took part today in the seventeenth series of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound under the auspices of the New York Athletic Club.

MORE than once in these columns have we had occasion to regret the transiency of motion pictures. Film reviewers have been selecting their "ten bests" since 1922, possibly before, but that has not guaranteed their permanence or kept their memory green.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 22. -- New Zealand's Labor government has turned to public works on a large scale as a remedy for unemployment. The principal provision of the plan announced by the Laborites is the spending of $105,000,000 for projects which range from building roads to irrigation plans.

TOKYO, Aug. 22. -- War on a really large scale between Japan and China is nearer today than it has been at any time since the conclusion of the Treaty of Shimonoseki in April, 1895, whereby the first Chino-Japanese war was liquidated.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Sensation and Judge Mahoney, 2-yearolds from the, Newbrook Stables, and Mary Evelyn, juvenile pacer owned, by Max Yavner of Newark, triumphed in the three events of the matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.
ALEXANDRA PALACE television station, on London's northern heights, is ready for action. Soon pictures will be showering from its tapering mast, 600 feet above sea level, on across countless roofs.

The reduction in passenger fares made on June 1 caused an increase in Eastern railroad revenues which surprised even proponents of the change and resulted in an immediate decline in highway omnibus receipts, a survey disclosed last week.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Preparations for the national open championship scheduled to start here next Saturday were continued at the Meadow Brook Club today as several high-goal poloists practiced on Whitney Field with Michael Phipps snaring the scoring spotlight.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- For the second successive week there are no openings ahead, but the two weeks immediately following will make up amply for that state. On Monday, Aug. 31, Chariot will sponsor a straight play, "Gentle Rain," at the Vaudeville. On Tuesday, in Manchester, "Farewell Performance" will be tried out.

While major sentiment with respect to Fall operations continues notably optimistic on the part of retailers and manufacturers, the rise in the price of foodstuffs occasoned by the drought has now become enough of a factor to cause some revision of estimated gains in retail trade for the next four months.

MOSCOW, Aug. 21. -- In a frivolous ballroom of a vanished nobility, where dancing girls in the plaster frieze smile down on sixteen doomed revolutionaries, a fantastic drama is moving toward its final curtain.

WEDDINGS: City Clerk Michael J. Cruise opened a new and quite cheerful marriage chapel in the Municipal Building last Tuesday. As a dedication service he joined in wedlock Henry Hoffman, 34, of Queens, and Mrs. Eugenic Zimmerman, 32, of Manhattan. Thereafter the regular marriage performer, Philip A. Hines, first deputy clerk, took over.

Admiral William Daniel Leahy, now commanding the Battle Force of the United States Fleet, probably will be named the new Chief of Naval Operations, to succeed Admiral William H. Standley, who is scheduled to retire in December, it was learned yesterday.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Summer colonies along the Vermont shore of Lake Champlain are crowding many recreational events and social activities into the remaining August days. This is particularly true of the several camps for boys and girls along the lake shore, most of which will close at the end of this week.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Evening-up operations accounted for a good part of the trade in grains today on the Board of Trade, and price fluctuations were somewhat erratic. September wheat and corn were affected by scattered liquidation, but the distant deliveries had relatively firm undertones, local operators buying corn on reports of shipping sales of 118,000 bushels, while only 30,000 bushels were bought to arrive from the country.
SEATTLE, Aug. 22. -- The Seattle chapter of the American Newspaper Guild announced a mass meeting for Tuesday night to "inform the public" on the issues of the strike.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Governors of Louisiana and Mississippi chose "seconds" today for their Labor Day yachting duel off the Mississippi Gulf Coast.

With the defending champion in men's singles, William Lurie, not scheduled to play until today, the metropolitan public parks tennis championships began yesterday at Walker Park, Livingston, S. I.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 22. -- Imagine, if you can, the picture of a hurtling comet striking the State of Rhode Island, devouring two-thirds of its area and chasing its inhabitants to cover, and you have in effect a picture of the blight that the ravaging forest fires of the last three weeks have caused in Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 22. -- For the next major phase of its tercentenary celebration Harvard University moves this week to the field of public health. A five-day symposium of the subject will start Monday and include conferences, special sessions and meetings of learned groups in various specialized fields.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- The outlook for concerted action by European powers for a "hands-off" policy toward the Spanish struggle is viewed in German official quarters as materially improved in the past twenty-four hours. Ratification of a common embargo accord, embodying all the essential conditions for rigid non-intervention, is now be-

PAMPLONA, Spain, Aug. 22. -- Rebel forces drove their "big push" on toward Madrid tonight, fighting desperately to reach the side of their comrades in Toledo's besieged Alcazar before it was too late.

ROME, Aug. 22. -- The Italian press hastens to throw cold water on the optimism caused in international circles by Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano's note of acceptance of the French neutrality proposal by unanimously emphasizing that effective application of the accord depended on all other European powers' unconditional agreement to Italy's definition of neutrality.

THE rebellion in Spain now is revealed as a movement which, if successful, would establish another Fascist dictatorship in Europe and confront democratic France with three Fascist neighbors on her frontiers. It is significant that Spanish Rebels quickly received from Germany and Italy both sympathy and airplanes with which to overthrow the legitimate Spanish Government.

NEW streamlined automobile trailers which bring all the comforts of home to the open road are becoming increasingly common on the highways. America's fast-growing transient population, said to have achieved record-breaking proportions within the last few months, now takes to the road in style.

SARANAC INN, N.Y. -- The annual Saranac Inn invitation motor-boat regatta, to be held on Saturday, will be featured by the handicap free-for-all race for the Saranac Inn Cup, presented by Walter E. Frew of New York.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Sinclair gave a dinner for fifty at the Maidstone Club tonight in honor of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Bole, who are at the Hedges. A party at Fairlawn, the Sinclair home, preceded the dinner.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The leading social event of the coming week will be a fancy dress ball to be held at the Bar Harbor Club on Wednesday. The ball itself will be preceded by several private dinners at the club.

MANY of New York's Summer visitors who come from inland States have more than sightseeing on their minds; they want to sample one of the main attractions of the Atlantic seaboard -- shore dinner. They can find it in some of Manhattan's seafood restaurants, but they are more likely to route their cars to fishing ports and near-by resorts where the shore dinner is traditional.

NEW streamlined automobile trailers which bring all the comforts of home to the open road are becoming increasingly common on the highways. America's fast-growing transient population, said to have achieved record-breaking proportions within the last few months, now takes to the road in style.

SARANAC INN, N.Y. -- The annual Saranac Inn invitation motor-boat regatta, to be held on Saturday, will be featured by the handicap free-for-all race for the Saranac Inn Cup, presented by Walter E. Frew of New York.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Sinclair gave a dinner for fifty at the Maidstone Club tonight in honor of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Bole, who are at the Hedges. A party at Fairlawn, the Sinclair home, preceded the dinner.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The leading social event of the coming week will be a fancy dress ball to be held at the Bar Harbor Club on Wednesday. The ball itself will be preceded by several private dinners at the club.

MANY of New York's Summer visitors who come from inland States have more than sightseeing on their minds; they want to sample one of the main attractions of the Atlantic seaboard -- shore dinner. They can find it in some of Manhattan's seafood restaurants, but they are more likely to route their cars to fishing ports and near-by resorts where the shore dinner is traditional.

IT is difficult not to overestimate a man one admires but does not love. Yet Cezanne's influence on the painters of today cannot be overestimated. He was the first abstractionist. He is still the first abstractionist -- even including those of our contemporaries who are putting an increasingly finer point on their definition and will soon be giving spiritless exhibitions of celluloidless celluloid in spaceless space.

All peoples are today becoming largely standardized as regards customs, costumes and food as the result of tourist, radio and cinema influence; but, despite this, it is coexistent with a growing and bitter spirit of nationalism. Unless the worst manifestations of this can be overcome, war is inevitable.

The spectacular Drukman case enters another important phase, and perhaps its most dramatic, in the executive chamber at Albany at 2 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon. At that time, Governor Lehman will begin hearings on the demand of the extraordinary grand jury of Kings County for removal of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan.

ABOUT 60 per cent of all drivers have defective eyesight, and correction of their vision would tend to reduce accidents, Dr. Ewing Adams, president of the board of governors of the Optometric Research Institute of Michigan, revealed after a visit to the De Soto plant, according to L.G. Peed, vice president of the company.

THESE are strange days in an odd world and perhaps the Red Dawn is breaking over the big league diamond. Comrade Van Lingle Mungo threw down his tools in Pittsburgh, snapped his fingers at Capitalist Casey Stengel and abandoned his fellow-workers under the Brooklyn banner. He couldn't get away fast enough afoot, on horseback or by rail.

THE Highland gatherings are in full swing. Not since the last of the pre-depression years, say 1930, have there been so many Americans in Scotland to watch the clans compete in the playing of the pipes, the dancing of reels, flings and sword dances, and the tossing of the caber (Gaelic for tree trunk).

MOSCOW, Aug. 22. -- Mikhail Tomsky died suddenly today at his home near Moscow. Officials said Mr. Tomsky, who was head of the State Publishing House, had committed suicide because "he became entangled in the conspiracy of counter-revolutionary terrorists."
It was to the Lake Dwellers of Switzerland in the Polished Stone Age that jade, in the form of a highly polished little knife blade, neatly fitted into a stag-horn handle, brought good luck.

The Ninety-second meeting of the American Chemical Society will be held in Pittsburgh Sept. 7 to 11, with more than 3,000 scientists present. Delegates from America and Europe will discuss chemistry's expanding influence on the world's natural resources.
SEATTLE, Aug. 22. -- The Seattle chapter of the American Newspaper Guild announced a mass meeting for Tuesday night to "inform the public" on the issues of the strike.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Governors of Louisiana and Mississippi chose "seconds" today for their Labor Day yachting duel off the Mississippi Gulf Coast.

HOLIDAYS are drawing to a close. Returning trippers disembark from every boat from Europe; they step out of planes; and they rush from trains to their automobiles. All have a common thought: "What's new in dresses?"
With the defending champion in men's singles, William Lurie, not scheduled to play until today, the metropolitan public parks tennis championships began yesterday at Walker Park, Livingston, S. I.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 22. -- Imagine, if you can, the picture of a hurtling comet striking the State of Rhode Island, devouring two-thirds of its area and chasing its inhabitants to cover, and you have in effect a picture of the blight that the ravaging forest fires of the last three weeks have caused in Minnesota, Wisconsin and Michigan.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 22. -- For the next major phase of its tercentenary celebration Harvard University moves this week to the field of public health. A five-day symposium of the subject will start Monday and include conferences, special sessions and meetings of learned groups in various specialized fields.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 22. -- San Sebastian was bombarded this morning and afternoon by the Rebels' 10,000-ton cruiser Canarias, which recently left Ferrol. Only four shells fell in the city this morning, but in the afternoon the bombardment was intensified and

IF radio programs are to continuously improve, a growth in discrimination on the part of the average listener is needed, according to the National Committee on Education by Radio. While stimulation of the broadcasters is essential, the committee warns that most of the improvement must come through a concerted effort to develop a critical public.

Criticism by consumer groups that retailers misrepresent the cost of installment credit buying through quoting "6 per cent carrying charges" is receiving attention in retail circles. The criticism is based on the fact that the 6 per cent is based on the unpaid balance and that regular monthly payments actually bring the cost close to 12 per cent.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was steady and quiet. Treasury bonds were generally higher, with three advancing to new high prices. High-grade domestic corporation issues held firm, while the more speculative vehicles were irregularly weaker, apparently as an aftermath of Friday's decline in stocks. Foreign bonds were not particularly active and showed no pronounced trend.

The Regional Labor Board was informed yesterday that a single union embracing deck officers and licensed engineers was the only agency capable of providing proper representation for the licensed personnel of the merchant marine in negotiations with employers.

OPENLY defying a permanent court injunction as well as the Pennsylvania Department of Highways, an aroused public sentiment in the vicinity of this small town has brought about the closing, possibly forever, of the Fallston Hill section of Route 51, which is a heavily traveled Pittsburgh-Cleveland highway.

BRETTON WOODS. -- The Bretton Woods Boy Singers will be heard today at the Joseph Stickney Memorial Church of the Transfiguration, where the Right Rev. John Thompson Dallas, Bishop of New Hampshire, will preach. This evening the boy choir will give a concert at Becketts Playhouse on Sugar Hill before a group of subscribers from surrounding resorts.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- The Madrid government today gave assurances to Great Britain that it would not exercise its right to search British ships outside of Spanish territorial waters. It was understood that the ruling applies also to shipping of other nations.

A week after its approval by the Federal Housing Administration as a mortgagee the South Shore Trust Company of Rockville Centre, L.I., announced yesterday that it had a $10,000,000 fund available for investment in mortgages under the FHA plan of insurance.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Aug. 22. -- Plans are being made for the annual Fall meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association, which will take place at the Rockaway Hunting Club at Cedarhurst on Saturday, Sept. 12.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 22. -- In San Sebastian, which Rebel propaganda has "razed" with shells, "scourged" with an epidemic of typhoid and "parched" with a water shortage, the writer spent a quiet afternoon Thursday.

A BIOGRAPHY of Field Marshal Haig by Duff Cooper, Secretary of State for War in the British Cabinet, is announced for publication on Sept. 4 by Doubleday, Doran Co. Duff Cooper was one of Haig's staff officers during the World War.

THE lucky listener is not always the one who gets a ticket to the broadcast, that is, if he is still to enjoy listening in at home. Radio thrives on illusion, and once that is destroyed by sight the mind suddenly becomes aware that it has been fooled by something picked up by the ear to stir the imagination.

Culminating several seasons of intensive work with a close and hard-fought victory, Ray Mullane, 20-year-old swimmer of the Flushing Y.M.C.A., yesterday won the metropolitan one-mile free style swimming championship in the Jerome Cascade Pool, and added his name to the James A. Farley Cup, donated by the Postmaster General for the event in 1933.

Mikhail Tomsky was a member of the once famous Right-wing "troika" of the Russian Communist party's Political Bureau, which is the real ruling power of the Soviet Union. He was then far removed from Leon Trotsky's Left-wing group.

Decreases in the number of motor vehicle accidents, in the number of persons killed and the number injured in such accidents in New York State during the first six months of this year compared with the same period of last year are noted in a report made by the Bureau of Motor Vehicles yesterday.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Aug. 22. -- The Atlantic Coast Star Class championship and the Bedford Trophy returned to Long Island Sound, after an absence of six years, today as John Abberley and John Middlebrook, the Pequot pair representing the Central Long Island Sound fleet, triumphed over a dozen rivals on points.

TWO events, six years apart, conspired to give American literature "The Outcasts of Poker Flat" and "The Luck of Roaring Camp." One was James Marshall's discovery of gold at Sutter's Mill, on the south fork of the American River, in January, 1848. The other was the arrival in San Francisco in February, 1854, of a youngster named Francis Bret Harte, whose hundredth anniversary will be celebrated next Tuesday.

ALTHOUGH charges of propaganda have been leveled at the screen through the years they have, for the most part, been unfounded. Now there is a well-defined movement toward using celluloid to subtly or otherwise advance ideas and purposes.
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Manchester, N.H., defeated Minneapolis, 9 to 7, today in the semi-finals of the American Legion junior baseball tournament.
A move to enforce clean sidewalks throughout the city by means of summonses for persons who violate the anti-litter ordinances was made known yesterday by the Department of Sanitation.

MUCH has been written and said concerning the advantages of the constant speed propeller. Little has been recorded, however, about the mechanism itself and how it operates. These propellers are now coming into general use on the airlines both here and abroad and are being included in the design of many new airplanes for military and commercial service.

Dark deeds have a way of appearing doubly sinister when they are perpetrated in a setting of genteel luxury. In an entertaining story of love and mystery, Maxwell March decks out some pretty wicked doings with the luscious elegance of soft carpets, broad staircase, old tapestries, Rolls-Royces and family acres.

MR. JOHN BEEVERS is the literary editor of London Time and Tide. He is a critic with a hammer. He hits steadily and hard, which possibly compensates him for not hitting the nail on the head in every instance.

Bishop Oldham received much information from your three correspondents who wrote concerning his inquiry -- Why must we build more warships when Britain announces plans for two more battleships? I submit, however, that no adequate reply was given to the Bishop's real question -- Against what power are we to construct additional battleships?

OAKHURST, N.J., Aug. 22. -- George J. Comber, 70-year-old gardener on the estate of Mrs. Campbell Clark here, died today in the Fitkin Memorial Hospital, Neptune, from a poison infection in his left arm believed to have been the result of a bite on his hand last Monday by a black widow spider.

Numerous indications pointing to a 1936 business volume 20 per cent greater than in the preceding year are observed by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents in its monthly report on industrial conditions issued yesterday.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Medalists in yesterday's qualifying round, Dr. Edward Kempf of St. George's and Alfred A. Brown of Brentwood led the field into the semi-finals of the second annual Arthur Man Memorial best-ball golf tournament at match play started at Seawane today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- New industrial activity was reported today by the Federal Housing Administration to have done away with "For Rent" signs in many cities and towns. The administration said a widespread survey by its field agents disclosed that even in the larger industrial centers, where empty houses had been numerous, vacancies were being rapidly reduced.

THE HOLD-UP," a book-like box containing a pair of garters, may be one of the more trifling examples of books that are not books. But the collector of bogus volumes will point out, if you speak slightingly of his peculiar hobby, that the late Czar Nicholas II had among his treasures a sumptuous jewel box in the form of a book, of palisander wood and gold mountings, set with precious stones.

THERE is a peculiar fascination about making new plants from cuttings or "slips." Perhaps a certain sentiment attaches to these specimens -- direct offspring of the parent plant -- that is not felt toward plants grown from seed.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Myrtlewood, Brownell Combs's speedy filly, carring top weight of 122 pounds, set a new track record in winning the $5,000 added Motor City Handicap today. She was trailed by Professor Paul and Gristate, Mrs. J. Chesney's entry, in the order named.
DENVER, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Repeal of the Canadian reciprocal trade agreement was demanded today by the executive committee of the American National Livestock Association.
DETROIT, Aug. 22. -- Senator James Couzens announced in a brief statement today that he would support President Roosevelt for re-election.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Statistics issued today by the Bureau of Mines showed that in 1935 Oklahoma produced minerals valued at more than $250,000,000.

With mingled satisfaction and regret Professor Casey Stengel yesterday watched his Dodgers blasting merrily away at three Philly pitchers for seventeen hits to gain a one-sided 12-3 victory over the league's cellar-dwellers. He was gratified at the display of power but regretful that a part of it wasn't directed against the Giants in the recent uphappy experiences at the Polo Grounds.

THE celebration of the 300th anniversary of the founding of Harvard University. America's oldest institution of learning, is the occasion for an exhibition of antique furnishing, housed in Robinson Hail and open to the public until Sept. 16.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- Italy's acceptance of the French non-intervention proposal in the Spanish civil war, in at least as far as "direct intervention" is concerned, has undoubtedly relieved the situation for Premier Leon Blum and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos.

For the boon of being a good sleeper Alf M. Landon owes gratitude to a kindly Providence. Last week he started his first campaign trip. It was arduous going. Each time his train crossed a State line it picked up a group of politicians, who rode and conferred with him to the next State line and then departed, to be succeeded by another group of riding and conferring politicians.

LIGHT comedy exploiting British and American slang and the complications of a British American romance, is offered in "What Price Gloria!" The book definitely aims at the Wodehouse mood, and it succeeds in producing a fairish imitation.

OUT in Hollywood where oddities in the news are everyday occurrences there is successfully functioning an organization which unquestionably rates the much-abused designation of "unique." This is the one-woman central casting bureau, directed by Mrs. Wynonah Johnson.

FREDERICK WILLIAM HENRY MYERS was the son of an English curate. He entered Cheltenham College when he was 13 years old and knew Virgil by heart before he became classical lecturer at Trinity College, Cambridge.

UPHOLDING the tradition established in the field of Russian history by his eminent predecessors, such as V. Kliuchevsky and S. Platonov (to name only two of them), Professor George Vernadsky has contributed in great degree to an understanding of Russia's past extending over some eleven centuries and filled with "dramatic tension throughout the ages."

ALL through New England this Summer the traveler sees announcements of centenary, bi-centenary and tercentenary celebrations. In Bridgeport, where a centennial is being observed, the activities sanctioned by the committee in charge will include a contract bridge tournament.

While some slackening from the recent pace of activity featured both retail and wholesale trade here last week, the general picture continued to show substantial gains over last year at this time. Retail trade was not quite so active as in the preceding week and the showing between stores was spottier.

EXPERT carvers in a shed lately built in Madison Square will soon be at work on a pedestal for the famous Farragut statue by Saint-Gaudens, copying in toughest granite the beautiful design of the old blue-stone pedestal near by. The bronze admiral has for some time been looking quaintly at Broadway from the roof of a shack that completely conceals from sight and from the weather the original base, now crumbling away.

MR. MATTHEWS has sketched, from a blend of gentleness and mockery, the tragicomedy of a sensitive child at grips with the cruel, cruel world. There is a phase of childhood -- the frantic childhood of inordinately self-conscious people -- that culminates in a denial of reality: the child, exaggerating the meaning or the force of events, comes to think of himself as the hub of the world and the object of its malice.

AS its name implies, this book combines the interest of both architecture and genealogy as it looks back to Colonial days in Southern New Netherland. But it actually covers a wider field than that; indeed, its field spreads out in two directions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Bureau of Mines reported today that the 1935 domestic production of monetary metals -- gold and silver -- and base metals -- copper, lead and zinc -- increased substantially over production in 1934.

DINANT, Belgium, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The memorial to 23,700 Belgian civilians killed in the World War, incorporating the famous "war guilt" inscription of Whitney Warren, New York architect, will be unveiled here tomorrow.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 22. -- Champion Sturdy Max, English setter, owned by the Maridor Kennels of East Long Meadow, was adjudged best in show at the Lenox Kennel Club's annual exhibition, held on the grounds of the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club.

ERIE, Pa., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Representative Rayburn of Texas, chairman of the Democratic National Committee's speakers' bureau, told a party rally here today that the business of those opposing the New Deal's public utility regulation program had not been ruined.

VIENNA, Aug. 21. -- By dissolving political parties and closing political clubs Premier John Metaxas has continued to follow the examples of fellow-dictators. By declaring the present state of suppression of Parliament, partial suspension of the Constitution and individual liberty and the declaration of martial law as a transitory period until the "golden age without political parties" has been reached, Premier Metaxas merely has copied other dictatorships.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 22. -- Twenty-three graduates of Eastern and Middle Western high and private schools are entering Harvard College this Fall on scholarships, totaling over $11,000 awarded by the Harvard Clubs of their localities. They were leaders in scholarship and extracurricular activities.

The proposed city charter, which the voters of New York will be asked to approve in November, and which has just been filed with the City Clerk, reached its final form in an attempt to retain the essential outlines of the present city government, and by a separation of legislative and administrative functions, to bring about greater efficiency and decrease wasteful expenditures.
LONG-DISTANCE stations have been traveling through the August air with remarkable clarity, and the waves of a number of new transmitters found their way into the New York area.

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- If it has not already gravely affected the prospect for the smooth functioning of the new conference of the Locarno powers, the drift of the Spanish civil war will probably make an indefinite postponement of that meeting inevitable.

HOMEWORK for school children has been debated in the House of Commons. By a unanimous vote the House has decided that "it is undesirable that school children should have their evenings occupied with homework to the exclusion of rest and recreation and that whenever practicable preparation on the school premises should be substituted for homework.
HARDIN, Mont., Aug. 22. -- Out of hundreds of square miles of towering mountains and irrigated lowlands here in Southwestern Montana a man is building a new empire.

William Lurie, starting the defense of his metropolitan public parks tennis championship, advanced into the quarter-finals on a bye and two straight-set triumphs yesterday at Walker Park, Livingston, S.I.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 23 (AP). -- South Carolina will choose a Senator Tuesday from a field of three candidates -- a stanch New Dealer and two New Deal critics.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 72.1 on Aug. 19, compared with 72.4 a fortnight before, 71.7 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

ROCKY GLEN, Pa., Aug. 23. -- The Public Utilities Act of 1935 was defended and praised today by Representative Rayburn of Texas, chairman of the Speakers' Bureau of the Democratic National Committee, who pointed out that despite the "doleful predictions" of holding companies, utility stocks had risen under the operation of the act.

ZARAPATH, N.J., Aug. 23. -- Adherence to the "old-time fervor of the spirit that has been neglected by other Protestant denominations" explains why the Pillar of Fire Church has "unprecedented material prosperity" while gaining new converts, Bishop Alma White, 74-year-old founder of the church, said here today.
Hugh M. Campbell's 8-meter yacht Roulette led the sailing division home yesterday in the City Island Yacht Club's annual overnight race.

The long-deferred opening of Governor LANDON'S campaign took place on Saturday at his birthplace in Pennsylvania. He naturally took occasion to greet old friends and to identify himself with the type of American families among which he was born. They were independent and self-supporting citizens. They were good specimens of the "plain people" whom LINCOLN said that the Lord must have loved because he created so many of them.
In an address before a farmers' union picnic in Iowa Mr. Lemke, the Union party candidate for President, made several statements regarding foreign trade that merit serious consideration.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The magazine Steel said today that the national steel-works operating rate rose 1 1/2 points last week to 72 per cent, the highest rate since May, 1930, and 20 points higher than in the corresponding week last year.

THIS year's Atlantic $10,000 prize novel is a book that will temporarily plunge women back into that frozen pool that represents adolescence, that will make the men who read it curious again as to what women think about when they won't talk. The title is "I Am the Fox" (Little, Brown, $2.50). Winifred Van Etten of Iowa is the author.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,156,545,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

The names of thirty-five persons who will represent American peace organizations at the Universal Peace Congress to be held in Brussels, Belgium, from Sept. 3 to 6 were made public yesterday by the National Peace Conference, 8 West Fortieth Street.
Six merchant ships have entered crews in the annual international lifeboat race to be held Sept. 12 off Bay Ridge, it was announced by the committee in charge.
BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- Each with a sprig of heather in his buttonhole, the British Walker Cup golf team arrived today with "every expectation of going home with the cup this time."
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23. -- The old cruiser Boston, which helped Admiral Dewey's squadron destroy the Spanish fleet in Manila Bay, is headed for the junk pile.
The program for the eight-day visit, commencing tomorrow, of the Japanese cruisers Iwate and Yakuma, veterans of two wars, was announced yesterday.

MERIDA, Spain, Aug. 22 (By Courier to Gibraltar). -- Behind a screen of airplanes General Francisco Franco, Rebel commander-in-chief, has thrust all his picked troops forward from Badajoz and Merida by way of Cacares in a desperate drive to surround Madrid from the south. The Rebels hope to be in Madrid in five days, perhaps less.
PENSACOLA, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Three Federal agencies, attacking by air, land and water, smashed at illicit distilling operations in West Florida during week-end raids.

To every intelligent reader of the newspapers it must be evident that the Olympic Games are over. The army officer who had charge of the construction of Olympic Village at Berlin has killed himself after being dismissed from the service as a non-Aryan.

The Colombia Bondholders Committees announced yesterday that they have sent a letter to the Minister of Finance and Public Credit of the Republic of Colombia with respect to the government, departmental, municipal and mortgage-bank dollar issues in default, denying the right of the banking houses that marketed the bonds and the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., to negotiate a settlement on behalf of the bondholders.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Some 1,400 members of special National Guard units from Manhattan and Brooklyn will take the field at Camp Smith here tomorrow to begin two weeks of training that differs widely from the infantry training that has been under way thus far this season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The Townsend pension organization made ready tonight for a preliminary strength test in its home State by urging members to vote for twenty selected candidates in next Tuesday's Congressional primary.

It is time that we give proportional representation serious consideration. It will be submitted in the Fall election along with the new charter. Proportional representation has its ardent supporters, but there are some controversial opinions which should have their weight. Let's look them over.

With indications that the advertising campaigns of manufacturers of medicines and allied products during the coming Fall and Winter seasons will be the heaviest in years, the advisory committee on advertising of the Proprietary Association is preparing to intensify its work of checking up on copy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Following a personal survey of political conditions in various States, Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, predicted today a decisive Democratic victory in November.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- A solution of world economic warfare through international agreements on minimum wages and maximum hours was proposed today by Bernard M. Baruch.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 23. -- Although the Spanish insurgents' northern headquarters were moved from Burgos to Valladolid in preparation for a renewed drive against Madrid, the tide of battle in the Southwest and Northeast flowed today in favor of the government forces.
The answer of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn to the Drukman special grand jury's charges demanding his removal was made public yesterday by Governor Lehman.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 23. -Driving a single-engine speed boat faster than any other member of her sex in this country or elsewhere ever achieved, Mrs. Maud Rutherfurd of Sands Point, Port Washington, who tips the scales at 105 pounds of racing courage and skill, stole a good part of the show on the North Shrewsbury today.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- About 5,000 lawyers are expected at the annual meeting of the American Bar Association which opens here tomorrow. The city's welcome will be extended by Bentley W. Warren; president of the Boston Bar Association, and Stanley Reed, solicitor general of the United States, will make the response.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The Republican National Committee, in a statement issued today, charged that, "according to information reaching Republican headquarters," high ranking officials of the Works Progress Administration in Ohio from July 1, 1935, to July 1, 1936, "raided the Federal Treasury and voted themselves three general salary increases ranging from $150 to $210 a month."

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 23. -- In a thrilling three-and-a-half-hour final that required two extra holes before the issue could be decided, John P. Budde and John Cashman of the Garden City C.C. conquered Captain Ernest F. Carter of Sands Point and James Nelson of Munsey Park, 1 up, to win the second annual Arthur Man memorial best-ball golf tournament today at Seawane.
TOOELE, Utah, Aug. 23. -- The Federal Soil Conservation Service, fighting the silt-storm menace, claimed a spectacular victory today in Central Utah's "dust bowl."

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- The stock markets here continue to judge the international situation pessimistically. Although the Boerse early in the week witnessed no precipitate selling, stocks declined steadily because of the absence of buyers, and when on Friday offers suddenly increased, a complete debacle ensued, certain leaders losing 7 to 8 points.

Senator COUZENS of Michigan announced on Saturday that he considers the re-election of Mr. ROOSEVELT so important for the country that he himself, though a Republican, will support the President. Almost the sole proof that he gives of being a Republican is that he is a candidate for renomination in the Republican primary next month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Confidence that a workable form of all-risk crop insurance can be developed under guidance of the Federal Government was expressed today by Roy M. Green, director of a financial division of the Agriculture Department.

BEND, Ore., Aug. 23 (AP). -- Former President Herbert Hoover took time out from a fishing trip on the Deschutes River to tell a Republican rally in Oregon's Second Congressional District that America stands at a crossroads today.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Aug. 23. -- Communism as a world menace will be the theme of the Nazi party congress opening here Sept. 8, according to Dr. Robert Ley, leader of the German Labor Front, who bears the title of Reich Organization Director for Annual Conclaves.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Representative William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, today pictured a midland empire on the eastern slopes of the Rocky Mountains wherein the nation's youth "will have an opportunity to build homes and enter the industrial field."

Four basic rules for keeping ourselves happy were given yesterday by the Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, pastor of the South Congregational Church, Springfield, Mass., in a sermon at the Riverside Church.

NEW CASTLE, Pa., Aug. 23. -- Governor Landon attended services today in the church at West Middlesex of which his grandfather, the Rev. William H. Mossman, was pastor when Landon was born, and heard the present pastor pray that the spirit of Christ might descend on him in his candidacy for the Presidency.

Most vices are really abused virtues, the Rev. Dr. Henry Hallam Tweedy of the Yale Divinity School declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

THE TIMES asks, "Has the magnifying of the functions of government since 1929 -- inevitable under the circumstances -- thrown great masses of our people into confusion of mind about what any administration at Washington can do?"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP). -- In an inconspicuous section of the State Department lights burn nightly into the early morning hours while occupants work overtime to aid Americans caught in the Spanish revolution and comfort their anxious relatives in the United States.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 22. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84.1, which compares with 84 the week before, 84.3 two weeks before, 83.7 three weeks before, and 83.2 four weeks before.

Persecution would cease and there would be no danger of war if Christ's admonition to regard every one as our neighbor were obeyed, the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg declared in his sermon yesterday at high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The use of war in attempts to improve economic conditions was criticized by President Roosevelt today as a false effort that puts the cart before the horse.

The Citizens Budget Commission, in a statement issued yesterday by William Church Osborn, chairman, declared that the Mayor's survey of payroll waste in the five Sheriffs' offices was only a minor investigation.

BERLIN, Aug. 23. -- The latest appeal of the Brotherhood Council of the Confessional Church of German Protestantism was read from many pulpits throughout Germany today and everywhere its delivery produced a moving effect on the congregations.

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- German industry is active and official reports stress progress in the consumption goods branches, which in 1934 and 1935 lagged behind the capital goods lines. Already a shortage of workers prevails in thirty-seven industries or specialized handicrafts.
WHITEFIELD, N.H., Aug. 23. -Mrs. Henry G. Prout of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was hostess at a tea at the Mountain View House here today for sixty guests. Mr. and Mrs. Prout are spending the Summer here.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 23. -- Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, today suffered his first defeat in the international masters' tournament when he resigned his adjourned game from the ninth round to Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, from whom he won the title.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, due to reach her pier this morning from Southampton and Cherbourg, has among her passengers Mr. and Mrs. Edsel Ford and their sons, Henry, Benson and Richard. Others aboard the ship include:
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 23 (AP). -- Pat Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and one of President Roosevelt's closest advisers, faces the political fight of his life at the polls Tuesday.

The Interborough Rapid Transit System had an increase of 2,871,855 passengers, or 3.93 per cent, in July, compared with a year ago, Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, reports. The subway division carried 58,878,365 passengers, a gain of 2,609,329, or 4.64 per cent, and the Manhattan division carried 17,105,448, a gain of 262,526, or 1.56 per cent.

From London by way of Hollywood comes word that Bette Davis has approved Jack McDermott's story, "I'll Take the Low Road," which Toeplitz Productions will make in England. Douglass Montgomery will appear opposite Miss Davis and Monty Banks will direct.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 24. -- Spanish Government navy men have made a daring but unsuccessful attempt to cut off Seville, the headquarters of General Fracisco Franco, from the sea by sinking two old freighters at the entrance to the Guadalquivir River.

The monthly index of deliveries of rayon broad-woven cloth advanced from 121 in June to 151 in July, according to figures on operations of manufacturer reporting to the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., and the National Rayon Weavers' Association, Inc.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23. -- In what probably will be his last tune-up before the national amateur, which he has won once and hopes to win again, Jess W. Sweetser today sent out storm-warnings to his prospective opponents at Garden City.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 23 (AP). -- Minnesota's role in President Roosevelt's campaign for re-election became an unknown quantity tonight with the death of Governor Floyd B. Olson.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Arthur Lynch, 40, public relations counsel, and his wife, known professionally as Emilia Bourgue, 48, French teacher to the children of wealthy Chicago families were found dead today in what police said was a suicide pact.

The 1,250 sun-tanned, blue-uniformed midshipmen who have been "doing the town" for the past three nights bade a not-too-regretful farewell to Times Square last night and added the Great White Way's glories to fond memories of Swedish "smorgasbord," Biscay storms, Norfolk hospitality and other highlights of their Summer cruise now ending.

Completely surrounded by their third largest crowd of the season, a gathering of 63,906, the Yankees put on a show at the Stadium yesterday that seemed to leave most everybody satisfied, with the possible exception of Marse Joe McCarthy, who, somehow, still likes to win them all.
PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 23 (AP). -- The universe is expanding at an explosive rate which, if continued, will bring its destruction, according to Milton L. Humason, authority on nebulae.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- Larger imports of Argentine corn in the next twelve months than in any recent years are expected because of the shortage of the corn crop here. Estimates of imports run from 25,000,000 to 50,000,000 bushels. Already much Argentine corn has been bought.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 23. -Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge arrived at the Wendell Hotel this morning from San Francisco and this afternoon she attended the seventh chamber music concert of the Summer on South Mountain. Her son, Professor Albert Sprague Coolidge of Harvard, viola player, and Gunnar Johansen of Copenhagen were the assisting artists.

Miss Sarah Conley of 431 Riverside Drive, who served from 1930 to 1934 as a member of the Democratic County Committee from the Thirteenth Manhattan Assembly District, has been appointed to the women's staff of the Republican National Committee, it was announced yesterday by Miss Natalie Couch, director of the women's campaign for Governor Landon in the Eastern States.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The Cardinals snatched their slim National League lead out of the Fire with late rallies today, the first giving them a 7-3 victory over Pittsburgh and the second gaining a 6-6 tie called on account of darkness after the tenth inning.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The Senators defeated the Athletics in both games of a double-header today, beating them 9 to 3 in the first and 9 to 6 in the nightcap.

PARIS, Aug. 23 (AP). -- American Olympic rack and field athletes, duplicating the United States victory at Berlin, defeated teams of Japanese and French in triangular meet before 20,000 spectators in Colombes Stadium today.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary set a new record for a transatlantic crossing last night, when she passed Ambrose Lightship at 11:12 o'clock, with an elapsed time of 4 days 7 hours 12 minutes for the voyage from Cherbourg.

ALBANY, Aug. 23. -- There were 13,370 persons placed in jobs in private industry during July by the New York State Employment Service and National Re-employment Service, the Industrial Commissioner, Elmer F. Andrews, reported today.
DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Chicago scored four runs in the first five innings today and beat the Tiger, 4 -- 2, to take a lead of two games to one in the current four-game series.

A modern elevator apartment house will replace the three-story dwelling at 3,086 Hull Avenue, just north of Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx, which was sold by John H. Hamill after occupying the property since 1893. The property is 50 by 110 feet and has been purchased by the Amsbar Construction Corporation, Jacob Abrams, president, for an indicated consideration of $9,000.

Active missionary work in the face of suffering and opposition was stressed as the mark of the true regenerate church by the Rev. William C. Boone, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Jackson, Tenn., in his morning sermon yesterday at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP). -The Huisache team from Houston, Texas, met the bid of Hunting Valley's powerhouse hitters today and defeated the Cleveland club, 7 to 5, for the intercircuit polo championship of the United States.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 23. -- An ordinance designed to test the authority of municipalities in controlling radio interference will be presented to the Village Board here tomorrow night by Mayor Alanson Abrams as the first step in a country-wide prpgram to improve radio reception.

There is no basis for the prevalentattitude that the younger generationis any more irreligious now thanyounger generations were in the past,the Rev. Dr. Albert E. Beebe, pastorof the First Methodist EpiscopalChurch, Bridgeport, Conn., said in asermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 23. -Bill Cox sailed Robert Shields's Interclub sloop Canvasback to victory, A.P. Davis won the Atlantic class event with New Deal and B.A. Hinman's Snipe Patsy triumphed today as forty-six boats sailed in the Horse Shoe Harbor Yacht Club's special regatta.
MADRID, Aug. 23. -- Spain's government, it was authoritatively disclosed today, has seized direct control of nearly 600 industries since the civil war began five weeks ago.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., Aug. 23. -- William Arthur Coles, 56 years old, a real estate man here, and his wife, Frances Carman Coles, 53, were instantly killed at about 10:30 A.M. today at the Boisseau Avenue crossing of the Long Island Railroad when their car was struck by a speeding train.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The War Department is opposed to the nationalization of the country's munitions factories on the ground that such a plan would undoubtedly fail in time of war, according to Major Gen. William H. Tschappat, chief of ordnance, in an article to be published Tuesday in Army Ordnance, the journal of the Army Ordnance Association.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- Wild fluctuations prevailed in the livestock markets here last week, due to light receipts. The top price for hogs was $12.05 a hundred pounds, the highest for this year. Farmers were holding their stock back. At that level, buyers withdrew and prices dropped to $11.50 on Thursday, and rallied on Friday to $11.60.

WARSAW, Aug. 23. -- Grave anti-Semitic riots occurred at Wiszonki in Central Poland Friday night when about 200 members of the National Democratic (anti-Semitic) party raided the town. Their leader rode a horse and they arrived in motor trucks.

Five cases now before the Interstate Commerce Commission are of importance to commerce and industry of this port, according to a survey published yesterday by the Merchants Association. In some instances the port is aligned against competing ports and in others interests within the port district are involved.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The stock markets here continue to demonstrate their resistance to the disquieting international political developments and are showing a response to the encouragement of domestic news. Despite the inactivity of imports in this, the holiday season, the public is steadily absorbing industrial securities, many of which reached new high levels this week.

LODI, N.J., Aug, 23. -- A serious relief problem faced officials of this community today as a result of the closing down yesterday of the United Piece Dye Works, one of the largest plants of its kind in the country. The company employed more than 5,000 persons, of whom about 900 are residents of Lodi Borough.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Charlton Ogburn, general counsel of the American Federation of Labor, will urge the American Bar Association at its meeting in Boston this week to reject its pending report on social security prepared by a special committee which also studied the t Unemployment Insurance Law.

Five persons were critically injured early yesterday afternoon when the sedan in which they were riding across the Manhattan Bridge went out of control, plunged through the guard rail of the south upper roadway, squeezed under the casing of the suspension cables and plummeted to the promenade twenty-two feet below. It landed upside down in a crumpled mass of wreckage.

Considering that the forces behind the movement of financial and industrial recovery have been confronted, on the one hand with continuance of devastating drought, on the other with political uncertainties suggested by the Spanish episode, it certainly appears that the movement is holding well.

The letter of Frank Cist on the "dangers of excess gold" production suggests a collateral question, namely: Who legally and equitably owned the gold in he United States Treasury represented by the gold certificates that have been withdrawn from circulation?

The importance of importunity in prayer was emphasized by the Rev. John Seldon Whale, president of Cheshunt College, Cambridge, England, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- A delegation of the People's Mandate to End War, in urging their program on President Roosevelt today, asked that the United States immediately stop increasing armaments.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The wheat market in England has fallen into a hesitant condition, with a general disposition among consumers and speculators to await further developments. Meanwhile, prices are tending slightly upward again.

The Brookhattan eleven of the American Soccer League unofficially opened the season at Starlight Park yesterday before 2,500 fans with a 3-to-2 victory over the Hatikvoh team of Brooklyn, members of the German-American League, in an exhibition game.

CHAUTAUQU, N.Y., Aug. 23 (AP). -- Chautauqua, host to seven Presidents and many Presidential nominees in its sixty-two years, expects its greatest crowd tomorrow night to hear an "old Chautauquan," Governor Landon, make a campaign address.

Reordering of Fall merchandise that has so far proved popular featured activity in the local wholesale apparel markets last week. There were fewer buyers here from out-of-town, as most retailers have completed purchases for early Fall and are now awaiting definite response to new offerings.

Social progress hinges upon the contributions of individual initiative, the Rev. Frank C. Williams, pastor of the Epworth Methodist Episcopal Church, 150th Street and Twelfth Avenue, Whitestone, Queens, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.

The American Bankers Association announced yesterday it was conducting comprehensive studies of all phases of practical operating and economic facts and conditions relating to banking, and the findings are to be placed at the disposal of all State banking associations.

Discussion of a new wage contract for seamen on ships operating from the port of New York will be resumed today at a meeting of the local board of mediation and conciliation, comprised of spokesmen for the lines and their employes.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The Palestine Government revealed tonight it had deported fifteen Jewish Communists and one Armenian and was prepared to send a second group from the country next Wednesday in an effort to end disorders now in their nineteenth week.

In Topics of The Times of Aug. 19 there appeared, regarding my questionnaire which was used to determine whether or no a considerable number of children are ignorant of the laws and ordinances for violation of which they are later punished: "* * * questions ranging from the meaningless to the utterly absurd, as when you ask a 10-year-old the difference between murder and manslaughter."

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 23. -- Newark divided a double-header with Syracuse today in the Chiefs' final appearance of the season at Ruppert Stadium. The visitors won the first game, 4 to 3, and the Bears took the second by the same score.

PEACHES or punches, the time for picking them is when they are ripe. With the postponement of the heavyweight championship bout between Braddock and Schmeling to next June, Jim's luck seems to have run out. The rags-to- riches romance of the ring is sagging a bit toward the end.

NEWPORT, Aug. 23. -- Former State Senator William H. Vanderbilt and Mrs. Vanderbilt, who have the latter's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Everett Colby, as their guests at Oakland Farm, entertained in their honor at the Clambake Club today. There were nearly 150 guests present.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP). -- The Cubs cashed in on a brilliant four-hit pitching performance by Southpaw Larry French today by bunching hits off Benny Frey to shut out the Reds, 7 to 0.

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 24. -- Gregory Zinovieff, Leon Kameneff and fourteen fellow defendants were sentenced to death at 3 A. M. today for conspiring to assassinate Joseph Stalin and other Soviet leaders and actually accomplishing the death of Sergei Kiroff in 1934.

Net declines of 20 to 29 points were registered by cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week, with prices see-sawing over a wide range, just as during the week before. The market appeared influenced by adverse crop developments in the western part of the Cotton Belt. current high consumption, improved crop prospects in the eastern belt, unfavorable trade conditions in Europe ana the imminence of new crop hedging.

Harpers are convinced that Carl Van Doren's "Three Worlds," to be published on Sept. 17, will be an important "first" for collectors. The book contains a long letter from Sinclair Lewis written in 1921, hitherto unpublished, and giving an explicit account of his career before "Main Street" and of his early plans and ambitions.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- The stock market here opened the week irregular, with declines predominating, but with advances in brewery and paper pulp shares. The weakness continued until Friday, when increased selling from bank clients led to a general collapse.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 23. -- American Legion officials offered a formal defense here tonight of their proposed ricksha relay between New York and Asbury Park when, in a telegraphed statement to Mayor La Guardia, they took issue with his characterization of the event as "un-American" and "a symbol of slavery."

For what seemed an interminable time, Casey Stengel's Dodgers and Jimmy Wilson's Phillies engaged in combat at Ebbets Field yesterday, but not much of it was baseball. Nearly 12,000 Flatbush fans were seeing the last of the Dodgers until Sept. 9 and they didn't appear to be broken-hearted about it.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, will speak on a national radio hook-up over the Columbia Broadcasting System at 9:45 P.M. (E.S.T.) Thursday, the Democratic National Committee announced last night from its headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

May I submit a comment on General Rivers's interesting letter? He mentioned the report of your Tokyo correspondent that the Japanese Government had decided to appoint a Minister of Defense in order to effect better coordination of their three armed services-the navy, air and army.

Fire at about 8:30 o'clock last night in a seven-story apartment house at 229 East Twelfth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, drove 150 persons from their apartments and made about fifty of them homeless. A crowd estimated at several thousand persons watched the blaze, necessitating the calling of three police emergency crews.
ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, Aug. 23. -- Sir Edgar Britten, master of the Queen Mary, gave out the following statement tonight after his ship had passed Ambrose Light:

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- Because of the appreciation of sterling in terms of the gold currencies, the market price of gold has fallen to the lowest in two years. The demand for the metal has been general, and with the character sufficient to maintain sterling at a fairly substantial premium over parity of the French franc.

" Once more the pitiful remnant of waterfowl that formerly swept down the sky in untold millions is to be raked with shot from the northernmost settlements of white men to the southern limits of the birds' Winter range," declares John H. Baker, executive director of the National Association of Audubon Societies, in a statement issued following the government's announcement of a thirty-day open duck shooting season this Fall.

MADRID, Aug. 23 (Passed by the Censor) -- Loyalists forces were urged today to respect the lives of prisoners and hostages, regardless of actions of the Rebels. The appeal was made by the Socialist newspaper, El Socialista, and by Politica, the newspaper of President Manuel Azana's Republican party.

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- It was stated officially here this week that no importation of wheat by Germany will be necessary in the crop year 1936-37. Nevertheless, the Reich Nourishment Corporation issued a warning to farmers against the use of bread cereals as fodder,

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 23. -- Headed by a prairie schooner in a parade that resembled those of the Republican National Convention, some 4,000 men, women and children gathered here today at the annual Morris County Citizens Republican Clubs family outing to hear United States Senator W. Warren Barbour and Representative Charles A. Eaton, both seeking re-election, urge the voters to "Win America back for the Americans."

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 23. -- A review of the facts in the strike of the American Newspaper Guild against the Seattle Post-Intelligencer, a Hearst morning newspaper which has been forced to suspend publication since Aug. 13, indicates that the future effectiveness of the strike depends largely upon an investigation being conducted by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- Foreign exchange strengthened against the franc this week, continuing last week's trend, and most currencies rose to the gold-export point, especially the Dutch florin, the Swiss franc and the United States dollar.

Her left arm snug about a 7-week old baby boy, Mrs. Susan Frawley Eisele of Blue Earth, Minn., picked stoically at a portable typewriter with two fingers of her right hand in her room at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Real property has been rehabilitated to the extent of $395,882,687 by guaranteed loans, according to an analysis issued today by the Federal Housing Administration. More than two-thirds was expended on residential property.

DUBLIN, Aug. 23. -- General Owen O'Duffy, a former leader of the Cosgrave party and now chief of the Blueshirts, has started a dramatic re-entry into public life here as the leader of the crusade against the Spanish Popular Front.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Aug. 23. -- John Cunniff, winner of the qualifying medal, today captured the first annual metropolitan public links championship over the Hendricks Field course. Cunniff, representing Branch Brook, a club formed by Hendricks Field players, won two matches by playing even-par golf.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- The longest Giant winning streak in twenty years grew to an even dozen games today as two aging members of the cast showed the way in twin victories over the Bees before 26,000 fans.

A man who registered at the Commodore Hotel as "J. Rose of N. Y.," but whose name Yonkers, in a card case in his pocket was given as Harold S. Freedman, 46 years old, of 163 Sparks Avenue, Pelham, N.Y., was found dead at about 3:30 P.M., yesterday in a room on the sixteenth floor of the hotel.

" First Love" closed Saturday night in Jackson Heights -- "for revision," is the phrase -- and as early as yesterday its two leading players had made other plans. The week of Sept. 7 will find Ernest Truex at the County Theatre, Suffern, in G.B. Stern's "Middle Man," his role being that originally planned for Roland Young.

VIENNA, Aug. 23. -- Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Hungarian Regent, after attending yesterday's performance of "Die Meistersinger" at Salzburg, left there early this morning, going by automobile over Bavarian territory to the tiny Tyrolean village of Hinterriss where he arrived this afternoon. Tomorrow he will hunt chamois.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 23. -- Great Britain today sent warships speeding from Gibraltar and Malaga to protect the rights of her shipping after the Spanish cruiser Miguel de Cervantes halted and searched on the high seas the British Bland Line merchant ship Gibel Zerjon, carrying gasoline from Gibraltar to Melilla, Spanish Morocco.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- The leading French monetary authorities continue to endeavor to bring about an abatement of fears for the nation's economic status. In this connection it was noted that Governor Labeyrie of the Bank of France when addressing the new General Council said he would endeavor to pursue a policy designed to protect France's money and such as would oppose inflation.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Assistant Attorney General Chester P. O'Hara predicts additional indictments tomorrow in the investigation of the Black Legion. Twenty-two terrorists have already been accused of criminal syndicalism and conspiracy.

The study of the nation's housing situation by the American Federation of Labor is interesting both for its facts and for its conclusions. The building industry, the Federation finds, normally creates constructions worth more than $10,000,000,000 each year, and 2,300,000 workers depend on it for their livelihood. Indirectly 4,600,000 more workers are affected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- R.H. Macy Co. of New York has been cited by the Federal Trade Commission to show cause by Sept. 25 why it should not desist from making certain advertising claims for "Macy's double-edge de luxe blades" for safety razors, the commission announced today.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., Aug. 23. -- Nanette Guilford, the young New York soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera in Gatti-Casazza's productions of "Madonna Imperia" and "The Jest," gave a recital here for the benefit of Morrison Hospital today at the Chase Barn Playhouse.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- With the holiday season now slowly waning, currency is returning from circulation and the active note issue of the Bank of England declined 5,745,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. This compared with a decline of 5,100,000 in the corresponding week in 1935, but the total decrease in the two weeks since the August peak was reached is 1,500,000 less than last year.
