PERPIGNAN, France, Aug. 23. -- The almost complete rout of the first Catalan column that landed on the Island of Majorca a week ago was confirmed for the first time by witnesses who reached this frontier town today.

More than 150 Archbishops and Bishops of the Anglican Church in the Western Hemisphere have been invited to attend a three-day Pan-Anglican Congress in Chicago, beginning Oct. 15, for a discussion of world peace and a restatement of Christian unity.

BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Spanish Rebel leaders announced tonight that their troops had smashed an assault on the northern insurgent stronghold of Oviedo by 20,000 Asturian miners carrying dynamite.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 23. -- There was at times fairly active trading in the cotton contract market here last week. The principal influences were the continued deterioration of the crop in the western half of the belt and the serious conditions in Europe growing out of the civil strife in Spain.

MADRID, Aug. 19 (From a Resident, by Courier to France). -- "If the Rebels ever take Madrid, they will find only corpses, not living persons, in the streets," says Indalecio Prieto, Spain's "ghost" Premier.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- Speculative enthusiasm in the world's grain markets, which was large in the last part of July and the first weeks of August, failed last week to keep prices ascending at a rate that would make a runaway market. Several days of hesitation by buying interests and a wave of caution resulted in a sharp setback in prices.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP). -- Seventeen-year-old Bob Feller, making his first start for Cleveland, fanned fifteen-batters in pitching the Indians to a 4-to-1 victory over the Browns today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 73 per cent of capacity, up two points. It exceeded the average rate in May, the high month since early in 1930.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 23. -- The Count of Romanones, who was Premier of Spain in the days of King Alfonso and who recently was reported dead in San Sebastian, was escorted across the French border today. Those who are seeking an end to Spain's fratricidal struggle see hope in the report that the Count has been entrusted with a secret mission of mediation.

A wind and electrical storm suddenly loomed out of the northwest last night and after lashing the metropolitan area headed up-State, leaving in its wake lightning-struck steeples, chimneys and houses. The accompanying wind also did damage before its force was dissipated here.

Trouble, which comes frequently to all of us, is valuable because when life runs too smoothly we are apt to be beset with temptation, the Right Rev. Stephen E. Keeler, Bishop Coadjutor of Minnesota, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street.

Opera at popular prices last night attracted 5,000 persons to the Hippodrome Theatre, where Alfredo Salmaggi and his company offered Verdi's "Aida." The audience showed its approval of opera and singers by frequent applause.

ROOSEVELT, L.I., Aug. 23. -- The younger set of Long Island is deserting its teas, dances and cocktail parties to campaign for Governor Landon, and a friendly rivalry has developed between North and South Shore groups for pre-eminence in vote-getting.

PARIS, Aug. 23. -- More than 100,000 persons gathered in an openair meeting at Lille today, expecting to hear the labor leader Leon Jouhaux abuse the government for not helping the Spanish Government and wasting time trying to obtain an international non-intervention agreement.
Sixty years ago today Mgr. Gallus Bruder was ordained to the priesthood. He is the oldest active pastor in the Archdiocese of New York, and the longest ordained. The Monsignor is 85 years old.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Mrs. Stephen S. Cummins will entertain at tea on Thursday afternoon at her home here for her house guest, Mrs. McKenzie Frasier of Dothan, Ala.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin gave a luncheon today at Les Alouettes, their place on Lake Agawam, for Mr. and Mrs. E. Ward McMahon of Belle Terre, L.I., who have joined them for the week-end.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Consistently displaying superiority and keeping Roslyn well at bay, Aurora galloped to an 11-to-3 triumph at Bostwick Field today in another test match preparatory to the national open polo championship which will start Saturday.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 24. -- The American Newpaper Guild, whose strike for the reinstatement of two dismissed editorial workers has resulted in the suspension of publication since Aug. 13 of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, a Hearst morning newspaper, rests its case upon its asserted legal right to organize for collective bargaining under the Wagner-Connery Labor Relations Act.

Senator COUZENS declares that he is sick and tired of hearing people talk about the need of balancing the Federal Budget. Then he must be sick and tired of Mr. ROOSEVELT, whom he, as a Republican, proposes to support for re-election. No one has talked about budget balancing more frequently or with more emphasis than the President.

Servel, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on July 31 a net profit of $2,122,306 after depreciation, bond interest, Federal income taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the profit was equivalent to $1.18 each on 1,781,426 $1-par common shares outstanding at the end of the company's fiscal year on Oct. 31, 1935.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 24. -- Spanish Rebel aircraft today dropped a dozen 100-pound bombs on Irun, in the San Sebastian area, and on the government artillery position near by. Three planes afterward returned to the Rebel stronghold of Burgos and a fourth made a long reconnaissance flight over the government positions.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- Great satisfaction is being expressed here over the German Government's decision to put an embargo on all arms export and transit to Spain in accordance with the French non-intervention proposal.

The Most Rev. Michael J. Curley, Archbishop of Baltimore, is among the passengers on the Cunard White Star liner Laconia, which is due to arrive today from Liverpool. The passengers also include the Most Rev. Patrick Collier, Bishop of Ossory; the Right Rev. Mgr. D.S. Lavery and A.L. Smith.

A plan of refunding for the $11,680,000 of 3 per cent bonds, due in 1991, of the Commonwealth of Virginia was announced yesterday by the State. The securities, known as the "century" bonds, were issued in 1891 and have been callable since 1906.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Five national campaign headquarters, swinging into high speed as Fall approaches, counted their employes at more than seven hundred today.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- Summoning the members of the American bar to a militant defense of the independence of the judiciary as the keystone of the nation's liberties, William L. Ransom of New York, president of the American Bar Association, aroused 3,000 of its members to high enthusiasm here this morning in opening the annual convention of the association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Rhode Island Public Service Company of Providence, a subsidiary of the New England Power Association, has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for issuance of notes evidencing loans amounting to $8,000,000 which it expects to obtain from twelve banks.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- Perched on the weather rail like so many sparrows on a fence, 14-year-old Bryce Kirk and his able Manhasset Bay Yacht Club crew of Burton Morris and Rodman Deky sailed off with the first race of the Long Island Sound midget championship series today.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 24 (AP). -- With the Mississippi River at its lowest level in eleven years, Federal engineers of the Memphis district today had six dredges working at top speed to keep a clear channel for navigation.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- Hearing of evidence before a special commissioner in the $1,000,000 slander and libel suit brought by J. Raymond Cornell of Newton in the New York Supreme Court against Mary Pickford will begin here Wednesday. The special commissioner is Francis B. Burns, a Boston lawyer, appointed by Federal Judge Knox.

The first twelve railroads to report earnings for July showed an increase of 87.8 per cent in net operating income, compared with July, 1935. The following table compares earnings of these companies in July with those in the same month in 1935 and 1934, with the percentage of increase:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24. -- I.A. Horowitz of New York took the lead tonight in the open tournament of the American Chess Federation with a score of 2 1/2 points out of 3. He won two matches and drew the third.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 24. -- Leon Trotsky issued the following statement today:

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, advocate of $200-a-month pensions for the aged, testified today in connection with the receivership suit against his organization that more than a million dollars has been spent in organizing Townsend Clubs in the United States.
A weakness and "joker" in the Milk Control Act was blamed yesterday for the threatened milk strike of up-State producers by John J. Dillon, editor of The Rural New Yorker.
The twenty-third junior championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association will be held at Wheatley Hills, East Williston, L.I., starting tomorrow and lasting three days.

Hamlin Garland has written from California that his "Forty Years of Psychic Research" closes his writing career. He began to write in 1885 and has had published nearly forty books of fiction, history, poetry, drama, essays and literary comment. Macmillans have been his publishers.

Another important purchase in the Rockefeller Center zone near Fifth Avenue was reported yesterday. The National City Bank, through the Kempner Realty Corporation, acquired the two houses at 7 and 9 West Fifty-first Street, adjoining the Women's Republican Club.

It is a pleasure to notice that the Virginia Republicans are going to open headquarters in Richmond about Sept. 1. While the party's chances of success are a distant prospect, the machine will be all the better for oiling. It will do "the boys" good to have some money to spend and it will do the Democrats no harm.
ST. PAUL, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Hjalmar Petersen, Danish emigrant and country editor, took the oath of office as Governor of Minnesota today, succeeding Floyd B. Olson, who died Saturday night.

The Coamo of the New York and Porto Rico Line arrived in port yesterday with the distinction of having been the first commercial ship to reach the shore of Santo Domingo in her modern commercial history.

When Thomas W. Lamont minimizes the danger of war in Europe and the possible dragging into any international upheaval of the United States he undoubtedly knows what he is talking about, and he deserves the thanks of not only the American people but the commendation of the major nations of Europe, who have little, indeed, to gain if they once more involve themselves in a general conflict.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- The Boerse opened the week with a veritable boom which was more than a recovery from the slump of "black" Friday. Gains of two, three or more points were numerous, especially among heavy industrials, machines, autos and related issues.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24. -- Hale C. Jones, 29-year-old automobile salesman from East Alton, Ill., won the Champion of Champions feature of the thirty-seventh annual Grand American Trapshoot today, but an 80-year-old Ohioan and a 13-year-old Kansan stole the show.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 24. -The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Aug. 15 shows the following changes, in paper pesos:

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 24. -- A tie for first place existed between Mikhail Botwinnik of Leningrad and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the world champion, at the close of tonight's play in the twelfth round of the international chess masters' tournament.

PARIS, Tuesday, Aug. 25 (AP). -The newspaper Le Matin published a report today that Abd-el-Krim, one-time belligerent chieftain of the Moroccan Riffs, had escaped from exile on the island of Reunion in the Indian Ocean.

An application by the Phillips Petroleum Company for the listing of 296,631 additional shares of its capital stock, to be offered pro rata to shareholders at $30 a share in the ratio of one new share for each fourteen shares held, has been approved by the stock list committee of the New York Stock Exchange.

Disproportionate to its size, population and natural resources, but proportionate to its dramatic history and rich upper culture, South Carolina, which today is holding an important party primary, is one of the most famous States of the Union. The very word "Union" instantly recalls the portentous occasion when South Carolina attained world attention by leading the train of State secession in an effort to end that union.

NORTHPORT, L.I. Aug. 24. -- Charges by Alfred M. Caddell of Stony Brook, L.I., that he had been assigned to a Federal project twenty miles from his home and to work for which he is physically unfitted were challenged here today by W.F. Birmingham, in charge of the WPA in this district.

PAMPLONA, Spain, Aug. 24. -Spanish Rebel officers reported today the execution of five Frenchmen fighting with the Loyalist forces and warned that other French nationals who joined in the civil war might expect the same fate.

Unusually cautious burglars who must have figured their angle of operations with rule and compass looted the shop of Alfred Dunhill of London, Inc., in Rockefeller Center of gold and jeweled smoking accessories worth between $25,000 and $35,000.

Walter A. Rathbourne, 41 years old, an inmate of Sing Sing since last February on a conviction in a bogus bond transaction, received another sentence of five to ten years from Judge William Allen in General Sessions yesterday. Rathbourne had pleaded guilty on Aug. 10 as he was about to go on trial in another bond forgery plot which he engineered from his cell.

That any broad movement of corporations to finance their activities through offerings of rights to stockholders would affect the profits of the underwriting business is evident from the listing application of the Phillips Petroleum Company, covering an offering of 296,631 shares of its own shares to stockholders.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- A number of picnic luncheon parties were given at Bailey's Beach today. Mrs. James H.R. Cromwell entertained there, as did Miss Lesley Bogert, Mrs. Henry Drummond Wolff, Mrs. Byrnes MacDonald, Baroness de Villiers Terrage and J.H. O'Connell.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Wage increases for all WPA workers and recognition of the Workers Alliance of America as a collective bargaining agency for them were major proposals in a program of "demands" presented today to President Roosevelt and to Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator.

With election day ten weeks away, it is interesting to note what were the facts in regard to registration and election in our city in 1934. That was the last time we elected a Governor and members of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The amendment to the Securities Act of 1934, which provides that the Securities and Exchange Commission, under certain conditions, may permit unlisted trading on an exchange in securities listed and registered on another Exchange, will become effective on Wednesday and several applications for the extension of such privileges are expected at once.

Justice Alfred J. Hofmann testified for about two hours yesterday in the New York County grand jury's inquiry into the fake telephone call that took him from the Special Sessions bench on July 29 to the Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park to learn Mayor La Guardia had not sent for him.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 24. -- A bluefish has an underslung jaw like a bulldog's, a long, streamlined body meant for speed, and a mean temperament These are admirable traits in a game fish. But, best of all, his small body houses a fighting heart and a will to live.

CONNEAUTVILLE, Pa., Aug. 24. -- A crowd of about 1,500 men, women and children were startled this afternoon by the sound of four shots fired in a chase after a pickpocket, just after Governor Landon had expressed thanks for his reception in the little village of 1,200 inhabitants, which was the home of the Landon family for a hundred years.

TOKYO, Aug. 24. -- The Japanese Army at Hsinking, Manchukuo, announced today that nine Russian Communists had been executed, five sentenced to life imprisonment and twelve to terms ranging from five to twenty years.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 24. -- The Bretton Woods choir boys of Camp Duncan went to Jackson where they gave a concert at Grays Inn Casino tonight before a large audience of colonists.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The text of Governor Landon's address here tonight was as follows:
The dollar on the local forein exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

While there were periods of hesitancy in yesterday's share market when trading was extremely dull, the market followed the line of least resistance and closed slightly higher on the day. The trade and industrials news over the week-end was mainly cheerful, and reports on the progress made toward European neutrality in the Spanish situation were distinctly reassuring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The administration's recent promise that no new taxes would be sought at the next session of Congress was intended as a "legitimate and aboveboard" assurance that no sweeping changes of any kind were contemplated in the revenue laws, whether for new levies or shifting the burden of taxation.
LONDON, Aug. 24. -- Again the Nazi Reich has hurled a bombshell at France and Russia, but she has timed the stroke so skillfully that it will do the least possible damage to Anglo-German relations.

Pedro Montanez won another fight last night. The Puerto Rican lightweight chalked up his eighteenth consecutive victory in this country by outpointing the courageous Eddie Brink of Scranton before a crowd of 6,000 persons at Dyckman Oval.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Miss Patricia Cumming of Westfield, N.J., and Miss Dorothy McCann of Larchmont led the field into the semi-finals of the metropolitan junior invitation tennis tournament for the challenge trophy presented by Mrs. Roy Lucas of Yonkers as play began today on the grass courts of the Ardsley club.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- The use of colored light as a treatment for stomach trouble was described today to the American Academy of Optometrists.

Patrolman Michael Belanchuk of the East Twenty-second Street Station was arrested last night in the Wilson Avenue precinct in Brooklyn on a charge of homicide growing out of the death of a man he arrested on July 22. He was accused of using "unnecessary violence" in making the arrest.

Waterfront sages puckered their lips last night and pondered the question "When is a ship a champion?" Involved therein were such matters as the direction she travels when she makes her bid, the importance of the ocean's currents and the willingness of her rivals to accept her performance.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, made a two-hour tour of inspection of the Saratoga Spa this afternoon. It is expected the President will visit here in September.
MADRID, Aug. 24. -- "Revolution proof" vaults, declared by Bank of Spain officials to be strongest in the world, safeguard the nation's $700,000,000 gold reserve.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- On his way from Pennsylvania to New York today, Governor Landon stopped for an hour and a half visit in the village of Conneautville, which was the home of the Landon family for a century.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24. -- Henry Culley and Joe Hunt of California, winners of the Longwood Bowl tournament and conquerors of Donald Budge and Gene Mako, the Davis Cup combination, at Seabright, were eliminated from the national doubles championship in the opening round today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

Among letters to THE TIMES appears a short missive from "Brooklyn Sufferer." The purport of the message is to prompt public recognition of our Sanitation Department's action in regard to law enforcement in the case of dog filth.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Quiet campaigning ended tonight for candidates in tomorrow's State primary election which will furnish a test of strength for the Townsend organization in its approval of twenty contenders for Congressional seats.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24. -- Among girls who will be introduced to society here during September will be Miss Nancy I.S. Downs, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Findlay Downs of Chestnut Hill, will give a supper dance on Sept. 10 at their home. Preceding the debutante's dance Mr. and Mrs. Downs will give a dinner for out-of-town house guests.

The electric power and light industry has filed with the Federal Communications Commission an application for the allocation of sixteen radio frequencies and two additional "special-emergency" allocations and the retention of two allocations at present available on the "special-emergency" basis, the Edison Electric Institute reports in its August bulletin.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 24. -- Severe attacks upon the dictators in Europe and upon Japan's persistent "obstruction" of reconstruction and unification in China were made today at the conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations.

Major Wilfred E. Boughton, former director of the WPA Industrial Re-employment Bureau, declared in a radio interview last night from Station W2XR, under the auspices of the Republican Radio Council, that WPA jobs should have been given exclusively to those in need and that those in charge of this branch of relief work had not adhered to that principle.

Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn, speaking yesterday afternoon at the annual convention of the Improved Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks of the World, Negro, promised the cooperation of State, city and borough officials in breaking down the barriers of religious and racial hatred.

Seven oil company executives, indicted in Madison, Wis., for gasoline price fixing in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law, posted $5,000 bail yesterday pending a hearing on Oct. 1 and then were taken to police headquarters to be fingerprinted and photographed.

Last-minute orders for merchandise for school reopenings featured the start of the week in the wholesale markets here yesterday. A substantial business had already been placed in misses' college and sports wear, with the mail volume yesterday tending to emphasize juvenile apparel, stationery and other types of school equipment.

In his address to the American Bar Association yesterday its president, Mr. WILLIAM L. RANSOM, tried to make the flesh of his hearers creep. The British lawyers and judges present must have been surprised, if not edified. Apparently this eminent lawyer had transported himself into the Seventeen Seventies.

The fate of holders of American certificates for participating debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company will be settled definitely at a hearing to be held here on Sept. 22 by Harold P. Coffin as referee. About 7,365,000 certificates were outstanding in May, 1932, held by 41,605 stockholders.
AVELLINO, Italy, Aug. 24 (AP). -Amid the rumble of war thunder in Europe, Italy tuned up her war machines for the army's annual manoeuvres scheduled to start at midnight.

SEATTLE, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Mrs. Ester Hilda Olson, impoverished young mother, was charged with murder tonight after a deputy sheriff said she confessed the axe slaying of her daughter, who "fussed" because she could not have "pretty clothes, a nice home and good food."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -Cotton of this year's growth ginned before Aug. 16 was reported by the Census Bureau today to have advanced to 208,327 running bales, counting 452 round bales as half bales.

NANKING, China, Aug. 24. -- A spokesman for the central government admitted today that thousands of Communists led by the notorious Chu Teh had evacuated Szechuan Province and were swarming northward through Southern Kansu.
The Fifth Avenue Association pledged support yesterday to Mayor La Guardia's campaign to keep the streets of the city spick and span.

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 24. -- James Oleska of Shoreview and Pat Doyle, Clearview professional, one of the last pairs to finish, carded a 66 to take first honors in the amateur-pro tournament held today by the Long Island Golf Association at Engineers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Errors by Alex Kampouris and Les Scarsella in the tenth inning broke up an overtime pitching duel between Lon Warneke and Gene Schott and gave the Chicago Cubs a 2-to-1 decision over the Cincinnati Reds today.
THE central idea of Norman Thomas's new book "After the New Deal, What?" (Macmillan, $2) is that until the United States has a Socialist government, it will have no satisfactory government.

Sharp improvement in the jewelry trade thus far this year, with increases ranging up to 30 per cent or more over 1935, was reported yesterday at the opening of the thirty-first annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 24. -- A single by Frank Hawkins scoring Bill Baker with two out in the ninth gave the Bear a 7-6 triumph over Albany in the opener of a six-game series today.

Two of the strongest teams entered will face each other in the first match of the national open polo championship at Meadow Brook Saturday, according to the draw made public yesterday by the United States Polo Association.

MADRID, Aug. 18 (Uncensored, by Courier to Hendaye, France, Aug. 24). -- President Manuel Azana of Spain shipped truckloads of baggage to the port of Valencia, reliable sources said tonight, as government officials expressed fears that Madrid might fall before the Rebel advance.

SEATTLE, Aug. 24. -- Newspaper publishers of the Pacific Northwest received a call today to confer here Wednesday on The Seattle Post-Intelligencer's newsroom strike, which caused the paper to suspend publication Aug. 14.
A WPA worker was stabbed to death last night in the Flushing subway station, the terminus of the Flushing division of the B.M.T. and I.R.T. Lines and one of the busy stations in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The blackboard displayed in butcher shops by the Republican party, purporting to show housewives how much taxes they pay when buying meat cuts, has given the administration "a bad case of jitters," according to Arthur M. Curtis, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The total value of agricultural trade between the United States and Canada has increased 24 per cent in the first six months of operation of the reciprocal trade agreement, according to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24. -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, battering four St. Louis pitchers for twenty-five hits and a 17-to-5 victory, today rammed the Cardinals down to a first-place tie in the National League with the idle New York Giants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Spanish Government has formally assured the United States that it has no intention of confiscating private property belonging either to Spanish citizens or to foreigners. Excerpts from the Spanish note were cabled to the State Department today by Eric C. Wendelin. United States Charge d'Affaires in Madrid.

Amateur golfers throughout America today face one of the crucial days of the entire golf year. It is the day on which the qualifying rounds for the national amateur championship, to be held at the Garden City Golf Club, Garden City, L.I., Sept. 14-19, will be played on thirty different golf courses located at strategic points throughout the country.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 24. -- A resolution calling upon Governor Hoffman to call a special session of the State Legislature to consider a permanent relief program and also a complete revision of the New Jersey taxing system was adopted here tonight by the executive and advisory boards of the League of New Jersey Municipalities.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, who has spent $250,000 to escape a prison term, got out of Dannemora today, but only for the brief period necessary for a court argument.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 24 (AP). -Leon Trotsky, exiled Russian Bolshevist leader, said tonight he stood ready to answer charges he had fomented a plot to overthrow the Soviet regime and incidentally kill Dictator Joseph Stalin.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- By a pen stroke Chancellor Adolf Hitler today re-established Germany's prewar position as the biggest military power in Europe, if Russia's Asiatic forces are excepted from her total, when he issued a decree raising the term of compulsory military service from one to two years.

The Twentieth Century Limited arrived in Grand Central Terminal yesterday morning with its last two cars streamlined. The two Pullmans, of an entirely new design, comprised a jointed unit, a bedroom car followed by an observation-lounge-buffet car with an oval-shaped solarium.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 24. -- President Lazaro Cardenas, in a letter addressed this evening to former Provisional President Emilio Portes Gil, indicated his regretful acceptance of Mr. Portes Gil's resignation as leader of the National Revolutionary party.

Edsel Ford returned from Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after a five-week business trip. He said he had been impressed by the industrial activity abroad and by the absence of any threat to the peace of the Continent.

This evening will be largely Philip Barry's, a matter that is probably all right, any way you want to look at it. His "Spring Dance," which goes into the records as the first comedy of the new season, opens at the Empire Theatre (8:40 P.M.) with a cast including Louise Platt, Ruth Matteson, Philip Ober, Martha Hodge, Marie Bruce and Richard Kendrick.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The White Sex advanced within a half-game of third place in the American League today as they collected fourteen hits to defeat the Tigers, 8 -- 4, behind the effective hurling of Ted Lyons. The victory gave the Sox the series three games to one.

HONGKONG, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Five demands, including war against Japan, were laid down today by leaders of the Kwangsi Province rebellion as a preface to their surrender to the authority of the Nanking government.
LODI, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Another large textile dyeing plant in Northern New Jersey threatens to close on Aug. 31, throwing between 800 and 1,000 workers out of employment.

More than 100 keepers, policemen, zoo officials and volunteers could not bring Peter, the Himalayan black bear, back alive yesterday afternoon. They surrounded him, closing in with a heavy net, but he broke through them and to prevent his getting out of the Bronx Zoological Gardens and endangering children in the streets they had to shoot him.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 24. -- Nomination of Senator Pat Harrison for a fourth term by the smallest majority given him during his eighteen years in that office was indicated today on the eve of the State primary election.

Mayor La Guardia, in a letter yesterday to American Airlines, called attention to the fact that a large sleeper plane owned by that company had landed at Floyd Bennett Airport in Brooklyn on Aug. 10, when weather conditions at Newark Airport were bad.
A 1937 departmental budget $479,756 above the 1936 allotment was submitted yesterday by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx to Budget Director Leo J. McDermott.

Bright sunny skies and high temperatures warmed the city yesterday after a triple thunderstorm that caused widespread damage from lightning and a downpour of rain that totaled 1.59 inches. It was the heaviest rain this Summer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- While most of the nation perspired today, twenty-five men in widely scattered points crawled into heavy clothing to protect themselves from freezing temperatures.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Freedom of education, the press and the radio from control by an autocratic government as necessary for the preservation of democracy in America was advocated by Governor Landon here tonight.

A little bit shaky in the knees after their ten-day crossing of the Atlantic, the members of the British Walker Cup team arrived here late yesterday afternoon and were bundled immediately into busses and taken to Clementon, N.J., where tomorrow they will take their first peek at the awesome Pine Valley Golf Club course, scene of the international matches on Wednesday and Thursday of next week.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The Rumson Country Club Quartet, led by H.W. (Rube) Williams, defeated the Rumson Elephants, 5 -- 4, in the opening match of the annual J. Ernest Stern Cup tournament at the Norwood Country Club this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- On the eve of his departure with President Roosevelt on a tour of the parched Midwest. Secretary Wallace today disclosed tentative plans to lend from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 to farmers storing seed corn for next year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Prices of grains on the Board of Trade were on the downgrade almost from the start of trading today. At no time were they as high as Saturday's finish, and the markets became increasingly weaker as the session progressed, with the close at virtually the bottom, except on September corn.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 24. -- A story of how five factory girls taught the management of the Western Electric Company that good human relationship was one of the secrets of industrial success was told today at the opening of the Harvard tercentenary's six-day symposium of the university's School of Public Health on "Environment and Its Effect on Man."
A well-distributed demand for apartments in buildings on the East and West Sides of Manhattan was indicated in leases announced by brokers and renting agents yesterday.

The decentralization of industry, as a result of large companies setting up separate entities in States, in order to avoid the provisions of the Robinson-Patman law, was predicted yesterday by Representative Emanuel Celler at a round-table discussion and luncheon of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.
Jesse Owens, all-conquering Olympic hero and international idol, came back to his homeland yesterday to receive an enthusiastic welcome.

President Roosevelt will get pluralities in Oregon, Iowa and North Dakota as large if not larger than he received in 1932, leaders from those States who visited James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, asserted yesterday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., who has been burning up the fairways in America and England this year, began defense of her Western women's closed golf championship today by tieing for the medal at seventy-nine strokes with Miss Dorothy Gustafson of South Bend.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24, -- Mrs. Orson D. Munn gave a dinner and bridge tonight at the Arches. Mrs. Stuart Duncan Preston en-, tertained with a dinner at Miramichi, taking her guests later to the presentation by Michael Strange at the John Drew Memorial Theatre.
SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 24. -- Loyalist airplanes today bombed the Granada airdrome in retaliation for the Rebel bombing of the Madrid air base at Getafe yesterday.

Although one corporate food chain has signified its displeasure with the dropping of advertising allowances under the Robinson-Patman Law by discontinuing its own advertising in certain sections, the voluntary food chains feel that they will be much harder hit by the provisions of the law than the corporate groups.

The protective committee for holders of debentures of the National Public Service Corporation said yesterday that it would oppose approval by the court of the petition for reorganization of the company under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act submitted by Associated Gas and Electric interests. These interests hold more than 32 per cent of the debentures or their certificates of deposit.

Eugene A. Bowen, 42 years old, of 1,105 Park Avenue, Manhattan, was held in $2,500 bail to await action of the grand jury on a bigamy charge yesterday before Judge Anthony J. Botti in First Criminal Court, Jersey City. Bowen was arrested on a warrant by Police Lieutenant Philip Beggans at Lake Mahopac, N.Y.
PAMPLONA, Spain, Aug. 24. -Paulino Uzcudun, Basque heavyweight fighter, trudged fifty miles through the woods and over mountains to "return from the dead" today.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 24. -- A demand for the arrest and handing over to Japanese authorities of about 200 Koreans living in and around Nanking has been made upon the Chinese Foreign Office by Yakichiro Suma, Japanese Consul General in Nanking.

A woman, arrested as a pickpocket suspect in a Brooklyn department store, was subdued after a short chase in West Twenty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon when she tried to escape while being escorted by Policewoman Anna C. Orr to the West Thirtieth Street station.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Sixteen men convicted of a plot to overthrow Joseph Stalin and the Soviet Government have been executed, it was officially announced today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- A recital was given tonight in the John Drew Memorial Theatre by Michael Strange (Mrs. Harrison Tweed of New York and Southampton). She presented some of her own and other poems to a harp accompaniment.

Chautauqua gave Governor LANDON a national platform for the discussion of that which is nearest to most families throughout America outside of the home -- the public school. In plain, straightforward speech, without adornment of rhetoric, he set forth the essential contribution of the free school to a free democracy.

Of the sixteen men executed in Moscow for having conspired to assassinate Joseph Stalin and other Soviet leaders, four -- Zinovieff, Kameneff, Evdokimoff and Smirnoff -- were close to Lenin and prominent in the Communist party leadership in the years immediately after the October (1917) revolution.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 24. -- American track and field stars won six of eight events in a meet with picked Finnish Olympic stars today.
TOKYO, Aug. 24. -- Japanese military forces announced tonight the execution of nine members of a "secret Soviet shock battalion" near

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 24. -- The ushers for the dramatic and musical entertainment at the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club, Lenox, on Thursday, will be the Misses Nora I. Bullitt, Barbara Bullitt, Frances M. Clucas, Anne Treadway, Margaret McL. Johansen, Hope and Beatrice S. Proctor and Barbara Longcope.
VIENNA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Felix Weingartner, director of the State Opera, resigned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Jay N. (Ding) Darling, former chief of the Bureau of Biological Survey, charged in a radio discussion tonight that the water conservation program in the drought area of North Dakota was in the hands of "political administrators."

MADRID, Aug. 21. (Uncensored London Times Dispatch). -- Accumulated evidence shows that lust for violence has spread over Spain with devastating rapidity. Accounts from the country wherever there is fighting tell of bloody, pitiless reprisals by both sides with no quarter expected or given.

Helped by the recovery in stock prices, second grade bonds and bonds convertible into common stock were bid up yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. High-grade issues generally held firm. Treasury obligations mostly were stronger, with two issues making new highs.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24. -- The Giants' holiday today before plunging into a three-game series with the Reds was made most enjoyable by the news late this afternoon that they were tied with the Cardinals for first place in the National League's hectic first-place scramble.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- An answer to charges that the Commodity Exchange Act of 1936 is unconstitutional was filed today on behalf of the Federal Government. Hearing on the suit for an injunction to block enforcement of the law will be held tomorrow afternoon before Federal Judge John P. Barnes.
Directors of Bloomingdale Brothers voted yesterday a dividend of 45 cents a share. On June 27 and in previous quarters the company paid 10 cents.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Herman Barron and Max Pasmantier, both of Fenway, turned in a card of 67 to win the pro-amateur tourney sponsored by the Westchester County Golf Association on the course of the Westchester Country Club.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 24. -- Pharmacy has been a material factor in reducing the death rate in the United States, Dr. George D. Beal of Pittsburgh, president-elect of the American Pharmaceutical Association, said at a meeting today preliminary to the convention of the association and its five allied organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- President Roosevelt has invited the Governors who will attend his drought conference in Des Moines on Sept. 1, including Governor Landon, to dine with him on his special train that night, the White House announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- A grand jury indicted Magistrate James J. Campbell and former Magistrate Louis Hamberg today on charges of malfeasance and misfeasance in office.

Prices were irregular or weak on commodity futures markets here in dull trading yesterday. Cocoa, which reflected a new high spot price, was an exception. On the other cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, cotton, lard, silk and rubber declined.

IF they can look at the thirteenth hole at Pine Valley without blanching, those British Walker Cup players are brave fellows. They might even like the layout. It's the youngest team Great Britain has sent to the Walker Cup wars and the chipper chaps may not know any better.

OTTAWA, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Successive dry spells in Southern Saskatchewan and Alberta have created a national problem which will be recognized as such by the government, Finance Minister Charles Dunning announced today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 24. -- After hearing arguments for and against the proposal of the War Department to establish a national cemetery on one of three suggested sites in Nassau County, the Nassau Board of Supervisors went on record today as unanimously opposed to the establishment of any additional cemetery in the county.

Ocean queens tie the blue ribbon of the Atlantic in their hair with knots instead of bows. The Queen Mary has done it with 30.01 knots. taking the coveted hair ornament away from the Normandie, who could muster only 29.64 knots.

The New Deal is engaged in "a definite and well-planned attempt to buy up American youth," Walter J. Mahoney, president of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs, declared in a radio address last night over Station WEAF and a State-wide network.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Noting that cities with a large number of policemen in proportion to their population generally have less crime, the Federal Bureau of Investigation made public today a survey of forces maintained in 1,950 American communities.

The best prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were reached at the opening of trading in response to steadiness in markets abroad, but they came under the combined pressure of liquidation and hedge selling and declined 15 points, going again into new low ground, and closed with net losses of 5 to 9 points.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- A.A. Baroni, who has done so well training Top Row and the rest of his string, brought off a double today over the roughest track of the meeting when his Sun Archer and Risotto were first in the fourth and first races respectively.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, was reported tonight to be preparing to announce that he would appeal from the dismissal last June of the government's suit seeking to recover $2,842,616 from nine member banks of the New York Clearing House Association to complete the payment of depositors in the closed Harriman National Bank.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Two light limbering-up drills were staged at the Blue Hill Country Club today. As Coach Steve Owen continued preparing the New York Football Giants for their game with the college all-stars at the Polo Grounds on Tuesday, Sept. 8.

In the welter of nationalistic world confusion, when no man is big enough to comprehend it sufficiently to solve all problems involved, there is one thing that every wideawake American can do, namely, take every opportunity to speak a good word for neighbor Canada and act accordingly.

LENOLA, N.J., Aug. 24. -- About 500 striking WPA workers of Burlington County gathered here tonight at a mass meeting to protest the differential in the work relief wage scale that gives them less money and more hours of work than WPA men in near-by Camden and Mercer Counties.

Vincent Sheean's "Personal History" has been bought by Walter Wanger as the keystone of his first production schedule for United Artists. Negotiations are under way with Fredric March for the lead opposite Madeleine Carroll. Lewis Milestone will direct.

With approximately 500 lines as against 379 last year and attendance of buyers exceeding the 600 mark, the New York Gift Show opened yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. It is expected that the local event will make as good showing as that at Chicago during the first two weeks of this month at which attendance showed an increase of 30 per cent over last year, according to George F. Little, managing director.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- G.E. Phillips, trainer for DeWitt Page's Maemere Farm, was suspended indefinitely by the New York State Racing Commission today as the result of a drug detected in the saliva of Maeriel, a filly which won the Catskill Handicap last Wednesday at odds of 30 -- 1 after being as high as 50 -- 1.

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings and his counsel, Lloyd Paul Stryker, will leave by automobile this afternoon for Albany, where Mr. Geoghan has been summoned to defend himself tomorrow against the Drukman grand jury's charges and its demand for his removal from office.
VIENNA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Military excursions and alarms beset Vienna tonight in the midst of rumored fears of an anti-Nazi coup.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Prices of hogs here advanced 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight early today, but trade was light and late business was done at quotations generally steady with Friday's. The day's top of $11.80 was 20 cents above the best figure of Friday, while the average was up 10 cents at $10.30.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 24. -- The close of the Northfield Summer Conference season came today with the departure of the 1,400 delegates of the United Presbyterian Youth Convention, which had been holding its annual national session here the past five days.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24. -- After many conversations with leading Arabs here, Nuri Pasha as-Said, the Iraqi Minister of Foreign Affairs, left Jerusalem this morning. At Amman he lunched with Emir Abdullah of Trans-Jordan and then flew to Alexandria, Egypt.

It would be useless, and perhaps not wholly proper, to comment at length upon District Attorney GEOGHAN'S reply to the charges brought against him. These are all to be sifted in a quasi-judicial proceeding conducted by Governor LEHMAN. There will be long arguments and close cross-examination; presentation of evidence and testimony of witnesses.

When Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians announced yesterday that it planned to call a strike of 1,000 WPA musicians to reduce the number of weekly services, performances and rehearsals required of them, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, warned that he would abolish the music project in case of a Walkout.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 24. -- Five miners were killed today, four by black damp and one by a slide, when they were trapped in the Clear Springs shaft of the Sullivan Trail Coal Company by a cave-in that followed an explosion this morning. The dead, whose bodies were recovered in the afternoon, were:

When Leo Zarifian, 17-year-old Jackson Heights youth, knotted two ropes about his neck and told friends to "yank hard," seventy-five persons who gathered in Forest Park, Queens, yesterday for the borough trials in the Park Department's city-wide magic contest began to wonder whether they had come to witness a contest or an execution.

Dr. Charles A. Elsberg, chief of the surgical service of the Neurological Institute, was the guest of honor yesterday at a tea at the institute given by his colleagues of the medical staff on the occasion of his sixty-fifth birthday.

Under the glaring lights in the "big ring" on a vacant lot in Flatbush, Brooklyn, thirty boys, ranging from 12 to 18, squared off in pairs last night for the first big outdoor boxing tournament of the Police Athletic League of the Juvenile Aid Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Using for the first time a law enacted at the last session of Congress, the Senate Labor Investigating Committee moved today for quick indictment of six witnesses who failed to appear in response to subpoenas.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Governor Olin D. Johnston tonight authorized use of National Guardsmen, if necessary, in Charleston County tomorrow as South Carolina Democrats prepared to make a choice in a fight between Senator James F. Byrnes, administration defender, and two critics of the New Deal.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 24. -- The will of Eila Haggin McKee of 136 East Seventy-ninth Street, Manhattan, a Summer resident of Smithtown Branch, filed for probate in Suffolk County Surrogate's Court here today, bequeaths $500,000 to the San Joaquin Pioneer and Historical Society of Stockton, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Aug. 19 shows a decrease for the week of $68,000,000 in total loans and investments, an increase of $29,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, an increase of $42,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and decreases of $120,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and of $208,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24. -- Because all government offices are closed today, this being a "free day," it is impossible to learn whether any of the sixteen men, including Gregory Zinovieff and Leon Kameneff, condemned to death early this morning for an assassination plot against Joseph Stalin and his associates, have asked for clemency.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 24. -- Gibson White's Rosalind, driven by Ed White, repeated her victory in the Hambletonian trot by defeating Ed Lasater in the American Stake at the State Fair Park today in the resumption of Grand Circuit harness racing here.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- The German Government announced today that it would establish an embargo on all shipments of arms to Spain, effective immediately, and it has so notified the French, British and Italian Ambassadors.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Thousands of government sympathizers in San Sebastian, enraged by the Rebels' renewed bombardment, tonight rushed the doors of the prison and tried to lynch political hostages, diplomats here reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Charges of wastefulness on WPA projects in Monroe County, Ind., made last week by the Republican National Committee on the authority of John T. Stapleton, City Engineer of Bloomington, who later denied them, are reaffirmed in an affidavit said to have been sworn to by him Saturday and quoted in a statement issued by the committee today.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Five men were charged today with a Black Legion plot to murder a city commissioner of Highland Park in a new series of indictments returned by the grand jury investigating the night-riding organization.

MADRID, Aug. 24. -- Dr. Jose Robles, professor at Johns Hopkins University, who became chief of Spain's foreign press relations after the outbreak of the revolt, declared today he was confident the government ultimately would down it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- A plan to publish a national weekly magazine in Washington, bearing the name "Politics," to be devoted to politics and public affairs, "on a strictly nonpartisan basis," was revealed in a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by Politics, Inc., which gave its address as the Barr Building, Washington.

When Colonel SOMERVELL, now WPA Administrator in this city, was informed that the musicians who had been unemployed and for whom work had been provided out of the relief funds threatened to strike, he promptly served notice that if they did strike, their particular project would be abandoned.

Governor Landon's speech on education at Chautauqua was lauded and assailed yesterday by educators. The Republican National Committee made public a series of statements acclaiming his views, while the Democratic committee released a copy of a telegram from two educators hitting sharply at the Governor for his attitude toward the educational system of his own State.

program featuring opposition to unfavorable legislation which "paves the way for the chiseler and the bootlegger," and organized opposition to dry propaganda, was urged upon the liquor industry yesterday by Joseph H. Krause, president of the National Institute of Wine and Spirit Distributers at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25. -Prominent members of the Summer colony who have long taken interest in the work of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children attended the annual exhibition of the youngsters' handicraft this afternoon at the headquarters of the home in Sebonac Road.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The final concert in the Saratoga subscription series, of which Thomas H. Dickinson is director, was held tonight when the Gordon String Quartet was heard in a program of Haydn, Debussy and Beethoven. The performance was at the Spa Theatre.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Aug. 25 (AP). -- A double killing, which authorities declared was a murder and suicide, terminated early today a wild automobile ride in which a woman participated as an unwilling third-party passenger.

Everybody is pleased at the continued extension of the system of parks in Greater New York. Under the magic touch of Park Commissioner ROBERT MOSES they have been multiplied, rejuvenated, and made more accessible to thousands of adults and children. With this gratifying enlargement, however, one defect has become still more apparent.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,069,600 barrels daily, compared to 3,070,400 in the preceding week, a decrease of 800, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 15,100 barrels in the daily average output of California and a gain of 10,350 in Texas were the important changes.

The fog surrounding the meaning and application of the Patman-Robinson Anti-Price Discrimination Act remains as dense as it was on the day the act was passed. The Federal Trade Commission, to which business men have appealed for an interpretation of the act, has cautiously confined itself to repeating the language of the act and the previous explanations and debates of the Congressmen who sponsored it.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- William F. Whitehouse Jr. observed his twenty-first birthday today, and his parents, Mr. and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse, gave this evening a dinner dance at the Clambake Club in his honor. There were thirty young guests at the dinner and many more came in later for dancing.
PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 25. -- Officials of Dyers and Finishers Union worked strenuously tonight to avert the closing of more dyeing and printing plants in this section of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Contracts were awarded by the Navy Department today to private yards for the construction of six 1,500-ton destroyers and three 1,300-ton submarines. At the same time allocations were made to navy yards for the construction of four destroyers and two submarines of equivalent types.

Nine persons suffered from shock and minor injuries as the result of a sudden drop of a passenger elevator in the loft building at 327 West Thirty-sixth Street at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. Fourteen persons were in the car, according to the police, whose investigation showed that the car had "slipped" from the third floor to the safety device at the bottom of the shaft.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Following a call at the White House at the invitation of President Roosevelt, Senator Glass declared emphatically today that he planned to vote for Mr. Roosevelt's re-election.

The Warner Brothers film version of Hervey Allen's "Anthony Adverse" comes to the Strand this morning for its New York opening. Fredric March has the title role and the cast includes Olivia de Havilland, Anita Louise, Edmund Gwenn, Claude Rains, Louis Hayward, Gale Sundergaard, Steffi Duna and Billy Mauch, who plays Anthony as a boy.

The planting of 62,336,000 forest trees, the control of insect pests over 1,731,373 acres, and the improvement of 24,420 acres of standing forests are included in the work projects completed in the last three years in New York State by the Civilian Conservation Corps, it was announced yesterday by George H. Combs Jr., New York State Director of the National Emergency Council.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 25 (AP). -The Brazilian Senate, it was learned today, has annulled a 2,410,000-acre Japanese land grant in the State of Amazonas. The action was taken in secret session yesterday.

MADRID, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Premier Jose Giral said tonight that the Spanish Government had demanded that a European neutrality pact be signed as quickly as possible "to prevent our enemies from profiting by delay."
TOKYO, Aug. 25. -- Out of thirty "national renovation" policies submitted by government departments the Cabinet today approved seven, as follows:

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 25. -Howard, an odds-on choice owned by Mrs. Walter E. O'Hara, wife of the president and managing director of Narragansett Park, came from far back to win the Tiverton Purse at a mile and a furlong, which featured today's card.

The American Civil Liberties Union, it became known here yesterday, has filed with the clerk in Chancery at Trenton, N.J., a petition for appeal from the decree dismissing the divorce petition of Mrs. Mabel Eaton and awarding the custody of her two children to her husband, Warren Eaton of Bloomfield, N.J.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, conferred several hours yesterday afternoon with representatives of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which has threatened to call a strike of 1,000 WPA musicians if the WPA goes ahead with plans to increase from four to seven the number of weekly "services" -- performances and rehearsals.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25. -- Governor Landon had an enthusiastic reception on his arrival today at Buffalo, second largest city in the State, which now has a Democratic city administration and which his supporters hope to carry for him on Nov. 3.

Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska has entered the Presidential campaign as an active backer of President Roosevelt. He also will be a candidate for re-election as an independent in his own State. This was disclosed here yesterday on the heels of revelation of a split in the Democratic ranks in Nebraska.
May I pacify the perturbed mind of Hendrik Willem van Loon as to "The Rights of Authors" as indicated by his letter printed in THE TIMES?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- A registration statement for an issue of $20,000,000 of general and refunding mortgage bonds, series G, due on Sept. 1, 1966, by the Detroit Edison Company was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Details will be filed later.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- President Roosevelt left Washington late this evening for a tour of the drought regions, including visits to eight States and conferences with sixteen Governors.

A city-wide campaign to draw attention to the proposed new city charter and to promote its adoption by voters at the November election was launched yesterday by the newly formed Citizens Charter Campaign Committee.
OMAHA, Aug. 25. -- Democratic forces throughout Nebraska were dividing into three camps today following announcement that Senator Edward R. Burke had resigned as Democratic National Committeeman.

As a result of an investigation ordered by Mayor La Guardia to fix responsibility for the accidental imprisonment of two small children in Public School 19, the Bronx, on Aug. 18, the teacher in charge of the play school at the building will be asked to resign, James Marshall, acting president of the Board of Education, announced yesterday.

Passenger revenues on the Illinois Central Railroad from the first of the year to mid-August were $759,000 more than in the same period last year, according to L. A. Downs, president. From March to July, inclusive, revenue from the transport of merchandise increased $150,000, he added.
A ruling interpreted by the management of the company as removing a serious obstacle to changing the capital structure of the B.F. Goodrich Company was rendered yesterday in Supreme Court.

FRISCO, N.C., Aug. 25 (AP). -- Two 13-year old boys related a tale today of how they battled a school of maddened sharks from a rowboat, bagged one, escaped, and displayed the big fish to prove their story.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25. -- A "hands off" policy, as far as taking personal part in the selection of a Republican candidate for Governor of New York is concerned, was announced by Governor Landon in talks with party leaders.

Helen Payne, a 7-year-old American girl who is a refugee from the Spanish revolution, was saved from returning to the custody of her mother who lives in Barcelona by a decision of Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Schoolboy Rowe of Detroit pitched a two-hit game today to shut out the Red Sox, 5 to 0, in the first game of the series. No Boston player got beyond first base and only two went as far as that, Roger Cramer in the fourth inning and Joe Cronin in the fifth. The schoolboy's victory was his fifteenth.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 25. -- Senator James F. Byrnes, stanch supporter of the New Deal, buried two anti-administration opponents under an avalanche of votes in today's Democratic primary on the basis of incomplete returns.

For the seventh consecutive week the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday reached the thousand mark. The total, however, was slightly less than in the preceding week but was well ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

PARIS, Aug. 25. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank and German economics minister, arrived in Paris by airplane today to continue talks begun with Emile Labeyrie, governor of the Bank of France, on the latter's recent visit to Berlin.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary will sail today at 1 P.M. for Cherbourg and Southampton -- with no blue pennant at her mast to indicate her claim to the speed championship of the Atlantic.

A banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer to the public today at 102 $35,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first-mortgage bonds, due in 1966, of the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company. Net proceeds from the sale of the issue will be used by the company to redeem on Oct. 1, $35,000,000 of its series A 4 per cent bonds due in 1968.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The foreign affairs committee of the Cabinet met today to consider various aspects of the European situation. It was the first time any two or more Ministers of the Baldwin government had been together since Parliament adjourned at the end of July.

CINCINNATI, Aug., 25. -- The Giants today hammered their way into sole possession of the National League lead at Crosley Field, past the hoodoo of their thirteenth straight victory, the enervating heat as the thermometer soared close to 100 degrees, despite the disturbing shrieks of a ladies' day gathering of 15,000 and in spite of the Reds.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- With promptitude characteristic of this government without benefit of Parliament, War Minister Werner von Blomberg issued today the administrative decrees necessary for the enforcement of the two-year military conscription term decreed by Chancellor Hitler last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP). -President Roosevelt today announced the appointment, effective Oct. 1, of two major generals and six brigadier generals to fill vacancies to be caused by retirements Sept. 30.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 -- The National Association of Women Lawyers barred political addresses from its convention today a few minutes after a Boston attorney completed under protest his twice-interrupted speech against the New Deal.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 25.--Japanese delegates to the Institute of Pacific Relations conceded today that there had been mistakes in Japan's China policy. It was the first Japanese admission of this nature in the five years since the outbreak of the Manchurian "affair."

The United States liner Washington will sail today for Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg, carrying among her 525 passengers Dr. L.R. Thompson, Assistant Surgeon General of the United States; Owen B. Hunt, Insurance Commissioner of Pennsylvania; Hugh R. Wilson, American Minister to Switzerland; Robert P. Skinner, former United States Ambassador to Turkey, with Mrs. Skinner, and Federal Judge John C. Knox, with Mrs. Knox.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Allotments totaling $11,981,964 were announced by the War Department today for flood control projects in the North Atlantic, South Atlantic and Ohio River divisions, under the Emergency Appropriation Act passed this year.

BOSTON, Aug. 25. -- The Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 "constitutes the gravest threat to the liberties of the American citizen that has emanated from the halls of Congress in my lifetime," said John W. Davis today in an address before the section on Public Utility Law of the American Bar Association, which is holding its annual convention here.

Mrs. Charles Moller gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Robert A. Sands, who returned from Europe recently. The other guests were Mrs. George B. Salisbury, Mrs. Charles W. Hubbard and Mrs. Henry W. Slocum.

The man-of-war ensign of Japan floated above the waters of the Hudson yesterday for the first time since 1929 as two historic ships of the Japanese Navy, the old armored cruisers Iwate and Yakumo steamed into port for an eight-day visit.
Two new freight services to the East were announced yesterday by American lines, making a total of four such services that have been projected in the last month by lines operating from New York.

SEATTLE, Aug. 25. -- The management of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, a Hearst morning newspaper which has suspended publication since Aug. 13 because of a strike of editorial workers called by the American Newspaper Guild, based its case today upon an appeal to public opinion to demand action by the public authorities which would permit it to reopen its plant and resume publication.

Philip Barry has been prowling that dangerous road the College Highway and last evening at the Empire he distributed his notes on the same. Call the collection "Spring Dance," and say at once that much of it is swell, bearing the same imprint as "Holiday" and tossing off dialogue that cannot be beaten in the land.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 25. -- Two Loyalist airplanes today flew over the southwest seacoast city of Cadiz at a height beyond the range of Rebel anti-aircraft guns, killing ten civilians -- four adults and six children -- General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, the insurgent commander here, declared tonight.

Dr. Clyde Fisher, chief of the astronomical department of the American Museum of Natural History and director of the Hayden Planetarium, returned on the Swedish-American liner Drottningholm yesterday after passing most of the Summer in Europe.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 25. -Felix Weingartner's resignation as artistic director of the Vienna State Opera was made at the request of the Austrian Ministry of Education. Although more than 70 years old, he had assumed the post last year with a five-year contract.

The semi-annual report of the Warren Foundry and Pipe Corporation and subsidiaries showed a net income of $147,267 after depreciation, depletion and Federal taxes. The income was equivalent to 84 cents a share on 174,000 no-par shares of capital stock, excluding 25,600 held in the treasury.

Stock prices closed irregular yesterday after displaying mild advancing tendencies early in the day. The expectation of very favorable midweek trade reports today, notably in the case of steel, probably did more to head off selling of any importance than to induce new buying.

Business failures declined in the manufacturing, wholesale and retail groups in the week ended Aug. 20 in comparison with those in the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

There was a time when the execution of sixteen men for plotting against the life of a Chief of State would have produced a shattering effect on world opinion. Six men and women paid with their lives for slaying Czar ALEXANDER II in 1881. In this anti-Stalin conspiracy which began with the assassination of his lieutenant, KIROFF, two years ago, it is estimated that between 100 and 200 lives have already paid the forfeit.

ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 25. -- Calling upon the American Legion to support "peace at any price, except submitting to aggression," Harry H. Woodring, Acting Secretary of War, declared today that armed forces of the nation, "low in efficiency and morale when the present administration took charge of the government three years ago," were now in better condition than they had ever been in peace time.

MADRID, Aug. 23 (From a Resident, by Courier to France). -- German Lufthansa planes must leave now from Alcala de Henares instead of Barajas, the commercial airport, which the Germans can no longer use because planes for the Madrid government from France are delivered there.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 25. -- State Senator Pliny W. Williamson, in a letter today to certificate holders of defunct Westchester mortgage concerns, charges his fellow-trustees, Orie R. Kelly, New York banker, and Anthony J. Kerin, accountant, with "a direct evasion of duty" in placing upon certificate holders the responsibility for checking the request of $112,150 counsel fees by James T. Heenehan, attorney for the Westchester mortgage trustees.

" The United States is the last civilized nation to accept social security plans as inevitable," Owen B. Hunt, Insurance Commissioner of Pennsylvania, said yesterday at the opening of the twenty-third annual National Fraternal Congress of America, founded fifty years ago in Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25. -- Harold Morton of Providence, R.I., New England's representative in the American Chess Federation's championship, put up stout resistance to Israel Horowitz of New York, leader in the field of twelve, and succeeded in forcing a draw in the fifth round at the Hotel Philadelphian tonight.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 25. -- Governor Hoffman had before him today the request of the State League of Municipalities that a special session of the Legislature be called to adopt a long-range emergency relief financing program and revise the entire taxing system.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Aug. 25. -Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Earle, who arrived by airplane yesterday, will be guests here of her cousin, Mrs. E.B. Simonin of Philadelphia, and Mr. Simonin at Camp Arokortu.

QUEBEC, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press) -- The friendship of the United States and Canada lies in the "mutual respect which the people of each nation have for the traditions of the other," Louis H. Pink told delegates to the nineteenth annual conference of the Association of Superintendents of Insurance of Canada tonight.

Colored light in medical treatment was discussed at a meeting of the American Academy of Optometrists at Chicago. Violet light relieves headache. Red light increases blood pressure. Green light is helpful in digestive ailments.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 25. -Three of the teams preparing for the open championship engaged in a round robin today on Phipps Field. The pace was fast despite the intense heat and a field that was feeling the lack of rain.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 25. -- A comprehensive schedule of projects to cost $15,363,373 and employ 9,000 persons in Newark for a year was made public today by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein and William H.J. Ely, State Administrator of the Works Progress Administration.

A youthful inventor who had toiled for months to perfect a miniature double-wing rocket plane was seriously injured early last night when he sought to demonstrate the finished product to an interested group of friends who had gathered for the long-awaited test flight.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 (AP). -- A threat by the judge to "throw" rival lawyers "out of the court bodily" when one cried "liar," ended today a hearing in which Dr. Francis E. Townsend described the financial operations of his Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 25. -Over 3,500 of the nation's major leading rifle and pistol experts, including many champions, reported today and started preparations for the championship matches which open next Monday. The small arms firing school under Colonel Charles L. Bonesteel opened today with the largest attendance in the history of Camp Perry.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25. -- The Cardinals were blasted a game and a half out of the National League lead today, losing to the Boston Bees in both ends of a doubleheader, 20 to 3 and 5 to 4.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

A moderately improved trend prevailed on the commodity futures markets here yesterday, with trading quiet except in hides, coffee and cocoa. On the cash markets cocoa reached a new high level and cotton, corn, rye and rubber advanced.

A mother's example of thrift was rudely upset in Brooklyn yesterday in a swift spendthrift gesture by her 2-year-old son. The gesture created an hour of anxiety for the mother and a vexing problem for the police and led to an eventual solution by a police emergency squad.
BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, President of the Reichsbank and Economics Minister, left Berlin for Paris today. Domestic and foreign anxieties undoubtedly caused the visit.

Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. will offer today an issue of $1,536,000 city of Providence, R.I., 3 per cent WPA school loan bonds. Offering will be made at prices to yield 1.90 to 2.40 per cent. The bonds will mature in various amounts from Jan. 1, 1946 to 1947, from 1949 to 1955, and from 1958 to 1965.

Regarding Aurelio Pego's recent letter on the Spanish situation, which evidently refers to my own previously published letter on the same subject, I wish to say that he has misquoted me and misrepresented my views.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 25. -- Two Japanese were killed and another was injured in Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province, yesterday afternoon when a Chinese mob attacked a group of four Japanese visitors at their hotel. The fourth member of the party is missing.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 25. -Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., defending champion and co-medalist, today led a parade of the favorites through the first round of the women's Western closed golf championship.

Harry Balsamo, 158 1/4, of Harlem, knockout sensation, added another victim to his string last night when he stopped Lou Halper, 147 1/2, of Newark in the fourth round of the scheduled 10-round main bout at the new Queensboro arena.
PARIS, Aug. 25. -- French parliamentarians tonight cast about for ways and means to meet the challenge of the expanded war machine of Nazi Germany.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 25. -- Cleveland roared its welcome today to Jesse Owens, returning home from his Olympic triumphs.

Linking the eleven principal coat and suit markets of the country by 16,900 miles of telephone wire, the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board yesterday held a "transcontinental convention" symbolizing the welding of the industry into a single unit through a "voluntary little NRA," designed to uphold fair trade practices and labor standards.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The Athletics took a wild contest from the White Sox in the opener of a three-game series today, 13 to 11. Dusty Rhodes, starring as a relief pitcher, won the game in the seventh inning with a single that scored Frankie Hayes and Al Niemiec with the deciding runs.

August Heckscher, philanthropist and head of the Heckscher Foundation, will be 88 years old today. Abandoning his annual custom of being at the children's birthday party in his honor at Camp Heckscher, which he founded, near Peekskill, N.Y., he and Mrs. Heckscher will entertain about fifty close friends at a birthday luncheon party today in the penthouse at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue, where he has his offices.
One person was overcome by the heat yesterday before the mercury climbed to the high mark of the day, 90 degrees. The record high for the date was 93, in 1893.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Prices of hogs declined 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight here today except on packing sows, which were steady compared to yesterday. Demand was slow, although receipts yesterday and today were only 19,000 head, the smallest number on record for this season of the year.

A fine point in the laws governing race-horse betting, which Magistrate Henry H. Curran predicted would have to be settled eventually in the Court of Appeals, was raised yesterday in the West Side Court when an alleged bookmaker was dismissed after testifying that he was merely an agent, accepting on commission bets that were to be placed legally at the race tracks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 (AP). -Townsend-approved candidates held leads over their opponents in eight districts, but were tailing in five tonight in incomplete returns from today's primary.

Continuing the trend noted in the previous four months, industrial production improved during July, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board. Orders for machine tools in July, the board reported yesterday, were 16.5 per cent above those in June, compared with a usual seasonal decline of about 8.5 per cent.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 25. -The sixth and penultimate presentation of operettas for the current season here tonight on the water stage on Zach's Bay was a revival of Noel Coward's "Bitter Sweet." The operetta, as well as the previous ones, has been presented by Fortune Gallo in conjunction with the Shubert productions.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 25. -The Black Rock Yacht Club started the defense of its Atlantic Class yacht racing championship in impressive fashion today when its representative, Margot, led eight other boats across the finish line in the first race of a series of three.
