A group of reporters spent yesterday morning tracking down the names of two girls who had baffled detectives by simply refusing to talk. Their identities finally were learned.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 25. -- By a margin of more than two to one, Senator Pat Harrison swept aside all opposition in the primary today to win the Democratic nomination to succeed himself and begin his fourth term in the United States Senate.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 25. -An indication that the Hungarian Government might soon raise the problem of Hungary's rearmament and the introduction of compulsory military service was seen today in an article in the semi-official Esti Ujsaj. After pointing to Germany's two-year service decision as a consequence of an ever-growing Soviet menace, the paper continued:
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 25. -The resolutions calling for the re-election of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman, adopted by the State Federation of Labor today, were as follows:

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25. -- A sunburned mining man named "Lucky" Blackiet told the police here today that three weeks ago he talked with a wanderer in the mountain and desert country behind San Diego, Calif., who professed to be Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, who disappeared from New York City Aug. 6, 1930.

Aggressive and intelligent merchandising and selling to recapture that part of their market which has been lost to other industries were urged upon members of the American National Retail Jewelers Association by speakers at the groups' annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

A new low mark for the movement was reached early yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here when October touched 11.39 cents a pound, but the market developed resistance below 11 1/2 cents and a recovery left the list with net gains of 6 to 9 points.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation reported yesterday for the year ended on July 31 a consolidated net income of $10,960,990 after all deductions, which was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 6 cents each on 33,673,325 no-par common shares.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Hailing a continued upward trend in business activity and in consequent Federal tax collections, President Roosevelt predicted today that a recheck of receipts and expenditures, to be made in the next ten days, would show the fiscal position of the government to be much better than was expected at the beginning of the year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The Bethlehem Steel Corporation filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering $55,000,000 of 3 3/4 per cent bonds, of which only $14,682,800 was specifically set aside for refunding and the remainder, or approximately $40,000,000, earmarked for future acquisitions, betterments and improvements and other corporate purposes.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 25. -- Newark and Albany divided two abbreviated games tonight. The opener, a seven-inning twilight duel, went to Newark, 6 to 5, when Bill Baker's single climaxed a two-run winning rally in the seventh after Shanty Hogan's homer had scored three runs and put the visitors ahead in the first half of the last inning.

MADRID, Aug. 25 (passed by the censor). -- A special court, consisting of three High Court judges and fourteen members of various workers' institutions, has been formed in Madrid to try all cases of rebellion and sedition. Accused persons are dealt with summarily. The fourteen workers' representatives act as a jury.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25. -- History repeated itself today in the Grand American trapshoot as Mrs. Lela Hall of Strasburg, Mo., and Joe Hiestand, the Hillsboro (Ohio) farmer boy, retained the North American clay target championships which each won a year ago -but the story belongs to Mrs. Hall.

The most prevailing defect among intelligent laymen is inability to grasp economic reasoning. We constantly hear people refer to our ten or twelve million unemployed people as if they constituted the greatest problem of government, and our government gravely seeks to provide special remedies which do not remedy.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Carl J. Vosburg, manager of the Great Lakes Symphony Orchestra, announced tonight the unconditional release of Jose Iturbi, Spanish conductor and pianist, as guest conductor of the orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- President Roosevelt today allocated $1,500,000 to finance a compilation of occupational statistics about the 2,400,000 men carried on the rolls of the Works Progress Administration.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Aug. 25 (AP). -- State penitentiary guards killed W.E. McDaniel, Atlanta robber, and wounded fifteen convicts today in subduing a five-hour riot led by T.B. Burrus, a former inmate of the Federal prison at Alcatraz Island, brought here as an escaped convict.

With virtually every Republican leader of consequence identified with the State or national campaign in New York having gone to the Western counties where Governor Landon of Kansas, Republican Presidential nominee is campaigning, word came back to the headquarters here that the favorable impression created by the candidate had tended to confirm the conviction of the leaders that he would make a good showing in this State.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 26. -The Chengtu affair is "a very unhappy incident that is likely to have serious results," Eiji Amau, spokesman for the Foreign Office, said today. He declared that before acting the Foreign Office was awaiting reports from a consular inquiry party, including a doctor, sent from Chunking.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 25. -- A serious strike in the whaling industry broke out today, with 10,000 Norwegian whalers refusing to man a fleet of British vessels on which they are employed as crews.

ALBANY, Aug. 25. -- Governor Lehman's hearings of the grand jury's charges demanding the removal of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn will open here at 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon. The Governor has called a conference at 11 o'clock in the morning between counsel for Mr. Geoghan and Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today called for bids on fifty-five issues of securities of municipalities, counties and school districts in twenty-seven States and the Territory of Puerto Rico, aggregating $5,007,250, to be opened on Sept. 10, at the corporation's offices here.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Leading a field of 102 players, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg of Fresh Meadow today added another Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament to her long list of golfing victories.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- A.A. Baroni again won the feature today when he sent out his Man o'War filly, Ann O'Ruley, to fight her way home first in the Amsterdam Claiming Stakes, a mile and a furlong test that goes back for thirty-four years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Factory employment and payrolls in July reached the highest level recorded since October, 1930, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

The Hitler decree lengthening the term of compulsory military service from one to two years, thus raising the standing army to a strength estimated at 800,000, rounds out the decree of March 16, 1935, whereby Germany broke loose from the restrictions of the Versailles treaty and began rearmament on the grand scale.

A strike of 12,000 members of the Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers' Union was called yesterday for 8 o'clock tomorrow morning. The union forecast a "complete tie-up of building construction and alteration."

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25. -- There are times when nothing can restrain the Dodgers. Today not even rain, a high wind and darkness that halted proceedings twice for a total of fifty-five minutes, and a third time permanently at the end of eight innings, could prevent them from opening a Western trip for the first time this season with a victory.

The edition of Shakespeare's works that Professor George Lyman Kittredge began to plan thirty years ago will be published next month by Ginn Co., in one volume entitled "Complete Works of Shakespeare." Professor Kittredge retired last Spring after fifty years of teaching at Harvard University.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- The upward movement on the Boerse continued today at an accelerated pace and with an increased turnover. Heavy industrials other than "war industry" values profited most as a result of the new military expansion program, but the firmness spread to the entire list under the influence of the visit to Paris of Hjalmar Schacht, head of the Reichsbank, which trip is expected to include a discussion of possible devaluation.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP). -A four-State police search for Virgil F. Effinger began tonight on the heels of his disappearance from an extradition hearing.

With production of cotton goods this year expected to reach a level which has been exceeded only three times in the industry's history, a return of "relative prosperity" to the field has set in, Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, declared yesterday in a survey of market results for the first half of the year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- President Roosevelt's last day at the capital before starting his tour of the drought region was marked by a restatement of some of the work, in addition to direct relief, that is being done to aid farmers to rehabilitate themselves.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 25. -- A story that a WPA foreman heads a fraudulent gambling ring on Long Island that employs Federal workers and obtains booths at important fairs and carnivals was being investigated today by Suffolk County officials.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 25. -- Federal Referee Robert E. Steedle abruptly adjourned the William Fox bankruptcy proceedings here this afternoon with a warning to Mrs. Eva Fox, wife of the former film producer, who was on the witness stand as president of the All-Continent Corporation.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 25. -- The press of this country almost unanimously repudiates the German arguments in defense of the introduction of the two-year military service period. It describes the raising of the Bolshevist bogy by Germany as skillful manoeuvring.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Aug. 25. -- While young men in large numbers were flocking to General Owen O'Duffy's headquarters here today and signing up to join his proposed Irish volunteer brigade for service with General Francisco Franco's Rebel army in Spain, President Eamon de Valera and his Cabinet were deliberating upon the Free State's attitude toward the Spanish crisis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- President Roosevelt today named William C. Bullitt, Ambassador to Russia, to be Ambassador to France to succeed Jesse Isidor Straus, and announced acceptance with "deep regret'' of the resignation of Mr. Straus, who pleaded that acute illness would require an extended period of rest.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 25. -- Unanimous endorsement of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman for re-election was voted by the convention of the State Federation of Labor at its opening session here today.

The United Air Lines Transport Corporation plans to raise between $3,000,000 and $4,000,000 by the sale of stock to its stockholders, it was announced in a letter signed by W.A. Patterson, president, and made public yesterday. About 50,000 shares will be offered to officers and employes at a price not less than that charged stockholders.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Aug. 25. -- Burlington County's WPA strike took an exciting and unexpected turn today when strikers trying to persuade WPA workers to abandon a road repair project were chased off with shovels and picks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP). -- After a weak start Buck Newsom settled down today to hold the Indians to six hits and give the Senators the first game of the series, 5 to 3.
Two more white marlin were caught by Beach Haven anglers over the past week-end, proof that the jumping jacks are still roaming the Jersey coastal waters.

SEATTLE, Aug. 25. -- With its tenth issue today, The Guild Daily, published by the striking editorial employes of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, became more of a newspaper and less of a propaganda organ. But it is still limited to four pages of eight columns each, ordinary newspaper size.

In commenting on William E. Taylor's letter my two contentions were that his criticisms of the Republican platform and the acceptance speech of Governor Landon were not specific, and that in neither the speech nor the platform had the issues of the depression and unemployment been ignored.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP). -The constitutionality of the 1933 "Truth in Securities" Act was challenged today in the Supreme Court for the second time by J. Edward Jones of New York, an operator in oil royalties.

A real, old-fashioned Yankee slugfest was on view at the Stadium yesterday. The McCarthymen started swinging early and never stopped, so that it wasn't very long before they were in complete command and the invading Browns submitted meekly to a 13-1 drubbing.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 25. -- Blunders figured in two of the important matches of the international chess masters' tournament, the thirteenth round of which was contested at University College today. One of these oversights, in the ending of an otherwise well-contested game, caused the downfall of Dr. Max Euwe of The Netherlands, world champion, in his encounter with Dr. Emanuel Lasker of London, one of the three ex-champions competing.

Although 12-year-old Eleanor Herman won a gold medal yesterday afternoon for a typically feminine quality -- taste in decoration -she should have had another award for her courage and intrepidity. For Eleanor, who denied with a crippled, emphatic "no" that she was a tomboy, stood alone in representing her sex against eighty-nine boys in the West Side "skipmobile" races held by the Boys Athletic League on Fifty-first Street between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues.

Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, will announce plans today for marketing a new issue of State of New York long-term bonds, the first such financing by the State since last September. It is expected to consist of $55,000,000 of unemployment relief bonds, due serially from one to ten years.

Assistant Attorney General Alfred W. Jones, who for twenty years has been managing clerk in the local offices of the State Law Department, accepted service "on behalf of the people of the State of New York" yesterday of his 500,000th legal paper.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- The constitutionality of the Commodity Exchange Act was upheld today by Federal Judge John P. Barnes in denying an injunction to restrain enforcement of the law. He dismissed the bill of complaint filed on Aug. 15 by William S. Moore on behalf of himself and other members of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

" Definitely," Ruth Chatterton answers by wire from Beverly Hills, when asked if she will return to the stage in "Louise of Coburg," a play bought for her by Auriol Lee, written by Felix Salten, Viennese dramatist-novelist, and translated by Margaret Webster, English actress and daughter of Dame May Whitty.

I wish to compliment William E. Taylor on his letter to THE TIMES, particularly on his belief that the Republican party has underestimated the fundamental importance of determined action against the ravages of depression and unemployment, when it advocates in its platform "the return of responsibility for relief administration to non-political local agencies familiar with community problems."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission permitted today a committee representing twelve life insurance companies, holding $72,287,500 of bonds of the Chicago North Western Railway Company, to intervene in reorganization proceedings involving the railroad now pending in the Federal District Court of the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division.

A budgetary appropriation of $6,320,392 for 1937, an increase of $1,313,227 over the amount allotted this year, was asked yesterday of Budget Director Leo J. McDermott by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens.

Strength in the market for United States Government bonds yesterday lifted twenty of twenty-four issues to new high marks for all time, with gains 1-32 to 7-32 point. Trading in Federal issues was active, amounting to $904,000, compared with $434,000 on Monday.

The motion-picture industry opened a campaign yesterday to protest the wholesale invasion of their field by radio broadcasting companies, according to Jack Cohn, vice president of Columbia Pictures Corporation, 729 Seventh Avenue.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- The Jewish Review, organ of the Zionist Jews in Germany, makes a considerable display of an article in which it asserts the Zinovieff case in Moscow is the best indication of the minor and subjugated role that Jews play in present-day bolshevism.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Fairly general buying of corn futures developed today on the board of Trade after an early decline and disclosed a lack of pressure on the September. The latter rallied and closed around the top with a net gain of 1 3/4 cents a bushel, and at a 2 1/8cent premium over the same delivery of wheat.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 25. -- The Italian cruiser Gorizia was towed stern-first into Gibraltar harbor at noon today by British naval tugs after an internal explosion off Tangier that cut a gaping hole from side to side of her about ten feet behind her bow. The hole was so large that it was easy to see light through it, and it extended upward almost to the deck, downward to below the waterline.

President Roosevelt was hailed last night by Herbert S. Houston, life-long Republican, for exercising courage and decision in bringing the nation out of the throes of the depression. He spoke over the Columbia Broadcasting Company facilities under the auspices of the Good Neighbor League, which is backing the President.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Derbyshire appears likely to win the English county cricket championship for the first time in sixty-two years. Leading teams in the race have only two matches to play before the season closes and only complete collapse of the Midlanders and two victories for Yorkshire, runner-up in the standing, can deprive Derbyshire from winning the honor for the second time in the county's history.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Plagued by light airs that caused one race to be cut in half, Emil Mosbacher Jr., Knickerbocker Yacht Club defender, and his crew of Jimmy Horton and Eddie Leahy, won twice today in the Long Island Sound midget championship series to assume a 6 1/2 point lead.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Two sensational rounds by Frank Strafaci, 20-year-old public links player; a record-breaking round by Ray Billows, former New York State amateur champion, and the failure of Harry L. Givan, Walker Cup nominee from Seattle, to gain a place were the three outstanding features of the metropolitan district qualifying test for the United States amateur golf championship at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The center of gravity of the situation in Spain now shifts from Madrid to Barcelona. While the public still studies the news of the civil war the European governments already believe the fate of the extremist regime is sealed.

As election day draws near, brokers in Wall Street are more freely disposed to ascribe the movements of the stock market to fluctuations in the political fortunes of the rival Presidential candidates. Actually, however, an increasing number of members of the financial community is showing indifference concerning the outcome of the election.

PARIS, Aug. 25. -- The German Government's extension of the military service term to two years has naturally provoked much comment in France, but it is obvious that nothing will or can be done about it.

With no deaths from measles, whooping cough, typhoid fever, scarlet fever or meningitis reported in the week ending last Saturday, Health Commissioner John L. Rice said yesterday the record for the week showed the city was "in many ways exceptionally healthful."

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 25 (AP). -- A major Rebel offensive on the northern front in Spain was believed imminent tonight as insurgent reenforcements steadily moved up on Irun and San Sebastian. From air and sea the Rebels kept up their incessant bombardments of the cities.

It seems rather a delicate task, hard to dissociate from political intention, for a Federal judge to compare unfavorably appointments to the Federal bench made by Mr. ROOSEVELT with those of some of his predecessors. But anything that tends to reassert the independence of the judiciary, now in grave danger according to some prophets of the American Bar Association, is to be gratefully accepted.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 25. -- The Monmouth County Country Club poloists scored an upset in the second game of the J. Ernest Stern Cups tournament at the Norwood Country Club today when they eliminated the Evergreen Farms squad, heavy favorites to win the tourney, 5 to 4.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 25. -Jewish German nationals returning to Germany from Spain on official refugee transports are not receiving the treatment that was promised to them when they were picked up at Barcelona, Madrid and other points in the Spanish danger zone.

Frederick Samuel Fish, industrialist and former head of the Studebaker Corporation, who died at South Bend, Ind., on Aug. 13 last, left his estate in trust to his widow, Mrs. Grace Studebaker Fish of 640 Park Avenue. This was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.
BERLIN, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The Peichsbank's statement of Aug. 23 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, largest subsidiary of United States Steel, received today from employe representatives a demand to recognize the John L. Lewis "one big union" industrial organization plan of collective bargaining.

Families receiving from $20 to $40 a week do the bulk of the buying of advertised merchandise, according into a study released yesterday under the title "Buying Begins at $20" by the market research department of Modern Magazines. In that classification there are 11,393,677 families out of a total of 29,904,663, with expenditures of $5,651,000,000 of a total of $17,045,000,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 25. -A new system of treating "bends," suffered particularly by divers and men who are working under high air pressures, was disclosed today by Dr. Louis A. Shaw, Assistant Professor of Physiology at the Harvard School of Public Health, in an address before the symposium on "The Environment and Its Effect on Man."

PARIS, Aug. 25. -- No appreciable movement took place on the Bourse today. All speculation seems to have ceased for the moment and no attention was paid to even such sensational news as the increase in the term of military service in Germany.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 25. -- Details of the massacre of ninety priests, monks and theological students by Spanish Communists reached the Vatican this evening. It was announced that thus far proof had been received of the murder of twenty-two friars and four priests and the imprisoning of scores whose fate is not known.
LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 25. -- The Spanish insurgents claimed a long series of successes today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 25. -An unranked team from the University of Chicago eliminated Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta and J. Gilbert Hall of East Orange from the national doubles tennis championship today on the beautifully. groomed turf of the Longwood Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Coincident with the announcement in Warsaw that the authorities would not prosecute Mrs. Dorothy Atkinson of Minneapolis, Minn., for failing through an oversight to declare all her traveling funds to customs officials at the Polish border, a second case of the same type came to light today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 26. -- An added danger to workmen in the toxic fumes given off in chromium plating, an industry introduced in 1927, was revealed today by Dr. Lawrence T. Fairhall, Assistant Professor of Physiology at Harvard, in an address before the health symposium at the Harvard School of Public Health.

The directors of Fairbanks, Morse Co. voted yesterday to pay an extra dividend of 25 cents a share in addition to a quarterly of 25 cents on the common stock. The quarterly payment places the stock on a yearly rate of $1, plus extras as earned and declared. These are the first dividends on this issue since the 40-cent disbursement on June 30, 1931.

The New York County grand jury yesterday completed its inquiry into the motive and source of the telephone call last July 29 which took Justice Alfred J. Hofmann from the Special Sessions bench to Mayor La Guardia's office in the Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park, only to learn that the Mayor had not sent for him.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- For nearly five hours this afternoon Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister and President of the Reichsbank, conferred with Premier Leon Blum and his principal Cabinet collaborators in a meeting that has stirred many hopes and even more curiosity.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 26. -- For a few brief moments today the Reds threatened harm to that amazing winning streak of the Giants and the glory of the redoubtable Carl Hubbell. But in the end the spell of the master asserted itself and the New York steamroller flattened the Rhinelanders again for the Giants' fourteenth straight victory as they strengthened their grip on first place.

Local commodity futures markets were generally higher yesterday. Trading was quiet and changes either way were small for the most part. In the cash market, wheat, cocoa, butter, eggs, tin, rubber and hides were higher, while corn, rye, cotton and lard were lower.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The State Board of Tax Appeals sustained the Essex County Tax Board today in dismissing a petition by the Public Service Corporation for a reduction of Newark's 1935 assessment of $11,135,600 on personal property to $1,717,721.28.

WE are undoubtedly in the midst of a great period of conversion. Books of autobiography are always good trend-pointers and our autobiographers are becoming more and more like Sunday School teachers with every publication day. Few of them are content to tell. They all want to teach. And they all want to teach the same thing.

GENEVA, Aug. 26. -- President Roosevelt's reported peace suggestion met a puzzled and cautious reception in League of Nations quarters today only partly because of the meager information regarding it that was available here.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, Aug. 26. -- The two most promising junior players in the metropolitan district met in the final of the first junior girls' tennis tournament for the new Aunita R. Lucas Trophy on the grass courts of the Ardsley Club today and Miss Helen Bernhard of New York City was the victor, upsetting top-seeded Patricia Cumming of Westfield, N.J., 4 -- 6, 13 -- 11, 6 -- 1.

Pedestrians, pushcart peddlers and women and children who had been basking in the afternoon sun scrambled for cover near Cook and Morrell Streets in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn just before 3 P.M. yesterday as two men sprayed the streets with bullets.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Social activity here has gained momentum as visitors arrive for the final races of the season.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The State's round-up of twenty-two Black Legion members accused of criminal syndicalism neared completion today with the surrender of Arthur F. Lupp Sr., described by the prosecution as the State commander, and two fellow-defendants.

Last Winter, having been advised by many counselors of the peculiar qualifications of Governor Landon to oppose the President for re-election -- geographical and personal William Randolph Hearst headed a Pullman car caravan to Topeka and had a talk with the Governor of Kansas.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Extracts from THE NEW YORK TIMES article concerning the possibility of President Roosevelt proposing a peace conference next year were cabled to British newspapers today, but it is too soon for any reaction to manifest itself at Whitehall.

Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Dodd, in Brooklyn, yesterday reserved decision on an application for a writ of peremptory mandamus to restrain the Board of Elections and the members of the New York City Charter Revision Commission from presenting the proposed new city charter to the voters on election day.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Governor Lehman made today the following statement at the opening of the hearing involving charges against William F.X. Geoghan, District Attorney of Kings County:
Earl Beatty, 31-year-old son of the late Admiral Earl Beatty, sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after a visit of several weeks here.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- Germany's 1,000-mark penalty for a visit by a German to Austria was removed today by the terms of the new commercial and travel agreement between the German and Austrian Governments.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- Discussion before the American Bar Association today of the preliminary draft of the proposed rules for civil procedure in the Federal courts was opened by William D. Mitchell, former Attorney General, chairman of the advisory committee appointed by the United States Supreme Court to assist in preparing it.
BUFFALO, Aug. 26. -- The text of Governor Landon's speech here tonight, on the object of "Taxation," was follows:
Various leases in the midtown and uptown sections of the east side were included in the apartment rentals reported yesterday, as follows:

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Aug. 27. -- While reports here last night indicated the possibility that no Japanese had been killed Monday in Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province, when a Chinese mob attacked four Japanese visitors in a hotel, the assault by yesterday had assumed the proportions of a grave new Chino-Japanese issue.

Continuing their advance of the previous day, United States Government bonds moved higher in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, eleven issues reaching new high prices since their dates of issue. Closing quotations were somewhat lower than the best for the day and were interspersed with net declines.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 26. -- Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., today led the field into the quarter-finals of the women's western closed golf championship in defense of the title she won last year at Cleveland.
TOKYO, Aug. 26. -- The Japanese Foreign Office considers that Europe is rapidly being split into Fascist and Communist camps, and is determined to steer clear of the coming "age of confusion."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Battering Dennis Galehouse from the mound with an opening-inning attack, the Senators beat the second-place Indians for the second successive time today, 14 to 1.

SEATTLE, Aug. 26. -- Fifty Pacific Northwest newspaper publishers "reviewed the situation" here today, the fourteenth day of the Post-Intelligencer-Newspaper Guild strike, against a background of meetings by the Law and Order League and by Guild supporters.

Messages of international amity and good-will were broadcast to Japan and the United States last night by Admiral William H. Standley, chief of naval operations and Acting Secretary of the Navy; Vice Admiral Zengo Yoshida, commanding His Imperial Japanese Majesty's Training Squadron now anchored in the Hudson, and by Rear Admiral Harris Laning, commandant of the Third Naval District.

The Wolkofsky-Abramson wrangle over a brown-and-white mongrel puppy, which had caused numerous headaches in the Madison-Henry Street section, was settled in two and a half minutes in Small Claims Court yesterday.

EAST PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 26. -- A new contract with the Dyers and Finishers Union was signed this morning by executives of the National Dyeing and Printing Company of this borough, granting the union forces a major victory. The National is the largest single dyeing unit to accept the union terms.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Lou Ambers, the Herkimer Hurricane, is confident that he will lift the lightweight crown from the brow of Tony Canzoneri when they meet in their title fight at Madison Square Garden a week from tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Despite the current drought, a Federal survey indicates that the country's food supply for the twelve months ending June, 1937, will be only 3 per cent below that of 1935-36 and 1 per cent less than in 1934-35. This was stated today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in a special report based on an analysis of weather conditions, especially in the drought States.

The necessity of adding 1,132 patrolmen to the Police Department personnel to provide adequately for public safety was stressed yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine at a hearing before Leo J. McDermott, Budget Director.

QUEBEC, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Maurice Duplessis, who led the allied Conservative and insurgent Liberal forces in defeating the Liberal Regime of Quebec in last week's general election, announced his Cabinet as follows today:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26. -- Near tragedy marred the Dodgers' decisive 10-3 victory over the Pirates today when Eddie Wilson, sensational young Brooklyn outfielder, suffered a fractured skull when struck by a pitched ball.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The Pittsburgh Stock Exchange has made application to the Securities and Exchange Commission, under an amendment to the Securities Exchange Act which became effective today, for permission to carry on unlisted trading in twenty-five bonds and stocks which the issuers have not registered on that Exchange but which are fully registered on another Exchange.

Mae Scheible, convicted of white slavery last April, won yesterday her plea for return of $10,000 bail forfeited just before her arrest in San Francisco for leaving the New York jurisdiction. Judge Martin T. Manton of the Federal Court of Appeals ruled, however, that she must stay in jail until the appeal of her case is decided.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Long home runs by Ernie Key and Johnny McCarthy featured the Bears' 8-to-5 triumph over Albany today.

BUFFALO, Aug. 26. -- Governor Landon tonight arraigned the Roosevelt administration for extravagance and for piling up a huge debt which either will have to be paid by the mass of the people with moderate and small incomes, or be passed on to their children as a staggering burden which will close the door of opportunity to the youth of America.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- Sharply criticizing many aspects of the Hauptmann murder trial last year, and deploring the subsequent conduct of Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, a special committee of the criminal law section of the American Bar Association precipitated a storm at the annual convention of the association here today.

The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company has decided to accept advertising allowances from food manufacturers again and is offering contracts containing provisions for both allowances and discounts, it was learned here yesterday.

Each year sees an increasing number of fresh-water anglers of the metropolitan area turning to the ocean for sport. They are not exactly forsaking the lakes and streams permanently, but taking advantage of the opportunity to get some action while the Summer run of salt-water species is under way.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Strict rules to control speculation by its 1,100 employes have been completed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, one of the provisions being that the commission regards as prima facie not for investment purposes any purchase of a security which an employe fails to hold for one year from the date of purchase.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26. -- The Boston Bees sank their stingers deep into the Cardinals again today, winning 10 to 4.

SEATTLE, Aug. 26. -- Public opinion on the strike of the American Newspaper Guild against William Randolph Hearst's morning newspaper, The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, is dividing more or less along economic and social lines.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 26. -- Edward Stetser, 20-year-old member of the Atlantic City Beach Patrol, won the title of champion lifeguard of the United States in the national lifeguard tournament here today.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 26. -- The Rebel seaport of Cadiz was bombed by Madrid planes again today. Six persons were killed and twenty wounded, General Queipo de Llano announced here tonight. He added that such activities had made it necessary for him to order that five Leftist prisoners be killed henceforth for every one hurt in these raids.

Sensational handling of his car earned Ronney Householder of Los Angeles a thrilling victory in the thirty-lap Major George Robertson Sweepstakes on the card of midget auto races last night at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City before a crowd of 16,500 persons.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Joseph Stalin, The Evening News said today, in a speech broadcast to every barracks and parade ground in Russia, declared that "war is imminent.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were generally firm today, with further improvement in British Government securities. The industrial list showed a number of bright spots, notably Woolworth, which jumped to a new high record of 150s 6d on prospects of a bonus.

The compensation of officers of Pacific American Fisheries, Inc., the Loose-Wiles Biscuit Company and the Thompson-Starrett Company, Inc., was disclosed yesterday in annual reports of these companies to the Securities and Exchange Commission, filed with the New York Stock Exchange.

ALBANY, Aug. 26. -- District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan began today an aggressive and emphatic defense in removal proceedings before Governor Lehman by blaming Police Commissioner Valentine for whatever failure there was in the prosecution of the Sam Drukman murder case.

Sears, Roebuck Co. reported yesterday for the twenty-four weeks ended on July 16 a net profit of $12,634,285 after depreciation, interest, estimated contribution to employes' savings and profit-sharing fund, and estimated normal Federal income taxes, but before provision for surtax on undistributed earnings.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follow (quotations are in cents):

The governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday the original applications of five companies for listing of their securities and the application of a sixth corporation whose securities were already traded on the Exchange.

Directors of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., approved yesterday a plan of recapitalization by which will be paid the accruals of dividends on the preferred stock, amounting to $28 a share on Feb. 1. Holders of each share of 7 per cent preferred stock of $100 par are to receive one and one-fourth shares of new $6 preferred stock and $6.62 1/2 in cash.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Dollar value of sales on national securities Exchanges amounted to $2,057,844,758 in July, an increase of 42.1 per cent over those in June and 44.7 per cent greater than in July one year ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Hugh R. Wilson of Chicago, United States Minister to Switzerland, sailed on the United States liner Washington yesterday for his post at Berne, having spent the Summer here on leave. He said in reply to a question that the possibility of consideration at Geneva of an arms embargo against warring factions in Spain probably would await the independent action of a member nation.

An additional $1,310,000 gold was engaged in France yesterday for shipment to this country, it was announced at the Federal Reserve Bank, bringing to $38,700,000 the total of gold taken abroad for American account on the current gold-import movement which began Aug. 7.

HONOLULU, Aug. 26. -- Hawaii's Board of Harbor Commissioners said "No" to Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell, one of the world's wealthiest women, yesterday when by a vote of 3 to 2 they rejected a request of her agents that she be permitted to build a private swimming pool on a cove beach.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 26. -- Although she is a vice president and director of the All-Continent Corporation, Miss Belle Fox knows nothing of the affairs of the concern and never attended any of its meetings, she testified here today.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 26. -- A seven-point legislative program for the coming session at Albany was approved today by the convention of the State Federation of Labor after hearing a report of its legislative committee.

EDMONTON, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press). -- The Alberta Supreme Court interim injunction restraining the city of Edmonton from entering into an agreement with the Province to accept Alberta prosperity certificates in lieu of a cash relief grant was upheld by Justice T.M. Tweedie today.

SALZBURG, Aug. 26. -- The Salzburg festival is coming to an end in a blaze of success even beyond anything indicated in its auspicious opening four weeks ago. Last night Dusolina Giannini, American prima donna, repeated her previous triumph as Donna Anna in "Don Giovanni" in the final performance of that work.
Apartment house purchases by operators and investors featured the Bronx realty trading reported yesterday.

A new issue of $1,000,000 City of Rochester, N.Y., public welfare certificates of indebtedness, dated Sept. 1, 1936, and maturing on Feb. 1, 1937, was bought yesterday by Salomon Bros. Hutzler, who paid a premium of $7 for securities bearing an interest rate of 0.31 per cent.

The stock market continues to move warily. The market for many stocks is admittedly thin, so that a little concentrated buying or selling can open up gaps of a point or two with comparative ease. Yesterday's levels of support for various groups of stocks were well under Tuesday's prices, and the closing was generally lower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The Spanish Government was informed in a note from Secretary of State Cordell Hull delivered today to the Foreign Minister by Eric C. Wendelin, Third Secretary in charge of the United States Embassy in Madrid, that the United States would not recognize the validity of the war zone declared around certain Spanish ports unless an effective blockade was maintained.
PIERRE, S.D., Aug. 26. -- A water conservation program which already has produced more than 600 small dams awaits President Roosevelt's inspection when he begins his drought survey in South Dakota.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, announced today that he would offer for sale $55,000,000 emergency relief bonds of the State at his office here on Wednesday, Sept. 9, at 1 o'clock, daylight-saving time. This comprises the entire amount authorized by vote at the election last November and completes all such financing authorized to date.
MADRID, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Expecting the momentary surrender of 1,700 Rebels besieged in the Alcazar at Toledo, the government tonight prepared to rush them here and place them in improvised prisons.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange, at their regular meeting yesterday, discussed but took no action on expanding that market's unlisted department under the privileges granted in the new rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Offering will be made to the public today of 192,000 shares of Westvaco Chlorine Products Corporation $30 par 5 per cent convertible preferred stock at $31 a share by an underwriting group consisting of Hornblower Weeks; Eastman, Dillon Co.; C.B. Ewart Co., Inc., and Lawrence Stern Co., Inc.

A committee for holders of preferred stock of Continental Shares, Inc., an investment trust in Cleveland, made public yesterday a letter to these security holders urging them to withhold their support from a recently announced plan of reorganization for the company.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 17 per cent for the week ended Aug. 22, it was reported yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure compares with a gain of 18 per cent for the previous week, indicating a slightly slower pace of retail trade.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Sir Auckland Geddes, chairman of the Rio Tinto Company, said tonight that the company had received a cable confirming the Seville radio report that the territory surrounding the Rio Tinto mines had been occupied by Spanish anti-government forces.

The pennant-bound Yankees went back to roadside resting at the Stadium yesterday and while no one can exactly blame them for these occasional siestas, the spectacle, it must be conceded, does become a trifle boring.

Samuel Padgett, motorman of a Long Island Railroad train, had only his injuries yesterday to show people that a bird had unceremoniously visited him in his cab shortly after midnight while his train was speeding through the darkness from Brooklyn.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Huey Longs law requiring public utilities to pay the costs of rate investigations was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal court.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 26. -- John H. Curtiss, who as Hunterdon County Sheriff had charge of court room accommodations during the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, said today the trial of the Lindbergh baby slayer was a "circus because the public, and not the officials, made it one."
ROME, Aug. 26. -- The reported suggestion by President Roosevelt for a peace conference of world leaders was commented on favorably in circles close to the government today.

BUFFALO, Aug. 26. -- By adopting a "hands-off" policy on the Republican nomination for Governor of New York, Governor Landon adroitly side-stepped a perilous political situation, which some of the party leaders here saw today as somewhat analogous to that which caused Chief Justice Charles E. Hughes to lose California and the Presidency in the election of 1916.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- In the historic Locarno room of the Foreign Office a new treaty was signed today ending the long and stormy period of Anglo-Egyptian relations and opening what Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, called "a new chapter" in the history of the two countries.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 26. -- Assistant Attorney General Theodore Backes held in an opinion today that a balance of more than $1,500,000 turned over to the State Financial Assistance Commission by the State Relief Council when the latter agency ceased functioning cannot be distributed to the municipalities without legislative sanction.

A sharp advance in early trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here carried prices of the staple more than $1 a bale higher than the lowest levels of this week, but later in the session the market came under hedging pressure, which erased most of the improvement and left quotations at the day's lowest, these being from 2 points higher to 3 points lower than Tuesday.

John Cotes, 19 years old, of 3,475 Knox Place, the Bronx, was sentenced to the workhouse for 150 days for six traffic law violations and held without bail for action of the grand jury for homicide and assault by Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. in Homicide Court yesterday. A charge of leaving the scene of an accident was dismissed.
PARIS, Aug. 26. -- Much regret is felt and expressed here at the retirement of Ambassador Jesse Isidor Straus because of ill health.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Mechanics today were-finishing the installation of new 700-gallon gasoline tanks in a big red and green monoplane, destined, its owners hope, for a non-stop flight from New York to Stockholm.

A plea in abatement was denied yesterday to J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, who for more than a year has figured in court contests over the constitutionality of the acts of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and in consequence must stand trial on a fifteen-count indictment charging use of the mails to defraud and conspiracy.

The first prison sentence was imposed in General Sessions yesterday in the campaign of the new Accident Fraud Bureau against ambulance chasing and fake accident indemnity claims. The bureau, headed by Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney, was created several months ago at the request of the Appellate Division and the Bar Association.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26. -- Radio experts and amateurs alike sought tonight an explanation for a sound wave "calm" that practically silenced all short-wave stations along the Pacific Coast.
PARIS, Aug. 26. -- Unaccustomed activity in operations and considerable firmness in prices marked trading on the Bourse today. Gains were made in several departments.

Governor Henry Horner and Mayor Edward J. Kelly of Chicago spoke to each other and shook hands here yesterday for the first time since their bitter feud in the Spring primary. James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, saw in their action a harmony among the Democrats in Illinois that would insure the State's electoral votes for President Roosevelt.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- In all political circles of France the news published in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning that President Roosevelt is considering the summoning of a conference among the chiefs of State of five great powers if he is re-elected has produced a great impression.

The Royal Yacht Squadron's challenge for the America's Cup will be taken up today by the New York Yacht Club at the West Forty-fourth Street clubhouse. The challenge will be read to the members and then a cup committee will be appointed "with power" to act.

New York City has brought suit against the National Dredging Company, James J. Browne, former Brooklyn Commissioner of Parks, and George F. Davy, who was chief engineer under Mr. Browne, for the repayment of $59,830 alleged to have been paid to the dredging company in excess of the amount due on the contract to fill in the Marine Park marsh lands.

POLAND, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- If six demands outlined here tonight by the directors of the New York Milk Producers Federation, Inc. are not met next week, a milk strike will be called, it was announced here tonight by Stanley and Felix Piseck, heads of the federation, after a private meeting of the thirty-three directors of the federation.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 26. -- Defeating Dr. Milan Vidmar of Yugoslavia in their postponed game from the tenth round, Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world champion, today tied for first place in the international chess masters tournament with Mikhail Botwinnik of Leningrad, whom the Cuban barely outranked in the recent congress at Moscow.

For failing to appear as a private lawyer at preliminary hearings in a civil case, District Attorney Thomas J. Walsh of Richmond, a leading Democrat on Staten Island, was arrested yesterday morning by a deputy of his close personal friend, Sheriff John Timlin, a leading Republican on Staten Island. His arrest cost him $25.

A reception and luncheon marked the joint birthday, celebration yesterday of Mr. and Mrs. August Heckscher in the penthouse adjoining Mr. Heckscher's offices at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue. The philanthropist celebrated his eighty-eighth birthday and his wife her sixty-fourth.

President Roosevelt's allocation of $1,500,000 to the United States Employment Service for an occupational survey of Federal relief rolls seemed likely yesterday to save the jobs of 500 WPA workers assigned to the local offices of the National Re-employment Service and the State Employment Service.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26. -- Charges were made here today that the social and economic department of the State Publishing House had been turned into a "nest of Trotskyists." The State Publishing House was headed by Mikhail Tomsky, who committed suicide Saturday while under investigation as a result of the mention of his name by some of the accused at the Zinovieff-Kameneff trial.

If the mantle of the late Florenz Ziegfeld were looking for a pair of contemporary Broadway shoulders about which to drape, it might -- without any embarrassment -- fold itself around those of Clifford C. Fischer, whose fourth production at the unique French Casino, the "Folies d'Amour," opened Tuesday evening.

As the President traveled westward to inspect the drought areas, he must have been gladdened by the news from the Democratic primaries in Mississippi and South Carolina. By impressive majorities Senator HARRISON, in Mississippi, against a powerful political combination, and Senator BYRNES, in South Carolina, against two Democrats who strongly attacked legislation which he has helped importantly to guide through Congress, were renominated for new terms.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- One of the most interesting trials at the forthcoming sessions at Old Bailey involves Arnold Spencer Leese, proprietor of The Fascist, a newspaper, and Walter Whitehead, printer of the paper, who are on bail on charges of seditious libel in an attack on the Jews.

Jewelers were advised yesterday to divert their attention from silver futures to an intelligent study of the reasons why they are not selling more sterling silverware by G.H. Niemeyer, vice president of Handy Harman, speaking at the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association in its third day at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 26. -- Leon Trotsky, the exiled Russian Bolshevik, signed an agreement tonight pledging himself to refrain from any revolutionary activities. He signed only after an official deputation had told him at his home that immediate arrest would be his only alternative.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 26. -- In the last half minute of play John Hay Whitney scored for his Greentree team today and triumphantly the side concluded its scheduled preparations for the national open polo championship starting Saturday at the Meadow Brook Club.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Despite the rains of last night and early morning, Aurora and Hurricane polo teams found the field of the Piping Rock Club ready for play this afternoon and rode through another test match in preparation for the open which starts Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- An "unfavorable" trade balance for July, as was reported also for June, was shown in foreign trade statistics given out today by the Commerce Department, but at the same time both exports and imports were larger than in July, 1935.

Swerving after it had hit a girl and fatally injured her, an automobile mounted the curb yesterday afternoon in Pacific Street, Brooklyn, and struck a perambulator parked beneath a tree, throwing the occupant, a 3 1/2-year-old girl, to the street.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Aug. 26. -- The members of the American committee of inquiry on cooperative enterprise in Europe appointed by President Roosevelt arrived here from Belfast this evening to make a study of the cooperative movement in the Irish Free State.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 26 (By courier to France). -- Victory is still out of sight and Madrid's leadership is slow and uninspiring in the eyes of the impatient Catalonians, so Barcelona has gone ahead to install a regional government which is rapidly taking over control of buildings and industries, eliminating the church and liquidating the upper middle class.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Mrs. Dwight F. Davis heads the patroness committee for an entertainment to be known as the gala dinner dance of the Hamptons, which will be held on Sept. 4 at Canoe Place Inn for the benefit of Camp Grant at Baiting Hollow, L.I.

" The world has created the Jewish problem and the world must help to solve it," the Zionist Organization of America declared yesterday in a review of the Jewish affairs in Palestine, issued in behalf of the organization by William M. Lewis of Philadelphia, acting president.

ON BOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL TRAIN EN ROUTE TO BISMARCK, N.D., Aug. 26. -- President Roosevelt's first day of travel toward the western drought regions turned long before sundown into a series of political demonstrations, despite Mr. Roosevelt's insistence previously that this trip must be considered purely as non-political.

BUFFALO, Aug. 26. -- Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee, in a statement here today declared that Governor Lehman in his speech at the convention of the State Federation of Labor yesterday sought to obtain the support of organized labor through certain labor leaders on the State payroll, and by "enshrouding himself in a synthetic blanket of humanitarianism."

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 26. -- An offer by Dr. W.B. McKinney of Philadelphia, on behalf of a company to be formed under the name of Newark Tidewater Terminals Inc., to lease the former army base at the Port of Newark for fifteen years at a rental of not less than $100,000 a year was accepted in a resolution adopted today by the City Commission.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Emil Mosbacher Jr. and his Knickerbocker Yacht Club crew of Jimmy Norton and Eddie Leahy successfully defended the Long Island Sound midget sailing championship and the Scoville Trophy today as the five-race series came to an end.

Steel ingot production has reached a new peak for this year at 73 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly summary of Iron Age, issued yesterday. Steel-finishing mills in many instances are operating at 80 to 100 per cent of theoretical capacity, the review says.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., N.Y., Aug. 26. -- After spread-eagling New York's best amateurs yesterday at Winged Foot, 20-year-old Frank Strafaci, Brooklyn public links ace, today set another winning pace as he captured the medal in the metropolitan junior golf championship qualifying round at Wheatley Hills.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Dr. Fritz Meyer, noted heart specialist of New York, attended Secretary of War Dern at Walter Reed General Hospital today, at the suggestion of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The Bureau of Motor Carriers of the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that a highway carrier which transported a particular class of freight exclusively on June 1, 1935, could not subsequently move other classes without proof of public convenience and necessity.

Secretary Ickes will go on the radio tonight, according to the Democratic National Committee, to disclose "hitherto secret documents revealing how orders went from William Randolph Hearst to Alfred Landon."

A plan for refunding the $41,633,000 of outstanding bonds and notes of the City of Asheville and Buncombe County, N.C., and the Asheville local tax school district has been declared operative jointly by the bondholders' and noteholders' protective committees of which Frederic W. Ecker, vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and Nolan Harrigan, vice president of the Irving Trust Company, are chairmen respectively.
PARIS, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Air Minister Pierre Cot said tonight he would make a tour of inspection throughout the nation preparatory to reorganizing the French air defenses.

Yielding to strike threats made by spokesmen for labor unions, the Board of Estimate ignored yesterday the low bidder on a contract for electrical equipment on the Queens branch of the city's Independent Subway and authorized an award to a "closed Shop" contractor whose bid was $47,052 higher.
Looking feverishly about for theatres, the season's early entries are slowly finding bookings. Among the houses reported yesterday to have prospective tenants are the following:

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday that its passenger revenue in July increased from $4,528,010 in July, 1935, to $5,494, 166 last month, or 21.3 per cent. The increase in the first seven months of the year was 12.8 per cent, or from $31,126,996 to $35,090,232.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Reports of President, Roosevelt's embryonic peace conference plan, whereby if re-elected he would call together the leading figures of Europe for a personal declaration against war, were received by official and diplomatic Washington today with an appearance of utter surprise, and with considerable misgivings as to the practical possibilities of such a proposal.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- For the second time within three days the New York Racing Commission suspended a trainer of race horses, when action was taken today against Emerson Davis, trainer of Shoeless Joe and others owned by Connie Smythe, a Canadian.
Ranks figured prominently as sellers of Manhattan real estate yesterday when several building sites changed hands.
Philip S. Nutt, president of the American Society of Teachers of Dancing, does not think that "swing" dancing will last beyond this Winter.

Governor LANDON'S address at Buffalo is probably the most effective he has made thus far in the campaign. His comments on the Federal Government's financial problem were quiet in tone; they were put forward in very simple, almost elementary terms, but they showed a sound grasp of the problem, and they attacked the Roosevelt Administration at admittedly its weakest point.

BARCELONA, Aug. 26. -- The backbone of the Catalonian resistance to the Fascist rebellion is the war committee of the anti-Fascist militia, which has been entrusted by the government with supreme authority over military and civil life in the whole province.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- The recovery in prices reflected in the trend of the Boerse since the beginning of the week continued at a slightly slackened pace tody, and while the turnover was considerably smaller than that of yesterday the general tendency remained firm.

The oncoming Presidential election will witness the furor of political combat, and in this the words individualism, collectivism, dictatorship, democracy, fascism, communism and Americanism will be tossed' about in the oratory which politicians so delight in displaying.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had ordered the Metropolitan Surgical Instrument Council, Inc., of New York City, its officers and forty-eight member firms to "cease and desist from combining to fix and establish uniform prices at which members or others shall sell surgical instruments and supplies."
INNSBRUCK, Austria, Aug. 26. -- German gliders are now able to fly from Bavaria over the Alps at an altitude of more than 10,000 feet and land safely in Italy, after passing over Austrian territory.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 26. -- Jack Polk, 14-year-old-son of J.L. Polk Sr. of Troy, N.Y., topped a field of sixty-nine today in the opening event of the Junior Rifle Corps matches on the National Rifle Association program when he scored 196 out of a possible 200 over the fifty-foot range.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The New York Giants were put through their third scrimmage today and at its conclusion there was little doubt among observers that the Eastern champions of the National Football League are on the threshold of another brilliant campaign.

Philip H. Gladstone, vice president of the Association of Master Painters and Decorators, expressed doubt last night that a strike call, which is expected to take 12,000 members of the Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers Union from their jobs at 8 A.M. today, had been prompted by any of the aims professed by the union.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Six marksmen blazed their way into class championships of American trapshooting today over the rain-swept traps of Vandalia.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 26. -- The harness racing at the eighty-fourth annual Suffolk County Fair today was the fastest ever witnessed on a Suffolk County track. Two of the records of the Fair Grounds track were broken.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- That part of the report of a special committee of the criminal law section of the American Bar Association referring to Governor Hoffman's activities in the Hauptmann case read as follows:

The new Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers musical, "Swing Time," will have its local premiere today at the Radio City Music Hall. Sponsored by RKO Radio, the film has music by Jerome Kern, with lyrics by Dorothy Fields. The cast of featured players includes Victor Moore, Helen Broderick, Georges Metaxa, Eric Blore, Betty Furness and Landers Stevens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Defeat of Governor Landon, declared to be the "figurehead" of financiers and wealthy Americans desiring fascism, is the goal of the Communist party of America in the November election, Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, said today at the National Press luncheon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Women from all over the country assembled here today to celebrate the issuance of a postage stamp honoring the memory of Susan B. Anthony, pioneer leader in the suffrage movement.

John Gunther reports that his study of dictators, "Inside Europe," has been officially banned in Germany. The Gestapo (Secret State Police) have orders to confiscate all copies found. The book, a best seller here, has been translated into many languages -- French, German, Dutch, Czechoslovak, Swedish, Danish and Finnish -- and serial rights have been widely sold on the Continent.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- The plan for a world peace conference, to be attended by the heads of the principal world powers, as reported to be entertained by President Roosevelt, today startled German officialdom somewhat by its boldness, but the first reactions to the idea ranged from deep skepticism regarding its practicability to amusement over "its charming naivete."

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- The plan for a world peace conference, to be attended by the heads of the principal world powers, as reported to be entertained by President Roosevelt, today startled German officialdom somewhat by its boldness, but the first reactions to the idea ranged from deep skepticism regarding its practicability to amusement over "its charming naivete."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 26. -- Pastime, the Seawanhaka Club's representative in the Atlantic Class yachting championship, took the lead in the annual regatta by finishing second in today's race off Rock Harbor. As Pastime was also the runner-up in yesterday's title contest, today's effort gave her a total of 16 points, 3 more than Black Rock, the defending champion, and Manhasset Bay, which were tied for second with 13.

Although they may not have any intention of starting another inter-industry fight, Wellington, Sears Co. has launched a widespread advertising campaign, which will, at least, annoy the paper industry. After a successful one-shot test in a number of business magazines, the company has started to use about a dozen business papers and trade magazines to publicize the advantages of cloth towels over paper towels.

Participation of the Savings Banks Trust Company in railroad reorganization proceedings was disclosed yesterday in an application filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration of certificates of deposit issued by a committee for New Orleans, Texas Mexico (Gulf Coast Lines) bonds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The Rotating Valve Corporation, New York City, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 49,997 shares of no-par-value common stock to be offered at $20 a share. Net proceeds would be used to publicize and market the corporation's products, to buy real estate and equipment, and for other corporate purposes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 26 (.m i Governor Floyd B. Olson was mourned today by notables and' the. man in the street, who thronged the City Auditorium and watched the funeral cortege in numbers estimated by Adjutant General E. A. Walsh to be 150,000.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Reports of an impending wage increase for the nation's steel workers were revived again today in labor circles. Executives of the big steel companies declined to comment.

BIRIATOU, France, Aug. 26. -- A violent offensive by Spanish Rebels broke on Irun this morning after a night of desultory firing. The battle ended at 9 o'clock tonight after having raged for fifteen hours without a pause. Even thereafter an occasional machine gun or shell could be heard.

Operators in the intercoastal shipping trade admitted yesterday that the impasse between Pacific Coast ship owners and spokesmen of the Pacific longshoremen threatened serious consequences for ships moving between Atlantic and Pacific ports.
Remington Rand, Inc., has removed all sales, service and executive offices here to larger quarters in the Remington Rand Building, 315 Fourth Avenue.

MADRID, Aug. 26 (From a resident, by courier to France). -- The extent to which hatred against the Catholic church and clergy is dominating the activities of the government's most powerful allies -- Anarchists, Syndicalists and Communists -- is demonstrated in cartoons and pictures published in the Madrid newspapers controlled by those groups.
Reid Snyder, a subsidiary of Larimore Co., operating drug-store chain, in 300 Madison Av., northwest corner of 41st St.; E.S. Willard Co. and Cushman Wakefield, brokers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26. -- Israel A. Horowitz of New York held the lead in the open championship of the American Chess Federation today as six adjourned games were played off and a start made on the sixth round. Horowitz, on the black side of a Ruy Lopez, made short work of D. Polland of New York, winning in 24 moves.

Prominent citizens coming home from Europe report no war clouds over the Continent. They now have corroboration from the Foreign Affairs Committee of the British Cabinet. It had a meeting on Tuesday and found the international horizon clear.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- One of E.R. Bradley's Hopeful candidates, Biologist, turned in a keen performance at the Spa course today in winning the thirty-fourth Albany handicap from a field of seven others, including the Teddy colt, Tedious.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell, Red Sox pitching ace, rushed to the mound today, pitched brilliant to ball and shut out the Tigers, 7to 0.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26. -- A day of perfect tennis weather and one of the largest mid-week crowds in recent years saw the favorites come through all along the line today in the national doubles championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26. -- Townsend pension planners claimed victory in the State primary tonight because eleven of the twenty candidates they endorsed won Congressional nominations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Appeals to Great Britain for the termination of Arab anti-Jewish disorders were received here today by the Zionist Organization of America from Senator William H. King, Senator David I. Walsh, Senator Morris Sheppard, and Senator Arthur Capper, and Representative John J. O'Connor of New York and Representative Isaac Bacharach of New Jersey.

The President's idea of calling together the heads of the great nations to discuss world peace, reported in yesterday's TIMES, is admittedly as yet only an idea, fascinating in its possibilities, which the author is turning over in his mind. He himself is not sure whether, if re-elected, he will go through with it, or whether it is at all possible of realization.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Thursday, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Joseph W. Harriman, former New York financier, was released from the Northeastern Federal Penitentiary early today. His parole became effective at one minute past midnight.

The New York visit of the Japanese ships with their 1,500 officers and men, including "midshipmen," should not pass without calling special attention to the service of TOWNSEND HARRIS, an early New York "merchant prince" who became our first diplomatic representative in Japan.

Edwin Barber, deep sea diver, lay at Bellevue Hospital early yesterday suffering from spasmodic attacks of the "bends," dread diver's disease, while doctors and the police made futile efforts to locate a decompression chamber to relieve his agony and save him from death.
Building plans filed by architects yesterday included projects for a number of small dwellings in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.
Eight properties -- four in Manhattan and a similar number in the Bronx -- were bought in at foreclosure sales by plaintiffs yesterday.

Into the history, ancient or modern, of Democratic factions in Nebraska it is unnecessary to enter. After a long struggle Senator NORRIS has yielded his strong personal desire to the public interest. In a generation of steady and fruitful hard work in Congress he has won the respect and esteem even of those who differ fundamentally with some of his policies.

Edward Julius Berwind, coal operator, corporation director and internationally known capitalist, who died on Aug. 18, named his sister and nephew principal beneficiaries in his will which was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Senator James F. Byrnes's majority over his two anti-administration opponents reached record-breaking proportions today, but his claim that the outcome of yesterday's Democratic primary was an endorsement of the New Deal was questioned by his colleague, Senator Ellison D. Smith.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- Increased receipts of hogs met with a relatively slow demand here today and prices declined 10 to 25 cents. The top of $11.33 a hundred pounds was 25 cents under Tuesday and the lowest in two weeks. The day's average was off 10 cents at $10.05.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The third-place Cubs bunched their hits today to take both ends of a double-header from the Phillies, 4 to 2 and 7 to 4, before 10,000 fans.

Recently we drove through Third Street and turned the corner from Fifth Avenue going west toward Sixth Avenue. The traffic policeman stood at the corner with elbow akimbo, thus preventing any car from turning without touching him.

To understand the case of jitters that struck the State Department in Washington Wednesday morning it is necessary to remember the training of men in the diplomatic service. Discretion and caution in action and speech are the essential attributes of him who wants to advance in the career division.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Aug. 28. -- Positive identification yesterday of the bodies of two Japanese at Chengtu definitely established the fact that a rioting Chinese gang had been responsible for the fatalities in an attack on four Japanese visitors to the Szechwan Province capital on Monday.

The pageant of "Our Lady," with a cast of sixty children and a chorus of more than 1,000, was held yesterday afternoon in the music grove of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, as the closing event of the Summer program of the Catholic Charities Vacation Centers in Brooklyn.

Irregular fluctuations over a 10-point range characterized yesterday's trading on the Cotton Exchange to end with gains of 2 to 5 points. Relative steadiness in Liverpool, combined with demand from trade sources on the decline of $1 a bale from early quotations of Wednesday, maintained the price level and the market made little progress in either direction.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27. -- The Soviet Union's elaborate efforts to become independent of cotton imports, of which she purchased $9,000,000 worth from America last year, have been sabotaged by counter-revolutionary elements linked to the Trotsky-Zinovieff-Kameneff factions, it was charged today by the Commissariat for Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Violation of official United States mail in Spain was reported to the State Department today by Eric C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge of the United States Embassy in Madrid, who said he had taken up the matter with the authorities and had obtained assurances against a repetition of it.

Cooperation of the millinery union as a major step in the enforcement of the trade-practice program of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, particularly with respect to the use by manufacturers of the "Consumers' Protection Label," was announced yesterday by O.W. Pearson of the commission, following a meeting of the advisory committee of the organization.

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- Hopes that tangible results will come from the visit of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister, are being entertained here today by both parties to yesterday's discussions, which were followed today by a new conference between Dr. Schacht, who is also president of the Reichsbank, and Emile Labeyrie, governor of the Bank of France.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 27. -- The games in the fourteenth and semi-final round today failed to break the first-place tie between Mikhail Botwinnik of Russia and Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba in the international chess masters tournament at University College.

Renting agents of apartment houses in the city and suburbs were kept busy again yesterday showing rooms to prospective tenants. 1any of the suites contracted for will be occupied in the early Fall, according to the brokers, who report buildings filling up rapidly because of the demand for apaxtments available for September and October occupancy.
BISMARCK, N.D. Aug. 27. -- The summary of conclusions reached in the report of the Great Plains Drought Area Committee is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Dissensions and death have raised uncertainties in the Senatorial situation in several important States, but the Democrats nevertheless are fortifying the majority which is certain to be theirs in the next session.

WITH SPANISH GOVERNMENT FORCES, Irun, Spain, Aug. 27. -- A carefully laid trap to blow up Rebel troops advancing over a dynamite-sown field failed tonight through treason, as 15,000 men locked in battle at the close of the second day of a concerted insurgent drive along the Irun-San Sebastian sector.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- An increase of 43,000 positions in the classified competitive civil service during the fiscal year 1935-36, bringing the total Federal employment of this type on June 30 to 498,725, the largest since 1919, was reported today by the Civil Service Commission.
In your editorial "Social Security Problems" the statement was made that "only one State had unemployment insurance legislation prior to the passage of the Federal act."

James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, was told emphatically yesterday by party leaders from Utah and Nevada that President Roosevelt would win there, but United States Senator Alva Adams of Colorado admitted it was a close battle in his State.

After scanning the skies above Pelham Bay Park and listening to the cool rustle of wind in the trees, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would move the Summer City Hall back to town a week from tomorrow. It was the first definite "sign" that the Summer is almost over.

Mayor La Guardia agreed yesterday with Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine that more policemen are needed to enforce the law in the city, especially in the parks, At the same time, he made it plain that he could not commit himself to support any substantial increase in the police budget for the coming year until he had discussed the city's fiscal outlook with Budget Director Leo J. McDermott and other city officials.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- The rush of the week-end entertaining will start tomorrow evening when Mrs. Skirvin Adams is to be hostess of the largest party of the night at her home, Beachmound. She is to have 150 for dinner and 200 others will come in for the dancing that is to follow.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Closing of a sweatshop at 200 Thirteenth Avenue, where two women and seven girls were said to have worked in a small converted coal and wood bin, was announced today by the State Labor Department. At the same tithe action was begun to enforce penalties against Mrs. Antonetta Ranaldi, the operator.
