BARCELONA, Aug. 27. -- How the Catalan Workers' Army is fighting the Rebels was described to the writer by the military committee of the United Socialists, which is the third group forming, with the Catalan Nationalists and Anarcho-Syndicalists, the Central War Committee of the Anti-Fascist Militia -- the supreme military authority in Catalonia.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- The news of Italy's decision to borrow abroad for the first time since the lira was stabilized at the end of 1927 reached London after business hours, but it was immediately suggested that the Italian Government, as had been anticipated, required money for the economic development of Ethiopia.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27. -- The determined march of the Giants toward the National League pennant was interrupted today, without a break, however, in the amazing string of successes the club has enjoyed since July 15.
Elaborate preparations for entertainment of the members of the American Olympic squad scheduled to arrive tonight were announced yesterday by H. Stanley Howe, secretary to Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The first move by over-the-counter dealers to have a security removed from unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which called hearings for Sept. 11 on applications filed by Tweedy Co. of New York City, involving the $100-par capital stock of the Piedmont Northern Railway Company and the $10-par capital stock of the City and Suburban Homes Company.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 27. -- The Hydro Electric Power Commission of Ontario has decided to call for redemption on April 1, 1937, its issue of bonds of a par value of $17,626,950, issued for the purchase of Ontario Power Service Corporation bonds to the amount of $20,000,000, T. Stewart Lyon, chairman of the commission announced today.
May we reply to "Another Puzzled Traveler" whose letter appeared in THE TIMES of Aug. 22?

ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- Winners of the university scholarships awarded to high school students on the basis of their standing in Regents' tests were announced today by the State Department of Education. The awards total 745 in the entire State, of which 310 go to New York City, 40 to Erie County, 25 to Monroe and 25 to Westchester.
BERLIN, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Men from all walks in German life are being sentenced to prison terms, it was learned today, in a new wave of trials on charges of improper relations with youths.

Stock prices recovered briskly yesterday, with leading issues up 1 to 6 points at the close. The net result was that the average level was moved to where it was last Thursday before the market broke out of the narrow trading range that had persisted for several weeks.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Aug. 27. -- If Puerto Rico wants to be a part of the United States, her people will have to learn more English, said Senator William H. King of Utah as he concluded his visit here.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Aug. 27 (AP). -- An airplane stood ready tonight "awaiting the King's orders" while former King Alfonso of Spain read stacks of mail from his homeland and observers wondered whether he would make a dash for the civil war scene.

Interest in the forthcoming cotton crop report by the government is not the only factor which has caused dry goods wholesalers to curb their buying this week, they said here yesterday. Having exhausted most of their cheap goods, they are now faced with the prospect of paying the higher prices put into effect in recent weeks and are reluctant to do so, as it means raising quotations to their retail accounts.

A hint of irregularities in the Department of Markets was contained in a sharp interchange that occurred yesterday between Mayor La Guardia and Walter Chambers, until last July 15 the secretary of the department. It was provoked by the publication of a book Mr. Chambers had written.

Just before sailing for Europe, Vilhjalmur Stefansson left the manuscript of his latest book, "Adventures in Error," with his new publisher, Robert McBride. This is a study of "bunk in history" that the explorer has been working on for some years.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Frank Strafaci, defending the metropolitan junior golf championship at Wheatley Hills, had a close call this morning and was forced to the final green to subdue Robert Bach of Woodmere, 1 -- up, in the first round of the top flight.

MADRID, Aug. 27 (Passed by the Censor). -- An air raid was carried out over Madrid today. At 5 o'clock this morning Madrid residents were startled by a series of explosions and it soon became evident what was in progress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- William Gallacher, Communist member of the British Parliament, was denied entry to the United States today by Secretary Hull under the provisions of the Immigration Law which bar revolutionists from this country. Mr. Gallacher had sought admission from Canada to visit sisters in this country.

HAMPTON BEACH, N.H., Aug. 27 (AP). -- Turning his campaign fire on President Roosevelt's acceptance address, Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, declared today that the President's attack on "economic royalists" was only "shadow-boxing."

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- The text of the new Anglo-Egyptian treaty of alliance, published tonight, shows how skillfully Great Britain has kept control over this crossroads of her empire while surrendering the symbols of control that have been so hateful in Egyptian eyes for half a century.

ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine of New York and District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, friends and former Brooklyn neighbors for more than twenty years, disputed each other's veracity today in the removal proceedings against Mr. Geoghan before Governor Lehman.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., today met the severest test of her defense of the women's Western closed golf championship, but when the last raindrop had fallen on the nineteenth green, she was the victor over Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City by that one-hole margin.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The New York, Westchester Boston Railroad Company has demanded a 50 per cent reduction in the assessed valuation of its railroad lines, it was announced today by a committee of Mayors in Westchester, which is attempting to save the railroad from liquidation.

The payroll of the local Works Progress Administration has been reduced to a previously announced goal of 202,000 workers, including those on regular work and on the four Federal Arts Projects, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, New York City WPA Administrator.

BEUTHEN, Polish Upper Silesia, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Three hundred miners, at the close of their fourth day of a hunger strike deep down the shaft of a coal mine, sent word tonight to the top that they would "not take another drop of water" until their back wages had been paid.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 27 (AP). -- Walter B. Orr, former Police Chief of Charlotte, claimed today a $1,000 reward offered for the arrest and conviction of Martin Moore, Negro hotel employe, as Helen Clevenger's slayer. He termed the work of the two New York detectives on the case "negligible."
LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 27. -- Apart from the battle at Irun, the fighting in Spain today consisted mainly of an interchange of air and artillery bombardments.

VIENNA, Aug. 27. -- Viennese Nazis were greatly disappointed last night When Austria cut the Berlin Olympics film in half by eliminating the parts-showing Chancellor Adolf Hitler and other Nazi notables. The reason given was that these parts evoked noisy Nazi demonstrations at previous showings.

Lavishly praising the manner in which the recent Olympic Games were conducted in Berlin, William A. Dalton, president of the New York Athletic Club, returned home yesterday aboard the French liner Lafayette, accompanied by a delegation of forty club members and guests, who also made the trip to Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Contrary to the usual decline in July, industrial production was maintained at the level of the three preceding months and factory payrolls increased, the Federal Reserve Board announced in its business review today.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The Newark Bears ended a short home stay tonight by taking both ends of a double-header from Albany, 5 -- 1 and 9 -- 1.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices lost 1.7 points in the week ended on Tuesday and closed at 127.3. The decline canceled almost all the rise of the preceding week and the index now stands but 1 point above the level of a year ago, drought and other factors notwithstanding.

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- As a fitting commemoration of the tenth anniversary of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's transatlantic flight, the French Air Minister, Pierre Cot, today announced his decision to organize an international transatlantic air derby from New York to Paris on May 21 next year.

Two members of the Queens Business Men's Committee resigned yesterday as a protest against the action taken by Robert Charles Moore, Forest Hills attorney and chairman of the committee, in filing charges with the Governor demanding the removal of Mayor La Guardia on the grounds of incompetence and waste of public moneys due to delay in operating the new city subway under Queens Boulevard.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 27. -- According to private information received today from Moscow -- information that is regarded as truthful in informed quarters -- the Soviet Government has arrested a number of leading Finnish-born Communists in connection with the Zinovieff case.

In an address to the August grand jury, which appeared before him to hand up indictments, Judge Franklin Taylor in Kings County Court expressed yesterday the opinion that Brooklyn was the dirtiest borough in the city and suggested that money being paid out by the city for home relief could be used to pay more employes in the Department of Sanitation.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The death of twenty Arabs in three fights with British troops was reported today by the government. At least fifteen others, it said, were wounded in the engagements last night and today.

TOKYO, Aug. 27. -- Answering gesture with gesture, officials, after a study of THE NEW YORK TIMES article dealing with President Roosevelt's consideration of a new peace conference idea, indicated that Japan would not refuse an invitation to participate in a world conference seeking to remove the menace to peace.

BISMARCK, N.D., Aug. 27. -- In a brief talk this evening President Roosevelt complimented the residents of this area for keeping their "chins up" in the face of the drought disaster. He made the talk after he had driven more than fifty miles through the countryside and had had a long talk with two farmers typical of thousands who have lost their crops in this region.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotat. ions for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):
ROME, Aug. 27. -- An issue of Italian Treasury bonds for sale in the foreign market is announced in the Official Gazette tonight.

From London BERNARD M. BARUCH makes the proposal that every economic agreement between nations should be accompanied by an understanding or formula on minimum wages and maximum hours. "Not that "any nation should impose its ideas "upon another, but any tariff or quota "or money stabilization should have "some stated minimum wage and "maximum hour which a nation could "not break without breaking the whole "agreement."

MANILA, Aug. 27. -- Marcelino Suria, Manila business man, who is an adviser of the 5,000 Filipino veterans of the World War, said action toward the cashing of bonus bonds must be taken immediately to relieve distress. The bonds must now be sent to Washington after certification.
OTTAWA, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The Cabinet Council approved today a recommendation of the Canadian Wheat Board to fix the minimum price for the 1936-1937 wheat crop at 87 1/2 cents a bushel.

Former Supreme Court Justice Daniel F. Cohalan, one of the five Democratic signers of a letter urging the Philadelphia convention to pass over President Roosevelt and name a "real" Democrat as the candidate, carried his "walk" one step further yesterday and declared that he would vote for Governor Landon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- A slight upturn in the level of wholesale prices in the week ended on Aug. 22 lifted the Department of Labor's index to 81.5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, was 81.1 on Aug. 15 and 80.8 on Aug. 24, 1935.
POTENZA, Italy, Aug. 27. -- A warning to depopulated France was seen in a speech made tonight by Premier Benito Mussolini, who said:

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- A seventh-inning rally gave the Tigers a 4-to-2 victory over the Red Sox today as Tommy Bridges chalked up his eighteenth victory of the season. Simmons doubled to score two mates, breaking a 2-all tie.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Aug. 27 (AP). -- Joseph W. Harriman, former New York financier, was freed from the Federal Northeastern Penitentiary today, after serving two years of his four-and-one-half-year sentence for banking irregularities involving more than $1,000,000.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 27. -- It was officially announced today by the famous Vienna heart specialist, Dr. Karel Frederik Wenckebach, that Premier Julius Goembees of Hungary must be transferred to a sanatorium abroad.

ONCE in a while the ball players get to arguing about positions on the diamond. Nobody wants to be a catcher except the catchers, who don't seem to mind working back there with heavy harness draped over their sturdy forms and steel cages hiding their noble features. All hands except first basemen seem to think that first basemen should be made to pay their way into the park.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- Proponents of the Federal child labor amendment to the Constitution, reinforced by letters from President Roosevelt and a spokesman for Governor Landon expressing approval, made a vigorous but unsuccessful effort today to swerve the American Bar Association 'from its opposition to the measure.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27. -- Leroy (Tarzan) Parmelee, Cardinal hurler, was near fame today, but after pitching seven hitless innings against the Bees, weakened and Boston won in the tenth, 1 to 0.
DAIREN, Manchuria, Aug. 27. -- As a result of the latest clash between Russian and Japanese frontier forces, both sides are bringing up machine-gun detachments and reinforcing themselves.

A cup committee was appointed to handle the America's Cup challenge of the Royal Yacht Squadron of Cowes, and the actual wording of the challenge was given to members yesterday at a special meeting of the New York Yacht Club at the West Forty-fourth Street club house.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27. -- A demonstration of stingless bees, held today at a meeting of the Philadelphia Beekeepers Association in Chestnut Hill, was a big success -- except that one of the visitors was stung.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ABOARD S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, AT SEA, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The returning Olympic forces, although lacking most of the official as well as the athletic big guns, likely will fire a few pot shots that will make the home folks sit up and take notice upon their arrival tomorrow.

Your editorial discussion of "Hippodroming Justice" is especially interesting to me as a former newspaper man. No one can fairly question that the publicity side of many important criminal cases is badly overdone these days, but when the Bar Association seeks to fix the whole blame on the press, the radio or the onlookers, the readers or the broadcast listeners, it is not so easy.

BISMARCK, N.D., Aug. 27. -President Roosevelt today changed radically the schedule for his tour of the drought regions in order to go to Salt Lake City and attend funeral services there on Tuesday for Secretary Dern.

The trial of eleven of the twelve persons, arrested Friday night on charges of disorderly conduct after an anti-Nazi demonstration on the Bremen shortly before the liner sailed from Pier 86 on the Hudson River, started yesterday morning in the West Side Court before Magistrate Henry H. Curran.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Luncheons were given at the Gideon Putnam today before the races by Mrs. George C. Shevlin, Mrs. James L. Hand and Mrs. Charles C. Van Deusen.

The Hapag Lloyd liner Europa arrived yesterday from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg with 2,142 passengers, the record for a westbound ship since 1930. The ship was booked to capacity and officials of the line reported that scores of applicants had to be turned away.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The present healthy condition of the bond market is the best answer to Governor Landon's attack on the Roosevelt fiscal policy, Secretary Morgenthau suggested today in a two-sentence statement issued at his press conference.

The impression prevails among salt-water anglers that fishing in near-by waters is poor after Labor Day or thereabouts. Somehow, they subconsciously fix the end of the ocean fishing season with the close of the Summer resort activities, and do not consider it worth while to go out again.

ABOARD THE S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, AT SEA, Aug. 27. -- The main army of American Olympians is due home tomorrow night, when 199 athletes, their job completed, will arrive in New York ready to scatter throughout the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Randall Gumpert, 18-year-old right-hander and recent high school graduate of Birdsboro, Pa., held the White Sox to two hits in his second big league start today as he pitched the Athletics to a 5-2 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- One hundred and fifty officers of the Army Air Corps received temporary promotions by the War Department today under the provisions of the act of June 16. They included 20 lieutenant colonels promoted to colonel, 31 majors to lieutenant colonel and 99 captains to major.

The world has just been assured by the British Government that the international horizon is now clear, and that there need be no fear of a European war. It is a wise statesman who knows how long the sky will stay cloudless and can be sure that it is not an instance of the fact looking to the eye as the eye likes the look.

MADRID, Aug. 27. -- Indalecio Prieto, the "strong man" behind the Madrid government, complained bitterly today that France and Great Britain by withholding aid were making Spain the "Ethiopia of Europe."

More than 5,000 persons attended a performance last night in Forest Park, Queens, at which the winning quartet from the borough was selected to compete in the annual city-wide amateur barbershop quartet contest by the Park Department.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27. -- While I.A. Horowitz of New York and Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., were engaged in a close match, in which the Pacific Coast champion built up a good position in a queen's gambit declined, Arnold S. Denker of New York took the lead in the open championship of the American Chess Federation at the Hotel Philadelphia tonight.

An indictment accusing two independent coal dealers of criminally receiving coal allaged to have been stolen by jobless miners in the anthracite district of Pennsylvania was handed up yesterday by the additional New York County grand jury to Judge William Allen in General Sessions.

With sales of diamonds this year by the Diamond Corporation showing a 25 per cent rise over 1935 and a four-fold gain over the low point in 1935, the future of the industry is becoming brighter, Sidney H. Ball of Rogers, Mayer Ball, and an authority on diamonds, told members of the American National Retail Jewelers Association yesterday morning in the fourth day of their annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The Weyerhaeuser Timber Company of Tacoma and associated companies petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today for an order requiring operators of dock facilities at Port Newark, N.J., to provide such facilities for that company and on the same basis as to competing concerns.

IT was a difficult breakfast yesterday morning. The eggs were fresh and the coffee was hot, but there, staring up at me from the tabletop, were the newspaper reports of Governor Landon's speech at Buffalo. Reckless spending in Washington. Staggering public debt. The door of opportunity closed to the youth of America. Face the issue squarely. The debt to be paid by our children.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

ABOARD PRISON SHIP URUGUAY, off Barcelona, Spain, Aug. 23. -- Before this account of their trial is published these four men who are now in the dock in front of us will most probably have been shot. They are being judged today for the crime of military rebellion.

Is it safe to peek for a moment into Maine, where Democrats and Republicans are bent so fiercely on bagging that earliest prophetic bird, the Maine election? Governor BRANN, Democratic candidate for Senator, and Mr. DUBORD, Democratic candidate for Governor, seem curiously able to keep calm.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- These tributes were paid by officials today on the death of Secretary of War Dern:

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- A warning that the nation was headed for another all-time "record of slaughter" on its highways was sounded today by the National Safety Council as it released figures showing July to be the third successive month with more fatalities than the corresponding period last year.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad, which led in the movement to reduce passenger fares in the East, reported yesterday that its passenger revenues in July amounted to $1,075,819, against $875,957 in July, 1935, an increase of 22.3 per cent.
TOPEKA, Friday, Aug. 28.--Governor Landon returned at 1 o'clock this morning from his first campaign trip, well pleased with his reception in New York and Pennsylvania and on his stops on the way.
Contracts for the sale of houses and other properties in scattered sections of the city were announced yesterday.
Responding to a call of union officials to put an end to the "kickback racket," members of the Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers Union went on strike yesterday.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- Joe Hiestand of Hillsboro, Ohio, won his fourth national trapshoot title of the year today, successfully defending his doubles crown, but the big prize of the day, the preliminary handicap, went to Ernest L. Hawkins of Fort Wayne, Ind.

A hearing held yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board on the refusal of The Associated Press to recognize the American Newspaper Guild as the collective bargaining agency for Associated Press employes was devoted mainly to a discussion of the Seattle and Milwaukee strikes of Guild members on Hearst-owned newspapers.

Several of the leading steel companies have individually decided not to increase wages at this time. The decision is expected to be followed by the entire steel industry, giving assurance that there will not be a general increase in the wages of the 500,000 steel workers at least until Jan. 1, 1937, according to steel executives.

In his letter to THE TIMES, F.J. Dundon outlines a theory as to the actual ownership of the gold coin and bullion in the United States Treasury which, if correct, would make the 1933 seizure of gold and gold certificates by the government appear an arbitrary and illegal violation of individual rights.

Bank clearings of the leading cities throughout the United States for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $4,524,896,000, against $4,552,390,000 in the corresponding week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The loss of 0.6 per cent compares with a 2 per cent decline the week before.

DIXVILLE NOTCH, N.H., Aug. 27. -- One of the gayest affairs of the season at the Balsams, Dixville Notch, was the costume ball given last night in the ballroom decorated with Autumn foliage, for the benefit of the New Hampshire Society for Crippled Children.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 27. -- The spare players of Argentina's international team, combined with C.V. Whitney to form the Old Westbury team for the open championship, came from behind to defeat Raymond Guest's Roslyn team in a practice match today on Mitchel Field, 10 to 9.

SEATTLE, Aug. 27. -- A strike blockade of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, Hearst newspaper which has failed to publish for fourteen days, prevented the transshipment here today of Sunday editions of The San Francisco Examiner, also a Hearst publication.

BIRIATOU, France, Aug. 27. -- The Spanish Rebels' attack on Irun, which reopened today with somewhat diminished intensity along the two-mile front that they have chosen for their attempted advance, was definitely checked tonight after a series of fierce charges and countercharges.

Mrs. Grace Goodhue Coolidge, widow of the former President, returned from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa accompanied by her friend and traveling companion, Mrs. Florence B. Adams, who is her neighbor in Northampton, Mass.

Moderately firmer tendencies appeared yesterday in the local commodity futures markets, although some staples showed slight losses and old Rio coffee contracts were sharply lower. In the cash markets, corn, flour and silk declined, while cocoa made a new high record and refined sugar, wheat, rye, rubber, butter and tins advanced.

MANILA, Aug. 6 (AP) (by mail). -- Goaded by a published story that the office of the United States High Commissioner is opposed to issuance of public works bonds by the Commonwealth government, President Manuel L. Quezon issued a public statement clearly defining relations between the new government of the Islands and the United States.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 27. -- The 2-year-old trot at the eighty-fourth annual Suffolk County Fair today was captured by Hollyrood Audrey, a bay filly owned by D.W. Bostwick of Westbury. Starlight, the property of Archie Paine, took the 2:18 pace.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Sub-par practice today presaged sensational scoring in the eighth annual Glens Falls open golf tournament, beginning tomorrow, with about 200 shotmakers seeking part of the $3,500 in prizes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Allocations for public works projects will be resumed, unimpeded by President Roosevelt's new regulations concerning the employment of relief labor, which will be observed to the fullest extent consistent with the carrying out of the program, Secretary Ickes said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Earl Averill's tenth-inning single drove in the winning run here today as the Indians beat the Senators, 10 -- 9.

Last January MABEL EATON sued for divorce in New Jersey on the ground of extreme cruelty. Her husband denied the charges and filed a counterclaim for divorce. The Advisory Master in Chancery, who decided the case, threw out the wife's charges, granted the divorce to the husband, and awarded also the custody of the two children, a boy of 6 and a girl of 11.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27. -- A revamped line-up, necessitated by the loss of Eddie Wilson, brought a turn in the Dodgers' luck today and they dropped the series final to the Pirates, 6 -- 3.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- The British and French Governments acted jointly today in urging through the agency of their embassies and legations that all countries that have agreed not to intervene in the Spanish civil war implement their decisions immediately by establishing embargoes on shipments of munitions.

Plans of a three-story milk pasteurizing plant at 806-30 Eleventh Avenue, 530-56 West Fifty-seventh Street and 517-45 West Fifty-sixth Street for the Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., of 524 West Fifty-seventh Street, were filed yesterday.

Engagements of $5,724,000 of gold abroad -- $2,273,000 in France and $3,451,000 in Canada -- for shipment here was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Total gold engagements since Aug. 7, when the current influx began, were lifted to $44,400,000 by these operations, $23,500,000 of the amount having been taken in France.

Large space in forty-six newspapers throughout Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut will be used today to announce the formation of the Taste-Masters Institute, Inc., composed of eleven wholesale distributers of wine and liquors doing business in those three States and brokering their products to the State-controlled liquor stores of Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont.

LINDEN, N.J., Aug. 27.--The General Motors Corporation will build one of the largest automobile assembly plants in the world on an eighty-acre site here near State Highway Route 25 and Stiles Street, it was announced today.

Predicting that the complaint he has filed with the Federal Trade Commission on the score of payment by millinery manufacturers of fees to commission buyers is likely to be the first test case under the Patman law, Joseph H. Dryer, president of the National Council of Traveling Salesmen's Associations, disclosed yesterday that he had given the commission specific data regarding the interstate nature of his charges.

OTTAWA, Aug. 27 (Canadian Press) -- Substantial increases in reserves held in sterling and in United States funds were shown in today's bank of Canada statement for the week ended yesterday. The statement follows:

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued firm today in a cheerful atmosphere, with selective buying of industrials again prominent. British Government securities were steady under the influence of the war loan, which rose 107 3s 9d.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Wee Roy Henshaw, called in from bullpen exile, pitched the Cubs to their fifth straight victory today, limiting the Phillies to six hits, to win 1 to 0. It was Henshaw's first triumph since July 2 and pulled the Cubs to within three games of the National League pace, set by the idle Giants.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, returned from a brief trip to Europe yesterday, repeating the note of alarm expressed earlier this month in his report to the stockholders in which he said that a grave future faced the country unless government spending was curtailed.

Furs, with a rise of 59.6 per cent over the same month a year ago, led the sales increases by departments in local department stores in July, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Note three cinema arrivals on Broadway today: "Piccadilly Jim" at the Capitol, with Robert Montgomery, Madge Evans and Ralph Forbes; "Girls' Dormitory" at the Roxy, with Darryl Zanuck's new French star, Simone Simon, aided by Herbert Marshall and Ruth Chatterton, and "The Case of the Velvet Claws," a new Perry Mason mystery with Warren William, Claire Dodd, Winifred Shaw and Addison Richards at the Rialto.

BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- German Catholic Bishops sent to Chancellor Hitler from their annual meeting at Fulda a pastoral letter that is more than conciliatory, it became known today. It contains, nevertheless, another strong warning against the spread of pagan doctrines.

A new health center building planned by the city on the upper East Side of Manhattan will be used not only for municipal health-promotion work in that district but also for a part of the training of students in the Cornell University Medical School, it was learned yesterday.

Reports of three companies in the Electric Bond and Share group were made public yesterday and showed marked improvements in earnings for the year and the three months ended on July 31, compared with the reports issued a year ago.

BERLIN, Aug. 27. -- The Boerse fell into one of its perennial "insecurity moods" today and the firmer tendency that had prevailed in the first half of the week gave way to losses of 3 or more points. The slump was laid to the increasing shortage of fluid capital and the tightening of the money market in general.

There have been indications recently that industrialists are not of one mind on the advisability of increasing prices of goods. A leading copper producer announced a week ago that it was increasing its output 25 per cent, and the interpretation placed on this move was that the company was opposed to any plan to raise the price of copper.

JOSEPH STALIN and LEON TROTSKY are in agreement on one point at least. Sixteen men were found guilty in the treason trial at Moscow and shot, but the real defendant was TROTSKY in absentia. When the sentence was carried out TROTSKY called it one of the greatest crimes in history, but went on to declare proudly that he, TROTSKY, still lives.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Lighter receipts of hogs today at the market here prompted a stronger undertone. Sales were steady to as high as 10 cents gains, with light sows the feature of upturn. The top was 5 cents higher at $11.40, with the day's average up 5 cents at $10.10.

Further advances in United States Government bonds brought four new hgh records yesterday, gains ranging from 1-32 to 4-32 for the day in most issues, although others were off 1-32 to 3-32 point. The turnover in this group on the Stock Exchange was only $308,900, against $773,700 on Wednesday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- About the coolest rider in racing, the veteran Harry Richards reached up under the plaited mane of his mount in the stretch today and yanked a leather strap which probably meant the difference between defeat and victory in the $3,385 Huron Handicap.
VATICAN CITY, Aug. 27. -- Pope Pius XI was so distressingly weakened tonight from worry over Spanish bloodshed that prelates feared he might soon be unable to walk.

The President, officially and personally, will miss his Secretary of War. GEORGE H. DERN was a man of kindliness and dignity, possessed also of a long head and ripe experience in public affairs which held errors to a minimum. The President seldom if ever was burdened by anything happening or failing to happen at the War Department.

Republican leaders returning yesterday, after attending the meetings addressed by Governor Landon at Chautauqua and Buffalo, were enthusiastic over the welcome accorded the nominee on his first campaign appearance in the State. They were admittedly less optimistic in their guarded utterances about the Republican State Convention, which will open at Albany a month from today, and the Governorship campaign.

SEATTLE, Aug. 27. -- David Beck, international vice president of the Teamsters Union and president of the Teamsters Joint Council for this area, charged today that William Randolph Hearst, publisher of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer; the Industrial Council of Washington, Inc., and the Seattle Chamber of Commerce were jointly trying to crush organized labor here.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Soviet-Manchukuoan border incidents tonight caused the second Soviet protest in two days. The chief of the Eastern Department of the Soviet Foreign Office, Mr. Kozlovsky, protested to the Japanese Charge d'Affaires, S. Sakoh, against a reported attack upon Soviet frontier guards yesterday while they were watering horses in the Usago River near Dunnin on the frontier.
Official comment here in New York on the death of Secretary Dern was as follows:

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The 25,000 soldiers of the Ninety-eighth Infantry Reserve Division assembled in units along the South Pemberton Road from Mount Holly to the New Lisbon traffic circle this morning to begin their final drive in the war games here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Rumors that the Canadian Wheat Board was contemplating raising the government-guaranteed minimum price for this year's wheat crop from the level of 87 1/2 cents a bushel for No. 1 Northern, which has been in effect since late in 1935, was largely responsible today for a somewhat higher level of prices for wheat in North American markets.

Johnny Broaca, Yale's outstanding gift to the major leagues, carefully adjusted his spectacles at the Stadium yesterday, focused his eyes on the Browns and forthwith held them transfixed for one hour and forty-five minutes, which, as there was no aiding wind blowing, very likely will be accepted as a world record for that sort of thing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The text of the radio address by Secretary Ickes was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- George H. Dern of Utah, who had been Secretary of War since President Roosevelt took office, died at 10:55 o'clock this morning in Walter Reed General Hospital of cardiac complications following a severe attack of influenza. He was 63 years old.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 27. -- After a stormy debate between advocates of craft and industrial unionism, the convention of the New York State Federation of Labor voted at its concluding session today to keep "hands off" the conflict between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.

BISMARCK, N.D., Aug. 27.--President Roosevelt began here today a personal study of the difficulties of the drought-ridden West, receiving in his first conference a report by the Great Plains Drought Area Committee urging detailed studies looking toward a shift in the whole economy of the "Dust Bowl" and creation of a Federal-State board to carry out a program of water and land conservation.

Governor LEHMAN made it plain at the opening of the hearing on the charges against District Attorney GEOGHAN that he proposes to insist upon keeping the procedure correct and orderly There is to be no "hippodroming" of justice in this case. It is too important for all concerned to be allowed to take on a purely sensational aspect.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Secretary Ickes declared in a campaign speech over the radio tonight that William Randolph Hearst was "the new Republican boss," and he quoted testimony given in a Chicago lawsuit in July to show that Mr. Hearst had advised against too many campaign speeches by Governor Landon, Republican nominee for President.

EDMONTON, Aug. 27. -- Provision for formation of a board of not more than five members to fix prices and investigate price spreads in Alberta is contained in a bill introduced in the Provincial Legislature as an act to amend the Trade and Industry Act, it was announced here today by E.C. Manning, head of the Trade and Industry Department.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 27. -- In a history-making second set that stands unequaled in longevity in women's national championship play, Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley, Calif., and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Boston, the defending titleholders, defeated Miss Kay Stammers of England and Miss Alice Marble of Palm Springs, Calif., today to gain the final round of the national doubles tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.
PARIS, Aug. 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The Brooklyn Democratic district leaders expect to obtain pluralities of more than 300,000 for President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman at the November election, it was asserted yesterday after a meeting of the executive committee in the office of Frank V. Kelly, county leader.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 27. -- More than 500,000 workers in the United States are daily exposed to the dread silica dust to a harmful degree and living in constant danger of contracting silicosis and its attendant complications, it was revealed today by Dr. W. Irving Clark, Assistant Professor of the Practice of Industrial Medicine at Harvard, speaking before the symposium on health being held at the Harvard School of Public Health.

The City of New York has invited several banks and banking houses to submit tenders next week, probably on Monday, for $6,000,000 of corporate stock notes, to be dated Sept. 3 and to mature on Dec. 15. Bidders are to name the rate of interest.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 27. -- The Stockbridge Golf and Tennis Club is holding a dance Saturday night for players in the women's golf tournament. Mrs. Seaton Treadway will have charge of the tournament tea at the club that afternoon.

BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 27 (By Courier to Hendaye, France), (AP). -- General Emilio Mola's Rebel troops drove their lines three miles closer to Madrid today after five days of bloody fighting. The troops, aided by artillery and planes, captured important positions on Cerro Nevero, dominating the Lozoya Valley about forty miles north of the capital.

A novel forward-looking suggestion has been made by the Division of Education of New York University for our World's Fair educational exhibit. It is not to be a collection of lifeless charts and graphs, specimens of children's handwriting and drawing, examples of products of manual-training classes,

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The Railroad Retirement Board is considering "appropriate action" to meet the "emergency" created by the refusal of the carriers employing 90 per cent of the employes subject to the board's jurisdiction to execute forms prescribed by the board, pending the final determination of the constitutionality of the Railroad Retirement Act of 1935.
Richard Merrill, veteran air mail pilot, and his backer and co-pilot, Harry Richman, the actor, plan to take off from Floyd Bennett Field late this afternoon for a non-stop flight to London.
Andre V. Smolianinoff is in the office of Eastman, Dillon Co. in Rockefeller Center.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27. -- Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler gave a dinner tonight at Leny Cottage, their place in First Neck Lane.

A 13,000-mile automobile tour of the United States, Mexico and Canada was completed here yesterday by six New York and New Jersey youths, all sons of wealthy parents, and their leader, John Dallavo, an instructor at the Horace Mann School for Boys in Riverdale.

GENEVA, Aug. 27. -- Vague suggestions for League of Nations reform, apparently aimed at weakening the covenant, were received today by the League from Uruguay. This is the first definite answer that has come to the invitation to League members to submit suggestions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today a petition by railroads operating in Southern territory to establish rates on hauling paper to New York, Philadelphia, Boston and Providence without observing the long and short haul clause of the law.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 27. -- A scheme for setting up regional peace machinery for the North Pacific area, under League of Nations auspices, was offered today at the Institute of Pacific Relations by a British delegate, as the conference sought practical means of solving the problems aired in the last thirteen days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Still reluctant to discuss President Roosevelt's idea for a peace conference with European rulers, State Department officials went forward today with their own plans for the Pan-American parley at Buenos Aires, hoping to make of it an example for the rest of the world.

Let this morning's chief bulletin link the names of a leading producer and a leading playwright, and go on from there to say that Herman Shumlin has acquired a new play by Ben Hecht. As yet untitled, it is a tale of modern South America; and, if a male star can be found, it will enter rehearsals in two weeks.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- Jack Polk, the 14-year-old Troy (N.Y.) champion, was back on the firing line today to take first place in two of the Junior Rifle Corps events of the national small bore program in Group B for boys and girls from 12 to 15 years.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $80,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $1,890,000,000, according to the weekly report of the System, published yesterday. Virtually all this gain was concentrated in the hands of the New York City banks, however.

Directors of the Mesta Machine Company have declared a dividend of $1.50 on the common stock. On July 2 a dividend of 75 cents was disbursed, before which payments had been 50 cents quarterly. The directors said the $1.50 declaration was not to be considered the quarterly rate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 26, as reported by the Federal Reserve banks, was $2,472,000,000, a decrease of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $2,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Mrs. Edward Stevens, who has one of the steadiest golfing averages of any metropolitan player, took the Westchester-Fairfield Association one-day low gross award on the Hudson River Country Club course today with a total of 84.

SAINT JEAN DE LUZ, France, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Members of the Madrid diplomatic corps exiled to Hendaye by the Spanish civil war tonight prepared to call a new meeting seeking an agreement between the Spanish belligerents for the exchange of prisoners.

The opposition expressed by Governor Landon in his address at Chautauqua, N.Y., to the requirement of an oath of loyalty for teachers in American schools was characterized in an editorial printed in The New York American, a William Randolph Hearst publication, as "a regrettable departure from the high plane of true Americanism to which he has consistently adhered."

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP). -- Colonel W.E.R. Covell, Chief of Army Engineers of the Pittsburgh District, announced today that July freight tonnage on the Monongahela River totaled 2,564,444 tons, within 206,000 tons of the record peak of the Panama Canal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--Governor Landon's speech at Buffalo in which he attacked the undivided profits tax is evidence that his candidacy is "the candidacy of corporate wealth and special privilege," Labor's Nonpartisan League charged tonight in a statement issued by George L. Berry, its president.

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, president of the Zionist Organization of America, said on his return from Europe yesterday that the great task facing the Zionist movement in this country and of all Jews throughout the world who are concerned with the rebuilding of the Jewish national homeland in Palestine was firm resistance to the threatened suspension of Jewish immigration into Palestine.
The New York trout season closes Monday in a state of quiescence.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 28. -- For the second year in succession, the women's golf team of the Huntington Country Club today won possession of the large silver cup which members of the Crescent Athletic Club donated in 1933 for triangular team matches among the Huntington, Crescent and Northport C.C. women players.

While I admit that the passing of any "height" law probably would be unfair to those basketball players of unquestioned ability who happen to be above the average height, you undoubtedly agree that there is some merit in the complaint of the Japanese that they were at a decided disadvantage when playing against our six-and-a-half footers.

What makes a champion? Is it merely the fact that he accidentally happened to win a fight or a race or a game? It would certainly appear so to one who surveys the titleholders of recent years. The champion is not necessarily the leader or the best performer in a sport, but simply the chance victor in some so-called "championship" event.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 28. -- B.F. Cheek, 59-year-old garage owner from Clinton, Ind., made good a boast today and won the thirty-seventh annual Grand American Handicap, highest prize in the trapshooting world, in his first attempt in the annual classic.
Salaries in 1935 of officers of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., were disclosed yesterday in the company's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission filed with the New York Stock Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28. -- George Horace Lorimer, editor and for almost two score years directing genius of The Saturday Evening Post, has tendered his resignation as editor. He has relinquished the chairmanship of the Curtis Publishing Company also.

Necessities such as foods and medical supplies, as well as newsprint, will be exempted if the teamsters' union votes to call a strike of 15,000 drivers in the metropolitan area on Tuesday, it was announced by the union yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE Mass., Aug. 28. -- In discussing "Applications of Air Conditioning to Normal Life," Dr. Drinker, who is Professor of Industrial Hygiene at the Harvard School of Public Health, said.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28. -- Playing until dusk had crept over the field, the Dodgers and Reds managed nothing more progressive than to split a double-header today, Professor Stengel's men winning the opener, 8 -- 1, and the Dressen boys the twilight contest, 6 -- 4.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Aug. 28 (AP). -- Francis Ouimet, captain of the American Walker Cup team, scored a par 70 in a practice match on the Pine Valley course today. It was the second time par has been equaled in the twenty-four-year history of the club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP). -The Cubs celebrated Manager Charlie Grimm's thirty-eighth birthday today by blasting four Boston pitchers for an 184o-3 victory, their sixth straight, and their thirty-first in thirty-seven starts against Eastern clubs at Wrigley Field.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 28. -- Announcement was made here today by the Princeton Municipal Improvement, Inc., of a $4,500,000 civic building project that will alter the appearance of Princeton's historic Nassau Street, while preserving and recreating the traditional architecture of the town as it was in its early days.

JAMESTOWN, N.D., Aug. 28. -- "Roosevelt luck" manifested itself today in the form of a hard rain which fell steadily, coincident with the President's visit. This was the first precipitation in almost a month, and while too late to help crops it cooled the air.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 28. -- A combination wind and electrical storm swooped down on Terre Haute late this afternoon, leaving the city with damage estimated in the hundreds of thousands of dollars but only one death, that of a 6-year-old boy.
BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- The long-awaited first major tax increase was announced today.

Robert Francis Erskine, 22 years old, a research worker employed by News-Week, Inc., leaped eighty-six floors to his death from the lower observation platform of the Empire State Building at 9:50 A.M. yesterday. He was the fourth person to try suicide from the tower since it opened in 1931, but the first to fall to the street.
IRUN, Spain, Aug. 28. - Preceding tonight's fresh assault on Irun, its Loyalist defenders drove back a Rebel attack by hurling home-made dynamite bombs.

Pleas of not guilty were entered in General Sessions yesterday by Frank L. Nowosatka and William Slutzky, coal dealers, on four indictments alleging that they conspired to bring into this city coal alleged to have been stolen from anthracite mines in Pennsylvania, Aug. 6.

Charges that officers and members of the crew of the North German Lloyd liner Bremen beat paricipants in the anti-Nazi demonstration aboard the liner last Friday night were made yesterday by two newspaper reporters who covered the sailing of the vessel.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- Boston and St. Louis divided a double header here today, the Browns taking the first game 8 -- 1 behind a barrage of fifteen hits for twenty-three bases, and the Red Sox winning the second, 2 -- 1.
Leases and buildings in Manhattan for restaurant purposes and sales of fiats and dwellings in Brooklyn featured the realty market in the city yesterday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 28. -- Governor Landon's speech at Buffalo Wednesday night was attacked by Senator Robinson in a speech tonight as the "most confused and confusing dissertation on the vital subject of taxation which the public has heard in recent years."

LINDEN, N.J., Aug. 28. -- An attractive tax rate, $2.92 this year, one of the lowest of any city of its size in the country, was seen today by city officials here as the major factor in the decision of the General Motors Corporation to choose Linden as a site for a $5,575,000 assembly plant, plans for which were revealed yesterday by the corporation.

Mayor La Guardia threatened yesterday to bring about the revocation of the licenses of the 2,000 new cabs of the Sunshine taxicab fleet unless there is a "noticeable reduction" in the din of their horns over the week-end.

July sales of reporting wholesale firms in this district averaged 31 per cent higher than last year, the largest increase since March, 1934, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Sales of department stores in the metropolitan area for the first half of August, as previously reported, were 6.8 per cent higher, following a rise of 17.1 per cent in July.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Aug. 29. -- Both the Chinese and the Japanese authorities acted yesterday to obtain fuller details of the killing of two Japanese newspaper men and the wounding of two other Japanese by a Chinese mob at Chengtu Monday. More direct reliable information is needed for a determination of the policies of the two nations in the newest incident to strain Chino-Japanese relations.

DRUMHELLER, Alberta., Aug. 28 (AP). -- William Gallacher, Communist member of the British Parliament, told the Canadian Press today that he was "greatly disappointed'' by the State Department's refusal to permit him to enter the United States because of his political beliefs.

Kansas, home State of Governor Landon, was claimed for President Roosevelt yesterday by State leaders who visited Democratic National Chairman James A. Farley. They insisted that Governor Landon would not get a majority in his own Congressional district.

Tomorrow will mark the official end of the Summer season in the churches. Numerous edifices where special visiting preachers have been occupying the pulpit will have the concluding guest service tomorrow. Assistants will do the preaching until the last Sunday of September in a few of the leading churches in mid-Manhattan.

BIRIATOU, France, Saturday, Aug. 29. -- After three days of fighting for Irun during which they failed to break the government's lines, Spanish insurgents launched a new attack late last evening. The onslaught was preceded by a heavy artillery barrage, but the Basque defenders, in their sandbagged redoubts, were holding out early today with grim tenacity.

PARIS, Aug. 28. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister, had another interview with Premier Leon Blum this morning at the Hotel Matignon before he left for Berlin. He expressed great satisfaction with his visit.

Trading was quiet and uneventful as a rule yesterday in the local commodity futures markets, with changes slight in either direction. Silk improved and hides eased moderately, with other staples erratic. In the cash markets, oats advanced while cotton, wheat, rye, corn, flour, lard, butter, printcloths and tins eased.

The General Motors Company will build one of the largest automobile assembly plants in the world at Linden, N.J. The plant will represent an outlay of about $5,575,000. The Packard Motor Car Company announces that it is completing the expenditure of $5,100,000 for the doubling of the productive capacity of its plants.

Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, organization candidate for the Democratic nomination for judge of General Sessions, cited Governor Lehman yesterday as a witness to his qualifications. He spoke at a luncheon in his honor by a committee of the textile-apparel industry at the Hotel New Yorker.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 28. -- Rain in the morning interfered with the program of small-bore matches of the Junior Rifle Corps today, causing a late finish.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Farmers' cash income in July was $735,000,000, the largest for any month since 1929, the Department of Agriculture reported today. Sales of farm products alone brought $711,000,000, as compared with only $451,000,000 in July, 1935, and $582,000,000 in June, 1936.

NEWPORT, R,I., Aug. 28. -- Beachmound, the Summer home of Mrs. Skirvin Adams, was the center of social activity tonight, when Mrs. Adams entertained with a large dinner dance amid a striking floral and electrical setting. It was the first of two major parties arranged for the present week-end, the other to be given at Hopedene, the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel P. Hill, for a dance tomorrow night.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- In a pastoral letter to be read from all Catholic pulpits in Germany Sunday the hard-pressed Catholic Church joins the National Socialist regime in its public fight against bolshevism. But at the same time the church also turns the tables on the regime by inveighing against the "religious Bolshevist" within the National Socialist ranks who favors neo-pagan mysticism, an oppressed Christian church, and thus opens the way for bolshevism in Germany.

The Citizens Budget Commission, in a statement issued yesterday by Henry J. Amy, its executive director, branded as untrue Mayor La Guardia's assertion that he gave the commission permission to make public a letter he wrote the civic body a few days ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 28. -- Science may be able in the future to sterilize the air just as milk and water are now purified, Dr. Philip Drinker of the Harvard School of Public Health asserted today in the final session of the health conference at the school.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- A mild rally in the market for hogs here today lifted prices 5 to 10 cents a hundred-weight above yesterday's quotations, with 200 to 275-pound averages showing the most strength. Reports of a slow demand for fresh pork failed to affect the market owing to the small offerings.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Illinois joined today in urging the Supreme Court to rehear the case in which the New York minimum wage law for women was declared unconstitutional in June on a five-to-four division.

Secretary ICKES made a speech over the radio on Thursday night, in which he said that the control over Governer LANDON exercised by Mr. WILLIAM RANDOLPH HEARST might easily become the paramount issue in this campaign. This address had the appearance of having been prepared a week or ten days earlier and, although intervening events had taken the heart out of it.

When life in America has been taken thoroughly in hand, will a baseball team be permitted to run up a string of fifteen victories? The winning streak has been known to go as high as twenty games in a row.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, predicted at headquarters here today that the Landon-Knox ticket would win from 225 to 230 electoral votes east of the Mississippi in the November election.

Thirty sailors from the Japanese naval training ships Iwate and Yakumo met some of their Americanized fellow-countrymen yesterday afternoon on ground that was common to both and to almost all male representatives of the Japanese Empire.

Vera Hurst, an English actress who came here nearly nine years ago and has since played supporting roles in a number of Broadway productions, sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Laconia under the watchful eyes of an immigration agent.

A businesslike James Cagney hastened into Hollywood Thursday night, after a vacation at Martha's Vineyard, and yesterday conferred with his producer, Douglas MacLean, over "Great Guy," the first picture scheduled for him at Grand National.

A flood of reports, analyses and recommendations, most of them favoring adoption of the rapid transit unification plan prepared by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., will be submitted to the Transit Commission by the time it begins public hearings on the plan on Sept. 10.

Note a remarkable conversion in New Hampshire. That veteran joker and fleerer, Mr. GEORGE H. MOSES, has sworn off "wisecracking." The man who drove him to this late repentance is Governor BRIDGES, his opponent for the Republican nomination for Senator. Forgetting the fruit of his past transgressions, Mr. MOSES began his campaign in his usual way.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Byron Nelson, former Texan, who won the metropolitan open this Spring, took a commanding lead in the Glens Falls open today when he equaled the course record with a 66.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Superior Judge Walter T. Stanton ruled today that the bulk of a $660,310 surplus from a trust fund created by Marshall Field when he died in 1906 must go to sixty-seven American heirs of the Chicago merchant.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 28 -- Scoring 10 points each out of a possible 14, Mikkail Botwinnik of Leningrad, Soviet chess champion, and Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world champion, today wound up in a tie for first place in the international tournament which was concluded tonight.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 29 (AP). -- -- Hundreds of persons died in a typhoon which swept across the China Sea and ravaged the southeastern provinces of Korea, it was disclosed today. The cyclonic winds, reports said, whirled through Korea Thursday and yesterday.

Flanked by an agreeably large weekday gathering of 24,000 spectators at the Stadium yesterday, the Yankees felt constrained to advance a couple of more specific reasons why they soon are to succeed the tottering Tigers as champions of the American League.
Housing purchases featqared the Westehester realty deals reported yesterday.

Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, warned last night in a radio address broadcast on a nation-wide hook-up that the shadow of war hung over the world, declared that growing Fascist forces constituted the most serious menace to peace, and demanded that the United States "come out actively against the present Fascist intervention in Spain."
SEATTLE, Aug. 28. -- The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, through W.V. Tanner, resident publisher, rejected a "truce meeting" offer today by the American Newspaper Guild to end the fifteen-day-old strike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The long stride that the railroads of the country have taken as a result of improved economic conditions was emphasized sharply today in a survey by the Association of American Railroads which showed that 113 Class I rail carriers in July, had a net railway operating income of $61,133,129, compared with $26,706,708 in the same month one year ago, an increase of about 129 per cent.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- The authorities determination to stamp out "Jew-baiting" in Great Britain was emphasized in Old Street Police Court today when Magistrate F. O. Langley dealt summarily with John Penfold, an auctioneer, 45 years old, who, the police charged, used insulting words at an open-air meeting in the East End of London.

Two men were shot dead early this morning when an automobile in which they were riding was forced to the curb in front of 15 Rutgers Place, on the lowest East Side, by a large touring car containing several men. A barrage of shots rang out and then the gunmen fled, abandoning their car.
Casting, plans and kindred subjects:

After a slow start, retail trade here picked up sharply around the middle of the week. With cooler weather, last-minute response to August sales events in both apparel and furniture lines was brisk. Furs again led with sharp increases as customers placed orders in anticipation of the higher prices predicted later.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28 (AP). -- Sep Palin of Indianapolis drove the winners of four events in the Grand Circuit harness races at State Fair Park today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28. -- The possibility of a protest by the Soviet Government against Norway for providing asylum to Leon Trotsky, on the ground that he has violated his pledge not to engage in political activity, was seen today in violent attacks on the Norwegian Labor party both in Izvestia and Pravda.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- The Boerse was steady and firmish today. Numerous issues were able to recover a small part of the losses suffered in yesterday's slump, which it now appears was due to the realization that action on the devaluation question, discussed in Paris by Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Finance, had been postponed.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 28. -- This resort's annual baby parade was held today before 20,000 spectators, with 250 children in the line of march.

A statement by James Casey, managing editor of The Daily Worker, resigning that post, resigning from the Communist party and denouncing the Presidential campaign tactics of the Communists as "hypocritical," was delivered to newspaper offices last night.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Aug. 28 (Canadian Press). -- The Alberta Social Credit House Bill formulated by the government for implementation of social security principles in the Province passed second reading today and was moved through committee of the whole in the Legislature.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Governor Landon will make a campaign tour in the Middle West in September and another swing through the East in October, it was announced here today by John D.M. Hamilton, national chairman.

TOKYO, Aug. 28 (AP). -- Japan's War, Navy and Foreign Ministers conferred tonight on the newest troublesome Chino-Japanese incident. The Domei News Agency reported they agreed the Tokyo government must "deal sternly" with China.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Cardinals dropped with a thud into third place today as the last-place Phillies blanked them, 8 to 0, for the sixth consecutive setback and the second straight shut-out for the Gashouse Gang.

Recovering from the lag of the two weeks preceding, retail demand turned stronger in many sections of the country this week, and, in spite of the further decline in many of the drought-affected areas, sales were estimated at 12 to 15 per cent larger than in the corresponding period last year, according to the trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

As was natural after the sharp recovery of prices on Thursday, the stock market had to contend with not a little profit-taking yesterday, mainly in the industrials. But the demand was about equal to the occasion and the list closed irregularly higher.

Asserting that the Federal Court of Appeals did not make its meaning clear in a recent unanimous opinion that apparently would send thousands of probationers back to jail, United States Attorney Lamar Hardy sought yesterday to have the court reverse itself or give a clarifying opinion.

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan's three-week delay in completing the Drukman murder case evidence before the April, 1935, grand jury was upheld today by Governor Lehman, who said that he might have criticized Mr. Geoghan if he had finished the case in two days, as the special grand jury suggested he might have done.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 28. -- Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn, the defending titleholders, and Donald Budge and Gene Mako, American Davis Cup combination, advanced to the final of the national doubles tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club today and will meet tomorrow at 2 P.M., as they did a year ago.

Governor Alfred M. Landon comes out a winner with a substantial lead over President Roosevelt in first returns from a straw vote now being conducted in rural sections by some 3,000 small-town newspapers in cooperation with the American Press and the Publishers Auto-caster Service.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (Canadian Press). -- After a lapse of sixty-two years Derbyshire won the English county cricket championship today. Although defeated by Somerset by one wicket at Wells, the midland county emerged victorious in the competition, as Yorkshire, its rival, was held to a first innings' decision by Sussex.

The new stadium at Randalls Island will be the scene of two of the services of the national convention of the Holy Name Society which will be held in this city Sept. 17-20. A "solemn holy hour" will be held at 9 P.M. on Friday, Sept. 18. A rally of men will be held at 2 P.M. on Sunday, Sept. 20, and it has been estimated that 250,000 men will be present.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Watching the next to the last day's racing events at this resort today were many new visitors, including Owen D. Young, Bernard M. Baruch Sr., Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Stone, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Feigenspan, Mrs. Morgan Cowperthwaite, Mr. and Mrs. Burton H. Jackson, Mr. and Mrs. W. Deering Howe and Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Jackson, all of New York.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28. -- Colonel Bill Terry came off the coaching line at first base today in a dramatic fourteen-inning struggle with the Pirates at Forbes Field and by the power of his bat raised the Giant victory string to fifteen straight.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28. -- The 999-year leases of the companies underlying the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company are upheld as valid in a report filed today in the United States District Court by David Bachman, special master in the court proceedings aimed at reorganization of this city's transit system.
Labor organizations merit profound praise for the opportunity that they afforded to athletes to participate in sports events at Randalls Island recently.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 28. -- Governor Landon, who returned to Topeka early this morning, expressed satisfaction over the reception he had on his first campaign trip.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 28. -- Using the same line-up with which they captured the Olympic championship, the Argentine poloists gave ample indication of their power by riding to victory over two of the quartets entered in the open championship in a round-robin on the Meadow Brook Club's No. 2 field today.

OSLO, Aug. 28 (AP). -- Forrest Towns, University of Georgia hurdler who was clocked in the phenomenal time of 13.7 seconds for the 110-meter hurdles yesterday, won his specialty again today in an international track and field meet.

Six crows with varied social backgrounds are en route to the Trailside Museum in Bear Mountain Park, it was announced yesterday by William H. Carr, director of the Trailside Museum. The new arrivals will seek, in some measure, to substitute for Joe, a crow that was killed recently by Napoleon, a weasel.

A young man jumped overboard from the Hudson River excursion steamer Pilgrim last night and disappeared in an effort to rescue his young woman friend, Miss Ann Pollack, 22 years old, of 59 Willow Avenue, Wallington, N.J., who was later saved by members of the steamer's crew.

Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes was characterized yesterday as "chief mudslinger" of the campaign, in comment by Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Landon-Knox campaign manager in the East, on his "Hearst Over Topeka" radio address on Thursday night, in which Secretary Ickes branded the Republican nominee for President as the creature of William Randolph Hearst, and pictured the publisher as the new G.O.P. boss.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- A combination of developments which the trade regarded as decidedly bearish started today a liquidating movement in grains in all pits on the Board of Trade which carried prices off sharply, with corn in the lead.

Being a "dirt" farmer and having given considerable thought to the question of crop insurance long before the question was raised publicly by Secretary Wallace. I will answer some of the baffling questions raised in your editorial "Crop Insurance."

THE door was opened by Mickey (Himself) Cochrane. He was in his shirt sleeves. Black Mike looked a bit thin, but he seemed in better shape than when he was here last. In addition to other woes at that time he had an infected left eye. This time his eyes were clear.

The committee in charge of the 1940 Olympic Games should make it a special point to arrange the schedule of events in such a way that no nation can claim to have won them except the nation that actually has won them.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 28. -T. Jefferson Coolidge, Boston banker, who was Under-Secretary of the Treasury for two years in this administration, announced today that he would support Governor Landon for President. He indicated that he did not expect to take an active part in the campaign.

Counsel for the Associated Gas and Electric interests and for the National Public Service Corporation debenture holders' protective committee have signed a stipulation whereby the scheduled auction of collateral securing the debentures has been postponed from Sept. 10 to Sept. 28 and whereby the Associated interests have deferred action on their petition in Federal court to restrain the auction and for approval of a reorganization plan under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act.

New financing has been scheduled for next week by one State and sixty-one municipalities for an aggregate of $69,193,560, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. It compares with a revised total of only $23,808,291 for the week ended today and with a weekly average of $23,541,655 for this year to date.

The Italian liner Roma will sail today for Mediterranean ports. The passenger list includes Lincoln MacVeagh, United States Minister to Greece; Mr. and Mrs. M. Martin Berard, Mr. and Mrs. Fausto Cleva, Mr. and Mrs. Axel Sahlin, Professor Enrico Fermi, Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Oliver, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wose and Mrs. William H. Andrews.

ON BOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL EN ROUTE TO PIERRE, S.D., Aug. 28. -- Two long automobile rides today through sections called typical of the great plains drought area gave President Roosevelt an excellent view of both the ravages of the weather and the steps which are being taken by government agencies to alleviate suffering.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28. -- Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., went into the lead in the open championship tournament of the American Chess Federation tonight when he drew his game in the ninth round with Isaac I. Kashdan, New York State champion.

Officials of the New York Curb Exchange indicated yesterday that they would not oppose the plea of a local over-the-counter house to the Securities and Exchange Commission to remove from the Curb's unlisted trading division two inactive securities.

RATS, lice and Dr. Victor Heiser make up the subject-matter of the current Book-of-the-Month Club selection, "An American Doctor's Odyssey" (Norton, $3.50). There have been better medical memoirs in our day, and worse, but no others of exactly the same kind. It is not quite required reading, but sufficiently amusing, instructive and annoying to be worth your attention.

Mayor La Guardia volunteered yesterday to go before the Kings County Grand Jury and explain why street conditions in the city are unsatisfactory. It was to this grand jury on Thursday that County Judge Franklin Taylor expressed the opinion that Brooklyn is the "dirtiest borough in the city."

OSLO, Norway, Aug, 28. -- Leon Trotsky refused today to accept more stringent conditions laid down by the Norwegian Department of Justice for his continued stay in Norway after the recent Moscow trial. Following a conference at which Mr. Trotsky was present, the department thereupon decided that he and his wife should immediately be interned and that his two secretaries should leave the country.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 28 (AP). -- In two of the hardest fought matches of the thirty-sixth annual women's Western closed golf tournament Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco and Miss Beatrice Barrett of Minneapolis today reached the final, Miss Traung firing a bombshell with her victory over the defending champion, Miss Marion Miley.

WARSAW, Poland, Aug. 28. -Gen- ] eral Edward lydz-Smigly, InspecJ tot General of the Polish Army [virtual dictator of Poland], left Warsaw for Paris this afternoon accompanied by the chief of the general staff and other high-ranking officers.
A further increase to farmers in the price of milk, which would be passed on to consumers, was indicated yesterday at a meeting of the board of the Greater New York-New Jersey Milk Institute.

Preliminary steps to revise the buying, selling and credit practices of the jewelry industry, through an optional deferred payment plan for both wholesalers and retailers, were taken yesterday at the final session of the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, when a resolution was passed empowering William D. McNeil, re-elected president for the fifth time, to appoint a committee to study the plan.

Leaders of the rank and file group of members of the Marine Firemen, Oilers and Watertenders Union scored yesterday in their contest with officials who recently were ousted in a general election and who refused to recognize the successful candidates as their successors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today extended from Oct. 1 until Dec. 1 the date on which seven Class I rail carriers serving the Port of New York are obliged to observe an order of June 8 to discontinue the supplying of insurance, storage space and services for handling goods in warehouses at rates which do not fully compensate them.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- Saratoga's long race meeting will come to an end tomorrow with the running of the $40,000 Hopeful Stakes and a two-horse race which to many is comparable to that between Zev and Papyrus in 1923.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- The Labor party and trade union leaders, at a joint conference behind closed doors today, reluctantly approved the policy of non-intervention in Spain as the only expedient for preventing the precipitation of a general European war by the dictators of Germany, Italy and Portugal.

The polo season starts today on the climax events of 1936 with the first game of the national open championship. It will be held on famous International Field at the Meadow Brook Club, beginning at 4 o'clock. Drawn together in this match are Greentree and Aurora, the teams which fought it out in the final round last year, Greentree winning after a full period of extra play.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 28. -- The main column of General Francisco Franco's Rebel army, fighting its way toward Madrid from the south, scored a signal victory today over Loyalist forces at Calgado de Oropesa. just east of Talavera and about eighty-five miles from Madrid.

SEATTLE, Aug. 28. -- Mayor John F. Dore explained today why he did not provide police protection for union mechanical employes to pas through the picket line around the building of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer.

That elaborate premiere on Tuesday evening of the gilt-edged "Folies d'Amour," fourth in the French Casino's series of spectacular revues, made it perfectly apparent that the management of this extraordinary theatre-restaurant is determined to outdo itself with each successive new show.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28. -- A warning that Chancellor Adolf Hitler was preparing events that would bring Europe closer to "slaughter" was published simultaneously tonight in newspapers of the Soviet Government and the Communist party.

YOSEMITE, Aug. 28. -- An appeal to the United States to drop isolation and come into a world system of collective security was made today by A.V. Alexander, member of Parliament and former First Lord of the British Admiralty.

A quantity of narcotics and devices used in their consumption, which were seized by the police during the last year in the five boroughs, were burned yesterday morning at a vacant lot at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn. The collection had an "underworld retail value" of $300,000, according to the police.
