The polo season starts today on the climax events of 1936 with the first game of the national open championship. It will be held on famous International Field at the Meadow Brook Club, beginning at 4 o'clock. Drawn together in this match are Greentree and Aurora, the teams which fought it out in the final round last year, Greentree winning after a full period of extra play.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 28. -- The main column of General Francisco Franco's Rebel army, fighting its way toward Madrid from the south, scored a signal victory today over Loyalist forces at Calgado de Oropesa. just east of Talavera and about eighty-five miles from Madrid.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28. -- A warning that Chancellor Adolf Hitler was preparing events that would bring Europe closer to "slaughter" was published simultaneously tonight in newspapers of the Soviet Government and the Communist party.

YOSEMITE, Aug. 28. -- An appeal to the United States to drop isolation and come into a world system of collective security was made today by A.V. Alexander, member of Parliament and former First Lord of the British Admiralty.

A quantity of narcotics and devices used in their consumption, which were seized by the police during the last year in the five boroughs, were burned yesterday morning at a vacant lot at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn. The collection had an "underworld retail value" of $300,000, according to the police.

BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 28. -- Fascist Rebel leaders say tonight that, if their forces are victorious, Spain will have first a military dictatorship similar to those in Italy and Germany. Then, if the people express the desire in a plebiscite, their former monarch, Alfonso, will return to the 300-year-old Bourbon throne.

Plans for small homes in Brooklyn and Queens formed the bulk of new construction projects filed in the city by architects yesterday. In Manhattan plans were submitted for a gasoline station in Harlem and various alterations to existing buildings.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 28. -- One of the unique events of the season was held here tonight when Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine gave a large nautical costume supper dance at Valmay Cottage, her home, for Mr. and Mrs. Charles Garfield King of Chicago, who are passing their first Summer in Southampton.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 28. -- Federal Judge George P. Hahn approved today the reorganization of the Willys-Overland Company as advanced by Empire Securities, Inc.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

A client of Nathan A. Goldenthal, attorney, sold to Netter Netter, attorneys, a four-story walk-up flat at 32-86 Thirty-fifth Street, northwest corner of Graham Avenue, Astoria. The structure, built about six years ago, contains three stores and seventeen suites of two to four rooms.

Earlier in the year there were grounds for hoping that at last we had made some progress in reducing the nation's death toll from automobile accidents. But in July, for the third successive month, the fatalities exceeded those for the corresponding period in 1935.

Mr. Landon says: "This is the most cockeyed piece of tax legislation * * *" Is it respectful to the Congress of the United States and the President to refer to their efforts as "cockeyed"? "Cockeyed" used to be funny in vaudeville, but it is a little stale now.

With the Olympic flag flying proudly from aloft, the United States liner President Roosevelt, bringing 199 American athletes back to New York after their great achievements in Berlin, docked early last night. There was hardly a person aboard who did not welcome the sight of American soil again.

Bond prices advanced in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with transactions amounting to $10,862,300, the largest since Aug. 13, compared with $8,878,900 on Thursday. Dealings in domestic corporation issues accounted for $9,916,000 of the total, compared with $7,783,000 the day before, while government securities dealt in amounted to $318,300, against $308,900 on Thursday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y, Aug. 28. -- An international automobile theft ring was believed to have been uncovered today by the police of New York City and Westchester as the result of the arrest of three men.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that B.D. Miller, president and chairman of the executive committee of the F.W. Woolworth Company of New York, received total remuneration of $337,479 in 1934.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 28 (AP). -- Charging an infringement of States' rights, the Kansas City Board of Trade challenged constitutionality of the new Commodity Exchange Act in a suit filed in Federal court here today.
GREENVILLE, Miss., Aug. 28. -- Drought has hit the Mississippi Delta from Yellow Rabbit to Vinegar Bend.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- Virtually without opposition, the American Bar Association at the closing session of its convention here today voted to receive and file both the majority and minority reports of the special committee on the rights of citizens, and to discharge the committee.

Far from declaring a preaching moratorium, laymen and ministers are united in an effort to increase the power of preaching in Protestant churches throughout the land. The plan of what is called the "National Preaching Mission" has been long in the making -- eighteen months of careful preparation.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 28. -- While guests in the fashionable Shoreham Hotel were asleep, a gang of armed men, wearing white masks and white gloves, swarmed into the deserted hotel lobby at 3 o'clock this morning, cowed a lone clerk working behind the desk, cracked open the hotel safe and escaped with nearly $30,000 in jewelry and cash, mostly the property of Summer visitors.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP). -Although outhit by the Senators the White Sox defeated Washington today, 6 to 5, in the first of twogame series.

Governor Landon's address at Chautauqua on the subject of education gave the nation an opportunity to size up the social philosophy of an aspirant for the Presidency. It revealed the social side of the Governor as one who has profound faith in the ultimate destiny of a nation where free education is the basis of enlightened citizenship.

Stefan Zweig has what might be described as a double-biography on the Viking Press Fall list. The title is, "The Right to Heresy," and it concerns Calvin and his antagonist, Castellio, and takes for its theme the eternal conflict between authority and liberty, dogmatism and tolerance.

It is curious that in all the controversy about the legality of minimum-wage laws, little attention has been paid to their economic possibility. As a matter of theory and experience, it is not possible to fix wages by law.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 29 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, attacked President Roosevelt tonight "for giving fanatics, theorists and impractical experimenters power and place in government."

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 28. -- Suit to halt the sale of $20,000,000 to $25,000,000 in stocks in a British utility concern was filed today in the Federal District Court here by four residents of St. Louis against the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, incorporated in Virginia.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 28. (AP). -- Many of the nation's leading men and women non-professional fliers converged on Cleveland today for the Ruth Chatterton Derby to the national air races at Los Angeles.
PARIS, Aug. 28. -- French newspapers quoted Dr. Hjalmar Schacht as offering to settle Germany's quarrels with Soviet Russia if the Communists would abandon "virulent propaganda."

Although the volume of advertising and the number of both publications and American advertising agencies are increasing steadily in South America, conditions surrounding the buying and selling of advertising space are still chaotic, Dermot Fitz Gibbon, advertising director for the Hays Bell Publications, Buenos Aires, declared here yesterday.

The International Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paper-hangers said yesterday that its strike of 12,000 workers was "100 per cent effective" at the same time that the Association of Master Painters announced that at the request of a union representative it had agreed to meet the union in a strike settlement conference at the Hotel Commodore tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock.

GENEVA, Aug. 28. -- Soviet Russia has offered a plan for League of Nations reform whereby the Council by a three-fourths majority of the members present, the disputants excluded, could make a decision on aggression six days after notification of the outbreak of war.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican candidate for the Vice Presidency, has started on a comprehensive tour of New England. He will speak several times in each of the six States, having started with his old home State, New Hampshire.

The familiar saying, "It's a poor rule that does not work both ways," has no place in the application of revenue laws. Such laws, and particularly those of income taxation, need be neither consistent nor logical. On the other hand, doubtful statutory provisions are not generally construed against the taxpayer; nor are provisions adverse to the taxpayer extended by implication.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- In a letter to counsel for the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad today, Director Sweet of the Bureau of Finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission stated that in the present proceedings for reorganization and consolidation of the system it would be necessary for three of the roads involved to make applications for consolidation to the commission.
The contributions to science and industry made by Dr. C.G. Abbot of the Smithsonian Institution and described in THE TIMES may warrant a short history of the solar engine.

While the deadlock created by recent events has been broken, there is no present assurance that our trade with Germany will be improved as a result of the arrangements entered into by the administration, according to the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., yesterday.

On all sides today we hear of the necessity of respecting and upholding the Constitution. All of us believe in the Constitution. None of us favor its violation. That, I believe, is so axiomatic among Americans as to require no declaration.

A YEAR ago there were in Europe only two great powers which were also colonial powers worthy of the name: Great Britain and France. With the Fascist conquest of Ethiopia the colonial balance has been rudely disrupted. England and France may still possess the world's greatest colonial empires, but they are no longer in a class by themselves.

PINE ORCHARD, Conn., Aug. 29. -- More than 500 members of the East Shore Summer colonies attended a special entertainment entitled "Une Nuit a Paris" tonight in the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club. The clubhouse was converted into a Parisian setting.

Widespread reports in the primary market last week that numerous cotton mills were adding a third shift were scouted here yesterday by association officials, who declared that only a few "isolated" cases have developed because of the pressure of emergency orders.

Bond prices advanced yesterday under the continued leadership of United States Government securities in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Transactions involved $5,208,200 of bonds, compared with $3,567,000 on the previous Saturday, but domestic corporation issues accounted for $4,717,000 of the total, dealings in "governments" being the smallest for any Saturday in the last month, at $163,200, compared with $286,000 the week before.

Last Thursday was the eighth anniversary of the signing of the Briand-Kellogg Peace Pact by the leading nations of the earth. There was, however, no celebration of an event that today serves as a sad reminder of the high hopes in which this covenant was conceived and ratified.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell handed down an opinion yesterday fixing $90,000 as the fee for services rendered by Rosenberg, Goldmark Colin as attorneys for the Irving Trust Company. trustee for International Match Corporation, during 1935.

ALTHOUGH daily newspapers and weekly journals are filled with the clatter of international acrimony, London is soothing her Summer evenings with no less than thirty plays and shows. We are happy in New York when the Winter season can muster that many.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 29. -- Small-bore shooters in the junior rifle corps match today found a stiff west wind over the ranges a hard proposition, but they pounded in the bullets for good scores over the four courses, with Hilary Brown, the 15-year-old Louisville lad winning the national junior championship with 348 out of a possible 400.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 29. -- Unless unforeseen circumstances arise between tonight and 10 o'clock tomorrow morning, an Arab High Committee meeting then will accept the intervention of General Nuri Pasha as-Said, Iraqi Foreign Minister, for a settlement of the present deadlock between the Palestine Arabs and the Palestine Government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29. -- The revival of Portland, Ore., as a wheat exporting center was indicated today with the announcement that for the first time in several years the commodity is beginning to move to Europe across the Columbia River terminals.

OF the many good regional novels produced in recent years, the Southern mountains have provided a surprising number. There is something in the beauty and isolation of the setting, in its traditional lawlessness, in the archaic speech and customs of its people, which makes it an excellent background for romance -- for romance of passion and violence on the one hand, or of poetic imagination on the other.

A short story about some of the "screwy" aspects of the theatrical business, "Hell Cat" successfully portrays the stress and strain an author undergoes between beginning of rehearsals and opening night. Minor mishaps are disregarded.

TAMMANY is passing through one of its periodic upheavals. Shorn of much or its power and deprived of its life-blood -- patronage -- this oldest of American political organizations moves into the Presidential campaign with divided ranks. And, what is more important from the Tammany point of view, there looms in the distance the Mayoralty contest of 1937.

THE management of the Philadelphia Orchestra announces that Paul Whiteman will be the only guest conductor with that organization during the regular concert season of 1936-37. Mr. Whiteman has officiated in the capacity of guest conductor at concerts given by the men of the Philadelphia Orchestra in Robin Hood Dell.
TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 29. -- F.P. Schoettle Jr.'s Class A catboat Lotus of the Island Heights Yacht Club today captured the historic Toms River challenge cup for the third year in a row.
FORT SAM HOUSTON, Texas, Aug. 29. -- A realistic war game that will test the preparedness of the army to repel a hostile invasion of our southern shores is about to begin at San Antonio.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- On Sept. 14 the American and Canadian members of the International Joint Commission, with engineers assigned by the two governments, will begin a week's survey of the practicability of deepening and widening the waterway from Montreal to New York, and making it available to ocean vessels.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Back to Moriches Bay came the fleet of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach today to sail the final race of the August series off the Speonic shore. More than, forty craft competed.

OMAHA, Aug. 28. -- The uncertainty over what Senator George W. Norris will do about seeking re-election and the anxiety to help him make up his mind have resulted in something like the old game played with a daisy. Some one is continually plucking a petal from the Senator and changing the political equivalent of "he loves me," or "he loves me not."

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The Boston Bees landed on Charley Root for five runs in the sixth inning today to defeat the Cubs, 6 to 4, and snap the National League champions' winning streak at six straight.
Two weeks ago Bernard Baruch gave an interview in which he summarized the economic conditions abroad, ending with these sentences:

Detectives do not, as a rule, like a cold trail. Yet here is one that is many months old. A rich young sportsman has disappeared, and two New York newspaper men undertake to find out what has become of him. The last record of him that has been found is that he gave a poker party in a Havana hotel.

After an all-day investigation detectives declared last night that the shooting of two men in Rutgers Place on the Lower East Side early yesterday morning had no connection with "an organized loan shark racket."

IN THE TIMES of last Sunday Werner Janssen, the conductor and composer, gave the public some interesting and suggestive information about the music he is composing for the screen production of "The General Dies at Dawn": interesting because of the glimpses his statements afforded of what is going on in the way of music in the cinema studio today, and highly suggestive because he shows how seriously moving-picture producers are now taking the composer.

RATHER spotty trade results were again discerned through the country last week. Hot weather held down sales in some sections, as emphasized in the drought districts, and there was apparent in others the lull before Labor Day.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- Preparations have started at the Lake Placid Club for the thirty-fourth annual Indian Council Fire, which will be presented by club members and guests on Friday evening. A cast of about 120 men, women and children will take part.

EVIDENCE accumulates that research is taking much of the uncertainty out of lawn making and lawn maintenance. Soil scientists have discovered new treatments for insuring better turf production. Chemists have made similar progress with fertilizers.

Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company, last night offered the Schubert production of Sigmund Romberg's work. "Blossom Time," as his final operetta presentation on the new gigantic stage on Randall's Island. The uncertain weather and the light rain which fell just before the opening act kept the attendance down to a small number.

HIMSELF a wealthy Wall Street man, of formidable reputation in the once unregulated stock market, Joseph P. Kennedy is equipped to judge the merits of that remarkable hatred which Big Business and Finance displays toward President Roosevelt and the New Deal.

WITH the Summer Philharmonic-Symphony concerts and Goldman Band off the air, the katydids singing and the praying mantises swarming into New York, the broadcasters have plenty of warning that the "ether's" entertainment ship will soon be out of the doldrums.

Entries already received by the National Skeet Shooting Association indicate that close to a capacity list of 300 clay target stars will be on hand to compete in the second annual national championships at St. Louis Sept. 15 to 19.

IN the pioneer days of automobiling, motorists expected to find themselves stranded on the road from time to time and were banded in a brotherhood of first-aid reciprocity. The driver of any car would stop and tow any disabled machine he happened to meet because he could never tell when he would need some one to pull him in.
EL CENTRO, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP). -- The Imperial Valley, famous for its early crops of lettuce, melons and vegetables, believes in training its law enforcement officers young.

Scenting trouble from afar, Robin Bishop comes to Morgantown in the San Joaquin Valley, California, just in time to be in on a murder case. Since Bishop is a reporter, that is all to the good. He is able to send his paper an exclusive story to the effect that Dr. Morgan has been killed, apparently by a stray shot fired during a clash between striking peach pickers and farmers.

THE name of Charles Stedman Macfarland is one that has been writ large in American religious annals over the past fifty years. Now retired at the age of 70 as General Secretary Emeritus of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America Dr. Macfarland has given his time to setting down on paper an invaluable record of a life exceptionally devoted to the furtherance of the spiritual and social weal of his fellow-men.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 29. -- Play in the national doubles tennis championships was washed out by rain today at the Longwood Cricket Club and the finals were postponed until Monday by President Irving C. Wright, the referee.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29. -- The Giants' winning streak came to an end today. After capturing fifteen in a row, equaling the major league record for the season, Colonel Bill Terry's men bowed to the Pirates, 7 to 4, at Forbes Field, where on July 15 they started the sensational drive that carried them to the fore in the National League pennant race.

NOW for it! All the baseball drama of this week will be concentrated in the five-day battle on the western front as the Giants move in to attack the Cubs and Cardinals in turn, starting with the double-header at Wrigley Field today -- weather permitting.

Again we meet Peter Clancy and his faithful factotum, Wiggar. The word factotum must have been coined to describe just such a man as Wiggar, who literally does just about everything that his master could possibly require of him. He is a valet, a chauffeur and occasionally he helps out Clancy with his sleuthing.

THIS scrapbook of a ballet enthusiast is a very pretty picture book, of which the most noticeable feature is its omissions; in other words, the limitations of its subject. Mr. Haskell apparently collects his ballet photographs almost entirely from the de Basil company.

JULIAN DUGUID is the Britisher who turned from school teaching in England to exploration in Bolivia, whence he emerged with a manuscript which became a travel-book sensation of its season -- "Green Hell." This was followed by "Tiger Man," exploiting much the same material.
PIERRE, S.D., Aug. 29. -- When Governor Berry introduced Mr. Roosevelt today as "our friend and our President" the crowd cheered and applauded.

Although the European situation is a dangerous one and likely to involve all nations in disaster, the armament race need not necessarily lead to war, according to Sir Keith Murdoch, Australian newspaper publisher, who arrived here yesterday from Canada after a five-month visit to Spain, France, Germany, Austria and England.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- A 50 per cent drop in the new demand for WPA drought-relief jobs was reported today as a result of rains, which the Weather Bureau said had made a "big dent" in the dry area.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 29 (AP). -- The New York State Fair, show window for the Empire State's farmers and tradesmen, will open Sunday, Sept. 6, when Governor Lehman presses a telegraph key at Albany and sends the week-long event off on its ninety-sixth annual exhibition.

The estate of the late John F. Galvin, former chairman of the Port of New York Authority, was bequeathed to his immediate family, according to his will filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court. The estate was valued at "more than $10,000." Mr. Galvin, who at his death was director of the New York Port Development, died on July 16.

IT is a commonplace observation that our weary business man will regale himself with detective thrillers and the timid commuter will spend his half hours absorbed in tales of murder and arson. That our good, law-abiding citizens will turn to crime and find fascination in the lurid accounts of offenders against society who are usually cast in heroic roles, is evidence of one of the milder human aberration.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The race for honors in the annual Glens Falls open golf tournament tightened up today as Byron Nelson, the former Texan, failed to maintain his record-tying pace and surrendered his lead to Jimmy Hines, Long Island siege gun.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 (AP) . -- Soviet workmen tonight prepared to forego their day of rest in order to gear their machines and lathes for an onslaught on production records to celebrate the first anniversary of the Stakhanoffite movement next Monday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The first week's skirmishes in District Attorney Geoghan's attempt to vindicate himself before Governor Lehman of the Drukman case charges appeared today to have given the District Attorney the advantage thus far.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 29 (AP). -- A farmer who used airplane gasoline for a kitchen stove came to the aid of Ruth Chatterton, stage and screen actress, enabling her to accompany thirty-two contestants in the Chatterton cross-country derby as they took off for Louisville late today on the second lap of their flight from Cleveland to the West Coast.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29. -- The Soviet Union has formally requested the Norwegian Government to expel Leon Trotsky on the grounds he has fomented terroristic conspiracies and acts, including the assassination of Sergei M. Kiroff, while enjoying asylum in Norway.

TIME was when a trip to the South from the hopeful Middle West, with its booming towns, its twelve-foot corn, its wide grain fields and its alfalfa stands that almost buried fat swine, was a trip from mechanized, up-to-date agriculture to a decadent one-crop system with almost unlimited social and economic problems.

MISS SIMON has uncovered a rich vein Of Americana in her stories of Arkansas life, and she has invested her material with a reality and an understanding winch stems from intimate association with her people.

FOR a long time it has been the producers who practically set their own terms for the leasing or renting of theatres, this being a business that travels in petulant cycles. But just now a number of managers are heading their shows for what seems to be a lot of simultaneous openings, and it is the showshop owners' turn to laugh and raise the ante.

THE sunflower -- State flower of Kansas -- has achieved a new distinction this year. It has become a political emblem, and it is blossoming in the lapels of thousands of Landon followers. It burst into bloom at the Republican National Convention at Cleveland, and when Governor Landon was notified of his nomination at Topeka sunflowers were scattered before the feet of the marchers.

Conditions in the shipping industry are generally better than they were a year ago and there are many indications that improvement will continue, according to operators of foreign as well as American tonnage.

Jane Morton was a good sport and a girl with a mind of her own. She loved Jimmy Halyard, but decided that he was headed for drink and destruction unless something was done about his case. His budding abilities as an architect were completely overshadowed by his father's success in business and his mother's fame as a sculptress.

EVERYBODY, sighs Clarence Webster, has written about the New England Puritans. But that does not mean that he himself has written just another book. Far from it! This author's mood is thoroughly iconoclastic. His purpose is to destroy the image created by -- well, by a great many writers, and to substitute a rounded portrait of the New England country people as he has known them all his life.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- There has been much speculation regarding the ceremonial robes to be worn at King Edward's coronation, and the first instructions issued by the Earl Marshal this week announce that peers and peeresses are to wear the full coronation robes of their degrees but that peeresses will not wear coronets, as on previous occasions, but only tiaras.

NOW that the Summer is presumably melting into the golden haze of Autumn and September is rearing its head, most of those rural playshops which manifested themselves about the country this season in numbers practically comparable to the seventeen-year locusts and weeds have -- or are -- prepared to pull their signs down, put up the shutters and call quits for another year.

Two Dorothy Sayers stories for the price of one make a real bargain, even though both of the stories have previously been published as separate volumes. "Strong Poison" is the novel in which Lord Peter Wimsey first meets Harriet Vane and saves her from the gallows by proving that some one else committed the murder for which she is being tried.

PARIS, Aug. 28. -- Another week of civil war in Spain has gone by and there is still no clear indication as to which side will win. On most of the fourteen different "fronts" it has been the insurgents who have taken the offensive, but they have nothing tangible to show for all their effort.

Mayor La Guardia delivered another barrage against county offices yesterday when he made public a report by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, holding that the city could save $310,000 a year by reorganizing the offices of Register and Commissioner of Records in four boroughs.

COMPLETELY unpretentious, a light novel if ever there was one, "Miss Linsey and Pa" is as witty and casually discursive as all Stella Gibbons's books. Since "Cold Comfort Farm" -- that priceless travesty of the sodden rural epic -- Miss Gibbons has not again attempted parody-burlesque.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- The struggle of a militant German Protestantism for untrammeled freedom of worship and complete emancipation from State intervention continues to present those blurred outlines that have marked its progress since the rebellion of a handful of fighting parsons three years ago expanded to include the Confessional Church.

Lincoln MacVeagh, United States Minister to Greece, sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Rome for his post in Athens to resume in addition to his official duties some lay observation of the place of a language in the destiny of a nation.

"SPLENDID! This is fine," was President Roosevelt's comment upon the three and a half acres of gardens at the Great Lakes Exposition during his recent visit to Cleveland. A special observation platform, with a runway for the President's car leading up to it, enabled him and his party, which included Governor Martin L. Davey, to get a birds-eye view of the extensive horticultural displays.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Copley Thaw gave a dinner tonight at Windbreak, their place on the ocean, for Mr. and Mrs. John Magee, who have joined Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. du Pont at Chestertown House for a visit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- New mechanical aids will be available to the American farmer if experiments under way at the Department of Agriculture's farm-tillage machinery laboratory at Auburn, Ala., prove successful. This plant, completed recently with WPA funds, is part of the government's policy to develop more efficient farm machinery.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- After ten rounds of the open championship tournament of the American Chess Federation today, with two matches pending, five of the twelve contestants had a chance for first prize.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Ninety boats sailed today in the Port Washington Yacht Club's regatta, eighteenth in the Y.R.A. championship series, and among the winners were H.C. Taylor's 50-footer Barbara, H.T. von Frankenburg's one-design Twelve Zio, H.H. Anderson's 32-footer Clotho, Donald G. Millar's Interclub Nancy, William and Robert Benson's Victory Blue Jacket, A.P. Davis's Atlantic New Deal and Frank Cambell's Star Rascal.

IT is peach-picking time in the Sacramento Valley. Heat simmers over the valley. The sun burns like hot brass upon the ragged tents of the migratory workers pitched along the roadsides. Babies, stripped, seek patches of shade under the trees where they lie in the dirt.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 29 (AP). -- A religious revival in Spain cheered ailing Pope Pius XI tonight.

THE display of waterlilies at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park, which every Summer attracts many thousands of visitors, is now at its best. The great royal waterlily of the Amazon, the most remarkable specimen in the collection, is in bloom in the aquatic house in the main conservatory.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on the quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

One by one, the old managers round the corner. Joe Bickerton was not old in years, and he was only sporadically a manager, but he represented what was best in a disappearing kind of theatre, and in what may be a disappearing kind of man.

SEATTLE, Aug. 29. -- Organized business, industry and finance in this city are solidly behind William Randolph Hearst in the strike of the American Newspaper Guild which has forced the publisher's morning newspaper. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, to suspend publication since Aug. 13.

Will you permit me to express in your columns, on behalf of his many friends, a few words of appreciation of Gerald McGarrahan, former conductor of the Greenwich Sinfonietta, who died last Saturday. He was one of the original group interested in forming orchestras of unemployed musicians for the benefit of the players themselves and to the great delight of audiences in various parts of the city.

JUST as the redwood is the oldest living tree of the evergreen forests, so is the Joshua tree the oldest living plant of the desert, and it is equally worthy of preservation. Which is one of the reasons why President Roosevelt has just created, by proclamation, the Joshua Tree National Monument of nearly 1,000,000 acres on the Colorado desert of Southern California.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 29. -- From a springy cinder track Jesse Owens, the Buckeye Bullet, set out today for the glare of the footlights as a professional entertainer.

THIS is a chatty travel book about Hungary with short side-trips to "Upper Hungary," now part of Czechoslovakia' and to Transylvania, now belonging to Rumania. Miss Humphrey makes no attempt to penetrate the surface, to probe into the underlying causes of the Hungarian problem, or to analyze Magyar nature on anything but a purely subjective basis.

Premier Blum's efforts to obtain a European non-intervention pact in the case of the Spanish civil war and the differing opinions of various governments present the interesting question, "What are the applicable principles of international law in the Spanish situation in the absence of a non-intervention pact?"

Hedge selling, which is likely to be a feature of Saturday trading at this season of the year, caused another decline in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. All months went into new low ground and ended at the bottom with losses of 5 to 8 points.

HERE is another story about Hank Hyer, the tough detective who appeared in "Murder of a Dead Man" and "Murder for What?" Although the story deals with the murder of a college professor, there is an underworld tie-up that is right up Hyer's alley.

The winning of Ohio's electoral votes by Governor Alfred M. Landon was predicted yesterday by Mrs. Katherine K. Brown of Cleveland, Republican National Committeewoman, during a visit to Miss Natalie Couch, director of the women's division of the Eastern campaign being conducted by the Republican National Committee.
MOSCOW, Aug. 29. -- The Soviet governement, demanding the expulsion of Leon Trotsky from Norway, started tonight to clean its own house of counter-revolutionaries.

A thousand and one matters are bothering yachtsmen. They are asking themselves when and, above all, how will they haul out this season. These questions probably give more ammunition for arguments to the rocking chair fleet on club porches than any other phase of boating.

A large gymnasium, a playground covering almost the entire roof space, special classrooms and an exercise room for crippled pupils, and an auditorium to seat 549 persons are among the features of the new Public School 68 to be erected in West 127th and 128th Streets, between Lenox and Seventh Avenues, according to plans for the structure announced last night by the Board of Education.

Trouble is much too mild a word for what happens at Glaye Castle, near the Welsh border, from the day when Adam Damarel and Denne Hereford pay it an unexpected visit to the night when all its dreadful secrets are unmasked. The castle is very ancient and is honeycombed with secret passages, some of which are unknown even to the surviving members of the family whose home it has been for hundreds of years.

MADRID, Aug. 29. -- Government officials announced additional victories over the Rebels today. At Castro del Rio, southeast of Cordoba, they said, 300 peasants armed with only six rifles and a few shotguns had driven off a force of 400 Rebels.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug 29 (AP). -- Visualizing a "staggering" Federal indebtedness sixty years hence, Representative Lemke of North Dakota said in an address at a Union party rally tonight:

Over the rugged Pine Valley course which George Crump and H.S. Colt carved out of the sandy wastes and scrub growth at Clementon, N.J., sixteen miles outside of Philadelphia, the Walker Cup international matches will be played on Wednesday and Thursday.
In spite of repeated assurance about a balanced budget -- in October, 1932, after the banking holiday in 1933, in January, 1934, in January, 1935 and in January, 1936, what has happened?

ALTHOUGH one thinks of him as specifically a novelist of the South, DuBose Heyward's new book owes little to its setting. "Lost Morning" tells the familiar, unlocalized story of a middle-aged artist who has sold out to Mammon, and who is forever rationalizing the betrayal of his young dreams.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The Treasury has held that Ignace Jan Paderewski's donation of a statue of former President Wilson to Poland in 1931 was "an estimable gesture," but that he cannot deduct the cost in paying his income tax.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Concerts and performances by unemployed musicians on the rolls of the Works Progress Administration were attended by 20,000,000 persons throughout the nation in the first six months of this year, the WPA announced today.

The big push in yachting will begin this week, and when the spurt is over the season will go into a lingering decline. Three events of national and international importance are crowded into the nine days starting tomorrow, and in between will be the usual week-end fixtures on Long Island Sound.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The annual reward of McMullen Regional Scholarships in Engineering at Cornell University to twenty-four high and preparatory school graduates was announced today by President Farrand.

THE plight of the extras earning from $5 to $15 a day, friction between producers and talent and charges of chiseling, fortified by court action, leveled at some studios by the Screen Actors Guild revealed to the world this week that there is more trouble in Paradise.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- A large gathering of society today saw the Hopeful and last racing in this resort, after a steady rain.

While some spottiness in consumer response was evident in some sections, due to excessive heat, drought and other conditions, the general average of results obtained in August retail sales promotions forecasts substantial Fall trade gains, according to the consensus of merchandising executives and manufacturers here yesterday.

A SHORT time ago people were interested to read of a starling in St. James's Park which had learned to imitate the cry of the kestrel and thereby frightened the sparrows into the bushes. Quite a number of birds occasionally mimic others; this is an account of an instance that came under my notice.

FOR fifty years Vinland and the whole county of Clearwater, of which it was the seat, had lain under the blight of paralysis, the curse of decay. In the beginning the county, at the behest of highly plausible but dishonest promoters who promised a railroad, gave a bonded bonus of $100,000.

TO honor the memory of the famous Belgian violinist Eugene Ysaye, the Queen Elizabeth Musical Foundation, Brussels, Belgium, has instituted an international contest to be known as the "Eugene Ysaye International Competition."

THE Middle West is more progressive than the East in the field of public school music, according to Professor H.A. Smith of Boston University's College of Music, who has recently completed a 4,000-mile tour of investigation in this country.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- The Washington Canoe Club of Washington continued to carry away canoe honors when it captured the Clementon Park Trophy, emblematic of the South Jersey canoe championship in the regatta staged at Clementon Lake Park today.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 29. -- A belief that modern Christian martyrs probably outnumbered the ancient ones, although their deaths were not so heroic, was expressed today by Clifford P. Morehouse, editor of The Living Church, an Episcopal weekly.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The 275th anniversary of purchase of Mamaroneck from the Indians will be celebrated with pageants, parades, community dancing, community dinners and pilgrimages to historical scenes, it was announced today by Charles M. Baxter Jr., chairman of the celebration committee.

TOKYO, Aug. 29. -- The trend toward State socialism in Japan, one of the principal objectives of the insurrectionists of Feb. 26, who assassinated some of the ablest men in the empire, has not been stemmed by the suppression of that insurrection, but is actually making steady progress as a result of it.

TORONTO, Aug. 29. -- Gold production in Canada in the first six months of this year is estimated to be about 16 per cent above last year's rate for this period and about 23 per cent above the 1934 record.

The New York Football Giants, working out at Orangeburg, N.Y., are ready for the final drive which Coach Steve Owen is planning this week to put the men in top shape for the game with the College All-Stars at the Polo Grounds on Tuesday night, Sept. 8.

Having come a cropper through the moth-eaten scheme of getting rich quickly by demanding money from prominent families, William J. Butler Jr., 18 years old, of 139 Hemlock Street, Brooklyn, son of a patrolman, paced a cell yesterday trying to figure out where his plans had gone awry.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Leighton Rollins gave a buffet supper for 100 guests tonight at the Eastman cottage after a series of scenes from several well-known plays given by members of the Studio of Acting.

THIS book is a record of a great personality, an appreciation of a woman as Miss Tarbell says in her foreword, "whose impulses are as clear, as generous and as direct in action as the rays from the sun." Zella de Milhau, etcher and sportswoman, of an old French family settled in America, was nicknamed Bunty from her ubiquitous activities and successful pulling of all possible strings.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Senator Vandenberg, in a statement issued through the Republican National Committee tonight, asserted that the address of Senator Robinson Friday had left "completely unanswered" the Buffalo speech of Governor Landon.

TO the many who would find historically interesting this life of an explorer, navigator and administrator of early South Sea days will be added the thousands who have excitedly followed the thrilling tale of the mutiny on H.M.S. Bounty and the 4,000-mile voyage in an open boat of her commander and his handful of loyal subordinates.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Yonkers, candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, declared here today that "the people of this country do not want relief; they want work."

MADRID, Aug. 29. -- Marcel Rosenberg, the first Soviet Ambassador to Spain, presented today his credentials to President Manuel Azana. Speeches were made stressing the desire of Russia and Spain to assure peace.

FREE meals for long-distance bus passengers are among the latest inducements offered to the traveling public. It is a variant of the policy of the airlines which includes repasts aloft in the price of tickets.

MADRID, Aug. 29 (Passed by the Censor). -- A Rebel bombing plane raided Madrid last night for the fourth time in as many days, and for the first time bombs were dropped in the city itself, seventeen persons being wounded. Previously the Rebel bombs had been reserved for the military and commercial airfields on the outskirts of the capital.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- Heavily advertised clearance sales of surviving Summer merchandise and advance buying of Fall clothes for school needs brought a further expansion in retail sales in the week just ended. Sales were ahead of the preceding week and about 15 per cent in excess of those in the like 1935 week.

It has been evident, during several months, that industrial activity in this country, contrary to the usual midsummer trend, was increasing steadily. How rapidly the expanding movement has progressed was strikingly shown last week by the Federal Reserve's "index of industrial production" for July. That monthly statistical average is compiled from actual turnout in fifteen or sixteen major industries.

INDICATIVE of the change that has occurred in highway habits since truck drivers were almost universally considered the most, ruthless and worst mannered operators of motor vehicles, Paul G. Hoffman, president of Studebaker, said in a recent statement that, if private motorists were as courteous to each other at night as truck-men, many accidents would be avoided.

Reorders reflect the start of Fall consumer purchasing on special items, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Although retail trade was spotty last week, back-to-school and college merchandise and main-floor items were active.

THE public parks of New York City seem to have succeeded to the popularity of the sidewalks of New York, which the horse-and-buggy age immortalized in song. They make themselves so attractive to the seven million nowadays, and are liked so well in return, that they deserve a happy, rousing lyric of their own.
WELLINGTON, N.Z. -- After four months of high-pressure drive toward the new social order, the labor administrators of this southern land see a need to slacken the pace.
RAPID CITY, S.D., Aug. 29. -- President Roosevelt arrived here from Pierre at 6 o'clock this evening for a visit of about twenty-four hours. He planned to go tomorrow on a visit to Mount Rushmore.

GENEVA, Aug. 29. -- Argentina proposes that the League of Nations seek to become universal by weakening its membership obligations, in her note outlining her ideas of League reform, which the Secretariat published today. Her view runs counter to Russia's, which was reported yesterday, in every essential except that both agree the method of change should not be amendment of the covenant, but interpretative Assembly resolutions.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Aug. 29. -- The Wide Water Farm, owned by Ward Melville of Stony Brook, captured the Smithtown Hunt Cup, one of the chief trophies of the twenty-seventh annual Smithtown horse show which was held today on Fifty Acre Farm.
BERLIN, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler received today through the Bishop of Mainz a memorandum setting forth grievances of the Catholic church.

NO one alive today can escape the perception that he is living through one of the great crises of history. Certain landmarks loom out of the past to point the zigzag course of human progress: the coming of the barbarians and the fall of the Roman Empire; the long darkness and the thirteenth-century dawn of modern civilization; the Reformation; the Renaissance; the political revolution of the eighteenth century; the industrial revolution of the nineteenth.

The Loose-Wiles Biscuit Company is placing leaflets decrying the tax burden of the Roosevelt administration in the pay envelopes of the more than 2,000 employes of the company, according to company officials.

TWO exhibitions in rather unusual settings opened last week, braving the heat of the last week of August. At the offices of Theodore A. Kohn Son, 608 Fifth Avenue, the current show in the Summer series consists of pastels by Anne Kroll.

BUCKHANNON, W.Va., Aug. 29. -- New Deal economics were attacked today by Patrick J. Hurley, former Secretary of War, who, in a campaign address here, asserted that the administration has disregarded the fiscal policies proclaimed in the "statesmanlike" Democratic platform of 1932.

AMES, Iowa. -- Farm tenancy has dramatically taken the foreground as the leading farm problem in the Corn Belt. Further north, in the Dakotas, Minnesota and Wisconsin, the drought has centered attention on tax delinquent, marginal and arid lands and the resultant stranded farm population.

Home at last from athletic wars but still hearing a little desultory firing about them, nearly 100 athletes of the American Olympic team remained in New York yesterday at the city's expense and started to relax in earnest.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29. -- From San Diego and El Centro came reports today that two more men had seen a prospector in the mountainous country near Julian, who, they firmly believe, is the missing Joseph Crater, former New York Supreme Court justice, missing six years.

IN his fictionization of the late Pretty Boy Floyd (hers called Choc Paine), fairly recent Southwestern bank robber, killer and, for a time, Public Enemy No. 1, Mr. Cunningham has sought to plausibly present the bandit as a modern Robin Hood, tender-hearted and heroic, who stuck up rustic banks that he might aid with the proceeds the abjectly poverty-stricken farm folk of his native Oklahoma.

TORONTO, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The Toronto Star said today that Mrs. Grace Bagnato, entrant in the Charles Vance Millar $500,000 baby race, had been threatened in mail and telephone demands that she share the prize money if she wins it.
Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that he was keeping in close touch over the week-end with the threatened strike of 15,000 members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs.

FLOWER beds and borders of several years' standing present a problem when replanting is indicated. Not only is it necessary to take up, divide and set out again the varieties which have made such rapid growth that they are beginning to overcrowd, but opportunities for improvement in the grouping and arrangement of the plants almost invariably suggest themselves to the gardener.

VIENNA, Aug. 28. -- By the conclusion of the Austro-German accord, the principal obstacle to the formation of a Fascist bloc has been eliminated and the way opened for closer political cooperation among Germany, Italy, Austria and Hungary.
MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 29. -- Tampico and the surrounding districts are experiencing a flood second only to that of 1933, in which hundreds of persons died.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The next Congress will have to face early the question of continuing or allowing to lapse some of the most important emergency powers granted to President Roosevelt, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States pointed out today in its Washington Review.

WITH REBEL ARMY, BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 29. -- Two generals of the Fascist Rebels high command told this correspondent today that the war "wouldn't last very long," and that when it was over, with the Rebels triumphant, Spain would be placed under a unified, central government.

In 1605 an English ship, the Archangel, bent on an exploring expedition under the command of Captain George Waymouth, buffeted by storms and pulled by rip tides, found a haven in Casco Bay, on the coast of Maine. It was a stowaway, young Vespacian Robin, whose eyes first found the green line that was the New World, but because he interrupted the pious captain's prayers he was forbidden to go ashore with the scouting party.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Representative Ernest Lundeen of Minneapolis was named tonight by the Farmer-Labor party's State Central Committee as candidate for United States Senator to go on the November election ballot in place of Governor Floyd B. Olson, who died last Saturday.
DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Twelve men will be tried in Circuit Court next week for the killing that unmasked the Black Legion.

NEW SUFFOLK, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Leonard Gal, 18 years old, of Rutherford, N.J., was drowned in Peconic Bay today a few hours before fishermen sighted by accident and rescued his companion, David Little, 29, of 109 Hawthorne Street, Brooklyn, with whom Gal had clung to their capsized rowboat throughout the night.

THE occasion of the sixth annual Folk Conference and Festival at Marion and Whitetop, Va. -- organized by Annabel Morris Buchanan and John A. Blakemore -- leads one to reflect upon the actual state and future of American folk-music.

Sweeping improvements in sanitation, heating, fireproofing, air-conditioning and ventilation in recent years have brought too much noise and vibration into modern structures, according to officials of the Columbia University School of Architecture, which announced a new program of studies in the practical application of science to building and community comfort.

MURAL work commissioned outright by the Treasury Department, Public Works Branch, Procurement Division, has been making substantial progress. Several now completed panels were painted (all of them in fresco) by American artists of established reputation, whose work was ordered directly by the Federal Government and did not come to acceptance through competitive channels.

The Hapag Lloyd Line has resumed its practice of halting visitors to its piers when its large ships are sailing, as a means of identifying possible trouble makers. The practice was begun a year ago when a riot was staged on the deck of the liner Bremen and her flag was hauled down, but was abandoned after a few months.

THE editor of this small volume has styled it "A Book for Teachers and Parents." Though not designed to be a textbook, these collected articles by a pioneer in pre-school education should be welcomed by progressive members of the profession.

THE largest private ocean, you may be glad to know, is in Hollywood, but you never hear much about it because it has never had a stevedores' strike nor a walkout of deck stewards. Yet, after the Atlantic, it is the oftenest seen ocean in the movies.

A PROFESSOR at the University of Padua once observed that an Italian historian always writes about things Italian and always damns things Italian, while a Frenchman writes about everything, but always says in effect: "Ah, Messieurs! France is great; France is good; France is beautiful."

PORTLAND, Ore. ONE of America's longest stretches of sea-skirting highway is almost ready for traffic in the Far West. By early in September the last of five great Oregon bridges to enable the motorist on U.S. Highway 101 to drive along the coast from Astoria, Ore., to Eureka, Calif., will be completed.

HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 29. -- Champion True Charm of Wildoaks took best in show honors at the third annual North Shore Kennel Club exhibition held in a continuous rain at the Myopia Hunt Club today. The fixture was staged for the benefit of the Beverly Hospital.

DEVELOPMENTS of the week include the report that in the next tournament in which they play the Four Aces will present a new line-up, Merwin D. Maier of New York replacing B. Jay Becker of Philadelphia.

NINE years ago a young European arrived in the United States from Brazil. He had just crossed Equatorial South America, climbing the Andes from the Pacific by mule, then coasting the rivers by canoe to the Atlantic. Before that he had spent two years in the Arctic, drifting across the polar sea.

New York State, through a "deportation service" all its own, sent more stranded jobseekers, invalids, unemployables and others likely to become public charges back to the States and foreign countries from which they came during the fiscal year ended June 30 than in any previous year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The People's Bridge Corporation, New York City, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $300,000 of first collateral lien 5 per cent sinking fund bonds.

BIG TIM AULIFFE by many years of hard work had built up the Seven Slash spread of heavy shorthorn cattle on government land. When young Cody Venture, brought up by Auliffe and now United States Marshal, brought the news that President Theodore Roosevelt had issued an order that all fences on public domain in Arizona must come down, Auliffe was enraged.

SUSTAINED violence characterizes this sanguinary tale of gang feud between two rival sets of New York racketeers to exterminate each other, and thus seize undisputed control over various lucrative lines of smuggling whose operating base is secreted within the metropolitan underworld.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- The increased corporation taxes were blamed for another slump in prices today on the Boerse. Losses of several points were frequent, the entire list being included in the drop, although the market steadied near the close. Most "blue chip" issues among the heavy industrials lost between 3 and 5 points.

DUBLIN, Aug. 28. -- The result of the Free State census, taken in April last and officially announced on Thursday, provides surprises. With the virtual cessation of emigration to America, a substantial increase in population had been expected.

AUSABLE CLUB, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The Rev. Erdman Harris of New York heads a committee on arrangements for the hayseed ball to be given Wednesday in the casino at Ausable Club for the benefit of the Keene Valley Neighborhood House.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 29. -- Crews of workmen and property owners today began clearing away the debris left in the wake of the windstorm which struck Terre Haute and near-by territory last night, killing two persons, injuring several others and causing more than $500,000 damage.

James Casey, former managing editor of The Daily Worker, official organ of the Communist party of the United States, has been expelled from the party, it was announced yesterday in a statement released by the editorial board of the newspaper.

SUNDAY observance laws in the City of New York were brought to the forefront recently by the assertion of Magistrate Michael A. Ford that they would soon become obsolete. His opinion was expressed in a spirited colloquy with the Rev. Dr. Harry L. Bowlby, general secretary of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States and an ardent crusader against the violators of the First Day statutes.
IRUN, Spain, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Government artillery opened a new bombardment of Rebel positions tonight as the battle for possession of this city reached a critical stage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- After a memorial service attended by the leading government and diplomatic figures now in the capital, the body of Secretary Dern left Washington late today for Salt Lake City, where the funeral will be held at the great tabernacle of the Latter Day Saints Church Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- A rose bush from President Roosevelt's Hyde Park home will be set out at the dedication next Tuesday of Techwood Homes. Atlanta, the first Public Works low-rent housing project to be completed.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 29. -- A 70-year-old man and his wife lost their life's savings here late today to a thief who practices a new type of "confidence" game.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Jeff Davis, who has the title of "King of the Hoboes of the World," turned up today with a brand new idea for helping the government with its problems.

DEVELOPMENT of air transport planes, which was an outgrowth of the air mail operation in commercial hands, has more than kept pace with the growth of service. The single-engined, open-cockpit types of the early part of the last decade have given place to luxurious liners in which passenger comfort as great as in any form of first-class surface vehicle is assured.

The pastoral letter of the German Catholic Bishops, framed at the Fulda episcopal conference and read in all the Catholic churches of the Reich today, is an important document from several points of view. In the first place, the charges it rehearses will reach a wide audience.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- Escaping while under sentence of death passed by the now world-known "Committee of Public Safety" in Madrid, a Spanish Fascist refugee who arrived here by plane directly from Madrid told today one of the most harrowing first-hand stories of the Madrid terror.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 29 (AP). -- Thirty-two airplane pilots, including ten women, arrived at Bowman Field at 5 P.M. today (Central standard time) in the second lap of the Ruth Chatterton cross-country air derby from Cleveland to the West Coast. They were guests at a dinner sponsored by the Junior Board of Trade and were prepared to spend the night here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Referring to use of the same bleached skull of a steer in three different photographs depicting drought damage, a spokesman for the Resettlement Administration explained today that the three views "all were taken within ten feet."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- As the Mohawk Drama Festival closed tonight its second successful season on the Union College campus in connection with the eight weeks' session of the Institute of the Theatre, Charles D. Coburn, the director, looked forward to an expanded curriculum next Summer and to a possible post-season "road tour" to other colleges.

PARIS. -- Tablets representing documents of every-day life in the ancient Phoenician city of Ugarit were found by this year's expedition to Ras Shamra in Northern Syria. Dr. Claude F.A. Schaeffer described these finds in a recent communication to the Academy of Inscriptions.

Registered security Exchanges, as well as over-the-counter dealers, took steps last week to expand their volume of business under some of the provisions of the unlisted trading regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission which were promulgated on July 23 but which became effective only last Wednesday.
The new State Child Labor law, advancing from 14 to 16 the age at which children may discontinue full-time schooling to seek employment, will become effective Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Residents of New York State received 80,154 loans on their homes, totaling $410,024,089, up to the time the Home Owners Loan Corporation ceased lending operations, the corporation stated in a report today.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 29 (AP). -- Governor Horner's refusal to authorize Sam Bennett's extradition to Arkansas because of "possible ill treatment" left the Negro sharecropper a free man today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- The All-America football players of 1935, a squad of fifty-three stars elected from all sections of the United States in a great sports poll, will meet the Detroit Lions, champions of the National Football League, at Soldier Field Tuesday night.

DAIREN, Manchuria, Aug. 29. -- Yosuke Matsuoka, president of the South Manchuria Railway, has revealed that one of his main ambitions in regard to North China -- nourished as a dream for many years -- is a conservation project to prevent the annual floods of the Yellow River.

In announcing New York University's adult education program for this Fall, Dr. Ned H. Dearborn, dean of the general education division, declared yesterday that emphasis in this field was gradually shifting from purely utilitarian studies to those of "cultural enrichment."

Lord Beaverbrook in his article "A Military Alliance With England," in The American Mercury, suggests that an Anglo-American alliance against Japan is the safest way to preserve American interests and peace in the Pacific. He further asserts that "so far as the Pacific is corcerned, then it seems that the United States carries heavier liabilities than the British Empire.''

WESTWOOD, N. J., Aug. 29. -- Bergen County's season of flower shows was opened today by the Bergen County Gardeners Society, with several hundred floral displays at Roosevelt Hall here. Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow of Englewood was one of the major prize winners.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The Rev. William C. Hicks, pastor of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Yonkers, publicly urged today that Superintendent of Schools Lamont F. Hodge of Yonkers reconsider his announced plan to resign on Tuesday, and suggested three members of the Board of Education resign instead.

Speculation, increased industrial buying in anticipation of higher prices and indirect effects of the Spanish conflict and the threat of a European war were cited yesterday as major causes for the sharp price advances and threatened shortages in a number of key materials.

There is no "Far Eastern question "; many of the most vital and closely interrelated problems of China and Japan are powerfully affected by and have significant repercussions on events in Western countries. This interdependence of East and West is the central conclusion that emerges from the last fortnight's discussions of the Institute of Pacific Relations.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- The visit of Senator King of Utah to Puerto Rico has coincided with the nominating conventions of the island's major political parties, in which the issue of Statehood or independence was uppermost. Whatever part chance may have played in the time of his coming, no one who follows island affairs could deny that Senator King's presence has had considerable effect.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 29. -- For the next three weeks Harvard will to all intents be the intellectual center of the world, with the opening here Monday of the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Science, in which seventy-two of the world's greatest scientists and scholars, including eleven Nobel Prize winners, will participate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- State politics became of new interest in Westchester County this week, overshadowing local issues, because of the likely Gubernatorial candidacy of Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Yonkers.

TOPEKA, Aug. 28. -- Reports brought here this week by Republican party leaders who came here for the State Committee and Party Council meetings have stirred Governor Landon's Kansas organization to new efforts to try to remove all doubt about the Presidential candidate carrying his home State.

Expecting the next Christmas season to be the best since 1929 and predicting that business will continue to advance on a broad front, supported by expanding building activity and purchases of equipment by railroads and utilities, Edward B. Smith Co. investment bankers, have compiled an optimistic survey of commercial and financial conditions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- A statement that Senator Robinson was "obligated to defend the New Deal" in his speech last night was made today by the Republican Senatorial Committee, which added that it was because the New Deal "has contributed to Arkansas $30 in Federal aids for every dollar paid by that State in Federal taxes."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The Cardinals snapped a six-game losing streak today behind Si Johnson's steady hurling, defeating the Phillies, 4-0, to gain a game on the first-place Giants in the National League pennant race.

WHEELING, W.Va., Aug. 29 (AP). -- John Cudahy, United States Ambassador to Poland, asserted today that the Republican party and Governor Landon "have nothing to suggest for our guidance in maintaining our neutrality other than the rules of international law."

PARIS. EACH season reveals new outlines drawn by fashion on the style map and, correspondingly, each season finds one portion of the feminine anatomy getting major prominence. This Winter it looks as though legs would run away with the fashion show; isn't that their business, after all?
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 29. -- Here is a summary of the outstanding events of the 300 years of Harvard's history century by century:

ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Members of the Summer colony here contributed articles which were sold today at an old-fashioned all-day auction on the Mill Village grounds of Wayman Adams' art colony for the benefit of the Cobble Hill Golf Club.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Entries continue to pour in for the Fair Acre Challenger Cup golf tournament, which takes place on the championship Cascades course over Labor Day week-end, and this year's event promises to outdo last year's.

ROME. -- The campaign for "babies, still more babies," which seeks to give Italy a population of 60,000,000 by 1950 has now been fought with dogged perseverance for nine years. Though it is perhaps too early to judge its results, since the habits of a whole nation cannot be changed in a comparatively short time, it has certainly been less successful, so far, than had been hoped.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa. -- Real estate values and gold mining shares continue to soar sky-high in South Africa, and big fortunes are being made overnight by speculators. The buying fever shows no sign of abating, despite warnings of shrewd operators, who point to previous land and stock market booms.
William Lurie continued his defense of the metropolitan public parks tennis championship yesterday by vanquishing Louis Marvinney, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, at Walker Park, Livingston, S.I.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 29. -- The Eastern Slopes horse show was held here today for the benefit of the Memorial Hospital, and parties came from many White Mountain resorts for the event, the last of a series given for the hospital fund over a period of two weeks.

THE fourth and final concert of the Summer season will be given by the Naumburg Orchestra on Labor Day, Sept. 7, on the Mall in Central Park. Rosario Bourdon, director of the Cities Service radio program, will be the guest conductor.

DETROIT, Aug. 28. -- Senator Couzens's announcement that he supports the Roosevelt administration, despite the fact that he is running for renomination as a Republican, occasioned a ripple in Michigan which soon subsided, for the news was not unexpected.

WHILE Labor Day and Summer's last blossoms are still between us and the Winter winds, travel cruise charts for the coming season are nearing completion. Into these charts, or itineraries, goes a vast amount of labor.

THERE is more than passing good reason for considering in the pages of a literary review Mr. George Middleton's latest play. In "That Was Balzac," he has written dramatic literature of fine magnitude -- playable, high-water stuff; but, what is more important, be has carried out that most exacting of poetic quests -- the search to recapture for the stage the spiritual essence of a great historical figure.

Yesterday's match having been washed out by the rain, the officials of the United States Polo Association will make another effort today to start the national open championship. If the weather relents, Greentree and Aurora are to meet at Meadow Brook's International Field.

ATHENIA, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Four pigs of the English breed known as Large Black were shipped from the local animal quarantine station last Tuesday for Beltsville, Md., where the Division of Animal Husbandry, United States Department of Agriculture, will make experiments in crossing this breed with domestic ones in the hope of getting more and better bacon.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- A retirement plan for officers and employes of its member banks that will provide pensions adequate to maintain a standard of living comparable to that during employment will be put into operation on Tuesday by the New Jersey Bankers Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- News of Princeton's $4,500,000 civic building project was received with unqualified enthusiasm by local residents today and a movement has been started to select a name for the large, landscaped square which will be an integral part of the proposed development.

In one of the most difficult trial runs ever devised for a tug boat, newly off the ways, the new Winton Diesel tug Marie S. Moran is making a 2,000-mile trip from Beaumont, Texas, to New York, where she is expected to arrive late tomorrow or early Tuesday.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economics Minister, is understood to be Chancellor Adolf Hitler's personal week-end guest at the Summer capital in Berchtesgaden to report on the results of his Paris visit. Apparently there is no doubt in the German mind that this visit was an unqualified success and every effort is being made by Dr. Schacht and the German press to represent it as such.
Two months from this Tuesday we vote. As they approach the two-month homestretch both the candidates are bestirring themselves; the story of last week's bestirring splits three ways:

I HAVE built all these stories," Mr. Erskine says in his foreword to "Young Love," "around a remark I once heard that what we crave in our reading is the theme of young love. Myself no longer young, I fell to wondering at the casualness with which we name the ancient god, who does indeed bring the illusion of immortal youth, but whom we receive so rarely in singleness of heart.

William F.X. Geoghan, native of Philadelphia, graduate of Georgetown University Law School, erstwhile teacher of poetry and English at C.C.N.Y. and District Attorney of Kings County since 1931, appeared before Governor Lehman in the executive chamber at Albany last week to defend his job and his honor.

DR. HEISER'S autobiography, whose title is accurate if not original, begins with an account of the Johnstown flood, in which young Heiser's parents lost their lives, and which came within an ace of preventing this entertaining account of a useful career from being written.
BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, warmly praised the radio as a government instrument at the opening of the radio exhibition yesterday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va. -- The spotlight will be focused this week on the fourth annual tournament of the Mason and Dixon women's golf championship, which will be played over the Old White course for the President's Gold Trophy.
The New Deal cannot be wholly a failure; for the Republican platform has avoided condemnation of numerous features of it.

THERE will be this season, among the tourist brigades besieging the Soviet Union, a number who will have set aside a full day for a special trip away from the routine inspection of factories, river projects, collectives and creches -- for a literary pilgrimage to Yasnaya Polyana, the homestead of Count Leo Tolstoy.

Some observers have felt that the Governor was foolish to take to the road so early. He will, they predict, have worn thin before President Roosevelt begins his campaign in October. It may be part of the Landon strategy, therefore, to spend the next month getting acquainted with the various sections of the country, while holding the heavy artillery until later on.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- A statement of principles to guide the business interests of the country in their relations with the government, with their employes and with the economic problems of the day was issued today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

BERLIN. -- According to National Socialist ideology, national strength depends first of all on the strength and quality of numbers. All National Socialist population measures, therefore, are either designed to control marriages and births -the so-called "racial hygiene" laws -- or designed to stimulate them.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union defied the American Federation of Labor's executive council yesterday to suspend it because of its association with the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers.

WHEN women in the accessory business knit their brows and thoughtfully predict a "trend," it usually follows that the prophecy comes true. Just now wholesale stylists and retail salesgirls alike say that costume jewelry "is going to be big."

THIS book is prepared with the particular aim of usefulness to the stage and to all spectacles which make use of historic costume. But although it makes no claim of historic interpretation, it has a genuine-interest which goes beyond the narrow borders of stage pageantry into the realities of history itself.

A city magistrate will have the task tomorrow of deciding how loud a taxicab horn should be, as a result of Mayor La Guardia's campaign to hush the horns of the 2,000 sleek cabs operated by the Sunshine Radio System, Inc.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- With five dances, two of which will be coming-out parties; many luncheons, dinners and golf and tennis tournaments, this week will be one of the liveliest of the Berkshire season.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Members of the Summer colonies of the Hamptons, judging from the calendar of activities, are bent upon crowding as much gayety as possible into the coming week, the last important one of the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Net railway operating income of Class 1 steam railroads from Jan. 1 to July 31 was placed at $300,457,252, compared with $221,554,792 in the corresponding seven months in 1935, an increase of $78,902,460, or about 35 per cent, in a second summary of railroad finances issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to supplement the preliminary estimates made public yesterday.

WHEN the possibilities of international broadcasting were first discussed, visionary American broadcasters dared to suggest that some day Big Ben atop the Houses of Parliament might be heard in America striking off the hours in London.

CONSTANT advances in airway weather forecasting are being taught students of what is contended to be the nation's largest class in aeronautical meteorology by United Air Lines experts. The class has 650 students who are pilots, dispatchers and other employes of the air transport company, enrolled for a continuing course which takes up new developments and discoveries in the science of airway weather.

DECLARATION: Michigan, which claims for its city of Jackson the honor of having given birth to the Republican party, followed T.R. in 1912 but otherwise was consistently Republican in Presidential elections until 1932, when it went for Roosevelt.

TOKYO, Aug. 29. -- The appointment of Admiral Seizo Kobayashi as Governor General of Formosa has been approved. It is understood that this post, to which Japan attaches importance in view of her mandate over the Caroline and Marshall Islands, will in the future be held by an admiral.

With the memory of two weeks of almost constant hunger banished by a soft bed and a hearty breakfast in Bellevue Hospital, James Riley, sixteen-year-old runaway orphan from Nova Scotia, yesterday recounted the many advantages of being footloose in the country as compared to the city, where there seems to be no hope of exchanging labor for food and lodging.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -Charges that millions of dollars of notes covering money lent by the Resettlement Administration are carelessly stored in "fire trap" buildings in regional headquarters are made in a statement today by the Republican National Committee.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Aug. 30. -- Foreign Minister Chang Chun flew from Nanking to Shanghai late yesterday to meet the Japanese Ambassador, Shigeru Kawagoe, to discuss the Chengtu incident in which two Japanese were killed and two injured by a Chinese mob last Monday.

The nation and the world learned last week that President Roosevelt has under consideration a plan to call together the kings, dictators and presidents of the principal nations in a meeting designed to buttress peace.

UP to the opening of the van Gogh Exhibition at the Chicago Art Institute last Wednesday, the touring show has been attended by 637,344 people in its tour of this country, according to figures just made public by the Museum of Modern Art.
