THE curtain is going up on radio's 1936-37 season. Since the radio showmen plan their performances weeks ahead, an advance glimpse at the Autumn card at this time reveals what listeners may expect to hear between now and the year-end.

MEXICO'S pride in the spectacular new scenic highway connecting its capital with the United States at Laredo, Texas, has been expressed in a series of six postage stamps commemorating the opening of the road.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 29. -- The second performance of the 1936 edition of the "Allenhurst Antics," was given last night in the Mon Paris room of the Monmouth County Country Club before more than 500 members of North Jersey Shore colonies.

AS the tourist season opens, the open season on place names opens with it. People from the West will murder, to Eastern ears, Poughkeepsie and Schenectady, while Easterners will injure Western sensibilities in much the same fashion.
ATLANTA, Aug. 29 (AP). -- A young convict paid with his life tonight for a few hours of freedom after an escape in which a guard was killed and a second fugitive was seriously wounded.

Recent improvements in the economic and social conditions of the Negro Republic of Liberia were credited by Lester A. Walton, United States Minister, who returned home last week, to the initial success of the program of rehabilitation instituted by Edwin Barclay, President of the West African country.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 29. -September, known on the North Shore as Long Island's "Little Season," gives promise of being one of the biggest seasons in many years. The calendar is crowded with events, including polo matches with attendant social activity, weddings, debuts, the opening of the season of the Meadow Brook hunt, flower shows, parties for the sub-debutantes before school and college open, steeplechase and house parties.

WHEN schoolbells summon the boys and girls of America to another year of classroom work many will answer the opening roll-call in new, modern buildings financed in part by PWA funds and constructed under the eye of its inspectors.

HAMMONTON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- When the trial of Patrolman Michael Messina of the town police force was called last night, it was discovered that there was no set of rules and regulations for the force in existence.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Despite occasional heavy showers, more than one thousand persons attended the twenty-seventh annual Smithtown Horse Show, held today on Fifty-Acre Field in St. James. Society was well represented. The day was marked by many dinner parties throughout the neighboring countryside estates.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28. -- Highlights of the steel labor front this week include a split in a central committee of Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation employes over an alleged attempt of the Lewis-Murray steel workers organization committee to seize control, and the permanent closing, on account of a strike, of two plants employing 750 at Coraopolis, near this city.

Housecleaning is not a particularly pleasant task anywhere, and in Japan, one suspects, it might be particularly arduous. At any rate, Taro Chan thought so. There was just one day in the year, he confided to the little china cat, that he didn't like, and that was Great Sweeping Day, the annual housecleaning day for all Japan.

For the past week more newspaper space has been given up to Governor LANDON than at any time since his nomination early in June. The reason was that he had begun his active campaigning. The question in all minds was how deeply he could impress him self upon the American people.

ATLANTA, Aug. 29 (AP). -- New Deal farm measures are issues in a bitter contest between Governor Eugene Talmadge and Senator Richard B. Russell Jr. for the right to represent Georgia in the Senate. They seek the Senatorial nomination in the Democratic primary Sept. 9, a nomination tantamount to election.

The sixth race meeting of the metropolitan season -- the Fall session at Aqueduct, will get under way tomorrow and run until Sept. 16. There will be eight stakes and almost $100,000 in stake and purse money, thus assuring continuance of the high caliber of competition which has prevailed during the Spring and Summer.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- The managers of twenty-nine student employment agencies for the academic year at Princeton University were announced today by Richard W. Warfield, director of the bureau of appointments and student employment of the university.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 29. -- The Soviet Government today warned Norway that if it continued to give asylum to Leon Trotsky it would endanger the friendly relations between the two countries.

THE grade-crossing elimination program which was begun last Fall is now well under way. The most recent announcement of the Bureau of Public Roads of the Department of Agriculture reports that to date 158 projects, at a total cost of $5,842,169, have been completed.
TEN MILE RIVER, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Bronzed to a healthy color by many hours in the sun, 2,000 New York Boy Scouts are entering the final week of the annual Summer camping season here.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 29. -- Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco today won her first major golf title, the women's Western closed championship, with a stunning 6-and-5 defeat of 19-year-old Miss Beatrice Barrett of Minneapolis.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 29. -- In compliment to Mrs. Henry Merritt Dement and her daughter, Miss Jane Dement, of Kenilworth, Ill., Mrs. Harry C. Holloway of Glencoe, Ill., gave a tea and reception this afternoon at Tamarack, Tyringham.

After four months of intensive competition during which several hundred teams were involved, the second annual metropolitan softball championships came to an end yesterday at the Polo Grounds before 3,000 fans.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP). --The Athletics and Cleveland divided a double-header today, the Indians winning the first game, 13 to 2, and the Macks the second, 5 to 3.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Miss Katherine Sui Fun Cheung was the first to take off here today on the first leg of the Ruth Chatterton Derby. She left at 10:29 A.M., the others following at one-minute intervals.

When the Rev. GERALD SMITH the other day whipped a Bible out of his hip pocket for a smashing platform climax against the Roosevelt Administration he had a very respectable precedent. The trick goes back almost a hundred years and to no rabble-rouser of the Mississippi River back-country.

MR. HECTOR PECKET'S boat was no ordinary boat. It had never sailed the seven seas. It had never sailed on sound or bay, river or lake, anywhere, except in Hector Pecket's mind. In cold fact it stood, before the enchanted voyage, in Mr. Pecket's backyard in the Bronx.
VALLADOLID, Spain, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Rebel army ranks were increased tonight as reserves from dismissed military classes responded to a recall from the insurgent high command.

STAR ISLAND, N.H., Aug. 29. -- "The Spanish revolution is only the first round in a world conflict which will last for a long time," Roger W. Babson, statistician and economist, declared today before delegates to the Conference on Creative Spiritual Religion.

THE National Air Races begin next Saturday at Los Angeles, but the most significant event in connection with this annual air display, the transcontinental derby sponsored by Vincent Bendix, starts from New York next Friday morning.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- Sizzling heat failed to dampen the ardor of soccer enthusiasts and 750,000 sweltering spectators watched the forty-four matches that marked the opening of the English football season today. With the thermometer registering 80 degrees in the shade police and club officials were kept busy with fainting cases.

ALL the way from the Nantucket Shoals to Chesapeake Bay, and off shore as far as Georges Bank (which is 200 miles east of Cape Cod), cap'ns of the fishing smacks are hearing about how Fulton Fish Market sheds fell into the East River.

THIS novel intends to give a picture of apartment life in an average middle-class family of uptown New York. The aging story runs something like this: once there was a woman getting middle-aged and restless who lived in a few stuffy rooms with her stuffy husband.

The critics of the administration delight in dwelling upon the shortcomings of the methods that were put in force to get the farmers to curtail their crops and thereby raise the price of farm products and lose sight of what these methods produced.
HOENEFOSS, Norway, Aug. 15 (By Mail). -- Wide publicity has been given by the press of America and the world to the preparations being made for a new Constitution in the Soviet Union.

A new type of real estate salesmen is preparing to enter the realty business of the country with renewed enthusiasm and faith in continued business prosperity, declares Percy Wilson, general manager of the real estate division of Marshall Field Co., Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Issuance of subpoenas for officials of four munitions companies and a detective agency was announced today by officials of the special Senate committee investigating alleged violations of civil liberties in industrial disputes.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 29. -- The government has signed a contract with the Sociedad Anonemia Aeroplani Caproni of Milan, Italy, for the construction of a $75,000 steel factory at Las Palmas, ten miles from the center of this city, now the site of the largest hangar in South America, with a total area of 7,000 square meters and a width of 165 feet.
SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 29. -- General Francisco Franco's Foreign Legion and Moors fought bitterly today at the gates of Talavera de la Reina, the last large town they must take on their way to Madrid.
Ranking players of Europe and America will gather at Forest Hills on Thursday for the combined national singles championships at the West Side Tennis Club.

EVERY river has its source, and the vast torrents of campaign vituperation now beginning to flow have also their springs. Were these more or less obscure fountains of intellectual ingenuity to dry up, politicians would have either to revise their system of campaigns or run the risk of looking very silly indeed.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 29. -The staff and headquarters detachment of the Twenty-seventh Division of the State National Guard, which has been studying tactical problems at Camp Smith for the past week, will engage in a five-day "war" beginning Monday.

THE Music Hall's "Swing Time,'" coming along at a time like this, was bound to divert Howard Lindsay's attention for the moment from his current collaboration with Russel Crouse and Cole Porter on the new Vinton Freedley musical "Red Hot and Blue."

WILL SHAKESPEARE appears to have come to terms with Hollywood. Somewhat harassed by the film city's previous attempts to translate his plays into celluloid, and embarrassed as much by its freedom in dealing with his "Taming of the Shrew" as by its blunt literalness in handling his "A Midsummer Night's Dream," the Bard staked his filmic all on Metro's good faith in the case of "Romeo and Juliet."

JOHN CARR, a husky Irish blacksmith of 22, left Peoria in 1850 to join the California gold rush. After panning the yellow metal without much success in all the famous mining camps, he finally settled down to practice his trade in Weaverville. Later lie went to Tombstone, Ariz., and was twice elected Mayor.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- A five-point Federal, State and municipal program to provide for the needy in New Jersey was outlined today by Governor Harold G. Hoffman.

The prospect of an expansion in the flight of gold from France to this country was increased yesterday, when the franc fell once more below its effective gold point in this market. The closing was its lowest price for the week, 6.58 5-16 cents, off 1-16 point from Friday and 1/8 point from a week earlier.

PACIFIC adventure -- whose? Mr. and Mrs. Willard Price, experienced in Oriental life and travel, open-eyed, tolerant, friendly and courageous, spent four months in the islands of Micronesia -- east of Asia and north of Australia -- which few Americans have ever known anything about.

WUERZBURG, Germany, Aug. 22 (By Mail). -- The part of the brain concerned with instinctive actions in animals has been located by Professor E. Gruenthal of the psychiatric and neurologic clinic of Wuerzburg University. He finds that the instinct centers lie in the middle part of the brain, in structure known technically as the thalamus and hypothalamus.

In the last few years political bombshells have exploded with increasing frequency in Europe. After each explosion tension has spread throughout the Continent; there has been talk of war; tension has eased -- until the next explosion. Gradually the people of Europe, though fearing war, have become hardened to the course of events.

FRIGHTENED: Before the solar eclipse last June the Soviet Government put on a great educational campaign to prepare the peasants for the approaching phenomenon. The hope was that education would save the peasants from being scared out of their wits.

A delicate question involving the lives of eight flying foxes was settled yesterday morning in a manner satisfactory to the director of the Staten Island Zoo, for whom they were brought from India, but disastrous to the four pairs of winged animals.

THREE years ago the happy idea of meeting for a mid-summer week on Cape Cod to thrash out -- amid sand, surf and clambakes -- a season's production schedule first occurred to the Theatre Union. With the last Cape Cod conclave just completed, the idea seems now well on its way to becoming a habit.

THE double-feature mania which has gripped the nation has killed one of the cinema's most flourishing institutions, the slap-stick comedy factory. Most of them have given up the ghost. Hal Roach, however, has adapted himself to the times by renouncing the two-reelers for the more respected multiple-reel films.

ONE of the most gratifying phenomena recently observable in the realm of recorded music is the rationalizing of the chamber music sections of the various catalogues. Two years ago, a survey of the lists of all string quartets making records in domestic and foreign studios would have shown bewildering results.

JONESBORO, Ark., Aug. 29 (AP). -- Three victims of purported floggings in connection with the East Arkansas sharecropper controversy filed damage suits in Federal Court today asking judgments from five Crittenden County residents.

ON the first Sunday in July of 1844, when a brazen sun heated the roofs and cobbled streets of the growing City of New York, 300 carriages rattled over the Shell Road through Dan Morell's toll gate into Coney Island, setting an all-time crowd record. On the following Sunday pulpits in the old town of Gravesend, adjacent to the island, shook with clerical thunder against a nation whose people went in for such wholesale Sabbath-breaking.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- About 300 members of the Summer colony with their week-end guests tonight attended a dance at Hopedene, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel P. Hill of New York. It was the major dancing party of the week and was preceded by a dozen or more large dinner parties at different Summer homes.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Nine young boys -- five of them dressed in girls' clothing as a method of punishment -- escaped here tonight from the Hudson County Parental School, a reformatory for boys and girls.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28. -- Chosen by the Anti-Saloon League as one of its three battlegrounds for 1936, California faces a stiff contest at the November election between prohibitionists sponsoring a local option amendment and organized wets who are asking adoption of a new State control plan to end the abuses of the present system.

Eager to show a delegation of returning Olympians how gold medals and little oaks are won in this country, the Yankees took a farewell poke at the Tigers at the Stadium and brought down the towering Schoolboy Rowe, 6 to 4, in the fading world champions' last appearance of the year in New York.
Serious difficulties in coat and suit deliveries next month and a sharp upturn in dress buying activity this week were foreseen here yesterday by trade association executives in these lines.

AS the end of Summer approaches, transport men and travel agents are taking stock of the season's business. They are well satisfied with the results. The American public has been traveling more extensively this season than in any other year since the depression began to weigh heavily on the country.

LEIPZIG, Germany, Aug. 29. -- Dr. Werner Heisenberg, a distinguished Leipzig University physicist, will not attend the Harvard tercentenary ceremonies next month. He was down on the conference program for a paper and he expected to sail a fortnight ago.

The authors have selected these ten folk tales from the hundreds which they heard first-hand from the Spanish people Reading them, one forgets the present daily echoes of civil war and enters the ageless world of fancy which has delighted the peasant for centuries.

WHEN is a radio talk political and when is it non-political? That is the problem confronting the broadcasters these days, for if the speech of a Presidential nominee is politicial he is charged for it; if it is non-political, the radio facilities are gratis.

THE theatre season opens in a few days now. The streets off Broadway will be bright with lights and loud with bitter traffic, and the Opening Night will resume its place in the carefully nurtured tradition of Times Square. Back from the country and the Summer theatres will come the actors, the producers, the friends of both, the drama reviewers and that indefinable section of humanity that insists on getting, somehow, to all the premieres.

GENEVA, Aug. 28. -- Surveying the outlook for reform of the League of Nations, Professor Pittman Potter, American member of the Walwal Arbitral Tribunal, told the Geneva Institute of International Relations recently that the trend was toward maintaining and strengthening rather than weakening the League.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Aug. 29. -- Lectures by Robert Frost, Julia Peterkin, John Mason Brown, Gorham Munson, Josephine Johnson and Bernard DeVoto were features last week of the annual Writers' Conference at Bread Loaf Inn, sponsored by Middlebury College.

Last week's demolition in one of the accidents in the Red Bank Sweepstakes regatta of John Charles Thomas's Tip Toe puts a different complexion on the 225-cubic inch championship series. This year for the first time the popular new class will conclude its season with a national title series to be run during the President's Cup regatta at Washington Sept. 24-27.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- Although it is now the eve of the month in which the League of Nations is committed to consider the reform of its covenant, at the September session of the Assembly, the plans of the British Government for its share in the discussions and the possible revision at Geneva are not yet prepared.

RICHMOND, Aug. 28. -- Any lingering doubts as to the South's probable attitude toward President Roosevelt next November would seem to have been dispelled by the overwhelming primary victories this week of Senator Pat Harrison in Mississippi and Senator James F. Byrnes in South Carolina.
There has been a sudden renaissance of interest in the local junior girls' golf championship, which the Metropolitan Association threatened to discontinue for lack of entries last year.

BAYSHORE, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Because of rain and high winds prevailing at noon the regatta committee of the Bayshore Yacht Club decided to call off its annual August invitation regatta today, but later, when conditions moderated, the Star and Timber Point classes were permitted to race.

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- Schiaparelli's afternoon handbags are veritable works of art. They are satchel-shaped and of black suede with black composition "slides," decorated with raised landscape designs -- reminiscent of the eighteen sixties -- that fit into each side.

IN No. 8 of the Treasury Department Art Projects bulletins appeared "a few remarks" by Reginald Marsh, which Forbes Watson, the editor, invited him to supply. These amusingly and instructively reflect some of the artist's experiences while he was at work upon the Postoffice Department murals in Washington:

TOPEKA, Aug. 28. -- Governor Alf M. Landon is back in Topeka, cheered by the reception he received on his first campaign trip. His personal advisers concur in this opinion, and an unprejudiced observer would agree that the trip, taken as a whole, was encouraging.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Slogging forward through deep mud, Granville, the 3-year-old champion, today made Discovery look slow as he amazed 18,000 persons with a six-length victory over the handicap champion, which had gone to the post a 2-to-5 favorite for the mile and three-quarters of the Saratoga Cup, closing-day feature of the month long meeting.

THE halls and corridors of the International Center of the University of Paris are gradually being thrown open to the students of all nations. The visitor sees these students sauntering about the grounds, discussing studies and politics, enjoying new comforts in the building that John D. Rockefeller Jr. has provided as his contribution to a better international understanding.
AVELLINO, Italy, Aug. 29 (AP). -- "Red" and "Blue" forces of the Italian Army ended the annual war manoeuvres today with a sham battle.

TRAVEL is such fun, Mary Boland says, after you're home. It gives you something new to talk about if you can corner anybody and make him listen, and that keeps the conversation off taxes (which Miss Boland would rather not discuss because she likes to be a lady at all times).

A TYPICAL strip near Mangum, Okla., where the first tree planted as part of the Shelter-Belt project was set out on March 18, 1935. This strip, three-fourths of a mile long and 100 feet wide, was planted the following month. The strips are laid out so they will have a peak at the center of the cross-section when mature, with the lowest-branching trees or shrubs in the outer rows.

WITH THE REBEL ARMY OUTSIDE IRUN, Spain, Aug. 29. -- Picked and seasoned fighting men of the Spanish Foreign Legion now are fighting shoulder to shoulder with other Rebel forces in their drive to capture the border city of Irun.

While from a physical standpoint the free port on Staten Island should be in operation by the first of the year, the numerous difficulties governing decisions as to what constitutes allowable processes in the zone indicate that it will be many months or even years before the port will function normally, James B. Herzog, vice president of S. Stern, Stiner Co., Inc., customs brokers, declared here yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 29. -- Premier George Tatarescu succeeded in eliminating the veteran Foreign Minister, Nicolas Titulescu, in forming a new Cabinet this evening, after presenting his resignation to King Carol this morning.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP). -- Dr. Thomas N. Barrows, dean of Lawrence College, Appleton, Wis., told the convention of the Phi Kappa Sigma today that "some educators believe the college fraternity has outlived its original purpose.

THE historic charm of Belgium's medieval cities is heightened during the Summer season. To them, when skies are blue and sunny, come artists as well as tourists, intent on painting the age-old cathedrals, monasteries, fortresses and guild houses, which remain as intact and habitable today as they did in the Middle Ages.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 29. -- Norway studied with grave concern tonight what to do with Leon Trotsky, the exiled Bolshevik "man without a country."

ROBERT NEUMANN'S forthcoming novel, which Alfred A. Knopf will publish on Sept. 28 under the title "The Queen's Doctor," is based on the life of Dr. Frederick Struensee, an eighteenth century physician-philosopher, a disciple of Rousseau, who wormed his way into the confidence of King Christian of Denmark and was believed to be the lover of Queen Caroline Matilda.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The sixth annual meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association will be held here on Labor Day on the course of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, formerly Bowman Park. C. Wadsworth Howard and Miss Florence I. Cahill head the committee in charge.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The unusual case of Carlton Chilton, a Cleveland citizen who is fighting return to a year's term in an Oklahoma prison from which he escaped twenty-three years ago, will go before Governor Davey Monday for decision.

NEXT week, at the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences, chlorophyll -- a substance which, gives plants their green color and which often has been referred to as "life's greatest organic chemical" -- will come in for a great deal of attention on the scientific program.

Volume of bonds called last week for redemption before maturity did not change from the restricted amounts posted in previous weeks this month. Small blocks of municipal bonds were the most numerous called while the largest separate issues were in the railroad classification.

Plans for extensive activity during the coming theatrical season have been announced by the sixteen units of the Federal Theatre Project in New York. Upward of thirty productions are scheduled for presentation before Nov. 1, with at least that many more due to come along in midseason and later.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- After the recent short lull, the new season is getting into its full swing next week. On Monday at the Vaudeville, Charlot, who is temporarily abandoning revues for a series of straight plays, sponsors "Gentle Rain," by Denison Clift and Frank Gregory, with Haidee Wright, Viola Keats and Alan Napier in the cast.

Underlying business conditions in the New York area continued favorable last week. The closing days of the August sale promotions at retail spurred consumer buying and merchants continued confident of the prospects for the new season which is about to open.

Mysterious goings-on in and about London provide the plots for Patricia Wentworth's recent novels, with a touch of sound romance to warm up their creepy atmosphere. In "Hole and Corner" the heroine is a poor little English orphan who lives in cheap lodgings and works as companion to a wealthy woman.

Gains and losses were about evenly divided in the commodity futures markets here in the week ended on Friday. Cocoa, rubber, hides and tin were strong, while silk, cottonseed oil and coffees were depressed. In the cash markets cocoa, rubber, hides and tins advanced, as wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, butter, lard, cotton, print-cloths, silk and wooltops declined.

Your editorial "Animals in the News" carries a note of hope for our vanishing wildlife that I wish I might share. While it is true that "a more genuine sentiment for enforcement and a belated realization of the value of our great game seem to be winning for the forces of conservation," many of our most valued species of birds and animals are in greater danger of being wiped out today than ever before.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Theodore Dreiser on his sixty-fifth birthday last week interrupted the writing of his twenty-third book to give an interview in which he hailed President Roosevelt's suggested peace conference of world rulers as "an idea worth planting."

During July the death rate for the 17,000,000 policyholders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company reached the highest figure -- 8.2 per 1,000 -- for any July in five years, according to a bulletin issued yesterday by the company. The figure marked a rise of 5.2 per cent over the rate for the same month in 1935.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT THROUGH THE DROUGHT AREA. -- In a career distinguished by the unusual, President Roosevelt has found still another means of asserting his individual manner of doing things as day after day he rides by train and automobile across the prairie's dusty face to study at first hand the ravages of the drought and the means being taken to alleviate these conditions.

The first case of violence in the painters' strike was reported to the police yesterday. Adolph Klein, 27 years old, of 1,946 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, was slugged and injured, he told the police, by six men who attacked him in the basement of 1,801 Loring Place, the Bronx.

Foreseeing in the new advertising allowance contracts issued by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company a renewed drive by all chains and other retailers for the return of these subsidies, which were dropped when the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Law went into effect in June, food manufacturers last week prepared to regiment their opposition to the move.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- At this time in August Deauville reaches the peak of its animation. Those interested in the turf, golf or the general gayety of this cosmopolitan resort are to be found in the numerous villas as well as at the hotels.

Aides of District Attorney Martin Littleton in Nassau County yesterday began an investigation of the circumstances surrounding the unauthorized use of a small truck owned by Gus Muller of Valley Stream by Mrs. Helene Fortescue Reynolds of Glen Cove, and its return.

MR HOSHOR has become greatly worked up over Father Divine. He doesn't know whether the little Negro is a "madman-menace or a messiah," and his book reflects his confusion. He seems on the whole to tend to the more respectful view.

MANY rooms recently decorated have reverted, in spite of their simplicity and efficiency, to coziness of effect. Table lamps, flower vases, mantel ornaments and other objects of art in wide variety play their part, adding new colors, textures and novel shapes to the ensemble.

Of all the little countries Palestine is the greatest. To the adherents of three great religions, it is a holy land. Small as it is, it has four different climates; all the features of a continent. To the saint, it is the chosen land; to the soldier, it is one of the most strategic spots on earth.

NEW ENGLAND is made up of six States and every one different -- the tourist finds when he drives from the South or Southwest, with two weeks to motor from Connecticut to Maine. A fortnight is considered long enough for the high spots -- ocean, mountains, rivers and lakes.
Fordham will launch its forty-eighth year of varsity football on Wednesday when fifty-three candidates for the 1936 edition of the Maroon eleven report to Coach Jimmy Crowley at Fordham Field.

Ten thousand Puerto Ricans, representing a score of political and social clubs in the city, paraded for three hours through the streets of lower Harlem yesterday afternoon to protest the attitude and actions of "Imperialistic America" in making "slaves" of the natives of the island.

WITH "Trumpeter, Sound!" Mr. Murray showed that he was a historical novelist to be reckoned with. "Regency" establishes him definitely in a high position among present-day writers who can evoke the past and make it live through fictional creation.
GREENS FARMS, Conn., Aug. 29. -- Mrs. Minot Howard's Brown Boy slashed through the mud to win the six-furlong test, the feature of the Fairfield County Hunt race meet held at Wynfromere Farm today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Where Away, 4-year-old son of Stimulus-Bobolink II, picked up by Anthony Pelleteri of New Orleans a year ago for $3,000, raced to a brilliant victory in the $5,000 added Great Western handicap before 12,000 spectators at Washington Park today.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 29 (AP). -- Staging his usual late rush, C.V. Whitney's Roustabout came from far back to win the first renewal of the Fall River Handicap, at a mile and one-sixteenth, for 3-year-olds and up, over a sloppy Narragansett Park track today.

Purchases of securities by leading American insurance companies rose 25 per cent last year from the 1934 figure, according to Poor's 1936 edition of Insurance Company Purchases and Sales. Approximately $3,875,000,000 of securities were bought by 840 insurance companies, against $3,097,000,000 in 1934.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP). -- Representatives of Japan, Great Britain, Russia and France agreed today that a method of achieving collective security and questions involving the changing of the balance of power in the Pacific were the most important problems to be met in the Far East.
TOPEKA, Aug. 29. -- Governor Landon made preparation today for his drought conference with President Roosevelt at Des Moines next Thursday by familiarizing himself with the situation in Kansas.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 29. -- The Dodgers were so engulfed in a red wave today that Professor Casey Stengel and a majority of his troops were crimson with mortification as early as the fourth inning.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Aug. 29 (AP). -- While most of their British rivals took a day off from practice, members of the American Walker Cup team today turned in some fine scores in preparation for the international golf struggle next Wednesday and Thursday.

The American Fox Terrier Club, departing from its custom of many years, announces that its annual specialty exhibition will be given in Cleveland on Sunday, Nov. 15. Leonard Brumby of Hicksville, L.I., noted professional handier and one of the leading terrier experts of this country, has been selected to judge the show.

Modernization of store fronts, a trend which had its inception in the depths of the depression, is now progressing so rapidly that the demand for modern, decorative fronts now far exceeds the supply, according to Edward L. Patton of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Halted once by rain and again by darkness brought on by impending showers, the Washington-Chicago game today finally was called in the ninth, giving the White Sox a 5-to-4 triumph to sweep the two-game series with the Senators.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- In an article entitled "Where Does Britain Stand?" the current issue of The London Economist says "it is credibly reported that when last Autumn it seemed that Britain's stout championship of the League might have forced the Duce to abandon his aggression in Ethiopia a deputation of Italian admirals saw the dictator."

Railway shares led the stock market into generally higher ground in yesterday's half-day trading period. Several of the carrier issues mounted 1 to 2 3/4 points. In the industrial list, many of the steel, automotive and sugar issues were in good demand.

THE international recreation congress held recently in Germany draws attention to the tremendous strides now being made toward solving the problem of mankind's leisure hours. Not since the era of Grecian games, perhaps, has organized recreation commanded such widespread public participation or been fostered so diligently as a community function.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (AP). -- The State Supreme Court was asked today to reopen the mayhem and conspiracy charge case against two San Francisco surgeons who performed a sterilization operation on Ann Cooper Hewitt, heiress.

ARTHUR WAUGH, the chairman of Chapman Hall, has been celebrating his seventieth birthday by contributing to The Fortnightly a review of the changes that have passed over the book world in this country during the last fifty years.
SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Aug. 29 (AP). -- Eleven nations were invited tonight by a group of foreign diplomats to discuss plans for "humanizing" the Spanish civil war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. The usual seasonal rise in industrial production occurred in the first three weeks of August, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of business.

MR. TUTT is still at his old game of playing the legal Robin Hood, using his kindly wisdom and his complete grasp of the trickery of the law to unseat the uppity and raise up the under dog. His righteous joy in helping the hopeless is equaled only by his wicked delight in outsmarting the overconfident opposition.

LONG, rambling wooden grand stands, painted a pale robin's-egg blue, their tops gay with flags rippling in the breeze of a late Summer day, frame a long expanse of green turf. Turf so green it has almost the unreal appearance of a stage property.

A SUMMER music pilgrimage in Italy would not be complete without taking in at least one performance of open-air opera in Verona's famous Arena. In the two decades and more since Zenatello, Serafin and other pioneers first attempted al fresco lyrics here, the old Roman amphitheatre has, year after year, been the subject of scenographic experimentation.

IN this little midland town of some 6,000 inhabitants there are few conspicuous signs of Britain's rearmament and there is no obvious alarm at the European crisis. The British are not the most articulate of peoples and one might remain in Uttoxeter for days without hearing Europe discussed.

IF this man is elected, fellow-citizens, "the Constitution will inevitably fail. * * * The navy is to be laid up, the ships are to rot at our wharves, our commerce is again to be plundered, our farmers are to be impoverished, and our merchants ruined"; in short, our country will be brought to utter destruction, if Thomas Jefferson is elected President of the United States!
FURNITURE and decorative objects in the modernistic styles are being turned out in great numbers in the home workshops of today's amateur metal craftsmen.

THE anonymous compiler of this volume speaks of the difficulty of giving a precise definition of an essay. In this collection "the term has been interpreted widely to cover the review, the leading article, the formal gossip, the pamphlet, the treatise, and the biographical sketch."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Eighty per cent of the 1936 senior class of Rutgers University are now employed in industry or are planning to attend graduate school in the Fall, Edward H. Heyd, director of the Bureau of Personnel and Placement, announced today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 28 (AP). -- The Department of Highways is looking to "stabilized" highways -- earth roads graded, made compact and treated with sodium chloride or calcium chloride -- as a possible answer to the problem of mounting maintenance costs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the fact that President Roosevelt is considering, in the event of his re-election, a proposal for a joint conference with the heads of the most important nations in an effort to assure peace of the world has served to recall that Presidents of the United States for many years have made significant contributions to the cause of international peace.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28. -- The execution of Gregory Zinovieff, Leon Kameneff and fourteen of their fellow-accused at the conclusion of the Soviets' greatest and most sensational trial undoubtedly meets the approval of a majority of citizens, at least in Moscow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- While the grain markets here fluctuated today in an erratic manner, there was a notable absence of the heavy liquidation so much in evidence yesterday. An accumulation of overnight selling orders caused a lower opening, but short covering absorbed the offerings and later when commission house and local buying appeared there was little pressure.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 28. -- Improvement of the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal to accommodate deep-draft shipping is now proceeding at top speed day and night. The canal, which extends from the Delaware River to an arm of the Elk River, one of the upper branches of the Chesapeake Bay, is being deepened from 12 to 17 feet and widened from 90 to 250 feet. About half the dry excavation has been completed.

Preparing for what promises to be the most active Fall season in several years, all branches of business forged ahead at a lively pace in most sections of the country last week. Although there was a seasonal letdown in buying in some areas, trade in general continued to move along satisfactory lines in most areas as merchants began to feature fresh supplies of Fall merchandise.
ATLANTA, Aug. 29. -- The upward trend in all major lines of industry was maintained in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The social colony and the towns-people of Bar Harbor are making preparations for the arrival on Thursday of the Committee of One Hundred of Miami Beach for two days of merrymaking and sightseeing.

MORE than 7,000,000 radio sets, an all-time high, are estimated as the total sales for 1936, according to a survey of manufacturers' production and Federal excise tax returns completed by Radio Today.

A permanent injunction against unauthorized use of the term and designation "realtor" has been Issued by the Superior Court of Cook County, Ill., in a case brought by the Chicago Real Estate Board and the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

THE new automotive season will get off to a running start next Saturday when a prominent Detroit car company publicly announces its 1937 models. The announcements will be of uncommon interest because a six-cylinder car will be added to the company's line of eight-cylinder cars.

ROME, Aug. 28. -- Despite her official attitude of neutrality since the outbreak of the Spanish revolution Italy's interest has been extremely keen in a victory for General Francisco Franco's insurgents. This can easily be understood if one pauses to consider the benefits of a political, strategic and economic nature that Italy would derive from a permanent Right dictatorship in that Mediterranean State.

THE Fallston Hill Road on Pennsylvania Route 51, northwest of Pittsburgh, has been reopened to passenger car and westbound truck traffic, it is reported. As was related here last week, citizens of Fallston barricaded the road and closed it to all traffic after a succession of fatal and otherwise serious accidents.

Prices of cotton seesawed last week and futures closed on the New York Cotton Exchange at net declines of 6 to 17 points. It was the fifth consecutive week in which net changes were on the minus side.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- A consideration of Great Britain's industrial and financial position at this time brings to light extremely encouraging factors both in regard to current activity and the prospect of its maintenance.

Charles Chaplin has determined upon the next starring picture for his protegee, Paulette Goddard. It will be based on D.L. Murray's "Regency," which the comedian has just purchased. The picture will follow the currently projected film, now known only as "Production No. 6."

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 30. -- Neutral shipping in the Strait of Gibraltar was endangered this afternoon when big Spanish Rebel guns near Ceuta, Morocco, opened fire on the Spanish Leftist warship Libertad after the ship had poured broadsides into Tarifa Point near Algeciras on the Spanish side of the Strait.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Late news of the corn crop last week was more mixed. A private report covering a large part of the territory in Central Illinois, extending into Iowa, shows an absence of full ears, as the result of numerous factors that seldom come in ordinary years.
Alfredo Salmaggi and his opera company last night offered Rossini's "Barber of Seville" at the Hippodrome Theatre, attracting another near-capacity audience of 5,000 persons.
The youngest contestant in the Eastern United States Open Horseshoe Pitching championship won the title in Central Park yesterday after a tense playoff with two older rivals.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 30. -- Members of society devoted to polo had to decide this afternoon which of three matches to attend -- the first game of the open championship at Meadow Brook, where the favorite Greentrees played the Auroras; the match at Sands Point, where the Texas and Roslyn teams met on the club field, and that at Bostwick Field.

BERLIN, Aug. 29. -- After substantial recovery in the first half of the week, stocks on the Boerse mostly closed below the semi-panic level of the Friday before. From the temporary recovery of Monday to Wednesday, steels derived most benefit for the comeback, gaining 4 to 6 points.

PARIS, Aug. 29. -- The French money market remains very quiet and despite the approach of the month-end expansion there has been no tightening in rates. Call money is still at 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 per cent, outside discounts are at 3 to 3 1/4 per cent and treasury hill discounts are at 3 to 3 1/8 per cent.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 30. -- The strange, practice of making boy inmates of the Hudson County Parental School here wear the clothing of girls as a form of punishment was declared today by Dr. William G. Ellis, New Jersey Commissioner of Institutions, to be "most unusual and psychologically unsound."

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, the country's sixth ranking woman player, scored an impressive victory over Miss Kay Stammers, ranked second in England, in the feature match of the second and final day of exhibition matches at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

PARIS, Aug. 29. -- The Bourse was irregular this week but the market's tendency was better than last week's although business was dull. News of the lengthening of Germany's compulsory army service was received with great calmness.
MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 30 (AP). -- The Mexican Government decided tonight to increase the silver content of its money because of the declining world price of silver.

RAPID CITY, S.D., Aug. 30. -- President Roosevelt today dedicated the second figure in the Mount Rushmore memorial monument, a gigantic head of Thomas Jefferson, as a symbol for future generations of current efforts to give citizens better government and better living.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- The Giants took two from the Cubs today, one the hard way, as they dropped the Chicagoans to third place, five games off the pennant pace, before the season's largest crowd at Wrigley Field.

SEATTLE, Aug. 30. -- With the strike of the American Newspaper Guild against The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, a Hearst morning newspaper, apparently deadlocked, with no visible hope of a peaceful settlement, friends of both sides are drawing battle lines for what may be a decisive struggle between capital and labor in this section.

" Muggsey" the 6-months-old wire-haired terrier which disappeared mysteriously last Friday was returned last night almost as mysteriously to Shirley E. Powers, 14 years old, of 32-43 Eighty-sixth Street, Jackson Heights, who had the police department and the city at large helping her search for the dog.

BELINDA JELLIFFE is the wife of Dr. Smith Ely Jelliffe, one of New York's better known psychiatrists. She was born Belinda Dan in a North Carolina barn. Under the feminine title, "For Dear Life" (Scribner, $2.75), she offers her autobiography, a story of search and conflict that is in the image of the poems that have lasted longest, that have always been written by men.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 30. -- Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes survived their first test in the national open polo championship by subduing the rugged Old Westbury quartet, which included the three spares of the Argentine squad in its line-up, in a bitter struggle at Bostwick Field today.

Indifference to the work of communal agencies was described as "irresponsible citizenship" yesterday by Gerard Swope, chairman of the 1936 Mobilization for Human Needs, in announcing the names of 101 leaders in many fields who will serve as members of the national citizens' committee for the mobilization.

Summer approached its end last week, with evidence of continuing trade expansion. While steel output reached 73 per cent of capacity, highest of any August since 1929, the Federal Reserve placed the country's July "production index" at 108, against 86 a year before.

A 17-year-old girl, believed by the police to be one of several feminine passers working for a counterfeit gang that has been passing bogus money to small shopowners in Brooklyn in the last few weeks, was arrested Saturday night charged with having attempted to pay for a purchase in a Brooklyn butcher shop with a fake $20 bill.

Displaying their art before their sixth consecutive gala Sunday audience, the Yankees took two more gigantic strides toward clinching the American League's 1936 pennant at the Stadium yesterday as they deftly hurdled the White Sox in both halves of a double-header.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug, 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. gave a dinner party tonight at Belvoir Terrace, Lenox, for their weekend guests, Mr. and Mrs. Shepard Titcomb and Mrs. Louise Leland of Boston.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Charles Kurtsinger, one of the outstanding jockeys of recent years, was under arrest here today as a hit-and-run driver. A charge of leaving the scene of an accident was changed to homicide after the victim, Miss Anna Ray, 49 years old, of 166 Woodworth Avenue, here, died in St. John's Hospital.
AVELLINO, Italy, Aug. 30. -- Following is the text of Premier Benito Mussolini's address today:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Newark divided today's twin bill with Baltimore. The Orioles rode to a 6-to-4 victory in the first game when Ab Wright homered with two mates aboard in the ninth, then lost the nightcap 6 to 2. This game was called at the end of the sixth because of darkness.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, spent today reviewing the effect of Governor Landon's swing into the East. He said that headquarters was pleased with the reactions, as evidenced by thousands of letters, telegrams and telephone calls.

A young medical student in his early twenties who will go back to his scalpel and test tubes at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons for his third year next month had the highlight yesterday of his Summer vacation as a yachtsman by winning the first annual Captain Billopp Trophy race.

Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind" topped all the fiction best-seller lists submitted last week by stores, and also led the Baker Taylor list based on actual count. "Drums Along the Mohawk" was second on the Baker Taylor list, and "Eyeless in Gaza" third. "

Mayor La Guardia appealed to the teamsters union and the merchant truckmen of New York City "to exert every effort" by direct negotiation to avert the threatened strike of 15,000 truck drivers. He offered his own offices or those of any agency of the city to mediate the controversy should direct negotiations fail.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- To the question whether the present expansion of industry in England will be maintained or even increased in the coming Autumn, qualified affirmative answers are being given. Some still struggling trades at length are showing signs of recovery, while the most depressed industry of all, namely coal, should derive benefit from the reorganization now progressing.

A group of forty American students, headed by J.C. Dengler of New York, returned from a two-month tour of England and Germany yesterday, arriving on the Cunard White Star liner Georgic with bicycles and knapsacks, into which all their traveling paraphernalia was crammed.

A flaming airplane dropped out of the sky last night like a meteorite and plunged into a picnic party on Old Ferry Point, a peninsula of the Bronx, killing one person and injuring three others. There was no chance for escape as the blazing plane cut its way through the nearby marsh and plowed into the midst of the picnickers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, acting at the direction of President Roosevelt, sent notes tonight to the Spanish Government and to General Francisco Franco, commander of the Rebel forces, protesting against the dropping of bombs by an unidentified airplane near the United States destroyer Kane in the Bay of Biscay.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 30. -- The intellectual caravan converging at Harvard from all parts of the earth for the opening here tomorrow of the celebration of the anniversary of 300 years of higher learning in America has been asked by the Harvard faculty, which has spent two years in preparing the program for the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences, to take part in a novel experiment on a gigantic scale.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Supplies of hogs in the market here last week were liberal but prices were unsettled. The top on Friday was $11.45 a hundred pounds, compared with $11.60 a week before. The week's average was $10.15, compared with $10.30 in the previous week, $10.55 a year ago, and $7.45 two years ago.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 30. -- The Arab High Committee today unanimously accepted the intervention of General Nuri Pasha as-Said on behalf of the Iraq Government in an effort to terminate the strife in Palestine. The following proclamation was issued by the Arab High Committee and signed by the President Haj Amin el Husseini:

RAPID CITY, S.D., Aug. 30. -- Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde has resigned from the post of Minister to Denmark to enter the active campaign for the re-election of President Roosevelt, it was announced here tonight by the President's office aboard his private train.

A new skirmish in the Sunnyside Gardens mortgage war loomed yesterday as the Sunnyside Home Owners Mortgage Committee prepared to offer organized resistance to the scheduled eviction this week of Steve George, 71 years old, and his wife, Mary, from their home at 39-06 Forty-seventh Street.

MADRID, Aug. 30. -- Spain's Anarchist and Syndicalist leaders spoke out tonight to halt "monstrous" acts by zealots within their own ranks, while a watchful fleet of government planes droned constantly over Madrid to block a new Rebel raid from the air.
BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The Red Sox gave Bob Feller, 17-year-old strikeout phenomenon, a cuffing today while sweeping a double-header with the Indians before 21,000.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 30. -- Saving its thunder until the late stages and then striking with swiftness and finesse, the Texas quartet today galloped into the semi-final round of the national open polo championship via a thrilling 10-to-9 triumph over Roslyn at the Sands Point Club.

VIENNA, Aug. 30. -- The great news in Central Europe this weekend is the disappearance of Nicolas Titulescu from the Rumanian Cabinet. The "perpetual Foreign Minister," who has survived so many other Rumanian crises, has been dropped like a servant who has survived his usefulness.
MADRID, Aug. 30 (AP). -- A new warning that citizens of the United States have one more chance to leave Spain, or remain only at their own risk, was issued tonight by the American Embassy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Analyzing Governor Landon's Buffalo tax speech, Senator Clark of Missouri, in a statement issued through the Democratic National Committee today, declared it was filled with "inconsistencies and incongruities."

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Roland Munroe, 15-year choir boy, confessed today, according to the police, that he murdered Mrs. Agnes Roffeis, 65 years old, a widow and semi-invalid, for a small box of jewelry worth not more than $10. The youth, a newsboy who made a daily delivery at her home, said he wanted the money "for shows and things."

The first comprehensive "balance sheet" of the Works Progress Administration's contribution to the city's streets, sewers, parks and other facilities and services, was made public yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator.

PARIS, Aug. 30. -- France welcomed General Edward Rydz-Smigly, the Polish dictator, heartily and hopefully today but found plenty to worry about in the rude elimination of Nicolas Titulescu, veteran Foreign Minister, from the Rumanian Cabinet.

Greenwich Village echoed pistol fire at daybreak yesterday as a radio patrol car chased two Brooklyn youths driving a stolen maroon roadster. The chase ended in front of 288 West Eleventh Street with a resounding crash.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 30. -- Spain's wandering ocean liner, the Cristobal Colon, reached a safe and friendly port today -- under the very noses of Rebel warships.

The Christian Church can have no part nor lot with the teachers' oath bills, "gag laws" and curbs on the right of labor to organize and bargain collectively, the annual "Labor Message" of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America declares.

At the end of last week the game of hurling charges of personal and party inconsistency was kept up with great animation. Some one handed Senator ROBINSON the now familiar citations of what Governor LANDON said about certain aspects of the New Deal in 1933 and 1934, and, though they were not at all relevant to the Senator's speech, he made use of them with great relish.

Today marks the beginning of a conference of world scholars that gives promise of being the most important and significant in the history of higher education. The occasion is the celebration of the three hundredth anniversary of the founding of Harvard College. Yet it is not a conventional "family" affair, a self-congratulatory glorying over Harvard's proud past.

Sir Arthur Eddington, British physicist and theorist, announced yesterday that he had completed his calculations on the total number of electrons comprising the world in which we live. Electrons, infinitesimal units of matter in the universe, are believed to be the ultimate constituents of the atom.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- In an analysis dealing with the part played by the insurance companies of the United States in the balance of international payments covering the seventeen years from 1919 to 1935, inclusive, the Department of Commerce made public today its estimate that approximately $93,800,000 net was transferred from the United States to foreign countries on insurance account in that period.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30. -- A year ago Alexei Stakhanoff went down in a mine in the Don Basin region, where he had been cutting an average of thirteen tons of coal a day. By application of division of labor, he cut 200 tons that day. This launched the Stakhanoff movement, which has revolutionized Soviet industrial methods.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., Aug. 30. -- A number of White Mountain visitors entertained here at the Mountain View House dinner dance last evening. Mr. and Mrs. Soreno Lund of the Hotel Waumber, Jefferson, had a party here, as did Mrs. Randall Spalding of Spalding Inn, Whitefield.

R.F. Barrett questions what he terms my "thesis that gold certificates are merely warehouse receipts for an equivalent amount of gold coin and that the legal and equitable titles to this coin rest in the owner of the certificates." This, he says, "is, unfortunately, incorrect," adding: "The original owner of the bullion or coin sold the gold to the government and received paper currency in return."

STONEVILLE, Miss., Aug. 30. -- Skeptically and with some misgivings the cotton South was awaiting today an actual field test of the only mechanical cotton picker ever taken seriously in a land that long ago wearied of rumors about substitutes for human fingers.

PARIS, Aug. 29. -- Business prospects for the United States this Autumn are considered good here. Rising prices and government financial assistance will offset drought losses suffered by the farmers and, as a result, general buying capacity of the population will not be curtailed.

The disease of our present civilization is the plague of isolation and of disintegration, the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of Colgate-Rochester Baptist Divinity School of Rochester, N.Y., said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The magazine Steel said today that steelworks operations advanced 1 point to 73 per cent of capacity last week -- "a new six-year high." This rate, it said, was maintained despite a decline of 19,772 units in automobile production.

Plans for the Queens Midtown Vehicular Tunnel have been approved by Arthur S. Turtle, State Director of the PWA, and bids for construction of the first shaft in Queens will be received up to Sept. 15, the New York City Tunnel Authority announced yesterday.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week was devoid of special feature. Fluctuations in rates were narrow, while business was limited to routine requirements and preparations to meet month-end commitments.

Arthur Krock's article "Why Diplomats Are Startled by 'Ideas'" reveals a state of mind typical among men trained in the diplomatic service throughout the world. Prime Ministers and heads of State Departments are no less free from a certain feeling of apprehension at the very mention of a conference to consider some practical solution that would dispense with enormous outlays of public funds that enrich the munitions makers.

BIRIATOU, France, Aug. 30. -- The Battle for Irun, or, at least its first stage, is over and the result can best be characterized as a draw. Both sides, exhausted by their efforts, engaged today in reorganizing their battered forces and consolidating positions they had captured or those to which they had been forced to retire.

Before starting on his trip to inspect the drought-ravaged States, President ROOSEVELT declared that there would be absolutely no politics in it. No one has questioned the sincerity of this announced intention. The President would feel the shrinking of any public man with a fine sense of propriety from the thought of trying to make political capital out of a national calamity.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,156,541,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Max Krause, veteran back from Gonzaga, today joined the New York Giants in camp at the Blue Hills C.C. where the eastern pro gridiron champions are preparing to meet the College All-Stars at the Polo Grounds on Tuesday night, Sept. 8.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 for securities with estimated gross proceeds of $362,925,000 became fully effective in July, lifting the total for the first seven months of the year to $3,027,872,000, or approximately $350,000,000 more than the $2,677,000,000 for the twelve months of 1935.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 73 per cent of capacity, unchanged. August as a whole will show a decided increase over July, and probably will exceed May, which would make it the busiest month since February, 1930.

With a determination to conserve the Hudson River Valley as the "Rhineland of America," a group of prominent residents of this city and up-State organized the Hudson River Conservation Society. A certificate of incorporation will be filed in Albany today in behalf of a committee headed by William Church Osborn, an attorney of this city who has a home at Garrison, in Putnam County.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Over-buying in the speculative grain markets the last few weeks discounted all bullish conditions in the main and brought a liquidating movement as well as liberal short selling which carried prices down fully as rapidly as they had recently advanced.

EAST IPTON, L. I., Aug. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Martin Henry gave a buffet supper for 100 this evening at PIearthstones,he home of i Mrs. Henry's parents, Mr. and Mrs. 01hey B. Mairs, in honor of Miss Priscilla Godwin and Pierson Mapes, whose marriage will take place Sept. 11.

After nine months of research and experimentation, the Fire Department will begin within a few weeks the installation of two-way radio equipment on the city's nine fire boats and the construction of a transmitter in the Fire College building in Long Island City.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Dozens of offers of aid from over the country poured in today on Mr. and Mrs. Morris Levitt while they demonstrated their parental devotion by becoming human "test tubes" to develop a serum against the dreaded streptococci infection threatening the life of their son Philip, 7.
IRUN, Spain, Aug. 30 (AP). -- A Rebel threat to bombard this northern Spanish city by land, sea and air at dawn tomorrow caused the authorities to begin tonight the evacuation of women and children.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Eighth-inning rallies sent Cincinnati to a double victory over Philadelphia today, 6 to 3 and 4 to 3. The Reds took fifth place undisputed after Boston, previously tied with them, lost twice to Pittsburgh.

The human tongue has been perverted from a thing of beauty to an instrument for the propagation of profanity, the Rev. Robert W. Courtney said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Knox Memorial Reformed Church, 405 West Forty-first Street.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

In the heat of a campaign the voter would be extremely fortunate if he could depend upon either party to tell him the completely candid truth about anything. Even when he is spared downright falsehoods and distortions, he must resign himself at best to hearing from each side only those selected facts favorable to that side.

RAPID CITY, S.D., Aug. 30. -- President Roosevelt instructed the State Department by telephone late today to make immediate representations to the Spanish Government and the leaders of the Spanish revolutionary forces following the bombing of a United States destroyer by an unidentified airplane off the coast of Spain.
LIMA, Peru, Aug. 30. -- President Oscar R. Benavides today decreed a compulsory social insurance law which had been drawn up by a special committee named by Congress.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- While the reports of banks and chambers of commerce and authorities in general are optimistic on the growth of the world's industrial production, they hold that international trade is unlikely to increase substantially.

Every time President ROOSEVELT comes into a drought area he brings rain. The first rain in a month greeted his arrival in the stricken sections of North Dakota. It was the same thing, as Mr. ROOSEVELT pointed out to an audience on Friday, two years ago.

The Japanese colony of New York visited a bit of old Japan yesterday afternoon -- a Japan encompassed by teakwood decks and steel strakes -- and were reminded that the code of the samurai and the traditions of the past are still venerated in the Japanese Navy.

TOLEDO, Spain, Aug. 30. -- The crumbling northern wall of Toledo's Alcazar, once the fortified residence of Moorish and Castilian monarchs, bore evidence today of the desperate plight of nearly 2,000 Rebels inside.

THERE will be a lightweight championship fight at the Garden this week and probably most of the ringsiders will be rooting for Tony Canzoneri, the defending champion. They couldn't pick a better man in his profession.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 30. -- More than fifty persons were rescued from a heavy surf while bathing today at Jones Beach and Point Lookout Beach. Three persons, including a lifeguard, were taken to Meadow Brook Hospital for treatment and four others received treatment on the beaches.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The Athletics and Tigers divided a double-header before 18,000 today, the Hacks winning the first, 5 to 4, in twelve innings and Detroit taking the second, 3 to 2. Tommy Bridges outpitched Horace Lisenbe in the nightcap.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, in a statement yesterday reviewed reports from party leaders in forty-one States, and on the basis of them predicted a landslide victory for President Roosevelt in his re-election campaign.

Mrs. Frederick Nathan of Morris, Conn., philanthropist and social worker, announced yesterday, through the Eastern division of the Republican National Committee, her intention to support the Presidential candidacy of Governor Landon of Kansas.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30. -- A three-base clout by George Watkins salvaged the second game for the Dodgers in the thirteenth inning today, after they had been defeated in the opener by Dizzy Dean.

PARIS, Aug. 29. -- The prevailing opinion here is that the present weakness of the franc is attributable not so much to exports of capital to foreign countries but rather to the requirements for foreign exchange for trade and debt payments.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30. -- Mrs. Norrie Seller and Miss Eva Dahlgren entertained with beach luncheon parties today. There were many home luncheons Saturday. Among those entertaining were Dr. and Mrs. Henry Barton Jacobs, Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Young, Mr. and Mrs. Willing Spencer, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Tomlinson and the Misses Wetmore.

MADRID, Aug. 30 (Passed by the Censor). -- The Anarcho-Syndicalist Federation today issued a manifesto denouncing the "monstrous acts" committed by men disguised as members of this organization or by Fascists dressed as militiamen and in possession of member cards of this organization.

For the fourth successive year, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will have an important place on the program of the annual convention of the American Bankers Association. A schedule of the speeches planned for the forthcoming convention, to be held in San Francisco from Sept. 21 to 24, was announced yesterday by Robert V. Fleming, president of the association.

soUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 30.-Ar. and Ars. George A. Legg, who are passing the late season at the Irving. gave a luncheon today at the Beach Club for Mrs. Legg's daughter, Mrs. Bruce F. E. Harvey, to celebrate her birthday. The guests included also Air. tIarvey, ! who with Mrs. Harvey is visiting] his aunt, Mrs. John E. Berwind, atI Niinden, and Mr. and Ars. JohnI Bacon Aspegren, who are also at! the Irving.
The final audited report of the Associated Gas and Electric Company

AVELLINO, Italy, Aug. 30. -- Premier Benito Mussolini reiterated today Italy's desire for peace, at the same time telling the nation that an irresistible armament race was under way. He emphasized that political situations required the Italian people "to be so strong that we can face any eventualities."

Southern Brazil probably will increase its production of cotton much more slowly in the future if current conditions there continue, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service, which says this statement is based on information given it by Jose Garibaldi Dantas, chief of the Cotton Classification Commission of Sao Paulo.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Norwegian officials gave strong indications tonight the government would disregard Soviet Russia's request for the expulsion of Leon Trotsky and permit the former Communist leader to remain in Norway.
Is it not high time and important that some one with leisure and facilities at his disposal inquired exhaustively into the furor aroused over the teachers' oath of allegiance?

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Jimmy Hines, long-hitting Long Island professional, turned the annual Glens Falls open golf championship into a one-man show today as he regained the honors he had won in 1933.

Six persons were injured in an explosion aboard a twenty-eight-foot cabin cruiser at City Island about 5 P.M. yesterday. All the victims were rescued from Long Island Sound, some of them thrown in by the force of the explosion and the others jumping to escape the flames.

YREKA, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP). -- Two law-enforcement officers, and a maritime pilot were shot to death today at Horse Creek, isolated mining settlement near here, in a battle with two prospectors, who fled before a rapidly growing mob apparently bent on lynching.
SALISBURY, Md., Aug. 30. -- Salisbury experienced a record fall of rain last night and early today -- eight and nine-tenths inches in five hours.

A banking group headed by Charles D. Barney Co., the Wells-Dickey Company of Minneapolis and Bacon, Whipple Co. of Chicago will offer to the public today at $20 a share 34,160 shares of $1-par common stock of the W.H. Barber Company, wholesale distributors of gasoline and other petroleum products, naval stores and tires and automobile accessories in the Middle West.

Sixto Escobar of Puerto Rico will risk his claim to the world's bantamweight championship tonight when he opposes Tony Marino, Pittsburgh battier, in the feature bout of fifteen rounds at Dyckman Oval. Escobar is recognized as the titleholder in the 118-pound division by the New York State Athletic Commission and Marino enjoys the championship status in the eyes of the International Boxing Union.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 29. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.8, which compares with 84.1 the week before, 84 two weeks before, 84.3 three weeks before and 83.7 four weeks before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Further allegations of laxity in the keeping and safeguarding of notes given for loans made by the Resettlement Administration were made in a statement today by the Republican National Committee, which quoted a survey made by James E. Roads of the Mail and Files Section of the administration.

Accused of the fatal stabbing of a man with whom she had been drinking Saturday night in a Queens Village tavern, Mrs. Catherine Balser, 39 years old, of 215-13 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, was held without bail in Jamaica court yesterday for a hearing Sept. 9.

VALENCIA, Spain, Aug. 30. -- The Spanish tragedy continues to work toward a climax which may be reached this week. Madrid lives precariously from day to day, the fate of a great number of her 1,750,000 inhabitants at the mercy of events.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 30. -- A stiff northwest wind from the Lake Erie region swept the ranges today and the small bore and pistol shooters found plenty of opposition from the element, which interfered with their markmanship.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Aug. 30. -- Governor C.S. Ridley of the Panama Canal Zone announced today the appointment of Courtney T. Lindsay as general manager of the Panama Railroad Company to succeed R.B. Walker who died recently at Hot Springs, Ark.
Arthur Howe, secretary of the Montauk Yacht Club, relays a fish story that is typical of the offshore game, in which you never know what will happen next.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30. -- There was good trading in spot cotton here last week, but the business in futures contracts was erratic -- active at times but generally smaller in volume than in the preceding two weeks. While there was fair trade buying and also buying by foreign interests, there was but limited speculative buying, scarcely sufficient to absorb the growing volume of hedges against purchases of spots.

The four Interclub Class sloops which will meet the Bermuda one-design craft in the international match that starts on Long Island Sound off the Larchmont Yacht Club on Wednesday were named yesterday. The United States team will be made up of Charles B. Stuart's Ariel, Cornelius Shields's Aileen, R. McC. Shields's Canvasback and Lawrence Marx's Alberta.

Driving their own cars from their homes, forty-nine winners of the national "safe driving" contest conducted by the Commercial Investment Trust Safety Foundation and the American Automobile Association will arrive in New York this morning to attend a three-day safety conference at the Waldorf-Astoria.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (AP). -- The Pirates beat the Bees in both games today before 8,000, 4 to 2 and 3 to 1.

Preliminary to the refunding of the company's $2,518,500 of its five-year 6 per cent notes maturing on Feb. 1, 1937, the directors of the Thermoid Company have proposed a plan of recapitalization which would eliminate the book deficit in the surplus account and clear up all arrears in dividends and sinking-fund obligations on the present preferred stock.

Secretary Ickes's radio address, "Hearst Over Topeka," following Governor Landon's Chautauqua and Buffalo speeches, has clarified in this reader's mind the nature of the relationship between Mr. Hearst and the Kansas Governor.

GALLUP, N.M., Aug. 30. -- Colonel Roscoe Turner, holder of the transcontinental East-West air record, crashed on a little Zuni Indian farm about sixty-five miles south of here early today, but survived the wreckage of his bulletlike racing plane with minor injuries.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Pope Pius XI urged a group of pilgrims tonight to pray "lest the continued atrocities of men" result in "a grave affliction for Godless humanity."
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 30. -- Governor Landon passed a quiet Sunday with Lacy Haynes, Kansas manager of The Kansas City Star, at the latter's home in Bonner Springs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The prediction that the use of electricity will increase as rapidly in the next fifteen years as in the last fifteen years, with a doubling of the present use, has been made by those who have prepared surveys for the Third World Power Conference, scheduled to begin sessions here on Sept. 7, representatives of the conference announced today.

MUKDEN, Manchukuo, Aug. 30. -- Now that troops are definitely on the move in the Kwang-tung-Kwangsi area of South China, the position of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and the Nanking Government has become one of extreme difficulty, complicated as it is by the murder of two Japanese in Chengtu, with a dangerous revival of violent anti-Japanese manifestations expected in many localities.

YAPHANK, L.I., Aug. 30. -- The German-American residents of Long Island, supplemented by visitors from Manhattan and the Bronx, held their own celebration of the Long Island Tercentenary at Camp Siegfried here today. The occasion was primarily the first German Day of Long Island, and it brought at least 15,000 persons to this small mid-island community.
RAPID CITY, S.D., Aug. 30. -- The text of President Roosevelt's informal address today at Mount Rushmore National Memorial was as follows:

There is a need today for more cross-bearers, more people who will voluntarily undertake tasks for the good of others, the Right Rev. Stephen E. Keeler, Bishop Coadjutor of Minnesota, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

Abysmal ignorance and nothing else is the cause of the "insane hatred" communistic Spain is displaying toward the Catholic Church, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer, assistant rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared at high mass there yesterday.

OCEAN BEACH, L.I., Aug. 30. -- A supposed race with the stork early this morning cost two Coast Guardsmen several hours of sleep, but, in the parlance of the race tracks, it was "no race." The stork failed to appear.

POLAND, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Pledging their full backing to a milk holiday if one is called in the near future, more than 5,000 dairymen heard the Milk Board's classified price plan and Commissioner Peter G. Ten Eyck assailed anew at a State-wide mass meeting here this afternoon.

BELLMORE, L.I., Aug. 30. -- Two waiters were killed by a hit-and-run driver today as they walked along Sunrise Highway, about 800 feet west of New Bridge Road here. The victims were discovered by Nassau County policemen in a patrol car and identified as Nils Evert Persson, 33 years old, of 245 East Sixty-second Street, New York City, and Hann Lau, 30, of Bellmore.

If James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, should ask former Mayor James J. Walker to take the stump for President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman he would be guilty of "a brazen insult to the voters of New York State," Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee, declared in a statement yesterday.
