Efforts to reach an agreement in the strike of 12,000 members of the Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers Union, District Council 9, failed last night when representatives of the union and of employers ended a meeting at the Hotel Commodore with an announcement that they had not been able to come to terms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Building permits issued in the principal cities during July fell slightly below the June level, but the value of residential construction increased 14 per cent and the value of additions and repairs advanced slightly, according to a report made yesterday to Secretary of Labor Perkins by Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

It was learned yesterday that the Jimmy Savo-"White Horse Inn" controversy ended Friday with the signing of an agreement whereby the actor will receive, during the run of the spectacle, 55 per cent of the salary he would have received had he appeared in the show.

From the Battery to Inwood, and in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and on Staten Island, restaurant men spent quiet Sunday hours yesterday painting signs similar in text. They read: "Oysters R In Season."

The economic advantages of employing an advertising agency, in preference to maintaining a costly advertising department, were commented upon by Carlton H. Smith, of Buggelin Smith, Inc., in "The New Viewpoint," house pamphlet of the agency.

With thirteen named for the featured Woodmere Claiming Stakes, thoroughbred racing returns to the metropolitan area today with the opening of a fifteen-day meeting at Aqueduct. Six races are down for decision, with the probability that there will be some scratches from the main event.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- A rank and file referendum in the American Federation of Labor's family quarrel was proposed today by Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union.

ALBANY, Aug. 30. -- Those employers who are affected by the State's Unemployment Insurance Law will be subject after Tuesday to two new official instructions, according to Glenn A. Bowers, director of placement and employment insurance of the State Department of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP). -- Ben Chapman's bat brought Washington victory today in both ends of a double-header with St. Louis. The Senators won the first, 5 to 4, and took the nightcap, 7 to 4.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- Lower prices were made here last week for provisions because of liquidation in sympathy with the decline in grains and the low prices for hogs. Trade expectations are that there will be only a moderate change in stocks of lard here in the report to be issued on Monday.

An article in THE TIMES presented the statement of the Westchester-Rockland Crossing Authority in favor of the proposed bridge from Nyack to Tarrytown. The arguments against this project are much stronger than the arguments for it.

Faith, generosity and imagination are three attributes that every man must possess if he wishes to get along with his loved ones and friends and enjoy a happy life, declared the Rev. Dr. F. Raymond Clee, president of the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Madison Avenue, a street rich in the lore of New York and which for many years seemed half hidden between the bustling activity of shopping on Fifth Avenue and the modern apartment residences of Park Avenue, will be the center of a hundredth anniversary celebration the week of Oct. 4.

ALBANY, Aug. 30. -- The missing check used by the Drukman prosecution last week to show Governor Lehman that District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan failed to submit a murder motive to the April grand jury was traced by the Brooklyn District Attorney over the week-end.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- Crossing the Atlantic from west to east in 3 days 23 hours 57 minutes, or three hours and thirty-one minutes less than the best time of her French rival, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary surged past Bishop's Rock in the Scilly Isles at 7:12 tonight, Greenwich time.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- The Reich's announcement of its adoption of a two-year military service policy, on the whole, cleared the air and abated financial nervousness here. As a result, stocks early in the week enjoyed a considerable, although not a continuous, recovery.

Champion Vigow of Romanoff, famed Russian wolfhound, bred, owned and shown in the ring by Louis J. Murr of Spring Valley, N.Y., yesterday added one more triumph to his remarkable record when he was awarded the title of best dog in the first show of the Staten Island Kennel Club, which was held on the grounds of the Elks Club at Oakwood.

PINE VALLEY, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Indications of a possible break in the British ranks appeared today as the American and British Walker Cup teams continued their practice for the international matches next Wednesday and Thursday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 30. -- Greentree rolled to victory on International Field today in its first game in defense of the national open polo championship. Facing an Aurora team which had lost its captain on the eve of the opening match, the pink-shirted riders moved from the opening bell to the attack and they stayed on the attack nearly all the way.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 30. -- Large sections of land within the States of Durango and Coahuila, Mexico's greatest cotton-producing provinces, will be given to the workers, it was declared by labor leaders today after a night conference with President Lazaro Cardenas.

When one grows weary of the daily blasts of State chairmen, national chairmen and the corps of political "barkers," one turns almost with relief to the one-man show in Georgia. It is not much less intellectual and for a change it is more amusing. The Democratic primary in Mississippi was a bad omen for Governor TALMADGE of Georgia.

The Hapag Lloyd and Gdynia America steamship lines announced yesterday that they had added extra ships to their September lists to handle the unusually large crowds of passengers returning from Europe.

The ideas which "God gave the world through Jesus" are winning their "slow but inevitable victory," the Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, pastor of the South Congregational Church of Springfield, Mass., said yesterday in a sermon at the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Realty contracts reported in the city over the week-end included the purchase for investment of the nine story and penthouse apartment building at 124-26 West Fifty-fifth Street, near Sixth Avenue, by Maurice Epstein, treasurer of General Estates, Inc.
May I as one of the 180,000 dairy farmers in up-State New York -- each unit supporting five persons -- contribute a few observations to the discussion regarding the price of milk?

Wholesale dry goods houses in all parts of the country are registering sharp gains in sales, in comparison with last year's volume, according to figures released by the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute. Typical comparisons supplied to the institute of gains in July over the same month last year, with the increases in the first three weeks of August over those in the corresponding period in 1935 given in parentheses are as follows:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30. -- The annual open championship tournament of the American Chess Federation ended today in victory for Israel A. Horowitz of the Manhattan Club of New York.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 30. -- The Peconic Club, meeting place of many socially prominent residents here, was raided at 4 o'clock this morning by eight State troopers under the direction of C.J. Sullivan. Five of the club's personnel, including John E. Mack, proprietor, were taken into custoday, charged with being common gamblers.

Four tenement houses that figured in a recent foreclosure action changed hands yesterday when the Greenwich Savings Bank sold the six-story walk-ups at 214 to 220 West 140th Street, in Harlem. The buyer is Louis Lipman, who paid cash over first mortgages aggregating $133,000 for the property.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Bill Cox registered another victory with Robert McC. Shields's Canvasback today in a race which saw the leaders in the interclub class Royal Bermuda Yacht Club series justify their high ratings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The United States Embassy in Madrid has issued a final warning to the 164 Americans who are still in the Spanish capital, urging them to leave by special train Wednesday night for Alicante, there to board the cruiser Quincy Thursday morning, the State Department announced today. Every American in Madrid was personally notified to this effect by the consulate yesterday.

It took "Uncle" Charles Hertzog, 79 years old, a month to hitch-hike to New York City from New Orleans, but when he starts back today he will travel by train with money jingling in his pockets to provide for his needs on the way. The State Department of Social Welfare, with the cooperation of the Travelers Aid Society, has made arrangements to send him back to the Soldiers Home in New Orleans.

The songs of the horse and buggy era which have lived through several generations were a perfect wedding of words and melody, and therefore the parodies on such songs used in the Republican campaign are weak and have the opposite effect from that intended.

On Sept. 14 the old superstition, in vain demolished by scientific study, that "as goes Maine, so goes the nation," will be revived as usual. The day after omen-readers will be jubilating or explaining. Both sides are bound to be pleased in public whether they are or not.

American participation in the Olympic Games should be a government concern in the future, according to Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president and director of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, who returned from Europe yesterday on the French liner Normandie.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 31. -- Approval of disciplinary measures employed at the Hudson County Parental School here, where boys who attempt to escape are forced to wear girls' clothing and have their heads cropped, was expressed today by Walter O. Reed, president of the board of trustees, which supervises the institution.

THOUGH 90 years old, the Captain was still too young. Sitting on a Boston rocker in his Cape Cod farmhouse the other day, he spoke in angry tones. "Take my word for it, young man," said he, "the situation has never been as bad. And I've lived a mighty long time; during the Civil War I helped run guns up the James River to Grant, who was surrounding Richmond.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Aug. 31 (AP). -- Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old runner-up in the women's national golf tournament last year, led the way in the qualifying round of the Mason-Dixon tournament today with a 78.

B.S.B. Stevens, Premier and Colonial Treasurer of New South Wales, Australia, predicted in an interview yesterday that the development of the United States during the last century might be paralleled by that of Australia in this century.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 31. -- Saluted by every ship in the harbor and cheered by thousands who lined the shore, the liner Queen Mary sailed proudly up Southampton Water today at the end of the fastest round trip ever made across the North Atlantic.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 31. -- Only a few days ago the Tataescu government was lauding in the press. Dr. Nicolas Titulescu's achievements; today the government press lists the former Foreign Minister's "sins."

More than three months of speculation over rug and carpet price trends ended in the floor-coverings industry yesterday with the announcement by the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, one of the three large volume producers, that prices on many of their lines will advance 5 to 7 per cent Sept. 15.

ROME, Aug. 31. -- Germany's official approval of Premier Benito Mussolini's Avellino speech was indicated this morning by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Propaganda Minister, when he addressed members of the German colony in Venice before departing by air for Berlin.

APPLETON, Wis., Aug. 31. -- The problem of uniting the religions of the United States, not under one banner of dogma or doctrine, but under a united front to deal with civic, social and welfare problems of the nation was discussed here tonight by three clergymen of the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish faiths.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Prices of hogs here today were steady to as much as 10 cents a hundredweight higher than on Friday. Sows composed a smaller percentage of the arrivals and led the advance, while weights below 180 pounds were somewhat draggy.

The Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers' Union, District Council 9, will appeal today to the eighteen locals of the Building Trades Council for support of its strike of 12,000 union painters in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond, according to Louis Weinstock, secretary of the council.

The converted steeplechaser, Action, one of the large string of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs, added another to his score when he took the Woodmere Claiming Stakes, feature of the opening day program at Aqueduct yesterday. This made nine victories in his last ten starts for this 7-year-old son of Olambala, which was considered pretty much of a failure as a steeplechaser when he was sold for $1,000 early this year.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 31. -- Temporary alimony of $150 a month was awarded today to Mrs. Bertha Gott Smith, estranged wife of Alfred E. Smith Jr., together with $500 counsel fees, in a decision by Abram Zoller, Supreme Court Justice of Herkimer.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was on a slightly less active scale than in preceding months. Sales in August, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 26,564,032 shares, compared with 34,786,729 in July and 42,923,190 in the corresponding month a year ago.

It is Kenneth MacKenna and his brother, Jo Mielziner, who now plan to produce the play called "Mrs. Aphra Behn," by Eleanor Holmes Hinckley. It will be the second show the Messrs. MacKenna and Mielziner have done together (with John C. Mayer they offered "Co-Respondent Unknown" last season), and early November is the time they have set for it.
New and more stringent State laws to curb reckless driving and record each driver's violation of traffic rules will go into effect today. These laws were passed by the last Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP). -American Class 1 railroads today reported their best seven months since 1930 with an increase of 35.3 per cent in net operating income over the same period last year.

BERLIN, Aug. 31. -- Torn between the fear of ultimate devaluation, the hope of new armament orders and anxiety over increasing taxation, the Boerse fluctuated violently today. After a weak opening, causing losses up to 2 points, the market staged a recovery and closed for the most part above the week-end quotations.

Price changes were erratic yesterday and generally small in light trading in the local commodity futures markets, although there was good volume with lower prices for coffee, and cottonseed oil advanced in active trading. In the cash markets, cotton, corn, oats, eggs and tin were higher, while wheat, rye and cocoa declined.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 31. -- Declaring that if war comes again we must "conscript on a nation-wide basis both our manpower and our national resources," Governor Lehman welcomed the national convention of the United Spanish War Veterans to Saratoga Springs today.
ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- Governor Lehman issued a proclamation to night naming September as "Highway Safety Month." It read as follows:

With close to 200 entered, the pairings for the national tennis championships in the men's, women's and veterans' singles divisions were publicly drawn yesterday at the Vanderbilt Hotel. Thus was the stage set for the start of competition this Thursday on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Corn was the leader in the grain markets here today. Lack of deliveries of cash grain on September corn contracts was largely responsible for a sharp upturn in that delivery at one time, shorts covering freely on the way up, but as soon as selling appeared there was a quick recession from the top, with the close at a net gain of 5/8 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a list of about 100 brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market, including twenty-five from New York City and vicinity, who have filed applications for registration under the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act as amended by the last Congress.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Playing for the first time in the inter-county competition at the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association, which opened today at the Nelson House, representatives of Orange County carried off the honors to lead by half a point, with Onondaga second, Broome third and Dutchess, fourth.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 31 (AP). -- Mrs. A.M. Creech's Red Wagon proved a durable sort of plater when he won his second start in three days, taking the fifth race today by a head from C.V. Whitney's Two Bob. This was a six-furlong test.

Norway is not in the mood to expel LEON TROTSKY at the behest of the Soviet Government. He is not the idealist humanitarian who was once the accepted type of political refugee. TROTSKY in his day of power dealt harshly with political opponents actuated by as high ideals as his own.

An epidemic of minor ailments cracked down on the Yankees yesterday that for a few moments before game time had General Joseph V. McCarthy wondering whether he were directing a battalion in war-ridden Spain rather than a powerful ball club stalking majestically off to a pennant.

IRUN, Spain, Aug. 31. -- The sorely pressed government defenders of Irun sent more of their loved ones across the French frontier tonight after Rebel planes had bombed the the city, killing two women, and swore they would expose 300 insurgent prisoners as targets for Rebel bombs.

Political uncertainties abroad and weakness in foreign exchanges accelerated the movement of gold to the United States in August. The influx of metal, which had shown some abatement in July, following heavy shipments in the first six months of 1936, was on a smaller scale than in the previous movement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The Federal District Court for the District of Columbia was asked today to punish for alleged contempt of the Senate six officers and employes of the Railway Audit and Inspection Bureau for refusing to appear before the La Follette subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Education and Labor two weeks ago.
In the course of his address at Buffalo on the subject of taxation, an address which impressed me as thoroughly sound and of extraordinary simplicity and directness, Governor Landon had this to say:
New York City's traffic is easy to drive in and its traffic police match or surpass those of any other city in courtesy to motorists and ability to handle the automotive stream.

Details of the acquisition of assets of the Standard Printing Ink Company of Cincinnati by the International Printing Ink Corporation were disclosed yesterday in an application by the latter to list additional shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 31. -- Reports from all fronts suggest that the Spanish insurgents are massing their forces for a new, and this time they hope decisive, advance on Madrid.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Baltimore closed its final home stand of the regular season tonight by dropping a 4-to-2 game to Newark. The battle was a tight mound duel between Sheriff Blake of the Orioles and Steve Sundra, each allowing six hits.

SOMERVILLE, Mass., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Representative William Lemke, Union party Presidential candidate, declared tonight that the really "forgotten man and woman" were those trying to stretch their household budgets to meet rising food prices and "static" wage levels.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- The third defeat of the month of August was visited upon the Giants at Wrigley Field today. Lon Warneke, square-shouldered right-hander who was enjoying one of his good days, kept the Terrymen from circling the bases while Charley Grimm's men squeezed over a run in the sixth to carry off the spoils by a count of 1 to 0.

One young woman and twenty-two men of varying ages and dispositions were telling tall tales of the sea last night to admiring friends and relatives as the forty-seven-foot fishing boat Almira, out of Canarsie, was warped to her pier after a rough night on the briny deep.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Coach Steve Owen has ordered secret practice for the New York football Giants until after the game, with the college all-stars in the Polo Grounds on Tuesday night, Sept. 8. The Eastern pro champions have finished their heavy conditioning work at the Blue Hill Country Club.
Warden Lewis E. Lawes characterized as "imaginary vaporings" yesterday published reports of alleged luxuries and privileges allowed to inmates of means in Sing Sing Prison.

OAKDALE, L.I., Aug. 31. -- With prospects considered the brightest in years, a predominantly veteran squad of thirty-three candidates for Manhattan College's varsity football team reported today to Coach John F. (Chick) Meehan at La Salle Military Academy to launch preparations for a ten-game schedule opening with St. Bonaventure at Randalls Island Sept. 26.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review of credit and business conditions observes that the most noteworthy development in member bank credit in August was the unusual increase, for this time of year, in loans other than security loans.

The Hollywood Universals defeated the McPherson Oilers by 35 -- 80 last night in the feature game of a double-header which saw the Hippodrome opened for the first time as a basketball center. In the opening contest Union Temple of Brooklyn defeated a team of collegiate all-stars, 36 -- 31.

MADRID, Aug. 31 (By Courier to Hendaye, France, Uncensored). -- Growing criticism of President Manuel Azana within his Leftist regime inspired predictions today of an approaching government crisis, even if the Fascist rebellion is crushed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Thirty-two building and loan associations and individuals owning real estate in Milwaukee County, in Wisconsin, applied to the Federal District Court today for an injunction to restrain Secretary Ickes as PWA Administrator and Rexford Tugwell, RRA Administrator, from completing two government projects calling for the expenditure of $4,000,000.

Patrolman George A. Heidt, for twenty years a member of the force and recently prominent in the Lucania vice investigation, was dismissed from the department yesterday. First Deputy Commissioner Harold Fowler, who ordered his expulsion, found that Heidt did not make a satisfactory explanation of savings totaling $74,500 deposited in an eight-year period.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- The New York Stock Exchange firm of Hemphill, Noyes Co. will enter the markets here tomorrow when it takes over offices in the Board of Trade building which have been occupied by Munds, Winslow Potter, which firm is withdrawing from Chicago.
The cost of relief in this city increased by one-third in the year ended July 31, according to statistics made public yesterday by the research bureau of the Welfare Council.

Thirty minutes after a collector for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company scared off a hold-up man on the Lower East Side, another collector for the same company was shot and critically wounded last night in the hallway of the six-story tenement at 105 Monroe Street, a block away.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 31. -- King Haakon held an extraordinary State Council this morning to discuss the case of Leon Trotsky, exiled former Bolshevist leader, who is interned at Hoenefoss, Norway.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 31. -- The quest of Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn for permanent possession of the national doubles challenge cups ended in defeat today at the hands of the team that had turned them back in ten previous meetings on the tennis courts this year and wrested the Davis Cup assignment from them.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Dr. Hugh M. Parshall piloted Calumet Epsom to victory in the 2:13 trot today in the feature event of the first Grand Circuit racing program at the Ohio State Fair.

Clark Gable and Norma Shearer will be starred together in Metro's "Pride and Prejudice," the first appearance of the two in the same picture since "Strange Interlude." For a time there was talk that the picture would be made in England, but it is beginning to appear that all the atmosphere will be provided on Hollywood's backlots and stages.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- The Republican National Committee, through William Hard, radio commentator, in a broadcast tonight offered $1,000 in cash prizes for the three best letters on the topic, "Why I Am for Roosevelt."

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- A delicate problem for the Blum government has arisen with the arrival here today of five Spanish Left leaders including Dolores Iriburri, better known as "la Pasionaria," They make no secret of the fact they are here to play upon French sympathies. Miss Iriburri expects to address a number of meetings.

A steady market for cotton in Liverpool and absence of relief in the northwestern drought-affected section of the United States Cotton Belt caused yesterday a slight improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange here. The October advanced above 11.40 cents a pound, but this induced selling of the staple and hedges in the afternoon and carried the list back around Saturday's quotations, but a rally left final prices with gains of 3 to 6 points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- In a new drive to expand its reciprocal trade program, coinciding with the return today of Francis B. Sayre, assistant secretary in charge, the State Department is making a survey of the nations with which trade pacts might be concluded.

A new musical enterprise known as the Institute of Avocational Music, which will "provide teachers and advice for those who wish to take up music as an avocation," was announced yesterday by Miss Lucrezia Bori, former leading soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, who is a member of the new organization's advisory committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- The Customs Bureau, which three years ago was chiefly concerned with illicit drink, now has as its chief annoyance illegal food.

GENEVA, Aug. 31. -- The first World Youth Congress to Prevent War and Organize Peace opened here tonight with 500 delegates and 200 alternates from thirty-six countries, representing with two exceptions all the important movements into which is divided the generation that was too young to fight in the last war but is old enough for the next.

Cockeyed economics is playing havoc with our debt problem. Here is Joseph P. Kennedy, a reputable business man, contending that a big increase in government indebtedness is all right as long as the national income increases many times the amount of debt. Here are also the reviewers of his book apparently unable to make out what is wrong with this utopian contention.
LONDON, Aug. 31. -- That rare mental trouble, folie a deux, or madness of two, affecting two persons living together, was mentioned in Liverpool today when two women were accused of shoplifting.

Chester W. McNally, 43 years old, general attorney for the Yorkshire Indemnity Company of New York, and F. Chester Steup, 48, its secretary and claims superintendent, were convicted in Special Sessions yesterday of corruptly requesting and receiving a $900 gratuity in a $4,200 settlement in an indemnity claim.

Officials of the Milk Board, the Department of Health and various milk distributing concerns indicated yesterday that they felt there was no reason to fear a milk shortage here. Discontent among milk producers up-State is not widespread at present, it was said.

Working with unrelated and only partly disclosed facts, obtained through the use of hypnotism, doctors on the staff of the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital were making special efforts yesterday to learn the identity of a 60-year-old amnesia victim who was committed to the hospital by the police on Aug. 18.

TOPEKA, Aug. 31. -- With the drought conference with President Roosevelt at Des Moines only three days away, Governor Landon appealed today to officials of the ten railroads entering Kansas to establish joint emergency rates for shipments of cattle and feed.

The show of confidence on the side of the advance that was manifested in the stock market during the latter half of last week gave way yesterday to cautious trading. For one thing, the railway issues, as a group, failed to follow through; a few leading industrial groups made small gains, so that while THE NEW YORK TIMES railway average declined 0.20 point, the industrial stock average moved up 0.06 point on the day.

ON BOARD KNOX CAMPAIGN TRAIN, Aug. 31. -- Touring New England industrial cities today, Colonel Frank Knox, Vice Presidential nominee, told a station audience at Lowell, his train's first stop, that the Republican campaign was one for "the preservation of the democratic principle in America" and part of a "contest of ideas" of government.

School-opening advertising campaigns by leading manufacturers this year will run on an average of about 20 per cent ahead of last year in linage, according to comment here yesterday. National advertisers have scheduled budgets calling for this increase, while unbranded goods sold through department stores will receive a similar increase in retail promotions, based on the advance volume of business placed, it was said.

Uncle Robert, whose Stay-On-Sidewalks safety campaign for children has attracted wide attention, was commended yesterday by Mayor La Guardia for his work in behalf of youngsters. The Mayor told Uncle Robert the Slogan S.O.S. "is just the thing to be instilled in every child's mind."

Miss Patricia Cumming, last year's winner, and Miss Helen Bernhard, the runner-up, scored twice yesterday as the four seeded players gained the semi-final round in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's girls' invitation tournament on the grass courts of the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, S.I.

William F. Bleakley, justice of the State Supreme Court, an aspirant for the Republican nomination for the Governorship of New York, last night attacked President Roosevelt, charging he desired to change the Constitution in an unconstitutional manner.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 31. -- There were persistent reports again today of trouble in the Spanish zone of Morocco, where the insurgents are confronted with serious native unrest. Despite severe measures by insurgent leaders, numerous delegations have complained of the promises made to the African soldiers now in Spain that have not been kept, notably in the matter of living allowances for families.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 31. -- As a penalty for having stolen an automobile Herbert Levine, 16-year-old son of Rabbi Louis Levine of 5,411 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, was ordered today by Common Pleas Judge Daniel J. Brennan to read in the metropolitan newspapers daily for three years the accounts of accidents and deaths resulting from the operation of stolen vehicles.

Faced with the problem of deciding what part of this year's earnings to withhold and what part to distribute to shareholders, many directors of corporations in August elected to increase dividend payments rather than pay taxes of from 7 to 27 per cent under the Federal Revenue Act of 1936 for undistributed earnings.

One more indication that the book trade is picking up comes from Little, Brown, who report that they are making a first printing of 25,000 copies of the sixth "Jalna" novel, "Whiteoak Harvest," by Mazo de la Roche. The book will be published on Sept. 25.

The acquisition of nine important works of art by French masters and three pieces of Egyptian and Greek sculpture was announced last night by Dr. Albert C. Barnes, collector and founder of the Barnes Foundation at Merion, Pa.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Colgate's Red Raiders held their first sessions of the Fall season today, with sixty men reporting to Coach Andy Kerr for morning and afternoon workouts. Double practices will be held until late in the month before the Duke game.
JONES BEACH, L.I. Aug. 31. -- The Nassau-Suffolk County contest of the "barber shop" quartets was held here tonight before nearly 11,000 persons at the water stage of Jones Beach Auditorium.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 31--Discovery of a new type of geometry, in which the sum of the measure of the parts is greater than the measure of the whole, was announced here today by Professor Edward Kasner, Research Professor of Mathematics at Columbia University, before the Mathematical Association of America, meeting as part of the program of the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences.

The Joint Legislative Committee to investigate investment companies, bondholders' committees, management companies and similar organizations will try to frame legislation requiring companies which issue mortgage bonds to file with a State authority full details regarding the issue, the value of the property, the amount of previous mortgages and the equity of the proposed issue.
A supervisor of municipal relief and two Jersey City grocers were arrested late yesterday in Jersey City, charged with conspiring to defraud the city by allegedly taking money intended for the needy.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Fear that the future of Jews in Palestine was imperiled by British "inaction" was voiced today in a declaration issued at the close of an extraordinary session of the general council of the World Zionist Organization.

Cash dividend payments by the companies in the Standard Oil group for the third quarter of the year are estimated at $29,911,505, compared with $17,653,161 in the corresponding period last year, an increase of $12,258,344, according to Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.

Securities offered here to the public in August made the smallest total for a month since May. The decline in offerings coincided with a lull in refunding operations. Both bond and stock issues, however, were greater than a year before.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced last night that there was no reason for the 8,000 workers on WPA educational projects "to worry about their jobs or the possibilitiy of their transfer."

ON BOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL TRAIN EN ROUTE TO SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 31. -- A study of the advanced status of agricultural reclamation work in Western Nebraska, particularly Summer fallowing which has gone forward despite the drought, occupied President Roosevelt for three hours today during a stop at Sidney, on his way to attend burial services for Secretary Dern.

Operations of the W.T. Grant Company and its subsidiaries for the six months ended on July 31 resulted in a net profit of $1,448,978, or the equivalent of $1.21 a share on the outstanding capital stock. This compares with a net profit of $669,529, or 56 cents a capital share, in the corresponding period of 1935.

Engineers of the Port of New York Authority announced last night that the final barrier of rock and stone in the new Hudson midtown tunnel would be blasted away tonight or tomorrow. The barrier lies below King's Bluff, on the New Jersey side of the river, where tunneling will link the main underwater section at the New Jersey end with the New Jersey plaza inland, which will serve as the entry for eastbound motor cars.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Chosen by the fans of the nation, the greatest group of all-star college football players ever assembled will battle the Detroit Lions, professional champions, at Soldier Field tomorrow night before a prospective crowd of 80,000 spectators.

RUTH BRYAN OWEN has solved the problem raised by her marriage to a Dane by resigning her post as United States Minister to Denmark. The first "Madame Minister" in American diplomacy has proved two things: first, that a woman diplomat can serve her country as ably and acceptably as a man, and second, that she has several hurdles to cross before she enjoys equal status.

LOYALIST HEADQUARTERS, Near Saragossa, Aug. 31 (By Courier to Barcelona). -- "Of course we shall take Saragossa, and before long, too," said General Buenaventura Durruti, leader of one of the Loyalist columns operating against the provincial capital of Aragon.

BAYSHORE, L.I., Aug. 31. -- The first race in the national junior sailing championship for the Sears bowl today was captured by a fresh-water crew from the Sheridan Shore Yacht Club of Chicago, representing the Lake Michigan Yacht Association.

Reginald Everett Gillmor Jr., eldest son of Reginald Everett Gillmor, president of the Sperry Gyroscope Company, Inc., of Brooklyn, was accidentally shot and killed last night at Dodge Pond, Rangely, Me., according to word received by his family at their home on Red Brook Road in Great Neck, L.I.
HENDAYE, France, Aug. 31. -- The Argentine Ambassador to Spain tonight issued the following statement:
General Hugh S. Johnson, at times a sharp critic of New Deal policies, will deliver an address in Buffalo on Sept. 12, urging the reelection of President Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday.

Two-of Forty-fourth Street's favorite children, that are also among the most distinguished alumni of the theatrical season of 1935-36, came home from Summer vacation last night to find old friends and new ones waiting for them -- for "Victoria Regina" and its star, Helen Hayes, at the Broadhurst, for "Idiot's Delight" and the Lunts at the Shubert.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 31. -- With more favorable weather and wind conditions today, marksmen went to the firing line for the opening of the national rifle and pistol matches with hopes for record scores in the several events. The nearly two miles of firing line was not only filled with rifle shooters but hundreds of automobiles provided a background which had the appearance of the side lines of a track meet.
PARIS, Aug. 31 (AP). -- The troubled Franco-Spanish border situation was complicated today by reports that a French priest had been killed in attempting to flee Spain's civil war zone.
MADRID, Aug. 31. -- Powerful searchlight beams latticed the sky over Madrid tonight as government leaders prepared for a Rebel air attack such as the one last Friday night.

The Governor of Kansas and other Chief Executives of drought-ridden Commonwealths will confer on Thursday of this week with the President of the United States in an effort to work out more effective relief and prevention plans. The purpose is serious -- economic, humanitarian and social.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Aug. 31. -- Two young Texans, Ed White of Austin and Reynolds Smith of Dallas, blasted their way into Walker Cup fame today by beating par on the "heart-breaking" Pine Valley course for the first time as the American team staged a Scotch foursome practice session.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Twelve rail carriers serving New York City filed today a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission in which they attacked as too comprehensive the motor-trucking zone area for that city which had been recommended by an examiner of the commission.

" Political control of the courts means crime uncontrolled," General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein told 500 persons gathered in the Hotel Commodore last night to organize the lawyers committee for his nomination and election to the post he now holds by appointment.

STONEVILLE, Miss., Aug. 31. -- A ponderous machine, ten feet high, lumbered through a delta cotton field near here today and in less than an hour picked more cotton with its moistened steel fingers than a man could gather by hand from daylight to nightfall.

Mayor La Guardia's denunciation of overloud automobile horns, coupled last week with the warning that he would seek revocation of licenses of taxicabs that offended, bore fruit yesterday in traffic court.

ORADELL, N.J., Aug. 31. -- Alex Ternyei and Miss Ann Fleck of Elmwood, with 87 -- 13 -- 74, were low net in the pro-women's one-day tournament at the Hackensack Golf Club today, leading twenty pairs. The home club players, Jack Forrester and Mrs. F.A. Neuberg, finished second, a stroke back, in the net division, but their 77 gave them the gross prize by several strokes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP). -Morris L. Cooke, chairman of the drought committee which met President Roosevelt in the Midwest last week, said today that the President has in mind a survey of possible new Federal laws "to assist agricultural readjustment and the conservation of water and soil."

The Italian war manoeuvres took place this year in the south of Italy. They were participated in by 60,000 men, about half the number engaged last year, when the war games were held in the Alps with the object of impressing Germany and Europe with Italian strength at the Brenner.
Sixto Escobar, hard-punching Puerto Rican, established a clear claim to the world bantamweight championship by stopping Tony Marino, courageous Pittsburgh battler, at Dyckman Oval last night.
This department's No. 1 Maine scout, Gene Letourneau, writes that temperatures already are falling in the northern counties.

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 31. -- The Templeton players who will open their quest for the national open polo championship on Wednesday took part in a practice match at Schiff Field today, with the Red four on which Stewart Iglehart and Winston Guest performed defeating Michael Phipps's and Jimmy Mills's White Riders, 12 to 9.

The Charles Schweiler Press, largest magazine printing house in the city, has decided to close the eight-story plant in which it employs 1,000 men and move out of New York to a location where labor costs are lower, it was disclosed yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31. -- Miss Ethel Wickham gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at Bonnie Bourne, her home, for Mrs. Eliot Betts Hoadley, who has just returned from a motor trip through the West and will pass the remainder of the season at the Mallows, her home here. Earlier in the day Mrs. Albert Symington gave an informal luncheon for Mrs. Hoadley.
Farson, Son Co. are distributing a circular on Florida municipal bonds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- In a more intensive campaign against smugglers of narcotics, 570 customs border patrol agents have been assigned to the attack against this traffic, effective tomorrow.

Convinced that at last industrial recovery has firmly set in, officials of Bliss Fabyan Co., one of the largest cotton textile selling houses in the country, yesterday told some eighty-five members of its twelve sales branches that future conditions in the industry could be plotted with more certainty now than at any time since 1929.
The threatened strike of 15,000 truck drivers, which would have seriously crippled business and industry in the city, was averted last night.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 31, (AP). -- Carlton B. Chilton was beaming as he walked out of the State House tonight freed, temporarily, at least, from the threat of being returned to Oklahoma State Reformatory from which he escaped twenty-three years ago.

J.P. Morgan Co. and the National City Bank, fiscal agents, announce that upon receipt of sinking fund payments from the Argentine Government, together with cash in the fund, they will have available $316,062 for the purchase of the republic's external sinking fund 6s, Oct. 1, 1925, and $170,778 for the external public works 6s of Oct. 1, 1926.
LONDON, Aug. 31. -- The discussions proceeding in France and Germany about the future of European relationships are being closely watched in London.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 31. -Assailing the "heavy hand of Federal government" on industry and labor, Colonel Frank Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, declared in a speech here tonight that the experience of labor in other nations showed that "an apparent friendliness" of government for labor "ends with tyranny over labor.''

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- The French governmental and military hosts of General Eduard Rydz-Smigly, inspector general of the Polish Army, put forth their utmost efforts today to convince him of France's friendliness and military power.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks for which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

New York City borrowed yesterday $6,000,000 at the lowest interest cost in its financial history, when Controller Frank J. Taylor awarded, through competitive sealed bidding, an issue of special corporate stock notes dated Sept. 3 and due on Dec. 15, 1936.

State Senator Frederick H. Bontecou, Republican leader of Dutchess County, said yesterday at Republican State headquarters in the Liggett Building that President Roosevelt would lose his own home county by a plurality of at least 9,100 and possibly more.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP). -- Eleven countries, informed sources said today, have approved formation of an international committee to regulate a "hands-off-Spain" policy.

Colonel SOMERVELL'S "balance sheet" of what the WPA has contributed in New York City in the eleven months from Aug. 1, 1935, to the end of last June is an impressive answer to those who believe that WPA consists mainly of boondoggling. In the period covered, nearly 170,000 persons, as a monthly average, were employed on engineering projects.

Eleven participants in the anti-Nazi demonstration aboard the North German Lloyd liner Bremen on the night of Aug. 21, including eight young women, were found guilty on disorderly conduct charges yesterday afternoon by Magistrate Henry H. Curran in Yorkville Court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Aug. 26 shows increases for the week of $8,000,000 in total loans and investments, $92,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $117,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and $14,000,000 in time deposits, and a decline of $24,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 31 (AP). -Frank Spreckels, research chemist of San Francisco, was announced as winner of the $1,000 Cleveland-Dallas half of the Ruth Chatterton Air Derby here tonight. He is now in line for the sweepstakes trophy to be given by Miss Chatterton to the high-point pilot in the flight between Cleveland and Los Angeles.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 31. -- Mrs. Thomas R. Rudel of Oakland and Miss Ann Weeks of the Rockaway Hunting Club combined to win the qualifying round of the annual women's Long Island Golf Association two-ball foursome event today.

Michael E. Paterno, contractor and builder who erected many of the largest apartment house buildings along Fifth and Park Avenues, has been lodged in the New York County jail at 434 West Thirty-seventh Street since last Tuesday for non-payment of alimony, it was disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- Wilmarth Ickes, 37 years old, adopted son of Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, shot and killed himself early today in the family home at Winnetka, a suburb.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Sept. 1. -- The Hopei-Chahar Political Council has decided to impose as from today a special tax of one-eighth the national tariffs on all smuggled goods imported through Tsanghsien and Yenshan in Hopei Province, south of Tientsin, and will grant to all goods upon which the tax is paid official "protection."

Dr. William Hallock Park, who collaborated with Dr. Hermann M. Biggs in developing a successful diphtheria antitoxin, and Dr. Harold Dickinson Senior, eminent research scientist in the field of embryology of arteries and veins, will retire today from the faculty of the New York University College of Medicine after a total of sixty-four years of teaching service.
The vast changes in the skyline of New York City in the last thirty-five years have gone virtually unnoticed by Thomas Stewart, although most of them have taken place before his eyes.

SEATTLE, Aug. 31 (AP). -- The Seattle Post-Intelligencer answered the American Newspaper Guild complaint today, challenging the constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act and the jurisdiction of the Regional Labor Relations Board here.

The announcement by the American Bankers Association that Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, is to make his fourth successive appearance at the annual convention of that body in September calls to mind the masterly service Mr. Jones has rendered both to the administration and to business, and the prospect that, New Dealer though he is, he will have a most flattering reception from the bankers.

Fresh from his $1,000 triumph in the Glens Falls open the previous day, Jimmy Hines, Garden City Country Club professional, paired with Francis G. Makowski and captured top honors in the Long Island P.G.A. pro-amateur best-ball golf tournament yesterday over the exacting Fresh Meadow course in Flushing.

ALBANY, Aug. 31. -- District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan's failure to develop suspicions in the Drukman case last year was not shared by his own assistant, Harry Sullivan, who prepared the case, or by his old friend, Police Commissioner Valentine, who warned him that the case was to be used against him as campaign ammunition.

BERLIN, Aug. 31 -- The German press featured Dr. Joseph Goebbels's speech to the German colony at Venice in which, emphasizing the presence of German warships in Spanish waters, he served notice to the world that henceforth Germany was determined to protect every one of her nationals abroad.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 31. -- Charles Lincoln became the 1936 Meteor Class champion as the last race of the season was sailed today off the Port Washington Yacht Club. His Yankee scored the highest percentage for the season series, 89.02.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania will arrive today from Southampton and Cherbourg. On board are Dr. John Clyde Hostetter, who directed the casting of the 200inch telescope mirror at Corning. N.Y.; John Cobb, racing driver; Sir Hector Hetherington, vice chancellor of the University of Liverpool, and the following others:

Ten issues of United States Government bonds established new high marks yesterday. Changes for the day in the Federal list ranged on the up side to 3-32 point, and down 1-16 point, with most of the obligations registering advances. Trading in the governments was $886,900, compared with $318,300 on Friday.

HSINKING, Manchukuo, Aug. 31. -- China's mobilization of more than 60,000 Suiyuan and Shansi troops along Suiyuan's eastern borders was branded today a useless precaution against a non-existent danger by General Kenkichi Uyeda, Japan's Ambassador to Manchukuo and commander-in-chief of Japan's army in this country.

DELHI, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Speaking before 800 Delaware County dairy farmers here today, Stanley A. Piseck, president of the New York Milk Producers Federation, Inc., intimated that a milk holiday would be called within "one week or ten days."

For the third consecutive month, interest rates for both call and time loans in August were unchanged. Demand for loans, however, increased despite the irregular trend of stock prices and the smaller volume of trading.

Cooler weather aided retail trade yesterday and brought a beneficial reaction in the major wholesale markets here. While reorders did not show an immediate gain over last week, the feeling was general that stores are due to get a favorable start on their early Fall selling.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Announcement was made today of the sale of Mid-Week Pictorial, the independent pictorial news weekly published since 1914 by The New York Times Company, to Monte Bourjaily, general manager of the United Feature Syndicate. The announcement was made jointly by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president of The New York Times Company, and Mr. Bourjaily.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Residential and commercial consumers served by the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company will save $560,000 a year, compared with 1933, as a result of a new schedule of rates approved by the Public Service Commission and effective tomorrow.

While Vice Admiral Zengo Yoshida, commanding the Japanese squadron now visiting New York, and members of his staff were the guests of the Japan Society at a luncheon at the Lawyers Club yesterday, more than 750 officers, cadets and men of the squadron were granted shore leave to see midtown New York.

The regular New York County grand jury handed a presentment to Judge Allen in General Sessions yesterday on its recent inquiry into the fake telephone call on July 29 which took Justice Alfred J. Hofmann from the Special Sessions bench to the Bummer City Hall at Pelham Bay Park to learn that Mayor La Guardia had not sent for him.

LONDON, Aug. 31. -- Despite some profit-taking in the afternoon, stocks made a broad advance today and some stocks touched new high records. A renewed demand sprang up for British Government securities under the influence of the continuance of cheap money.

BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 31. -- The Rebel authorities are considering the possibility of placing their case before the League of Nations, particularly in regard to atrocities alleged to have been perpetrated by Madrid government troops.

Having spent ten days with that common denominator, "The Mikado" the members of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company are now moving into the specialized forms of Gilbert and Sullivan. This week -- which is an immediate matter -- there are "The Pirates of Penzance" and its curtain raiser, "Trial by Jury."

WHEN they let go with both barrels on Sunday and bagged a couple of games from the Cubs in P.K. Wrigley's pet ball park, the Giants made sure that they were going to wind up this Western trip in first place. Those other clubs couldn't haul them out of there with a writ of "habeas corpus." Not before the night of Thursday, Sept. 3, anyway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Alleged coercion of employes by the Carnegie-Illinois and the Jones Laughlin Steel Companies of Pennsylvania will be investigated by the special Senate campaign funds committee.

Gustav Eder, welterweight champion of Europe, outpointed Mickey Serrain of Scranton, Pa., in a fifteen-round bout last night at Dexter Park in Brooklyn to improve his prospects as a leading title contender. A crowd of 4,000 watched the battle.
A man died yesterday because he was hungry. An act of kindness was the indirect cause of his death.

Security dealers, with the assistance of their attorneys, have discovered something else to worry about in the Securities Act of 1933. Some believe that they cannot use the traditional "We maintain an active market in" certain securities without publishing also a prospectus of issues less than twelve months old.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Philip Duggan, 21-year-old son of Mrs. Fairman R. Dick and a student at Yale University, was found shot to death early this afternoon on the bridle path of the Harold Simonson estate in this community, the grounds of which adjoin his stepfather's place.

An increase of 1 cent a quart in the retail price of milk by the end of the week was expected by dealers here yesterday after the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., advanced its price 17 cents a hundredweight, or a little more than one-third of a cent a quart, effective immediately.

C.L. Bardo, trustee in bankruptcy for the New York, Westchester Boston Railway, made public yesterday a letter from Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the Federal Court in New Haven, which has jurisdiction in the bankruptcy, stressing the need for reducing expenses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Contending that he was operating bird dog kennels as a business, Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, complained today to the Board of Tax Appeals that the Treasury had disallowed a deduction of $6,825 as a loss on the venture in 1933.
New Jersey reopened the trout season yesterday for the month of September, continuing a policy adopted two years ago, when it was decided to split the season by closing the streams in August.

A new issue of $300,000 of sewer bonds of La Crosse, Wis., dated Sept. 1, 1936, and due on Sept. 1, 1937 to 1946, has been bought by a banking group consisting of Lehman Brothers, the Milwaukee Company and Well-Dickey Company at 100.261 for 1 3/4 per cent securities.

Changes on the marquee and sign of the St. James Theatre indicated yesterday that Sidney Kingsley's "Ten Million Ghosts" would precede "Napoleon the First" on that author-producer's schedule. And, to be sure, the change of plan was confirmed by a Kingsley representative, who said that rehearsals of Mr. Kingsley's drama would begin in a week or ten days.

Leasing of a West Side building by a new motion-picture company, sales of a West Side apartment house and a Lexington Avenue corner and rental of a Fifty-seventh Street building by an expanding dressmaking firm were included in the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

The death rate for the city for the week ended last Saturday was the lowest for any seven-day period since the week ended Aug. 25, 1934, Health Commissioner John L. Rice said yesterday. With total deaths from all causes numbering 1,125, a decrease of 159 from the preceding week's total, the death rate was 8 per 1,000.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1. -- Settlement of the American Newspaper Guild strike at The Wisconsin News was negotiated by a committee of four set up by the Milwaukee Federated Trades Council which met with J.H. Black, manager of the newspaper, during the last week.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 1. -- A.G. Tarn's Lt. Greenock made it two in a row when he triumphed by half a length over the favored Carvola, the property of E.K. Bryson, in the mile and a sixteenth of the Greenwich, feature race on today's card at Narragansett Park.

A rise of retail failures featured business defaults for the week ended Aug. 27, with declines shown in the manufacturing and wholesale classifications in comparison with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report follows:

Former Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial opened his independent campaign for the Democratic nomination for Aldermanic President with a speech in Queens last night in which he denounced as "unadulterated rot" the "fabrication being used against me to the effect that if I win this year the Democratic organization will be destroyed."

Most of us, I believe, will agree with L.T. Fetzer that too much ado has been raised about the teachers' oath. But his arguments give the crux to the objections to a special oath for teachers. For he practically charges that our college professors and school teachers spread disloyalty among their pupils.

In a roughly run race that saw a good deal of bumping, the Western colt Privileged from the barn of Warren Wright, got home first yesterday in the featured Pharos Purse at Aqueduct. Eddie Arcaro piloted the winner which ran the five furlongs out of the chute in the fast time of 0:59 4-5.

SEATTLE, Sept. 1. -- The State of Washington, which gave President Roosevelt a plurality of 145,000 in 1932 and has a completely Democratic representation in Congress, is regarded by most well-informed observers here as safe for Mr. Roosevelt in November.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1. -- While the youth of all nations were making correct ideological demonstrations in Red Square this evening, the fourth annual Russian theatre festival was opening with a whirl at the Folk Art Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The American Chain Company of Bridgeport, Conn., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for 110,000 shares of $100-par 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock and an undetermined number of shares of no-par common stock, the latter to be reserved for conversion of the preferred.
ROCKY POINT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- Labor was urged today by Colonel Frank Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, to beware the "invasion" of its field by the New Deal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- An estimate that the average husband and wife are touched by 2,700 "hidden taxes" daily was made public today by the taxpayers' division of the Republican National Committee here.

GLACIER PARK, Mont., Sept. 1 (AP). -- The worst forest fire in seven years ran across the Continental Divide, cut a path of destruction across a popular Summer resort and roared through valuable timber lands while 1,200 foresters battled in vain to check its advance tonight.

Swinging into the Fall home-furnishings season, manufacturers of rugs and carpets will make the strongest bid for business they have financed since 1929 in the coming two to three months. Plans for Fall advertising, executives pointed out yesterday, include expenditures averaging 15 to 35 per cent greater than in the Spring months.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania will sail today for Cherbourg and Southampton with Sir Cedric Hardwicke, actor; Rudolph Reimer, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization in New York, with Mrs. Reimer, and Howard K. Travers, American Consul in Southampton, England, with Mrs. Travers and Helen Travers.

MUKDEN, Manchukuo, Sept. 1. -- Japan's objection to Hopei and Chahar sending delegates to Nanking to attend the November Congress to adopt a constitution and elect China's President was explained here in official Japanese and Manchukuoan circles today.
Jesse Owens, Olympic sprint and broad-jump champion, yesterday "sold" his athletic future to Marty Forkins, Broadway theatrical promoter.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1. -- The strike of part of the editorial staff of The Wisconsin News, afternoon Hearst paper, was ended late today. The employes who have stayed on strike and not sought other employment elsewhere will return to work tomorrow, said John H. Black, manager of The News.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1. -- A judge went to prison today for a three-day voluntary term "to find out how it feels."

A twenty-five-foot section of rock and dirt was blasted away yesterday morning beneath King's Bluff, Weehawken, clearing the final barrier in the Midtown Hudson Tunnel between its Thirty-eighth Street entrance and the plaza which will serve as its New Jersey entry.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Mrs. Thomas H. Barber gave a luncheon today at Claverack House, her home, for the Rev. Adrian Weld Blundell, prior of St. Anselm's Priory, Washington, who arrived yesterday to pass several days as her guest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The sale of oil supplies to the Spanish insurgents in Morocco has thus far been a question that has been settled by the various oil companies having stocks in the international zone at Tangier. The United States Government, at least, has taken no official action on the question and has approached no other government, in the hope that the commercial interests involved can agree on a course of action.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- The series of fashion shows to be staged in various Summer homes here during the week began today, when Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs opened Rosecliff for a two-day show. Mrs. Herbert Shipman will open Seaview Terrace for a one-day show on Thursday.

The Summer trade season has come to a satisfactory close and the Fall trade outlook is favorable, the National City Bank says in its monthly bulletin, published yesterday. The bank finds that industry is operating at the highest level in six years, farm prices are advancing, and bonus and other government payments are adding temporarily to purchasing power, with the result that the volume of goods moved has equaled the most hopeful expectations.
The Labor Book Shop, 28 East Twelfth Street, issued a statement yesterday saying that it had received a letter from Leon Trotsky which declared, in part:

PARIS, Sept. 1. -- A new element has been introduced into the international situation as regards Spain by reports from Tangier that governmental authorities in Madrid are proposing to cede sovereignty over the Spanish zone in Morocco to France.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The strike of the members of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers spread yesterday to Brooklyn, where 2,000 of the 18,000 painters in the borough joined the walk-out in Manhattan, Bronx and Richmond.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Big Jim Weaver tightened after a weak start today and limited the Bees to seven hits as the Pirates made a clean sweep of the current series with a 3-to-1 victory. Weaver beat Danny MacFayden in a close pitching duel to post his thirteenth pitching victory of the season.

PANAMA, Republic of Panama, Sept. 1. -- President Roosevelt's calling of a Pan-American peace conference amid rumors and threats of wars was called "a magnificent gesture" by President Harmodio Arias in his message to the National Assembly, which convened today.

There is a high demand for political converts this year. If any man or woman of more than local significance has changed party allegiance, a good price can be got for the news of it, at least in passing notoriety. This kind of reclame, however, is not what it used to be in the older days of Presidential campaigning.

Conditions in local commodity futures markets remained mixed yesterday, with cocoa, rubber and coffee moderately firmer and cottonseed oil easier. On the cash markets, cotton, wool tops and rubber advanced, and cocoa and quicksilver reached new high levels.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- The British Government applied diplomatic pressure on Germany and Portugal today so that the new committee on non-intervention in Spain could be brought into being without further delay.

Monday being a slack day in political circles, the Republican National Committee branch office in New York City appropriately hailed State Senator BONTECUE of Dutchess, who came in with a fascinating prophecy. All Manager MARTIN had been able to think of was to "repudiate" Chairman FARLEY'S assertion that it now looked as if forty-one States are "in the bag."

If it is "tres chic" next Spring to wear a chapeau decked with eagle feathers, a la American Indian war bonnet, Suzanne Talbot will be to blame. The diminutive Parisienne, whose creative ability has placed her among the first few of the great designers, speaks no English, but made actions talk for her yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel on her first visit to this country.

A former district superintendent of the Home Owners Loan Corporation accused of accepting installments from clients of the government and keeping them for himself contended yesterday in Federal court through counsel that he could not have committed embezzlement as charged even if he had taken the money.

Indecisive movements of prices characterized virtually all groups in the stock market yesterday. The news of the day did not provide much inspiration for buying or selling, so that trading was mainly professional, with switching operations in moderate volume.

GENEVA, Sept. 1. -- The American delegation to the World Youth Congress here submitted six proposals today, including one for the sending of an "impartial delegation to Spain to make a report to the youth of the world," one for a world youth disarmament demonstration on Armistice Day and one for the holding of a "peace plebiscite among the young people."

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Rain forced postponement of the football game between the college all-stars and the Detroit Lions, world's professional champions, at Soldier [Field tonight, causing disappointment to 80,000 fans.

American Light and Traction Company -- Year ended July 31: Net income, $5,298,978, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.62 a share on 2,767,418 shares of $25 par common stock, comparing with $3,902,286, or $1.12 a share, the year before.

Negotiations between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau were resumed yesterday after the union the night before had called off its threatened strike of 15,000 truck drivers to make possible a new agreement without resorting to a walkout.

ON THE NORTHERN SPANISH FRONT, via Hendaye, France, Sept. 1. -- At 7 o'clock this morning five insurgent planes flew over Irun and dropped thirty 100-pound bombs, twenty-eight of which exploded with shattering detonations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1.--The White House disclosed today that President Roosevelt almost deprived himself of a chief of staff of the army, and the army of its ranking officer, by the appointment of General Malin Craig to the United States Harvard University Tercentenary Commission.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Argentina's international polo team galloped through a practice game on Mitchel Field today and defeated Aurora, with John Fell at No. 1 in place of the absent Seymour Knox, 12 to 9.
The letter of L.T. Fetzer on the subject of teachers' oaths sounds a note sadly needed in the prevailing discussions of this vexing question.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday three appointments to the bench, including that of Myles Paige, a Negro. He also named a Deputy Commissioner of Accounts. All four will be sworn in at 11 A.M. today at the Summer City Hall.

Son of a Scotland-born divine, a business man with a fortune in prospect, a reporter with promise of a successful career as a daily newspaper man, GEORGE HORACE LORIMER has hewed out a unique and notable career for himself as an American editor. He could himself write, as he gave ample evidence, but he showed his editorial genius by getting others to write at their best.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- About 30,000,000 of the new King Edward postage stamps -- the simplest and neatest since the "penny blacks" of Queen Victoria -- had been sold by the time weary postoffice clerks all over the country closed their windows tonight.
Business and apartment properties were included in the Bronx turnover reported yesterday.

With the new State laws designed to curb reckless driving becoming effective yesterday, the Automobile Manufacturers Association announced that its board of directors had adopted a formal resolution recommending to all member companies that they make no reference in their advertising and publicity to the top speeds attainable by their cars.

Mrs. D.K. Marlowe, 29-year-old housewife of West Lafayette, Ohio, recently postponed making peach jam long enough to write a letter on "What the New Deal Has Meant to Me," and won a trip to New York. Yesterday, as the guest of the Democratic National Committee, which sponsored the event, and winner among the 500 entrants, she got her first glimpse of Manhattan sights.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade here made a firm start and a tame finish today. There was no pressure of consequence at the opening and it took little buying to lift both wheat and corn about 1 cent a bushel above yesterday's final prices, hut the upward movement was checked quickly by commission-house selling, which continued until the close.

Public offering will be made today of $28,000,000 first and refunding mortgage 3 1/2 per cent series bonds, due in 1966, of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company, at 102 3/4 and accrued interest, through an underwriting group managed by the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1. -- Mrs. Eva Fox, wife of William Fox, former film producer, was ordered by Federal Referee Robert Steedle here today to take the stand tomorrow in the bankruptcy proceedings of her husband.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1. -- Perhaps the most persistent attempt in many years to play a ball game under almost impossible weather conditions was made today with President Ford Frick watching the affair.
The Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences formally took title yesterday afternoon to the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The transaction took place at the law offices of Morgan Lockwood, 44 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept- 1 (AP). -- J.M. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of the Department of Commerce, said today that the department expected to have "two good bids in about ten days" on a new liner to replace the obsolete Leviathan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Pounding the offerings of Elon Hogsett as Earl Whitehill held the Browns in check, Washington defeated St. Louis, 5 to 3, today for its third straight triumph over Hornsby's team and went into a fourth place tie with the idle Chicago White Sox.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 1.--Word reached here today that General Francisco Franco, informed of the dangerous unrest in Spanish Morocco, flew Saturday from Seville to Tetuan, where he examined the situation. In response to the demands of a large number of notables addressed to the Grand Vizier of Tetuan, General Franco ordered the release of Abd-el Alek Tores, leader of the Arab national party, who was imprisoned at Ceuta.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Mrs. Dorothy Sherwood, 28-year-old widow, stepped clear of the shadow of the electric chair today by a surprise plea of guilty to a charge of first-degree manslaughter for the drowning of her 2-year-old son.

After hypnotism had led them on the wrong trail the police identified yesterday by routine methods the amnesia victim who has been in Bellevue Hospital since Aug. 18 as Edward G. Trenholm, once wealthy and a former business associate and relative by marriage of Francis I. du Pont.

As a Manhattan Republican, I want to ask our party leaders if they are about to make the monumental blunder of nominating an up-Stater for Governor, and not only lose the State for themselves but for Landon? The winning majority no longer comes down to the Bronx. State campaigns are won or lost in this city.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding ,week, but more than doubled the corresponding week last year when Labor Day was a week earlier, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Schoolboy Rowe held the Athletics hits today, a single by Frank Hayes in the eighth and Bob Johnson's twenty-second home run of the season in the ninth, as Detroit won, 4 to 1. Rowe pitched almost perfect ball for seven innings, allowing only Johnson to reach first base in the fifth and seventh, both times on walks.

WUCHOW, Kwangsi Province, China., via United States Gunboat Mindanao, Sept. 1. -- "War may begin at any time," the Chinese garrison commander of the Wuchow area told your correspondent yesterday. "We are still negotiating with Nanking for a peaceful settlement, but one of our demands is war against Japan, and if Chiang Kai-shek [Nanking leader] does not agree, China will have another civil war."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Lake Ontario became a center of widespread Star Class activity today as skippers, crews and boats awaited the start tomorrow of the world championship regatta, commonly known as "the International."

TOKYO, Sept. 1. -- The Japanese third fleet now stationed on the Yangtse, which was preparing to depart shortly to hold local fleet manoeuvres, has been ordered to remain in Chinese waters pending a settlement of the Chengtu affair.

A two-story building at the northA two-story building at the north-163d Street, Jamaica, has been purchased for investment by the Rohick Corporation of Jamaica from the Henry C. Bohack estate, Brunswick, Praver Nassof, Inc., the broker, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- C. B. Baldwin, Assistant Administrator of the Resettlement Administration, announced tonight that thirty projects would be "suspended" by that agency because funds are being transferred to drought relief.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Both the Madrid government and the Spanish insurgent forces under General Francisco Franco disclaimed today all knowledge of the attempted bombing of the United States destroyer Kane by an unidentified airplane off the southwestern coast of Spain on Sunday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 1. -- President Roosevelt joined with other leaders of the government and with citizens of Utah today in paying final tribute to George H. Dern, Secretary of War, at impressive funeral services conducted by the Church of Latter Day Saints, the Masonic order and 1,600 soldiers.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Mrs. Thomas R. Rudel and Miss Ann Weeks, yesterday's medalists in the women's Long Island Golf Association two-ball foursome tournament, continued to lead the small but exclusive field through the first two rounds of match play today.

An edition of 100,000 copies of Senator William E. Borah's book, "Bedrock," with an introduction written by William Hard, was issued yesterday by the National Home Library Foundation. The book is a collection of nearly fifty speeches, articles and letters by the Senator.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- A steady downpour of rain held up the final battle of the year between the Giants and the Cubs at Wrigley Field today for one solid hour. Then when the conflict finally got under way a deluge interrupted hostilities for a twenty-minute period in the second inning.

The engagement of $275,000 gold in Paris for shipment here was announced yesterday as the franc showed renewed weakness in foreign exchange. In addition, $262,000 gold was taken in India. These engagements brought to $51,000,000 the total of gold obtained abroad since Aug. 7, when the current movement began.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- After two weeks in Philadelphia, where he finished among the federation prize winners, Isaac Kashdan, United States internationalist, arrived today to defend his title at the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association against eleven rivals at the Nelson House.

J. Donald Budge, first rated on the national seeded list, will meet George L. Seewagen in a stadium match at 4:30 P.M. tomorrow in the first round of the men's national tennis singles championship tournament at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, according to the schedule of matches for the opening day of play made known by the United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia formally committed himself yesterday to the cause of President Roosevelt as he signed a call for a conference of progressives which will meet in Chicago on Sept. 11 and endorse the candidacy of the President for reelection.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- A somewhat left-handed welcome is extended to David Lloyd George, who is arriving in Germany for a study trip this week, by the Angriff, one of the principal National Socialist organs.
MADRID, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Reorganization of the Cabinet to give representation to additional factions of the Popular Front political coalition was reported under consideration today.
LANCHOW, China, Sept. 1 (AP). -- A grim battle with modern weapons of war was raging tonight in a medieval setting at Minhsien, an obscure Kansu Province town south of here.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 1. -- News from the western Spanish front shows that the insurgents have launched strong attacks toward Madrid from the southwest and northwest, but the government claims to have repulsed them. It denies the insurgents are in possession of Oropesa, on the main line from Lisbon to Madrid, which they claim to have taken Saturday.
The Democratic drive to keep New York State in the Roosevelt column, and to re-elect Governor Lehman, will start at the end of this week, it was indicated yesterday.
