SEVILLE, Spain, Sept. 1. -- Battle-weary but grimly determined, the brown-clad Foreign Legion and turbaned Moors of General Francisco France's Rebel Army were advancing tonight across the level plains of Castille. Only eight miles from Toledo, his headquarters here announced tonight.

TANGIER, International Zone, Morocco, Sept. 1. -- It is reported here that the State Department in Washington is preparing to inform the appropriate French officials that the United States will agree to a French order prohibiting all shipments of oil from French Morocco to Rebel Spanish Morocco only if there is an agreement not to sell oil to the Madrid forces as well.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization and one of the ten unions ordered suspended by the executive council of the A.F. of L. for "insurrection," resigned yesterday as a vice president of the federation and a member of the council.

LOYALIST HEADQUARTERS, Near Saragossa, Spain, Sept. 1 (By Courier to Barcelona). -- It is a strange, amateurish war they are fighting here on the outskirts of the mighty fortress which held out for more than half a year against the flower of Napoleon's army.
I wish a great hush might come over the earth, for I am listening for voices that should he raised at this time on a matter that is pertinent.

BURGOS, Spain, Sept. 1. -- The first government air raid on Fascist headquarters here and bombardment of a Rebel hospital, with four dead and twenty-three injured, roused Rebels to angry protest tonight to the International Red Cross at Geneva.

GENEVA, Sept. 1. -- New Zealand agrees, in a note given out by the League of Nations today, "to the institution of an international force under the League's control or to the allocation to the League of a definite proportion of the armed forces of its members to the extent it desires of the whole of those forces, land, sea and air."

Two aspects of "Jefferson in Power," a new work of history by the American Ambassador to Spain, which was yesterday placed on sale, make it more than a rather partisan, highly documented account of the administration of the United States from 1801 to 1809. Its date of release automatically puts this record of a political struggle long past into the Presidential campaign of 1936.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Arriving and departing in a motor trailer driven by her husband, Captain Boerge Rohde, Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, defended the Roosevelt administration before a gathering of 500 Democrats here tonight and declared the future had been "barricaded against depression."

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP). -- While twelve shackled members of the Black Legion were being led into Circuit Court here today for trial on murder charges, the Oakland County grand jury denounced the hooded order as a politically ambitious guerrilla band mentally incapable of wresting control from established authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted exemption from provisions of the Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 to the Washington Gas Light Company of Montgomery County, Md., in connection with the issue and sale of $128,000 of general mortgage 4 1/4 per cent bonds, Series A, maturing March 1, 1956, and certificates representing 500 shares of its capital stock of $20 par value.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Little Pat, a trim bay gelding owned by the Biery Farm of Butler, Pa., and driven by the veteran Charley Lacey, won the Pop Geers Memorial Stake, feature event of the second day's Grand Circuit card at the Ohio State Fair today in two straight heats.

The report of the Diamond Match Company and subsidiaries for the six months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $1,010,101, equivalent to 80 cents a share on the common stock. No provision was made for the Federal surtax on undistributed profits. The total compared with a net profit of $1,123,545, or 96 cents a common share, for the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Power officials, economists and engineers from sixty or more countries are expected here Monday for the opening session of the Third World Power Conference. An attendance of more than 800 foreign delegates is likely, with an American contingent of 2,000 or more.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Reds made a clean sweep of the final at-home series with Philadelphia and ran Cincinnati's winning streak to five straight by winning today, 3 to 2.

Hedging sales of contracts on the Cotton Exchange here were absorbed more readily yesterday and prices climbed 6 to 11 points. The greatest gain was in the October, reflecting price-fixing and the removal of hedges from the near month.

Mayor La Guardia and a group of city officials, it was learned yesterday, will test personally any carbon-monoxide gas danger in the vehicular tunnel on Park Avenue, which is to be opened within a few weeks. Ordinarily, it was explained, canary birds are used for such experiments.
A new set-up at Women's Court to transform it from "a show place to a court room" was started yesterday by Mayor La Guardia during a visit in which he acted as a magistrate in a vice case.

More than 400 boys and girls from the five boroughs and some of the suburbs vied yesterday morning for honors in a freckles contest at Hearns Department Store on Fourteenth Street. To aid in determining the winners, the judges used a "freckle machine," which consisted of a magnifying glass, two electric lights and a peep hole.

Indian Hurtado, 137 1/4, lightweight champion of South America, added Stumpy Jacobs, 139, Richmond, Va., to his imposing list of victims last night, before 1,500 persons at the Coney Island Velodrome. He overcame a poor start to gain the decision in eight rounds.

Mayor La Guardia appointed an honorary civic committee yesterday to witness the start from Floyd Bennett Field on Friday of the transcontinental air race for the Bendix Trophy. The race will mark the opening of the National Air Races at Los Angeles.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Europe watches the rearmament of Great Britain and again hopes that war may be averted by a display of force. The British people ignore the importance of their armaments to Europe. But then they are not informed sufficiently of Britain's large part in the affairs of the Continent.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Candidates for the Army football team, eighty-two strong, turned out today for the first practice of the 1936 season. Head Coach Gar Davidson and his staff started with a stiff workout, knowing that the players were in excellent physical condition and eager to get their assignments.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 1. -- President Lazaro Cardenas at the opening of Congress today stated that Mexico two weeks ago sold to the Madrid Government 20,000 rifles and 20,000,000 cartridges of Mexican manufacture. This had previously been officially denied.

OTTAWA, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Fair and warm weather in the Prairie Provinces last week enabled farmers in all except the northern sections to complete their harvesting, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics announced today in the last of its fifteen weekly crop reports.

With 40 per cent of its total retail trade on a cooperative basis, Finland now leads all other capitalistic countries in percentage of cooperative sales volume, it was reported yesterday by Hugo Vasarla, managing director of the Suomen Osuuskauppojen Kekesunta (S.O.K.), or Cooperative Wholesale Society of Finland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1.--A gross Federal deficit for the fiscal year 1936-37 of $2,096,996,300--nearly $1,000,000,000 more than was forecast in January, but still the lowest thus far under the New Deal--was predicted in a budget summation issued from the Treasury today in the form of a statement by President Roosevelt.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 1. -- A number of large dinners and luncheons are to be given in honor of visitors who will be in Berkshire for the coming-out parties of Miss Frances P. Clucas at the Lenox Club Friday night and Miss Beatrice S. Procter at Orleton Farm, Stockbridge, Saturday night.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, appealed to organized labor yesterday for aid in ridding the WPA rolls of "two-timers," persons who simultaneously hold jobs on relief and in private industry.

LONDON, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press). -- A final spurt that shook Yorkshire from the runner-up position in the English county cricket competition, concluded today, enabled the speedy Middlesex eleven to finish its 1936 campaign a peg behind Derbyshire. The Midlanders last week made sure of their first championship in sixty-two years.

TOPEKA, Sept. 1. -- The need for a comprehensive program of water conservation and flood control in the watersheds of the Kansas and Arkansas Rivers by cooperation of the State and Federal Governments was suggested by Governor Landon in a letter to President Roosevelt on June 4, 1934, it was recalled today.

BAYSHORE, L.I., Sept. 1. -- After four more races had been held today for the national junior sailing championship, the crew from Vineyard Haven, Mass., out on the island of Martha's Vineyard, led tonight in the scoring by 49 1/2 points to 38 for the Pequot Yacht Club crew from Southport, Conn., representatives of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

To a reporter of The Sun Mr. GEORGE FEARON has disclosed some well-known secrets. He is making no campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor. He has merely been going up and down the State making speeches. He would withdraw if he didn't think he could beat Governor LEHMAN. He doesn't want to run if the Republicans don't want him to run.

At the first business session of the Safe Driver Conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, forty-nine drivers, selected from all the States and the District of Columbia for their safety records, took part in a discussion of the factors that had made those records possible.

BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- The Reich Government took another step today in the direction of accelerating the process of enforcing non-intervention in Spain when it recommended to the French Government the adoption of procedure to eliminate recourse to a complicated diplomatic mechanism similar to that applied in carrying out sanctions against Italy.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Sept. 1. -- A memorial service at Saratoga Battlefield this morning and the "crawl" of the Military Order of the Serpent tonight were features of today's activities of the national encampment of the United Spanish War Veterans.

The Skelly Oil Company has declared a dividend of $6 on the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock on which there are arrears. On Aug. 1, the company resumed dividends on the preferred with the payment of $1.50. Because of changed conditions, including the effect of the new Federal Revenue Act, the special adjourned meeting of stockholders adjourned yesterday without authorizing the plan to refund the 6 per cent preferred stock.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 1. -- When the golfing representatives of the United States and Great Britain square off tomorrow for the ninth Walker Cup competition, a familiar name will be missing from the American line-up.
BERLIN, Sept. 1. -- Operations on the Boerse were marked today by nervous fluctuations, numerous gains being offset by similar losses.
The dollar on the local foreign xchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Polo's national open tournament will continue today with the semi-final round games at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury. Starting at 3 o'clock, Greentree will play the Hurricanes on Cochran Field, and at 4:30 the spectators will move over to the adjoining stands of International Field to watch the debut of Templeton, which drew a first-round bye, against the Texas team which surprised last Sunday with an upset of Ray Guest's Roslyn side.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 1. -- Dougherty, Corkran Co. of Philadelphia, investment bankers, won today the award of $45,000,000 of Commonwealth of Pennsylvania tax-anticipation notes, bearing interest at 1 1/2% per cent. Their bid was 99.52 for all or none of the issue.

A new geometry which succeeds in measuring the horn angle that has baffled mathematicians for 2,500 years was described at Harvard University. Failure to understand this new triumph of the human mind should induce a feeling of humility rather than humiliation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 1. -- An important extension of modern mathematical methods, which promises to bridge the gap between the universe of the stars and the world of the atom, embracing at last the relativity and quantum theories, was presented here today before the Harvard tercentenary conference of arts and sciences.

There was a slight decrease in the number of life insurance policies issued last year to residents of Connecticut, and the average amount of the policies was larger than in 1934, according to the Connecticut Insurance Department's annual life report, a summary of which was issued yesterday by John C. Blackall, Insurance Commissioner.

A few days ago THE TIMES reported the ordered increase of the German Army, which will bring 1,200,000 soldiers under the command of Hitler. With the publication of this order there ran throughout Europe another of these tremors of fear which have become the accompaniment of any Hitler order.

A seaplane of the Deutsche Lufthansa making the first of a series of North Atlantic experimental mail flights is expected to land in Bermuda next Tuesday, according to a message received here yesterday from Hamilton. The announcement of the proposed service was made at a luncheon there yesterday by C.A. Jahn, representative of the German air line.

The series of international races between a team of four United States Interclub Class sloops and Bermuda one-design craft will be launched today on Long Island Sound off the Larchmont Yacht Club. In all, the series will include seven races, with three yacht clubs conducting the events on different days.

Renting was brisk in the Fifth and Park Avenue areas yesterday, according to reports from brokers. The demand for apartment space generally also was noted as increasing with the approach of Oct. 1. Various penthouses were among the larger units taken under lease.

TORONTO, Sept. 1. -- Frank Pritchard of Buffalo won the fivemile professional marathon swim at the Canadian national exhibition today after Gianni Gambi of Italy, the 1935 winner, had dropped out after the first mile and one-half.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Winnie Anderson, former captain and end at Colgate, today joined the New York Giants at the Blue Hill Country Club, where the Eastern pro champions are preparing to meet the College All Stars at the Polo Grounds next Tuesday night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Following is President Roosevelt's statement on the summation of the 1937 budget:

MOSCOW, Sept. 1. -- The youthful population of Moscow paraded through Red Square tonight in fighting regalia singing revolutionary songs in the Soviet's part of the International Youth Day celebration. The day was set apart at a conference of Socialist young people at Bern in 1915 for annual demonstrations against war.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Red Sox swept their three-game series with the second-place Indians by coming through with a 4-to-1 victory in the finale today behind Lefty Grove's seven-hit pitching. With the Yankees idle, the defeat dropped Cleveland seventeen games back of the league leaders.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1. -- The Soviet Union is greatly concerned at the Rumanian Government's dropping Nicolas Titulescu as Foreign Minister, feeling that in his removal Rumania at a critical juncture loses her most authoritative statesman and the cause of peace loses an influential champion.

The much-discussed expansion of Japan into the South Seas is neither a military nor a naval, but a commercial one, Vice Admiral Zengo Yoshida, commander of His Imperial Japanese Majesty's training squadron, explained yesterday on the eve of his squadron's departure this morning from New York.

Morris Scheier, 53 years old, a painting contractor, of 275 East 234th Street, the Bronx, was killed by an I.R.T. train at the Seventy-second Street subway station about 2 P.M. yesterday. With Arthur J. Bisdale, another contractor, of 5 East Forty-fourth Street, he had gone to the northbound platform to board a train for the Bronx.

Stockholders of the Bangor Aroostook Railroad will meet on Oct. 9 to vote on authorizing the first offering of stock by a railroad since the end of 1935. The offering, which would consist of $3,828,000 of a new issue of $100-par cumulative convertible 5 per cent preferred stock, would be used to redeem $3,480,000 of 7 per cent preferred stock now outstanding and for other corporate purposes.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Suddenly brandishing a "big stick" in its quarrel with Norway over Antarctic whaling the British Government today decided to abandon the closed season and send its own whaling crews to Southern waters immediately.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Announcement that the United Mine Workers of America had taken under its wing a group of gas and coke workers' unions, hitherto affiliated directly with the American Federation of Labor, evoked an assertion today by William Green, president of the federation, that the action proved that the miners, as part of the Committee for Industrial Organization, were engaged in building a rival labor organization.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 1. -- When the winner of the 50-meter (any sight) small-bore match was announced today, Walter Shanessy of Brooklyn was in sixth place and Thomas Lewis of St. Albans, L.I., was ninth. They each scored 398 out of a possible 400, placing in the list of winners for bronze medals.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 1. -- The bankrupt Amoskeag Manufacturing Company's rehabilitation committee decided today on the organization of a corporation to be known as Amoskeag Industries, Inc., which will be created tomorrow when articles of incorporation are filed in Concord with Enoch Fuller, Secretary of State.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Suddenly brandishing a "big stick" in its quarrel with Norway over Antarctic whaling the British Government today decided to abandon the closed season and send its own whaling crews to Southern waters immediately.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Announcement that the United Mine Workers of America had taken under its wing a group of gas and coke workers' unions, hitherto affiliated directly with the American Federation of Labor, evoked an assertion today by William Green, president of the federation, that the action proved that the miners, as part of the Committee for Industrial Organization, were engaged in building a rival labor organization.

TWO novels today, both unusual specimens. I chose them from among many others because each is by an author of reputation whom I had heard much of and never read. One is Robert Nathan's "The Enchanted Voyage" (Knopf, $2). The other is Julian Green's "Midnight" (Harper, $2.50).

An offer of $1,250,000 by the New York Cuba Mail Steamship Company in settlement of all claims arising from the Morro Castle and Mohawk disasters has been accepted by lawyers for the claimants, it was announced yesterday.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Fortune Gallo, impresario of the San Carlo Opera Company, presented his seventh and final operetta of the current season here tonight on the water stage on Zach's Bay. The offering was Victor Herbert's "Naughty Marietta," a decidedly popular musical play.

The Correction Department's request for an increase of $567,737 over the current year in its 1937 budget was explained yesterday by Deputy Commissioner David Marcus at a hearing before Budget Director Leo J. McDermott. Mr. Marcus said that $298.951 of the increase was needed for additional personnel and for salary increases and readjustments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- A statement of the quality of the American cotton crop as it is ginned will be issued each Saturday this season by five of the field offices of the Department of Agriculture, the reporting offices to be in Atlanta, Austin, Dallas, El Paso and Memphis.

LONDON, Sept. 1. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange remained cheerful and active today, dividend disbursements bringing a considerable amount of reinvestment business. British Government issues continued to make headway. Industrial shares were more quiet than yesterday, although numerous issues showed strength.

The first conviction in New York County on a State income-tax evasion charge was handed down by Justices Kernochan, Kozicke and McInerney in Special Sessions yesterday. Oscar Saffer, head of Samuel Saffer, Inc., clothing manufacturers at 1,239 Broadway, was found guilty by the justices on evidence uncovered by Thomas E. Dewey in his current secret investigation of racketeering in the clothing industry in this county.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 1. -- In preparation for the three symposia on the social sciences and the humanities to be held here next week on the program of the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences the university made public today the first of a series of summaries, serving as general introductions to the subjects to be discussed, and outlining the scope and purpose.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,032,050 barrels, compared to 3,069,600 in the previous week, a decline of 37,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 33,000 and 18,000 barrels, respectively, in the daily average outputs of Oklahoma and California were the important changes.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Miss Marion Fisher of Lakeville captured the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day medal handicap tournament at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today, finishing one stroke ahead of Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill.

BUCHAREST Rumania Sept. 1. -- The Cabinet tonight decided to order the dissolution of all armed organizations, to introduce compulsory labor camps for youths between 18 and 21 years of age and to deprive Rumania's universities of their autonomy.

Advances of 1-32 to 5-32 point in United States Government bonds resulted yesterday in the establishment of twelve new high records for those issues on the New York Stock Exchange, and the volume was more than doubled at $809,100, against $386,900 the day before.

Dean Willard C. Rappleye of the Columbia University Medical School announced yesterday that fifty-nine scholarships, valued at $16,000, had been awarded to students of the medical school for the coming academic year. The list is as follows:

ALBANY, Sept. 1.--District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan's defense to the Drukman removal charges met its first severe test today as the prosecution launched its heaviest attack through the testimony of Police Commissioner Lewis A. Valentine.

Two notable arrivals on Broadway screens today are "The General Died at Dawn," with Gary Cooper, Madeleine Carroll, Akim Tamiroff and Dudley Digges heading its cast, at the Paramount, and the Reliance version of "The Last of the Mohicans," most widely read of James Fenimore Cooper's "Leather Stocking Tales," at the Rivoli.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 1. -- Harry Untereiner, superintendent of the Hudson County Parental School at Bayonne, agreed today to follow the advice of State Institutions Commissioner William J. Ellis and abandon the use of "dresses" as a form of punishment for boy inmates.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Third Cavalry officers of Fort Myers, Va., turned back the bid of the Huisache team of Houston, Texas, for its second national polo title in three weeks, defeating the Texans by 7 to 3 late today in the final of the national twelve-goal polo tournament.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Estimating the country's annual bill for sickness and accidents at $10,000,000,000, the Public Health Service figured today that it could be cut by as much as $2,000,000,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- A larger proportion of underweight hogs was received here today and prices for this class declined 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds. Other weights were off 15 to 25 cents. The top price was $11.30, which was 20 cents less than yesterday and the lowest in three weeks.

The hit tunes of 1935, according to the frequency with which they were played on CBS and NBC units, were listed yesterday in the annual analysis of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 1 (AP). -- Miss Patty Berg, youngest member of the Curtis Cup team at 18, and Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., advanced with ease through the first round of match play in the Mason and Dixon women's golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- Last year's Congressional battle over utility holding companies echoed today in discussions prepared by American experts for the forthcoming world power conference.

PARIS, Sept. 1 (AP). -- Thousands of Europeans, rallying to the call "peace is in danger," headed for Brussels tonight for an international congress against war. Mindful of the danger that Spain's civil war might spread to a Fascist-Socialist duel of European powers, the delegates went as private citizens to voice their demand for peace above that of diplomatic conversation.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 1. -- Government defenders of Toledo prepared tonight to dynamite the famous Alcazar if the 1,700 besieged Rebels -- men, women and children -- within its crumbling walls do not surrender.

Two hundred persons gathered at a Mississippi cotton field on Monday to witness what may prove to be a historic spectacle. A ponderous machine, ten feet high, lumbered over the field and picked cotton with a thousand moistened steel fingers. In about eight hours it picked as much as seventy-five or eighty men and women could have gathered picking by hand for the same period.

Shipments of all types of hosiery during July amounted to 9,321,587 dozen pairs, a gain of 5.4 per cent over the previous month and 36.7 per cent over July, 1935, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reported yesterday. For the first seven months of 1936, shipments of all types were 9.3 per cent ahead of 1935.

Anita Simpson, a tiny 3-year-old who looked like an old-fashioned doll, won third place and a silver medal at the finals of the children's amateur singing contest held on the Mall, Central Park, last night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- John Hamilton, Republican national chairman, met today with seventy-five Negro Republicans from States bordering the Mason and Dixon line, who are organized as a national planning board to work among the colored voters.
The Eastern managers of the Republican national campaign announced yesterday that Jesse Owens, the Olympic Games track star, would support Governor Landon.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 2. -- Arthur E. Moreau, chairman of Amoskeag Industries, Inc., announced tonight that final arrangements have been made by local banking and business interests to buy the physical assets of the bankrupt Amoskeag Manufacturing Company.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 2. -- By staging one of the most sensational comebacks ever witnessed in an international golf match, G. Alec Hill and Cecil Ewing saved the day for Great Britain as the ninth annual competition for the Walker Cup got under way at the Pine Valley Golf Club today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade here fluctuated today in an erratic manner, running into commission-house and local selling on the advances and meeting good support on declines. Wheat had a range of 1 1/2 cents a bushel and closed with net gains of 1/4 to 1/2 cent.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Receipts of hogs today were smaller than yesterday and prices generally advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight. The top was $11.45, which was 15 cents higher than yesterday, while the day's average was up 10 cents to $10.20.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Asserting that application of the Railway Labor Act to its relations with employes was unconstitutional, the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company yesterday petitioned the Federal court here to declare that it was not a railroad of the type subject to the act.
CARROLLTON, Ky., Sept. 2. -- The story-telling ability of J. Harve Raisor, a 70-year-old Kentucky hill farmer, won him check No. 1 when the State began its old-age pension program.

Today will be a field day for the city, with a revival of the era of big parades. The occasion is the return from Germany of fifty-two members of the Olympic team, the last of about 380 American athletes, most of whom returned during the last few weeks.
PARIS, Sept. 2. -- Agitation for increasing military service from two years to two and a half or three years has been growing in the last few days.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 2. -- The mid-week polo matches this afternoon at the Meadow Brook Club were attended by less social activity among society members than the week-end games. The interest in the two matches, one on Cochran Field and one on International Field, precluded the possibility of entertaining if none of the periods is to be missed.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 2. -- Development of a medicine which relieves mental depression and has demonstrated a tendency toward prevention of suicide was reported to the American Psychological Association today by Dr Abraham Myerson of the Division of Psychiatric Research at the Massachusetts State Hospital in Mattapan.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- The business of setting up an international committee at London to supervise working of the non-intervention agreement concerning the Spanish civil war has been further delayed by Germany's failure to participate such a committee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Good campaign news for the Democratic party was included in predictions voiced today at the All-American Astrologers Convention, attended by about 500 "star-gazers" from all parts of the country.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, invited Democratic support tonight by declaring that the Democratic party had been seized by "alien and un-American elements."

Ten Manhattan parcels were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Among the holdings were a 14-story loft building at 256-60 West Thirty-eighth Street and groups of structures in Sixth Avenue at Fifty-fourth and Fifty-sixth Streets. The results were as follows:

The entry list in the Bendix transcontinental air derby has dropped from ten to four, it was announced last night at Floyd Bennett Field. The race for which Vincent Bendix has offered $15,000 in prizes is scheduled to start after midnight tonight from New York and will end at Mines Field, Los Angeles, where the National Air Races open on Saturday.

In preparation for the public hearings on rapid transit unification, scheduled to begin next Thursday, the Transit Commission has retained Chester W. Cuthell of 20 Pine Street as associate special counsel to work with John J. Curtin, who has been its special counsel since 1931.

The pamphlet report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System and subsidiaries for the year ended on June 30, including the Brooklyn and Queens Transit System, which was issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $5,607,588. This was equal, after annual preferred dividend requirements, to $5.59 a share on 735,664 common shares.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- Japan precipitated a new naval dispute with Great Britain and the United States today by announcing that she would keep 15,598 tons of submarines as well as 11,059 tons of destroyers above what is allowed her under the dying 1930 naval treaty.

At 1:30 P.M. today Miss Helen Jacobs and Miss Esther Edwards will walk down the steps leading from the marquee to the stadium courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Ells and the combined men's and women's national championships will get under way.

Labor's support of President Roosevelt in the impending national election is certain, Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York declared last night in his first speech of the campaign. Starting a series of weekly broadcasts under the sponsorship of Labor's Non-Partisan League and its New York State affiliate, the American Labor Party, Senator Wagner spoke over station WEVD and a network extending as far west as Chicago.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Isaac I. Kashdan of New York City, defending champion in the annual tournament of the New York State Chess Association, today maintained his clean record, defeating his opponents in the third, fourth and fifth rounds.
BAYSHORE, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Sailors from the Pequot Yacht Club today loomed as dangerous rivals to Vineyard Haven's crew in the latter's defense of its national junior yachting championship.

Import figures just released by various government agencies indicate a continued increase in the importation of manufacturers of wool, according to the National Association of Wool Manufacturers yesterday, and bear out the group's contention that "present differences in wage rates in this country and both Great Britain and Japan are making it increasingly difficult for domestic manufacturers to meet the competition of foreign countries."

Overruling a contention that he was subjecting two prisoners before him to double jeopardy, Justice Panken of the Domestic Relations Court, sitting as a judge of the Children's Court in Jamaica, utilized for the first time yesterday an amendment to the Children's Court Law enacted last Winter and increasing its scope.

Directors of the major milk distributing companies in the city held meetings yesterday to decide what course to take in case of an increase in prices to producers. Spokesmen for the companies declined to divulge the decisions reached pending the outcome of a conference tomorrow in Syracuse of representatives of the distributors and producing organizations.

A diet for a lost collie that has a pink birthmark on his nose and "gets stomachaches easily" was broadcast yesterday by the 11-year-old owner of the animal, in the hope that it may come to the attention of whoever may have found her pet.
A woman was injured and four automobiles were slightly damaged about 9:40 o'clock last night when a small sedan, traveling at high speed, went on a rampage at Broadway and 100th Street.

An almost "miraculous" improvement since last May in the income and condition of security behind the $14,000,000 B-K series of certificates sold by the closed New York Title and Mortgage Company was credited yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler when the court took under advisement an application by the trustees for approval of their accounting and budget.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- The Detroit Lions, champions of the professional football world, were faced with defeat for more than three-quarters of their battle tonight at Soldier Field, but rallied in the final period to send Ernie Caddel around the left end of the All-Stars' line for eight yards and the touchdown which eventually produced a 7-to-7 tie.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made ready today to resume on Sept. 14 its far-reaching investigation into the $4,000,000,000 investment-trust structure in the United States.
Two important things happened on Old Rose Hill yesterday.

Declines were the rule in light trading yesterday on local commodity futures markets, with coffee active on the downtrend, although cottonseed oil, cocoa and lead futures were stronger. On the cash markets, cocoa reached a new high level, and wheat, cotton, butter and eggs advanced.
TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Glenn H. Brink of Detroit led thirty-three participants in the Ruth Chatterton air derby into Tucson laste today on the ninth lap of the Cleveland-Los Angeles race.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 2. -- General Francisco Franco, the Rebel commander, has moved his personal headquarters from Seville to Caceres, nearer the front, in order to direct personally the final drive on Toledo and Madrid.

SEATTLE, Sept. 2. -- Whether or not its Governorship candidate, John C. Stevenson, radio speaker, wins in the Democratic primary next Tuesday, the Washington Commonwealth Federation is likely to give considerable embarrassment as well as help to President Roosevelt in the election campaign.

By cable from London comes word that when Gilbert Miller presents "Promise" here this season the cast will be headed by Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Charles Laughton -- an announcement which automatically makes the Bernstein play one of the top-flight events of the season.
Among the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday were two sales of private residences which will result in the conversion of the houses into apartments.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Browns handed over the American League cellar to the Athletics today by clubbing out a 13-to-ll victory over the Mackmen in their series opener.

In answer to insistence from London that Berlin agree at once to take part in an international committee to enforce nonintervention in Spain, the German Government recommends that instead of the proposed committee the task of insuring neutrality be delegated to a single power, preferably Great Britain.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Governor Hoffman was a guest of the Flemington Fair Association today and presented a trophy to W. D. Blood of Newark for the victory of his brown colt Mighty, which won the 3-year-old trot for a $600 stake in 2:09 1/2.

Apartment leasing continued active yesterday, with the greater part of the demand centered on the areas east and west of Central Park. Interest in suites in the East Sixties and Seventies about equaled that in the area extending from the park to West End Avenue and Riverside Drive, both of which were well represented in the list of rentals.

BUFFALO, Sept. 2 (AP). -- An order instructing customs inspectors to enforce a ban against importation of liquor from Canada by any person other than a licensed importer was countermanded today with as little warning as it was imposed late yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2. -- The slender margin that separated fair from foul on a fatal tap in front of the plate brought ruin to the Giants today in the first of their crucial games with the Cardinals before a gathering of 13,500 at Sportsman's Park.

A principal feature of the musical season of 1936-37 will be the world premiere in Philadelphia and a performance in New York a few days later of Sergei Rachmaninoff's latest symphony, which is called his Third. This work was completed by Mr. Rachmaninoff a month ago in Switzerland. The symphony takes about forty minutes to play.

Albert H. Atterbury, whose letter appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 29, relies on the somewhat frayed, though still widely accepted, notion that the law of supply and demand is the sole determinant of the rate of wages. By applying this conclusion to the particular, he seeks to demonstrate the economic unfitness of such legislative mechanisms as the Minimum Wage Law, recently declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court of the United States.
Richard Merrill, veteran airline pilot, and Harry Richman, actor, were speeding over the North Atlantic early this morning toward London, with a helping wind of forty miles an hour behind them.

MADRID, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Madrid, on which Rebel air raids have been almost a nightly occurrence, went to sleep tonight wondering whether its airmen had assured a night of uninterrupted rest by destroying a secret Fascist airdrome.
Apartment house investment deals featured the Bronx trading reported yesterday.

Alarmed by the spread of boycott sentiment against American goods in South Africa, foreign traders moved yesterday to spread the American side of the trade controversy before the people there. A committee to study the situation, map out a program and raise funds with which to put it into force, was named yesterday at a meeting of exporters and importers called at India House by the National Foreign Trade Association.

Pig iron production in August, as estimated by The Iron Age from reports on Tuesday, totaled 2,711,431 gross tons, compared with 2,594,268 tons in July, the daily rate having been 87,466 tons, against 83,686 tons in the previous month, a gain of 4.5 per cent. Furnaces in blast Sept. 1 totaled 147, a gain of one since Aug. 1.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Pole's national open championship reached its final round today with two games on Meadow Brook fields. As had been expected, Greentree and Templeton will fight it out for the title and the right to represent this country in the matches against Argentina.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday it had revised the form of basic agreements to be executed, when applicable, by corporations applying to list securities on the Exchange. The changes are principally in arrangement, form and phraseology.

Thrilling as are the "adventures of the mind" reported at the Harvard tercentenary conference of arts and sciences, the layman reacts to these researches in the logic and mathematics of the spheres with something like religious awe. Abstractions that seem clear as print to scholars like Professor CARTAN, the great mathematician of the University of Paris, and Professor CARNAP, the philosopher of Vienna, are far beyond the range of most scientists.

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 2. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's political activities and his attacks on President Roosevelt in the heat of the Presidential campaign were severely criticized today by the Osservatore Romano, which usually reflects opinions of the Vatican.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- Although business on the Boerse was so quiet today that many issues remained quotationless throughout the session, those stocks in which there was trading continued rather firm, with individual gains of 2 or more points.

Early replies to a questionnaire on the effective development of internal store promotion already indicate a marked interest in this question on the part of department store executives, it was reported yesterday by Thomas Robb, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Mr. LA GUARDIA has let it be known that his name has been added to the call for a meeting of Progressive Republicans in Chicago, along with Senator NORRIS, Senator LA FOLLETTE and others. The object is to aid in the reelection of President ROOSEVELT, and Mayor LA GUARDIA intimates that he will take part in an active campaign for that end.

Most readers are familiar with the reasons that have obliged the President to revise the estimates he made last January of the Government's revenues and expenditures for the fiscal year to end June 30, 1937. They include the Supreme Court's invalidation of the AAA and the processing taxes connected with it; the passage by Congress of the soldiers' bonus; the new revenues to be brought in by the Revenue Act passed by Congress last Spring.

SHOREHAM, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Funeral services for Julius H. de Lagerberg, a leading authority on numismatics, will be held here at 10 A.M. on Friday at the de Lagerberg home. Burial will be in the family vault at Brookside Cemtery, Englewood, N.J.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Jack Sabol, professional at Westchester Hills, and Donald Bomann of Mount Kisco turned in a card of 62 to win the pro-amateur bestball tournament over the course of the Mount Kisco Golf Club today. It was one of the lowest best-ball scores turned in at the par-72 course this year, the victors going out in 29 and coming back in 33.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 2. -- A net estate of $6,318,439.89 was left by Virginia Fair Vanderbilt when she died at her country home, Fairmont, Manhasset, on July 7. A transfer tax appraisal was filed on her estate here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell. Deductions of $453,532.45 were made from the gross estate of $6,755,972.34. A Tax of $688,390.38 has been levied.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- On the eve of the drought conference at Des Moines the Republican National Committee asserted today that if suggestions Governor Landon made two years ago on water storage had been applied in the Great Plains States, drought hardships would have been alleviated.

The retirement of Captain John F. Jensen, master of the United States liner President Roosevelt, was announced yesterday by the International Mercantile Marine Company, owner of the line. Captain Jensen sailed in command of his ship yesterday at noon from Pier 60, and will quit the sea when the voyage ends.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Question Mark, the big chestnut gelding owned by Miss Fredericka Fry of Greenwich, Conn., and jumped By Lieutenant John W. Morris of West Cornwall, N.Y., was the winner of the Johnston L. Redmond Trophy in the open hunter class, amateurs up, the leading cup event of the first day of the seventeenth annual Rhinebeck-Dutchess County Fair Horse Show.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- While the civil war goes on in Spain real political games are being played in Central Europe in intrigues and secret negotiations. The public is not aware of these developments until suddenly it learns of events which it finds difficult to explain.

Fifty-eight men and women who said they were artists, models and photographers, went to the officers of the Federal Art Project at 6 East Thirty-ninth Street yesterday and announced that they would remain there until they received jobs, "even if we have to wait three weeks."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Works Progress Administration issued an order today that its more than 2,300,000 workers "shall be entitled to exercise their voting franchise in the same manner as other citizens."

Announcement that his company is seeking a plant location outside this city after fifty-three years of operation here was made yesterday by Alfred Murphy, president of the Ocean Bathing Suit Company. one of the largest local producers.

The President's first official forecast of the amount of the 1937 deficit again brings home the fact that the various forms of relief are responsible for most of the Treasury's red ink. Natural calamities, such as the drought, cannot be provided against in any budget estimate, and therefore the only point at which the chisel of economy can be applied is continuing unemployment relief.

Republican members of Congress from New York State yesterday challenged President Roosevelt's forecast of the Federal deficit for the current fiscal year as a "distorted picture" presented for political reasons. One statement was to the effect that a fair estimate would take into consideration the fact that relief funds would be exhausted by Jan. 1, while the fiscal year does not end until June 30, 1937.

Johnny Allen, now enjoying a successful season with the Indians, embarrassed his former Yankee mates no little yesterday at the Stadium as he silenced the booming bats of the McCarthymen, set them down with just three, hits, fanned eight and generally added to the discomfort of the pennant-bound New Yorkers.

Persons convicted of speeding or reckless driving before Sept. 1, when the new State penalties went into effect, will star with a "clean slate" and the old conviction will not be added to any new one, Chief Magistrate Jacob Gold Schurman Jr. declared yesterday.

William Albert Robinson, 34-year-old navigator and author, who took his 32-foot ketch the Svaarp around the world some years ago, is planning another bluewater odyssey, he announced yesterday in his suite at the Hotel St. Moritz.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Roosevelt House in New York was the beneficiary of a large bridge tournament, arranged by prominent women in the Summer colony headed by Mrs. Arthur B. Claflin, which was held tonight at Mrs. Claflin's place in the Shinnecock Hills.
Building plans filed yesterday included loft and apartment structures for Manhattan and theatre and apartment buildings for Queens, as follows:

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 2 (AP). -- Red-haired Patty Berg shot her way into the semi-finals of the Mason-Dixon women's golf tournament today with a convincing 5-and-4 victory over Miss Fritzi Stifel of Wheeling.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Blame for the crash of the TWA giant airplane, "Sun Racer," which cost the lives of twelve of its fourteen passengers when it flew into a mountain near Fair Chance, Pa., last April 7, was put upon Otto Ferguson, pilot of the plane, in a report issued today by the Bureau of Air Commerce.

The Stamford Yacht Club's annual race to Vineyard Sound Lightship and return will begin at 6 P.M. tomorrow with thirty-seven craft scheduled to compete. The race is over a 232-mile course and is open to cruising as well as racing type yachts from 30 to 75 feet overall length.

GENEVA, Sept. 2. -- The British delegation to the World Youth Congress here proposed today that the congress recommend that all League of Nations members "place their forces at the League's disposal" to maintain peace.

The Seas Shipping Company, operator of the Robin Line, announced yesterday that a differential of $2 a ton would be allowed in favor of boxed automobiles carried to South Africa by its ships, starting with the sailing of the Robin Grey from New York on Oct. 24.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 2. -- This city awaits the meeting tomorrow of President Roosevelt and Governor Landon of Kansas, rival candidates for the Presidency.
BERLIN, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 31 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

MADRID, Sept. 2. -- Fifteen Americans, whose ages varied from 14 days to 77 years, were evacuated from Madrid tonight by the United States Embassy. They left by train for Alicante, where they will board the United States cruiser Quincy tomorrow and sail for Marseilles or Nice.

A conference between James A. Farley, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Democratic leaders in the five counties of New York City will be held tomorrow, Mr. Farley announced yesterday.

Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, Tammany organization designee for the General Sessions judgeship now held by Jonah J. Goldstein under appointment of the Governor, revealed yesterday that last April Governor Lehman had endorsed him, in a letter to President Roosevelt, for a Federal District Court judgeship about to be created for New York City.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- The weather and the Cubs both put the chill on the Dodgers today as they submitted to a 4-0 shutout under gray skies on a soggy field, and with a comparative handful of spectators in the stands. The paid attendance was 2,480.

PARIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- More than 3,000 workers occupied French factories today in a fresh outbreak of "stay in" or "folded arms" strikes. The new refusal to work was attributed to employes' demands for readjustment of salaries to meet rising costs of living.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Two youths were hurt, one seriously, when a rented seaplane they were flying crashed in New Rochelle Harbor 200 yards offshore at 7:35 o'clock this evening, They are Joseph Colombo, 21 years old, a WPA Worker, and Joseph Iscaro, also 21, an automobile mechanic.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 2.--A law enacted in 1795, revised in 1846 and 1877, and not employed in the last twenty-five years, according to Supreme Court officials, has been invoked by John Burg, owner of a farm in Florence Township, Burlington County, in an effort to recover triple damages for the alleged failure of his tenant, Alex Daskel, to fertilize the land properly.
TOPEKA, Sept. 2. -- Governor Landon will leave tomorrow morning to attend the conference of Governors of drought States called by President Roosevelt.

Mr. LLOYD GEORGE is replenishing his mind by a visit to Germany, where, curiously enough, he is said to be "studying" the subject of unemployment. He has provided in program so many painless remedies that it is surprising to find him seeking any further light.

Ralph Johnson, 31 years old, Negro janitor of 550 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, vigorously denied in Pennsylvania Avenue Court yesterday that symbols scrawled in a notebook he had were code signs for the policy game.

A drive to deliver the Negro vote to President Roosevelt was started yesterday by Stanley High's Good Neighbor League. With forty Negro leaders, including two Bishops of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, actively in charge, the campaign will be waged mostly intensively in the pivotal Northern States, where the disposition of some 2,000,000 Negro votes may spell the difference between victory and defeat for Mr. Roosevelt.
HENDAYE, France, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Daniel Garcia Mansilla, Argentine Ambassador to Spain, tonight announced that foreign diplomats were seeking a truce in Spain to prevent a "world war."

The letter from Frank R. Wilson about the milk situation carried valuable information for city people. He pointed out that a twenty-cow dairy producing 160,000 pounds of milk a year selling at the Control Board price leaves the producer $4,320, against a cost of $4,555, which means that he is laboring for a year for nothing and paying $235 for the privilege.

A former assistant district supervisor of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, who was accused of accepting loan installments of $104 from three clients of the government and of keeping the money for himself, was freed of that charge yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The United States Government has notified Great Britain that it must "very reluctantly" keep in service after the end of this year 40,000 tons of over-age destroyers in excess of the total permitted by the London Naval Treaty of 1930.

POSSIBLY John T. McIntyre's prize-winning novel. "Steps Going Down" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50), is pointless by design. Certainly it parallels the lives of the people who populate it. It just runs along for a while, sometimes very brisk and lively, sometimes fairly dull, and then stops. Nothing accomplished, nothing done, and what of it? That is the earned reaction.

It was said of ancient wisdom that length of life was in her right hand. More fitly may it be said of the wisdom which has made possible the statistics reported by the Health Department of this city that still greater expectation of life is in her hand. In the Bulletin for August it is stated that between 1880 and 1930 the expectation of life at birth grew from 32.77 years to 55.77 in 1930.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Jake Wade held the Senators to three hits today as the Detroit Tigers beat Washington, 3 to 2.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 2. -- In an interview with your correspondent yesterday General Anastasio Somoza, Nicaraguan leader, predicted he would be victorious in the forthcoming Presidential election.

The negotiations between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau for a new agreement reached a new impasse yesterday, with indications that Mayor La Guardia's intervention might again become necessary to avert a walkout of 15,000 drivers.

Formation of the Laundry Institute, Inc., to correct competitive abuses said to be costing laundry owners of the metropolitan district hundreds of thousands annually, was announced here yesterday following a meeting of representatives of the Laundry Board of Trade and the Brooklyn Laundry Owners, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore.

A banking group composed of the Chase National Bank, the First Boston Corporation and Roosevelt Weigold, Inc., won the award yesterday of a new issue of $1,142,000 bonds of Mount Vernon, N.Y., on a bid of 100.02 for 2 1/2 and 3 per cent securities.

Paramount is experiencing some difficulty in getting "You and Me," Norman Krasna's first directorial effort, before the cameras. George Raft, who has the leading role, believes that the part does not suit him and he is somewhat reluctant to appear in the film.

VIENNA, Sept. 2. -- Kirsten Flagstad made her first appearance in Vienna at the State Opera tonight in a performance of "Tristan und Isolde." The Vienna debut of the Metropolitan Opera Company's Wagnerian favorite was devoid of sensational features.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Michael F. Tighe, 78-year-old president of the nation's biggest steel union, announced his retirement today and simultaneously called upon workers to support the campaign to enlist the men of the mills under one banner.

Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions sentenced yesterday Frank Rivera, 23 years old, a Puerto Rican, who lived at 2 West 115th Street, to twenty years to life in Sing Sing. Rivera had pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the slaying last May of Miss Rafaela Rodriguez, 25, in a jealous rage when he saw her entering an East 116th Street restaurant with a rival suitor.

Tony Canzoneri will risk his lightweight championship of the world tonight when he clashes with Lou Ambers, the speedy battler from Herkimer, N.Y., in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden. On the same card the semi-final bout will show Mike Belloise of the Bronx defending his claim to the world's featherweight championship against Dave Crowley of England in a fight also listed for fifteen rounds.

The Queens County Bar Association yesterday notified the Democratic and Republican leaders of the five counties in the Second Judicial District that it had endorsed eleven borough attorneys and jurists as "especially qualified and competent" to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court bench in the district to be caused by the retirement of Justice Burt Jay Humphrey at the end of this year because of the age limit.

Governor Landon is outdistancing President Roosevelt in the "grass roots" poll being conducted by some 3,000 country newspapers in cooperation with the Publishers Autocaster Service and the American Press, according to the second installment of returns made public yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia in a speech at Coney Island yesterday afternoon defended his administration in its efforts to keep the city's streets clean. Referring to a statement by County Judge Franklin Taylor last week, in which he called Brooklyn the "dirtiest borough," the Mayor said:

Among the persons returning today from European ports is Bishop Michael J. Gallagher of Detroit, who will arrive on the Italian liner Rex. Others on the ship are the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic delegate at Washington; Fritz Reiner, conductor; Max D. Steuer, lawyer, with Mrs. Steuer; Harvey Duell, editor; Adelmo Della Casa, Mgr. Vincenzo Monteleone, Robert H. McCormick, Sabino Solafrizzo and Count and Countess Giancarlo Camerana.

I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES that experts have been making exhaustive tests in London to determine how to eliminate noise in the subways. They think that they have succeeded by placing a continuous sheet of asbestos, one and one-half inches thick, parallel to the tracks, between the subway floor and the running board of the trains.

Customs men, facing the busiest period of the year today and tomorrow when 14,000 baggage-laden tourists arrive from Europe and Southern vacation ports, said yesterday that steamship companies might be compelled in the future to stagger ship arrivals as well as sailings.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Wallace Benjamin will give a large buffet supper Saturday night to precede the Maidstone Club's annual costume ball.

Further advances yesterday in United States Government bonds on the New York Stock Exchange brought new high records for fifteen issues, with advances ranging from 1-32 to 7-32 point and the volume $912,300, against $809,100 on Tuesday.

With more than 300 employers on the list of those who have signed agreements with the union, according to strike leaders, 3,300 of the 12,000 striking members of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers will return to work this morning in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island.

GENEVA, Sept. 2. -- Denmark proposes that the League of Nations Assembly this month consider the possibility of opening negotiations with all non-League members "with a view to bringing them into it." She also seeks the adoption of "any measure that may make it easier for non-member States to join."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Two long semi-final matches, one ending on the eighteenth green of the Cherry Valley Club course and one on the twentieth, resulted in triumphs today for Mrs. Thomas R. Rudel of Oakland and Miss Ann Weeks of the Rockaway Hunting Club and Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. and Miss Marianne Dickson of Women's National.

Ending the first national Safe Driver Conference at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, the forty-nine representative safe drivers from all States and the District of Columbia voted to form a permanent Safe Drivers League to cooperate with existing safety groups in all sections of the country.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2. -- A drive by the State Labor Department against employers who fail to carry workmen's compensation insurance has produced a list of 600 employers in New Jersey violating the law by this neglect and indictments will be sought against them, it was announced today by John J. Toohey Jr., State Labor Commissioner.

HARBIN, Manchukuo, Sept. 2. -- While the Japanese complain that Russia has massed more than 300,000 men along the northern Manchurian boundaries, and interpret secrecy and censorship as indicative of warlike intentions, investigation reveals that Japanese-controlled fighting men are few short of the asserted Soviet total and that secrecy and censorship are also the general rule in Manchuria.

There appeared in THE TIMES a very interesting news item that nine of twenty-two slayers in the death house at Sing Sing awaiting execution are between 17 and 20 years of age. This item should make the present generation take notice of the serious problem we are facing.

ON BOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL TRAIN ON THE WAY TO DES MOINES, Sept. 2. -- After a final motor tour through a typical agricultural region in Northeastern Colorado and conferences with the Governors of Colorado and Nebraska, President Roosevelt prepared tonight for his meeting at Des Moines tomorrow with Governor Landon, his opponent in the Presidential campaign, under circumstances that are without precedent.
An apartment house site, a garage and three dwellings figured in deals reported by brokers in Queens yesterday.

Charles J. Hartman, described by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as "one of the shrewdest security thieves in the country," pleaded guilty yesterday to an indictment charging conspiracy to sell and transport stolen bonds and received a prison sentence of nine months.

One of E.R. Bradley's homebreds, the North Star gelding, Bijuro, at last ran to his promise when he won and made favorites a little less hard to find at Aqueduct yesterday. This is the youngster of last year which could not get out of the maiden class despite nine tries and many game finishes.

The Deisel-Wemmer-Gilbert Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a share and the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the common stock. Its subsidiary, the Bernard Schwartz Cigar Corporation, declared a dividend of 75 cents on the common stock.
Yale University has sold to the Atlantic Refining Company the rights to broadcast six football games to be played in the Yale Bowl at New Haven, it was learned last night.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- The government of Premier Leon Blum was reliably reported tonight to be strengthening its defenses at home and abroad to meet the threat of Germany's lengthened military service. The Socialist cabinet, informed sources said, had considered plans to strengthen its armed forces and to reinforce the nation through foreign alliances.

DETROIT, Sept. 2(AP). -- The State today began to purge its payrolls of men suspected of member, ship in the Black Legion, and the head of a citizens' committee in Pontiac, declaring the activities of the terrorists there had created "a rotten, disgraceful mess," demanded that the city do likewise.

VALENCIA, Spain, Aug. 31 (Uncensored London Times Dispatch). -- The stalemate to which both parties in the Spanish civil war appear to be reduced is likely to be prolonged unless some new horse is brought from the war stable.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The Cumberland County Power and Light Company of Portland, Me., filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $9,500,000 first mortgage bonds, due in 1966, and 10,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred capital stock.

Myles A. Paige, attorney, who starred at end for the Howard University eleven in 1920 and later worked as a Pullman porter while studying law at Columbia, was sworn in yesterday afternoon as the first Negro magistrate in the city's history.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 2. -- Favored players dominated the field in the qualifying round and then advanced to the semi-finals in the annual match-play tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Innis Arden Club today.
The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed registrar of the common stock of the Cook Paint and Varnish Company.

LOYALIST HEADQUARTERS, Near Huesca, Spain, Sept. 2 (By Courier to Barcelona). -- "This is a war of ideas and political theories as well as of soldiers and weapons," said General Trueba, leader of a Loyalist column from Barcelona, "and I hope the fire of combat will fuse into union the different and sometimes the politically discordant elements of which the Catalan militia is composed."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 2. -- Anton Rudert and Anton Rudert Jr. of Munsey Park and Henry and Robert Reeve of Shelter Rock finished in a deadlock for the honors in the Long Island Golf Association's thirteenth annual father and son two-ball championship competition over the Hempstead Golf Club course today.

Commenting on the action of customs officials in Buffalo in having temporarily barred the importing of liquor from Canada by visitors, Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, said yesterday that at the request of Buffalo licensed liquor dealers he recently had forwarded to the Secretary of the Treasury the ruling of the Appellate Division upholding the State law prohibiting any one not a licensed dealer from importing liquor into the State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Reports of transactions in securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations for July, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed numerous sales and purchases.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Under an opportune breeze, then rain and fog, the Long Island Sound Interclubs and the Bermuda One-Design sloops started their international series this afternoon off the Larchmont Yacht Club, and the Interclubs won the first race of the seven that are to be sailed by the thread-like margin of one-quarter of a point.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas fell off sharply for the week ended Aug. 29, in comparison with the gain for the preceding week, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. An increase of 9 per cent for the week over the same period a year ago was noted, against 17 per cent for the preceding week.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

The widow of John M. Phillips, alleged master mind of the notorious Queens sewer graft ring of 1928, joined yesterday in already complicated litigation in Federal court over possession of a gold dinner service now valued at $100,000. The widow, now Mrs. Marian M. Cassidy, contended that the gold plate was given to her in 1927 by "certain sewer contractors in and about New York City."
Two young thugs, both armed with revolvers, held up about thirty card-players in the Garment Center Club at 245 West Thirty-eighth Street about 9:30 o'clock last night and escaped.

BERLIN, Sept. 2. -- The German press, which has hitherto paid little attention to the Paris visit of General Edward Rydz-Smigly, Polish dictator, is beginning to warn Poland against a plot to lure her into the Franco-Soviet pact system with promises that Russian troops marching against Germany will avoid her territory and pass through Rumania and Czechoslovakia instead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, asserted today that steel mill workers in Western Pennsylvania were being told that they would be expected to report for duty on Labor Day, when several mass meetings of the committee are scheduled to take place.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiary companies reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $2,668,401 for the twelve months ended on July 31 after all deductions except provisions for possible Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 2 (AP). -- The great flour milling industry, a bulwark of this city's food processing activities, was near a standstill tonight as a group of pickets from the 1,800 strikers involved in five current labor disputes brought a shut down of one of the nation's largest mills.

The most significant change in the revised listing agreements made public yesterday by the Stock Exchange was that requiring listed companies to notify the Exchange of changes in accounting methods, policies of depreciation and depletion or bases of valuation of inventories or other assets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- In a brief attacking an order by the Interstate Commerce Commission increasing warehouse and storage charges of railroads in the Port of New York district, seven railroads opposing the edict raised today the question of the constitutionality of the order and indicated that the issue might be taken to the courts if the commission failed to reopen the case and reverse its decision.

SUMMERVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- H.F. Beardslee and M.L. Lehman of California in By-C won the first race in defense of their Star Class world championship today. Johnny Arms and Macrea Sykes were second with Andiamo III and Paul Shields, with L.M. Bainbridge tending sheet, played the light air right for third place in Jack Rabbit as the series got under way on Lake Ontario.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The Federal fiscal picture brightened during August, the second month of the fiscal year. Treasury receipts were substantially higher and expenditures and the deficit were lower.

The threat of a strike of 1,000 union musicians employed on WPA projects was withdrawn yesterday when Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, drew up what union officials regarded as an acceptable scale of hourly wages for WPA musicians.

A college boys' ricksha relay race from New York to Asbury Park to advertise an American Legion convention in the resort city was run in fourteen and a half hours through heavy traffic and rain yesterday despite a hostile reception by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall, the starting line.
The season's record catch of giant tuna for local waters was turned in yesterday by an angler who just went out for a boat ride.
BUFFALO, Sept. 2 (AP). -- Remington -Rand representatives and leaders of strikers accused each other of blocking an agreement on a basis for collective bargaining with impossible demands here today.

Followers of the security markets pondered President Roosevelt's budget statement and discussed reports oh the political polls yesterday in addition to scanning the midweek trade reviews, which were quite favorable. The result was that the stock market moved higher during most of the day, easing slightly in the final hour to close with fractional gains.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- With protests becoming ever more vehement in nationalist quarters here, Mrs. Dolores Iriburri, Spanish Communist deputy, who is known as La Pasionaria, made an impassioned plea for the Spanish Government's cause in an interview with the press this afternoon.

TRENTON, Sept. 2. -- Governor Hoffman disapproved today a proposal for an immediate special session of the Legislature to revise the State relief formula. His opinion was expressed in a reply to Samuel S. Kenworthy, executive secretary of the State League of Municipalities, which has asked for the special session.

City officials are hopeful of further amending the bankers' agreement to cut in half the $20,000,000 tax reserve fund that the agreement provides must be in the city's 1937 budget, it was learned yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 2. -- Mrs. Eva Fox, wife of William Fox, former film producer, again failed to appear for questioning in her husband's bankruptcy proceedings here today and Referee Robert E. Steedle announced he would certify her for contempt of court.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- Former Prime Minister David Lloyd George went to Germany today for the first time since the war. He was invited to study methods of dealing with unemployment by the recently appointed German Ambassador, Joachim von Ribbentrop, when the latter made his last visit to England.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The birthday of Jane Addams next Sunday has been chosen as the date for the start of a drive to obtain the signatures of 5,000,000 people in the United States to a petition opposing war. The Committee of the People's Mandate to Governments to End War, in announcing this today, said the petition would be presented to the Pan-American Peace Conference, scheduled to open in Buenos Aires on Dec. 1.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 2. -- "A powerful revival of the medieval feeling for the universal, non-national and non-racial character of truth is the only protection for humanity against the encroachments of the totalitarian State," which "threatens mankind with the worst form of slavery -- mental slavery," the Harvard tercentenary conference of arts and sciences was told tonight by Professor Etienne Gilson of the University of Paris.

James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, announced yesterday the creation of a National Council of Roosevelt Electors to raise the remainder of the $2,000,000 campaign fund needed for the Roosevelt fight for re-election.

A Negro, about 30 years old, said by police to be one of three who had held up a grocery store proprietor a few moments earlier, was shot and seriously wounded by a patrolman at about 8:30 last night during a chase through West 131st Street, between Lenox and Seventh Avenues.

A wide variety of industrial and business properties figured in commercial leasing throughout the city yesterday. Store space was in good demand as well as offices, showrooms, lofts and space suited to light manufacturing.

ALBANY, Sept. 2. -- The dramatic disclosure of important contradictions in police reports dealing with the Drukman murder case led Governor Lehman today to ask Police Commissioner Lewis A. Valentine for a fuller explanation, which the commissioner found himself unable to supply without further inquiry himself.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- A recommendation that 10,000,000 aliens in this country be sent back to the lands from which they came was adopted today by the United Spanish War Veterans, in encampment here.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Confidence was the keynote as the home guards stood up to defend the Walker Cup against the attack of the British brigade over the Pine Valley trenches. When President John G. Jackson of the U.S.G.A. gave the signal to start firing, only Scotty Campbell of Seattle was on the first tee to face the British pair, Hector Thomson and Harry Bentley.

The large Negro community in New York City has every right to share in the administration of justice by the city judiciary, and in naming for the first time a member of the race as magistrate the Mayor brings to mind the thought that some predecessor should have recognized this fact long ago.
DELHI, India, Aug. 15 (by Mail). -- Mahatma Gandhi has found his heaven on earth at last.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Creation at Washington of a national operatic institution for the development and advancement of the art of music and for Americans is the objective of a movement started today by the Grand Opera Artists Association, which is a branch of the Associated Actors and Artists of America, with headquarters at 125 West Forty-fifth Street, New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- The petition of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company of New York to intervene in reorganization proceedings of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad was granted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CAMBRDGE, Mass., Sept. 2. -Any cue liking to add, subtract and multiply easy numbers can take pencil and "sit in" today with the world's foremost mathematicians as they near the solution of a 250-year-old problem announced at the Harvard tercentenary.

Inspired by the State Department's wish to prevent the shipment of arms to Spain, the Department of Justice has begun an inquiry into charges that four steamship companies failed to comply with regulations designed to preserve the neutrality of the United States, it was revealed yesterday.

GOTHENBURG, Sweden, Sept. 2 (AP). -- America's touring track and field athletes, appearing fatigued from their post-Olympic travels, won only three and tied one of the eight events on the final card of the two-day meet which saw three new Swedish records established today.

The Seven Arts Feature syndicate, which serves fifty-nine English-Jewish weeklies throughout the country, made public yesterday Jewish New Year's greetings from President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.

TRENTON, Sept. 2. -- Police investigation of a boy's complaint that he had been "hypnotized" by a lifeguard at a city bathing beach resulted today in an official order prohibiting the use of any practices to render persons unconscious during rescues.

Theodore Dreiser, the author, declared in a statement yesterday that he does not believe we have a Socialist government in the United States, which he was quoted as having said in an interview printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday. Mr. Dreiser asserted that "to say such a thing is obviously ridiculous.''

Cable advices on the total amount of burlap stocks in Calcutta at the end of August were confusing to the local trade here yesterday. One report put the figure for hessians at 65,700,000 yards, a decline of 2,300,000 yards from the total at the end of July and a sharp drop from the 104,483,000 yards at the close of August, 1935.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange remained cheerful today, although prices in some groups turned irregular on profit-taking. British Government issues continued their advance of the last few days. Industrial shares became more quiet, but aircraft, building and electrical equipment stocks continued in demand.

With the weekly weather summary disclosing unfavorable progress in some of the most important producing sections of the Cotton Belt and no moisture to relieve the drought in Oklahoma and Northern Texas, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced 16 to 18 points yesterday.

The Gold Dust Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a consolidated net profit of $1,510,467. After dividends had been paid on the preferred stock, the earnings were equal to 71 cents a share on the voting trust certificates for the common stock.

One of THE TIMES financial correspondents in Berlin remarked on the irony of Russo-German relations. "Germany, although terrified by thoughts of Russian aggression, imperturbably continues to supply to them the machines indispensable in the manufacture of armaments."
