WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- Dr. John A. Lapp, Director of Labor Relations of the PWA, has agreed to serve as virtual "czar" to settle jurisdictional disputes among the nineteen unions in the building industry affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

Ella Winter (Mrs. Lincoln Steffens) is collecting the letters of her late husband with a view to publication. She particularly wants to obtain letters written to students and others who were not intimate friends. She promises that all letters sent to her at Box 855, Carmel, Calif., will be handled with great care and promptly returned.

The monthly index number of commodity prices, published by Dun's Review, indicates an average advance during August of less than one-tenth of 1 per cent, as against an average rise of 2 per cent in July and of 3 1/2 per cent in June.
ON THE SPANISH NORTHERN FRONT, via Hendaye, France, Sept. 2. -- Fort San Marcial has fallen to the Rebels and Irun is as good as lost to the Loyalists.

A "surprising" increase in the number of foreign-born and Negro residents of New York in recent years is reported by the Mayor's Committee on City Planning, on the basis of census report studies made by its staff of WPA workers.

Yale University forced Harvard's seventy-two world savants off the front page by selling the broadcasting rights for six football games in the Bowl to an oil company for the sum of $20,000. How this affects commercialism and professionalism versus amateur sport only a rash man will venture to say offhand.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Sept. 3 (AP). -- Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, youngest member of America's Curtis Cup golf team, stroked her way into the final of the Mason-Dixon women's tournament today and tomorrow will oppose Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, N.Y., for the championship.

Mrs. Katherine Elkins Hitt, wife of William F. Hitt of Washington, D.C., and daughter of the late United States Senator Stephen B. Elkins of West Virginia, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. The funeral will be held at 3:30 P.M. tomorrow from 1,501 New Hampshire Avenue, Washington.

I am beginning to have a profound dislike for this vast pile of whited sepulchres called Manhattan. I have been here only two and a half months and I have already lost five letters in the mail. Your city may be very impressive and your mile-the-minute subways are dashing indeed.

ROME, Sept. 3.--The Italian Government announced today that orders had been issued to increase the number of Italian warships in Spanish waters when the government was informed that an Italian artisan, Umberto Fasanelli, the father of seven children, had been "atrociously killed" in Barcelona yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 3.--The German Government, it was announced today, fundamentally is not opposed to the British plan for the formation of an international committee to supervise execution of the non-intervention agreement.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3. -- More than fifty military airplanes of the latest types and some 100 of the cream of American and foreign racing and acrobatic pilots, were poised here and at near-by fields today, ready for the opening of the annual National Air Races at the Municipal Airport tomorrow.

It was an ingenious device of the New York Republican Club to use the Park Row statue of BENJAMIN FRANKLIN for purposes of propaganda. The final treaty of peace between the United States and Great Britain was signed on Sept. 3, 1783. The Republicans used the anniversary yesterday, not to commemorate the peace or Mr. Commissioner FRANKLIN but to advertise the Republican party as a follower of Poor Richard's precepts of thrift.

BERLIN, Sept. 3. -- The fourth Reich Congress of Germans Abroad, attended by 5,000 representatives of National Socialist organizations from all parts of the world, opened at Erlangen today with pledges of devotion to Adolf Hitler and of commemoration of National Socialist martyrs abroad.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, returned yesterday from a brief trip to England, prepared to carry out the program of the Committee on Industrial Organization despite the action of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor in suspending the committee's member unions.

More than a dozen occupants of a twelve-story loft building at 625 Broadway and seven firemen were treated for varying degrees of gas poisoning early last night after a drum containing a chemical solution ignited on the seventh floor of the structure.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 3. -- Reverence for the classics has become "something of a nuisance" in our outlook toward music, the Harvard Tercentenary Conference on Arts and Sciences was told here tonight by Professor Edward J. Dent of the University of Cambridge in a lecture on "The Historical Approach to Music."

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 3. -- An unerring putter that fairly sizzled on the lightning-fast greens of her home links today enabled Mrs. Russell Holman successfully to defend her title in the annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association match play tournament at the Innis Arden Golf Club.

ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- Henry S. Manley, who has resigned as coun sel for the division of milk control, effective Sept. 15, is to speak over the radio tomorrow night at 7:30 o'clock on "Farewell to Milk Control." He is expected to tell his reasons for quitting the work with which he has been associated since it was established.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 3. -- In sight of battle-scarred Gallipoli early this morning the Turkish destroyers Adapepe and Kojapepe met the yacht of King Edward VIII of Britain off Imbros. At 8 A.M. General Fahrettin Altay went aboard bearing a message of welcome to Turkey to the King from Kemal Ataturk, the Turkish dictator.

The Central Presbyterian Church, Jefferson and Marcy Avenues, Brooklyn, the largest church of its denomination in the East, was destroyed by fire last night. After firemen, who responded to five alarms, had surveyed the ruins, the damage was estimated at more than $400,000.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 3 (AP). -- Vagabond king, from the Adolph Wilson stables of Dayton, trotted to victory over a heavy track today in the Governor's Cup stake, featured event of the day's Grand Circuit program.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3. -- The Giants are riding home tonight four games ahead of the Cardinals and five in front of the Cubs, in the National League's pennant race, because this afternoon at Sportsman's Park, before a gathering of 23,000 fans, the Terrymen downed Frankie Frisch's clan in a dramatic ninth-inning surge to victory by as tense an exhibition of baseball as has been seen in many a day.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday were the highest in eight weeks. The total, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for twenty-two leading cities in the United States, was $5,842,270,000, a rise of 37.1 per cent from the $4,261,026,000 a year earlier, which week included the Labor Day holiday.

Our schools are about to resume. The reluctance with which most children are returning is judgment sufficient to warrant the question, Why? "We have nothing to do. It's just words and words. The same old things, the same old dirty books, no time to think, no time to play."

DETROIT, Sept. 3. -- Before nearly 4,000 distributors of and dealers in Packard automobiles, Alvan Macauley, president of the Packard Motor Company, and M.M. Gilman, vice president and general manager, stated today that production of Packard cars in the next year would far exceed that of any year in the history of the company.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3. -- Members of the international team of the Oxford Group will arrive tomorrow. A meeting will be held at the Casino Theatre on Sunday afternoon, to be followed by a supper on the Casino clubhouse piazza.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Amelia Earhart plans a flight around the world in a new Lockheed-Electra plane, flying nearer to the Equator than any pilots before her, Colonel J.M. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of the Department of Commerce, revealed here today while commenting upon the value of the Richman-Merrill transatlantic flight.

With most commodities working lower for the second week in succession, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices dropped to 126.4 on Tuesday compared with 127.3 the week before and 126.2 on Sept. 3, 1935. Farm and food products declined most, while prices for the metal and miscellaneous groups improved somewhat.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (AP). -- A new draft of an old-age pension bill, with $200 a month the minimum pension, was promised today by Dr. Francis E. Townsend at the next session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Citing troubled foreign conditions which possibly may disturb the American money market, Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the Treasury would borrow $400,000,000 in cash Sept. 15 in addition to refunding about $514,000,000 in 1 1/2 per cent notes maturing on that date.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Three policemen narrowly escaped death today when an 80-year-old man almost succeeded in an attempt to explode a home-made bomb in his shack among the scrub oaks near Jericho Turnpike in Middle Island, near here.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Sept. 3. -- With reports in circulation here that all WPA projects in Burlington County will be closed because of the workers' strike for a pay rise from 45 to 50 cents an hour, Frank S. Absalom, deputy director in charge of this district, warned county authorities that workers would be withdrawn from projects where they were not protected from interference.

The attempts of the municipal government to gain the terminal for trans-atlantic airplane flights is an extremely important matter for it concerns the ability of New York to remain a great metropolis during the next twenty years when air travel will be as common as steamship travel is now.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 3. -- Declaring that "unjust criticism directed at the American Legion because of the bonus issue had now disappeared," Edward N. Scheiberling, commander of the department of New York State, opened the seventeenth convention today by demanding Congressional action leading toward the proper care of Gold Star Mothers.
PARIS, Sept. 3 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

THE executors of the late Lord Haig, who invited me to write this book, have placed at my disposal all the relevant documents in their possession." Thus does Duff Cooper begin his "Haig" (Doubleday, Doran. $4), a biography of the man who led the British armies in France from 1915 to the Armistice. Thus, also, it may be added, does he acknowledge a fundamental weakness in his work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Developments today in the conflict between the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization indicated that neither side had any plan under which a definite split would be averted on Saturday, when the thirty-day period for the C.I.O. to dissolve expires.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 (AP). -- The Reds ran their winning streak to seven games today with a double victory over the Bees, 3 -- 0 and 6 -- 4.

New York City greeted 121 returning members of the American Olympic team yesterday as the athletes, headed by the invincible Jesse Owens, rode in open automobiles through streets lined with thousands of sightseers from the Battery to Randalls Island.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 3. -- The poorest actor at the post proved the best runner in the race when the Mulvihill Brothers' Mountainy Man won the Bridgeport at a mile and one-sixteenth for 3-year-olds and upward at Narragansett Park today.

Taking his turn in the procession of the favored array through the opening round of the national championship, Frederick J. Perry of Great Britain made his return yesterday to the stadium turf whereon he came a bad cropper and yielded up his American crown a year ago at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Naval revision upward is now the fashion. Great Britain, the United States, and now Japan have announced that they are going to utilize the so-called escalator clause of the 1930 naval treaty to retain tens of thousands of tons of destroyers or submarines which they otherwise, under the terms of that treaty, would have had to scrap by Dec. 31 of this year.

An increase of almost $8,000,000 in the city's general fund revenues in 1937 and a reduction of more than $5,000,000 in debt service charges for the coming year were predicted yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor in a report to the Board of Estimate.

In a suit by Jeanette Gootzeit, 16 years old, of 1,268 Noble Avenue, the Bronx, against Dr. Henry Hein, principal of the James Monroe High School, the Board of Education and the Board of Superintendents to compel them to give her the diploma alleged to have been illegally withheld at her graduation, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler decided yesterday that a jury must pass on the case.

The campaign headquarters for Saul S. Streit, organization designee for judge of General Sessions, announced yesterday that pledges of support of Mr. Streit have been received from Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Tammany leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District. James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany and president of Mr. Mahoney's district club, is campaigning for Jonah J. Goldstein, Mr. Streit's primary opponent.

ALBANY, Sept. 3. -- District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan opened his defense to the charge that he failed to prosecute bribery reports in the Drukman case by an indignant attack today on Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 3 (AP). -- Former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri declared in an address here tonight that "no one has the right to say President Roosevelt is a Democrat."

Under the influence of gold imports and further disbursements by the Treasury of funds previously accumulated, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $70,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $1,960,000,000, according to the weekly Federal Reserve reports, published yesterday.

Samuel Laufbahn's interpretation of the process of WPA work relief as "a boondoggler gets from the government $10 for being alive," suggests a tactless ridicule of the plight of the unfortunate, and is an icy blast in the face of the millions of unemployed victims of the depression, whose only offense is "being alive" and selfishly requiring food and shelter.

LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 3 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, campaigning as Republican Vice Presidential nominee, declared here tonight that "it is monstrous to talk about security when banks are swollen to the explosion point with government bonds."

Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., in a letter yesterday to the traffic committee of the magistrates' court, called for a meeting Sept. 11 to consider "the practicability of establishing uniform fines for first, second and subsequent offenders in traffic cases."

A seasonal lull has developed in the wool-goods markets, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Most of the men's wear lines for Spring are being shown. but it is unlikely that much buying will develop until after the holiday.

MADRID, Sept. 3 (AP). -- "Sensational revelations" concerning foreign aid to the Spanish Rebels were promised at an early date by the Madrid government tonight. The government said documents found on the body of an Italian aviator killed in a battle revealed that foreign aviators in the employ of the Rebels were bombarding defenseless towns.

The suggestion is made that the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad be acquired by the city to form part of a new trunk subway line that should be extended to downtown. It seems to me that it would be well to consider this in connection with the plans, which I believe have long been on file in the office of the Transit Commission, for the Boston Road-Second Avenue subway.

Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church approved yesterday the report of Murray H. Klinger, appointed referee in the suit brought by the Marine Midland Trust Company, trustee for the 1929 issue of $50,000,000 of Kreuger Toll debentures, for the sale of the collateral on the ground of default in the payment interest on the foreign government bonds that constituted security for the issue.

With two plays about military schools on the near horizon, George Abbott has stepped into the market and acquired another. "Brother -- Rat" is the title, whatever you think of it, and the authors are John Monks Jr. and Fred Finklehoffe -- both one-time students at Virginia Military Institute.
BERLIN, Sept. 3. -- Trading on the Boerse today was very quiet and prices were rather weak. The turnover was merely nominal and the general situation invited profit-taking.

Tony Canzoneri scaled 135 pounds and Lou Ambers 134 1/4 for their lightweight championship bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Arthur Donovan was the referee and the judges were Charley Lynch and George Kelley.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $465,157,689 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on Sept. 1 was $40.56, compared with $40.30 at the beginning of August.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 3. -- The residence here of Bishop Ernest M. Stires of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, now touring Europe with his family, was robbed early today of clothing and rugs of undetermined value.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- One of the best catches, and certainly the most spectacular, by a player who makes a commonplace of such things, today saved a game for Van Lingle Mungo and enabled the Dodgers to win a thriller from the Cubs in ten innings, 1 -- 0.
Lou Ambers's rise to the lightweight championship was a four-year climb. The Herkimer Hurricane started his professional boxing career in 1932 in his native city.
A good demand for dwellings and flats on the West Side was indicated by sales and leases yesterday. The activity included deals involving houses in Harlem.

BAYSHORE, L.I., Sept. 3. -- For the second season in succession sailors from the Vineyard Haven Yacht Club won the national junior yachting championship and the Sears Cup today as the eleven-race series was concluded off Bayshore.
The United Carbon Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on its stock, lifting the annual rate to $3, from the $2.40 paid previously.
The proportion of the nation's income derived from government sources more than doubled between 1929 and 1934, according to a study made public last night by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Settlement of the painters' strike, now in its second week, appeared near last night when negotiations were resumed between representatives of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, District Council 9, and the Master Painters Association.

Knickerbocker Village, model housing community on the lower East Side, was startled at 9:20 A.M. yesterday by a blast, followed by a rumbling roar. It was eventually traced to a gas explosion at B-Building, 40 Monroe Street.

Although they did not reach their announced destination before landing, the flight of Dick Merrill and Harry Richman was hailed here as a record. It was compared with Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's 33_/-hour flight to Paris and Clarence D. Chamberlin's 42-hour flight to Eisleben, Germany.
ROME, Sept. 3. -- The 10,000-ton cruiser Pola sailed tonight from Gaeta for Barcelona "to give added protection to Italians there." The Pola is one of Italy's finest war vessels.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- The Union party, which entered the Presidential campaign less than five months before the election, appeared today to be in a position to put its candidates' names on the printed ballots of forty States.

The continued advance of United States Government bonds yesterday lifted seventeen issues to new high prices on a turnover twice that of the day before -- $1,856,600, against $912,300, on Wednesday. Of the volume, however, one block of $1,000,000 Treasury 2 3/4s of 1954, callable in 1951, changed hands at 102 5-32, up 1-16 point.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 2, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,472,000,000, unchanged from the preceding week and $6,000,000 below the corresponding week in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Sharp disagreements over the role of government in the development and integration of large power systems, with particular reference to the Tennessee Valley Authority and other projects started under the Roosevelt administration, were forecast today for the sessions of the Third World Power Conference and Second Congress on Large Dams, meeting concurrently here next week.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Miss Maud Overall and her brother, John H. Overall Jr., gave a dinner with dancing tonight at the Peconic Club for their sister, Miss Amelia Overall, and the letter's fiance, Samuel C. Davis Jr. of St. Louis, who is visiting them and their parents, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Overall, at La Revo, their Summer place.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- United Spanish War Veterans, their woman's auxiliary and allied organizations closed their national encampment here today after electing officers. Most of them were en route home to the four corners of the county tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 3. -- Swiftly following a conference of Ministers in Downing Street early today, the army manoeuvres due to commence in Sussex tomorrow forenoon were called off and the First Division, comprising twelve infantry battalions with artillery, totaling approximately 15,000 men, received orders to prepare to proceed to Palestine.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 3. -- Six thousand delegates overflowed the Palais du Cinquantenaire here tonight for the opening of the first unofficial World Peace Conference.

MADRID, Sept. 3 (AP). -- The Ministry of War announced that government troops marched into the Rebel stronghold of Huesca tonight. The town, thirty-six miles northeast of Saragossa, had been in the hands of the Rebels since the early days of the civil war.
Vice President John N. Garner will make his first major campaign appearance in New York City on or about Sept. 16, it was announced yesterday by James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman.

Despite record-breaking sales to their retail accounts, dry goods jobbers continued cagey this week in placing orders. They came through with some small repeat business and were forced to pay higher prices, a development not particularly to their liking.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 3 (AP). -- Evidence that both thinking and feeling begin before birth was offered today to members of the American Psychological Association by two University of Rochester scientists.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 3. -- A sparkling 33 -- 34 for a 67 by Mark Stuart, former metropolitan amateur champion, and W. Stanton Barbour, Forsgate pair, gave them medal honors in the qualifying round of the annual John D. Chapman memorial invitation best-ball golf tournament today at the Greenwich Country Club.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen arrives today from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg, bringing among her 2,117 passengers about 100 Germans and Hungarians who will attend the World Power Conference in Washington, beginning Monday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 3. -- In a decision filed today, Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff sustained the writs of habeas corpus obtained in the Supreme Court in July by Philip Kohut, Chief of the Long Beach City Police Department; Captain Thomas McGowan and Sergeant Thomas Moore of the same department.
Apartment rentals, which recently have been about equally divided between the East and West Sides, yesterday showed a greater volume on the West Side, as follows:

KENT'S ISLAND, Bay of Fundy, Sept. 1, via Brunswick, Me., Sept. 3. -- Severe storms and fog have been seriously impeding the operations of the Bowdoin College Scientific Expedition. A gale destroyed the party's wind generator, which was used for a source of electric power, and damaged meteorological equipment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP). -- Contending that 350 new ships are needed to put the American Merchant Marine on even terms with foreign vessels, officials of the Shipping Board Bureau reported today that they were making tentative plans for a large construction program.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 3. -- Marksmen are finding the shooting more difficult as the national matches progress, and it is requiring the keenest ability to get in the medal class this year. Never before has the list of contenders been as large and records are being broken daily in the various events.
The beginnings of what is expected to be a record flow of traffic to and from New York for a Labor Day week-end became apparent yesterday in the transportation terminals serving the city.

With the prospect of good weather from coast to coast, the first of seven racing teams entered in the Bendix Transcontinental Derby from New York to Los Angeles took off from Floyd Bennett Field at 1:37 1/2 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The smallest prospective world supply of United States cotton since 1929, with consequent sharp improvement in the price of cotton in the United States, was reported today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the Department of Agriculture.

Advertising volume continued to register substantial gains in August, according to comment here yesterday. In many cases the total did not dip as much seasonally as in other years and the increase over 1935 were marked for all types of media.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 4. -- Japan's demands in connection with the murders of Japanese in Chengtu, West China, now exist in a draft prepared by bureau chiefs of the Foreign, Navy and War Offices. They will be discussed in the Cabinet today.

WITH THE REBEL ARMY, Burgos, Spain, Sept. 3 (AP). -- The Rebel junta here declared tonight that the insurgents had conquered four-fifths of Spain. The claim was based on scattered reports from Rebel columns of victories, advances into government-held territory and consolidations of forces.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 3. -- The New York football Giants made their first appearance of the season tonight and if their performance was a sample of their potentialities, then the eastern division champions appear on the eve of another brilliant campaign.

Budget Director Leo J. McDermott heard yesterday the petition of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity for a 1937 allowance of $18,397,165, an increase of $1,602,090 over the 1936 appropriation.

Its driver slumped over the steering wheel, the victim of a fatal attack of heart disease, a passenger automobile sidewiped a taxicab in Eighth Avenue between Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth Streets at 7 o'clock last night, darted across the street through heavy Columbus Circle motor traffic, jumped the curb at Fifty-eighth Street and plunged through a stream of pedestrians.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Employed consumers can still buy more food with their present earnings than they could in 1928 or 1929, despite the droughts of 1934 and 1936, it was reported today by L.H. Bean, economic adviser to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Mrs. Edith Lustig, 45 years old, estranged wife of Henry G. Lustig, president of Longchamps, Inc., a restaurant chain, and of several other important companies, committed suicide by inhaling gas in her apartment at 180 East Seventy-ninth Street, at 3:50 P.M. yesterday, according to a medical examiner's report.

DES MOINES, Sept. 3. -- President Roosevelt and Governor Landon met, shook hands, and smiled at each other today as a prelude to a "non-political" discussion of drought relief which brought them together here in a friendly conference with the Governors of half a dozen other States.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Arrangements were completed today for the use of the Pan-America Airways seaplane terminal here as a base in this country for transatlantic survey flights by the Lufthansa company of Germany.

DES MOINES, Sept. 3. -- Creation of more small water-storage ponds as an immediate remedy for drought conditions, and, through cooperation of Federal and State governments development of the watersheds of the Arkansas and Kansas Rivers by the erection of dams to make large storage reservoirs were recommended today by Governor Landon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company asked today the United States District Court to enjoin Guy T. Helvering, Internal Revenue Commissioner, from collecting the excise tax levied on it under the Railroad Retirement Act.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 3 (AP). -- Frank Spreckels of San Francisco was declared winner tonight of the grand prize of the Ruth Chatterton Cross Country Air Derby, which ended here today.

Engineering awards in the United States last month made a total higher than that for any month since last January, The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday. The August aggregate was $192,317,000, an average of $48,079,000 a week, compared to a weekly average of $44,008,000 this year.

The Treasury's announcement that, in addition to refunding the $514,000,000 of notes due on Sept. 15, it would seek $400,000,000 of new money came yesterday as a surprise to many in Wall Street, who had expected that the forthcoming financing would be limited to refunding.

Another parley of Republican leaders came to an end late yesterday at the State headquarters in the Liggett Building without bringing within sight the harmony sought by the party in the nomination of a candidate for Governor.

BOSTON, Sept. 3. -- The mills of the defunct Amoskeag Manufacturing Company of Manchester, N.H., one of the largest cotton-textile plants in the world, were bought today for $5,000,000 by a group of residents of that place who are determined to keep their city a leading industrial community.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 3. -- David Lloyd George arrived here this morning for a week's visit to Germany, which will include interviews with Chancellor Adolf Hitler and other National Socialist leaders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- Hog prices today were strong to 15 cents higher with a good proportion of the supply being taken at 10 to 15 cents up. The top was $11.60, while the day's average rose 10 cents to $10.30, the best in ten days. Light receipts and cooler weather were factors in the strength.

LONDON, Sept. 3. -- The British Government was informed today that Russia would accept membership in the international coordinating committee of Ambassadors and Ministers to supervise enforcement of the agreement for non-intervention in the Spanish civil war. Similar acceptances have been received from Hungary and Finland.

MOSCOW, Sept. 3. -- Reports in the German press of hunger riots in various parts of the Soviet Union were countered today by Soviet official reports of unusually good food conditions in those very places.

GENEVA, Sept. 3. -- Russian Communist youth entered the World Youth Congress here today calling for recognition of equality among all peoples as a basis for peace. This was stressed in a speech to the congress by A.V. Kossariev, head of the Soviet delegation of eight young men and two girls, who arrived today.

Yesterday's share market followed the usual pattern of pre-holiday trading in that it was quiet and irregular. As a rule, the best prices of the day were established in the forenoon, some fifty-four issues touching new high marks for the year, but prices eased under light selling as the day progressed and the closing was irregular.

A plan for consolidating the Outboard Motors Corporation of Milwaukee and the Johnson Motor Company of Waukegan, Ill., as the Outboard Marine and Manufacturing Company, has been proposed to stockholders, it was announced yesterday.

Hundreds of passengers returning to this port yesterday were delayed in reaching their homes or railroad terminals by the lack of available customs inspectors to examine and clear their baggage at the piers.

Beginning tomorrow morning, New York housewives will have to pay 1 cent a quart more for milk, announcements yesterday by the two major distributing companies said. Grade B milk will be 14 cents a quart and grade A milk 17 cents. Store prices for the same grades will be 13 and 16 cents, respectively.

No restraint of any kind has been imposed by the Vatican on the political utterances of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, "radio priest" of Royal Oak, Mich., it was emphatically declared yesterday by Bishop Michael J. Gallagher of Detroit, who returned on the Italian liner Rex from a visit to the Holy See.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3. -- Business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week reached a new high level in the recovery period, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's index of business in which allowance has been made for seasonal changes and for trend stood at 98.2 last week, or less than 2 points below normal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade were on the upgrade today. General buying of corn on prospects that the private estimates of that crop would make a bullish showing lifted prices as much as 2 cents a bushel above yesterday's final level before the upturn was checked.

Gold imports aggregating $8,710,400 were received here yesterday, according to the daily report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the total $3,537,900 came from France, $3,057,600 from Canada, $1,582,800 from India and $532,100 from England.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, the defending champion, recorded his sixth and seventh victories in the State title tournament today and took sole possession of first place.

Riding with the complete confidence felt only by a jockey when he has a champion under him, Harry Richards yesterday won at Aqueduct with J.H. Louchheim's Pompoon, the uncrowned king of the 2-year-olds. When he was behind, Richards just sat still and let his mount wear down those ahead of him.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 3 (AP). -- It took the Newark Bears twelve innings to score a run against Syracuse tonight, but once they got started there was no stopping them, and they won a double-header, while the Chiefs went nineteen innings without a score.

Lieut. Commander Walter L. Steiner, Protestant chaplain of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, died last night a few minutes after he had been taken ill while attending a performance in the Roxy Theatre at Fiftieth Street and Seventh Avenue.

Bernard W. Lynch has been elected president of the Standard Gas and Electric Company to succeed the late John J. O'Brien. This announcement was made yesterday by the company after the election had been confirmed by the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., where Standard Gas is undergoing reorganization in accordance with provisions of Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The Gulf States Utilities Company of Beaumont, Texas, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $17,300,000 of first mortgage and refunding bonds, Series C, 4 per cent, due on Oct. 1, 1966, and $4,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures, due on Oct. 1, 1946, proceeds from which will be applied to refunding.

Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas, Republican nominee for President, has better than a two-to-one lead over his Democratic opponent, President Roosevelt, in the first tabulated returns from the Literary Digest's 10,000,000 ballot public sentiment test poll on Presidential candidates, made available for publication yesterday, after being broadcast over the radio on Wednesday evening.
BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 3. -- Barcelona has changed greatly in the week since I came here. Instead of streets being darkened and deserted after 10 P.M., they now are thronged until midnight.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City:

Lou Ambers punched his way to the world's lightweight championship last night. The ebullient little hurricane from Herkimer won the decision over Tony Canzoneri, the scarred veteran campaigner from Brooklyn, in a viciously waged, though not tremendously exciting, battle of fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden.
Valuo of Dollar in ]Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

PARIS, Sept. 3. -- The Spanish Embassy here informed European governments pledged to neutrality today that it had received a report that twenty-four Italian airplanes arrived today at Vigo, Spain. Officials said the notification was sent to all governments that have accepted the French plan for non-intervention in Spain.

A jury of twelve business and civic representatives will listen to the toots of two taxicab horns today in an effort to determine a standard of noise to be approved for shooing pedestrians from the paths of automobiles.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 3. -- Orville White, youthful Overland (Mo.) professional, fired a five-under par 68 today to lead a field of 152 golfing sharpshooters in the opening round of the fourth annual 72-hole $5,000 Hershey open tournament.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- In the presence of a small company of horse show enthusiasts that remained to the very end of the final session of the seventeenth annual Rhinebeck-Dutchess County Fair Horse Show, Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, gave the President's Trophy for best in show to the chestnut gelding Kilkare Chief, owned by Mrs. Samuel Schiffer of Elberon, N.J., and shown by Arnold Funger.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 3. -- Minister of Justice Trygve Lie, acting on behalf of the absent Foreign Minister, Halvdan Koht, handed to Soviet Russia's Minister to Oslo, I.S. Yacubowitz, the Norwegian Government's rejection of the Soviet's demand for the extradition of Leon Trotsky.

The Pacific Coast has been the fruitful mother of radical political ideas. UPTON SINCLAIR and Dr. TOWNSEND in California have had imitators, though scarcely rivals, in Oregon and the State of Washington. From the latter a correspondent of THE TIMES reports the activities of several groups and organizations that make proposals which many would call revolutionary.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 3. -- This year's Thorn Memorial Cup honors went to the Broad Hollow team today when it took the final of this annual polo test for boys under 21 years of age from the Meadow Larks in a well-played game on Phipps Field.

LONDON, Sept. 3. -- The silver and blue monoplane Lady Peace from across the sea landed on a lonely South Wales pasture this afternoon at the end of the fastest flight ever made between New York and Britain.
CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 3. -- Once more a British Walker Cup team has come and gone -- down in defeat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- Asserting that the Department of Agriculture was responsible for lowering the wage scales of live-poultry handlers by reducing charges paid by farmers and shippers for unloading poultry, Dennis Lane, secretary-treasurer of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, threatened today a strike of poultry handlers in New York City and Jersey City terminals if the department did not rescind its order.

OTTAWA, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press.) -- Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada declined $21,574,879 during the week ended yesterday, the bank reported today. Deposits by chartered banks decreased $5,594,990.

The threat of a strike of 15,000 truck drivers, averted once by the intercession of Mayor La Guardia, became real again yesterday when it appeared that representatives of employers and employes had reached an impasse in negotiations for a new agreement.

E.P. O'Donnell's novel of the Mississippi delta country, "Green Margins." has been made the October choice of the Book-of-the-Month Club, it is announced by Houghton Mifflin. The novel was written under one of the Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship awards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted the application of the Salt Lake Stock Exchange for unlisted trading privileges for the $5 cumulative preferred stock of the Amalgamated Sugar Company, ruling that it is "substantially equivalent" to the same company's $8 preferred stock, a security admitted to unlisted trading.

If WILLIAM CHURCH OSBORN and the Hudson River Conservation Society of which he is the head succeed (as they must) in conserving the natural beauty of the Hudson, especially where the beauty is greatest, they will deserve the gratitude not only of millions now living but of other millions unborn for whom that beauty should be preserved till the end of time.

SUMMERVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- It was "no ball game" as far as the second race in the international Star Class world championship series was concerned today. The thirty-five boats sailing for the title were to have gone around a triangle twice, but there wasn't enough wind on Lake Ontario to get them around even once within the time limit.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP). -- The Browns got only two hits off Herman Fink and Randall Gumpert today, but came from behind to beat the Athletics again, 3 to 2.

The possibility of a coal scarcity after Jan. 1 has assumed sufficient importance for the coal committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents to advise members of the group to consider advantages to be obtained by contracting promptly for tonnage and start stocking programs in the near future.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 3 (AP).--Stockholders who came into Federal District Court today seeking to restrain the Utilities Power and Light Corporation from disposing of securities in an English company were informed by attorneys that $25,000,000 already had been received from the sale and that the money was on deposit in a bank in Montreal.

VALENCIA, Spain, Sept. 3 (Uncensored London Times Dispatch). -- Massacres, battles and an elastic Spanish interpretation of loyalty make it difficult to estimate the numbers fighting for and against the Spanish Government. The following calculation, however, gives an idea of the two forces as they stand at present, although events next week may reverse or modify them.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 3 (AP). -- Five passengers and Pilot Steve Mills lost their lives in the wreck of Mills's plane on the Kenai Peninsula, about sixty miles south of here, a dispatch from Seward said today.

Fred I. Kent, president of the New York University Corporation, and William M. Kingsley, treasurer, announced jointly yesterday that the university had completed a new $5,000,000 refunding operation through the refinancing of mortgages on investment and educational properties.

LONDON, Sept. 3. -- The undertone continued strong today on the London Stock Exchange, although business was quieted by the approaching end of the account. British Government stocks were steady, but demand slackened and trading became listless.

For two years the sensation mongers have been writing of the "Dust Bowl" and now Stuart Chase comes to the front in the current Harper's with a calamity howl that makes my old friend Jeremiah look like an incurable optimist.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

A story of how the sea had again frustrated an attempt to salvage the treasure entombed in the steamship Merida under thirty-two fathoms of water fifty miles off Cape Hatteras was told yesterday when the schooner Constellation came home to Jersey City.
DES MOINES, Sept. 3. -- Unusual precautions were taken to give to the drought conference the appearance of being non-political and to safeguard the President and other officials.

Governor Lehman formally accepted yesterday the notification of the American Labor party designating him as its candidate for reelection. In a letter to Luigi Antonini, State chairman of the newly formed party, the Governor expressed his gratitude for the party's action.

ON THE SPANISH NORTHERN FRONT, Hendaye, Sept. 3. -- Recovering from a check in the early hours of the morning when the government guns in Fuenterrabia shelled out the Navarrese who had occupied Fort San Marcial in their center, the insurgents attacking Irun continued the advance of their right flank along the Bidassoa River this afternoon.

The Mayor acted with his customary energy and humanity in reforming the setting and procedure in the Woman's Court. Hereafter there is to be no more "hippodroming" before this tribunal by bad actors in the legal profession. The cases are to be treated as inquiries and not as trials.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP). -- Tom Yawkey's Red Sox divided a doubleheader with the White Sox today, winning the second game, 5-0, behind the seven-hit pitching of Johnny Marcum after Wes Ferrell dropped a pitchers' battle with John Whitehead, 3 -- 2.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 3. -- The first big-scale, big-time effort to present first rate concert artists to large audiences at moving picture prices or less is to be tried in Cleveland this Winter.

Jesse Owens, world's premier sprinter, got his first glimpse of the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday, the Yanks got their first view of Bob Feller, 17-year-old pitching sensation of the Indians, and the whole thing worked out to every one's satisfaction with the possible exception of the youthful Feller.

An early improvement on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried quotations $2 a bale above recent low levels, but the market ran into an increased volume of hedges which erased virtually all of Wednesday's gains and left the list with net losses of 8 to 16 points.

The controversy between Judge Franklin Taylor of the Kings County Court and Mayor La Guardia flared up again yesterday when Judge Taylor told the Kings County grand jury that the Department of Sanitation "has become politicalized."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Charles Metzger Jr. of the Rockville Country Club got off on the right foot in the defense of his crown as play in the Long Island Golf Association's fifteenth annual junior championship tournament began today on the Hempstead Golf Club's links.

PARIS, Sept. 3. -- With unwonted unanimity the French press today frankly discusses the necessity of increasing France's military strength as an answer to Chancellor Hitler's move in raising the period of German conscript service to two years.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 3. -- New scales for weighing the giant and super-giant stars, new clinic thermometers to measure their immense temperatures and new measuring rods for determining the size of the infinitesimal particles of cosmic dust in interstellar spaces were among the advances in man's knowledge of his universe reported today before the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences by astronomers from three continents.

It is one of the privileges, if not among the blessings, of a democracy, that straw polls can be taken and published -the official quadrennial season beginning with the general newspaper release of its preliminary test today by The Literary Digest. In an autocracy the dictator would not have to forbid the poll, but only for the reason that no opposition ballots are allowed and therefore a straw poll would be futile.

The idea of commercial radio sponsorship of college football games, brought into prominence when the Atlantic Refining Company bought from Yale University the right to broadcast its six home games this season, spread to another sponsor and to other colleges yesterday.

APPLETON, Wis., Sept. 3. -- Calling for the dignifying of the individual man and woman through affirmation of religious liberty, Roger W. Straus, New York engineer and co-chairman of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, speaking tonight before the Midwest Institute of Human Relations at Lawrence College, said that "each individual must be permitted to work out for himself that most personal of all relations, man's relation to the universe."

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- The second race of the international series between the Long Island Sound Interclub sloops and the Bermuda One-Design crafts was finished at twilight tonight. Bermuda won the contest, 20 1/4 points to 16, thus tying the match at 1-all.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 3. -Long-hitting Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. and Miss Marianna Dickson, whose shots are short but straight and whose putting is remarkably accurate, combined their different types of play most effectively to win the two-ball foursome title of the Women's Long Island Golf Association over the Cherry Valley Club course today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP). -- A successful double steal gave the Senators the edge today in beating the Tigers, 3 -- 1.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP). -- The Pirates and Phillies divided a double header today, the Phillies winning the first, 4 to 3, and the Pirates the second, 5 to 1, with 5,000 fans watching the games.

Advances were almost general in moderately active trading in futures on local commodity exchanges yesterday, mainly because of evening-up before the extended holiday on most exchanges. Wool tops, rubber and silk alone were irregular in the face of the improved trend.

Labor Day week-end rings down the curtain on the fishing season for Summer vacationists at lake and shore. But this type of angler is strictly in the minority. Your inveterate fresh or salt-water enthusiast regards the impending holiday as just another week-end.

With New York assured of at least half the world series show and standing more than an even chance of grabbing all of it this Fall, might not a word be said at this time against the practice of club owners selling tickets in "blocks of three," as they call it, instead of allowing the fans to buy their reserved seats for single games.

CROWN POINT, N.M., Sept. 4 (AP). -- Ben O. Howard, 1935 Bendix Trophy winner, and his wife were seriously injured today when his plane in this year's Bendix race crashed on the bleak Navajo Reservation forty miles north of here.

NANNING, Kwangsi Province, China, Sept. 4. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has accepted Kwangsi Province's two proposals for peaceful solution of China's critical southern situation, by General Li Tsung-jen, Kwangsi leader.

PARIS, Sept. 4. -- France has accepted the Loyalist defeat at Irun with a calmness which seems to bear out the government's contention that it is strictly neutral with regard to Spain and intends to remain so. Despite the impression abroad, the French are not by any means united in their sympathies for the Madrid Government.

The greatest local advertising campaign in the history of Ipana tooth paste will break on Sept. 13 and will be carried in newspapers of every State, reaching some 18,600,000 families, for twelve consecutive weeks. The coverage in this area will be particularly heavy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Prices of hogs here today were generally steady, although the top at $11.55 was 5 cents less than yesterday. The day's average was unchanged at $10.30. Firmness in fresh pork loins helped the market, local prices being unchanged to 1/2 cent higher than yesterday at 16 to 27 1/2 cents a pound wholesale.

About 250 persons were eating lunch in the Automat Cafeteria on the southeast corner of Broadway and 104th Street at 12:30 P.M. yesterday when a man seated at a table on the mezzanine balcony fatally slashed with a razor another with whom he had been seated, then ran down the stairs and dashed for the door.

A 19-year-old California girl, playing for the first time for the title won by her mother in 1904, eliminated the second highest ranking American player in the field yesterday in the national championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Bernard A. Dombron, Leonardo Bcrcovici, in 2 Horatio St.; Theodore T. Christmas, in 59 W. 12th St.; Stuart A. Farleigh, in 302 W. 12th St.; Doris Volland, in 235 E. 73d St.; Frederick M. Kimball, in 220 E. 73d St.; 5ugene W. Russell, in 210 5. 73d St.; Dorothy C. Pelham, Mrs. Jean Stiles, in 504 W. 110th St.; Blng Bing, lessors.

More and more, in pursuing their election strategy, the political managers are concentrating efforts on what are known as "groups." Presumably, these are divisions of the "classes," of which much has been heard since the days of JEFFERSON in American politics.

BOSTON, Sept. 4. -- Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard, failed to pass a recent automobile-driving-examination, taken in accordance with the recent ruling promulgated by the State Registrar of Motor Vehicles requiring all drivers over 65 years of age to submit to yearly examination.

Asserting that long-range weather forecasting would reduce future losses resulting from abnormal weather conditions and by contributing to advance planning and production, Edward Heitman, director of the Temperature Research Foundatlon of the Kelvinator Corporation, yesterday urged the government set up such a service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The Mutual Savings Bank Group of which Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank of New York is chairman, was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in the pending proceedings in the case of the Chicago Northwestern Railway Company, in response to a petition filed by the group some weeks ago.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 4 (AP). -- The flour milling industry here was tied up completely tonight after strike picketing resulted in the closing of the plants of three concerns.

It was curious and rather amusing to note the chill which fell upon Democratic headquarters in this city with the publication of the first political poll by The Literary Digest this year. As frankly noted by that magazine itself, the first returns were too meager, and too much restricted to limited areas, to furnish any trustworthy inference respecting the final result in November.

I have a grievance with the powers that be in tennis circles. From the tennis draw which appeared in your paper on Wednesday, Sept. 2, it seems that New York City's legion of public high school players are to go unrepresented in the so-called national interscholastic championship tournament which is being staged at Forest Hills this week.

The expected Fall upturn started in a number of trade branches this week, instead of awaiting the traditional Labor Day turning point, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Cooler weather turned consumer buying away definitely from Summer goods to Fall offerings, while rains brightened the outlook in the drought areas.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 (AP). -- Asserting that freedom of the press had "its definite limits," Chief Justice William M. Maltbie of the Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors proposed tonight that newspaper men representing out-of-State publications be barred from trials in Connecticut court.

With four of the properties going to savings banks, five parcels in Manhattan and six in the Bronx were bid in at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Other properties were acquired by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, the State Mortgage Commission and the City of New York.
HENDAYE, France, Sept. 4. -- The five square miles of Irun was in flames tonight as its Rebel conquerors headed toward governmentheld San Sebastian eight miles away.
With ten named for the featured Aqueduct Handicap today, the Queens Jockey Club may see its largest stake field of the meeting go to the post for the mile and a sixteenth test.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- A veteran campaigner, the aged bay gelding Prince Charming II, owned by Edward Quinn's Claredda Farm of Shrewsbury, N.J., added another successful day to his long and brilliant competitive career today as the annual Orangeburg Fair horse show opened at the local fair grounds.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- The action of corn today dominated the grain markets on the Board of Trade, Congestion developed in September, corn soon after the opening, local offerings being absorbed by commission houses, and when shorts tried to cover their commitments they found little corn for sale and the price ran 5 5/8 cents a bushel above yesterday's finish and closed at or near the top at $1.11 to $1.11 1/2.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week consists of offerings by one State and ninety-three municipalities and totals $63,297,050, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with a total of $69,193,560 for this week and with a weekly average of $24,809,763 for 1936 to date.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 4. -- Aurora, riding in a new line-up that shifted young Skiddy von Stade from No. 1 to No. 3, and sent Ebby Gerry to No. 1, want very much better today and upset the Argentine international polo team that also was experimenting with a new line-up, 6 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Although the deadline for the automatic suspension of ten unions of the American Federation of Labor for forming a rival organization and creating a "rebellion" does not expire until tomorrow, John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, viewed the suspension of more than 1,000,000 members as an accepted fact today.

Paramount is guarding itself against a possible star raid by signing Bing Crosby for an additional two years, nine months in advance of the expiration of his current agreement. Crosby will make three films a year under the new contract.

Because Monday is Labor Day tomorrow will be observed in the churches as annual "Labor Sunday." Clergymen will preach on the problems of labor and how in their opinion they can be solved in the light of religion. In Protestant churches there will be read the whole or part of the annual "Labor Message" issued by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Amid suddenly increased tension over the Far Eastern situation, Russia tonight warned Japan that border incidents were endangering peace.

Francisco Largo Caballero, Spain's new Premier and War Minister, is a remarkably preserved man of 67 years. He has worked all his life -- he began earning his living when he was 7 -- and has been a revolutionary for more than thirty years.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP). -- The Newark Bears further increased their second-place lead over Rochester tonight when they split a twin ball with the Chiefs, winning the second game, 4 to 1, after dropping the first, 1 to 0.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 4. -- D.E. Bates, president and general manager, announced today that the Reo Motor Company would discontinue the manufacture of passenger cars and would concentrate exclusively on making commercial vehicles. The change is to be effective in ninety days.
Lieut. Col. Brehon S. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, ordered yesterday the dismissal of 500 relief workers on WPA rolls because of prolonged absence from their jobs.

BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- The Boerse continued today to fluctuate in an uncertain manner, but turned somewhat firmer near the end of the session, although the lack of business caused many issues to remain quotationless. Heavy industrial shares opened soft, but closed with gains of an average of approximately 1 point.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation announced yesterday that the directors have called a special meeting of stockholders to vote on dissolving the following subsidiaries to escape some provisions of the Revenue Act of 1936 and to effect savings in operations: the Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company, Inc.; Curtiss-Wright Airplane Company (Missouri), Curtiss-Wright Airplane Company (Delaware), Curtiss Caproni Corporation and Curtiss-Wright Airports Corporation.

Several hundred members of Actors Equity Association held the first of the season's discussion meetings yesterday afternoon at the Astor Hotel. A number of resolution -- dealing with the WPA, the A.F.of L. and Equity's internal problems -- were passed, with the recommendation that the council, the organization's governing board, be informed of the meeting's desires.

William S. Murray, Republican leader of Oneida County, said in a statement issued here yesterday that canvass of counties in the Fifth Judicial District had disclosed "virtually unanimous" sentiment for the nomination of George R. Fearon of Syracuse, Republican floor leader of the State Senate, for Governor.

The assistance of 10,000 alumni of the University of Notre Dame in the fight of the Catholic Church against communism will be offered to Pope Pius XI soon by Arthur J. Hughes, Chicago attorney and president of the Notre Dame National Alumni Association.

From the various letters appearing every Saturday in your paper concerning the managerial abilities, good or bad, of Bill Terry, it strikes me rather oddly that so little credit is accorded him from certain fans who seemingly know their baseball. Their hasty desire to reduce Bill to the ranks of ordinary managers is beyond me unless it can be some petty personal dislike.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 4 (AP). -- Dr. Clark L. Hull of Yale University, president of the American Psychological Association, tonight urged psychologists to revolutionize their reasoning in an effort to bridge the chasm of scientific thought between tiny electrons and the intellect of man.

BOSTON. Sept. 4. -- For three innings on this almost chilly early Autumn afternoon a Ladies' Day gathering of 15,000 Hub loyalists seemed fully under the impression that Boston's day, long deferred, had finally arrived.

In preparation for the National Preaching Mission, which will begin Sept. 13 in Albany and end in this city Dec. 6-9, the missioners will hold a conference and retreat Tuesday and Wednesday at Beaver College, Jenkintown, Pa. The mission will be under the auspices of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, with headquarters at 105 East Twenty-second Street, this city.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):
In all the pow-wow about boondoggling in the PWA I have been searching for one key-word and today I found it in your editorial regarding WPA achievements. The word is "usefulness."
Having just returned from the Olympics at Berlin, I would like to state my humble opinion of what I witnessed. I was fortunate in also witnessing the two previous Olympics.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4. -- Miss Lucy Saunders, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Truman Laurance Saunders, and Miss LeBrun Cruger Rhinelander, daughter of Mrs. LeBrun Rhinelander, were honor guests at a dance given tonight by Frazier Jelke at his home, Eagle's Nest.
PITTSBURGH. Sept. 4 (AP). -- The third place Cubs picked up half a game on the National League pacesetters today by trouncing the Pirates, 8 -- 0, behind Larry French's seven-hit pitching.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Quoddy Village, near Eastport, Me., where the New Deal had planned to harness tidal waters for the creation of a great power system comparable in its capacity to the Tennessee. Valley Authority, was designated by the War Department today as a National Youth Administration training school for the time being.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 4. -- A positive statement that the credit of the United States was on "a sounder basis than ever before in its history" was made by President Roosevelt today as he approached the end of his tour of the drought areas in the West.

Proverbially, like the flowers that bloom in the Spring, Labor Day marks the beginning of a new season on Broadway and the end of another. Although the Fall session was rushed a bit this year by the French Casino, which offered its new "Folies d'Amour" last week, the season will really get under way in the night club field of entertainment between now and Oct. 1.
TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The northeast tower of Toledo's ancient Alcazar crashed today in flames and dust under direct fire of Socialist government artillery.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 4. -- That women have been figuring in some of the National Rifle Association events is evident by today's results. When Miss Janet Lewis, 18, of St. Albans, L.I., scored 399 out of a possible 400 in the United States Cartridge Trophy small-bore match she piled up a new record for the woman's division and landed a gold medal.

Within a few days the committee that is conducting an inquiry into investment trusts under the jurisdiction of the SEC will resume public hearings in Washington. There has been considerable discussion in Wall Street as to the direction which the investigation will take.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary carried 20,654 passengers in her first three months of operation in the transatlantic service, it was announced yesterday. A statement by the line, which is a member of the Atlantic Passenger Conference and thus has access to the figures of all transatlantic carriers, said this exceeded the total of any other ship during the period "to the best of our knowledge."

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Joe Jacobson, 31, contestant in the Bendix air race, narrowly escaped death today when his Northrup Gamma plane exploded near Stafford, Kan., throwing him clear. He landed by parachute and was not hurt.

A popular villain of the day is the middleman in the food industries. He interposes between the farmer and the consumer and charges an unconscionable percentage for his unsolicited and unnecessary services. That, roughly, is the usual statement of the case. People want to know why a steak for which the Texas cattleman gets 10 cents costs $2.50 on a New York hotel table.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Sept. 5. -- Within a week or ten days the curtain will be rising upon another act in the tragic drama of Chino-Japanese relations, for it is learned that Japan intends to insist on acceptance of harsh terms in connection with the murders of two Japanese in Chengtu, West China, and is ready to back her insistence with a show of force.

Joseph Speiser, 46 years old, a member of the law firm of Speiser Speiser at 29 Broadway and described by Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney at the head of the new Accident Fraud Bureau, as "having the largest negligence practice in the United States," was arrested at 5 P.M. yesterday on an ambulance-chasing charge.

Eight more trucks, each loaded with ten tons of coal alleged to have been stolen from anthracite mines in Pennsylvania, were seized yesterday by detectives from the safe, and loft squad as they emerged from the Holland Tunnel and ferries along the lower North River.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4. -- Thirty-four craft, the largest fleet in the six years' history of the event, set sail this evening in the 230-mile race to Vineyard Sound and return, conducted by the Stamford Yacht Club.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 4. -- Settling down to the actual business of coordinating and centralizing peace efforts in thirty-two countries, the World Peace Conference today divided into twenty committees, which formulated a score of suggestions that will be presented to the Assembly of the League of Nations.

Labor Day holiday travel reached its peak at the close of the business day yesterday. By rail, bus, plane and boat thousands deserted New York City and the same carriers brought in about an equal number of thousands for a weekend of sightseeing.

Aided by cooler weather, retail trade in the metropolitan area scored substantial gains this week. The average of department store volume was placed at about 15 per cent greater than for the comparative period last year. The week was featured by strong consumer buying of apparel and supplies to cover school opening requirements, and also by continued good consumer response to the extended August sales offerings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- To compute soil conservation and crop diversion payments under the soil conservation program, 4,000,000 farms must be measured before the end of October and their farmers I quetioned upon their "performance'' and "method" during the past four years.

TOPEKA, Sept. 4. -- Governor Landon today took a leaf out of President Roosevelt's campaign book, and on his way back from Des Moines inspected farms, vineyards and apple orchards in Northeastern Kansas, chatted with the farmers and fruit growers, their wives and children, and followed a style of indirect campaigning which the President used successfully in his "non-political" inspection tour of the drought areas of the Northwest.

The pressure of capital in flight from the French franc increased strongly in the foreign-exchange market yesterday, driving France's currency unit down to 6.58 1/4 cents, its lowest price since Aug. 7. This brought about the engagement of $4,995,000 gold in Paris for shipment here, the largest operation of its kind in France since Aug. 8, and lifted the total of gold taken there on the current movement, which began a month ago, to $32,000,000.

MADRID, Sept. 4 (Passed by the censor) -- For the first time since the Popular Front's election victory last Feb. 16 nearly all its component elements, from the moderate Left Republicans to the extreme Marxists, Communists and Socialists, are represented in the Cabinet, formed today.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The long-awaited explanation of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan concerning his friendship with Leo P. Byk and the calling to the witness chair of Detective Charles S. Corbett, whose story of a bribe attempt reopened the Drukman inquiry, gave Governor Lehman today a nearly complete picture of the grand jury's case against the Kings County prosecutor.

Polo settles its national championship this afternoon when two teams of international handicap rating including some of the most famous players in the world come together in the final round of the open tournament. At 4 o'clock Tommy Hitchcock will lead Greentree out in defense of its title against Winston Guest and Templeton on the famous stretch of International Field at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Winning another game in the tenth and semi-final round in the late session tonight, Isaac I. Kashdan of New York increased his lead to such an extent in the annual championship tournament of the New York State Chess Association at the Nelson House that he shook himself entirely free from the rest of the field to win the State title the second time in succession.
I am surprised at the hullabaloo that is being raised about naming Harry Balsamo as a formidable contender for the world's middleweight championship.

With aggregate lettings up to Sept. 1 in excess of $577,000,000, construction in the South is ahead of any years snice 1931 and is within $40,000,000 of the $617,000,000 valuation for the entire year of 1935. Engineering and general construction contracts awarded in Southern States last month amounted to $70,965,000, with more than $122,000,000 of new work planned and proposed, according to a tabulation prepared by The Manufacturers Record.

In his column this morning Arthur Krock set forth the reasons advanced by some persons for supporting the President on the issue of economy. Perhaps he thought the reasons against doing so were too obvious to need stating.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP). -- The twelve Federal Reserve Banks this year, for the first time since 1924, may not have sufficient income to cover dividends. The Federal Reserve Board's bulletin for September disclosed that for the first six months of the year the net earnings of the banks fell short of dividend payments by $743,348.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4. -- Two veteran women pilots, Mrs. Louise Thaden of Bentonville. Ark., and Mrs. Blanche Noyes of Memphis, landed here this afternoon 14 hours 54 minutes 49 seconds out of Floyd Bennett Field, New York, to win one of the most famous events in aviation, the Bendix transcontinental derby. Between them they took first money of $4,500, plus $2,500 for a new woman's record.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 4. -- Sir Arthur Eddington presented before the Harvard Tercentenary Conference today his latest mathematical calculations of the total number of particles of which the universe is constituted. The number, reduced to relatively simple terms, is 544 multiplied by itself 256 times.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4. -- Republicans continued to hold an approximate 8-to-3 lead in registration as official and unofficial returns from yesterday's enrollment indicated that 400,000 persons qualified for the Nov. 3 Presidential election, breaking all previous one-day records.

Mayor La Guardia was formally invited yesterday to appear Wednesday morning before the Kings County grand jury, which is investigating charges made by County Judge Franklin Taylor that Brooklyn is the city's dirtiest borough.

Mayor La Guardia's adventure in transacting the business of the city from a spot in the great out-of-doors, cooled by breezes from Long Island Sound, amid terraced gardens and tinkling fountains, came to an end for the present year at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Lowell M. Clucas of New York and Bluefens, Stockbridge, introduced their daughter, Miss Frances P. Clucas, tonight at a large dance at the Lenox Club, which had been decorated with flowers from the club gardens.

CAMBRIDGE. Mass. Sept. 4 (AP). -- The appointment of Thomas D. Bolles, former freshman crew coach at the University of Washington, as head coach of crew at Harvard was announced tonight by William J. Bingham, athletic director.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Inquiry into reports the major parties in Michigan were piling up war chests which together would total $3,000,000 is under way by agents of the Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures.

FAIR Harvard opened its gates to the great gathering of scientists just in time to help out the baseball fans. This was suspected right from the start when Professor Edward Kasner of Columbia rose up at Cambridge and stated that, in certain mathematical situations, the sum of the parts exceeds the whole.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 4. -- Utilization of "organized intelligence'' on a large scale in the broad field of human, social relationship was advocated here tonight by Professor John Dewey of Columbia University as the best means for bringing about the proper balance between the authority of the State and the freedom of the individual.

The Democratic chieftains of New York City gathered in a "harmony" conference with James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, yesterday and told him that President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman would have a city plurality of at least 835,000 and probably would eclipse the Roosevelt city plurality of 871,000 in 1932.

After four hours of quiet trading yesterday in which prices showed minor irregularities, so that the market assumed all the usual pre-holiday characteristics, stocks firmed up in fairly active trading in the final hour. The closing was generally higher.

The strike of 12,000 painters in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond was settled yesterday under an agreement by which the master painters, among other things, bound themselves to hire from union rolls 25 per cent of their workers as against 50 per cent demanded by the union, which called the strike more than a week ago to enforce that demand.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- President William Green of the American Federation of Labor announced today that the Seattle Central Labor Council acted in accordance with the laws and procedure of the federation in putting The Seattle Post-Intelligencer on the "unfair list."

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- Mrs. Beryl Markham, 33-year-old sister-in-law of Sir Charles Markham, coal mine owner, and mother of a 7-year-old son, left the Abingdon military airdrome in Berkshire this evening at 6:50 o'clock Summer time (1:50 P.M., New York time), in an attempt to fly to the United States.

DETROIT, Sept. 4. -- Louis R. Glavis, chief investigator of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures, began an investigation here today of statements that a fund of $3,000,000 had been accumulated for use in the election campaign in Michigan.

Egg on one's vest-once a private catastrophe -- is a public statistic now. Big business has eyed those familiar souvenirs of mealtime mishaps and is prepared to announce, among other things, how frequently a soup spoon wobbles, how often a steak knife slips, how many times a fumbling fork squirts a jet of salad dressing smack onto a dismayed bosom.
A mixture of animals, snakes, birds and fish was listed on the manifest of the American-South African liner City of New York when the ship docked at the Bush Terminal in Brooklyn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Making the second move within six weeks to extend the merit system in the government service, President Roosevelt has ordered the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to begin at once the application of merit requirements to future personnel for itself, the Home Owners Loan Corporation and its other subsidiaries.
How can it be said, as you did in your paper of Tuesday morning, that Sixto Escobar knocked out Tony Marino in thirteen rounds?

Lou Ambers, the new lightweight champion of the world, was deliriously happy yesterday as he tried to accustom himself to his lofty estate. The 22-year-old Herkimer fighter, who captured the 135-pound title from Tony Canzoneri in a close 15-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, could speak of nothing but the rosy future as he waded through the swarm of well-wishers who besieged him all day long.
RYE, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Tide-dodging in foreign waters, the Bermuda skippers today again defeated the Interclubs in the third race of their international series.
Aug. 23 -- Cast first straw vote for President on 5:37 local express from Grand Central Terminal.

The New York State Symphonic Band, directed by Giuseppe Creatore, will give a concert tonight at 8:30 o'clock on Central Park Mall, with Elvira Heal, soprano, as soloist. At the same hour, the Manhattan Concert Band, under Anthony Giammatteo, assisted by Lily Wolmers, soprano, will offer a program in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.
HANNIBAL, Mo., Sept. 4. - Following is the text of President Roosevelt's speech here today dedicating the Mark Twain Memorial Bridge:

The Pacific Telephone and Teleigraph Company yesterday declared a dividend of $2 a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 30i to stock of record of Sept. 19. It has been paying $1.50 quarterly. N. R. Powley, president, aid the directors had been influenced by consideration of improved earnings and also the undistributed profits tax.
LONDON, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Nearly 11,000 miners barricaded themselves underground tonight as efforts to avert a threatened strike of 120,000 South Wales coal miners reached an apparent stalemate.

Life in New York City in the future should be a little less difficult on ears and nerves. Pedestrians, perhaps, will be spared the fright which now startles them out of their shoes. Taxicab drivers will forego their theory that the stroller's ear is quicker than his eye.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- For the second day in a row the boats sailing for the world's Star Class championship finished on the end of a tow line today. Not one of the thirty-five was able to complete the course within the three and a half hour time limit and the second race had to be deferred again.
