WITH THE REBEL ARMY AT IRUN, Sept. 4. -- Most of the many hostages held in Fort Guadalupe escaped unharmed. Among them were Count de la Maza, a friend of former King Alfonso, and Marquis de Recondi, a former Cabinet Minister.

ON THE SPANISH NORTHERN FRONT, via Hendaye, France, Sept. 4. -- Irun, the center of Spain's wood trade, is burning to the skies. At nightfall anarchists were still firing houses in the town and the center of the sky is red with flames.

Desperately battling against odds so formidable as to arouse the concern of experts of the British Air Ministry and other aviation authorities, Mrs. Beryl Markham, seeking to be the first woman to fly the Atlantic alone from east to west, was zooming toward Hew York last night high over the windswept ocean.

WITH cheerful countenance and great good nature, John R. Tunis has written one of the saddest books of the year. Entitled "Was College Worth While?" (Harcourt, Brace, $2), it poses that question through 230-odd pages, and concludes with a faint but unmistakable NO.

Puccini's "Madame Butterfly" was presented by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company last night at the Hippodrome Theatre before a large and demonstrative audience. The creditable performance was conducted by Fulgenzio Guerrieri, who made his season's debut on this occasion.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- From the standpoint of fishing, there are sick lakes and healthy lakes, streams that are anemic and streams that are virile. Whether or not fish thrive depends entirely on the wholesomeness of their environment.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Paul Scheerer gave a dinner tonight for their week-end guests, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Murray of Llewellyn Park, N.J.
A trail followed for many years by Federal narcotic agents came to an end yesterday when an alleged narcotics smuggler took his life as agents were preparing to take him into custody.

The Giants are back home with a four-game grip on the National League lead in their possession and the pennant urge strong upon them. Radiating the confidence that a winner inevitably shows, the Terrymen rolled into town last night, their last swing through the West behind them and before them the friendly Polo Grounds, where they will do most of their fighting in the stretch run.

The college textbooks on logic, in my day, always stressed the need for the definition of terms as indispensable requisites for clear thinking, But the concepts behind the words used change with the changing times and changing circumstances, and redefinition often becomes necessary.

Gains were the rule in fairly active trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with rubber, cocoa and silk exceptions to the general improvement. On the cash markets gains were registered in wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, lard, cotton, printcloths, wool tops and tin, while rubber and silk were easier.

Confident of their ability to cope with the strongest opposition the professional game has to offer, the College All-Stars arrived yesterday from Chicago to complete preparations for their football battle with the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds Tuesday night.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Under an agreement reached today at a conference of the State Financial Assistance Commission, headed by Governor Hoffman, and a committee representing the State League of Municipalities, local governing bodies will be required to contribute $2,225,000 toward relief instead of $4,500,000, originally fixed as their share for the period from July 1 to Dec. 31.

Four religious leaders joined yesterday in a "Labor Sunday" statement through the Good Neighbor League asserting that more progress had been made toward establishment of economic principles of organized religion during the Roosevelt administration than in the preceding thirty years.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 5. -- The gravity Japan attaches to the murders of two Japanese in Chengtu, West China, on Aug. 24 is shown by the fact that Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita today obtained the Emperor's sanction for the demands to be presented to China.

WATERVILLE, Me., Sept. 4 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, assailed [the administration's public works projects tonight, asserting that government construction enterprises "do not create new work."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- In the last three weeks in June, when bonus payments in large volume were being made to veterans, the amount of money in circulation increased by $310,000,000, and since then has shown only a moderate decline, the Federal Reserve Board, announced in its monthly bulletin today.

The Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation reported yesterday that its shipments and earnings in July were larger than in any preceding July. Its net profit was $129,620, equivalent to 17 cents a share on the 746,31 common shares outstanding.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 4. -- The conference of representatives of milk producers and distributors here seeking to prevent a threatened State-wide milk strike ended late this afternoon in a disagreement.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- In response to queries from Berlin and Lisbon concerning the scope of the proposed international coordinating committee to supervise the practical application of the neutrality agreement in the Spanish civil war, the British Government assured the German and Portuguese Governments today that the jurisdiction of the committee would be confined strictly to the matter of none-intervention.

The drawing for ballot positions in the Democratic primary fight for election to the Court of Special Sessions was held yesterday by the Board of Elections with the result that two insurgents, Thomas Jefferson Ryan and former Magistrate Benjamin E. Greenspan, won first and second positions respectively.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 4. -The suit of Eddie Cantor, comedian, against Goldman, Sachs Co., in the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, and the Central States Electric Corporation, has been settled and th sequetrator appointed by Chancellor Josiah Wolcott to sequester stocklaoldings of the defendants has been discharged.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Warning of the dangers of a general European conflict, intensified by the present civil war in Spain, John Thomas Taylor of Washington, national legislative director of the American Legion, called on legionnaires, assembled in State convention here today, to throw their influence behind a universal draft measure for ''America's own protection."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Rosalind, winner of the Hambletonian at Goshen, N.Y., this year, took all three heats of the $1,500 Deshler-Wallick Stake today, feature of the closing day of the Grand Circuit harness program here.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 4. -- Scoring two easy triumphs over their opponents, Mark Stuart and W. Stanton Barbour, Forsgate pair, led the way into the semi-finals of the John D. Chapman memorial invitation best-ball golf tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today.
Mild realty activity in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens yesterday was marked by deals involving business buildings, houses and a vacant plot for improvement with an apartment.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 4. -- Orville White, 27-year-old Overland (Mo.) professional, held a four-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the fourth annual $5,000 Hershey open tournament today as he added a sub par 71 to his previous 68 for a 139.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in August totaled $23,454,653,729, a decline of 13.7 per cent from July and 3.3 per cent from August, 1935. The total was the smallest for a month since last September.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 4 (AP). -- Rosalind, winner of the Hambletonian at Goshen, N.Y., this year, took all three heats of the $1,500 Deshler-Wallick Stake today, feature of the closing day of the Grand Circuit harness program here.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 4. -- Scoring two easy triumphs over their opponents, Mark Stuart and W. Stanton Barbour, Forsgate pair, led the way into the semi-finals of the John D. Chapman memorial invitation best-ball golf tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today.

Besides improving passenger-train equipment last year by the installation of streamlined, lightweight rolling stock, the Class I railroads progressed also in the elimination of wooden cars in service, a report issued yesterday by the Association of American Railroads disclosed.

United States Attorney Lamar Hardy asserted yesterday that he would institute criminal proceedings against the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company if it failed to comply with the Railway Labor Act. His intention was announced in an answer which he filed in Federal court to the injunction suit brought against him by the Hudson tube line.

In a single volume of 1,400 pages Leon Trotsky's "The History of the Russian Revolution," translated from the Russian by Max Eastman, will be published by Simon Schuster on Sept. 17. The work was formerly published in three volumes.

Alfred H. Schoellkopf, president of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, announced yesterday the adoption of a model housing project, specifications for which will be based on the experience and opinion of 250,000 customers of the utility system.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 4. -- A display of fireworks this evening formed the principal entertainment following the dinner of the American Astronomical Society, now meeting in conjunction with the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 4. -- The final of the Long Island Association junior golf tournament lies between Charles Metzger Jr. of the Rockville Country Club and Eddy Butler of the Hempstead Golf Club, where the quarter and semi-final rounds were run off today.

Agents of the Department of Justice trapped yesterday Raymond Miller, alleged loan shark, of 481 Wales Avenue, the Bronx, and charged him with being one of the three robbers who slugged a messenger of the First National Bank of Farmingdale, L.I., on June 19 last and robbed him of $12,500.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- Many members of the Summer colonies of Southampton, East Hampton and Westhampton attended the gala dinner dance of the Hamptons, held tonight at Canoe Place Inn for the benefit of Camp Grant at Baiting Hollow, L.I. Mrs. Dwight F. Davis headed the patroness committee and Miss Constance Torney, the junior committee.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 4. -- King Edward's yacht, the Nahlin, with her escort of Turkish and British destroyers, anchored off Dolma Bagtche Palace this morning.

General Franz Ritter von Epp, Governor General of the German State of Bavaria, and Dr. Julius Dorpmueller, director general of the German Railways, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, heading a group of delegates to the world power conference.
Albert H. Atterbury in his letter to THE TIMES leaps immediately to a discussion of "the general rate of wages" and insists that what he says applies to the regulation of minimum wages.

The Board of Transportation rejected yesterday all bids submitted for construction of the second section of the Sixth Avenue subway line, extending between Thirty-third and Fortieth Streets. Work on the first section, from Fortieth to Forty-seventh Street, is already in progress.

ALBANY, Sept. 4. -- As Governor Lehman was sending his reply today to the dairy leaders at Syracuse, Henry S. Manley, counsel to the State Division of Milk Control, who quits office Sept. 15, declared in a radio address that milk control had definitely broken down.

APPLETON, Wis., Sept. 4. -- Having completed its six-day discussion of the areas of difficulty in human relations, the Midwest Institute of Human Relations turned this afternoon in its concluding session to the question "Where do we go from here?"

While most divisions of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange again were active yesterday trading in United States Government obligations subsided, although six new high marks were registered. Gains were 1-32 to 3-32 point, while some issues were 1-32 to 1-16 lower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP). -- The pooling of electric power, both government-owned and private, in regional systems under Federal agencies was proposed today by Basil Manly, vice chairman of the Federal Power Commission.

As was the case last week, new bond issues marketed this week were public utility and municipal offerings, to the total of $77,576,000, compared with $50,181,000 last week and with $30,799,000 in the corresponding week in 1935.

TRENTON, Mo., Sept. 4. -- Thirteen union employes of the Missouri public Service Company barricaded themselves in the plant here today and paralyzed power, gas and water services for twelve hours in protest against a proposed municipal electric plant.
Building work filed for by architects in Manhattan yesterday consisted of plans for making changes in existing structures.
ROME, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Reliable sources said tonight that three 6,000-ton cruisers had sailed for Spain today in the wake of the 10,000-ton cruiser Pola heading for Barcelona.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, threatening a strike of 15,000 truck drivers to enforce its demand for a forty instead of a forty-eight-hour week to spread employment, submitted to the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York last night a compromise offer of a forty-four-hour week.

The French liner Paris sails today for Southampton and Havre. Those on board include Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Jones, C. Marshall Barton, Mr. and Mrs. Marcel Delaporte, Ernest W. Dunbar, Mr. and Mrs. William Enneking, John Lintault, Louis Shurr, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kauffmann, C.E. Michaux, Mr. and Mrs. Francois de Maindreville, Mrs. Mabel Powell and Rene Grandchamp.

The capture of Irun is an important Rebel victory. The significance attached by both sides to the control of the western gateway to France was shown by the tenacity of the prolonged attack and the utter desperation of the defense. Obviously, much more was involved than possession of a town of ten or fifteen thousand inhabitants.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 5. -- Clouds of smoke rose tonight from the southern battlements of the beleaguered Alcazar, as government troops rained heavy shells on its crumbling walls, preparatory to storming the citadel.

SPONSORED by the French Government and for the greatest cash prize ever offered for such a competition, an international air race that will be held next Spring should set daring pilots and designers to planning through the Winter months.

Two methods of advancing prices, both apparently meeting with success, are being tried in home furnishings fields this Fall. With buying the best experienced since 1929, rug mills last week started to adjust prices to make up for higher costs of raw materials.

With two musk ox calves lolling in crates on the after deck and hundreds of specimens of birds, fish and flowers in boxes below, the Effie M. Morrissey returned to this port at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon from her tenth voyage into the Arctic.

Current reports of a possible peace conference to be called by the President bring memories of 1920, when Woodrow Wilson, inspired by similar idealism, attempted to hoist the olive branch over Downing Street.

BOSTON, Sept. 4. -- A canvass of leading local merchants indicates a general expectation of the best Fall trade since 1929. Currently, department store sales in New England are running about 12 to 25 per cent ahead of a year ago.

GENEVA, Sept. 5. -- Joseph A.C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, is leaving for Rome tomorrow to discuss League questions with Foreign Minister Count Galeazzo Ciano, preparatory to the Council's session of Sept. 18 and the Assembly's opening on Sept. 21.

GOLD is having an anniversary this month -- a golden jubilee. Johannesburg, in the Transvaal, Union of South Africa, will hold from Sept. 15 to Jan. 15 a fair to celebrate the fiftieth year since an English miner, George Walker, stumbled over an outcrop of unfamiliar rock on a farm in the high veldt.

Although fewer buyers were in the local wholesale markets last week, fairly steady activity was noted in most merchandise lines, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. A larger number of buyers is expected here with the passing of the holiday tomorrow.

It will be a young and inexperienced football squad that Columbia will muster tomorrow at Baker Field for its first practice of the season. Coach Lou Little has asked forty aspirants to report and while there is a good proportion of veterans, Columbia is resting its hopes for a successful campaign on the large number of promising players coming up from last year's powerful freshman squad.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 4. -- Weather built a backlog for the business fire for September in the Ninth Federal Reserve District. Cool conditions held off for most of August and consumers postponed Fall buying until this week, when the first effects were felt in the retail centers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- Seven members of the Chicago Board of Trade joined today in filing a bill of complaint before Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan seeking to restrain Federal officials from enforcing the Commodities Exchange Act.

MADISON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Henry G.E. Pansius of Summit, N.J., foreign freight agent of the Lackawanna Railroad, was fatally injured here this afternoon when he was hit by an eastbound Lackawanna suburban train which was pulling into the station at 2:20 o'clock. He died while being taken to the Overlook Hospital in Summit. He was 47 years old.
THE coming season bids fair to have at least as large a quota as usual of dance series under the auspices of various educational institutions.

Despite the restraining effects of the holiday tomorrow, the beginning of an active Fall trade featured business developments in the metropolitan area last week. Department store sales, revealing a brisk call for apparel and supplies for school reopenings and continued good response to extended August promotional offerings, ran ahead of the same week last year by close to 15 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that it had authorized to Aug. 31 advances amounting to $11,308,722,497. Of this amount, $1,223,111,476 had been canceled and $1,052,902,040 still remained available to borrowers and to banks in the purchase of preferred stock and capital notes.

Two hundred and fifty children, each under 5 years of age, vied for prizes yesterday afternoon as the Home Thrift Association staged its third annual baby show at its playground, York Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- President Roosevelt's budget recapitulation for the current fiscal year shows that government income and outgo are slowly swinging back into balance as Federal revenues are pushed upward by the rising trend of business.
I read with a great deal of interest your article concerning the computation of the earth's electrons by Sir Arthur Eddington.

At least three field trials for dachshunde will be conducted this Autumn under the auspices of the Dachshund Club of America and sanction of the American Kennel Club. The dates at present arranged are as follows:

After all, there is nothing better than the good old family circle as the scene of a baffling murder. The situation of the rich patriarch, foully done to death in the midst of his hopeful relatives, is old and ever new: well tended by a skillful author, it provides a fertile field for novelty, ingenuity, original and pertinent characterization, and the sustained puzzling of the attentive reader.

Carefully laid plans to protect this city in the event of a milk strike by New York State producers and to insure its millions a milk supply by having dealers purchase it from Western farmers and by mobilizing city-owned motor vehicles for its distribution, if necessary, have been made by Mayor La Guardia and Health Commissioner John L. Rice.

While the percentage gain is not as large as that noted in 1935, the increase in installment sales volume in the department-store field this year continues to run far ahead of the average department-store sales rise, according to estimates made in well-informed quarters hers last week.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Bishop Michael J. Gallagher returned from a trip to Europe to his own diocese today and reiterated emphatically his denials that the Vatican had instructed him to discipline the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- Trading on the Boerse was dull today, and prices were irregular, the stock board having more blanks than quotations. Interest in the market dwindled to a minimum, and most changes remained merely fractional. Generally the closing was without any movement of significance.

SIMPLE Fall dresses in black or rich dark colors, with rather high draped necklines, form a faultless background for artificial flowers; indeed, many of the dresses would be too severe without such a bright touch. And since Paris has decreed bigger and better costume flowers, one is enabled to change the effect of a good basic frock by the use of a selection of artificial blooms in velvet, cire or feathers.

ON APPROVAL: Britain is suffering from a shortage of Tommy Atkinses. For some time the army has been shouting for more recruits but hasn't been getting nearly enough. Last week the authorities took steps to make the army more attractive to young men.

The offer of an annual award to "that individual who through amateur radio has contributed most usefully to the American people either in research, technical development or operating achievement" was announced yesterday in New York by the Columbia Broadcasting System for William S. Paley, president.

BOSTON, Sept. 4. -- New England is prosperous. There is no boom here. None is wanted, lest there follow a slump. For months these States have been on the upslant. The arrival of Labor Day, marking the transition from Summer to Autumn, finds the great majority of the people facing the future with confidence.

That jaunt to the headquarters of the Biological Survey in Poughkeepsie the other day was an exciting adventure. It was something like taking a peek into the unknown. Here were persons who, through scientific inquiry, were baring the secrets of the watery realm.

PARIS, Sept. 3. -- Schiaparelli has created a novel bed cover for a well-known elegante. It is of blue satin; over its surface are the long-hand signatures of all her friends. These have been composed into a pattern by Schiaparelli's master hand, and then embroidered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Bob Johnson's single in the tenth inning drove in the winning run to break up a pitcher's battle today between Fred Archer and Joe Cascarella and give Philadelphia a 4-to-3 victory over Washington.

IN "Splendor in the Grass" Audrey Wurdemann again proves that she is more than ordinarily expert in the art of versifying. Her lines tinkle merrily their small lyric note, or step a demure minuet, as she pleases to order. Expert is Miss Wurdemann also in the craft of rhyming.

During the last half of the second century B.C. the condition of small owners and tenants of agricultural lands in the Roman Empire became almost intolerable. Wealthy owners of large farms were able to operate with slave labor, and the owners of large estates were driving the small owners and tenants to the wall.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- The White Elephants were at home tonight. For several Summers a group of the young women of the Summer colony here have given a ball that they have called the White Elephant Ball at the Newport Country Club.

Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Action, a 7-year-old son of Olambala which has improved from a selling plater to a stake winner under the handling of Hirsch Jacobs, thrilled a crowd of 15,000 at Aqueduct yesterday as he rushed up from almost last to capture the $5,000 added Aqueduct Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth in 1:44, within a second of the track record.

To enable holders of certificates to reorganize their real-estate equities under jurisdiction of the State courts, Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church yesterday replaced the Federal court appointed trustees of the Prudence Company, Inc., who controlled six large apartment buildings in Manhattan.

AMERICANS like to ask questions and one of the things they seem to be most curious about is their government. And since the government, in one form or another, takes in a lot of territory, so do the questions. From Park Avenue to Peoria, people want to know about everything from agriculture to insulation, and from baby foods to the recovery program.

Bernie Bierman of Minnesota, chief of staff on the coaching board of the College All-Stars, who will face the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds. Tuesday night, lectured on offensive football at the concluding session of The Herald Tribune's football school yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 5. -- Governor Lehman, in addressing the State convention of the American Legion here today, advocated a universal draft in case of war. He urged the legionnaires, however, to do all in their power to "keep our country out of war except in defense of our liberties."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- A fresh challenge of the constitutionality of government loans and grants for construction of municipally-owned electric systems was presented to the Supreme Court today by the Alabama Power Company and the Texas Utilities Company.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- This township, seat of modern beach and country clubs and of waterfront estates, will forget the fast pace of 1936 highway traffic and the hum of airplanes to celebrate its 275th anniversary from Sept. 20 to 26.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 5. -- Harry Cooper, sprightly veteran from Chicago, and Orville White, young Overland (Mo.) professional, deadlocked at 214 today for the 54-hole lead in the fourth annual $5,000 Hershey open golf tournament.

SEATTLE, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The Hearst Publications, Inc., filed a motion with the National Labor Relations Board here today asserting that the American Newspaper Guild should be held in contempt and asking that the Guild's complaint, demanding reinstatement of two discharged employes of The Post-Intelligencer, be dismissed.
The lowest elementary school enrollment in fifteen years was forecast yesterday by Dr. Harold C. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, for the term opening Sept. 14.

COMMONER'S DAUGHTER: Being the daughter of William Jennings Bryan, three times Democratic candidate for President, Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde can no more stay out of politics than her father could. She was Congresswoman from 1929 until 1933, when President Roosevelt made her Minister to Denmark.

A SECOND accession of early Greek sculpture to be announced within the year stands to the credit of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. The first, a fragment of a sixth-century head, belongs among the masterpieces of pre-Persian Athenian sculpture.

JACKSON, Wyo. "WATCH your step. There's the footprint of a moose." With such words of caution and comment a ranger naturalist leads a party of tourists up the trail of Cascade Canyon to Lake Solitude, a small, deep-blue lake at the base of the mighty pinnacles of the Tetons in the Grand Teton National Park.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 4. -- Now that Senator William E. Borah has been overwhelmingly renominated at the Idaho primaries, he is definitely in the Autumn campaign as a bearer of the Republican accolade.

THIS is the kind of book which makes the stay-at-home one of the glorious company of explorers. Written by a native New Yorker who has a fine enthusiasm for the surprises and odd corners of her own city, it opens new vistas for the city-bound child, so long as he or she has the enterprise of its red-headed young heroine.

SUCCESS stories aplenty dot our national life and literature, but few of them are so extraordinary as this. The progress of a Southern farm girl from bitter poverty and ignorance to comfort and culture and social stability in New York City is not, possibly, so remarkable in itself -- these things do happen, determination for self-improvement does reach its goal; this material is unusual, to be sure, but it is not unique.

TOPEKA, Sept. 5. -- Governor Landon today issued a Labor Day proclamation in which he recalled that Kansas in 1890 was the first State officially to establish the holiday, and reiterated his belief that labor should be free to organize for fair consideration without coercion from the government or any other source.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Members and their guests attended a dinner dance held tonight at the Beach Club of the Apawamis Club here. Among the hosts were Albert Newcomb, Colonel J.H. Cohos, T.K. Carpenter, J.S. McCulloh, Mrs. Natalie Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. J.F. Park, Mr. and Mrs. W. Murray Lee, Martin Matthews, E.W. Harris, Benjamin May and Austin Sargent.

New York's 1936 football season will descend prematurely but spectacularly on New York Tuesday night when the College All-Stars, the "dream team" of hundreds of thousands of gridiron fans the nation over, meet the New York Giants, Eastern champions of the National League, the major professional circuit, at the Polo Grounds.

" STEPS GOING DOWN," by John T. McIntyre, is a novel that comes with a fanfare of trumpets. The jacket proclaims the story as the "American contender" in an all-nations prize-novel competition. Clearly, the example of the Olympics has invaded the field of letters.

The number of bookings at the Town Hall already filed forecast the breaking of all previous records this season, according to Kenneth Klein, booking manager. To date 95 per cent of available weekday nights and more than 80 per cent of Saturday and Sunday matinees and evenings have been sold.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 5. -- In one of the longest and most thrilling golf matches of the season and with fifteen extra holes needed to reach a decision, William S. Meany Jr., and his young partner, Charles S. Munson Jr. of Waterbury, outlasted Mark Stuart and W. Stanton Barbour of Forsgate, 1 up, in thirty-three holes, and gained the final in the John D. Chapman Memorial invitation four-ball tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today.

RECENT heavy rains, which have restored moisture to the soil, and the prospect of cooler weather have brought about ideal conditions for the planting of evergreens. While such planting can be, and often is, done much later in the season, nothing is gained by waiting.

ONE of the most responsible posts in Britain's Royal household is that of Captain of the King's Flight, which was recently created. It is held by Flight Lieutenant E.C. Fielden, the first man ever to pilot a King of England in the air. Since 1929, when King Edward, then Prince of Wales, bought his first airplane, he has been flown aloft by Lieutenant Fielden.

A sharp rise in the number of buyers in the wholesale markets is expected here beginning on Tuesday, the total rising to a secondary peak for the Fall season or possibly setting a new high for this year, according to reports reaching the wholesale markets here.

CARNEGIE HALL will be the scene of WEAF's symphonic concerts on Sunday nights from 10 to 11 o'clock, beginning Sept. 13. Erno Rapee will be permanent conductor, and guest directors will be invited from time to time. Albert Spalding, violinist, and Harold Bauer, pianist, are the soloists on the opening program; the Cossack Russian Male Chorus is listed for Sept. 20 and Rosa Ponselle, soprano, for Sept. 27.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the Harvest Moon Ball which was held tonight at the Beach Club. Blue floodlights illuminated the breakers in front of the clubhouse.

LONDON, Sept. 2. -- A busy week lies ahead. On Monday, Edinburgh will see the premiere of Basil Dean's first production of the season, Lesley Storm's "Follow Your Saint," with Edna Best, Nicholas Hannen and Francis Lister in the cast. Tuesday, Ronald Jeans's "The Composite Man," with Richard Bird and Diana Churchill, will open at Daly's.

The Rev. Lawrence A. Walsh, S.J., Dean of the Graduate School of Fordham University, announced yesterday the appointment of thirty-one graduate assistants and the award of twenty-one graduate scholarships for the year 1936-1937.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- Professor Stengel's Dodgers won a doubleheader from the Phillies today, the first game by normal baseball in nine innings, 3 -- 2, but the second contest through a series of miracles in twelve innings, 4 -- 3.

After expressing the wish that her daughter be married later in the day, as had been planned, Mrs. Augustine James Brett died at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning of a heart attack at her home in Sayville, L.I. She was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- While fifty-seven food items of eighty-four included in the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics advanced in price between July 14 and Aug. 18, sharp declines in other items held the retail index unchanged, the bureau announced today.

CREDIT has never been given to the small private presses scattered over this country for the important part they play in fostering an interest in books. Not only are they encouraging a far-flung taste for fine printing, but they are also publishing the work of promising young writers in their vicinity and preserving picturesque sidelights on local history.

The telegraph companies are at it again. And once more we find ourselves thinking what a pity it is that the profit motive should be the source of so much evil, because really the lust for profits does stimulate ingenuity.

OYSTER BAY, Sept. 5. -- Continuing the string of victories he has scored during the season, Commodore Van S. Merle-Smith of Seawanhaka piloted his 12-meter craft Seven Seas to victory today in the sixty-fourth annual Fall regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

HOLLYWOOD. THE cinema's glamour machine that takes waitresses, debutantes, actresses, schoolgirls and their masculine parallels and by adroit veneering makes of them the dream children of the silver screen is a complex lot of wheels and cams.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Sept. 2 aggregated $8,727,000,000, or 20 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 29 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

QUITE the most joyous art event of this sunlit Swedish Summer has been the unveiling of the Orpheus Fountain by Carl Milles at the Concert House Square in Stockholm. To the hundreds of Americans who had an opportunity to visit the artist's studios in Cranbrook some months ago when the model was exhibited, this towering Orpheus is already a familiar figure.

I The 1,400 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $44,279,021,992 in par value, had a market value of $42,235,760,556 on Sept. 1, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. On Aug. 1 there were 1,403 issues, aggregating $43,980,902,150 par value, which had a market value of $41,685,172,818.

PERHAPS one of the most lasting contributions of the Safe Driver Conference which ended at the Waldorf last Wednesday is that it proved that safety can be dramatized. Somehow safety conferences, however lofty their intentions, have more often than not provided reading which failed to arouse the interest of the average man-at-the-wheel.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Edwin Ruthwin Butler, Colgate sophomore, won the junior title of the Long Island Golf Association from the defending holder, Charles Metzger, 2 up, over the Hempstead Golf Club course today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- With the exception of the Virginia Boat Club's one-foot victory in the junior eight-oared event, Philadelphia oarsmen swept the Schuylkill River in the forty-fifth annual Middle States Regatta today.

PARIS. -- In order to compete with intensive organization of dictatorial States, France has created a school for advanced studies in national defense. What other countries would accomplish by discipline, France hopes to secure by education.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 4. -- As the Sept. 15 primary date draws near New Hampshire is tensely awaiting the result of one of the most talked-of Republican tangles of its political history -- a three-cornered contest for the Senate nomination of the Republicans.

SEVILLE, Spain, Sept. 5. -- The main Rebel army of General Francisco Franco near Toledo is cleaning up the little towns off the main road to insure against flank attacks and against bitter opposition by the peasants and Leftist militia. Every small hamlet is delaying the advance on Madrid which aides of the careful generalissimo want to begin immediately.

THERE is a story the oldest natives of this small and ancient city like to tell each year at this time. It is simple and straightforward, yet it concerns one of the historical epics of the old Southwest. It is the story of Fiesta.

IN New York at the season of the vine harvest there is no feast of Bacchus, no parade of the wine casks in the traditional fashion of the grape-growing regions of Europe. But some suggestion of these colorful ceremonies comes to Manhattan at this time of year in the presence of pushcarts heaped with sweet-smelling mounds of ripe grapes.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Procter introduced their younger daughter, Miss Beatrice S. Procter, at a dance at Orleton Farm on Prospect Hill here tonight. The lawns and gardens were illuminated with Japanese lanterns and there was dancing in a wooden-floored marquee installed for the occasion near the barn, where Mrs. Procter and her daughter received their guests.

THE plight of Miss Kay Brown, talent scout for Selznick International, and Robert Ross, screen test director for the same company, is reminiscent of Miss Sophie Tucker's position one night in Cincinnati among the Singer midgets.

THIS is the story of a man who came alive at the age of 30 in the year 1930, shaken loose from his old sell by the jar of the depression. Eight pages of foreword serve to cover -- quite adequately -- his family, education, marriage and moderate success in business.
DETROIT, Sept. 5. -- The residence Ulysses S. Grant occupied when he came to Detroit in 1849 was opened to the public today as a memorial to the General.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Greentree still rules polo in the United States. Late this afternoon, while a crowd of 18,000 in the tall Stands of International Field roared with excitement, little Pete Bostwick poked Up a short pass and big Gerry Balding jammed through the goal that ended the over-time final of the national open championship and sent Templeton to defeat, 11 to 10.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- Efforts to obtain honest neutrality of the European powers in their attitude toward the Spanish civil war may have to be written off the international books as merely another British-French failure in dealing with the dictators of Berlin and Rome.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The German Government announced today that it had agreed to join the international committee to be established at London for the handling of problems arising out of the Spanish arms embargo and that it has instructed Prince Otto yon Bismarck, its London Charge d'Affaires, to represent Germany on that committee.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES recently Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, used a pamphlet issued by the American Liberty League entitled "Socialization of the Electric Power Industry" as the basis for a dissertation in favor of public ownership.

The New York University football squad, led by Head Coach Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens, is scheduled to depart from University Heights this morning for the Fall training camp at Lake Sebago, near Sloatsburg, N.Y. The pre-season drills will begin tomorrow for the forty-nine candidates who have been invited.

MEADOW BROOK, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Although members of society have taken an active interest in the polo matches of the open championship meet which opened a week ago, it took the deciding game of this afternoon to bring out the big crowd and line up the followers of the leading teams into a real demonstration.

Appointment of 350 business and professional men to thirty-five committees was announced yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants' Association of New York. Composed of specialists in their fields, the committees will aid the association's board of directors in determining its attitude on public questions during the coming year.

The Burroughs Adding Machine Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $3,418,887 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, equivalent to 68 cents a share on 5,000,000 no-par shares of capital stock.

MADISON, Conn., Sept. 5 -- More than two hundred members of the Madison Summer colony attended a Tacky party at the Madison Beach Club tonight, bringing to a close the social events of the season here.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- Without placing too much trust in Germany's sincerity or in the value of her pledges, officials here were pleased tonight she had agreed to join the international committee to supervise non-intervention in Spain.

PINE ORCHARD, Conn., Sept. 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Edgar H.L. Stonington of New York gave a dinner for their son, John, and daughter, Beatrice Stonington, prior to the regular week-end dance at the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club tonight.

THE annual "two months' open-air dahlia show" begins this week-end at the New York Botanical Garden, where the first of more than 400 varieties of this Autumn flower will be ready for inspection by flower lovers from the metropolitan area and dahlia enthusiasts from all over the country.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 5. -- Trouble is feared tomorrow when there will be an island-wide demonstration of sympathizers of Pedro Albizu Campos and other Nationalist prisoners. GENEVA, Sept. 5. -- In 1935 the value of world trade improved slightly over 1934, the first such annual rise since 1929, according to the League of Nations' annual review of world trade just published. The volume increased more than 4 per cent over 1934 but was 18 per cent below 1929.

SAN SALVADOR. -- President Martinez has appointed Dr. Manuel Castro Ramirez, an outstanding international lawyer, to head El Salvador's delegation at the Pan American Conference at Buenos Aires next December. The other members of the delegation are Max Patricio Brennan and Joaquin Leiva.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The naming of George M. Brown as resident agent of Princeton's new $4,500,000 civic square and the appointment of William R. Lewis as manager of the new Nassau Tavern were announced today by officials of the Princeton Municipal Improvement, Inc., sponsor of the project.

The strike of 12,000 painters in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond formally came to an end yesterday afternoon when District Council 9, of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, signed a one-year agreement with the Association of Master Painters and Decorators.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 (AP). -- A new definition of the common air is being written by Mellon Institute and the Harvard Medical School.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- A warning that voters should not be deceived by the "prosperity mirage" of the New Deal was sounded here today in a Labor Day statement issued by John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 5. -- With a field that included several of the country's leading women golfers, the second annual mixed foursomes championship sponsored by the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club got under way today.

INVITATIONS have been sent to a list of several hundred New York bridge players to join a new club, to be known as the Regency Club, Inc., which is to open early in October at 15 East Sixty-seventh Street. This will be the third club of its type in New York, the first having been the Cavendish Club and the second Crockford's Club, both of which are in operation now.

Sopwith's Endeavour II would be built at the Bath Iron Works in Bath, Me., was reflected yesterday in a conference held there between Harold S. Vanderbilt, who will manage and sail the new racer, and W. Starling Burgess and Olin J. Stephens, who will collaborate in her design.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- In the presence of one of the largest gatherings that has attended an outdoor dog show this year, George N. Owen of Great Neck, L.I., today passed over the gold cup emblematic of best in show to the Sealyham terrier Champion Wolvey Noel of Clairedale, owned by the Clairedale Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. W.O. Penney of Riverhead, L.I.

Today we mark one more step of progress -- one more imprint of a changing order -- this great structure spanning the Mississippi. The river ferry started to go when the old railroad bridge joined Missouri and Illinois back in 1870. As the years went by, this structure carried the rail, the horse-drawn and the motorized commerce in and out of Hannibal across the Mississippi.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 5. -- The fourteenth International Congress of P.E.N. Clubs opened here today. Ninety delegates, representing thirty-nine countries, attended the inaugural session in the City Hall in the presence of General Augustin P. Justo, president of Argentina.

THE newly formed British Music Drama Opera Company will give a three weeks' season of opera at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London, Nov. 16-Dec. 5. All of the six operas to be produced will be sung in English.
THE Packard Motor Car Company announced yesterday its new models for 1937, which include an entirely new car, a Six, priced at less than $1,000.

Maritime labor problems affecting world commerce will be discussed by representatives of all the leading maritime nations except Germany at a special session of the International Labor Conference, which will open Oct. 6 in Geneva, according to announcement made here yesterday.

The most important, unsensational, recent item of news from China was the announcement last Wednesday of the opening of the 453-mile Canton-Hankow railroad. The completion of this first modern link between the cities of the Yangtse River and those of the South China Sea is, of course, an indication of the increasing influence of the Central Government throughout the south, and is a means of consolidating that power.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5. -- Nearly a month has elapsed since General John Metaxas virtually assumed the dictatorship of Greece by proclaiming martial law and dissolving Parliament, but it is still impossible to forecast the future of the experiment.

A SPECTACULAR exhibition of popular outdoor Winter sports events on real ice and snow, together with a comprehensive exposition of exhibits illustrating the growth of the Winter sports industry, is being arranged for Madison Square Garden for Dec. 9-13, inclusive, when the North American Winter sports carnival will take place.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 5 (AP). Mrs. William Cohn, president of the Bridgeport Parent-Teacher Association, characterized as "rather ridiculous" tonight the removal of three novels by Victor Hugo and Alexander Dumas from the required reading list of Bridgeport's three high schools.

STONE HARBOR, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Fred Jacoby Jr. of North Bergen, N.J., present high-point champion, carried off the honors in the outboard events of the eighth annual regatta of the Yacht Club of Stone Harbor today.

VIENNA, Sept. 4. -- Little more than two decades ago German foreign policy moved under the influence of a beautiful dream. The dream had a name -- it was called "Mitteleuropa." Through its fulfillment all manner of desirable things were to come true.

Three armed and masked men drove into the garage of the Coca-Cola Bottling Works, 536 North Sixth Street, Newark, shortly after 8 o'clock last night, lined the assistant manager, cashier and ten drivers against the wall and escaped after robbing the cash register of $910 in cash and $99 in checks.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, the industry's largest producer, announced today an increase of $2 a ton on semi-finished products, reflecting higher prices for raw steel and expanding production in the mills.

The Third World Power Conference, convening this week in Washington, serves to emphasize the magical rapidity with which electricity is becoming the symbol and substance of a higher standard of living. Electric power is the chief factor that today makes life richer for the average home.

" Aunt Anne" Kitson is so kind that she feeds the mice in her apartment, not to mention every stray cat, dog and pigeon in the neighborhood, and a few human "down and outers." When she isn't doing a good turn she says she "just don't feel right."

TWO members of the Washington family are on a committee organized to preserve the birthplace and boyhood home at Portsmouth, N.H., of Tobias Lear, George Washington's secretary, Lear, it is recorded, was closer to Washington than any other man, from the end of the Revolution to the general's death; tradition holds that he was the last man to whom Washington spoke.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 4. -- Never were the possibilities of an Arab-Jewish understanding in Palestine more remote than at present, and the reasons for this are manifold.

New York City's non-residential districts could be built up to accommodate a working population equal to the total population of North and South America without violating the city building and zoning laws, the Mayor's Committee on City Planning pointed out yesterday after a study of figures compiled by the New York City Housing Authority and used by the committee for the preparation of a detailed map of actual property use in New York.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 5. -- Several hundred Williams College pilgrims will go from here to Stockbridge next month during the Mark Hopkins Centenary celebration to participate in the dedication of a bronze plaque at Cherry Cottage, the birthplace of the nineteenth century philosopher.

That most persistent of modern revolutionaries, Leon Trotsky, is again in trouble. On June 18 this wanderer on the face of the earth arrived at Oslo in Norway en route, it was said, to a sanatorium. The Norwegian Government has now confined the unwelcome guest within a strict internment.

The show at Des Moines was the President's, of course, and therefore, in dominating it, he did not "steal" it. The facts that he called the conference, that the subject was interdependently Federal and State, that he is the President and that Mr. Landon -- for this occasion -- is only one of several Governors, would have made the show Mr. Roosevelt's even if he had not, in addition, possessed certain personal attainments.

WASHINGTON. -- One of the chief issues of the coming political campaign will undoubtedly be the foreign trade policy of the United States. The Democratic party has come out clearly in its platform in favor of the continuation of the trade-agreement program as laid down in the Act of Congress of June 12, 1934, under which fourteen reciprocal trade agreements have already been negotiated.

ON BOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL En Route to Washington, Sept. 5. -- In spite of the announced purpose of President Roosevelt to make his trip to the Western drought area a non-political affair, some of his associates believe political gain has accrued to him.

THIS sumptuous volume, limited to a few hundred copies and priced at a figure which would buy some 12,000 pages of our latest best seller, will obviously never flood the bookstores. It cannot go into new editions, even though the public should drop bridge or golf for papermaking, and should turn out to have thirty-six dollars.

TOPEKA, Sept. 5. -- Governor Landon's memorandum setting forth his recommendations for drought relief, which he gave to President Roosevelt after his conference with him at Des Moines on Thursday, proposed much the same program that the Governor has advocated and partly carried out during the three and two-thirds years of his administration.
NEWPORT, R.I. -- This resort is having a gay Labor Day week-end. Many guests arrived yesterday, especially young people, who attended the White Elephant Ball at the Newport Country Club last night.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

LOUISBURG, N.S., Sept. 5. -- A forced landing this afternoon in the deep mud of an isolated farm in the coal mining and coast village of Baleine Cove, eighteen miles from here, ended in spectacular fashion the attempt of Mrs. Reryl Markham, English aviatrix, to fly from England to New York.
SAINT JEAN DE LUZ, France, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Efforts of foreign diplomats to "humanize" the Spanish civil war and end reported mass execution of hostages collapsed tonight.
New Yorkers who take the citywide automobile safety campaign seriously were astounded yesterday to see a driverless cabriolet winding in and out of traffic-cluttered streets.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4. -- Were Russia and Germany actually at war, they could hardly call each other worse names than those they are belaboring each other with now through their respective presses.

ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Sergeant Daniel Glasheen of the New York State police is satisfied that the series of petty burglaries in Western Suffolk County has come to an end with the arrest early today of Frank J. Cervany, 29 years old, of 62 Second Avenue, Bay Shore, lone thief who was captured looting a stationery store at 173 Islip Avenue, Islip.

NEW YORK CITY'S brides and bridegrooms need never again climb impatiently from the second to the third floor of the Municipal Building to get from the Marriage License Bureau to their weddings. For the little chapel that has been silent witness to nearly 250,000 civil ceremonies during the last twenty years has been closed.

JUST returned from four months of dashing about Europe looking for rare films, John E. Abbott, director of the Museum of Modern Art Film Library, modestly admitted the other afternoon that his tour proved to be a "fabulous success."

VIC HURLEY has a flair for effective book titles. For the third time he has put his best foot forward, as he did in "Southeast of Zamboanga" and "Men in Sun Helmets" -- both clear-cut yet atmospheric descriptions of life in Mindanao -- and he has come before his audience with another telling cue-line.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- The first successful flight of balloon-supported instruments into the stratosphere in the study of cosmic ray activity was effected today by the Bartol Research Foundation of the Franklin Institute.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4. -- Building operations continue to occupy the spotlight on the Pacific Coast. Figures for the year to date are already greater than for the entire year 1935. Private building permits in San Francisco in August were the highest for any month this year.

When the Italian liner Rex left her pier at the foot of West Eighteenth Street yesterday at noon Mr. and Mrs. Pietro Pozzebon, middle-aged couple recently of Vancouver, B.C., were on board for a trip to the "old country" which almost came to a sad ending.

The methods and problems of successful department store merchandising and what the manufacturer should do to adjust his procedure and product for sales through this form of distribution are analyzed in a new book "How To Sell To and Through Department Stores" by E.B. Weiss, vice president of the Grey Advertising Agency.

THE itinerant Douglas C. McMurtrie, leading surveyor of cradle days of printing in various parts of the United States, has lighted upon Colorado for the scene of one of his major operations. A more ambitious volume than any of the predecessors emerges from the process with the title, "Early Printing in Colorado.

Approach of Labor Day win serve to fix the thoughts of many upon the unusual questions or controversies which today confront organized labor in the United States. Most formidable of these are, of course, the sharp differences and bitter quarrels which have arisen within the ranks of labor itself.

After a twenty-eight-hour vigil, government agents and city detectives early yesterday captured a bail jumper charged with defrauding the Federal Housing Administration of $20,000 and arrested a man and a woman accused of harboring him, in a brownstone building at 116 West Eightieth Street.

FORT LEE, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The body of Theodore Van Bemmel, building contractor and civic leader, was found by a searching party early this morning on a ledge about 100 feet from the top of the Palisades less than a quarter of a mile from his home at 3,141 Lemoine Avenue here.

General Franz Ritter von Epp, Governor General of Bavaria, and Dr. Julius Dorpmueller, director general of the German railways, pleaded for international understanding and amity at a luncheon in their honor yesterday. The event was held at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, under the auspices of the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce.

BASEBALL'S little brother, soft ball, is thriving lustily. Born in the Middle West only three years ago, this abridged version of our national game has grown so rapidly that there are now about 60,000 teams and 1,000,000 players throughout the country, with new teams being organized daily.

SINCE the days of Thoth of the Egyptian -- 4,500 years ago -- alchemy has fascinated the minds of men. And never has it been more fascinating than now, when its great strange dream has come true. In olden times "the practices associated with the transmutation of elements were known as the Divine Art," although in medieval legends the figure of the alchemist is as often sinister as saintly.

IN casual retrospect, it seems that scarcely a theatrical season has passed in recent years without the attention of American audiences being directed upon at least one of those brilliant young Englishmen who are constantly popping up on the London stage.
Not hate, but glory, made these chiefs contend;

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- Ambassador Robert W. Bingham, who has been spending a holiday in Scotland, has returned to his residence in Princes Gate and Mrs. Bingham has returned from Germany. Mr. and Mrs. Pay Atherton expect to return here from New York on Sept. 14.

FOR 300 years Harvard University has been associated in the public mind with the English University of Cambridge. To this day, Harvard is in the tradition of Cambridge, not Oxford, and the tercentenary, the celebration of which begins next Sunday, suggests the question: What, in actual fact, has been this academic kinship?
Here is a historic resume of silver prices that may be of interest in view of Republican criticism of the New Deal silver purchase policy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The same industry which upset the NRA and its codes in a Supreme Court test -- the live poultry trade in Greater New York -- today was said by officials of the Department of Agriculture to be causing trouble in their efforts to regulate it.

WHITEFIELD, N.H. THE third annual White Mountain Music Festival comes to a close this afternoon in the Chase Barn Playhouse, which stands about a mile from this town in the heart of the mountains. Sydney Rayner, the tenor who joined the Metropolitan Opera for the Spring season and has been retained for the Winter term, will join with Norman Roland, young American baritone, in the eighth recital of the season.

A feature in trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was the appearance of the heaviest hedging operations of the season, estimated as high as 75,000 bales against purchases of the moving crop. Under the impact of these contracts, an early advance in response to strong Liverpool cables was turned into a decline of $1 a bale.

With the government involved in labor questions as never before in the history of the country, industry must develop more intelligent labor management to cope adequately with the numerous problems arising in employer-employe relationships, Ordway Tead, editor of economic books of Harper Brothers and president of the Society for the Advancement of Management, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- When America's 30,600,000 students begin their trek back to school this month they will find, throughout the country, new buildings embodying the most advanced thought of educational experts, and increased, improved and safer facilities made possible by the Public Works Administration, according to a special report to Harold L. Ickes, Public Works Administrator, made public today.

IN its theme, but not in its approach, "Skutarevsky" recalls a period in Soviet literature that was marked by a persistent, troubled devotion to the subject of loyalties. With subtlety and infectious good humor, however, Leonov has written a character study in which allegiance is given the quality of an emotion, not of a mechanical response.

The westward flight to America over the North Atlantic has been especially hazardous to aviators in heavier-than-air machines. Only two planes bound for New York have ever made the trip non-stop. Other flights have ended short of their goal or made the trip in stages.

A center to include a permanent museum of health and hygiene is planned for the World Fair of 1939, Grover Whalen, president of the fair corporation, announced yesterday. The Oberlander Foundation and the Carnegie Corporation have already pledged financial assistance and other grants will be sought, the announcement said.

DENVER, Sept. 5 (AP). -- A heated contest between Governor Ed C. Johnson and former Governor William E. Sweet for the Democratic nomination for Senator dominates interest in Tuesday's primary election.
DETROIT, Sept. 5. -- Mrs. Della Carter's brown house was partly white today, and the faces of three painters were very red.

The hearings of Brooklyn's District Attorney, William F.X. Geoghan, before Governor Lehman at Albany on charges of laxity in the Drukman murder case, failure to prosecute bribery in that case and consorting with persons of ill repute went into their second week.

The Zeppelin Hindenburg will make a daytime exhibition flight Oct. 9 over the Northeastern States with fifty guests, including W.S. Farish, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, and business associates and friends.

Captain John F. Jensen received orders last week to be prepared to go ashore at the end of the present voyage of the liner President Roosevelt. Although in the best of health and an imposing figure as he treads the deck, Captain Jensen must accede to the rule of the United States Lines that at 60 a ship master is retired.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- A small gold bust of Bolivar, South American patriot, was stolen last night from Dr. R.J. Alfaro, Minister of the Republic of Panama, while he and his family were spending the night here at the home of their cousin, Mrs. Roy Hebard of 205 Soundview Road.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 5 -- More than 1,000 pieces of early American furniture, pewter, antique silver, glass, copper and museum objects of art, the entire contents of the Stage Coach Inn, where society has gathered for many years, are to be sold.

An audience which filled the Hippodrome Theatre to capacity was on hand last night to hear the first performance of Gounod's "Faust" in the Hippodrome Opera Company's season. Four hundred standees -- the limit permitted under the city's fire regulations -- were lined up before the rise of the first curtain, and more than a hundred persons were turned away at the box office.

IF ever there was a legitimate and literal application for the term "brain trust" -- meaning a company in possession of some of the world's choicest resources of gray matter -- that term applies to the gathering now in progress at Cambridge.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The first official justification for the prolongation of the military conscription term by which German armed forces were increased by an estimated 200,000 men was submitted to the world in an article just published in the German press under the signature of Major Walther Jost, the War Ministry's press liaison officer.

The dedication of the old Billop mansion in Staten Island, now known as the Conference House, as a national shrine will be urged at exercises next Saturday afternoon marking the 160th anniversary of the peace conference held at the house in a futile attempt to end the Revolutionary War.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- To keep the first half of its name, Great Britain needs the empire. To live well, the British people need the empire. Yet it will not be theirs if they cease to be strong and prosperous.

Two armed bandits, fleeing after an attempt to hold up a jewelry shop at 2 Church Street, were chased two blocks early yesterday afternoon by a shouting mob of 500 men and women and were finally brought down near the Cortlandt Street steps of the Ninth Avenue elevated by six shots fired by a detective.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 5. -- The maxim of Protagoras that "man is the measure of all things" will be the keynote of the second and major half of the two-week Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences at Harvard University.

WITH his "Jefferson and Hamilton" Claude Bowers starred to tell the story of that mighty clash of men and ideas which was initiated during the Presidency of George Washington and has never wholly died down. Now he carries it to the end of the second Jefferson administration.

OMAHA, Sept. 4. -- The event of the week in the Corn Belt, of course, was the drought conference in Des Moines at which President Roosevelt met not only his political antagonist, Governor Landon of Kansas, but the Governors of six other Middle Western States and several of their United States Senators as well.

ATLANTA, Sept. 4. -- The "red suspenders campaign," Georgia's most spectacular political contest since the Hoke Smith-Clark Howell Governorship race thirty years ago, will come to a close with voting Wednesday in the State primary.

History repeated itself in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday when Sidney B. Wood Jr., found himself two sets down to J. Gilbert Hall, as a year ago, and then came on to win in a thrilling fifth chapter that left the crowd of 6,000 spectators hoarse of voice and limp from excitement.

IRRESPECTIVE alike of economic factors and the well-being of the peoples concerned, the nations are preparing not for peace but for war. Preparation has reached its climax everywhere, even in England, in the adoption of a military economy under which the national life is ordered; not with the peace and happiness of the nation as first consideration, but with the military necessities of international strife as the basis.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Wallace Benjamin gave a large dinner tonight at the Crossways before the advertising party at the Maidstone Club.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The men's colleges of Rutgers University will open their 170th year on Sept. 14, when a freshman class of approximately 400 students will report for the orientation period designated as freshman week.

BERLIN, Sept. 5 (AP). -- German Catholic clergymen will read a pastoral letter from all pulpits tomorrow complaining bitterly against the treatment accorded by the Nazi press and officialdom to immorality trials in Germany.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Russell F. Randolph, missing 68-year-old retired banker and insurance broker, who disappeared from the home of his daughter, Mrs. Vernon J. Tiger, some time between midnight and 5 o'clock Thursday morning, was seen walking along a road near Doylestown, Pa., early yesterday morning by Donald Douglass of Liberty Corner.

WHATEVER else the Federal Music Project of the WPA may have signified in the minds of its creators, it was originally launched as a relief measure. Today, however, while the relief element in the movement remains of vital importance, the cultural aspects of the Project's activities have become so apparent that they loom largest in the picture.

TO G.E.R. Gedye, THE TIMES correspondent in Vienna, Professor Bronislav Huberman recently gave details of the completion of his scheme for a Palestine symphony orchestra. The opening festival has been fixed for Dec. 26 in Tel-Aviv.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The Tigers turned back the Browns, 7 to 2, today in the opener of a two-game series at Navin Field.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 4. -- Vermont, which has not elected a Democratic Governor since the Civil War, will face next Tuesday the most complicated primary election, in many years. Out of this election, many observers say, may come a situation which could result in the choice of a Democratic Governor in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Construction of homes in cities of more than 10,000 population during the first seven months of this year already exceeds the entire volume of urban construction in the calendar year 1935, according to a forthcoming issue of the Federal Home Loan Bank Review.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Anxious to know but reluctant to discuss the probable effect of William Hale Thompson's entry into the Illinois campaign as candidate for Governor on the ticket of the Union party sponsored by Father Coughlin and headed by Representative William Lemke, Republican and Democratic chiefs have received their first clue to the former's present strength.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The text of the Labor Day message to American workers by President Roosevelt, issued today, was as follows:
AVON, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- The annual Autumn horse show of the Genesee Valley Breeders Association was held today in the oval show ring at the Avon Springs.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Nineteen entries, representing five International Star Class fleets of the Atlantic seaboard, started the eighth annual Jersey Coast challenge series today off the Seaside Park Yacht Club. The series will continue tomorrow and Monday.

WHAT, for instance, is that often-neglected territory known as the road doing about the new theatrical season? Appended below are home of the opening attractions which will relight the houses in the hinterland:

PARIS. AFRICA now occupies almost as much space in Winter fashion headlines as it did last season in the news columns. Tunisia, Morocco and Egypt are all represented in the new Paris mode. Embroideries are probably the most striking thing Africa has offered us; the more barbaric the glitter, the smarter the model.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Business in August maintained about the same high level as in July, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- So many events of varied interest have been planned for late season here that there is little indication that Labor Day will put an end to formal entertaining, as in previous years. In fact, the conclusion of each Summer finds an increasing number of colonists remaining through the delightful September days.

EVERY five years Harvard's Class of 1911 publishes brief personal histories. The members of the class send in facts about themselves, tell how many children they have, what business they are in -- that sort of thing.

THANKS to the Italian aggression of last Autumn, Egypt has at last won terms of political independence from Great Britain which would have been unthinkable only a year ago. Nearly every political fetter which up to now has made a mockery of its independence has been struck off in the new Anglo-Egyptian treaty which now awaits ratification by London and Cairo.

Republican claims for a heavy up-State plurality for the Landon-Knox ticket in November are without foundation, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared yesterday after conferring with party leaders of eleven counties outside New York City.

Mrs. Flora Spiegelberg, who has worked to make New York City cleaner and more healthful for more than a score of years, will celebrate her eightieth birthday Thursday at a quiet family party at her home, 111 East Eighty-eighth Street, with her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, will give three concerts as a part of the Harvard University tercentenary celebration. At the first concert, Wednesday night, Sept. 16, in Symphony Hall, Boston, the program will consist of the Brahms "Academic Festival" overture, two movements from Hill's "String Sinfonietta," Ravel's "Daphnis and Chloe" (second suite), and Beethoven's Fifth symphony.

PRODUCTION activity on the Coast is at a new high point, with all studios endeavoring to get the current season's product out of the way. A check-up of the companies shows there are forty-five features in production, seventy-five in the cutting rooms and about the same number in various stages of story preparation.

THE Yaddo Music Group, consisting of some twenty musicians now in residence at the Yaddo estate in Saratoga Springs, will give a series of five chamber music concerts at the Yaddo mansion for an invited public next Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics today issued the first of its weekly grade and staple reports for the Cotton Belt as a whole.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4. -- Termination of the drought and intense heat helped conditions in the Eighth Federal Reserve District in the last week. While a heavy rainfall did little to save crops, except late corn in some sections, it revived pasturage and filled depleted water supplies.

COOLER weather had a highly stimulating effect upon retail trade in many areas last week. Centers in the drought district reported a brisk upturn, while Chicago experienced volume l on a level with last Christmas. Some the gains enjoyed in other sections were remarkable.

Aside from the Spanish situation the governments of Europe had a busy time last week, each pushing their own enterprises and watching carefully the countermoves of their neighbors, friends and enemies.
LONDON, Sept. 5. -- England was astonished tonight at the news that Mrs. Beryl Markham had crossed the Atlantic and had come down safely.
WASHINGTON. -- Several hundred officers and men of the United States Army and Navy recently were granted the right to wear on dress parade decorations awarded them by foreign governments.

BANGOR, Me. -- Ten thousand men and boys and some hundreds of women and girls will be busy from now until the middle of October gathering Aroostook County's potato crop. For eight or ten hours daily of the constant and vigorous work, this army will be paid about a million dollars, for the Aroostook crop will be considerably in excess of 30,000,000 bushels, and the pickers are paid 7 1/2 cents a barrel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- A government official's suggestion that utilities "experiment more with rate reduction" was met today by a utility executive's argument that rate cuts do not always bring increased use of electricity.

A NORMALLY, or perhaps unusually, active season among the Eastern Summer art colonies is now about at an end. Upon this page has appeared from week to week comment concerning some of the major groups, such as those at Woodstock, Silvermine, Mystic, Old Lyme, Newport, Provincetown, Gloucester and Rockport, named in the order in which they were discussed.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 5. -- Victim of what police called an attempted murder, Harry E. Byram, 72, a retired railroad executive, was in Norwalk Hospital today suffering from a pistol wound in the head.

IN the wake of last week's pictures is bobbing a rather pitiful bit of wreckage, the cast-adrift claque which swept into the Paramount Theatre to applaud Clifford Odets's first Hollywood effort, "The General Died at Dawn." Fittingly seated in the theatre's left wing, they had come to hear their prophet of social reform in his first sermon from a cinema pulpit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Increase in the coming elections of two Senate seats, in Maine and Iowa, bringing the Democratic strength in the next Senate to 71, the largest majority held by any party since the Civil War, was predicted today by Democratic leaders directing the Senate campaign.

In the course of his oratorical marathon Colonel KNOX has not confined himself to his heroic task of saving the nation. He would also save the Democratic party. He is not fighting it but fighting for it. It must be rescued from those "alien and un-American elements" that, in the vision of his falcon eye, now control it.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 5. -- Taking the lead rounding the first turn, George D. Widener's High Fleet won the first running of the New England Oaks, a mile-and-one-sixteenth stake for 3-year-old fillies, at Narragansett Park today.

BOSTON, Sept. 5. -- Having been officially declared out of all contention so far as the 1936 pennant may be concerned, Tom Yawkey's Red Sox began plans today for the 1937 campaign and forthwith put on a show that gave tremendous heart to a gathering of 21,000 loyal enthusiasts who, being Hub fans, naturally would become encouraged at the slightest provocation in any circumstances.

The prospects for the refunding or partial retirement of the $235,000,000 of long-term debt of the Argentine Government outstanding in this market engaged the attention of investment bankers last week. Dr. Alberto Hueyo, former Argentine Minister of Finance, who arrived recently from England, conferred with several bankers here in the course of the week, and his presence stimulated discussion of the matter.

ARTISTIC designs and certain technological improvements in the making of rugs and carpets have resulted in the creation of a distinctly American product quite different from the hand-woven rugs of Europe and the East.

Broad gains in production, distribution and in construction marked last week's business activity in all parts of the country. Heavy rains, bringing relief to some drought-stricken areas, active consumer buying of both apparel and home furnishings and increased production schedules in many manufacturing lines were outstanding features of the week.

The French franc continued under pressure in the Foreign Exchange market here yesterday and $1,805,000 of gold was engaged in Paris for shipment to New York. The franc fell again to 6.58 1/4 cents and closed, unchanged from Friday's final price, at 6.58 1/16 cents, unchanged also compared with a week ago.

WRIGHT FIELD, DAYTON. THE Army Air Corps at its huge experimental plant here has developed equipment for the teaching of blind and instrument flying to student pilots. With the new device a plan is being studied which will enable them to obtain credit toward their necessary flying time while learning the difficult art of flying without the aid of a horizon.

Stocks were active and generally higher in the brief trading period yesterday, contrary to the usually dull and indecisive markets before long week-ends. Gains on the day ranged from fractions to 1 point, with steel issues notably strong on the news of higher prices for the fourth quarter of the year announced by one large producer on some finished and semi-finished items.
PARIS, Sept. 3. -- France has been welcoming Poland back into the fold this week as if that country were a prodigal son who had strayed away some years ago and was now returning repentant.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 5. -- In a mood tinged with almost religious solemnity, 6,000 delegates to the World Peace Congress vowed tonight that their closing session would only be a prelude to years of practical work.
