Thus with the closing of the doors of the Palais Cinquantenaires, the World Peace Congress became a permanent universal peace campaign.

GENEVA, Sept. 5. -- The increasing secrecy in Italy, Germany and Japan regarding their armaments has delayed publication of the League of Nations armament year-book, which has regularly appeared in mid-August but which may not appear before mid-September this year.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College and one of the foremost figures in the peace movement in this country, announced yesterday that she would break a lifelong allegiance to the Republican party and support President Roosevelt in this campaign because of his record, particularly in international relations.

With scrap iron prices back to the 1929 levels and difficulty experienced in filling orders, domestic consumption of the material this year will run around 30,000,000 tons as against 40,000,000 tons in the peak year of 1929, dealers declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- In the mathematics of national economy unemployment is still a discouraging constant. The latest government figures indicate that, despite the undoubted recovery displayed by other economic indices, there are still more than 11,000,000 jobless in the country.

MORE attention than ever is being given this year to making the use of motor vehicles safer, and some results have been accomplished, for the total of fatalities for the first seven months of 1936 is about 2 per cent less than for the corresponding period of 1935.

A crew from the New Dorp station of the United States Volunteer Life-Saving Corps won the annual lifeboat race of Staten Island stations at 5:30 o'clock last night when it covered a mile course in the lower New York Bay in 7 1/2 minutes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- Strength in foreign grain markets and an accumulation of over-night buying orders lifted wheat futures today as much as 1 cent a bushel at the opening of business on the Board of Trade, while corn was up 3/4 to 2 1/4 cents, the latter on September.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4. -- September was ushered in with general rains and cool weather in Missouri, and, as drought-hit farmers look over what is left and business looks around to see what the harvest will be, there is the comforting fact, established by competent surveys, that the State is not so badly off as it thought and that the outlook for the Fall and Winter is far from bleak.

IF advance bulletins are a trusty barometer, prosperity's sun bids fair to shine brighter this Fall than last upon the school and college campus. East and West, with little variation, larger applications and enrollments are expected.

SHANGHAI. THE Chinese are becoming more and more air-conscious as modern airlines are being extended in the interior of the country, while the plane is proving to be the most effective harbinger of civilization that the country has ever known.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 5. -- Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie refused today to review an indictment on which three alleged members of a Philadelphia gang have been held in the Cape May County jail since July 29 last in default of $10,000 bail each. They are awaiting trial. The defendants are Ignatius Lanzetti, Michael Falcone and Louis Del Rossi.

MANILA. -- Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, has announced that he will ask the current session of the Assembly to grant him flexible tariff powers to raise the current schedules by as much as 100 percent.

All the New England States will be found in the Republican column in November, with Maine giving the Landon-Knox ticket a two-to-one majority, Colonel Frank Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, predicted yesterday in an interview given aboard his special train in the Pennsylvania Station.

A letter signed by 125 members of the Lambs Club, requesting the facts in the case of George Bowles, a member of the club and veteran Broadway figure who is said to be held in Tahiti on a charge of murder, will be forwarded early this week to the French Consul General in New York, it was learned yesterday at the Club.

An elaborate plant for the manufacture of alcohol, with a long tunnel for the transportation of supplies between the sub-cellar and the fenced backyard of a house on another street, was uncovered last evening in a raid by Federal and city police on a three-story brick house at 166 President Street, between Henry and Hicks Streets, South Brooklyn.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- Skippers from the south shore of Long Island found the wind on Lake Ontario to their liking today and won two races, but the Californian defender, H.F. Beardslee's By-C from Newport Harbor, had a 1-point lead over Adrian Iselin's Ace from Western Long Island Sound in the Star Class world championship point standing.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4. -- The Third Federal Reserve District began the new month with indications of a continuance of recovery encouraging to producers and distributors and to the intermediate factors.

MISS WYNYARD'S following in the theatre is such that no play in which she appears could fail to run in London for several weeks. Her last appearance was in "Sweet Aloes," a piece which had, in itself, the seed of popularity; the result was one of those runs that one ceases to count in weeks and begins to reckon in months and years.

WILLIAM C. BULLITT, America's first Ambassador to Soviet Russia, will soon sail to France to head our embassy in Paris. He will take up his duties at a time when democratic France, ruled by a Socialist government, is disturbed by the dramatic struggle between fascism and communism which has the whole of Europe as its stage.

THOUGH he already had all the plays he could reasonably expect to offer in a season, Sam H. Harris has gone ahead and bought another one. Which, off-hand, must mean that Mr. Harris was impressed. Call it "Bright Rebel," wherein Stanley Young, a frequent reviewer of books for this journal, has assembled episodes in the life of Lord Byron from England to the final phase in Greece.

THE lads who followed the band on the first September Monday of 1894 have seen many changes in forty-two years, but none more astonishing than the development of Labor Day. The old-fashioned Labor Day parade has grown to a vast procession of holiday-makers off for the Summer's last long holiday week-end. And off in all directions.

The first official Steuben Day, in honor of General Frederick William von Steuben, will be celebrated on Sept. 17, the birthday of the Revolutionary War officer. On that day the Steuben Society of America will give a dinner and ball in the Hotel Astor to mark the culmination of efforts throughout the past decade to establish a legal holiday in New York State on General von Steuben's birthday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5. -- The monthly tonnage report of the Marine Department of the Chamber of Commerce reveals that there was a gain last month in arrivals over August, 1935, but that the departing tonnage figures showed a loss over last year, so it would appear that the total business was about even.

THE student body of the Stewart Technical School were taken on an inspection tour of the United States Naval Aircraft Factory at Philadelphia recently. The aircraft engine overhaul shop and the airplane shop in which the navy airplanes are repaired and built drew much interest.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- The Franco-Polish negotiations promise to reach a successful conclusion of their first stage tomorrow, when General Edward Rydz-Smigly, Polish dictator, who is here again after his tour of the Northeastern fortifications, will see President Albert Lebrun at Rambouillet.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 5 (AP). -- A psychiatrist described chronic alcoholism today as a childish "disease."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- Ten international unions having about one-third the membership of the American Federation of Labor became deprived today of the privileges and benefits of federation affiliation because they refused to withdraw from the Committee for Industrial Organization in accordance with the thirty-day ultimatum of the federation's executive council.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 5. -- A four-State drought conference, set against the background of an enthusiastic reception by this city, closed today the tour on which President Roosevelt set out from Washington Aug. 25.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan and Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd left Albany today with members of their staffs to pass the week-end holiday at their respective Summer places, but it was evident that the much-needed holiday will not be particularly carefree for either of them.
PARIS, Sept. 5 (AP). -- Syria, a French mandate, will be launched on its way to independence, officials announced tonight, in a treaty with France ending the mandate in 1939.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The Newark Bears fell into third place in the International League tonight as they bowed to Baltimore, 5 -- 1, behind Cliff Melton's five-hit pitching. The Newark team now trails Rochester by a half game in the second-place fight.

BOSTON, Sept. 5. -- More than 100 members of the National Puzzlers League, Inc., and the American Cryptogram Association met here today for their annual joint convention. The convention, the 106th semi-annual one for the former group and the fourth annual gathering of the latter, will continue through Monday.

Followers of the markets did not wait for the traditional Labor Day signal for a quickening of trading activity. Trading in stocks and bonds increased measurably last week, with prices yesterday substantially above those of the Saturday before.

Fairfield County, Conn., is destined to show a steady increase in population because of its natural attractions and proximity to New York, and should prepare for this growth immediately by development of an adequate park and parkway system and more extensive methods of stream protection in a report by the Regional Plan Association.

A HANDBOOK of the collections of the Walters Art Gallery of Baltimore has just been issued by the board of trustees. In his foreword B. Howell Griswold Jr., president, expresses the hope "that it will prove of great value to the public, and that a study of its contents will result in deeper appreciation of the gift made by Henry Walters."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5 (AP). -- The Cardinals cut the Giants' lead in the National League to two and a half games today by scoring a 3-2 victory over Cincinnati while the Giants were dropping a doubleheader. The Cardinals' triumph stopped a Red winning streak at seven straight.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 5. -A new speed record for material ejected from an exploding star was established by Nova Lacertae, the "new" star discovered on June 18.

WITH THE REBEL ARMY AT IRUN, Spain, Sept. 5. -- Rebel troops pursued Leftists today as they retreated from Irun in two directions, toward Fuenterrabia and the sea and along the nine-mile road to San Sebastian. As the Leftists have no alternatives now but surrender or suicide, the final stages of the struggle here are expected to be desperate.

A couple of pitchers who once fell short of New York hurling requirements came back to the Polo Grounds yesterday disguised as Boston Bees and reduced that Giant lead over the Cardinals in the pennant fight to two and one-half games.

Party controversies over one European governmental system or another are strongly reflected in New York's foreign-language papers in their attitude toward the political situation in their respective mother countries. A survey reveals that in their columns the struggle that has been carried to these shores from the Continent and the Far East goes on vehemently in spite of the fact that in most cases the issue has already been settled abroad.

KINERHOOK, N.Y. -- One hundred years after his election to the Presidency a serious effort is to be launched this month for the creation of a national monument to Martin Van Buren at Lindenwald, the estate near Kinderhook, N.Y., where the eighth President lived for many years and where he died in 1862.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Sept. 5. -- New Jersey exhibitors carried off three championships today to furnish several of the high lights as the annual Orangeburg Horse Show came to a close before another large assemblage grouped about the mountainside ring at the local fair grounds.

Los Angeles is steadily growing as an important market for sports wear, ready-to-wear and varied novelty goods, including pottery and glassware, it was reported yesterday by Nell Petree, president of James McCreery Co., Inc., who returned last week from a vacation trip to the Coast, which included a study of the Los Angeles market possibilities for the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, of which the McCreery store is a unit.

THIS novel rings all the changes from "Auld Lang Syne" to "God Save the King." In it no less than four generations of a well-born English family have been exhibited in the splendor of their period costumes, conventions and sentiments.
MADRID, Sept. 5 (Passed by the Censor). -- The new government headed by Francisco Largo Caballero issued the following declaration this evening:

CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- Trade and other indices continued their advance this week. Sales of leading department stores here during the last days of August were at a pace about equal to the best of the Christmas shopping period last year.

The flash-back method is cleverly made tree of here, in a mystery novel which has no detective, either Amateur or professional, and no detection at all. In a prologue which occupies less than two pages the author sets down a newspaper headline which states that a "socially prominent actress" has been murdered, and follows that with a handful of comment from the newspaper's readers.

THE croix de guerre, with morning glories intertwined about two early birds, is awarded this year to the Midtown Galleries for the earliest reopening of the new season. An exhibition of new work by members of the group was put on last week and will be current throughout the month.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- French Leftists, who have been expecting the Loyalists to win in Spain, now see that their hopes may be dashed and as a result there has been a violent reaction against Premier Leon Blum's policy of non-intervention.

Arriving from Southampton and Cherbourg today, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary has on board Lord Fermoy, Sir Archibald Page, chairman of the Central Electrical Board, London; Sir William Firth, chairman of the South Wales Tin-plate Corporation; Sir Claude Reading, governor of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, and John St. Clair Harvey, wine exporter.

Detective Henry Widder of the Wilson Avenue station in Brooklyn has a sense of humor. It lies a bit on the punning side, but he thinks that if a man on the force can get a laugh out of the job now and then that doesn't matter.

MADRID, Sept. 6. -- Spain's defending armies, in a seemingly decisive turn in the civil war, announced today the recapture of the vitally important Talavera de la Reina sector, key to the southern door to Madrid.

A few days ago Frank Marchesani, a mason, of 663 Hillside Place, North Bergen, N.J., built an elaborate mouse trap and placed it in the cellar of his home. He was confident it would capture a mouse that had been living in the cellar for four months, despite Marchesani's efforts to catch it.

The 6-year-old brown gelding Sir Gareth has been assigned top weight for the featured Adjacent Hunts Trophy race today at the annual Adjacent Hunts Racing Association one-day meeting at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club in Rye. In a field of nine timber-toppers the son of Sir Gallahad III-Sandy Land will carry an impost of 158 pounds.

Critical financial and political conditions in France and Spain made for an irregular trend in foreign exchange values last week. The French franc hovered around its low for the year, at 6.58 1/4 cents, bringing in its wake fresh engagements of gold in Paris, while the Madrid unit slumped to a new low for the year at 11.92 cents.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6. -- There was a fair volume of business in futures in the cotton market here last week and active trading in spots. While profit-taking by longs and an increase of hedge selling at times, halted the upward tendency of prices, there was an increased volume of buying, particularly toward the close of the week, and this absorbed the hedges.

Unwittingly, MUSSOLINI has made peace between Great Britain and Egypt. Fear of Italian colonial ambitions in Africa has shown British and Egyptian statesmen that their common interests far outweigh their differences, which for more than fifty years have troubled their relations.

GENEVA, Sept. 6. -- The first World Youth Congress closed its week's session here tonight, unanimously adopting a report that declares: "The peace we want is a heroic peace that will satisfy the virile virtues that some persons contend are fulfilled only by war."
BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- Money rates here at the end of August were one-quarter of 1 per cent higher than at the end of July. Yesterday the day loan rate began to weaken and today it was 3 3/4 per cent.

The participation of trade unions throughout the nation in politics on an organized and independent basis was described as "the most significant single fact before the laboring population and its friends in this year's Labor Day celebration" in a statement issued yesterday by the American Labor party and union leaders supporting its program in this State.

Primarily under the influence of crop developments, prices of cotton moved up last week after declining for five successive weeks. At the close Saturday, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains in the period of 10 to 21 points.

The City Fusion party plans to name its own candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen. A joint statement issued yesterday by Fusion leaders indicated that a dozen or more persons were under consideration.
Real estate trading in the metropolitan area over the week-end was featured by sales of homes in Westchester County and the purchase of a large tract by the developers of Candlewood Lake.

BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's press organ admits that after three years of forced production, Germany's industrial plants need renovation. To this, however, employers retort that they lack the necessary funds for rehabilitation.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6. -- Anticipating that the Nuremburg Nazi Congress may be largely devoted to lambasting communism and the Soviet Union, the official press here greeted it today as the "revolting buffoonery" of a hypocritical regime hoping by wild cries of "Bolshevist menace" to blackmail the bourgeois world into furnishing allies for a crusade against the U.S.S.R.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Making their first appearance of the season, the New York Football Yankees, metropolitan entry in the newly formed American League, defeated the Locust Valley Yellow Jackets, 6 to 0, in an exhibition game before a crowd of 5,000 on the local high school field today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 6.--Three types of newly discovered forces locked up within the hearts of atoms, each one of them greater than gravitation, electricity, magnetism or any known force, will be described before a comprehensive symposium on nuclear physics on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences.

Francis J. Robinson, president of the Waverley Boat Club, one of the oldest rowing clubs on the Hudson River, revealed last night that the clubhouse faces demolition by the city unless it is removed by Thursday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6. -- Development of a compound among the benzoates which, in clinical tests at the Jersey City Medical Center, has given relief to arthritis sufferers was reported tonight to the American Chemical Society, which opens its ninety-second general meeting here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP). -Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Labor Department's Women's Bureau, said today that "facts and figures" show "women's special need of labor laws to be just as great as it has been in the past."
NANKING, China, Sept. 6. -- Intense gratification is voiced in government circles here over settlement of the Kwangsi problem, as signalized by the issuance of three government mandates yesterday.

The theatre's idea of a holiday is an extra performance in the afternoon, and so the dozen productions now on the Broadway boards will have Labor Day matinees today. For all but one, it really will be an extra showing, as they are holding to their midweek and Saturday matinee engagements, too.
HENDAYE, France, Sept. 6. -- The story of the capture of Irun and the nerve-racking experiences of the hostages held in Fort Guadalupe can now be told in greater detail.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 6. -- Fifteen thousand persons attending the World Peace Congress open-air sports and artistic pageant here today suddenly learned that Dolores Ibarruri, the Spanish workers' idol, known as La Pasionaria, was in their midst.
HENDAYE, France, Sept. 6. -- Eager Spanish Rebel armies, their red and gold flags flying from Irun and Fuenterrabia, fought their way toward San Sebastian today from the east and south.

A happy thought and something more is the course of action decided upon by the Midwest Institute of Human Relations recently meeting in Appleton, Wis. It has declared in favor of a whispering campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- With organized labor facing a critical period in which the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization doubtless will fight out for dominance, Secretary of Labor Perkins reported today, on the eve of the forty-ninth anniversary of Labor Day, that employment conditions had greatly improved and that all States were now cooperating with the Social Security Board for the establishment of social security benefits.

When 19-year-old Henry Struck left his home at 79-17 Roosevelt Avenue, Jackson Heights, yesterday morning, bound for the third annual meet of the Airplane Model Builders Exchange in Marine Park, Brooklyn, he and several young friends tenderly carried a large cardboard carton full of flying gadgets.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- All leading grain markets of the world, with the exception of Buenos Aires, were active and unsettled last week but closed higher, with small to good-sized net gains.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 5. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.7, which compares with 83.8 the week before, 84.1 two weeks before, 84 three weeks before and 84.3 four weeks before.

The ordinary milk consumer, like me, would feel surer that the milk distributors are dealing fairly with him if while stating why they must raise the price of milk they would include statements of their executives' salaries, their advertising bills, the profits on their stock, and whether their stock represents a fair valuation of their properties.

SUGAR HILL, N.H., Sept. 6. -- Mrs. Charlotte Barbour of New York gave a picnic last night at her Sugar Hill estate. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Hamilton, Mr. and Mrs. John Jameson, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Cornell, Mr. and Mrs. Milton L. Cornell, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Parker, William B. Symmes Jr. and Curtis Andrews.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- A projected meeting of thousands of Ku Klux Klansmen broke up in disappointment tonight after a concessionaire imbibed too much from his own bottle just before a scheduled religious service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Crediting his much-criticized spending policies with a great share of the responsibility for the upturn in private business and employment, President Roosevelt in a fireside radio chat to the nation tonight outlined a program which would extend to the drought sufferers of the West "the same protecting arm which had shielded and raised up the industrial workers of the rest of the country."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Reform of the direct primary system, appearance of Cabinet members on the floors of Congress, creation of a single department of national defense and a more rigorous regulation of labor disputes were among some of the proposals made here this evening by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Nine-months-old James Edward Cook spent a quiet sabbath at the Leonard Kramp home in the village of North Baltimore today, unmindful that a scant block away his mother was mustering legal forces in a court fight for custody of the baby she gave away.

Mayor La Guardia, planning to make no Labor Day Speeches or comment, declared yesterday he thought his speech in 1934 at the Chicago World's Fair before the American Federation of Labor was "still timely today."

So far as markets were concerned, last week exhibited mostly the usual end-of-Summer, pre-holiday lethargy. Until the week-end, when a brief advance occurred, Stock Exchange prices were all but motionless. Even wheat and corn, after swinging idly up and down, ended Thursday at the previous week's closing prices, although with a belated rise next day.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 6. -- The New York rifle team No. One placed fourth in the Caswell small-bore match today with a score of 2,371, sixteen points below that of the American Legion East outfit which triumphed on a total of 2,387. Second place went to the New Jersey Civilians, who had 2,379, and third to the Ohio Civilians, also with 2,379.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Behind Frank Makosky's sparkling six-hit pitching, the Newark Bears stayed in the running for second place in the International League with a 13-2 triumph over Baltimore today. Makosky, ace relief twirler, went the distance for the winners.

Traffic moved in a comparative lull yesterday as stragglers left the city for a shortened Labor Day holiday. The pause gave a breathing spell to traffic police, railroad and bus officials to prepare for the greatest boom in travel today since the height of the travel-conscious era in 1929.

Colonel Bill Terry and Master Melvin Ott followed the trail of the vanquished across the Polo Grounds yesterday. Unapproached, almost unnoticed, the last of the Giant squad to leave the dugout, they strode dejectedly toward the clubhouse.

Gleanings from mailbag and notebook: It isn't often that an angler setting out to grab a mess of trout includes a .45 caliber revolver in his equipment. . . . Yet that's how F.F. Dunne of this city fared forth when he trekked into the Maine woods last month to secluded trout ponds. . . .

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 6. -- Harry E. Byram, 72, retired railroad executive who was shot in the head at his Westport mansion Friday morning, and his son-in-law, Don Burdick, 39, who is accused of the shooting, were reported recovering in Norwalk Hospital today.

The treacherous black Atlantic behind her, New York expanding like a fairy city before her eager feet, Mrs. Beryl Markham bounded into the lobby of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel last night at the end of her transatlantic journey for what she hopes will be quite a stay.

BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- The Boerse this week was partly under the influence of the 50 per cent increase in the corporation-prafits tax. After 1936 this will cost business an additional 500,000,000 marks each year. Industrial leaders not with apprehension that both an official communique and the party press contain new strictures against "anonymous capital."
OGDEN, Utah, Sept. 6 (AP).--Herbert Hoover headed eastward today into what he indicated would probably be the thick of the Republican national campaign.

F.C. Bouman, managing director of the Holland-America Line, arrived yesterday for a three-month stay in the United States. He will confer with officials of the New York office and make a tour of America.

Support by the Communist party in France has been regarded as essential to the stability of the Blum Ministry. The Communists number nearly ninety in the Chamber of Deputies, and without them the Popular Front, upon which Premier BLUM depends for his Government, would be much weakened.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The Zionist Organization of America made public here today messages from thirty United States Senators and Representatives expressing deep concern over the troubled situation in Palestine and expressing the hope and belief that Great Britain would not interfere with Jewish immigration or otherwise hinder the rebuilding of the Jewish homeland in Palestine.

This year Labor Day falls within the shadow of a major split in the American labor movement. The suspension of ten international unions for failing to withdraw from the Committee for Industrial Organization has now been formally announced by WILLIAM GREEN, president of the American Federation of Labor.

Two methods are now being employed to prevent the excessive use of money in political campaigns. One is the set of laws which puts a maximum on the amount a candidate may spend. The other is the spotlight of publicity through the requirement that, before and after an election, candidates must give an itemized accounting of their expenditures, and through the operation of Senate committees of inquiry.

SEVILLE, Spain, Sept. 6. -- Repudiation of the capitalistic system and nationalization of all public services are included in the twenty-seven point program of the Spanish Fascists, it was revealed today in a pamphlet circulated in rebel territory.

When the police raided a two-and-a-half-story dwelling yesterday in the exclusive Jamaica Estates, Central Queens, after neighbors had communicated their suspicions, it was disclosed that the entire interior had been altered to make room for stills.

BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- By airplane, by train, by motor and afoot more than a million Germans will be on their way tomorrow to Nuremberg. The following day will begin there the grandiose spectacle of the annual National Socialist Congress, the seventh in actual rotation, the fourth since the Nazi accession to power.

CANNES, France, Sept. 6. -- Forest fires that started in the Esterel Mountains, only a few miles from the Mediterranean seacoast here, are being blown by a high wind toward the villas of a large number of wealthy Americans and Europeans.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- With the score of races three to one against them after a morning contest, and only one more event needed by the Bermuda yachts to win the international series, the Long Island Sound Interclubs came back this afternoon to take the first four places in the fifth race.

LIBERTY CORNER, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Henry Wightman of Upper Montclair, who captured fourth place at the recent national soaring championships at Elmira, N.Y., loomed as the outstanding contender for the New Jersey State gliding title, winning two second places and one fourth place in the second day's events of the third annual New Jersey State championship glider meet here today on Schley Field.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Sept. 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert Spalding entertained a company of twenty today, with swimming and diving matches at Aston Magna, their home here. Luncheon was served beside the pool. Later in the afternoon Mr. Spalding appeared with the Jacques Gordon String Quartet before a crowded house at Music Mountain, Falls Village, Conn.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 6. -- A match that should be worth going miles to see will take place tomorrow morning when Charles H. Mayo Jr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Berry meet Frank Strafaci and Miss Dorothy Traung in the semi-final round of the second annual mixed foursomes golf championship at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

One of the modern church's "most obvious responsibilities" is to bring about a restoration of self-confidence," the Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, pastor of the South Congregational Church of Springfield, Mass., said in his sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church.

BERLIN, Sept. 5. -- The Boerse opened the week dull and weak in tone as a result of the increase in the corporation tax, and although a recovery ensued the volume of trading remained small. On the whole, movements of all groups were irregular.

Man's moral inadequacy to cope with the welter of confusion brought on by his own scientific achievement was termed "the modern dilemma" by the Rev. Dr. John S. Whale, president of Cheshunt College, Cambridge, England, in his last morning sermon yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

SEATTLE, Sept. 6 (AP). -- A multiplicity of issues and a record number of candidates confronted Washington State voters as they considered choices to be made Tuesday on a type of primary ballot they have not used before.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP). -- William L. Hutcheson, director of the labor division of the Republican National Committee, in a statement prepared for Labor Day, called on labor to stand against what he termed "the un-American theory advanced by radicals" and asserted that "these evil influences never became a menace until the last three years."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Shipping Board Bureau officials disclosed today they are gathering comprehensive data to determine whether the government is aiding in maintaining any "non-essential" transoceanic trade routes.

With Warner Brothers' new singing star, Jeanne Madden, hurling the champagne magnum, the Warner Vitaphone studio in Brooklyn will launch production on its new 20,000-square-foot sound stage tomorrow afternoon. All the leading screen personalities in town and some from the theatre, too, have been invited to the ceremonies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Indications are that the crop of corn in the United States this year will be the smallest in fifty-five years. The average of five leading statisticians who have covered the Corn Belt thoroughly this season is 1,416,000,000 bushels.

Preaching yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Rev. Dr. Floyd Van Keuren, executive secretary of the Social Service Commission of the diocese, characterized as "sinister" the movement of radical labor for political control.

A slight expansion in Federal aid to needy high school students here was assured yesterday when Mark A. McCloskey, regional director of the National Youth Administration, announced that $500,000 had been allocated to keep 10,500 secondary school students, 16 years old and over, from leaving their classrooms to glut the outside job market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The number of civilian employes in the executive branch of the Federal Government at the end of July was 830,622, a gain of 6,363 in one month, the Civil Service Commission stated today. This increase was due largely to the regular Summer employment in the Engineer and Quartermaster Corps of the War Department outside of the District of Columbia.

President Roosevelt will open his active campaigning for re-election, it was indicated yesterday, with a speech addressing the Democratic State Convention in Syracuse on Sept. 29, after the convention has nominated Governor Lehman and the other candidates on the State ticket.

The United States Lines will receive bids tomorrow on the construction of a new ship which will be operated as a sister ship of the liners Manhattan and Washington in the transatlantic trade. It is understood that the New York, Federal and Newport News shipbuilding companies have prepared estimates.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Polo's most important handicap event, the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup, started with an upset today at the Sands Point Club when Roslyn took two goals on handicap from the Hurricanes and defeated them without needing the allowance, 11 to 7.

Man is more sacred than work, and industry should recognize that fact, the Rev. John King Benedict declared yesterday at the Centenary Methodist Episcopal Church, Washington Avenue and East 166th Street.

Thousands of New Yorkers went rural yesterday, but thousands of out-of-towners took their places in midtown. Times Square became again a combination outdoor market, glamorous promenade and clearing house of information.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP). -- The Athletics dropped both games of a double bill with Washington today as a pair of veterans, Earl Whitehill and Monte Weaver, scored victories. The scores were 7 to 1 and 7 to 5.

Any number of dogs and cats have trapped themselves in chimneys and drainpipes. But yesterday was probably the first time that the police were able to release an imprisoned animal and say: "Voila! We did it all with mirrors!"

PLYMOUTH, England, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Communist plans for a united Popular Front in Great Britain are likely to receive scant encouragement from organized British labor when the Sixty-eighth Trades Union Congress opens here tomorrow.

TULSA, Okla., Sept. 6 (AP). -- Senator Clark of Missouri told the convention of the Oklahoma American Legion today that revelatiohs made by the Senate Munitions Investigating Committee "had their effect -around the world," and predicted passage by the next Congress of "drastic permanent neutrality legislatior_ necessary to safeguard the nation," "

Twelve firemen of Engine Company 222 spread a net in the street in front of a tenement house at 14 Reid Avenue, Brooklyn, at about 11 o'clock last night in a dramatic effort to save the life of a 2-year-old child threatened by a madman.
DALTON, Ga., Sept. 6 (AP). -- A mob lynched a 21-year-old Negro accused of an attempted attack on a white woman near here early today after hustling the prisoner away from the Whitfield County jail.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- For the tenth time this season the Dodgers today faced the high hurdle of a fourth straight victory and fell ignominiously on their several faces, emerging from the farewell fiesta with the Phillies in great embarrassment, and on the short end of a 7-5 count.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Scientists digging in ancient Babylon ruins reported evidence today that the Cyclops which captured Ulysses, legendary hero of Greece, had a counterpart in an older civilization.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson gave a dinner tonight at Lenoir, their place here, for Mr. and Mrs. John Magee of Pebble Beach, Calif., who are passing the holiday week-end with them. Earlier in the day, Mr. and Mrs. Dwight F. Davis gave a luncheon for Mr. and Mrs. Magee at Bayberry Land, their home in the Shinnecock Hills.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- An advance of 2,375,000 in the circulation of the Bank of England after the decline which began in the first week of August stirred no comment here. For one thing it as good as corresponded to the rise which occurred in the same week last year and it merely represented a normal expansion which develops at the end of the month.

A reorganization of the public relations staff of the Association of American Railroads with a view to bringing about better public understanding of the railroads and their progress has been announced by J.J. Pelley, president. This followed the start of an advertising campaign employing magazines, newspapers, displays, direct mail, films and other mediums.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Rear Admiral Frank B. Upham, chairman of the Navy General Board, who served on the Olympia, flagship of Admiral George Dewey, during the Spanish-American War and has received the Navy Cross for distinguished services during the World War, will retire from active duty Oct. 1, having reached the statutory retirement age, the Navy Department announced today.

PARIS, Sept. 6. -- General Edward Rydz-Smigly left Paris for Warsaw this evening after a week spent in France, during which the Franco-Polish alliance was restored to all its former vigor. There is no question of the satisfaction felt on both sides at the renewal of this important friendship which greatly strengthens France's hand at a time when she needs support desperately.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- Although still maintaining their confident tone, with speculative activity, notably in oil shares, showing signs of increasing, the security markets here as a whole appear a little weary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP). -Memos reminding him of vacancies in more than a dozen high-ranking posts were before President Roosevelt today after his return to the capital, giving fresh hope to many aspirants that he soon will fill several of them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- An appeal to women to honor the birthday of Jane Addams today by beginning intensive work for the Peoples' Mandate to Governments to End War, in a determination to obtain action in the coming Inter-American Peace Conference to banish war from this part of the world, was made today by Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College and chairman of the organization in the Western Hemisphere.

PARIS, Sept. 6. -- Events of the past week have demonstrated only too clearly that labor unrest is far from ended in France. It is beginning to look as if this Fall would bring new and serious trouble if the present trends continue.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- Financial circles here are of the opinion that while the Blum government has declared itself plainly opposed to devaluation of the franc, it may be forced to it by pressure of the growing discrepancy between French and foreign prices.

PARIS, Sept. 6. -- Harassed by powerful Communist pressure to abandon France's neutral attitude toward Spain in favor of the Loyalists, Premier Leon Blum this afternoon made an unexpected address before the Seine Socialist Federation in which he frankly admitted that he and his associates hoped to see the Rebels beaten, but he firmly refused to alter his government's neutrality policy.

LONDON, Sept. 5. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 72.8 on Sept. 2, compared with 72.1 a fortnight before, 72.4 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- Financial circles here professed to discern this week a slight relaxation in the tension in international affairs, although the Boerse did not respond to any such improvement. Those who are associated closely with Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Reich Minister of Economics, affirmed this week that his recent conversations in Paris were confined to the general political and economic situation and dealt concretely only with the exchange of goods between Germany and France.

CHICAGO, Sept 6. -- Conditions in the corn trade are more mixed here. Operations are fairly heavy in futures, with most of the local traders last week on the bull side during breaks. Nevertheless, buyers are reported to have taken fair profits on price upturns. Spreading operations between wheat and corn furnish a large part of the trading activity.

ALMA, Mich., Sept. 6 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, of the Alma College Class of '97, who arrived in this little town in 1893 with $25 to work his way, came back today in a special six-car campaign train as Republican Vice-Presidential nominee.

TOPEKA, Sept. 6. -- With the drought conference with President Roosevelt behind him, Governor Landon is giving thought to the speeches he will make on his next campaign trip. He will speak at Des Moines on Sept. 21 or 22 and then will continue with major speeches at Milwaukee and Minneapolis and short, rear-platform appearances at towns in Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin.

Milk at 11 cents a quart, the minimum price permitted by the State Control Board for retail sale, may be obtained in New York City today at more than 1,500 stores and from fifteen cruising milk trucks.

It will be the running offense of the College All-Stars against the passing attack of the New York Giants when these elevens open the metropolitan football season at the Polo Grounds tomorrow night -- if the final stiff preparatory workouts held by the teams yesterday bear any significance.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 6. -- The seventeenth annual overnight race from the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club to Stratford Shoals and return ended in a victory today for Valencia, the New York Yacht Club thirty-two footer owned by John B. Shethar.

The United Spanish War Veterans have, according to your issue of today, issued a communique on the unemployment situation. The solution which they recommend consists in sending 10,000,000 aliens "back where they came from."

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, issued a Labor Day message yesterday in which he promised job security to all diligent workers among the 202,000 on the WPA rolls in this city.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 6. -After Sept. 13 none will be employed by the Insular Government whether Governor or scrubwoman, who does not sign an oath of allegiance to defend the Constitution of the United States and the laws of Puerto Rico against all enemies, as provided by a measure sponsored by the Socialist Senator Reyes Delgado in the last Legislature.
MARGATE, N.J., Sept. 6. -- The second annual regatta of the Absecon Island Yacht Club was productive of one world record and plenty of thrills for more than 15,000 spectators today.

Longmans, Green are experimenting this Fall by publishing two new novels by Ursula Parrott in one volume, with the pages so arranged that neither novel takes precedence. Either way the book is opened the reader finds the start of a novel, and both books end near the volume's center. The titles are "When Summer, Returning," and "Though You Be Far." Publication date is Sept. 16.

PARIS, Sept. 6. -- In a ceremony coinciding with the celebration of the 179th anniversary of the birth of Marquis de Lafayette and the twenty-second anniversary of the first battle of the Marne, General John J. Pershing today presented the American Hospital in Paris with a scroll conveying greetings from the United Hospital Fund of New York.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 6 (AP). -- The Reds put another crimp in the pennant hopes of the Cardinals today, taking a double-header, 5 to 3 and 8 to 4, to drive the second-place club three full games behind the league-leading Giants, who lost to Boston.

ROME, Sept. 6. -- Italy resumed today large-scale military operations in Ethiopia after three months of little activity. A motorized column formed of two detachments of Eritrean and Ethiopian soldiers left Addis Ababa to round up Rebels in territories not occupied by Italian troops before the beginning of the rainy season.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- Financial circles here hold that weakness of the franc is attributable less to capital exports than to trade or banking settlements. The demand for foreign exchange for such settlements has all the more influence on exchange rates as the holders of foreign currency fail to repatriate their funds, because of uncertainty over the internal and external situation.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 6. -- A sharp-hitting and alert Argentine polo team, preparing for the forthcoming Cup of the Americas series, rode to an 11-to-5 victory over Aurora in a seven-period exhibition on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Although Corporation Counsel Aaron Simmons has served legal papers for the condemnation of the $2,500,000 plant of the New Rochelle Water Company, which this city hopes to acquire as a municipal system, it was reported today that the company would contest the legality of the action.

The Bureau of Recreation of the Park Department branched out yesterday from the promotion of quartet singing and succeeded without difficulty in persuading 4,000 or more persons to lend their voices to a community sing on the mall in Central Park. Singing will be repeated on the mall each Sunday afternoon until cold weather.
ALBANY, Sept. 6 (AP). -- New York State children are now required to remain in school until they are 16; heretofore they have been able to obtain work certificates at 14.

POLAND, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The New York Milk Producers Federation, Inc., whose president, Stanley Piseck, had threatened to call a strike on Wednesday, will not issue a strike call at least until after the conference on Saturday called by Peter Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, at Governor Lehman's order.
WHITEFIELD, N.H., Sept. 6. -- The Yale Forty Niners invited 200 friends to attend an informal entertainment at the Chase Barn Theatre here last night.

THE Man From Down Under is on his way back to the land of the wallaby and duckbilled platypus, but he paused long enough in the vicinity of the Golden Gate to mail the following communication under postmark of San Francisco:

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 6. -- Edlu, the ocean-going yawl of Commodore Rudolph J. Schaefer of the Larchmont Yacht Club, was the first craft to finish today in the 232-mile race from Stamford to Vineyard Sound and return.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The text of President Roosevelt's address follows:

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 6 (AP). -- Henry Picard, Hershey Country Club professional, equaled his own course record of 67, 6 under par, today to win the fourth annual $5,000 Hershey open golf championship with a total of 287, 5 under perfect figures for the seventy-two-hole route.

The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday an expedition would leave New York tomorrow for Anticosti Island in the Gulf of St. Lawrence to study deer development on the island and to make a collection of the large and small mammals to be found there.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,156,514,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

The Atlantic Ocean has twice been spanned by airplanes in the last week. Last Thursday DICK MERRILL, veteran air mail pilot, and HARRY RICHMAN, the actor, flew from New York to Wales in record-breaking time. They crossed the North Atlantic between Newfoundland and the British coast in about ten hours.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6.--The Third World Power Conference, with more than 3,000 delegates representing practically every nation in the world in attendance, will convene in Washington tomorrow.
We should like to correct am error in THE TIMES of Sept. 4 and register some observations regarding the column in the same issue by Arthur Krock.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- H.F. Beardslee and By-C, the California defender of the world's Star Class championship, still had a one-point advantage to top the series after the fourth race was sailed on Lake Ontario today, but his chief rival, Adrian Iselin, beat him to the finish with Ace.

Emulating Sidney Wood's rally against J. Gilbert Hall, John McDiarmid of Princeton University came back after losing the first two sets to defeat Frank Bowden of New York yesterday and preserve the status quo in the national championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Johnny Goodman of Omaha, former national open champion and No. 1 player on the United States Walker Cup team, turned back two rivals today as the Arcola Country Club's invitation golf tournament progressed through the second round.
MADRID, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Julio Alvarez del Vayo, new Socialist Foreign Minister, demanded today a full report on the incident involving an attempted bombing of the United States destroyer Kane.

Catholic parents who fail to provide a Catholic education for their children are unwittingly potential instruments of the Reds, the Rev. Matthew Golden asserted yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 6 (AP). -William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, called tonight for a new national effort to regulate hours of work and increase purchasing power.
MONTAUK, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Sutphen of East Hampton were dinner hosts at the Montauk Yacht Club last night to Mr. and Mrs. Preston Lee Sutphen and Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Irons.

Price advances for fourth-quarter deliveries featured the iron and steel markets last week, as producers entered September with current consumption holding up and activity in the raw-materials markets undiminished, according to the magazine Steel.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6 -- Mr. and Mrs. C. Oliver O'Donnell entertained a group of about sixty with a dinner and music at the Clambake Club tonight.

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 6. -- The Brooklyn Dodgers of the National Football League gave an impressive exhibition as they opened their campaign tonight with a 21-0 triumph over the Stapleton Buffaloes in a non-league battle. The game was played at the Freeport Stadium before 3,000 persons.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP). -- The charred and tangled wreckage of an airplane yielded the body of a tenth victim today following the crash and destruction by flames of the big sight-seeing craft in Buttermilk Hollow last night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- High prices for tenderloins and other cuts of pork have caused increased consumption of beef and reduced the consumption of pork products. Dressed beef carcasses here are selling at 8 to 15 cents a pound, compared with 17 1/2 to 27 1/2 cents for pork loins.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Addressing an audience of about 500 persons here this afternoon, Norman Thomas, Socialist nominee for President, charged Frank Hague, Democratic leader of New Jersey, with responsibility for defeat of the Anti-Labor Injunction Bill fostered by organized labor in this State last Spring.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 6.--Governor Lehman, at his home in Purchase today, closed a telegraph key, sending an electric impulse to Syracuse that marked the opening of the ninety-sixth annual New York State Fair.

President BUTLER'S address at Southampton yesterday, which has by now become an annual fixture, was more specific and detailed than some of its predecessors. He limited himself to a few subjects, all of them having to do with laws and governmental practices in which he argued strongly for a reform.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP). -- Heavy hitting drove both starting pitchers -- Curt Davis and Jim Weaver -- from the mound today as the Pirates beat the Cubs, 5 to 4, for their second victory in the last game of a series of three.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 6. -- Coming on with a rush after the intermission, C.V. (Sonny) Whitney's Old Westbury four triumphed over a Texas quartet led by Tom Mather, 9 to 6, in a practice match before 4,000 persons at Bostwick Field today.
A cry of pain from the center of a group of skylarking prisoners during the afternoon recreation hour on Harts Island yesterday, resulted in momentary turmoil and confusion.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday that a group of commercial organizations and shippers in the New York metropolitan district had filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a reply to exceptions recently made by the Eastern railroads on the proposal for an official metropolitan district under the new Federal Motor Truck Act.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Breaking all its own world's records, held since 1930, Newark Airport showed marked increases in passenger, mail and express traffic in the first six months of 1936, according to figures compiled by Richard Aldworth, superintendent of the airport, and made public today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- John A. Byers, a fugitive, who escaped from the Middlesex County workhouse on Aug. 25, was recaptured this afternoon by County Detective J. Stephen Drosdick on Route 25 between Hightstown and Freehold, several miles from here.

BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- The belated drive of the Red Sox to salvage something from the wreckage of a disastrous campaign was still moving along gayly today when, to the delight of a near-capacity crowd of 31,000, Manager Joe Cronin's men flattened the startled Yankees in both ends of a double-header.

ALBANY, Sept. 6. -- Up to Sept. 1, 12,691 new stock companies were formed this year in this State, against 12,690 for the corresponding period in 1935, according to a report issued today by the Bureau of Corporations of the Department of State.

PARIS, Sept. 5. -- The tendency of foreign exchange quotations continues generally unfavorable to the franc. In terms of the United States dollar, France's currency unit again sank to its gold-export point this week. The Netherlands and Swiss rates also were at a level to draw gold from Paris.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 72 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the rate in the two preceding weeks. Only minor fluctuations have taken place since the middle of July.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- There will be no explanation by District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan as to why he paid for his trip to Europe in 1935 with $1,300 in cash, and the whole subject of his financial transactions will be dropped, so far as the hearings before Governor Lehman are concerned, it was indicated today by both the prosecution and the defense.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Speaking before an audience estimated at more than 80,000 Illinois members of the National Union for Social Justice, Father Charles E. Coughlin denied today that the Vatican had intervened in any way to curb his political activities.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 6. -- Unless the eleventh-hour efforts of Emir Abdullah, Ibn Hussein and some level-headed Arab leaders who realize the gravity of the situation are successful in persuading the Arabs to call off their strike and cease violence, Palestine will be under martial law the latter half of this month.

Mr. Barrett is apparently of the opinion that a gold certificate is ordinary currency and quotes the Supreme Court's decision in Nortz v. U.S. to substantiate his contention. A careful reading of that decision does not bear out the facts. Prior to Roosevelt a gold certificate always was considered, and in fact always was, a warehouse receipt for gold deposited with the government.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 6. -- That Rebel advance positions in widely separated parts of Southern Spain were being bitterly attacked tonight by Madrid forces was announced by General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, Seville commander, in a radio broadcast late tonight.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Harlem's pride, the 369th Infantry, said to be the only all-Negro National Guard regiment in the United States, moved into Camp Smith here today to begin the final two weeks' Summer encampment of the New York State National Guard.

The really important issue seems to be neglected in the current controversy over the present administration's gold philosophy. The important point is not whether the gold certificates were warehouse receipts or currency, nor whether the government had the right to embargo gold or to suspend gold redemption.

LIMA, Ohio, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Sheriff Ralph Marshall, asserting he was convinced "we are working on a murder case," sought today to penetrate a mystery surrounding the death of Fred Counts, 30, in a burning automobile and the disappearance of a friend.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Nine residents of Utica won prizes with their exhibits at the Universal Stamp Association, Inc., convention here, it was announced today at the close of the session. This city also was recognized by the re-election of Gordon E. Kienzle as international president.

Two members of the crew of the American Export liner Exochorda will appear this morning before a United States Commissioner in the Federal Building on charges growing out of a plot to smuggle narcotics. The two men, who have been held at the government Barge Office at South Ferry for questioning, are Erich Schiller, the ship's butcher, and Pedro Cueto, a pantryman.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- Casting financial caution to the winds a French Ministerial council approved today a bill to strengthen French military forces on land and sea and in the air. It is France's smashing answer to the raising of the period of conscript service by Germany.

Violence is to be answered by overpowering military force. At last, after nearly five months of patient adherence to a policy of conciliation, the British Government moves to establish military law in harried Palestine. Unless Arab terrorism and the strike against British authority are discontinued within the next few days, the High Commissioner, Sir ARTHUR GRENFELL WAUCHOPE, is to be replaced by Lieut. Gen. J.G. DILL; civil administration is to be superseded by military.

Delaware, one of the six faithful Republican sisters in '32, has been carried easily this year by the omnivorous Mr. FARLEY. In duty bound, the national committeeman for the State chimed in with his chief. These formalities are taken for granted. Mr. ROOSEVELT'S plurality over Mr. HOOVER was 2,700.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- While two New York businessmen slept in the Blackstone Hotel last night a thief -- or perhaps a procession of thieves -- marched in and out of their rooms.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Throngs of auction sale fans crowded into stately Castle Philipse today as Miss Elsie Janis, actress, disposed of a large assortment of furniture and bric-a-brac as the first move of what she described as "my new life."

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and its affiliate, the American Joint Reconstruction Foundation, appropriated $1,040,000 in 1935 to help Jews in Poland and other Eastern European countries, it was announced yesterday.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 7. -- King Edward of Great Britain was cordially greeted during his passage through Bulgaria today. This morning he crossed the Turkish-Bulgarian frontier, where several thousand peasants waited to present to him a bottle of the famous Bulgarian attar of roses in a bouquet of fresh roses.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- Long, lean and placid Carl Hubbell, pitching marvel of this and perhaps any other age, once again stepped into the breach for the Giants today and by his sheer wizardry sent Colonel Bill Terry's craft skimming once more on a straight course for the National League pennant.

Capacity audiences of 5,000 each attended afternoon and evening performances of opera at the Hippodrome yesterday. Alfredo Salmaggi's New York Hippodrome Opera Company presented "Aida" at the matinee and the double bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" at night.

FOR ten years, if not longer, those interested in the history of American culture and institutions have awaited the completion of one of the greatest lexicographical works ever undertaken, "A Dictionary of American English on Historical Principles." Part I, covering the letter "A" and a portion of the letter "B," is published today by the University of Chicago Press ($4).

ALBANY, Sept. 7. -- In anticipation of the offering on Wednesday of an issue of $55,000,000 emergency unemployment relief bonds of the State of New York, authorized by the voters last November, State Controller Morris S. Tremaine made public today a condensed report outlining the condition of the State's finances.

FOOTBALL already! That's rushing the season a bit. Perhaps the Giants and the College All-Stars are in tip-top shape for their scrimmaging this evening at the Polo Grounds, but the fans probably are all out of condition. There should be a little session of tackling the dummy before plunging into the thick of a new season.

Labor Day attendance at the leading picture houses reached a new high yesterday. Managers of the midtown theatres hung out the S.R.O. signs early in the morning and the signs remained throughout the day. The Music Hall with "Swing Time" did capacity business at 31,000.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The knights and women of the Ku Klux Klan fired a twenty-foot cross on top of Carmen Hill, near here, tonight, and brought to a close their first outdoor meeting since 1931 in this section.

Department store chains in 1934 earned a net merchandising profit of 4.4 per cent on sales, after paying out 71.7 per cent of sales for merchandise and incurring operating expenses of 23.9 per cent on sales, according to a report issued yesterday by the Bureau of Business Research of the Harvard Business School.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 7. -- The first of a series of Canadian refunding loans was announced this evening by Charles Dunning, Minister of Finance. It is for $100,000,000, of which more than $73,000,000 will be used for refunding and the remainder for general government purposes, and it includes for the first time in Canadian financial history an issue of perpetual bonds.

LOGA-NSPORT, Ind., Sept. ? (2P). -- Roy Stanberry, 42 years old, a re-I / jected suitor, shot and fatally wounded Mrs. Avanelta Ruth Klooz, I I 35, today and then made an unsuccessful attempt to kill himself as! I the police overtook him in fn auto-I mobile three miles north of Logans- I port.
The Department of Health added 2,300 retail stores yesterday to its list of 1,500 pledged to sell milk at 11 cents a quart.

ERLANGEN, Bavaria, Germany, Sept. 7. -- The annual convention here of the foreign section of the National Socialist party heard with out protest from any party functionary present a speech on the necessity of alienating citizens of German birth in foreign countries from their exclusive allegiance to such countries and preparing them to become instruments of the German Government if policy should ever require that.

Matthew Woll, third vice president of the American Federation of Labor, called yesterday on the warring factions in the American labor movement to compromise their differences and offer a united defense against the threat of war, fascism and communism.

ROME, Sept. 7.--A source close to the Italian Government tonight interpreted the visit of League Secretary Joseph A.C. Avenol as conclusive evidence that Italy had dropped her non-collaboration policy at Geneva.

Emileo and Savage were the stake winners at Aqueduct yesterday as a crowd estimated at 20,000, the largest since the Epinard-Ladkin race, turned out to see seven events. Postmaster General Farley and leaders of society were as eagerly scrutinized in their boxes as were the horses on the track.

Substantial gains in retail ad linage are expected to feature the Fall retail season, which gets actively under way this week. Thus far this year, the national increase in total retail linage has averaged around 7 per cent, but this figure is likely to move up to 10 per cent, if the optimistic sales expectancies for the closing four months of the year are realized.

The belief that the administrative staff of the Emergency Relief Bureau could be cut more than 70 per cent without impairing efficiency was expressed by James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, in a letter published yesterday in the ERB Staff Reporter, journal of the A.W.P.R.A. council of the American Federation of Government Employes.

The city's contributions toward the support of free patients in private hospitals have increased 79.79 per cent in the last five years, according to a report made public yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 7. -- Members of the Lenox Club and their house guests, 150 altogether, gathered at the club house today for the annual Labor Day luncheon, Mrs. Edwards Spencer had forty-six at her table and among others who entertained were Mr. and Mrs. David T. Dana, Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. de Gersdorff, Mr. and Mrs. George K. Livermore, Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay C. Hoguet and Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Procter.
" There are some conveniences in connection with fishing, however small, that help to round out the day's sport and send you home with the feeling that all's well with the world," writes J.R.

TORONTO, Sept. 7 (Canadian Press). -- Miss Helen Stephens, Fulton (Mo.) flash, continued to dominate women's track events at the Labor Day meet at the Canadian National Exhibition today. The husky American girl carried off honors in the 100-yard dash and the invitation 220-yard event.
DENVER, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Forecasts of fair weather supported the prediction of a record primary election vote tomorrow when Colorado Democrats select their nominees for Senator and Governor.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 7. -- The Roslyn Rifle and Revolver Club of Brooklyn, N.Y., dropped 43 points in the Remington Trophy small-bore team match today and finished in fifth place with a total of 757 out of a possible 800. Pietrowski was high man with 194.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Fugitive, the aged chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. G.H. Bostwick, and Richard E. Mellon's 6-year-old brown gelding, The Stag II, carried off the principal honors in the sixth annual Adjacent Hunts Racing Association meeting today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.
NUREMBERG, German, Sept. 7. -- This City, normally a community of 407,000 inhabitants, presents today the aspect of a medieval nucleus surrounded by immense camps.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Sept. 7.--After being 4 down to George T. Dunlap Jr. and Miss Charlotte Glutting, two of the country's foremost golfers in their respective spheres, with only seven holes left to play, Frankie Strafaci and Miss Dorothy Traung today staged a sensational uphill fight to win the annual mixed foursomes championship at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club. The score was 1 up.

Dancers of many countries joined yesterday afternoon in the folk festival in Washington Square, surrendering their consciousness of nationality as they mingled in the traditional dances of their homelands.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Two officials of the American Medical Association announced today they were protesting to the American Chemical Society against what they termed "unwarranted, premature and harmful publicity" in connection with the announcement of a new preparation for the treatment of arthritis.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- Ignoring Premier Leon Blum's warning that he would not change his neutrality policy toward Spain, the metal workers of the Paris region carried out their one-hour "warning strike" this afternoon.

Columbia had thirty-six football aspirants working out yesterday at Baker Field in the Lions' first practice session of the season. It was a predominantly youthful squad with fourteen sophomores, sixteen juniors and six seniors on hand for a double drill.

The Port of New York Authority yesterday hailed the publication by the Eastern railroads of new rates on unboxed automobiles between the Middle West and Gulf ports as a move to end long-standing discrimination against New York and other ports on the North Atlantic.

Miss Elizabeth Kompa, 1935 national outdoor back-stroke champion and runner-up to Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett for the same crown this year, shattered the world 400-meter long course dorsal record at the invitation swimming meet held at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

All commodity and Stock Exchanges in the United States closed for the Labor Day holiday. Last quotation for call money was 1 per cent; time money, all maturities, 1 1/4 per cent; commercial paper, best names, three-quarters of 1 per cent.

Arthur Krock argues that in case Mr. Roosevelt should be re-elected he would handle the relief situation far better than Mr. Landon because "American history's experience is that second-term Presidents are bolder and far less politically motivated than first termers."

HENDAYE, France, Sept. 7. -- Antonio Ortega, the civil Governor of San Sebastian, and Jesus Larranaga, the War Commissioner, are speeding the defenses of the city, which used to have 78,000 inhabitants. It is rumored that there is fighting in the Spanish resort city between Basque nationalists, who do not wish to see it destroyed as Irun was, and extremists of the Left, who intend to hold out against all odds.

HYANNIS, Mass., Sept. 7.--Five men and four women were rescued from rough water in Vineyard Sound today after the fifty-foot yawl Rondonella on which they were cruising for the holidays in Cape Cod waters sprang a leak and sank about one mile southeast of Hedge Fence Buoy.

The Italian liner Saturnia sails today for Mediterranean ports with the following among her passengers: Mrs. Gertrude Grosvenor, John J. DeMartino, Dr. Carl J. Sebastian, Dr. J.A. Hill, Joseph O'Hanlon, Mrs. Ephna Townley, Mr. and Mrs. S. Turoto, Mr. and Mrs. W.M. Stuart, Mrs. Robert Arnold, Mr. and Mrs. J. Francis O'Sullivan, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ringling, Mr. and Mrs. Karl Pribram.
MADRID, Sept. 7 (AP). -- A steady advance against an enemy "demoralized and disorganized by a long series of crushing defeats" was claimed tonight for Madrid government troops on all fronts.

The Astoria Swimming Pool squad of twenty boys and girls won the all-city championship for outdoor municipal pool teams in a meet sponsored by the Park Department and the Mayor's Committee on Municipal Athletics yesterday afternoon in the Astoria Pool, Queens.

One hundred young Britishers a group of school boys who are seeing America on their holidays, awoke yesterday morning in a midtown hotel to encounter their first day in New York City. Their first act was to open the doors of their respective rooms to take in the 100 pairs of shoes, left outside upon retiring.

HAILEY, Idaho, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Senator Borah, in an address at a Labor Day picnic, declared that if this country ventures into other foreign wars or mixes in the political affairs of foreign governments, "nothing will be saved of all that is known and revered as American."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The gravity of the international situation as viewed through the Washington administration's eyes was disclosed in plain language tonight by Secretary Hull in an address to the 3,000 delegates, representing more than fifty nations, who are in Washington to attend the Third World Power Conference.
Partly rested from the strain of her flight across the Atlantic, Mrs. Beryl Markham began a quiet approach yesterday to the round of activities that her fame has brought her.

Three men, one of whom carried a gun, held up a watchman at the plant of the Eskimo Pie Company at 4,788 Bronx Boulevard, the Bronx, at midnight last night and escaped with about $1,000 stolen from a safe, which they broke open with a drill.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 7. -- Civilization is passing through "a very severe, perhaps a critical, stage of maladjustment," according to Dr. Bronislaw Malinowski, Professor of Anthropology at the University of London.

If the United States were a business corporation managed by business men instead of a business corporation managed by politicians subject to the periodic review of a continental people, a sheet listing the nation's credits would now be as familiar to the stockholders -- the voters -- as the list of debits.
WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 7. -- Governor Landon's address at the State convention of the American Legion here today was as follows:
ATLANTA, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Governor Talmadge and Senator Russell pressed their campaigns today for the Georgia Senatorial nomination, each with forecasts of victory in Wednesday's primary.

It is the Plymouth Theatre which, on the evening of Wednesday, Oct. 14, will house "Tovarich," originally set for Oct. 12. This is Robert E. Sherwood's adaptation of Jacques Deval's play, being brought to this country by Gilbert Miller, with John Halliday and Marta Abba in the cast.

SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Tuesday, Sept. 8. -- The Spanish Government administration in San Sebastian has offered to surrender the city if full amnesty is promised the defenders, a reliable source said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Charges that Federal relief funds have been misused and that WPA activities have been employed by Democratic workers in Pennsylvania to strengthen the party's cause in November were made in a statement issued today by the Republican National Committee.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., Sept. 7. -- This village will have some new fire equipment within the next month or some of its residents will move to other Long Island communities, according to the plan of a committee formed today to protest the destruction by fire yesterday of a bungalow that might have been saved if the East Meadow Fire Department hose lines had not burst.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- It took an armored car and a United States cruiser to get Miss Eleanor S. O'Kane of 221 South Forty-fifth Street, Philadelphia, out of Spain, but today, resting at her home, before resuming teaching duties at Bryn Mawr College, she was calm about it all.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Norman Thomas. Socialist candidate for President, addressed a series of meetings and picnics in Rockland County today. The most important of meetings for the Socialist leader was held at Tallman Mountain Park.

Residential deals featured the reports of realty transactions for the metropolitan district over the holiday week-end. Two Queens apartment houses, several Manhattan homes and some suburban dwellings figured in the deals.
WHITEFIELD, N.H., Sept. 7. -- There was a great deal of entertaining at resorts in the White Mountains for Labor Day.

Drought over large areas of the country has forced electric light and power companies to depend more and more on their steam plants to supply the growing requirements for electricity. This, however, adds considerably to their operating costs.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7. -- Entertainments in honor of the members of the international team of the Oxford Group continued today and chief among these was the reception given late in the afternoon by Mrs. Beverley Bogert at Anglesea for the entire team.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The ten unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, no longer members in good standing of the American Federation of Labor, probably will not Send delegates to the Tampa convention of the federation in November, it was reported today.

BERLIN, Sept. 7.--Panic was created among wealthy German Jews today by a government order that, if enforced, would mean outright confiscation of 25 per cent of their remaining fortunes and therewith, in many cases, ruin of remaining Jewish businesses.

Influential Englishmen are hoping for the re-election of President Roosevelt because they want to continue deriving benefits from our low tariffs and because the President has not bothered them on the question of war debts, according to Paul Block, the newspaper publisher, who returned from Europe yesterday on the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line.

Football comes back today -- or tonight, rather -- earlier than it has ever been seen in New York or in the East, at least in recent years. Under are lights said to be so excellent as to provide conditions very similar to daylight, the New York Giants, one of the game's most brilliant professional combinations, will meet a team of selected college stars at the Polo Grounds.

LIBERTY CORNER, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Henry Wightman of Upper Montclair won the New Jersey State gliding championship, dethroning Wilbur Duff of Cranford, as the third annual three-day title meet closed here today on Schley Field.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 7 (AP). -- George L. Berry, president of Labor's Non-Partisan League, told a Labor Day rally here that labor was determined the Constitution "shall be interpreted in harmony with the spirit of the founders."
PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The protocol establishing an agreement between the French Government and the Syrian delegation regarding Syria's future will be signed at the Quai d'Orsay Wednesday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Kitty Belaire, a 5-year-old chestnut mare bred on Mr. and Mrs. Reed A. Albee's estate, out of Sweet Kitty Belaire, won in the hotly contested model saddle class at the Empire State Fair Horse Show tonight.

GENEVA, Sept. 7. -- Peru, in a note to the League of Nations, published today, proposes dropping from the League covenant its recognition of the Monroe Doctrine, which it holds is unilateral and a United States policy and not a regional agreement recognized by Latin-American nations.
