SUFFERN, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Before a capacity audience here tonight, Robert F. Cutler presented the final production of the County Theatre's season, the world premiere of "Middle Man," a new play by G.B. Stern, starring Ernest Truex.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 8. -- Signs of Right Wing unrest are again disturbing the authorities, who summoned a conference of the chiefs of special police sections yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Four Cleveland errors gave the Browns the first game of a double-header today, 6 -- 4, but Bob Feller, 17-year-old rookie, fanned ten Brownies to win the second game for the Indians, 7 -- 1. The holiday bill drew 17,000 fans.

The American Ship Building Company reports a net income for the fiscal year ended on June 30 of $171,545, equal, after preferred dividend requirements on 393 shares of 7 per cent preferred stock, to $1.32 a share on 127,683 shares of common stock.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- Aroused by a story that the Spanish Rebels had threatened to drop gas bombs on Madrid, the British Government today ordered official inquiries made on both sides and at the same time sent an indirect warning to the Rebel leaders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The economic power exercised by corporate employers like the American Iron and Steel Institute in the field of labor relations "demands some fair counterpoise in the collective power of the workers," said John L. Lewis, president of the United Wine Workers of America, in an address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Research on living human beings to supplement experimentation with guinea pigs and other animals was advocated as "vitally important" to medical progress yesterday at the opening sessions of the fifteenth annual meeting of the American Congress of Physical Therapy at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates grabbed a lead in the opening inning today and went ahead to subdue the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 to 1, then ran wild to win the second contest, 14 to 1.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The Communist newspaper Humanite charges that plans for a Fascist uprising have been made by the French Social party, a political organization headed by Colonel Francois de la Rocque, which arose from the dissolved Croix de Feu veterans' league.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Adrian Iselin brought the world championship trophy for international Star Class boats back to Long Island Sound from the Pacific Coast today in the fifth and final race of the series on Lake Ontario.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The Treasury today announced as its September financing program an offering of 2 3/4 per cent bonds maturing in twenty-three years and callable in twenty years to obtain about $400,000,000 in cash and in exchange for $514,066,000 of 1 1/2 per cent Treasury notes maturing on Sept. 15.

Our neighbor The Sun has completed its own survey of unemployment. With laudable industry it has secured returns from firms employing nearly 10,000,000 workers in the manufacturing and mechanical industries, in trade, in mining, and in transportation and communications.

Charles Hansen, 50 years old, of 108 West Sixty-eighth Street, a riding instructor at the Central Park Riding Academy, Fifty-eighth Street and Seventh Avenue, was acquitted in Yorkville Court yesterday of beating a horse when seven eyewitnesses asserted he had struck the animal in question only three or four times with a riding crop, and that the blows were gentle.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd arrived in Albany tonight after his weekend holiday, prepared to question District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of King County on friendship with Leo P. Byk, former Brooklyn slot-machine operator.

The world scholars in the arts and the sciences, gathered at Harvard, spent the first Tercentenary festival week chiefly in contemplating the cosmos, from the invisible and still divisible atom to the infinity which mathematics has permitted them to enter -- a real ascent into the hill of the Lord.
The curtain rang down on the championship hopes of an old favorite and also on the most talked-of young player of the season yesterday as 9,000 looked on at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 7 (AP). -- State police said they learned today that a discussion of financial matters took place between Harry E. Byram, 72, and Don Burdick, his son-in-law, a day before Byram was shot in his Westport home.

Doubt that any considerable number of employers were categorically opposed to hiring WPA workers in their businesses was expressed yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7. -- Whatever the propaganda value of the Nuremberg congress to the Nazis among their own people, the Bolshevists are certainly making the most of it for their own purposes here.

ROME, Sept. 7. -- While Joseph A.C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, was understood to be promising Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano of Italy that France would support Italy's demand for the permanent exclusion of Ethiopia from the League, Giuseppe Bastianini, Italian Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, left Rome today for Venice to meet General Edward Rydz-Smigly, Polish dictator.

Commenting on the protest by Dr. Morris Fishbein and Dr. Paul N. Leech, Herman Seydel, manufacturing chemist of Jersey City, asserted yesterday that the report on a new treatment of arthritis which he has placed before the American Chemical Society is warranted by the clinical results obtained in the past two years in several hundred cases at the Jersey City Medical Center and the Post-Graduate Hospital in New York and by private physicians.

BABYLON, L.I. Sept. 7. -- A ten-foot, 250-pound whiptail shark was caught by Commander George R. Le Sauvage of Argyle Park, Babylon, while he was fishing for tuna this afternoon three miles southeast of the Fire Island lightship.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 7 (AP). -- With the veteran Will Dickerson handling the reins, Bill Strang gained a straight-heat victory today in the feature event of the opening Grand Circuit program, the Horseman Futurity 3-Year old trot for a purse of $3,235.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Representative William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, recommended today that the government use its own money and credit to retire its tax-exempt interest-bearing bonds and apply the $1,000,000,000 he estimated it would save yearly to an old-age pension fund.

HARTFORD, Sept. 7. -- Connecticut Republicans will convene here tomorrow and on Wednesday will nominate a State ticket. For the first time in sixteen years there will be a roll-call of the 606 delegates to decide which of three aspirants shall be the opponent of Governor Cross, State's Attorney Hugh M. Alcorn of Suffield, State's Attorney Arthur M. Brown of Norwich, or the former Congressional floor leader, John Q. Tilson of New Haven.
A Presidential election in the United States offers a nation-wide "laboratory" for serious study to philosophers and students of social psychology.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn gave a large tea dance this afternoon at the Meadow Club for Mr. and Mrs. Edward La Rocque Tinker of Setauket, L.I., who are passing the holiday week-end with them.

ALMA, Mich., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, told a Labor Day audience at Bahlke Stadium that the Roosevelt administration had "fomented labor strife" and passed laws raising "the iron hand of government" over labor in this country.

A substantial volume of mail orders offset the lack of buyers in the local merchandise markets last week and purchases increased as stores prepared for an active post-Labor Day business. The new accessories have already received excellent consumer response and made up a good portion of the commitments.
WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Louis J. Taber, master of the National Grange, told the New Castle County Grange today that the American farmer must be guaranteed the American market.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 7. -- A $3,200 claim less than two weeks ago, the 5-year-old chestnut gelding Howard, now owned by Stephen Panarella, won the What Cheer Handicap over a mile and a furlong at Narragansett Park today before 51,000, the largest crowd of the season.

BOSTON, Sept. 7. -- No progress for Professor Casey Stengel's pilgrims can be reported as a result of their altercations with the Bees today. While 15,000 looked on in mingled admiration and annoyance the Dodgers took the opener in eleven innings, 2 -- 1, then more hastily dropped the nightcap, 4 -- 1, and hurried home.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Inspectors sifted the ashes of a wrecked sight-seeing monoplane today for clues to the cause of the crash of the tri-motored liner with the loss of ten lives.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7. -- Isolation of a substance in the milky sap of the fig tree which destroys worms parasitic in human intestines, and chemical tests which have foretold with 80 per cent accuracy the occurrence of common colds in the individual were reported here today at the general meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Now it is "The Gondoliers" they are giving over at the Martin Beck, the They being still the members of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company as well as every Tuesday morning's favorite children. But perhaps today a note of rapture somewhat modified must creep into the report, for Item Three in Forty-fifth Street's Gilbert and Sullivan festival is neither "The Mikado" nor "The Pirates of Penzance," which preceded it.

Republican leaders, responsible for the conduct of the Landon-Knox campaign, are eagerly awaiting the verdict of the voters in the early State election in Maine. The voters there will go to the polls next Monday to elect a Governor, a State Auditor, a United States Senator, three Representatives in Congress and members of both branches of the State Legislature.

DALLAS, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Centennial All-Stars, a hustling band of 1935 college football heroes, smashed the professional jinx held over college elevens tonight by subduing the Chicago Bears, 7 -- 6, before nearly 25,000 fans in the Cotton Bowl of the Centennial Exposition.

Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, criticized the labor records of his two major party opponents in a Labor Day address last night over station WJZ and a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- Speculative interest in the grain market in the first eight months of 1936 was in slightly larger measure than a year ago, official records of the Commodity Exchange Administration showed today.

HENDAYE, France, Sept. 7. -- Four methodical Rebel columns closed in today on San Sebastian. Confident that their next major objective would fall by the end of the week, the Rebels advanced with unhurried precision.

MERCHANTVILLE, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Over the grave of the founder of Labor Day today pleas were made for a reunion of labor's ranks, now divided by the rift between the American Federation of Labor and John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization.

Housewives who protest that their work prevents their getting any exercise might be surprised to learn that without leaving their homes they walk a distance equal to that from Boston to San Francisco every year -- more than 3,000 miles. Business men, who long to follow a golf ball for eighteen holes, walk further than from New York to Boston in three or four weeks during their office hours.

In his familiar and friendly way, President ROOSEVELT gave to the country, on the radio Sunday night, an account of his trip through the States hit hard by this year's drought, together with some of his observations and conclusions. Two things will be noted by the public with warm approval.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- President Roosevelt spent a quiet day today, clearing his desk of correspondence in preparation for his departure tomorrow night on a Southern trip which will keep him away from Washington until Friday morning.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Ab Jenkins's projected forty-eight-hour race against time ended abruptly tonight when his huge, ruddered automobile broke down after 1,942, record-breaking miles.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7. -- Political circles see a new anti-Soviet move, and consequent further weakening of the Little Entente, behind Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch's departure tonight for Bucharest, Rumania.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Responding to demand by WPA officials for proper protection for employes at projects picketed by strikers, Sheriff John Chant of Burlington County has called a meeting for tomorrow night in Mount Holly of State, county and local law enforcement authorities to take measures to prevent strike violence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Forsaking temporarily its traditional garb of solemnity, the State Department turned today to verse to answer in kind the poetic plea of a homesick vice consul for transportation-paid leave in the United States.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 7 (AP). -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today there has been "a considerable improvement" in employment since last Labor Day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Tourists are becoming too friendly with the wild bears in national parks, according to the Park Service.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 7. -- The thirty-seventh annual regatta of the Ocean City Yacht Club on the waters of Great Egg Harbor Bay today was marked by thrilling contests among outboards, inboards and hydroplanes. A crowd of 20,000 witnessed the events.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- A physically fit New York University varsity football squad began practice today in preparation for a nine-game schedule, the longest for the Violet in recent years, which opens next month. Forty-five candidates reported to Head Coach Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens and his staff following their arrival here yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- The stock markets here opened the new account today cheerfully and generally firm, with some expansion in the volume of business. British funds were higher on the resumption of investment operations. Buying of German bonds was the principal feature in the foreign market.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7. -- The Newark Bears completed their International League season today by dividing a double-header with the Baltimore Orioles. The Orioles won the first game, 8 to 4, and Newark captured the nightcap, 7 to 0.

The series of conferences on the New York State political situation between James A. Farley, in his capacity as Democratic State chairman, and groups of Democratic county leaders will be resumed today, with thirteen up-State leaders visiting Mr. Farley's quarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7. -- Flying an invincible race in his needle-pointed Renault-powered Caudron, Lieutenant Michel Detroyat of France easily won the American speed classic, the Thompson Trophy race of 150 miles, at the wind-up of the 1936 national air races here this afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 7. -- Professor Bronislaw Malinowski, Polish scholar, anthropologist, traveler and author, has lived among Esquimos and primitive people in Africa and Melanesia, but no experience in his "exotic wanderings" has ever matched the "shock" he felt on his first visit to New York ten years ago, which, he said, in a lecture tonight, was his first contact with American civilization.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 7. -- When the corrected times on the boats that competed in the sixth annual Vineyard Sound race were computed today at the Stamford Yacht Club, Edlu, Rudolph J. Schaefer's yawl, was the victor.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The sixth annual meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association, held here today on the course of the Blink Brook Turf and Polo Club, attracted a large gathering. The proceeds will be used for the New York City visiting committee of the State Charities Aid Association.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Two figures in Wall Street today tried trench-digging in a mudflat to free a racing yacht that had grounded, and they made a signal success of it.

Traditionally a heavy day in shipping because of the grouping of returning Labor Day cruise liners, today will be one of the busiest in the harbor in many years. Customs staff officers were occupied yesterday with plans for examining the baggage of 9,401 passengers returning on nineteen vessels ranging in size from small ocean craft to great transatlantic liners.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Calumet Evelyn, world champion double-gaited horse, won the $2,000 Onondaga Hotel Stake, feature of the opening Grand Circuit program before a near-capacity crowd here today.

BERLIN, Sept. 7. -- The semi-official organ of the Foreign Office, the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, expresses doubt that Premier Leon Blum will be able to continue France's neutral policy in the civil war in Spain.

The campaign headquarters of William F. Brunner, regular organization designee for the Democratic nomination for President of the Board of Aldermen, issued a statement yesterday declaring that Mr. Brunner will carry Manhattan and the Bronx on primary day by a vote of four to one.
Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, State campaign director of the American Labor party, issued a "post-Labor Day" statement yesterday denouncing the tone of Republican pronouncement as on the day.
Citizens of the United States are "too much alarmed" by fear of war in Europe, according to James Speyer, banker, who returned from his annual European visit on the Queen Mary.

Hollywood has taken a sudden liking to Vincent Sheean. Two weeks ago Walter Wanger bought the screen rights to the author's "Personal History," and now RKO-Radio has purchased "Violette," which concerns a feminine newspaper correspondent assigned to the Geneva conferences of the League of Nations.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Arizona's primary campaigns, so fraught with State issues and personalities that the New Deal and national problems, except the Townsend plan, were relegated to the background, closed tonight in a barrage of Labor Day oratory.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 7. -- Sir Arthur Eddington tonight took an international audience of 2,500 scholars attending the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences on a journey into the raging infernos in the interior of the sun and the stars.
It is necessary to carefully examine the figures before accusing the Roosevelt administration of excessive spending and accumulation of an immense deficit.

PLYMOUTH, England, Sept. 7. -- The annual congress of the British trade unions began its sessions here today with the delegates standing for a moment of silence as an expression of respect and sympathy for the workers of Spain in their struggle to maintain their recognized government against the Fascist rebellion.

A bust of Benjamin Franklin has been sent to Governor Landon as a birthday gift from William Guggenheim, 3 Riverside Drive, honorary president of the International Benjamin Franklin Society. Governor Landon will be 49 tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- Miss Barbara Winslow of Hollywood, Calif., the top-seeded player, led the favored group through the opening rounds of the nineteenth annual national girls' tennis championship on the grass courts at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The search for 17-month-old Harry Browe Jr., who disappeared from his perambulator Saturday evening, spread to adjoining States today as police investigated reports that a child resembling the missing boy had been seen in various sections.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Where Away, Anthony Pelleteri's bargain horse, paid another big dividend today by conquering Mrs. John D. Hertz's fleet Count Arthur by a head in the $10,000 added Washington Park Handicap, closing feature of the meeting.

Building costs in this city are slated to increase during the next six months, following a rise of at least 10 per cent between last Jan. and the present, according to the current number of News and Opinion, published by the Building Trades Employers Association of this city.

BERLIN, Sept. 7. -- The Boerse was quiet and soft today, but the turnover was so small that most issues were not even quoted. Heavy industrials opened weak but improved later, closing with fractional losses on the day. Machines, autos and cables were irregular and moved within a narrow range.

The body of Irving Denmark, 20 years old, of 1,452 Fifty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, clad in a bathing suit, was taken from the water off Manhattan Beach yesterday morning. Drifting near by was a battered sailing canoe in which, with Hymen Hellman of 905 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, Denmark had set out from Sheepshead Bay on Sunday for Atlantic Highlands.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Former President Herbert Hoover spent Labor Day in Chicago, discussing with friends the part he would play in the Presidential election campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- A uniform system of accounts for public utility holding companies registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, intended to eliminate some of the alleged bookkeeping abuses against which the act is directed, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, to become effective on Jan. 1.
Counter-tides of traffic on highways, rails, waterways and in the airlanes bore millions of vacationists into and out of New York last night in the city's greatest Labor Day migration.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Mr. Watt, 2-year-old trotting colt from the Newbrook Stables, and Happy the Great, veteran trotter owned by William Harkhurst of Maplewood, won the feature events of the holiday matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

Simon Schuster are trying out the stunt of printing facsimiles of their readers' reports on the jackets of mystery stories. Five of these informal reports, written before the manuscript was accepted, appear on the jacket of "A Puzzle for Fools," by Patrick Quentin, that will be published on Sept. 21.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Cincinnati's Reds defeated Chicago's Cubs twice today, 6 to 2 and 8 to 4, in a double-header interrupted by a resumption of fisticuffs that marked two previous meetings of the teams this year. A holiday crowd of 19,047 saw the twin bill.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 7 (AP). -- A Production-for-Use ticket, the Townsend plan and a heated campaign for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination held the interest of Washington voters tonight on the eve of tomorow's primary election.
LONDON, Sept. 7. -- The government announced its decision tonight to send Lieut. Gen. J.G. Dill to Palestine, where he will be placed in supreme military control of five brigades of troops.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 7. -- With a sparkling demonstration of iron play, Johnny Goodman of Omaha, former national open champion, today won two matches to reach the final of the Arocla invitation golf tournament. His opponent in tomorrow's thirty-six-hole final will be John W. Dawson of Chicago, trans-Mississippi champion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The opening skirmish between the over-the-counter dealers and the Exchanges for stock-trading privileges is looked for on Friday, when the Securities and Exchange Commission takes evidence on the application of Tweedy Co. of New York for the removal of the capital stocks of the Piedmont and Northern Railway Company and the City and Suburban Homes Company from unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange.

WASHINGTON Sept. 7. -- Following is the text of the address of welcome by Secretary Hull tonight to the Third World Power Conference and the Second Congress of the International Commission on Large Dams:

Labor Day saw the vacationists winging homeward, and from no holiday ground in greater numbers than from New England. In that there is nothing new, yet it is surprising to see how big this holiday trade looks in actual dollars.

The fact that the Yankees are on the verge of clinching their first pennant in four years and the Athletics are going no place very rapidly meant absolutely nothing to the baseball populace yesterday. Some 45,144 fans spent the holiday at the Stadium where they enjoyed the spectacle of a twin triumph for the Ruppert forces.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP). -- Jimmie DeShong scored his sixteenth victory of the season as the Senators defeated Boston, 6 -- 4, in the first game of a double bill today, but the Red Sox came back to take the nightcap 6 to 5.

WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 7. -- Members of the American Legion, who fought to save America, now have three important duties -- the duty of tolerance, the duty of citizenship and the duty of preserving peace -- Governor Landon declared today. He urged unity of action by the Legion in performing these duties.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 7. -- The Meadow Brook Club's annual twelve-goal Autumn Plates polo tournament, in which seven teams are entered, and which was scheduled to have started today, has been postponed until Wednesday.

Marked progress in providing more adequate protection against fire and other hazards for thousands of New York families living in old multi-family houses is reported by Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post.
OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Sept. 7 (AP). -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt advised today "those who wish a Russian, German or Italian type of government" to vote for President Roosevelt in November.

As chairman of the National Committee of Welfare Leaders, organized to support President Roosevelt, Miss Grace Abbott of Chicago, formerly head of the United States Children's Bureau, announced yesterday the names of thirty-seven nationally known social service workers who have accepted places on the committee.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP). -- The Tigers and White Sox fought it out for undisputed possession of second place in the American League today, but got nowhere as the Bengals won the first game of a double bill, 8 -- 7, and the White Sox took the nightcap by the same score before a crowd of 35,000.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Two cash realty transactions of $40,000 each in the Miami area high-spotted today the busiest buying and building activity here since the 1925 "boom."
Conveyance of a factory in Kearny featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

The college All-Stars did not play their exit marches from the football picture in their game with the Giants at the Polo Grounds last night. Half of them were starting new careers, the professionals-to-be merely meeting the professionals who-are.

Several prominent figures in the coal-mining industry in Pennsylvania will be called, as witnesses today when the New York County grand jury resumes its investigation of alleged bootlegging, or theft, by miners of millions of tons of coal in the anthracite region.

The routine coverage of news these days brings growing demand on the space of newspapers to record improvement in business, large and small. And the critical condition of affairs in Europe produces an overtone in any gathering of the citizens of more than one country, as the opening proceedings of the World Power Conference in Washington Monday again illustrated.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Governor Landon is pictured as the "one man" who can "put the country on its feet" in a song entitled, "Our Landon," which the Republican National Committee predicted today was destined to be the song hit of the campaign.

Efforts to avert a strike of 15,000 members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs seemed likely to break down again last night, following rejection by the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of the union's compromise offer of a forty-four-hour work week.

The estate of Clinton White Toms, former president of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company and a leading figure in the American tobacco industry, was left in equal shares to his three sons and two daughters, according to his will which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

Trading in stocks yesterday was typical of a brisk day in Autumn although the temperature was not. The market opened strong on the accumulation of favorable trade news over the long week-end, and enthusiasm on the side of the advance continued through to closing despite moderate profit-taking in the afternoon.

Progressives outside of New York are anxious to see proportional representation tried in the great metropolis. Most of our badly governed cities are controlled by the two-party system. There is need of more independent influence in government free from partisanship.

ARCOLA, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Johnny Goodman of Omaha, former national open champion and No. 1 player on the United States Walker Cup team, today defeated John W. Dawson of Chicago, trans-Mississippi champion, 2 and 1, in the thirty-six-hole final of the annual Arcola Country Club invitation golf tournament.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 8. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler this afternoon proclaimed his restoration of "full arms sovereignty" to the German nation during the last year. His assertion was contained in a three-minute speech at the City Hall after his arrival here for the annual National Socialist party convention.

Governor LANDON can well afford to be accused of old-fashioned ideas, provided they are like the old-fashioned idea he stressed twice in two days over the week-end. It is the antiquated doctrine of tolerance.

The Alaska Juneau Gold Mining Company estimates its profit at $1,702,400 for the eight months ended on Aug. 31, after operating expenses and development charges, but before depreciation, depletion and Federal taxes. In the first eight months of 1935 the profit was $1,242,600 after similar allowances.

Stronger markets in fairly active trading predominated yesterday on the local commodity futures markets. Rubber was lower, however, and sugar was unsettled in quiet dealings. On the cash markets, cotton, printcloths, flour, butter, eggs, lard and tin advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, rubber and silk declined.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups in July have been announced by the Department of Commerce; they are here compared with those of the preceding month and with July, 1935. Exports as given in the tables that follow cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported. Imports cover only those for consumption in this country.

Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service, announced yesterday that total receipts of the service's three-cent-a-day plan for hospital care would pass $1,000,000 today. Yesterday the total was $998,957.

A WPA worker assigned to Bellevue Hospital to investigate the ability of patients to pay for hospital services was arrested yesterday on a charge of taking $63 in fees from a woman whose daughter was treated at the hospital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Scheduled air lines in the United States and American lines operating in foreign territory again showed rapid gains during the first six months of 1936 over the corresponding period of 1935, the Bureau of Air Commerce said today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The White Sox took sole possession of second place and blasted the Detroit Tigers' last mathematical chance at the American League pennant by trouncing the 1935 world's champions, 7 to 5, today in the only major league game of the day.

Boxing and wrestling dates for the indoor season were allotted yesterday at a meeting of the New York State Athletic Commission. According to the schedule, six clubs will operate for boxing, with eleven staging wrestling shows, in addition to the Mecca Sports Club, which was allowed Friday nights tentatively.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP). -- The Rev. John F. Burke, general secretary of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, has been elevated by Pope Pius XI to the rank of Domestic Prelate with the title of Right Reverend Monsignor.

OLD LYME, Conn., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Judge Robert M. Marsh of New York City, outbid the Florence Griswold Association, Inc., by $50 at a Probate Court hearing today and bought the Florence Griswold estate for $18,550.

PORT HENRY, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Massachusetts acted today to obtain through taxation part of the estimated $80,000,000 estate of Colonel Edward H.R. Green, bequeathed to a sister, Mrs. Matthew Astor Wilks of New York City, in a twenty-eight-year old will filed here for probate.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 8. -- A defense of a State's interference with and regulation of private enterprise, predictions that State regulation would increase, and a warning that economic nationalism led to national animosities which could bring on a devastating war were made by scholars today at the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A plan of governmental reorganization more far-reaching than anything attempted in many years, and involving possibly the consolidation or abolition of some of the major departments and bureaus, is being considered by President Roosevelt for submission to Congress in the event of his re-election.
The legions returning to New York after the Labor Day weekend, or going home after a visit to the city, set new records for traffic over bridge and tunnel facilities, figures issued yesterday showed.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 9. -- Chinese mobs continue to play into the hands of those elements here that demand a strong policy toward China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Subscriptions to the Treasury's cash offering of $400,000,000 of twenty to twenty-three-year 2 3/4 per cent bonds dated Sept. 15 were oversubscribed nine times, Secretary Morgenthau announced late today. The final announcement on subscriptions will be made on Friday, he said.

PARIS, Sept. 8. -- Portugal's failure to reply and the controversy between Premier Leon Blum and French extremists over the question of intervention in Spain tonight threatened to complicate the negotiations in London for coordinating the efforts to control enforcement of the international neutrality accord.

TYLER HILL. Pa., Sept. 8. -- Thirty candidates for the City College football team arrived at the Wayne Country Club tonight for their annual pro-season training at this spacious camp, ready for the daily double sessions which start tomorrow.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8. -- The sightseeing airplane which crashed here Saturday night and killed ten persons violated two strict regulations, Federal inspectors declared today.

Borough President Harvey of Queens refused yesterday the request of the Queens Communist party for a permit to hold a meeting in the Town Hall, Jamaica, Queens, and declared the State should never have permitted the legal authorization of a party with "such dangerous aims as those the Communists have embraced."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The Investment Bankers' Conference Inc., which has just been incorporated under the laws of Delaware, announced today that plans for the establishment of a permanent national organization for self-government and cooperation with Federal agencies would be discussed at meetings of investment bankers and over-the-counter securities dealers in seventeen cities throughout the country on Thursday.
Although tiny shoes are valued as keepsakes, babies should not wear them until they have learned to walk, according to Dr. Max Cohen, child specialist.

The International Power Conference which opened its sessions in Washington on Monday is primarily intended for an exchange of ideas about a great development of peace. This was alluded to by Secretary HULL in his official speech of welcome. He dwelt briefly upon the new resources and energies which had been placed at the disposal of man through harnessing and applying in a thousand ways the power of falling water.

SYRACUSE, N. ., Sept. 8 (AP). -- Twilight Song, bay filly owned by W.H. Strang Jr. of Brooklyn, again showed her superiority over the horses of her age as she won the $7,500 Ten Eyck Stake for 2-year-old trotters in straight heats to feature the second day's Grand Circuit program at the New York State Fair today.

Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Westchester County, candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, gave yesterday afternoon his first general press interview on the subject of his candidacy.

Clarence J. Dillon and thirteen other members of the firm of Dillon, Read Co., who were ordered last April to surrender stock of the National Cash Register Company, valued at more than $18,000,000, to the clerk of the United States Court in Maryland, were accused here yesterday of failure to obey the mandate of that court.

A fake doctor pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to "padding" bills to insurance companies in accident compensation claims. The grand jury also ordered "informations" filed in the same court against two lawyers in separate alleged ambulance-chasing charges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A reduction of 36 per cent in farm real estate taxes from 1929 through 1935 was reported today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, which said that the average last year was about 37 cents an acre the country over, as compared with 58 cents in 1929, the highest rate in the country's history.

LINWOOD, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Mrs. Norman Lack of the Wilmington Country Club, twice Philadelphia district champion, toured the Linwood links in 83 strokes today to capture the medal in the first annual women's Atlantic Coast golf tournament.

Playing par golf on both nines, Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Lido, Long Island amateur champion, toured North Hills with a scintillating 72 to win the low-gross prize in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day amateur tournament at Douglaston yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse entertained at tea today in the Guild Hall Art Galleries after the annual meeting of the Village Improvement Society, at which Mrs. William R. Maloney presided. Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford and Mrs. Percy Schenck presided at the tea tables.

SIMLA, India, Sept. 8. -- A message brought by runners from the base camp of the Nanda Devi Anglo-American Expedition tates that two members of the party succeeded in reaching the summit of Nanda Devi on Aug. 29. The names of the two climbers were not given.

PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 8 (AP). -- State Senator Benjamin Muse, Democrat and champion of old-age pensions and social legislation, announced his support of Governor Landon in a written statement which drew the immediate fire of Horace Edwards, director for the Virginia Democrats.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8. -- Every arm of the Soviet Union's land forces -- infantry, artillery, tank, aviation and chemical -- took the field today near the western border in a four-day manoeuvre designed to test this country's defensive and striking power in an area likely to have great strategic significance should Germany and the Soviet Union ever go to war.

As long as the family handyman is allowed to repair and install electrical devices it will be impossible to reduce the fire hazard, it was declared yesterday at the opening session of the Eastern section of the International Association of Electrical Inspectors at the Hotel New Yorker.

Nationalism has won another victory in the Near East. Today in Paris a protocol is being signed by the representatives of the French Government and a Syrian delegation; on the basis of this agreement it is expected that, after a three-year probationary period, Syria will become unified and independent.

On account of the Labor Day holiday, the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was well below the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

The 1936 National Electrical and Radio Exposition will open at 11 A. M. today in Grand .Central Palace with more than 100 manufacturers and distributors of radio receivers and home electric appliances exhibiting their products. The exhibition will last eleven days,

A general price advance on all lines of cotton goods and a resumption of the heavy buying characteristic of June and July were forecast in the primary market yesterday, following the government's "astonishing" cotton crop estimate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A warning of the necessity of cooperating with the Senate committee's agent investigating expenditures in the Michigan primary campaign was telegraphed today by Chairman Lonergan to Archie P. Frazer, manager for former Governor Wilbet M. Brucker, Republican, opponent of Senator Couzens for renomination.

The report of the Department of Agriculture yesterday giving the indicated cotton crop as of Sept. 1 as 11,121,000 bales, a drop of 1,360,000 bales from its figures of a month ago, generally was considered too low in the trade.
Strange things happen to ocean fishermen, as George Ruben, a New York angler, will tell you after his experience off the Jersey coast.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens denied yesterday charges contained in a story published in The New York Post and forwarded by the newspaper to Governor Lehman for investigation, alleging that he was lax in the prosecution of Police Sergeant Frank Donnelly, who is being tried for wife-slaying.
Colonel Frank Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, will address the Republican State convention at Albany, Sept. 28, it was announced yesterday by Melvin C. Eaton, State committee chairman.

Magistrate McKiniry, in Traffic Court, tried 502 cases of traffic violations yesterday. Twenty-eight said they did not know that persons who broke traffic laws must show their licenses in court so that the conviction record could be stamped upon the certificate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- President Roosevelt left for the South tonight, less than sixty hours after returning here from a tour of the Western drought regions. He will go first to Knoxville, arriving there tomorrow morning.
Two men who have devoted the greater part of their lives to the spiritual and medical care of inhabitants of Alaska arrived together yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Rosa.

Americans of future generations will probably not know the songs of today as we now know "Sweet Rosie O'Grady" and "The Sidewalks of New York," Gene Buck, president of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, declared yesterday as he re- turned from California on the Grace liner Santa Rosa.

After stating that his principal objective was to repay the city of New York, by service in its behalf, for the opportunities it has given him, Judge Jonah J. Goldstein said yesterday that he had no intention of "quitting that service on the say-so of one man playing politics with the courts.

The Pro-Palestine Federation of America held a meeting last night at the Hotel New Yorker at which it was decided to call a conference here soon to devise ways to mobilize American public opinion in support of the Jewish national home cause.

a]es of General Motors cars to consumers in the United States in August totaled 133,804, the largest number for any August since 1929, it was announced yesterday. In July, 1936, the sales were 163,459, and in August, 1935, 127,346. In the first eight months of this year sales were 1,261,714, a new record. against 884,826 in the same time last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Indictment of six officers and employes of the Railway Audit and Inspection Company, Inc., for contempt of the Senate, arising out of their failure to appear before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee when it began its investigation on Aug. 21, was asked of the district grand jury today.

Volume of Summer travel by railway or steamship, but particularly the requisition of Labor Day on railway facilities, has always been accepted as indicating the variations of good and bad times. The exceptionally large outgoing and incoming travel reported for this year's Labor Day was natural reflection of the better times.

Paris set the pace but America garnered the laurels as the Autumn modes swished and swirled into view last night at the annual preview presented by Bergdorf-Good- man. Individuality and originality of the domestic, custom-made clothes was an outstanding element in a presentation that veered acutely away from precedent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Asserting that there was nothing wrong in providing work for a needy person formerly well to do, Corrington Gill, Acting WPA Administrator, today made public the reply of C. H. Barlow of Marlinton, W. Va., to Walter S. Hallanan, Republican National Committeeman, who had intimated that Barlow had been improperly employed as a timekeeper on a WPA project.
Fifty detectives joined uniformed policemen late yesterday in a cellar-to-cellar search through the East Side's "Little Spain" for a 4-year-old boy missing since Sunday afternoon.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8. -- Four hundred persons attended the junior bachelors committee dance, which took place at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton tonight. It was given in honor of the season's deutantes.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 8. -- Although Jimmy Mills was the side's spark plug with six goals, Templeton had a difficult time shading Aurora, 10 to 9, on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

PLYMOUTH, England, Sept. 8. -- There was an outburst of resentment at the Trades Union Congress today when a delegate suggested that there be a one-day general strike next May on the occasion of King Edward's coronation as a protest against the Baldwin government's measures for unemployment assistance at the rate of 10 shillings a week for jobless workers whose insurance has lapsed.
WARSAW, Sept. 8. -- Simultaneously with the consolidation of the Franco-Polish alliance, Poland's relations with Czechoslovakia are becoming more embittered.

In addition to the Waverly Boat Club, now facing demolition to make way for the development of Riverside Drive and its adjoining park, the knickerbooker Canoe Club at 183d Street also has been notified to move out of the path of construction, it was learned yesterday.

A long adjournment of the trial of eight former officials of the National Title Guarantee Company charged with using the mails to defraud was refused yesterday by Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks of New Haven in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- Delegates from twenty-three nations will meet around the table in the Foreign Office tomorrow as proof of Europe's determination not to let the Spanish civil war spread beyond the Pyrenees.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Sept. 2 shows increases for the week of $106,000,000 in reserve balances with the Federal Reserve Banks, $4,000,000 in time deposits and $134,000,000 in balances standing to the credit of domestic banks and a decline of $44,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

Eddie Cantor, who for a price won an annulment of his contract with Samuel Goldwyn, has finally signed that agreement with Twentieth Century-Fox. According to an unofficial version of the terms, he will make three pictures in the next two years, for a price said to be $1,000,000.

News of the French Government's decision to add to its deficit by a rearmament program involving 4,200,000,000 francs brought new fears for the ultimate safety of the gold-bloc currencies to the foreign exchange market yesterday. The flight of capital from France increased, carrying with it new and larger engagements of gold for shipment to this country.
Mayor La Guardia found Manhattan's heat oppressive yesterday as he returned to the downtown City Hall after more than two months spent in the old Bartow Mansion in Pelham Bay Park.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8. -- Many factory managers have been dismissed and others warned they must improve their work or lose their jobs, in an attack by I.E. Lubinoff, Commissar for Light Industry, on the lagging output and bad quality of consumers' goods.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 8. -- Charles Askins Jr. of El Paso was declared the national individual pistol champion today, when he topped the list of 667 competitors with a score of 276 for first place, winning the Custer Trophy and a gold medal.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 8. -- Governor Clarence D. Martin held a lead over John C. Stevenson, backed bye production-for-use organization, for the Democratic nomination for Governor in returns tonight from a State primary election. Earlier returns had given Stevenson a lead.

Graduation exercises for the Summer session of St. John's University School of Law, 96 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, will be held in the gymnasium at 8 o'clock tonight. The degree of Bachelor of Law will be conferred upon ninety-one students.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- Virtual stagnation continued on the Boerse today. Only selected issues had any turnover and they showed losses up to 2 or more points. Rises of Chade of three marks and of South German sugar of 1 point were the two exceptions.

It is rather discouraging for a taxpayer to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES that although estimated Federal receipts for the current fiscal year are the highest in history, except for the post-war fiscal year 1919-20, it will require a further increase of 27 per cent before a balance with outgo is attained, due to the constant record levels of government expenditures.

SEA GIRT, N. J., Sept. 8. -- American agricultural problems cannot be solved by the New Deal doctrine of "an economy of scarcity" nor can the nation return to permanent prosperity as long as the present administration of "brain trusters" is in office, United States Senator Leroy J, Dickinson of Iowa, declared here this afternoon.

MIMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 8 (AP). -- A shortage of cotton pickers plagued Midsouth planters today. Wages for pickers soared to the highest level since 1929 and still there were not enough field hands to harvest a rapidly maturing crop.
PARIS, Sept. 8. -- Among armament decrees approved by the Cabinet Council is one that admits Algerian natives to competitive examinations for French military careers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- July expenditures by all Federal agencies from appropriations made by the Emergency Relief Acts of 1935 and 1936 were $276,016,564, bringing the amount expended through the end of July to $3,700,581,080, or 72 per cent of the $5,105,125,740 allotted.

A letter in THE TIMES entitled "Children in the Streets" has made a very direct and worth-while suggestion, namely, that we should provide all-day schools with supervised recreation in the interest of crime prevention. This is a point well taken.

The team of Jockey Johnny Gilbert and John Hay Whitney's Peggy Porter proved the outstanding combination in the Melpomene Purse, feature of the racing at Aqueduct yesterday. This was a five-furlong dash for 2-year-old fillies and the chestnut daughter of The Porter scampered home with a margin of a length over Hugh W. Jackson's Clamorous.
LONDON, Sept. 8. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange opened dull today, with profit-taking prominent. Prices became firmer later, based on reports of a further reduction in unemployment.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8. -- Greenwich society attended the annual card party of Putnam Hill Chapter, D.A.R., at the Kent House, Belle Haven, this afternoon. Tea was served after the card playing. The proceeds will be used for the maintenance of the historic Putnam cottage, the chapter's headquarters, of Revolutionary fame.

The Standard Oil Company of Venezuela has concluded arrangements with the Venezuelan Government through which it has obtained a concession covering about 1,000,000 acres, largely in Eastern Venezuela. The company has agreed to construct a large refinery in Venezuelan territory.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 8. -- A skeleton believed to be that of Juan Schomberg, long-lost German scientist, has been found near the volcano Santiago, in the Department of Masaya, Partial identification has been made by means of the teeth.

The Board of Higher Education, the governing body of the three city colleges, asked Budget Director Leo J. McDermott yesterday for a 1937 allotment of $8,916,812, a figure $1,812,297 above the 1936 appropriation for the colleges.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Representative William Lemke, Union Party candidate for President, laid claim today to the seventeen electoral Votes of Massachusetts after his appearance at a Labor Day rally sponsored by former Mayor William Hale (Big Bill) Thompson of Chicago.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Jack Orr and Shirley Hanover triumphed in the Horseman Futurity events which featured today's Grand Circuit program at the Indiana State Fair.

Excessive comfort and idleness for convalescent patients are dangerous and may lead to a mental condition that ultimately may be more difficult to cure than the original malady, according to Dr. Robert H. Kennedy, Associate Professor of Clinical Surgery of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School of Columbia University.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 8. -- After having adopted at the morning session a resolution calling on world governments to safeguard peace the International Congress of P E N Clubs, attended by writers of thirty-nine countries, came near disruption this evening during a quarrel between the French and Italian delegations.

TORONTO, Sept. 8 (Canadian Press). -- Miss Quebec II, owned and driven by curly-headed Jack McInnes of Quebec City, pounded through heavy Lake Ontario seas tonight to capture the first of three ten-mile heats for the 225-cubic inch power boat championship of the world.

SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Sept. 8. -- Spanish Rebel columns tonight converged on San Sebastian, their leaders spurning an offer of surrender reported to have been made through the son of the Governor of the city. Through French intermediaries the Rebels flatly refused to consider the reported offer and vowed to punish all those who had borne arms against "the true government of Spain."

Harry Balsamo of Harlem moved a step nearer a match for the world's middleweight championship last night at the Queensboro Arena, Long Island City, by stopping Al Rossi of Newark in 2:41 of the second round of the feature bout listed for ten rounds.
Seven boy-and-girl teams of the Republican First Voters League started a house-to-house canvass for London last night, by way of experiment, and met with something less than middling success.

Under lights that made them appear like actors on a distant stage, the football Giants defeated the college All-Stars at the Polo Grounds last night in a game sponscored by The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund.

DENVER, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Governor Ed C. Johnson, seeking the Democratic nomination for Senator, led former Governor William E. Sweet 7,423 to 4,644 tonight on returns from 120 of the 1,521 precincts in Colorado.

MONTREAL, Sept. 8. -- The rank and file of Canadian organized labor, which for the most part is closely affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, indicated today a tendency to favor John L. Lewis and his industrial unions in the dispute with the A.F. of L.
[ THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. S. -- Prineess Juliana is extremely popular everywhere in the Netherlands, and particularly in the young court set.
NUREMBERG, Sept. 8. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler came here by special train from Berchtesgaden this afternoon for the National Socialist party's annual congress.
HENDAYE, France, Sept. 8. -- Spanish insurgents marching on San Sebastian were at grips today with government forces at the port of Pasajes, three miles from the resort city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- The mysterious airplane that attempted six times unsuccessfully to bomb the United States destroyer Kane off the southwestern coast of Spain Aug. 30 may have belonged to the insurgent forces in the civil war, according to an official communication the State Department received today from General Francisco Franco, commander-in-chief of the Spanish Rebels.

Smoke pollution measured in Central Park by the New York Meteorological Observatory under direction of the United States Weather Bureau indicated that last month was the clearest August in the seven-year history of the records.

A dispatch from Topeka reveals that Governor Landon in 1934 outlined a drought prevention plan to President Roosevelt. It is stated that "little has been done along the lines of the Governor's recommendation."

ATLANTA, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Georgia Democrats will decide in a primary tomorrow a bitter Senatorial contest between Senator Richard B. Russell Jr., who has upheld the national administration, and Governor Eugene Talmadge, New Deal critic, who "will support the President when he is right."

Following a greeting by President Roosevelt last week to American Jews on the occasion of their holy days, to be celebrated Sept. 17 and 18, similar messages from two other Presidential candidates were announced yesterday by the Jewish Telegraphic Agency.

LONDON, Sept. 8. -- Nervousness regarding the future of the French franc is disturbing the foreign ex- change market here. Throughout i today it showed a weak tendency, the final quotations for the franc being ?$ 49-64 to the pound ster- ling against 76 37-64 yesterday.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Although Miss Elsie Janis personally swung the auctioneer's hammer for a half hour this afternoon to help get rid of her personal belongings so she can start on her "new life" of service to others, the crowd was less than half the size of yesterday's.

NANNING, Kwangsi Province, China, Sept. 8. -- Although Nanking reports, that the Kwangsi Province revolt has been peaceably settled to the government's benefit and declares that Nanking's control now extends throughout South China, actually the peace is most precarious and temporary.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 8 (AP). -- The annual scramble for apartments finds Southern landlords boosting prices for the third straight year. Rents are up from 5 to 20 per cent over last Fall and the demand for apartments exceeds the supply in many cities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- Reports that there is a swing to Governor Landon of growing velocity were made today by members of the Republican executive committee meeting here with National Chairman Hamilton to discuss plans for the rest of the campaign.

JACKSON, N.H., Sept. 8. -- A meeting of the Eastern Slopes Ski Club, North Conway Chamber of Commerce, Conway Ski Club and many Summer colonists interested in the development of Winter sports in this section met tonight in Wentworth Hall at Jackson to confer with members of the newly formed Jackson Ski Club.

Scheduled to reopen in revised form this Saturday night, the "Follies" will instead wait until Monday evening to return to the Winter Garden. Lee Shubert said last night that the Labor Day week-end had delayed the painting of scenery, and that this was responsible for the postponement.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here showed a firm undertone today and although dipping early on scattered selling there was no appreciable pressure later and prices advanced as much as 2 cents a bushel from the low point of the day in sympathy with Winnipeg and closed with net gains of 1/4 to 5/8 cent.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- The Republican National Committee today denounced as the "cheapest form of political propaganda," without factual support, the campaign it asserts is fostered by the Democratic National Committee to accuse Governor Landon of balancing Kansas's budget at the expense of the school teachers.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 8. -- In a battle between Honduran rebels and 200 government troops on Aug. 28 fifteen government soldiers were killed and three were wounded, according to a report reaching here today.
PARIS, Sept. 8. -- France and the Blum government are close to a serious crisis.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8. -- The Mellon-controlled Gulf Oil Corporation today sent notices to stockholders advising them of a special meeting to be held on Nov. 10 at which they will vote on a proposal for an increase of 150 per cent in the capital stock to $300,000,000, consisting of 12,000,000 shares of $25-par-value stock. The present capital is 4,800,000 shares of $25 par value, authorized, of which 4,538,101 were outstanding on Dec. 31, 1935.

ROME, Sept. 8. -- Joseph A.C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, saw Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano again this morning, and although no official indication was given either in Italian quarters or by Mr. Avenol, it was presumed from the optimism reigning on both sides that the negotiations for Italy's return to Geneva had taken a favorable turn.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 8. -- Mrs. Maybelle B. Hart of Arlington went to jail today rather than pay a $3 fine for failing to stop at a traffic light.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8. -- Roger Don Rae, race flier and parachute jumper of East Lansing, Mich., flying a Menasco-powered Keith Rider Special, took the postponed fifty mile Shell trophy race for 550 cubic inch engines here today, as an aftermath feature of the annual national air races. His average time was 225.544 miles an hour.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 8. -- Willem Willeke, director of the South Mountain Music Colony here, announced today the prize winners for the season. The Victoria Kneisel Willeke Memorial Prize was awarded to Miss Elizabeth Priest, 'cellist, of Bristol, Conn., and two prizes given anonymously were awarded to Miss Eleanor Davies, 'cellist, of Summit, N.J., and Miss Dorothy Averill, violinist, of Helena, Mont.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 8. -- Lord Fermoy is making his first visit here in eight years. He has come to this country from England to attend the Harvard tercentenary celebration, for which he is leaving on Friday. He is the guest here of his brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Guy Fairfax Cary.

Thirty-five hundred persons appeared in person or telephoned to the offices of the Adult Education Project of the WPA and the Board of Education at 257 West Fortieth Street yesterday seeking information about courses to be offered by the project this year.

Plans already under way for the 1937 National Cotton Week contemplate organization of committees in every branch to muster the full strength of the entire industry behind next year's promotional campaign, Charles K. Everett, manager of the new uses section of the Cotton Textile Institute, said yesterday.

Leroy A. Van Bomel, president of the Sheffield Farms Company, charged yesterday that the campaign of the city administration to keep milk at 11 cents a quart available to consumers here was giving encouragement to a group of "fly-by-night wholesalers who underpay help, market milk by demand instead of quality and who cheat farmer and consumer alike."

Democratic county leaders from up-State, after a conference yesterday with James A. Farley, State and national party chairman, predicted gains, not losses, for the Roosevelt-Lehman ticket in their territory, as compared with 1932. The least optimistic prediction was that the ticket would do as well this year as it did then, when the Republican up-State plurality was so small that the Democratic plurality for the State as a whole totaled 596,000 for the President.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Imports of chemicals and related products into the United States reached $12,481,000 in value in July, little changed from the preceding month, but 40 per cent above July, 1935, the Department of Commerce reported today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 8. -- Six hundred delegates to the Republican State Convention joined with an enthusiastic gallery in Foot Guard Armory here tonight in applauding the keynote address of Charles Francis Coe, author and criminologist.

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 8. -- The Committee on Judicial Business of the West Jersey Presbytery, meeting today in the Presbyterian Church at Somerdale, recommended that five ministers be deposed and two church properties seized. Three of the ministers have become affiliated with the newly formed Presbyterian Church of America and the two others have signified a similar intention.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- Although the Finance Ministry asserted today that it knew nothing about demands being served on wealthy German Jews for an immediate deposit of 25 per cent of their capital assets as security for proper payment of the Reich flight tax should they desire to emigrate, the local tax authorities confirmed this action and emphasized its legality.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,008,550 barrels, compared to 3,032,050 in the previous week, a drop of 23,500, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Decreases of 15,950 and of 13,550 barrels, respectively, in Kansas and Oklahoma and a gain of 11,800 in California were the important changes.
Production of steel ingots in August amounted to 4,195,130 gross tons, the largest amount for any month since March, 1930, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass, Sept. 8. -- Scientists attending the Harvard tercentenary conference of arts and sciences were taken today on a journey into the interior of the atom and heard reports on the first fruits of knowledge recently garnered on the cosmic forces within the atom that hold the universe together.

The mercury rose to 86 degrees at 3 P.M. yesterday, 6 below the record for the date, established in 1881. The average, 77 degrees, was 8 above normal. The low was 68 at 8 A.M., a time when the humidity had reached 93 per cent of saturation.

GARDEN CITY, Sept. 8 (AP). -- Chick Evans's record 71 for the Garden City Golf Club course, set 15 years ago, went by the boards today as T. Suffern Taller Jr. of New York, toured the lay-out in 70 strokes, 3 under par, in practice for the national amateur championship starting next Monday.

Reports of the arrest of truck drivers for hauling "bootleg" coal into this city from Pennsylvania direct attention to the strange conditions prevailing in that State. For more than a year un employed coal miners in the anthracite regions have been going onto private property and mining large quantities of coal, but no action by the local police or State authorities seems to have been taken.

Despite the handicap of a painfully swollen thumb on her racquet hand. Miss Helen Jacobs, the defending women's titleholder, defeated Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson of Boston yesterday in the national championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4.

BERLIN, Sept. 8. -- Bernhard zu Lippe-Biesterfeld is a modest representative of a German noble house noted for the number of its minor branches. His father was the former ruler of the petty principality of Lippe-Detmold, in North Central Germany, and held the rank of major la suite in the Prussian Army.

The Deutsche Lufthansa seaplane Aeolus, with Flight Captain H.W. Von Engel in command and a crew of three, left the Azores at 10:21 o'clock (New York daylight time) last night, bound for New York by way of Bermuda.

OTHERWISE well-disposed persons are likely to be a bit contemptuous of Latin-American leaders. That conclusion was inevitable after a catechizing of recent visitors to this office. One and all the visitors looked with attention upon the gold-and-red dust-wrapper of Thomas Rourke's "Gomez: Tyrant of the Andes" (Morrow, $3.50), which lay on the desk, but none could succeed in identifying the subject.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sails today for Cherbourg and Southampton. Her list Includes Mohammed Amine Youssef, Egyptian Minister to the United States; Ray Atherton, counselor of the United States Embassy in London; Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Wistar Morris, Mr. and Mrs. Truman Talley, Mr. and Mrs. P.W. Parker, Ruth Gordon, actress, and Judge and Mrs. Frederick C. Hill.

Fifteen persons, all members of four families living on the third floor of a tenement at 146 Hester Street, were taken ill last night after they had eaten a meal containing a vegetable they believed to be mushrooms.

Georgia Democrats today, in choosing between Governor GENE TALMADGE and Senator RICHARD RUSSELL, will decide how much "support" they want their United States Senator to give to the President, if Mr. ROOSEVELT should be re-elected. Both have professed their party loyalty from every stump.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 8 -- The crews of the sloop Afonso de Albuquerque and the gunboat Dao revolted early this morning and left their anchorage in the Tagus River to put out to sea, but after an attempt at mediation they were fired on from Fort Almeida and Fort de Duque and quickly disabled.

Louisville, Ky., will consider tenders next Tuesday for a new issue of $4,400,000 of bridge revenue refunding bonds dated Nov. 1, 1936, and maturing Nov. 1, 1955. The bonds will be redeemable on any interest date at a graduated scale of prices, beginning with 102 if redeemed in 1937-38 and 1939.
Steps to strengthen the New York Central Railroad's mortgages will be submitted to stockholders for approval on Oct. 15. The approval of two-thirds of the stockholders is required.

Peter J. McGuinness, Kings County Sheriff, announced last night that he would support Frank J. Prial, insurgent Democratic candidate for the Aldermanic Presidency. His announcement was cheered by 200 of his supporters in the Greenpoint clubhouse.

I see by the morning papers that the departure of the President Hoover from San Francisco for the Orient was again postponed due to the unwillingness of the owners to sign on a certain member of the crew who had been rated as a troublemaker on a previous voyage.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8. -- Discussion concerning the vitamins necessary to physical wellbeing had a large share in the doings of the American Chemical Society today.
Mrs. Beryl C. Markham, the first woman to fly alone westward across the North Atlantic, will be received at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.

The "practical politics" of labor leaders in throwing their support to President Roosevelt this year was sharply criticized last night by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, in an address entitled "The Socialist Party and Labor's Non-Partisan League."

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- After tomorrow's sale of $55,000,000 of emergency unemployment relief bonds no State issue will be offered for sale in the remainder of this calendar year, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, said today. The statement was made in response to inquiries from various banks, he said.
RENO, Sept. 6. -- Mrs. Jane Foster Douglas of New York and Boston obtained a divorce today from Barclay Kountze Douglas on grounds of cruelty. An agreement was reached as to custody of the one child.

ALBANY, Sept. 8. -- District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan opened today the third and last phase of his defense to the removal charges made against him with an angry denunciation of what he described as a "diabolical" attempt to poison the public mind concerning his association with Leo P. Byk, the former Brooklyn slot-machine operator.

All the chain stores and mail-order companies that have reported thus far their sales for August and the first eight months of this year showed increases over the corresponding periods of 1935. Of the eighteen concerns that have issued figures, the volume of sale of four rose at least 20 per cent from sales for August, 1935.

TOPEKA, Sept. 8. -- Governor Landon decided this evening to take part in the campaign in Maine, which is the only State to hold an election in September and is regarded by some persons as a political barometer in Presidential years.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8. -- Four California girls and the same number from the East, including 15-year-old Miss Helen Bernhard of New York, reached the quarterfinals in the girls' national tennis championships on the grass courts of the Philadelphia Cricket Club, St. Martin's today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Allotments of $4,855,142 for 140 PWA projects in thirty-two States, Hawaii and Puerto Rico, were made today by Secretary Ickes. By means of these, it was stated, the Public Works Administration is making possible permanent construction estimated to cost $10,936,233.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 8. -- When the breeze hums through the rigging and the seas just play, the Long Island Sound Interclub sloops are in their element. But when the air is thin with an under-running wash of water, Bermuda craft go faster.

Directors of the Western Electric Company declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 30 to stockholders of record of Sept. 21. On June 30 a dividend of 50 cents a share was paid on the stock, the first distribution since June 30, 1931, when 75 cents was paid.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Roger D. Mellick gave a supper dance tonight at Oldacre, their home here, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Catharine Ginna Mellick. Dancing was in one of the marquees, lighted by pink balloons, which were erected on the lawn of the estate.

Solly, Kreiger, 163 1/2, veteran Brooklyn middleweight, spoiled the metropolitan debut of Ralph Chong, 163, New Orleans, by stopping the Chinese boxer in 2:17 of the seventh round of a scheduled eight-rounder at the Coney Island Velodrome last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A cotton crop of 11,121,000 bales for 1936 was forecast today by the Federal Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture based on conditions on Sept. 1. The new estimate forecast a crop 1,360,000 bales less than predicted one month ago and would compare with a yield of 10,638,000 bales in 1935, 9,636,000 in 1934 and the five-year (1928-32) average of 14,667,000. The Sept. 1 forecast was 59.1 per cent.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 8. -- Rochester captured second place in the International League tonight by defeating Newark, 5 to 2, in a play-off to break a deadlock for that position. The visitors also won the $2,000 cash prize put up by the league for second place.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- The New York Firemen today defeated the Chicago Firemen, 5 to 0, in the fifth meeting between the two baseball teams since the rivalry was started over a decade ago.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8. -- Another step toward solution of the mystery of life was reported here today to the 3,000 chemists attending the meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Maine is crowded with Republican orators denouncing the New Deal, lock, stock and barrel. So far as we have had the happiness of reading these "vigorous" speeches, they are models of overstatement, good enough for stern and unbending Republicans but unlikely to make converts. Governor BRANN is more skillful.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 8. -- As its first formal function in the celebration of Harvard's tercentenary, the Harvard Alumni Association today witnessed the opening by President Conant of the "mysterious" package sealed by President Josiah Quincy at the Harvard bicentennial in 1836.

Mayor La Guardia told 200 probationary patrolmen sworn in yesterday in the trial room at police headquarters that "the department is not what I would like it to be" and announced that he intended to make some corrections.
VIENNA, Austria, Sept. 8 -- King Edward VIII of Britain arrived here today for a stay of two or three days.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 8. -- Entries from the Liangollen Farm of Mrs. John Hay Whitney took five blue ribbons in the hunter classes today at the Empire State Fair horse show.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- American utilities were warned today by Judge Robert E. Healy of the Securities and Exchange Commission in a paper written for the World Power Conference, to free themselves from the hands of "jugglers of finance" and to devote themselves more to the production and sale of gas and electricity and less to the production and sale of securities.

While cut with his mother to buy a book to appease his hunger for knowledge, 13-year-old Stuart Rosencrans of 24 Fifth Avenue, who wants to become a scientist, was seriously in injured yesterday morning when struck by a taxicab near Womrath's book store at MacDougal and Eighth Streets.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8. -- Raging down canyons toward the ocean and over lower ridges of the Santa Monica Mountains, the Topanga District grass and brush fire today destroyed more cabins and thousands of acres of watershed.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Senator Robert M. La Follette Jr. said tonight that seventy-five nationally prominent liberals had accepted invitations to meet in Chicago Friday to pool their support behind a common choice for President.

The largest exhibition of sculpture that has yet been shown in the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third treet, was opened there yesterday. Although the galleries have had eleven previous art exhibitions since January, this is only the third time they have shown sculpture.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 8. -- Queen Wilhelmina today radioed to the nation and the Netherlands colonies her pleasure at her daughter's engagement to wed and then asked both Princess Juliana and her fiance to tell the listeners how happy they were.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 9. -- The Yankees came to the end of the trail at League Park today with a celebration that started mildly enough in the dugout and grew in fervor in the confines of their clubhouse.

The consolidated income account of the Pittsburgh Steel Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on June 30 was issued yesterday and showed a net loss of $265,360 after expenses, depreciation, depletion, amortization, taxes, interest and other charges.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Leo (Lippy) Durocher collected five hits Off Danny MacFayden today and drove in enough runs to give the Cardinals a 3-1 victory over the Bees and end the brilliant fifteeninning pitching battle between the spectacled veteran and the right hander Jim Winford.

PLYMOUTH, England, Sept. 9. -- The joint committee of the Labor party and the Trade Union Congress that has been to Paris to ascertain what line British workers should take concerning non-intervention in the Spanish civil war returned to Plymouth tonight with a report.

Engagement of $8,365,000 gold in Paris for shipment here was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This engagement, the largest of the current gold movement, reflected continued flight of capital from France, where fears for the financial and political stability of the government have been enhanced by the announcement of a large rearmament program.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 10. -- The Foreign Office will await the reports of the consular party investigating the Pakhoi murder before acting.
LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 9. -- The sailors involved in the mutiny aboard two warships in Lisbon Harbor yesterday have been dismissed from service and ordered deported to the Portuguese penal colony.

When the Democrats try to prove that Governor LANDON comes from a State where they neglect their schools, it makes The Emporia Gazette a trifle impatient, and, it must be confessed, with reason. Emporia's sage, Warwick and editor points out that Kansas has twice as many boys and girls in high school as New York, in proportion to her population, and a good many more students in college.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Hogs met with a rather slow demand today, due in part to reports that the call for fresh pork was not as active as recently. Sales were steady to as much as 15 cents a hundredweight lower, with the leading packers bidding generally 10 to 15 cents lower.

John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, will arrive here tomorrow to confer with leaders from eighteen States at headquarters of the committee's Eastern division in the Liggett Building, 41 East Forty-second Street.
