WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Imports of iron and steel products, excluding scrap metals, reached 38,350 tons in July, compared with 40,323 in the previous month and 30,310 in July, 1935, the Department of Commerce reported today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Harness ponies and horses owned by Miss Judy King of Atlanta took the spotlight of the Empire State Horse Show's third session away from the spectacular entry of saddle horses, hunters and jumpers tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9. -- The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Aug. 3l shows the following changes, in paper pesos:

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- Two million francs in prizes will be offered for the transatlantic air derby from New York to Paris, which the French Air Ministry is organizing to be held on May 21 next year to commemorate the tenth anniversary of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's flight.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Short-lived was Andres Gazzotti's return to action today, for the highest-ranked member of the visiting Argentine polo squad, resuming play after more than a week's layoff, fell hard in the opening period of a practice battle on the Meadow Brook Club's Whitney Field and had to call it a day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, Rochester, N.Y., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 40,000 shares of $100 par value Series E 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Tully Leemans, former George Washington back and an outstanding ball carrier for the All-Stars in games against the Lions and the Giants, today reported to the New York eleven at the Blue Hill C.C. Leemans will be put to work in earnest tomorrow learning plays so that he will be ready for action Sunday, when the Giants open the defense of their Eastern title against the Eagles in Philadelphia.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 9. -- The Japanese Navy today ordered the destroyers Wakataki and Sanae to steam immediately to Hongkong and Canton in preparation for providing protection for a Japanese investigation of the murder of Junzo Nakano, a Japanese, at Pakhoi, Kwangtung.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 9. -- Governor Landon's unexpected and dramatic announcement that he would speak the final word in the Republican State campaign at a rally here Saturday night, on the eve of the State election Monday, was the chief topic of discussion in political camps today.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., Sept. 9. -- Paying a first visit today to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, President Roosevelt ate an al fresco luncheon in a pouring rain, more than a mile above sea level, viewed the natural wonders of the park and, at the end of his holiday, pronounced himself "delighted and thrilled."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Loans and grants amounting to $16,000,000 for 127 PWA projects in thirty-six States, of an estimated total cost of $15,860,075, were announced today by Secretary Ickes. The difference between the total cost and the allotments will be provided by the applicants.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9. -- Organized medicine and organized chemistry apparently have been widening an open breach since 3,000 chemists gathered here on Monday for the meeting of the American Chemical Society.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- This city will be unable to carry its refief burden beyond the end of this month, the City Commission declared in a telegram sent today to Governor Hoffman, members of the State Financial Assistance Commission and members of the State Legislature from Essex County.

Public offering will be made today by Hammons Co., Inc., and Dulin Co. of Los Angeles, of voting trust certificates for 280,869 shares of $1 par value common stock of the Universal Corporation, at $10 for each certificate. This offering represents financing to provide new capital for Universal, which in April of this year acquired controlling interest of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., and the Big "U" Film Exchange, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Regular air passenger and mail service by the Pan American Airways will be started between Oakland, Calif., and Manila, a distance of 7,990 miles, within thirty to sixty days, Secretary Roper announced today with the statement that the plans had the approval of the Bureau of Air Commerce.
Four attempts to burn Public School 171, which occupies the block from 103d to 104th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, were frustrated yesterday by members of the registration staff.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- The National City Bank of New York City and associates won today the award of an issue of $55,000,000 emergency unemployment relief bonds at a public sale conducted by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller. The interest cost to the State, the lowest at which the State ever has borrowed money, is 1,36338 per cent.

PARIS, Sept. 9. -- After a day of critical negotiations with government representatives the administrative committee of the General Confederation of Labor broke away from the militant Communists and agreed to a mild formula requesting reconsideration of the French neutrality policy toward Spain.

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 9. -- The Vatican issued today another rebuke to the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, who is reported here as having said in a recent press interview that criticism of his political activities contained in an article in the Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, reflected only that paper's opinion and not that of the Vatican.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Money in circulation at the end of August amounted to $6,226,557,523, the Treasury announced today. This was an increase of $64,609,824 in the month and of $597,776,121 over Aug. 31, 1935. The average per capita circulation was $48.43, compared with $47.98 on July 31 this rear and $44.09 on Aug. 31, 1935.

For obvious reasons it is not likely that Colonel Knox, Chairman Hamilton, other Republican dignitaries and a host of small tradesmen will end the campaign under indictment for having violated Federal and State laws in campaign utterances and activities. The administration and Democratic State governments could not risk the charge of fascism that would immediately arise.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- America's game conservation groups, loosely allied in years past, now are being welded into a compact organization prepared to use its voting strength to obtain appropriations and other legislation for wildlife preservation.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens announced yesterday he would interview Governor Lehman concerning the charges published by The New York Post and placed before the Governor alleging that Mr. Sullivan was lax in prosecution of the Donnelly murder case.
The weekly report of crop conditions, issued by the United States Weather Bureau, follows:

COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 9. -- That nemesis of the sea, all-enveloping fog, very effectively put a stop to all attempts to get the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Cup series for the national women's sailing championship under way off this harbor today.

More than 300 underprivileged children competed in games yesterday afternoon and romped on the lawn of the stately chateau of Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, at Riverside Drive and Seventy-third Street.

The population of New York City should be about 9,227,000 in 1965, assuming that will be the year in which stabilization will be reached, the Mayor's Committee on City Planning reported yesterday. The committee said the estimated probable ultimate figure had been adopted by its staff for purposes of plan-making, adding that "there is far more room in the city than ever will be required by any conceivable population."

Former President Herbert Hoover and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, rivals in the Presidential race of 1928, met again yesterday at a directors' meeting of the New York Life Insurance Company. They did not discuss politics or the New Deal, which both men are opposing, Mr. Smith said.

Stocks eased slightly and closed lower yesterday as professionals were disposed to take profits after Tuesday's brisk advance. Add to this the fact that trading was slower on the decline, and the story of the stock market is about complete.

Peace reigned at Tammany Hall yesterday as the district leaders met for their first executive committee meeting since the one at which Christopher D. Sullivan and William P. Kenneally had their fist tight.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which discontinued all newspaper advertising in the Eastern territory after the Robinson-Patman bill was passed, launched a new newspaper campaign yesterday. Major newspapers throughout the area will be used, it was stated at the offices of the Eastern division of the company here.

LINCOLIN, Neb., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Senator George W. Norris, veteran Nebraska Republican independent, was named today a candidate for re-election with the filing in the Secretary of State's office of a pe tition bearing 40,504 signature on his behalf.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Vic Fleming, Syracuse driver, scored a double in today's Grand Circuit events before 6,000 fans, winning the classified pace in straight heats with The Baker, owned by the Cahill Brothers of Syracuse, and completing the double with Mr. H.M. Jones, the property of F.L. Wiswall of Loudenville.
Holiday Monday, Sept. 7, Labor Day: No reports.

SEATTLE, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Attorneys for the Hearst Publications, Inc., charged today that the American Newspaper Guild engaged in a boycott against The Seattle Post-Intelligencer before the Aug. 13 strike of Guild members which resulted in the paper suspending publication.

Shipments of burlap from India to North America during the month of August reached the highest level in more than six years, according to cable advices received here yesterday by C.E. Rockstroh Co., Inc. The total was 112,600,000 yards, as against 76,000,000 yards in July and 65,208,000 yards in August, 1935.

The Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures disclosed yesterday that a group of wealthy men headed by five members of the du Pont family, J.P. Morgan and the John D. Rockefellers, senior and junior, had contributed $51,600 for the Republican campaign in Maine.

Building plans filed by architects yesterday included projects for a garage in West Nineteenth Street and a taxpayer on Second Avenue. Other Manhattan plans call for alterations to be made in a variety of: existing structures.

The wage scale committee of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, which has threatened a strike of 15,000 union truce drivers in this city, voted yesterday to break off negotiations with the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau, representing the employers.
BERLIN, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 7 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

FARGO, N. D., Sept. 9. -- The Fargo Forum editorially will charge the Works Progress Administration tomorrow with bad faith in "an attempt to squirm out of a charge of faking drought pictures" by announcing that The Forum had retracted its charge of "fake" in connection with a photograph which showed a herd of cattle grazing near the North Dakota Capitol Building at Bismarck.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 9. -- Burgomaster Adolf Max, Belgian war hero, was assaulted today and struck on the head by a worker while he was visiting the annual fair in the St. Catherine quarter of Brussels. He was able to continue his visit, but was taken home hurriedly tonight, although it was said that his injuries were not serious.

Mayor La Guardia and Controller Frank J. Taylor conferred yesterday afternoon at City Hall with representatives of the city's bankers with a view to further revising the bankers' agreement so that the city will be able next year partly to wipe out the ply cuts imposed on city employes three years ago.

A State law to prohibit the dissemination of communistic doctrines through political speeches or by other means was proposed yesterday by Borough President George U. Harvey, who refused a request of the Queens Communist party on Tuesday for a permit to hold a meeting in the Jamaica Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The Public Service Company of New Hampshire, Manchester, N.H., a subsidiary of the New England Public Service Company, a registered holding company, has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 for an issue of not more than $3,000,000 of promissory notes to be sold at private sale to not more than six banks.

Mrs. Beryl Markham, the English pilot who crashed in a Cape Breton bog after flying alone across the North Atlantic, called on Mayor La Guardia yesterday afternoon. Her appointment with the Mayor was for 4:30 o'clock, but because of other conferences with Controller Taylor and a group of bankers Mrs. Markham had to wait a half hour.

Today is the date set for the National League birthday and old-timers' celebration at Ebbets Field, but the Dodgers and Pirates seemed to have their dates mixed yesterday and gave a premature exhibition of the bewhiskered burlesques that have been enlivening President Ford Frick's circuit this season.

The sudden decision of Governor LANDON to make a speech in Maine on the eve of next Monday's election has set the politicians gossiping and guessing. Is it a sign that the Republican managers are frightened lest they lose that New England State ? Do they regard the outlook as so desperate that they have frantically summoned Mr. LANDON to the rescue?

BOSTON, Sept. 9. -- Donald Leveridge of New York, one of the passengers on board the steamship New York who rushed from his cabin to the deck when the vessel was in collision with the excursion steamer Romance, related tonight how it appeared to him that the crash occurred.
The Giants began their big drive for a pennant amid the encouraging roars of 23,000 onlookers at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but managed to hit the nail on the head only once in two tries.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The peace and quiet of a neighborhood are of greater importance than the vocal liberty of dogs, Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley ruled today in holding that Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Bolles of the Westchester Country Club may not keep dogs given to "excessive barking."

MADRID, Sept. 2 (By Courier to Hendaye, France, Sept. 9). -- Mass executions of Fascists continue daily in Madrid. It is estimated that the total since the civil war began is well over 1,000. The death penalty is decreed almost hourly.

The family row over the Olympic Games which split the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States so sharply last Winter broke out afresh yesterday as a result of a proposal to move the 1936 annual convention from Houston to Chicago.

Eleven new diphtheria cases last week, an increase of three over the previous week, brought the total number of cases in the city thus far this year to 937, as compared with 839 cases in the same period last year, Health Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- The last and most serious of the special grand jury's charges against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn was laid before Governor Lehman today through an array of evidence depicting Mr. Geoghan as the close friend of the head of the city-wide slot machine business at a time when that suspected enterprise had reached its most menacing proportions.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 9. -- Scientists are not especially concerned with the social consequences of their work. Statesmen have no way of foreseeing how science will reshape society. Hence "the crucial impact of science on society is nobody's business," Sir Josiah Stamp, economist and industrialist, told the British Association for the Advancement of Science in his presidential address today.

Up-State Democratic leaders told James A. Farley, National Chairman, yesterday that President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman would hold Republican pluralities in their areas down to the 1932 level and thus assure a Democratic victory in the State.

In the best played match thus far in the women's tournament Miss Katherine Stammers of Great Britain valiantly fought off the dangerous challenge of Miss Carolin Babcock of Los Angeles yesterday to gain the semi-final round of the national championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

William A. Brady, theatrical producer, announced yesterday his intention of asking for new hearings on the present plan of reorganization of the Baldwin Locomotive Works. His attorneys, Loria Martinson, of 535 Fifth Avenue, will enter a plea this week before the Federal District Court in Philadelphia for a rehearing.

L'ANSE, Mich., Sept. 9. -- A model farm-industrial village will rise in the forest near here, as a part of Henry Ford's "back to the land" movement, when relocation of a section of Highway U.S. 41 is completed.

BERLIN, Sept. 9. -- The Boerse continued to be in a semi-paralytic condition today. Issues that had any turnover at all opened with signs of recovery, but sagged again toward the close. Losses amounted to 2 points and more, but stocks representing cellulose, which is playing a big part in Chancellor Hitler's new autarchical program, closed fractionally firmer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 9. -- Criticism of the Supreme Court, coupled with the warning that the American people are heading toward a constitutional crisis "of unpredictable gravity," was voiced here today by Dr. Edward S. Corwin, Professor of Jurisprudence at Princeton University.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 9. -- Although he finished sixth in a seven-horse race and disappointed the crowd that made him an odds-on favorite, Cavalcade, the 3-year-old champion of 1934, gave a performance satisfactory to Trainer Bob Smith today when he made his first start in more than fifteen months in a mile-and-a-sixteenth allowance event at Narragansett Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- A hearing today by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the application by the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Corporation to have stricken from listing and registration on the New York Stock Exchange 89,772 shares of its common stock which it held to be "without value," attracted unusual interest because of the bearing the decision by the SEC may have on its attitude in other delisting proceedings.

If sensitive souls were pained yesterday by the keynoter of the Connecticut Republican State Convention, keening our lost liberty, they were refreshed and lifted up by reading the good old news of the Vermont Republican primary. A farmer and horticulturist was nominated for Governor.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 9. -- Jockel V. Burgund, Doberman pinscher, owned by Owen A. West of Lake Forest, Ill., was judged best of the show at the State Fair today. It was his fifteenth all-breed championship this season.

Movements of prices were mixed in moderately active trading on the local commodity exchanges yesterday. Tallow, silk and tin futures were strong and copper and rubber easy. On the cash markets, beef, printcloths, silk and tins advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, cotton and rubber declined.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 9. -- Arthur M. Brown of Griswold was nominated for Governor by the Republican State Convention here this afternoon by 383 out of a possible 606 votes. Hugh M. Alcorn of Suffield, Hartford County States Attorney, the 1934 nominee, received 127 votes, and John Q. Tilson of New Haven, former floor leader in the National House, received 96.

Playing the role of a Mayor in an old-fashioned town meeting, Mayor La Guardia gave an account of his stewardship since 1934 yesterday to the 7,600,000 residents of New York. His report was in the form of the first city year book to be published by the municipality.

J. Stanley Cohen, 27 years old, a lawyer, of 218 East 169th Street, the Bronx, was arrested yesterday by Detective Thomas Neary of the new accident fraud bureau on a warrant charging him with ambulance chasing. His bail was fixed at $250, for pleading on the charge today.

MADRID, Sept. 9 (AP). -- A body of about 100 anti-Fascist Germans, it was reported from Lerida in Northeastern Spain, left for the front today, with cheers following their march through the streets. Most of them, the dispatch said, were World War veterans.

BOSTON, Sept. 9. -- Edmund L. Dolan, City Treasurer of Boston in the last Curley administration, must repay the city $131,161.90 "which he obtained illegally and in breach of his official duties" while in office, Judge Edward F. Hanify of the Superior Court held today.

Apartment renting spurted yesterday as the end of the vacation season brought home to prospective tenants the nearness of Oct. 1 and the beginning of the new rental year. The Manhattan leases reported were about equally divided between the East and West Sides.

With shipments to Spain suspended by almost all exporters here, uncertainty widespread regarding Portugal and rumors of devaluation growing stronger in France, the Continent held first interest for export credit men who met yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania to discuss credit and trade conditions in foreign countries.

ATLANTA, Sept. 9. -- Richard B. Russell Jr., Georgia's bachelor Senator, claimed victory tonight in his bid for renomination as mounting returns from the State Democratic primary increased his lead over his anti-New Deal opponent, Governor Eugene Talmadge.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9. -- Miss Hope Knowles, 17-year-old Chestnut Hill player, prevented California entrants from making a clean sweep in the quarter-final round of the girls' national tennis championship singles at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 9. -- Spanish Government forces claimed tonight the capture of the Toledo Alcazar, where more than 1,000 military cadets, soldiers and Civil Guards have been besieged since the outbreak of the civil war. The fate of the garrison is unknown here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Speakers from New York City, appearing in the name of Mayor La Guardia, caused a stir at the World Power Conference today. Mayor La Guardia's power policies were the basic subject-matter of talks by Maurice P. Davidson, former New York City Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, and Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner and Chairman of the New York City Housing Administration.

The rise of more than $3 a bale in the price of cotton that followed Tuesday's unexpected reduction in the government's forecast of the crop just when new cotton is beginning to move in volume attracted heavy hedge selling yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange lost an early advance, to end with losses of 4 to 14 points.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Buffalo, International League pennant winner, defeated Newark, 6 to 0, tonight in the first game of the best four-out-of-seven series in the semi-final play-offs for the Governor's cup and the right to represent the league in the little world's series.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9. -- Gladys George's performance in "Valant Is the Word for Carrie" has elicited so much favorable talk around the Paramount studio that she has been borrowed from Metro for a second film. It will be "A Man and a Woman," a B.P. Schulberg production, in which she will appear opposite Edward Arnold.
Investors showed a preference for apartment houses in the Washington Heights and Harlem sections in deals announced yesterday.

Unless Japan transforms her hitherto auxiliary chemical industries into independent trusts "capable of producing any kind of modern chemicals, from fertilizers to rayon, from soap to explosives, from celluloid to perfume," she can never become a really powerful nation, according to the Far Eastern Survey of the American Council, Institute of Pacific Relations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The Fall sports card at Princeton University, which was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics, includes fifty-one contests for nine teams, in addition to a special running of the Princeton Invitation Mile.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 9. -- Salient points of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's proclamation of the government's program for the next four years, which was read before the National Socialist party congress here today, are given textually, as follows:

Recurrence of warm weather has played some part in the slower pace of retail trade which has developed in comparison with last month, but retail executives here were inclined to believe that the later date of the Labor Day holiday has delayed active consumer shopping by about a week.

Five former national champions, an equal number of British Walker Cup players and seven members of the victorious American team, to say nothing of the lesser luminaries, are scheduled to swing into action on Monday when the national amateur championship gets under way at the Garden City Golf Club.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 9. -- At the very outset of the fourth annual National Socialist party congress this morning there was laid before it and before the world Chancellor Adolf Hitler's program for German policy for the next four years.

The Viking Products Corporation announced yesterday that hereafter it will concentrate its efforts in the manufacture and sale of its own and controlled products and will retire from a general electrical wholesaling field. The wholesale division has been sold to the Westinghouse Electric Supply Company.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Dusty Hanover, owned by the Hanover (Pa.) Shoe Farms and driven by Henry Thomas, gained a straight-heat victory at the Indiana State Fair Grounds today in the $10,000 Fox Stake for two-year-old pacers, richest event of its kind on the Grand Circuit program.

Two New Yorkers accused of trying to extort $75,000 from a Dubuque, Iowa, manufacturer, a bidder for the sale of $1,250,000 worth of snow-removal machinery to the New York City Sanitation Department, were held without bail yesterday by Magistrate Samuel M. Katz in Felony Court.

The governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of $29,500,000 of 3 1/2 per cent, Series E, "gold clause" bonds of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company but required the applicant to cite Public Resolution 10 of the Seventy-third Congress outlawing promises of payment in gold.
Directors of the Midland Steel Products Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1.25 a share on the common stock. On July 1 a distribution of 25 cents was made.

Auctioneers held foreclosure sales of eleven Manhattan properties yesterday, all the offerings being taken over by the mortgagees. The list consisted largely of tenement houses, one sale involving a group of six flats on a Madison Avenue corner.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, commented here tonight on a statement released in New York by James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, in which Mr. Farley listed a number of wealthy contributors to the Republican campaign in Maine.

TORONTO, Sept. 9 (Canadian Press). -- Roaring over Lake Ontario at an average speed of 48.7 miles an hour, Miss Quebec II tonight scored her second successive victory in the three-heat race for the 225-cubic inch class powerboat championship of the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will resume on next Monday public hearings in its investment trust inquiry, taking up the affairs of Central Illinois Securities Corporation, of Chicago, and the National Bond and Share Corporation and Granger Trading, both of New York City.
This matter of milk price is a vexing problem. In any consideration a matter of controlling importance is politics.

After a Summer of practice at Nichols, Conn., the Group Theatre people have decided on the first show of their sixth Broadway season. It is "Johnny Johnson," the play by Paul Green with music by Kurt Weill -- and not merely incidental music either.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Phillies and Cubs divided a double-header today, the visitors winning the first game, 10 -- 8, when Larry French limited the Phils to eight hits and hung up his seventeenth victory of the season.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Moulton opened their home, Oakwood, here tonight for one of the largest attended musicales of the season. It was a concert by Alessandro Niccoli, violinist, who had William Ellis Weston as his accompanist.

Business failures increased in the manufacturing, wholesale and retail groups in the week ended Sept. 3, compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Although insolvencies in the retail group continued lower than the thirty-six weeks' average this year, the reduction was narrowed to 20, against 23 and 36, respectively, in the two preceding weeks.

Upward of 4,000 men, hopeful of getting jobs as truck drivers in the Sanitation Department, were massed outside the north section of the Municipal Building when it opened at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. Some of the job-hunters had been waiting in line since midnight.

With the largest number of exhibitors in recent years, the 1936 National Electrical and Radio Exposition was opened yesterday in Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue at Forty-sixth Street. All available space was sold long before the show opened at 11 A.M.

Charges that officials of Stone Webster, Inc., a holding company for engineering and other concerns, wasted the company's assets in "pegging the market" to maintain the price of the stock and in lobbying against the Public Utility Act, were made yesterday in Supreme Court in a stockholder's suit against the company and sixteen individual officers and directors.

Cotton colored yarn fabrics took the lead in a number of price advances which were put into effect yesterday in the primary cotton goods market. A substantial volume of orders was placed by buyers, particularly garment manufacturers, although dry goods jobbers were inclined to await developments, because of some distrust of the government's cotton crop estimate on the previous day.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 9 (AP). -- John Cobb of London set four new world motor car speed records today, and tonight A.B. Jenkins of Salt Lake City, fighting to bring those four and many others back to the United States, charged that the Briton "trespassed" in his run on this famed salt speedway.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The fight of the taxpayers of Annsville, a suburb of this village, against consolidation of its school district with that of Van Cortlandtville ended today when Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, dismissed their appeal from a dissolution order and ordered the one-room school closed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Motion pictures of the attempted airplane bombing of the United States destroyer Kane off the southwestern coast of Spain on Aug. 30 were taken by an unidentified person aboard the warship, Secretary of the Navy Swanson revealed today. The films will be thoroughly examined by the Navy Department when they reach Washington.

Bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange continued to point toward moderately higher prices yesterday in the most active trading for bonds on the Exchange since July 17. Activity was centered main-in domestic corporation loans, and selected issues, led by second-grade railroad loans, responded to a demand which carried some 1 to 3 points higher.

The letter from Mrs. L.S. Jurist on "Children in the Streets" should be of interest to every thoughtful citizen. "All-day schools" are suggested as a solution for idle, mischievous children who are our potential criminals.

Formation of a new bureau within the State Department of Insurance to have full jurisdiction over mortgages and mortgage certificates was approved at a conference yesterday among Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance; William R. White, Superintendent of Banks; Ambrose V. McCall, Deputy Attorney General, and members of the joint legislative committee to investigate investment companies and bondholders' committees.

DONCASTER, England, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Lightly regarded in the wagering, William Woodward's Boswell, a 20-to-1 shot, today won the 156th running of the St. Leger Stakes, last of the British turf season's classics for 3-year-olds.
Stockholders of the B.F. Goodrich Company approved yesterday the plan for readjusting its capital structure.
TOPEKA, Sept. 9. -- From all parts of the United States came telegrams to Governor Landon today approving his decision to participate in the Maine campaign by speaking at Portland Saturday night.

Marking the fourth consecutive month of relative inactivity, no improvement was shown in the selling markets for men's wear cloths during July, according to the statistical report issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

BOSTON, Sept. 9. -- Driving through a blinding fog at about 7:15 o'clock tonight, the steamship New York of the Eastern Steamship Lines rammed and sank the excursion steamer Romance, returning to Boston from Provincetown with 274 on board.

New York City has issued almost $900,000,000 in bonds and notes to provide rapid transit facilities, Controller Frank J. Taylor said yesterday in a report sent to the Transit Commission on the eve of the unification hearings.
SEATTLE, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Candidates endorsed by Townsend pension-plan advocates apparently were headed tonight toward nomination in four of Washington's six Congressional districts.

The history of the establishment of the "prevailing wage" principle in the WPA is instructive. In January, 1935, when the President presented his work-relief proposal to Congress, he declared that the compensation "should be larger than the amount now received as a relief dole, but at the same time not so large as to encourage the rejection of opportunities for private employment."

DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Washington came from behind today with an attack featured by four home runs to beat the Tigers, 11 to 4, and take possession of third place in the American League pennant chase.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Business improved today at the third session of Elsie Janis's auction and so did the crowd, but because many things still remain to be sold the auction will continue tomorrow. Miss Janis, who again acted as auctioneer part of the time, is selling her belongings to devote her life to the service of others.
Mayor La Guardia undertook last night to prove by personal demonstration that the new Park Avenue Motor Vehicle Tunnel may safely be completed without a ventilating system.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, Lakeville star, played some of her best golf of the season to win the Long Island Women's Association's one-day event at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

BOSTON, Sept. 9. -- A new offer for the purchase of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in Manchester, N.H., the world's largest textile plant, has been made by a New York syndicate which sent representatives to confer with the trustees of the company and examine the machinery and equipment in Manchester all day today.

Bids were submitted yesterday by two shipyards for the construction of a new passenger-freight ship which would be operated by the United States Lines in its service between New York, the Channel ports and Hamburg.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9. -- A forecast of new developments in the science of food which would help to produce a race of supermen and superwomen, raising the mental levels of the human race and perhaps eliminating the idiot was presented before the American Chemical Society today in an address by Dr. E. P. Armstrong, president of the Association of British Chemical Manufacturers.
Mayor La Guardia in a ninety-minute talk yesterday to the Kings County grand jury disputed charges of insanitary conditions in Brooklyn made by County Judge Franklin Taylor to that group.

Fighting head winds and running into squalls and rainstorms, the German airplane Zephyr and its crew of four were over the Atlantic Atlantic early this morning on a flight from the Azores to Port Washington, L.I.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9. -- Speculative interest in wheat on the Board of Trade was light today with the action of foreign markets the dominating influence. An early advance of around a cent a bushel was followed by a recession when Winnipeg weakened, and the close was within a fraction of the bottom, with net losses of 1/2 to 5/8 cent.

Despite the fact that the city has rented considerable additional space to house its activities, the 1937 rental total will be $19,973 below the 1936 figure, Budget Director Leo J. McDermott was informed yesterday by officials of the Finance Department.

VIENNA, Sept. 9. -- King Edward of Britain visited the Vienna Fair this morning, spending a long time at the British Indian pavilion. Later he called on President Wilhelm Miklas, who returned the call at the British legation.

District Attorney William C. Dodge notified Henry H. Klein, a lawyer, yesterday, that he would not cause the rearrest of two of the principal witnesses for the State in the slaying of Herman Rosenthal, the gambler, twenty-four years ago, unless Mr. Klein could furnish new evidence justifying such action.

In the ordinary course of events any coach who found himself left with eight regulars from the year before and a well-equipped group of sophomores might be expected to be slightly muscle-bound from patting himself on the back. But Sleepy Jim Crowley is in no such self-congratulatory mood these days.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 9. -- Within each of the germ-cells out of which all living creatures emerge, from tape-worm to man, there sits a "sculptor" who molds the aboriginal clay of life into his own image, and a master-builder who organizes the stuff of life into its various tissues and organs.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Seventy-five craft, including the Bermuda One-Design sloops and eight Interclubs, competed today in the opening regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week. Among the class winners were Bert Darrell's Princess, which finished first three times in the international match concluded yesterday; Lawrence Marx's Interclub Alberta; Robert W. Fraser's Victory boat Black Jack and James Moxham's Atlantic craft Petrel.

More than 3,000 men and women filled Carnegie Hall last night to hear the reports of sixteen American delegates to the World Jewish Congress, held in Geneva last month. Thirty-two nations were represented at the Geneva session.
LONDON, Sept. 9. -- Italy and Germany again showed today how easily they could obstruct the rest of Europe in the effort to keep war supplies from Spain and prevent the civil war from spreading.

License Commissioner Paul Moss, after a hearing yesterday, denied an application for a permit to operate a motion-picture theatre at 1 East Fifty-second Street, in the heart of the Fifth Avenue business area.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP). -- Vernon Kennedy defeated Rube Walberg and Bob Grove in a thirteen-inning pitchers' battle today to achieve his twentieth victory of the season as the White Sox downed Boston, 3 to 2.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Albert (Scotty) Campbell, American Walker Cup player from Seattle, today shot a 69, four under par, in his first time around the Garden City Golf Club course, scene of the national amateur championship, starting Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Works Progress Administration ruled today that although the needy must accept available private jobs, they need not do so "unless they are qualified to do the work and when such work is at a standard or going rate of wages."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Seventy-five craft, including the Bermuda One-Design sloops and eight Interclubs, competed today in the opening regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week. Among the class winners were Bert Darrell's Princess, which finished first three times in the international match concluded yesterday; Lawrence Marx's Interclub Alberta; Robert W. Fraser's Victory boat Black Jack and James Moxham's Atlantic craft Petrel.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 9 (AP). -- Albert (Scotty) Campbell, American Walker Cup player from Seattle, today shot a 69, four under par, in his first time around the Garden City Golf Club course, scene of the national amateur championship, starting Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP). -- The Works Progress Administration ruled today that although the needy must accept available private jobs, they need not do so "unless they are qualified to do the work and when such work is at a standard or going rate of wages."

New Yorkers experienced yesterday another day of oppressive heat. The highest temperature was 87 degrees at 1:15 P.M. The low was 70 at 6:30 A.M. The record high for the day is 92, established in 1872. The average was 78, 9 above normal.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 9. -- Keen competition prevailed today in the national individual rifle match, in which 1,854 are battling for the championship, and when the first four stages had been concluded five shooters of the first eleven were only six points down, with totals of 194 out of a possible 200.

CANNES, France, Sept. 9. -- Mrs. Ottilie Gobel Moore of Brooklyn, N.Y., who has just arrived at her villa at Villefranche from Salzburg, Austria, reports she was insulted by German frontier customs guards at Schwarzach.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Cooperation between the States in the solution of common agricultural problems must be achieved with more certainty and the Federal Government is the proper agency to do it, Governor Lehman declared here tonight in an address at a farm dinner sponsored by Jerome Barnum, publisher of The Syracuse Post-Standard.

The capture off Seabright, N.J., last Tuesday of a 720-pound tuna, largest ever taken on rod and reel in United States waters, suggests the interesting possibility that the Jersey grounds may yet produce the world's record for the species. L. Mitchell-Henry's 851-pounder, landed off the English coast, is the world record fish.

ALBANY, Sept. 9. -- Attorney General Bennett, in construing Subdivision 2 of Section 196 of the Election Law today, ruled that at a primary election any political committee may have a watcher and any two or more candidates whose names are upon the ballot to be voted at the polling place may have a watcher.

The opening of hearings on the management's plan for reorganization of the Chicago North Western Railway at this time before the Interstate Commerce Commission will mark the beginning of an arduous period for that body. The commission will hear cross-examination on Sept. 22 of the plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific put forward by leading insurance companies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Long telegrams carried on today the charges and counter-charges between Wilber M. Brucker, candidate for the Republican Senatorial nomination from Michigan against Senator Couzens, and the special senate committee investigating campaign expenditures, under the chairmanship of Senator Lonergan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Plans for two new battleships of 35,000 tons each, which the Navy Department is "getting in shape," tentatively include the installation of 18-inch guns, the greatest caliber armament in the history of the world, it was disclosed at a press conference with Secretary Claude A. Swanson and Admiral William H. Standley, Chief of Naval Operations, this morning.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 9. -- Minturn de Suzzara Verdi of Syosset gave a dinner dance tonight at the Piping Rock Club to introduce to society his youngest daughter, Miss Patricia Verdi. Later, the host took his daughter and their guests to the party at Mrs. Walter B. James's home in Cold Spring Harbor.

Those hardy souls who seek to demonstrate their intrepidity by taking a cold shower in the morning before rushing off to work place their systems under "a tremendous strain" which in some cases may lead to great harm and even premature death, according to a warning sounded at yesterday's session of the fifteenth annual convention of the American Congress of Physical Therapy.

Threats of reprisals by municipalities in the Pennsylvania anthracite region on New York trucking concerns because of the recent seizure in this city of trucks containing coal alleged to have been stolen from mines there, reached John C. McDermott, Assistant District Attorney, yesterday.

Public hearings on the $436,000,000 rapid-transit unification plan negotiated by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. with representatives of the B.M. T., Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company will begin this morning before the Transit Commission at 270 Madison Avenue.

THE night gathering on the Polo Grounds gridiron was a great show, but just a fair-to-middling football game. Naturally it would be at this time of year. The College All-Stars had been playing together only a few weeks. The Giants won't be in full stride for a month or more yet.

" Man never is but always to be blest." So Government is always to be simplified, made more efficient and more economical, but never is. Plans for the radical reconstruction of the Federal Government at Washington are many years old. President TAFT urged Congress to take action on the subject.

Testimonials have always been distasteful to me, but I feel a pent-up urge to express my gratitude for the truthful and splendidly accurate dissemination of current history that has been my benefit from the daily reading of THE NEW YORK TIMES for the last twenty years.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 9. -- An unofficial but effective armistice tonight halted fighting in the Spanish Rebel siege of this government-held city on the Bay of Biscay.

RUBBER collars, Hollywood sizzle pants and hair dye stand for romance, a wheel chair for hope, a charred oak keg for charity, a fancy shirt for pride, Mae West perfume for girlish dreams, and a septic tank for progress, in George Milburn's bitter, often funny, first novel, "Catalogue" (Harcourt, Brace, $2).

The opening of hearings on the management's plan for reorganization of the Chicago North Western Railway at this time before the Interstate Commerce Commission will mark the beginning of an arduous period for that body. The commission will hear cross-examination on Sept. 22 of the plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific put forward by leading insurance companies.

Book publishers of New York and other cities met yesterday at The Times Annex for the first showing of the official floor plans of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair to be held at Rockefeller Center Nov. 5 to 19. Drawings for exhibitors' space at the Book Fair will be held today at the offices of Reynal Hitchcock, 386 Fourth Avenue.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10. -- The press will not be admitted tomorrow afternoon to the meeting of the American Chemical Society at which Herman Seydel, Jersey City manufacturing chemist, will read his much-debated paper discussing the relief of arthritis by a new benzoates compound.

OTTAWA, Sept, 10 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday increased $9,715,069, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. Deposits by chartered banks declined $7,046,641.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Remington Arms Company, Inc., has been called for Sept. 25 in Wilmington, Del., to consider a plan of recapitalization by which the company's 7 per cent first preferred stock would be eliminated and additional common stock would be offered to stockholders.

TOPEKA, Sept. 10. -- Just before leaving tonight for Portland to speak in the Maine State campaign, Governor Landon approved a schedule calling for short speeches in four up-State New York cities on his way back and made public the names of those who will accompany him on the trip.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10. -- Choline and its chemical "cousins," first discovered in the bile of cattle and later isolated (one-tenth of an ounce of it) from a ton and a half of mushrooms, is probably one of the "most important chemicals in the animal body," and has proved of great therapeutic value, papers presented today to the American Chemical Society declared.
Nine foreclosure sales of Manhattan properties yesterday included a variety of buildings. The list comprised dwellings, tenements, a loft and a Masonic temple. Two scheduled sales were adjourned.

Attendance yesterday at the 1936 National Electrical and Radio Exposition in Grand Central Palace was reported far ahead of last year's figures at the same time. A survey conducted among the exhibiting manufacturers indicated high hopes for brisk business before the show ends on Sept. 19.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 9, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,479,000,000, an increase of $7,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $1,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 10. -- A heavy artillery bombardment by Spanish Rebels tonight shattered a forty-eight-hour unofficial truce in the San Sebastian sector.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

The largest turnout in the history of the event was on hand for the fortieth annual outing of the New York Stock Exchange, held yesterday at the Fresh Meadow Golf Club in Flushing. More than 300 reported and 212 competed in the golf tournament, which was the chief attraction of the day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- The government report today on the corn crop suggesting a yield of 1,458,000,000 bushels was somewhat of a surprise to the grain trade, as a further lowering in the indicated supply had been expected. The figure for Sept. 1 was 42,000,000 bushels in excess of the recent private returns and was 19,000,000 bushels above the official returns a month ago.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10. -- Business in the Pittsburgh district continued to improve last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Gains were primarily in the heavy industries although nearly all lines of business reported improvement.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 10. -- Called because of the stress of the times, the Malines congress of Belgian churchmen, which meets four times a century, assembled today.
BURGOS, Spain, Sept. 10 (By Courier to Hendaye, France). -- The fighting resulting in the Rebel capture of Arenas de San Pedro on Sunday involved cavalry for the first time in the Spanish civil war.
A total of 6,232 passengers will arrive on various ships today on one of the heaviest shipping days of the year, with about 6,000 of the arrivals from Europe.

WASHINGTON Sept. 10 (A.P.). -- Allotment of $19,606,767 to projects in forty-eight States, New York City and the District of Columbia was announced today by the National Youth Administration. The total included $1,118,494 for increasing student-aid quotas in drought-stricken States.

The report of the illness of King GUSTAV V of Sweden will give anxiety to others than his own subjects and men and women of Swedish descent around the world, and especially in the United States, to which they have made so sturdy, industrious and progressive a contribution.
John C. Ahti is in the trading department of Schloss Summerfield.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- All American vessels under government supervision were ordered removed from Spanish waters today. There are one cruiser, two destroyers and one Coast Guard cutter now operating along the Spanish coast evacuating United States citizens who desire to leave the country.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 10. -- In a blunt warning to dairymen over the threat of a State-wide milk strike, Governor Lehman told a New York State Fair crowd today that the State would not be intimidated by "threats of strikes and disorders."

The election of Louis Broido, attorney, as executive vice resident of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., was announced here yesterday by Bernard Gimbel, president of the chain of department stores. The post is a newly created one in the central management of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and Mr. Broido will assist Mr. Gimbel in the general supervision of the company's business.

Arcady Dubensky has composed a "Political Suite," which will receive its first performance on next Thursday's "Sinfonietta" program, directed by Alfred Wallenstein in his concert over the WOR-MBS network. His suite deals with political "isms."
NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 10. -- The National Socialist "congress of honor" resumed its political discussions today with a sweeping broadside attack on bolshevism by Dr. Joseph Goebbels.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 10. -- That stolid Canadian, C. Ross (Sandy) Somerville, only representative of the land of the Maple Leaf ever to annex the U.S. amateur championship, threw a scare into the portion of the field that practiced today for the national amateur starting Monday at the Garden City Golf Club.

ALBANY, Sept. 10. -- District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan will be asked tomorrow to explain to Governor Lehman his friendship with Frank A. Erickson, the alleged large-scale bookmaker, and he will be called upon particularly to explain why he failed to report a campaign fund contribution of $500, given him by one Abraham Allenberg, as having come from Erickson.

The Transit Commission was publicly warned yesterday that failure to adopt promptly and without substantial change the $436,000,000 transit unification plan drafted by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. would mean that the city must either drop the idea of unification altogether or seek to transfer to itself the unification powers now vested in the commission.
LONDON, Sept. 10. -- By proclaiming Germany's "right to colonies" at the Nazi party congress at Nuremberg yesterday, Chancellor Adolf Hitler touched a sensitive nerve here.

Play in the national championships came down to the semi-final round at the West Side Tennis Club yesterday with the favorites progressing in each instance and Miss Helen Jacobs and Donald Budge turning in reassuring performances to allay misgivings arising earlier in the week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 10. -- Eminent scholars attending the Harvard tercentenary conference of arts and sciences delved deep into past ages today in an investigation of the forces which mold human conduct.

The best 3-year-old jumper of the year won the Harbor Hill Steeplechase yesterday at Aqueduct, just as everybody predicted he would. The colt, Saluda, owned by Thomas Hitchcock, and coupled with Congaree, was a 1-to-12 shot in the betting, according to the accompanying chart.

The iron and steel industry earned $3.92 a ton on materials produced for sale in the first half of 1936, compared with $2.99 a ton in the same part of 1935. The earnings afforded a return of 1.73 per cent on the investment, compared with 0.91 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Habitues along the waterfront of the East River raised themselves from their afternoon slumbers yesterday and cast quizzical glances at some fifty boys participating in a "marathon" race. The race was the high spot of the "Gramercy Olympics," conducted by the Gramercy Boys Club, 535 East Sixteenth Street.

EVERY day now, weather permitting, young Horace Stoneham sits in his office overlooking the playing field at the Polo Grounds and tries to pull a pennant through the window. Or through any one of four windows. There are four, and he keeps shifting chairs and his point of view as the games go on.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 10. -- The belief that the forthcoming Pan American conference at Buenos Aires would devise an anti-war pact with "teeth" in it was expressed today by United States Ambassador Josephus Daniels in an address to the American Chamber of Commerce of this city.

The most discouraging item in the day's news is the report of the discussion by economists and political scientists at Harvard of the important problem of governmental interference and regulation of industry and finance. The weird notions of the various speakers, concerning the extension of collective meddling with private affairs, are an answer to the query: Why does the advocacy of paternalism, socialism and communism flourish?

Mrs. Charles S. Whitman, wife of the former Republican Governor of New York, announced yesterday that she will campaign for President Roosevelt. Literature issued to her when she joined a class in public speaking at the Women's National Republican Club, she explained, convinced her that she couldn't make a speech against the administration and led to her resignation from the club and her bolt from the party.

COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 10. -- The Cohasset Yacht Club crew of Miss Frances McElwain, captain; Miss Katherine Johnson and Miss Joan Chapin appeared well on its way to a successful defense of the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams cup for the women's national sailing championship tonight with a lead of 2 1/4 points over Miss Joan Earle's Bellport Bay crew from Long Island at the end of the third race.

Administrative savings of $7,740,000 annually are reported by Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, in her section of "New York Advancing," the summary of the accomplishments of Mayor La Guardia's administration.

LITTLETON, N.H., Sept. 10. -- The White Mountain Garden Club held its annual meeting today at the Ledges, Littleton estate of Mrs. J.G.M. Glessner. A luncheon preceded the meeting and election of officers, at which Mrs. John W. Guider, president, presided.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 10. -- The United States Marine Corps came in for more honors today when Waldo A. Phinney, U.S. Marine Corps headquarters, Washington, D.C., landed the national individual rifle championship match with a score of 244 out of a possible 250, only 1 point over his next two competitors.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 10. -- With supreme courage and icy calm, Colonel Jose Mascarron, commander of voluntarily imprisoned Rebels in the besieged Alcazar, refused a government demand to surrender today.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 10. -- Democrats in Maine are making political capital out of the disclosure by the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee that more than $50,000 had been contributed to the Republican campaign in this State by the Rockefellers, J.P. Morgan, the Archbolds and several members of the du Pont family.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10. -- Alan Marshal, a newcomer to the screen from the Broadway stage, has been cast in the role of Rhett Butler in the David O. Selznick production of Margaret Mitchell's noted story "Gone With the Wind."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10. -- Budding California tennis stars made up two of the four winning teams in the girls' national doubles championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club today. The East furnished the other triumphant combinations.

A sharp reduction in mortality in surgical operations is now possible as the result of a simple mathematical test which any physician can make to determine the susceptibility of a patient to the shock of the operating table, according to a report presented yesterday at the American Congress of Physical Therapy at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- The stock markets here were somewhat better today, with improvement of the franc in foreign exchange. British funds were quiet and steady. German issues recovered. Home rails reacted, in spite of good traffic reports.

As Colonel Bill Terry trooped silently and rather dejectedly off the playing field at the Polo Grounds yesterday it seemed to be with the feeling of a man who had lost a number of things all on the roll of the dice.
Value of DolLar in xchange '1 The dollar on the local foreign{ exchange market, based on quota- tions for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as fol- lows (quotations are in cents):

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10. -- Opening the Democratic city campaign, Governor Earle asserted today that President Roosevelt and the remainder of the New Deal ticket would carry Pennsylvania by a 250,000 majority.

GEORGE U. HARVEY, Borough President of Queens, wants a State law to prohibit the dissemination of communistic doctrines through political speeches or any other means. "Those "who advocate the overthrow of Gov"ernment," he says, should be "put in "jail or sent back to the country "whence they came."

Marking its transformation from a home furnishings establishment into a complete department store, Ludwig Baumann will open eleven modern sales floors tomorrow at its building at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

Under the leadership of secondary railroad issues, domestic corporation bonds rose yesterday on the average to a new high level on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace was again stepped up, total sales reaching $16,721,300, the most active session since July 15, and compared with $15,253,300 on Wednesday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10. -- The college-trained chemist as well as the college that trained him were criticized today as four industrialists told the Division of Chemical Education of the American Chemical Society "what industry wants of its chemists."

VIENNA, Sept. 10. -- It's an old Austrian custom, so King Edward of England went hunting today with a tuft of gray chamois whiskers stuck in his soft hat. He would have felt "out of place" without them, persons close to him said.

Governor Alf M. Landon will pass through New York City, but will not stop even for a brief reception, when his train reaches the East tomorrow morning, on its way to Maine, it was announced yesterday by Joseph W. Martin Jr., head of the Eastern Republican campaign headquarters here.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP). -- St. Louis's doughty Cardinal's pulled their second straight game with the Boston Bees out of the fire with a late two-run rally today and gained a 3-2 triumph that moved them to within three and a half games of the pace-setting Giants.

Announcement yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau that cash subscriptions for the Treasury's 2 3/4 per cent bonds, due in 1959 and callable in 1956, were more than twelve times greater than the $400,000,000 offered by the Treasury, aroused no little amount of discussion in government bond circles as to the extent of "padding" of subscriptions, versus the actual, or legitimate, tenders submitted, due to the tremendous volume of available funds seeking employment.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10. -- A group of English visitors who are in this country to make a survey of the political situation, with special reference to the November election, for the British press, are the guests of Edward Clark Carter, secretary treasurer of the American Council, Institute of Pacific Relations, and Mrs. Carter at Sunset Farm in Lee.

Ridiculing James A. Farley's figure of an 850,000 plurality for the Roosevelt-Garner ticket in New York City, three of the five Republican county leaders in the metropolitan area told Melvin C. Eaton, State chairman, and Clarence R. Kings, chairman of the State organization's executive committee, yesterday that there was a "definite swing" to the Landon-Knox slate in their respective counties.

Representatives of the city, the aeronautical industry and her own country joined yesterday in according Mrs. Beryl Markham, the transatlantic flier, an enthusiastic reception at a luncheon given in her honor by the Advertising Club of New York in the club's dining rooms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- "Maine will re-elect Senator White and cast a decisive Republican majority in its September election," declared John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in an interview today.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Directors of the General Alliance Corporation and its subsidiary, the General Reinsurance Corporation, approved yesterday a plan designed to simplify the corporate structure and to effect operating economies. The plan, which provides for the dissolution of General Alliance and the distribution to its present stockholders of one share of General Reinsurance Corporation stock in exchange for each two shares of General Alliance, will be submitted to the stockholders on Oct. 14.

The stock market moved higher during most of the session yesterday but buying at all times was unhurried. Moderate selling in the final hour resulted in an irregularly higher closing. Low-priced issues, especially, did well. Trading on the Stock Exchange aggregated 1,545,000 shares, against 1,575,000 the day before.

Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens, regular Democratic designee for nomination for Aldermanic President, called upon audiences at thirteen rallies in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx last night to repudiate the candidacy of his opponent, Frank J. Prial, at next Tuesday's primaries because Mr. Prial had criticized Governor Lehman and had supported Robert Moses as Republican candidate for Governor two years ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 10. -- A new link bridging the gap between the animate and the inanimate, which offers evidence for the existence of a twilight zone between living and non-living matter inhabited by shadowy creatures, some of which produce deadly diseases, while others aid man to combat disease, was reported here today before the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Darkness halted the American League cellar race with the Browns and Athletics tied, 4 -- 4, at the end of the ninth inning of today's second game after the Philadelphians had defeated St. Louis, 12 -- 7, in the opener.

Three domestic films and an importation from France are listed on today's schedule. At the Roxy will be Twentieth Century-Fox's musical comedy, "Sing, Baby, Sing," with a cast headed by Alice Faye, Adolphe Menjou, Gregory Ratoff, Ted Healy, Patsy Kelly and the Ritz Brothers.

SERIOUS, solid and eloquent, I.J. Singer's novel "The Brothers Ashkenazi" (Knopf, $3) is a memorable piece of fiction. Translated from the Yiddish by Maurice Samuel, it is the story, 640 pages long, of the rise and fall of two Polish Jews.

TORONTO, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press). -- Jack McInnes of Quebec City won the world's championship ten-mile race for 225-cubic-inch power boats over the Canadian National Exhibition waterfront tonight, piloting Miss Quebec II into fourth position after winning the two previous nights.

BERLIN, Sept. 10. -- The Boerse was strong today and a little more active. Chancellor Hitler's new four-year plan, which promises better profits for many industries, and the French suggestion for an international currency conference, which probably will mean devaluation, stimulated interest in stocks.
PARIS, Sept. 10. -- The Ministry of Foreign Affairs published today the texts of all the letters exchanged with various governments on the subject of non-interference in the war in Spain.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press). -- Six of the seven directors who will in future control the Canadian National Railways system were announced here tonight by Prime Minister Mackenzie King at the conclusion of a Cabinet Council.

A picketing campaign against movie houses and other theatres that have abandoned their orchestras, vaudeville acts and other stage presentations was announced last night at a mass meeting sponsored by Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, at the Manhattan Opera House, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10. -- Lord Fermoy, who is visiting his brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Guy Fairfax Cary, was guest of honor at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Cary tonight at Elm Court.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- Best hogs were in demand here today, with prices steady to a shade lower, while sows were off 5 to 15 cents a hundred pounds. A load of fancy hogs sold at $11.40, or 5 cents above the best price on Wednesday, while the day's average was off 5 cents, at $10.15.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 10. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address at the Municipal Stadium today:
Citizen Goldsmith once had three one-thousand-dollar gold certificates. In the free-gold days he could get for one 48.37 ounces of gold at $20.67 an ounce. Then the gold certificates were called. in.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture said today that for the first time in recent years there was "no pressure" for a government loan on the current cotton crop. Sharp improvement in the price and a demand for the United States cotton both in this country and abroad, they said, would make any form of loan this year unlikely.

Fear that the National Youth Administration's insistence on the performance of some useful work by high school students receiving NYA subsidies might jeopardize the program to aid 10,500 students here vanished yesterday when Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced that the city schools would cooperate with the NYA in enforcing the work requirement.

Gone from the schedule of Billy Rose is "Yellow Tide," by George S. Brooks. Most managers would have deemed its production quite a spectacular effort -- a cast of 300 in an operetta dealing with the Chinese-Japanese unpleasantness -- but Mr. Rose thought otherwise.

The engagement of $7,710,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported by the Federal Reserve Bank yesterday. Of this amount, $3,700,000 was taken in France, $3,500,000 in England and $510,000 in India. These transactions brought to $89,600,000 the total of gold engaged since Aug. 7, of which $53,400,000 has been obtained in France.

BLACKPOOL, Sept. 10. -- Science, lending aid to man both in war and peace, "recognizes no moral obligations," the British Association for the Advancement of Science was told today by Professor William Cramp, president of the engineering division of the association.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP). -- Racing within half a second of her own record in the final heat, Rosalind once again asserted her superiority over the trotters of her age as she swept all three heats of the $10,000 Governor's Stake for the 3-year-olds at the State fair today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 10. -- The highest defense fund in Australia's history, 8,809,107, and remissions in taxation totaling 5,275,000 yearly are the outstanding features of the budget R.G. Casey, Assistant Federal Treasurer, presented to the House of Representatives today.

Baseball went back sixty years at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Brooklyn Atlantics beat the Pittsburgh Alleghenies, 2 -- 0, in a two and one-half inning burlesque as the main feature of Brooklyn's celebration of the National League birthday.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 11. -- The possibility that the United States may build submarines in answer to Japan's intention to do so evokes anxious criticism in the press and is described as a violation of the spirit of the naval limitation treaties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The Republican National Committee expended $2,524,950.59 from January to Aug. 31 of this year, according to reports filed with the Clerk of the House under the Corrupt Practices Act. Receipts for the period between June 7 and Aug. 31 were $2,050,654.94 and expenditures $1,687,811.42.

Higher prices for cotton, grains, livestock and meats largely accounted for a two-point rise in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices, the index rising to 128.4 on Tuesday from 126.4 the week previous and 128.0 a year ago.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs promised Mayor La Guardia yesterday that it would call no strike of truck drivers in this city before next Tuesday, when the Mayor is due back from Chicago. Members of the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York unanimously agreed to the truce.
NICE, France, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The former Queen Victoria of Spain sped toward New York tonight and the bedside of her son, the Count of Covadonga, who is ill in a hospital.

A plan of reorganization of the Lawyers Mortgage Company was submitted yesterday by Weinstein Levinson, attorneys for the creditors committee, at a hearing called before James A. Martin, referee appointed by the Supreme Court in the rehabilitation proceedings.
PLYMOUTH, England, Sept. 10. -- The British Trade Union Congress, by an almost unanimous hand vote, adopted a resolution today in favor of non-intervention in the Spanish civil war.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs, thanks to Stanley Hack's eighth-inning homer, scored a 3-to-2 victory over the Phillies today to gain a full game on the league-leading Giants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announed today bids received for bonds which it had offered at public sale. The bonds were taken over from the PWA. The interest rate on each issue is 4 per cent unless otherwise stated.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 18 per cent for the week ended Sept. 5, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The week, however, included six days, against five last year, due to the later date of the Labor Day holiday.
ATLANTA, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Reports on yesterday's primary election from each of the 159 counties, 58 of them complete, give the following figures:

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 10. -- Flashing its most powerful attack, the smooth-working Greentree quartet today routed a selected White combination in a tune-up contest for the series against the Argentine poloists. Held to an 8-5 margin for the first half of the battle, the pink-shirted riders scored with machine-line regularity in the following three sessions to win by 19 -- 9 at Whitney Field.

Mayor La Guardia and District Attorney William C. Dodge conferred yesterday on plans for the prosecution of A. Reginald Von Heller and Lawrence S. Timen, who are held in an alleged attempt to extort money from a Dubuque (Iowa) manufacturer bidding for a $1,250,000 Sanitation Department contract here.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 10. -- In reviewing the present position of Darwin's Theory and showing how well it stood up in the light of the knowledge acquired of the mechanism of heredity, Professor Julian S. Huxley, grandson of Thomas Huxley, predicted today the biological future of man before biologists of the British Association for the Advancement of Science meeting here.

Countess Gladys Vanderbilt Szechenyi began an action yesterday in Surrogate's Court to have the State transfer tax on the estate of her mother, Alice Gwynne Vanderbilt, reduced by excluding from the estate a $5,935,572 trust fund set up for Mrs. Vanderbilt by her husband, the late Cornelius Vanderbilt.

Mrs. Augusta J. Fink -- shy, dignified and not inclined to talk much about herself -- received yesterday afternoon a gold medal given by the Grand Street Boys Association, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street, for having driven a car in New York City since 1903 without getting involved in an accident or violating a traffic law.
LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
GENEVA, Sept. 10. -- Efforts are getting under way here to center the attention of the new Assembly on the economic and monetary situations as the least difficult problems facing the League.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Production of 1,458,295,000 bushels of corn was forecast today by the crop reporting board of the Department of Agriculture, an increase of 1.3 per cent over the forecast of a month ago but still the smallest crop in fifty-five years.
PARIS, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Absence of panic and the efficiency of officers and crews of the Eastern Steamship liner New York and the excursion steamer Romance were what prevented a major sea disaster when the two craft came together in a dense fog Wednesday night off Boston Harbor.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The wheat production of Canada for 1936 is estimated at 232,973,000 bushels in a crop report issued today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. Of this amount 220,903,000 bushels is Spring wheat and 12,070,000 bushels Fall wheat. The Spring wheat crop of the Prairie Provinces is estimated at 216,000,000 bushels.
MADRID, Sept. 10. -- (Passed by the Censor). -- Preparations are feverishly proceeding for defense of Madrid.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 10. -- With A.G. Tarn's Rushaway, winner of two Derbies and seven other races this season, bowing to defeat in a six-furlong dash, Mrs. H. Teller Archibald's Black Mistress captured the feature event on today's Narragansett program by a length over Mrs. F.J. Ryan's Sachem.

Reflecting cessation of operations for Labor Day, steel ingot output declined 2 points this week to 70 per cent of capacity, according to The Iron Age summary made public yesterday. A resumption of the upward trend of production was predicted by the magazine, however, even with a minimum of automotive industry orders.

Ceferino Garcia, hard-hitting Filipino welterweight, will make his first appearance in an Eastern ring when he meets Cleto Locatelli of Italy in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The battle heads a card that comprises four ten-round contests and one four.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Sharp declines in the prices of farm products, principally grains, livestock and poultry, depressed the general level of wholesale prices in the week ended on Sept. 5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, fell to 80.9, compared with 81.2 the preceding week and 80.4 a year ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 10. -- President Agustin P. Justo of Argentina today addressed the delegates to the fourteenth international congress of P E N clubs at a luncheon given in their honor at Government House.

LONDON, Sept. l0. -- "Farewell Performance," adapted from the Hungarian of Lajos Zilahy by John L. Balderston, was presented at the Lyric Theatre tonight. It has an unusual and interesting theme which might have been designed for the extremely varied gifts of Mary Ellis.

Plans for the second annual observance of Loyalty Days in churches and synagogues throughout the country were begun yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Governor Clinton under the auspices of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, which has offices at 60 East Forty-second Street.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 10. -- After having been cheered by thousands of enthusiastic admirers on his trip through Poland from the Czechoslovak frontier, General Edward Rydz-Smigly [virtual dictator of Poland] arrived in Warsaw this afternoon. His special train was a half hour late owing to delays caused by receptions in all the larger towns along his route, especially in Upper Silesia.

BUFFALO, Sept. 10 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons made it two in a row tonight in their International League semi-final play-off by trouncing the Newark Bears, 7 to 1, behind the seven-hit pitching of Ken Ash.

Patrolman Joseph Yokono, attached to Emergency Squad 12 of Brooklyn and living at 582 Grand Street, shot two men early this morning after they held up a cafe at 2 Goerck Street, where Yokono, who was off duty, was a patron. Two others escaped after a chase in which Yokono fired several shots.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 10. -- Most of the excitement in today's Monty Waterbury Cup handicap polo semi-final at the Piping Rock Club was crammed into the last period with John R. Fell recording three straight goals to provide Roslyn with a 9-to-7 success over Old Westbury.
