Steadily Nazi Germany moves toward the fulfillment of the goal foreshadowed in "Mein Kampf," a militant, regimented Reich, dominant in Continental Europe and unchallenged in world affairs. HITLER'S proclamation and address at the opening on Wednesday of the Fourth Party Congress at Nuremberg, fulsome in praise of party achievements and unbridled in denunciation of communism and democracy, were demagogic appeals for support at home and confidence abroad.

HENDAYE, France, Sept. 10. -- Most of the Alcazar in Toledo now appears to be in the hands of the government forces but the defenders are still resisting with desperate courage. After a siege of more than seven weeks the Rebels are said to have taken refuge in a block of buildings near by and to be continuing the fight from there.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Once again Mrs. Emmet Whalen of Westchester Hills won low gross in the one-day tournament of the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association. Adding to a long list of these weekly medal play victories, Mrs. Whalen today negotiated the lengthy Winged Foot Golf Club course in 86 strokes.
MOSCOW, Sept. 10. -- Sarcastic expressions of disappointment over Chancellor Hitler's attack on bolshevism appeared in the Soviet press today.

In your issue of Sept. 5, Irving Lieberman writes in criticism of Harold J. Blitz, "that juries pass judgment solely upon questions of fact." Apparently the former is unaware that in various jurisdictions juries retain their common law prerogative to pass on questions, of law in criminal cases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP). -- An Edgewater (N.J.) ordinance requiring a license to maintain vessels in the Hudson River within its territory was challenged as "void" in a brief filed with the Supreme Court today by David T. Wilentz, New Jersey Attorney General.

Nomination by both parties and re-election of General Sessions Judges Cornelius F. Collins and Morris Koenig were urged last night in a joint statement by former Judge Clarence E. Shearn, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, and Charles Evans Hughes Jr., president of the New York County Lawyers Association.

PARIS, Sept. 10. -- French attention was concentrated today upon two points in Adolf Hitler's speech -- first, the German decision to maintain. Europe's most powerful army, and, second, the inferential demand for colonies.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 10 (AP). -- Examiner Edwin S. Smith, member of the National Labor Relations Board, late today halted efforts of counsel for the Hearst-owned Post-Intelligencer to show that the newsroom strike which closed the 60-year-old morning daily here on Aug. 13 was caused by the paper's attacks on communism and radicalism.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- The first two floors of historic Philipse Manor house in which Elsie Janis lived for ten years were stripped of furnishings tonight at the close of a four-day auction which brought a total of about $5,000.

" Government," Governor TALMADGE once said, "is nine-tenths bluff." Preposterous in its original sense, this assertion applies perfectly to his methods of government since he began to covet the laurels of HUEY LONG. He started well as Governor. He reduced taxes and the State deficit.

BERLIN, Sept. 10. -- Catholic prelates drafted a pastoral letter today admonishing church members to fight for the preservation of the confessional schools as guaranteed in the concordat between the Nazi Government and the Holy See.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 10. -- A bill to appropriate $25,000 for a suit by the State of New Jersey in the United States Supreme Court to enjoin collection in this State of payroll taxes under the Federal Social Security Act, on the ground that this act invades States rights, was made public here this evening by the New Jersey Social Security Commission.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 10. -- In a speech addressed primarily to the South, President Roosevelt told thousands of persons at a great "Green Pastures Rally" today that the depression had been conquered without any infringement by the Federal Government on the rights of the States.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 10. -- The Baltimore Sun will announce tomorrow morning that it is "unable to advocate the re-election of President Roosevelt."
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 10 (AP). -- A drive by the Latter Day Saints Church to take all its needy "off the dole" neared success tonight.

President ROOSEVELT'S address in North Carolina yesterday was in his most attractive vein. What he really set out to prove was that a great degree of prosperity had been brought about under his Administration. But with what literary skill and grace he did it!

The East Side led in volume of apartment rentals reported yesterday, as the post-vacation period was utilized by more prospective tenants seeking new quarters before Oct. 1. The Greenwich Village and Washington Square areas and the Chelsea section also figured in the day's reports.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Detroit gained an even break with Washington both for the season and the closing two-game series by winning, 5 to 2, today behind the five-hit pitching of Tommy Bridges.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 10. -- The lads of the Labor Service Corps who will form next year's contingent of Germany's conscript army put on their own show today for the National Socialist party congress, and they made it an inspiring spectacle.
What happens when you have a fish three feet long on the hook and nothing but a trout net in the boat?

Due principally to the Labor Day holiday which was a week later this year than in 1935, bank clearings for the five business days ended on Wednesday declined 9.8 per cent from the corresponding six days a year ago. In the previous week there was a gain of 37.1 per cent over the 1935 comparative figure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Investigation of the long-distance communication services of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with a view to further reduction of its ratets and charges, which are still held to be unreasonably high, was ordered today by the Federal Communications Commission.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10 (AP). -- Lee Hanover, reined by Charley Lacey of Cleveland, swept all three heats of the Governor's Stake in the Grand Circuit competition at the Indiana State Fair today. He turned the second brush in 2:01 1/4 for the fastest trotting time of the current meeting. The feature event carried a $1,200 purse.

Under the heading "Gem Bandits Shot in a Wild Chase" you ran a story in your Sunday issue. I wish to comment on this from two different angles, from both of which I am qualified to pass an opinion -- almost, it happened, as an innocent bystander.

The first public financing for the Buffalo Sewer Authority, Buffalo, N.Y., is scheduled for today with the offering of a new issue of $3,392,000 of its 3 1/2 per cent bonds, 1936 series, by a syndicate headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and including Bacon, Stevenson Co.; Roosevelt Weigold, Inc.; E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; George B. Gibbons Co., Inc., and A.M. Kidder Co.

TORONTO, Sept. 10. -- Lawson Little, the amateur golfing kingpin of the United States and Great Britain until he turned professional last Spring, took the St. Andrews public course apart to see what made it work in the opening round of the Canadian open championship today.

The World Power Conference in Washington reminds one of the writing of millenniums ago in the Book of Books. In the sixty-second of the selections called Psalms, we read, "Once have I heard, twice have I heard, power belongeth unto God."

Restoration of the salaries of the city's Supreme Court and Appellate Division justices and of the nine judges of the Court of General Sessions to the pre-pay cut level was asked yesterday of Assistant Budget Director Kenneth Dayton.

Wholesale lumber dealers protested to the Shipping Board at a hearing yesterday at 45 Broadway against the proposal of the inter-coastal ship lines to increase the freight charge on lumber moving between the Pacific Northwest and Atlantic ports from $12.50 to $13 per 1,000 feet.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 10. -- Fifty-three persons were indicted on charges of election frauds by the Atlantic County jury at Mays Landing, the county seat, today. Eighteen indictments were returned.

Mgr. Fulton J. Shean of the Catholic University last night attacked Earl Browder, Communist candidate for the Presidency, as one who is "offering the kiss of Judas when he says communism is not an enemy of property, the family and religion."

The Giants, holding a three-and-one-half-game lead over the Car dinals and a five-game margin on the Cubs, can clinch the National League pennant by winning fifteen of their remaining eighteen games provided the second-place Cardinals do not win more than eighteen of their nineteen games left to play.

In the local commodity futures markets yesterday cocoa was quite strong and rubber, silk and hides improved slightly. Other staples eased. In the cash markets lard and tins alone eased, while wheat, corn, rye, cocoa, butter, silk, wool tops and rubber advanced.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 10. -- Two brothers will lead teams against each other in the final round of the Waterbury Cup, most important of polo's handicap events. While Winston Guest and Templeton were turning back Texas, 17 to 11, on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club today, his brother Raymond was riding to victory in the other semi-final match with his Roslyn team.

Rayon shipments to American mills during August established a new high record and again exceeded production, according to the Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. This resulted in a drop in producers' stocks on hand to the ridiculously low figure of four-tenths of a month's supply, based on average monthly shipments during the past twelve months, it is stated.

The Waverly Boat Club at 167th Street and the Hudson River, delayed moving yesterday although it had been ordered by Park Commissioner Robert Moses to vacate its three-story clubhouse on or before Sept. 10.

Loans to brokers and dealers by reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in this city rose $68,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $1,052,000,000, according to the condition statement of the banks, published yesterday. The rise was interpreted in financial circles as a reflection of the customary expansion of borrowings by government security dealers in advance of a new Treasury offering.

QUEBEC, Sept. 10. -- Announcing his intention of going into rehearsals for "Hamlet" in New York on Sept. 21, Leslie Howard, stage and screen performer, who will be the director-star in Shakespeare's tragedy, arrived in Quebec on the Empress of Britain this afternoon.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 10. -West- [ ern New York farmers who crowded I the Rochester Exposition today forI the Grange and Farm Bureau Day[ program heard a warning against a milk strike, voiced by Louis J.[ Taber, master of the National Grange.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- An unequivocal endorsement of President Roosevelt for a second term is expected to come from the conference of Progressives to be held here tomorrow under the joint leadership of Mayor La Guardia of New York and Senator La Follette of Wisconsin.

" Fashion Futures 1936," an international review forecasting the mode for months to come, was staged last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Fashion Group, a non-commercial organization whose membership includes the leading women fashion authorities of the country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Arthur J. Altmeyer, a member of the Social Security Board, said tonight that he disagreed with the New Jersey Social Security Commission's criticism of the Federal Social Security program "on all three counts."

Final plans for an extensive promotional campaign to put uniforms on workers in every industry which even remotely contacts the public will be outlined by the business promotion committee of the Linen Supply Association of America at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania on Sept. 21.

Briefs from counsel representing the petitioner, the Board of Elections and the New York City Charter Revision Commission on the question whether or not a writ of mandamus shall be issued preventing the submission of the new city charter to the electorate in November were submitted yesterday to Justice Charles J. Dodd in Supreme Court, in Brooklyn.

Puerto Rico purchased 10 per cent of all food products shipped from the continental United States during the fiscal year 1935-1936 and bought substantially increased quantities of textiles, footwear, cigarettes and wheat flour, according to the Association of Sugar Producers of Puerto Rico.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 10. -- Five boats out of eighty-two had their times recorded in the second race of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fourth annual Fall series today, the others being beaten by a combination of calm and, indirectly, by the arrival here of the German plane Zephyr on its test flight from the Azores.

PARIS, Sept. 10. -- Fifty thousand metal and textile workers in the Lille district had joined the strike there today and it seemed probable that unless the strike was promptly settled it would become general.

The American Chain Company declared yesterday a dividend of $8 a share on account of accumulations on its preferred stock. The dividend is payable on Sept. 21 to holders of record of Sept. 18. One of $3.25 on this issue was paid on July 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Predicting that jobs and other relief for drought-stricken farmers will cost double the original estimates, administration officials today drafted plans to support more than half a million families until the Spring planting season.

GROTON, Conn., Sept. 10. -- In a harmonious convention marked with confidence and enthusiasm, Governor Wilbur L. Cross and the other Democratic State officers were renominated today to run on a platform which endorsed the Roosevelt-Garner ticket and ratified the Philadelphia platform.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Bon Diable, an outstanding gray gelding owned by Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Llangollen Stables, Upperville, Va., won the hunter championship, the feature event of the afternoon session of the ninety-sixth Empire State Horse Show today. Spring Hope, also owned by Mrs. Whitney, gained the reserve award.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. -- The eagerly awaited loan exhibition of Japanese painting and sculpture opened with a reception and private view at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts this evening. It was attended by thousands of invited guests, who were received by the Japanese Ambassador, Hiroshi Saito; James B. Conant, president of Harvard University; Edward J. Holmes, president of the museum, and George H. Edgell, director.

With buyers showing more confidence in the price levels established in recent weeks, trading in all types of wool goods is beginning to broaden, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. More men's wear buyers were in the market this week, it is stated, and the majority made selections that were indicative of quantity orders in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- When the World Power Conference convened this morning speakers were warned that there must be no politics. The censorship also included any remarks of an "advertising" nature.

Heavy transactions and irregular fluctuations again were a feature in the trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. After advancing to around 12 1/4 cents a pound for the near months, the list eased in the last hour to close with net gains of 3 to losses of 9 points.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 10. -- Costa Rica, one of the last strongholds of free speech and a free press in Latin America, is weakening under the protests of neighboring dictators, who want their own propaganda disseminated but object to the same privilege for opponents.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Dr. Marvin A. Stevens now knows full well just how the French aristocrats felt before going to the guillotine. His N.Y.U. football team meets the Ohio State powerhouse in its opening game of the season and what ordinarily would shape up as an excellent Violet combination may find itself decapitated with the first blow.

The wage-scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association drafted demands yesterday for a new wage contract to be submitted next Monday to ship operators in ports ranging from Portland, Me., to Hampton Roads, Va., at a conference at 80 Broad Street.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10. -- A homer by Hal Trosky, his thirty-seventh of the season, spoiled a plan of the Yankees today at League Park to widen the margin by which they will win the American League pennant.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10. -- A homer by Hal Trosky, his thirty-seventh of the season, spoiled a plan of the Yankees today at League Park to widen the margin by which they will win the American League pennant.

Compensation for the fiscal year ended with April of officers and directors of three corporations whose securities are listed on the New York Stock Exchange was disclosed yesterday in annual reports of the concerns to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

To his nation-wide audience Mr. Walter Lippman, resuming his articles after a long period of reflection, has imparted a reason for supporting the candidacy of Governor Landon which no other political writer or orator has yet employed. Highly abridged, but complete, it is as follows:
Apartment houses in the Yorkville and Washington Heights sections proved attractive to investors yesterday.

In a recent letter in THE TIMES a writer inferred that Joe DiMaggio was not a great player and that he never would approach the performances of outstanding stars of the game. This comment seemed to be based largely on the fact that the Yankee rookie was no great shakes in the All-Star game at Boston in July.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- With a proposed tax rate increase of $5.14 on each $1,000 of assessed valuation, White Plains citizens studied today the tentative budget for 1937 made public by Richard Appel, Finance Commissioner, to find reasons for the rise.

CANTON, China, Sept. 11. -- Guarded by the guns of four Nanking warships anchored in the Pearl River, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, Central Government dictator, was sojourning in the old, abandoned Whampoa Military Academy, a few miles from Canton, today wrestling with a combination of the most complex and critical domestic and foreign problems.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

OTTAWA, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Final steps in the partial nationalization of the Bank of Canada were taken today when the government acquired 100,200 Class B shares and appointed six additional directors to represent those holdings, thus assuring it of control, in accordance with legislation adopted at the last session of Parliament.

Second-grade corporate bonds continued to move forward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but on a somewhat smaller turnover. Domestic corporation issues rose 0.18 point on the average to establish another new high, with secondary railroad obligations and certain utility loans again leading the way.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11. -- Governor Louis J. Brann, Democrat, running for the Senate against Wallace H. White Jr., the Republican incumbent, read the New Deal out today as an issue in the Maine State campaign.

Apartment houses on the West Side added many new names to their tenant rosters yesterday when brokers and renting agents announced lists of additional tenancies. Much of the renting was done in buildings along Riverside Drive and West End Avenue and adjacent streets.

A form of facial neuralgia known as tic douloureux, which is so painful that many of its victims have committed suicide rather than continue to suffer its agonies, has for the first time successfully yielded to treatment, according to a message given yesterday to the American Congress of Physical Theraphy.

" NOW THAT APRIL'S HERE" (Random House, $2) is Morley Callaghan's first book of short stories, and a good one. It is filled with honest and skillful writing, as those who know the author's novels need not be told. A reviewer is tempted to short-circuit the average short-story collection by reading at the beginning, the middle and the end.

TORONTO, Sept. 11. -- William Lawson Little Jr. of San Francisco, abdicated monarch of amateur golfdom, continued to sweep the professional field before him over the St. Andrews course today as he shot his second straight subpar round in the Canadian open championship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Describing a plan for a large power pool for the exchange of government and private electric energy in the Southeastern States, David E. Lilienthal said today that he saw "very great possibilities" in such a "grid."

Various considerations are suggested by the Government's September grain-crop estimates. They indicate, first, that progressive damage to the corn crop was halted during August. In the drought year 1934, Washington's September forecast on corn was reduced 122,000,000 bushels from the already low estimate of a month before; this week's estimate is raised nearly 19,000,000 bushels.

Net profit of the National Steel Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30 was announced yesterday as $10,003,171 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, interest, estimated Federal income and excess profits taxes and other charges. It was equivalent to $4.64 a share on 2,156,977 shares of $25 par capital stock. No provision was made for possible Federal tax on undistributed earnings.

The U.S.S. Indianapolis, a 10,000-ton "treaty" cruiser, which served as a floating White House for President Roosevelt in the Summer of 1933, was the object of sabotage recently when she was laid up for repairs in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by the Navy Department at Washington.

ROME, Sept. 11. -- Angered by United Press reports of communistic activities in Italy, which were reported to have occurred in Leghorn, Grosseto, Rome and Terni, the Italian Government has ordered the expulsion of Henry T. Gorrell, staff correspondent of the Rome bureau of the United Press, it was learned today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 11. -- Memories of another era were revived here today when Charles (Chick) Evans and Francis Ouimet arrived at the Garden City Golf Club and began to tune up for the national amateur championship, which starts on Monday.

The roar of an improvised cannon, the hurling of a steel projectile more than 1,000 feet through the air and through the roof of a Bronx apartment building, brought about the arrest yesterday of James Gillespie, 20-year-old student of chemistry at New York University who had been experimenting on the creation of synthetic diamonds.

GRAND VIEW, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Led by Mrs. Elmer S. Hadar, wife of an author and illustrator, indignant women of this community banded themselves together this afternoon and with the help of the police routed a group of State surveyors who had invaded the village to survey the western anchorage of the proposed Nyack-Tarry-town Bridge.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 11. -- A city-wide inoculation against typhoid fever was advised here tonight following a conference of medical officials of the community and State, held at the offices of the Community Chest, a private welfare organization.

Lieutenant Raymond W. Curtis and Captain Harvey Ellis, members of the United States Olympic equestrian team, returned to this country yesterday aboard the Hamburg-American liner New York. Both were accompanied by their wives.

Some 1,500 non-relief workers on the rolls of the four Federal art projects are facing dismissal on Tuesday unless they file a certification of need, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator.

Price changes were erratic in the local commodity futures markets yesterday. A further sharp rise on large volume in the cocoa market was the principal feature of the day. On the cash markets, tins alone declined, while wheat, corn, rye, flour, cotton, cocoa, butter, eggs, silk and rubber advanced.
A few of the pieces excavated recently by the Persian expedition of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at Nishapur near the tomb of Omar Khayyam will go on exhibition in the museum today.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Captivation, a hackney mare from the West, was the sensation of of championship night at the Empire State Horse Show which closed tonight.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The Pirates reached young Bill Weir for five runs in the first inning and then pushed on to a 10-3 triumph over the Bees today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11. -- Glimpses of Soviet life were contained yesterday in two official announcements and one murder conviction.

BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- The unprecedented attack by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, on bolshevism and high officials of the Moscow regime at the National Socialist congress is unlikely to have the grave sequel that had been expected in diplomatic quarters here.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 11. -- Bayonet and grenade charges at close quarters in the town of Sietamo within sight of Huesca, the capital of Upper Aragon, constituted a dramatic chapter in yesterday's and today's fighting on the Aragon front.

Following the Deutsche Lufthansa flying boat Zephyr, which completed a successful over-ocean flight from the Azores to New York on Thursday, its sister experimental ship, the Aeolus, is expected to complete the flight on a different route this afternoon, with a scheduled landing in the Pan-American Airways air harbor at Port Washington, L.I.

While those individuals who vent their spleen on the New Deal by the grim intensity with which they track down the elusive boondoggle to its lair will hail your editorial on prevailing wages in WPA, others will be keenly disappointed.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Sept. 11 (AP). -- Robert W. Sparks of New York declared today that banking "needs a new suit of clothes" and "cannot afford the restlessness of inertia, especially in these days when revolutionary changes in people's habits are being formed." Mr. Sparks, vice president of the Bowery Savings Bank and president of the Financial Advertisers Association, spoke at the annual convention of the Savings Banks Association of Massachusetts.

Apparently the Connecticut Republicans have given up any hope of beating Governor CROSS. Mr. J. HENRY RORABACK, for years that outrun memory sole steersman of the Republican party in his State, may almost be said to have ratified the Governor's renomination for a fourth term.

BOULDER CITY, Nev., Sept. 11 (AP). -- The world's greatest power plant bestirred itself today when Boulder Dam started producing power. President Roosevelt pressed a key in Washington and the first flow of electricity started from the $165,000,000 government project.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today were under brighter conditions than yesterday, although business remained-small. British funds continued firm. The German list strengthened further in the foreign department.

Burgess Meredith has not abandoned the Stage, despite all those reports which have been seeping from the West. He leaves Hollywood next week and before doing another picture he expects to be in two shows: (1) "High Tor," by Maxwell Anderson, which is scheduled to start rehearsing the middle of November; (2) "The Hat My Father Wore," by Kurt Weill and Helen Deutsch.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $36,884,047, representing two States and fifty-one municipalities. The revised total for this week is $163,497,050, which is unusually large, because of the $100,000,000 offering of the Dominion of Canada on Thursday.

Stock prices fluctuated narrowly yesterday, save for a comparative handful of issues, mainly high-priced. A few groups showed fair strength early in the day, including the amusement, copper, aircraft, electrical and mail-order issues, but by closing time these gains were either greatly reduced or entirely wiped out.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- An armistice in the internal conflict which has split the American Federation of Labor into two warring camps was demanded today by the American Federation of Hosiery Workers, according to its president, Emil Rieve.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- The text of the resolution adopted today by the convention of Progressives was as follows:

FLINT, Mich., Sept, 11. -- Harlow H. Curtice, president and general manager of the Buick Motor Company, announced today that an additional appropriation of $14,500,000 was being spent to carry out the production and factory improvement inaugurated two years ago with a $15,000,000 expenditure, making a total of about $30,000,000 over the two-year period for this General Motors division.

Sales of copper abroad were made yesterday at a price equivalent to 9.875 cents a pound, c.i.f., European base ports, the highest level since April 20, 1931. This is 5 points above the previous high level this year and compares with 9.775 to 9.80 cents on Thursday.

Below are given the nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

PARIS, Sept. 11. -- The Bank of France lost about 250,000,000 francs of gold today, and yesterday, despite a strengthening of the franc on the foreign exchange markets, more than 200,000,000 francs of the metal was engaged for shipment abroad, according to an important bank director.

The Right Rev. August Marahrens, Bishop of Hanover, Germany, and head of the Lutheran Church Council of Germany, who is the new president of the Lutheran World Convention, will come to this country to preside at a meeting of the executive committee of the convention.
The carrying of large bundles and packages on the city subway will be impossible under restrictions which were tightened up yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 11. -- The United States Marine Corps holds the lead in the national rifle team match at the end of the first four stages with a total of 1,900 out of a possible 2,000, having a margin of 35 points over the United States Infantry, which has 1,865.

Arguments against age restrictions in the New Jersey Federation of Junior Women's Clubs boomeranged back yesterday on seventy-odd young married women members of the Bergenfield Junior Woman's Club. Incensed by a ruling of the convention last May that they be graduated automatically into senior membership at 30, they have voted to secede from the junior fedeeration, to preserve their associations in their own age group.

Selling a store's best and most susceptible market -- the customers actually within the store -- will be the subject of a new publication called "Internal Store Promotion," to be distributed early next month by the sales-promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The New Brunswick Government has decided to continue the special non-resident deer and bear license inaugurated last year. The price again will be $10 and holders will be entitled to take two deer and two black bears between Sept. 30 and Nov. 30.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The first hearing on an application by an over-the-counter dealer for removal of securities from unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange was held today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The importance attached to the question was indicated by the presence of Chairman Landis and Commissioners Mathews, Healy and Douglas, who sat with Charles S. Moore, the examiner.
Your correspondent, Mr. Frank Scott, appears to have taken my remarks about Colonel Bill Terry as animadversions, prompted by "petty personal dislike."
With the chips down and the pressure on to the bursting point, our Giants, it seems, are still able to go. Either that, or it may have been another case of just plain Carl Hubbell.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, told several hundred delegates at the Republican State Colored Convention in Brooklyn last night that if President Roosevelt were re-elected it meant that the Federal Government would "swing further left." He urged them to "vote and win with Landon."

A libel action against Harper's Magazine was begun yesterday by Governor James M. Curley of Massachusetts with the service of a Supreme Court summons upon Cass Canfield, president of Harper Bros. The suit is based on an article in the September issue of the magazine, entitled "The Kingfish of Massachusetts."

For the third successive session, fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange here were irregular yesterday, with a large turnover, and the market met contracts on advances but trade buying power on slight recessions. Several times the October position eased to around Thursday's closing figures, only to stiffen in late dealings.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, which has threatened a strike of 15,000 drivers in New York City unless the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York grants its demand for a reduction of the work week from forty-eight to forty hours, made no further move yesterday to reach agreements with individual truck owners.

We cannot avoid a political administration. It intrudes our every activity. This administration has avoided or ignored about every promise made in 1932, as well as many important promises made since gaining power. Many of the platform promises, it may justly be said, became impossible of fulfillment.

Last month showed a 41 per cent rise in residential building contracts over July and a level not achieved since March, 1931, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday in a survey of the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains and the District of Columbia. Last month's figure was about two and one-half times that of August, 1935.

SEATTLE, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Using the government's own exhibit, a full-page newspaper advertisement in which the Washington Industrial Council criticized The Post-Intelligencer newsroom strike, Hearst counsel late today obtained the first evidence of picketing violence before the National Labor Relations Board.

From a white-draped tower in the center of Ebbets Field, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin expounded his theories of social justice last night and explained why he wanted his followers to vote for William Lemke in preference to Franklin D. Roosevelt or Alf M. Landon, the old party candidates for the Presidency.

The Transit Commission has no intention of giving a "rubber-stamp" approval to the $436,000,000 rapid-transit unification plan proposed by Mayor La Guardia's transit advisers, Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle, after negotiation with representatives of the B.M.T., Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company.

An all-steel yacht with a shell, or plating, from one-quarter down to one-fifth of an inch thick, is planned for defense of the America's Cup, it became known yesterday. In addition the entire hull may be welded instead of riveted together.

Pompoon will get the juvenile championship by acclamation if other youngsters keep ducking as is the case in the Junior Champion at Aqueduct today, where the uncrowned king of the 2-year-olds is scheduled to run under top weight of 119 pounds. Notable among the missing are Maedic, which took five stakes in a row at Saratoga, and Moonton, the colt which won in such fast time recently.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The upturn in business holds little hope for those wage-earners whose widespread undernourishment has just been revealed by Federal studies, according to the American Federation of Labor's monthly survey of business, made public today.

Stressing the need of a new system for financing United States Olympic teams, Gustavus T. Kirby, treasurer of the American Olympic Committee, arrived last night aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa. A central bureau, headed by an experienced executive, was his recommendation as the most practical means of raising funds.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 11. -- With a large gallery in attendance and 175 horses competing, the annual Far Hills Horse Show for the benefit of the Visiting Nurses Association of Somerset Hills, opened its two-day stand today on the Far Hills Fair Grounds.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

I notice that several of our big-league managers have set up a System of penalties and rewards to stir their players to winning efforts. If a player fails to drive home a runner from third, he now gets docked a couple of dollars. If he succeeds, somebody else gets docked.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 11. -- Zenas M. Crane, paper manufacturer of Dalton, left personal property of $4,889,382 and real estate of $127,330 in Massachusetts, according to an inventory filed in the Probate Court today by the Pittsfield Third National Bank and Trust Company, special administrator.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11. -- College men and prep school youngsters edged other breeds of amateur speed-boat race drivers into the background this afternoon in the first of two days of outboard events for the Eastern championships on the Schuylkill River Henley course in Fairmount Park.

In hope that his train will spend a sufficient time here this morning, New York Republican leaders announced plans last night for an elaborate welcome, including a brass band, to Governor Landon now en route to Portland, Me.

Intercoastal steamship operators defended yesterday their proposal to increase the freight rate from $12.50 to $13 per 1,000 feet on lumber shipped between the Pacific Northwest and Atlantic coast ports by citing the rising cost of operations, particularly that share represented by labor.

The special Sunday matinee series of Wagner operas scheduled by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company will open with "Tannhaeuser" on Oct. 11. "Lohengrin" follows on Oct. 18; "Die Walkuere," Oct. 25, and "Tristan und Isolde," Nov. 1. The casts will be announced shortly.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 11. -- Spanish Rebel batteries tonight bombarded San Sebastian as the Municipal Governor, Antonio Ortega, admitted that it would be "difficult" to prevent anarchists from burning the city.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday for the seven months ended on July 31 a net income of $3,824,301 after all deductions except allowances for possible Federal surtax on undistributed profits. This was equal to $3.66 each on 1,045,279 shares of $100-par capital stock.

BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- Prices on the Boerse continued firm today, especially issues that might expect to profit from Chancellor Hitler's new four-year plan. This was particularly true of chemical, textile and cellulose shares, which registered gains up to 3 points.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The first of five chamber music concerts was presented here tonight by the Yaddo Music Group in the mansion on the beautiful grounds of the corporation of Yaddo. Several years ago Yaddo stood sponsor for two festivals of modern American music.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 11. -- A dozen foremost biologists discussed the question of race before the British Association for the Advancement of Science today without accomplishing more than showing that a proper study of man was the most difficult of all learned pursuits.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 11. -- It was stated in circles close to the Tennessee Valley Authority today that President Roosevelt and members of the Authority's directorate had under consideration a plan for a new TVA power policy, to be predicated on cooperation between private power interests and the Federal Government.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11. -- Returning to their home field tonight, the Newark Bears won their first game of the Governors' Cup series from the Buffalo Bisons. The score was 2 to 0, with Vito Tamulis registering his third straight shutout victory for the Bears.
No more need little shavers who fly into tantrums, kick paint off the parlor furniture and knock mother's favorite vase smashing to the floor be rushed out to the woodshed for a sound spanking.
A $250,000 housing project near the New York University campus was announced yesterday by Armstrong Brothers, brokers in the assembling of the plot.

The Sanitation Department submitted to Budget Director Leo J. McDermott yesterday an estimate of $30,788,987 for expenses for the coming year, a total of $2,676,162 in excess of the sum allowed the department in the current budget.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- An expansion program under which the company will purchase, at once, twenty twin-motored airplanes on an outlay of about $2,200,000 and, in 1937, acquire, if tests are satisfactory, an unspecified number of four-engined airplanes with a maximum capacity of forty passengers each, was made known today in a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by United Air Lines Transport Corporation, Chicago, for issuance of additional $5-par capital stock.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 11. -- For the fifteenth consecutive year Owen Johnson, the author, today won the blue ribbon at the twenty-fifth annual Stockbridge Grange Fair for the best display of vegetables, fruits and flowers grown on a gentleman's estate.
Five exhibition homes, furnished and decorated by L. Bamberger Co. of Newark, will be opened for public inspection this afternoon, according to William J. Wells, president of the store.

ALBANY, Sept. 11. -- An increase of 2.7 per cent in the number of factory employes in this State and an advance of 4.9 per cent in payrolls from the middle of July to the middle of August lifted the State's index of factory employment to 79.5, the highest for a month since November, 1930.

ALBANY, Sept. 11. -- District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan told Governor Lehman today in the hearing of the grand jury's removal charges that he thought it was all right to associate with Frank A. Erickson, the large-scale bookmaker, because Erickson took his bets from Kings County customers from his telephone headquarters in Hoboken, N.J., and thus committed no breach of the law in Mr. Geoghan's jurisdiction.
Permit a Frenchman to be the interpreter of some millions of Frenchmen in addressing to the entire American people the following message:

THAT high, wide and handsome catcher for the Cubs, the esteemed Charles Leo Hartnett, was discovered about noon yesterday ensconced in a comfortable chair in the lobby of his hostelry. He looked about as cheerful as usual. Certainly he didn't appear to be terror-stricken at the idea of getting up out of there in a half hour or so to head northward for the afternoon battle with the Giants.
The possible loss of his laborer's job concerned Frank Gelada yesterday more than the public interest in his heroic act that forced him to remain away from work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Station WCAE at Pittsburgh was ordered today by Anning S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to explain its refusal to broadcast the Aug. 28 address of Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, after having previously put on the air speeches by the Democratic and Republican party candidates.

The Giants, now holding a four-game lead over the Cardinals and a six-game margin on the Cubs, can clinch the National League pennant by winning fourteen of the their remaining seventeen games, even though the second-place St. Louisians take all of their seventeen games left to play.
Periodically the milk industry becomes a target for criticism by politicians. The lives of babies and milk for the poor make a sentimental appeal on which political heroes build easy reputations.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 11 (AP). -- Keeping his unbeaten record intact, Greyhound scored a straight-heat victory in the Empire State free-for-all trot today, feature of the closing day of the five-day grand circuit meeting at the New York State Fair.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- The demand for hogs here today was only fair, and while main sales were 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, some sales of sows appeared as much as 25 cents lower. The top price was off 15 cents to $11.25, the lowest since Aug. 11, and the day's average was 10 cents lower at $10.05.

The French liner Ile de France will sail today for Plymouth and Havre. Her passengers include Albert Sarraut, former Premier of France, who attended the Institute of Pacific Relations at Yosemite Park; Jules Henry, counselor of the French Embassy in Washington; Joseph Clark Baldwin Jr., Professor Etienne Dennery of the School of Political Sciences in Paris and Dr. Pryns Hopkins of the University of London.

When four men were convicted in Special Sessions yesterday as gamblers, James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, announced they were connected with one of the most profitable Italian policy gambling rings in the country, which the police, after more than a year's work, had succeeded in breaking up.

John Langdon Leighton, 39-year-old scion of a prominent New York and Boston family, committed suicide last night in the bathroom of a suite in the Peter Cooper Hotel, 130 East Thirty-ninth Street, where he lived with his wife, Helen, whom he married three weeks ago.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 11. -- Caprice in the Interclub Class, Gopher among the Victories, Jay among the Stars, Sunshine among the Wee Scots and Yankee among the Meteors were winners today in the third regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Fall series.

Salaries of officers of the Crane Company and the Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation, both of which recently listed securities on the New York Stock Exchange, and of the Zenith Radio Corporation were announced yesterday in annual reports of the companies to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 11. -- Two hundred and fifty young people of the North Shore Summer colonies attended the last of the junior dances of the Nassau Country Club, many of them coming from dinner parties. Dancing took place both indoors and on a platform erected beside the swimming pool on the terrace.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Two hits, mixed with eight walks and a hit batsman, gave the Red Sox a 6-2 victory over the Browns today.

State Senator Frank B. Hendel of Queens accused James C. Sheridan, Democratic county leader, yesterday, of refusing to redesignate him for re-election because he opposed the passage of the Desmond Bill in the Legislature which would have substituted a bridge for the vehicular tunnel under the East River from Thirty-eighth Street to Queens.

In the comments of the golf experts on the heavy defeat of the British team at Pine Valley there was one factor that was overlooked entirely. That is the difference between the American and British ball.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 11. -- With predictions of a clothing sales boom and the consensus that the male in becoming increasingly interested in style, Fashion Park today closed its two-day observance of the 100th anniversary of the clothing manufacturing business in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The Phillies defeated Cincinnati 9 -- 6, today in the first game of the series. Hallahan, who started in the box for the Reds, was knocked out in the sixth inning, when the Phils pushed over four runs to break a 5-5 tie.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Smiling John Cobb, leading Britain's defense of world motor car speed supremacy, thundered over a twelve-mile circular course under clear desert skies tonight, pointed toward a new mark for twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Addressing the delegations of fifty-four nations to the World Power Conference and the Congress on Large Dams this afternoon, President Roosevelt said the United States has reached the age of maturity.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- Progressive leaders from all parts of the United States organized themselves here today into a nonpartisan band for the re-election of President Roosevelt.

Your editorial on the recent report of the Association of American Railroads would lead one to believe that the Class I railroads were carrying more traffic with fewer cars. This I do not believe to be the case.

ON BOARD LANDON SPECIAL TRAIN ON THE WAY TO PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11. -- On his way to make the closing speech of the Maine campaign tomorrow night, Governor Landon made short rear platform talks today in five Indiana towns, met eighty Cook County committeemen at the Chicago home of George F. Harding, national committeeman, and heard former Governor Frank O. Lowden of Illinois predict his election in November.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 11. -- Burlingame Dubarry, 18-month-old puppy bitch, today scored a notable triumph when she was placed best in show at the annual specialty exhibition of the Brussels Griffon Club of America. This youngster, an American-bred, is owned and was shown in the ring by Mrs. Rosalind Layte of the Burlingame Kennels of Short Hills, N.J.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 11. -- All the institutions and instruments of modern Western civilization are undergoing a suicidal process, according to Dr. Masaharu Anesaki, Emeritus Professor of the Science of Religion and the History of Religion at the Imperial University of Tokyo.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 11. -- There was only the flag hanging limply from the flagpole in center field to remind the visitor here today that the champions of the baseball universe last year were the Tigers.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- The qualifying medal in the annual invitation tournament at the Leewood Golf Club today went to Charles Brown of the Wyantenuck Club of Great Barrington, Mass., who carded a 75 to lead Jack Creavy of Green Meadow, by the narrow margin of a stroke.
BURGOS, Spain, Sept. 11. -- San Sebastian must surrender or fight, Rebel leaders said at their headquarters here today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. G. Forrest Butterworth Jr. gave a dance tonight at the Apawamis Club here to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Isabel Imlay Butterworth. The dance took place in a floral setting, the ballroom and dining room having been decorated with Southern smilax and Jersey dahlias.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- The world's statistical position in wheat dominated the action of the market today from start to finish and prices both here and abroad advanced. Winnipeg led the upturn as the result of general buying of cash wheat and futures attributed to foreign account and closed 2 3/8 to 2 5/8 cents a bushel higher.

Too much of the discussion of the 1936 tax law is in the realm of theory and too little in the realm of facts. Thus, Governor Landon repeated at Buffalo the generalization that the 1936 Tax Bill is a "millstone around the neck of the little business man."

John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, came to town yesterday for a few hours and took the occasion to announce that in the remaining weeks of the Presidential campaign his party would proceed with added vigor against President Roosevelt.

While retail sales this week were the heaviest of any week this year in some cities, a moderate contraction occurred in wholesale volume, as merchants awaited a more definite appraisal of consumers' preferences before adding further to their inventories, according to the trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 11. -- The last of the Newport tercentenary exhibits opened at the Old Colony House today. Among those who are showing old Newport articles, furniture, prints and porcelains are Countess Laszlo Szechenyi, Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Allen and Mrs. John Elliott. The exhibit opened with a tea.

The appropriate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

A.E. Houseman's "More Poems" will be a November selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club, together with "Audubon," by Constance, Rourke. Mr. Housman's posthumous volume of lyrics will be published on Oct. 26 by Alfred A. Knopf. Harcourt, Brace are the publishers of "Audubon."

MADRID, Sept. 11 (AP). -- All the genuinely foreign industries in Spain that were seized by the government at the start of the Fascist rebellion have been returned to their owners, a high Spanish official announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Alleged nepotism in the Roosevelt administration was the subject of a statement today by the Republican National Committee, which declared that "under the direction of President Roosevelt the New Deal makes family affairs out of government affairs at the expense of the taxpayer."

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Knocking Dennis Galehouse from the box before he could retire a batter, the Senators piled up a five-run lead in the first inning today and coasted to a 7-2 victory over the Indians.

Stockholders of Consolidated Film Industries, Inc., are to vote on Oct. 9 on a plan of recapitalization providing for the elimination of the dividends accumulated on the present preferred stock, which on Oct. 1 will be $5 a share. The directors propose to declare promptly a dividend of $1 a share on the preferred stock on account of unpaid dividends if the plan is approved by the stockholders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Tying the modern major league record for hits off a single pitcher, the second-place White Sox today pounded a total of twenty-six safeties off Horace Lisenbee to overwhelm the Athletics, 17 -- 2, in the first of a two-game series.
Governor Landon's lead in The Literary Digest poll declined slightly to less than two to one, in the list of second returns made public yesterday by the publication.

The crews of six passenger and freight ships, representing the North and South Atlantic, the South American and Bermuda trades, will face the starter's pistol this afternoon off the Bay Ridge shore for the tenth annual running of the international lifeboat race.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- One of the by-products of the Third World Power Conference here has been a quiet feeling out by some foreign delegates of American sentiment in regard to a conference of the leading commercial powers of the world over the economic problems facing them all.

The city magistrates committee on traffic agreed yesterday on a schedule of uniform fines to be imposed "without discrimination" by all magistrates for Traffic Law violations. The committee met in the afternoon in the office of Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. at 300 Mulberry Street.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11. -- Two of America's largest scientific organizations "officially" buried the hatchet today.
MADRID, Sept. 11 (AP). -- The Spanish Government announced tonight that the northern Rebel city of Oviedo had been set afire by bombardments.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 11 (AP). -- Little Pat, owned by H.D. Biery of Butler, Pa., and driven by Charles Lacey, won all three heats of the 3-year-old pace which featured the closing program of the Grand Circuit meeting at the Indiana State Fair today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address today at the Third World Power Conference:

COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 11. -- Some fine sailing on the part of Miss Margery Bavier and her Larchmont crew of the Misses Sarah Whiting and Allegra Knapp featured the racing for the women's national sailing title off this port today. But when the three contests were completed the net result saw Miss Frances McElwain's Cohasset crew virtually certain of a successful defense of the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Cup.

Yesterday it became known that President ROOSEVELT'S lead in Maryland, as registered in The Baltimore Sun's straw vote, was shrinking. It seems that Mr. ROOSEVELT at the beginning of the poll had 56.88 per cent of all votes cast.

Storming into Ebbets Field yesterday confident of improving their standing in the hot National League pennant race, the second place Cardinals routed the Dodgers in the first game of a double-header, 12 to 8, but they were doomed to disappointment in the nightcap, in which Van Lingle Mungo tamed the Gas House Gang, 5 to 4.

Motion-picture issues were the strongest and most active group on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Of the ten most active stocks, no less than four were motion-picture issues. They were Paramount common, up three-eighths point; Paramount second preferred, up a like amount; Warner Brothers, up an eighth, and Loew's, up 1 3/4.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- Britain has suggested the proposed conference of the five Locarno powers which partly on account of vacations, partly on account of the trouble in Spain, has been sidetracked since the end of July, shall be held in London during the second half of October.

New bond financing this week consisted solely of tax-exempt securities; and the marketing of $55, 000,000 of New York State emergency unemployment relief 1 1/2 per cent bonds lifted the total of issues for the week to $60,757,000. Corporate borrowing was at a standstill, this being the first week since that ended on May 15 in which no new corporate loans were placed on the market.

Tomorrow the Winter's activities in the churches will begin. Many pastors will appear in their pulpits for the first time since their Summer vacations. Several churches which have been closed will reopen. Some of the churches will resume their Sunday evening service.

Archibald Palmer, attorney for a group of holders of bond and mortgage participation certificates of the Prudencee Bond, Corporation, applied yesterday to Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the Federal Court in Brooklyn for an order to restrain eighteen substitute trustees named last week by Justice Lloyd Church in the Supreme Court in Manhattan, for six certificate issues, from taking any action affecting foreclosure of the properties underlying the issues.

A sharp upturn in the radio and electrical household appliance business was indicated yesterday at the 1936 National Electrical and Radio Exposition in Grand Central Palace by reports of exhibitors. One estimated this year's trade increase at "already about 800 per cent greater than at the same time last season in radios."

PLYMOUTH, England, Sept. 11. -- Sir Walter Citrine delivered a slashing attack on the Communists today when the Trades Union Congress discussed a report opposing the united front with Communists. The report eventually was approved with only a few in opposition.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11. -- Franchot Tone has been borrowed from Metro by RKO to appear opposite Katherine Hepburn in the screen version of Barrie's "Quality Street." Production will start next week, with George Stevens directing.
OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 11. -- Every so often a football eleven comes striding across the horizon bearing the flamboyant label, "Team of Destiny." Manhattan seems to have one this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11. -- Franchot Tone has been borrowed from Metro by RKO to appear opposite Katherine Hepburn in the screen version of Barrie's "Quality Street." Production will start next week, with George Stevens directing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- President Roosevelt returned to the White House from his Southern trip this morning to spend a week resting and devoting himself to the routine of his office between travels.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 11. -- Perfection of a process for the conversion of wood-waste, such as sawdust, into virtually unlimited supplies of synthetic food products containing all the fundamental elements of nutrition was announced here today before the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences.

COOKEVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 11 (AP). -- Federal District Judge John J. Gore called today for a speedy hearing on the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority Act before the question of jurisdiction is determined.

HENDAYE, France, Sept. 11. -- Because The Times of London does not call the Spanish Government forces "Reds" and will not withdraw its correspondent from Madrid, Jack Barker, a photographer for The Times, was expelled from the battle zone by the insurgents today.

Mrs. Dwight Davis, who until last Spring was Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, was welcomed back yesterday into the Republican fold, which she deserted four years ago to support President Roosevelt. Disillusioned by what she said was his "faithlessness to the Democratic platform of 1932," she has offered her services to Miss Natalie Couch as a campaigner for Governor Landon.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 11 (AP). -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, in an address at the city auditorium here tonight, criticized the Democratic administration's fiscal policies and warned of what he termed potential danger of a "drought in the public treasury."

The flight of capital from France continued yesterday at an accelerated pace, with $12,540,000 gold engaged in Paris for shipment here, and with the pound sterling again forced above $5.06 by the pressure of funds seeking to escape from the Continental European gold currencies into the British.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 11. -- The loud-speakers in the streets had scarcely ceased reverberating to last night's anti-Bolshevist thunders from Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, and Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, supervisor of the intellectual schooling of the Nazi movement, when the roar of airplanes over Nuremberg just after dawn this morning shattered all thought of sleep.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 11. -- When the British Government announced its decision to take drastic measures to restore order in Palestine, dispatching here an entire division, the immediate reaction among Arab politicians was apprehension, but now this seems to have disappeared.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Between June 1 and Aug. 31 the Democratic National Committee spent $1,008,840.65, a little more than half the amount expended by the Republican National Committee in the same period. This is shown in its report filed with the clerk of the House today.

Hot weather definitely checked sales expansion in local department stores this week, with the extent of the sales gains or losses under a year ago largely dependent upon how much business is done today. The general experience of merchants has been that this week, which they felt would mark the active beginning of the Fall season, has run well under expectations, while trade in the week prior to Labor Day was better than anticipated.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 11 (AP). -- Senator George W. Norris, veteran Nebraska independent Republican, accepted today a petition nominating him as an independent candidate for re-election.

ALBANY, Sept. 11. -- Hundreds of milk producers will gather here tomorrow for a hearing which will determine whether the prices of milk to them will be changed and whether classifications, as they demand, shall be abolished. The producers demand a flat $3 rate for each 100 pounds of milk delivered, regardless of classification.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11. -- Friendly trade relations between Canada and Soviet Russia have been restored, according to an announcement made tonight by Prime Minister Mackenzie King. W.D. Euler, Minister of Trade and Commerce, who recently visited Russia, is expected next week to outline a limited trade agreement with that country with which Canada has been at economic loggerheads for five years.

STAUNTON, Va., Sept. 11 (AP). -- The Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals today granted a new trial on the ground of insufficient evidence to Edith Maxwell, under a twenty-five-year sentence for the murder of her father in Wise County in 1935.

The British Government has every intention of carrying out its obligations under the Palestine mandate land will, regardless of race and religion, secure the human rights of the inhabitants of the country. This assurance was given yesterday to the Pro-Palestine Federation of America on behalf of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin of Britain in reply to a cablegram sent to him by the federation on Sept. 2.

President ROOSEVELT'S address at the World Power Conference yesterday was perhaps more notable for what it did not say than what it did. Some may have feared that he would again throw down a gage of battle to our big utility companies. On the contrary, he merely complimented them for their great achievements, and declared that the more they were "integrated," the larger would be their service at a smaller cost.

Miss Helen Jacobs played one of the finest matches of her career and Frederick Perry was seen in one of his most unconvincing roles yesterday as the American and British titleholders advanced with Miss Alice Marble and Donald Budge to the finals of the national singles championships at Forest Hills.

About 100 WPA artists and models refused to work and embarked upon a "sit-down" strike yesterday at the Federal Art Project headquarters, 6 East Thirty-ninth Street, when they were called there to make up for time lost during the Labor Day holiday.

With the arrest of Thomas Blackburn, who said he lived at 157 West Eightieth Street and was 36 years old, Secret Service agents revealed yesterday that they had rounded up five men believed to be the last members of a counterfeit ring who were disposing of bogus $20 notes turned out by Victor (Count) Lustig, now serving a twenty-year term in Federal prison.

One of the pleasing and hopeful aspects of the stretch of earth between our two oceans, as it is seen from the skies, is the vast extent of the ground that lies within the shadow of trees. Twenty-five years ago a very definite step was taken looking especially to the protection of the watersheds, the sources of streams that become navigable rivers.

MADRID, Sept. 11 (Passed by the Censor). -- Heavy fighting is going on near Santa Olalla in the Talavera de la Reina sector, about seventy miles southwest of Madrid, after a desperate attempt by Spanish Rebels to break through.

One of the pleasing and hopeful aspects of the stretch of earth between our two oceans, as it is seen from the skies, is the vast extent of the ground that lies within the shadow of trees. Twenty-five years ago a very definite step was taken looking especially to the protection of the watersheds, the sources of streams that become navigable rivers.

MADRID, Sept. 11 (Passed by the Censor). -- Heavy fighting is going on near Santa Olalla in the Talavera de la Reina sector, about seventy miles southwest of Madrid, after a desperate attempt by Spanish Rebels to break through.

THE edge of severity is often taken off the season's first street dresses by the flattering softness of pearls or the brilliance of rhinestones. Both come in new and interesting settings. Rhinestones are now often combined with black enamel or catalin.
VIENNA, Austria, Sept. 12. -- A dramatic series of documents has been published by the official Heimwehr organ Die Neue Zeit showing how the Fascist Heimwehr had fallen from favor.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Visitors who attended the opening program of the first International Horticultural Exposition in the International Amphitheatre at the Union Stock Yards today found the huge building transformed into a palace of blossoms.

Thirty-nine new courses, including a survey of the motion-picture field and a course for women executives in business, will be offered this Fall in the Hunter College evening and extension division, Professor Broderick Cohen, director, announced yesterday.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.T., Sept. 12. -- Miss Laura Hall Jennings was introduced to society here tonight at a dinner dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Percy Hall Jennings of Laurel Brake, and her aunt, Mrs. George Small Franklin, at the home of Mrs. Franklin.

Entering its 105th academic year next week, New York University anticipates an enrollment of 42,000 students for 1936-37, the largest in the history of the institution, Henry G. Arnsdorf, registrar, announced yesterday.

COSHOCTON, Ohio, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The mother of a 4-month-old baby, according to Prosecutor Russel E. Lyons, has confessed that she plotted with three men, one of them her brother, to wreck and rob a Pennsylvania passenger train "because I needed money to get a divorce."

A policy of neutrality is easily adhered to only when the non-warring countries regard the issues as intrinsically unimportant or important merely for the parties to the conflict. Unhappily, in the Spanish civil war, as was evident from the first days of the struggle, outsiders -- nations and class-conscious groups -- behaved almost as if the war were their own.

NEWARK, Sept. 12. -- Buffalo made it three out of four over Newark in the Governor's Cup series today, defeating the Bears, 6 to 1. The pennant winners need only one more victory to eliminate the Bears in the first round of the play-offs.

The share market made little progress last week. Aside from the brisk advance on Tuesday following the Labor Day holiday, the market was hesitant and mildly reactionary. THE NEW YORK TIMES railway stock average reached a new high for the year, surpassing the Aug. 10 high by a small margin -- 44.65 against 43.93.

THE centenary of the birth of Sir Walter Besant has not been marked by any public celebrations, or by the erection of memorial tablets, or even by the publication of a centenary edition of his works. If such an edition had been issued its sales would probably have been disappointing, for there exists today no widespread demand that it would meet.

TORONTO, Sept. 12. -- W. Lawson Little Jr., the subject of much doleful head-shaking because of his performances since he gave up his amateur status last Spring after two years of sweeping the United States and British amateur championships, came into his own as a professional golfer today.

NANKING, CHINA. MODERNIZATION and the spread of Western methods, conveniences and ideas bring more than benefits to the Chinese people. They also bring many difficult problems, at least to the officials of China's capital city.

In Volume XIX of Dictionary of American Biography, Troye-Wentworth, GEORGE WASHINGTON is first in space. His career is told in seventeen pages. Two other Presidents grossly misjudged and calumniated not only in life, as WASHINGTON was, but long after their deaths, JOHN TYLER and MARTIN VAN BUREN, are treated with the impartiality and discrimination that political hate so long denied them.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- After almost five months of hesitation the British Government has finally taken the plunge and decided to use overwhelming force against the turbulent Arabs in Palestine. A division of 12,000 men has been ordered from England, 3,000 reservists have been called up to bring the understaffed units to full strength and a scathing indictment of Arabian "violence and outrage" has been issued by the Colonial Office.

THIS book of short stories by Canada's most promising novelist reveals the interesting fact that Mr. Callaghan's fictional style is more naturally effective, at present, in the short-story form. His novels, of which "They Shall Inherit the Earth" is the most memorable, have running through them a sensitive, warm, emotional tone that is the stuff of finely realized experience but they maintain a certain flatness of tone that runs to monotony in a long work.

FOR eighteen years Australian children have been reading "The Magic Pudding," written to prove the author's theory that child fantasy is based largely on food. At least it proves that Australians know a good thing when they see it, for this tale of the great war between the puddin' owners and the puddin' thieves is as rollicking a bit of nonsense as has been turned out since Gilbert and Sullivan parted company.

THE word "middle-class" may have enjoyed a brief prestige during the mid-Victorian years, but today it is scarcely the thing. Nobody is eager to claim it as the correct description of himself. None the less, it exists; unfortunate adjective, it is not obsolete.

They linger longer at Montauk, even when the season is about to close elsewhere. All through September and up toward the end of October cruisermen and especially sports fishermen with craft trim, fast and sound will find it hard to leave this most popular center of game fishing along the Eastern seaboard.

The necessary condensation in the overappreciative review of my book "Across the Years" in the issue of Aug. 30 left some matters of historical data open to possible misinterpretation which are fully recorded in the text.

WHEN the Philharmonic-Symphony Society decided to reduce its season to twenty-four weeks and scheduled this year's opening for November, a month later than usual, it was predicted that October would be a quiet month on the music front.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 11. -- After sharp skirmishes running over several days, Midsouth planters have at last come to grips with WPA officials over the demand of the planters and the refusal of WPA administrators to curtail or suspend for ten weeks local WPA projects so that relief clients may be forced into the fields to make up an alarming shortage of cotton pickers.

WASHINGTON. -- If the opponents of the New Real accomplish nothing else in the current Presidential campaign, they at least will have impressed upon many Americans who did not know it before that they are taxpayers, and big ones at that.

Bringing eight choice mounts with which they expect to do well in the military events at the National Horse Show in November, the Chilean army team, consisting of five officers, arrived in Brooklyn on the S.S. Antofagasta yesterday.

Inspector Higgins is not one of your know-it-all detectives, who always go straight to the solution of every puzzle, sneer at the stupidities of ordinary mankind and never make a mistake. No, Inspector Higgins is very human. And when he matches wits with the brilliant, genial, nonchalant and exasperating gentleman crook Henry Prince over the murder of Michael Randall, M.P., at Cliff House, he is never quite sure that he is coming out ahead.

RADIO sets built during the Coolidge era are rapidly vanishing from the American homes, and this applies to the rural regions as well as the cities, according to a survey, the tabulation of which has been released by the Federal Communications Commission.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP). -- General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA administrator, at a Democratic rally tonight called upon "poor people" to "stick by the only President in history who ever threw the force of government into the fight for social justice -- Franklin Roosevelt."

A lively primer on proportional representation has just been published by the Women's City Club. Under the auspices of Mrs. Samuel Sloan Duryee, president of the organization, this primer will be extensively distributed in the campaign to inform voters on the fundamental principles of the issue. The club will concentrate during the Fall on the adoption of a new city charter.

THE commission that President Roosevelt sent to Europe to study consumer cooperation is now on its way back to this country. What the President will do with the commission's report is a question to be answered later; meantime his mere interest in the cooperative movement has lifted it out of obscurity into the realm of controversy.

SCATTERED through the bulb catalogues may be found glowing descriptions of rather unfamiliar species. Nevertheless, for the average planter, these descriptions do not dispel all the mystery about them, nor give full information of their behavior.

This is the time in an election year when the nation looks east toward Maine. The records do not bear out the assertion that the nation always goes as Maine does. The slogan probably gained vogue from the fact that Maine is normally Republican and the Republican party, since the Civil War, has sent its candidate to the White House more frequently than the Democratic.

By the familiar magic of orderly assembly, a world of scattered vacationers will fuse itself this week into closely knit organizations, and the club season will be officially opened. Poised for the moment between the leisure of the Summer and the brisk pace of the colder months, executives and members contemplate a calendar that promises as much as it demands.

Marking the first big week of the Fall season, retail trade last week showed sharp gains, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Producers in many apparel lines are now unprepared to fill orders for immediate delivery.

FEW travelers return from French Morocco without a desire to revisit this land of camel caravans, desert mirages and high-spirited tribesmen. A country of contrasts, from Marrakech in the South, with its modern hotels, to Fez in the North, with its mosques, covered streets and atmosphere of mystery, French Morocco in the last few years has become a popular objective for tourists.

PARIS. ONE of the most interesting manifestations of the Paris Winter collections may be seen in the selection of fabrics made by the couture houses. Some have elected to make their most effective models in plain fabrics; others have resorted to the most sumptuous materials.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- There will be no local contests in the primaries next Tuesday. Rockland County Democrats will vote to select a State Senatorial candidate in conjunction with Richmond. James P. Morrison and State Senator Rae L. Egbert, both of Staten Island, are the candidates, and little interest is displayed in the contest here.

HONOLULU. -- If the Navy Department grants permission, there will be a great slaughter of rats on tiny Wake Island, where one of the Pan American Airways bases is located. The work will be done by representatives of the United States Biological Survey here.

PARIS, Sept. 11. -- Those two strange bedfellows, Communists and Socialists, came to blows this week in France and now there is a latent political crisis here that bodes ill for the indefinite continuance of the Blum government. It was expected to happen but no one thought it would come so soon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12. -- A strike of 5,000 workers in the California lettuce area has seriously reduced shipments and cost the lettuce belt farmers $75,000 for the last week. Normal shipments for the season amount to 125 cars per day. Scarcely a crate was moving as the week closed, with prices climbing rapidly.

THIS story is a sort of "Live Alone and Like It" for old ladies. Mrs. Meigs at 81 did live alone, in a comfortable bungalow at the very edge of the lake shore in a big Middle Western city, and she liked it very much. Most readers, without exactly wishing to be 81, will find her life pleasant, lively, full, very little shadowed by her years, and highly diverting to read about.

Uncle Sam's bills, in each of the last three years and in spite of recovery, have been larger than the year before. Examination of the new figures submitted in THE TIMES of Sept. 2 shows that if non-recurring bonus payments are eliminated for both 1936 and 1937, Federal expenses as estimated for 1937 will come within $4,000,000 of equaling the $7,206,305,725 actually spent in 1936.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The veteran Waite Hoyt pitched almost flawlessly for eight innings today, only to weaken in the ninth and give the Bees four hits, all they needed to drive in the three runs for their 3-2 triumph over the Pirates.
The calendar of important events for the week among women's clubs follows:

AMONG the chagrins of Britannia, if one may judge by the letters in the London journals, is the poaching on her preserves by Hollywood film-makers.
