Such disasters as the compulsory shaving of Beefeaters, the abolishment of cats'-meat men and the cracking of the bell at St. Clements Giles move public-spirited civilians and ex-admirals only to sad resignation, but the enterprise (or impudence) of Hollywood goads them to chauvinistic fury.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 12. -- The second annual amateur night for Guild Hall benefit was held before a capacity audience tonight at the John Drew Memorial Theatre. Mrs. Thomas Aquin Kelly and John Custis Lawrence headed the committee arranging the benefit.

Plans were announced yesterday for the construction of a new 25,000-ton steamship for the Swedish American Line to enter the transatlantic service in 1938. The new vessel, to be named the Stockholm, will be equipped to make twenty knots and will accommodate 1,400 passengers in three classes, 400 of them in cabin class, 600 in tourist and 400 in third.

FEUDALISM, outmoded and outworn, received a deathblow on the field of Agincourt; and nationalism -- better to call it patriotism -- sprang into vigorous young life when a girl in armor raised the siege of Orleans and crowned the King at Rheims.

HASSARD SHORT, who usually can be found directing the players and subterranean mechanical gadgets for such spectacles as "The Great Waltz," is finding modern life not kind. No spectacles, or, as they phrase it elsewhere, a paucity of musical shows: stellar talent being what it is these Hollywood days.

IN its original issue the violin concerto in D -- played by Jascha Heifetz with the London Philharmonic Orchestra and released domestically in Victor Album M-309 -- was part of the Sibelius Society's fourth volume. The remainder of that set is now listed here and Album M-311 contains two tone poems -- "Night Ride and Sunrise" (Op. 55) and "The Oceanides" (Op. 73) -- played by the British Broadcasting Corporation's orchestra, under Adrian Boult.

HOLLYWOOD. THE makers of movies are thinking in international terms these days. There was a time when they were decisively national in their views, but the problems of showing pictures abroad, the revenue to be derived from foreign markets and the fascinating offers of financing from European capitals have all tended to divert their attention from this limited corner of the earth.

The United States Constitution Sesquicentennial Commission has plans well under way for the nation-wide celebration of the 150th anniversary of the formation of the Constitution, on Sept. 17, 1937, together with observance of many other dates of importance in connection with the history of the Constitution.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 12. -- Government defenders abandoned the seaport of San Sebastian to the Rebels tonight.

NEW shows coming on the air this week put an end to radio's Summer routine. Again the studios and rehearsal realms are buzzing with activity. Musicians and actors who have been absent from the radio haunts are back on the scene to join in what promises to be one of radio's most active and prosperous seasons.

WARSAW, Sept. 11. -- The commander of a victorious army, coming home with his head crowned with war triumphs, could hardly wish for a better reception than was accorded to General Rydz-Smigly on his return from a peaceful mission to France, the traditional friend he reconquered for Poland.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -- Rallying after being on the verge of defeat in the second set, Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco captured the girls' national tennis singles championship today, beating Miss Eleanor Dawson of Piedmont, Calif., in the final round at the Philadelphia Cricket Club, 6 -- 8, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 2.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- A coroner's jury today returned a verdict of suicide while deranged in the death of Count Arnaldo C. Tamburini, 51 years old, who plunged from a second-story window of St. Luke's Hospital early this morning. The Count was a portrait painter and friend of Mussolini.

AMERICAN industry has produced several figures who, though not national in reputation, either by virtue of industrial expansion or personal leadership, nurture, nevertheless, the core of a certain type of sound labor relationships.

Thirty-four contests in the Democratic primary will be settled by the enrolled voters when they go to the polls here Tuesday. There are no contests for nominations in the ranks of the Republicans, Socialists or Communists.

ON a hot night last Spring I sat in a Kansas schoolhouse while a county agent explained to a group of fifty or sixty farmers the need for re building soil fertility on their farms. Charts made graphic the declining crop yield in Osage County, made understandable the agent's appeal for the planting of legumes, for crop rotation, for the terracing of sloping fields that are wearing out.

BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- Although the outside world, thinking in familiar grooves, has been most impressed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's demand for colonies, the Germans themselves are concerned in the main with Hitler's new four-year plan, as announced at Nuremberg the other day.

CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 12. -- Chief interest in Tuesday's New Hampshire primary election is centered in the close race between Governor H. Styles Bridges and former Senator George Higgins Moses for the Republican Senatorial nomination.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12. -- The Dollar Line's President Hoover is plowing to Honolulu at the fastest clip the vessel has ever essayed between the two ports in an effort to make up some of the six days lost in this harbor by a strike over the hiring of a single seaman.

The body of Dr. Elinor Edgar, 36-year-old physician, was found yesterday in the kitchen of her office-apartment at 277 Park Avenue, between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets. Detectives Thomas Foran and Xavier McFarland of the East Fifty-first Street station listed the case as a suicide.
"Skeet is a sport that women can enjoy as well as men. This is not just a general statement. There are enough successful women skeet shooters at this moment to prove this to be a fact."

DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Lengthy ballots will face Michigan voters in many sections of the State next Tuesday when they select candidates for offices ranging from United States Senator down to County Drain Commissioner.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 12. -When the New York National Guard riflemen totaled 2,691 of a possible 3,000 in the national team match, they landed in sixteenth place. The title was won by the United States Marine Corps of Washington with 2,830.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- The first contingent, 1,500 officers and men, of the 12,000 troops ordered to Palestine -- the largest expeditionary force to leave England since the World War -- sailed from Southampton today on the troop ship Dorsetshire.

THE annual dahlia show of the Garden Club of Nyack will be held on Tuesday at the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. La Roche, Voorhis Point, South Nyack. . . . The annual Fall flower show of the Garden Circle of New Rochelle opens Tuesday afternoon at the Community House, Temple Israel; a novel feature will be special classes for members who have belonged to the Circle for less than three years.

PLUTARCH ascribes to EURIPIDES (or some other ancient Greek) the remark that "the first requisite to happiness is to be born in a famous city." Had one of these read "New York Advancing" (being a picture of New York during the first two years of the administration of Mayor LA GUARDIA) he would regard as fortunate those born or reborn as citizens of this famous city.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12. -- Society is expected to turn its interest to international polo next Saturday when the Argentine and American Greentree teams will play the opening matches of the championship meet.

MILAN. PASSERS-BY wondered whether Rome, like London, had exchanged zoos with Moscow when operatic aspirants were allowed to exhibit their God-granted gifts in a series of official auditions recently held here (and in Rome) before representatives of the National Opera Syndicate of the Centro Lirico Italiano and of leading impresarios.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11. -- Faced with drastic demands by ship owners, involving reduction in pay, less advantageous working conditions and a weakening of union control, Pacific Coast longshoremen will begin voting next week on rejection or acceptance of the employers' proposal that they submit all differences between them to arbitration.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12. -- About the best sailing breeze of the entire season sprang up today for the thirty-seventh annual Fall regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, which also was the twenty-first championship event of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, and it resulted in splendid contests in all the classes from the fifty-foot waterline sloops down to the dories manned by the future greats among the amateur sailors.
PARIS, Sept. 12. -- The government's efforts to arbitrate the textile strike at Lille and its environs broke down this afternoon precipitating what threatens to be a serious situation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Permission to appeal a ruling of Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson denying an injunction to restrain the Chicago Board of Trade and Federal officials from enforcing the Commodity Exchange Act was granted today to seven members of the Board of Trade by Judge John P. Barnes in Federal District Court here, who was sitting in the absence of Judge Wilkerson.

After absorbing the heavy hedge-selling which is usual on Saturdays at this time of the year, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange hardened in final dealings yesterday to end unchanged to 7 points higher than Friday's close. A combination of trade and commission-house buying imparted decided resistance, and, as a result, fluctuations held within a 10-point range and October ended at 12.15 cents a pound, compared with 11.51 the previous Saturday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- The return of hot, humid weather toward the end of the week retarded retail trade. With the exception of one store, which was sold to a local department store chain, and another which featured a heavily advertised special sale, the larger retail establishments ran only slightly ahead of last year in their sales volume.

Claiming that "I never would jeopardize my amateur athletic status for any consideration," Jesse Owens yesterday gave the lie to the widely ballyhooed reports that he was turning professional, announced that he positively would compete in three events at the track and field meet of the New York Caledonian Club at the Yankee Stadium on Thursday night, and gave the already harried officials of the A.A.U. something more to ponder over.

A substantial drop in the volume of Soviet Russian purchases in the United States this year compared with last is feared by exporters who called attention yesterday to the fact that commitments during July and August this year were $5,500,000 lower compared with the corresponding months of last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Cottonseed crushed during August was reported by the Census Bureau today at 102,451 tons, compared with 143,385 in August last year.

BACK with us, and very much the beaming Lochinvar, is Henry Fonda, whose first trip to Europe won for him the plighted troth of Mrs. Frances Seymour Brokaw and the honor of playing the lead in Europe's first Technicolor film, New World's "Wings of the Morning," with Annabella.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- On Nov. 17, twenty years almost to the day, since her American debut in the auditorium theatre here, Amelita Galli-Curci will make a start on what she hopes will be a second career by an appearance with the Chicago City Opera Company in the Civic Opera House.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 12. -- The foreign commerce of Peru during the first six months of this year reflects not only recovery from the world slump but also a return to prosperous conditions which reached their peak in 1929.

DETROIT is not viewing with alarm the coming elections. The men of the motor city are too busy pointing with pride to their 1937 model automobiles. Of course, the various company executives have their personal political opinions and are interested in the November results, but all those available for interviews last week were calm in their preferences for one or the other of the principal Presidential candidates.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Playing like pennant contenders instead of a seventh-place club, the Browns won both games of a double-header from the Red Sox today, taking the opener, 6 -- 4, and the second, 3 -- 2, in ten innings.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 13. -- The largest budget in Japanese history, aggregating 3,200,000,000 yen, has been drafted by the spending departments for submission to the Cabinet, according to the newspaper Asahi.

FOUR concerts are scheduled at the Sheffield Festival, to be held in Sheffield, England, in October. There will be an afternoon and an evening session on the opening day, Oct. 21. At the first of these the program will consist of the Berlioz "Te Deum"; the Brahms violin concerto, with Adolf Busch as soloist, and Rachmaninoff's "The Bells."

Narrow movements of prices characterized the stock market yesterday, and trading was the slowest since Aug. 22. The turnover on the Stock Exchange in the brief trading period amounted to 494,000 shares, compared with 715,000 the Saturday before.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 12 (AP). -- Six Purdue University football players suffered painful burns late today when a heater stove in their shower room exploded.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 12 -- Manhasset Bay Yacht Club fourth annual Fall race series came to an end today with the Benson brothers, William and Robert, placing on top for four races in the Victory Bluejacket. E.P. Alker winning among the Interclubs with Opal II, Margery and Robert Bavier Jr.'s Frolic getting first among the Atlantics and G.W. Vaughen's Thetis taking the honors among the stars.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11. -- Building construction has taken on additional activity in the Eighth Federal Reserve District and reports from all sections indicate a sharp increase. While the termination of the drought has quickened many lines, the general seasonal dullness is generally evident.

In chiding Donald Comer for his realistic comments on the ever-mounting tide of Japanese imports of cotton goods THE TIMES recent editorial is predicated on a fallacy that is common to commentators on the textile industry.

WASTE" is a very small book. It can be slipped lightly and easily into a man's coat-pocket or a woman's fair-sized purse. It is written with complete simplicity, and calmly withal. Yet it is a clarion cry for the saving of our country.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 12. -- The Piping Rock Cup, feature race of the Fall meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association, staged over the Rockaway Hunting Club course today, went to Louis E. Stoddard Jr.'s entry, Blackcock.

Great was the rejoicing at the Polo Grounds yesterday along about the fourth inning when the scoreboards on the left and right upper balconies revealed the cheerful tidings that the Dodgers -- those dear old Dodgers of Flatbush -- had brought down the Cardinals in the first game of their double-header.

MR. LASKI began as a liberal, but in recent years he has been moving rapidly to the left. At some point he must have felt that he had definitely broken through the liberal section of the political spectrum and emerged as a full-fledged Marxist.

WITHIN ten years the courses of instruction offered by virtually every small high school will compare favorably with those now available only at the larger schools of a plan of supervised correspondence study continues to advance as it has during the past year.

The Bible, which sells about 25,000,000 copies a year, has entered the field of new literature. Last week it was announced that the Book of the Month Club would distribute the Bible as a "book dividend." A special edition, arranged and edited by Ernest Sutherland Bates, will have a first printing of 85,000 copies.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 12. -- John Nogrady of Astoria, L.I., seeded third, and Percy Kynaston of Rockville Center, L.I., seeded seventh, and runner-up a year ago, entered the third round of the Eastern New Jersey clay court tennis championship at the Elizabethtown and Country Club today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The Phillies defeated the Reds in both ends of a double-header today, winning the first game, 7 -- 1, and the second, 7 -- 2.

A rise in carloadings last week to the highest level since 1931 served to show that the railroads rapidly were approaching a point at which their earnings might be considered normal. Substantial gains in both freight and passenger revenues have been achieved in recent months.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. IN New England this year one State, one city and one institution of higher education are celebrating their 300th aniversaries. Rhode Island is the State, Springfield the city, and Harvard the university.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- "Only what we expected," was the reaction tonight of such Russians as learned of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech at the National Socialist congress in Nuremberg today.

The contemplated retirement of Walter R. Okeson, chairman of the football rules committee, almost caused the breaking up of the Eastern Intercollegiate Association at a special meeting, which preceded the gathering of football officials, coaches and athletic directors for rules interpretations at the Hotel McAlphin yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's address at today's milk hearing:

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 12 -- Cavalcade, the turf's 1934 champion attempting a comeback, pulled up last today in a field of nine when he was given his final warm-up for next Wednesday's $25,000 Narragansett Special.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 11. -- Arriving in Gibraltar at the end of August, this correspondent motored to Algeciras and obtained the necessary safe conduct to proceed to Seville. General Queipo de Llano, one of the insurgent commanders, granted the writer a special permit to accompany the troops under his command on their advance against the Loyalist forces.

CIRCUS collecting started as a one-ring show, so to speak. Its present status is comparable to the glorified Big Top, with its three rings, four stages and hippodrome track. In the beginning, the adult fans who made a hobby of the circus made an all-inclusive quest for circus relics and circus trophies; but, as the possibilities of the pursuit unfolded, specialization set in.

ONE of Hollywood's favorite beliefs, most often expressed when script writers are in conclave, is that the screen be more closely related to the novel than it is to the stage. The lads on the drama side of the fence are all in support of the theory, but, even so, it has merit.

HUNTERS in the metropolitan district are inspecting their guns, training their bird dogs and reading game laws in preparation for the shooting season. Already there is scattered firing in the New Jersey marshes with the lifting of the legal ban on the small rail birds.

DETROIT, Sept. 12. -- Husky Charley Ruffing, Joe McCarthy's ace hurler, tried today to set for himself a new pitching mark as the Yankees look their season's farewell of the Tigers. But the Nokomis red-top was unhappy in his choice of days, and missed the mark.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 12. -- Lightning, thunder, downpours of rain and a lofted, last-second drive combined to produce a wildly exciting polo final for the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup. That last-minute goal, from the mallet of Stewart Iglehart, brought a 14-13 victory to Templeton over a Roslyn combination that fought to the final bell.
Robert Erskine Ely, director of the League for Political Education for thirty-five years, will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday today at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y.

ONE of the most primitive races or types of man left in the world is the Australian aboriginal, or black man. He lives today as he did thousands of years ago, and anthropologists say he will never change until the race has been eliminated -- an eventuality which does not seem far off.

Of course Adolf Hitler, who never misses an opportunity to proclaim Germany's devotion to peace, did not mean he would use his new army to go get it; it must have been just an oratorical hyperbole which led him to tell his followers assembled at Nuremberg yesterday that "If I had the Urals, if we possessed Siberia, if we had the Ukraine, National Socialist Germany would be swimming in surplus prosperity."

TWENTY-FIVE years ago, on Sept. 17, 1911, Calbraith Perry Rodgers left New York on the first transcontinental flight. It took fifty days (3 days 10 hours 14 minutes actual flying time). Rodgers made it in some seventy hops, flying a Wright biplane which was damaged and repaired so many times en route that nothing remained of the original machine at the finish but the drip pan and the vertical rudder.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Rock X., owned by H.H. Cross's Tranquillity Farm Stable, splashed to a narrow victory today in the $2,500 added Crete Handicap at Lincoln Fields. Rock X, held only a nose margin at the finish of the six-furlong journey over Manners Man, with Roguish Girl a distant third.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- For "thinking and acting fast" in saving the lives of two playmates, Kathryn Van Horn, a 12-year-old lass of White Cottage, Ohio, received a medal of valor and a toy mickey mouse from President Roosevelt today.

PERHAPS in a few months, perhaps in a year, Eamon de Valets will again face the people of the Irish Free State and ask their approval of his reform administration. If other events do not force the issue sooner, the submission of the new constitution now being drafted with the maintenance and extension of the reform program in view may supply the reason for a general election.

LOS ANGELES. ANOTHER step toward the opening of national parks to greater use through air transportation was taken recently when an airline operating out of Boulder City, Nev., to El Tovar, on the south rim of the Grand Canyon in Arizona, instituted regular daily service.

An enthusiastic crowd of more than 1,000 persons surged yesterday against the police line at Pennsylvania Station trying to get a glimpse of Governor Landon when his special train arrived here en route to Portland, Me.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Happy the Great, aged troting star from the William Parkhurst Stables, captured the Class A event, feature at the matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

The last important site of ancient ruins along the River Nile to remain unexplored will be tackled this Winter when the Egypt Exploration Society of London, England, sends men to solve the mystery of Soleb and Sesebi, cities founded nearly 3,500 years ago in the heart of Nubia, which is today the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan.

Miss Baldwin's new novel is based on that still wide-open question of whether woman's place is in business or at home devoting herself to Kinder, Kueehen and Kirche. The set-up is arranged in the author's usual competent style.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11. -- Premier Aberhart of Alberta really means business. The first Premier ever to win power on a Social Credit platform has demonstrated during recent weeks that he is actually going to put Social Credit into practice -- or perish politically in the attempt.

THOSE who attended the sixteenth annual national air races, which closed on Monday at Mines Field (now called the Los Angeles Municipal Airport), and have likewise been at previous holdings of this air classic, find themselves no little disturbed.
THERE is no phenomenon in nature," says Dr. Davenport, "not even the universe of galaxies, that compares with the marvelous intricacies of development, composition and structure of a child."

BEDFORD, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Currie Lee gave a reception with dancing this afternoon to introduce their daughter, Miss Damaris Lee, and their niece, Miss Mary Jo Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Day Lee. Later Mr. and Mrs. Lee gave a dinner dance for the debutantes. Both parties took place in the gardens of Driftway, the Ronald Lee place here.

The formation by ten unions of the Committee on Industrial Organization -- a move that has been outlawed by the leadership of the American Federation of Labor -- is variously interpreted. Some observers see in it the long-delayed awakening of a segment of labor to its need of a new structural strategy; others view it as an outburst of idealism and inspired leadership; still others regard it as an ominous beginning of a revolutionary program.

GENEVA, Sept. 12. -- The report of J.A.C. Avenol, Secretary-General of the League, on the world economic situation, suggesting that the time has come to renew efforts for an international agreement in this field, has just been published by the League.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Gross income from farm production for 1935, including government payments applying to 1935 production programs, is the highest since 1930, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today. Bureau statistics put the 1935 gross income at $8,505,000,000 or 17 per cent greater than the 1934 estimate of $7,276,000,000 and 59 per cent greater than in 1932, the low point of he depression.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The first picture of how the civil war has cut into American trade with Spain was drawn today in Commerce Department statistics.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 12. -- Upholding the penal provisions of the Securities Act of 1933, Federal Judge John D. Martin today overruled demurrers intended to remove from the court trials involving alleged fraudulent stock transactions.

THIS is National Electrical and Radio Exposition week in New York. The show opened on Wednesday at the Grand Central Palace and will continue until Saturday night. All that is modern in radio receivers is on display in the arena, together with hundreds of domestic electrical appliances, from flatirons to furnaces.

IN the afternoon I had seen the last group exhibition of the Summer at the Woodstock Gallery; visited it, indeed, with but a narrow margin to spare, since the gallery called it a season and closed its doors yesterday.

Highly gratified that the government's extremely bullish report last week did not produce the bulge in cotton prices that might be warranted by such a large cut in the crop, both manufacturers and buyers of cotton textiles agreed yesterday that the primary markets had become soundly entrenched for the balance of the year and that buying would not be upset by an unduly sharp rise in quotations.

A summary of the fourth annual report of the League Loans Committee (London) received here by Speyer Co. from Eliot Wadsworth, American member of the committee, emphasizes that the contrast between good and bad debtors has become more marked in the last year.

The Governors Island poloists rode off with the Colonel Joseph H. Colyer Trophy for the fourth straight year as they defeated their Brooklyn rivals, the First Division players of Fort Hamilton, 8 -- 5, at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Under the direction of the National Resources Committee, State planning boards will make a canvass of the public construction needed in the United States during the next six years, according to the announcement of Secretary Ickes, chairman of the committee.

WITH the organization by nature-lovers of the Hudson River Conservation Society, a fresh step has been taken in efforts extending over more than a generation to preserve the grandeur of the Hudson River Valley, "the Rhineland of America."

DALLAS, Sept. 12. -- Business conditions throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District continue to show steady improvement as attention shifts to new merchandise in the stores. The opening of schools has had a stimulating effect on retail sales, especially in wearing apparel lines.
A porter's error in putting a handbag with the wrong luggage almost caused another flare-up of the "war in the air" between New York and New Jersey yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 12. -- The creation of a permanent colonial army in Ethiopia, extraordinary appropriations for the army, navy and air force, the resumption of commercial relations with former sanctionist States, excepting Britain, the Netherlands and Russia, as well as an 8 per cent average salary increase for all State employes, were announced in a communique at the end of today's Cabinet meeting.

The most important race meeting of the Fall season in the East, that at Belmont Park, is scheduled to begin on Thursday and continue until Oct. 3. Before it has run its course such famous stakes as the $100,000 Futurity, the Jockey Club Gold Cup, the Lawrence Realization, the Champagne, the Matron, the Jerome and Manhattan Handicaps will have been renewed.

AS Fall approaches, the earnest gardener begins to plan operations for the coming year. Many of them cannot be carried into effect until Spring and will of necessity for the time being remain plans only. But work on some projects may be begun at once, and among these the water garden is important.

PARIS, Sept. 10. -- Parisian elegantes will plunge "feet first" into Winter fashions with colored kidskin shoes; they are creating a veritable furor. Julienne is sponsoring shoes that match the dress and have contrasting heels and ribbon laces which echo details of the trimming.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 12. -- Fear of the possibility of a "write-in" campaign against the redesignation of Representative Robert L. Bacon of Westbury by the Republican organization of the First Congressional District at the primary election in Nassau County next Tuesday caused Supervisor J. Russel Sprague, Republican county leader, to send a letter to all Republican committeemen today urging on them the importance of "getting out the votes" for Tuesday's poll.

SCHOOL reopens tomorrow with additional housing accommodations, smaller classes in the elementary schools, enlarged facilities for dealing with maladjusted children and every prospect of a further extension of educational service generally as a result of an increased budget.

Only by establishing a "thoroughly socialized democracy" can the people of the United States escape the dictatorship and tyranny of communism and fascism, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Social Justice Commission of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, of which Dr. Sidney E. Goldstein is chairman.

FOR more than twenty years the mystery-loving public has been waiting for another story by the author of "Trent's Last Case." Having achieved a mystery novel which was famous wherever such novels were read, and which was invariably to be found on even the shortest lists of the world's greatest detective stories, E.C. Bentley retired into silence.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- One of the earliest churches in New York State, the Bedford Presbyterian Church, will celebrate tomorrow the 255th anniversary of the action of the first settlers in allotting land upon which to build a meeting house. That was in 1681.

Evidence is accumulating that, in accord with the general expectation, there will be an unusual amount of voting across party lines this year. The Literary Digest poll is the only one, we believe, which includes these shifts of party allegiance. So far as it has gone, it reveals a large percentage of them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- President Roosevelt today approved 124 new PWA construction projects having a total estimated cost of about $17,140,000. This is the first allocation of funds entirely from the $300,000,000 revolving fund authorized by the last Congress.

The ferryboat Queens was transformed into a cruise ship yesterday and 675 lower East Side mothers and children went on an outing in waters about the city. The excursion was arranged by the Volunteers of America, an organization founded forty years ago by General and Mrs. Ballington Booth for the relief of the underprivileged.

STUTTGART, Sept. 11. -- Functionaries here who make a business of what is known as Germanism abroad apparently have no intention of abandoning the doctrine that every German by birth, irrespective of his citizenship, remains a member of what they call the German nation.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 12. -- Unlike the meetings of the British Association for the Advancement of Science held in the past decade this year's is restless, even rebellious. Fascism and the dread of war have caused chemists, biologists and engineers to break the bounds of scientific reserve.

Perhaps some Hollywood children lead happy, wholesome lives. But not the two in "The Sentence of Youth." Their mother was a beautiful motion picture star -- not one of the wilder sort, just utterly selfish, eager for success, and ravenous for loads of love and admiration.

POLITICS and baseball are the country's two major sports, and this is the frenzied season for each. It is a Presidential year -- and most probably a New York City world's series year -- and the battles will drip vitriol and patriotism. Afterward, come the Winter, some of the leaders in both fields will have moved quietly off into dim retirement and new ones will be on their way up.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The effect of the Labor Day holiday was felt generally in business last week and this, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey, indicated a more-than-seasonal rise in some fields.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12. -- Governor Landon traveled today through New England, which this year seems likely to be the Republican stronghold, and received assurances that he would carry all six States.
TOKYO, Sept. 12. -- A Japanese desire for new naval treaties, based on parity with Great Britain and the United States, was hinted today by Admiral Osami Nagano, Minister of the Navy.

THE contract-bridge season traditionally begins the week after Labor Day. Bridge players, a pleasure-loving lot, leave town in a body during the Summer, and most of the bridge-playing is done at the New Jersey and Long Island coast resorts.

NOW and again this department receives woeful letters from those who report musical activities in small cities. Frequently the writers show that they are serious, well informed, enthusiastic for their work, but they find little that is important to write about.

The area of Soviet Russia, including Siberia, is 8,144,228 square miles. It is a vast land, rich in raw materials and natural resources, largely undeveloped. The area of Nazi Germany is 186,627 square miles. It is, compared with other major countries, a small land, poor in natural wealth.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP). -- Detectives decided today that the fatal shooting of Mrs. Marie Saner, 31, at municipal airport last night was a suicide, and Deputy Coroner Arthur I. Donlan said there would be no inquest.

In a thrilling last inning finish, featured by Ralph Summas's triple to deep left, the City of New York Municipal baseball team topped the Boston Park Department All-Stars, 5 to 4, at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12. -- The striking 8-year-old chestnut gelding Molyneux, owned and handled by Miss June Hanes of Rye, gathered in the major prizes at the annual Greenwich Horse Show held over the spacious Yale University farm grounds today.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12. -- Attacking the NRA and the AAA as agencies designed to bring about domination by the Federal Government of industry and agriculture, Governor Landon declared tonight that planned economy was incompatible with a democratic form of government, that the Roosevelt administration was heading the United States toward a dictatorship, and that the world-wide trend away from democracy meant war.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 12. -- Next week Harvard University celebrates that day in the Autumn of 1636 when the General Court of Massachusetts Bay Colony, which had entered the wilderness only a few years before, voted, as the last item of the day's business, that:

The four-year reign of Miss Helen Jacobs as national tennis champion was brought to an end by Miss Alice Marble at Forest Hills yesterday, and Frederick Perry of Great Britain averted defeat by two points against Donald Budge to set an all-time record in winning his third American crown.

THIS is a straightforward narrative of a man's conflict with nature, both the human and external varieties. That the latter remains in the end unconquered is by no means surprising nor disastrous, since it takes the form of drought, blight and hurricane, and man's failure in this respect is adequately compensated for by his conquest of the human variety, which gives him the hope he needs for carrying on.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 12. -- An unusually successful yacht-racing season on Moriches Bay came to an end with the sailing of the Commodores Cups events today under the auspices of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach off the Speonk Shore.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club announced yesterday that it will conduct the first race in defense of the Scandinavian Gold Cup off Oyster Bay on Aug. 28, 1937. The decision conforms with the regulations governing the Gold Cup to the effect that the defending club must arrange the races for the trophy to be sailed within the period of June 15 and Sept. 1.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 12. -- The Foreign Ministers of the Little Entente, who will confer here tomorrow, visited President Eduard Benes today at his Summer residence at Topolciany. The questions that will be discussed tomorrow were reviewed by the President.

ROME, Sept. 10. -- Italy, with her expansionist policy realized through the Ethiopian conquest, is now bent on reconquering her place among the European nations. Economic as wall as political motives dictate this policy.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12. -- A legal code to control labor unions to the extent that railroads, public utilities and large industries are controlled by law to protect competition, contractural obligations and the public welfare was urged here today at the convention of civic associations and chambers of commerce of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- The grain markets showed a firm undertone today. Wheat was affected by continued strength in Liverpool and Winnipeg and closed on the Board of Trade here unchanged to 1/8 cent a bushel higher than yesterday. Corn was up 3/4 to 1 cent, with December showing the most gain.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation notified representatives of its 90,000 employes today that the management had concluded that "a wage increase should not be granted at this time."

Directors of the Electric Auto-Lite Company have authorized the distribution of $811,350 in dividends, with the declaration of the regular quarterly dividend of $1.75 a share on the preferred stock and another of 60 cents each on 1,221,000 common shares.
In an article entitled "New Miracles Come From the Chemist's Laboratory," by Waldemar Kaempffert, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, the following statement appears:

THERE can be little question that here on the Pacific Coast a major aeronautic development is taking place in the field of big flying boats. Just as the Sikorsky and Martin plants on the Atlantic seaboard are busily at work on the current clipper ships and larger types which are to follow them, so, on this side of the continent, the Douglas, Consolidated and Boeing plants are heavily engaged in boat development.

THE old superstition that the Summer is a time when dancers must take a vacation whether they like it or not is rapidly being exposed as a myth. Though there has been an increasing amount of activity in the warm weather months during the past few years, it has remained for the little Ballet Caravan to show just what the possibilities are for transforming this off-season period into an active time.

BISHOP OF DETROIT: On the crucifixion tower of the Shrine of the Little Flower in Royal Oak, Mich., are sculptured the figures of five archangels. The face of the Archangel Michael, it is often remarked, closely resembles that of Michael James Gallagher, Bishop of Detroit.

THE automobile industry is poised for its jump into production of 1937 cars. In fact, the Studebaker Corporation and the Packard Motor Car Company, having made public announcements of their new lines, are well into the task of supplying dealers with fresh stocks of cars.

In the first of a series of twenty-six Saturday night radio "discourses" on national affairs, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin called upon Democrats and Republicans alike last night to put patriotism above partyism and adopt the principles of social justice as enunciated by him and by Pope Pius XI in his encyclical of 1931.

DOUBTLESS the reason that fantastic book, the great American novel, has never yet been written has something to do with the fact that no single account, though it were longer than "Anthony Adverse" and "War and Peace" rolled into one, could begin to contain an imaginative portrait of the sprawling and protean phenomenon which is America.

Decrying what they termed the trend toward regimentation and the growing use of government bureaus instead of "eminent private talent" to plan public edifices, New York architects are opposing the plans under which the New York State World War Memorial in Albany will be designed by the Division of Architecture of the State Department of Public Works, it was learned yesterday.

BOMBAY. -- Before the new constitution comes into force next April, India, from which Burma has been separated, also will lose Aden, a possession for the last 100 years. This little piece of territory at the entrance to the Red Sea is greatly valued for its importance to British Empire communications.

NEW Studebaker scars for 1937, embodying improvements said to make for easier handling, smoother riding and more economical operation, were introduced yesterday. The new models are produced in two lines, the President, with base list price of $965, and the Dictator, priced from $665.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12. -- Dr. Wu Yi-Fang, president of the Ginling Women's College at Nanking, China, who was recently elected executive chairman of the National Christian Council of China, is spending the week-end here, the guest of Mr. and Mrs. James Stewart Cushman.

Narrow movements and mixed trends of prices prevailed in routine trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market appeared susceptible to a "breathing spell" following the buoyant tone in secondary corporate loans during most of last week.

Men's and women's service clubs of Atlantic City will be guests of the Business and Professional Women's Club of New Jersey when that organization opens its nineteenth year, on Saturday, with a board meeting and dinner at the Hotel Dennis there. Miss Earlene White, first vice president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women and postmistress on the Senate side of the Capitol at Washington, will be the principal speaker.
Interesting personal details are interwoven with the victories of the finalists in the Constitution contest for high school teachers in the tri-State area.

THE difficulties with which an American will be confronted in piloting a plane in Europe depend largely on the registration of the plane he expects to fly. If it is to be a United States registered plane, authorization must be secured from the Department of Commerce before the plane leaves the United States.

Advances were the rule in an improving volume of transactions on the local commodity futures markets in the week ended on Friday, with soaring cocoa prices the feature of trading. Only sugar and coffee were depressed. On the cash markets, advances appeared in all the grains, flour, cotton, butter, eggs, beef, print cloths, cocoa, wool tops, silk and tin.

MANY gardeners in the metropolitan area, as well as those of Eastern Pennsylvania, are looking forward to the joint show of the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society, the Garden Club Federation of Pennsylvania and the Pennsylvania Railroad, which will be held next Friday afternoon and all day Saturday in the Thirtieth Street station of the railroad in Philadelphia.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12. -- The address of Governor Landon of Kansas here tonight was as follows:

So much nonsense has been written about the effect of new inventions and increased mechanization on unemployment that the discussion of the subject before the British Association for the Advancement of Science by Sir JOSIAH STAMP is particularly refreshing for its thoughtfulness and balance.

THE thirty-fifth anniversary of the death of President McKinley, which occurs tomorrow, suggests a striking contrast between the events, the policies and the public opinion of McKinley's era and those of today. Particularly is it difficult to recall the mood in which the American people plunged into war with Spain.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12. -- Yale will start football practice next Tuesday at Gales Ferry for the opening of the season with Cornell at the Bowl on Oct. 3.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 12. -- Harvard's fifty greatest graduates have been chosen by a distinguished committee of selectors for enrollment in a "Harvard Hall of Fame," compiled in connection with the university's celebration of its tercentenary.

RICHARD WAGNER, in his treatise "Opera and Drama," explains at great length his intentions regarding the function of gesture, facial expression, and so forth, which he desired actors of roles in his music dramas to employ in expressing emotions unconveyable by the orchestra.
DR. JAMES BERTRAM COLLIP, Professor of Biochemistry at McGill University, told the following story last week at the Harvard Tercentenary symposium on "Factors Determining Human Behavior."

A middle-aged woman, who applied for home relief after illness forced her to give up her job in a Manhattan restaurant, walked into the legal division of the Emergency Relief Bureau recently, clutching a roll of bills.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Farm population in the great plains States has remained stationary since the World War, the Agriculture Department reported today, correcting any impression that depopulation has occurred in States which have suffered drought, dust storms and grasshopper scourges in the past few years.

VIENNA, Sept. 11. -- The Little Entente conference which begins at Bratislava, on the Austro-Czech frontier, tomorrow affords Czechoslovakia the opportunity to acquaint her allies of the Little Entente -- as President Benes's recent journey of speech-making in the Sudeten German area did to inform the minorities -- of her considered attitude toward various urgent problems confronting the State.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 12. -- At Glen Crannie Farm, Richmond, this afternoon Mrs. Shaun Kelly was hostess at a tea and recreation given in honor of Miss Jeanne Millet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A.P. Millet of New York, fiancee of Shaun Kelly Jr.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 12. -- After nine and a half months of dormancy, king football will again rule University Field Monday afternoon as seventy-five candidates for the 1936 Princeton team report to Head Coach Fritz Crisler preparatory to the beginning of actual practice Tuesday morning.

THIS finely written novel is the story of an unsuccessful search for maturity. To become mature one should be equipped for taking punishment, for standing up to the situations most likely to bring on maturity. A slow reaction time and a lack of variety in talents are almost as helpful in gaining this end as is the conviction that one knows what is right.

TORONTO, Sept. 12. -- Prospecting in the gold-mining fields in Ontario has increased almost 100 per cent in the first seven and one-half months of this year, in comparison with the same period last year. The number of claims staked has almost doubled, an official survey released this week shows.

SALMON are running in great numbers now along many waterways in Eastern Canada. Much of the water is as open to the public as it is to the fish, and any one who pays a license fee and can wield a rod may flaunt a fly before the nose of a thirty-five pounder.

A military pageant viewed by some 3,000 persons at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, was presented yesterday by the Army Relief Society in its annual program for the benefit of needy widows and orphans of officers and enlisted men of the regular army.

As a buffer between two generations, an understanding uncle can work wonders. Ned Marsden, a bachelor of 47, freshly arrived in London from twenty-five successful years in a tropical British colony, is ideally suited to the business of working out the problems of an interesting young nephew and niece.

TOULON, France, Sept. 12. -- The struggle in Spain has two things in common with the civil wars of China and Russia. It is fought with words more than with bullets and there are a score of prisoners and non-combatants killed for every soldier wounded.

ROCHESTER, England, Sept. 12. -- The Caledonia, first of the huge flying boats destined for the Imperial Airways Atlantic mail service, has just been launched. Loaded to a total weight of 35,000 pounds the Caledonia immediately took off on her first trial flight.

SEATTLE, Sept. 12 (AP). -- A protest of Edward G. Woods, heading counsel for William Randolph Hearst, against asserted "coaching" of a witness by Edwin S. Smith, trial examiner, enlivened the National Labor Relations Board hearing on The Post-Intelligencer-American Newspaper Guild strike today.

THAT urbane cosmopolite, Adolphe Menjou, but lately returned to these shores after a month abroad, brings with him some disturbing impressions and a few conclusions, one particularly vehement, about the European scene.

THERE may be a formal alliance between Japan and Germany. There may be only a tacit understanding between them for common action if and when a favorable occasion arises. Or there may be neither. The subject is one on which there has been much speculation and little evidence.

MY father was a Connachtman who had come to London and joined the police as a constable." In the simplicity of this opening line of "The Last Landfall," by Desmond Malone, lies much of the secret of this book's remarkable allure.
The old Waverly Boat Club will become a floating one when its members complete the task they have determined upon of transfering the building now at 167th Street and the Hudson River to a barge.

THIS book will give pleasure to many readers, but chiefly to music-lovers of middle age, or slightly older. In form it is a novel, but its purpose and its success are to evoke nostalgic memories of great singers who belonged to yesterday's world, and of places and scenes which acquired romance from their performances.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Sept. 12. -- Several hundred members of society from the North Shore, New York, and the South Shore colonies and many from the Hamptons took part today in the social activities attendant upon the Autumn race meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association at the Rockaway Hunting Club, which were climaxed, tonight, with the hunt ball in the historic ballroom of the club.

THOSE who know Sean O'Faolain's work will open this book with excitement. Genius is the word that rises to the lips as one reads such remarkable pieces of genre painting as the title story in "Midsummer Night Madness" or that wonderful first chapter in "A Nest of Simple Folk," the one a picture of the decay of the Anglo-Irish Big House, the other a portrait of violent, religious, land-hungry peasant Ireland.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The White Sox, with Johnny Whitehead pitching six-hit ball, defeated the Athletics, 5 to 1, today. The victory enabled the White Sox to retain a game and one-half lead over the third-place Senators.

Bizarre as it sounded, home to young Philip Baring meant the jungles of West Africa. A year in England at school sent him back to the railway construction camp of his engineer father homesick for the sights and sounds of the Gold Coast where he had been born.

NOW that it is possible to drive from Ottawa, capital of Canada, through Washington, D.C., in the East, to the Mexican capital, efforts are being concentrated on building a motor route along the western side of the North and South American continents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- A sharp reduction in the amount of counterfeit money seized by the Secret Service during the fiscal year ended June 30 was attributed by the Treasury today to the arrest and conviction of two men -- the notorious "Count" Lustig, an Austrian, and his plate-maker, William Watts.

The 1936 world series will open on Wednesday, Sept. 30, in the city winning the National League pennant, it was announced yesterday following a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt before Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis. The session was attended by representatives of the teams still in the running in the senior circuit as well as the Yankees, who already have clinched the American League flag.

THE ubiquitous motor trailer now has found its way into police service. Both as a mobile headquarters for emergency to control and as a traveling laboratory for use in criminal cases, it has been tested and found highly satisfactory.

James O. McKinsey, chairman of the board of Marshall Field Co., will address the luncheon session on Sept. 28 of the eighth Boston Conference on Retail Distribution at the Hotel Statler, according to announcement made yesterday of the completed program.
DOES speed cause automobile accidents? Where the road is wide, straight and level and the motorist can see that his path is unobstructed, the answer is, no.

AN increased number of hobby classes will be opening all over the city within the next two weeks for tired business men, for housewives who seek escape from the tedium of pots and pans, and for all who find relief from daily chores in devotion to a craft requiring deft use of the hands.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 12. -- The text of the speech made by Governor Louis J. Brann, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, here tonight in reply to that delivered by Governor Landon of Kansas follows:

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept, 12. -- In the presence of a fashionable gathering which remained until the last award, the Tuxedo Kennel Club's final event today was the presentation by Mrs. David Wagstaff, president, of the handsome silver trophy denoting best in the show to Russell Openshaw for his charge, Flornell Soundfella, a brilliant black Scottish terrier, owned by the Relgalf Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Mark A. Matthews of Rye.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- The Northern Westchester District Nursing Association was the beneficiary of the annual horse show of the Lawrence Farms Hunt Club held here today in the outdoor ring of the clubhouse. Mrs. Marion Taylor Gibson served as president, assisted by Miss Wilhelmina S. Kirby as vice president.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 12 (AP). -- John Cobb of England, surviving a skid near the end of a twenty-four-hour drive, smashed eight world motor car speed records today.

The ever-increasing size of ocean liners has brought a new problem to river ferry captains. Last Monday as tugs were easing the thousand-odd feet of the liner Queen Mary into her slip at West Fiftieth Street the ferryboat Utica of the North Shore Railroad slammed against the piling of her slip as she attempted to tie up.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Dayton Dean's version of the Black Legion killing of Charles A. Poole was recounted in Circuit Court today as the trial of twelve men charged with the crime got under way just four months from the time the young WPA worker died under a fusillade of pistol shots.

Activity in the heavy industries has expanded rapidly this year, according to an analysis prepared by the American Iron and Steel Institute, which shows that the output of heavy steel products in the first half of 1936 was 44 per cent greater than in the same period of last year, while tonnage of the lighter forms of steel rose only 20 per cent.
THE Harvard Tercentenary Celebration is the occasion of several interesting broadcasts this week.

The expenditure of more than $1,000,000,000 for the improvement of plant and equipment by American railroads in the last five years has contributed to the profitable operation of all other business and has been an important factor in the country's economic recovery, John M. Fitzgerald, vice chairman of the Committee on Public Relations of the Eastern Railroads, told the fourteenth annual convention of the National Association of City Passenger Agents yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- The concerts of chamber music being presented here at Yaddo turned to contemporary music today. This afternoon's program was devoted to works of Wallingford Riegger, Paul Creston, Allan Sly, Aaron Copland and Harold Morris.

WHAT village housewives call harvest vegetables now decorate the stands of greengrocers with tints of yellow, orange, blue, purple, crimson, green and russet. Despite the drought in certain parts of the country, New York will have no shortage, thanks to the widespread sources tapped by this great market.

With a modest frenzy of excitement over the heavily contested final rounds of two city-wide tournaments under the auspices of the Police Athletic League (in cooperation with the WPA recreation division), the juvenile fans of urban shuffleboard and paddle tennis wound up a seasonal schedule on the East Thirty-first play street yesterday.

KRONBORG, the magnificent Renaissance castle at Elsinore, where Hamlet met his father's ghost, will once more become a center of interest for the world's Shakespeare enthusiasts. Following negotiations between representatives of the Danish Ministry of Education and a group of Shakespeare lovers, it has been officially announced that a Shakespeare stage is to be opened in the courtyard of the ancient castle.

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- Tenacious as has been the fighting of the Spanish Government troops and its ill-equipped militia on all fronts during the week, a war map shows that military success has been heavily on the side of the insurgents.

THE title of this book is taken from the sermon by a Negro preacher in the Mississippi Delta -- "God shakes creation in the Spring." And the book has to do with the life of the Negro people in that rich cotton-growing district where the colored population outnumbers the white by a ratio of three to one.

Heading a fleet of twenty-five yachts, from as far West as Toledo, Ohio, across the finish line, George R. Barnes's Southerly, out of Skaneateles, N.Y., took the lead yesterday off Great Kills, S.I., for the national championship of the Comet Class Yacht Racing Association.

WASHINGTON. -- In their efforts to improve American livestock Federal animal breeders recently have brought from England several animals of types and breeds previously little known in the United States. The latest shipment includes three South Devon cattle, four Large Black hogs, twenty-two Wyandotte chickens and eleven White Austrian turkeys.

Closing the most active week of the year to date, and one of the busiest periods in several years, rug and carpet mills had several weeks of advance business on their books yesterday. Buyers from leading wholesale and retail establishments furnished the orders in the course of rush visits to the market, dictated by a desire to cover against price advances of 5 to 7 per cent on regular Fall merchandise.

Striking testimony relative to the earning power of a first-class broadcasting station was recently disclosed by the Federal Communications Commission in a statement explaining the grounds for its decision approving the sale of KNX, Los Angeles, to the Columbia Broadcasting System.

THIS book, as its title indicates, deals with the strictly contemporary theatre, and much of it is no more than a rewrite of Mr. Nathan's routine handling of first nights. Still, the very fact that it is a rewrite, that it gave Mr. Nathan the chance to modify his reactions, imposes the penalty that these revised judgments shall cease to be reporting and attempt to be criticism; otherwise this book serves no worthy purpose.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Kildare, the handsome 11-year-old gray gelding belonging to E.B. Schley of Far Hills, was crowned champion hunter today, bringing to a close the two-day session of the Far Hills Horse Show on the Fair Grounds. The exhibition was held for the benefit of the Visiting Nurses Association of Somerset Hills.

THIS sensational story in its way does for the Glasgow Gorbals what James T. Farrell's Studs Lonigan series did for Chicago's East Side, but it is nothing like as well written or as psychologically interesting. Mr. Mc-

WHITEFIELD, N.H., Sept. 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. T.H. Clarke of Manhasset, L.I., gave a luncheon at the Mountain View House here today. Also giving luncheons here were Mr. and Mrs. Frank Z. Parsons of Brooklyn and Mrs. W.L. Saylor of Bridgeport, Conn.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -A large dance was given tonight at the Huntington Valley Club by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Bertsch Wentz of Rydal and by Mr. and Mrs. T.F. Dixon Wainwright of Gwynedd Valley for Miss Ann Wickham Leisenring, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Leisenring of Ardmore. It was proceded by many dinners.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- To the Nazi Congress at Nuremberg Chancellor Hitler this week expressed his satisfaction that Krupps was "reverberating with the machinery of rearmament" and that Germans had "overcome dishonor" and were "happy again."

MASON CITY, Iowa, Sept. 12 (AP). -- James Roosevelt, son of the President, said in an address made here today that "bad spots" on the economic system "are being removed," and condemned those who "tell us that it is no good trying to make America better."

In the letter of James Balsam in the columns of THE TIMES of this date I note a continuance of the controversy which has raged in your columns during the past month on the subject of the ownership of the gold which the government has planted as a "pay crop" at Fort Knox.

In about two years, if present plans go forward as rapidly as expected, there will be ready for New York a vast playground on the bed of the old Spuyten Duyvil Creek, it became known yesterday. The Federal, State and city governments are combining forces to develop for popular use Manhattan's last bit of wild woodlands.

As a precaution against the threatened strike of 15,000 truck drivers, the Police Department last night notified members of the detective and uniform divisions that all leaves, days off and vacations would be subject to cancellation in event of a strike.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 12. -- Two very notable utterances provided food for thought today at the National Socialist party congress here. Both were made to the leaders of the German Labor Front, assembled in Luitpold Hall. One came from Dr. Robert Ley, its head, and the other from Chancellor Adolf Hitler himself.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 12. -- Party nominations for the November elections will be made Tuesday when enrolled voters of 150 election districts in Suffolk County go to the polls. Despite the fact that no contests are scheduled by either major party, leaders are of the opinion that a record vote will be polled, due to the mounting interest in the Presidential campaign.

YOUNGSTERS in the throes of choosing a life work have a new aid available. From the office of the National Occupational Conference, 551 Fifth Avenue, New York City, there is pouring a series of pamphlets describing the opportunities and requirements in a wide range of vocations from cinematography to city management.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12. -- Fred Jacoby Jr., the New York theatrical scenic artist, put on a phenomenal demonstration of his boat racing skill today as if to produce ample and additional reasons why he is America's point scoring champion.

A merger of its multiple committees in charge of club activities has been effected by the American Woman's Association as an important feature of its new season's program. Two major committees have emerged from the reorganization -- the activities committee under the chairmanship of Miss Frances Pratt, and a membership maintenance committee, headed by Dr. Geraldine Wilmot.

LONDON. TRAVELERS in England who take to the open road by automobile find a never-ending source of entertainment in listing the odd names of villages through which they pass. A party of Americans, just back from a tour through Essex, found that they could travel from Mucking to Bigods, from Maggot's Green to Chignall Smeally, and from Elbows' to Snoreham.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- While recording two victories to reach the semi-final round of the Leewood Golf Club invitation tourney today, Thomas C. Robbins added the third link in his hole-in- one chain, registering one of the game's rarities on the 120-yard eleventh green with a niblick shot.

Your recent editorials have had much to say about the surplus tax, the Revenue Act of 1936 and the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act. These acts among others are the focal point of the political campaign. Landon believes that the former act must be repealed; your editorial of Sept. 5 commented on Senators Robinson's and Clark's separate replies to Mr. Landon's speech on taxes.

I believe that it was the first time that mention was made to the American public concerning the contribution of Italian mathematicians when Joseph Cartan of the University of Paris said at the Harvard Tricentennial Conference: "Every one is aware that Einstein's general theory of relativity might not have been conceived had this admirable instrument of research not been created, under the name of absolute differential calculus, by G. Ricci and T. Levi-Civita."

The six regional winners of the $400 first-place awards in the Constitution contest conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES for the best teaching plans and articles prepared by high school teachers of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were announced yesterday together with the winners in district elimination contests.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday that a minimum of 7 per cent of all future assignments to WPA jobs would go to physically handicapped persons. The ruling will not be retroactive.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Sept. 13. -- Chinese apprehension over the attitude the Japanese would assume regarding the Chengtu and Pakhoi incidents, in which Japanese were killed by Chinese, appeared likely today to be ended soon. It was announced that Shigeru Kawagoe, the Japanese Ambassador, was going to Nanking to open negotiations with Foreign Minister Chang Chun this week for the settlement of the two incidents.
The Spanish-bloodshed went into its ninth week, with the outcome still as much in doubt as ever.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 12. -- More than 10,000 ex-service men and seventy musical units, parading along the beachfront here, brought to a close today the eighteenth annual convention of the New Jersey State Department American Legion.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP). -- An enlarged force of suburban police guarded the Evanston home of former Vice President Charles G. Dawes as several hundred guests gathered tonight for the wedding of Miss Virginia Dawes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The American Government's reception to feelers being put out in regard to the calling of some sort of economic conference among eight or ten of the leading commercial powers of the world is likely to be noncommittal, according to indications today.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 12. -- Dr. Marcus Nadler, research director of the Institute of International Finance of New York University, today declared that he could foresee no return to a gold standard for this or any other country as long as "economic nationalism" continues to prevail.
NEW SALEM STATE PARK, Ill., Sept. 12 (AP). -- Restoration of the village where Abraham Lincoln lived a century ago is well under way here, aloof from twentieth century customs and invention.

Eastern delegates to the fourteenth annual convention of the Association of Bank Women will leave New York early this week for San Francisco, where they will participate in the program that will open Friday and continue through the following Tuesday. Problems of legislation, taxation and bank operation will concern the feminine financiers, many of whom plan to remain for the ensuing gathering of the American Bankers' Association.

MR. ELIOT'S 1928 edition of his essays "For Lancelot Andrewes" (now out of print) gave rise to one of the famous phrases of contemporary criticism. The essays were perhaps not much read, but every one seems to have heard of the preface in which Mr. Eliot stated his general position as "classicist in literature, royalist in politics and Anglo-Catholic in religion."

Business was reported "brisk" yesterday at the 1936 National Electrical and Radio Exposition, with thousands of men and women thronging the aisles to see the new radio and home electric appliance models. But a strong feature of the show is the "cooking school" held twice daily, which has attracted women visitors.

Preliminary to observance of its silver jubilee next February, Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, will launch a six-months' membership campaign on Tuesday, under the direction of Mrs. Alexander Lamport of Mount Vernon, N.Y. An enrollment of 50,000 in the senior group alone, which now totals 39,000, is the goal of the drive.

THIS book tells what really happens in the garden. Its author's purpose has been to bridge the gulf between botanists, most of whom "know all too little about horticulture," and practical garden-makers, who, Dr. Salisbury adds, "have but a meager acquaintance with advances in botanical knowledge."

OMAHA, Sept. 11. -- The drought has occupied so much of the attention of the Corn Belt this Summer that the government's soil-conservation program has been rather crowded out of the farm picture. But, if it has been unnoticed for a time, it has been neither forgotten nor neglected.

The engagement of $8,059,000 more gold in Paris for shipment here was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought to $41,672,000 the gold engagements in France last week, the largest amount for the movement to date.

FOR nineteen centuries certain forms of the civilization which claims the Christus as its founder have been striving to extinguish that ancient civilization which produced Him, accepted most of His teachings, but rejected Him as its Messiah.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- A request to the world not to take things said at the National Socialist party congress in Nuremberg too seriously and not to expect immediate diplomatic steps to follow them was voiced today by the Frankfurter Zeitung in a front-page editorial.

NEW ENGLAND is determined that its justly famed Fall foliage shall no longer blaze unseen. Leaders in the tourist industry hereabouts, heartened by the most opulent Summer business they have enjoyed since 1929, are now planning to exploit the region as a Fall playground as well.

THERE will be some new faces, some new playwrights and an unprecedented number of Yiddish playhouses in the Times Square sector when this season, which officially opens as usual on the first day of Rosh ha-Shanah, falling on Thursday of this week, is fully launched.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- President Roosevelt's radio speech on unemployment brought to public notice the work of the United States Employment Service, whose officials are proud of its contribution to the country's recovery.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12. -- As final appeals were being made tonight to the voters of this State by Governor Landon and leading candidates on the Democratic ticket, political managers of all parties agreed that Monday's election would bring voters in unusual number to the polls.

SYDNEY, Australia. BRITAIN'S oldest and most successful immigration scheme is taking another bound with the extension of the Fairbridge Farm plan to New South Wales, Australia. The plan. now a quarter of a century old, was the creation of Kingsley Fairbridge, a South African who won a Rhodes scholarship at Oxford.

A narrow escape from bombing in Spanish waters was described here yesterday by Edwin H. Bertuch, painter and yachtsman, who with his wife and a Czechoslovak sailor, the State Department reported on Aug. 11, was missing after sailing from Palma, Majorca.

ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- A nine-hour hearing before Peter G. Ten Eyck, Agriculture Commissioner, marked by Governor Lehman's assertion that he would not be "rushed into" a hasty decision on demands of milk producers for a $3 price for 100 pounds of milk, tonight failed to alleviate the threat of a strike of up-State producers.

Opening the Autumn field trial season for pointers and setters in this section will be the meeting of the Sport and Conservation League of Middletown, which will be held near Phillipsburg, N.Y., next Friday, Saturday and Sunday, with a program of five stakes.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12. -- Austin L. Smithers, 31 years old, a well-known stock broker who lived on Stanwich Road, was burned to death early this morning when his touring car capsized and burst into flames, pinning him beneath.

Beating the Cardinals in general and Dizzy Dean in particular twice in one afternoon proved too difficult a task for the lowly Dodgers yesterday, but some 17,000 fans at Ebbets Field were satisfied with an even split, the second in successive days between the clubs.

The Queens County Committee of the Communist party lost the first round of its legal fight yesterday to compel Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens to open the Town Hall at Jamaica for its rally next Wednesday night.
WILLIAM BYRD had a name in musical history, and not much more, till after the beginning of this century. A little of his music was known and, only by a few in those latter days, was highly regarded.

EXPERIENCED Scout campers have had rare opportunities in recent weeks for adventure far from the beaten track. In the East the Appalachian Mountains have been the scenes of long climbs. In the West, where the country is more rugged, treks into the wilderness have been made by packhorse and have called for careful preparation.

QUEEN MARY is shortly to leave Buckingham Palace -- which has been her London home ever since 1910 -- to return to the more shadowed life of Marlborough House, the vast old mansion half-hidden in the trees next to St. James's Palace in Pall Mall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP). -- A plan by Major Gen. George Van Horn Moseley, commanding the Fourth Corps Area at Atlanta, to provide CCC training for every 18-year-old youth in the country and to include military training in CCC activities was disclosed today in Happy Days, authorized publication of the corps.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 12. -- Completing the second over-ocean flight to be made by Deutsche Lufthansa experimental planes between the Azores and New York, the flying boat Aeolus landed in the Pan American Airways provisional harbor here at 4:02 o'clock this afternoon.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The Senators made seventeen hits today to finish off the season's schedule with the Indians with a 12-2 triumph, Jimmy De Shong, Washington right hander, scoring his seventeenth victory of the season.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12. -- Governor Landon's sudden decision to speak in Maine on the eve of its State election was not caused by any fear of an unfavorable result, but was brought about by complaints by Eastern Republican leaders that the campaign seemed to be sagging.

BATAVIA, N.Y. Sept. 12. -- George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, today ended a three-day tour of up-State New York with a speech in which he declared that the United States Supreme Court is the only institution in this country with which the New Deal has not tampered.
VATICAN CITY, Sept. 12 (AP). -- The world's moving pictures are 40 per cent "morally better" than last year, Pope Pius XI was told today.

Mrs. Douglas Moffat, New York State Chairman of the League of Women Voters, returned to New York last week and is established in the new headquarters of the league at 151 East Fiftieth Street. On her arrival a statement was issued of a change of policy in the league's election activities.

TOKYO. -- Japan's "national renovation" policies are taking shape. The army has shot its rebels and submitted to a self-imposed purge, and now the Cabinet is preparing to carry out its part of the bargain, made when the February revolt was suppressed, by reforms in the sphere of civilian administration.

Holders of defaulted dollar bonds of the Republic of Colombia and its departments and municipalities have received an idea of the trend of negotiations between Colombian officials and representatives of the bondholders toward the readjustment of the Republic's external debt, from a recent report of the Colombian Minister of Finance and Public Credit to the Colombian Congress.

Last week's statement by the Iron and Steel Institute of the country's steel production during August showed increase of 49 1/4 per cent over August, 1935. A longer comparison shows that it was the largest output of any month since March, 1930, and the largest August production since 1929.
ROME, Sept. 12. -- "Necessities of the international situation" tonight drew extraordinary appropriations for armed forces from the Italian Cabinet.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept 11. -- To the nation, Georgia's Democratic primary can properly pass for a smashing New Deal victory; but to Georgians, long in awe of a great political legend, the result holds much complexity and something of the miraculous.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12. -- Two trainloads of drama festival enthusiasts having left for Leningrad, Moscow is itself again and the ravaged theatregoer can search his mind in peace.

AUTUMN visitors to the "City of Angels" will have to watch their P's and Q's or they will unexpectedly find themselves running afoul of the law. Los Angeles imposes few restrictions upon one's pleasurable pursuits.

THE congestion of transatlantic home-comings in the present end-of-Summer travel has aroused harried customs officials to suggest "staggered" arrivals of the big ocean liners at New York piers. Travelers absent for ten days, or six weeks, or loitering abroad since May, all are coming home at the same time.

Saw a cable in from Vienna in your paper this week about Kirsten Flagstad, in which she is described as the "Scandinavian Singer." I am a Norwegian and wish to take this opportunity to tell you how much we Norwegians, and I know the Swedes also, dislike the vague expression "Scandinavian" describing a person, either from Norway or Sweden.

SEPTEMBER used to afford the museums and galleries a last languorous month-long moment to stretch before the new season, with quiet and decorous manner, a little tentatively entered upon the scene along with October's changing foliage.

Talk of the "business cycle" is nowadays not often heard. Even in pre-war days, when experienced people recognized as a factor in business plans the chronological alternation of its phases, the "prosperity cycle" would usually be discussed, not at a time of sustained recovery from depression but only after a great panic had abruptly ended good times.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12. -- Governor Louis J.
