Brann, Democratic candidate for United States Senator and prominent figure in Maine's campaign, made a radio address tonight following the speech of Governor Landon and challenged the Republican standard bearer to repudiate contributions to the Republican campaign fund in Maine by the "wealthiest men in the nation."

For some time the President's Committee on Administrative Management has been studying the question of a complete overhauling of the administrative machinery. It is expected to make its report in the early Winter. The President, according to a report last week, has already decided, if re-elected, to propose to Congress a far-reaching plan for consolidating and abolishing many existing bureaus and agencies.

Reports from the international, the national and the State divisions of the far-flung Federation of Business and Professional Women indicate that the career groups are starting off the season with a rush.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Charges of misrepresentation couched in terms which provoked both hisses and applause enlivened the closing session of the World Power Conference today.

IN "The Brothers Ashkenazi" a very powerful story has been seized upon by a very powerful story-teller; the result, at any rate in a contemporary sense, is literature. Writing in the traditional manner of nineteenth-century fiction, where the narrative marches forward without interruption, where character is portrayed through action, where human drama is expressed against a rich and substantial background, Mr. Singer has yet written out of twentieth-century knowledge and purpose.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- The Boerse continued firm today, especially issues likely to profit from Chancellor Hitler's new four-year plan. Textiles and cellulose again were in the lead, with gains exceeding 2 points. Special interest was displayed in AKU.

Naming twelve sales executives as "most closely typifying the best standards" and giving the consensus on major selling procedure, a pioneer survey on the "Problems of Leadership for Sales Executives" has just been completed with the participation of several hundred members of the Sales Executives Club of New York, it was announced yesterday by Charles C. Stech, research specialist of this city, who directed the survey.

Pedestrians on Eighth Avenue just north of Madison Square Garden thought they were witnessing some sort of freak police chase for a few moments yesterday afternoon. Sirens whined, police cars slipped by, and then a uniformed waiter bearing a laden tray came galloping along.

COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 12. -- By consistently finishing at or near the head of the fleet in every race Miss Frances McElwain and her crew, Miss Katherine Johnson and Miss Joan Chapin of the Cohasset Yacht Club, won the national women's sailing championship today for the second time in succession.

EVER since, or perhaps even before, Flaubert found that inhaling the reek of rotting peaches put him precisely on the spoor of the mot juste and consequently kept a drawer in his escritoire full of the decomposing fruit, the dodges employed by writers to whip up the creative frenzy have been many and outlandish.

MILES W. VAUGHN, the only journalist to be present at the private phases of the Japanese Emperor's coronation and the only one to have an interview with Emperor Hirohito, has written of his experiences in a book entitled "Covering the Far East," which Covici, Friede will publish on Sept. 22.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 12. -- When Harvard's hand-picked squad of 121 football players is assembled on Soldier's Field by Dick Harlow next Tuesday there will be available only three linemen who started last year's game with Yale and one first-string back.

MADRID, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Fighting was resumed tonight in the Talavera de la Reins-Santa Olalla sector, with infantry, cavalry and planes struggling for control of the province of Toledo. Heavy artillery fire covered the battles.

The action of the Chicago conference of progressive leaders in endorsing President Roosevelt for reelection was praised yesterday, by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, as an important contribution to the Roosevelt-Garner campaign.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 12. -- Both Democratic and Republican parties were "taken for a ride" this afternoon at the opening session of the State Socialist Convention here. The feature of the day was the keynote speech of Mayor Jasper McLevy of Bridgeport, who will be nominated for Governor tomorrow for the fourth time.

NAOMI MITCHISON, who is a historical novelist of some distinction, refers to her latest book as a "historical novel about my own times." Probably no happier phrase could be found to characterize this vastly serious and rather bewildering study of the contemporary scene.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 12. -- In the next to last dress rehearsal prior to the start of the fortieth annual national amateur championship over the Garden City Golf Club's world-famous layout, honors went to the veteran Boston linksman, Francis Ouimet, whose triumph over the two British pros, Harry Vardon and Ted Ray, at Brookline in 1913, is in no small degree responsible for the game's popularity today.

A total of 9,302 applications were received last week for jobs as truck drivers in the Sanitation Department, the Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday. At present there are ninety-five vacancies. The job pays $1,980 a year.

LONDON. THE decision to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the foundation of the symbolist movement in Paris this year is perhaps a little arbitrary, but in one way it is justified. It is just fifty years ago that Debussy seems suddenly to have perceived some connection between symbolist poetry and his vocation as a composer.

TULSA, Okla, Sept. 12. -- A sound and substantial measure of national recovery has been achieved under the Roosevelt administration, Secretary Roper said in an address here tonight, declaring that, with the national income increasing, the government is "rapidly approaching that point where the budget can be balanced without sacrificing recovery gains and without relinquishing responsibilities to the people before they can be properly assumed by others."

A study of the growth and distribution of large bank deposits which has just been prepared by the Federal Reserve System shows that, contrary to a widely held belief, the rapid recovery in bank deposits since 1933 has been distributed widely among the economic classes of depositors as well as regionally.

Idol of the French and English film world, Rene Tessier had fallen, or plunged, from his pedestal after the mysterious suicide of his only son. He was seen only in strange haunts, now, and with strange people, a wretched denizen of the Paris underworld.
NUREMBERG, Sept. 12. -- In his speech to the Hitler Youth today, Chancellor Adolf Hitler, speaking of Russia, said:
DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Three changes in the Constitution were demanded tonight by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, to avert "disorderly confusion -- even civil strife."
Opposition to Mr. Roosevelt does not mean support of Hooverism or of Old Guardism.

It is a little difficult to imagine a hog as a pathetic and appealing personality, but this hog was such a one, and Mrs. Bullard's drawings are sure proof. He was, to begin with, a very cheery pig, with a twinkle in his eye and a saucy curl to his tail.

THE Music School Settlement, which opens its forty-second season Oct. 5, begins registration this Tuesday. Enrollment of old pupils and beginners will be held this Thursday, and Monday, Sept. 21, from 2 to 9 P.M.; this Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday from 10 to 12 A.M. and 2 to 5 P.M. and this Saturday from 10 A.M. to 12:30 P.M.

THE decorating of walls and ceiling with plaster embellishments, an eighteenth-century practice, has been revived to add grace to the modern interior. The traditional "strapwork" moldings of the Jacobean ceilings and the graceful scrolls and rosettes of the Adam period are seen again, as well as distinctly contemporary designs in low relief, planned for walls rather than ceilings.

How good a colt Pompoon is was not shown yesterday when the son of Pompey and Oonaph won the Junior Champion by three-quarters of a length before 18,000 at Aqueduct. His rider, Harry Richards, who has unbounded confidence in himself as well as in J.H. Louchheim's colorbearer, went through the final part of the race looking across at John Hay (Jock) Whitney's Flying Scot, which finished second.

Before I left the United States I promised to write you concerning the trouble in Palestine. Let me state that it was impossible for me to enter the country. The general strike, which broke on April 18, was the culmination of a series of disorders. Since that time the country has been badly disrupted.

The Giants, with a three-and-a-half-game lead over the Cardinals and a five-game margin over the Cubs, can clinch the National League pennant by winning thirteen of their remaining sixteen games, even though the second-place St. Louisans take all of their fifteen games.

In releasing the program of gallery talks and lectures to be given at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the next four months, Huger Elliott, director of the museum's department of educational work, announced that last year the museum gave talks for 56,552 adults and for 15,874 public school children.

BUFFALO, Sept. 12 (AP). -- Federal Judge John Knight denied today the application of the Remington Rand Company for a permanent injunction restraining the National Labor Relations Board from prosecution of a complaint of unfair labor practices made by striking company employes.
LONDON, Aug. 28. THE month of August, not ordinarily productive in the theatre, has produced at any rate one piece, "The Two Bouquets," which is destined to survive far into the Autumn season.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 12. -- The United States Chamber of Commerce here at its annual banquet last night officially charged that American business interests were being discriminated against by the manner in which the Argentine Government allotted exchange to importers.

This story is one of the three runners-up in the $7,500 mystery contest organized jointly by Lippincott the country and Harrap in London. But it is less interesting as a mystery novel than as a crook yarn -- a crook yarn which makes original and exciting use of an always reliable formula.
Boatmen, with typical disregard for accuracy, call them albacore. Scientists know them as gymnosarda alleterata. To you and me they are little tunny. But to Block Island's old salts they are bums.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 12. -- Wisconsin's primary Tuesday will be less a test of New Deal strength or weakness than it will be a sounding board for sentiment on the formation of a Left Wing Farmer-Labor party for emergence on the national scene by 1940.

While retail trade in the metropolitan area last week fell below expectations, due to the reccurrence of hot weather, the general business picture here continued favorable. Retail executives felt the slowing-up was temporary and did not reflect any major change in consumer purchasing power.

BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- Reports from leading New England centers indicate that retail trade so far in September has been running 10 to 15 per cent over the same period a year ago. This is approximately the same percentage of gain shown during July and August.
The professional football campaign will be ushered in today with three games to mark the busiest inaugural day in the fourteen years of the National Football League.

Initial activities this Fall of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women focus on arrangements for religious services in connection with Rosh ha-Shanah, especially at Welfare Island. For a special service Wednesday evening patients will be brought on wheel chairs and crutches to the synagogue by members of the Welfare Island committee, supervised by Mrs. A.H. Goodman as chairman.

Murder, mystery, science and romance crowd the pages of "Shuddering Castle." The setting is a dreary stone castle at Sands Cliff, L.I. belonging to the Royces of old New York. The ultra-modern plot hinges on the amateur research of one of the elderly Royce brothers.

From July 2 until Labor Day Mayor La Guardia forsook the City Hall, traditionally a Summer hot box, and worked in the Bartow Mansion in Pelham Bay Park, facing breezy Long Island Sound. His office was cool and spacious, with twenty-foot ceilings, old paintings on the walls, and a view of a terraced garden with fragrant phlox, petunias, water lilies, roses.

FALL trade opened rather indifferently in many sections of the country, although a few districts reported substantial gains. Weather conditions appeared to have the greatest influence upon sales, though some retrenchment after large holiday expenditures was probably another factor.

PARIS, Sunday, Sept. 13. -- The Opera, one of the chief landmarks of Paris, took fire early today, and, with flames bursting from the central dome, it appeared for a time that the building would be destroyed.

The wails of the Summer theatre tycoons who have been maimed in their manipulation of the rural drama -- not to mention the story in a recent drama section of THE TIMES proclaiming the passing of another session of the same -- prove rather conclusively, if one may snatch a thought from Bryant, that the melancholy days are come again.
BOSTON, Sept. 12. -- On Monday, with the whole nation as a gallery, Maine will elect a United States Senator and three Representatives, a Governor and a full State slate of officials.

Newspapers, in mentioning the "goose step," quite commonly speak of it as something peculiar to the German Army. Friends of mine think similarly, I find. And yet I note the fact that pretty nearly a century ago Charles Dickens, in one of his charming short stories, "Somebody's Luggage, His Leaving It Till Called For," speaks thus of its chief character, Mr. The Englishman:

AN additional link of the Eastern A State Parkway in Putnam and Dutchess Counties will open for traffic next Saturday, it is reported by the Automobile Club of New York. The official ceremony will be held at the intersection of the parkway and New York Route 52 in East Fishkill in the morning at 11:30 o'clock, daylight saving time.

TO the casual visitor Moscow is a bewildering metropolis. After a few days, he ceases to be astonished by the novelty of a Socialist city, for the dictatorship of the proletariat most obviously is the single fact in the scene.

Three centuries of science and civilization have been passing in review before the elite of the learned world at the Harvard tercentenary festival. The deliberations of the scholars are troubled by the same agonizing doubts and fears that weigh down on the hearts of plain men everywhere. What will science do for civilization? How can the modern world escape destruction by its own technology?

In recognition of an increasing intensity of interest among women in events of national and international import, and in response to requests from outstanding feminine organization who have collaborated in the arrangements, a series of three "Review of the News" conferences will be held early in October under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

THE American farmer is again under the stress of a trying situation -- crop failure brought on by drought. Four years ago, when the writer traveled over a wide area of rural America, the farmer also was facing a crisis -- the collapse of prices for his abundant crops. A tour through the same territory, just completed, has revealed a farmer less despondent than he was in 1932.

Under orders from Acting Commissioner of Safety Daniel Casey, Jersey City policemen were placed yesterday on a new and higher plane of dignity. The acting commissioner advised the department that henceforth no member may "thumb" rides from the driving public, whether off or on duty.

ALBANY, Sept. 12. -- The last bit of evidence in the Drukman grand jury's removal charges against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn was presented to Governor Lehman this afternoon in the presence of seven of the twenty-one jurors who signed the charges.

SEEDS, of course, are not merely seeds. Seeds are also nuts and fruits. Or rather, one should turn that sentence around and point out -- for a better initial understanding of Mr. Quinn's odd and entertaining little book -- that nuts and fruits are seeds and, as such, have a place in these pages.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12. -- The part that women will take in the Republican national campaign was discussed by Governor Landon and a delegation of women on his special train today.

Although unreasonably hot weather retarded trade activity in some sections of the country last week, business in general continued to show satisfactory progress with the opening of the Fall season. Trade figures were well ahead of those in the corresponding period last year in most of the Federal Reserve districts and the slowing up in retail distribution was considered temporary and did not reflect any important change in consumer purchasing power.
YALE having blazed the trail for sponsored football, other colleges, during the past week, have "gone commercial on the air."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Despite the concentration of political interest on the possible Gubernatorial nomination of Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, there is a local election scheduled for Westchester in November to which more attention is being given as the voting day draws near.

IGNACE JAN PADEREWSKI will soon make his first appearance on the screen. According to the Pariser Tageszeitung, the world-renowned pianist, who was also the first President of the Polish Republic, will make his film debut in a picture to be entitled "The 'Moonlight' Sonata."

The milk war between the farmers and the distributors has come to a head again. The questions now to be determined are whether control of minimum milk prices by the State shall be continued and whether the farmer shall get a flat price for his milk at a higher rate than at present.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Miss Alice Marble, new national tennis champion and member of a San Francisco family noted for its athletic achievements, reached the top ten years after she first swung a racquet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Exports from the United States to all geographical grand divisions except Europe and Oceania were larger in July last than in July, 1935, the Department of Commerce announced today. Imports from Europe, Northern North America, Asia and Oceania increased, but those from Southern North America, South America and Africa decreased.

THE Far West, California in particular, has with pardonable pride long claimed Bret Harte for its adopted son. For hero was the scene of his first literary adventures and his most memorable achievements. And yet the East has a stake in the claim, for it was here that he was born and nurtured, and his early boyhood was spent in New York and Brooklyn and neighboring cities.

WEATHER MAN, be good! It certainly would be a shame to spoil the party at the Polo Grounds. Two games with the Cardinals! Here's a chance for the Giants to clinch the result of a season's hard work in one afternoon. If Bill Terry's men gave them both barrels and blew them down twice in one afternoon, the 5-cent fare to a world series would be just around the corner.

HARLEY STREET specialists, when they turn to writing books, carry their best bedside manner with them. They can tell us most terrible things, and do it with a jest. It is an art Dr. Kerable is no exception to the rule. And little wonder.

GRAND VIEW, N.Y., Sept. 12. -- Protest against the construction of the proposed Nyack-Tarrytown bridge here at a point where the Hudson River is three and a quarter miles wide, which was started yesterday when indignant women of the village routed a group of State surveyors who had invaded the community to survey the western anchorage of the bridge, gained considerable impetus throughout the entire Hudson Valley today.
VANCOUVER, Wash., Sept. 11. -- This State experimented last week with a new blanket primary law which permitted voters to ballot for any candidate, regardless of party affiliation.
President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University expressed yesterday his views on press freedom in a letter to the British Institute of Journalists and made public here.

THE Art Students League is reopening for its Winter season tomorrow, continuing the early opening policy established on the sixtieth anniversary of the league last year. An exhibition of work by artist instructors will be opened in the league gallery on Tuesday, continuing until Sept. 26.

James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes Union, made his first appearance as a sidewalk picket yesterday. He described it as a preliminary to the picketing of 1,000 apartment houses in the midtown area in a drive to force building owners to rectify alleged infractions and evasions of the Silcox agreement, which terminated the city-wide building service strike last Spring.

A Frenchman sailing back to Paris the other day after a Summer in the United States confessed that he returned to his own country with a heavy heart. He echoed the opinions expressed in the letter published in THE TIMES on Saturday from another Frenchman, who spoke for millions of Europeans in declaring that he had had enough of the tragi-comedy of "all "Europe on a war footing to defend -- "peace."

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Most specialists regard the corn situation as bullish. They buy on sharp price recessions and either limit their losses or achieve moderate profits. Speculative trading, however, is not heavy.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13. -- The Yankee machine that so thoroughly swept everything before it this season breezed past a four-year-old record at Sportsman's Park this afternoon before a double-header crowd of about 8,000. The mark for a season's home runs by a team, 173, was displaced in a day of riotous Yankee hitting.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 13. -- The newly concluded Franco-Polish military agreement is to be supplemented by a far-reaching economic understanding. The French Minister of Commerce, Paul Bastid, now on a four-day visit in Poland, declared tonight at a press conference that he was convinced Franco-Polish trade and economic cooperation must be extended.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13. -- Two slashing aerial plays, one going 55 yards for a touchdown and the other setting the stage for a short 10-yard field goal, encompassed the downfall of the New York Giants today as the National Football League season opened.

Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. made public yesterday the schedule of uniform penalties for traffic violations which was drawn up on Friday at a meeting of the city magistrates' committee on traffic. The magistrates will meet on Sept. 24 to vote on adopting the schedule.
Business space rentals reported yesterday included a contract for large midtown space to be used for broadcasting purposes and a variety of store, office and showroom leases.

The "supreme and sanctifying influence of religion" was placed above psychological, psychiatric and sociological principles in education in an address yesterday marking the opening of parochial schools of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

Statistically, the steel industry shows a forward movement from July to August, instead of the usual Summer lull, according to the magazine Steel, which says more steel is being produced and more finished steel is in shops. Steel-ingot production in August was 7 per cent larger than in July, rising 272,399 tons to reach the highest level since March, 1930.

While national advertisers are not particularly fearful about business prospects in 1937, there is a disposition on the part of some to delay final approval for next year's advertising budgets until after the Presidential election, according to comment.
MADRID, Sept. 13. -- Spanish Government leaders announced today that aerial bombardment of the Talavera de la Reina and Oviedo sectors had resulted in the most important successes of the civil war.

The most disturbing fact about people today is that they are content to look upon the growing troubles of the world from a detached and isolated point of view, the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared in a sermon yesterday morning.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Repeating his spectacular victory of yesterday at Tuxedo Park, Flornell Soundfella, the superb Scottish terrier owned by the Relgalf Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Mark S. Matthews of Rye, again won best in show today at the annual exhibition of the Westchester Kennel Club on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 13. -- Buffalo eliminated Newark from the International League Governors' Cup series today by defeating the Bears, 7 to 4, for its fourth victory in five games.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 13. -- About 2,000 Harvard undergraduates are expected to return to Cambridge tomorrow, two weeks before the opening of college, to prepare to act as hosts to fifth-four student delegates to the institution's celebration of the 300th anniversary of its founding and to begin their own program in connection with the tercentenary.
"Thank God for the testimony of the unwilling witness," said the Rev. Dr. John R. Atkinson in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine; Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would support the candidacy of A. Newbold Morris for President of the Board of Aldermen, for the one-year term that starts Jan. 1.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- Rains over a large part of the Corn Belt States, and where they were most needed, improved conditions of the crop, suggesting an increase of 19,160,000 bushels over the August estimate, and a crop of 1,458,295,000 bushels, of which 869,787,000 bushels is estimated for the eleven leading States.

BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- The president of the Reich Unemployment Board attributes the shortage of skilled labor in several industries to Germany's compulsory military service and predicts that the new requirement for two years' service will aggravate the shortage.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Defeating a number of larger racing sloops with her time handicap, the six-meter yacht Totem, owned and sailed by Clifford D. Mallory and A.E. Luders Jr., today won for the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich, Conn., the coveted Childs Trophy.

An offering to the public of $1,300,000 of Forth Worth, Texas, Independent School District, 4 per cent bonds, will be made today by a banking group consisting of Lehman Brothers; Blyth Co., Inc.; Keen, Taylor Co.; Eldredge Co., Inc.; the Equitable Securities Corporation, and the Dallas Union Trust Company.

Although the book will not be published until tomorrow, 10,000 copies of "The Songs We Sing," by Hendrik Van Loon and Grace Castagnetta have already been sold, Simon Schuster report, and a new edition of 10,000 copies ordered.

DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The Red Sox whipped the Tigers, 7 to 4, today in a game enlivened by a fight between Billy Rogell, Detroit shortstop, and Rick Ferrell, Boston catcher, which resulted in their ejection from the game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Federal regulation of trading in the chief farm products was expanded and tightened today as provisions of the Commodity Exchange Act went into effect as the successor to the Grain Futures Act of 1922.
LONDON, Sept. 13. -- The British Government definitely refuses to become involved in Chancellor Adolf Hitler's crusade against bolshevism.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 13. -- The following steamship lines have inaugurated and extended Baltimore service:

The British delegation to the international conference of marine architects and engineers arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Georgic headed by Lord Stonehaven, president of the Institution of Naval Architects. There were sixty-three in the party, said to be the largest foreign delegation attending the meetings.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 13. -- Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, the High Commissioner, meeting with the Arab High Committee yesterday, made clear that it must decide immediately on the cessation of the strike and violence.
DENVER, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Veterans of Foreign Wars, gathering by thousands for their annual encampment, heard charges today that communism and fascism are growing menaces in the United States.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- The tightness of money in Germany rather than the political dissertations at the Nazi party congress in Nuremberg dominated the financial markets here this week, and the Boerse, except in a handful of specialties, registered no recovery worth mentioning.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 13. -- There is no longer any doubt that Argentina has sent a good polo team to compete for the Cup of the Americas. Before a crowd of 5,000 that almost filled the capacity of the Sands Point Club's stands, Argentina overcame a 30-goal American team and more hard luck today to win at 14 to 8.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- The movement in the foreign exchange market was unfavorable to the franc this week, and the rise in foreign currencies, which was not of a nature to cause the grave anxiety of previous weeks, still gave financial circles some concern.

Communism, fascism, Nazism and all forms of dictatorships take away the development, rights and achievements of the individual, the Rev Dr James J. Henry declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Eighty-sixth Street, east of Park Avenue.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 13. -- Harvard's Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences, in which seventy-two of the world's leading scientists and scholars in all major fields of learning constituted a "macroscope" of living brains focused on man and his universe, has opened the way to perpetuating its method and objective.

After smoke from a basement fire in the Eagle Theatre, 1,852 Third Avenue, had routed more than 750 persons, including 500 children, from the theatre yesterday afternoon, police outside had a small riot on their hands when the children demanded to be readmitted to see the feature, "Custer's Last Stand."

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 11. -- The Bourse here, although irregular and with ups and downs, displays a firm undertone, under the lead of United States shares, in which activity is being stimulated partly by United States houses established in Amsterdam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- With the admonition of Secretary Wallace to "keep their fundamental objectives always in mind," farmers in the ten Corn Belt States of the North Central region will begin community meetings next week to consider a 1937 agricultural conservation program.
PARIS, Sept. 13. -- Premier Leon Blum went to Lille today for an interview with the striking workers and the employers but returned without having obtained a settlement of the textile strike.

American democracy was not endangered when President Roosevelt "made the government bend to the relief of the average man," Acting Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring declared yesterday afternoon at a Constitution day rally in Brooklyn.

Preliminary to reviving the humorous Yiddish weekly, Kundes, or The Big Stick, its sponsors offered a "Laugh Night" at Town Hall last evening. Jehudah Bleich read some choice excerpts from earlier numbers of the publication, of which a murderous critique by Moishe Nadir of the Yiddish Theatre was especially funny.

BEDFORD. N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Several hundred out-of-town visitors attended services in the historic Bedford Presbyterian Church here today in celebration of the 255th anniversary of the founding of the church.

PORT WASHINGTOAL L.I., Sept. 13. -- The four leading Interclubs in the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy series waged a stirring battle around a four-cornered course in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's special regatta today. When it was over Bill Cox had a narrow margin with Robert McC. Shields's Canvasback over Cornelius Shields's Aileen.

England, which abandoned "pump-priming" methods early in the depression and turned to direct relief instead, is enjoying one of the most prosperous eras in its history, Henry P. Fletcher, general counsel to the Republican National Committee, said yesterday in a statement issued from party headquarters here.

Constructive proposals for future development of the city will be based upon a series of fact-finding surveys included in the report of Mayor La Guardia's Committee on City Planning, which the Mayor will find on his desk in City Hall today.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- State Controller Morris S. Tremaine tonight called upon Colonel Frank Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, to prove the truth of "this amazing statement" credited to him that "today no life insurance policy is secure; no savings account is safe."
The Hall of the Birds of the World in the American Museum of Natural History was brought one step nearer completion yesterday when a new bird group was put on exhibition there.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- July's extreme heat was the chief factor in the rise in mortality in the State to the highest peak recorded for that month in seventeen years, the State Department of Health announced today. The death rate was 11.0 per 1,000 population.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 13. -- In a speech praising the achievements of the National Socialist press, Max Amann, president of the Reich Press Chamber, said yesterday that the number of newspapers in Germany had decreased to 2,300, with a total circulation of 19,700,000.

Finishing second in the morning race and first in the afternoon, Alton O'Brien's Aquila, representing the Raritan Yacht Club of Perth Amboy, N.J., won the two-day series for the national championship of the Comet Class Yacht Racing Association yesterday off Great Kills. S.I.
VATICAN CITY, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Pope Pius let it be known today that he would condemn the excesses of communism in his address tomorrow to Spanish civil war refugees.

Governor LANDOR opened his speech in Portland on Saturday evening by declaring that the Republican party was on the eve of a great victory in Maine. If assurance on this point had not been made doubly sure to him by the party managers, his journey to Maine for a last-minute speech at the end of the campaign would be one of the worst political blunders ever made.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 66 per cent of capacity, down 6 points in a week, but the decline was of no trade significance because some mills were idle on Labor Day, although it is not a regular steel-mill holiday, and its capacity is included in the reckoning.

TOKYO, Sept. 13. -- The Chinese Nineteenth Route Army has refused to allow Japanese to land at Pakhoi to investigate the slaying of a Japanese there, according to dispatches received by the Navy Office here from the commander of the gunboat Saga, which is anchored ten miles off Pakhoi.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 13. -- Brown battalions of Storm Troops and regiments of black-clad Schutzstaffeln [Special Guards] paid homage to their Fuehrer today. It was a tribute that began at 8 o'clock in the morning and lasted until well past 4 o'clock in the afternoon.

The program for the National Horse Show, which will be held in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 4 to Nov. 10, will comprise 118 competitive events, according to the prize list released yesterday by Adrian Van Sinderen, vice president of the National Horse Show Association of America.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- The stock market here opened this week with moderate declines, but the interest that was shown in rayon securities last week continued and later this week leading brewery issues advanced. After the middle of the week the market was increasingly active on a professional speculative basis, while outsiders held aloof.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 14. -- With almost 3,000 miles of good weather ahead of them, Harry Richman, Broadway actor, and Dick Merrill, veteran transport pilot, took off from the beach at Southport at 3:03 o'clock this morning (10:03 P.M. Sunday in New York) on their return flight to New York.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- The course of the security markets here this week has given rise to doubts whether, after all, they are so proof against the shocks from Continental Europe as generally supposed. On Wednesday there was afforded a test of this theory when ominous signs of a serious breach in the ranks of the French Government appeared and Chancellor Hitler made a truculent speech on Germany's needs and colonial ambitions.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- John Cudahy, United States Ambassador to Poland, declared today "only a miracle can prevent a general conflict" in Europe, and charged Governor Landon was "ignorant of foreign relations."

HAVANA, Sept. 13. -- Justo Luis del Pozo, president of the Cuban Senate, last night presented his resignation from the presidency of the Nationalist party when a majority of the delegates at the party convention voted to continue to support President Miguel Mariano Gomez as a member of the tri-party coalition of Nationalists, Republicans and Liberals.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were fewer than in the preceding week. The small volume marked a change from the week before, when the number of announcements showed a marked increase. Not only were the calls fewer last week, but, except for two large issues of public utility bonds and a large block of industrial bonds, the refundings were principally for small amounts of foreign and domestic municipal loans.

Ten more young attorneys were designated yesterday by the Bar Association and the New York County Lawyers Association as legal aides to Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney, in the work of the Accident Fraud Bureau, recently created by District Attorney William C. Dodge at the request of the Appellate Division and many leading lawyers in the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Renewed charges that relief rolls were being "loaded" in the expectation of influencing the national election were made by the Republican National Committee today in an analysis of the program report issued last week by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 13. -- As General Emilio Mola's Rebel troops raised the red and gold flag of the old monarchy over this city today they found the city largely deserted. They went about their occupation in comparative silence, greeted only by the cheers of middle-class residents, the only element of the city's population remaining.

For the third successive afternoon the seventh-place Dodgers gained an even break in a double-header against a contending club, splitting with the third-place Cubs yesterday before 18,000 at Ebbets Field and again lending a helping hand to the pace-setting Giants.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 12. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84.2, which compares with 83.7 the week before, 83.8 two weeks before, 84.1 three weeks before and 84 four weeks before.

Retail prices showed a gain of four-tenths of 1 point in August, compared with the July figures, according to the Fairchild Publications Retail Price Index. Quotations last month averaged 3.2 index points higher than August, 1935. Prices, according to the index, have advanced six-tenths of 1 point above the year's low recorded on July, and are 27.5 points above the May 1933 depression low.
BERGERAC, France, Sept. 13 (AP). -- France plans to take quick action to check the headlong armament race threatening Europe with "total ruin," Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos revealed today.

The Giants, holding a three-and-half-game lead over the Cardinals and a five-game margin on the Cubs, can clinch the National League pennant by winning eleven of their remaining fourteen contests, even though the second-place St. Louisans take all of their thirteen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Leaders of both major political parties will foregather with private welfare organization workers here this week to plan the annual Mobilization for Human Needs. The conference will be opened by President Roosevelt at 10 o'clock Thursday morning, with an address from the south portico of the White House.
Creation of a society for the suppression of "that ordinary vice of gossip" was advocated by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, at high mass there yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Virtually all means of transportation were put to use today as 25,000 Harlem residents arrived here at Camp Smith to pay homage to Harlem's pride, the 369th Infantry, which, in addition to being reviewed by Governor Lehman, observed visitors' day, which never fails to draw the largest gathering of the season.

An eminent biological scientist, whose name is not disclosed because he may have by now reached a different conclusion, said some years ago, in effect, that man had not surpassed the highest physical excellence of some individuals living ten thousand years ago, and that intellectually he had not advanced beyond a few individuals who lived two thousand or more years ago.

An attack on the idea that there should be a moratorium on sermons, on the use of current social and political problems as sermon topics, and on the portraying of Christ as a human rather than as an immortal figure, was made yesterday morning by the Rev. William Ward Ayer, in his sermon at Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ROME (By Radio from S.S. Conte di Savoia, at Sea), Sept. 13 (AP). -- Former Queen Victoria of Spain, crossing the Atlantic to visit her eldest son, who is critically ill in a New York hospital, begged today to be spared the fanfare usually given visiting royalty.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 13. -- Representations over the obstacles encountered by the Japanese investigation into the killing of a Japanese at Pakhoi were made to Nanking yesterday by the Japanese Embassy.

God completed in the Rev. Dr. William Koepchen "a yeoman's job," the Rev. Dr. Henry F.A. Stein of Concordia Collegiate Lutheran Institute, Bronxville, declared yesterday morning in St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 316 West Forty-sixth Street, just west of Eighth Avenue.

LONDON, Sept. 13. -- It is clear from the latest return of the Bank of England that note circulation is not undergoing its normal contraction for this period of the year and it will probably undergo considerable further expansion in the next few weeks.

Chancellor HITLER in his Nuremberg manifesto took a look at the work of his hands during the last three and a half years and saw that it was good. People would have laughed, he said, if back in January, 1933, he had boasted that in the next four years he would accomplish -- and then he calls the roll of his achievements.
BETTER take a quick glance at the starters in the amateur golf championship over the Garden City Golf Club links. Most of the divot-diggers will be leaving today or tomorrow.

Substantial increases in gross and net incomes from the operation of the structures under its control were reported yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. The periods covered were the twelve months ending Aug. 31, 1936, and the month of August this year, as compared with similar periods of 1935.
Harry H. Cook is with Lord, Abbett Co., Inc., in Buffalo. Robert P. Henderson, formerly their representative there, is now assistant to Leon Abbett in the office here.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The Phillies and Pittsburgh Pirates divided a double-header today, the Phillies taking the nightcap, 4 to 3, after the Pirates won the opener, 5 to 3, despite Chuck Klein's twenty-third homer.

PARIS, Sept. 13. -- Despite a fire that raged in the building for more than three and one-half hours early this morning the Paris Opera is not irreparably injured. Serious damages, which will probably much exceed the first estimate of 1,500,000 francs, were confined principally to the backstage mechanism and walls and the roof of the nine-story "well," which rises above the stage to the highest part of the building.
LENOLA, N.J., Sept. 13. -- A State-wide one-hour sit-down protest of all WPA workers has been called for Thursday from 1 to 2 P.M. by the Workers Alliance of New Jersey.

On a battlefield strewn with millions of strips of papers that gave the thing an Alaskan touch and to the encouraging roars of the largest baseball crowd in the history of the National League and the Polo Grounds, the Giants yesterday clung tenaciously to their lead in the torrid pennant race by breaking even in the double-header with their last dread foe from the West.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- A secret British proposal for an Anglo-Japanese-American conference designed to agree on a common policy in the Pacific and Far East as a prelude to the Washington disarmament conference was disclosed today in hitherto confidential diplomatic correspondence made public by the State Department.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- It Speaks well for the contemporary American composers whose works have been performed in the course of the concerts of chamber music at Yaddo this week-end that they have not hesitated to mingle with Bach, Handel, Vivaldi, Rameau, Lully and Purcell.
Three events tonight usher in a week that is pretty full of them. They are:

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- The money market continues quiet with rates virtually unchanged. Call money is 2 3/4 per cent, outside discounts, 3 1/8 per cent and treasury bond discounts 3 3/33 per cent, compared with 3 1/10 per cent last week.

TONERS, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Winning seven events, the Yonkers Canoe Club successfully defended its Westchester County canoeing team title on Tibbetts Brook Park Lake today. Yonkers scored 61 points to more than double the 27point total of the runner-up, Pendleton of New York City.

Those young men and women who by Summer represent the drama in Abingdon, Va., and are known in the process as the Barter Theatre, came as far north of the Mason-Dixon line as West Twelfth Street last night to try their theory of merchandise-for-art (and vice versa).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The Railroad Retirement Board announced today that, with the approval of the Acting Controller General, a procedure had been devised for preservation of rights under the Railroad Retirement Act of more than 50,000 rail employes whose retirement status and pay had been jeopardized by carriers that have cooperated to challenge the constitutionality of the law.

New York Athletic Club oarsmen, led by Frank Silvio and Allen Walz, carried off a major portion of the honors in the metropolitan championship regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Harlem River yesterday. Winged Foot representatives triumphed in six of the eleven events on the program.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Bob Feller, 17-year-old high school rookie from Adel, Iowa, wound up under a dark sky at League Park today and blazed his fast ones past the Philadelphia Athletics to strike out seventeen batters and allow only two hits, as the Cleveland Indians won both games of a double-header.

LILLE, France, Sept. 13 (AP). -- Textile workers at Lille stole a march on Premier Leon Blum today while he was en route there to try to end their strike. When the Premier arrived he found 35,000 strikers again in possession of the mills.

James A. Farley, summing up the New York State political situation after a week of conferences with Democratic county leaders in the city and up-State, predicted yesterday that President Roosevelt would carry the State by a larger plurality than the 596,996 figure he received in 1932.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- New records were set for slaughtering of cattle and sheep by packers working under government inspection regulations in August, suggesting a greatly increased use of beef and mutton. Slaughtering of cattle aggregated 1,011,743 head, exceeding the million-mark for the first time since October, 1935, when the total of 1,083,044 was the highest since January, 1919.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13. -- Taking a tip from history, Italy may use Christopher Columbus to rediscover America. Before leaving town Carlo Roncoroni, head of the new $10,000,000 Cines studios in Rome, discussed with Jack La Rue the possibility of the player's appearing in the title role of a film based upon the life of Columbus.

Police of New York and Westchester yesterday were seeking John F. Dwyer, former New York City Police Inspector who was known as the "czar of the Tenderloin," who disappeared on Saturday after having been discharged from the Rockland County State Hospital, an institution for the insane at Orangeburg, N.Y.

The first international meeting ever staged in this country by the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers will open this afternoon with a reception at the home of Rear Admiral George H. Rock, president of the society, on the grounds of the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, of which he is superintendent.

The legal limit of the city's tax levy available for the budget for next year will be about $554,000,000, or $20,000,000 below the total of department requests, it was estimated yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc. This figure is $2,000,000 higher than this year's total, due to taxes from new buildings.

Reflecting the government's reduced estimate of this year's domestic crop, prices of cotton registered sharp advances last week, following moderate advances the week before. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed on a net gain of forty-four to sixty-four points.

Preachers have engaged in too much faultfinding and have not given enough encouragement, the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland said yesterday in his sermon at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

Amid staccato roars and whiffs of burning castor oil typical of midget auto racing, twenty-two miniature speed boats churned around the surface of Conservatory Lake in Central Park yesterday in the annual Walter Elliot Memorial Trophy race, conducted by the New York Society of Model Engineers.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 13. -- The Committee for Industrial Organization, of which John L. Lewis is chairman, will face a major crisis in a few days when the annual convention of the International Typographical Union will vote on the question of supporting President Charles P. Howard, who joined the C.I.O. as an individual and is its secretary.

The Rev: Joseph A. McCaffrey in his sermon at the 12:15 P.M. mass yesterday in the Church of the Holy Cross, 333 West Forty-second Street, warned Catholic parents of America, and of his parish in particular, to send their children to Catholic schools if they would avoid a repetition in this country of the fate of their co-religionists of Russia, Mexico and Spain.

LOEN, Norway, Sept. 13. -- A million tons of rock toppled into Loen Lake early this morning from the towering black mass of the Ravnefjeld, 6,388 feet high, spreading death and destruction through the smiling farm country along the shores.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 13 (Uncensored, via Tangier, Morocco, and London) -- The most important outcome of the revolt on two ships of the Portuguese fleet several days ago is the apparent determination of officials here to permit Portugal to continue as a corridor through which supplies may be freely shipped to the Spanish Rebels.

VINCENT VAN GOGH made a religion of response. His letters to Anton Ridder van Rappard -- published today under the title "Letters to an Artist" (Viking, $3.50) -- are like records of vital discovery. An old-fashioned cape, a dingy alley, a line of starved women and children waiting outside a church for free soup, a hag begging -- brought what he thought were masterpieces into his head.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 13. -- A concert that Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice, daughter of John D. Rockefeller St., had arranged for yesterday afternoon at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown, was held although Mrs. Prentice is a patient at the City Hospital in Albany, N.Y. She is recovering from an operation for acute appendicitis performed Thursday night.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 13. -- Governor Landon has come and gone. Today Republican party workers are busily engaged in preparations for bringing to the polls at tomorrow's election the biggest Republican vote in the history of the State. They hope to make good the prediction of the Republican nominee for President in his address last night that "You will start a victory parade that will span the nation."

Henry Huddleston Rogers, 23 years old, son of the late Colonel H.H. Rogers, New York financier, was catapulted into the East River off East Fifty-third Street last night when his twenty-two-foot cabin speed boat was in collision with a railroad barge.

While a group of grim-faced members of the Waverley Boat Club toiled all day yesterday to demolish their boathouse at 167th Street and the Hudson River it was learned that the Knickerbocker Canoe Club, at 183d Street, also had been ordered by Park Commissioner Robert Moses to move at once to make room for Riverside Drive park improvements.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13. -- The Soviet Union today accepted the challenge embodied in Chancellor Adolf Hitler's address to the Nazi party congress in Nuremberg yesterday by proclaiming itself, on the basis of its new Constitution, the leader of the world's toilers in the struggle against dying capitalism, which was declared to have reached its final stage in Nazi Germany.

The crews of the Deutsche Lufthansa flying boats Zephir and Aeolus, which alighted at Port Washington, L.I., on Thursday and Saturday respectively, will inspect the latest air line flying equipment in this country this morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13. -- Three centuries of religious freedom in this State were marked in a unique service of worship this afternoon. Two thousand persons of all denominations took part. The ceremonies were held on one of the big drill fields of the Naval Training Station.

The $436,157,200 "price" to be paid for the combined properties of the B.M.T., Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company under the transit unification plan proposed by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. is a minimum figure that may be increased because of several factors, it was disclosed yesterday.
Father Divine led 3,000 exulting Negro "angels" five long miles from Harlem yesterday to the green pastures of Madison Square for a three-hour political rally.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- Mrs. Adele Blood Hope, 50 years old, actress and stock-company promoter, shot and fatally wounded herself at her home at 12 Griswald Road on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club here tonight. She died a few hours later at the United Hospital in Port Chester without regaining consciousness.

The Progressives from nineteen States who met in Chicago last week declared themselves to be forward-looking. Yes, but to what are they looking forward? Plainly, to the formation of a separate political party. They carefully and explicitly disavowed any intention to affiliate with the Democratic party.

The Citizens Union, in a statement released for publication today, recommends the nomination by the Democrats, in the primary election tomorrow, of Jonah J. Goldstein, Morris Koenig and Saul S. Streit for judges of the Court of General Sessions.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 13. -- Cheered by reports of a favorable reception of his last night's speech and by predictions of large Republican majorities in tomorrow's State election, Governor Landon abandoned politics for the day.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 13. -- The entries of Mrs. Julius Bliss and her son Philip accounted for five blues today before an enthusiastic gallery at the sixth annual exhibition of the Lawrence Farms Hunt Club. Twenty-eight events provided a busy day, with the program starting early in the morning and lasting until late in the day.

Substantial reorders in the form of mail requisitions comprised the bulk of activity in the wholesale apparel markets here last week. The delivery situation was made more difficult by the holiday at the beginning of the week and the urgent requests for back-to-school merchandise.

BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- Stringency in the money market here continues. Cash demands for income tax quarterly payments was met through heavy marketing by banks of Reich Treasury bills and their own acceptances. Day loans today were 3 1/4-3 1/2 per cent.
VIENNA, Sept. 13. -- King Edward VIII left here tonight for Zurich, Switzerland, whence he will fly to England. His departure was marked with demonstrations of popular enthusiasm.

With a score of old favorites on the program, the second of the recently inaugurated community sings under the auspices of the Bureau of Recreation of the Park Department was held yesterday afternoon on the Central Park Mall, more than 5,000 persons participating.

Shy, scared, feeling very important, the youngest recruits are starting to school. The child hidden somewhere in every grown-up remembers the excitement and the terror of that first day in the classroom, when numerals and phonetics were mysteries greater than any encountered since and the plunge into the critical society of one's peers called for a sang-froid that has never been adequately celebrated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- Philip P. Gadsden, chairman of the Committee of Utility Executives, today characterized statements made by President Roosevelt in his address Friday before the World Power Conference as an "official declaration" that the purpose of the administration's hydroelectric program is to bring about lower electric power rates.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- A bullish situation prevails in virtually all wheat markets of the world, and the trade has become impressed with the belief that higher prices impend, but a runaway market is not expected unless there is a decided increase in buying power and a stronger feeling among holders that prices will reach a level that has not been attained in a long time.

Some months ago statements appeared in the press to the effect that my play, "St. Joan." had been adapted to the cinema by myself and a syndicate formed for the production of the film version with Miss Elisabeth Bergner in the title part. These statements were duly authorized by me and by Miss Bergner's press representatives.

A former prosperous clothing truckman, who was driven out of that business by racketeers he had defied, died yesterday morning in a fusillade of bullets fired by four men in the candy store to which he had been reduced.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 13. -- Dunbar Bostwick, flashing some of his best polo of the season, scored six goals today to lead the Cyclones to victory over Aknusti at Bostwick Field in one of the opening matches of the Meadow Brook Club's annual sixteen-goal Autumn Plates competition.

Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, stormy petrel of the American Olympic team's Berlin expedition, was the feature performer of the "Eleanor Holm Sports Festival" sponsored by The New Jork Evening Journal at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 13. -- Singing "The Internationale" and waving red flags, about fifty delegates to the State Socialist Convention bolted early this evening, led by Devere Allen of Wilton, after the convention, controlled by the conservative wing of Socialists, had voted to disaffiliate with the National Socialist organization.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- Asserting that "State aid" to localities has become a question requiring "painstaking study," in view of the huge sum distributed annually in recent years, Controller Morris S. Tremaine, in his annual report, just issued here, asserts that the outlay gives a "misleading impression of the cost of actual State government."
It appears that one of our readers cannot take it any more.

Elementary school authorities have passed a "death sentence" on formal homework, most onerous element of the school program for countless generations of children. This became known yesterday as 1,100,000 city public school pupils packed pencils and notebooks in preparation for the opening of classes this morning.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- The final review of evidence in the removal proceedings against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn will be made to Governor Lehman today by Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd, and Lloyd Paul Stryker, counsel for Mr. Geoghan.
The destruction of churches in the civil war in Spain was discussed by clergymen of varying denominations yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13. -- After the lull early last week owing to the Labor Day holiday the cotton market here became extremely active. The main stimulating influence was the bullish character of the government's forecast of the crop, based on conditions on Sept. 1.

Prominent passengers arriving today on the French liner Normandie include Max Reinhardt, producer; Brigitte Helm, German actress; Gilbert Miller, producer; Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, with Mrs. Ecker; Judge Julian W. Mack of the United States Circuit Court, with his family; Charles S. Dewey, former financial adviser to the Polish Government, with Mrs. Dewey; Senator Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware, James Byron Drew, justice of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 13. -- A thief, whose methods resembled those of the "phantom" burglar who has operated among North Shore estates for several seasons, entered Mattapan, the country home of John W. Davis, former Ambassador to the Court of St. James and Democratic candidate for President in 1924, some time last night.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP). -- The Boston Bees, with Danny MacFayden pitching six-hit ball, defeated the Cincinnati Reds by 6 to 1 today after being set back by 2 to 1 and limited to three hits by Gene Schott in the first game of a double-header before a crowd of 12,216.

Still grave financial and political conditions in Continental Europe accounted for another week of iregularity in the foreign exchanges. There were a few exceptions to this reaction, however, this being notable in the case of sterling and associated currencies, all of which established new highs for the year.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 13. -- The business of selecting a golfer who will wear the crown that has adorned the brow of Lawson Little for the past two years will start tomorrow morning when 164 aspirants tee off in the opening round of the fortieth annual amateur championship.

Blase New York, living happily all these years under the impression it could take its greatest sporting events strictly in stride, arriving on time, late or not at all as fancy dictated, went completely hickory yesterday when the largest crowd in the history of the Polo Grounds packed the arena to suffocation.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,156,661,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 13. -- Chancellor Hitler reiterated in his annual address to the Nazi Women's League this year his faith that woman's place is in the home, but indicated vaguely that he did not intend to force women out of business or the professions.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Sept, 113. -- Edward Searle of Grassy Sprain achieved the signal honor today of being the first golfer to have his name inscribed on the Leewood Golf Club trophy as that club's first annual invitation tournament came to a close. The young Westchester star defeated Thomas C. Robbins, a fellow club member, 3 and 2, in the final.
HENDAYE, France, Sept. 13. -- The main force of the victorious Spanish Rebel troops before San Sebastian today occupied the Bay of Biscay resort city with little or no bloodshed.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 13. -- The Little Entente conference, which opened yesterday, continued today in Bratislava. The principal meeting, however, occurred unofficially last night when President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia outlined to the Foreign Ministers of Rumania and Yugoslavia proposals that formed the basis of their discussion today.
In an address delivered in Portland Saturday night, Governor Brann of Maine, referring to contributions by J.P. Morgan and others to the Maine Republican campaign fund, said:

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The prison parole system in the United States was condemned as parole "in name only" in a report distributed today at the opening session of the American Prison Association Congress.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 13. -- The Malines Congress of Catholic leaders closed today on a note of optimism when Premier Paul van Zeeland declared Belgians owed their tolerance, moderation and capacity for work to their deep religious feeling.
Plans for new housing projects were announced yesterday in connection with sales for properties in the Bronx, Westchester County and on Long Island.

Adoption of two new low-cost plans for hospital care, one whereby an entire family may benefit and the other for husbands and wives, was announced yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, 370 Lexington Avenue.

Describing the destitute condition of the oppressed groups in Europe, particularly the Jewish people of Germany, Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman made a plea yesterday for support for the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, which undertakes to help thousands of suffering persons abroad.

HARTFORD, Sept. 14. -- As a result of the bolt of left-wingers from the Socialist State Convention yesterday and their session last night, two Socialist tickets confronted the Secretary of State today and the decision as to which set of nominees shall go on the ballots in November was referred to Attorney General Edward J. Daly.
Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, warned organized labor yesterday against being tempted into unreasonable demands by increased public sympathy for labor.

Treasury financing operations, income-tax payments and interest and dividend disbursements due today will involve a money market turnover of around $1,900,000,000, a large part of which will be in cash. The Treasury will refund $514,000,000 of maturing 1 1/2 per cent notes into long-term 2 3/4 per cent bonds and at the same time will sell $400,000,000 of the bonds for new money.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. l4 -- In a hard-fought engagement this morning Rebel troops of the Spanish Foreign Legion took the village of Marute, on the Talavera-Maqueda road. If that column, which is commanded by Lieut. Col. Tella and is working in conjunction with other elements of General Francisco Franco's army, can reach Maqueda, as seems most likely now, Rebel forces will be within forty-five miles of Madrid.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 14 -- At the closing session of the Fourteenth International Congress of PEN Clubs today, Jules Romains, French novelist, was elected president, succeeding H.G. Wells of Great Britain. It had been expected that Karel Capek of Czechoslovakia would be president, but he stepped aside in favor of Mr. Romains.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Hogs sold slowly today with prices generally 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight lower than on Friday. One load brought $11.25 a hundred pounds, equaling the best price at the end of last week, but the practical top today was $11.05 and it was hard to get $11 at the close.

Scholarships to Nassau-Hofstra College, New York University's educational center at Hempstead, L.I., were awarded to graduates of thirteen Long Island High Schools, Arthur D. Whitman, dean of Nassau-Hofstra College, announced yesterday.

New life insurance written in August was 3.6 per cent more than in the same month last year, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reported yesterday to the Department of Commerce. The total for the first eight months of this year, however, was 3.5 per cent less than for the corresponding period of 1935.

Gains in construction, while substantial and promising, must become increasingly larger to make up for a dearth prior to and during the depression, L.A. McLean, president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, declared yesterday.

Governor Lehman will speak on his State social security program Saturday night at a dinner to be given in his honor by the New York Young Democratic Club in the Hotel Astor. The dinner will bring together hundreds of young Democrats from the five boroughs, including a number of first voters.

HELENA, Mont., Sept. 14. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, tonight discarded most of a prepared speech to repeat his assertion that life insurance and savings accounts were endangered by the administration's fiscal policies.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 14. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler closed the National Socialist Congress tonight with a speech which, after all the sound and fury of the last seven days, was almost an anti-climax. He still denounced bolshevism, but he sought no action against it.

The Democratic outlook in this State is so bad that the political lieutenants of Democratic Chairman James A. Farley do not dare tell him the truth about the situation, according to Republican State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Paul Waner tied a modern National League batting record today as the Pirates took both ends of a double-header from the Phillies, 11 to 4 in the first and 6 to 5 after ten innings.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept 14. -- Clipping four strokes from par with a sparkling 31, 35 -- 66, Alex Watson and Foster Nichols of Hudson River led a field of twenty-two pairs in the weekly Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur event at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club today.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP). -- The Red Sox were unable to score a run against Detroit today although they got eight hits off Tommy Bridges and were issued five walks, and the Tigers won, 1 to 0, to break even in the two-game series.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP). -- The White Sox beat Washington, 5 to 4 and 11 to 3, today to pull three and one-half games ahead of the Senators in the battle for second place in the American League.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Adolf Hitler, the official Soviet press commented today, has as much chance of seeing the Ukraine, Urals and Siberia "as he has of seeing his own ears."

A judgment dismissing a suit by Ruth M. O'Brien against the estate of Samuel Parker Hinckley, once a wealthy real estate man, for $32,125 was filed in Supreme Court yesterday on a decision by Justice Salvatore Cotillo. Miss O'Brien sued on the ground that she was engaged in 1923 as Mr. Hinckley's secretary, companion and aide at $75 a week during his lifetime and $25 a week for life after his death.

The grand jury investigation of the transportation of bootleg coal from Pennsylvania to New York approached its close yesterday with the questioning of seven witnesses representing coal producers and retailers. John C. McDermott, Assistant District Attorney, said that final witnesses would be heard today or tomorrow.

ALBANY, Sept. 14 (AP). -- For the second time in two weeks Stanley Piseck, president of the New York Milk Producers Federation, postponed a threatened strike call today as the "dead-line" he had set for State revision of milk prices passed without action by State officials.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- According to Hector Bywater, writing in The Daily Telegraph, German naval architects have solved the problem presented by having two systems of propulsion for submarines -- namely, an oil engine for running on the surface and an electric motor for running submerged.

In the last few years orthodox Communists have conceived and reiterated an orthodox explanation of fascism. It is, they tell us, the attempt of capitalism to make a last desperate stand by the naked use of force. It is not merely the Communists that represent fascism as the opposite extreme from their own position, but the Fascists themselves.

ALBANY, Sept. 14. -- Governor Lehman's hearing of the removal charges against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn ended today after seven hours of oratory in which counsel variously pictured Mr. Geoghan as a "disgrace and menace" to his community and as the "innocent victim of a plot spawned by foul politics and yellow journalism."

Closing with a great rush in the last furlong, Star Porter, from the stable of George McMitchell, was up just in time to take the Ben Holladay Handicap, which featured the racing at Aqueduct yesterday. The 6-year-old son of The Porter had a margin of a neck over Bootmaker, which in turn was half a length before Treford in the field of five.

A glowing picture of Palestine's growth into a world athletic power was painted by members of the Maccabee Palestine champion soccer team, who arrived here yesterday on the French liner Normandie for an extended schedule of benefit games in principal American and Canadian cities.

ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN, PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 14. -- Aides of Governor Landon refused today to permit Paul Block, publisher of a chain of newspapers, to attach his private railroad car to the Governor's special campaign train.

The opening this evening is "The Golden Journey," a work by Edwin L. Gilbert, which the Messrs. Shubert are distributing to patrons of the Booth. It will mark their first play offering of the new season. Alan Bunce, Leona Powers, Aldrich Bowker, Alan Hewitt, Raymond Bramley, Hugh Rennie, Jane Bancroft, Eleanor Lynn and Joan Tompkins are in it.

A feud between the offices of Kings County District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan and United States Attorney Leo J. Hickey was started yesterday on the eve of the trial of eight former directors and officers of the defunct National Title Guarantee Company which is to be heard before Federal Judge Edwin S. Thomas in Brooklyn Federal Court beginning today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 14. -- The final communique of the Little Entente conference was issued this evening. Its most interesting passage from the point of view of foreign politics expresses regret that relations between the Little Entente and Austria should be under a cloud as a result of Austria's one-sided modifications of obligations to which she was bound by the Treaty of Saint Germain respecting disarmament.

In vain do the cynics assert that there is no such thing as gratitude in politics. There was a notable instance of that virtue yesterday. Former Governor HUNTLEY SPAULDING of New Hampshire enriched the public with a letter of recommendation for former Senator MOSES, who will or will not be renominated for his old post in today's Republican primary.

Reports indicate that the governing board of New York World's Fair is now facing for decision the primary question affecting this enterprise: namely, what shall be the Fair's basic theme, which will determine its scope, character and significance.

CACERES, Spain, Sept. 14. -- Picked troops of the Rebel southern army are advancing again from Talavera de la Reina toward Maqueda, where one road swings north to Madrid and another south to Toledo, and it looks as if the Leftist defenses of the capital are beginning to crumble.

For the eighth time since last Tuesday's Government report on this year's cotton crop, December contracts moved yesterday above 12.20 cents a pound on the Cotton Exchange, only to back away under the weight of hedges, and the setback left the list with losses of 6 to 14 points.

Stocks were heavy yesterday, particularly in the forenoon, and closed lower. Trading was the smallest for a full day since Aug. 26. The decline of 0.83 point in THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks was the widest since the same date. For want of a better explanation, the suggestion will have to do that most traders preferred to remain aloof pending the tally of the Maine voting.
DETROIT, Sept. 14. -- Primary election day will dawn in Michigan tomorrow with a dark cloud hanging over the political future of Senator James Couzens.

SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Government defenders of Bilbao, Spain, tonight advised foreigners to leave the city and warned commanders of foreign warships that the harbor would be mined at midnight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The desirability of improved economic relations among nations was discussed for twenty minutes today by Secretary Hull and Max Frederic Horn, a director of the Sofina Company and a delegate from Belgium to the World Power Conference here last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Sept. 9 shows increases for the week of $170,000,000 in total loans and investments, $51,000,000 in demand deposits, adjusted, $41,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks, and $27,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

An underwriting group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Edward B. Smith Co. will offer today $55,000,000 of consolidated first mortgage thirty-year sinking fund 3 3/4 per cent bonds of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, due on Oct. 1, 1966.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The nebulous hope of convening the Locarno conference on Oct. 19, the date desired by the British Government, virtually vanished today when Berlin informed the Foreign Office in London that it would be impossible to prepare for negotiations as early as that.

For the first time in fifteen years in the local meat industry the A.F. of L. and an affiliate, Amalgamated Meat Cutters Union, signed a contract with the retail meat dealers committee that some of the signatories declared would change the entire situation in the industry.

One million, one hundred and twenty thousand pupils in the five boroughs turned reluctant backs on Summer yesterday and swarmed into elementary, high and vocational schools for the opening of the Fall term.

Vice President John N. Garner will be the guest of honor at a dinner of prominent Democrats at the Hotel Biltmore tomorrow night, it was announced yesterday by James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman.

PARIS, Sept. 14. (By Courier from Madrid). -- Eric C. Wendelin, United States charge d'affaires, estimates that there are still 170 Americans in Madrid, of whom forty are living in the embassy. Another circular warning to American residents was sent out yesterday that "American warships have left Spanish waters and will not return except on call by diplomatic or consular officials."

The fourth American season of Colonel W. de Basil's Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House from Thursday, Oct. 29, through Sunday, Nov. 8, it was announced yesterday by S. Hurok. Seventeen productions are scheduled.

The work of bringing up to date the calendar of the Municipal Court in the Bronx, which had fallen behind nearly three years, is nearly complete, President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell said yesterday at ceremonies marking the centralization of jury trials of the court in that borough yesterday morning.

Amid a great snarling, gnashing of teeth and even a fist fight among themselves because nobody else would fight with them, Frankie Frisch's colorful band of Cardinals evacuated New York last night, their gas tank riddled and their tires as flat as their remaining slim chances of winning the 1936 National League pennant.
