The 1936 edition of "The Follies," nurtured in the Shubert-Ziegfeld tradition, resumed its interrupted career last evening at the Winter Garden. After an amiable run earlier in the year, it drifted into a May decline, at the same time as did Fannie Brice, its leading exponent.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 14. -- New Hampshire's primary campaign, featured by a bitter battle for the Republican nomination for Senator between Governor H. Styles Bridges and former Senator George H. Moses, closed tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14. -- Mrs. Catherine Kendig Clegg of the Philadelphia Cricket Club, third seeded, advanced to the second round of the women's Philadelphia grass court tennis championship as the tournament got under way at Germantown Cricket Club today. She defeated Mrs. Doris Carney, former Reading champion, in straight sets, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP). -- A proposal to create an interstate prison commission was approved tonight by representatives of twenty-five States at the annual congress of the American Prison Association.
COLON, Panama, Sept. 14. -- An ingenious "ship tracer," which can locate vessels accurately during their transit of the Panama Canal, was demonstrated today for the first time.

A dinner held at Coney Island last night ostensibly for the purpose of "raising money for baskets for the poor of East New York" came to an abrupt end when the members of the Manhattan alien squad and the Coney Island police arrested eleven of the 100 guests and the two proprietors of the hall. All were charged with vagrancy.

Business men should work for domestic and international peace because their markets require peace in order to flourish, Estelle Sternberger, executive director of World Peaceways, Inc., suggested to members of the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., yesterday at their weekly luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- Out of the Lille textile strike there developed today in dramatic fashion a choice for Premier Leon Blum's Popular Front government to convert France into a Marxian Socialist State or to govern in accord with the existing laws regarding private property.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said today in his monthly business review that "the steadiness with which progress has been made this year is more important than the amount of the advance."

The code for standard automobile fines and penalties proposed by the city magistrates' committee on traffic will end discrepancies frequently observable in the punishments meted out in different courts and even in the same court for similar traffic violations, officials of the Automobile Club of New York declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during August was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 574,289 bales of lint and 65,382 bales of linters, compared with 603,203 and 70,246 during July this year and 408,325 and 59,102 during August last year.

A detective posing as a taxicab chauffeur caused the arrest early this morning of Steve Audressy, 32 years old, an unemployed baker of 215 East Seventy-seventh Street, who police said, confessed attempting to extort $500 from Mrs. Margaret Clark, a writer, of 319 West Ninety-fifth Street.

NANKING, China, Tuesday, Sept. 15. -- The troubled history of Chino-Japanese relations is entering a new and acute phase this afternoon when Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe and Foreign Minister Chang Chun are expected to open formal negotiations for settlement of the fundamental issues behind the Chengtu and Pakhoi incidents, which cost the lives of three Japanese.

Suit to test the constitutionality of the holding company provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 got under way yesterday in Federal court here when the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Electric Bond and Share System filed briefs with Judge Julian W. Mack.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 14. -- Justice John C. Crosby of the State Supreme Court and Mrs. Crosby entertained at dinner tonight at their home here in honor of Chief Justice Arthur Prentice Rugg and Associate Justices Edward P. Pierce, Fred T. Field and Henry T. Lummus.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Assets and deposits of the 14,506 insured commercial banks, which held 97 per cent of the total deposits of all commercial banks in the United States, increased substantially in the fiscal year ended on June 30, according to a report made public today by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Herbert A. May has resigned as vice president of the Safety Car Heating and Lighting Company to become vice president of the Union Switch and Signal Company with headquarters in Pittsburgh. He will continue as a director of Safety Car Heating.

Alfred E. Smith, speaking to more than 600 foreign delegates to the World Power Conference who were guests of the Consolidated Edison Company at a dinner last night, assured them they would always be welcome here and promised that "unless the forces of evil overtake us for a second time there will always be something in the larder to warm the cockles of your hearts."

Blocked by a flotilla of anchored liners and freighters as she neared quarantine at 8 A.M. yesterday, the French liner Normandie solved the problem by turning around outside the Narrows and backing in to her position.

ALBANY, Sept. 14. -- The American Labor party obtained a certificate of incorporation from the Secretary of State today, under the Membership Corporations Law. It is formed by twenty-one trade union leaders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Three Civilian Conservation Corps companies will be transferred to the vicinity of Binghamton, as soon as camp quarters are made ready, to start the flood control program authorized by Congress.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 14. -- Robert W. Sparks, vice president of the Bowery Savings Bank, New York, and president of the Financial Advertisers Association, told 400 delegates at the meeting of the association here today that bankers could not live in a "land of make-believe."

TOULON, France, Sept. 14. -- An attempt to estimate the respective chances of the Spanish Loyalists and the Rebels is complicated by the fact that they are engaged in a political, no less than a military, struggle, and the communiques of both sides not only are contradictory, but obviously are intended more as propaganda than as statements of fact.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 14. -- Mrs. W. Eugene Parsons will be a luncheon hostess at the Muenchinger-King tomorrow. Mrs. Eugene Roberts, who gave a picnic luncheon at Bailey's Beach today, will entertain at the Breakers tomorrow. Countess Alfonso P. Villa will also be among those entertaining tomorrow.
In THE TIMES Washington dispatch of Sept. 8 in regard to Securities and Exchange Commission matters the following appears:

The Transit Commission flatly rejected yesterday a demand by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., that it make known at once, "for the record," its exact position on the $436,000,000 plan of rapid transit unification offered by them as Mayor La Guardia's principal transit advisers.

The city of Detroit awarded yesterday a total of $19,952,000 of various bonds to a banking syndicate headed by the First National Bank of New York and Halsey, Stuart Co, Inc., on a bid of 100.0005 for coupons ranging from 2 3/4 to 3 1/4 per cent, or on an interest cost basis of 3.170 per cent.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., Sept. 14. -- The New York Maritime Association today won permanent possession of the James M. Curley golf trophy by defeating the Boston Maritime Association, 18 -- 9, in a team match at the Shenecossett Country Club.
READING, Pa., Sept. 14. -- A new world record for three heat paced over a half-mile track marked the opening day's card of the Grand Circuit meeting today at the Reading Fair.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- The Boerse opened the week today with a continuation of the upward movement that set in after Chancellor Hitler's announcement of his four-year plan. Special interest again was concentrated on the raw-materal issues likely to profit from the plan, but firmness spread to other issues as well, although there were some individual losses.

A strong undertone prevailed again on the local commodity futures markets yesterday at the start of the week's trading, with further strength in cocoa futures the feature of trading. Wool tops and sugar futures, however, were slightly depressed.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 14. -- During the opening round of the fortieth national amateur championship at the Garden City Golf Club today, in which some celebrities of the links were ousted by lesser lights, Walter Blevins of Kansas City was perhaps the most flabbergasted winner in the huge field.

SEATTLE, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Two former members of the home economics department of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, forced to suspend publication by a strike of the American Newspaper Guild, which has been aided by local trade unions, testified at a hearing before the National Labor Relations Board today that the staff was warned that membership in the Guild presented "an excellent opportunity for martyrdom."

WHEN seen the other day at Forest Hills, Stuart Chase appeared to be concerned with nothing more important than Bitsy Grant's forehand. He seemed not especially concerned, indeed, with even that, and ranged about the vacant topmost rows of the stadium restlessly, sitting first here, then there, until he fell into the clutches of an acquaintance (presumably), who led him away to be introduced to some other spectators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull termed "absurd" today the charge of the French newspaper Action Francaise that William C. Bullitt, former United States Ambassador to Russia, who has been appointed Ambassador to France, was being sent to Paris as a Soviet agent to foment a Franco-German war.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 14. -- President Getulio Vargas in a message to Congress today asked that the state of war be prolonged for ninety days as from Sept. 21, when the present period expires.

The spending of soldiers' bonus money played only a comparatively small part in the increase in retail sales of men's wear in various sections of the country, according to replies to a questionnaire sent out by the American Interchange Credit Bureau Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Receipt of nearly $500,000, mostly in small contributions, since Jan. 1, was reported today by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's National Union for Social Justice.

Senator Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware, who announced early in the Summer that he would not run for office again and was later "drafted" at the Republican State Convention, returned from the Near East yesterday on the French liner Normandie.

In today's primary three judges are to be nominated for the Court of General Sessions. For two of the judgeships, both Democrats and Republicans have joined in a nonpartisan endorsement of Justice COLLINS and Justice KOENIG. Both of them have acceptably served out a full term on the bench.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- After having told a lurid story that "a foreign power" had offered him 150 to shoot King Edward, George Andrew McMahon was sentenced to only one year at hard labor today for the revolver incident on Constitution Hill July 16.

Made a few years back by Alexander Korda, "The Girl From Maxims" or "Naughty Paris in the Gay Nineties" will have a belated Times Square premiere today at the World Cinema. Its players are Frances Day, Lady Tree, Leslie Henson, Sterling Holloway and George Grossmith.
Pedestrians and storekeepers who litter upper Broadway after Thursday will get summonses, William F. Carey, Sanitary Commissioner, announced yesterday.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on July 31 a net income of $2,088,173, compared with $2,117,049 for the preceding year. These figures allow for all deductions, including interest on the funded debt and amortization of debt discount and expense, including amortization of expenses in connection with the proposed extension of notes due on Oct. 1. 1935.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 14. -- Following is the text of the address today by Pope Pius:

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 14. -- Pope Pius depicted vividly today the horrors of the Spanish civil war, praised the martyrdom of the Spanish clergy and strongly denounced both bolshevism and nazism.

Rosh ha-Shanah, or the Jewish New Year, will begin at sundown tomorrow. In the Jewish calendar it will be the year 5697. Its observance will be followed by Yom Kippur, or the Day of Atonement, which will begin at nightfall, Sept. 25.

The demands of the Atlantic Coast division of the International Longshoremen's Association for new wage and working contract for its 40,000 members were submitted yesterday at a meeting of committees representing the men and the Atlantic ship lines at the Maritime Exchange Building, 80 Broad Street.

Several hundred NYA boys have spent the Summer cutting wide dirt paths along the lines of narrow hillside footpaths in Van Cortlandt Park, near the Putnam Division tracks. In doing so they have ruthlessly destroyed all vegetation for many yards on either side of the paths.

For the past twelve months Lou Little has been living pretty much out of an aspirin bottle. The 1935 Columbia football season was a headache for the professor of Baker Field and on top of that an ailing hip, which was operated on during the Winter, has caused him enough additional affliction to invalid the normal flesh-and-blood mortal out of such exacting work.

The directors of the Manufacturers Trust Company yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a common share, thus placing the stock on a regular $2 annual dividend basis, compared with a regular annual payment of $1 a share paid in the past three years. The increased dividend is payable on Oct. 1 to shareholders of record of Sept. 19.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Professional traders in the major farm products transacted business today on Chicago's big markets for the first time under the more rigid Federal restrictions, embodied in the Commodity Exchange Act which was passed last Spring.

PARIS, Sept. 14 (Uncensored. By Courier From Madrid). -- The censorship in Madrid is keeping back stories that would give the world a far better picture of what is happening in the city than it gets through official channels.

Harry E. Byram, former head of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, who was shot in the head ten days ago on the eve of his wedding, was married yesterday in a ceremony in the Hotel Vanderbilt.

PORTLAND, Me., Tuesday, Sept. 15. -- Maine elected a Republican Governor and three Republican members of Congress in yesterday's election, but with about two-thirds of the vote tabulated early today the contest for United States Senator remained in doubt.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Detective Miles Ledbetter reported tonight that an autopsy surgeon had informed him "uremic poisoning was a large contributing cause" of the death of Mrs. Anna Powell Crookshank, 78.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 14. -- Of the 100 papers presented before the British Association for the Advancement of Science today, that of Sir William Beveridge commanded the most attention because it dealt with the work-a-day question of unemployment.

In these days when so many young people fail in respect for their parents it is comforting to note a striking instance of filial devotion. Mr. JAMES ROOSEVELT is actively campaigning for the re-election of the President.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP). -- A "White Russian" who admitted addressing the Black Legion meeting May 12 at which the State charges members of the hooded band "sentenced" Charles A. Poole to death, testified today that he saw four men leave the hall with orders to abduct Poole.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Resuming its investigation of investment trusts and investment companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission delved today into the investment operations of the Central Trust Company of Illinois and its successor, the City National Bank and Trust Company.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 14. -- For his act of heroism in driving an automobile up Tiscapa Hill to rescue innocent men and women caught between the fire of the Sacasa forces and the National Guard on May 31 last, Fletcher Warren, first secretary of the United States Legation here, was decorated today by President Brenes Jarquin with the Nicaraguan medal of merit.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 14. -- As an emissary of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor Frank Morrison, the federation's secretary, put before the annual convention of the International Typographical Union today the council's demand that the printers' union compel its president, Charles P. Howard, to dissociate himself from the Committee for Industrial Organization.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 14. -- The Dixiana Farm's entry of Crow's Flight and Mata's Brother ran first and third in the six-furlong allowance race for 2-year-olds which featured today's Narragansett Park card. Crow's Flight finished two lengths ahead of Mrs. H. H. Brown's Miss Nico, which was a nose in front of Mata's Brother. The time was 1:12 3-5.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Fifty-seven candidates for the 1936 Princeton football team reported to the Osborne Field House today for physical examinations and a brief session with photographers as the orange and black uniforms were handed out in preparation for the initial practice session tomorrow.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- George Andrew McMahon, who testified in Old Bailey today to a plot by agents of a "foreign power" to assassinate King Edward, pleaded with the court to send him to prison to protect him from those whom, he said, he had betrayed by failing to carry out the deed.

A primer of information for WPA workers arrived in New York yesterday. Prepared in Washington for distribution among all persons on the WPA rolls, it contains a pictorial representation of the virtues of the work program, as well as a question-and-answer compendium of data on what the worker is expected to do.

Accompanied by a young golden retriever, Miss Constance Carpenter, English actress, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie. The dog is the property of James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, and Mrs. Walker, who is one of the actress's close friends, and had been acquired by the Walkers when they lived in England.

George Bernard Shaw's letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES complaining about Catholic efforts to rewrite his play "St. Joan" for the movies provoked considerable discussion yesterday. Spokesmen for the church lifted their eyebrows and wondered who had been picking on Shaw to goad him into the philippic he indited to the editor of THE TIMES.

GARDEN CITY, Sept. 14. -- Weather clear, track fast. Anyway, they had a fine day for it. There was a rich blue sky and a cool wind blowing as the amateur golfers started the chase for the national amateur crown over the links of the Garden City Golf Club today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Miss Gwendolen Shethar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Burke Shethar of this place, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at the American Yacht Club here.

The thirty-second Coney Island Mardi Gras opened with a parade last night with Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine among 300,000 visitors. The parade was chiefly a demonstration by various police units to further the department's street safety campaign.

Police Commissioner Valentine and Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey began yesterday a joint investigation to determine whether any policeman had said that Joseph Rosen, murdered Sunday in his candy store at 725 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, had been or was to be a witness in a Dewey racket investigation.

ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN, EN ROUTE WEST, Sept. 14. -- Confident of a Republican victory in Maine, where he spoke Saturday night, Governor Landon spoke at three cities in New Hampshire and Massachusetts today and carried his campaign into New York State.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade's figures for August: Total imports, 66,050,000; exports of British products, 35,250,000; re-exports, 4,350,000; total exports, 39,600,000; excess of imports, 26,450,000.

In a move interpreted as intended to discourage the sale in this country of dresses imported by manufacturers for copying purposes, the Treasury Department announced yesterday a new ruling under which a penalty of 25 per cent of the value of the garment will be assessed if any model gown is sold by the importer.

ALSASK, Sask., Sept. 14. -- Two men met and dined together in this little drought-stricken village of Southwestern Saskatchewan last Friday who had not seen each other since they were students in Edinburgh forty years ago. One, the host, was Alex Fraser, pioneer farmer of this district.

The enrolled voters of the city and the States will participate today in the regular Fall primary election, with the polls open here between 3 and 10 P.M. The primary here will be of little interest to any but the enrolled Democrats, as there are no contests in any other party.

John Masefield, poet laureate of England, arrives today on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania. Others on the ship, from Southampton and Cherbourg, are Sir Lenthal Cheatle, surgeon; Robert Lincoln O'Brien, chairman of the United States Tariff Commission; A. Harry Moore, U.S. Senator for New Jersey; Archbishop J.J. Glennon of St. Louis, H. Smurthwaite, director of Furness, Withy Co.; George de Ghika, Hungarian Consul General in New York, and Judge Allen Stearne.

Nearly 100 children who consider themselves pupils of Public School 82, at Macombs Road and 176th Street, the Bronx, failed to return to school yesterday. They stayed out because of a disagreement with the school system, which holds that they are pupils of two other schools.

On the ground that the majority stockholders of the Renaissance Bronze and Iron Works sold out without accounting to the minority stockholders, a judgment for $639,196 was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court in favor of Louis Liebman and Hyman B. Gabbe of 45-26 Forty-fourth Street, Long Island City, against Daniel A. Most and Rudolph Holstein of 210 West End Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- William E. Chapman, United States Consul, and Manuel J. Codoner, vice consul at Bilbao, Spain, left that city at 3:06 P.M., Spanish time, today on the United States destroyer Kane for France.

LONDON, Sept. 14. -- The stock markets here were quiet and irregular today, being overshadowed by the international situation. British funds continued steady. Outstanding in the foreign market was the further rise in German loans. Home rails eased on absence of support, and foreign rails also were dull, International issues were depressed.

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Sept. 14. -- Driven to seek shelter by rain, sleet and ice, their fuel supply low, Richard Merrill, veteran airline pilot, and Harry Richman, amateur flier and actor, landed their monoplane "Lady Peace" in a Newfoundland bog at Musgrave Harbor, more than 100 miles north of here, this afternoon at 4:47 o'clock Newfoundland time (3:17 P.M. Eastern daylight time).

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- An educational campaign through the medium of insurance advertising to make known the various opportunities for protection against calculable hazards was advocated today by J. Albert Robinson, vice president of the Risk Insurance Institute, Inc., and insurance manager of McKesson Robbins, Inc.

DIXIE, Que., Sept. 14. -- Miss Margery Kirkham of Montreal, seeking to regain the title she won four years ago, captured the qualifying medal in the Canadian women's open golf tournament today from a field which included several star players from the United States as well as most of Canada's outstanding golfers.

A moderate decline developed yesterday among second grade and convertible corporation bonds on the New York Stock Exchange, but the turnover was somewhat smaller. While the market as a whole displayed a highly mixed undertone, the most conspicuous price changes were toward lower levels, with local traction issues and several of the speculative industrial loans outstanding among issues to reflect the selling.

Ten youths from 17 to 20 years old were arrested yesterday in Brooklyn and charged with criminally assaulting a girl returning from a church dance. Three of the boys also were charged with kidnapping.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 14. -- The advance prices of steel for delivery in the last quarter of this year, announced within the last few days by the major iron and steel companies and averaging $2 a ton on semi-finished and finished products, will amount to a larger increase in many eases.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Oscar Saffer, clothing manufacturer, who was the first person to be convicted in New York County on a State income tax evasion charge, was sentenced in Special Sessions yesterday to an indeterminate term up to three years in the penitentiary.

With a lead of four and a half games over the second-place Cardinals, the Giants require only nine more victories in their thirteen remaining encounters to clinch the National League pennant. In the event St. Louis sweeps all its twelve contests, the New Yorkers still would be a game ahead.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 14. -- The pins began to fall at the Garden City Golf Club today as the fortieth national amateur championship got under way, but when it was all over most of the kingpins were still standing.

Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, who is mentioned as a possible Republican candidate for Governor, accused President Roosevelt's administration, in a radio address last night, of holding the United States Supreme Court up to "scorn and ridicule," urged the defeat for re-election of the President and of Governor Lehman and called for the election of a Governor with courage to reduce the State deficit by cutting expenses.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14. -- There is a strong possibility that the New Jersey State Federation of Labor will go on record in favor of the re-election of President Roosevelt before the close of its convention, which opened here today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- More than 200 Republican leaders from twenty-seven States, meeting in Chicago today, reported to national headquarters that support of Landon was "sweeping like a prairie fire over the West." The assemblage was under the direction of John Hamilton, the party's national chairman.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will open with a private view today, and to the public tomorrow, the first show of its 1936-37 season. It consists of material produced since August, 1935, by artists throughout the country on the Federal Art Project, and is called "New Horizons in American Art."

GENEVA, Sept. 14. -- The League of Nations Economic Committee's report to the Council, reviewing the world economic situation, was made public here today. While stressing the need for national and international action to combat economic and financial maladjustments, the report holds it is "necessary to set aside the idea of a world economic conference in which the diversities of the various countries' own interests would constitute from the beginning an obstacle to success."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- A conference of the heads of the nation's chief insurance companies and probably some savings bank officials will be held at the White House tomorrow, and, although the call for the meeting went out more than a week before Colonel Frank Knox's declaration that life insurance policies and savings accounts were unsafe, discussion of this assertion probably will take place.
An unprecedented concentration of anglers on the tuna grounds just off Seabright, N.J., since last Friday produced the most sensational week-end in the history of big-game fishing in near-by waters.

The effect of the warm weather last week was evident in both reorders and buyer attendance in the women's apparel and accessory markets here yesterday. Both were below expectations, although the number of buyers here today is counted on to run heavier than a week ago, when arrivals were reduced by the Labor Day holiday.

Ever since the Republican National Convention, where speeches and platform put so many curious critters on exhibition, romantic naturalists have looked expectantly at the eastern end of Lake Erie. Our old acquaintance, the sea serpent, fights shy of campaigns for the Presidency.

After attending a conference held by the Institute of Pacfic Relations at Yosemite National Park as a delegate from England, Dr. Margaret S. Miller, secretary of the Society of Women Housing Estate Managers of Great Britain, has come to New York and is studying housing here.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Mrs. R. H. Battle's Over Yonder won the featured seven-furlong dash by a neck at Lincoln Fields today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The new Commodity Exchange Act, amending and extending the Grain Futures Act by legalizing control over futures trading in cotton, rice, mill feeds, butter, eggs and potatoes, in addition to grain, which became legally effective yesterday was in effect in practice today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 14. -- A legendary figure, whose name is a rallying cry for Harvard men either in their yard or in Singapore or other far places of the earth, has come to life at the Harvard Tercentenary celebration. Rinehart is here.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 14. -- After a long day of competition in which the par figures of 71 were bettered repeatedly, four pairs today tied for first place with 66s in the Long Island Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament at the Sands Point Club.

WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 14. -- Labor camps for youths under 21 years, which is the military age in Poland, will be created in this country to extend military training to all young men, including those not entering the conscript army.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Bishop Gallagher of Detroit, asserted in an address last night that "the money plank in the Lemke platform is dangerous," and added that he believed "President Roosevelt has a much better background to work out these monetary problems than this man from the Dakotas."

Sporadic strikes to bring non-committed building owners under the Silcox award, which ended the strikes of elevator operators and other building service employes earlier in the year, were threatened yesterday by James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 14. -- An improved type of treatment for diabetes, which enables the patient to live a much more normal life and promises "to lessen the most dreaded complications" of this widespread disease, was reported here today at the tercentenary session of the Harvard Medical School.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- President Roosevelt's prestige in the northwestern tier of States and the farm belt has been generally maintained, Senator Shipstead said today after he had talked with the President. He predicted the President would win by the same relative vote as in 1932 and that the administration's soil-erosion policy would go a long way toward solving the farm problem.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Carrying out what police said was a carefully planned "revenge scheme," Harry L. Jeffrey of Varna, former janitor of the Animal Husbandry Building at Cornell University, today shot to death Miss Viola Elver, 40, in an office in the building, then shot himself fatally.
BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 14. -- Popular tribunals are still busy in all parts of Catalonia and the rest of Eastern Spain.

Greentree and the Argentines, who will meet in the Cup of the Americas series at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, starting on Saturday afternoon, are slated to participate in practice contests on Long Island fields today against formidable quartets.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 14. -- Playing well despite a stiff wind which swept the course during the greater part of the day, Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of White Beeches and Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont tied for medal honors in the fourteenth annual women's New Jersey State golf championship at the Echo Lake Country Club today.

When fifteen cities see twenty-eight Federal Theatre companies next month in the Sinclair Lewis -- J.C. Moffitt, "It Can't Happen Here," they will witness "no propaganda except for the American system of democracy, with all its failings, as opposed to dictatorship," Mr. Lewis said yesterday.

The engagement of $2,060,000 gold in France and $350,000 in England by local banks for shipment here was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank. These engagements lifted to $112,600,000 the total of gold taken abroad since the current influx began on Aug. 7.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 14 (AP). -- The Rebel captors of San Sebastian moved westward tonight to attack the Spanish Government's new line near Orio, about ten miles away.

Continuing the policy inaugurated last year on its sixtieth anniversary the Art Students League reopened yesterday a full two weeks earlier than formerly. More than a dozen of the artist instructors are represented by oils, pastels or sculpture in the League Gallery and several others by graphic work in wall cases opposite the reception room on the first floor.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Seventy golfers competed today over the east course of Winged Foot in the qualifying round of the twenty-fourth annual championship of the New York Athletic Club, the winner of which will receive for one year's possession the John G. Anderson Memorial Trophy.

At a time when Governor Landon is asking the President to "confess his error" in his advocacy of NRA and omitting to confess having made the same error himself, and when Democratic politicians decline to concede that any rich man can have other than a selfish interest in contributing to the Republican campaign fund, it is refreshing to read such sincere discussions of the national choice as those recently appearing in three newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- A proposal that CCC boys receive military training was attacked today by Frederick J. Libby, executive secretary of the National Council for Prevention of War, as "another attempt to put America on the road to fascism."

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., Sept. 14. -- Former President Herbert Hoover was "first hook" on a blue fishing expedition today in Block Island Sound with his former secretary, Lawrence Richey; Lewis Strauss, a member of the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., and George LeBoutillier, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
LOEN, Norway, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Survivors of Sunday's tragic avalanche and flood in the beautiful Lake Loen Valley tonight prepared to flee the district, fearing new catastrophes.
Trencher Furs, Inc., at 277 Grand Street, reported to the police yesterday that eight hold-up men, some of them armed, looted the plant of approximately $40,000 in furs at 10 A.M.

The conduct of the city's prisons by the Department of Corrections under Commissioner Austin H. MacCormick was praised by the Prison Association of New York in its ninety-first annual report, which was made public yesterday. Opening of the new penitentiary on Rikers Island and the closing of the old Welfare Island penitentiary was cited as a notable achievement.
Housing property deals in Manhattan and Brooklyn featured the urban realty trading reported yesterday.
BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Tales of horror were related here today by refugees from Spain arriving aboard the steamship Excalibur of the American Export Lines.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 14. -- Two hundred members of the New York State Historical Association, which began a three-day convention here, with 235 members of the Ontario Historical Society, went in autos today to the unveiling of the cobble-stone shaft commemorating the birth of Methodism in Canada 150 years ago.

Predictions of an impending price advance on leathers and a record attendance of more than 1,500 retailers and manufacturers featured the opening sessions yesterday of the semi-annual style conference and leather exhibit of the National Shoe Retailers Association and the Tanners Council of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 14 (AP). -- Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania's bid for freedom from Dannemora prison was turned down today by County Judge Thomas F. Croake, who dismissed a writ of habeas corpus.

It seems to me as I listen to the political speeches and read the interviews in the newspapers that the disagreement betwen the individualists and the collectivists waxes bitter because it is over a question of degree rather than over conflicting principles.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 15. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speeches at Nuremberg apparently have cost him the support of The Times of London, the most powerful organ of British opinion and in recent months most sympathetic to Germany's foreign policy.

DENVER, Sept. 14. -- In a speech before the national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today, Senator Steiwer of Oregon demanded that the cost of war be equally borne by all classes of society.

MINISINK FALLS, Pa., Sept. 14. -- Following the physical examination of the entire squad at Philadelphia, fifty-three candidates for the University of Pennsylvania varsity foootball team arrived today at Camp Wyomissing. The first practice will he held tomorrow morning.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 14. -- The Ohio district board of the Amateur Athletic Union interviewed Jesse Owens, sprint star, today and then recommended his reinstatement by the National A.A.U.

Restoration of city pay that had been cut, at least for six months of 1937, received official sanction yesterday when the Board of Estimate adopted a resolution ratifying an agreement between the city and its bankers that cuts the 1937 budget reserve from $20,000,000 to $12,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP). -- Constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act was challenged in the Supreme Court today by The Associated Press in appealing from an order by the National Labor Relations Board directing it to reinstate Morris Watson, a discharged employe of its New York office.

In the event that the Giants capture the National League pennant, an achievement that appears more than likely at the moment, Bill Terry and his merry men should in all fairness offer a rising vote of thanks to the Dodgers. For yesterday at Ebbets Field Casey Stengel's charges dropped the third-place Cubs a notch lower as Van Lingle Mungo sent them on their way on the short end of a 2-1 count.

The weeks of Oct. 12 and 19 were fixed yesterday as the time for the nation-wide sales drive on California dried fruits, a movement launched by 37,000 chain stores to aid a $35,000,000 industry, according to announcement made yesterday by Phillip Bancroft, chairman of the California Dried Fruit Stabilization Committee, with headquarters in San Francisco.

Mary Gardiner Thompson, 91-year-old philanthropist, left $13,027,737 of her estate of $14,914,031 to six New York City charities, the appraisal showed yesterday. Miss Thompson, who died last April 22, was a descendant of Lord Lion Gardiner, who in 1639 bought Gardiners Island at the eastern end of Long Island from the Indians and obtained for it a royal grant.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Representative Henry D. Steagall of Alabama, chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Currency, today characterized as "ridiculous and absurd" assertions attributed to Frank Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, that "no life insurance is secure; no savings bank safe." He was addressing the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The Central Illinois Securities Corporation, organized and sponsored by the Central Trust Company of Illinois, the so-called Dawes bank of Chicago, sustained losses of about $7,000,000 in the depression period, according to the accountants of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BOSTON, Sept. 15. -- The future oil mankind depends on the production of better minds in sounder bodies, not on political or economic theory, according to Dr. Earnest A. Hooton, Professor of Anthropology at Harvard University.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Miss Margaret Pitkin Brown made her debut today at a luncheon given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richmond L. Brown of Greenwich at the Field Club. The debutante was graduated from the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr last June and will enter Vassar College shortly.

Geoerge C. Johnson, treasurer of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, was elected yesterday chairman of Group V of the Savings Banak Association of the State of New York. He succeeds George S. Downing, president of the Jamaica Savings Bank.
Multi-family and business properties were included in the Bronx turnover reported yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 (AP). -- With the ability they have shown all season to beat the Browns easily, the Senators pounded out a double victory today.

John Masefield, poet laureate of England, who has seen the excitement of a fast-moving age supplant the intellectual thrill of poetry, voiced a plea yesterday for a return to poetry and for greater encouragement of all the arts.

Judge Robert A. Inch, in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, reserved decision yesterday on a motion by counsel for the Bush Terminal Company for permission to pay $1,164,000 of accumulated interest due on $6,629,000 of the company's 5 per cent consolidated mortgage bonds which will mature in 1955.
Election of several economists to the board of governors of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking was announced yesterday by Dr. Joseph E. Goodbar, president of the organization.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 15. -- The first heavy rainfall since the outbreak of the Spanish revolution slowed up the action yesterday and today on the Saragossa front, where the struggle for Huesca is still the center of interest.

ROME, Sept. 15. -- Germany's plea for a postponement of the conference of the five Locarno powers was supported today by a communication from the Italian Govern ment to London in which, though no explicit demand for delay was made, the opinion was expressed that a date should not be fixed until adequate diplomatic preparation had been made.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- Miss Sarah Churchill, actress and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winston Churchill, is aboard the liner Bremen en route to Chicago, according to The Daily Express, to marry Vic Oliver, Viennese-American light comedian, who is staging a show.

A book called "The Spanish Tragedy," by E. Allison Peers, who is Professor of Spanish at the University of Liverpool and the author of several books on Spain, has been added to the Oxford University Press Fall list and will be published on Oct. 29.

READING, Pa., Sept. 15. -- Favorites came through in all three races on today's Grand Circuit card at the Reading Fair. The speedy roan colt, Running Water, 2:01, by Guy Abbe -- Rippling Water, owned by Henry Warwick, New Hamburg, N.Y., breezed through a classy field of 3-year-old pacers to win the Reading Fair Futurity in three straight heats.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- The Bodleian Library at Oxford will mark the Harvard Tercentenary tomorrow with an exhibition of rare books and manuscripts illustrating the relations between Oxford and Harvard in the seventeenth century.

Frank Gillmore, president of Actors Equity Association, warned Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, yesterday that Equity would "protest strongly" the dismissal of any bona fide actor from the Federal Theatre Project so long as non-actors were permitted to hold jobs there.

Fulfilling the promise of the unusually brisk week-end activity, apartment leasing increased heavily in volume yesterday as brokers and agents reported long lists of new rentals and renewals and tenants and management companies alike became more acutely aware of the approach of Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- President Roosevelt conferred today with six executives of insurance companies on problems affecting both the companies and the Government, searching especially for means of cooperation in the exchange of information regarding farm and real estate values as appraised by government and private surveys.

Recording a considerable increase over the number of visiting buyers reported in the market here in the preceding week and in the corresponding period last year, registrations for the week ended yesterday were 1,213, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15. -- The size of the Republican vote and the close race of Republican candidates for the nomination for Governor distinguished early returns tonight from the Wisconsin State primary.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 15. -Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, co-medalist in the women's New Jersey State golf championship, continued to dominate the tournament as match play began at the Echo Lake Country Club today by defeating Mrs. Charles Harding of Rumson, 6 and 5, in the first round and going on to record a 79 for the eighteen holes, the best score of the tournament so far.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Easiness today in the wheat market in Liverpool discouraged operators on the Board of Trade here in the early part of the session and many of the pit element took the short side, feeling that a general reaction in the world's price structure was about due.

George Bernard Shaw's endorsement of Federal censorship of moving pictures in his recent letter to THE TIMES was criticized here yesterday as "confusing nonsense, profoundly disappointing to those who remember with admiration his tilts with the British Examiner of Plays."

Reaction from July's sensational gains brought a slight recession in business during August, the national index, prepared by the research department of Brooke, Smith French, Inc., dropping from 10 per cent to 12 per cent below normal. The decline was felt in a majority of the 147 trading areas, 85 of which showed small losses in business activity.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 15. -Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers, widow of Colonel Henry H. Rogers, oil man, quit a hearing into the accounts of the temporary administrators of her husband's estate before Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Hans Lange, for the last five years assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Society, has just been appointed associate conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Henry E. Voegell, manager of the Chicago orchestra, announced today.

ATLANTA, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Frank Edward Stephens, a mild-mannered youth who said he spent six of his sixteen years in a reform school, calmly told Federal authorities today of sending a $25,000 extortion letter to the mother of Shirley Temple.
Tonight, as the sun goes down, Jews throughout the world will enter their temples and synagogues to hail with prayer and chant the advent of the New Year -- the year 5697 in the Hebrew Calendar.

I have noticed in the news the request of Police Commissioner Valentine for additional appropriations so as to enable him to add 1,200 more men to the force. I concur. In fact, 5,000 more would be nearer to the number of men needed to police this city properly.

Because many readers of your newspaper deposited a check in the C.O.S. Vacation Fund for the children under our care. I would like to report to them the following good news as "interest on their investment." The final total of our vacation fund was $7,942.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 15. -With no contests among the regular nominees for the November election, a light vote was cast throughout Suffolk County today. Party endorsements by Democrats and Republicans were made with apparently little interest.

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan returned to his Brooklyn office shortly after noon yesterday to be greeted by a crowd of nearly 1,000 persons outside the Brooklyn Municipal Building. Some were merely onlookers, but many were personal friends whose welcome amounted almost to an ovation.

A plan for the adjustment of accumulated unpaid dividends on the $7 first preferred stock of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has been approved by the directors of the company, it was announced last night.

A dinner was given last night in the Oldelmonico Restaurant, 56 Beaver Street, by bankers and Wall Street reporters for James T. King, money-market expert of the New York News Bureau Association, who will be 80 years old tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Great Lakes shipping executives expressed confidence today that the 1,936 season would shatter early optimistic estimates and prove to be the greatest year for iron ore and coal movement since 1929.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 15. -- "If we don't win this one, I'll keep the horse right on going out the chute, and headed for New York," was the way Jockey Johnny Bejshak sized up his chances aboard Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery in the $25,000 added Narragansett Special, big feature tomorrow of New England racing.

More than forty builders, architects, engineers, city building officials and representatives of financial institutions lending money on mortgages, meeting yesterday at the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street, voted to form a committee to be known as the Vigilance Committee of the Construction Industry to concern itself with the promotion of safer construction.

When the Columbia Broadcasting System opens its new theatre-studio tomorrow night at the Manhattan Theatre, Fifty-third Street and Broadway, it will be possible, according to CBS engineers, to "sit in the balcony and hear a pin dropped on the stage."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- President Roosevelt indicated again today that the world situation might cause him to restrict his campaign activities. He said that a projected trip to the Pacific Coast was being held in abeyance to see what developments occurred between now and the first of October, and expressed the opinion that he ought not to be away from Washington as long as four days at a time, in view of present conditions.

The football teams of Columbia and Lafayette met in an intensive three-hour scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field. It was a bruising session from the opening whistle and shortly after 6 O'clock, when Lou Little and Ernie Nevers halted activities, the coaches ventured the opinion that the meeting had considerably benefited both teams in preparation for their regular campaigns.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 15. -- More than 100 armor-clad football players trooped across to the Harvard practice field from the locker building today to start the Crimson's 1936 gridiron campaign with two rugged sessions on fundamentals under the direction of Dick Harlow and his coaching associates.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- A demand by the law firm of Choate, Larocque Mitchell of New York for the resignation of a member, John W. Austin, was alleged today in papers presented to Surrogate George A. Slater.

Two 5-year-old boys who were unable to suppress a desire to go to school along with the rest of the city's 1,120,000 children were safe in their homes yesterday after they had been the subject of a city-wide search by police for more than fifteen hours Monday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 15. -- With no contests to draw them to the polls, fewer than 10 per cent of the enrolled voters of Nassau County turned out to cast their ballots today. Even the expected write-in vote by the National Union for Social Justice party against Robert Low Bacon, Republican designee for Representative, did not assume the proportions that were feared.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- A contest for the Republican nomination for State Senator in the Twenty-sixth district, which takes in Yonkers and runs all the way to the northern extremity of Westchester County, brought out a vote that was heavier than usual.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Defense lawyers were held today to be a contributing factor in the development of "repeating" felons, according to a report of the committee on crime prevention made to the annual congress of the American Prison Association. R.V. Bastin, superintendent of Ormsby Village, Anchorage, Ky., chairman of the committee, presented the report.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- Premier Leon Blum, declining tonight to concede defeat in his efforts to check the threat of a general textile strike, called successive meetings of employers' and workers' representatives at Lille for tomorrow.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 15. -- Development of a "hyper-immune serum" against influenza, and also of a vaccine which has immunized human beings against the disease, foreshadowing the final conquest of the plague which has taken so many lives during epidemics and is causing suffering to millions all over the world, was reported today at the tercentenary session of the Harvard Medical School and the Harvard Medical Alumni Association.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 15. -- Mrs. Edwin Denison Morgan gave a supper dance tonight at Wheatley, her country home, in honor of two granddaughters, Miss Theodora Morgan Jay, third daughter of Mr. and Mrs. De Lancey Kane Jay of Westbury, and Miss Polly Evarts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah M. Evarts.
BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 15. -- Slowly the sedate British Association for the Advancement of Science is realizing that man was not made for science, but science for man.

The Radio Corporation of America filed yesterday in the Supreme Court here an answer to the injunction suit brought by the Philco Radio and Television Corporation. It denied hiring detectives to ferret out confidential information regarding the Philco company's technical or scientific developments or processes.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15. -- Many large table reservations have been made by members of the Summer colony for the annual harvest ball on Friday evening in aid of the Rocky Farm Camp for Crippled Children.

Approximately 99 per cent of New Yorkers with third quarter Federal income tax installments to make paid promptly yesterday, the due date, and caused but little extra strain on the Internal Revenue offices in the city.

MADRID, Sept. 15. -- Government forces began a drive tonight in the Talavera de la Reina sector as evidence increased that the outcome of the fighting there probably would be a major factor in deciding the two-month-old civil war.

After two previews for invited audiences of film folk and notables, Warner Brothers' "Give Me Your Heart" opens for the public today at Broadway's newest cinema house, the Criterion. The chief players in the photoplay are Kay Francis, Roland Young, George Brent, Frieda Inescourt, Patric Knowles and Helen Flint.
MOUNT FREEDOM, N.J., Sept. 15. -- For the prize example of the amateur spirit in its undiluted essence, Brooklyn College is herewith recommended as football's leading entry.
BURGOS, Spain, Sept. 15 (AP)--General Emilio Mola, chief of the Fascist armies of the north, served notice on allied insurgents today that the army would run Spain "after our victory."

TOPEKA, Sept. 15. -- Governor Landon returned to Topeka a little before midnight tonight in the role of a man who had taken a gamble and won. He hailed the result of the Maine State election as starting a "victory parade" which would extend to the entire nation in November.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Schoolboy Rowe chalked up his eighteenth pitching victory today as the Tigers came from behind with a six-run splurge in the fourth inning to clinch an 8-to-5 decision over the Athletics.

Federal Judge Hulbert reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Federal Trade Commission for an alternative writ of mandamus to compel the National Biscuit Company to give information concerning the salaries of its officers, its costs and chain store customers, or show cause in court why it should not do this.

The Right Rev. Arthur Selden Lloyd, Senior Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, who died in Darien, Conn., on July 22, left most of his estate to Miss Mary Carroll of 124 West Ninety-first Street, an assistant in his mission work, it was revealed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court. His estate was valued at less than $10,000.
Apartment house sales by banks in midtown featured the Manhattan deals reported yesterday.

The theatre season, with its long, cold months of varied joys and sorrows, is now here officially: for last evening at the Booth the first farce sputtered dimly against the brighter lights of Forty-fifth Street. Call it Edwin Gilbert's "The Golden Journey," and in charity to the firstborn say that it is mainly harmless in a gentle sort of way, the batting average being little better than a string of nice, symmetrical negatives.

The murder last Sunday morning of Joseph Rosen, 46 years old, in his candy store at 725 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, is regarded by the police of such importance that twenty detectives have been assigned to the case, it was learned yesterday.

The Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act will prove of no material benefit to its supposed beneficiaries and "such teeth as it has will be gradually filed down by the courts," it was declared last night by Harry Eaton, associate editor of the Whaley Eaton Service, Washington, D.C. Mr. Eaton was the principal speaker at the monthly meeting of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at 2 Park Avenue.

Before the market had closed on Monday, brokers had analyzed the probable effect of the Maine election on yesterday's market and had undertaken to estimate how stocks would react to various results. One broker argued, in a market circular issued on Monday night, that the market probably would not advance unless the Republicans obtained at least 65 per cent of the votes cast in the election.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- A stirring call for the cooperation of Americans with other English-speaking people in defense of "our democracies, which are facing serious dangers," was made here tonight by Sir Robert Falconer, Canadian statesman and retired president of the University of Toronto, at the international banquet climaxing the meeting of the New York State Historical Association, which closes tomorrow with an all-day conference on local history.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 15. -- The International Typographical Union maintains that it has jurisdiction over employes on all "robot" printing and type-producing machines such as the teletype-setter, whether they are installed in or out of the composing rooms, according to an announcement today by C.P. Howard, president of the union.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15. -- Settlement of the differences between the American Federation of Labor, headed by William Green, and the Committee for Industrial Organization, under John L. Lewis, and reconciliation of the two groups was predicted here today by Spencer Miller Jr., sociologist of the Workers' Education Bureau.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15. -- Max Arnov, studio casting director at Warners, today received the difficult assignment of assembling a cast of performers for Booth Tarkington's "Penrod and Sam" and having the company ready to start production Monday.

PARIS, Sept. 15. -- The strike situation in Lille, which continues to dominate the political scene in France, remained unsettled today. According to Roger Salengro, Minister of the Interior, there is, however, "an impression of betterment" and "a glimmer of hope," that when Premier Leon Blum receives representatives of the employers and the workers tomorrow afternoon an agreement will be reached.

ALBANY, Sept. 15. -- Governor Lehman has been assured in a letter from General Maiin Craig, Acting Secretary of War, that the Air Corps will no longer drop bombs in practice over Fort Tyler, near Gardiners Island, N.Y.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 15. -Whatever hopes the invading British players had of turning the tables on the Americans by capturing our golf championship received a rude jolt today when Hector Thomson, their principal threat, was banished in the second round of the fortieth amateur classic.

Steadily downward has been the revision of the President's formal campaign speaking program, and steadily upward has been that of his chief rival. Now Washington reports that only two addresses classified as political will be made by Mr. Roosevelt between this period and election day and that there is less dispute over the decision than any which has been made since the number of his speeches was first discussed.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP). -- With the aid of homers Nos. 39 and 40 by Hal Trosky, and an assortment of thirteen other base hits by the rest of his mates, Johnny Allen chalked up his twentieth pitching victory of the year today, hurling the Indians to a 13-to-2 triumph over the Red Sox.

By a decision of Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church in the test case involving $200,000,000 in Federal taxes on gasoline sold to municipalities and State governments throughout the country, the City of New York lost its application for the dismissal of a $7,141 suit by the Richfield Oil Corporation.

The cornerstone of American foreign policy lies in the "willingness to be friends, but not allies," said Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, at a dinner last night of the Good Neighbor League, in the Hotel Commodore.

The French liner Normandie sails today for Southampton and Havre. Her list includes Albert Spalding, violinist, with Mrs. Spalding; Miss Sophie Tucker, comedienne, accompanied by her pianist, Ted Shapiro, and Mrs. Shapiro; Sally Eilers, film actress; Ricardo Cortez, actor, with his wife, and a group of actors from the company of "Night of January 16," who will appear in the play's London run.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Boston Albany Railroad asked authority today of the Interstate Commerce Commission to sell $500,000 of its 4 1/4 per cent bonds due on Aug. 1, 1978, the proceeds to be used to buy other securities for its reserve fund.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15. -- The Rev. Laurence H. Jongewaard, pastor of Roslyn Presbyterian Church, near Glenside, was suspended from the ministry today by the Presbytery of Philadelphia North.

The Interstate Commerce Commission was urged yesterday by the Port of New York Authority, Merchants Association and Shippers Conference of Greater New York to permit the railroads to effect their proposed store-door pick-up and delivery service of freight within the metropolitan district and the eastern section of the country.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Sept. 15 -- Always holding a commanding lead, a 30-goal quartet of Whites routed Greentree, 16 to 10, at the Sands Point Club today and thereby strengthened the doubts of many polo followers as to the latter's chances of victory in the coming Cup of the Americas series against the Argentines.

MADRID, Sept. 15. -- Instructions received by the United States Embassy here from Washington indicate that American women who married Spaniards before the Cable law of 1922 cannot receive the protection of the embassy no matter how serious the situation becomes.

Prospects for a settlement of the controversy between truckmen and their employers brightened yesterday when both sides agreed after a two-hour conference with Mayor La Guardia in City Hall, to resume negotiations at 1 o'clock this afternoon.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Sept. 16. -- Japanese warships were gathering in the vicinity of Hainan Island, ostensibly intending a demonstration against Pakhoi, where the Nineteenth Route Army will not permit an investigation of the murder of a Japanese merchant.

JESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 15 -- Argentina's international polo team cantered easily through six shortened periods against a twenty-five-goal team at the Meadow Brook Club today and won at 8 to 3, but the score didn't matter much and the game was never taken very seriously by any of the men in action.

Amid the sordidness and the artificial hates and heats of politics the sight of a magnanimous and philosophic sage is as welcome as unexpected. Chairman EATON, whose sagacity, tact and skill in avoiding controversies in the party and enlisting troops of friends have been so conspicuous, has kindly taken pity on Mr. FARLEY.
A drastic curb on WPA absences was ordered yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, in his drive against "two-timers" on the work-relief rolls.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- The government news service issued here today the text of a proclamation of gratitude to the German nation, given to its special correspondent at Burgos, Spain, by the Rebel leader, General Miguel Cabanellas.

At the office of Paul Block, publisher of a chain of newspapers supporting Governor Landon, who failed to have his private car attached to the Landon campaign special train at Worcester on Monday, the text of a telegram from the Governor to the publisher was made public yesterday by Mr. Block's secretary.
The city will build a new public market on the lower East Side on Essex Street, between Broome and Stanton Streets, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, announced yesterday.

A strong trend next Spring and Summer toward fashions taking their inspiration from American history, as a result of the vogue for Americana in literature, art and the motion picture, was foreseen yesterday by fashion authorities who addressed the closing sessions of the semi-annual style conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association and the Tanners Council of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The Continental Oil Company declared an extra dividend of 25 cents and another dividend of the same amount. On July 31, 25 cents was distributed.

The New York Caledonian Club track and field meet scheduled at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow night was called off last night after the Metropolitan A.A.U. notified club officials that Jesse Owens, triple Olympic champion, was ineligible to compete.

Early action in negotiating a reciprocal trade treaty with South Africa, as well as an immediate modification of sanitary regulations which handicap the sale of South African fruits in this market, are among the objectives of the South African Reciprocal Trade Committee, headed by James A. Farrell Jr., it was announced at the offices of the National Foreign Trade Association yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 15 (AP). -- The year's worst tropical storm, described by the weather bureau here as "of great magnitude and hurricane intensity," menaced shipping 1,000 miles east of Florida tonight.
To begin with some dates:

More than 100,000 visitors had viewed the new electrical equipment at the 1936 National Electrical and Radio Exposition in the Grand Central Palace at 6 o'clock last night, according to an estimate by the show managers. Crowds are growing daily and business is reported at a "high peak."

From Maine to Florida, Republican leaders of every State in the Eastern sector have been summoned to a conference in this city tomorrow at which, it was forecast yesterday, decisions with regard to Republican campaign strategy of first importance would be reached.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 15. -- In a statement issued today in reply to the Shaw letter, the Most Rev. John T. McNicholas, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Cincinnati and organizer of the Legion of Decency, denied that any official Catholic group had attempted to censor a proposed film version of Mr. Shaw's play, "Saint Joan."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, Inc., through its president. William A. Hollingsworth of 233 Broadway, New York City, has asked the Federal Trade Commission to authorize a trade practice conference to consider "present havoc-working" tactics in the trade and to formulate rules to eliminate any unfair methods of competition and abuses that may exist in the industry.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- Paul Bastid, French Minister of Commerce, interrupted his return trip from Warsaw to Paris with a one-day visit today to Berlin where he was the guest of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics. The visit, it was explained in official quarters, was of a wholly "spontaneous" nature and reciprocated Dr. Schacht's recent visit to Paris.

A weaker tone in the domestic bond market developed yesterday in average trading, while United States Government issues and foreign bonds were generally stronger in tone. The volume was $9,543,400, compared with $9,721,700 on Monday, with the turnover in domestic corporation bonds $8,038,000, against $8,176,000.

The New Jersey Social Security Commission has framed two bills which it is recommending to the Legislature of its State. One would appropriate $25,000 for a suit by the State of New Jersey in the United States Supreme Court to enjoin the collection of payroll taxes in New Jersey under the Federal Security Act.
Eighteen American philosophers refused yesterday an invitation from the German Philosophical Society to attend its thirteenth meeting in Berlin from Sept. 21 to 23.

The year 1936 is likely to witness fewer births in New York City than any year since 1890, in spite of the city's population growth to about three times what it was forty-six years-ago, according to estimates of Health Department statisticians announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice; Health Commissioner.
Newton D. Baker presents in eighty-six pages of the current issue of Foreign Affairs his first examination since leaving the Wilson Cabinet of "Why We Went to War."

The police have no authority to invade the rights of citizens and police orders must be obeyed only when they are lawful, Magistrate Charles Solomon said yesterday in Coney Island Court when he dismissed disorderly conduct charges against David Horowitz, 44 years old, of 2,002 East Twenty-eighth Street, and Irving Melchmar, 36, of 1,402 Avenue K, both Brooklyn.

DETROIT, Sept. 15. -- Leo T. Crowley of Washington, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, speaking this afternoon at the thirty-fifth annual convention of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, said the banking structure of the country now is in its strongest position for the last several years.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 15. -- The economic transformation of Catalonia foreshadowed by the recent formation of the Economic Council, composed of delegated workers and members of political organizations, was carried a stage further today when the Generalidad in conjunction with the Economic Council began organizing the Catalan proletariat in nine economic regions.

GENEVA, Sept. 15. -- According to reports reaching League quarters today from a good source it is understood that Emperor Haile Selassie plans to attend the meeting of the Assembly with Ras Nasibu and precisely the same delegation whose credentials the Assembly accepted in July.
MADRID, Sept. 15. -- Mass confiscation of estates and property owned by grandees and the Catholic clergy continues under the auspices of the Agrarian Reform Institute.

Erwin S. Dayan, 22 years old, part owner of the Fifth Avenue Linen Corner at 417 Fifth Avenue, was convicted yesterday in Special Sessions of misrepresenting as linen goods that were actually cotton. It was the first conviction for what Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson called "window larceny" in "the linen racket."
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 15. -- Forty-eight hours after its capture by Rebels, San Sebastian was once more full of fashionably-gowned women and idly chatting cafe crowds tonight.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Unmindful of the morning downpour and the continual threat of more rain, 179 men, the youngest 55 years of age, teed off in quest of the United States senior golf championship at Apawamis today. With more than 300 entrants, the competition will last four days, half the field playing eighteen holes today and the remainder on Thursday and Friday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 15. -- Fifteen additional candidates reported to Coach Fritz Crisler today to bring the total number of aspirants for the 1936 Princeton football team up to seventy-two as practice began on University Field with morning and afternoon drills.

It is inevitable, we know, that exaggerated interpretations of the Maine election on Monday will be set going. Republican managers will declare that it means the beginning of a victory parade which will soon cover the whole country. The exploded proverb that as Maine goes, so goes the Union, will be revived.
Lusty song filled Randalls Island Stadium last night as picked barber shop quartets indulged in harmonized melody in the sing-off of the Park Department's second annual American ballads contest.
Plans of a $250,000 apartment house for the Bronx were among the building projects filed yesterday, as follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- The Republican victory in Maine was hailed by Republican leaders today as showing the tide running strongly to Governor Landon and as an augury of a Republican triumph in November.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The suggestion that New York City be used as "an experimental laboratory" by insurance companies to reduce automobile accidents was made here today to advertising executives of leading insurance companies by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler of New York.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 15. -- The nearly final compilation tonight showed that the Republicans made a sweep of the major offices in yesterday's election. In the only race that was in doubt Senator Wallace H. White, Republican, defeated Governor Louis J. Brann, Democrat, by about 5,000.

The four-story apartment house at 27-21 Twenty-third Street, Astoria, on a plot 60 by 100 feet, was one of the Long Island residential properties figuring in sales reports yesterday. The building was bought by Netter Netter, as attorneys, from the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Showing a sharp increase over the first seven months of 1935, the value of aeronautical exports from the United States during the corresponding period of the current year were valued at $11,639,450, compared to $8,818,096 in the 1935 period, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The Giants' onward march to what now seems a certain clinching of the National League pennant came to a temporary halt yesterday when a drizzling rain during the forenoon, with the threat of more to follow later in the day, caused a postponement of the opening clash of the brief two-game series with the Pirates at the Polo Grounds.
THE TIMES of Sept. 10 contained the following statement in the column of Arthur Krock:

In the issue of Foreign Affairs published today, NEWTON D. BAKER has a long article on "Why We Went to War." It covers a great deal of research to which, he writes, he has devoted the leisure of an entire year. He has read every official document published by any of the Governments concerned, and is familiar with the revelations from the secret archives in Germany and Russia.
The text of the address of Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, at the dinner of the Good Neighbor League, Hotel Commodore, last night follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Pitching heights he has never before attained were scaled by Monte Pearson today as the Yankee steamroller shuttled into Comiskey Park and snapped a White Sox winning streak at seven straight. The score was 7 to 1.
Ernest R. Grauer, formerly of L.F. Rothschild Co., has joined the metropolitan sales department of Lord, Abbett Co., Inc.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 15. -- The speech from the throne with which Queen Wilhelmina opened the sessions of the States-General, or Parliament, today had an undertone of moderate optimism and made a favorable impression in financial circles, in contrast with the speech of last year.

William H. Fleet, Inc., a fur house at 52 East Thirteenth Street for thirty-two years, has leased for new quarters a store in 15-17 East Thirty-seventh Street. The Cross Brown Company was the broker. The fur firm, founded by William H. Fleet in 1875, had been previously in 92 Gold Street and 121 Mercer Street.

Operations of the Arnold Constable Corporation and subsidiary companies for the six months ended on July 31 were reported yesterday to have resulted in a profit of $26,087 after Federal income taxes and other deductions, equal to 8 cents a share on 337,109 shares of capital stock.

Accompanied by officials and prominent members of the Federation of Polish Jews in America, the Maccabees of Tel Aviv, soccer champions of Palestine, who arrived on Monday for a tour of North America, yesterday received an official welcome to New York from Mayor La Guardia at the City Hall.
LONDON, Sept. 15. -- The British Government today tried to bring the four smaller naval powers in the Baltic to accept the qualitative provisions of the new London naval treaty.

Naval architects and marine engineers of the United States, Great Britain, Germany, France, Italy, Japan and China discussed safety at sea, the construction of faster ships and allied problems yesterday at the opening of a two-day meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The National Park Service of the Department of the Interior has acquired its first airplane. When the Works Progress Administration turned over to the park service the beach erosion control project in the vicinity of Cape Hatteras, H.C., the equipment listed for transfer included an observation plane, powered by a 450-horsepower motor.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 15. -- John Haskell, secretary for the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange, told members of the Rhode Island Society of Certified Public Accountants tonight that although more information is available to the purchaser of listed securities today than ever before, the principle of "Let the buyer beware" does and should remain.

James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, minimized yesterday the Republican victory in Maine and at the same time disclosed that he would discuss here today with Governor Louis J. Brann of Maine all the problems raised by the election, including the possibility of a demand for a recount.

Louisville, Ky., awarded yesterday a new issue of $4,400,000 of 3 per cent refunding bonds to a banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., on a bid of 101.68 for a fixed rate of 3s. The bonds are dated Nov. 1, 1936, mature on Nov. 1, 1955, and will be re-offered at a price of 102 3/4.
Nearly 20,000 pheasants will have been liberated in Connecticut game covers before the start of the hunting season Oct. 20, according to an announcement by the State Board of Fisheries and Game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The living costs of wage earner families and lower salaried workers rose 1.7 per cent between April 15 and July 15, food rising 5.8 per cent on the average during the three months, Secretary Perkins stated today.

MADRID, Sept. 15. -- A new threat to this capital is being made by an insurgent advance up the Alberche River, but whether this is the beginning of General Francisco Franco's "big push" or is merely a demonstration following the weakening of the government's resistance on the far northern front is not yet determined.
BOSTON, Sept. 15. -- Governor James M. Curley won the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in the Massachusetts primaries tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- George Bernard Shaw was not surprised today, by the reaction yesterday to his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES bitterly assailing alleged objections of Catholics to the proposed film of his play, "Saint Joan."
