DETROIT, Sept. 15. -- Favored by ideal weather and an interest apparently surpassing that of any recent primary election in the State, about 1,000,000 Michigan voters expressed their preferences today on Republican and Democratic candidates for offices ranging from United States Senator to County Surveyor.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 15. -- Governor H. Styles Bridges defeated the come-back effort of former Senator George H. Moses for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate in New Hampshire's primaries tonight.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 15. -The colorful and efficient band of public links players, paced by two former national titleholders, Scotty Campbell and Frank Strafaci, provided some of the most spectacular shot making and furnished unquestionably some of the finest matches in the second round of the fortieth annual national amateur championship at the Garden City Golf Club today.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- A general rise in international issues in anticipation of activity in Wall Street following the Maine election stood out in today's trading on the London Stock Exchange. Otherwise the movements were quiet and irregular.

SEATTLE, Sept. 15 (AP). -- Philip Everhardt Armstrong, drama critic and one of two American Newspaper Guild members whose discharge caused a news-room strike, which closed The Post-Intelligencer Aug. 13, told the National Labor Relations Board today that he was let out for Guild activity.
MADRID, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The United States Embassy will be closed as a place of refuge next Tuesday, Eric Wendelin, third secretary, said tonight.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- It was reported in financial circles today that the German Government had acquired possession of a considerable block of shares in the Alpine Montan Gesellschaft, a giant Austrian steel and mining concern, through the payment by Italy of German coal deliveries during the last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Republicans in Washington today hailed the outcome of the Maine election as a decisive victory pointing to a national triumph, while Democrats countered with a declaration that Maine was merely again showing her fundamental Republicanism.

WHEN Louis Adamic was almost 15 he left his native village in what is now Yugoslavia and came to America. That was in 1913. In the interval he has served in the American Army, worked as laborer, factory hand, farmhand, dishwasher, dockworker and newspaper reporter, and, without benefit of formal schooling in this country, written a series of successful books in English, including the well-known "The Native's Return."

The death of OSSIP GABRILOWITSCH is a grievous loss to music and his countless friends and audiences on both sides of the Atlantic. He was a consummate artist, and more. His character was compact of humanity, nobility, and candor. These things found exemplification in his music.

The engagement of $4,053,000 gold in France for shipment here was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank also reported the engagement of $247,000 gold in India. Including these engagements the total of gold taken abroad since Aug. 7, when the current movement from France began, amounts to 116,900,000 of which $80,300,000 has been obtained in France.

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Sept. 15. -- Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, general manager of Eastern Air Lines, announced this afternoon that he would sail from Conception Bay tonight for Musgrave Harbor in a motor launch with spare parts and gasoline for the transatlantic plane of Henry T. (Dick) Merrill and Harry Richman, who landed in a bog on the northeastern shore of Newfoundland yesterday afternoon in a storm after flying from Southport, England.

Urging the complete organization of labor in a permanent political party to carry on its own work after the national election, Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, pledged yesterday the full support of his union in an effort to increase by 1,000,000 the membership of the United Textile Workers of America.
The closing date for submission of manuscripts in the contest for a short American symphonic work, which is sponsored by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, is Oct. 1.
ALBANY, Sept. 15. -- Constitution Day and General von Steuben Day were proclaimed by Governor Lehman today, both occurring on Thursday.

Business failures declined in the manufacturing, wholesale and retail groups in the five days ended Sept. 10 in comparison with the previous full business week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The number of failures in retail lines was fifty-seven lower than the thirty-seven weeks' average for the group.

Republican leaders in the East joined yesterday in a chorus of jubilant comment on the Republican triumph in Maine, hailing it as a repudiation of the New Deal and the forerunner of a victory for Governor Landon at the general election.

Dressed in colonial costume, with taffeta ruffles and white lace bertha beneath a snow-white wig, Mrs. Clarence N. Titterington, regent of the Mary Murray Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, participated yesterday morning in an outdoor ceremony to commemorate the 160th anniversary of a "reception" to British officers and soldiers by Mary Murray, wife of a Quaker merchant after whom the East Side's Murray Hill is named.

VIENNA, Sept. 15. -- The present sojourn of Dr. Guido Schmidt, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, in Rome, has for its object the presentation of a complaint from Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg to Premier Benito Mussolini that the Austro-German pact of July 11 is proving to be useless, it was said in Little Entente circles today.

In one of the most thrilling stretch duels staged during the meeting, the Orienta Stable's Emileo got his nose in front in the last stride to beat Mrs. Marian Cassidy's Bill Farnsworth and capture the Charade Handicap at seven furlongs, feature of the card at Aqueduct yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Vic Oliver, actor, who, according to London dispatches, plans to marry Miss Sarah Churchill, when she arrives in America aboard the Bremen, appeared at the Palace Theatre here late last month as the star of a revue, "Follow the Stars."

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Larger receipts of new-crop holdings and a slow demand for fresh pork were responsible for a decline today of 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight in the market for hogs, with some new-crop offerings of medium quality down 35 to 50 cents in late trading.

NOROTON, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Winthrop Neilson and Mrs. Lynford McCall Dickinson gave a dance tonight at the Wee Burn Club here to introduce to society Miss Emily Harold Alsop, daughter of Mrs. Neilson, and Miss Lynda Louise Dickinson, daughter of Mrs. Dickinson. Before the event Miss Mollie Cummings gave a dinner for the debutantes at the Round Hill Club, Greenwich.
The closing date for submission of manuscripts in the contest for a short American symphonic work, which is sponsored by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, is Oct. 1.
ALBANY, Sept. 15. -- Constitution Day and General von Steuben Day were proclaimed by Governor Lehman today, both occurring on Thursday.

Business failures declined in the manufacturing, wholesale and retail groups in the five days ended Sept. 10 in comparison with the previous full business week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The number of failures in retail lines was fifty-seven lower than the thirty-seven weeks' average for the group.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Vic Oliver, actor, who, according to London dispatches, plans to marry Miss Sarah Churchill, when she arrives in America aboard the Bremen, appeared at the Palace Theatre here late last month as the star of a revue, "Follow the Stars."

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Larger receipts of new-crop holdings and a slow demand for fresh pork were responsible for a decline today of 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight in the market for hogs, with some new-crop offerings of medium quality down 35 to 50 cents in late trading.

NOROTON, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Winthrop Neilson and Mrs. Lynford McCall Dickinson gave a dance tonight at the Wee Burn Club here to introduce to society Miss Emily Harold Alsop, daughter of Mrs. Neilson, and Miss Lynda Louise Dickinson, daughter of Mrs. Dickinson. Before the event Miss Mollie Cummings gave a dinner for the debutantes at the Round Hill Club, Greenwich.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
Vice President John N. Garner arrived here last night and tonight he will address a gathering of invited Democrats at a private dinner at the Hotel Biltmore.

The local commodity futures markets were unsettled yesterday, with trading occasionally brisk and a break in cocoa prices after about four months of advancing prices was the feature of the day. On the cash markets corn, rye and rubber gained, while oats, lard, tin, silk and cotton declined.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 15. -After an opening session of attacks on the New Deal, delegates to the Financial Advertisers Association's convention here were told today that there would be public regulation of banks, regardless of who was elected President or who ran Congress. This assertion was made in an address by Carlton K. Matson, editor-in-chief of The Toledo News-Bee.
The five Democratic county organizations in the city emerged victorious in virtually every contest in yesterday's primary election, returns at 3 o'clock this morning indicated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The Treasury Department made public today a statement of allotments by Federal Reserve districts of cash and exchange subscriptions received for its recent offering of 2 3/4 per cent bonds that will mature in twenty-three years.

DETROIT, Wednesday, Sept. 16. -- Unless his home city of Detroit should come to his rescue with a two-to-one majority or better, which did not seem likely early this morning, Senator James Couzens appeared doomed early today to defeat for renomination to the Senate as a Republican after having announced his support for the reelection of President Roosevelt.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 15. -- The restoration of pay to the level of 1932, before the first cut of 6 per cent was effected, for all employes of the Public Service Corporation, Public Service Electric and Gas Company, Public Service Co-ordinated Transport and Public Service Interstate Transportation Company, with the exception of higher paid officials was voted today by the board of directors of Public Service. The higher pay schedule becomes effective Oct. 1.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 15. -- Mrs. Carl A. de Gersdorff was hostess today to the Lenox Garden Club, of which she is president, in celebration of its twenty-fifth anniversary. Several charter members, who were dressed in costumes of the period of 1911, related reminiscences of the early days of the club, which was formed at the Summer home of the late Thomas Shields Clarke, the sculptor.

SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Sept. 15. -- Spanish Government firing squads tonight snuffed out an attempted revolt of the Bilbao garrison. Sixty-two officers who had tried to lead their men to join the Rebel armies were shot by militiamen in the court yard of the Bilbao military prison, it was learned through diplomatic dispatches.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens yesterday began resubmitting the Donnelly case to the grand jury. Mr. Sullivan is to resubmit the entire case and the published charges of laxity made against him by The New York Post.

The mythical average American was credited on the Government's books with $48.43 in cash on the first day of September. This is the Treasury's figure of the per capita "money in circulation" on that date.

George Frank Hasslacher, 40 years old, of Short Hills, N.J., a member of the firm of Snyder MacLaren Processes, Inc., at 10 East Fortieth Street, was killed at 4:30 P.M. yesterday when he plunged sixteen floors from the twenty-third floor of the Fortieth Street address to the roof of the Arnold Constable department store at 453 Fifth Avenue.

BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP). -- The defunct Amoskeag Manufacturing Company's huge Manchester (N.H.) textile mill, one of the largest in the world, became today the property of a group of Manchester citizens for $5,000,000.

The dead line was reached last midnight for entries for the 400-mile international George Vanderbilt Cup road race, which will open the Roosevelt Raceway on Oct. 12. Fifty-seven cars were named and about twenty more are expected to come within the time limit due to the allowance made for last-minute mailing.

General and Mrs. Ballington Booth, founders and commanders of the Volunteers of America, will celebrate their golden wedding anniversary today. The occasion also will mark the fortieth anniversary of the Volunteers of America, which has welfare centers in 200 cities throughout the United States.

The significance of the Nuremberg Congress is that it expressed the mind that rules Germany. The speeches of Chancellor HITLER, Dr. GOEBBELS, Dr. ROSENBERG, Dr. LEY and other leaders of the National Socialist party were the prepared and considered utterances of a Government in power.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- Rain and cold weather resulted in a light vote in the primary throughout Rockland County today. Reports that Mrs. Minnie Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Public Welfare, was the recipient of many writtenin votes for the office on the Republican ticket against Charles I. Allen of Sloatsburg resulted in Republican workers being called out in force to aid the cause of Allen, the designated candidate.

GALES FERRY, Conn., Sept. 15. -- With sixty-four of the sixty-five Yale football players ordered to report for the first practice on hand, Head Coach Ducky Pond today organized four elevens and drilled them under threatening skies but on a dry playing field four hours, divided equally between morning and afternoon.

Take it from some of the city's shrewdest purchasers of secondhand articles, sky-high prices have replaced bargains, all because business has improved to such an extent that there has been a 50 per cent drop in bankruptcy sales, causing a shortage of damaged items.

Kurt Bjorkvall, pilot for the Baroness Eve Von Blixen-Finecke, who is planning a non-stop flight from Floyd Bennett Field to Stockholm within the next few days, made two load tests yesterday afternoon with the Baroness's Bellanca monoplane. He flew to Floyd Bennett Field in the morning and returned to Roosevelt Field last night.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 15. -- Julius Streicher again employed the opportunity provided by a Nazi party congress to further his plans for an international, not simply a German, campaign against Jews.

William Church Osborn, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, urged yesterday that abrogation in part of the city employes' pay cuts, as contemplated by the Board of Estimate should be deferred until the city tax burden is eased.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 15. -- Maine had reasserted its usual allegiance to the Republican party tonight as returns from yesterday's election became nearly complete.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,020,850 barrels, compared to 3,008,550 in the previous week, an increase of 12,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 17,600 barrels in the daily output of California and a decline of 17,100 in Texas were the important changes.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Sept. 15. -- All day today Nuremberg has been in the throes of a mighty exodus. Moving half a million persons is no light matter. Throughout last night the tread of the heavy boots of departing battalions resounded through the ancient streets and the railway stations rang with the music of their marching songs.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- Following Germany's example of yesterday, the Italian Ambassador, Dino Grandi, informed the British Foreign Office today that his government thought the middle of October too soon for a conference of the Locarno powers as it would not allow sufficient time for preparatory diplomatic negotiations.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 15. -- Miss Karen Marie Chambaud Conze, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Henry Conze, and Miss Dorita Frances Robinson, daughter of Mrs. Watson Bryant Robinson, made their debuts at a joint supper dance given by their parents at the Beach Club, Belle Haven, tonight. About 400 guests attended.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Working in a secret, draftless office, twelve Senate investigators were completing today a jigg-saw puzzle composed of thousands of scraps of torn paper.

When the nip of Autumn is in the air and keen winds toss the combers high, it is time for the gathering of the surf fishing clans. Then you will find the lonely beaches dotted with hardy fellows who scoff at gale, rain and cold as they wait for the thrill of feeling a line come taut.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 16. -- A dangerous tropical hurricane moved through the Atlantic Ocean tonight in the general direction of Cape Hatteras, N.C.

ELVAS, Portugal, Sept. 16. -- The Madrid government declared today that the junction village of Maqueda, the key to Toledo and Madrid, must be the Verdun of the Spanish revolt as Loyalist reinforcements rushed to that sector slowed down the advance of General Francisco Franco's Foreign Legion and Moors.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Prices of hogs declined 10 to 25 cents today, weights under 200 pounds leading the drop. The top for load lots at $10.75 was 15 cents lower, and in the final trading it was hard to obtain more than $10.60 for the best offerings.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Virtually complete returns today disclosed that Governor Philip F. La Follette and his 2-year-old Progressive party scored gains in yesterday's Wisconsin primary.

In a jittery world Secretary of State HULL'S restrained and thoughtful address before the Good Neighbor League last Tuesday night can have only a quieting effect. Again, as throughout his public career, he illustrated in his own personality those qualities "of pa-"tience, of sympathetic understanding, "of steady poise and of assured inner "strength" which he believes requisite in a people if their Government is to have a satisfactory foreign policy.

BOSTON. Sept. 16 (AP). -- Governor James M. Curley and Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. stood arrayed against each other tonight for Massachusetts' second seat in the United States Senate. The State's Chief Executive had a margin of more than 100,000 votes over the combined total of two opponents to win the Democratic nomination.

Last night at sundown Jews throughout the world celebrated the advent of a New Year -- the year 5,697 in the Hebrew calendar. New York's Jewry filled the synagogues of the city and millions worshiped in their temples where prayers were said and psalms were sung.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 16. The Financial Advertisers Association heard today three New Yorkers on advertising and banking and elected the following officers: Thomas J. Kiphart, Cincinnati, president; William H. Neal, Winston-Salem, N. C., first vice president; George O. Everett, Utica, N.Y., second vice president; Stephen H. Fifeld, Jacksonville, Fla., third vice president, and Fred W. Mathison, Chicago, treasurer.

Purchase of Dey Brothers, Syracuse department store, by the Allied Stores Corporation was announced yesterday by B. Earl Puckett, president of the corporation. The store began operation under the new ownership yesterday, following consummation of the deal on Tuesday in Syracuse.

Opposition to centralization of city government was expressed by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens in a debate with Walter J. Millard, field secretary of the National Municipal League, on the proposed City Charter at a luncheon meeting of the West of Central Park Association yesterday at the Circle Club, 1,819 Broadway.

GENEVA, Sept. 16. -- The Austrian Minister of Finance, Ludwig Draxler, formally asked the League's finance committee today to abolish the post of League representative with the Austrian Government and adviser to the National Austrian Bank.

In an English play which was popular some years ago a Cabinet Minister was reminded by his secretary that he had agreed to dedicate a new bridge the next day. Then came this colloquy: "You have my speech ready?" "Certainly." "The usual thing, I suppose?" "Yes, sir, quite the usual thing."

It would have been better had we postponed our editorial comment on man's increasing part in determining the future of the race until the arrival of the remarkably illuminating and entertaining lecture by Professor HOOTON at the tercentenary celebration of the Harvard Dental School on "Man as a Director of Human Evolution," extensive extracts from which were published in yesterday's TIMES.

The information given to the President on Tuesday by the life insurance companies, that their assets had risen from $20,900,000,000 at the beginning of 1933 to $23,915,000,000 this year, was interesting for what it showed regarding both the progress of the insurance business and the nation's financial recovery.

When Colonel Bill Terry and his pace-setting Giants prance into Ebbets Field today they will be facing a double hazard, for yesterday Professor Stengel's superheated Dodgers, who are hard for the Giants to take at any time, took a double-header from the Reds and thereby achieved their eleventh three-game winning streak of the season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- President Roosevelt, in a letter to Secretary Roper made public by the Commerce Department today, expressed the hope that Federal, State and municipal agencies would cooperate in the observance of "Air Progress," as planned by the National Aeronautic Association.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Thursday, Sept. 17. -- Two Albany girls and a youth died in South Nassau Community Hospital early this morning of injuries received late last night when the automobile in which they were riding was struck by a train of the Long Island Railroad at the Merrick Road crossing here.

Not only as a trustee of the Brooklyn Public Library and a member of its book committee, but in a larger sense, speaking in behalf of the people of Brooklyn, I believe that the library's request for $250,000 for books in the 1937 budget should be granted.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Experiments in which the undeveloped teeth of a rat embryo were transplanted and made to grow in the hind leg of the mother animal, were described here today before the tercentenary session of the Harvard Dental School and the Harvard Dental Alumni Association.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- As the first half of the field of veterans competing for the United States senior golf championship completed their thirty-six holes of play today over the Apawamis course, Christopher W. Deibel, 1935 champion, from Youngstown, Ohio, led with a gross score of 155.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- An increase described as "noteworthy" by the Department of Commerce was reported today in Cuba's export trade with the United States in fresh fruits and vegetables during the current year, as compared with 1935.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- The world's wheat price level continued to mount today on the crest of an aggressive demand from European importing countries for supplies of Canadian grain. Winnipeg led the upturn, and at the top the October delivery showed a gain of more than 3 cents a bushel, as compared with Tuesday's finish.
TOPEKA, Sept. 16. -- The Landons had a family reunion today, telling each other of experiences since the nominee set out nearly a month ago on his first campaign tour.

The engagement of $2,910,000 gold abroad, $1,665,000 in France and $1,245,000 in England for shipment here was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the gold reported taken in France, however, $1,125,000 was obtained late Tuesday, making the amount engaged yesterday only $540,000, the smallest in several days.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 16. -- By an over,vhelming vote the International Typographical Union convention defeated today a proposal to endorse the Townsend plan.

Henry L. Doherty and the directors of his organizations, the Cities Service Company and the Cities Service Securities Company, are defendants in a suit for $18,000,000 brought by Morton Marks, a stockholder in Cities Service, in behalf of himself and other stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- A "remarkable" recovery from losses sustained in the period from 1929 to 1933 was reflected in the first tabulations reported for the Retail Business Census for 1935, Secretary Roper said today at his weekly press conference.

TYLER HILL, Pa., Sept. 16. -- For one who set a standard on the playing field that has seldom been equaled and who won all-America laurels in one of the hottest crucibles of football, the Big Ten, Benny Friedman has an amazing amount of enthusiasm and faith in working with youngsters starting in the game with practically nothing but the eagerness of youth and the will to learn.

Representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association and the deep-sea ship lines operating from Atlantic ports conferred yesterday morning and last night at the Maritime Exchange Building on the demands of the longshoremen for a new wage contract.

ROBERT P. TRISTRAM COFFIN writes of men as Conrad wrote of women. Readers of Conrad never learned much about women from him save that they were lovely and extremely feminine. His heroines were women mirrored in water. Readers of Coffin will learn comparable facts concerning the men of old Maine. It seems that they were handsome and extremely masculine.

As is the traditional custom, nine Yiddish theatres in the metropolitan area will officially begin their seasons today, the first day of Rosh ha-Shanah. Four of these houses are in Manhattan, two are in the Bronx and three are in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had issued a stop order suspending the effectiveness of a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Gold Hill Operating Company of Tacoma, Wash.
CAPE MAY, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Daily demonstrations of a new type landing boat for the United States Marine Corps are being made in Cape May harbor by Colonel M.P. Depassos of the War Department.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 16. -- The intensive practice which ushered in Yale's football training campaign yesterday was duplicated today. There were morning and afternoon sessions.

Paul Reynaud, former Finance Minister of France and now a member of the French Chamber of Deputies, who arrived last week to read a paper at the Harvard Tercentenary, sailed yesterday on the Normandie, hurrying back to France because of the illness of his wife in Paris.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 16. -- The biggest deal in lumber and timber in British Columbia in more than a decade was completed today with the announcement that the Canadian White Pine Company, a subsidiary of the H.R. MacMillan organization, had bought for approximately $4,000,000 the assets of the Alberni Pacific Lumber Company along with 1,000,000,000 feet of timber in the Alberni Canal area on Vancouver Island.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Trading was cheerful today on the London Stock Exchange, although the volume of business remained small. British Government securities were in good demand, and their prices made further fractional gains.
With only two weeks remaining before the start of the new rental season on Oct. 1, apartment leasings continued in volume yesterday, with both the East and West Sides well represented.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 16. -- Addressing one of the largest groups ever gathered to hear any one scientist on his specialty, Professor H. J. Fleure, distinguished anthropologist, discussed today the question of race, which subject has occupied more than one section of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

The State of Maine split three ways yesterday in the award of $2,900,000 of bonds. A group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and including Hallgarten Co., Kean, Taylor Co., Hemphill, Noyes Co., George B. Gibbons Co., Inc.; Starkweather Co., Inc., and F.L. Putnam Co., Inc., obtained $1,525,000 of 2 per cent improvement bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1937 to 1956, on a bid of 101.178.

Continuance of the present rate of ingot production in the steeel industry, 72 per cent of capacity, is assured until the end of October, at least, according to the weekly summary of The Iron Age, issued yesterday. The current rate is 2 points above that of last week.

Vice President John N. Garner made his first campaign appearance since his renomination when he addressed a private gathering of Democratic leaders and prominent business and financial supporters of President Roosevelt at the Hotel Biltmore last night.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's declaration at Nuremberg that Germany would never relinquish her colonial claims has furnished the text for one of the main topics to be debated at the Conservative conference Oct. 1. The official forecast of this party meeting, issued today, puts the question of mandates and colonies in the most conspicuous place on the agenda.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The total of bonus bond redemptions by postoffices and the Treasurer's office through Sept. 12 was $1,227,647,100, the Treasury announced today, indicating, it said, that about 70 per cent of the total bonus bonds issued had been redeemed and 30 per cent are being retained by the veterans.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Six industrial leaders have sent a joint letter to President Conant of Harvard calling public attention to the indebtedness of American industry to the universities.

TOKYO, Sept. 16. -- A peace conference under Japan's leadership that would inaugurate a new league of nations, based on self-denying principles excluding territorial conquest and national spheres of influence or trade wars, is proposed by the Shiunso (literally "purple cloud") society.

Plans of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers to entertain maritime technicians of several nations who have been in session in this city for two days have been changed at the behest of the Navy Department, it was learned yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16. -- President Roosevelt received today the unanimous endorsement for re-election of the New Jersey Federation of Labor. At the fifty-eighth annual convention in the Hotel Ritz-Carlton here, the federation adopted by acclamation a resolution endorsing his candidacy, but somewhere in the back of the hall there was one lone unidentified "nay."

Senator COUZENS has many excellent qualities, tempered sometimes with a curious vindictiveness. It is no disparagement of those qualities to say that he is what the Yankees used to call "an off ox." He might have had the Democratic nomination, it is said, but he wouldn't take it.
Six water-colors by Epstein and an oil by Cezanne will be shown at the Howard Young Galleries, beginning Monday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 . -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, investigating the origins and operations of investment trusts and investment companies, delved today into the investment-trust operations of two New York Stock Exchange houses: Dominick Dominick arurl Sulzbacher, Granger Co.

Credit collections during August showed a decrease of 0.27 per cent,' according to the index of twenty local key stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. Eight of the twenty stores reported increases for the month over 1935, the average being 39.43, against 39.16 last year.

An appropriation of S24,052,397 for the Hospital Department in 1937, an increase of $2,709,733 over the 1936 allotment, was asked yesterday by Hospital Commissioner S.S. Goldwater at a hearing before Budget Director Leo J. McDermott.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- A warning to merchants against posting notices inaccurately ascribing part of retail price increases to Federal taxes was given by Attorney General Cummings today.

The first public intimation that the Securities and Exchange Commission was looking into the advisability of recommending to Congress the divorcement of banking houses and brokerage firms from any investment trusts which they have sponsored came yesterday.

President Roosevelt is making gains in the Presidential poll taken among, small-town and farmer voters by some 3,000 weekly newspapers under the auspices of The American Press and the Publishers Autocaster Service.

Leon Trotsky attacks Stalin in a letter written at Honefoss, Norway, on Aug. 23 and sent to his American publishers, Simon Schustert. He introduces what he says are quotations from Lenin to support his own points.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Governor Lehman refused today to supersede District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens for the latter's alleged failure to prosecute properly Police Sergeant Frank X. Donnelly, charged with killing his wife.

Mortimer L. Nathanson, secretary of the National Association of Insurance Brokers, made public yesterday a telegram to Colonel Knox and John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, challenging them to produce figures to prove Colonel Knox's statement that "today no life insurance policy is secure" or else make public retraction.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 16. -- The mightiest rush Discovery has ever made ended in defeat today when he was beaten a head by Rosemont before 30,000 persons at the end of the mile and three-sixteenths of the Narragansett Special.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 16. -- The storm that sank the Pourquoi-Pas was so severe it sent all shipping around Iceland scurrying into the harbor and blew down telegraph and telephone lines from Seydisfjord, on the northeast part of the island, to Reykjavik.

Commodity prices were generally higher yesterday, although price changes were mostly small. Crude rubber and rawhide futures showed the largest gains. In the cash markets all grains and rubber were higher and lard, tin, cotton and raw sugar were lower.

This day marks the 149th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution of the United States by the convention which created it. The great charter of the nation is a living document, adaptable through reinterpretation and amendment to the changing needs of changing times.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- One hundred and twelve retired officers of the navy and marine corps were recommended for promotion on the retired list today by the Permanent Board of Awards of the Navy Department as officers who were commended by the head of an executive department for performance of duty during the World War.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- Vincent Auriol, Finance Minister, in an interview given to the French press last evening made such reassuring statements regarding the attitude of the government toward private property and liberty of capital that the Bourse took new heart today and there resulted a recovery in prices that was almost spectacular.

The course of least resistance yesterday in all classes of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was toward moderately lower levels. Several notable exceptions were apparent, however, particularly in the industrial group. There was little change in the volume of trading, transactions amounting to $10,372,000, compared with $9,543,400 on Tuesday.

This does not appear to be a good year for independent candidacies. With party lines tightening in preparation for the Presidential election, and with the organization machinery running at full efficiency, the defeat of regular nominees is uncommonly difficult. This was well shown to be true in the New York City primary of Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- Republicans and Democrats made gains at yesterday's registration in this city, the second of three enrollment days for the November election. The Democratic increases were the larger.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Captain Roland M. Litchfield of the coastal steamer New York, told a Federal Board today that the collision between his vessel and the Romance in Boston Harbor during a fog on Sept. 9 probably could have been averted if the Romance had had a radio in operation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- In another move to assure farmers in the drought areas a start on their 1937 crops, Secretary Wallace announced today that $10,000,000 had been made available for seed corn loans so that adequate supplies of seed corn will be planted in the Corn Belt.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 16. -- One fact was definitely determined in the course of today's double round in the national amateur championship at the Garden City Golf Club. No former winner is going to succeed Lawson Little as the titleholder.

TOULON, France, Sept. 16. -- The key to an understanding of events in Spain is the fact that, in the four great cities of Madrid, Barcelona, Valencia and Malaga, where the rebellion was suppressed, the suppression was accomplished not by government troops or by the Civil Guards, but by armed workers.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, yesterday urged the convention of the United Textile Workers to carry the fight in the American Federation of Labor between craft and industrial unions which led to the suspension of the unions in the C.I.O., to the membership of the federation.

DENHAM, in Buckinghamshire, England, Sept. 16. -- Catholic objections to the filming of George Bernard Shaw's "St. Joan" have been virtually overcome, it was announced today by Dr. Paul Czinner, motion picture director and husband of Elisabeth Bergner, who will play the title role.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech last night on the neutrality and friendly neighbor policy of the United States finds decided approval at the German Foreign Ministry but apparently fails to arouse any very intense enthusiasm.

The share market was able to muster little enthusiasm on the side of the advance yesterday. Selling was not particularly heavy in any section of the list, but the demand was rather slow and prices sagged most of the day. The closing was lower, with many of the leaders off from fractions to as much as 3 points.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- A contention that the principle of religious liberty is involved in efforts of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America to prevent the use of the name Presbyterian by seceding Fundamentalists is included in a preliminary answer to a bill of complaint filed in Common Pleas Court here.

Vic Oliver, Viennese-American musical and vaudeville comedian, denied emphatically yesterday that he was going to marry Miss Sarah Churchill, actress and daughter of Winston Churchill, a former British Chancellor of the Exchequer.
DENVER, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Men who fought America's foreign wars cheered violently today as a major general and a Senator called warfare "a business racket."

MADRID, Sept. 16 (Passed by the Censor). -- "Foreign aid for the militancy insurgents is only prolonging the Spanish civil war. The Madrid government is sure of victory because it has the support of the mass of the people."

Declaring that New York State has been governed as the tail of the New Deal kite, Senator George R. Fearon, candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, last night demanded the defeat of Governor Lehman so that the State could be run in the interests of the people and not for the "brain trusters at Washington."

One of the greatest religious demonstrations in American history will start here today when the third annual Holy Name National Convention opens its four-day meetings with a solemn pontifical mass at 10 A.M. in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 16. -- Mrs. Dudley Roberts entertained at tea this afternoon at her home on Further Lane in honor of Miss Mary Sandall, the psychologist, who is her house guest. Miss Sandall spoke on "The Tyranny of Moods and Their Control."

TWO internationalists have been added to the squad which is to defend the Cup of the Americas against the challenge of Argentina when the polo series starts at the Meadow Brook Club on Saturday. Stewart B. Iglehart and Winston F.C. Guest were named yesterday as substitutes for the team which will represent this country.

Julian Wood, a deputy city tax commissioner, who in pre-Fusion days held two other jobs in addition to his city post, was dismissed from the city service yesterday by the Board of Taxes and Assessments. The board's action followed a two-hour hearing at which Wood failed to explain away his triple job-holding.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Insurance advertising executives, at the closing session of the fourteenth annual meeting of the Insurance Advertising Conference at the Westchester Country Club, voted today without dissent to cooperate with the New York City Police Department in automobile-safety work.

SEATTLE, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Business men asked immediate action tonight of the Seattle Central Labor Council toward ending a newsroom strike on The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, the management of which announced that "any plans for abandonment of the plant have been held in abeyance at the request of business interests."

TOPEKA, Sept. 16. -- Senator Rush D. Holt, Democrat, of West Virginia, who broke with his party organization because of dissatisfaction with the administration of WPA projects in his State, lunched with Governor and Mrs. Landon at the Executive Mansion today.

ATLANTA, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Whether football is a private business or a part of the educational program was argued by attorneys today in a suit of the university system of Georgia to enjoin the Federal Government from collecting taxes on athletic admissions.

MADIRID, Sept. 16. -- Anti-aircraft batteries, the government announced tonight, shot several huge insurgent bombing planes out of the skies over Magueda and Santa Olalla, forty-five miles from Madrid.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The discovery of liquids which have properties closely akin to human tissue, in ionization by X-rays and radium, has been reported to the Commerce Department by Dr. Lauriston S. Taylor of the Bureau of Standards.

The many sanctimonious words that various politicians and "leaders" are uttering about the threatened milk strike bring out two points very clearly -- namely, that farmers are being paid too little for milk and consumers are paying too much. The annoying thing is that none of them seems willing to ask where the money goes and what happens to milk during its journey from barn to doorstep.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16. -- The Cardinals executed a triple play while losing the opener today to the Phillies, 7 to 3, and came back with a belated hitting parade in the nightcap to win, 5 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Nominations for the Senate and House were completed by yesterday's primaries except in Rhode Island, and party managers began making ready today for the final stretch of the Presidential campaign.

SALINAS, Calif., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Scores of special deputy sheriffs chosen from all the town's able-bodied citizens, armed themselves with wagon spokes and guns late today and began a drive to rid the city of all pickets in a twelve-day-old strike of lettuce workers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Creation of a government bureau to deal with educational problems associated with "prevention and alleviation of crime" was advocated today by John W. Studebaker, Federal Commissioner of Education, in a speech before the American Prison Association.

R.S.K. Irvin, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, writes of the regrettable situation which places "the fortunes of our shipping industry * * * at the mercy of irresponsible and radical labor leaders."

ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- Publication recently in a weekly periodical of a report that two companies regularly obtained lists of automobile owners in the State from the registration files of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles led today to inquiry at the bureau.

TRENTON, Sept. 16. -- After being questioned continuously for two days, Ramon Cota, 45 years old, a Mexican musician, who is said to be a deserter from the United States Army, confessed this morning to having killed his wife and led police to her body buried in a pit under his home in the suburbs of this city for four months.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia arrives today from Mediterranean ports, bringing among her passengers the former Queen Victoria of Spain. The Queen is coming here to be with her son, Alfonso de Borbon, the Count of Covadonga, who has been ill.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16. -- World scholarship convened in an impressive pageantry of gleaming badges and brilliant cloaks of authority this afternoon for the Harvard tercentenary celebration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- President Roosevelt scheduled another major speech today -- at Pittsburgh Oct. 1 -- after a series of conferences at which his attention was focused on national and international waterways.

The Giants, holding a four-and-a-half-game lead over the Cardinals and a five-game margin on the Cubs, can clinch the National League pennant by winning seven of their remaining eleven games, even though the second-place St. Louisians capture all of their ten games.
Civic leaders making their ninth annual tour of Bronx parks, highways and recreational facilities yesterday found more extensive improvements under way than at any time during the last fifteen years.
The weekly weather report of crop condition was issued yesterday by the United States Weather Bureau, as follows:

Mayor La Guardia and a party of city officials ,will leave for Cleveland Sunday morning to ask members of the American Legion convening there to hold the 1937 convention in New York City. The Mayor is strongly interested in having next year's convention come to New York, since it will mark the twentieth anniversary of this country's entrance into the World War.
CAMBRIDGE, Sept. 16. -- The address of W.L. Clayton today before the Harvard Business School Alumni Association in connection with the Harvard tercentenary was as follows:

The start of a general price advance in the cotton towel field took place yesterday when a number of leading mills advanced quotations 5 to 7 1/2 per cent. The new prices covered deliveries until the end of the year only, as most manufacturers were unwilling to take business for 1937 even at the higher levels.
TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 16. -- Tons of TNT, it was reliably learned tonight, at any moment may blow to bits the 1,700 men, women and children in the besieged Alcazar Fortress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Application for Federal permission to fly the Burnelli all-metal monoplane from New York to England on or before Oct. 15 has been flied with the Bureau of Air Commerce of the Department of Commerce by the designer and builder, Vincent Burnelli.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Democratic officials of this city began a legal action today to prevent submission of the proposed new Nassau County charter to the voters next Nov. 3.

The prospect of wholesale lay-offs among the non-relief personnel of the four Federal art projects vanished yesterday when Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator, received certificates of need signed by 80 per cent of the 2,449 non-relief workers on the projects.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Recognition of the existence of abuses in the American economic system and their substantial correction is one of two essentials for preservation of the system, the tercentenary meeting of the Harvard Business School Alumni Association was told here today by William L. Clayton, head of Anderson, Clayton Co. of Houston, the world's largest cotton-buying firm.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting, defending champion, and Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews, former titleholder, continued their march toward a final-round meeting in the fourteenth annual women's New Jersey State golf championship when both won second-round matches by wide margins at the Echo Lake Country Club today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Hal Trosky drove his forty-first home run of the season as the Indians bunched fourteen hits to crush the Red Sox today, 13 to 3. The game was called because of rain at the end of the sixth inning.

Testers of popular political sentiment in this country -- straw-poll takers, political managers and orators -- came last Winter to the conclusion that, despite the smashing Democratic victories of 1932 and 1934, the Republicans were on their way back to major party status.

Feeling now reasonably secure that they will bring the second half of the 1936 world series to New York, the Giants announced yesterday they were ready to receive reserved seat ticket applications for their expected joust with the Yankees.

The Navy and Marine Memorial Association, organized some years ago to erect a monument in Washington, D.C., as a memorial to sailors and marines in the service of the United States and all Americans who lost their lives at sea, failed yesterday to defend a suit by Begni Del Piatta, sculptor, for a balance of $73,294 due on a contract by which he was to receive $175,000 for the work.

READING, Pa., Sept. 16. -- The bay colt Pinero, 2:05 1/2, by Guy Day -- Pongee Silk, owned by Thomas I. Havens of Flanders, N.Y., captured the eleventh renewal of the Reading Fair Futurity for 3-year-old trotters, the feature of today's Grand Circuit harness-racing card.

Charles W. Kellogg, president of the Edison Electric Institute, issued yesterday a statement in which he disregarded the assertions made by President Roosevelt to the World Power Conference on the cost of electricity. President Roosevelt quoted a statement by the late Charles P. Steinmetz in support of his contentions.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 16. -- Quartermaster Eugene Gonedec, only survivor of the sinking of the French polar research ship Pourquoi-Pas, told of the disaster today when he had recovered sufficiently.

A medical career that promised to equal that of his illustrious father was broken off abruptly when Dr. Jean Charcot forsook his profession and succumbed to the lure of exploration. He had been the head of the clinics at the faculty of medicine of the University of Paris and had served with the Pasteur Institute, when, in 1903, he started for the Antarctic on his first expedition, aboard the small vessel Francais.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Cornelius Shields's Aileen led a fleet of seven boats home in the regular weekly Long Island Sound Interclub Class series conducted by the Larchmont Y.C. today.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 16. -- Catalan Leftists have shown a tendency toward unified war control because of the promise of a long, bitter struggle. Catalans have sent troops to aid Madrid and there is a tendency toward closer relations with the central government because Catalonia and the rest of Spain can scarcely escape a common fortune.

A dividend of $1.75 a share on account of accruals on $3.50 preferred stock was declared yesterday by the A.C. Gilbert Company, clearing up arrears on the issue. The regular quarterly dividend of 87 1/2 cents on the preferred was also voted.

Two arrests were made last night in connection with the disappearance four months ago of more than $104,949 worth of securities that had been left unguarded for seven minutes on a desk in the mailing room of the brokerage firm of Shields Co. on the twentieth floor of the Bank of America Building at 44 Wall Street.

BERLIN, Sept. 16 -- The ]3oerse be- I came firmer today, being able toI recover part of the losses sufferedI during the reaction yesterday, butI the turnover remained small. Gains I in stocks frequently xceeded a I point, although individual losses I were recorded a/so.
Launching of the United States Navy destroyer Fanning was postponed indefinitely yesterday because of a "sit-down" strike in the Staten Island plant of the United Shipyards, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- President Roosevelt expects the Senate, at its session starting in January, to ratify a new treaty with Canada to provide for construction of the St. Lawrence waterway, he indicated today in a letter to the National Seaway Council, emphasizing his confidence also in conversations with council representatives.

The Giants' dash to their expected National League pennant was reduced to half speed yesterday, when the Pirates moved into the Polo Grounds to offer a lot of stout resistance that was not exactly appreciated by any one in another gala week-day crowd of 22,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- The European squadron was ordered re-created by the Navy Department today after a lapse of seven years. The Spanish situation and disturbed European conditions generally were the causes of this action.

Leon Blum, Premier of France, declares in an article published in the current issue of The American Hebrew that loyalty to Judaism need not impair the patriotism of Jews. His article makes a plea for Zionism to provide a refuge for victims of intolerance and persecution.

Charges made before the Board of Aldermen last Winter that aliens were receiving preference over citizens in the granting of home and work relief and that Negroes were being discriminated against were contradicted by an Emergency Relief Bureau survey yesterday.

The Dowager Marchioness of Reading, whose husband, the Marquess of Reading, died last December, has just completed a 10,000-mile motor tour across the continent and back, studying at first hand the people of Canada and the United States, without disclosing her identity.

Metropolitan racing shifts today to Belmont Park, where the Westchester Racing Association will hold its Autumn meeting of fifteen days. Fourteen stake events are listed for the session, including the Lawrence Realization for 3-year-olds, the Jockey Club Gold Cup and the rich Futurity, which may decide the juvenile championship.

Dr. Margaret Miller of London, housing expert, arraigned the American public yesterday as oblivious to one of the great evils of metropolitan life -- the housing problem. Giving her impressions after a quick trip back across the continent, she reported to the luncheon meeting of the housing section of the Welfare Council her sense of shock at the despoilation of America by Americans.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange eased a few points yesterday under the weight of hedges against the moving crop. So large a quantity of December was wanted around 12 cents a pound, however, that while closing quotations were the lowest since the advance following last week's crop estimate, they were only unchanged to 3 points lower than on Tuesday.

GENEVA, Sept. 16. -- France, it is reported here, plans to propose at the League of Nations Assembly opening Monday that work be resumed on a draft convention for control of the manufacture of and trade in arms. A draft was submitted to the disarmament conference by the United States in 1935.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- Hector Bywater, The Daily Telegraph's naval correspondent, gives further details tonight of the new German submarine gas engine that, operating on oxygen and hydrogen, can function equally well when the submarine is submerged or on the surface.

CONVENT, N.J., Sept. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Crittenden H. Adams gave a dance tonight at the Morris County Golf Club here to introduce their daughter, Miss Agnes Claflin Adams. The debutante and her mother were assisted in receiving by Mrs. John Claflin and Mrs. William Crittenden Adams.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- The Republican National Committee, in an unsigned statement issued tonight, said it would "welcome a few prosecutions instead of just intimidating propaganda, designed to scare people to stop them from talking about high taxes imposed by the New Deal."

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Bainbridge Colby, Secretary of State under President Wilson, accused the New Dealers today of attempting to circumvent and nullify the Constitution by a process of "legislative attrition.''

The August grand jury that has been investigating the transportation of bootleg coal from Pennsylvania anthracite fields to New York filed a presentment yesterday strongly censuring the Pennsylvania authorities for permitting this "polluted commerce."

A demand for a recount in the Maine election, in which Governor Louis J. Brann was defeated in the Senate race by Senator Wallace H. White, was made yesterday by Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial campaign committee.
Three automobile companies -- General Motors, Chrysler and Studebaker-reported yesterday that gains had been made in their export business.
The New York, Ontario Western Railroad reported a profit and loss surplus of $6,057,042 on June 30, against $6,472,748 a year previously. Total assets were $102,613,579, against $102,725,328.

DIXIE, Que., Sept. 16. -- The United States representation in the Canadian women's open golf championship remained intact today as four players from below the border line, headed by Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., joined four Canadians in the quarter-final round.

NIAGARA FALLS, Sept. 16.-- Organization of a model institute of local history at Old Fort Niagara, the first in this country, to conduct summer sessions designed for teachers of grade and high schools, for librarians and curators of museums, was proposed today by Dr. Alexander C. Flick, official historian of New York, in an address before the closing session of the m annual meeting of the State Historical Association.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Painters and sculptors, men and women of society were in the large company who attended this afternoon the varnishing-day tea and reception of the annual Stockbridge exhibition at the Berkshire Playhouse.

Frank J. Prial, defeated by a margin of 24,714 votes in Tuesday's primary election for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday attributed the setback to fraud on the part of the Democratic organizations, and pressure exerted on district leaders by Democratic National Chairman James A. Farley.

Note two new film entries for today: The Radio City Music Hall's neaw tenant is Eric Hatch's "My Man Godfrey," transferred to the screen by Universal under Gregory La Cava's direction, with such players as William Powell, Carole Lombard, Alice Brady, Eugene Pallette and Gall Patrick

BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The Cubs observed their last meeting of the season with the Bees by taking a double-header, 3 to 2 and 4 to 2, today. Chicago won sixteen of the twenty-two games played this season with the Bees.

Dress manufacturers who import model gowns from Paris for copying purposes yesterday were awaiting word from leading couturiers who they expect will make a strong protest against the new Treasury Department ruling fixing a penalty duty of 25 per cent of the value of any model gown sold by importers.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
Being in a fairly lavish humor, the local theatre this evening will deposit two new ones on various Broadway doorsteps.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Four new champions were crowned today in the second national skeet shooting championship, but only after an exciting program in which rain and a stiff breeze made accurate marksmanship difficult.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 16. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin predicted tonight, in an address delivered under a threatening sky at William Donovan Baseball Field before 10,000 people, that constitutional amendments would soon come, but he pleaded that they be made by the entire people.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 16. -- After three days of heavy firing over the flat, tough links of the Garden City Golf Club the starting field of 201 players had been reduced to sixteen when the fading sun descended on the fortieth national amateur championship today.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- The death of Dr. Jean Baptiste Charcot and the destruction of his gallant ship, the Pourquoi-Pas, in a storm off Iceland has brought consternation to the scientific world in France.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 16. -- A howling seventy-mile gale blew the famous polar research ship Pourquoi-Pas onto the rocks of Western Iceland this morning and cost the lives of Dr. Jean Baptiste Charcot, veteran French explorer, and thirty-two of his men.

HENDAYE, France, Sept. 16 (AP). -- The Spanish Rebels have executed thirty-six Basque Nationalists in the soccer stadium at Irun. The Basques were accused of having led the resistance against the insurgents before the city was captured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull's pronouncement of foreign policy before the Good Neighbor League in New York last night, especially that part devoted to the Briand-Kellogg antiwar pact, may conceivably pave the way for important developments in the future with respect to Europe and Asia, competent diplomatic observers here believe.

With sales reaching a new high record for many companies, several mills in the cotton-goods field are launching their heaviest Fall campaigns in years and expect to carry through 1937 with sharply increased expenditures, according to comment here yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP). -- Before the smallest crowd at Navin Field in three years, the Tigers defeated the Athletics, 6 to 2, today in the final 1936 engagement between the two clubs. The official attendance was 1,100. The weather was cold and damp.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Leaving a request with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to draft a model bill, delegates fromi nine tobacco-producing States re-i turned to their homes today to i begin organization of committees to guide the proposed legislation to control tobacco production through interstate compacts.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Ken Strong's newly-formed New York Yankees of the American League swept to a decisive 21-0 victory over the West New York Pro Giants football eleven tonight in an exhibition game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Leaving a request with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to draft a model bill, delegates fromi nine tobacco-producing States re-i turned to their homes today to i begin organization of committees to guide the proposed legislation to control tobacco production through interstate compacts.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Sept. 16 (AP). -- Ken Strong's newly-formed New York Yankees of the American League swept to a decisive 21-0 victory over the West New York Pro Giants football eleven tonight in an exhibition game.

PARIS, Sept. 16. -- Anxiety over the textile strike situation and fear that a general strike movement might flame up again were felt here tonight following the failure of the government today to obtain any compromise between delegates of employers and workers who were summoned to separate conferences at the Premier's residence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16. -- One by one David O. Selznick is eliminating possible candidates for the r61e of lhett Butler in "Gone With the Wind." The producer, who holds a commitment from Ronaid Colrnan for one picture, is reported to be thinking about placing Mr. Colman in the film.
MADRID, Sept. 17. -- General Francisco Franco, commander-in-chief of the Spanish insurgents, tonight led his troops, 175,000 strong, against the government-held cities of Toledo and Madrid.

The eyes of the world are turned nervously on France. All observers agree that France is the crucial point in Europe and that on the developments there depend larger issues than the fate of the French Government. There will be a general sigh of relief, therefore, at the news that Premier BLUM has taken another hurdle on his difficult and tricky course.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Harry Fleischmann, Santa Monica (Calif.) marksman, stepped to the firing posts today and cracked 100 consecutive clay pigeons to gain the individual lead in the all-gauge event of the national skeet tournament.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Representative Prentiss M. Brown's margin of victory over Louis B. Ward, associate of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, for the Democratic Senatorial nomination apparently will be around 4,000 votes, nearly complete returns indicated today.

A drop of $290,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System was reported yesterday in the system's statement covering the week ended on Wednesday. This reduced the total of excess reserves to $1,710,000,000, which compares with the figure of $1,790,000,000 in mid-August when the 50 per cent increase in reserve requirements of all member banks went into effect.

Your paper published yesterday a statement from the Social Justice Commission of the Central Conference of American Rabbis which is deserving of the closest attention of all good citizens. I find myself in large agreement with its statements.

SALINAS, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP). -- A leader's warning today that "massacre awaits you" kept striking lettuce workers off Salinas streets, which were guarded by 1,000 deputized citizens with riot clubs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The Narragansett Electric Company of Providence, R.I., a subsidiary of the New England Power Association, a registered holding company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration under the Public Utility Act of 1935 in regard to the division of its capital stock into preferred and common shares.

Most commodity futures advanced in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Coffee, wool top, rubber and copper futures eased. On the cash markets, all the grains, silk, hides and tins advanced, while rubber and raw sugar declined.

Testimonials to the popularity of President Roosevelt were given yesterday by a group of socially prominent women at Sherry's on Park Avenue. Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien, daughter of Clarence Mackay, organized the function and presided. The tributes were broadcast.

Morris Roisner, underworld character of St. Paul, Minn.; one of his alleged lieutenants and two New Yorkers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy to violate the national stolen property act.

Some ideas recognize no limits of space or time. New York, in welcoming this week the Holy Name Society, witnesses striking evidence of the influence on American Catholic men of a conception first formally expressed six hundred and sixty-two years ago. It was the Church Congress of Lyons in 1274 which prescribed that "the "faithful should have a special devo-"tion to the Holy Name of Jesus."

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 17. -- A sharp clash of views on the industrial union issue that has split the American Federation of Labor into two warring camps occurred at today's session of the International Typographical Union convention.
Investment buying of housing properties featured realty activity in Brooklyn yesterday, savings banks figuring as sellers in some of the transactions.

Prices of United States Government bonds continued yesterday to decline on the New York Stock Exchange in somewhat more active trading. Lacking any outside influence, but rather affected by their recent advance, the Treasury issues yielded from 1-32 to 7-32 point on a turnover of $1,122,400, compared with sales of $800,000 on Wednesday.

In addition to releasing their statement of earnings for the six months ended on July 31, Interstate Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday the resumption of dividends with the declaration of one of 50 cents a share for the common stock. The last previous payment was a similar amount distributed on Dec. 29, 1931.
SUGAR HILL, N.H., Sept. 17. -- Mrs. Thomas F. Vietor gave a luncheon at Hill Top Farm here today for members of the White Mountain Garden Club.

During the New Year services at Tempel Emanu-El yesterday morning two girls, employed at Ohrbach's department store, 48 East Fourteenth Street, and members of the Department Store Employes Union, Local 1250, picketed the temple, carrying placards: "Mr. N.M. Ohrbach worships here but forces his Jewish employes to work on the Holy Days."
BERLIN, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 15 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

Kuhn, Loeb Co. will offer today an issue of $20,000,000 of Union Pacific Railroad Company 3 1/2 per cent debenture bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1936, and due on Oct. 1, 1970. The bonds will be priced at 99%; and accrued interest.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York, as successor trustee, yesterday informed owners of first consolidated mortgage fifty-year 4 per cent bonds of the Rio Grande Western Railway Company that it had called a meeting of holders of these bonds for Sept. 24 in order to afford them an opportunity to discuss what, if any, steps should be taken at this time for their protection.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- This is the golden jubilee year of Cornell football. The campus was as elated as a child with a new-found toy when Union was played back in 1886, in spite of Andrew Dickson White's animadversions against the agitation of a bag of wind, and today, fifty years later, the good burghers and professors of town and gown are caught up in the same contagion of excitement.

Signs are increasing that our Summer varieties of ocean game fish are preparing to take their departure from near-by waters, their migrations hastened by the series of brisk blows that have struck along the coast in recent weeks.
BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- The Boerse was generally friendly today, although business shrunk to merely a nominal turnover, many issues remaining quotationless. Most changes were only fractional.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday reached the highest total in nineteen weeks. With only one exception, all cities reported increases. The current figure included payment of the third installment of the Federal income tax, which was due on Tuesday.

The season's worst tropical hurricane, attended by gales over a wide area, roared against Cape Hatteras on the North Carolina coast late last night, bringing a ninety-mile wind, rising waves and mounting tides that had tied up several liners in Atlantic ports and had sent smaller boats running for shelter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Government agencies hurried into action today as a tropical hurricane howled toward the Middle Atlantic Coast.
President Roosevelt has cut Governor Landon's lead to about 3 1/2 to 2 in The Literary Digest poll, the latest figures made public by the magazine disclosed yesterday.

Asserting that a petition seeking reorganization of the National Public Service Corporation under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act had not been filed in good faith, three creditors yesterday asked the Federal Court to dismiss the petition on the ground that the utility already had been liquidated beyond the point where reorganization was possible.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Since the beginning of this century war "has become a destructive anachronism, useless as a tool, unpracticable as a measure of national policy and at the same time an unmitigated waste of all that is best in our civilization," the tercentenary meeting of the Harvard Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa was told her tonight by Professor Bronislaw Malinowski, anthropologist of the University of London.

Gold to the value of $7,691,000 was engaged abroad yesterday for movement here -- $7,125,000 in France and $566,000 in England -- swelling the total for the movement which began on Aug. 7 to $126,500,000. Of this amount, France has contributed $88,500,000.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 17. -- The bodies of Dr. Jean-Baptiste Charcot, French polar explorer, and twenty-two other victims of the Pourquoi-Pas disaster lay tonight in the chapel of the Catholic Hospital at Reykjavik, Iceland, while a French destroyer was ordered to speed north to bring them home.

The Giants, holding a five-game lead over the Cardinals and a five-and-a-half-game margin on the Cubs, can clinch the National League pennant by winning six of their remaining ten games, even if the second-place St. Louisians capture all their remaining ten contests.

Tonight the opening is of that melodrama called "Arrest That Woman" (nee "Calling All Cars"), the work of one Maxine Alton. It will open at the National Theatre at 8:40, with a cast including Doris Nolan, Lillian Emerson, Walter N. Greaza, Hugh Marlowe, Gertrude Short, Mervin Williams, George Lessey, Frank Andrews and Phyllis Holden. A.H. Woods, proprietor.

Republicans and Democrats continue to quarrel over the extent to which the Government's bills are being paid by indirect taxation, concealed from the taxpayer. Republican national headquarters in Chicago is busily distributing information which purports to show that the cost of living has been sharply raised by Federal taxes which escape detection on the part of most of those who pay them.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 (21:').The Pirates banged four pitchers for twenty-two hits today and downed the Reds, 14 to 10, in their series opener.
SAN ANGELO, Texas, Sept. 17 (AP). -- More than 700 persons were homeless here tonight as the worst flood in the city's history swept over the business and residential sections.
LONDON, Sept. 17. -- Charges of an Italian plot to stir up Arab unrest in Palestine were made by a special correspondent of The London Daily Herald now in Jerusalem.
ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- The text of Governor Lehman's decision on the removal charges against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn follows:

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Peck Prout of Summit gave a dance tonight at the Short Hills Club for their debutante daughter, Miss Virginia Prout, and for Miss Shirley Moore, daughter of Mr. and Airs. Livingston P. Moore, also of Summit.
READING, Pa., Sept. 17. -- Eleven keenly contested heats marked the Governor's Day program of the Grand Circuit meeting at the Reading Fair today as a crowd of more than 40,000 looked on.

James J. Braddock, world heavy weight champion, who has signed to defend his title against Max Schmeling next June, will engage in two and possibly three ten-round no-decision bouts in the intervening months. This became known yesterday from a reliable source after the return of the champion from Florida, where he took treatments for arthritis, which caused postponement of his fight with Schmeling this month.

Hurling bottle after bottle against the brick wall of the Police Department garage at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street in Brooklyn, a dozen civilian employes of the department began yesterday the destruction of more than $90,000 worth -- at retail prices -- of liquor and alcohol seized from 1928 to 1935 in the five boroughs.

In seeking a position under the keen competitive conditions existing today a man must develop a definite campaign to sell himself, just as he would in organizing an advertising drive, Sidney W. Edlund, president of Life Savers, Inc., told the Association of Advertising men at a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Bishop Joseph Schrembs of Cleveland, said on his return from Rome yesterday that he considered a priest of the Catholic Church well within his rights in discussing political and social questions, but he looked with disfavor on one who waged a regular political campaign.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- Republican France and the Leftist government of Leon Blum rounded today a most difficult corner when after several anxious days an agreement was reached putting an end to the strike of 33,000 Lille textile workers and setting down the future relationship between employers and employed.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt said in a Constitution Day address at Faneuil Hall today that the present administration was striking at the "Spirit of Democracy" contained in the Constitution.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The seventh place Browns downed the runner-up White Sox, 5 to 2, today, shaving Chicago's margin over the Tigers to one game.
TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. l7. -- The 1,700 men, women and children within the besieged Alcazar tonight received a last ultimatum -- to surrender or be blown to pieces.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- A new technique in industrial administration for the purpose of discovering hidden talent for responsible executive positions in American industry was outlined here today before the tercentenary meeting of the Harvard Business School Alumni Association by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the finance committee of the United States Steel Corporation.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Miss Virginia Gillette Kleitz and Miss Frances Crawford Talcott were introduced to society tonight at a dance given by their respective parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Lambert Kleitz and Mr. and Mrs. James Talcott, at the Apawamis Club here.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Peter C. Borre, counsel for the Congressional Committee on Bondholders' Reorganizations, announced today that the committee would investigate the defunct Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in connection with alleged "manipulative activities that caused approximately $50,000,000 loss to the investment public."

BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- Germany's foreign trade made its best showing of the year during August, when it produced the largest exports since last December and the biggest export surplus since October, 1933. Exports amounted to 409,000,000 marks and imports to 345,700,000, leaving an export surplus of 63, 300,000.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday an estimated consolidated net income of $3,358,813 for the first half of 1936, equivalent to 52.4 cents a share on 6,399,002 shares of stock, against $2,128,581, or 33.2 cents a share, in the same period in 1935.

The New York Stock Exchange denied yesterday published reports that it was conducting a formal investigation of recent transactions in common stock of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, which has risen approximately forty points in the last month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that he did not have in his mind, in his speech before the Good- Neighbor League in New York last Tuesday night, that this government might abandon treaty relations, such as the Kellogg-Briand pact to renounce war as an instrument of national policy, because these treaties had been frequently broken of late.

There came a moment when Governor CURLEY, after long hesitation, decided that he had made trouble enough in Massachusetts and should cultivate a new and larger area of disturbance in Washington. So he had himself nominated for Senator at the pre-primary convention. His peculiar methods and arbitrary administration have made him a host of Democratic enemies.

The General Motors Corporation rebought last month 16,381 shares of its common stock, increasing its treasury holdings to 644,B01 shares, according to reports yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange of stock reacquired by listed corporations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address today to the Meeting for Human Needs:

Republicans may repeat this year the effort which proved successful in 1928 when Herbert Hoover and Alfred E. Smith were the rival Presidential candidates of the two major parties, to break the solid South.

Lists of apartment rentals announced by renting agents yesterday indicated an extension of the Fall rush over a wide area. Leases in Manhattan were about equally divided between East and West Side buildings, with a demand for large suites in houses on Fifth and Park Avenues, Riverside Drive and West End Avenue.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Greetings from all points of the compass poured in on Harvard University today at a meeting of the Associated Harvard Clubs in connection with the tercentenary.

Charles A.
