Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, outlined yesterday before 200 members of the metropolitan chapter of the American Society of Safety Engineers at luncheon in the Hotel Astor a number of improvements in highways and traffic control which, he thought, would greatly reduce automobile accidents in this State.

Mayor La Guardia appointed two new members of the Board of Higher Education yesterday at City Hall, naming Mrs. Ruth Shoup and Lawton Mackall to succeed Mrs. Cornelia Kraft McKee and Judge John Dyer, respectively.

Although the weight of hedges against the new crop finally carried the December position through the 12-cent level on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, heavy mill price-fixing absorbed more cotton within a 5-point range than at any previous time this year and the list ended unchanged to 6 points higher on the day.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Vassar College will begin its seventy-second year tomorrow with an enrollment of about 1,200 students, of whom 355 are freshmen.

The Socialist party of New York announced yesterday that an invitation had been extended to the Communist party of Queens to send an official representative to speak at a Socialist campaign rally in the Jamaica Town Hall on Monday. The action was taken as a result of the refusal of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens to permit the borough Communists to meet in the hall, according to the announcement.
Commemorative exercises were held throughout the city yesterday in celebration of the 149th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution.

Senator GUFFEY of Pennsylvania, after a few minutes' talk with Chairman FARLEY in this city, said that he was convinced that the re-election of Senator WHITE in Maine was achieved by fraudulent methods. He added, with a delicate scrupulosity which does him honor, that he did not feel at liberty just yet to make the evidence of fraud public.
LONDON, Sept. 17 (2P). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, replying yesterday to the charges of District Attorney William C. Dodge that the commissioner had failed to cooperate with him, termed Mr. Dodge's conduct "stupid and evasive."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Continued and increased support of private welfare agencies so that they may carry on the rehabilitation and character-building work upon which, with returning material prosperity, more emphasis "must be placed," was urged today by President Roosevelt in an address to the American people opening the 1936 Mobilization for Human Needs.
Housing properties formed the bulk of the turnover in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday, trading in Bronx borough being marked by sales of a variety of buildings.

Because of the false emphasis which propaganda has led politicians to place on the September State elections in Maine, the public may not pay sufficient attention to what happened in this same week in Massachusetts, Michigan and Wisconsin. In this group are many more electoral votes, and the disclosure of a trend in their areas is far more likely to forecast a national result than any Maine statistic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Charges that wholesale slaughter of cattle and hogs, with their use as food for relief purposes forbidden, was carried out by the Federal Government in 1934 were aired today by the Republican National Committee and quickly denied by a spokesman for the Department of Agriculture.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 17. -- Rounding off its practice for Saturday's match against Argentina, Greentree, now designated as the United States team, defeated a 26-goal quartet on Greentree's field today, 9 to 3.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Non-Harvard men and women paid tribute to Harvard with a $5,000 gift today at the tercentennial observance of the Associated Harvard Clubs, a day marked also by the presentation of three other gifts to the university.

Two new faces are really the the news at the Second Avenue Theatre, which began its season yesterday with matinee and evening performances of what the management prefers to call, sort of romantically, "Papirossen" but which is nothing more than "Cigarettes."

DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Reminiscent, keeping a three-length lead won at the half-way mark, defeated Judge Kavanaugh in the six-fur-long allowance race for 3-year-olds, the feature today at the Fair Grounds track.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Several thousand graduates attending Harvard's Tercentenary celebration trooped over the old familiar paths to Soldiers Field today to witness the Crimson's big football squad in an hour's open practice.

The Commercial Credit Company will obtain new funds through the issuance of $30,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures, A.E. Duncan, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday in Baltimore. A registration statement covering the issue will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in a few days, Mr. Duncan said.

Share prices improved in quiet trading yesterday and THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks retrieved 1.06 points of the 1.28-point decline of the day before. The recovery was fairly general throughout the list, just as the sagging tendencies on the previous day embraced most of the stock groupings.

Metro's mammoth musical production, "The Great Ziegfeld," returns to Broadway today at the Capitol to compete with the Shubert-sponsored "Ziegfeld Follies," which only the other day assumed at the Winter Garden across the street after a prolonged absence.

United States Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska will deliver a radio address tonight on a nationwide hook-up in behalf of President Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday by the Democratic National Committee, under whose auspices he will talk from Omaha.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17. -- A larger than seasonal decrease in the operating rate of the iron and steel industry and a drop in the volume of trade resulted in a sharp setback in business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The sharp contrast of opinion between the railroads and trucking interests in connection with proposals for making free pickup and delivery service by the railroads a general policy, was shown today in briefs filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the rail carriers of the Eastern territory, various commercial associations and the trucking organizations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP). -- A report before the Clerk of the House today showed that the Liberty League in New Jersey received contributions of $7,719 between January and September this year.

GENEVA, Sept. 17. -- The faint hope of the League of Nations that Ethiopia, by absenting herself from the Assembly opening Monday, would spare it the disagreeable necessity of having to exclude the victim in order to coax back the country it had found guilty of aggression almost a year ago, expired tonight.

Sixty-four players are scheduled to start in the first round of match play in the metropolitan handicap golf championship tournament at the Cresmont Golf Club at Wrest Orange, N.J., on Monday morning. The competition will last through Wednesday.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 17. -- The prospect of a British invader carting the Havemeyer Cup back to England on the Queen Mary loomed more imminent than ever today when sandy-haired Jock McLean, 25-year-old liquor salesman fra' Glasgow, reached the semifinal round of the national amateur championship at the Garden City Golf Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17. -- The hurricane approaching from the South caused strong winds preceding it along the New Jersey coast tonight, while ocean-front communities prepared for gales and big seas. The rising waves forced all fishing and pleasure boats into the many inlets during the day, some of the craft capsizing or dashing on the rocks in the run for shelter.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Commemoration here of Constitution Day was marked today by speeches in which opponents of the New Deal depicted the "peril" now threatening the historic document.

Frankie Thomas has done much to lay the ghost that of old prowled the theatre, hissing of each knickerbocker player, "child actor." Already, and at the ripe age of 15, he has had to his credit some pretty distinguished plays, and he has been a credit to them.

The latest Literary Digest poll records 254,000 replies to its questionnaire. Of this total Governor LANDON has 153,000, which puts him thus far well in the lead. But The Digest itself frankly warns its readers that an accurate index of the final results is by no means furnished by this.

An informal discussion of the procedure to be followed by the railroads in an effort to retain revenues derived from surcharge freight rates when they expire at the end of this year was entered into yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference, the first since the Summer recess.

Trading in the wool goods market was spotty this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Orders during the first part of the week were quite large, but trading stopped Wednesday night, when the religious holidays began.

With private projects amounting to $30,513,000, the highest volume in more than five years, this week's total of engineering construction awards is $56,382,000, according to The Engineering News-Record. Public contracts make up the remaining $25,869,000 of this volume, $5,617,000 being in Federal awards and $20,252,000 in State and municipal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Attorney General Cummings, head of the Department of Justice, which has recently defended many New Deal laws before the Supreme Court, conceded in a speech today that there might be varying interpretations of the Constitution by the courts.

More than 500 first-year students of Columbia College will assemble at Morningside Heights this morning for the events of Freshman Week, prelude to the opening of the 183d academic year next Thursday.

Bainbridge Colby, anti-New Deal Democrat, was cheered by an audience of about 600 Republicans last night in Town Hall for a Constitution Day rally. He delivered a bitter attack on the Roosevelt administration and demanded the protection of the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- After a busy day clearing up routine matters, President Roosevelt left the capital tonight on a trip which will keep him away from Washington until Sept. 30. He will go directly to Cambridge to speak at the Harvard tercentenary exercises tomorrow.

Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, was celebrated yesterday in temples and synagogues throughout the city. While Jewish places of worship in the metropolitan area number 100, they were increased to more than 400 for the holy days, it was estimated.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 17. -- One of the victims of the Pourquoi-Pas disaster was a seagull that had flown aboard the ship off Greenland and had been kept by Dr. Jean-Baptiste Charcot as a bird of good omen.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bertles gave a dinner dance tonight at the Piping Rock Club to introduce to society their daughters, Miss Katharine Elizabeth and Miss Mary Anne Bertles, who returned recently I from visits in England, and Sugar Hill, N.H.
Governor Lehman completely exonerated District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan last night of all charges on which the Drukman grand jurors sought his removal from office as Kings County prosecutor.

WARSAW, Sept. 17. -- The problem of mass emigration of Polish Jews to Palestine will be raised at the meeting of the League by For eign Minister Josef Beck, who left today for Geneva with a large staff of experts. This question was discussed a few weeks ago in a semiofficial statement, and the idea of increased Jewish emigration with the aid of the Polish Government gained favorable comment in the Polish press.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- A newcomer to the competition, Richard Doughty of Detroit, set an eighteen-hole record for the tournament as the second group of players got under way today in the thirty-second annual United States seniors' golf championship at the Apawamis Club.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Undergraduates celebrated Harvard's 300th birthday tonight with a two-hour public show of fireworks along the Charles River.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- Miss Hope Knowles, 17-year-old Philadelphia Cricket Club star, and Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio today reached the final round of the women's Philadelphia grass-court tennis championship.
CORVALLIS, Ore., Sept. 17 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox asserted in a Constitution Day address tonight that the Supreme Court blocked a "course toward ruin" by throwing out New Deal legislation.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 17. -- An old-fashioned golf course finally shook out the anonymous tourists, masked marvels and wayward hitters who were romping around in a national title hunt for a few days. The eight men who came up for the sixth round this afternoon were good men and true, golfers of established reputations and reliable records.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- A warning that American business must sacrifice war profits to maintain peace was given today by Secretary Roper in an address before the Business Advisory Council.
Lieut. Gov. M. William Bray will be renominated for that office by the Democratic State Convention in Syracuse on Sept. 28 and 29, it became known definitely yesterday.

One of the soundest reasons for believing that the prospects for the Fall season remain highly favorable in most lines of department store merchandise, it was contended here yesterday, is that stocks in manufacturers' hands continue light. This is notably true in practically all of the women's apparel divisions and also in accessories and homefurnishings lines.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 17. -- The drastic effect upon Bermuda's export vegetable trade to Canada as the result of the United States-Canada trade agreement was revealed in statistics T.A. Russell, Director of the Bermuda Department of Agriculture, published today.

OMAHA, Sept. 17 (AP). -- William Lemke, Union party Presidential candidate, outlining his conception of the current money situation, said tonight "the money changers are still in possession of the temple, and in more thorough control than at any other time for years."
Alarmed at the spread of communism, atheism, sacrilege and apostasy, Catholic leaders issued a call to their adherents yesterday to rally to the defense of religion and patriotism.

The "most difficult hurdles" of the planning of the 1939 New York World's Fair have been passed, the theme and plan have been "virtually completed" and the engineering activities are being pushed at a swift pace, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair company, said yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- An ode, written for the Harvard tercentenary celebration, was read by its composer, Hermann Hagedorn of New York City, a member of the class of 1907, at a meeting of the Associated Harvard Clubs today.
IF you want to know whether you should bother to read Carl Van Doren's autobiographical "Three Worlds" (Harper, $3), the answer is "Yes, certainly."

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- A limestone blast in caves at Sterkfontein, near Krugersdorp, South Africa, in August scattered the fossil upper teeth and brain of a hitherto unknown type of anthropoid ape that may be a missing link.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure for the year.

The account of the Continental Baking Corporation will be transferred from Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., to Benton Bowles, Inc., on Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by the former organization. Officers of Benton Bowles declined to discuss Continental's future plans.

Petitions calling for downward revision of the whole program of State spending, including relief, and extension of the principle of home rule so that communities may have power to control their expenditures, are being circulated by the Merchants Association, it was revealed yesterday.

CHESHIRE, Conn., Sept. 17. -- Four persons were killed, three outright, and fifteen were injured late today when a Waterbury-Cheshire bus of the Connecticut Company skidded into a tree, tore it up by the roots, and dropped four feet into a gulley in the hamlet of Marion, two miles from West Cheshire.

TOPEKA, Sept. 17. -- Governor Landon sent letters tonight to former Senator Reed of Missouri and former Governor Ely of Massachusetts, anti-New Deal Democrats, expressing appreciation for their help in the Maine election.

Feeling the time had arrived in their ardent pennant pursuit to do something big in a big way, the Giants gave the Dodgers, a hostile crowd of 20,000 and a delegation of visiting Yankees an eye-filling performance of hitherto unrevealed power at Ebbets Field yesterday as they uncorked an offensive that was positively grandiose.

A 10 per cent increase in wages and other concessions granted yesterday by the Merchant Truck-men's Bureau of New York to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs averted a threatened strike of 15,000 truck drivers which for three weeks had caused deep concern in the business community.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- To Chancellor Adolf Hitler's words and manner at the Nuremberg Nazi Congress and to suggestions that "enfeebled France" might purchase immunity from war by taking a lenient view of her neighbor's eastward anti-Bolshevist ambitions, Premier Leon Blum replied tonight in a radio speech that will call for much revision of estimates in foreign Chancellories.
NEWPORT, N.Y., Sept. 17 (AP). -- Stanley Piseck, president of the New York Milk Producers Federation, appealed to Governor Lehman by mail today to "take personal charge of the milk situation."
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17. -- Pittsburgh faced the unusual situation today of having to choose on Oct. 1 between listening to President Roosevelt and Colonel Frank Knox in pre-election speeches.

BEAUFORT, N.C., Sept. 17. -- A 90-mile hurricane battered the treacherous, sandy North Carolina banks tonight, bringing threatened Continued From Page One destruction and damage to a wide section of the coastline.

MOSCOW, Sept. 17. -- A radical reduction in the Soviet's imports of cotton from the United States was indicated both by this year's cotton crop and the Soviet import figures published today. With picking well under way in the important cotton belt in Central Asia, officials estimate the yield will be 15 to 20 per cent higher than last year's, with the prediction that 280,000 bales will be available for the Soviet's textile mills.

In the November election the voters of New York City will be called upon to determine whether they approve the selection of candidates for the Municipal Council through the system known as proportional representation. The name seems to imply that each political party is entitled to representation in the Council in proportion to its voting strength.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- Another threat to France's political peace made its appearance today, new activity by the militant French Social party, successor to the Fascist Croix de Feu, disbanded by government decree. There is fear of fighting between Rightists and Leftists.

A settlement was announced yesterday in the six-month strike of New Jersey commuters against a 15-cent supplemental fare charged by the Pennsylvania Railroad for riding directly into the Pennsylvania Station instead of transferring to the ferry or the Hudson and Manhattan tube.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Because the title to a tract of 4.8 acres of land at the Port of Newark, twice sold and twice bought back by the city, was faulty throughout the transactions, the city will pay $190,535 to establish its title to the tract.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Mackey Wells, '08, of Milwaukee, has been elected president of the Associated Harvard Clubs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Details of what was characterized as "a most amazing contract" between the du Pont company and an agent described as an international spy for the sale of munitions to Germany was dug out today from one of the voluminous reports of the Senate munitions committee.

MOSCOW, Sept. 17. -- A blunt warning to possible enemies of the Soviet Union, specifically meaning Germany, of course, that the U.S. S.R. would not be content to meet the aggressor on Soviet soil but intended to invade and beat the enemy in the latter's own territory with every terrible artifice of modern military technique has just been delivered by Defense Commissar Klementy E. Voroshiloff.

Two French university students commissioned by the Ministry of Education of France will start a tour of American universities on Monday to examine the social life of the American student and to report officially on the desirability of transplanting some of it to France.

Reiterating the charge that business is moving out of New York State because of restrictive legislation both in Washington and Albany, State Senator George R. Fearon, one of the leading aspirants for the Republican nomination for Governor, addressed a campaign rally of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club last night at the Towers Hotel, 22 Clark Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Supplies of new crop hogs were more than ample again today for trade requirements, and desirable Weights declined as much as 15 cents a hundredweight, while some sales of hogs weighing 150 pounds and under showed losses of 25 to 50 cents compared with the best yesterday.

MUSGRAVE HARBOR, Nfld., Sept. 17 (AP). -- The rescue party led by Captain Eddie Rickenbacker reached here today after a stormy 17-hour boat trip from Harbor Grace to help Harry Richman and Dick Merrill put their transatlantic monoplane back into the air.

NORFOLK. Va., Sept. 17. -- J.J. Murphy, chief of the Norfolk Weather Bureau, said tonight reports received here indicated that the tropical storm sweeping up from Cape Hatteras may veer to the northwest and the center of the disturbance might miss the Virginia Capes.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 17. -- Leftist tribunals continue to function, five condemned officers having been executed here yesterday. The tribunal aboard the prison ship Uruguay condemned to death a major, a captain and two lieutenants and sentenced one lieutenant to life.

Rushing the calendar, the Radio City Music Hall has decided to have its April Fool's Day in September. With Universal's compliments, it presented yesterday the daffiest comedy of the year. "My Man Godfrey," from the novel by Eric Hatch, is on the order of the "Three-Cornered Moon" of a few seasons ago -- except that it is slightly more insane.

BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- While the German press reported under page-wide banner headlines that Marshal Klementy E. Voroshiloff the Soviet Foreign Commissar, had "rattled the saber" in a speech, Chancellor Adolf Hitler likewise delivered an army manoeuvre address today in which he proclaimed the doctrine of the "strong fist" and celebrated the new German Army as "the watch of our holy Reich."

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17. -- In speeches broadcast tonight from the Great Lakes Exposition, the executives of the nation's three largest steel corporations told the country what the steel industry had done for labor since the depression began and how labor and management in the industry "have worked together to establish a firm foundation of collective cooperation."

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Robert H. Cabell, president of Armour Co., reported today that the meat-packing concern's business for the last three months had been better than for any similar period in several years. He added that September had started well and that prospects for October were encouraging.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Proceeds of the Treasury's Sept. 15 financing, income-tax collections and other receipts increased the government's cash balance to $2,295,846,618, compared with $1,793,224,088 the day before an $1,903,692,202 on Aug. 31.

The United States must accept a share of blame in the "horrible record of murders and destructive acts" in Palestine, in the opinion of Senators Royal S. Copeland of New York and Warren R. Austin of Vermont, who returned yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia after an unofficial study of conditions in the Holy Land.

Obstreperous at the post, but fleeter than all in the running, Miss Merriment yesterday flashed her keenest performance to win the Fall Highweight Handicap as Belmont opened its Fall meeting before 8,000 devotees of the thoroughbred. The Victor Emanuel filly was a strong favorite and when she galloped home first by three lengths at 11 to 5 there was a rolling cheer from the crowd.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 17. -- Splendid teamwork and crisp hitting by the Argentines today featured their final scheduled practice match in preparation for the Cup of the Americas series opener to be played at the Meadow Brook Club on Saturday.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg arrives today from Hamburg. Southampton and Cherbourg. Gustav Schuetzendorf, tenor, and his wife, Grete Stueckgold, soprano, are among the passengers. Others are Serge Jaroff, leader of the Don Cossack Russian Male Choir; Dr. Harrison Randolph, president of Charleston College, Charleston, S.C., with Mrs. Randolph: Richard Cadwalader, banker; Thomas L. Kerney, Mrs. Adele M. Dill, Wolfgang Schandein.

Business activity decreased slightly last month as a result of a lower rate of operations in leading consumer goods industries. The Annalist Index of Business Activity is 101.5 (preliminary) for August, compared with 102.0 for July and 97.6 for June.

The former Queen Victoria Eugenie of Spain arrived hurriedly in New York yesterday and visited her son, Alfonso, Count de Covadonga, who is gravely ill with hemophilia at the Presbyterian Hospital, to find that his condition was improved.

The demand of the International Longshoremen's Association for a forty-hour week instead of the present forty-four-hour week developed yesterday into the most important barrier to the settlement of working differences between the Atlantic ship lines and their pier workers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The wheat market gave today a demonstration of strength which surprised many operators. An early decline in Liverpool and a forecast for showers in Argentina which was followed by light rain caused a moderate recession in North America early.

Troy, N.Y., has invited bankers to submit bids on Sept. 29 for a new issue of $470,000 of general city, debt equalization, public building and park bonds, to be dated July 1, 1936, and maturing July 1, 1937 to 1949. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Jake Wade, recruit hurler, pitched the Tigers into sole possession of third place in the American League today, stopping the Indians with seven hits while his mates were chalking up a 5-to-2 victory.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Authors who had enough foresight to retain the dialogue rights to their silent films are coming in for a profit. Latest to effect a resale is the estate of Mary Johnston, from whom Paramount has purchased the talking-picture rights to "To Have and to Hold" for $10,000.
PARIS, Sept. 17. -- Following is the text of the radio broadcast today of Premier Leon Blum:
PERPIGNAN, France, Sept. 17 (AP). -- An anarchist member of the defeated Spanish Government expedition to Majorca came to France today to tell a grim story of the ill-fated landing party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 16, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,487,000,000, an increase of $8,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $2,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

BERLIN, Sept. 17 (AP). -- Karl von Ossietzsky, one of the most brilliant anti-Fascist propagandists in Europe, may be released from Nazi imprisonment, it was learned today. He is suffering from heart disease.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- The tone on the London Stock Exchange turned dull today as the approaching end of the account tended to slacken business. British Government stocks continued their recent advance, but industrials lost ground.
PARIS, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

DIXIE, Que., Sept. 17 (AP). -- Two stars from below the border and a pair of Montreal players today shot their way into the semi-final round of the women's Canadian golf championship as form ran true over the Royal Montreal course.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- An educational campaign to take the toy firearm out of America was announced today by the National Congress of Parents and Teachers at the semi-annual meeting of its board of directors.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The women's metropolitan golf champion, Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich, of Briar Hills, furnished proof that her game has recovered from a recent short period of "staleness" when she won the Westchester-Fairfield Association's one-day event at the Whippoorwill Golf Club this morning.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept 17. -- Loren Green, American director of the Ingersoll-Rand Company in Spain, arrived in Lisbon from Madrid today and said the situation was becoming daily more serious in the Spanish capital on account of the scarcity of food.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 17. -- C.V. Whitney's Piccolo won his second victory of the current Narragansett meeting when he defeated J.C. Palmer's Rosselli by a neck today in the mile and one-sixteenth feature. Half a length back of Rosselli came the Dixiana Stud's Erin Torch.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 17. -- Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring, four-time winner of the championship, was eliminated in the semi-final round of the women's New Jersey State golf tournament at the Echo Lake Country Club today by Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont.

SEATTLE, Sept. 17 (AP). -- The second abrupt halting of the National Labor Relations Board hearing on The Post-Intelligencer strike in two days formed the setting today for renewed efforts by a group of business men to end the month-long newsroom walkouts.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- "Pretty grim," was King Edward's laconic comment on figures and pictures of working-class housing conditions shown him today when he interrupted his holiday to pay an unexpected visit to the building exhibition at Olympia.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Harvard men from all over the United States and many parts of the world linked themselves dramatically today to the distant past and the distant future with the unfurling of a flag and the reading of parts of letters handed down by alumni of 100 years ago and the sealing of a package of documents to be opened and read by alumni 100 years hence.

Six hundred supporters of the Spanish Government forces attended last night a meeting of the American Committee for the Defense of Spanish Democracy in Mecca Temple, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street. Speakers denounced Spanish "Fascist Rebels" for attempting "to crush the peasants and industrial workers."

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The London Stock Exchange was comparatively idle today except for a few specialties. British Government issues continued strong, more as a result of the absence of sellers than of any renewed demand.

The recent sharp rise in the price of steel scrap to the highest level since 1929 has brought forcibly to the attention of the entire steel industry the need of conserving the scrap resources of the country. Scrap steel, when once consumed or exported, can be replaced only with difficulty.
SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Spanish insurgents, diplomatic dispatches reaching here tonight said, captured the village of Orio from government defenders today.

The group of French players which has been presenting French plays at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza since last Spring under the name of the French Theatre Guild was restrained yesterday from using the name by Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 18. -- Larry S. MacPhail, a showman of the major leagues, resigned today as vice president and general manager of the Cincinnati Reds, effective Nov. 1. He declined to say whether he would continue in baseball.

Below are given the nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Adding a 75 to his record-breaking 73 of yesterday for a thirty-six-hole total of 148, Richard Doughty of Detroit won the United States senior golf championship as the second group of old timers completed play in the thirty-second annual competition today at the Apawamis Club.

The first six railroads to report for August showed a gain of 46.1 per cent in net operating income, compared with August, 1935. The following table shows how their earnings compared in totals and percentages with the same month in the preceding two years:
Sales of properties in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday indicated an interest in houses on the part of investors, who were especially active in the Washington Heights and West Side areas.

With the Giants and Yankees enjoying an open date in the schedule yesterday and therefore not at all concerned over the fact that the weather would not have permitted them to play in any event, baseball in the metropolitan area moved into a period of watchful waiting.

Gales are not unusual in the New York area, but never on record has there been a wind of such velocity as to equal the generally accepted definition of a hurricane, seventy-five miles an hour, the observer at the United States Weather Bureau said last night.
The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined to 128.2 on Tuesday from 128.4 on the Tuesday previous.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 18 (AP). -- Jay Jay, speedy gelded son of Wise Counsellor, racing in the old rose and white silks of Howard Bruce, won the $2,500 added Susquehanna Handicap, feature event of the opening day program today.

Active dealings in domestic corporation bonds, in which gains of small but steady character predominated, brought a sharp increase in volume of bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with sales at $12,761,000, against $9,562,400 the day before.
Does the history of professional baseball reveal any case in which a team has been "rained out of a pennant"?

TOULON, France, Sept. 18. -- The most interesting question in the Spanish situation is: How far do events and tendencies in Catalonia correspond with what is happening or will happen in the rest of Loyalist Spain?

Smashing furiously up 1,000 miles of coastline, the tropical hurricane yesterday took a toll of possibly fifty-four lives, cut off numerous communities, brought shipping almost to a standstill and tore at the New Jersey seaboard.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 18. -- Describing the system of reciprocal trade agreements as a "dismal failure," a spokesman for milk producers today urged abrogation of the most-favored nation principle of the United States foreign trade policy.

A resumption of borrowing by corporations and unusual activity in the market for new State and municipal loans swelled the bond financing this week to $113,531,000 from $60,757,000 last week and $74,623,000 in the week a year ago.

The grand jury should burn right down to the National Theatre this morning and start removal proceedings against District Attorney Dorgan. He can be accused of malfeasance in office, slander, assault, the use of the third degree and conduct unbecoming both Al Woods and the senior membership of the Actors Equity Association.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Argentina hopes to convert its outstanding dollar bonds in New York at lower interest rates, Roberto Ortiz, Minister of Finance, reported today to Congress.

District Attorney William C. Dodge replied yesterday to charges made against him by Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard by challenging Mr. Blanshard to produce before the grand jury evidence of graft by "employes" of the District Attorney's office.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The first double stake program of the Belmont Park Fall meeting will see large fields in both the Champagne Stakes and Jerome Handicap today. The Champagne attracted thirteen juveniles and, like the Jerome for 3-year-olds, will afford a sharp clash between the East and the West.

While virtually all fixed-base flying operations in the metropolitan area were brought to a standstill yesterday by the vanguard of the storm, only half a dozen of the seventy-six daily scheduled departures of mail and passenger planes, which make it one of the busiest airline terminals in the world, were canceled at the Newark Airport.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (AP). -- A national program to create new confidence in fiduciary institutions was a suggestion studied today by officials of Western trust companies. It was proposed at the Pacific and Rocky Mountain Conference here by Paul P. Pullen, manager of business development for the Chicago Title and Trust Company.

Plans for improving its property at 537 to 549 East 118th Street were filed yesterday by the Washburn Wire Company, which will alter its plant for a five-story building for offices, laboratory and hospital, in addition to quarters for manufacturing purposes.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18. -- President Angell of Yale University, speaking today at the Harvard tercentenary exercises, struck at requiring teachers' oaths by law and evoked prolonged applause.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18. -- Coach Dick Harlow surprised his Harvard football squad today by advancing his first scrimmage date and sending the men through their paces for more than an hour and a half in a driving rainstorm. For the most part the scrimmage was stationary, although hard tackling was allowed.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18. -- Amid scenes of academic splendor and in the presence of 15,000 alumni, which included the President of the United States and many others of Harvard's and America's distinguished sons, as well as an international gathering of leading scholars, Harvard University brought its tercentenary year to a climax today with a solemn re-dedication to a fearless search for truth.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The national junior champion, Dick Shaughnessy of Dedham, Mass., broke 100 straight clays today for a two-day total of 199 to pace the all-gauge 250-target championship event of the national skeet tournament.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 18. -- A silent crowd watched the berthing here today of the Gertrud Rask, a frigate-rigged steamer with a massive ice-breaking bow.

Major Gen. Moseley suggests that provision be made for intensive six months' training in something like CCC encampments for every 18-year-old youth in this country. It was stated that over 1,000,000 young men in this country reach the age of 18 years annually.

Competition and economic disorder and improved sales practices to meet improving market conditions both in the domestic and foreign fields were discussed yesterday at the final session of the thirty-ninth annual convention of the National Hardwood Lumber Association at the Hotel New Yorker.
WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 18. -Senator Daniel O. Hastings will accept the Republican nomination to the United States Senate.

As judged by the number of players in the world, tennis is a game of the people. It seems to me that the United States Lawn Tennis Association should awaken to this fact and reduce the prices of tickets for the national championships at Forest Hills.

Further heavy engagements of French gold were made yesterday as the franc weakened again. A total of $7,137,000 of the metal was taken in Paris for shipment to New York. Other gold contracted for yesterday for United States account was $976,000 in India.

A steady and relentless downpour, increasing in volume throughout the evening, drenched the metropolitan area yesterday. It was a forerunner of the tropical hurricane whose center, according to last night's forecast, will pass eastward of the city early today.

EDENTON, N.C., Sept. 18 (AP). -- Two barges reported missing with fifty-two Negro WPA workers aboard were the sole remaining causes for fear for a heavy casualty list tonight as Northeastern North Carolina began to dig out of the debris left by a tropical hurricane.

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- All Germany must cease its occupations for an hour Sept. 28 to listen to a repetition of the speech Chancellor Adolf Hitler made last Saturday at the Nazi party congress in Nuremberg.

GARDEN CITY, Sept. 18. -- It was no fit weather for man or beast, as a whisky salesman, an insurance agent, a stock broker and a law student -- 4 up and 2 to go -- went roaming the Garden City links to settle the semi-final round of the national amateur golf championship. A wild wind carried sheets of rain across the course.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The Federal Power Commission has granted authority to the Gulf States Utilities Company, a subsidiary of Stone Webster, Inc., operating in Texas and Louisiana, to issue and sell $17,300,000 of its first mortgage and refunding bonds and $4,000,000 principal amount of its unsecured debentures.

CAMBRIDGE, Sept. 18. -- Scientists at the Harvard Tercentenary Conference of Arts and Sciences discussed last week the things to come unnumbered centuries hence but they were unable to foresee that rain and chilly weather would mar the closing ceremonies of Harvard's 300th birthday celebration this morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Various questions of interest to the railroads of the country were discussed here today at the regular meeting of the law committee of the Association of American Railroads. The committee, however, made no announcement of any decisions it might have taken.

Former Governor Charles S. Whitman has offered his services as a speaker to the Republican National Committee. The announcement was made yesterday, a week after Mrs. Whitman, lifelong Republican, had joined forces with the Democrats and started out on Wednesday as one member of a caravan of socially prominent Democratic women making a speaking tour of the State by automobile.

SYRACUSE, iNv. Y., Sept. 18 CH. -- The Onondaga County delegation to the Republican State Convention pledged itself tonight to give "unanimous support to the candidacy'' of Senator George R. Fearon for the party's nomination for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The Federal Trade Commission today issued a supplemental and amended complaint against a group of Eastern manufacturers of and dealers in radio sets, tubes and appliances, charging that, without authority or consent of the legal owners, the respondents had adopted for their use on their radio sets the names, brands and symbols of corporations and individuals well known and long established in the radio and kindred industries.

Consistent and aggressive advertising and sales promotion, budgeting of production, reduction of speculative buying and progressive personnel policies are the four essentials in any program for better employment conditions, Roscoe C. Edlund, manager of the Association of American Soap and Glycerine Producers, said last night in a radio address over WEVD, under the auspices of the Works Progress Administration.

Harvard College is old for an American institution. As a university it is very young. The mere addition of professional schools did not make it one. But as a daughter of Emmanuel College, Harvard may be said to have inherited the medieval tradition; and some of its disciplines in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, such as "disputations," were purely medieval.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 18. -- Peace and order were imperiled in several localities today, the anniversary of the Mukden incident, which was the prelude to Japan's conquest of Manchuria, but only at Fengtai, important railway junction nine miles from Peiping, was a serious situation created, threatening a collision between Chinese and Japanese armies.

Carrying on his program to banish pushcarts from the city streets, Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. announced yesterday plans for four additional enclosed retail markets for Manhattan.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Playing through a pelting rain and with a gale sweeping across the course, Dr. Thomas J. Conte, Robert M. Clough, Henry McAleenan and John H. Forsman came through to the semi-finals of the twenty-fourth annual tournament of the New York Athletic Club at the Winged Foot Club today.

Your editorial "Munition-Makers and Bankers," which commented on an article by Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War under President Wilson, in which Mr. Baker tells us "Why We Went to War," is extremely interesting. It is exactly as interesting as many other articles and letters by him have been, which have explained why we went to war in just the same way as his recent article does.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 18. -- Coast Guard cutters steamed out at full speed tonight battling heavy seas in a race to reach several vessels calling for assistance in a tropical storm.

Being one of those tennis diehards, I spent ten days viewing the national championships at Forest Hills. What I saw was disillusioning. Except for the last two days, the quality of play was very disappointing.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 18. -- The condition of former Foreign Minister Nicolas Titulescu, who is very ill in Saint Moritz, Switzerland, was reported slightly better tonight after a second blood transfusion, but he is still in great danger. He took a little nourishment during the day.

There are 34,139,624 pupils in the Protestant Sunday schools of the world, an increase of 394,579 or 2.75 per cent in the last four years. These were among the statistics for 1936 released yesterday at the headquarters of the World's Sunday School Association, 51 Madison Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. Robert M. Hopkins, General Secretary for the United States.

Such rapid headway has been made in recent weeks by Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Westchester in his quest for delegates to bring about his nomination for Governor at the Republican State Convention, to be held at Albany on Sept. 28 and 29, that his supporters now say that his nomination on the first ballot is possible.

President ROOSEVELT has urged continued and increased support of private welfare agencies engaged in those many varied services "which private activities are best fitted to carry out." The occasion was the 1936 Mobilization for Human Needs, inaugurating local campaigns for funds in all parts of the country.

In one of your stories on the recent American Federation of Teachers Convention you used the headline "Fight on C.I.O. Beaten." In this same article you state: "Conservatives, led by Miss Selma Borchardt, fought for a motion * * * Miss Borchardt's fight was not only against adherents of the Committee for Industrial Organization but against permitting the executive council to cooperate with the American League Against War and Fascism."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 18. -Under conditions that would have kept even petrels from venturing out, a fifty-mile gale of wind accompanied by rain which came down in sheets, Johnny Fischer of Fort Thomas, Ky., and Jock McLean of Glasgow, Scotland, today reached the final round of the national amateur golf championship.

DIXIE, Que., Sept. 18 (AP). -- With the aid of one stunning upset, two Dominion golfers today advanced to the final round of the women's Canadian open golf championship, a tournament which no player from the United States has been able to win since Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews triumphed in 1931.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 18. -- Mrs. E.I. Wade's Up and Up, odds-on favorite in the Lafayette Claiming Stakes, a mile and a furlong for 3-year-olds and upward, ran to a half-length victory over A.C. Bostwick's Lost Friend at Narragansett Park today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Ship owners today flatly refused to deal individually with the Sailors Union of the Pacific and a negotiation meeting broke up abruptly.

Sponsorship of this season's football schedule of Notre Dame for broadcasting purposes was announced yesterday by N.W. Ayer Son, New York advertising concern. Five home games at South Bend, Ind., and "several" of the games away from South Bend will be on the air over WTAM, Cleveland, under the sponsorship of the Kellogg Company, cereal manufacturers of Battle Creek, Mich.

The estate of George Blagden, banker, philanthropist and vice president of St. Luke's Hospital, who died suddenly on March 22, 1934, while watching Bobby Jones play golf at Atlanta, Ga., was appraised yesterday at $2,510,729 gross and $2,329,067 net.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 18. -- After sixty-three days of desperate, heroic resistance, half of the garrison of the Alcazar fortress was believed to have been annihilated today by the explosion of mines driven under the building by government militia.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Giant trees crashing before a wind of gale proportions tonight nearly killed one motorist and endangered the lives of scores of others as storm damage mounted throughout Westchester County.

Alfonso, the Count de Covadonga, yesterday was reported improving in Presbyterian Hospital, where he has been ill since Aug. 26 with haemophilia. He was visited again by his mother, the former Queen Victoria Eugenie of Spain, for a few moments. He also had his twelfth blood transfusion.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- About 125 members of the Municipal Bond Club of New York braved the wind and rain to attend the fifth annual field day of the club at the Winged Foot Golf Club here today. The weather did not keep the more enthusiastic golfers in the clubhouse, and the matches were carried out on schedule.

Vice President John N. Garner declared yesterday that there was a "possibility if not a probability" that President Roosevelt would be re-elected with a larger electoral vote than he received in 1932.
GENEVA, Sept. 18. -- Behind closed doors, the Council of the League of Nations, meeting in the League's great new palace today, silently listened to Italy's terms for reoccupying her empty seat.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 18. -- In a message to the youth of the country, Governor Landon declared today that the real issue of the campaign was whether the Federal Government should "regulate" business or "direct and manage" it, and that the future prosperity and happiness of young Americans depended upon the preservation of a free form of government.

A "decided improvement" in apparel retailing was reported here yesterday by Albert M. Post, executive director of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, following his return from a five-week stay in major cities in connection with the Federal Trade Commission's inquiry into activities of the guild.

The award of twenty-four fellowships and scholarships for the academic year 1936-37 was announced yesterday by Teachers College, Columbia University. Graduate students in the Advanced School of Education received eleven valued at a total of $20,000.

ALBANY, Sept. 18. -- With the approval of Governor Lehman, State Agriculture Commissioner Peter G. Ten Eyck announced today that the price paid producers for Class 1 fluid milk would be increased on Sept. 25 by 20 cents per hundred pounds, bringing the new price up to $2.90, but strike threats continued.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Continued contributions were pledged toward Community Chest activities for the coming year, and plans were discussed for the establishment on a quota basis of a "yardstick" for the measurement of corporate responsibility for donations, at the final sessions today of the 1936 Mobilization for Human Needs, opened yesterday by President Roosevelt.

Less than four weeks after the receipt of the manuscript the Dodge Publishing Company will issue "America at the Crossroads," which will set forth, in Governor Alf M. Landon's own words, his political program and his ideas on American government. The publication date is Sept. 28. Senator Arthur C. Capper has written the introduction.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Important agreements regulating for the first time the hours of duty at sea of the men in the engine rooms, stokeholds and catering departments of foreign-going British merchant vessels were concluded today at a meeting of the sailors', firemen's and catering groups with the National Maritime Board.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Sept. 18. -Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont won the fourteenth annual women's New Jersey State golf championship at the Echo Lake Country Club today. She defeated Mrs. Maureen Orcutt Crews of White Beeches, former holder of the title, 1 up on the thirty-sixth green.

The hurricane had enough force left when it struck the North yesterday to wash away the opening game of the international polo series between the United States and Argentina, which was to have been played today at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury.

One hears occasionally from supporters of Governor Landon the singular argument that his election will not really mean any substantial reversal of New Deal policies, but merely a change of personnel in their administration. It must be a guileless innocent to whom such an argument would appeal -- or a very hungry Republican office-seeker.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 (AP). -- The Browns doubled the White Sox into defeat today, 6 to 5, and shoved Chicago into a virtual tie with Detroit for second place. Chicago has a one-percentage-point edge over the Tigers, .538 to .537.
Various housing properties were included in the Queens realty transactions reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18. -- With two of its major objectives already considered by leaders and observers as "in the bag," the selection of a new national commander and the city that will be host to the 1937 convention, several thousand of the anticipated 250,000 members of the American Legion had registered here tonight for the annual convention that will formally get under way on Sunday and last through Wednesday.

With coffee, sugar and cocoa sharply lower in active dealings, and hides, silk and rubber easier, firmness in local commodity futures markets yesterday was evidenced only in copper, tin, cottonseed oil, tallow and wool tops. On the cash markets corn and tin advanced, while wheat, oats, rye and raw sugar declined.

Several thousand persons attended the annual Fall fashion show presented last night at Frederick Loeser Co., 484 Fulton Street, Brooklyn. Bearing in mind the coming coronation of King Edward VIII, Miss Dorothy Cox, who arranged the show, pointed out the new period of magnificence that expresses itself through queenly silhouettes, suggestive of princesses, Madame Recamier and Empress Josephine, down to the modern tempo of "swingtime" in the mode.
MADRID, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Conscription of all able-bodied men and sweeping government reforms to stamp out fascism were demanded tonight by powerful Syndicalist elements in Madrid.

A new wage agreement affecting pier employes of the deep-water ship lines operating from the Port of New York was signed yesterday by representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, announced today that distribution to employes of benefits under the company's profit-sharing plan henceforth would be made semi-annually instead of yearly. He said the first distribution of 1936 shares would be made "as promptly as possible after Oct. 1."

READING, Pa., Sept. 18. -- The world's champion, Tara, 2:00, owned by Paul Bowser, Boston, and driven by Tommy Berry, won the Reading Fair free-for-all trot, feature of the getaway-day card of the Grand Circuit meeting at the Reading Fair today.

In a final rehearsal before New York City's official participation in the American Legion convention at Cleveland next week, Mayor LaGuardia reviewed 800 Police Department members of the legion yesterday afternoon in the 165th Regiment Armory, Twenty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

TOKYO, Sept. 18. -- Formation of a unitary political party in Manchukuo, to which will be assigned some of the elementary functions of self-government, was announced by General Kenkichi Ueda, the Japanese Ambassador, in a manifesto issued at Hsinking today, the fifth anniversary of the Manchurian "incident."

Officers and crews of the Deutsche Lufthansa experimental flying boats Zephir and Aeolus, which flew across the ocean from the Azores to Port Washington, L.I., were entertained at luncheon yesterday by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., at the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., Sept. 18. -- Miss Sara Worthington Clucas made her debut tonight at the Essex Fox Hounds Hunt Club in Peapack, where her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Welch Clucas of this place, gave a large supper dance in her honor.

For the ninth successive session, irregular fluctuations attended trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, and although the week's movement exceeded 600,000 bales prices held within a narrow range and ended with net changes ranging from a decline of 1 point to a gain of 2 points.

A few hours before Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard University, introduced President Roosevelt at the tercentenary exercises in Cambridge yesterday, a group of twenty-eight alumni made public in New York a pamphlet assailing Dr. Lowell's conduct and judgment as chairman of an advisory committee which reviewed the Sacco-Vanzetti case in 1927.

Apartment rentals reported yesterday included a lease of fifteen rooms and seven baths in 625 Park Avenue to Richard C. Bondy Jr., vice president of the General Cigar Company. Douglas L. Elliman Co., the brokers, also rented a furnished duplex suite of eleven rooms and four baths in 1 East End Avenue to George L. Harrison, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Baptized by a heavy sea and a raging fifty-mile gale, the United States destroyer Fanning slipped down the ways into the Kill van Kull at Staten Island yesterday at a launching unique in marine history. The launching, accomplished by a skeleton crew, was witnessed from behind locked gates by 1,500 striking shipbuilders who prevented the first scheduled launching last Wednesday.

The General Education Board, a Rockefeller institution, sold yesterday its 315,414 shares of South Penn Oil Company to the Tide Water Associated Oil group and to the South Penn Oil Company. The purchase price was $35 a share, or a total of $11,039,490.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 18. -- Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of the University of Newark, speaking at Bucknell University's annual convocation, said today that "education exists not primarily to maintain the State or to perpetuate its own institutions but to emancipate men's minds and to make those minds appreciative of other emancipated minds."

"WHY don't you review something light once in a while?" asks Constant Visitor, drifting in with a scowl and flicking cigarette ashes on the floor. Well, today there is something light; in fact, three somethings: Hiram Percy Maxim's "A Genius in the Family" (Harper, $2), Cornelia Otis Skinner's "Excuse It, Please" (Dodd, Mead, $2) and Richard Lockridge's "Mr. and Mrs. North" (Stokes, $2).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Carter Goodrich, Professor of Economics at Columbia, has been appointed Commissioner of Labor at Geneva, succeeding William G. Rice Jr., who resigned to return to the University of Wisconsin Law School.

Governor LEHMAN'S decision to dismiss the charges against District Attorney GEOGHAN of Brooklyn can hardly have come as a surprise to most people. Those who have closely followed the hearings at Albany must have discovered that the case of the prosecution, so far as technical and legal grounds are concerned, was weaker than was looked for.

Back at the Folks Theatre again, Menasha Skulnik, Second Avenue's favorite nitwit, outnitwits himself in his opening production, "Schlemiehl." He gets a break. For years now, as Getzel, Yeckel, Yankel, Berel, Schmerel, he has made it plain that he is no intellectual giant, that his plans always go wrong, that he just can't make a living.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Lonnie Warneke kept alive the Cubs' almost dead hopes of overhauling the Giants in the National League race today by choking off the Cardinals with three hits for a 3-to-0 triumph.

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- The Boerse was listless and irregular today, business being so dull that a large part of the stock board consisted of blanks. Considerable firmness was displayed, however, by heavy industrials, which registered gains up to 2 points, although some of the issues recorded fractional losses. Rayon and cellulose stocks also were generally stronger, with some exceptions.
Of the scores of persons reported yesterday missing in the storm area off the coast there was reason to believe that perhaps as many as fifty-four were dead.
I've read THE NEW YORK TIMES sports section for twenty-five years or more and have followed baseball just as long.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 18. -- The British battleship Queen Elizabeth, the 31,000-ton flagship of the Mediterranean fleet, and the destroyer Anthony are racing to Malaga following reports of serious disturbances there.

Distribution of merchandise at retail established a firm stride this week, which was broken only in a few scattered cities where heat retarded volume, according to the trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Trade in virtually all centers exceeded comparable 1935 levels, the agency reports.
As one who reads accounts of baseball each day in THE NEW YORK TIMES, but who gets to only a few games a season, I should like to take the liberty of asking you to enlighten me on two questions.

Relatives of the late Elizabeth Ann Ahearn, 68-year-old spinster, who was a school principal and head of the Welfare Board of Danvers, Mass., filed suit for $100,000 damages yesterday in Federal court against the Campagnie Generale Transatlantique because officers of the liner Ile de France buried her at sea instead of bringing the body to New York.

The headquarters of Frank J'l Prial, defeated by Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens for the Democratic nomination for Aldermanic President on the face of the returns, announced last night that an appeal would be made to the Board of Elections to re-examine several ballot boxes and that if the bcard l refused, a court order for a recount would be asked.

OMAHA, Sept. 18. -- Senator George W. Norris, progressive Republican, charged tonight in a nation-wide radio broadcast that Governor Landon and his followers were raising a "bogus cry" of "bolshevism" and "dictatorship" against President Roosevelt to divert attention from the real issue of the campaign.

A proposal that the Holy Name Society meet every year to strengthen a fight against "the growing menace of communism" was made yesterday as speakers at the society's third national convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel continued to deplore irreligion and condemn communism.

Victor Beauregard, honorary director of the French Ministry of Colonies, will arrive today on the French liner Lafayette as the official representative of the French Government and 3,000,000 French veterans to the American Legion Convention at Cleveland.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- A general rush of buying of wheat as the result of continued strength in Liverpool, where all deliveries sold at the highest marks since 1930, carried prices on the Board of Trade here today up about 1 cent a bushel at the start, and in Winnipeg around 1 1/2 cents, the latter getting into new ground for the season.

CACERES, Spain, Sept. 18. -- Driving forward today against stiffening opposition, the southern column of General Francisco Franco's picked troops on the way to relieve the Rebel cadets in the Toledo Alcazar advanced twelve miles today, from Torrijos to Rielves. The latter point is only ten miles from Toledo.

When the last out has been scored officially in the world series, and the last telegrapher wraps the cords around his key and leaves the press box to the sweepers, Damon Runyon will leave the world of sport writing behind after more than thirty years of it to become a screen writer for Paramount.

Having been unable to find any particular play for the early season, Blanche Yurka has decided, and it is quite simple, to be a program unto herself. Like Ruth Draper, Cornelia Otis Skinner and the rest, she will go out on a solitary tour, giving character studies and individual bits from the classics of the theatre.
TOPEKA, Sept. 18. -- Following is the text of Governor Landon's address before the National Conference of Young Republicans:
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18. -- The address made by President Roosevelt today at Harvard University's tercentenary celebration was as follows:

Improvement in the world economic outlook continued during July, according to the monthly review of foreign economic conditions issued yesterday by The Annalist (New York). World industrial activity increased further to the highest levels since 1929 and international trade rallied from its June setback, while commodity prices rose sharply and excess stocks of primary commodities were reduced further, it is stated.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area made a better comparative showing this week than last week, according to reports yesterday by department-store executives. Cooler weather aided turnover and gains over a year ago were registered on several days of the week.

In his address to the Young Republicans in Kansas yesterday, Governor LANDON sought to make clear a political issue which has often seemed to be confused. It was more or less confused in the speech which he himself made at Portland last Saturday night.

As executive secretary of the group organizing a Lawyers Committee for Minimum Wage Legislation, permit me to clear up the technical obscurity which apparently has led many friends of minimum wage legislation astray in their quest for a valid law.

OCEAN CITY, Md., Sept. 18. -- With water from three to four feet deep over the approaches to the Sinepuxent Bay causeway bridge, the only link with the mainland, and scores of automobiles stalled and abandoned in the flood, town authorities today forbade any further attempts on the part of natives or vacationers to get out of Ocean City.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses appealed yesterday for a departmental budgetary allowance of $9,754,951 for 1937, a figure almost double the 1936 budget allowance.

The second day of the Jewish New Year, Rosh ha-Shanah, was observed yesterday in temples and synagogues of orthodox congregations throughout the city. Jewish solidarity and the disturbances in Palestine were the subjects of many sermons.
DETROIT, Sept. 18 (AP). -- Young Bob Feller could not get his fast ball past the Tigers today and so he and the Indians were clubbed, 6 to 3, by the ex-world champions.

Solidly substantiated records show that General Abner Doubleday originated the great sport and business of baseball at Cooperstown, N.Y., nearly 100 years ago. This town expressed its pride in his invention by purchasing and developing the field on which Doubleday originated baseball.

The trustees in bankruptcy for the Western Pacific Railroad discussed plans yesterday for the sale of $3,000,000 trustees' certificates and the payment of $4,000,000 of certificates due at the end of the year. Proceeds of the new certificates would be used for current disbursements, the company having incurred a net loss of $2,105,579 in the first half of the year, in addition to a loss of $1,427,371 in the same period last year.

Stocks moved higher on a broad front yesterday, with the trading volume gaining more than 60 per cent over the day before. Many leading issues mounted 1 to 3 points, so that on the day THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks was up 1.01 points.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- With only two first-string men missing from the team that lost to Colgate alone last year and an exceptionally talented group of sophomores complementing the nineteen available letter men, Syracuse is in the position to hope for another gratifying football season.

A reduction of 1 cent a quart in the retail price of milk in New York City and suburbs, effective this morning, was announced yesterday afternoon by Borden's Products Company and the Sheffield Farms Company, Inc. As a result, New York housewives will be able to buy Grade B milk for 13 cents a quart delivered at the home, and 12 cents a quart at the store.

Net profit of the Kennecott Copper Corporation and subsidiaries for the first half of this year was reported yesterday as $9,097,891 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other charges, but before depletion. The profit was equivalent to 84 cents a share on 10,773,485 shares of no-par capital stock.

HOLLWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18. -- Metro is beginning to emerge from the confusion occasioned by the death of Irving Thalberg. Production has been at a standstill since Monday, but today "Camille," which will resume eventually its original title of "The Lady of the Camellias," was continued with Greta Garbo and Robert Taylor, the Marxes' "Day at the Races" was started again, and "Maytime" will continue on Monday.

A minor court judgment sustaining the contention of the city of Hornell, N.Y., that home relief payments are in the nature of loans which the community may recover if the recipient acquires property later, was discounted yesterday by law officials of New York City and State.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 18. -- Because the opening game of the international polo matches scheduled for tomorrow has been postponed as a result of the storm, many changes were made tonight in the social program.

The Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation purposes to exchange $7,030,000 par value of 6 per cent preferred stock now outstanding for new 4 1/2 per cent preferred stock, according to a petition filed with the New York Public Service Commission for authority to substitute the latter stock and to make certain amendments to its charter.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 18. -- Sir Henry Gullett, Trade Minister, announced today in the House of Representatives that the Armco International Corporation, a subsidiary of the American Rolling Mill Company, in conjunction with the John Lysaght Company of Australia, had decided to proceed immediately with the manufacture of sheet steel for automobile bodies, probably in New South Wales.
Directors of the Schenley Distillers Corporation declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock. Another disbursement this year will be considered later.

The Little Entente has not succumbed to the blandishments of HITLER and Dr. SCHACHT. Both the official and the unofficial reports of the conference concluded recently at Bratislava indicate that Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Rumania have not been dissuaded from their common efforts in the defense and promotion of their national interests.

The southern hurricane swept up 125 miles of New Jersey coastline yesterday, hammering away at bulkheads and boardwalks, nibbling at jetties, threatening to smash Summer houses. Roads were flooded, stalling hundreds of automobiles, trolley cars were halted, electric wires were blown down, windows were smashed and small boats were ground to driftwood, but there was only one death directly attributable to the storm.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $14,621,547, and it will be for fifty-two municipalities. The revised total for this week is $38,084,047.. The weekly average so far this year is $28,808,752.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Memorial honor was paid in Southwark Cathedral today to John Harvard, a native of the borough. His father had a butcher shop in High Street, and John Harvard was christened in St. Saviour's Church, now the cathedral church of the diocese of Southwark.

NEWPORT, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- Felix Piseck, secretary of the New York Milk Producers Federation, said today he expected a milk strike date to be set tomorrow as a result of Agriculture Commissioner Ten Eyck's compromise milk decision.

Settlement for $30,000 of a claim by the city against William Randolph Hearst, which has been pending since 1909 and really dates back to Nov. 4, 1902, was announced yesterday by Corporation Counsel Paul Windels.

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Sept. 18. -- The Lady Peace, plane in which Harry Richman and Dick Merrill twice flew over the Atlantic, landed here late today after a short hop from Musgrave Harbor. The need for repairs and adjustments on the craft will keep it here tomorrow, the actor and his pilot said.

Tom Mullen, who caught a 420-pound tuna off Seabright last weekend, had intended to return today and grab its twin. He had asked us to go along and act as official observer or something. More likely he wanted an extra hand aboard to help dish out the chum with that big soup ladle.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18. -Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, declared in an oration at the tercentenary exercises today that "we must have a spirit of tolerance which allows the expression of all opinions, however heretical they may appear."

ABOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL TRAIN ON THE WAY TO WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- After sitting in the rain for two hours at outdoor exercises this morning and then standing in rain-soaked clothes indoors later to deliver a plea for tolerance before an international audience as part of the celebration of the 300th anniversary of Harvard University, President Roosevelt rode tonight toward Washington, where Mrs. Roosevelt lay ill in the White House.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 18. -- The twenty-two bodies recovered from the wreck of Dr. Jean Baptiste Charcot's exploration ship Pourquoi-Pas, which had been lying at Straumfjord, today were taken aboard the fishing boat Aegir for removal to Reykjavik.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 18. -- The eightieth convention of the International Typographical Union, by an overwhelming vote today, completely vindicated President Charles P. Howard for joining the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Captain Stanley Burns, staff commander of the Furness liner Monarch of Bermuda, told THE NEW YORK TIMES in a radio telephone conversation at 8:30 last night that his ship was beating her way northward in a raging hurricane and high seas.

MAGNOLIA SPRINGS, Ala. (AP). -Bad roads, the plague of rural mail carriers the country over, never bother Carrier Emory Carson -- because he has the only all-water rural free delivery route in the United States. He even serves a ferryboat.

PELHAM, Mass., Sept 19. -- David Granick, 11 years old, of 106 West Thirteenth Street, New York City, won dramatic honors today when his play, depicting the life of Captain Daniel Shays, was the feature of the 150th anniversary celebration of Shays's historic rebellion in this town.

Strength in share prices in the last three days enabled the stock market to close yesterday with a small gain over the Saturday before. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks closed the week at 138.36, up 0.15 point; the week before the gain was 0.09 point.
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 19. -- John Steuart Curry will soon become "artist in residence" at the University of Wisconsin.

The twenty-fifth annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society (with the Garden Clubs of Greenwich, Rye, Riverside and Old Greenwich, and the Hortulus Club and the Little Garden of Rye cooperating) will be held at the State Armory, Greenwich, Conn., on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, the opening being at 3 P.M. on Tuesday.

SYDNEY. UNSETTLED conditions in Europe and the fear of being stranded there in case of war, as were so many travelers in Spain, have led scores of Americans to seek new places to spend their vacations. Some have found a way down through the tropic isles to New Zealand and Australia where strange beauty, new peoples and unique sights await them.

THOUSANDS of freshmen, more or less green and shivering, will gather this week for the first time in Alma Mater's halls. But instead of suffering homesickness and hazing among hostile or indifferent upper-classmen, the youngsters will have the campus pretty much to themselves in a special freshman week prior to college opening.

Following the development of streamlined engines, railroad companies are now experimenting with modernization of passenger coaches, among which are three new types produced by the Pennsylvania Railroad, according to The Mutual Magazine.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A striking monument depicting a man shielding a woman from the bitter wind while they view the grave of their child will be dedicated tomorrow by Mormon Church leaders in commemoration of the nearly 600 church members who died in "Winter quarters" here during the years of 1846-47.

On Sept. 28 the Walsh-Healey Government Contracts Act will go into effect, and the first series of regulations under it have been issued by the Secretary of Labor. This is the act, passed in the Senate on the last day of the last Congressional session, without debate and without a record vote, making various labor requirements of any contractor bidding on any Government contract of more than $10,000.

This is a good story spoiled in the telling. The basic plot is sound. It is so sound that the reader, surprised at the end, can go back in the story and say, "I might have suspected here -- and here -- but I didn't." And that quality, of holding suspense through rational development, meets a high demand in the mystery novel.

A scorched parchment page torn from a large Roman Catholic brevlary that for centuries was read in a Spanish monastery, which was recently destroyed by fire in the antichurch sweep of the Loyalist forces, will be placed on exhibition today in the Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West Thirty-first Street.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- A six-foot putt at the nineteenth green won the golf championship of the New York Athletic Club and gained possession of the John G. Anderson Trophy for Dr. Thomas J. Conte over Robert M. Clough, as the annual competition came to a close today at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

The United Textile Workers of America, in session at its biennial convention at the Hotel Delano, 106 West Forty-third Street, voted yesterday to change its main offices from New York City to Washington. The union for years has maintained its headquarters at the Bible House, Eighth Street and Third Avenue.

General buying activity in the wholesale markets here was heavy during the first three days of last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevy, Werring Howell, Inc. A considerable number of buyers arrived for short visits to the market.
