While women's clubs throughout New Jersey await developments in the revolt of the Bergenfield Junior Woman's Club against the State federation's ruling that members over 29 years of age must quit the ranks of the juniors for those of the seniors, the club itself has decided on a series of conferences before taking its threatened drastic action of withdrawing bodily from the federation and forming an entirely new and independent organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18. -- Highly significant is the fact that California's most serious agricultural labor trouble in many years should have broken out in a district where orthodox American Federation of Labor unions had made their first successful attempt to organize farm workers.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18. -- The unpopular if productive Ohio sales tax has been dragged into the State campaign and is expected to undergo a wide modification at the November election in the form of a Constitutional amendment designed to exempt from the levy all articles of food except served meals and refreshments.

AFTER eight and one-half months of intensive activity, the National Safety Council's "five-year-campaign" to reduce traffic accident deaths 35 per cent by the close of 1940 is turning out to be about what we expected -- a picture in two colors.

Mrs. Caroline O'Day, representative-at-large from New York and a tireless worker against war, will be the guest speaker at the first Fall meeting of the New York branch of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow at 99 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- On formal complaint by Senator Davis, the special Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures will inquire into allegations of political coercion of WPA workers in Pennsylvania. Senator Lonergan, the chairman, said today the charges by Mr. Davis were the first to be put before his organization officially, and that they would be considered when the committee met Sept. 28.

ANTIQUE furnishings are considered a record of our historic past, an important supplement to official archives and literary accounts. To make them available for observation and study has heretofore been chiefly the task of museums.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Sept. 19. -The Most Rev. John Francis Noll, Catholic Bishop of Fort Wayne and episcopal chairman of the Catholic lay organizations of the country, has announced the organization of a nation-wide drive against communism.

With the movement of the new crop of cotton approaching the maximum of the season, liquidation of an extensive long interest in October prior to notices next Friday and the first sign of easiness in Liverpool since the government's estimate was issued on Sept. 8, prices on the Cotton Exchange here yielded ground yesterday.

EARLY architecture of New York and the architecture of various international expositions and world's fairs will constitute the central points of interest in the series of exhibitions to be held in the Avery Library of Columbia University during the season 1936-37, according to announcement by Talbot Hamlin, librarian.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 19. -Wesleyan University will introduce a modification of the Oxford tutorial plan during its 106th year, which starts Wednesday. Other innovations will include a marked increase in interdepartmental instruction, introduction of a new course on "The Physical Universe" and five fewer courses than in 1935-36.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 19 (AP). -- George D. Widener's High Fleet, the season's leading 3-year-old filly, won her eighth victory in twelve starts today in the $5,000 Weybosset Handicap at Narragansett Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Steel ingot production has returned to the level of late August following the Labor Day recession, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly summary of business conditions. The current rate of 72.5 per cent of theoretical capacity is much nearer actual capacity than might be thought, the summary said, because of the poor condition of idle furnaces.

THE gardener who is concerned with the building of a rock garden or a wild garden of native plants and has only a semi-shaded spot available need not feel discouraged, as there are many shade-loving native plants which may now be obtained from nurseries, some of which specialize in plants of this type.

ALTHOUGH the days are growing shorter and the nights cooler, and a presage of Autumn fills the air, the house plants in their Summer garden quarters look so thriving that it seems unfeeling to rout them out and move them indoors.

PARIS, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Diplomatic circles tonight predicted that a Ministerial shake-up in Poland would result from the recent Paris visit of the nation's "strong man," General Edward Rydz-Smigly, inspector general of the army. He was reported desiring to take the government out of the hands of pro-German Rightists and establish a Center government more friendly to France.

Opening tomorrow, a Students' Essay Contest on the Constitution will be conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES for high school students in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut through the school year of 1936-37.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- New Dealers, Old Dealers, adherents of the modern school of art and conservatives are having a controversy over another of the murals with which the Department of Justice is being decorated.

The share market yesterday continued the advance that had begun on Thursday and closed steady and higher, with gains ranging from fractions to 2 points. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was 897,000 shares, compared with 494,000 the Saturday before, and represented the largest Saturday trading total since April 4.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Trevanion Thayer of Ballanreas, Elkins Park, and Mr. and Mrs. George Whitney Martin of New York introduced their daughters, Miss Mary Dixon Thayer and Miss Julia Whitney Martin, at a dance which they gave tonight at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Thayer.

The Giants, holding a five-and-a-half game lead over the Cardinals and a six-game margin on the Cubs, can clinch the National League pennant by winning four of their remaining nine games even if the second-place St. Louisans capture all of their eight scheduled contests.

CRAWFORD NOTCH, N.H., Sept. 19. -- A group of thirty-five members of the Appalachian Mountain Club, gathered at the Crawford House for an annual program of mountain climbing, last evening heard a talk upon Winter life on Mount Washington with motion pictures of trails for the Olympic ski races, skiing in June and other features of sports life in the region.

Your editorial entitled "The Anatomy of Fascism" reminds me of the late Edward King, well known in the Eighties and Nineties as a philosophic labor advocate. He used to say that he felt it his duty to lecture before radical groups of young men and women in order to make them understand clearly the various theories and "isms" they were claiming to follow.

HANKOW, China, Sunday, Sept. 20. -- Chino-Japanese tension in the middle Yangtse Valley was seriously heightened yesterday morning when an unidentified Chinese leaped from a passing truck, shot a Japanese consular policeman in the back of the head, killing him instantly, remounted the truck and sped away.

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- As the drumm're of the anti-Bolshevist speeches which echoed around the world from the Nuremberg Nazi party congress grows more distant and the verbal onslaughts are now calmly perused in cold print, the sound and fury which made them bristle in the ears of radio fans lose their first effect.

Several hundred sales people in leading department stores have given their answer to the question of what qualities are most important for an individual to perform successfully a selling job in a retail store and the collective replies were announced yesterday by the personnel group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the first part of a study entitled "An Inventory of Your Sales People."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19. -- Retail and wholesale business held about unchanged from the preceding week. While somewhat warmer than usual for this time of year, the weather was excellent for shopping and the volume of sales was generally satisfactory.
PARIS. -- With the creation of National Interprofessional Wheat Office, France is organizing the most extensive experiment in governmental supervision ever undertaken in agriculture here.

THE mixed-suit ensemble, so expressive of the relaxed, informal air of the country club and the sports field, again will be the foremost style along the sidelines this Fall when undergraduate toes begin to thud against pigskin.

The hurricane which came up the Atlantic Coast at the end of the week, keeping ships in port and endangering the lives of those on low land spits, was remarkable only because it ran in a track which such storms do not usually take. In other respects it was typical of the twisters which come out of the tropics and carry destruction.

Kaspar Khron is a master in the occult -- well, anyway, that is what he seems to be. That is what his credulous followers believe, listening to his patter of the higher life, and watching open-mouthed as his physical body disappears -- in just the right circumstances -- to the astral plane.

ESCANABA, Mich., Sept. 18. -- Defeat of the veteran Senator James Couzens by former Governor Wilber M. Brucker in the Republican primary and a party vote double that of the Democrats are hailed by Michigan Republican leaders as evidence they will triumph in November, despite the fact that the New Deal backers sent to Manila to get former Mayor Frank Murphy of Detroit to make his successful bid for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination.

ONE of the sights of Johannesburg which few American tourists miss is the Mai Mai Compound. Here dwell craftsmen who specialize in the particular requirements of natives working in the gold mines of the Reef, and some of the trades which flourish within the precincts of this compound are not to be found in the pages of any telephone or trade directory.

THE Cleveland Orchestra, which opens its nineteenth season Oct. 15 at Severance Hall, Cleveland, under Artur Rodzinski, will give twenty Thursday night concerts, which will be repeated on Saturday nights instead of Saturday afternoons, contrary to the former custom at these events.

VISITORS to Australia usually are surprised to find the seat of the Federal Government so far removed from the centers of trade and industry. For it is in the midst of a wilderness 200 miles from the nearest large city and off the main railroad that Canberra, Australia's American-designed capital, stands.

AS a result of the demands of modern collectors virtually every known intrinsic feature of books has been enlarged upon by investigators. Paper and ink have been scrutinized, signatures and cancels examined, discrepancies in the text analyzed, and the resultant points of issue exploited by vendors.

PUTTING color in men's suits has always been a delicate process, beset with the dangers of violating good taste and of offsetting unduly the colors of the accessories -- shirts, ties and socks. Fabric designers have evolved for this season a type of cloth that avoids these dangers and yet serves to give life and color to suits.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 19. -- The Newbrook Stable's fast 2-year-old pacer Judge Mahoney and Colorado Scott, pacing gelding owned and driven by J. Bruce Hay of South Orange, triumphed in the feature classes of the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today.

An open house tea this afternoon will signal the start of the thirty-third year of girls' club work for the Catholic Young Women's Club, at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street. Mrs. William C. Hammer, who had a major role in the work of redecorating the headquarters of the organization during the Summer, will assist in greeting the guests and in directing the festivities.
BOSTON, Sept. 19. -- A letter, 156 years old, which described Benedict Arnold's treason at West Point, was disclosed today by the Works Progress Administration.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The Fall season is expected to turn the interest of most visitors to golfing, horseback riding, bicycling, hunting and fishing.

Weakened and uncertain about both present and long-range policies, the Assembly of the League of Nations meets tomorrow just as its magnificent new building overlooking Lake Geneva nears completion. It is as if the sardonic gods had chosen to present man with a glaring symbol of contrast between the appearance of success and stability and the reality of failure and insecurity.

FALL study courses at the New York Botanical Garden and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden are attracting many students from the metropolitan area. The courses available at the New York institution include tree and shrub studies, trees in Winter, and Fall and Winter gardening.

Getting Judges Together THE announcement last week, by Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., of a proposed uniform schedule of penalties for traffic violations was good news to those who believe in what Maxwell Halsey, of the Harvard Bureau for Street Traffic Research, has called the sharp-shooting rather than the scattergun method of law enforcement and safety promotion.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 19. -- Government militiamen fought tonight to rout surviving Rebels from the dungeons of the razed Alcazar fortress. Advancing behind a smoke bomb barrage, the militiamen rushed one after another of the Rebels' breastworks, fashioned from piles of debris.

INCREASINGLY the travel seasons tend to merge into one another. This week, marking the end of Summer and the beginning of Fall, finds the late vacationist already on his way, tracing fresh travel patterns across routes that were once swept clear at the first breath of Autumn.

WITH the Ethiopian war off her hands, Italy has turned to a new travel "offensive." The first drive is designed to meet the double challenge of the British and French leviathans, Queen Mary and Normandie, which not only have wrested the speed laurels from the Italian Line, but also have devoted larger and more luxurious accommodations to lower-than-first class passengers at sharply reduced rates.

The eighty-seventh year of classes at City College will begin tomorrow when students return to the College of Liberal Arts and Science, the School of Technology and the School of Business and Civic Administration. The School of Education and the evening session will resume classes a week later.

THE current exhibition of Japanese art at the Boston Museum is the occasion of an informative discussion of Japanese painting and sculpture by Louis V. Ledoux in the September number of The American Magazine of Art. Mr. Ledoux's text is accompanied by many pictures illustrating his comments.

In the splendid Swiss Hall of the Castel Gandolfo last Monday morning Pope Pius, 80 years old, clad simply in white, walked firmly up the two steps to the papal throne. Observers noted that his breath came in irregular gasps, for he suffers from asthma, but his color was good and for his age his general appearance vigorous.

FROM the cloisters of Baltimore's Little Theatre has come Herman G. Weinberg to manage our town's newest foreign-language film haven, the Filmarte, at 202 West Fifty-eighth Street. Mr. Weinberg's first feature, marking the official debut of the theatre on Tuesday night, will be the noted French production "La Kermesse Heroique," which won the Grand Prix du Cinema Francais this year.

The rivalry manifested by the trunk lines in the contests for railroads to further ambitions for consolidations in the pre-1929 era has been revived in a new struggle for supremacy on the highways, it developed yesterday. The major railroads are devoting as much energy now in opposing one another's aims on roads and streets as they did in buying "key lines" at high prices a few years ago.

PARIS, Sept. 18. -- During the past week France has moved inexorably and with increasing pace toward a crisis in which Premier Leon Blum and his followers will have to make a choice between the employers and labor and in a larger sense between capitalism and socialism.

"One Summer" was written by a 15-year-old girl, but, and this is a genuine proof of the book's quality, it need not be read with the author's youth in mind. Any girl, aged from 8 to 12, who loves horses and outdoor life will enjoy this account of three girls on a Summer vacation in the country.

THE important news in men's shoes for Fall is the tendency toward modification of the American custom last, as interpreted in the past few seasons in terms of exaggerated "spade" sole extension and pointed toes.

Unless her continued illness prevents, Republican women who have declared for President Roosevelt for re-election will be greeted on Tuesday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at a small luncheon in the private dining room of the Junior League Club at 221 East Seventy-first Street, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Helen Walker Homan, vice chairman of the Progressive Republican Committee for Franklin D. Roosevelt.

TOPEKA, Sept. 19. -- Governor Landon today made public the itinerary of the first part of what many of his advisers believe may be the most important trip of his campaign. His three major speeches on this trip next week will be at Des Moines, Minneapolis and Milwaukee.

FLIGHTS across the North Atlantic, whether landings are made in swamps on Newfoundland's shore or in the sheltered waters of a Long Island harbor, have become so common that certain features of them are being overlooked by many.

The Dodgers, with their fiery fire-ball ace, Van Lingle Mungo, on the firing line, were crowding Carl Hubbell pretty hard at Ebbets Field yesterday to the mingled cheers and jeers of a strictly bipartisan crowd of 27,000.

HAVING successfully weathered its crucial first semester, the University of Newark, which last year was formed by the merger of five distinct cultural and professional schools, is trying out this Fall its first unified curriculum as a single institution.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP). -- H.G. Wells, youngest of the "big three" of modern English literature, who will celebrate his seventieth birthday Monday, already has written his obituary telling how he died at the age of 97.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 19. -The hole-by-hole description of the final round of the national amateur golf championship, in which Johnny Fischer defeated Jock McLean, follows:

THROUGH the kindly and progressive offices of the Museum of Modern Art the public is now enabled to take stock of a year's activity as carried through by the Federal Art Project. "New Horizons in American Art," the exhibition is called.

The Federal Reserve Bank reported yesterday that $8,602,000 in gold had been engaged abroad raising to $34,026,000 the week's engagements for American account. The metal contracted for yesterday consisted of $7,835,000 in France and $767,000 in England.

Public utility executives in New York yesterday saw "a ray of hope" in President Roosevelt's decision to call a "Southeastern Power Conference" in Washington on Sept. 30, but they felt that the main conclusions to be drawn from the news dwelt more in the points upon which the White House statement was silent than in those discussed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Applications by the Laclede Gas Light Company, a subsidiary of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, a registered holding company, for exemption from provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 requiring the filing of a declaration in connection with two issues of securities used for "financing the business of the company," were granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

George Bernard Shaw's letter alleging a proposed censorship of the film version of "Saint Joan" restates the thesis presented by the play and elaborately defended in its introduction, i. e., that Joan was a "Protestant martyr," setting up her private judgment against the church, and therefore, from the church's viewpoint, justly condemned as a heretic, though subsequently canonized, "because the church has a place for all types of character, including the ultra-Protestant."

CAPE TOWN. -- The work of reinforcing the Union's military machine is taking shape. Oswald Pirow, South Africa's young and energetic Minister of Defense, has returned from London, where he conferred on means of safeguarding the Union of South Africa against foreign aggression.

IN 1405 died Timur the Great just when he was on the point of setting out for China, which he intended to add to his other Asiatic dominions. It is at this moment that Miss Kneen begins the story of Middle and Southeastern Europe in the fifteenth century and of the effect wrought by Timur's death.

Miss Randall has a penchant for piling up masses of obstacles in the course of true love, and then sweeping them all away in a grand romantic finale. In "Maid of Honor" she brings together a man and a girl in the lovely setting of a farm on one of the Finger Lakes.
BRISTOL, Conn., Sept. 19 (AP). -Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg asserted today that Congress was "utterly dumb" in its spending of public funds.

Your editorial "The Crop Estimates" carries a gentle criticism of the economic planners in agriculture. One wonders why the thought is not carried further. On the same morning there came to my desk The Chicago Journal of Commerce, carrying a list of agricultural imports compiled by Parmalee Prentice.

NEW YORK CITY is endeavoring to solve a familiar but remarkable problem. She is spending about $137,000,000 this year on the education of 1,120,000 children in public schools. Yet within these schools there persists a surprising accumulation of illiteracy.

In the seventh week before November, Maine held its "barometer" poll, and other States held primaries. The Republican candidate campaigned actively, while the President worked busily in Washington, talked of a vacation and helped his alma mater celebrate a birthday.

THE inventive genius of bridge players seems to be nearly unlimited. Every year brings forth a crop of bridge gadgets -- mechanical dealing machines, devices that keep score and add up the total points scored at the same time, chips for scoring designed to replace the score pad and pencil, and other articles of kindred nature.

WITH the expansion of night life in this country, the generally gayer mood is reflected in the new styles for formal and semi-formal evening wear. Besides the recent incursion of midnight blue into the whole field of evening wear, there are changes apparent in the lines of fashionable evening apparel that set it off quite definitely from the models of previous seasons.

UNDER Lowell P. Beveridge, the Columbia University Chorus will be reorganized this season as a unit of Columbia University Extension. Several major choral works will be given during the year with the Columbia University Orchestra and assisting soloists.
STOCKHOLM. -- Socialization is the broad issue on which Sweden goes to the polls in the nation-wide election to the lower house of the Riksdag on Sept. 20.

GENEVA, Sept. 18. -- Geneva's temper is unhappy, discouraged and apprehensive as its concentrated world fills it again for the Council which opened its ninety-third session today and for the Assembly which opens its seventeenth session on Monday.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (AP). -- A wild throw to the plate with the bases full by Alex Kampouris in the eleventh inning allowed Lloyd Waner to score the winning run and gave the Pirates a 7-to-6 victory over the Reds today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Another name is to be added to the list of famous tennis players who have competed at the Casino Courts here. Kay Stammers, ranking English player, heads the list of entries for the forthcoming annual Fall championship, which will be held for the twenty-fourth successive time the week of Sept. 28.

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 19. -- The high school football season was opened in Nassau County today when the Freeport High School eleven opposed the Stamford (Conn.) team in the Freeport Stadium. The result of the battle was not gratifying to the home forces, however, for the Stamford eleven registered a 12-to-7 triumph in a close battle.

"THERE'S a long, long trail a-winding," and it beckons to hikers, campers and other recreation seekers of the wild and primitive. This network of paths for pedestrians now winds its way for 136,959 miles across the nation, over hill and dale, along the shores of lakes, across mountains and through primeval forests.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 19. -Burton Rascoe Jr., 22-year-old son of the author and literary critic, was found asphyxiated this afternoon in the kitchen of his parents' home at 42 Stuyvesant Avenue here. Doors and windows were closed and gas was flowing from five jets of the stove.

Goldeneye and Privileged, Western colorbearers both, captured two of the East's historic stakes at Belmont Park yesterday, with horses from this sector beaten off behind them. The former carried the silks of A.A. Baroni of Reno, Nev., and took the sixty-seventh Jerome Handicap by a head from Maeriel, with Tatterdemalion three lengths further back in third place.

This is the most entertaining of Miss Smalley's informational picture tales. The under-water world is full of wonders, some of which are here clearly set forth in pictures and brief descriptions that 7 to 10 year olds will find very satisfactory.
THE newspaper woman," says Ishbel Ross, speaking from experience and wisdom, "usually gets there."
COLEMAN, Texas, Sept. 19 (AP). -Eight members of a family, marooned atop their farm home by flood waters, were rescued late today after the belief had been expressed that they had been drowned.

DALLAS, Sept. 19. -- Business in all lines in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District reflected continuation of the upward trends evident throughout the year, in many instances the increases in volume and activity being more marked than in the earlier months.

The Port of New York Authority has appealed to the Interstate Commerce Commission to order the railroads serving the metropolitan district to unify their motor truck services in order that store-door pick-up and delivery service may be made possible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Cash income of the nation's farmers, including money realized from sales of produce and from government payments, will reach $7,850,000,000 in 1936, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today. The comparable farm income in 1935 was $7,090,000,000 and in 1932 it was $4,328,000,000, the depression's low point.

Martin Witte of the Lenox Hill A.A. fought off the closing burst of his team-mate, Wesley Wallace, in the latter stages of the 600-yard handicap run and slammed through to victory in the feature race of the 137th track and field games of the New York Athletic Club in the picturesque Travers Island setting yesterday.

Twenty-six college graduates have received fellowships providing for a year of advanced study from the Carnegie Institute of Technology, according to an announcement made last week by Professor O.T. Geckeler, secretary to the committee on graduate instruction.

About 4,000 bankers, drawn from all sections of the country and including many of the higher executives of Wall Street's biggest banks, are expected to attend the sixty-second annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which will be opened tomorrow in San Francisco.

Domestic corporation bonds, under the leadership of railroad issues, maintained a buoyant tone in yesterday's short trading period on the New York Stock Exchange. The demand spread over a broad list of rail liens and a few selected industrial loans, resulting in many impressive gains and the establishment of new high marks for several issues.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 19. -- The remnants of the defenders of the Alcazar were still grimly holding the shattered fortress tonight. Government forces have brought up pieces of light artillery in preparation for a close-range, final bombardment.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- After an indifferent start, clear, crisp weather brought a sharp improvement in retail trade toward the end of the week, particularly in women's hats and ready-to-wear. As a result, the average sales increase for the larger department stores was around 10 per cent over last year.

THE California calendar consists of twelve vacation months, according to East Coast standards. This may be more or less true, but the accent in the Golden State falls, as elsewhere, on June, July, August and September -- maybe one month more, for the sake of the hunters.

Twenty-five leaders of the Ethical Culture movement attended yesterday the annual fraternal conference of the society to discuss social, religious and philosophical problems. The session, which was held at the Hudson Guild Farm near Netcong. N.J., will be continued today and tomorrow.

Asserting a pride in the record of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, J. Edgar Hoover, its director, in an address here yesterday, viewed the bureau's recent critics as "schemers" for whom he had the "utmost scorn and contempt" and as enemies of "efficient, honest and straightforward law-enforcement."

AMAD clan, the Dalcarys, but respectably mad in the Jalnaesque tradition. For 500 years they have held their ground, clung to their home, half castle, half manor house, somewhere in the southwest of Scotland. For 500 years they have reproduced a headstrong and lazy temperament, and a family look on every face.

Political sunflowers bloomed this year in September, although that is the month in which the actual species goes to seed. The Republicans had a very good week, beginning last Tuesday, and from the election results in Maine and the primaries in Massachusetts, Michigan and Wisconsin certain forecasts seem conservative enough. These are:

THE Soviet Union has just celebrated the first birthday of the Stakhanoff movement, designed to vitalize and revolutionize socialist industry. In that celebration were mingled self-congratulation on the successes of the system and demands for ruthless elimination of the weaknesses and abuses which have reduced its accomplishments.

Announcement of several transactions involving the sale of retail stores during the last ten days are but the forerunner of a string of substantial deals that will be consummated in the near future, comment in well-posted retail circles indicated.
Brooklyn College came back from the brink of defeat to conquer a strong alumni combination, 20 -- 14, before 3,000 persons at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

FROM the handicraft benches of Summer camps the Boy Scouts have brought home a variety of useful articles. The trick of using fingers and creative talent to fashion something out of clay, wood, leather or metal is increasingly popular in the camp educational program.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Opportunities offered students in the United States for uninterrupted educational progress and research are duplicated in few other countries, Miss Margaret T. Corwin, dean of New Jersey College for Women, told the student body and faculty of that college today. She spoke at a convocation in Voorhees Chapel, which marked the official opening of college for its nineteenth academic year.
LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Recruiting for the British Army is going badly, although the Royal Air Force is swamped with applicants and the navy finds no difficulty in filling its ranks.

WOMEN whose foot size is on the generous side are expected to be especially interested in the shoes in one Fall collection, which have the apparent effect of shortening the foot. These shoes, high in front, swoop down in a graceful curve at the sides.
Improvements in the economic status of American wage-earners during the last twenty-two years are reviewed in a study just made by the National Industrial Conference Board.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 19. -- President Mary E. Woolley of Mount Holyoke College will address a student body exceeding 1,000 in Mary Lyon Chapel Thursday morning as the college officially opens its 100th academic year. The centennial will be celebrated next May.

With the hurricane raging seaward after missing New York, and leaving calm, clear weather in its wake, steamship officials were busy yesterday trying to rearrange their schedules, disrupted since last Thursday night when the first warnings were issued.

MONTREAL, Sept. 17. -- A French enclave within the framework of Canadian confederation was publicly stated this week as the goal toward which the younger supporters of the new Quebec government are striving.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 19. -- Yale has 31,003 graduates, according to the 1936 alumni directory, just out, and a university statement issued today said boastfully that the addresses of all except eighty had been obtained.

NANKING. (AP). -- To millions of Chinese who know little and care less about Occidental principles of public finance, the recently promulgated income tax law seems just another excuse to transfer hard-earned cash from private to official pockets.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- In an afternoon of amazing upsets, when not a single 1935 titleholder had speed enough against the competition to get out in front and stay there, five national championships in outboard hydroplane racing changed hands today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 19. -- Miss Edwina Cruikshank of Sixth Street will give a large cocktail party tomorrow afternoon at her home. Miss Cruikshank's engagement to Edward C. Weatherhead has recently been announced.

A COLLABORATOR telling tales out of school is always on the spot. He becomes the object of indecent remarks, the victim of violent nose-thumbing or the subject of considerable tsk-tsking and sympathy. It all depends on the point of view.

BEACON, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- In a historic and colorful setting before a crowd of more than 2,500 persons at Gayhead, Governor Lehman today dedicated the first completed section of the Eastern State Parkway in Dutchess County.

The number of persons treated in the out-patient clinics of seventy-two general and thirty-five special hospitals in New York decreased 1.8 per cent in 1935, as compared with 1934, according to a report made public yesterday by the United Hospital Fund of New York.

When in 1931, after the municipal elections, the Spanish republic's united parties, combined with the Socialists, won the majority a provisional government was formed presided over by Niceto Alcala Zamora, former Monarchist and head of the Moderate Republican party. General elections were then called, from which was born a government, several important portfolios in which were held by members of the Socialist party.

AN eminent philosopher was once gravely perturbed lest the production of new music should some day come to an end. Every new composition, he reflected, is only a fresh combination of a very few musical notes, and must not the time come, sooner or later, when all possible combinations have been exhausted ?

IN this age of specialists, when the general practitioner and the traditional Solon or wise man are ostensibly considered quite out of fashion and unreliable, it is amusing to watch the public bombarding every specialist of any repute with a variety of questions which should definitely imply their omniscience.

WE have all been hearing a lot about twentieth century pioneering -- jobless folk striking for the open road, struggling with old farms, settling new homesteads. But this fictionized experiment has an unusually back-to-nature flavor about it.

Former Secretary of State Stimson's interesting book, "The Far Eastern Crisis," that is just coming from the press, deals some body blows to the policy of isolation proclaimed in the Republican platform. Even Dr. Butler is not further away from that philosophy than is his fellow-Republican.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19. -- This Ohio metropolis, which has had many conventions, has put on its "Sunday clothes" in anticipation of the eighteenth annual gathering of the American Legion. There is no way to tell how many thousand of the expected 250,000 are here tonight, but a call has been dispatched by the reservations committee to Akron, almost forty miles distant, for accommodations for the overflow.

IT is not pleasant to record the complete collapse of a talent, but in no milder words can one make clear both the degree of failure and the kind of failure which M. Julian Green has registered in "Midnight." This is not just a book which fails to come off; it is a book which turns a method that once proved powerful into the grossest caricature.
May I offer an opinion to the question in Topics of The Times: "Why in the face of economic recovery is it pretty generally agreed that New England will go against Roosevelt and for Landon?"

The newly formed American Labor party of New York State, an affiliate of Labor's Non-Partisan League, is busy making plans to get its ticket on the ballot in November, to align organized labor and sympathetic groups in the State solidly behind President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman, and to serve as a spearhead in the formation of a national labor party in 1940.

SELECTION of good names for leading trains is a railroad problem about which the public hears little. A catchy and euphonious name can do much toward making a train successful. Who wouldn't rather ride on a "Gold Coast Limited" or "Twilight Special" instead of a prosaic "No. 18"?
DEATH VALLEY RANCH, Calif., Sept. 19 (AP). -- "Death Valley Scotty," master spender of the Western wilderness, will be 61 years old tomorrow.

Property owners along the East River waterfront from Twenty-third Street to Sixty-first Street are opposing the plan for the construction of the East River Drive through their territory in the belief that the motor highway would have an adverse effect on the exclusive residential districts which have been built up there in recent years, and on land being held for improvement later.

Addressing the New York Young Democratic Club and a distinguished audience at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Astor last night, Governor Herbert H. Lehman accused Republican leadership of supporting a "Bourbon philosophy," and replied to critics of President Franklin D. Roosevelt who accuse him of arousing class feeling.
DETROIT, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Bernard F., an outsider, defeated Oddesa Girl by a length to win the $2,500 Marquette Handicap, one of today's feature races. Jadva was third.

The editorial "A Cleveland Curiosity," in THE TIMES of Sept. 15, was amusing and astonishing. The ignorance of the elevator boy is comprehensible and excusable, but that the "president of the Board of Education, himself a teacher of fifteen years," as well as the president of the Teachers Union, and also a clerk in the office of the Superintendent of Education should have had no knowledge of the word "sibling" seems incredible.

Almost a hundred years ago Ralph Waldo Emerson. speaking of the American scholar, declared that the scholar is that man who must take up into himself all the ability of the time, all the contributions of the past, all the hopes of the future. In this troubled century the burden is to be borne not by one individual or by one group but by those who live in many lands.

The 1936 National Electrical and Radio Exposition closed last night at 11 o'clock in Grand Central Palace with the show's managers and radio leaders pointing to new records in both attendance and sales. The estimated attendance at closing time on Friday night was 181,000, to which was added an estimated final day crowd of nearly 20,000 between 11 A.M. and 11 P.M.
Yesterday was the seventh anniversary of the end of the last great bull market in stocks and the beginning of the depression.

MUCH has been heard about the menace of Japan, her power and her alarming future; little or nothing has been written about the weaknesses of Japan, her internal rivalries and her very uncertain future. The reason is that probably most people who write about Japan live there, and the Japanese prefer the world to see only their strength.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Lynde Selden of this place and New York gave a dance tonight at their home here to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Muriel Selden. The debutante, who received with her mother and younger sister, Miss Joan Selden, wore a princess gown of white and silver lame and a muff of gardenias. Mrs. Selden's gown was of blue satin with silver.

PEIPING, China, Sunday, Sept. 20. -- The fourth "Fengtai incident" within three months culminated yesterday in the placing of entire control of North China's most important railway junction in the hands of the Japanese Army.

ON one day 600 Fall and Winter mail-order catalogues arrive in the mail at Conchartee, Okla., population 2,000. Every year when the catalogues come it is a great day for the countryside. George Milburn (you may remember "Oklahoma Town" and "No More Trumpets," volumes of short stories) tells a string of tales involving some of these catalogues as they are distributed through the town and over the far-flung R.F.D. routes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The third annual concert sponsored by the Social Service Committee of Grasslands Hospital will be held on Tuesday evening at the County Center here. The artists will include Winifred Cecil, soprano; Edward Kane, tenor; Archer Gibson, organist, and Gibner King, pianist.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Mrs. Henry Morgan Tilford, with twelve blue ribbons, won the honors at the annual flower show of the Tuxedo Horticultural Society in the riding hall here today. The show was the largest in recent years, with eighty-four classes shown and an additional section of three classes for the Garden Club of Orange and Dutchess Counties.

An ambitious sports program with participation in the Olympic Games in Japan in 1940 as its objective is now under way in Palestine. The ancient homeland of the Jews is rapidly becoming sports conscious, and interest in athletics there is so abounding that it is certain that Palestine, for the first time in history, will have representation in the Olympics as a separate entity.

ON THE GUADARRAMA FRONT, by Courier to Burgos, Spain, Sept. 19. -- The Seventh Division of the Rebel army is hammering at the village of Guadarrama on the highway thirty miles northwest of Madrid, aiming to isolate the villages of Cercedilla and Los-Molinos-Guadarrama, now in the Leftists' possession.

Five thousand first-year students, the largest in the institution's history, will be welcomed to New York University this week by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase and other members of the administration in a series of orientation programs.

Before the echoes of HITLER'S speeches at Nuremberg have died away, it may be fitting to remark on one repeated assertion in them. He indulged in a great deal of self-glorification. He invited the world to look at the great Babylon which he had himself builded in Germany.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- A battle royal over the merits of the new postage stamps is raging in the columns of The Times of London. Most of the letters to the editor are of a critical character, deploring the fact the design is based on photographic art rather than engraving.
WITH only about six weeks to go before the Presidential campaign ends, broadcasters are waiting for the boom business expected from the Republican and Democratic National Committees.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Powel Crosley Jr., president of the Cincinnati Reds, tonight named Warren C. Giles, president of the International League, as vice president and general manager of the Reds, to succeed Larry S. MacPhail, resigned.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19. -- The Red army staff professes to have information that Germany is intensively fortifying and manning East Prussia in a manner constituting a potential threat both to Poland and Lithuania, between which East Prussia lies.

WIDER-SPACED striping and the development of the so-called checked stripe, which combines the virtues of both stripes and checks, are two characteristics of the new Fall shirtings. The checked stripes range from designs in which the vertical and horizontal lines are of approximately equal width to patterns in which the vertical stripes are pronounced and the cross-hatching exceedingly tenuous.

POESTENKILL, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- A pageant honoring the memory of President Garfield was conducted tonight in a field near this little Rensselaer County village on the fifty-fifth anniversary of his death.

Mayor La Guardia's contention that New York City will resemble a crazy-quilt, unless substantial progress is made in city planning during the next decade is amply supported by the progress report of the Mayor's Committee on City Planning which has just been published.

Three months of uncertainty regarding advertising allowances in the grocery industry will be cleared up in the course of the next two to three weeks as the country's largest producers of packaged foodstuffs resume payment of the subsidies which were suspended when the Robinson-Patman law became effective.

CONTRACTORS have thrown open to the public a new scenic three-mile link of modern concrete on U.S. Route 40, the National Highway, in the Great Meadows Plateau of the Alleghany Mountains east of Uniontown, Pa., adding another important unit to the improvements that are rapidly changing this historic old trail from narrow, bumpy washboard to a smooth highway.

Through the operations of the insurance department of the Emergency Relief Bureau more than $10,000,000 was obtained for home relief families from Jan. 1, 1934, to June 30, 1936, Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the ERB, reported yesterday.

We have tried to bring together American opinion and opinion in other countries in a common determination against the use of force for the settlement of disputes or for other national purposes. In that connection we have sought to maintain the vitality of the international agreement to renounce war which was signed by virtually all countries of the world when Mr. Kellogg was Secretary of State.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 19. -- H.T. Von Frankenburg's 12-meter sloop Zio and Heaton R. Robertson's Varuna led the large craft classes today in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's championship regatta, the next to last of the Long Island Sound series.

THE HAPPY MARINERS" is a very happy combination of adventure story and makebelieve. The four children, 12-year-old Rex, Guy and Elizabeth, the twins, who are 10 1/2, and 7-year-old Martin, are entertaining youngsters and very much alive.

Back to the city's 700-odd schools last week trooped an army of nearly a million and a quarter boys and girls -- some reluctant, some eager, but nearly all destined for surprises in the way of advanced pedagogical methods. To the casual observer the crowds filing into school houses doubtless seemed as large as ever.

THE thirty-fourth annual watercolor exhibition will be held at the Pennsylvania Academy beginning on Sunday, Nov. 1, and continuing through Sunday, Dec. 6, under the joint auspices of the Pennsylvania Academy and the Philadelphia Water-Color Club.

ONCE again the dahlia fans of the East, professional and amateur, are preparing to invade Manhattan for their annual show, to be held Wednesday and Thursday in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center. In scores of amateur gardens and in dozens of fields of commercial growers dahlia plants are being watched and tended that their blooms may be perfect for the leading dahlia event of the year.

TOKYO, Sept. 19. -- An imperial gesture will mark the significance that the Japanese Government attaches to the promotion of South American trade when on Monday the Emperor and Empress receive the six leading members of the Brazilian trade mission and their wives.

THIS is a book of "reasonable standards" for a girl. A girl who is modern, intelligent, well bred. In the form of a wise mother's letters to her daughter at college, Mrs. Banning has set down candid and detailed answers to the most pervasive problems that beset today's American girls; and this book may well find a place in many homes.

James M. Cox, Democratic candidate for President in 1920, will make a campaign speech for the Roosevelt-Garner ticket on Sept. 28 at Dayton, Ohio, James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 18. -- The rainy season in East Africa is drawing rapidly to a close and Viceroy Rodolfo Graziani's armies in Ethiopia will soon be on the move again to stamp out the last remnants of native resistance and take effective possession of those territories at present Italian only in name.

IN an increasingly insecure world British foreign policy seems to be approaching a turning point comparable in some ways to that of four decades ago when, after almost a century of virtual isolation, Britain began, reluctantly but inevitably, to throw her weight once more on the side of one of the two great armed camps into which Europe was divided.

Municipal Court Justice Nathan Sweedler of Brooklyn announced yesterday that notice had been served on the National Broadcasting Company that "any attempt to commercialize the use of the name 'Good-Will Court'", which is scheduled to go on the air tonight at 8 o'clock over WEAF under the sponsorship of a coffee company, would be followed by a suit for damages.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 19. -Baron Constantin von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, arrived here today from Berlin for an informal hunting visit. He plans to stay until Thursday.

Joseph B. Weaver, director of the Bureau of Steamboat Inspection Service of the Department of Commerce, yesterday declared himself in favor of the establishment of a series of training schools for seamen desiring advancement.
BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- The Berlin Tageblatt, in its issue dated tomorrow, asserts that Joseph Stalin of Russia is critically ill and will be succeeded by Klementy E. Voroshiloff, Commissar for Defense.

As part of its extensive vocational guidance program, Hunter College has issued this week the third revised edition of "What To Do in the World's Work," containing additional data on vocational opportunities and requirements in fields for women.
GREENVILLE, Texas, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Striking train crews on the Louisiana, Arkansas Texas and the Louisiana Arkansas Railway lines left their jobs today.

SHAKESPEARE has ceased to struggle. He lies resigned and supine in Hollywood's lush embrace. The movies have been a generous if persistent lover. They have given their best to "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and "Romeo and Juliet," and they are pledged not to relent on the proposed "Twelfth Night" and "Julius Caesar."

Imports of iron and steel products from all sources on which import duties were reduced by a reciprocal trade agreement with Belgium, increased 173 per cent in value in the first year of the agreement, according to a statement issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute as based on official statistics.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19. -- A call to Catholic laymen to combat communism by teaching the truth to the masses was sounded today by the Rt. Rev. Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University in an address to members of the Catholic Evidence Guild at their annual national conference here.

APPARENTLY there are novelists who are unwilling to let the ten-twenty-thirty melodramas rest in peace. Miss Peters has disturbed the remains of several of these swashbuckling plots to make up the story of her first novel.

TAPPAN, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- More than two hundred members of the Association of Blauvelt Descendants attended the eleventh annual meeting of the society today at the Dutch Reformed Church here. Committee reports were received throughout the morning session and were followed by election of officers and a luncheon in a recreation hall on the church grounds.

Speaking last week at Cambridge, W.L. CLAYTON, head of Anderson, Clayton Co. of Houston, the world's largest cotton-buying firm, presented a thoughtful defense of capitalism. Like most such defenses today, it was made with certain qualifications and conditions.
The tenth Washington Square outdoor art exhibition was opened yesterday morning under new management, but otherwise little changed.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 19 (AP). -The Southern Tenant Farmers Union appealed to Governor J.M. Futrell's Commission on Farm Tenancy in Arkansas today to "face facts" in the "name of truth and justice" at its sharecropper inquiry Monday at Hot Springs.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- A telegram, signed by more than 400 residents of the Nyacks and Grand View, was sent today to Governor Herbert Lehman protesting the construction of the proposed Nyack-Tarrytown bridge here at a point where the Hudson River is three miles wide.

ARMONK, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- On the basis of a musty old deed written in longhand in 1755, the Township of North Castle in Westchester County will invite President Roosevelt to attend its bicentennial celebration on Oct. 10, 11 and 12.

The American Legion is about to meet in national convention, and the responsible leaders of that organization have an opportunity to perform a public service. This is to throw their influence against any plan to make the successful drive for prepayment of the bonus a precedent for a similar drive to obtain a general service pension for World War veterans.

Portrait drawings of every White House hostess will be exhibited this week at Arnold Constable, Fortieth Street and Fifth Avenue. A special gallery has been created for this exhibition on the third floor of the store. There will be preview on Monday afternoon, to which members of Presidential families, civic and social leaders have been invited.

Mrs. Emma Guffey Miller of Pennsylvania denounced Republican business men and championed President Roosevelt at a luncheon yesterday of the Democratic Business and Professional Women at the Hotel Lincoln. Among some 350 women present was Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor.

GENEVA, Sept. 19. -- The French Government, there is ground to believe, is bringing pressure on Professor Gaston Jeze, French adviser to Haile Selassie, to prevent his serving on the Ethiopian delegation to the League of Nations Assembly, opening on Monday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 19. -- National fraternities and local clubs at Rutgers University have pledged 127 freshmen and 19 upper classmen during the pre-season rushing period, which ended this week, Dean Fraser Metzger announced today.

THE single-breasted balmacaan raincoat of worsted gabardine, whipcord or twill, with fly-front, is the leading style in wet-weather wear for the Fall. Light tan, gray and dark blue are the favored colors, with tan far in the lead.

IN ten years government food tasters have eaten, in palatability tests, countless thousands of roasts of beef, lamb and pork. They have chewed beef ribs, legs of lamb, veal, pork loins, fresh ham, cured ham, bacon, beef chuck and beefsteak.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The Red Sox took the opener of a three-game series from the Athletics today, 5 to 1. Wes Ferrell, going the route, turned in his twentieth' victory.

CRUSADING against the rising toll of life and limb in traffic accidents will assume more widely national proportions next month. On Oct. 1 and 2, official representatives of virtually every State and the District of Columbia will gather here to formulate a definite program by which it is hoped the individual States will muster their forces against highway menaces.
SINGAPORE (Reuters). -- Mobile defense units, composed of volunteer troops thoroughly familiar with the topography of the local countryside and jungle, are being trained in Malaya.

MOSCOW, Sept. 18. -- The Adolf Hitler Nuremberg hymn of hate against the Soviet Union, especially his boast of how Germany could exploit the riches of the Ukraine, the Urals and Siberia, is regarded here as amply justifying the Soviet's thorough distrust of German intentions as well as its own tremendous military establishment and its determination to make itself still stronger.
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- Thomas Campbell Black, noted English airman, died tonight after a collision at Speke Airdrome, Liverpool.

Scarcely were the awards distributed yesterday to the winners of the baby parade, which was the official climax of a week of events in Coney Island's annual Mardi Gras, when gloom spread like a hurricane among discontented mothers.

UNIONTOVN, Pa., Sept. 19 (AP). -- Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti declared tonight an investigation showed that Frank C. Monaghan, hotel keeper, was "barbarously and brutally beaten to death" while under questioning by officers in connection with the stabbing of a detective.

LONDON, Sept. 16. -- A flood of new plays continues next week. On Sunday Charles Landstone's "Front of the House," with May Agate and Sir Esme Percy, will open at the Arts. The entire action takes place in a theatre bar during a performance.

Headliners of all political parties will be audible -- although in individual cases not visible -- from the rostrum of the sixth annual Forum on Current Problems, to be held Tuesday and Wednesday under the auspices of The New York Herald Tribune at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Velvet Ball and Debutante Election Cotillion, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 30 in behalf of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, is now being arranged as "an American election party" enlisting various patriotic features and historical tableaux in a color scheme of red, white and blue.

Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College delivered his address of welcome to the freshman class yesterday morning at 9:45 o'clock in the McMillin Academic Theatre. The dean stressed the fact that the new entrants had been chosen from a large number of applicants because it was felt they "had the natural ability to make their college experience profitable."

IT would be difficult to represent the loss to music and to the men and women who genuinely love that art which has come with the death of Ossip Gabrilowitsch. And the circle can be further widened. His value projected further than the sphere of his personality or his practical services in his special field.

AFTER forty years of spinning new worlds, H.G. Wells at 70 is dreaming of vaster worlds than any he has yet spun. He has had "a few conversation with friends" on the subject of an "encyclopedia of modern thought" along the lines of Diderot's famous encyclopedia. Diderot spent twenty years on his monumental enterprise -- and Mr. Wells will be 70 tomorrow.

Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen at Binghamton, N.Y., recently defended the "spending policy" for relief purposes, arguing that "if, in time of war, this country is justified in using all of its resources to defend itself from another nation, it seems to me that in time of depression it is equally justified in using its resources to aid its own starving people."

TO the bibliography of rubber, already extensive, has now been added "Rubber. A Story of Glory and Greed," by Howard and Ralph Wolf. To read it through from cover to cover would tax the interest and endurance of a man as infatuated with the printed page as was Macaulay, who remembered everything he read, and he read everything.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- The defeat of C. Van Mess Wood by Joshua M. Fiero Jr. in the Republican primary fight in the Twenty-sixth Senatorial district on Tuesday marked the first defeat of an organization Republican candidate in Westchester for some time.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 19. -- With the approach of Winter, the "off the relief roll" program of the Mormon Church faces its first test in effectiveness.

PRINCIPAL addition to the staff of conductors during the coming Metropolitan Opera season will be Maurice de Abravanel. He will take over at least a portion of the duties assigned in recent years to Louis Hasselmans, who has left the Metropolitan.

MOSCOW (AP). -- Taking the offensive to check Fascist and White Guard propaganda in Soviet Armenia, on the far southern borders of the Soviet Union, the government has announced an extensive public and civil works program to assist Armenian immigrants there.

James Pyke, acting lieutenant in charge of the Bomb and Forgery Squad, received an official commendation yesterday from Commissioner Valentine for his handling of a forgery case. What he had done was to make personal restitution of the amount the forger obtained and set the offender free.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19. -- Big advertising and special sales campaigns have increased retail sales in a marked degree in the Eighth Federal Reserve District this week. Department stores report gains over last year of from 6 to 18 per cent.
DETROIT, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Detroit beat Cleveland today for the third straight time and moved into second place in the American League standing. The score was 7 to 3.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Five hundred applications for new distilled spirits labels are being received daily by the Federal Alcohol Administration, it was disclosed today. These labels are intended to protect the consumer and give him accurate information as to the contents of the bottle goods he purchases.

WHILE the scenic wonders of our twenty-four national parks and sixty-eight national monuments remain the major attraction for their visitors, these 15,000,000 acres of playgrounds are increasingly becoming educational institutions.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 19. -Colgate's Red Raiders defeated St. Bonaventure in a practice game today, 32 -- 0, with Whit Jaeger, halfback, turning in the most spectacular performance on an 80-yard run for a touchdown.

An announcement that has been awaited with keen interest by dog show folk the country over was made yesterday by Dr. Samuel Milbank, chairman of the bench show committee of the Westminster Kennel Club. It is the full board of judges for the annual exhibition of this famous organization, which will be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 10, 11 and 12, 1937.
TOULON, France, Sept. 19. -- Efforts of the Spanish Government to suppress the Fascist rebellion are hampered by three difficulties:

LET no one pick up this book in the belief that the familiar phrase "time to kill," which serves as title to Mr. Conner's second novel, has more than a very ironic connection with leisure, and how to spend it.

WESTBURY, L.I., N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Although the opening game of the international polo series was not played today as scheduled because of yesterday's storm, the many dinners and dances tonight that were planned to follow the match took place as planned.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 19. -Frank M. Gould's What Have You, an 8-year-old chestnut gelding, captured first honors in the feature and most exciting race today, the third running of the Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase.

A 19-month-old baby girl was fatally injured and her father and a 5-year-old girl were critically hurt last night in North Bergen in what, according to the police, was the "most unusual accident in the city's history." All three received their injuries when a rope, stretching across Church Lane where a block party of the Central Democratic Club was in progress, snapped when struck by n automobile and flew into the crowd standing near by.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- Reports on the Red army manoeuvres, which a British mission under Major Gen. A.P. Warell is attending, seem to show that last year's striking development in "parachute warfare" has been carried a stage further.

An interesting prospect for the coming season is the revival of the Dance Center, that courageous little theatre venture of Gluck-Sandor and Felicia Sorel, which has been inactive for the past three years. At present, it seems, a company has been lined up and a repertory outlined, and all that remains to be done before rehearsals actually get under way is to find a suitable location.

It was just two months ago that part of the Spanish Army in Morocco revolted and the unrest which had been sweeping Spain flared into insurrection. Since then Spaniard has been killing Spaniard; the Iberian Peninsula has been washed in blood. Last week, though the outcome of the civil war was not yet certain, the bloody struggle approached a decision.

FOR this novel of Maine shipowners and captains of an earlier time Mr. Coffin might have taken as its motto that there were giants in those days; giants, that is, in the stark crude power of their mental grip on life, in their grasp of essentials and their lordly scorn of the trivial and base.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 19. -- Federal Judge Merril E. Otis today upheld a lease signed in 1890 requiring a realty company here to pay 139,320 grains of pure gold, or its money equivalent at current gold prices, as quarterly rental for a store location.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 20. -- Although the Japanese Government cannot stand by while its nationals are being murdered, the latest outrage in Hankow will be dealt with in the first instance by a protest to Nanking.

LIVELIER trade appeared last week under the influence of cooler weather, but toward the close the storm in the East and rains elsewhere hampered sales. In sections that had suffered from heat, volume spurted ahead as temperatures dropped.

IN a report on present and impending applications of radio to education, the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education asserts "the whole activity in television is still in a highly experimental stage." Television of persons or scenes in natural colors is called "a more remote possibility" than black-and-white pictures.

A NEW translation of the Koran from the Arabic into the Polish will soon be available to Poland's 30,000 Mohammedans. The work is being published by Yugoslavia's State Printing Office at Sarajevo, the historic town where the spark that kindled the World War was struck.

LEWES, Del., Sept. 19. -- Three men were known to be dead and three others were listed as missing today from the crew of forty-one of the 390-ton fishing schooner Long Island, which, after being pounded by the heavy Atlantic's seas early Friday morning, went to the bottom just outside of Delaware Breakwater.

WITH the completion of her eighth visit of the current season to the United States, the Zeppelin Hindenburg will have carried a thousand passengers safely across the Atlantic since last May. The end of this voyage will give this new airship a record of fifteen North Atlantic crossings and eight South Atlantic hops since she was commissioned last Spring.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 19. -- America must be ready to sacrifice "commercial rights and economic advantages" to remain out of any war which may break out in Europe and must be ready to exert its influence to prevent such a war, President Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers University told the student body and faculty of the men's colleges today at the convocation formally opening the l70th college year.

A survey of college enrollments this Fall gives evidence of improved economic conditions. Nearly all institutions reported an increased total of applications and, where there are no restrictions on the total of admissions, larger freshman classes.

WE Americans are now going through our quadrennial performance, perhaps the most characteristic in our national life, that of a campaign for a Presidential election. Theoretically a noble democracy weighs, intelligently and dispassionately, men and issues, and then records the verdict of the national mind in a great and solemn referendum.

ON THE GUADARRAMA FRONT, Sept. 19. -- The youngest flier in the Spanish Rebel army, Jorge Luis Muntadas, 18 years old, brought down his first Loyalist plane today after a thrilling aerial duel high over the Guadarrama Mountains.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP). -- Lawson Little, who saw 24-year-old Johnny Fischer crowned as his successor today, characterized the Cincinnati boy's sub-par finish as "the greatest I've ever seen."

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The Poconos are looking forward to one of the busiest Fall seasons they have had in many years. Reservations for week-ends in the larger hotels have been exceptionally heavy and many people have taken advantage of fine weather to linger on in the mountains.

The balance sheet of Oppenheim, Collins Co., Inc., for July 31 showed total assets of $7,466,177, initial surplus of $920,943 and earned surplus of $777,456. Current assets, including $527,538 cash, marketable securities and accrued interest receivable, amounted to $2,289,531.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Lithgow Osborne, State Conservation Commissioner, in a speech here last night before the tenth annual convention of the New York State Division of the Izaak Walton League, made public for the first time that the Department of Purchase and Grant has acquired the fishing rights to eighty-one miles of the best trout fishing streams in the State, which will forever be open to the public.

The College of New Rochelle began its thirty-second year last Tuesday with several featured new courses. One, covering propaganda, its psychology and technique, including a study of attempts to mold public opinion, was particularly well received.
BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Young Bill Weir held the Phillies to four hits today and the Bees opened their final series with the visitors with a 5-0 shutout.

SYRACUSE no longer is to be known to the world as "the city where the trains run through the streets." That appellation, which has made citizens of Syracuse squirm for many years, will become a misnomer next Thursday with the formal opening of a vast system of overhead tracks, constructed at a cost of $17,000,000.

The nation celebrated on Thursday the 149th birthday of the Constitution. Speakers extolled the virtues of the document under which the United States became united and prosperous, holding together despite early foreign threats, swift territorial expansion, economic change and civil war.

BROWNWOOD, Texas, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The treacherous Colorado River, slashing through Central Texas on the worst flood in its history, drowned two men today, inundated a village, drove hundreds of families from their farm homes and caused inestimable property damage.

FOR the first time in the history of the theatre, press agents, of all people, are being selected with the same care as the actors. The managers are buying names, reputations and, what is the strangest phenomenon of all, engaging advance men for the road tours well in advance of the opening dates.

The opening ceremony of the 183d academic year at Columbia University will be held in the McMillin Academic Theatre at 3:30 Wednesday afternoon. It will be preceded by the traditional academic procession of trustees, members of the faculty and other officers of the university.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 19. -- A $200 scholarship, its winner's name to be pulled out of a hat -- or its equivalent -- bore the approval today of the University of Maryland's Board of Regents.

Coincident with the opening of new headquarters of the National Council of Women in the Hotel Astor, a rejuvenation of that vast federation is in progress which inevitably will influence materially its twenty-five member groups of women.
DE MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin "challenged" President Roosevelt today to repudiate what he said was the support of "Earl Browder and the Communist party."

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18. -- The Republican and Democratic parties in Wisconsin have changed positions in their ranking strength as a result of votes cast in the State-wide primary on Tuesday. The Republicans have moved up from third to second place, and the Democrats have dropped from second to third place, with the Progressive party, dominated by the La Follette brothers, the Senator and the Governor, in first position.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- A serious accident said to have been caused by a hit-and-run trolley car of the Third Avenue Railway System baffled police for eight hours today. Eugene Bradford Jr., son of a Mount Vernon detective, finally appeared at police headquarters and said he had been motorman of the trolley, but that he had summoned an ambulance for the two injured men before leaving the scene.

A poll of members of the New York Young Republican Club, announced yesterday by Paul W. Williams, president, and H. Dudley Swim, chairman of the board, has revealed a strong tendency toward Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Westchester County for the nomination for Governor.

University women of Nassau County's northern and western sections have organized a new chapter of the American Association of University Women, with a charter membership of sixty-eight. The first meeting of the new unit, the Sewanhaka Chapter, is to be Thursday at 4 P.M. in the Bellerose Women's Club.

SOME two years ago President Roosevelt united the four chief outlying dominions of the United States under one Jurisdiction. By executive order of May 29, 1934, he created the Division of Territories and Island Possessions in the Department of the Interior and allocated thereto the previously scattered supervision of Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

My Man Godfrey--A completely daffy comedy based on the Erici Hatch novel, dealing with the I lunatic Bullocks and Godfrey, the forgotten man, who became their butler and, willy-nilly, their son-inlaw. With William Powell, Carole Lombard, Alice Brady.

In a decision handed down yesterday, Justice Cropsey in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn granted the application of two plaintiffs for judgment against the Chase National Bank for damages suffered by reason of acts and omissions by the bank while acting as trustee under indenture of a series of notes amounting to $15,000,000 issued by the United Steel Works Corporation, a German concern.
MADRID, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The Socialist-Communist government turned down today the Syndicalists' demands for general conscription and a decentralized government.

FOLLOWING "Heritage," George F. Hummell's second novel, "Tradition," would seem intended to play upon the great theme of the American dream, on the American idea and the American way. The old Norwold cemetery, with its historic family names graven on aged stones, affords a description at the beginning and a setting at the end of a long book.

THOMAS MANN has become a member of the German Academy of Arts and Letters, a new organization dedicated to keeping German culture alive in exile. Other members are Thomas Mann's brother, Heinrich, and his son Klaus, Stefan Zweig, Lion Feuchtwanger, Ernst Toller, Bruno Frank and Felix Mendelssohn-Bartholdi.

VIENNA, Sept. 18. -- Optimistic views are expressed in Little Entente circles concerning the principal question discussed at the Little Entente conference which was concluded this week at Bratislava -- the relations of its various members with Russia.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 19. -The fact that no golf match is ever won until the last putt is holed was demonstrated in a convincing manner at the Garden City Golf Club today when Johnny Fischer, elongated law student at the University of Cincinnati, came from nowhere or even beyond to beat Jock McLean, Scottish Walker Cup star, for the national amateur championship.

The American League commemorated an epochal baseball record yesterday at the Stadium. A beautifully bound Morocco-leather encased, suitably inscribed scroll was presented to Lou Gehrig as a testimonial marking the 1,800th straight game in which the "Iron Man" has engaged since joining the Yankees on June 1, 1925.

CACARES, Spain, Sept. 19. -- Below the vaulting cliffs of Maqueda, the "Verdun" of Toledo and Madrid, General Francisco Franco's artillery roared today, attempting to silence the Leftist guns which are delaying the advance to the relief of Toledo where the remnants of the military cadets and Rightists are still holding out in the blasted Alcazar.

THE adding of a fraction of an inch more width to the brim of the Fall snap-brim hat and the lowering of the crown to almost as minute an extent is a striking example of what a few tiny but judicious changes can do in improv ing line in men's wear.

IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Sept. 19. -- Back at his desk in his law offices at Boise today, United States Senator James P. Pope had received pleasing news of the aftermath of a recent encounter in a neighboring village in which he won laurels as a peacemaker.

Tom K. Smith, president of the Boatman's National Bank of St. Louis, is scheduled to be elected president of the American Bankers Association to succeed Robert V. Fleming, president of the Riggs National Bank, Washington, at the annual convention of the association, which will open tomorrow in San Francisco.
The League of Nations is in abeyance, disarmament has failed and Europe is divided by new and challenging alignments. The territorial map no longer represents the complete situation.

Until the present State debt has been reduced substantially there should be no further submission to the people of propositions to increase the debt for any purpose, and the State should adopt immediately a pay-as-you-go policy, says the newly organized "Restore New York Committee" in its six-point program submitted yesterday to citizens and taxpayers of New York State.

Here is a romanticized Baedeker, a guide to pleasant spots in Wales and England and to the secret ways of a maiden's heart. Lively Nancy Lee, an American girl of good family and wealth, found travel with a much older friend was growing rather dull.

Three eminent authorities have been added this week to the faculty of the Department of the History of Art at New York University for courses which the university's graduate school will sponsor at the Metropolitan Museum of Art this Fall, Professor Walter W.S. Cook, chairman of the department, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Democratic expenditures in preparation for the Maine elections of Monday totaled $21,867.16 out of contributions of $23,347.90 made up to Aug. 31, the special Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures announced today.

Secretary ROPER of the Commerce Department has for some years gained the distinction, not shared by all the Government's present bureau chiefs, of envisaging sanely and practically matters of economic interest which concern his department's activities. For that reason, his forecast last Wednesday of the country's financial future attracted interest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The White House issued today a formal statement denouncing "a planned attempt led by a certain notorious newspaper owner to make it appear that the President passively accepts the support of alien organizations hostile to the American form of government."
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP). -- A committee of thirteen dairymen voted today a call for a milk "holiday," to start Thursday.

JUAN VICENTE GOMEZ died last December. For twenty-seven years he had been dictator of Venezuela, during which time, says the author of this astounding biography, "there was not one line of free, unsubsidized opinion set up in type and preserved in public archives, nor indeed one word of free opinion uttered in public."

Mrs. W. Henry France, who was elected last Spring as president of the Wellesley Club of New York, has announced her retirement from that post due to her imminent departure for residence in England. A successor to Mrs. France will be elected at a meeting of the board to be held Oct. 5 at the headquarters in the Women's University Club at 106 East Fifty-second Street.
