PARIS, Sept. 17. -- At the grand evening galas at Cannes all-white or dead-black tulle gowns, forming a background for extravagant jewels, were outstanding. Mediterranean-blues were their only serious rivals.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- City officials announced here today that they would start legal action on Monday to force Miss Christabel Creswell to move a two-story wooden frame house that, they declare, has stood for six years in the middle of Railroad Place, partly blocking the road.

THE Guild for Musicians, recently organized by Ethel Cohen and Erminie Kahn, has been formed to represent musicians as performers or lecturers in special fields, especially those of old and new music and chamber music.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., Sept. 19. -- Opposition by industrial and financial interests to President Roosevelt was attributed today by John L. Lewis to a realization that if the President is re-elected he "will revive his original program of fundamental reform, which they have temporarily checked by their opposition."

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Mucho Gusto, 16-to-1 shot, owned by Mrs. K. Ramsey of Louisville, Ky., was the surprise winner of the $2,500 Francis S. Peabody Memorial Handicap at one mile, feature at Lincoln Fields today. Silk Mask was second and Noble Count third. Ten started.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Army engineering contracts for more than $2,500,000 construction work in various sections of the country were announced by the War Department today as follows:

MACKAY, Idaho, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Senator Borah declared today that the "depression was permanently receding," making an address on "Reclamation" at the annual irrigation celebration in Lost River Valley.

WITH the opening of the next National Automobile Show here on Nov. 11 less than eight weeks away, those responsible for the staging of the exhibition in the Grand Central Palace are busy with preparations. They are reported as busier than usual at this season because, for one thing, an extra floor has been added to the exhibition space to take care of a new entry -- trailers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Possibility of a joint conference between railroads and the Interstate Commerce Commission on the problem of the railroads' contributions to community chest funds was hinted here at a meeting of railroad executives who attended the conference of the Mobilization for Human Needs.

RACING against time, government archaeologists are digging in the region of Lake Mead before the swelling waters of the largest man-made lake cover up traces of what is said to be the oldest known human habitation on the North American Continent, an old Indian settlement.

HE is small and gray, solid and wise, and in 1923 he decided he was through as an active showman. That was too bad, everybody said, ,because no smarter vaudeville magnate had ever put his stamp upon the then still flourishing two-a-day.

WITH the coming of cool Autumn days, the city devotees of walking are looking over their brokenin shoes and are preparing to renew or gain acquaintance with the aspect of things more or less close at hand.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, said last night that the agreement reached on Friday between longshoremen and steamship operators would not actually become effective until it had been ratified by the membership of Atlantic Coast unions.

The Patman anti-price-discrimination law continues to be a bone of contention in both distribution and manufacturing circles. The great interest shown in the law is indicated by the fact that the large crowds which will attend the mock trial of the act under the auspices of the Sales Executives Club of New York have compelled the selection of a larger hotel space.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19. -- Indications that the purge of "Trotskyists" from the Communist party is beginning to moderate are seen in a strongly worded warning from the Kremlin to local party leaders to quit expelling members for trivial or imaginary reasons.
MADRID, Sept. 19 (AP). -- The Chilean Ambassador, Aurelio Nunez Morgado, acting dean of the diplomatic corps, made an effort tonight to obtain the release of the women and children in the Alcazar.

A speed-boat racing season which has seen several records topple in the more than one hundred 1936 regattas held on rivers, lakes and harbors will wind up this week with a great and impressive finale. On the Potomac at Washington the President's Cup Regatta will attract the drivers from coast to coast, on Saturday and Sunday.

THE National Association of Science Writers might readily confer an honorary membership upon H.G. Wells. First, because it might be a cheering birthday gift to a man who tomorrow faces what he calls the "melancholy occasion" of reaching the age of threescore and ten.

An uncounted number of thousands do their yacht cruising the year round. They follow the sun and go where it is Summer for twelve months -- up North from May to October and to Florida during the Fall and Winter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Recent important announcements on foreign policy by President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull, combined with critical situations in Europe, have served to focus public attention on subjects which ordinarily are largely ignored in a Presidential campaign year.

A HUMDRUM description of this book would be Japan brought up to date. Within the volume we find a clear and comprehensive survey of Japan's traditions, her development, her culture, her customs, her institutions and all that is hers.

Zooming across Manhattan in a squadron of transcontinental airliners, members of the New York League of Business and Professional Women will hold what they believe to be the city's first "air picnic" Wednesday evening. The flight will start from the Newark Airport.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- Figures issued by the Reich Ministry of Justice, revealing that no fewer than 501,373 persons profited from the amnesty law decreed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler on April 23, show almost as many profited from it as did from the "Hindenburg amnesty" decreed Aug. 7, 1934.

MUNICH, Sept. 18. -- The number of political prisoners still confined in German concentration camps is slightly in excess of 5,000, according to figures obtained from official quarters. A total of more than 40,000 prisoners have experienced varying periods of internment since the camps were installed by the National Socialist regime in the Spring of 1933, the figures admitted for the three years being 14,283 in 1933, 13,200 in 1934 and 13,033 in 1935.

New York City's retail public market system, which consists primarily of about 5,000 pushcarts, is on the threshold of profound changes. Last Spring an enclosed market, clean, bright and orderly, replaced a 15-year-old open-air pushcart market on Harlem's eastern fringe.

RICHMOND, Sept. 19. -- Except for the drop in the eastern area of the Fifth Reserve District, affected by hurricane threats, retail trade for this week has been in excellent volume, aided by the reopening of schools and colleges. Even interior points in Virginia and the Carolinas report slackening of trade, due to the storm.

ONLY, perhaps, when he sees a great many Oriental works of art assembled does the Occidental appreciate in full measure the Japanese precept that but a single object of great beauty should be shown at a time.

Mrs. William P. Earle Jr., member of the New York City Charter Commission, will speak on "The New City Charter" Tuesday evening at 8 o'clock at the first regular meeting of the season of the Pierrepont Tuesday Club in the undercroft of the Church of the Saviour on Brooklyn Heights.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 19. -When Princeton University begins its 190th academic year on Tuesday, Sept. 29, four departments will be headed by new chairmen and the faculty will be augmented by twenty-two new appointees to the rank of instructor or higher, it was announced here today by President Harold Willis Dodds.
Following is the text of the address by Governor Herbert H. Lehman last night before the New York Young Democratic Club at the Hotel Astor.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, took issue yesterday with the statement recently made by State Senator George R. Fearon of Syracuse that industry is being driven from the State because of "laws put on the statute books at Albany."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- This week's grade and staple report for the Cotton Belt as a whole, issued today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, showed that 70 per cent of the cotton classed this week was white middling or better in grade; 80 per cent of the cotton classed to date from the current crop was of this classification, compared with 84 per cent up to a week ago.

COSHOCTON, Ohio, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Mrs. Edith Buckmaster West, who sought to wreck a train and rob the passengers to obtain money for a divorce so that she could remarry, heard herself and three men sentenced to prison terms today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- President Roosevelt today called a conference of government power experts and prominent representatives of private operators for Sept. 30 to discuss the possibility of "pooling" public and private operations in the Southeast, where the Tennessee Valley Authority is functioning, and later in other regions where the government will have its own developments.

While weather conditions still proved somewhat of a handicap, retail trade in the metropolitan area showed improvement last week in comparison with the preceding week. Department store volume ran ahead of the comparative 1935 period by an estimated 4 to 5 per cent.

LONDON. HAS a human being the same right to euthanasia that he gives a dog whose life has become a burden? "Gentle Rain," a piece by Denison Clift and Frank Gregory, presented at the Vaudeville this week, raises the question once more, and as it slowly takes shape one feels, and tries not to feel, like an elderly member of a debating society which is about to discuss capital punishment.

While Fall retail trade has yet to hit its stride, a significant indication of how retailers view the outlook was given last week when buyers began early preparations for what is expected to prove the best Christmas holiday season since 1929, from the standpoint of sales increases and profits.

ILLITERACY AHEAD?: Does the world grow more literate -- or more illiterate? 'Dr. Frank C. Laubach, who is traveling in the Far East for the World Literacy Movement of New York, asserted in Manila last Wednesday: (1) that more than half of the earth's population is illiterate; (2) that at the present rate of education a majority of all peoples will be illiterate in a thousand years.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- At a meeting of Cabinet Ministers including Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Malcolm MacDonald, Dominions Secretary, yesterday, it was decided to delay making a declaration on martial law in Palestine until the situation further develops.

WHILE the number of travelers returning from holiday scenes is reaching peak figures, other travelers are either outward bound or making ready for October and November tours. Particularly does the popularity of the short cruise continue unabated through all seasons.

ALONG line of celebrities, from Henry VIII to Nogretti and Zambra, the renowned makers of meteorological instruments, has been associated with London's Hatton Garden, which is not a sylvan retreat, as its name might indicate, but a commercial street where wholesale dealers in diamonds make their headquarters.

There has been considerable prediction this past week that the national tennis victory of Miss Alice marble over Miss Helen Jacobs presages a new era in women's tennis. This statement would seem to be true, not necessarily because the termination of a many-times champion's reign means a new development, but because in this instance Miss Marble has a modern all-around attack different from any American champion of the past.

HOLLYWOOD. TWO decades ago D.W. Griffith made "The Battle of Elderbush Gulch." It did with Indians and in one sequence the braves stalked through the night to within a few feet of the unsuspecting settlers.

THE Casey Jones School of Aeronautics, Newark, N.J., started its Fall term on Sept. 14 with a record entering class of 122 students, bringing the total enrollment to over 400. The incoming students were divided as follows: Day school -- 33 aeronautical engineers, 30 master mechanics; night school -- 31 aeronautical engineers, 28 master mechanics.

G.B.S. IN ACTION: It must have been like old times for George Bernard Shaw last week. It seems that the 80-year-old dramatist and polemist has written a scenario from his play "Saint Joan"; also that he discovered that an alleged ecclesiastical body, which he calls the "Azione Catholica," or "Catholic Action," in the "Hays Organization," had suggested deletions in his script on pain of disapproval.
In looking over the statistics appended to your recent editorial "Our Trade With Germany" it occurs to me that these figures should be weighed, also, from another angle.

NEW fashions in hand-knitted clothes have a dual interest: they parallel the style evolution of both silhouette and textiles Anny Blatt, well known for her hand-knitted models, has many interesting novelties of surface this season.

More than 7,500 stores from New York to California will participate in the third annual silk parade, the annual promotion of silks and silk merchandise, which begins tomorrow and continues throughout the week, it was announced yesterday by the International Silk Guild.

Supreme Court Justice Edgar L. Lauer yesterday ordered Father Divine, Negro evangelist in Harlem, to appear for examination in proceedings against him to enforce payment of two judgments amounting to $7,245.

Drastic changes in the methods and procedure of the Societies for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in the five boroughs were recommended by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, in a report made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Search as you may, it is impossible to discover signs in Europe of the existence of a common front resistance to the Bolshevist menace which seems to cause such anguish to Chancellor Adolf Hitler. Neither would it be true to say that Europe is about to fall into two camps on this issue.
PARIS, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Settlement of the strike paralyzing the French textile center in the Vosges Mountains was held up tonight by the refusal of workers to leave the mills pending negotiations.
Mrs. William Foster Rowland, president of the City Federation of Women's Clubs, has reopened the headquarters in the Hotel Astor and is immersed in preparations for the impending programs.

IN "Grandsons," his first novel, Louis Adamic used his intimate knowledge of expatriation to write a parable of patriotism. As penetrating as anything he had ever written about himself, it lacked, for all of its understanding and distinctive power, several of the more essential qualities that make a novel satisfying as well as arresting.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19. -- National Commander Ray Murphy, in his annual report made public tonight, urged mobilization of the whole strength of the American Legion to prevent another war involving the United States and cited legislative gains made by the organization.

Under the aegis of the Women's Trade Union League, the Laundry Workers International Union is starting a drive to organize the 20,000 women in this industry. This drive is a result of the decision of the Supreme Court that the Minimum Wage Law was unconstitutional.

WITH the first hint of Autumn-crimson and gold leaves and a nippy breeze -- comes news of tweeds, grand and soft and yet rough enough to suggest warmth, and rich enough in color to harmonize with the Fall atmosphere.
BOSTON, Sept. 18. -- The primaries on Tuesday last produced surprises both in Massachusetts and New Hampshire.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Of all the issues debated by Democrats and Republicans, severally and collectively, probably no single item is more hotly discussed than the cost of the New Deal. In practically all of these debates the debaters attempt to prove their respective contentions without much real knowledge of the actual figures involved.

ATHENS, Greece, Sept. 6. -- Although the import of his political talks was not revealed by King Edward after his recent swing through the Balkans, late advices indicate that statesmen, press and people there found his visit an important reaffirmation of Britain's mounting interest in the Near East.

THE extent to which industry and business have recovered from the ravages of the depression is indicated by the unparalleled volume of commercial car and truck sales this year. The truck people have the distinction, not attained by many industries, of surpassing their 1929 record, which heretofore had topped all other years in their history.

WENEVER Hiram Percy Maxim roused his father's attention something more wonderful than the total of all of most men's remembered Christmases was likely to occur. A dead cat buried beneath a runty, ill-bearing peach tree brought forth huge, magnificent peaches in an hour, just enough of them to fill to the brim a large, new peach basket that happened to be in the yard.

The current upswing in the demand for machine tools, plant equipment and new factories was credited yesterday to the substantial recovery in general business and the development of new machinery by well-informed accountants and engineers, who discredited the opinions of some business men that the artificial stimulus of the Corporate Tax Law was responsible.

CUBA, N.Y., Sept. 19 (AP). -- Henry S. Manley, who resigned recently as counsel to the State Milk Control Division, declared at a Republican rally here tonight that "one reason milk control has become a dishonest pretense is because Governor Lehman has never backed up by action any of the things that he has said should be done."

About 100 Hunter College freshmen found yesterday morning that college life is not all books and study when, as guests of the Freshman Advisory Committee, they frolicked at a roller-skating party on the Central Park Mall.

IN the Nineties a sardonic cigarette manufacturer established a monopoly in the use of "Coffin Nails" as a nickname for his product. A President of the United States gave written permission for the use of his name as a cigar brand.

ROME (AP). -- Italian leaders have started in a campaign to convince colonists of Ethiopia that the color line must be sharply drawn and rigidly observed.

Kikugoro, the reigning favorite of the Japanese stage, accompanied by a troupe of thirty supporting artists, will visit New York early next Spring as the climax to an Occidental itinerary arranged for him by leading figures in the civic and cultural life of the island empire.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (P). -- A 10 per cent wage increase, to be taken out of profits of the prevailing business upturn, vas demanded today by two groups of employes of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, subsidiary of United States Steel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Another effort to solve the problem of shortening and improving the form and content of the selling prospectus that, under the Securities Act of 1933, is supplied to prospective purchasers of registered securities is being made by the Securities and Exchange Commission and representatives of investment bankers.

The Southern hurricane that raged up the Eastern seaboard on Thursday and Friday swung eastward early yesterday morning and was dissipating itself over blue water in the Atlantic after giving New England a mild sample of its force.
BURGOS, Spain, Sept. 18. -- Generals Emilio Mola and Francisco Franco say they are planning to take Madrid in the same way that Sir Arthur Wellesley, later the Duke of Wellington, did.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 18. -- An unusually heavy vanguard battle in a national campaign was brought to a successful termination by the Republicans when the ballots of Maine's early State election were counted on Monday night.

NO Don Quixote tilting at windmills could have charged his foe more magnificently nor more tragically than did the illustrious George Bernard Shaw last week when he leveled his acerb lance against film censorship.
BURGOS, Spain, Sept. 19 (AP). -Rebel armies were ready tonight for a "final attack" on Madrid. The northern and southern armies, an announcement said, were ringed around the Spanish capital.
Additional bond redemptions announced last week for this month comprised only a few small municipal issues. New calls for pre-maturity payments in future months continued on a moderate scale.

FAMOUS as Dame Ethel Smyth is as a musician, her work has always flowed outside the current of English music; yet her life has been very much a part of English life. Her autobiography is interesting, thus, from two points of view.

Prices of commodity futures were mixed in local markets during the week ended on Friday, with sugar, coffee, cocoa and wool top futures lower, and rubber, silk, hides and tin futures higher. Other staples showed slight changes.

WITH the return of box-office prosperity, the industry is on its first expansion spree since boom days. The independents are finding rental space at a premium and the majors are contemplating or executing improvements.
MADRID, Sept. 19 (AP). -- Fernando de los Rios, one-time Foreign Minister and now dean of Madrid University, was named Ambassador to Washington today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. SIGNS of revival of playgoing -an old civic custom which threatened for a time to become obsolete -- are in the air. It seems that some higher power has said "Let there be shows for Chicago."

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher Webster Rockwell of New York and Riverside gave a tea dance this afternoon at the Round Hill Club here to introduce to society Miss Alexandra Grosset, daughter of Mrs. Rockwell and of the late Alexander Grosset.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 19. -With the sun sinking beyond the hills, a thousand spectators remained on the greensward of the Fair Grounds today to acclaim the victor in the final event of the eighth annual dog show of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club.

ANEW short-wave station, "Radio Podebrady," at Prague, Czechoslovakia, is transmitting daily on 15.23 megacycles from 2:25 to 4:30 P.M., Eastern standard time, according to the Czechoslovak Consul General in New York. All afternoon programs include news in English at 4:15 o'clock.

The Brooklyn Football Dodgers wound up their pre-season exhibition series last night by downing the Stapleton Buffaloes on the loser's home gridiron at Dexter Park, Brooklyn. A crowd of 3,000 saw the Dodgers triumph by 14 to 7.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 19. -- In a statement made to The Chattanooga Times tonight, Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, TVA chariman, asserted that if President Roosevelt succeeds in carrying out his proposal for a power transmission pool for the Southeastern area "it will represent one of the finest achievements of his administration and he will deserve the highest credit for a fair and permanent solution to a perplexing and bitter controversy."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va. -- White Sulphur Springs, encircled by the towering Alleghanies and resplendent in Autumn colors, will offer a beautiful setting for the coming garden club event at the Greenbrier.

JOAQUIN MILLER was such an incorrigible showman that he had less need for a publicity agent than other American authors. The experiences of his early life were entertainingly picturesque and unusual, but this did not prevent him from gilding the lily.

RECENTLY, in connection with my activities as chairman of the motion-picture committee of the National Education Association's Department of Secondary Education, I visited the leading film studios in England, notably Alex Korda's plant at Denham and the Gaumont British studios at Shepherd's Bush.

TELEVISION is seen as a partial solution to keeping farm boys on the farm. T. Stewart Lyon, chairman of the Ontario Hydro-Electric Commission, told delegates to the Third World Power Conference that television might raise "a most formidable barrier to the drift of rural population to the cities."

With wash goods lines scheduled to open around Oct. 1, dry goods jobbers will launch their Spring purchasing during the first week of next month, they said here yesterday. From current indications, buying of all types of Spring cotton goods will be considerably earlier and heavier than last year, and by the end of 1936 mills will have piled up a strong backlog of orders, it was said.

With all the fanfare and color that only international polo brings to its broad surface, International Field at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury today will feel the hoof-beats of the teams of the United States and Argentina in the opening match for the Cup of the Americas.

TRAVIS INGHAM, apparently, must be counted as another recruit to the gilded cause of potboiling. His first novel, "Young Gentlemen, Rise," was no masterpiece, but it did have something to say and it was at least timely and honest.

NOW and again in the spate of publication there will be a book -- it may be large, it may be small -- which seems to leap far above the surface, as a dappled fish breaks suddenly from a stream to flash iridescently in the sun. "Before the Great Silence" is such a book.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Sept. 19 (AP). -- Thurlow M. Gordon of New York, formerly with the Federal Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission, urged today that specific authority be given to the Federal Trade Commission by Congress to approve trade practices under the Robinson-Patman act.

COMPLETELY surrounded by Gae Foster girls, we listened in backstage at the Roxy the other night on Leo Carrillo's engaging personal appearance. The girls, modestly enveloped in diaphanous safari outfits, reclined about or sighted aimlessly along mean-looking elephant guns painted green, apparently not as interested in Mr. Carrillo's words as we were.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 19. -- Colonel Charles G. Blakeslee of Jamaica, L.I., commanding officer of the 104th Field Artillery of the National Guard, was appointed today by Major Gen. William N. Haskell to succeed Brig. Gen. John J. Phelan as commander of the Ninety-third National Guard Brigade.

THE awards in the school song competition sponsored by Ginn Co., for which some 900 entries were received from all parts of the country, have just been announced by the judges -- Howard Hanson, Albert Stoessel, Mabelle Glenn, A. Walter Kramer and Will Earhart.

DIXIE, Que., Sept. 19. -- Mrs. A.B. Darling of Montreal won the women's Canadian open golf championship today, defeating Miss Margery Kirkham, another Montrealer, 4 and 2, in a thirty-six-hole final at the Royal Montreal Golf Club.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- A series of social affairs at the country clubs, resort hotels and inns here will be continued into the Autumn season. A special 'post-season visitors' golf tournament will be held on the Asheville Golf and Country Club course starting Oct. 1.
A HEADY combination of love and danger is Captain Hardy's latest romantic thriller. Its exciting, engrossing story is warranted to keep the reader on tenterhooks till the last page.
THE key to this enigma," said Poirot, "lies in a complete understanding of Mrs. Leidner's character."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP). -The Bureau of Mines recommended today a daily average crude oil production of 2,842,300 barrels to meet October estimated demand for petroleum and provide for reasonable changes in stocks. This was 21,700 barrels lower than for September, but 288,100 higher than for October last year.
VADUZ, Liechtenstein (AP). -- Liechtenstein, the fairyland principality which peacemakers forgot, is having her troubles.

OMAHA, Sept. 18. -- Long ago it was all but unanimously conceded in Nebraska that George W. Norris held the option to a life tenure of his seat in the United States Senate, if he chose to exercise it.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- King Edward's arrival at Balmoral Castle this week-end is giving added interest to the shooting season. His guests include the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough and the Duke and Duchess of Sutherland.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, leader of the conservative Democrats who are opposing the Roosevelt administration, will open a campaign of pre-election addresses attacking the administration and the New Deal in a speech Oct. 1 at Carnegie Hall, it became known last night.

The dirigible Hindenburg, on its seventh flight from Germany to the United States, was reported passing Montauk Point, L.I., shortly after 1 o'clock this morning. The report was sent out by Mackay Radio. An earlier message from the airship said that it was traveling along the New England coast at a speed of sixty-six miles an hour.
NANKING. -- With "squeeze" and corruption greatly reduced, China's government-controlled merchant marine is earning profits for the first time in years.

Mayor La Guardia and Controller Frank J. Taylor were sharply criticized yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York for their suggestion that the reduction in the reserve for uncollected taxes in the 1937 budget, recently negotiated with banking interests, be used to restore city employes' salaries to the levels in force before the pay cuts.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- Prices on the Boerse were irregular today and the turnover remained merely nominal. Heavy industrial shares profited from the higher dividend expectations for Kloeckner, which jumped 3 1/2 point, taking other stocks with it for rises approximating 1 point.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press). -- Surprising form reversals today by Derby County and Middlesbrough sent Portsmouth and Stoke Citer into the lead in the English Football League. Preston North End gained a 2-1 victory decision over the county, playing at home, for its first victory of the season.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- A story book home run by Pinch-Hitter Jim (Ripper) Collins with the bases loaded in the seventh inning today carried the Cardinals to a 9-to-6 triumph over the Cubs and back to second place in the National League.
PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT and Governor Landon were telecast over the New York area a few days ago on the late evening air.

KINGSTON, R.I., Sept. 19.--Rhode Island State had an easy time defeating the American International College eleven, 32 to 0, today. Rhode Island scored three touchdowns within a few moments as the second quarter opened. Bobby Mudge cracking through his own left tackle for a 61-yard run to tally the second.

Another advance in carpet and rug prices appeared certain before the end of November as a result of the 5 to 10 per cent increase in quotations on carpet wools at the close of the London wool auctions Friday. Mill men and rug buyers here both agreed that the London advance would be felt in the finished goods lines within, a short time because of low stocks on hand here.

JUNE, by a sort of general agreement has come to be accepted as "garden visiting month." Garden clubs and other organizations then plan innumerable inspection trips to famous gardens. On such trips garden lovers pick up a great fund of general information, and especially do they have a chance to compare and judge the performance, under actual growing conditions, of new varieties of recently introduced perennials, bulbs and shrubs.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 19. -- The East Orange and Cranford High School elevens, engaging in their opening battle of the season, played to a scoreless deadlock today.

KINGSTON, R.I., Sept. 19.--Rhode Island State had an easy time defeating the American International College eleven, 32 to 0, today. Rhode Island scored three touchdowns within a few moments as the second quarter opened. Bobby Mudge cracking through his own left tackle for a 61-yard run to tally the second.

Another advance in carpet and rug prices appeared certain before the end of November as a result of the 5 to 10 per cent increase in quotations on carpet wools at the close of the London wool auctions Friday. Mill men and rug buyers here both agreed that the London advance would be felt in the finished goods lines within, a short time because of low stocks on hand here.

JUNE, by a sort of general agreement has come to be accepted as "garden visiting month." Garden clubs and other organizations then plan innumerable inspection trips to famous gardens. On such trips garden lovers pick up a great fund of general information, and especially do they have a chance to compare and judge the performance, under actual growing conditions, of new varieties of recently introduced perennials, bulbs and shrubs.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 19. -- The East Orange and Cranford High School elevens, engaging in their opening battle of the season, played to a scoreless deadlock today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- A continued upward trend in placement of jobseekers in private enterprise, through the United States Employment Service, was reported today by Secretary Perkins with the statement that 128,353 applicants had been put to work in this field in August.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The condition of Mrs. Roosevelt, who has been ill with the grip for several days, being much improved, President Roosevelt left tonight for his Hyde Park home.

Members of the committee running the tenth Washington Square outdoor art exhibition agreed yesterday, the second day of the show, that their greatest difficulty was in getting the artists settled. The painters do more "squawking" about the positions they draw than about anything else.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Adding still third national championship to the two he won here yesterday, Clinton R. Ferguson, the Massachusetts prep school student whose idea of a Summer's vacation is to risk his neck in the dangerous sport of racing speed boats at nearly a mile a minute, became the first driver in outboard history to carry off three American titles the same year.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 20. -- The insurgent garrison is still holding out in the reeking shambles of the Alcazar. The Rebel column under Colonel Juan Yague is making slow progress in its desperate fight to break through in time to save the defenders.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company provided 148,300 free rides for poor children in July and August, representing 74,150 round trips between city parks and the congested tenement districts of Manhattan and the Bronx, Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the company, announced yesterday.

Merchandising and promotional events centered about wines for both beverage and cooking purposes will bring the sharpest advance in consumption since repeal, liquor interests predicted yesterday. For the first time since prohibition was abolished, they added, the wine industry feels confident of being able to interest consumers in their products and is ready to spend money for promotion.

Headed by George W. Mason, president and chairman of the board, 600 Kelvinator men will sail on the Franconia tonight for Havana on a good-will tour. The group of executives, star salesmen and guests will arrive back in New York on Sept. 30.

Twenty-four English girls, daughters of British Rotary Club members, arrived in New York at 7:15 P.M. yesterday and declared they were "starved for tea." They have been visiting in this country since Aug. 24, when they arrived on the Queen Mary, and though they have visited in Boston, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C., and Buffalo, no one has given them afternoon tea.

WITH THE REBEL ARMY ON THE MAQUEDA FRONT, Sept. 20 (By Courier to Burgos). -- A battle royal that may well prove decisive in Spain's civil war is now being fought on the last twenty-five-mile stretch of road between Talavera de la Reina and Maqueda.

GIBRALTAR, Sept. 20 (AP). --John Dored, Paramount newsreel camera man, reached Gibraltar today after his release by Spanish Rebels, who arrested him in Southwest Spain. He was transferred to Seville, and General Francisco Franco, commander-in-chief of the Rebels, obtained Mr. Dored's release at the request of the United States Consul, Charles A. Bay.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Leonard Collins's Canadian-bred Old English sheep dog, Ideal Weather, now in his first year of competition, was named best in show in the fifth annual Camden County Kennel Club exhibition today at the Crescent County Club, where 575 dogs were benched.

The directors of the International Mining Corporation, in response to the request of holders of approximately 57 per cent of the common stock and a substantial amount of the stock-purchase warrants, have recommended a plan suggested by stockholders for eliminating outstanding warrants to buy common stock below its market value which will not expire for nearly three years.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,459,886,300. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

WILDWOOD CREST, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Arne Elo, 24 years old, and Alexander Barcezf, 38, fishermen from Cold Spring Harbor, N.J., were rescued near here today by a Coast Guard cutter after they had been adrift and without food for two days in a thirty-foot cabin cruiser during the hurricane that swept the Jersey coast.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- It is a principle of warfare that victory lies on the side with the stronger reserves. If this be true, then the New York Giants' football team will come through the 1936 league campaign with a minimum of trouble.
BY this time those who saw the golfing finish at Garden City must be breathing naturally again. It was a heart-breaker and a breath-snatcher. It was a smashing climax to a muddling match.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 21. -- Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita yesterday called in his leading Cabinet colleagues and reviewed Japan's China policy in light of the slaying of a Japanese policeman in the Hankow Japanese Concession.

PARIS, Sept. 19. -- After great irregularity and some heaviness at the beginning of the week, the Bourse's tendency hardened considerably and yesterday the list was exceedingly firm. Securities which derived the most benefit from the turn were French industrials and government stocks.

James Hague, 55-year-old brother of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, New Jersey State Democratic leader, was critically injured early yesterday morning when he was struck by an automobile as he was crossing Hudson Boulevard at Sip Avenue, Jersey City.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 20. -- The play-by-play description of the first match of the polo series between the United States and Argentina on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today follows:

Through his private secretary President ROOSEVELT has denounced as false reports that he had invited or would accept the support of "alien organizations" in this country, acting under orders from foreign sources. Apparently, the President's attention had been called in advance to matter printed in yesterday's New York American.
A statement by William Randolph Hearst, entitled "A Reply to the President," was issued yesterday by The New York American.

Whatever its political implications, President ROOSEVELT'S act in summoning a conference of public and private utility officials to discuss the possibility of pooling facilities in the Tennessee Valley and the area round about may be accepted as something more than a mere campaign gesture.

LAMINGTON, N.J., Sept. 20. -- Amsel v. Holzgarten, black and tan bitch owned and handled by George McKay Schieffelin of Gladstone, today won the first field trial of the year conducted by the Dachshunde Club of America.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The Browns ended their last home stand of the season today by clouting twenty-three hits in two games to take both ends of a double-header from the White Sox, 8 to 5 and 9 to 3.
The Yankees yesterday warmed up for the world series at the Stadium without leaving a favorable impression on a surprising gathering of 29,000 fans.
The interest in reproductions of paintings in color, an interest which has been steadily mounting in recent years, is further attested by three current simultaneous events.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- In a series of speeches divided between rallies of the National Union for Social Justice in Chicago and the Lake County Fair at Crown Point, Ind., Representative William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, devoted a busy Sunday to attacks on both his Democratic and Republican rivals in the national campaign.

GENEVA, Sept. 20. -- Deprived of Professor Gaston Jeze, the only delegate of Ethiopia acquainted with the intricate procedure of the League of Nations, but likely to replace him with an American citizen, Emperor Haile Selassie's delegation arrived tonight to fight in tomorrow's Assembly a forlorn battle for its continued existence in the diplomatic world.

Lady Astor, the former Nancy Langhorne of Virginia and England's first woman member of Parliament, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen for her first visit here in four years. She said she liked coming to America at election time because "I am not noticed by any one and don't have to make speeches."

MADRID, Sept. 20 (AP). -- Optimistic reports were received from all fronts, government communiques announced, particularly from Santa Olalla, southwest of the capital and in the path of the insurgent attack on Madrid.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 20. -The sweepstakes prize at the tenth annual Maplewood garden show, which closed here this afternoon, was won by Mrs. A.A. Adams with 1,557 points. Second place was taken by Mrs. Otto Mueller with 1,060 points.

TOPEKA, Sept. 20. -- Gratification over a statement by Felix M. Warburg, New York banker and philanthropist, announcing his support of Governor Landon, was expressed here by friends of the Republican Presidential candidate as the statement was made public here today at the office of the Governor.

Circulars booming Major Melvin L. Krulewitch for the Republican nomination for Attorney General, to oppose John J. Bennett, have been sent to all the county chairmen in the State and to many party workers as well, it became known yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 20. -The award of freshman competitive scholarships to twenty-one residents of New York City and vicinity was announced by the Committee on Undergraduate Scholarships of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today.

Atheism, liberalism, radicalism, secularism and "indifferentism" were described yesterday by the Rev. Kilian Hennrich, a member of the parish staff of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Sorrows, 103 Pitt Street, as wounds in the body of Christianity in his sermon there.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The pulse of shipping beat faster than usual along the Pacific Coast tonight, spurred by widespread efforts to move cargo before Sept. 30, when agreements between waterfront employers and unions expire.

The Giants, holding a six-game lead over the Cubs and a six-and-a-half-game margin on the Cardinals, can clinch the National League pennant by winning two more of their remaining eight contests, even in the event that the second-place Chicagoans win all of their six left to play.
MADRID, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The Spanish Government, authoritative sources declared today, will protest to the League of Nations against alleged support of the Rebels by Germany, Italy and Portugal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The decision of Judge Merrill E. Otis at Kansas City yesterday, that a rental must be paid in gold under an original contract to pay gold is regarded here as typical of other causes upon which the Supreme Court will be asked to pass at the term which will begin two weeks from tomorrow.

The declaration that the projected campaigning by Alfred E. Smith against the New Deal "will not add a single vote in the Landon column that is not already there" was made here yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, executive vice chairman of the Progressive National Committee.

West Side detectives displayed undisguised satisfaction last night when they heard that Robert J. (Farmer) Sullivan, former pugilist, election slugger, hi-jacker, boss stevedore and all-around thug, had been shot dead an hour before daybreak yesterday in Matawan Township, near Keyport, N.J.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The Pirates, fighting for second or third place in the National League, closed their home season before 10,000 fans today with two victories over the Reds, 5 to 1 and 6 to 4.

Deportation of "alien Bolshevik agitators," abolition of the Communist party in the United States, and a world united front of religions to oppose communism were advocated in a sermon yesterday morning at the Folsom Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, near Myrtle Avenue, Glendale, Queens.

Another one opened Saturday evening, when the ghoulish humors went briskly to work over the Longacre stage on behalf of "Timber House." Only a little bit ago they were saying the Broadway theatre is bloodless, and right there was the third melodrama in as many days.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Sept. 20. -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, who was to have delivered the principal address before the first general session of the annual convention of the American Bankers Association here on Tuesday morning, suddenly departed this afternoon for the East, leaving behind him a letter of regret for his inability to fulfill his engagement.

Predicting a bloody conflict between believers in God and the forces of anti-Christ, the Rev. Robert E. Woods, preaching yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, warned Catholics, Protestants and Jews they must be prepared to take aggressive measures to defend their faith in "the one and only true God."

Two French pictures will have their New York premieres tomorrow. "Le Barbier de Seville," with a score by Mozart and Rossini and a cast headed by Andre Bauge, tenor of the Paris Opera, will succeed "Ciboulette" at the Cinema de Paris. "La Kermesse Heroique," directed by Jacques Feyder, will open at 8:45 P.M. at the Filmarte, the new little theatre at 202 West Fifty-eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The text of President Roosevelt's letter to Secretary Wallace on crop insurance follows:

Marching, which Richard Welling calls "the silliest part of the whole military game and of no practical use in modern warfare," is probably the most essential and fundamental feature of army tactics. Not only does it teach obedience and discipline, without which even a business office is doomed to failure, but it also enables large bodies of men to be moved with a minimum of time and effort.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Production of bituminous coal has increased to a point where it is taxing the facilities of the railroads in some sections, the National Coal Association said today in a report to its members. A real shortage of cars is threatened if production continues to increase, according to the association.

Reclassification of 450,000 workers of the Works Progress Administration in this State facilitate their return to normal employment as conditions permit will be undertaken by the New York State Employment Service and the National Re-employment Service.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Dairymen of twelve Central and Northern New York counties will accept no compromise on the classified price plan but will consider one on a flat price, they indicated at a meeting at Sunny Island Camp, near Poland, today. Speakers urged full cooperation in the milk holiday which is scheduled to start at dawn on Thursday.

PARIS, Sept. 20. -- In a day of many important political addresses, Radical Socialist leaders cautiously intimated that they would continue to support the government but would not support continuance of the stay-in strikes.

What the city has done for the sick unemployed since the start of the medical and nursing service of the Emergency Relief Bureau in December 1932 is told in a report submitted yesterday to Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the ERB, by Charles F. McCarthy, director of the service.

A special rush-hour service between Manhattan and Queens, using four trains made up of the new lightweight, high speed, multi-section cars recently purchased by the B.M.T., will be started on Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- Governor Landon has increased his lead over President Roosevelt during the last month in the Presidential straw vote taken by The Farm Journal, according to the third tabulation of figures made public today.

A man was burned to death, and six other persons, including three firemen, were injured early yesterday morning when a three-alarm fire virtually destroyed a frame dwelling at 1.017 Boulevard East, overlooking the Palisades at Weehawken, N.J.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Regular weekly passenger service across the Pacific is to start next month, Pan American Airways announced here yesterday. The first passengers will embark on the Philippine Clipper at San Francisco on Wednesday, Oct. 21, and six days later they will be landed in Manila.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Broadcasting Station WCAE at Pittsburgh, which refused to permit Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, to broadcast a speech on Aug. 28, said today that Mr. Browder would speak over that station tomorrow and on Oct. 23 and Oct. 30.

True charity is more than the alleviation of immediate suffering and the church should recognize that it is the only institution ideally equipped to render the highest form of aid, the Rev. Dr. Clarence E. Krumbholz, said in a sermon yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

The Park Department is draining the water out of wading pools to make roller skating rinks. The department announced yesterday the closing of twelve swimming pools and said that they will be reopened on Thursday for use as play areas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- President Roosevelt was described by Harry H. Woodring, Acting Secretary of War, in an address to the Grand Army of the Republic tonight, as a man "who hates war with every fiber of his soul" and who is devoting his life to keeping America at peace.

An appeal to the principal governments of the world to act in concert "for the solution of the world's most urgent political and economic problems while there is still time" was made in a report submitted yesterday by a group of economic and financial experts to the Joint Committee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the International Chamber of Commerce.

The Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, declared yesterday in his sermon that a "church aflame" with divine fire was the only possible answer to the "flaming churches of Russia and Spain."

A campaign to raise $500,000 for the settlement of 1,000 European Jewish families in the Russian all-Jewish territory of Birobidjan was announced yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Edison, Forty-seventh Street, west of Broadway, of the American Committee for the Settlement of Jews in Birobldjan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- The Cubs caught up with Dizzy Dean in the eighth inning today to conquer the Cardinals, 4 to 3, and moved ahead once more in their argument over second place in the National League, before 32,342 spectators at Wrigley Field.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The Red Sox pulled a triple play in the second game today, but it was not enough to stop the Athletics. The Mackmen won both ends of a double-header, 3 to 1 and 5 to 4.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- More than 2,000 residents and visitors gathered at Manor Park here this afternoon and opened with religious and patriotic services a week's festival to mark the 275th anniversary of the reputed purchase of what is now the town of Mamaroneck by John Richbell.

LONDON Sept. 19. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Sept. 16 at 73.5, compared with 72.8 two weeks before, 72.1 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- The Reichsbank's mid-September report shows a continued strain in its position. Discounts were 160,000,000 marks larger than a month before, this being due to the turning in of work-creation and armament bills by companies that are short of cash.
MOSCOW, Sept. 20. -- The struggle of a handful of men against the Arctic Winter was written here tonight in radio messages from the region of the North Pole.

The complexion of the trading in the foreign exchange market last week showed no variation from that of its predecessors. Sterling and its associated currencies reached up into new high ground for the year, and beyond, and while the French franc was steady the other gold bloc currencies were irregular.

In your editorial "Cross-Voting" you express some surprise at the extent of the switching of Hoover supporters to President Roosevelt this year, as revealed by The Literary Digest poll. May it be suggested that any analysis will be incomplete which does not emphasize one explanation which may account for a large number of voters now supporting the President who voted for Mr. Hoover in 1932?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- President Roosevelt today appointed two committees of government experts to study and make reports on the twin problems of crop insurance for farmers and the improvement of land use in the great plains area, hit by serious droughts in 1934 and 1936.

The principals of the Atlantic Passenger Conference will meet in Berlin on Oct. 1 to consider several problems, among which will be the increase of passenger fares and the abolition of rate privileges on round-trip tickets in the transatlantic trade.

TORONTO, Sept. 20. -- The expansion of gold and base metal mining in Ontario in the last eighteen months has changed the course of economic trends, the Ontario Government reported last week in a general survey of economic conditions in the Province.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Holding a slim 10-to-3 advantage at the half, the Chicago Bears pounded over three touchdowns after the intermission for a top-heavy victory over the Green Bay Packers today, scoring 30 to 3, in a National Football League game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- In a comprehensive analysis of the public debt of the United States, now $33,816,273,460, Secretary Morgenthau announced yesterday a gradual but steady increase in the proportion of long-term obligations, compared with the outstanding short-term securities, a condition regarded as highly desirable from the Treasury's viewpoint.

LISBON, Portugal, via Tangier, Morocco, Sept. 20. -- Hunger is already pinching the peasants out in the hills fighting General Francisco Franco's southern Rebel army, and the specter of hardship faces the Spanish masses this Winter as a result of two months of civil war, which has made the harvesting of crops in many sections impossible.

Tears are at hurricane high tide at the downtown National Theatre, for Jennie Goldstein has opened her season with a product of the William Siegel lachrymatory known as "Souls for Sale." Miss Goldstein counts that stage day lost in which she does not spend a little time either in the gutter or in a psychopathic ward.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 20. -- Four riders in pale blue shirts with a white stripe around their middle suddenly merged into a beautiful flowing unit and rolled over the United States team like a flood on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

Private donors have pledged approximately $14,000,000 toward the Municipal Art Center sponsored by Mayor La Guardia, through the efforts of the Mayor's Municipal Art Center Committee, headed by Mrs. Henry Breckinridge, it became known yesterday.

Whether Monday's Maine election and Tuesday's Michigan primary did or did not foreshadow nationwide November results, at all events the stock market's immediate response was a decline. Probably, if there had been no preliminary voting, last week's action of the market would have been described as natural reaction after a prolonged advance.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The board of trustees of the National Association of Life Underwriters announced tonight that it sought "one of the major Cabinet posts" in the United States to safeguard the interests of 63,000,000 policyholders.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 20. -One of the largest society golf tournaments ever held here was played today over the Tuxedo course. Several hundred persons took part in the tournament a mixed foursome. As a preliminary a dinner was held at the club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- White House officials made no comment tonight on William Randolph Hearst's reply to a statement yesterday by Stephen T. Early, assistant secretary to the President.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Elmer S. Hader, chairman of the Zoning Commission of Grand View and a leader in the movement against the proposed Nyack-Tarrytown Hudson River bridge, announced today that plans had been completed for a midstream ferryboat conference of prominent citizens of Rockland and Westchester Counties on Oct. 3.

A banking group headed by Coffin Burr, Inc., will offer today a new issue of $20,000,000 of general and refunding mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, series G, due on Sept. 1, 1966, of the Detroit Edison Company. The bonds will be priced at 105 and accrued interest.

A plot of 77,000 square feet fronting on Newtown Creek, at Grand Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Grace Reynolds to the 1,100 Grand Street Corporation for improvement with a bulk oil station. The sale was arranged by Frank R. Fischer, Inc., broker, who also sold for the Chemical National Bank to the Republic Paper Stock Corporation the three-story manufacturing building at 5 to 9 La Grange Street.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 20. -- A report is printed by the Anarcho-Syndicalist newspaper Solidaridad Obrera to the effect that the island of Majorca has "in practice and in fact" been delivered to the Italians, one of whose leaders -- a lieutenant named Rossini -- has established a virtual dictatorship over the island.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20. -- Reports that the Greentree polo team might be shifted to introduce Stewart Iglehart and Winston Guest into its line-up after today's smashing defeat at the hands of the Argentine team in the Cup of the Americas series brought objections tonight from Lieut. Col. Enrique Padilla of the Argentine Polo Association.

"Some churches are societies of individuals banded together to hire a professional to do their duty for them," said the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, Secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, Fort Washington Avenue at 181st Street.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 20. -- Mrs. Howland Spencer entertained with a tea this afternoon at Bayview in honor of Mrs. M. Van Rensselaer Johnson, who is a guest of Mrs. Nicholas Brown at Harbour Court.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Sept. 21. -- Two Japanese destroyers left Shanghai last night bound for Hankow, carrying several hundred Japanese marines from the barracks here, where usually at least 2,000 are maintained.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- A paragraph in "London Diary" in the current issue of The New Statesman and Nation attributes the large naval construction program of the United States not to fear of war with Japan but to preparation to meet the situation that might arise out of a German attempt to colonize in South America because Britain and France are determined to keep her out of Africa.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 19. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84.1, which compares with 84.2 the week before, 83.7 two weeks before, 83.8 three weeks before and 84.1 four weeks before.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Representatives of more than sixty realty and taxpayer organizations met here tonight at the call of the State Tax Limitation Committee and laid plans for presentation of a new bill in the next session of the State Legislature designed to restrict municipal spending and ease the tax burden on real property.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 74 per cent of capacity, up 8 points from the preceding week, when the holiday interfered, and slightly above the average in August, the highest month in tonnage since March, 1930.

Kay Boyle has finished her editing of "365 Days," the collection of 365 stories which she has compiled and edited with the assistance of Laurence Vail and Nina Conarain. More than 100 writers of England, America and the Continent collaborated on this book.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Merle L. Youngs, at the tiller of his Interclub sloop Olive, came through this afternoon to win a Sunday race in one of the most closely contested class series that ever has been conducted in the history of yacht racing on Long Island Sound.

Despite the religious holidays, which retarded buying activity to some extent, the total volume of trade in the local wholesale apparel markets last week was encouraging. Cooler weather stimulated retail sales in various sections of the country, and this was reflected in the number of reorders received here hy manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The conference of power company executives and government experts, which President Roosevelt has called for Sept. 30, is understood among organized business representatives in Washington to be another of a series of parleys which he is planning to hold between now and election day with captains of commerce and industry.

Despite civil war in Spain and uncertainty elsewhere on the Continent, business continues to improve in most European countries. It is a noteworthy fact that The Annalist's index of world industrial production has risen to the highest level reached since 1929. Meantime international trade has rallied from an early Summer setback.

ALBANY, Sept. 20. -- Governor Lehman made public tonight a report from Dr. Frank P. Graves, Commissioner of Education, outlining a comprehensive program for the teaching of highway safety in the State schools.

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's formal notice served on the world at Nuremberg that Germany could not "relinquish the solution of her colonial demands," has spurred German colonial propaganda to increased activity. Arguments, pleas and demands for colonies have become a part of the daily grist turned out by the wast National Socialist propaganda machine.

After what happened on the thirty-fourth green in the match between Johnny Fischer and Jock McLean at the Garden City Golf Club on Saturday it is almost a certainty that there will be an important rule change in the game of golf before the next national amateur championship.

MAHOPAC FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Traveling incognito, as it were, this rambling reporter toured the Putnam County countryside today in an effort to determine the attitude of the average farmer or landowner toward the hunter from the city, and, incidentally, get a picture of what the metropolitan gunner is up against in trying to line up a happy hunting ground when the upland game season gets under way next month.

I have been indulging in some simple arithmetical relaxation during the past few days, brought on by the I.C.C. reduction and adjustment of passenger fares, and the expressed opposition thereto by some of the railroads. The results are rather interesting.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20. -- The cotton market here last week was rather less active than in the preceding period when it was stimulated by the bullish crop forecast issued by the government on Sept. 8. After the heavy short covering and equally heavy profit-taking that immediately followed the estimate had been done, traders began to figure on what the next estimate would be.

The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Parish, refused yesterday to recant a single word from the declaration made in his annual report to the parish that there was "a foolishness of preaching" and that a moratorium on preaching would enhance the strength of the churches of Christ.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- At no time in the history of the trade has the world's wheat situation drawn so much attention as currently, and indications are that it will become more interesting as the season advances. There is a closer adjustment of world consumptive requirements to supplies, and this, it is expected, will bring sharp price fluctuations, with a broad-term upward trend.

The Dodgers' fervent hopes of prolonging the National League pennant race and doing something important in its closing stages wound up a complete failure at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Giants, behind a brilliant exhibition of knuckleball tossing by the stoutish Freddy Fitzsimmons, blanked Casey Stengel's inept helpers, 5 to 0.

At a recent Harvard tercentenary conference an English judge, Lord Wright, uttered these words: "It [the common law] will guard rights of property, but it will reconcile those rights with the rights of human beings."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Labor's Nonpartisan League, which seeks the re-election of President Roosevelt, today made public a statement by Judge E.R. Sloan of Topeka in which he asserted that civil service is a dead letter in State employment in Kansas under Governor Landon.

A Federal judge in Kansas City has upheld a lease signed in 1890 requiring a realty company there to pay 139,320 grains of pure gold, or its money equivalent at current gold prices, as quarterly rental for a store location. Until 1934 the lessees had been paying $6,000 in currency quarterly; the owner in 1934 demanded $10,158.75 quarterly.
BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The Bees overcame the Phillies, 5 to 3 and 6 to 5, today before 7,000 fans.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Prices of hogs here moved down last week to the lowest levels of the year, and there was only a moderate rally. Fresh dressed loins were affected and were quoted on Friday at 16 to 23 1/2 cents a pound wholesale, compared with 16 1/2 to 27 1/2 cents a week before and 17 1/2 to 27 a year ago.

PARIS, Sept. 19. -- The money market here was slightly less easy this week, but rates show little change. Bill discounts were 3 1/8 per cent and call money 2 1/2-2 3/4 per cent. Treasury bond discounts were quoted at 3 5/8-3 3/4 per cent. The Bank of France's return of Sept. 11 showed, as expected, a decrease of 653,000,000 francs in the gold reserves, these being 53,532,000,000 francs, compared with 53,932,000,000, the June low.

HAVANA, Sept. 20. -- After the explosion at the newspaper Pais some police officials expressed a belief that a "terrorist" campaign was being waged against Havana newspapers, but they said they were unable to fix the blame for today's incident.
NORTH TONAWANDA, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP). -- Three boys and two girls drowned early today when their automobile smashed through a guard rail and plunged into the barge canal two miles east of here.
The establishment of an official residence or mansion for the city's Mayors is urged by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx in a letter to the Board of Estimate, made public yesterday.

President Roosevelt, in a message read at a meeting in Town Hall yesterday afternoon, endorsed the proposed mobilization of the moral and spiritual forces of the country on Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 3 and 4, designated as Loyalty Days, in a united front to fight irreligion and evil.

As our account yesterday pointed out, the final round of the national amateur golf championship at Garden City demonstrated again that no match is ever won until the final putt is sunk. At the tenth hole of the afternoon round, young JOCK MCLEAN of Scotland had what seemed to be an unbeatable advantage over young JOHNNY FISCHER of the University of Cincinnati.

An appeal for more common sense in religion and everyday life was made by the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street. The need of the world today, he declared, was not more subtle diplomacy but more straightforward and steadfast common sense.
DETROIT, Sept. 20 (AP). -- The Tigers rallied in the eighth inning today to scalp the Indians, 5 to 3, and make a clean sweep of their four-game series.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20. -- Paramount has decided that "Safari,'' not the Bing Crosby "Waikiki Wedding," will be its one color picture this season. The Crosby film was to have been filmed in Hawaii, but the Bing was unable to carry on his radio work from that point, so it will be made at the studio in black and white.

PARIS, Sept. 20. -- Facing the problem of how to prevent fascism and communism from coming to war and to preserve liberalism in the world, the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, and the French Premier, Leon Blum, had a two-hour interview here today on the eve of the League of Nations Assembly meeting at Geneva. Mr. Eden eft for Geneva in the evening and Air. Blum will go there later in the week.

Despite some evidence of amelioration, Chino-Japanese relations are dangerously strained. Sept. 18, the fifth anniversary of China's "day of humiliation," commemorating Japan's seizure of Mukden and the beginning of the occupation of the northeastern provinces, passed without the anticipated widespread outbursts of Chinese popular feeling; in South China, in fact, the nearly unbearable tension between the two countries was somewhat relieved.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Considered the best season in its history by Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York State National Guard, the Summer training period of the Guard ended at Camp Smith here today with the departure of the 369th Infantry of Harlem, commanded by Colonel John G. Grimley, after two weeks of training.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 20. -- A 100-foot section of grandstand, five tiers high, collapsed slowly beneath the weight of about 500 spectators at the training camp of Al Ettore, Philadelphia heavyweigh boxer, at Clementon Park, near here, today. None of the persons on the stand were seriously injured although a number of them suffered minor bruises and sprains.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Since Andy Kerr came to Colgate in 1929, the prophets engaged in the hazardous and painfully mortifying occupation of wrestling with the future of football teams have rendered up thanks annually for a setup that never fails to provide an oasis in a desert trapped and bunkered with mirages of beautiful theories.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the first air-mail flight will be celebrated on Wednesday when one of the new transcontinental air liners of American Air Lines will fly over the original route. On board will be a delegation of the "Early Birds," whose membership is limited to pilots who learned to fly before 1914.

John McCormack, tenor, who has been abroad for two years, will arrive today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary; Jack Lovelock, New Zealand's Olympic track champion; B. Charney Vladeck, president of the American ORT Federation; Jean Wood, 10-year-old Scotch dancer, and Justice George Sutherland of the United States Supreme Court, are others on the list.

An unidentified man about 45 years old was killed late last night when struck by a bus as he attempted to cross Eighth Avenue near Forty-sixth Street. The driver of the bus, Frank Mitchell of 3,434 North Ella Street, Philadelphia, was held on a technical charge of homicide.
Realty activity in the city Saturday was marked by deals involving a variety of properties, some of which will be modernized by the new owners.

BAYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 20. -- Miss Mavis Freeman of the Women's Swimming Association and a member of the 1936 United States Olympic team was an easy winner of the women's national A.A.U. long distance swimming championship held today off Oak Neck Beach.

The world today is suffering from virtually the same disorder of economic and monetary instability as in the early Nineteen Twenties and it is largely for that reason that gold again is flowing to this country, according to Dr. W. Randolph Burgess, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, whose book, "The Reserve Banks and the Money Market," is being published today by Harper Brothers, in a new and revised edition.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 20. -- Society almost to a family was represented today at the opening game of the international polo series at the Meadow Brook Club, and long before the parade of the ponies at 3:45 most of the boxes were occupied.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -Mr. and Mrs. Logan M. Bullitt of Chestnut Hill introduced to society their daughter, Miss Mary Logan Bullitt, this afternoon at a tea which they gave at their home.

Sixty-four book publishers of New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago and Indianapolis will be represented with exhibits at The New York Times National Book Fair, to be held at Rockefeller Center Nov. 5 through 19. Room and space assignments, which alternate with salons containing displays of general public interest, were allotted by the Book Fair Directing Board last week upon the basis of drawings held on Sept. 11.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Sept. 20. -- The German airship Hindenburg, with a record load of seventy-two passengers, completed her eighth eastbound voyage of the ten experimental round trips from Frankfurt, Germany, in fifty-nine hours flat. She has not yet been late on a crossing.

The Associated Gas and Electric and other interests, which have filed a petition with the Federal District Court here for the reorganization of the National Public Service Corporation, announced yesterday their intention to amend their plan. At the same time, they said they had served notice on the committee acting for the 5 per cent debentures of the National Public Service Corporation that they would withdraw their debentures from the committee.

Sixty thousand Catholic men participated in a great rally at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday afternoon, bringing to a close the national convention of the Holy Name Society with one of the largest religious demonstrations ever held in the East.

HAVANA, Sept. 20. -- Four persons were killed and twenty-seven injured this morning when a dynamite bomb concealed in a small delivery truck exploded at the building of the newspaper Pais. The bomb was estimated by the police to have weighed 1,500 pounds.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- The week's markets here were quiet, with the only interest on the Boerse being in colonial and raw material stocks, but no wide influence was exerted by the Nazi party congress at Nuremberg.

Miss Sarah Churchill, daughter of Winston Churchill, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen and was met down the bay by Vic Oliver, the orchestra leader and comedian, to whom she has been reported engaged. After her precipitate departure from London Miss Churchill was said to have notified her family that she would marry the musician, and he in turn denied here that he had any intention of marriage.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- A feature in the corn market here last week was the liberal selling of the September position and the buying of the December, which was credited to the Farmers National Grain Corporation. Traders assumed that it was a changing over of spreads, and sharp price fluctuations were the result.

HENDAYE, France, Sept. 20. -- Insurgent airplanes appeared today over Bilbao, Santander and neighboring villages to drop a message from General Emilio Mola, commander of the Rebels' northern troops, giving them until Friday to surrender.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- The week's markets here were quiet, with the only interest on the Boerse being in colonial and raw material stocks, but no wide influence was exerted by the Nazi party congress at Nuremberg.

Miss Sarah Churchill, daughter of Winston Churchill, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen and was met down the bay by Vic Oliver, the orchestra leader and comedian, to whom she has been reported engaged. After her precipitate departure from London Miss Churchill was said to have notified her family that she would marry the musician, and he in turn denied here that he had any intention of marriage.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- A feature in the corn market here last week was the liberal selling of the September position and the buying of the December, which was credited to the Farmers National Grain Corporation. Traders assumed that it was a changing over of spreads, and sharp price fluctuations were the result.

The Morosco will be host this evening to a major event of the Fall season, George Kelly's new play, "Reflected Glory," starring Tallulah Bankhead. It is Mr. Kelly's first work for Broadway since "Philip Goes Forth" (1931), and it comes to town after visits to San Francisco, Los Angeles and New Haven.

Cotton futures moved irregularly downward last week, with daily fluctuations generally narrow despite frequently active transactions. Closing prices on Saturday on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 18 to 30 points for the week.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The financial markets here this week were much more subdued in tone and sentiment than they had been for some time. Developments in the domestic situation continue to be the most encouraging, with evidence of the robust state of internal trade being supplied daily, but, as has often been the case in the past, foreign politics are causing a feeling of hesitation and, in some minds, distinct uneasiness.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- Pronounced strength in foreign markets with the prices of wheat in Liverpool in new ground since 1930 and those at Winnipeg at new highs for the season carried quotations on the Board of Trade up sharply in the early trading, with all deliveries selling within a fraction of the best figures of the year.

McCall's Magazine, national women's publication, has leased the thirty-ninth floor of 444 Madison Avenue, where it will install three modern home-test kitchens, a laundry, and equipment laboratory to conduct tests of foods and household appliances.

CEDAR LAKE, Ind., Sept. 21. -- American outboard one-mile speed records, which apparently have been pushed up to almost unbeatable heights, yielded only slightly today as two score of the country's leading drivers laid down a savage barrage of r.p.m.'s in the mile trial finale of the national championships run at Chicago over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- A proposed issue of common stock to realize a maximum of $13,056,446 and a minimum of $7,978,939 was submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration by Remington Rand, Inc.

HAVANA, Sept. 21. -- Most of the hundred persons detained following yesterday's bombing of the newspaper Pais, which killed four and wounded twenty-seven, were released today as the police continued their investigations. The authorities refuse to divulge, however, the number still in custody and decline to comment on the case.
SANTA OLALLA, Spain, Sept. 21. -- This hamlet, the gateway to Maqueda, was in the hands of Rebel troops today after desperate fighting that cost hundreds of lives.

In something even more than their usual numbers, those Monday-nighters were out again last night at Martin Beck's house in Forty-fifth Street, this time to burn candles and beat palms in the presence of "Iolanthe."
