There are three other bills yet to come in the D'Oyly Carte Company's engagement, but already the Monday-nighters were ready to venture an assertion, dare a preference.

Grover R. James, attorney for the Erie Railroad, representing the Trunk Line Association, appealed yesterday at a hearing before Joint Board 3, under the Motor Carrier Law of 1935, for a delimiting of an application for charter service by the Garden State Lines, Inc., a motor-bus company of New Jersey.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The Baltimore Orioles squared accounts with the Buffalo Bisons at two victories apiece in the final International League play-off series tonight by batting out an 8-to-6 victory.

Duttons have heard from Ralph Bates, author of "The Olive Field," who has been fighting in Spain on the side of the Loyalists. Mr. Bates mailed a note from France in which he said: "Things are ghastly inside Spain. Italian airplanes are smashing us up."
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

North River ferry lines will rearrange their schedules when the Queen Mary and the Normandie are being docked, to avoid the currents created by the ships. On two occasions ferryboats have been damaged and passengers injured.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- The Giants' final dash to the National League pennant ran up a siding today when the Phillies, with whom the Terry forces were slated to open a three-game series, chose to postpone the opening clash because of wet grounds.

BABYLON, L.I., Sept. 21. -- Results of a private survey of electricity, water, telephone and gas rates made by John D. Whittaker of Babylon, a consulting engineer, will be submitted to the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors at its next meeting in October.

Directors of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation yesterday authorized officers of the company and its subsidiaries to amend and extend the wage agreements with the various committees representing employes so as to provide two increases in wages for hourly rated employes.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- No immediate solution of the State's milk problem was reached here today in an eight-hour conference between groups of dealers and producers and deliberations will be resumed tomorrow morning with neither side having much hope that a compromise flat price for producers will be agreed on.

The Federal Reserve Bank reported yesterday that $6,725,000 more French gold had been engaged in Paris for shipment to New York, bringing to $110,100,000 the total taken from France since the present movement began on Aug. 7. Of the amount reported yesterday, $1,800,000 was actually an addition for Saturday, making the total contracted for on that day $9,635,000.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21. -- In an opening day which officials described as the most successful in the history of the institution, the Mineola Fair presented its ninety-fourth annual exhibit today with record crowds thronging through the agricultural and industrial displays.

On Sept. 1 new laws of this State went into effect providing for a severe schedule of minimum and maximum fines and jail sentences for reckless driving. In the same spirit a committee of the city magistrates has drawn up a schedule of uniform fines to be imposed by all city magistrates for traffic violations.

Grant Glenwood Flory, personnel manager of the Fundamerican Corporation, an investment trust company, with offices on the eighth floor of 40 Exchange Place, and a former New York advertising executive, fell or jumped to his death shortly after 3 P.M. yesterday from a washroom on the thirteenth floor of the building.

How 17,895 of the city's children were entertained and unconsciously taught during the summer in play schools and day camps operated by the WPA in cooperation with the Board of Education, is illustrated in a large exhibit that opened yesterday afternoon in Education Hall at the American Museum of Natural History and will remain on view daily until Oct. 15.
TOKYO, Sept. 21. -- Japan's fleet in Chinese waters is being reinforced immediately from Japan by additional landing parties, which take the place of marines.

Officials of Allegheny County, Pa., have invited bankers to submit bids on Oct. 5 for a new issue of $3,600,000 of bridge and park bonds, to be dated Oct. 1, 1936, and to mature on Oct. 1, 1937, to 1966. Bidders are requested to name a rate of interest not exceeding 2 3/4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Seeking postponement of enforcement of the new Safety-at-Sea Act until the next session of Congress, five representatives of maritime labor unions, led by Harry Bridges conferred today with officials of two government departments.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, one of the aspirants for the Republican nomination for Governor, declared last night in a radio address from WEAF that the Federal handling of relief had led to waste and pleaded for supervision by local agencies.

B. Charney Vladeck, president of the American Ort Federation and general manager of the Jewish Daily Forward, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with Mrs. Vladeck. They have been in Europe and the Near East for four months, half of it in Palestine.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- With the promise of clear skies and pleasant weather, Philadelphia is prepared to celebrate its greatest boxing holiday in ten years when Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, opposes Al Ettore, local Italian pride, in a fifteen-round bout at the Municipal Stadium tomorrow night.

SIMLA, India, Sept. 21. -- An appraisal of the scope and potentialities of India's new Federal Constitution was made here today by the Viceroy, the Marquess of Linlithgow, when he addressed a joint meeting of the Legislative Assembly.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Officers of the Westchester County Division of the Independent Coalition of American Women, a nonpartisan organization opposing the New Deal, denounced the use of coercion as a means of obtaining votes for Landon and Knox at an organization meeting here this afternoon.

With reference to your editorial of yesterday on life insurance assets: Is it not fair to call the public's attention to the fact that the present total assets cited are expressed in dollars worth just a little more than the imperial Russian ruble, and those quoted in 1931 were in real dollars?

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation directed its technical staff yesterday to begin work on the preparation of data to be used in the conference on southeastern power pooling called by President Roosevelt for Sept. 30.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- Henry J. Allen, former Governor of Kansas, accused the Roosevelt administration today of making a "political racket" out of relief by wasting $12,000,000,000, which, he said, never reached the nation's needy.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 21. -- There have been receptions of all kinds to fliers of all kinds, but so far as the records show there has never been a reception to a flying hat.

Unless some injury should meanwhile befall a member of the Greentree polo four which, representing the United States, went down to honorable defeat before the Argentine team on Sunday, the same two quads should meet in the second match. The president of the Argentine Polo Association has correctly pointed out that the agreement was for a series between the winner of the American open championship and a picked four from the Argentine.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21. -- The importance attached by the Soviet Union in its war calculations to the political loyalty of both soldiers and civilians was fully evident today as the Red army forces of Moscow Province went into action in their Fall manoeuvres.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Governor George H. Earle said tonight that "the danger of European war completely overshadows every other issue" of the present Presidential campaign.

Five holders of debentures of the National Public Service Corporation asked yesterday for dismissal of reorganization proceedings; adding their objection to those advanced last week by minority interests.

Arthur H. Laemmle, 31 years old, a prospective post-graduate student, was found dead at 10 A.M. yesterday in his room in Furnald Hall, Columbia University. His body was on the floor and beside it were two bloodstained razor blades and a small dirk, designed as a letter-opener.

New Jersey detectives toured Greenwich Village with local detectives yesterday seeking clues to the murderers of Robert J. (Farmer) Sullivan, West Side thug who was shot dead in a tavern near Keyport, N.J., on Sunday morning.

Members of the visiting Maccabee Palestine soccer team which plays an All-Star eleven at the Yankee Stadium this Sunday, were the guests at a luncheon tendered by the Federation of Polish Jews in America at Jack Dempsey's Restaurant yesterday.

The two European members of the jury for the 1936 Carnegie International at Pittsburgh arrived yesterday on the Queen Mary -- Pierre Roy, distinguished French modernist, and A.K. Lawrence, an associate member of the Royal Academy in England.

Izzy Jannazzo of the East Side, a contender for Barney Ross's welterweight title, gained a fifteen-round decision over Gustav Eder of Germany in the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Partial confirmation of the report of an impasse in the execution of the agreement reached on July 20 which would have given Twentieth Century-Fox and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer equal shares with Isidore and Mark Ostrer in the controlling 57 per cent of the voting stock of the Gaumont British Picture Corporation came yesterday from Joseph M. Schenck, chairman of the board at Fox.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Six officials of the Railway Audit and Inspection Company, Inc., were indicted by the district grand jury today for contempt of the Senate arising out of their failure to appear before the La Follette Subcommittee on Civil Liberties last Aug. 21.

WILMINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Russell L. Heberlin, vice president of Philco Radio and Television Company, testified today that the company was established as a corporation separate from the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company to form a proper basis for payment of excise taxes and royalties, and to protect its records from competitors.

Somebody is always solemnly announcing the paramount issue of this Presidential election. Usually, it is an announcement good for one speech only, or at most for one week only. It is now several weeks since Secretary ICKES made a radio address in which he said that the influence of Mr. HEARST in selecting Governor LANDON for the Republican nomination would probably be the deciding factor in this campaign.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21. -- The polo forces of Argentina and the United States went about preparations for the second game of the Cup of the Americas series today and there was no indication anywhere that any change was contemplated in the line-up of the team which would represent this country on Wednesday.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 21. -- Michael Fugmann, German Army veteran and Hanover Township miner, stood before Judge Samuel E. Shull in Criminal Court today and pleaded not guilty to a charge of murder growing out of the death of Thomas Maloney, president of the United Anthracite Miners and one of the three victims of the Good Friday mail bombings of April 10.

Leaders at Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee in the Liggett Building, assured of the active participation of former Governor Alfred E. Smith in the Landon campaign, were jubilant yesterday, but professed to be somewhat in the dark with regard to Mr. Smith's speaking program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21. -- Selznick International's search for a Tom Sawyer, which has been conducted fervently all over the country for the last six weeks or so, has apparently ended right in Hollywood. The one lad among the 15,000 interviewed who seems most suited to the part is Tommy Breen, an 11-year-old lad who was screen tested without the knowledge of his parents, who do not want their children to pursue screen careers.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 21. -- Several hundred cancer specialists from all over the world gathered here today for the opening of the Second International Congress for Scientific and Social Struggle Against Cancer. The meeting begins in earnest tomorrow and continues until Saturday.

ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 21. -- Ray Kilthau holed a 25-foot chip shot on the eighteenth hole today, and the Oakland amateur and his professional partner, Charles H. Mayo Sr. of Lido, carded a 67 to triumph in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day amateur-pro tourney at the Shelter Rock Country Club.
Senator Robert J. Bulkley of Ohio visited James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, yesterday and declared that President Roosevelt would carry Ohio over Governor Landon by 150,000 votes.

CACERES, Spain, Sept. 21 (By Telephone to Lisbon). -- The town of Maqueda, key to Toledo and intended by the Madrid Government to be the Spanish Verdun, was occupied today by General Francisco Franco's Foreign Legion, Rebel headquarters announced tonight.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 21 (AP). -- William Gallagher's Rudie, a 2-year-old son of the mighty Reigh Count, made a showing of eight rivals as he took the featured six-furlong dash by two lengths before 7,500 at Narragansett Park today.

Anthony Macino, an 18-year-old bus boy in Anselmo's Restaurant, 212 West Seventy-second Street, got a summons yesterday for sweeping rubbish from the sidewalk into the gutter and thus became the first victim of the Sanitation Department's drive to clean up Upper Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The Republican National Committee said in a statement tonight that "the men who advocated revolution, who calmly discussed the amount of 'blood that ought to be shed,' are still in Roosevelt's confidence and controlling his actions."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- The use of force as a method of achieving a world balance in the distribution of population and raw materials was the subject of sharp disagreement among speakers of three countries at a meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science here tonight.

The Roberts, Cushman Company bought from the Continental Mortgage Guarantee Company a six-story store and loft building at 10 Washington Place, between Greene and Mercer Streets, on a plot 42 by 98 feet. The buyer has occupied a large part of the building for forty-five years.

The construction of a crosstown subway in the Bronx was proposed by James J. Lyons, president of that borough, in a letter to the Board of Estimate yesterday. Mr. Lyons suggested a route along Tremont Avenue, one of the main crosstown highways, which at present is served by a surface car line and a bus line.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21. -- The nation's bankers, assembled here in the sixty-second annual convention of the American Bankers Association, were advised tonight by one of their past presidents to accept gracefully the "more moderate evolutionary changes going on at home" lest they be faced with the social upheavals that have taken place and still are taking place throughout Europe.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 21. -- Dr. John Murray, principal of University College, Exeter, England, joined with Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, in an exposition of the dangerous crisis in which the world's democracies find themselves, at the opening of Union College this morning.

"It is incredible that nations of the world not yet emerged from the agonizing aftermath of the World War should be preparing for another with almost fiendish eagerness," Mrs. Caroline O'Day, Representative at large, declared yesterday at the first Fall meeting of the New York branch of the Women's International League, 99 Park Avenue.

This letter is prompted by the item in THE TIMES regarding the surveying of a new highway to by-pass South Amboy and Perth Amboy in order to relieve Summer Sunday congestion across the Victory Bridge.
Henry T. (Dick) Merrill and Harry Richman landed at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday afternoon, completing their round trip to England nineteen days after their takeoff.

Elimination of right turns on red lights was proposed yesterday to the traffic committee of the Board of Aldermen by Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner, who said such a change would expedite traffic and make the streets safer for pedestrians.

Your editorial "Cross-voting" contains two sentences which may well raise a question in many minds concerning straw-ballot procedure. Quite without reference to the merits of the current Presidential polls as gauges of political opinion, and without any question as to their integrity or disinterestedness, should not the social consequences of this practice of opinion-testing be seriously considered?

Randolph Churchill, son of Winston Churchill, British statesman, arrived here yesterday morning aboard the Queen Mary, but his presence did little to clear up the confusion regarding the reported marriage plans of his 22-year-old sister, Sarah, to Vic Oliver, Viennese-American orchestra leader and comedian.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- The death of a young woman by epidemic meningitis, a disease which strikes without warning, and the exposure of a New York mother and her two children were revealed today by Miss Mildred Bracy of the Travelers Aid Society.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- Asserting that the depression was definitely over Kenneth Collins, vice president, of Gimbel Brothers, today told retail merchants to abandon "absurd caution" and "penny pinching," change their habits of thinking and plan for expansion.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 21. -- Declaring that the great threat to the American system of government is the bloc of organized minorities, the Veterans of Future Wars dispatched to the five Presidential candidates today a set of seven questions on their attitude toward pensions and war-time conscription of capital and labor.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, predicted in a new attack on the administration's handling of old-age pensions and job insurance tonight that working men were going to rebel against the Social Security Act.

Net earnings of the Phillips Petroleum Company in August were $2,087,409 after all charges and reserves, or 50 cents a share on the outstanding stock, Frank Phillips, president, announced on his return from the West. This is a substantial gain over the same month last year.

A passing grade in at least three-fourths of their scholastic work will be required of the 10,500 city high school students who will receive monthly subsidies from the National Youth Administration, it was announced in a bulletin sent to principals yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

The suggestion that the new Italian Ambassador may discuss terms for a resumption of payments on the Italian war debt when he arrives in Washington next month is unofficial and must be received with reservations. It is known, however, that the matter has been under consideration in Rome since last Spring, before the conquest of Addis Ababa.

TOPEKA, Sept. 21. -- On the eve of his departure for Des Moines, Governor Landon made public today that part of the farm speech he will make in that city tomorrow evening which deals with crop insurance.

A resolution protesting the proposed Tarrytown-Nyack bridge as an "obvious injury" to the scenic beauty of the Hudson River was adopted yesterday by the directors of the Hudson River Conservation Society and will be sent to Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Talk that next Wednesday's parade of the Grand Army of the Republic might be the last did not set well with the boys in blue today as they sang old war songs and swapped battle stories at their national encampment, not being bothered by such things as formal sessions.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- Temple University earned an 18-0 victory over St. Joseph's College in the opening football game for each team at the Temple Stadium tonight before 17,000.
BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- Millions of Germans between the ages of 25 and 45 are carrying in their pockets a secret order telling them exactly when and where they must report in the event of war.

SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The Rebel forces of General Emilio Mola tonight tightened their lines on the way to Bilbao after having broken through the Azpeitia line, held by government forces for more than a month.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 21 (AP). -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg replied today to the Challenge of Senator J. Hamilton Lewis for a joint debate on constitutional issues of the campaign in a letter saying "we might hope to meet, perhaps, once at the finish."

MOSCOW, Sept. 21. -- The surprising spectacle of the head of the League of Militant Atheists advocating the bestowal of suffrage on priests was provided in a statement by Emil Yaroslavsky defending that provision in the new Soviet Constitution, which will be adopted this Winter.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- This city's new theatrical season opened tonight with the first American performance of "Love from a Stranger," the three-act melodrama written by Frank Vosper from a story by Agatha Christie, which has been seen on the London stage for more than six months.

Maintenance of standards of civic decency is dependent on the constant vigilance and effort of citizens' groups, Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard told members of the Advertising Men's Post of the American Legion yesterday at a luncheon at the Advertising Club.

Following a survey of Queens buildings that disclosed numerous violations of the Building Code, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would press for passage of a local law requiring that all construction work should be supervised by a registered architect or a licensed professional engineer.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Wheat, cotton and corn were listed by Department of Agriculture spokesmen today as major commodities upon which data looking toward crop insurance were being assembled.

Stressing luxury and quality and with approximately 7,500 stores throughout the country participating, the "Silk Parade," the annual promotion of silks and silk merchandise, got under way yesterday and will continue through Saturday.

A considerable interest was aroused yesterday in public-utility circles by the week-end news of President Roosevelt's Southeastern power conference. Offices of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation here were deluged with inquiries, not only from other utilities but also from bankers, brokers and investors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- A supplemental summary of transactions in securities in July by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. It showed generally that sales were somewhat in excess of accumulations, as did the earlier summary for the same month and recently made available.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Led by Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., who last week won her State championship for the first time, fifteen New Jersey players amassed 19 points on the Century Country Club course today to win the intersectional team matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association and carry across the river with them the Myrna D. Paterson Trophy.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 21. -- The question of payment of legal fees charged against the estate of Colonel Henry H. Rogers was heard here today by Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau in Suffolk County Surrogate's Court. Decision was reserved on all claims.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Seated at the head of the table in a dining-room where she has presided for fifty-eight years as mistress of Hyde Park House, Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt received presents and tributes tonight from three generations of her descendants on the celebration of her eighty-second birthday anniversary.

In his talk at the real estate men's convention yesterday HAROLD RIEGELMAN had kind words for some aspects of the Government's housing venture. "Most fruitful," according to the speaker, have been its efforts to save homes from distress foreclosure, to make mortgage credits liquid, to encourage home building and rehabilitation.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Paul Runyan, Westchester open champion and Metropolis Club professional, paired with two members of the club to win the chief honors in the first annual pro-women's Scotch foursomes tournament held today by the Westchester P.G.A. at the Grassy Sprain Golf Club.

KEYPORT, N.J., Sept. 21. -- State police tonight rounded up seven men and two women as material witnesses in the slaying of Robert J. "Farmer" Sullivan, former New York pugilist, who was shot by an unidentified person or persons as he sat at a table in Joseph Martini's tavern on Old Road, in Matawan Township, near here, yesterday.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The National Wrestling Association Championship Committee today named Leo (Daniel Boone) Savage, Dave Levin and Everett Marshall as outstanding contenders for the world's heavyweight title and suggested a tournament to clear up the situation in that division.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- The Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania will give its forty-ninth annual show this academic year during Thanksgiving Week, instead of during next Easter Week as tradition would require.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Politics, low wages and poor training are the real "public enemies" of the nation's police, J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, declared tonight.

Station WCAE at Pittsburgh, which was compelled by the Federal Communications Commission to broadcast campaign speeches by Earl Browder, Communist party candidate for President, was one of those included in the National Broadcasting Company hook-up last night featuring an address by James W. Ford, the party's Negro candidate for Vice President.

In quarterly session at the Hotel Astor yesterday, 576 members of the Actors Equity Association heard Frank Gillmore, president, plead for unity in the organization and in particular for "a little more confidence in its officers and council."

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21. -- Registering a 7-to-5 victory over the Old Westbury riders, the Meadow Larks advanced to the final round of the annual sixteen-goal Autumn Plates polo tournament today on the J.S. Phipps estate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- British opposition to the arrangement under which Germany built the dirigible Los Angeles for this country was disclosed today by diplomatic documents kept secret for fifteen years.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 21. -- Fourteen first-round defaults and the elimination of Jerry De Rosa of Branch Brook featured the opening of match play today at the Crestmont Golf Club in the Metropolitan Golf Association's second annual handicap tournament.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21. -- Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War during the World War, told the American Legion in convention here today that if the Legion had one mission above others it was "to see that the principles of individual liberty are not surrendered in deference to any political heresy or any imagined economic needs."

Those of us who have mistaken our trembling legs for the tottering pillars of the Constitution can now brace up. Senator VANDENBERG spoke in Chicago on Constitution Day: He is a specialist in diseases of the Constitution. His diagnosis is comforting:

Traders returned yesterday in a fairly optimistic frame of mind, and the share market resumed the advance begun last week. Utility and railway issues were in demand at the outset but by midday the market's momentum had largely spent itself, and prices worked lower in the afternoon.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Convinced that they are on the eve of a new period of expanding activity, realty leaders mapped plans here today to promote the orderly development of New York communities and to prevent repetition of some of the errors of the recent "boom" period.

Jack Lovelock, the great New Zealand miler from Oxford, who won the Olympic 1,500-meter championship in world-record time, arrived here yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, accompanied by his trainer, Bill Thomas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Sept. 16 shows increases for the week of $181,000,000 in total loans and investments, $28,000,000 in United States Government deposits and $30,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks and a decrease of $240,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 21. -Freshman and upper-class students were welcomed to Vassar this morning at the annual convocation, with Dr. Henry N. MacCracken, president; Professor George F. Dickinson and Dean C. Mildred Thompson as speakers.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, who with Sidney Hillman, head of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, is being denounced by William Randolph Hearst in his newspapers as "a Communist supporter" backing President Roosevelt for re-election, yesterday issued a statement denying any sympathies for communism and citing his record of opposition to the Communists.

Houses and vacant properties figured in deals reported by brokers in Queens yesterday. An apartment house site, approximately 30,000 square feet in size and bounded by Austin Street, Talbot Place, Eighty-fourth Road and 125th Street, Kew Gardens, was sold for Olla M. Barlow and Howard J. Barlow to the Dutchess Holding Corporation of Brooklyn by Cook Gload.
One man was killed and two were wounded in Christopher Street near Seventh Avenue at 4:30 A.M. yesterday by gunfire in a drunken brawl in which eight men, three of them patrolmen, were involved.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Sept. 21. -- Dr. and Mrs. C.W. Bowers of New York were honor guests at a cocktail party given here today by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Sanderson. Mr. and Mrs. William J. Cullen of New York and Mr. and Mrs. R.E. Fries of Camden, N.J., have arrived at the Mount Washington.
Plans for a new court house for a block front in Jamaica were among the building projects filed yesterday, as follows:

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- Great Britain and Norway agreed today to end their whaling dispute, which a fortnight ago threatened to lead to indiscriminate slaughter of the Antarctic's most valuable denizens.

The New York State Racing Commission, after reviewing the two cases of stimulation of horses at Saratoga, yesterday ordered the reinstatement of George E. Phillips, trainer for DeWitt Page's powerful Maemere Farm, but allowed the suspension of Trainer Emerson Davis of Canada to stand.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Sept. 21. -- A collision with a seagull tore a hole nearly a foot across in the metal wing of a big Martin bomber yesterday. The plane, flown by Cadet Norman C. Osher of the Ninety-ninth Bombardment Squadron, was on its way to manoeuvres at Providence when a flock of gulls flying high suddenly loomed ahead.

The war clouds now threatening Europe could be dispersed through the conversion of two men to peace, according to Professor William E. Rappard, director of the University of Geneva, who spoke yesterday at a luncheon of the faculty of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

The discovery in Sweden of a new star of the class known as novae, stellar bodies that suddenly flash into prominence and then die out again, was announced here last night by Professor Harlow Shapley, director of Harvard University Observatory.
Apartment leasing continued to be active over the week-end, with good demand indicated in all sections and classes of accommodation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Allotments totaling $9,795,959 for 103 PWA projects in thirty-two States and Puerto Rico were announced today by Secretary Ickes. The cost of these projects was put at $21,733,563.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21. -- What Next, a chestnut gelding owned by Henry Seaman of Mineola and driven by Henry Fleet of Oyster Bay, won the 2:24 class trot for amateur drivers in three straight heats before more than 20,000 at the opening of the Mineola Fair harness racing meet today.

PARIS, Sept. 21. -- The question of whether Dr. Nicolas Titulescu, former Foreign Minister of Rumania, was poisoned or not became the talk of France today, when the Paris-Soir printed a sensational article by Jules Sauerwein, who is now at St. Moritz, Switzerland, where the Rumanian statesman is fighting an apparently losing battle for his life.

GENEVA, Sept. 21. -- Emperor Haile Selassie, his American delegate, E.A. Colson, and a small-power revolt foiled the scheme to unseat the Ethiopian delegation at the opening of the eighteenth League of Nations Assembly today, so that the Italian delegation might return to it in triumph tomorrow.

Readjustment of the capital structure of the International Paper and Power Company is being considered by officials of the company and preliminary discussions on ways and means of accomplishing this have been held, it was ascertained yesterday.

Budget Director Leo J. McDermott said yesterday that funds for the maintenance of the city's park and playground system would be allotted in the 1937 budget in accordance with the city's financial ability to meet these new charges.

Mr. Krock refers to the Republicans' "pother over Maine, before and after the election." He points the finger of scorn at "Representative Bacon's amazing formula of adding up the majorities of each successful Republican candidate for Congress to find a State-wide majority, instead of using the available vote on an actual State-wide contest -- that between Senator White and Governor Brann."

GALES FERRY, Conn., Sept. 21. -- Yale football under Ducky Pond hasn't exactly had the world beating a path to the Bowl to see the Bulldog "mousetrap" tackle, but if there is any coaching group in the East whose stewardship has been more laudable than that of the hybrid Eli staff it does not readily come to mind.

Lady ASTOR brings over a temperance story about GEORGE BERNARD SHAW. He has been thought to be a good deal of a teetotaler as well as a vegetarian, but it seems that on one occasion he fancied that it might improve his writing if he were to drink heavily.

PEIPING, Sept. 21. -- The Fengtai tension was renewed today and lengthy conferences at the Japanese headquarters in Tientsin and Peiping are likely to result in a Japanese charge that the Chinese forces have failed to carry out their agreement to retire to a point south of the Peiping-Hankow Railway.

Irving Sommer, president of Sommer Realties, Inc., purchased from a client of Lionel Bauman the six-story elevator apartment house at 220 Highland Boulevard, Brooklyn, in the Highland Park section of that borough. The property is on a plot 200 by 100 feet, accommodating 100 families in suites of two, three and four room apartments.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 21. -- New plays and blocking occupied the Princeton football squad today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21. -- An hour and a half scrimmage was given to Harvard's football squad on the soggy Soldiers Field gridiron today with four touchdowns being scored.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 (AP). -- John Hamilton, National Chairman of the Republican party, said tonight that nomination of Governor Landon of Kansas as the Republican choice for President had started a surge of business recovery in the United States.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Patrick (Packey) McFarland, member of the Illinois State Athletic Commission and one of the greatest lightweight boxers of all time, tonight was fighting his toughest battle.

OVER in Philadelphia there are some enthusiastic fight fans who insist that Al Ettore is going to give Joe Louis a rough dusting this evening. Local pride and prejudice may have helped them to form that opinion. The rough-and-ready Ettore is a native product of the Quaker City area and apparently he stands well in his own community.
An extra dividend of 50 cents in addition to the regular quarterly disbursement of 50 cents on the common stock of the Lerner Stores Corporation was declared yesterday.

In a surprise move yesterday, Sam H. Harris shifted the opening of "Night Must Fall" from Oct. 13 to next Monday night at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, canceling the pre-Broadway tune-up scheduled for Oct. 8-10, in New Haven. Although the Harris office let its announcement go at that, the shift is seen as a manoeuvre in the race between this show and Alex Yokel's production of "Love From a Stranger," due next Tuesday the Fulton.

The surtax on undistributed profits will be upheld as constitutional by the courts, Edward H. Green of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, predicted last night in discussing the law before 1,300 accountants who attended a meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The American Legion's fun makers, the gay and impudent members of the 40 and 8, took over Euclid Avenue tonight as though it were a back street in a country town and pulled their monkeyshines for thirty blocks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Internal Revenue collections for July and August amounted to $542,352,774, compared with $466,600,853 in the first two months of the preceding fiscal year, the Treasury Department announced today. The increase of $75,751,921, or more than 16 per cent, was in face of a net loss of $28,185,264 in processing taxes.
BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- The new German Army began today the biggest and most spectacular field manoeuvres seen in Germany since 1914.

There exists today a very definite trend toward better prison administration, following the lead taken by the Federal Bureau of Prisons, William B. Cox, executive secretary of the Osborne Association, 114 East Thirtieth Street, said yesterday. Mr. Cox has just returned from a survey of the prison road camps in Virginia and West Virginia.
SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Sept. 22. -- Japan's decision to dispatch addi-

Both political parties want the farm vote and both may be expected to go after it diligently during the remaining weeks of the campaign. Governor LANDON set out yesterday on a tour which will take him through six Middle Western States. At Des Moines tonight he will presumably reveal to a farm audience his interpretation of the double-subsidy program which the Republican platform offers the agrarian voter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The record of operations of the Massachusetts Investors Trust, organized in 1924 as a voluntary trust, from its formation to the present time was told today to the Securities and Exchange Commission as the commission continued its inquiry into the operation of investment trust companies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- Prices of hogs here today declined 10 to 15 cents, compared with the close last week. The trade took a liberal movement soon to get under way, but the demand generally was not aggressive. The top was 10 cents off at $10.50, the lowest since July 15, while the day's average declined 10 cents to $9.65.

LONDON, Sept. 21. -- Because he had published a charge of ritual murder and other libels against the Jews, Arnold Spencer Leese, 57-year-old veterinary surgeon and editor of the violently anti-Semitic newspaper The Fascist, was sentenced to six months' imprisonment at Old Bailey today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- The battling Gas House Gang from St. Louis bounced back into second place in the National League today by defeating the Cubs, 5 to 4, and at the same time further aided the Giants' championship cause.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21. -- The Right Rev. Robert Lewis Paddock, retired Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Eastern Oregon, and Mrs. Paddock gave a tea and reception at their Buxton Hill Summer home in Williamstown this afternoon in honor of the Rev. Grant Noble, the new rector of St. John's Church, and Mrs. Noble. Mr. Noble is a former chaplain of Yale. Mrs. Florian J.C. Vurpillot of Washington presided at the tea table.

SEATTLE, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Hearst interests today demanded a subpoena for Dave Beck, Pacific Coast representative of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, in an effort to prove that he furnished some of the pickets whose blockade closed the Post-Intelligencer here Aug. 13.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 21. -- The last tower of the old Alcazar fortress crashed tonight under the artillery fire of Spanish Government forces preparing for a final assault on the besieged Rebels, who have held out for sixty-two days.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 21 (AP). -- Lawrence Westbrook, chairman of the WPA advisory board, told the Arkansas Farm Tenancy Conference today that industrialization of the South should be considered in any long-term program designed to improve the economic status of sharecroppers, tenants and impoverished farm labor.

A nation-wide drive to enlist Negro voters in support of the New Deal got under way last night with a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden. The proceedings were broadcast over a national radio hook-up and were linked with twenty-five similar meetings in cities throughout the industrial Northeastern States.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 21. -- Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, accompanied by his Chef de Cabinet, Mr. von Kotze, today went to Goedoelloe Castle to visit Regent Horthy, with whom the Germans will go hunting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Without disclosing its purpose, the New York State Power Authority entered today the eight-year-old controversy over a permanent license for diversion of Niagara River water remaining under United States control by the terms of a treaty with Canada.

Forty employes of THE NEW YORK TIMES and their families entered exhibits in the second annual Times flower show, which opened yesterday in The Times Annex. There was a colorful display of many kinds of flowers, and the vegetable exhibit was comparable with that at any professional show.

Miss Tallulah of the Legislative Bankheads came back to town last evening in a new play by George Kelly, also returning at the end of a Coast siesta. Say at once that when they are right, they are very right indeed, but add, in the dim postscript that is kin alike to the theatre and its morning after, they are not always so.

MADRID, Sept. 21 (AP). -- The People's Tribunal tonight condemned Rafael Salazar Alonso, former Minister of the Interior, to death for having been active in the present Spanish rebellion and also for having taken part in the Asturias uprising in October, 1934.

VIENNA, Sept. 21. -- Speaking at the conclusion of manoeuvres of the Fatherland Front militia today, Edouard Baar-Baarenfels, recently appointed militia commander by Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg, declared that the government intended to force men to enter the militia by law if a sufficient number did not volunteer.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 21. -- Arthur O. Wharton, president of the International Association of Machinists, asserted today that John L. Lewis, smarting under his inability to become president of the American Federation of Labor, would now attempt to set up a permanent national labor federation rival to the A.F. of L.
A boy of fourteen, sandy-haired, clean-featured Dick Shaughnessy, won the national all-bore skeet championship at St. Louis on Saturday.

With more buyers here and mail orders increasing, this week is expected to see a sharp pick-up in wholesale market activity. While adverse weather conditions have retarded broad expansion of the consumer demand for Fall apparel and accessories, enough inroads have been made into retail stocks to require heavier reordering than that which appeared during the last ten days.

BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- The Boerse opened the week today in its now chronic lethargy and with a weaker tone. An attempt to mark up prices at the opening fell flat, losses of 1 to 2 points being frequent. Heavy industrials opened uncertain, weakening later.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Howard Creel of Pueblo, Col., added an aft- I ernoon 70, one under par, to his morning par 71 to win medal honors in the thirty-six-hole qualifying round today of the first national left-handed golfers' tournament.

MADISON, N.J., Sept. 21. -- ]Iaurice O'Connor, New Jersey State P. O..4.. champion, today clipped six strokes from par to lead the field in the sectional qualifying test for the National Professional Golfers Association championship which will be played in November at Pinehurst.

Preparations to stamp out any attempts at violence such as have marked the strike of garage washers and polishers in the Bronx since it went into effect last Friday night were made by the police last night, when the union ordered the strike extended to Manhattan.

The advance in the prices of second-grade corporate bonds continued yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the average for forty representative issues in this group gaining .07 point to set a new high. The trading pace also was accelerated, total transactions reaching $13,094,700, compared with $12,761,100 on last Friday.
Staff members of some New York newspapers have asserted rather timidly that the cause of a hurricane is not known with certainty.

HYDE PARK, Sept. 21. -- Government loans at "moderate" interest rates to assist farm tenants in buying land were proposed by President Roosevelt today as a subject for legislation by the Congress which meets in January.

Allie S. Freed, chairman of the committee for economic recovery, returned yesterday on the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line after a survey of English housing activities, particularly land and city planning and small home design. While abroad he conferred with Sir Harold Bellman, executive of the English Building Societies.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- Duncan Fraser, a Chicago carpenter, was declared the winner tonight of the $500 first prize in the nation-wide contest for the best 200-word letter on "Why I Am For Roosevelt," which was sponsored by the Republican National Committee.

A.G. Becker Co., Inc., will offer today at $42 a share, 25,000 shares of capital stock (no-par value) of Compressed Industrial Gases, Inc. The proceeds, to the extent of approximately $400,000, will be used by the company to extend its operations into Pacific Coast territory by acquiring half of the stock of National Cylinder Gas Company-Pacific Coast.
Deaths from all causes in New York City for the week ended last Saturday totaled 1,173, the highest in the last four weeks, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The Biological Survey gave the lie today to the ancient assertion that the owl is wise.

WHEATLEY HILLS, L.I., Sept. 21. -- The Nassau County "ghost burglar" added another robbery to his long list some time last night when he entered the home of Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, and escaped with jewelry and cash amounting to $3,500.

Prices of commodity futures were mixed in fairly quiet trading yesterday. Sugar and cottonseed oil contracts again were heavy, while cocoa futures moved up sharply. In the cash markets, wheat, cocoa, butter, silk and rubber were higher, while corn, oats, cotton, lard, tin and wool tops were lower.

Condition once more told over a big reputation in a juvenile chute race at Belmont Park yesterday, which served to put forward new challengers against Pompoon for the $100,000 Futurity to be run at the conclusion of the present meeting.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 21. -- With four former holders of the United States senior championship setting the pace, the American team took the lead in the annual seniors' international triangular matches which began today over the picturesque course of the National Golf Links of America.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- The Board of Trustees of South Nyack, residential community here, voted tonight to formally join the protest movement against the proposed Nyack-Tarrytown bridge here at a point where the Hudson River is three miles wide.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Sept. 21. -- With her officers hoping to ride the tail end of last week's hurricane across part of the Atlantic, the dirigible Hindenburg departed for Germany at 11:05 P.M., New York time, tonight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- Charges that the CCC camps are being organized as a "floating New Deal machine under James A. Farley" were made today by Harrison E. Spangler, Assistant Republican National Chairman.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21. -- Seven hundred Los Angeles motorists whose traffic violations have repeatedly landed them in Traffic Court today underwent the first of a series of modern scientific tests to determine their driving ability.

Borough President Harvey of Queens, who recently refused a permit to the Communist party to hold a political meeting in the Jamaica Town Hall, and Supreme Court Justice Bonynge, who subsequently denied the organization legal redress, "struck a blow at the liberties and rights of the American people," speakers declared last night at a protest rally.
NANKING, Tuesday, Sept. 22. -- Responsible officials of the Chinese Government believe China is approaching a showdown with Japan in which "anything can happen."

BOSTON, Sept. 21. -- Perhaps confusing today's encounter between the Bees and Dodgers with a secret practice session of Harvard's football team, fewer than 100 fans invaded the privacy of the ball park to see Professor Stengel's boys bat out an easy 7-1 victory in the opener of a farewell four-game series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Labor's Non-Partisan League, headed by Major George L. Berry, and the Progressive National Committee, of which Senator La Follette is chairman, decided today to unite their forces in the campaign for re-election of President Roosevelt.

Co-Captain Harry Wheeler, Dick Tuckey and Vic Fusia were back in the line-up yesterday as Manhattan's football team launched its final drive for the St. Bonaventure game at Randalls Island Saturday. These men, slated to fill key positions, were held out of Saturday's scrimmage with Columbia, but took an active part in the two-hour drill on fundamentals at Innisfail Park.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 21. -- Responding to the urging of Jockey Hilton Dabson in the stretch, J.B.J. Townsend's Alexandrine today defeated A.G. Vanderbilt's Irrepressible in the running of The Prospect, feature of the program at Havre de Grace.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign axchange market, based on quotalions for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (AP). -- Frederick J. Perry of England and J. Donald Budge of Oakland, favorites to reach the singles final of the Pacific Southwest tennis championships, advanced to the third round today.

With satisfying sales increases, liquor campaigns this Fall will be the largest since repeal, according to announcement by three important companies yesterday. Newspapers will be used chiefly by Schenley Products Company to promote its Ancient Age straight whisky, by Canada Dry Ginger Ale for Johnnie Walker Scotch Whisky and by Oldetyme Distillers, Inc., for its Three Feathers and Green River products.

The United States has grown into an economic unit, and the Constitution should be changed to meet the interdependence of the States, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday morning in a speech opening the annual convention of the New York State district of Kiwanis International at the McAlpin Hotel.

The 1,500 employes of the United Drydocks Corporation at its Mariners Harbor, S.I., plant, who have been on a "sit down" strike since Wednesday, threatened last night to make their strike action official. The men charged that the company had violated a wage contract made last June.
DRESDEN, Germany, Sept. 22. -- Dr. Ferdinand Sauerbruch, noted German surgeon, issued today a warning to the political regime to let science alone unless it wants to wreck it.

TOULON, France, Sept. 22. -- Although conditions in Barcelona, Valencia, Madrid and other sections of Loyalist Spain where there is no actual fighting may be described as normal, the revolt already has introduced many changes, some striking and some less apparent but no less real.
There is no approach of science to religion, according to Sir Arthur Eddington, recognized internationally as one of the foremost contributors to the fields of theoretical astronomy and physics.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22. -- RKO has engaged Adolph Walbruck of the European screen for the title role of "Michael Strogoff" in the production of which Joseph N. Ermolieff, who directed a picture of the same title abroad, will assist Pandro S. Berman. Walbruck portrayed Johann Strauss in "Waltz Time in Vienna" and has appeared in many other notable Continental films.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here and in Winnipeg advanced around 2 cents a bushel today on the crest of a wave of general buying which swept prices into new high ground for the season, with the September delivery here selling at $1.16 1/2 at the close, the highest level at this period of the year since 1929.

A motion-picture house to be known as the Gramercy Cinema has been planned for 127-29 East Twenty-third Street, leased by Max J. Kramer to a group including Arthur Mayer, operator of the Rialto Theatre, and Michael Ruden and Arthur Rapf, operators of twenty motion-picture houses in Manhattan and New Jersey.

Reflecting what seemed to be a generally favorable opinion of the proposed new traffic code for the city, discussed on Monday before the traffic committee of the Board of Aldermen, executives of the two leading automobile clubs in the city gave yesterday, in general, their support to the measure.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers tightened their claim on second place in the American League race today by blanking St. Louis in both games of a twin bill.

The Rev. Dr. Henry A. Stimson, founder and pastor emeritus of the former Manhattan Congregational Church, who died on July 18 last, named his widow, Mrs. Alice Bartlett Stimson, sole beneficiary of his estate. This was learned yesterday when his will disposing of an estate of more than $20,000 was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.
BILBAO, Spain, Sept. 22. -- Bishop Mathieu of Dax, France, today appealed personally for the relief of the 4,000 hostages held by Spanish Loyalists in this area.

Passengers carried by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company on both the subway and elevated divisions in August numbered 73,085,759, of whom 56,577,689 rode in the subway and 16,508,070 on the elevated lines, according to the monthly report filed yesterday in Federal court here by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Replying to a WPA forecast of serious suffering in many New Jersey municipalities unless additional relief funds are provided, Arthur Mudd, State relief director, declared today that a survey of his own has convinced him that the majority of municipalities are "doing all right."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Allegations of "graft, payroll padding, intimidation and political discrimination" against the Works Progress Administration were made in a statement issued today by the Republican National Committee. The statement asserts that WPA officials raised their salaries, and that inefficiency exists in WPA units in New York, New Jersey, Indiana, Illinois and Michigan.

In a setting resembling the spirit if not the magnitude of a Viennese festival, the Park Department presented last night its third annual water carnival on the west side of the Seventy-second Street Lake in Central Park.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Aug. 31 a consolidated net income of $11,312,251 after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 7 cents a share on 33,673,328 no-par common shares.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 22. -- The semi-finals of the second annual Metropolitan Golf Association handicap title tournament became a New Jersey-Long Island affair today at the Crestmont Golf Club, when two New Jersey players came through successfully in the upper bracket and a pair of Long Island linksmen survived the preliminary rounds in the lower bracket.

HYDE PARK, Sept. 22. -- While continuing routine conferences on Federal administration affairs, President Roosevelt turned today toward consideration of practical politics, announcing that eight to twelve leaders of the Democratic party would meet with him here Thursday to discuss campaign plans and related matters.

Taking advantage of their mutual training facilities at Innisfail Park, Manhattan and the New York Giants combined their football workouts yesterday, engaging in a ninety-minute non-contact forward passing scrimmage. The drill gave Coach Chick Meehan a chance to review the Jasper aerial game in preparation for the opening contest with St. Bonaventure at Randalls Island Saturday, while Coach Steve Owen pointed his charges for Sunday's road game with Pittsburgh.

Hearings on departmental budgetary requests for 1937 were closed yesterday by Budget Director Leo J. McDermott with the departments and other city agencies seeking about $30,000,000 more than was allotted them this year.

Printed reports that Harry Richman, the singer-aviator, had dumped 500 gallons of gasoline into the ocean before landing at Musgrave Harbor, Nfld., on Sept. 13, were denied by Dick Merrill, co-pilot with Richman on the round-trip flight to England completed at Floyd Bennett Field on Monday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- After the usual preliminaries the weights were announced as 203 1/4 pounds for Joe Louis and 189 3/4 for Al Ettore, the Detroiter having an advantage of 13 1/2 pounds.
Regarding your editorial about the Italian quest for credits, may I call attention to a cable in the Sept. 21 issue of The Christian Science monitor from its London office?

A suit for $100,000 damages for libel was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn by Herbert Smithers, an attorney of 189 Montague Street, Brooklyn, against Warren Leslie, real estate operator, who was one of the figures in the Bergen Beach condemnation proceeding.

Sales of furs, with a gain of 29.4 per cent, showed the largest percentage increase in August in large department stores in the Second Federal Reserve district, compared with volume in the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

With the tremendous increase in the use of automobiles, distributors are no longer dealing with statis markets and they must adjust their selling policies to catch this highly accelerated type of buying power, Dr. Miller McClintock, head of the Bureau of Street Traffic Research at Harvard University, declared here yesterday.

Brokers are watching closely the action of the stock market as it approaches the triple top represented by the highest prices of July 28, Aug. 10 and Sept. 9. On three occasions this Summer the market has backed away from a level represented by the range 134-136 in THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks.

Mrs. Nathaniel R. Landon gave a luncheon yesterday at the Weylin for Mrs. Augustus Van Cortlandt Jr., the Misses Carolyn and Katherine Van Cortlandt, Miss Cynthia Landon and Augustus Van Cortlandt 3d.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- In a move to effect a saving in fixed charges, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company of San Francisco has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $35,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, Series I, 3 1/2 per cent, due on June 1, 1966.

One of the largest of the many deals which have made the Dyckman section of Manhattan Island one of the most active realty centers this season was closed yesterday in the purchase by an investment company headed by David Rose of a frontage of more than 300 feet on Broadway at the northeast corner of Dongan Place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- A program for erosion control and soil and water conservation in the upper limits of watersheds where floods are born was advocated today at the opening sessions of the Up-Stream Engineering Conference called by Secretary Wallace with the approval of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today a summary of registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933, including one by The World Digest Association, Inc., of New York City, covering 25,000 certificates of beneficial interest in a trust representing 150 shares of no-par value common stock of the company to be offered with subscriptions to World Digest Magazine as follows:

A pay-as-you-go policy requiring each generation to support its aged and to determine the amounts to be paid toward old-age security was among the planks which the National Republican Club decided last night to recommend to the forthcoming State convention.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Flood waters of the Colorado River, considerably diminished in force, were entering low-lying sections of the city tonight, and some of the residents evacuated their homes.

Persons tough enough to have lived through a number of Presidential campaigns are aware that the country is saved or lost every four years. Each side represents itself as saver and the other as destroyer. Evidently the United States is a hardy plant. The old farce is now being played with the traditional amount of bellow and slapstick.

Two specimens of unusually rare fish were in the cargo of the liner American Banker when she arrived yesterday from London. They were the gift of Edward G. Boulenger, director of the aquarium of the London Zoological Society, to Dr. Charles H. Townsend, director of the aquarium of the New Fork Zoological Society.

ALBANY, Sept. 22. -- Removal charges filed against Mayor La Guardia of New York City by Robert C. Moore of Forest Hills, Queens, were dismissed today by Governor Lehman with the brief announcement that there was no reason for executive action.

Chagrined at their failure to find any "truly American" trinkets that met with their approval, twenty-four English girls made ready last night to sail for home today on the Queen Mary with gifts of European manufacture for their friends in London.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22. -- Although the Soviet Government still carefully dissociates itself from any official connection with the campaign among Soviet women for funds for Spanish workers' families, the newspaper Pravda, chief organ of the Russian Communist party, declared today the Soviet people were heart and soul with "the courageous fighters for the Popular Front."

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22. -- On the eve of a vote whether or not to call on Congress for pensions for widows and orphans of all World War veterans, without regard to the cause of death of the veterans, nearly a quarter million members of the American Legion in convention here faced in the local morning paper today a challenge from the American Veterans' Association to abandon anything even intimating a "general pensions law."

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 22 (AP). -- As violence flared again at a linseed plant here, Governor Hjalmar Petersen ordered mobilization of the Minnesota National Guard tonight in preparation for any emergency arising out of the city's milling strike, at the same time he called a conference of strike leaders for 9 A.M. tomorrow in a final effort to reestablish order without the aid of troops.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin asserted here tonight that he was actively engaged in the political campaign because the encyclicals of Popes Leo XIII and Pius XI contained a "mandate to every priest" to seek the eradication of "the evils of modern capitalism."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22. -- Starting late because of the heat, Harvard's football squad continued its pre-campaign drive today with a hard drill. Following a defensive scrimmage in which the A and B varsities lined up against the third eleven which ran plays from both single and double wing back formations. Coach Harlow's ranking players put in more than an hour on attack.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- A 5-day-old baby, doomed otherwise to death because of an intestinal deformity, was operated on this afternoon after his father's objections had been overcome. His wife's hopes and surgeons' convictions convinced him there was a chance that the child might live a normal life.

In 1930 more than a thousand economists petitioned President HOOVER not to raise the tariff. Mr. Hoover entirely ignored the petition and signed the Tariff Act of 1930 with its substantial increases in duties.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 22. -- Cincinnati left its work-a-day tasks today to shout a welcome home to "King" Johnny Fischer, tall, slender 24-year-old United States amateur golf champion.

Two men who are alleged to have accompanied Robert J. (Farmer) Sullivan to Martini's Tavern in Matawan Township, N.J., where he was shot to death last Sunday morning, were held yesterday by the New Jersey authorities as material witnesses in the case.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- Despite increasing pro-German feeling among the British public and in a sizable faction of the Baldwin Cabinet itself, it is not the intention or desire of the government to urge France to abandon its Soviet alliance for the sake of luring Chancellor Adolf Hitler into a new Locarno agreement.

Price movements were irregular on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. On the cash markets wheat, rye, oats, cotton, wool tops, silk and rubber advanced and quicksilver sold at a new high price. Corn, butter, lard and tin declined, while raw sugar fell 5 points to 3.45 cents, a decline of 25 points in two weeks.

Rallying furiously in the last three sessions, Charlie Gomer, 133 1/2, Paris, gained an eight-round decision over Carl (Red) Guggino, 133, Tampa, in the feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 5,000 watched the battlers in their second meeting, the first having ended in a draw several weeks ago.

NANKING, China, Sept. 22. -- The United States Embassy office here announced today that it had notified the Chinese Foreign Office that the new Income Tax Law could not be considered applicable to Americans.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,037,000 barrels, compared to 3,020,850 in the previous week, an increase of 16,150, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 25,000 barrels daily in Oklahoma was the most important change.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Only one player in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day medal play event at the Rockville Country Club today registered a score below 90 and she was Mrs. Belle C. Rosenberg of Lakeville.

Thirty-three students from twenty-five American colleges, about to depart for a year's study in a Munich, were warned yesterday against becoming pro-German or anti-German and were advised rather to seek understanding and experience in a culturally older country.

Hervey Allen has virtually completed what he calls his new short novel (100,000 words long), "Action at Aquila." After finishing this book he will return to work on "Richfield Springs," which is to be 350,000 words long. His "Anthony Adverse" sold 3,700 copies last week, Farrar Rinehart say, and an "author's edition," limited to 20,000 copies, is about to be published.

The small Norwegian freighter Pluto and the Central Vermont Transportation Company's freighter New York were in collision in a dense fog at 9:40 o'clock last night in the East River off Hunt's Point, the Bronx.

MADRID, Sept. 18 (By Courier to Paris, Uncensored). -- A majority of Madrid's 850,000 inhabitants apparently hope that the military insurgents will enter soon in order to save the capital from proletarian misrule and Red terror.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- After accusing the New Deal of failing to deal with fundamental economic questions, Norman Thomas, Socialist nominee for President, predicted the re-election of President Roosevelt when he spoke today at a National Press Club luncheon.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 22. -- E.D. Shaffer's Floradora, one of the leading 3-year-old fillies of the season, showed a clean pair of heels to five colts and geldings of same age in winning the featured mile and one-sixteenth by a half length from Sandy Boot at Narragansett Park today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Plans to have definite data for a Federal crop insurance program on hand by the time Congress convenes in January developed today from an organization meeting of administration leaders named by President Roosevelt to explore that subject.

Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, who became president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation in 1933 and has been in office since, yesterday was re-elected to that position at the annual meeting of the board of directors, which followed a morning meeting of the stockholders, at which every member of the board of directors was renamed.
TOLEDO, Spain. Sept. 22. -- Fasc ist war planes blew up a vital railway bridge not far from this city today, and the government rushed fresh troops to meet the advancing Moorish columns.

What started out yesterday to be a simple publicity stunt with fifteen chorus girls engaging in a tug-o'-war in the center of Times Square ended with one of the girls being held for Special Sessions to face a Sullivan Law charge.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- Only a few hours after having returned from an inspection tour in Near Eastern waters Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, issued a peppery statement today announcing that Great Britain would stay in the Mediterranean and defend her interests there against all comers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Income tax collections from Sept. 1 to 21 amounted to $283,607,585, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced today. This is compared to $226,352,401 from Sept. 1 to 20, 1935.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The Indians and the White Sox battled to an 8-to-8 tie today, the game being called at the end of the twelfth inning on account of darkness.

Taking stock of the season's fishing in the waters of Westchester and Putnam Counties, Melville C. Rosch, secretary of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, concludes that the yield of trout in the lakes and reservoirs was beyond expectations, while the results from stream angling were considerably below the normal level.

War in Europe, brought much closer by recent events, can be averted only if the democratic countries stand together in a demonstration of readiness to resist by force aggression from Fascist countries, Sir Walter Citrine, general secretary of the British Trades Union Congress and president of the International Federation of Trade Unions, said yesterday upon his arrival on the Cunard-White Star liner Laconia.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Japanese marines were landed on Chinese soil tonight, with their commanders determined "to eradicate anti-Japanese feeling."

Reporting upon conditions abroad, RUDOLF S. HECHT, New Orleans banker, advised his fellow-bankers at their annual convention at San Francisco to accept gracefully the "more "moderate evolutionary changes going "on at home" lest they be faced with the social upheavals that have taken place and still are taking place abroad.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Lambasting two Pirate pitchers for fifteen hits, the Chicago Cubs beat Pittsburgh, 11 to 4, today to remain in the National League fight for second place.
MADRID, Sept. 22. -- The Spanish Government broadcast an urgent call tonight to "every man able to carry a gun or help build defenses" in an effort to stem the Fascist advance toward the capital.

After declining early to the lowest quotations since the advance of Sept. 8 that followed the government's estimate of the cotton crop, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered sharply yesterday and ended with net gains of 4 to 8 points. The recent slow decline from above 12 1/4 cents to around 11 3/4 cents a pound appeared to reduce selling pressure and also to increase the quantity of scale-buying orders until definite resistance developed.

SANTA CRUZ DE RETAMAR, Spain, Sept. 22. -- A motley Spanish government army held desperately to its position here tonight after three days of savage and bloody fighting -- the most severe Fascist attack of the civil war. [Santa Cruz de Retamar, a Spanish Government headquarters, is 37 1/2 miles from Madrid.]

ROME, Sept. 22. -- An Italian expeditionary force is being actively organized in Addis Ababa to march on Gore, 230 miles southwest of Addis Ababa, as soon as the rains end. The object of this is to deprive the supporters of Haile Selassie of their last reason for contending that an organized native government still exists in Ethiopia capable of appointing delegates to the League of Nations.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22. -- Through streets lined deep with paper thrown from windows by applauding spectators, with an estimated half million lining the curbstones for more than two miles, the American Legion staged its annual parade today. It was the most colorful and most impressive parade ever seen in the United States, National Commander Ray Murphy and other officials declared.

BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- The Boerse was generally dull and weaker today, excepting rayon and colonial issues. The latter shares continued their spectacular upward movement in line with the expansion policy of colonial companies. New Guiana stocks, which registered a gain of 24 points yesterday, rose 6 more today, and Cameroon added 3 1/4 points.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The determination of leading north county dairymen to withdraw from the milk strike was announced today by Paul J. Woodard of Sandy Creek, as Oswego County Supervisor and chairman of the northern counties' strike committee.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Sharecropper and landlord, brought together in a mutual effort to solve the South's farming problem, agreed today that mutual confidence and cooperation must be the foundation of any tenant-uplift movement.
The dollar on the local foreign mxchange market, based on quota-i tions for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as fol-! lows (quotations are in cents):

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 22. -- John P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor, who filed the charges that resulted in the suspension of ten unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, made a bitter attack today on John L. Lewis, chairman of the C.I.O., and accused him of treason to the labor movement and to the nation's institutions.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. 22 (By Telephone to Lisbon, Portugal). -- General Francisco Franco's Foreign Legion and Moors were sweeping southeast tonight toward relief of the besieged cadets in the Toledo Alcazar after smashing the backbone of the Leftist forces and cutting Madrid's communications with the south.

The security and commodity markets gained ground yesterday. Stocks closed irregularly higher in fairly active trading, although the volume on the Stock Exchange was less than on Monday -- 1,547,000 shares against 1,766,000. The market felt its way carefully, as may be judged by the fact that prices were mixed in the first hour, substantially higher in the second, firm at midday, generally higher in the early afternoon, and easier in the final hour.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The parliamentary recess has run half its course. The Berlin Olympic Games, which may perhaps be treated as its German equivalent, are a thing of the past, and the Nuremberg Nazi Congress week is over. It seems an opportune moment to review the situation and take stock of our position.

Whether the Millinery Quality Guild, Inc., and its affiliate, the Uptown Creators Guild, can legally stamp out style piracy and expel members selling retailers who do not cooperate, will be argued before the Federal Trade Commission in the near future.
A desire for travel seized an 8-month-old wire-haired fox terrier yesterday and the 8:36 A.M. train from Port Washington, L.I., supplied the motive power.

America's most important art at present is architecture, in the opinion of Pierre Roy, founder of the Surrealist movement, who arrived on Monday from Paris on the Queen Mary with Alfred Kingsley Lawrence, British artist. Both left last night for Pittsburgh to serve with Edward Bruce and Guy Pene Du Bois, American artists, on the jury of this year's Carnegie International Art Exhibition, to be opened to the public on Oct. 15.

A heavy demand for apartment space was indicated in reports from brokers yesterday as Fall renting approached its peak. A large number of penthouses were included in the day's rentals and there was considerable activity in the upper East Side residential section extending from the Fifties to the Eighties east of Central Park.

All city departments have been warned that the WPA plans to withdraw its workers from jobs that should be included in the regular city budget, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 22. -- The Uruguayan Government severed diplomatic relations with Spain this afternoon on the ground that the Madrid Government was no longer able to guarantee the lives or property of foreigners.

Second-grade corporate bonds advanced yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, several of them reaching new high levels. The buoyancy of railroad loans sent prices up from fractions to 2 1/2 points and carried the average for that group to a new peak.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Leo Diegel of Philadelphia won two matches with a total eight under par today and advanced with five other Philadelphians and two New Jersey players to the quarter-finals of the Philadelphia Professional Golfers Association tournament.

A LITTLE more than fifty years ago some one tossed a dynamite bomb into a squad of Chicago policemen. The bomb went off immediately, killing one officer outright and wounding almost seventy others. Quickly re-forming their ranks, the police fired into a crowd of workmen out of which, presumably, the bomb had come.

Appreciation of the desire of Peru and Ecuador for the peaceful settlement of controversies was expressed yesterday by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, in a message to the Pan-American Society, read at a luncheon at India House, 1 Hanover Square, in honor of the members of the arbitration commission from the two countries.

After listening to a motion seeking to have the claims of American holders of certificates and participating debentures of the bankrupt Kreuger Toll Company subordinated to all other types of claims, Harold P. Coffin, referee, adjourned a hearing in the Federal Building yesterday until Oct. 22.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 22. -- The New Jersey Supreme Court has granted a writ of certiorari to review the legality of a contract entered into between the city of Bayonne and Central District, Inc., which makes the corporation the city's agent in the construction of the proposed $5,252,045 ship to rail terminal on the New York Bay shore.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- Joe Louis took the second successful step toward his former eminence as a leading challenger for the world heavyweight championship by knocking out Al Ettore, the barrel-chested Philadelphia Italian, in the fifth of their scheduled fifteen-round bout tonight.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Sandstone, a Pompey-Stone Image filly, overcame interference to score her second victory in fourteen starts today. She won in a field of $3,000 claiming sprinters in the outstanding race of a featureless program.
