The Latin peoples must overcome the "uncivilized tendency of settling political issues with the sword rather than the ballot, declared Dr. Juan B. Sacasa, former President of Nicaragua, who arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Elena from Panama. He was accompanied by his brother, Dr. Frederico Sacasa, and was met at the West Nineteenth Street pier by his wife and two daughters.
HILLSGROVE, R. I., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Three army aviators were killed tonight when their Martin bomber crashed and burned near the State Airport here during a heavy fog.

The city of Buffalo, N.Y. awarded yesterday two issues of bonds aggregating $5,000.000 to a banking group headed by Edward B. Smith Co., on a bid of 100.0299 for $2,500,000 of relief bonds, due 1937 to 1946, as 3.10s, and $2,500,000 of refunding bonds, due in 1937 to 1986, as 2 1/2s.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 22. -- Governor Landon's farm address here tonight was as follows:

As one who once intended being a preacher, but, instead, became a sermon reporter, I would like to offer as an alternative to a moratorium on preaching, as suggested again by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming of Trinity Church, that a better plan might be to allow more time for preachers to prepare their sermons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Charges that Lawrence Simpson of Seattle, the American seaman who has been under arrest in Germany since June 28, 1935, accused of treason and espionage and whose trial is scheduled to open before the People's Court in Berlin Monday, had not received adequate protection from the State Department were indignantly denied today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- Conflicting reports concerning an Anglo-American film deal resulted today in a further slump in the price of shares of Gaumont-British Pictures. Contradictory rumors continued to circulate in regard to the status of negotiations for a deal with film interests in the United States.

An extra dividend of 25 cents a share, together with a dividend of 25 cents, on the Class A and B common stock of the North American Rayon Corporation were declared yesterday. On July 1, 25 cents was distributed.

The National Chairman of the Republican party has evolved the theory that the nomination of Governor LANDON is responsible for the recent surge of business recovery. Pointing to the gains made during the past three months, he says:

l Mr. CHARLES E. HUGHES Jr. made an impressive speech in the Bronx yester day advocating the proposed new charter. He explained how the commission, of which he is a member, had retained the Board of Estimate, this city's unique contribution to the science and practice of municipal government, as a body peculiarly well-fitted to discharge the municipality's business affairs.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 22. -- A larger, more brilliant and varied display of exhibits than ever before marked the opening this afternoon of the annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society, with the Greenwich, Riverside Hortulus, Old Greenwich, Rye Garden Clubs and Little Garden Club of Rye cooperating.

R.J. Baker, president of the American Steamship Owners Association, yesterday defended the provision of the newly enacted Copeland merchant marine act that merchant seamen must carry continuous discharge books bearing a record of their employment and their status at the time they left their last job.

SEATTLE, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Edwin S. Smith, National Labor Board examiner, denied a motion by Edward G. Woods, a Hearst attorney, today for dismissal of the American Newspaper Guild complaint that The Seattle Post-Intelligencer discharged two veteran employes for Guild activity.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Felix and Stanley Piseck announced late tonight at a meeting of 400 dairymen in Cincinnatus, Cortland County, that the milk strike scheduled for Thursday had been called off and that they were putting the milk dealers "on probation" for a month.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- A long-angled shot by Earle A.S. Hopping, after more than five minutes of an extra period, brought victory in the Geoffrey Cup tournament to Great Island tonight on Whitney Field at Meadow Brook.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday that a report from the department's ballistics bureau indicated that the bullet that killed Harold Sullivan, cabaret owner, during a drunken brawl in Greenwich Village early Monday morning was from the service revolver of Patrolman John V. Buckley.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- William A. Brady of New York, theatrical producer and a holder of common stock of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, filed a petition today in Federal District Court here asking for dismissal of the reorganization proceedings of the Baldwin company under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act. He contended that the company's business had improved so much in the last nine months that reorganization was not necessary.

John Masefield, English poet laureate; Mrs. Beryl Markham, the only woman to fly the Atlantic from east to west; Lord Stonehaven, who headed the English delegation to the naval architects' convention here; Miss Betty Sze, daughter of the Chinese Ambassador, and members of the British Walker Cup team are among the passengers leaving today on the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line.

The Colonial-type residence containing seven rooms and three baths recently erected under the auspices of McCall's Magazine at Woodlea Lane in the River Road development adjacent to the Frank A. Vanderlip estate at Scarborough-on-the-Hudson has been purchased by an officer of the Lehn Fink Products Corporation of this city.

With its list of soloists almost completed, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society announced yesterday the engagement of twenty-nine guest artists for the coming season, which will begin on Nov. 5. Eleven pianists, six violinists, two 'cellists and ten singers are among those scheduled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Assertions that a serious situation may develop in many municipalities in New Jersey this Fall and Winter unless the State provides more relief funds and establishes closer control over the 550 separate jurisdictions now charged with responsibility for relief were made today by the Works Progress Administration basing their statements on a recent survey of twelve communities.

Keron Dwyer's letter in opposition to the proportional representation method of election which is to be presented to the voters of the city on Nov. 3 indicates that he intends to be fair but is not in possession of the full facts.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 22. -- Carrying the Republican Presidential fight into Delaware tonight, John D.M. Hamilton, national chairman, charged here that corporations holding government contracts had been forced "under duress and threat" to contribute to the Democratic party's campaign fund.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The Army sent Howard Creel of Pueblo, Col., into the third round of the national left-handers' golf tournament tonight even more easily than he had advanced to the second round today.

Unless the $460,000,000 transit unification plan advocated by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. can be consummated without a substantial reduction of the city's borrowing capacity under the State constitutional debt limit, its adoption would be of questionable wisdom, Mr. Berle told the Transit Commission yesterday.

The foreign exchange market was enlivened yesterday by heavy engagements of gold in Paris for American account, by a sharp decline in the guilder and by the raising of the pound sterling to the highest level since Aug. 04, 1934, as French and Dutch capital was apparently transferred to London in large amounts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The New Rochelle Water Company filed with the city of New Rochelle today a new schedule which would reduce municipal and private consumer water rates an average of 25 per cent.

STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 22. -- Robert Bosch, veteran Swabian inventor and industrialist, will be 75 years old tomorrow. He will be acclaimed not only in his native city but throughout Germany as a man whose inventive genius, commercial integrity and enterprise have brought world fame to his fatherland.

HYDE PARK, Sept. 22 (AP). -- President Roosevelt named today a committee of 18 headed by Dr. Floyd Reeves of the University of Chicago, to study the need for an "expanded program" of Federal aid for vocational education.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Harry Pownall of the Nassau Driving Club piloted all three winners on the harness racing program at the Mineola Fair today. They were Mack Yerks in the 2-year-old pace, Hal Bee Laurel in the 2:17 pace and Joy Lincoln in the 2:17 trot.

Eight Queens election inspectors, all from the Second Assembly District of that county, were dismissed by the Board of Elections yesterday after it was discovered that they had left their official primary returns overnight at a Democratic club in the district.

Paris originals and their copies paraded as twins at the fashion show of Fall and Winter costumes presented yesterday at Lord Taylor. Models selected from the Paris collections by Dorothy Shaver, vice president and style director of the store, were shown with the reproductions.

The personnel of a committee appointed to resume the investigation of Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, and of the college affairs in general, was announced last night at the first Fall meeting of the Board of Higher Education by Mark Eisner, chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- Joe Louis was very pleased with his victory over Al Ettore, but felt that it was an inevitable result. "Ettore was tougher than a lot of people thought he was and he certainly was game," said Joe in his dressing room.

Gains in business failures were recorded in the manufacturing, wholesale and retail groups in the week ended Sept. 17, compared with the previous five-day business week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The number of retail insolvencies was forty-one below the average of the group for the first thirty-eight weeks of this year.

Efforts of the Tenement House Department to enforce the Multiple Dwellings Law will cause a housing shortage in New York City, "with all the tragedy that a housing shortage entails," Tenement House Commissioner Langdon Post said last night at a meeting of Local 10 of the Workers Alliance of Greater New York at Greenwich House, 29 Barrow Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Prices of hogs continued on the down grade today, losing 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight. The top of $10.35 was in new low ground since June, off 15 cents from yesterday, while the day's average was reduced 10 cents to $9.55.

Despite an offer by Captain John Hay (Jock) Whitney of the Greentree polo team representing the United States in the international series against Argentina to withdraw, the United States Polo Association decided yesterday to use the same quartet in the second match today that was defeated by 21 to 9 in the opening game on Sunday.

A banking group headed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., will offer today $17,300,000 of first mortgage and refunding 4 per cent bonds, Series C, due on Oct. 1, 1966, and $4,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures due on Oct. 1, 1946, of the Gulf States Utilities Company.

The revamped Brooklyn Football Dodgers will be out to get off on the right foot tonight at Ebbets Field when they usher in their National League campaign at 8:30 o'clock in a clash with the Pittsburgh Pirates. The battle also will inaugurate the league professional gridiron season in New York.
Nearly 100 children of the lower East Side harvested yesterday afternoon the vegetables they had grown during the summer in a half-acre enclosure at the southeastern end of Seward Park.

Those who consider the Robinson-Patman act another law subject to the casual type of enforcement which characterized prohibition and NIRA are treading on exceedingly dangerous ground, Gilbert H. Montague, attorney, said yesterday before the second annual Perfume and Cosmetic Buyers Conference and Exhibition in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Supervised Shares, Inc., a mutual open-end investment trust, declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 13 cents a share from net income on investments, as well as a special payment of 37 cents a share, representing part of the net profits realized from the sale of securities thus far in 1936.

BURGOS, Spain, Sept. 22. -- The military high command in this seat of the insurgent junta announced tonight that after the capture of Maqueda by the Fascists government forces fell back along the two main arteries running out of the city. One highway runs from Maqueda northeast to Madrid and the other southeast to Toledo.

John C. Jay, chairman of the executive committee of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company, and Laurence G. Payson, president of the Stock Clearing Corporation, have been elected trustees of the Franklin Savings Bank.
The aging Pat Malone notched his twelfth victory of the campaign for the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium in a game that was peculiar in more ways than one.

ALBANY, Sept. 22. -- The Public Health Council announced today that it had enacted several amendments to the State's Milk Code. One will aid dairy farmers whose milk is being sold without pasteurization and whose herds have not been blood-tested for Bang's disease.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange continued cheerful today although British Government issues reacted slightly after several days of uninterrupted gains. Renewed attention was paid to aviation and motor stocks.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22. -- Don Gutteridge, fleet-footed young third baseman, drove five runs over the plate with a single, double and triple today and enabled the Cardinals to retain their half-game second-place margin over Chicago by beating the Reds, 6 to 3.

In the past seven years six large book and periodical printers have moved their plants to such cities as Dunellen, N.J., Stamford and Bridgeport, Conn., and Philadelphia. Approximately 250 magazines with a large New York circulation and formerly printed here are now printed out of town.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22 (AP). -- Astronomers scanned the heavens tonight to follow the path of a newly discovered comet and observe another nova, or "new star."

A program defined as an analysis of the new way of living was presented yesterday in the sixth annual forum on current problems sponsored by The New York Herald Tribune at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Capacity attendance in the grand ballroom, including women from most of the forty-eight States, marked the morning and afternoon sessions.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- The Giants gritted their teeth today and settled down to the business of clinching the 1936 National League pennant with great gusto. But after more than five hours of great mental torture and general anguish, our Giants, their gusto gone, were still doing nothing more than gritting their teeth, which now operated as though somebody had left an awful lot of sand in that spinach.

Yesterday's buyer registrations were the highest since Aug. 4, when a peak of 692 was established, according to the listings in THE TIMES. However, the weekly total was lower for both the previous week and the corresponding period in 1935.

The cultivation of sportsmanship and fair play in our relationships would afford a solution to our present "mud-slinging" political campaigns, as well as obtaining international amity and promoting good citizenship, Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, Pa., declared yesterday.
BERLIN, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Persistent rumors that Adolf Hitler might relinquish the Chancellorship, remaining as Fuehrer, drew official denials tonight.

Federal Judge Harlan W. Rippey of Rochester is slated for the Democratic nomination for associate judge of the State Court of Appeals, it was indicated here yesterday. One of the seven places on the court will become vacant at the end of this year through the retirement of Judge Leonard C. Crouch of Syracuse, and a candidate to succeed him must be selected at the State conventions of both parties next week.

GENEVA, Sept 22. -- The League of Nations Financial Committee in its report to the Council, out today, recommends strongly, though implicitly, that France, the Netherlands and Switzerland depreciate their currencies to the point at which their price levels are brought into line with those of the sterling and dollar areas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- A general gain in factory employment, plus a small net increase in non-manufacturing industries, sent 166,000 persons back to private employment in August and increased weekly payrolls in the industries studied by about $7,300,000, Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- The government as a partner in business is "unwanted and undesirable," Colonel Robert H. Montgomery of New York City, senior partner of the accounting firm of Lybrand, Ross. Brothers Montgomery, declared today at the thirty-first annual convention of the National Stationers Association.

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company reported yesterday for the eight months ended on Aug. 31 an estimated net income of $3,782,769 after Federal income taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other charges.

WASHINGTON, Ind., Sept. 22. -- A wild dash down a hillside in pursuit of her runaway automobile and trailer has placed Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde, former United States Minister to Denmark, in Davies County Hospital here, with a broken left leg and put an abrupt end to her campaign tour for President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- An application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the 6 1/2 per cent external sinking fund gold bonds of 1930, dated Feb. 1, 1930, and due on Aug. 1, 1961 (unassented), of the Province of Buenos Aires was granted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective at the close of trading on Sept. 28.

Marc Connelly, who arrived from England only last week, starts back today on the Queen Mary to become a London producer late next month with Geoffrey Kerr's new play, "Till the Cows Come Home" (in which Adrianne Allen will play opposite Leslie Banks, who in turn will impersonate a young English statesman on a holiday).
HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 22 (AP). -- The National Boxing Association today named Max Schmeling, former heavyweight boxing champion, as the leading contender for James J. Braddock's crown.

A President running for re-election, if he has the courage and the decisiveness, can blanket almost any strategy of his rival when that rival is trying to outdo him in promises of the same general type. Recently Mr. Roosevelt has demonstrated this in a way to irritate and confuse the Republican campaign management and Mr. Landon himself.

Intervening at the request of both sides, Mayor La Guardia, by telephone from Cleveland, where he is attending the convention of the American Legion, brought about a quick termination of the strike of garage washers and polishers, which spread throughout Manhattan yesterday.

Although less than the usual seasonal increase in domestic trade occurred in August, the general outlook for Fall appears to be favorable, according to the regular monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board. The board reported yesterday that its survey shows, on a seasonally adjusted basis, rural retail sales recorded the smallest decline, 2.2 per cent.

BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- The battle of Cambrai in 1917, in which British tanks, making their World War debut, surprised the Germans and inflicted a severe defeat on them, was re-enacted in the vast German field manoeuvres today with similar results.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP). -- Joe Cascarella, the little relief pitcher cast-off, today humbled his former mates as Washington shut out the Red Sox, 4 to 0, in the first of a three-game series.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The excursion steamer Onteora, which for the last thirty-eight years has carried many thousands of excursionists up the Hudson River to Bear Mountain, was swept by a fire of undetermined cause early today and burned to the water line near her mooring at the Bear Mountain dock.

Buick will display its new lines to dealers during the first week in October and will at that time announce plans for substantial increases in its advertising budget for 1937, according to reports reaching here yesterday. The company, which centered more than 60 per cent of its 1936 appropriation in newspapers, using 1,700 papers during early Summer, will again place chief reliance on this medium, it was said.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Steps to safeguard property Values in residential communities and bring about sounder methods of realty taxation were taken at the closinng sessions of the annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Refusing to be outdone by their Walker Cup juniors who smothered the British amateurs at Pine Valley, the United States' seniors today wrested the international team honors from the British seniors, who had held the title for the past four years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Evidence that the Railway Audit and Inspection Company engaged in labor espionage and strike-breaking was brought out today by the La Follette subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Labor and Education, which is investigating alleged violations of civil liberties.

A strike was called by 1,500 employes of the Mariners Harbor (S.I.) plant of the United Drydocks Corporation yesterday afternoon in protest against the refusal of the company to arbitrate complaints of the employes.

More than a dozen Negro clergymen, with Bishop David Henry Sims of Philadelphia presiding, met yesterday at headquarters of the Republican State Committee in the Liggett Building to prepare for a pulpit crusade and large mass meeting in this city toward the end of the campaign, to protest the attempts of the Democratic National Committee to divide the Negro vote at the coming election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Exercising its authority under the Federal Power Act in such a case for the first time, the Federal Power Commission announced today that it had denied the joint application of the Metropolitan Edison Company and the Northern Pennsylvania Power Company, operating utility properties, to merge their facilities by a sale of properties.

The victory of Benjamin Lissberger's Juliet W., which begins to look more and more like the best juvenile filly in training, was scored yesterday afternoon at Belmont, but the preparation for it was brought off between the hours of ten and noon.

The Securities and Exchange Commission resumed yesterday at its regional office at 120 Broadway hearings in the case of Charles C. Wright and others charged with having manipulated the common stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- The weather, the Dodgers and the fans were kinder to the Bees today. Heartened by warmth and sunshine and the loud approval of some 2,000 spectators, the McKechnie boys buzzed swiftly through two games to win, 4 -- 3 and 3 -- 2.

DES MOINES, Sept. 22. -- A crowd which some persons estimated at nearly 100,000, and equal in numbers to that which filled the streets when Governor Landon and President Roosevelt were here for the recent drought conference, greeted the Republican Presidential candidate on his arrival late this afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22. -- The problems raised by fundamental changes that have taken place in the character of banking in this country engaged the attention of the nation's bankers on the second day of the annual convention of the America Bankers Association, being held here.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Army is on the march and is bringing up the heaviest artillery to rumble along the plains since Gar Davidson was put in command.

Former Queen Victoria of Spain, who arrived here last week to be at the bedside of her son, the Count of Covadonga, in the Columbia University-Presbyterian Hospital Medical Center, went shopping again yesterday. Saleswomen agreed that Her Majesty was a model shopper.

Dr. William E. Rappard, president of the University of Geneva, League of Nations delegate, economist and author, stepped out of his role of international scholar, in which capacity he was honored at the Harvard tercentenary, to speak informally before a dinner of his Swiss compatriots, given in his honor at the Hotel Vanderbilt last night.

Sweeney -- his first name is John, but the police know him so well they just call him by his last name -- was taken home to Philadelphia yesterday after another brief stay on Broadway, a street he has visited three times in the last two years after running away from home.

GENEVA, Sept. 22. -- The signs tonight point strongly to the Ethiopian delegation's retaining its seat through this League of Nations Assembly meeting pending a decision by the World Court on its credentials and to the continued absence of the Italian delegation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 22. -- An hour's scrimmage on university field late this afternoon, in which the third varsity defeated the Scrubs, 13 -- 6, concluded the longest day's workout given the Princeton football squad this Fall.

Governor LANDON and the Roosevelt Administration are competing with each other in bids for the farmer vote. This is not an unkind or untruthful inference to draw from their rival plans Both of them set out to insure the farmer against various possibilities of loss.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Army is on the march and is bringing up the heaviest artillery to rumble along the plains since Gar Davidson was put in command.

Former Queen Victoria of Spain, who arrived here last week to be at the bedside of her son, the Count of Covadonga, in the Columbia University-Presbyterian Hospital Medical Center, went shopping again yesterday. Saleswomen agreed that Her Majesty was a model shopper.

Governor LANDON and the Roosevelt Administration are competing with each other in bids for the farmer vote. This is not an unkind or untruthful inference to draw from their rival plans Both of them set out to insure the farmer against various possibilities of loss.
THE tall Long Islander cried, "Whoa, Bellerophon!" and reined up his quivering gas chariot at the curb. Leaning out across the steering-wheel, he said in accents disconsolate:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Incorporated Investors of Boston, one of the country's largest investment trusts, disclosed today the facts of its organization and subsequent operations to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- The most-favored-nation principle was championed by the Economic Committee of the League of Nations today in terms almost passionate for economists as one of the keystones in recovery. This view is printed in a report to the League Council entitled "The Most-Favored-Nation Clause."
WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 23. -- Springfield and Windsor entries turned in straight-heat victories on the Eastern States Exposition harness racing program today.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 23. -- William Roe, 26-year-old employe of a Wall Street banking firm, won the second annual Metropolitan Golf Association handicap championship today at the Crestmont Golf Club, defeating Myron Friedman of Branch Brook, 1 up, in the eighteen-hole final.
In a statement given out here yesterday Representative Hamilton Fish denied he had helped prepare the Hearst attack on President Roosevelt. The statement was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Charges that "slipshod methods under the present emergency work program" had resulted in washouts of storage and check dams in many watershed areas, leaving conditions worse than before their erection, were made today by irrigation and hydraulic engineers, in addresses before the Up-Stream Engineering Conference.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- Premier Leon Blum conferred today with Vincent Auriol, his Minister of Finance, and two other high officials of that ministry about the French Treasury situation, the 1937 budget and "divers financial questions." The conference coincided with a suddenly rising anxiety here over the future of the franc, induced, curiously enough, by reports from abroad.

A huge dahlia named for Jimmy Foxx, the baseball player, won three awards yesterday afternoon in the twenty-second annual flower show of the American Dahlia Society in Horticultural Hall of Rockefeller Center.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Warning of a tendency to "parasitism" in this country, the Agricultural Adjustment Act was cited as a typical example by President George Barton Cutten in a convocation address at Colgate University today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23. -- At closed ceremonies here tonight forty Masons were elevated to the honorary thirty-third degree, the highest attainable in the fraternal order.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed agent to accept shares of Ford Motor Company of Belgium and repay one-third of their par value, beginning on Monday.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday appointed Bradford Bixby Smith, assistant vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, as economist of the Exchange, a position vacant since the death in 1934 of J. Edward Meeker. Mr. Smith, who since 1928 has been statistical assistant to Leonard P. Ayres, the Cleveland bank's economist, will begin his service with the Exchange early next month.

GALES FERRY, Sept. 23. -- During an hour and a half scrimmage against the second varsity eleven today, the Yale first team drove over three touchdowns and Dave Colwell place kicked 2 points in three tries, giving the first squad a 20-0 "victory."

An audition board authorized to re-examine the qualifications of dancers employed by the WPA Federal Dance Theatre postponed the beginning of its work last night on receiving a protest presented by the first few dancers summoned before it.

Movements of share prices yesterday were inconclusive. Advancing tendencies at the outset were not pursued far and the mixed character of the trading through to the final hour reflected the general uncertainty, particularly on the score of the French financial situation.

John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, before leaving last night for Charleston, W.Va., where he is to deliver a campaign address this evening, challenged President Roosevelt to have the name of David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, removed from the list of Democratic Presidential electors from this State.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23. -- The second day of the twenty-fifth annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society, with the garden clubs of Greenwich and Rye cooperating, attracted 2,000 persons today.

The following earnings of subsidiaries of the American Power and Light Company for August and the year ended Aug. 31, in which no provision was made for the tax on undistributed profits, were reported yesterday:

The Norwegian freighter Pluto, which was rammed by the freighter New York of the Central Vermont Transportation Company in the East River late Tuesday night in a heavy fog, sank yesterday morning after her master and the seventeen members of her crew had been taken off.

The Celotex Corporation announced yesterday a plan of exchange for its outstanding $821,500 of 6 1/2 per cent first-mortgage bonds and $1,707,000 of 6 per cent cumulative income bonds. The project provides for a new issue of $4,000,000 of fifteen-year debentures, convertible into common stock until maturity at two shares of common stock for each $100 of debentures.
STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 23. -- Robert Bosch, inventor of the Bosch magneto, was feted today in ceremonies in the Municipal Auditorium here on the occasion of his seventy-fifth birthday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Fred Perry of England moved another step toward his fourth Pacific Southwest tennis championship today by defeating formidable John McDiarmid, Chicago, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, in the quarter-finals.

Restrictions placed upon American business under the NRA were mild in comparison with the limitations on distributive freedom as a result of the Robinson-Patman law, Frank L. Weil of Weil, Gotschal Manges, told members of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at their first Fall dinner meeting at the Advertising Club last night.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 23. -- The Brandywine Hounds' fine bitch hound Dimple was named champion today as American foxhounds were judged in the opening day's competition of the Bryn Mawr Hound Show.
Three local theological schools reopened yesterday, each with an enrollment in the first-year class larger than that of a year ago.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Candidates for Saturday s $10,000-added Potomac Handicap competed in the Fort McHenry Purse, today's feature, and the victory went to E.R. Bradley's 3-year-old ace, Bow and Arrow.

Short casts: The question in the minds of deep-sea fishing devotees these days is: Did the storm chase the fish from the inshore and offshore grounds? .... It is an accepted tradition that the first severe blow after Labor Day marks the turning point of the season, and no one doubts that the tempest of last week-end was severe enough....
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Paul J. Woodard of Sandy Creek resigned today as chairman of a Four-County Milk Holiday committee.

DANZIG, Sept. 23. -- The Free City's Supreme Court gave its blessing to the Nazi Senate's anti-constitutional decree of July 17 today when it refused to consider the Socialist trade unions' complaint against dissolution by the police. The court held that according to the decree all police ordinances of a political nature were exempt from judicial review.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 23. -- James J. Wadsworth, chairman of the Assembly Committee on Public Relief and Welfare and author of a measure liberalizing the Old-Age Pension Law, denounced the Lehman Social Security Bill at a meeting held today under the auspices of the Nassau County Federation of Republican Women at the estate of Mrs. Henry P. Davison.

Supreme Court Justice Dodd ruled in Brooklyn yesterday that the law creating the New York City Charter Revision Commission is unconstitutional and that therefore the proposed city charter cannot be put before the voters on election day. His ruling was based on the principle that the Legislature cannot delegate its law-making power either to a commission or to the people.

Acting Governor Frank Durand of New Jersey contended yesterday that politics was involved in the charges by the WPA that local relief in nine of twelve Jersey municipalities recently investigated was drastically less than under the previous Federal and State administration.

The President's announcement that today at Hyde Park he will hold an admittedly "political" conference, preliminary to making some confessedly political speeches, serves to remind that thus far the open campaigning has all been on the Republican side. Democratic spokesmen and the few important newspapers supporting the President have challenged the utterances of the Republican candidates.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 23. -- Seasoned criminologists tonight constructed this composite picture of the typical American criminal of today:

A complaining letter from Massachusetts accuses THE TIMES of being unfair in its editorial treatment of Governor CURLEY. Our correspondent is kind enough to say that this newspaper is noted for its impartial and dignified comments upon public men.

TOKYO, Sept. 23. -- To raise 200,000,000 yen additional each year in taxation and at the same time fulfill the government's promise to spread the burdens more fairly between industry and agriculture, Finance Minister Eiichi Babe has introduced a new taxation scheme, which he describes as an epochal reform.

In a recent letter to THE TIMES K. Grunewald quoted figures to prove that the boycott against Germany is injurious only to United States trade. He points out that exports to Germany have fallen from 133,000,000 in 1932, the last pre-Hitler year, to about 95,000,000 in 1936, while imports from Germany have maintained a steady average throughout the same period.

Directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company authorized yesterday the filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a registration statement covering the issuance of $175,000,000 of twenty-five-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures due in 1961.

DES MOINES, Sept. 23. -- Pleased by reports of a favorable reception of his farm speech, Governor Landon conferred today with party leaders, talked with members of several delegations and spoke at a luncheon attended by more than 200 Iowa newspaper editors and farmers.

In an effort to prevent waste and increase the effectiveness of the advertising expenditures of banks and other financial institutions, the New York Financial Advertisers Association, at its first luncheon meeting of the Fall season yesterday at the Lawyers Club, unanimously adopted a resolution, recommending that members abstain from using certain classes of media and types of advertisements.

MADRID, Sept. 15 (By Courier to Paris, Uncensored). -- There are now in this capital 130 foreign aviators -- French, anti-Nazi Germans, anti-Fascist Italians and British Communists -- all commanded by a Frenchman, whose chief officer is also French.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 23. -- Frank Allan of the Fox Hill Country Club of Pittston, Pa., was the medalist in the Shawnee invitation amateur golf tournament at Buckwood Inn today, covering the route in 35, 35 -- 70, two under par. There were more than thirty entries in the tournament and some fine scores were carded.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens County announced yesterday that he was investigating the case of eight primary election inspectors who left official returns in a Queens Democratic district club instead of taking them, as the law requires, to the borough office of the Board of Elections.

Justice DODD'S decision in the charter case comes as a surprise. Critics of the work of the commission had urged that the referendum be postponed until next year, when the air will be clear of national and State issues. When they failed in their effort to obtain that postponement, it was generally believed that the issue would go to the people in November; whatever the popular verdict might be, it was to be rendered now.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Suits to force three of Chicago's huge packing companies to return $113,640,652 allegedly paid to them by their customers in the form of processing taxes were filed in the Federal District Court here today.

President Roosevelt, closing the New York Herald Tribune's sixth annual Forum on Current Problems at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, appealed to the people of the nation to abjure prejudice and rancor and apply "calm deliberation and clear thinking" to the nation's problems.

A resolution requesting that the Federal Trade Commission make an investigation of "unofficial groups" which have condemned cosmetic products will be presented today at the luncheon meeting of the second annual Perfumery and Cosmetic Buyers Conference now being held in the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Professional strike-breakers told a Senate committee today that, hired as company "guards," they had deliberately stirred up violence and damaged property to discredit striking unions.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced yesterday that he had asked Secretary of Commerce Roper to postpone the enforcement of the provision in the Copeland Merchant Marine Act requiring that seamen carry continuous discharge books showing the record of their employment.

The October issue of Scribner's Magazine, the first edited by Harlan Logan, has a new format, designed by Thomas Cleland, who also made the illustration for the cover. The format is larger than that formerly used and the paper glossy rather than rough. The type has been changed and there will be more emphasis on illustration. The present issue contains some illustrations in color.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Dr. Walter F. Barry of the Essex County Country Club took the lead today in the fifteenth annual New Jersey State Seniors golf championship when he added a 75 to his 84 of yesterday for a total of 159, one stroke better than last year's winning score.

Both Governor LANDON, in his Des Moines speech, and President ROOSEVELT, in his recent letters to two Congressional leaders, advocate steps to reduce tenant farming. The President speaks of "the steady increase in farm tenancy from 1880 to 1935." This development was held in cheek before 1880 by an abundance of good public land for homesteading.

BUFFALO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Buffalo won the Governors' Cup and the right to represent the International League in the little world series by downing Baltimore, 3 to 1, in the final play-off tonight. Thus the Bisons became the first club in the four-year history of the Shaughnessy play-offs to win both the regular season pennant and the play-offs.

There was no occasion for surprise at the vigorous reassertion by Sir SAMUEL HOARE, First Lord of the Admiralty, last Tuesday of Britain's determination to maintain unimpaired its shortest sea-lane communication to the East. His words are a distinct warning to MUSSOLINI that there is a limit to the price Great Britain is willing to pay for Italian friendship.

In August factory employment gained 2.2 per cent, bringing the index of the Department of Labor to 88.7, the highest since September, 1930. Factory payrolls increased during the month 4.1 per cent to 81, the highest since October, 1930. Thus employment continues to improve, though the rate of improvement is still disappointing.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Railroad executives from all parts of the country will be here tomorrow for a general meeting of the Association of American Railroads in the Blackstone Hotel. J.J. Pelley, president of the association, will preside.
ROME, Sept. 23. -- It is now considered quite certain that Italy will not participate in the present League of Nations Assembly.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Julian Tafel Jr., six days old, died tonight at the Danish-American Hospital, despite efforts made to save the child's life through an operation to correct an intestinal abnormality.

Starting this Saturday, the World Cinema will present special matinee film shows for children on Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. The programs, lasting an hour and a half, will be composed of educational films, comedies, Mickey Mouse cartoons and Silly Symphonies.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 23. -- The New York Football Yankees defeated the Danbury Trojans by a single point, 7 to 6, in an exhibition game played in Lee Stadium tonight. All the scoring came in the second half.

Initial public financing for Roxborough Knitting Mills, Inc., Philadelphia, will take place today with the offering by means of a prospectus of 75,484 shares of participating preferred stock at $4 a share by Reichart, DeWitt Co., Inc.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed a decline of 4 per cent for the week ended Sept. 19, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The decrease follows one of 21 per cent for the preceding week.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23. -- The Soviet Union unsheathed a new weapon today in the fight, so far largely fruitless, to improve the quality of consumer goods, which under socialized production is wretchedly low while prices are appallingly high, measured either in gold value or in relation to wages.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Testifying before the Securities and Exchange Commission today, Paul C. Cabot, president of the State Street Investment Corporation of Boston, outlined some recommendations that in his opinion the commission should make to the next Congress and also some things that he thought the commission should not recommend.

Although the main body of second-grade corporate bonds met some resistance yesterday after advancing to new high levels and eased slightly from the peaks, the group nevertheless ended the day generally higher and lifted the combined average for forty corporate issues 0.08 point to a new high mark.

Acting on a recommendation of its law committee, the Board of Education yesterday accepted a decision of Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, overruling the dismissal of William R. Hayward as principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School and gave Mr. Hayward thirty days in which to retire.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23. -- Tom K. Smith, president of the Boatmen's National Bank of St. Louis and former adviser to Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, was elected today president of the American Bankers Association at the second general session of the association's annual convention here.

The thirty-six-hole metropolitan sectional qualifying test for the National Professional Golfers Association championship is scheduled to be staged tomorrow over the links of the Lakeville Golf Club in Great Neck, L.I. Fifty-one players representing Long Island and Westchester will tee off, according to the official list of pairings released yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- A "sugar shock" treatment for schizophrenia, one of the most common forms of insanity, was described today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

Brooklyn's experiment with "midget" backs in professional football provided fireworks at Ebbets Field last night in the 1936 home debut of the Dodgers, but the Pittsburgh eleven played the sounder game over the full route to take temporary command in the National League's Eastern division by gaining its second straight triumph of the young campaign.
United States Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas charged Governor Landon yesterday with inconsistency in pledging cash benefits to farmer's and at the same time promising a balanced budget.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 24. -- Yesterday's killing of a Japanese sailor in Shanghai has precipitated a crisis, and the navy is preparing emergency measures to insure the security of Japanese residents in China.
The text of Governor Landon's message read at The Herald Tribune Forum at the Waldorf-Astoria last night follows:

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Eugene V. Homans of the Knickerbocker Country Club today succeeded Mr. and Mrs. H.J. Paine of Hackensack as the leading golfing couple of the metropolitan area.

The committee for $45,000,000 first and refunding 5 per cent bonds, due in 1974, of the Florida East Coast Railway, headed by Arthur M. Anderson of J.P. Morgan Co., has incurred $61,495 expenses in the five years of its existence, according to an announcement made to bondholders yesterday.

After a battle of affidavits by opposing lawyers had left unsettled the question whether John Barrymore was a millionaire or a bankrupt, Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe decided yesterday that the actor must post $250 security to guarantee payment of court costs in the event he loses a suit against his former attorneys, Maurice Hotchner and John F. Finn Jr.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The progress made in economic recovery was emphasized today by the quarterly report of the Reconstruction Finance. Corporation for April, May and June, which showed that in that period loans and advances disbursed by the government corporation, exclusive of advances made to other government agencies and for direct relief, aggregated only $77,493,369, while repayments were $305,740,323.

Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College announced yesterday that he had declined to change the decision he made last June refusing Robert H. Burke of Youngstown, Ohio, president-elect of the junior class, permission to register this Fall. Burke was a leader of the anti-Nazi demonstration last May in front of the home of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia.

Rain the night before, coupled with a stubborn fog that lasted all through the morning, made it impossible for the polo teams of the United States and Argentina to go through with the second match of the Cup of the Americas series at Meadow Brook yesterday.

Miss Mary de Peyster Carey, descendant of Jan de Peyster, who came to this city from Holland in the early seventeenth century, named seven public institutions as legatees in her will which was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court yesterday. Miss Carey died at her home, 720 Park Avenue, on Aug. 28.

The ten-round feature heavyweight bout between LeRoy Haynes, Philadelphia Negro, and Bob Pastor, former New York University football star, scheduled for Madison Square Garden tonight, has been postponed indefinitely, it was announced yesterday by James J. Johnston, Garden promoter.

Six members of the British Walker Cup golf team sailed for home yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, terminating a month's visit to these shores. Except for pleasant memories and the fact that they had acquired many new friends, they returned to England without the prizes they had hopefully sought.

John Masefield terminated his brief visit to the United States yesterday, departing on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. He attended the Harvard tercentenary celebration, where he read a poem inspired by Harvard lore. He expressed the belief that such gatherings of the world's great minds might do much to guide a troubled world into paths of sane, clear thinking.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Browns ended Detroit's nine-game winning streak and spoiled the Tigers' final home appearance of the season by battering four pitchers for a 10-to-1 victory today. Ivy Paul Andrews held the Detroit batsmen to six hits.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Broad authority to further the development and maintenance of the American Merchant Marine is conferred upon the Maritime Commission by the Merchant Marine Act of 1936.

What was interpreted as a move for peace between the warring craft and industrial union factions of the American Federation of Labor was seen yesterday in the presence of leading representatives of both factions at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor to Sir Walter Citrine, general secretary of the British Trades Union Congress and president of the International Federation of Trade Unions.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- The Bryn Mawr Horse Show opened today at the Polo Field, Bryn Mawr, and will continue through Saturday. W. Plunket Stewart is president of the show and Mrs. Edgar Scott heads the horse show committee. Beneficiaries of the event are the Main Line Community Health and Civic Association and the Cancer Research Institute of the Lankenau Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Through the intervention of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Steve Vasilakos, White House peanut vendor who was driven off the streets by the Washington police, had his stand restored to him today.

The public belief that headaches and nausea experienced while riding on buses or while walking in streets with heavy motor traffic are due to carbon monoxide gas is just a fantasy, according to the results of hundreds of tests made by chemists in the air pollution survey which is being conducted throughout the city by the WPA for the Department of Health.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Prices in the Boerse at the opening today lacked trend, but they turned firmish later, although the changes were small. The boom in colonial issues and the strength in foreign bonds continued.

General Hugh Johnson, creator and head of the United States Army's supply and traffic organization in the World War, lashed back sharply yesterday at David Lloyd George's criticism of General John J. Pershing and the American contributions to the allied cause, according to The Associated Press.

More than 6,000 women volunteers in seventeen Eastern States have tied the brown-and-gold pennant of the Landon motor corps to the radiator caps of their cars in token of their readiness to transport Republican speakers, distribute literature and get out the vote on election day, Mrs. Roger W. Straus, regional chairman of the motor unit, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Broadway at Forty-second Street, New York City, is the country's greatest recruiting station for strike-breakers, witnesses told the La Follette subcommittee of the Senate Labor and Education Committee today at a continuation of the investigation of the activities of the Railway Audit and Inspection Company.

Mrs. Hollister Sturges of Stone Ridge, N.Y., was hostess at a luncheon yesterday in the Fountain Court of the Biltmore for her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Montague Sturges. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. William P. Eno, Lady Faith Montague of London, Mrs. Joseph B. Long, Henry T. Leggett and Hollister Sturges Jr.

After a stormy meeting, at which efforts were made by some to continue the strike, striking garage workers, assembled in the Central Opera House, Sixty-seventh Street and Third Avenue, last night, voted to return to work.

Holdings of government securities by reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System are expected to be slightly less in the forthcoming statement than they were following the government's June 15 financing, it was said yesterday in financial circles. This trend is particularly interesting in view of the increase, in the meantime, of approximately $500,000,000 in outstanding Federal securities.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- Carl Hubbell, looking, if anything, more lean and serious than ever, once again took high command of the stumbling, faltering Giants today and set them straight on their course to the goal which for the last few days had again become a trifle obscure.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 23. -- The convention of the International Association of Machinists unanimously endorsed today the candidacy of President Roosevelt for re-election and upheld by an almost unanimous vote the action of the American Federation of Labor's executive council in suspending the ten unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. 23 (Via Lisbon, Portugal). -- From dawn to dusk today General Francisco Franco's Rebel air fleet bombed and machine-gunned the roads and railroads between Madrid and Toledo to isolate the two cities completely.
Digests of the addresses of Mr. Hoover and others who spoke before The Herald Tribune forum follow:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23. -- The American Legion in convention here today, pledged itself anew to fight relentlessly against the spread of communism and to oppose every effort of aliens to gain advantages and disseminate subversive propaganda in the United States.

The flight of capital from. France was unchecked yesterday and engagements of French gold for movement here amounted to $12,455,000, 'a new high record for a single day i since the current movement began on Aug. 7. This raised the total engagements since that date from France to $134,000,000, and the total [from all sources, including Frmnce, [ to $175,000,000.

Opening the 183d academic year of Columbia University, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler declared in an address at the exercises yesterday afternoon that "the disorderly and lawless force of a group of disturbers of the peace" had driven 650 working people into idleness against their will in Seattle recently.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- The generally credited reports that if the Rebels win control in Spain they will cede the Balearic Islands to Italy and the Canary Islands to Germany in payment for those countries' support were supplemented here today by the assertion that Germany also is to get the Azores from Portugal as an additional reward.

AKRON, Sept. 23. -- Ten thousand employes of the B.F. Goodrich Rubber Company remained idle tonight after an all day meeting between representatives of the United Rubber Workers of America and company officials had resulted only in an agreement to reconvene tomorrow.

KEARNY, N.J., Sept. 23. -- The WPA spent more than $9,000 painting, reroofing and fireproofing the West Hudson Hospital on Bergen Avenue here from last May to August before discovering that the institution was privately owned and therefore ineligible for Federal grants.

For weeks the Hammer of Monopoly has been missing. The country swarms with squadrons of word-bombers. The nation is being saved and lost. From the A1 class to the newest and greenest of the speakers' bureau statesmen of all kinds have uttered solemn warnings, appeals and vaticinations.
The Persian Room of the Plaza was formally opened last night for the season, with many persons of prominence in attendance.
A self-portrait that Hans Holbein the younger painted in 1542, a year before he died of the plague in London, arrived in New York list Monday on the Queen Mary.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- What David Lloyd George really thought of General John J. Pershing and other United States war leaders is told in the fifth volume of the former Prime Minister's war memoirs, to be published here tomorrow. He charges that the equipment of the United States Army was a "lamentable story of indecision and bustling incompetency."
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23. -- Conditions in Buena Vista Township are not so bad as the WPA relief survey would indicate, according to James Rovegno, Township Clerk.

SEATTLE, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The National Labor Board threatened today to strike out all of the testimony of Ray Colvin, day managing editor, when he refused to answer in a Post-Intelligencer and American Newspaper Guild hearing whether he objected to newspaper employes bettering their economic well-being.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- A lucky bounce on Ossie Bluege's grounder with the bases loaded in the ninth inning brought the Senators a 3-to-2 triumph over the Red Sox today and sent them into third place in the American League. The victory was Washington's second straight over the Red Sox.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 23 (AP). -- If University of Illinois students may be regarded as representative of the youth of the land, the State Department of Health decided today, then "young people on the threshold of maturity are much better developed physically and better nourished than were those of corresponding ages twelve years ago."

By all ordinary military indications, the city of Madrid will soon fall into the hands of the rebellious troops. It is now virtually in a state of siege. The Government still talks of making a determined and heroic stand so long as there is one man left to shoulder a gun.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 23. -- Perfect weather greeted a good-sized opening-day crowd at the fortieth annual Bryn Mawr Horse Show today.
TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. 23. -- Insurgent commanders poised their forces tonight for the final onslaught on Madrid and Toledo, confident that the fall of both cities was imminent.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Indians divided a double-header with the White Sox today, winning by 17 to 2 in the opener and dropping the nightcap, which was called at the end of the sixth inning because of darkness, 8 to 3.

No whit dismayed by his late venture with "Arrest that Woman," A.H. Woods has hastened to buy another play. "Story to Be Whispered" is its title, and William Hurlbut is named as its author. A tale of Virginia City, Nev., in the Eighteen Seventies, it will have five settings and thirty-six characters, and Mr. Woods will take steps at once toward a production.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Burns cause one-third more deaths among children of pre-school age than automobile accidents, according to statistics made public by the United States Public Health Service today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Only half the sixteen southpaws had to play -- mostly in the rain -- in their scheduled thirty-six-hole matches for places in the quarter-finals of the national tournament of left-handed golfers today.
LONDON, Sept. 23. -- Tonight's court circular from Balmoral Castle, Scotland, where King Edward is staying, begins with the following announcement:

SYRACUSE, Sept. 23. -- Committees worked feverishly tonight to set the stage in order for the Syracuse Jubilee, celebrating the abandonment of West Washington Street as the New York Central's main line route and the opening of the elevated structure through the city.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. issued a statement yesterday defending the contributions made last month by himself, his wife and his son, John, to the Republican party in Maine.

The most disheartening thing in other countries is the way youth is corralled and regimented in ways "which make for discipline, but surely not successful living." Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University declared in his convocation address yesterday to incoming students of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance.

ST. JEAN DE LUZ, France, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Diplomats, churchmen and a representative of the International Red Cross tonight joined in frantic last-minute efforts to save 4,000 hostages from slaughter in the Spanish Government-held city of Bilbao.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 23. -- Woof, two-year-old daughter of Bull Dog recently claimed from Dixiana for $4,400, carried the silks of Mrs. Ernest A. Rotelli of Providence to an easy four-length victory in the first running of the New England Juvenile Handicap before 10,000 at Narragansett Park today.

TRENTON, Sept. 23. -- Defending his fiscal policies, Governor Hoffman said in a statement made public today that reduction of public debt offered the "real and biggest" opportunity for lowering the cost of government in New Jersey.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions arid, wholesale prices in New York City;
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- A thin, wavering line of all that is left of the Grand Army of the Republic marched gallantly today under a hot sun.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 23. -- Mr. Watts, 2-year-old bay colt owned by the Newbrook Stables of Short Hills, N.J., maintained his winning streak when he captured the pace at the Mineola Fair today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Walter A. Wolfe, 58-year-old home club ace, chalked up a 77 today to lead the field of sixty-six starters in the second annual Westchester seniors championship at the Westchester Hills Golf Club. With this splendid start, it will require sub-par golf by his rivals to overtake him tomorrow on the final eighteen holes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- President Roosevelt today designated October 12 as Columbus Day in a proclamation made public at the White House. The proclamation said:

HENDAYE, France, Sept. 23. -- Although the main Rebel forces south of Madrid are concentrating on a decisive attack on the capital, it is not believed by observers here that the insurgents will drive their attack to the point of invading the city.
The proposal for all-risk farm insurance is perhaps the most radical departure from sound government. The proposal is unsound from every governmental, political and insurance standpoint.

Attorneys for United Chromium, Inc., yesterday were studying a decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for this district holding invalid the patent under which the company has licensed more than 300 manufacturers using chromium plating in production processes.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 23. -- Coast Guards, village and State police began an intensive search of Great South Bay today for Kent Pearson, 17-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert P. Pearson of New York and Long Cove, who is feared to have drowned while sailing his catboat from this village to Long Cove last Saturday.

To date Mr. Landon's speeches have revealed high-sounding generalities with the exception of (1) his condemnation of the administration corporation tax and (2) his condemnation of the insurance of bank deposits. His views on these laws have been very specific. If he is elected these laws will be repealed and the nation goes backward instead of forward.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- What to do with a "bureaucracy" that has grown in four years from eighty-four bureaus and agencies to 138, with a personnel now of more than 200,000, was the problem presented to the Special Senate Committee on Governmental Reorganization and the President's Committee on Administrative Management when them met jointly today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23. -- There are indications of turmoil at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, despite the efforts of the studio heads to bring about a smooth adjustment of the condition created by the death of Irving Thalberg. While his films have been distributed among the remaining producers with an eye to maintaining peace, disintegration of his former unit has begun. Al-

Lou Schneider, Indianapolis, held a slim lead from the start to win the feature twenty-lap sweepstakes last night on the card of midget auto races at Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City before a crowd of 14,300 persons.

After an hour's questioning before the September additional grand jury, in which District Attorney William C. Dodge took part, Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, won from the jurors yesterday the right to return tomorrow with Mr. Dodge and his assistants excluded from the room.

MADRID, Sept. 23 (Passed by the Censor). -- On the road from Madrid to Toledo this morning this correspondent passed a stream of refugees -- women, children and old men -- afoot, astride donkeys and in donkey carts. They were on their way to this capital.
GENEVA, Sept. 23. -- The pro-Ethiopian mutiny of the small powers in the Assembly of the League of Nations triumphed today and the consequences promise to be far-reaching.
The Yankees easily thrust aside the Athletics yesterday to win their 100th game of the campaign, 12 to 5. Only about 1,500 fans saw them reach this milestone.

The strike of 1,500 employes of the Mariners Harbor (S.I.) plant of the United Drydocks Corporation, which had been in effect since last Wednesday, was called off yesterday afternoon when officials of the company agreed to the appointment of a non-partisan chairman of a committee to consider the complaints of the men.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Sept. 24. -- The greater portion of the Hongkew district of Shanghai was subjected to Japanese military occupation at 8:30 last evening, ten minutes after a group of gunmen wearing Chinese clothes had shot three uniformed sailors who were members of a Japanese landing force.
Albert Bocca, 12-year-old son of an unemployed truck driver, was improving yesterday in Murray Hill Hospital after having undergone an experimental treatment for haemophilia.

The Manhattan College football team yesterday met Columbia in an hour-and-fifteen-minute scrimmage at Baker Field. It was the final heavy workout for the Jaspers before their opening game on Saturday against St. Bonaventure at Randalls Island.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23. -- While the Red Army manoeuvres were being held over much of the Soviet Union, including the Moscow military district, the strengthened Red navy was also holding war games in the Baltic, where an attack on the Soviet Union from the sea by any Western power would be most likely to fall.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 23. -- Governor James M. Curley and William Randolph Hearst were described as the greatest menaces to freedom in the academic world by President James L. McConaughy in the matriculation address at the opening of Wesleyan University today.

BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- The Dodgers finally succeeded in making Professor Casey Stengel sick. He was so ill last night and this morning that he didn't come out to the field until a few minutes before game time.

The fashion-conscious made a movie tour to the salons of famous French couturiers yesterday when they saw a colored motion picture presented at Macy's. The showrooms of Vionnet, Rouff and Schiaparelli and others in Paris were pictured with the models selected by the store as representing the fashion highlights of the season.
The text of Justice Dodd's decision yesterday holding the New York City Charter Revision Commission unconstitutional follows:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 23. -- A.R. Aitken, heavy-set British golfer from Cooden Beach, today annexed the Founders' Cup as the international seniors' competition came to a close at the National Golf Links of America.

YES and no. That seemed to be the mixed verdict as the fight fans wandered away in the darkness after the Louis-Ettore bout in Quakertown. One handicap that Louis labors under is that too much is expected of him.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23. -- One of the most brilliant football classes in Princeton's history departed Nassau's halls of learning last June, leaving behind imperishable cleat prints on the sands of time.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The Pirates came back after losing a six-run lead today to score a run in the tenth inning and defeat the Cubs, 7 to 6, squaring the series at 1 -- all.

Preliminary plans for a crosstown vehicular underpass, to be constructed in bed rock far below Thirty-seventh Street at an estimated cost of $28,000,000, were disclosed yesterday by Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan.

A fresh wave of buying has increased steel production to 73 1/2 per cent of capacity, the highest rate thus far this year, according to the weekly summary of The Iron Age, issued yesterday. "Further gains in output," the magazine says, "are likely to be limited by physical factors at the mills.

PARIS, Sept. 23. -- Rumors that the two-week delay in opening the Paris theatre season was caused by the managers' refusal to accept governmental regulations of box-office prices were denied today by Max Maurey, head of the organizatoin of theatre directors.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Wheat futures sold at new high levels for the season early today on the Board of Trade and at Winnipeg and Liverpool, but heavy profit-taking sales carried the North American markets off sharply from the top figures.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP). -- Wild Turkey, owned by H.H. Cross of Chicago, won the feature mile handicap race at Lincoln Fields to day, following a sensational stretch run.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Prices of hogs today were unchanged from yesterday's 9 to 15 cents a hundred-weight lower as demand was relatively slow. Weakness in fresh pork continues to be a factor, with choice loins quoted at a top of 22 cents a pound wholesale locally, or a half cent lower than yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 23. -- In the Albany railroad yards of the New York Central system the six-car special train that is President Roosevelt's traveling "hotel" is being reconditioned while the President is at his family home in Hyde Park.

PARIS, Sept. 23 (AP). -- The increasing flow of gold from the Bank of France and the rise of the British pound against the French franc led to reports tonight in political circles that Premier Leon Blum was considering a speedy "alignmentt" of French money.

Speaking before more than 1,000 officers and members of needle trades organizations last night, Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, attacked the campaign tactics of William Randolph Hearst, and denounced the publisher for characterizing supporters of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman as Communists.

First, if it be true as Mr. Wierum says in his letter to THE TIMES that in forty years he has seen no great difference between Democratic and Republican placeholders in the ranks, why should he assume that the present Democratic administration "could do a better Job" than a Republican one?
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message last night to The Herald Tribune Forum at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

Acting Captain John J. McGowan, who has been in charge of the Brooklyn homicide squad for the past five years, was demoted to the grade of lieutenant yesterday and transferred to uniformed duty in the Tenth Inspection Division embracing the Bath Beach, Coney Island and Sheepshead Bay sections of Brooklyn.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Vic Ghezzi, Deal professional, and Jerry Krimke teamed today to win the first pro-club member tournament held by the New Jersey State P.G.A., scoring a sub par 70 over the Mountain Ridge Country Club course.

Commodity futures were generally lower yesterday in more active trading. Coffee futures again declined, the old Rio contract selling at the lowest level in thirty-three years. In the cash markets, corn, rye, cotton and lard were higher, while wheat, oats, cocoa, sugar, butter, eggs and tin were lower.

In a spectacular finish that brought her from last place to an easy victory in the final quarter of a mile, Louis Strube's 4-year-old filly Rust thrilled a midweek crowd at Belmont Park yesterday by capturing the Ladies' Handicap at a mile and defeating some of the best fillies in the East.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- Another fat check was added to Joe Louis's rapidly swelling bank account today when Mike Jacobs handed over a draft of $60,150 to the Brown Bomber's managers. This represented the Detroit Negro's share for his winning fight against Al Ettore last night.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- President Roosevelt appointed late today three members of the Maritime Commission authorized by Congress, ordering them to set up immediately a skeleton organization to begin exercising the wide authority vested in the commission members.

Net earnings of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 are estimated at $577,174, equal to about $1.73 a share on the outstanding common stock. In the comparable period of 1535 earnings were $275,068, or 72 cents a share.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 23. -- The question whether cancer is hereditary aroused much discussion today at the International Cancer Congress, meeting here, but the argument demonstrated only that experts are still divided on the subject.

DORCHESTER, N.B., Sept. 23 (AP). -- Two brothers, Arthur Bannister, 19, and Daniel, 20, were hanged together early today for killing a woodsman-squatter during the kidnapping of his infant daughter for their mother to use in the "baby doll" extortion plot.

The appointment of a working majority of the new Maritime Commission, as announced Wednesday night by President Roosevelt, held the attention of leaders of the shipping industry yesterday. The general reaction was one of surprise, but none of the ship lines or associations of shipping men would discuss the matter formally.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Smaller receipts of hogs checked the decline in the market here today and sales Were generally steady with Wednesday, except on sows. Some sales of the latter showed a decline of 10 cents a hundredweight. No fancy 240 or 250 pound offerings were available and the top dropped 5 cents to $10.25, a new low level since June.

ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 24. -- One hundred and forty members of New York's financial center took time off from their daily problems today to compete in the Wall Street Golf Association's twentieth semi-annual eighteen-hole golf tournament over the tricky Shelter Rock Country Club links.

Three members of the American Student Union, including Robert Burke, who was expelled in June for leading the anti-Nazi demonstration last May, addressed a gathering of 500 students of the college and the various schools of Columbia University in front of Hamilton Hall yesterday noon, appealing to them to support the youth in his fight for reinstatement.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator, yesterday told the Engineers Club at a luncheon at its headquarters, 32 West Fortieth Street, that he has found no glaring examples of boondoggling since taking charge of the WPA here last July.
Your humorous and kindly criticism under the editorial caption "Tush Tush," of Senator Norris's "sic semper tyrannis" radio address inspires the following reminiscence:

ALBANY, Sept. 24 (AP). -- A gain of 66.9 per cent last month in the number of persons placed by the State Employment Service in private industry as compared to August, 1929, was reported to day by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner.
CLARKSDALE, Miss., Sept. 24 (AP). -- A shortage of cotton pickers harassed the Mississippi Delta today and threatened to curtail the harvesting of a bumper crop through waste.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Sept. 24. -- Institutional advertising campaigns by big business, banks, the Stock Exchanges and insurance companies to offset the misconceptions the American public holds about these institutions were urged today by William A. Thomson, director of the bureau of advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

ROME, Sept. 24. -- Despite alarmist reports that have spread abroad, stating Italy will immediately resign from the League of Nations as a consequence of yesterday's decision to admit the Ethiopian delegation to the Assembly, a distinct effort was visible today on the part of the Italian Government not to dramatize the situation.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- The parity of the franc hangs in the balance tonight, and in all quarters -- business, financial and political -- there is talk of little else than the possibility of devaluation or a gold embargo in the very near future.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The great schism which developed in Methodism in 1824 and 1844 came a step nearer to being ended today when the New Jersey Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, at its 100th annual session, voted unanimously in favor of a merging of the North and South churches and the Methodist Protestant Church.

SEATTLE, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Robert Watts, associate counsel for the National Labor Board, stressed City Editor Oliver Morris's opposition to newsroom unions today in cross-examining him on American Newspaper Guild activities which resulted in a strike suspending publication of The Post-Intelligencer here on Aug. 13.

Austin, Nichols Co., Inc., reported a net profit of $37,955 in the four months ended on Aug. 31 after depreciation, interest and Federal income taxes, but before surtax on undistributed profits. This equaled $1.32 a share on 28,780 no-par shares of $5 cumulative prior A stock which will be outstanding after the exchange of 259 shares of old preferred stock not yet presented.

Some days ago Mayor La Guardia made the remark that in case of a milk strike he was prepared to permit the purchase of milk outside the New York milk shed. To producers of milk for New York City this suggestion seems strange and absurd.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The undefeated 1935 Princeton football season produced the largest receipts for the university's athletic association of any season since 1930, according to its financial statement for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1936, which was released today by Asa S. Bushnell graduate manager of athletics.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 24. -- The American Legion, closing its convention here today, adopted a resolution interpreted as including support of a proposal for pensions for all widows and orphans of World War veterans and elected Harry W. Colmery, a Topeka lawyer, its national commander to succeed Ray Murphy.

Re-election of President Roosevelt as an aid to maintaining a peace policy was urged yesterday by a group of educators, peace advocates and welfare leaders, who based their arguments on successes of the foreign policy of the present administration.
