WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- F. B. Geddes of Scarsdale, last in the field to post his card, carried off the honors in the second annual Westchester senior championship at the Westchester Hills Golf Club today.
Purchase of an investment property in the vicinity of Pennsylvania Station featured realty sales in Manhattan yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- Dr. Franz Meyer, second secretary general of the Reich Central Commission for Jewry, and Rabbi Max Nussbaum and Dr. Benno Cohn, both directors of the League for Jewish Culture, were taken into custody today by the secret police.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 24. -- The International Cancer Congress devoted the greater part of today's session to a general discussion of the relative merits of high-voltage X-rays and radium in the treatment of cancer. On the whole, high-voltage X-rays seemed to be most favored.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Acceptance of applications for adjustment of ocean mail contracts and negotiations with Pacific Coast shipping interests toward settlement of their differences with seamen's unions are important problems confronting Maritime Commission members appointed yesterday by President Roosevelt.

A benefit performance of Cole Porter's new musical comedy, "Red, Hot and Blue," will be given on the night of Oct. 27 at the Alvin Theatre to aid the work of the West Side Day Nursery. It will be one of the first large theatrical benefits of the season to enlist the interest and support of members of society.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French frano on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year.
TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. 24. -- The final insurgent attack on Toledo, Leftist stronghold, was scheduled tonight to begin at dawn tomorrow.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- What is believed to be one of the most important single collections of Christian relics in existence has been discovered in the archives of the Franciscan Order monastery adjoining St. Bonaventure's Roman Catholic Church, on Ramsey Street, here.

ERIE, Pa., Sept. 24 (AP). -- A Federal grand jury climaxed a long investigation of an alleged $1,000,000 shortage in the Commercial National Bank of Bradford today by indicting eleven persons, including ten officers and employes of the institution.

OTTAWA, Sept. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government increased $301,391 and deposits by chartered banks rose $2,047,382 in the week ended yesterday, said the bank's weekly statement, issued today. The statement follows:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- Catalase, an enzyme or chemical susbtance of vital importance in the processes of digestion and fermentation, has been actually observed at work for the first time, providing experimental proof for a theory held for more than a half century.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The correspondence between Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg and Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. over the United States gold-purchase policy follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- Friends of Governor Curley were accused tonight by Louis J. Ferreira Jr. of Fall River of promising him a job if he would keep quiet about an accident involving the Governor's car in Dighton early this morning and of frightening him with the loss of his license for ten years if he talked.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Replying to John D. Rockefeller's explanation of his contributions to the Republican campaign war chest in Maine, United States Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska demanded yesterday a "purging" of political parties of "such evil influences."

BERLIN, Sept. 24 -- In its efforts to make Germany colony-minded and win more members for itself, the Reich Colonial League, headed by General Franz Ritter von Epp, is distributing leaflets denouncing the mandate system over the former German colonies as "theft and robbery" and demanding their immediate return.

HYDE PARK, Sept. 24. -- President Roosevelt will concentrate his campaign for re-election almost exclusively in the industrial centers east of the Mississippi River, it was indicated today as he conferred with twenty-eight political advisers and associates for two hours in the library of Hyde Park House.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- Vincent Auriol, French Minister of Finance, alone among the members of the Cabinet of Premier Leon Blum held out today against devaluation of the franc, according to reliable reports reaching London. He was still in opposition tonight, although all the rest of his colleagues were ready at a meeting this morning to take the plunge during the coming weekend.

The Arthur R. Rombouts Realty Corporation of 300 Madison Avenue, Manhattan, has bought from the title and mortgage rehabilitation and liquidation bureau of the State Insurance Department a four-story walk-up house at 27-21 Twenty-third Street, Astoria, assessed at $58,500.

There is an appalling prevalence of crime among our young people, Cardinal Hayes declared in a pastoral letter issued yesterday. He laid the blame for this situation on those who lack adequate religious education. The letter will be read Sunday in all the churches of the archdiocese.
DENVER, Sept. 24. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, wound up his Western campaign tour tonight by asserting that high living costs overshadowed the nation's recovery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has been asked by the Chase National Bank of New York and the City Bank Farmers Trust Company to make provisions for their reimbursement in connection with expenses incident to intervention as trustees in railroad reorganization proceedings.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- The French Government has come to the conclusion that it cannot any longer keep the franc at its present gold parity. If things work out according to what is understood in well-informed quarters here, this weekend should see the break-up of the European gold bloc with the devaluation of the franc to 100 to the pound sterling, compared with today's closing quotation of 76 7/8.
SHANGHAI, Friday, Sept. 25. -- Rear Admiral Eijiro Kondo, commander of the Japanese armed forces in Shanghai, said today:

Fixed, or unit, investment trusts in Great Britain are to be included in the scope of the British Companies Act as amended in 1929, according to pending legislation, Denys Lowson of Dawney Day Co., Ltd., London, said at a luncheon in the Broad Street Club yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett does not have anything to say to Avery Brundage, head of the American Olympic Committee, but declared today she would "like to bump into him."

A special meeting of stockholders of the Fifth Avenue Bus Securities Corporation, a subsidiary of the Omnibus Corporation, will be held at 11 A. Monday at 111 Broadway to vote on a plan of liquidation already approved by the directors.

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- The National Socialist party has released to the German press for tomorrow morning's newspapers a bitter attack on the Catholic Bishops in Germany and particularly on their pastoral letter defending the sectarian schools, which is expected to be read from Catholic pulpits this Sunday and the Sunday following.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 24. -- The text of Governor Landon's campaign address here tonight was as follows:

City Court Justice Peter M. Daly of Queens was nominated unanimously last night for a post on the Supreme Court bench by the Democratic delegates at the Second Judicial District convention in Brooklyn. He was one of five active aspirants for the post.

Depicting the high cost of present and future taxation under the New Deal through animated tableaux with living models, the First Voters League, a Landon organization with headquarters at 400 Madison Avenue, gave a preview yesterday of its "Barrel Show."

The American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry announced yesterday the award of medals to two American chemists, Dr. Walter S. Landis and Thomas Midgley Jr. Dr. Landis is vice president of the American Cyanamid Company, New York, and Mr. Midgley is vice president of the Ethyl Gasoline Corporation, New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 23, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,479,000,000, a decrease of $8,000,000, compared with the preceding week and an increase of $2,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

An exhibition of German art from 1500 to 1850 has been assembled and will be circulated by the Carl Schurz Memorial Foundation. It is to be shown at the Pennsylvania Museum of Art, in Philadelphia, on Oct. 5 and will remain current there until Nov. 1.

Secondary corporate loans continued to move forward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange under the impetus of encouraging trade reports, but the growing seriousness of the foreign situation was reflected in an easing of United States Government bonds as well as other strictly high grade investments.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24. -- A tentative agreement whereby this city's Bureau of Power and Light will purchase entire electrical properties of the Los Angeles Gas and Electric Corporation for $46,340,000 was announced today to the City Council. The city has an option, expiring on Sept. 30, 1939, to make the purchase.
The Lawyers Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the common stock voting trust certificates of the Starrett Corporation.

When Ernest Truex comes to town in G.B. Stern's "Middleman," it will be under the management of Robert F. Cutler, at whose Suffern County Theatre the play was tested earlier this month. That tryout was on behalf of Max Gordon, who, although his option would not have expired till Nov. 1, has released the play.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Concerted opposition to proposed increases in rates for cable and radio-telegraph messages was registered today at a meeting under the auspices of the Federal Communications commission by a group which asserted that it represented more than 80 per cent of this country's traffic in communications with foreign nations.

Business is 50 to 200 per cent better for savings and loan associations now than it was last year, the depression is over and the next ten years will see the greatest opportunities this field has ever known, Roy H. Bassett of Canton, N.Y., president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations, said last night.
PARIS, Sept, 24 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

INVERNESS, Scotland, Sept. 24. -- Those who assert that Gaelic is a dying language would have been astonished to see the Town Hall at Inverness packed to the doors today with musical enthusiasts and critics on the second day of the Gaelic Music Festival.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Pinero, which this season set a world record of 2:05 1/2 for 3-year-old trotters over a half-mile track, triumphed at the Mineola Fair Grounds today.

GRAND VIEW, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Zoning Commissioner Elmer S. Hader of this village, who heads a committee of local residents protesting construction of a bridge across the Hudson River between Nyack and Tarrytown, received a letter from Governor Lehman today assuring him no site for the bridge had been selected and that the State Bridge Authority would give consideration to the wishes of residents of Rockland and Westchester Counties.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24. -- Business in future months will find itself subject to more rather than less legislation affecting the rights of consumers, labor and competitors, in order to assure fair dealing to all, H.I. Kleinhaus, manager of the controllers congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said here today in an address opening the Pacific Coast regional convention of the congress.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The favorite, the most colorful player, the dark horse and the upset victor today marched into the semi-final round of the first national left-handers' golf tournament.

Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed steady and mixed in diminished trading yesterday. By all odds the principal topic in trading circles was the French financial situation, and, rightly or not, there was general expectancy that the French financial authorities might make an important move in the matter in the next few days.

NANKING, China, Friday, Sept. 25. -- Major Gen. Seiichi Kita, the Japanese military attache, and Rear Admiral Sato left by air for Shanghai yesterday. The Japanese Embassy said their sudden departure was connected with the "extremely grave" situation in Shanghai.

In a week marked by somewhat diverse price movements, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined to 127.6 on Tuesday from 128.4 (revised) the preceding Tuesday. Outstanding was a 55-cent drop in hogs to'$9.76.

The vanguard of party leaders will leave today for the Republican State convention to be opened in Albany Monday. Incidentally, the battle among contenders for the Republican nomination for Governor will shift to the convention city.

The Broadway Manufacturers Supply Company of 500 Broadway will remain in the old wholesale dry goods area as the result of a lease it signed yesterday for the entire five-story building at 488-492 Broadway, northeast corner of Broome Street.
Although bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were lower than the high total in the previous week, they were 5.3 per cent above the figure for the same period of 1935.

Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, arrived yesterday from Europe aboard the Cosulich liner Vulcania. Subjected to a barrage of questions on the dismissal of Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, he steadfastly defended the committee's action in dropping the back-stroke swimmer from the team for breach of training regulations.

Tammany Hall held its judicial convention last night, and chose the occasion to defend its method of dispensing judicial nominations, and to affirm its allegiance to the Democratic State and national tickets. The speeches were aimed at the criticism of the organization for having failed to nominate Jonah J. Goldstein for the Court of General Sessions, after he had been appointed to fill a vacancy, by Governor Lehman.

The Transit Commission's fourth public hearing on rapid transit unification was thrown into a turmoil yesterday when John J. Curtin, special counsel, produced an anonymous circular dealing with the 3 3/4 per cent collateral trust bonds recently floated for the B.M.T., declaring that it was sent to "insiders'' to advise them that substantial profits awaited holders of the bonds if the unification plan now before the commission went through by July 1, 1937.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 24. -- Mrs. Vanderbilt Davis, who will celebrate her birthday tomorrow, entertained with a picnic luncheon at Bailey's Beach this afternon. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, her parents, returned from New York last night and will give a dinner in her honor at Beaulieu, their residence, tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Assertions of an attempt "to create a dictatorship in Angelus Temple" were made tonight as a new row split into two camps the leadership of Aimee Semple McPherson's Temple of the Four Square Gospel.

OSHKOSH, Wis., Sept. 24. -- Holding that the railroads have ceased to be "even a quasi-monopoly because of competition of government-aided carriers by air, highway and water," Samuel O. Dunn, editor of Railway Age, said today in an address to the Wisconsin State Chamber of Commerce that one of the important developments in recent years had been to make problems confronting business similar to the problems of the railroads during the last twenty-five years.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 24. -- Continuing his drive for the farm vote, largely lost by the Republican party in 1932, Governor Landon in a speech here tonight condemned the reciprocal trade pacts made by the Roosevelt administration with foreign countries.

David Dubinsky made a vigorous reply yesterday to a statement by John D.M. Hamilton, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, which called upon President Roosevelt to have him removed from the list of Democratic Presidential electors on the ground that he had collected money for the aid of Communists fighting for the life of the radical government in Spain.

Charles C. Wright's explanation of his transactions in common stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., which the Securities and Exchange Commission charges were manipulative, was introduced yesterday as evidence by attorneys for the SEC at another of the series of hearings to determine whether Mr. Wright and eleven other defendants should be suspended or expelled from the New York Stock Exchange and other exchanges of which they are members.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- The westbound Empire State Express, rolling slowly into the old New York Central station in a downpour of rain at 2:08 o'clock this afternoon, ended the era of locomotives and railroad cars mingling with motor and trolley traffic in the business section of this city.

Frank J. Taylor, Controller, was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate to acquire a site for the Central Needle Trades High School in West Twenty-fourth Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Paced by Carl Mueller, who carded a 78, the artist contingent stalked off with eight of the twelve prizes at stake in the annual Fall tournament of the Artists and Writers Golf Association contested today at the St. Andrew's Golf Club.

The milk strike is off, at least for the present. It ought never to have been proposed. For better, for worse, the milk industry in this State is now regarded as a public utility, and a milk "holiday" is as clearly contrary to that public interest with which it is "affected" as an electric light "holiday" would be.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- Uncertainty about the franc tended to restrict business on the London Stock Exchange today, and prices finished irregular generally. British Government stocks were dull, but the new housing loan of the London County Council, amounting to 10,000,000, was oversubscribed ten times this morning, and active dealings in the issue are expected to begin at a premium tomorrow.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 24. -- In short speeches in nine Iowa and Minnesota towns, Governor Landon, while traveling today from Des Moines to Minneapolis, called attention to empty corn cribs and Condemned the Roosevelt "program of scarcity."

Marching Home, the filly that used to stop in the stretch, apparently has dropped that habit, for yesterday she once more came from behind to win, scoring by a nose in the Lion d'Or Handicap at Belmont.

Mrs. Charles H. Jeckel of Mount Vernon, N.Y., with eight first prizes, won the sweepstakes award yesterday in the garden club section of the twenty-second annual flower show of the American Dahlia Society, held in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center.

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- Struggling desperately, like a Channel swimmer who, with the goal in sight, finds the eddying off-shore tides almost too much for him, the Giants gained their objective at 3:35 P.M. today and exhaled a sigh of relief that almost knocked over the near-by Bunker Hill Monument.

GENEVA, Sept. 24. -- With Rome ominously silent, the League of Nations Assembly elected this evening as one of its six vice presidents the undesignated first delegate of the absent Italian delegation. This was the result of all-day lobbying, presumably inspired by France and Great Britain, and was meant as their good-will gesture to soften the sting of yesterday's seating of the Ethiopian delegation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP). -- C.H. Williams Ruhe of Pittsburgh was elected commander-in-chief of the Grand Army of the Republic today after Madison, Wis., had been chosen for next year's encampment.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- Fresh from an inspection tour of the Mediterranean, which took him as far as Palestine, Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, intends to visit the leading naval dockyards in Great Britain early in October.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24. -- West Coast waterfront employers and maritime unions were asked today by Labor Department conciliators to "cooperate in preventing a stoppage of work and commerce on Oct. 1" by extending all existing agreements pending negotiation of new contracts.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Sixty-six players teed off at the Apawamis Country Club this morning in the weekly one-day event of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association, but due to the heavy condition of the course and the fact that the majority of entrants had high handicaps, only twenty-two handed in cards.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP). -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis named the Yankee and Giant eligibles for the World Series today as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The proposed issue of $175,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures authorized yesterday by directors of American Telephone and Telegraph Company was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration under the Securities Act of 1933.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 24 (AP). -- A cell door closed behind Don Burdick today in the Fairfield County jail following the failure of his counsel to raise satisfactory bail for his appearance in the Westport town court on a charge of shooting with "intent to murder" his aged father-in-law, Harry E. Byram.

State game commissions have a habit of climbing out on a limb before the opening of a season with optimistic predictions regarding the supply of birds and animals. Usually the hunter takes too cheery forecasts with a grain of salt, for he realizes the difficulty of obtaining an accurate State-wide survey of Wildlife in advance of the shooting season.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 24. -- Joseph Gelders, representative here of the National Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners and former instructor in physics at the University of Alabama, staggered up to the home of Isaac Hamrick, near Maplesville, early today, bleeding, bruised and clad only in underwear.

Trading in wool goods markets continued slow this week and is expected to remain so until more seasonable weather accelerates the movement of men's and women's wool clothing at retail, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens County began an investigation yesterday into the conduct of eight dismissed election inspectors who left official primary ballot returns in a Democratic clubhouse instead of turning them over to the Board of Elections as the law requires.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The Pirates shoved the Cubs deeper into third place today by beating them, 4 to 0, in the final game of the National League season at Wrigley Field.

With social-security payments by employers jumping to a minimum of 3 per cent of total payrolls on Jan. 1, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, yesterday suggested that his members analyze their cost figures thoroughly and cover higher expenses by "appropriate increases in the price per yard on orders after a certain date."

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The so-called "lie detector" of the Newton Street School here was reduced to kindling wood in the school basement today after causing more embarrassment in school circles here than would have been experienced by any schoolboy caught telling a lie.

When the Kansas journalists and politicians, the Eastern bankers and the representatives of the Eastern exporters had finally achieved agreement on the Republican platform at Cleveland, it was obvious that here was another political contract that would not be kept, for the simple reason that it could not be.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 24. -- Mrs. C.V. Whitney's noted gray gelding Lincoln triumphed twice in interesting jumping competitions during the second day of the Bryn Mawr horse show today. Lincoln scored first in a test over the outside course, defeating Mrs. Ellsworth H. Augustus's Chatter Chat for the blue ribbon, then took the knockdown and out stake.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System were increased by $30,000,000 to a total of $1,740,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly statement issued yesterday by the system. Although only a small part of the $290,000,000 loss of the week before was regained, it is expected that next week's increase will be much greater.
Substantial gains in revenues for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31 were reported yesterday by leading affiliates of the Electric Bond and Share Company.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 24. -- The report is abroad that Navy is the team of the year to beat in the East.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The men's singles of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament narrowed to four survivors today as Donald Budge, America's No. 1 singles star, and Jack Tidball, Los Angeles, reached the semi-finals.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 24. -- Miss Alice M. Carson, member of the Greenwich Hortulus Club and daughter of Mrs. Frank M. Carson, won the sweepstakes in the twenty-fifth annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society and Garden Clubs of Greenwich and Rye today for having the highest number of points in the classes for artistic arrangements, and also the Fenwick Medal for excellence in decorative arrangements.

Even though the moral victory of the League of Nations in choosing between Italy and Ethiopia comes a little late, too late to have any effect on the fate of the conquered tribes, it may be said with truth that from the beginning of this sorry episode the policy of Geneva has been fairly consistent. The League went as far as it could, further than it ever went before, to stop the aggressor.

The crisis in the French franc was the principal influence in the financial markets here yesterday, making for cautious trading in stocks and for some nervousness as possible repercussions of devaluation of the French currency were thought out.

The cities of the United States will experience an acute housing shortage with continued recovery, Roy Wenzlick of St. Louis told the members of the Savings Banks Association who assembled in their annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

In President CUTTEN'S address at Colgate on "The Parasite" he confessed that it was not easy to decide upon the proper emphasis as between the individual and the State, but that history seems to say (and he quotes especially the experience of Rome) that "when "the supremacy of the State over-"shadows that of the individual, the "civilization, of which both are mem"bers, begins to decline."

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Wood McClave of Englewood, N.J., entertained at dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Miss Elizabeth Koehn and Robert M. Ingham Jr., who will be married today in the First Presbyterian Church, Englewood.

It was announced yesterday at a meeting of holders of Rio Grande Western Railway first consolidated 4 per cent bonds of 1949 that the Guaranty Trust Company would intervene as trustee for the bonds in the bankruptcy proceedings of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad.

Price changes in general were narrow yesterday in markets here for commodity futures, but a plunge occurred in aid Rio coffee and moderate upturns in hides and copper. In the cash market, silk, wool tops and hides eased, wheat and rye made new high marks, and corn, oats, quicksilver, cocoa, tin, butter and lard gained ground.

Apartments in East Side houses proved attractive to families seeking a change of living quarters in the Fall renting rush yesterday. The rentals showed a demand for large suites on Fifth and Park Avenues and adjoining streets. Agents also reported long lists of new tenancies in buildings on the West Side.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24. -- Columbia has found two promising screen personalities in minor roles in the Irene Dunne-Melvyn Douglas "Theodora Goes Wild." One, Leona Maricle, familiar to Broadway in Woods Brady, Harris and Miller shows, has been placed under contract and left tonight for New York for a brief vacation before resuming her new career.

AKRON, Sept. 24. -- By unanimous vote of about 3,000 member of the B.F. Goodrich local of the United Rubber Workers Union tonight it was decided to return to work on the terms arranged today at a meeting of union officers and spokesmen for the management.

Tonight, at sundown, Jews throughout the world will observe their most sacred holy day, Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, of which they were reminded on Rosh ha-Shanah, the New Year. At virtually every service, orthodox, conservative or reform, the traditional Kol Nidre will be intoned tonight, while tomorrow night the annual prayer for the dead will culminate the observance.

TEL-AVIV, Palestine, Sept. 24. -- More than 120,000 Jews from all parts of Palestine paid a last tribute to Meier Dizengoff, Mayor of Tel-Aviv, as his funeral procession passed through the principal streets of the city this morning from the Tel-Aviv Museum, where the body lay in state yesterday, to the cemetery.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Ferdinand Hubert of the Essex Fells Country Club, over whose home course the championship was played, scored an 82 today to tie Dr. Walter F. Barry of the Essex County Country Club for the New Jersey State senior golf title.

The Dodgers and the Phillies played ball at Ebbets Field yesterday before 1,700 fans for four hours and 20 minutes, completing nineteen and one-half innings before their activities were suppressed by darkness and the umpires.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The United States is not expected to retaliate by a further devaluation of the dollar if France cuts the gold value of the franc, but officials preferred to maintain silence on the question today.

BOMBAY, India, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The Mahatma Gandhi, only recently recovered from a malarial attack, pledged himself tonight to die rather than abandon first-hand study of the disease-ridden villages in India.
Plaintiffs took over four properties in Manhattan and four in the Bronx at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Four of the parcels went to savings banks.

The Metropolitan Opera Association is seriously considering the projected Municipal Art Center for its future home, it was learned yesterday, following the disclosure that private interests had pledged about $14,000,000 for the center through the Municipal Art Committee.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Sept. 25. -- The tension in Shanghai gave an appearance of slight lessening today, but not since the fighting of 1932 have Japanese forces so heavily patrolled the Hongkew section of Shanghai, North Szechuen Road and the fringes of Chapei as now.

John Ford, who last year received the Motion Picture Academy's award of merit for his brilliant picturization of Liam O'Flaherty's "The Informer," has been engaged by Walter Wanger to direct "Desert Intrigue," an adaptation of the novel "African Intrigue,'' by Alfred Batson.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The traditional practice of letting a few days or a week elapse between the nomination of a Governor and his formal notification will be dispensed with next week by Republicans at their State convention in Albany, as in the case of the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, it was announced today by Charles H. Griffiths, chairman of the Westchester County committee.

MADRID, Sept. 24. -- According to government reports tonight, a ten-foot wall of water, released from Alberche Dam by government forces, roared down on a column of Fascists advancing on Madrid and swept many of them to their deaths.

ALBANY, Sept. 24. -- Improvement in the position of many investors in guaranteed mortgage certificates is noted in an interim report of the State Mortgage Commission to Governor Lehman, made public here today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- The name of Dr. Francis E. Townsend's Old-Age Revolving Pensions movement was changed today to the Townsend National Recovery Plan, Inc.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 24 (AP). -- Roman Soldier, E1wood Sachsenmaier's star, won his first race since last June in today's featured Penn Athletic Club Handicap before a crowd of 9,000.

Stepping up its advertising budget 50 per cent, the Nash Motor Car Company will put more than $1,000,000 in advertising and promotion behind its 1937 line of Nash and Lafayette automobiles, distributors and field representatives were told yesterday by company officials at Kenosha, Wis.

Substantial increases in orders placed were reported yesterday at the second annual Perfume and Cosmetic Buyers Conference and Exhibition being held in the Hotel Pennsylvania. More than 150 buyers were registered during the day, bringing the total attendance for three days to approximately 400.

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 24. -- Getaway day was a banner one today for W. Gilmour and his stable from Luzerne, N.Y., as the light harness racing meet ended at the Eastern States Exposition half-mile track.

After receiving assurances that Virginia is a good Republican prospect this year, the Republican National Committee has decided to send Colonel Frank Knox, party nominee for Vice President, into that State to appeal for votes in support of Governor Landon.

There is a strong possibility that James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion will fight Joe Louis in a no-decision contest in February, several months before he is scheduled to defend his title against Max Schmeling next June.
Various dwelling deals in Westchester were reported yesterday.

An analysis of the cost of First Houses, built by the New York City Housing Authority at Avenue A and Third Street, shows a total expenditure for construction of $1,155,649, against a $328,621 estimated cost by the Authority on Oct. 26, 1934, before construction began, according to the current Real Estate Record, a weekly published by the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

Lord Dudley Marley was one of the speakers of the Ort (Society for the Promotion of Trades and Agriculture Among Jews in Eastern Europe) at a dinner of the organization last night at the Hotel Commodore. He has just returned from a trip abroad.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- Simultaneously with the publication of its weekly statement showing a gold loss of 840,000,000 francs the Bank of France today raised the rate on discounts from 3 to 5 per cent and the rates on advances on securities and thirty-day advances to 6 and 5 per cent respectively.

Somehow Mr. LLOYD GEORGE reminds us of Sir GODFREY KNELLER. It is not that Mr. LLOYD GEORCE is also a painter -- though he could doubtless have surpassed all contemporary artists if he had given his mind to it -- but that he has something like Sir GODFEEY'S regret that he did not choose a different career.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- It is indeed a gloomy picture that I have drawn of Western and Central Europe, although not, I think, more gloomy than the truth. But I have, as yet, said nothing of Russia. The shadows of the East fall across the already darkened picture of the West.

LITTLE ROCK, Sept. 24. -- A Federal grand jury investigating reports of peonage in the East Arkansas Cotton Belt indicted a city official today on charges of violating the Federal anti-slavery laws by obtaining laborers for his farm through false arrests.

Isaac Comeaux, chief accountant and deputy controller of the city of Seattle, who is in New York to arrange with bankers for the refinancing of the city's transit system and its conversion from street cars to buses, declared yesterday that Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler was "sadly misinformed on conditions in Seattle."

The audition board authorized by the WPA Federal Theatre Project to re-examine dancers now employed on the project's dance units resumed its work yesterday after it had been discontinued temporarily because of protests filed by a group of seventy-five dancers charging discrimination and "firing" without cause.

MADRID, Sept. 24 (Passed by Censor). -- Government troops today recaptured Quismondo, a small village, the importance of whose capture lies in the fact that it is only five miles from Maqueda, which is a strategic point controlling communications between Talavera de la Reina and Toledo. The government troops are trying to recapture Maqueda as well as to cut the Rebel retreat on Torrijos.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 24. -- The Meadow Brook hounds had several outstanding winners in the cross-bred foxhound competition in today's sessions of the Bryn Mawr Hound Show, being held here on the polo field.

A history of attempts to undermine the freedom of the press is presented by Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, in a book, "The Freedom of the Press," issued today by the D. Appleton-Century Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- After a heavy day of firing over the heavy, testing links of the Fenway Golf Club, three players, Henry C. Hagen, Emil Mosbacher and William A. Brindley, were deadlocked today with scores of 81 for the championship in the annual Fall tournament of the New York Curb Exchange.
LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

DENVER, Sept. 24. -- A prediction by Governor Landon that "seven fat years," all of them "Republican years," lie ahead was made by Governor Landon in a telegram sent to Colonel Jose Sena, secretary of the New Mexico Republican organization, in Santa Fe. It said in part:
A $300,000 apartment house project for Rego Park, Queens, was among the building plans filed yesterday, as follows:
To Face St. Bonaventure in Opener at Randalls Island Tomorrow -- Columbia Perfects Kicking, While Fordham Loses Lawlor in Double Scrimmage -- News of Other Squads.

Following a four and one-half hour conference at the Park Central Hotel last night, representatives of the Metropolitan Garage Owners Board of Trade and of the Garage Washers and Polishers Union, Local 272, both parties agreed to refer their differences to arbitration.

WITH THE GOVERNMENT ARMY NEAR QUISMONDO, Spain, Saturday, Sept. 25. -- Three determined Madrid government divisions, spurred by victories with water and steel, charged against a floundering Rebel army today. The attack, from three directions, threatened the insurgents with annihiliation after Rebel regiments had been swept into disorder by 10,000,000 cubic yards of water released from Alberche River dams north of San Martin de Valdeiglesias.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 24. -- Both Greentree, which forms the United States quartet, and Argentina galloped through pony games over heavy fields late this afternoon, Argentina defeating a team which included two of their spares and the Guest brothers, 9 to 4, and the United States representatives losing to a Blue combination on Cochran Field, 10 to 6.

The Sanitation Department's plans for an immediate purchase of almost $1,000,000 of new snow-fighting equipment came a cropper yesterday when the Board of Aldermen declined to vote the necessary permission to buy without competitive bidding.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24. -- The United States Steel Corporation, which long has owned many choice industrial and building properties along the Ohio, Monongahela and Allegheny rivers in and about Pittsburgh, plans to sell all its unused real estate not necessary to its manufacturing needs or expansion.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24. -- The annual convention of the American Bankers Association came to a close here today with the adoption of resolutions recognizing the progress of business recovery and declaring that the bankers of the nation "have confidence in the fundamental credit of the United States Government."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 24. -- Ogden L. Mills said this evening that the chief issue before the American people was "whether government is to dominate and control the life of the people, or whether it is to lay down the broad rules that are to govern the activities of all, to act as umpire and impartially to enforce the rules."

President Roosevelt will attend the third game of the world series, the first of this year's set to be played in the Yankee Stadium, next Friday afternoon. Announcement to this effect was made yesterday at the Stadium, where plans for accommodating the President's party were completed.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith made public last night a telegram he had sent to President Roosevelt, notifying him that, "in deference to the high office of President which you hold" and in order not to deprive him of a nation-wide audience for his radio address from Pittsburgh on Thursday night, he had changed his own radio time for the same evening.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- The wheat market resumed today the advance that has been under way with only minor interruptions since early in September and sold at new high levels for the season. The September delivery on the Board of Trade at $1.18 7/8 a bushel was in new ground for this period of the year since 1929, and in Liverpool prices were the highest since 1930.
Harold Bauer has become the chairman of a nation-wide committee which will work toward the establishment of an Ossip Gabrilowitsch memorial. The form the memorial will take will be decided later.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe approved yesterday a settlement of damage claims reached between owners of the Sound steamer Lexington, which sank in the East River on Jan. 2, 1935, and owners of the Jane Christenson, which was in collision with the former vessel.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The Cardinals took a double-header from the Reds today, winning the twelve-inning opener, 5 to 4, and topping the Reds, 2 to 0, as darkness ended the nightcap after five and a half innings.

Active liquidation of October contracts in advance of today's notices caused yesterday further slight recessions in prices on the Cotton Exchange here, and, in conjunction with a liberal quantity of hedges in later months, the list closed unchanged to six points lower than on Wednesday.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 25. -- The government, after deliberation on the situation in China resulting from murders of Japanese, has reached a double decision. Though further naval reinforcements will be sent to Chinese ports, Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe will continue negotiations with Nanking.

The 1936 American League season for the Yankees in the Stadium ended yesterday in an atmosphere of gloom, low-hanging clouds threatening a deluge any moment. The Yanks were overcome with lethargy from which not even Lou Gehrig's forty-ninth homer could rouse them, and they lost to the Athletics, 4 to 3.

Dry goods jobbers continued to place a substantial volume of orders for immediate shipment goods this week, but in many cases found they could not obtain quick delivery. All types of Fall staples were in demand by jobbers, who continued to receive unusually large reorders from their retail accounts in most sections of the country.

Shortly after a novena was held last night in St. Valentine's Roman Catholic Church, 810 East 221st Street, the Bronx, fire started in the building and spread throughout the entire wooden structure, wrecking it. The damage was estimated at $50,000).

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24. -- Business activity in the Pittsburgh district declined mildly last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's index of business, in which the effect of seasonal variations and trend is eliminated, was 96.6 last week, or nine-tenths of a point less than in the preceding week.

Adolf Hitler's attempt at the Nazi Congress in Nuremberg to connect the Jews and communism is only a mask to hide his real assault on democracy and world peace, according to a statement issued yesterday on behalf of the American Jewish Committee by Dr. Cyrus Adler, its president, and Sol M. Stroock, chairman of its executive committee.

As predicted, Governor LANDON opened at Minneapolis last evening his direct attack on the reciprocal trade treaties. He made several preliminary reservations. The Governor denied that he or his party is for an isolationist policy. He believes in and hopes for a great resumption and expansion of international commerce as one means of making the world prosperous and thus averse to war.

More than 3,000 persons, including many officials of New York and New Jersey, attended the solemn high mass of requiem yesterday at St. Patrick's Catholic Church, Jersey City, for James Hague, brother of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, who died on Monday of injuries received in an automobile accident.
The American Legion wound up its annual convention yesterday at Cleveland with the election of a new national commander and the adoption of various resolutions. Among them appears the following:

Heartening as it is to see new about city planning and a municipal art center, a thoughtful person cannot avoid a feeling of despair at the idea of locating a municipal art center north of Rockefeller Center in the area bounded by Fifty-first and Fifty-third Streets and Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

Captain James Mollison arrived yesterday on the French liner Paris to take possession of the new Bellanca plane which he ordered some months ago and which, according to his present plan, he will fly back across the Atlantic.

After being in succession against Harding, against Coolidge, against Hoover, against Smith and against Roosevelt for President, H.L. Mencken finally has come out for Governor Landon for that high office. This endorsement appears in an article in the October issue of The American Mercury, "The Case for Dr. Landon."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- A plan to fill with tear and nauseating gases the mines operated by "bootleg" miners in the anthracite fields of Southern Pennsylvania was brought to light today by the La Follette subcommittee investigating charges of violations of civil liberties.
A Bronx apartment that was completed last March and is now fully rented was sold by the builders yesterday.

FREEPORT, Ill., Sept. 24 (AP). -- The Utilities Power and Light Corporation, with principal offices in Chicago, was the defendant in a bankruptcy action filed here today in Federal Court by four creditors holding $8,500 in twenty-year gold debentures.

PROBABLY it was overlooked or unheard on the Yale football field, but a new note in biology was struck by Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, during the celebration of the 300th anniversary of the Cambridge institution of learning. Lest there be any serious breach of the peace while this matter is being laid before the house, it might be best to strap all Yale men in their chairs at the outset.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 24 (AP). -- The nation's police officials today urged broader deportation laws to help them cope with the problem of alien criminals.
The State of Mississippi has invited bankers to submit bids for a new issue of $5,500,000 of highway bonds. The award will be made on Oct. 6. Further details of the offering will be announced later.

The Rev. Dr. George A. Wieland, rector of the Church of the Epiphany, Seattle, Wash., has been appointed executive secretary of the field department of the National Council of the Episcopal Church, it was announced yesterday at the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue, when the national council ended a three-day session.
An extra of 30 cents and the regu- [ lar qualerly dividend of 60 cents aI common share were declared yes-i terday by the Pacific Lighting Corporation.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday a shake-up among several of the ranking officers "to increase the efficiency of the department." The commissioner added that there would be "other changes made in the detective division."

The Hamburg-American liner Hansa arrives today from Hamburg, Southampton and Cherbourg. Her passengers include Mr. and Mrs. Walter Zingelmann, Countess Maphie Coudenhove, Colonel Marcel S. Keene, the Countess Selma von Wirsing, George M. Priest, Mr. and Mrs. William Friebel, Dr. Walter Heerdt, Stanley L. Wang, Donald Mackenzie, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Scotoni, Robert T.S. Lowell, Mr. and Mrs. John K.G. Fuller, Emiliano Hinojosa, Rafael Bejor Zamora and Mrs. Esther Ridder.

Many stock market authorities feel that if the franc is devalued, stocks will not decline sharply here. In the first place, it is pointed out, devaluation already has been heavily discounted in Wall Street as a result of the periodic drives against the franc for more than a year.

" When every actor has hopes of landing a job on the stage this Fall, I haven't a pair of trousers and a coat to match. It's no use to go to casting directors unless I can put up a good appearance. When an actor is down it is a thousand times harder to get work again."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- Generating unusual power, Pop Warner's Temple University football squad scored a 50-to-7 victory over Centre College of Danville, Ky., in the Owls' Stadium tonight before.

BERLIN, Sept. 25. -- The Boerse was dominated again today by uncertainty over the fate of the French franc, with which is connected the fate of the German mark. Demand continued for foreign bonds and some colonial issues, but their trend was nervous, considerable changes both ways marking the close of the session. New Guinea shares, for instance, rose 5 points more, but Cameroon stock slumped 7 1/4.

The prospect of a strike of Pacific Coast waterfront employes on Thursday has caused several shippers to withhold their freight from the intercoastal ship lines, it was learned yesterday. The report that some of the liners were refusing freight was generally denied.

The Federal Reserve Bank reported yesterday that a total of $43,532,000 in gold had been engaged in Paris to establish a new record for a single day. With this amount, the total taken from France since the current move merit was begun on Aug. 7 is $197,700,000.
I have read the letter from William H. Matthews Jr., which you published on Sept. 15, about the work of employes of the National Youth Administration in Van Cortlandt Park.

The Gulf States Steel Company announced yesterday that it would submit to stockholders on Oct. 19 a plan to set up a first mortgage on the company's properties to secure an issue of $7,000,000 of twenty-five-year 4 1/2 per cent bonds and to offer to common stockholders approximately 98,750 shares of unissued common stock.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 25. -- The outstanding chestnut geldings Chatter Chat and Sand Den carried off three blue ribbons for Mrs. Ellsworth H. Augustus of Willoughby, Ohio, during the third day's competition at the Bryn Mawr horse show today.

PARIS, Sept. 25. -- An offer to cease "stay-in" strikes throughout France if the employers would agree to closing of the factories during labor negotiations and grant a wage scale that would rise with increases in the cost of living was made by Leon Jouhaux, secretary general of the General Confederation of Labor, at a conference of the federation's national committee this morning.

Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, yesterday defended the methods used in constructing First Houses at Avenue A and Third Street, and said an analysis of the cost of the project made by Walter Kruesi in the current issue of Real Estate Record was "false and maliciously misleading."

James A. Farley, Democratic National and State Chairman, will depart for Syracuse today to set the stage for the State convention on Monday and Tuesday at which Governor Lehman and the entire Democratic slate will be renominated and President Roosevelt is expected to "take the gloves off" in an address to the convention.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 25. -- The eight-goal internationalist, Stewart Iglehart, turned in another fine performance on Belmont Field of the Meadow Brook Club today as the Westbury House four downed the Orange County riders, 9 to 5, in a quarter-final round match of the sixteen-goal Autumn Plates polo tournament.

About $600,000 will be distributed to investors on Oct. 15 by the three trustees appointed by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler to reorganize and administer the C-2 issue of guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

A list of books recommended by the Cardinal's Literature Committee for Catholic reading was announced yesterday. The selections deal with fiction, politics, biography, religion, poetry, education, economics, social sciences and a wide range of other subjects.

Public-utility borrowing accounted for the greater part of new bond financing this week, three such operations amounting to $44,050,000 lifting the total of new offerings to $51,763,750. This compares with new issues of $113,531,000 placed on the market last week.

With the exception of Chicago, New York City is far behind all other large American municipalities in the relative size of the public health nursing staff of its city and private agencies, Miss Lillian D. Wald declared yesterday in making public a report on the city's Advisory Committee on Nursing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Aided by Jimmy DeShong's sight-hit pitching and nine walks and a balk by Boston pitchers, the Senators beat the Red Sox today, 9 to 3.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 25 (AP). -- Held scoreless for the greater part of four periods, Bucknell University's football team unleashed a passing and running attack in the closing minutes of its game with Ursinus College tonight to score one touchdown and win, 6-to-0.

NANKING, Saturday, Sept. 26. -- "The outcome of this very critical phase of Chino-Japanese relations depends entirely on the attitude taken by the Chinese Government." declared Consul General Yakichiro Suma of Japan yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Macdonald Smith, Glendale (Calif.) veteran, is leading the nation's professional golfers for low average scoring honors, with Harry Cooper of Chicago a fraction of a Stroke behind.

Manuel Azana, Spanish President, who has asked for refuge on an Argentine warship, was an ardent proponent of a liberal, democratic bourgeois regime rather than a Red, or Leftist, government in Spain.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 25. -- Governor Graves spurred the hunt today for the kidnap-floggers of Joseph Gelders, representative of the National Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners, with the offer of a $200 reward for the capture of the attackers.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Tom Kerrigan, veteran pro from Siwanoy, fashioned a 70, 78 -- 148 today over the Lakeville course to lead the field in the metropolitan district qualifying round for the national P.G.A. championship, which will be contested at Pinehurst in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Secretary Hull and Secretary Wallace, as members of the Roosevelt Cabinet, made sharp replies today to Governor Landon's speech last night at Minneapolis in which he criticized the administration's farm policies.

AMHERST vs. Hobart -- What, already! Still, there was fair warning. Just the other day George Marshall donned his dazzling Autumn scenery and sauntered down the avenue, stopping ever and anon to tell friends, Romans and countrymen that his Boston Redskins would rip through the professional league and the George Vanderbilt Cup Race on the new Roosevelt Raceway would be hot enough to carry all Long Island safely through a cold Winter.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $18,122,189 for one State and forty-two municipalities, against a revised total of $15,771,547 for this week. The year's weekly average of new offerings stands now at $28,474,465.

Prices of commodity futures generally were lower yesterday, reflecting uncertainty over the monetary situation in France. In the cash market corn, cotton, tin and eggs were higher, while wheat, rye, oats flour, silk and rubber were lower.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25. -- The Otis Steel Company announced today plans to eliminate back dividends on its 7 per cent preferred stock through the issuance of a new preferred stock paying a smaller dividend, and to clear up its capital structure. The back dividends will amount on Oct. 1 to $37 a share.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will have to provide an additional $500,000,000 for new plants and distribution systems for its electric business in the next ten years if its present rate of growth continues, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of directors, said yesterday at a public hearing before the Public Service Commission.

Those Hollywood newlyweds, Dick Powell and Joan Blondell, are the people of first importance in "Stage Struck," which moves into the Strand Theatre this morning. It is a Warner Brothers musical, with Jeanne Madden, 19-year-old colorature soprano; Frank McHugh and Warren William in the cast.

May I call attention to two articles from high sources appearing in THE TIMES on Sept. 18, and, six weeks earlier, on Aug. 3? They present confusing and apparently contradictory points of view on the important and pressing subject of expenditures for relief.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25. -- Duquesne University opened its football season with a 14-to-0 victory over Waynesburg College at Forbes Field tonight.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 25. -- It was officially announced today that the Czechoslovak Charge d'Affaires at Berlin had handed a protest note in the name of the Czechoslovak Government to the German Foreign Office on Wednesday against speeches made at Nuremberg by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Minister of Propaganda, and Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, German Commissioner of Culture.
Departmental budgetary requests for 1937 total $490,667,179, not including debt service and the tax reserve fund, Budget Director Leo J. McDermott announced last night.

CACERES, Spain, Sept. 25. -- General Francisco Franco, Rightist commander-in-chief, rushed forward to Talavera de la Reina today to take personal command of the situation created yesterday when the Leftists blasted the River Alberche dam, swamping his main line of communications just east of Talavera.

Kansas most properly has a right to be proud of her schools. And Governor Landon has helped our common schools more than the average Governor. The best piece of State school legislation in recent years is the Landon Cash Basis Law.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 25. -- The eleventh annual Montclair horse show opened today at the Montclair Riding Club with a splendid entry. Nineteen of the forty-three classes listed for the two-day exhibition were decided during morning and afternoon sessions.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Eugene V. Homans, the New Jersey ace who has restricted his golf to week-ends except for a few invitation tournaments, today teamed with Miss Louise Iselin of the Women's National Club in the annual invitation mixed Scotch foursome tournament of the Piping Rock Club and walked off with the honors in the qualfying round with a 78.

HAVANA, Sept. 25. -- Preliminary negotiations between the Cuban Treasury and various holders of public works bonds, short-term credit and contractors' obligations issued during the Machado regime and now in default have come to a close, Secretary of the Treasury Walter del Rio said this afternoon.

The committee headed by Franklin D'Olier, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company, for first 4 per cent bonds of 1949 of the Wisconsin Central Railway and first 4 per cent bonds of 1936 of the road's Superior Duluth division and terminal reported yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission and to the New York Stock Exchange that its expenses from July 1, 1935, to July 26, last, were $831.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP). -- The vanguard of New York State Democrats, coming here next week to nominate Governor Herbert H. Lehman for a third term, swung into Syracuse today predicting a "landslide" victory for their entire ticket.
BERLIN, Saturday, Sept. 26. -- The currency entente between Paris. London and Washington created a sensation in Berlin. Most of the morning newspapers featured it with page-wide banner headlines.

ROME, Sept. 25. -- An editorial by Roberto Farinacci, former Secretary-General of the Fascist party, in the newspaper Regime Fascista today charges that Jews have caused recent European disturbances by an "essentially subversive" international policy, but it represents his personal views and cartainly does not in any way reflect the government's.

" Who's Who In America" for 1936-37 will be published on Monday, it was announced yesterday by the publishers, the A.N. Marquis Company of Chicago. This is the nineteenth biennial edition of the volume, which has grown to 2,880 pages, and contains up-to-date biographical sketches of 31,434 Americans, men and women.

A charge that the American Legion had taken a course at the Cleveland convention that would lead inevitably into demands for life pensions for every man who ever wore a uniform was made yesterday in a statement by Donald A. Hobart, national commander of the American Veterans Association. The statement follows:

David A. Schulte sat in a tapestried witness chair in a pleasant green room of his penthouse apartment at 1 East Eighty-eighth Street yesterday morning and testified concerning the operations of the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation and his holdings in various related companies.

When "First Houses" was dedicated nine months ago with elaborate ceremonial, an observer who appeared somewhat skeptical of the economic success of the venture was greeted by a prominent local official with the remark, "Come, come now, brother, "surely you would not apply cost ac- "counting to the Pearly Gates?"

Cardinal Manuel Goncalves Cerejeiva of Lisbon will return to Europe today on the Italian liner Vulcania, which sails for Mediterranean ports and Trieste. Others listed are Mr. and Mrs. James E. Cushman, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ethan Davis, Judge Frank Leveroni, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Cotton Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Allen, Miss Gloria Armstrong, William P. Bernton, Professor Corrado Gini and Mrs. Gladys I. Strecher.

Manhattan will make its 1936 football debut against St. Bonaventure at Randalls Island today, encouraged by a team superior in size, speed and experience to any Jasper combination in Chick Meeban's five-year coaching regime. A gathering of 15,000 fans is expected at the contest, which opens the metropolitan intercollegiate season and introduces football to the magnificent new municipal stadium.

General expectations that France was about to abandon the gold standard nullified yesterday, marketwise, the splendid reports on the state of domestic business, and stocks were sharply lower on the day.

Below are given the nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Seventeen of the twenty-one special Drukman grand jurors took yesterday what is believed to be an unprecedented step in writing a twenty-page letter to Governor Lehman reproving him for dismissing their removal charges against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County.

Proponents and opponents of the Municipal Civil Service Commission's proposal to bring the 11,000 employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau under civil service on an open competitive basis presented their arguments yesterday at a hearing before the commission.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25. -- Three principal objectives for the American Legion during the next year, and the years that come, were outlined by Harry W. Colmery, newly elected national commander of the American Legion, in an interview today with this writer.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the decisions in the cases of the twelve policemen who were tried on departmental charges of paying bribes to a "fixer" in attempts to gain preferred places on the Civil Service promotion lists.

Accompanying the announcement that President ROOSEVELT will make no speeches further West than Denver is the inferential explanation that he considers all the States on the Pacific Slope certainly Democratic. Politicians have a way of arranging the space in columns marked "Sure" and "Doubtful."

Nathan Straus Sons, Inc., hotel and restaurant equipment, has leased from next Feb. 1 the store and basement, comprising 150,000 square feet, at 45 West Eighteenth Street. The structure is the Central Mercantile Building, formerly occupied by Greenhut's Department Store, at Sixth Avenue.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 25 (AP). -- Five residents of Philadelphia owning securities of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, asked the Circuit Court here today to appoint a receiver for the company and to restrain its directors from selling its interests in a British utilities concern.
The latest Literary Digest poll showing Governor LANDON well in the lead in all the Northern and Western States is no doubt an honest tabulation of the replies received to its questionnaire.

Scholastic football will make its official 1936 debut in the metropolitan district today with a program of nearly seventy games slated to hold the attention of school sports followers in New York City, Westchester, Long Island and New Jersey.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will deliver the second speech of his "personal" campaign against the New Deal in Philadelphia the night of Oct. 8. This address, to be broadcast over a nation-wide hook-up, will be delivered under the auspices of a group of "Jeffersonian Democrats" opposed to the policies of the Roosevelt administration.

Former State Senator John A. Hastings announced last night his independent candidacy for Representative in Congress in the Sixteenth Manhattan District, with the approval and support of Father Charles E. Coughlin and his National Union for Social Justice.
Robert Crawford, the "flying baritone," joins the faculty of the Institute of Musical Art this Fall as director of public school choral singing and of the institute's general chorus.

ALBANY, Sept. 25. -- "One candidate and one ballot" is the slogan of a group of Republican leaders already on the ground for the State convention beginning here Monday. Anxious to avert a clash between rival candidates on the floor of the convention, with the possibility of discord that might continue after the session, they would welcome a showdown for elimination purposes between the Gubernatorial aspirants before the opening.
Will you please answer the following insignificant question?

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 25. -- Prelates said today that they "would not be surprised" if the Vatican were obliged to give the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin a stronger "warning" than the one which appeared recently in Osservatore Romano.

Although unseasonably warm weather retarded retail distribution in some sections of the country this week, sales generally averaged 10 to 15 per cent over the volume in the corresponding period last year, according to the trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, is undergoing considerable renovations outside and inside. When parishioners enter it tomorrow morning they will hardly know the brownstone Gothic edifice with the highly ornamented tall spire at the entrance to Rockefeller Center.

Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement and the most sacred day in the Jewish calendar, was observed last night. Jews in this city filled synagogues and temples and began the ritual by fasting "from sunset of the ninth to sunset of the tenth day of Tishri, the sacred seventh month."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- There was a sharp decline in the dollar value of sales on all registered security exchanges in August, the aggregate being $1,657,152,204, or 19.5 per cent less than in July and 14.3 per cent below the total in August, 1935, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SEATTLE, Sept. 25. -- Aboard three special trains from Minneapolis, nearly a thousand football fans arrived today, bringing with them the Gophers of the University of Minnesota who have been undefeated in twenty-four consecutive games. Tomorrow the Gophers meet the Huskies of the University of Washington in the college stadium here.

Governor Alf. M. Landon, Republican Presidential nominee, leads President Roosevelt by something more than 3 to 2 in a total of 503,509 votes cast in twenty-one States in The Literary Digest poll. The fourth tabulation of returns was made public yesterday. The returns are incomplete.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 25. -- The arrest of an alleged traveling thief of rare books, believed by library authorities to have stolen more than $100,000 worth from public libraries throughout the country over a period of ten years, was announced here today by Deputy Chief of Police John Haller.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, spent an hour and twenty minutes before the September additional grand jury. He had been called to give whatever evidence he had concerning allegations of graft by "employes" in the office of District Attorney William C. Dodge.

Removal of the Board of Education's main office from Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street to the Elks Club Building in the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn received a temporary setback yesterday in the Board of Estimate, but the transfer drew sufficient affirmative votes to guarantee its passage at the board's next meeting.

GENEVA, Sept. 25. -- In view of the complete lack of reliable information from Greece because of the very strict censorship of the telephone, telegraph and mails, the following report by a British official who has just arrived in Geneva has considerable interest.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Sept. 26. -- The Japanese landing force greatly reduced its number of guards and patrols in Shanghai yesterday and also withdrew the marines from the larger portion of the Chinese territory occupied.

PARIS, Saturday, Sept. 26. -- There is little doubt that devaluation of the franc will be received with immense satisfaction in business, economic and financial quarters in France. Some commentators already are enthusiastically predicting a genuine boom with American tourists returning as they did in good old days before the depression and with the languishing export trade brought back to new life.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The Cincinnati Reds -- troublesome all season -- kept the Cardinals from clinching second place in the National League today by winning their only victory of the present series, 3 to 2.
DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 25. -- Duke and Colgate are to clash tomorrow on the gridiron in an intersectional contest that is the first between teams of the two institutions.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The University of Kentucky capitalized on three scoring attempts tonight and, although on the defensive most of the second half, defeated a fast Xaxier University football squad, 21 to 0. A crowd of 12,000 including Governor A.B. Chandler of Kentucky, saw the game.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- America's speed boat racing season, which got under way in February in Florida and in May up north with the Albany marathon and has been assembling the outboard and inboard drivers in one city or another every week-end, has its windup on the Potomac tomorrow and Sunday.

SEATTLE, Sept. 25 (AP). -- D. Douglass Welch, a reporter for The Post-Intelligencer, told the National Labor Relations Board today that Frank M. Lynch, discharged photographer, enlisted support of trades unions for the American Newspaper Guild strike.

Time was when, at least in legend, the sunflower turned to the sun. Astronomy and astronomical botany need revision. The other night in Baltimore at a Republican meeting glorified by the presence of Chairman HAMILTON, State Senator PHOEBUS rose radiantly and gilded with his beams the ambassador of Sunflowerland.

WARSAW, Sept. 25. -- Unrest continues in Zamosc, in Southeastern Poland, where a policeman and five peasants were killed eleven days ago in a clash between the authorities and villagers. Pacification of the three counties of Zamosc, Hrubieszow and Tomaszow has not yet been effected.

Now that France is scheduled to abandon the gold standard, Holland and Switzerland are not expected to be long in following suit. The question now is whether there ever will be a return to the gold standard as it once existed. For the immediate future, the principal currencies of the world are likely to be "aligned" with one another.

The WPA's Federal Theatre Project takes the honor of providing an opening for this evening. It is "Horse Eats Hat?", a farce derived from the French, which is to go on at Maxine Elliott's Theatre. The authors and musicians involved are Edwin Denby, Orson Welles, Virgil Thompson and Paul Bowles.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The Most Rev. Michael J. Gallagher, Bishop of the Catholic Diocese of Detroit, said today that he agreed with the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's advocacy of the "use of bullets" against "any upstart dictator."

BERLIN, Sept. 25. -- The German Lufthansa plans to establish as early as next year a regular transatlantic air-mail line that will take mail from Berlin to New York within forty-eight hours, Baron von Gablenz, Lufthansa director, announced today.

For the first half of this year, according to a statement issued yesterday, the old Colorado Fuel and Iron Company had a net profit of $891,559 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and interest on general mortgage and industrial mortgage bonds but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed income.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin said here this evening that he had no intention of ceasing his attacks upon President Roosevelt and that he anticipated no further "warning" from the Vatican.

The unpredictability of late-season off-shore fishing is well illustrated by developments of the last few days. While there was a marked scarcity of fish on the near-by grounds immediately following the storm, it appears now that, although the bluefish schools have been scattered, the small tuna, at least, are staging a comeback.
The public will be given a preview of the four-mile Roosevelt Raceway today when the gates of the new road-racing plant at Westbury, L.I., will be thrown open to spectators without charge.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 25. -- The town of Kearny, N.J., was notified today by William H.J. Ely, State WPA Administrator here, that it would have to reimburse the WPA for $11,556.43 spent on repairs and renovation work during the past year for the West Hudson Hospital in that town.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- Jack McCarthy's first home run as a Giant, and his sixth hit in his first eight efforts as a Stoneham henchman, lifted the Giants to a 3-2 victory over the Bees today in the game which ended the Terrymen's activities on the road for this year.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 25. -- In one of the most hopeful notes struck at the International Cancer Congress, which has been held here all this week, Dr. Payne Palmer of Arizona, representing the American College of Surgeons and the American Society for the Control of Cancer, declared today that patients and their families should be told that cancer was a curable disease.

Charles R. Henschel, president of the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, will arrive tomorrow on the Staatendam, after spending three months in Europe. While in Paris he arranged for the loan by the Louvre and by French provincial museums of paintings for an exhibition at the Knoedler Galleries, Nov. 23-Dec. 12, for the benefit of the Museum of Blerancourt in France and for the Lycee Francais in New York.

With the prospects of an even larger crowd than that which witnessed Argentina's smashing first victory on Sunday, the polo teams of Argentina and the United States meet on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today in what may prove to be the deciding match of the series of the Cup of the Americas.
The Court of Appeals agreed yesterday to hear on Thursday an appeal from the decision of Supreme Court Justice Dodd banning a vote this November on the proposed new city charter.

Although few international bankers were available last night to discuss the devaluation of the French franc, those who could be reached expressed the belief that the measure, backed by the American and British Treasuries, would succeed not only in aiding France but in promoting international trade.
ALBANY, Sept. 25. -- Governor Lehman broke his non-smoking rule of two years' standing today and returned to a pipe given him four years ago by his son, John.

While lower temperatures toward the end of the week stimulated consumer demand for Fall merchandise, retail trade here during the earlier period continued to reflect the retarding effects of adverse weather. Department store sales were estimated as averaging slightly under the figures for the comparative period last year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Miss Alda Deery, 25-year-old vaudeville actress from New York, was brutally attacked and left to die of strangulation with a stocking knotted around her neck early this morning in her room in the Washington Hotel. She survived, but is in a serious condition.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- An agreement was reached here today between railroad executives and union engineers and firemen for installation of power reverse gears on locomotives, John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, announced after a special meeting in the Blackstone Hotel.

TOKYO, Sept. 25. -- The moderates in the Japanese Government are still in control of its policies and are doing their utmost to prevent a clash of arms with China, despite the provocation of recent mob murders of Japanese within China.

Fingerprints on an empty paint can provided the police last night with a clue in the search for the vandals who smeared the outside walls of South Hall and John Jay Hall at Columbia University Thursday night.

If it were not for respect for his great position as wartime British Prime Minister, only the short and ugly word would apply to David Lloyd George's statements in the fifth volume of his impressionistic memoirs, which has just been published in London.
Reports of subsidiaries of the National Power and Light Company and the Electric Power and Light Corporation for August and twelve months follow:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The promotion of Harry Hines Woodring to the War Secretaryship caused no surprise and considerable gratification in official and military circles here. Because of precedent and his familiarity with the affairs of the War Department Mr. Woodring's selection was regarded as logical.

If the ten largest cities in the United States were ranked as to the number of public health nurses in each per 100,000 inhabitants, New York would be next to the bottom of the list. Boston is well in the lead with 45. The others follow in this order: Detroit 32, Cleveland 30, Milwaukee 30, Pittsburgh 28, Baltimore 26, St. Louis 22, Philadelphia 19, New York 18 and Chicago 17.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25. -- Authoritative sources declared tonight Argentine officials in Madrid had informed the Buenos Aires government that the Spanish President, Manuel Azana, had asked for refuge aboard an Argentine cruiser off Spain.
