Frank J. Prial, defeated candidate for the Democratic nomination for President of the Board of Aldermen, started suit yesterday for a recount. He got an order from Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Lauer directing the Board of Elections of show cause on Monday why the primary returns should not be recounted.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Charley Whitehead, State amateur champion, and Johnny Kinder, home club professional, shaved five strokes from the Plainfield Country Club's par of 72 today to win the qualifying medal in the first annual New Jersey State pro-amateur golf championship.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The Indians lost their last mathematical chance to finish in the American League's first division today when they divided a double-header with the St. Louis Browns. The Tribe won the second game, 7 to 6, after the Browns had taken the opener, 8 to 2.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 25. -- John R. Woolford of R.W. Pressprich Co., with a net score of 72, assumed the lead today among 150 members of the Bond Club of New Jersey who competed at their thirteenth annual Fall field day at the Crestmont Golf Club for the Bond Club trophy.

Simon Lake, veteran submarine enthusiast, has notified the Treasury Department at Washington that he has discovered a hulk in the East River which he believes to be the almost fabulous vessel H.M.S. Hussar, a British frigate which sank in 1780 with, possibly, $1,800,000 in gold aboard.

AKRON, Sept. 25. -- While Akron breathed easier today because the "sit-down" strike in the B.F. Goodrich plant had been settled and 10,000 employes will return to work tomorrow, both employers and employes agreed that the crisis in this city's industrial relations had not been settled, but merely postponed.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend will begin negotiations tomorrow with the Mexican radio stations for a series of "educational" broadcasts on his pension plan.

If the explanation of hidden taxes on Governor Cooper's overalls by John E. Staley, research worker of the Republican National Committee, in a recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, is typical of the mental processes of the Republican Brain Trust, the G.O.P. should call in a psychopath.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 (AP). -- Two big innings, the fifth and eighth, gave Milwaukee a 7-to-5 victory over Buffalo tonight in the first game of the little world series.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 25. -- In the closing day of the Bryn Mawr Hound Show today, the quality was of the highest order in pack and individual classes for beagles and basset hounds. The latter hounds were being shown here for the first time.

Granville, rated by many the best horse in training, will run this afternoon at Belmont in the Lawrence Realization, the country's longest test exclusively for 3-year-olds. The race is expected to be merely something of a formality for this route-running son of Gallant Fox, which stepped out of his class to triumph in the Saratoga Cup.

OSHKOSH, Wis., Sept. 25. -- Governor Landon began today a two-day campaign in Wisconsin, stronghold of the La Follette brothers. Although in Wisconsin the Republican national ticket has to face the combined opposition of the Democrats and the La Follette Progressive party, which is supporting President Roosevelt, the Kansas Governor was told that he had a good chance to carry the State.

PARIS, Sept. 25. -- Anticipation of immediate monetary measures caused one of the most agitated sessions today that the Bourse had known for a very long time. An opening rush of large buying orders sent prices soaring in the most unaccustomed fashion.

Tomorrow the observance will begin of the tenth annual "Religious Education Week," closing next Sunday. Sermons will be preached on the general theme for the week, which is "Developing Christians for Times Like These." The observance will be conducted jointly by the Greater New York Federation of Churches, the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation, the Brooklyn Sunday School Union and the Queens Federation of Churches.

Replying to President Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago, the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S.J., president of Fordham University, defended the Fordham system of "social education" in a sermon before the Fordham College student body in the university chapel yesterday.

The first guns of the real barrage in a new football season sound today and under their cover the shock troops of the Autumn pastime begin their drive to push other sports into the background and finally to stand alone in the spotlight.

With yesterday's chilly weather definitely establishing the advent of Autumn earlier this week, apartment hunters were reminded further of the nearness of the new rental season at Oct. 1. The increased activity as the final week of the old season began was apparent in the long lists of renters furnished by brokers.
The text of the special Drukman grand jurors' letter to Governor Lehman follows:

PARIS, Saturday, Sept. 26. -- Under cover of an international monetary stabilization agreement whose final terms were negotiated by transatlantic telephone yesterday evening, the gold content of the French franc will be reduced Monday from 65.5 milligrams of nine-tenths fineness to a figure that will be controlled between 49 and 43 milligrams, or a reduction of about one-third.

The members of the Savings Banks Association of New York ended their two-day annual convention yesterday with the adoption of a resolution calling for more economy in government. Andrew Mills Jr., president of the Dry Dock Savings Institution, was elected president of the association for the coming year.

A Communist-arranged "coffin act" stole the show yesterday from an anti-New Deal tableaux sponsored by the First Voters League, a Landon organization at 400 Madison Avenue, but wound up with the cast of six Jailed for disorderly conduct.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- Business and manufacturing rode on an even keel in August and the first three weeks of September, industrial activity increasing seasonally in August, while there was a substantial increase in factory employment and payrolls, the Federal Reserve Board announced today in its monthly summary of the nation's commerce.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP). -Testimony that the Pinkerton National Detective Agency has 200 under-cover men collecting information on union and radical activities was placed before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- The hog market here today was somewhat unsettled, with the best grades, 160 to 290 pounds, selling mostly around Thursday's average. Sows and heavy butchers generally were 10 cents lower, although some sales of underweights and pigs were as much as 25 cents off.

Raymond Guest, polo player and sportsman, was elected president of the United Hunts Racing Association at a meeting of the directors at the Recess Club yesterday. He succeeds Thomas W. Durant, who has held the office for four years and who resigned because he is making his residence in California.

PARIS, Sept. 25. -- Mrs. Irene Joliot-Curie tendered her resignation as Under-Secretary of State for scientific research to Premier Leon Blum today. She has been replaced by Professor Jean Perrin, noted physicist.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- In an attempt to prevent a strike of longshoremen and seamen on the Pacific Coast, Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, left Washington tonight by airplane for San Francisco. He hopes to be in San Francisco by noon tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The long-awaited registration statement by the Conversion Office for German Foreign Debts (Konversionskasse fur Deutsche Auslandsschulden) of 3 per cent dollar bonds which it is proposed to offer dollar for dollar in exchange for coupons and other interest claims maturing between July 1, 1934, and Dec. 31, 1936, on certain dollar obligations of German debtors, was filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 25. -- The Most Rev. John T. McNicholas, Archbishop of the Cincinnati archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church, issued a statement tonight condemning the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's assertion that President Roosevelt was "anti-God."

The monetary crisis in France had an unsettling influence on cotton as well as other commodities yesterday. Houses with Continental European connections became active sellers here, while prices in Havre advanced sharply the equivalent of nearly a cent a pound before the rise was officially limited to 15 francs above opening quotations.

Representative Wright Patman and Senator Joseph T. Robinson, authors of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, will be honorary chairmen of the "mock trial" dinner to be held by the Sales Executives Club of New York in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor on Oct. 20.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP). -- A Supreme Court ruling that the 1934 Municipal Bankruptcy Act was unconstitutional because it violated States' rights was disputed today by ten States seeking a reversal of that decision.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 25. -- Leading figures of the Baptist denomination in the country came to Columbia today to participate in a program commemorating the life of the Baptist organizer and leader, the Rev. Dr. Luther Rice, born in Northboro, Mass., in 1753.

A prowler was shot and killed almost instantly last night by Patrolman Morris Sandberg in the rear yard of a six-family house at 2,061 Seventy-fifth Street, Brooklyn. The slain man was identified through cards as Peter Alberto, 23-year-old PWA worker of 1,515 Eightieth Street, Brooklyn.

Decisions of the utmost importance were announced last night in Paris, London and Washington. The French Government has summoned Parliament to meet in extraordinary session on Monday. It will then propose devaluation of the franc. This decision is welcomed in formal statements issued by the British and American Governments.

MINISINK HILLS, Pa., Sept. 25. -- Taking his text from the Bard of Avon, Harvey Haman analyzes the outlook for the Pennsylvania football team as largely contingent upon the cooperation of the destiny that shapes our ends.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 25. -- William Robertson Coe, exhibiting blooms from the gardens and greenhouses of Planting Fields, his estate on Chicken Valley Road, won the silver jubilee sweepstakes prize donated today by the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society to the exhibitor who won the greatest number of points in the twenty-fifth Fall flower and vegetable show, which closed tonight in the parish hall of Christ Episcopal Church.
LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 26. -- A turning point of many years came early this morning in the form of a Treasury announcement of a monetary agreement among Britain, France and the United States.

VIENNA, Sept. 25. -- Arturo Toscanini has just broached a project for erecting at Salzburg either a new theatre more in keeping with the artistic importance of the annual festival there than the present Festspielhaus, with the inadequately outfitted stage and the improvisational character of its auditorium, or else remodeling this house to eliminate the various handicaps.

PORT HENRY, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP). -- A charge of fraud was written into the record today in the battle between two elderly women for the $80,000,000 estate of Colonel Edward H.R. Green, who died in Lake Placid last June 3.

Although the tendency in the two major leagues over a long stretch has been to develop along strikingly contrasting lines, the American League stressing offense and the National circuit pinning its hopes on defense, perhaps no series in recent years has seen this difference so pronounced as promises to be the case in the forthcoming clash between the Yankees and Giants.

GENEVA, Sept. 25. -- The League of Nations Assembly's general discussion opened today with a slashing attack by Julio Alvarez del Vayo of Spain on non-intervention as a "de facto blockade" of the Spanish Government and as "a legal monstrosity.

ALBANY, Sept. 25 -- Controller Morris S. Tremaine declared in a statement today that the current expenditures of the State had been reduced by $105,568,925 in the last four fiscal years as compared with the preceding four years.
Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday the appointment to parishes of eleven newly ordained priests, three of whom took their vows in Rome.

A gathering of 5,000 spectators, including many members of society from New York and Long Island, is expected to turn out this morning for the thirty-eighth running of the Meadow Brook Cup at the race meet of the Meadow Brook Steeplechase Association on the estate of Ambrose Clark at Westbury, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- George A. Keyser and Lucian Jordon, examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission, recommended in a report submitted today that a petition by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., for authority to start passenger and express schedules between Albuquerque and San Francisco should be denied.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP). -- The few members of Congress remaining in Washington tonight were guarded in their comment on the Franco-British-American monetary agreement, pending a careful study of its text.

HYDE PARK, Sept. 25. -- Harry H. Woodring, Acting Secretary of War, was raised tonight to the full rank of Secretary by an act of President Roosevelt, taken in conformity with a law requiring that this office must be filled within thirty days after being vacated.

BILBAO, Spain, Sept. 25 (By Warship to Saint-Jean de Luz, France). -- Eight insurgent bombing planes rained bombs on Bilbao today, killing at least 126 persons and wounding many more. In retaliation the Loyalists executed sixty hostages from among the 4,000 held at Bilbao.

There are three co-existent reasons why France is abandoning the gold standard. The critical treasury situation is a matter that required fairly prompt action. The general state of internal finances was poor, but could be handled in more leisurely fashion.

The current controversy between the Federal Trade Commission and Acme Breweries, Inc., and the Rainier Brewing Company, San Francisco, as to the fattening qualities of beer, has attracted considerable interest in the advertising field, as it may have considerable effect on the future of the industry.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- In announcing tonight that it had joined France and Great Britain in the plan to link the franc, the pound and the dollar on a stable basis of exchange, the American Government, speaking through Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, evinced the feeling that it had taken the most direct and effective step possible to promote the peace of Europe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The statement of Secretary Morgenthau, announcing the part of the United States in the monetary agreement with France and Great Britain, follows in full:

BERLIN, Sept. 25. -- An urgent appeal to all German peasants to recognize their duty and deliver 30 per cent of their bread grain crops to the Reich Nutrition Estate by Oct. 15 has been issued by Mr. Zschirnt, head of the Central German Grain Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The text of Secretary Wallace's radio speech tonight follows:

Donald B. Woodward, economist and writer, said last night the plan to readjust the value of the French franc should stimulate business in France, clear the path to world recovery and have no markedly adverse effects in the United States, according to The Associated Press.

The baseball clans started assembling yesterday from all parts of the country, some from Canada. Headquarters of the Giants and Yankees were deluged with ticket requests. Hotels were flooded with applications for reservations, some of which could not be granted.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- Uncertainty over the French franc continued to overshadow trading today on the London Stock Exchange, although prices held fairly steady. British Government bonds declined fractionally because of indications of further municipal borrowing in the near future.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25. -- Asta, the dog that fought with William Powell and Myrna Loy for top honors in "The Thin Alan," will compete again with the two in Metro's "After the Thin Man."

Willhouse, Inc. (Leon and Norman Block) leased the seven-story building at 5 East Forty-seventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, for their custom tailoring establishment. The building has been remodeled and will be opened formally next Tuesday.

With Bill Robinson and Cab Calloway heading its elaborate revue, there could be little doubt that the "new" Cotton Club, which found itself opening at Broadway and Forty-eighth Street on Thursday evening, would turn out an Entertainment.

MARRYING and becoming the father of a baby have done something to Ogden Nash. Back in 1932 the seniors of Wheaten College voted him their favorite author, with a couple of fellows named John Galsworthy and Thomas Hardy in second and third places. A year earlier Mr. Nash announced in The Yale Daily News that Harvard (he is a Harvard man) had destroyed his mind.

PARIS, Saturday, Sept. 26. -- A decree published in the Journal Officiel this morning gives debtors owing sums that are to be paid in gold or foreign currencies the right to hold up payment on their written demand. The date when payment can be demanded will be fixed by Vincent Auriol, the Minister of Finance.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. 24. -- Ten years ago Baron Carl won Haartman, cavalry captain and a former general staff officer of the Finnish Army, was training Hollywood soldiers how to fight for Erich yon Stroheim and other directors.

Almost all classes of bonds weakened yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the most active trading since July 15. The international situation, particularly the financial crisis in France, was the major influence in the market for both domestic and foreign dollar obligations and precipitated substantial nervous selling of both high-grade and speculative issues.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- Charley Ruffing, red-haired right-hander, had his dress rehearsal for the world series at Shibe Park today, and, with a strong finish, demonstrated that he was ready for the mound assignment in the opening game against the Giants if Manager Joe McCarthy calls upon him.

Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn signed yesterday an order directing C. Walter Randall, trustee in reorganization proceedings of the Bush Terminal Company, to take immediate steps to have the Bush Terminal Buildings Company, a subsidiary of Bush Terminal, file a petition for reorganization under Section 77-b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

The American Association of Rhodes Scholars gave a reception last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania for the Rhodes scholars-elect who will sail this morning on the Cunard White Star liner Laconia for England. Paul Kieffer of the association was the chairman.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- Six formal speeches, including major ones in Syracuse and Pittsburgh, and in addition at least four platform appearances will be made by President Roosevelt next week as he starts his political campaign. The week's program was announced today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Operations in the world's wheat markets were affected to a considerable extent today by uncertainty regarding official action on the French franc and a sharp decline in sterling. At no time were prices on the Board of Trade as high as at the close yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 26. -- The Great Neck Real Estate Board has circulated pledges which bind the signers not to buy products of business concerns which buy space on the outdoor advertising signs now being erected on the white concrete walls of the Great Neck station of the Long Island Railroad.

Many Americans are disturbed by the appearance of "blocs" in various foreign countries, with an apparent determination to seize upon Governments in order to serve their own ends. It might be equally disturbing if our citizens gave serious consideration to similar dangers in our own country.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 26. -- A new airplane launching device which will permit increased pay loads was called a success today by W.B. Wheatley, chief test pilot of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The text of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's statement today on the Franco-British-American monetary move follows:

THE timeliness of this new work by Louis Aragon will unquestionably overshadow all other aspects for the majority of readers at the moment. And certainly there is a sense in which it is at least as timely as the last important news dispatch from abroad.

Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson, president of the General Federation, has left her headquarters at Washington for a series of executive calls on the conventions of several State Federations of Women's Clubs. She will start her tour from here tomorrow, after speaking at 5 P.M. over NBC on "Training Our Future Statesmen," a topic in which she is especially interested.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, and his daughter, Miss Beatrice Phillips, spent a few days in London at Claridge's on the way to Rome. Mr. Phillips started his diplomatic career as private secretary to Ambassador Joseph H. Choate in London.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Under the influence of cooler weather, retail trade moved forward on a broad basis, the average gain for the week among the larger stores advancing to about 18 per cent by comparison with 1935. While the apparel lines showed the most conspicuous improvement, purchases were remarkable for their scope.

THE Curtis Institute, Philadelphia, directed by Josef Hofmann, begins its thirteenth season tomorrow. Sixty-five new students accepted after auditions last Spring comprise one-third of the total number of students enrolled.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Opposition to the construction of an armory at the gateway of the Morristown National Historical Park in the Jockey Hollow area resulted in a protest by several property owners of Morris Township to the Board of Freeholders of Morris County, this week.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26. -- The text of Governor Landon's address in the Milwaukee Auditorium tonight follows:

IGOR STRAVINSKY," edited by Merle Armitage and printed by G. Schirmer of this city, is a collection of critical essays concerning various phases of the composer's development, by writers including Eugene Goossens, Henry Boys, Merle Armitage, Emile Vuillermoz, Louis Danz, Jose Rodriguez, Manuel Komroff, Jean Cocteau, Eric Satie, with an "abridged analysis" by Boris de Schloezer.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Students returning to Amherst College, which opened on Wednesday, found their new $400,000 gymnasium virtually completed and work started on the $50,000 swimming pool. These units, joined to the indoor athletic field and baseball cage and the Davenport Memorial squash courts, make Amherst one of the best equipped small colleges in the country in respect to its physical education plant.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26. -- Former Governor Charles S. Whitman of New York, who returned to spend the week-end at his Summer home here, was guest speaker at the Art Association this morning at the last of the September Saturday talks.

The murdered man is Professor Singer of the fine arts department of Harvard University and the man who finds the body is Jupiter Jones, a brilliant graduate student in that department. "Jupiter" is merely a nickname, but few of Jones's acquaintances know that he has another name.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Revaluation of the French franc was not entirely unexpected by the grain trade and today fell flat as a price-making influence in the leading grain markets. Wheat held within narrow limits here and abroad, and while fluctuations were somewhat erratic net changes were confined to small fractions.
Range of call loans on the New York Stock Exchange in this week for a series of years:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Lefty Vernon Gomez and Bump Hadley, possible world series pitching starters, had their tune-up for the Fall classic at Griffith Stadium today and both came through the test excellently.

SEATTLE, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Edwin S. Smith, Labor Board examiner, today ordered stricken out testimony of a Post-Intelligencer witness which was alleged to show an American Newspaper Guild chapter was organized here as part of an "anti-Hearst vendetta."
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 24. -- Outscored during the first half, Virginia's eleven registered two touchdowns in the second to defeat Hampden-Sydney today, 26 to 10.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Senator Borah has promised the Republican leaders that he will make two speeches over the radio before the close of the campaign dealing with national questions. He will emphasize his belief that the administration's reciprocal trading agreements are causing great injury to the American farmer and in the end will destroy tariff duties.
LONDON. -- The revolt against Great Britain's severe libel law is growing so fast that many lawyers now expect it to reach Parliament in the form of a bill during the next session.

PUBLISHERS predict that the success of such philosophic novels as "The Last Puritan" and "Sparkenbroke" will give rise to a run of meditative works. But it is likely to be a long time before an American or English author produces fiction on a philosophic scale equal to Albertini's "Two Years."

Disintegration of German Kultur will be the consequence of the Nazi interference with science and learning, according to Dr. Emil Lederer, a former Professor of Economics at Heidelberg University, now Dean of the University in Exile at the New School for Social Research.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The South Berkshire town of Great Barrington is to celebrate the 175th anniversary of its incorporation with a five-day pageant, starting next Tuesday, on the Housatonic Agricultural Society fair grounds.

THE photographic exhibit which opens on Tuesday at Rockefeller Center reflects the growing interest of amateur as well as professional camera men in the artistic possibilities of picture making. A substantial number of amateurs are represented in the 475 prints in the show.

The current interpretation of the Walsh-Healey Government-Contract Law, which would enable manufacturers to escape the provisions of the legislation by clearing their goods through established "dealers," was doubted by some business men here yesterday, because it offered such an obvious "loop-hole" for those producers who will not or cannot abide by the labor regulations.

BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- The fate of the German mark remained in the balance today as the German Government studied the financial and political implications of the Franco-British-American currency agreement. As seen here it broke the gold bloc and created something like a democratic entente.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Bloomfield High's Bengals smashed their way to a 50-to-0 victory over Phillipsburg's eleven in their opening gridiron battle today before more than 12,000 persons. The teams last year were undefeated and were declared tied for the group four State high school championship.

Dr. Jane Perry Clark of the Government Department at Barnard College and Professor Elizabeth Baker of the Department of Economics have received grants from the Council for Research in the Social Sciences of Columbia University.

Although indications are that Russia's oil industry will continue to expand for several years at a steady rate, J. Garfield Buell, an oil producer of Tulsa, Okla., who has just returned from a tour of the Soviet oil fields, is of the opinion that it will become less and less a factor in the world oil markets.

Richard Floethe has caught in his drawings the sturdiness, the matter-of-factness and the directness of the two young Americans of this book, and also something of the kaledioscopic quality of their adventures in an old world made new and turned topsy-turvy in the process.

WERE it not for that glowing Alexandrian romance. "Hypatia," or the popular "Westward Ho!" or the enchanting moral fairy tale, "The Water-Babies," Charles Kingsley might today be no more than a footnote in a history of literature.

The remarkable growth in the number of American branch plants established in the Argentine in the last year is the outstanding economic development. of the country, J. Hayes Bell, publisher of several magazines in Buenos Aires, said here yesterday. Visiting this country for a vacation, Mr. Bell said that Argentina was enjoying an unusual period of prosperity.

Three successful years of operating a public boat basin at Forked River, N.J., a couple of miles inland from Barnegat Bay, have convinced the New Jersey State Board of Commerce and Navigation of the urgent need for a chain of marinas along the New Jersey waterway.
AUTUMN New England is held by many to be the best time of the year, and late vacationists are getting ready for an October holiday. It is the month of the "flaming leaves."

Pointing for his most important meeting of the year with the Yankees next Wednesday, Coach Bill Terry rested his varsity squad yesterday at the Polo Grounds and allowed his scrubs to hit the Dodgers' line.

An unidentified man was killed about 7:30 last night by a northbound local of the Second Avenue elevated line at Twenty-first Street and First Avenue, between the Nineteenth Street and Twenty-third Street stations. After a fifteen-minute tie-up, northbound local traffic was resumed over the express track and one hour later a police emergency squad succeeded in removing the body from the wheels of the stalled train.

AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 26. -- In the Pratt Field opener today Hobart and Amherst battled to a scoreless tie before a crowd of 3,000. The defensive play of both teams was superb. Hobart recorded eight first downs to Amherst's nine.

The highest registration in the history of Teachers College, Columbia University, may be reached this semester with an already indicated gain of 11 per cent over last year's total. It is expected that this figure will be even larger after the late registrants have enrolled, according to Frank H. Hagemeyer, registrar.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Jumpers and hunters owned by Mrs. Helen R. Benson of Princeton and the entries of Moses W. Faitoute of Short Hills took the major honors in the closing session of the eleventh annual Montclair horse show today at the Montclair Riding Club. The crowd was the largest in the history of the fixture.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Litigation potentially involving the constitutionality of ten New Deal laws awaits action by the Supreme Court when it reassembles on Oct. 5 after the Summer recess.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 25. -- Governor Alf M. Landon, one reason for whose nomination for President was a belief that he was more likely than any other Republican candidate to carry the farm States of the Middle West, staked his chance for so doing on speeches addressed particularly to farmers at Des Moines and Minneapolis this week.

Formal demand has been made the President of the upon Municipal Council of the city of Bogota, Colombia, by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee for Bogota's consolidation power and light dollar loan, to take immediate steps to place in escrow to the account of the trustee all moneys received from the revenues pledged for the servicing of these bonds.

The Soroptomist Club of New York will sponsor a political forum for its members on Thursday at the Pan-Hellenic Club in the Beekman Tower at 6:30 P.M. It will take the form of a symposium on current political issues, with speakers from the Republican, the Democratic and the Socialist parties.

VIENNA. MUSIC lovers who, one of these days, will be indebted to the distinguished German critic and musicologist, Dr. Alfred Einstein, for a new and improved edition of the Koechel Mozart catalogue (in its original form almost unobtainable), now have Dr. Einstein to thank for the publication of a virtually unknown Mozart rondo for piano and orchestra, just issued in Vienna by the Universal Edition.

LONDON. A PROFITEERS' paradise has been severely circumscribed by the announcement of the unusually long route to be taken by King Edward VIII's coronation procession on May 12, 1937. Seats for royal pageants have long been a great source of revenue for London's opportunists, but with both sides of a six-mile route available there should be sufficient competition to keep prices within a reasonable range.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Henry W. Clark, general counsel for the Union Pacific Railroad, has written to the Interstate Commerce Commission, in reply to an inquiry, stating that a net saving of interest of $2,520,000 would be effected by carrying out the proposal of the railroad to sell $20,000,000 of thirty-four-year 3 1/2 per cent debenture bonds to refinance a like amount of 4 per cent bonds.

Motor truck competition has reduced the freight revenues of Canadian railways by $38,000,000 annually, S.W. Fairweather, director of the bureau of economics of the Canadian National Railways, said at the recent annual meeting of the Maritime Board of Trade in Charlottetown, P.E.I.
MILAN. THE Theatrical Inspectorate, coordinator of the activities of Italy's principal lyric stages, announces from Rome the following bills for the coming season:

PARIS, Sept. 25. -- By capturing Maqueda this week the Spanish insurgents have, in the opinion of most observers, assured their final victory. For Maqueda is believed to have been the last strongly prepared defensive position between them and Madrid.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT in his campaign for re-election has assumed the role of salesman for a single commodity -- confidence. Confidence in economic recovery, in social security, in business stability -- that is what he is trying to sell as he campaigns energetically up and down the country.
GENEVA, Sept. 26. -- The Swiss Federal Council, after fighting against devaluation this morning, came out this afternoon in favor of readjusting the Swiss franc.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25. -- Peace on Pacific Coast waterfronts hangs on a hair as shipowners insist that they will terminate present relations with the International Longshoremen's Association next Wednesday unless the latter agrees to arbitrate employer demands in the meantime.

From Long Island, where the national amateur championship was played recently, the scene now shifts to New Jersey for the women's national title competition, starting with the usual 18-hole qualifying round tomorrow.

THE place to be given music in the World's Fair to be held in New York in 1939 is a matter of exceptional importance, for this element can constitute one of the most impressive features of the exposition. It is particularly appropriate that it should be so, since the coming Fair is planned to emphasize cultural developments in our society as much as or more than its practical achievements.

With the Yankees sitting astride the American League like a Colossus, a position they have been holding ever since Sept. 9, when the last dissenting voice in their circuit cried "enough," and the Giants safely brought to port in the National League after a careening course down the home stretch, New York settles down this week to its long-awaited world series on a five-cent fare.

IT seems to be the fate of some introductions to be conspicuous from the moment they are put on the market, while others remain almost unknown until gardeners happen upon them, to the delight of the latter when the full worth of these modestly presented novelties is understood.

GEORGE WASHINGTON is, naturally, the outstanding figure in the nineteenth volume of the Dictionary of American Biography, which covers the names from the painter Edward Troye to the Revolutionary spy Paul Wentworth.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 26 -- The Dartmouth Players will be starting their twenty-fifth season this Fall and greater things are expected from the organization with the announcement that tradition will be broken by bringing a professional actress to play the lead in the Fall house party show.

PARIS, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The measure to requisition gold, scheduled for presentation to Parliament Monday, may meet stiff opposition from hoarding French peasants and workers, financial sources said today.

The body of Thomas Kerins, 32-year-old policy runner, hacked in many places with a cleaver or an axe, was found at dawn yesterday in "Poultry Alley," a one-block thoroughfare that connects Fifty-ninth Street with the live-poultry terminal of the New York Central Railroad, between Twelfth and West End Avenues.

Regular surveys to ascertain as accurately as possible the quantities of finished garments and piece goods in the coat and suit market will be conducted by the national coat and suit recovery board, it was announced yesterday by Alexander Printz, chairman of the board.

Escape literature with a vengeance is offered by this bright English travel novel. A hardworking American engineer, free for a few months' holiday, decides to run away to Wesbech, his mother's birthplace in England. In reckless and romantic mood, he wagers that he can get to England as a stow-away, dodging payment of fare and jail.

DEATH knell of a century-old British industry has been sounded by the march of fashion, bringing with it the announcement that Henry Howell Co., a London firm supplying walking sticks all over the world since 1832, is being forced out of business.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 26 (AP). Tennessee officials announced today plans to start a cooperative effort among seventeen States to stamp out evasion of gasoline-tax payments.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Ellsbery O'Hair, an employe in the State Department of Agriculture, said today that he and his father, H. Z. O'Hair of Bushton, Ill., have succeeded in growing a grain and forage crop which defies drought, heat, grasshoppers and chinchbugs.

PARIS, Sept. 26. -- France woke up this morning to find that one of its vital organs had been subjected to an emergency operation. It is a somewhat bewildered country this evening, but the patient is apparently doing fairly well.

In this, the most epochal season in the twenty years of existence of the Woman's Club of Great Neck, Mrs. Frederick L. Keays of that community returns to the presidency of the group she headed when it first was organized. In that capacity she will officiate late this year at the festivities that will mark the dedication of the new clubhouse, now under construction.
Your recent Sunday article on the novel and the screen, with especial reference to "Anthony Adverse," had a particular appeal for me as head of the Warner Brothers story department.
THE Mitchell movement for pair tournaments has been the method most widely used for duplicate contests since it was introduced by its inventor, John P. Mitchell, in 1892.

That bankers of this country are losing some of their recent absorption in political questions, and are becoming more interested in problems directly related to the profitable operation of their banks, was the conclusion drawn by numerous observers from events of the sixty-second annual convention of the American Bankers Association held in San Francisco last Monday to Thursday, inclusive.

THE new season, which according to all indications is to be a bumper one, is wasting no time in getting into action. With a greatly increased market for touring attractions as well as a healthy home demand, the dancers are apparently warmed up and ready to start as soon as the calendar says Oct. 1.

The newly formed American Football League will make its local bow this afternoon when the New York Yankees meet the Syracuse Braves, led by Morris (Red) Badgro, at Randalls Island Stadium. The game will get under way at 2:30 o'clock.

Moderate declines resulted from the trading in most of the commodity futures markets in the week ended on Friday, some liquidation here being attributed to American operators entering the French and certain other foreign markets, where exchange devaluation was anticipated.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The Post-Dispatch, in a copyrighted story from New York, said tonight that "partners in the banking firm of J.P. Morgan Co. paid virtually no income tax to the Federal Government on the profits of that international banking firm for the year 1935."

THE lifting to super-neons of Gladys George's fame is only on the face of it sudden, and far more difficult to explain is how the electricians have contrived to pack into one rim of the marquee the whole title of "Valiant Is the Word for Carrie."
LONDON, Sept. 26. -- It can't happen here, was in effect how Sir John Simon, the Home Secretary, disposed of the possibility of a dictatorship in Great Britain when he spoke at Perth today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25. -- The manoeuvres now drawing to a close in which the entire Soviet Red Army from Minsk to Vladivostok and from Leningrad to Tiflis has been thrown into the field are only the regular Autumn exercises, but they have been carried out on a grandiose scale in the midst of an international situation that gives them great military importance and probably political importance as well.

WHILE the Drama Festival was singing hosannas to Soviet Russia in Leningrad a few days ago, this correspondent hid away in Moscow, venturing out only to see performances at the Art Theatre. On the whole this was a sane policy.

LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 26. -- Franklin and Marshall, champions of the Eastern Pennsylvania Collegiate Conference, defeated Albright College, 7 to 6, today before 14,000 spectators. The Lancaster eleven will play Fordham in New York next Saturday.

TOKYO. -- A unique canal, excavated not from the land but under the sea, is to connect Tokyo and Yokohama, according to plans which have just been completed by the engineering department of the Home Office. It is part of an ambitious land reclamation scheme which will rescue from Tokyo Bay sufficient new land to provide Tokyo with an industrial zone comparable to that of Hamburg or Rotterdam.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The proposed devaluation of the franc caused great excitement today in financial London. The stock markets were closed as usual on a Saturday, and dealings in the foreign exchange market were suspended after the market had been open about a half hour.

BONNEVILLE, Ore., Sept. 25. -- The Federal dams being constructed here and at Grand Coulee, Wash., have assumed new political significance since the beginning of the campaign. Local enthusiasm over the giant irrigation, power and navigation projects on the Columbia River is regarded as one of the paramount reasons most straw polls and prognostications have credited the Pacific Northwest's electoral votes to Mr. Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, speaking tonight in the Municipal Stadium at a Tri-State rally of the National Union for Social Justice, reiterated his willingness to resort to the use of bullets to preserve American liberties should they be jeopardized by the rise of communism.

Captain Harry Manning sailed Friday for Plymouth and London in command of the American Merchant liner American Banker. He recently was promoted from chief officer of the United States liner Manhattan to succeed Captain William B. Oakley, who has been made master of the liner President Roosevelt.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 26. -- For the first time in seventeen years Muhlenberg gained a football victory over Lafayette today in a thrilling opening game by 19 to 6.

The Maccabees, soccer champions of Palestine, will make their American debut this afternoon at the Yankee Stadium when they oppose a team known as the All-Stars and composed of the leading players of the game in the country. The kickoff is set for 3 o'clock.

Harvest Day will be held Tuesday afternoon at the Children's Gardens, York Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, under the auspices of the New York Plant and Flower Guild. During the afternoon there will be a pageant displaying the vegetables and flowers found here at the period Henry Hudson purchased the island of Manhattan from the Indians.

Upward trends in the major lines of business last week were indicated by reports received here yesterday from the various Federal Reserve districts as the demand for Fall merchandise expanded as the result of more seasonable weather conditions.

THE new German society for aeronautical research named after the German pioneer Lilienthal, which has superseded all the older German aeronautical technical organizations, has invited three representatives of American aeronautics to attend its meeting to be held in Berlin in October. Dr. Clark B. Millikan of the California Institute of Technology will deliver a paper on American airplane design.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- British Governmental and financial circles were elated tonight at the news that the United States Treasury had used its stabilization fund to buy 1,000,000 which had been thrown onto the American market by the Soviet.

HENRY HOGG middle-aged sign painter just trying to get along in Washington. He got along fairly well, for he faithfully read Harvey Upp's column of administration gossip called "Washington Jitters." When Upp hinted at new appointments, Hogg dashed round to the new appointees and sold them signs bearing their new titles.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 25. -- Complete reorganization of the machinery through which the Quebec government imports and distributes wines and liquors to the inhabitants of this wine-drinking, French-speaking Canadian Province is among the radical changes which its new Premier, Maurice Duplessis, has been making since his sweeping victory in the election a few weeks ago.

The factors involved in improving fishing water are many and complex. It becomes increasingly evident that restocking alone will not suffice, that if better fishing is to be provided it is necessary to adopt management practices which will increase the capacities of the waters to produce.

SINCE the days of Washington's first election the political parties of the country have gone forth to the fray chanting their songs. Like the battle song, the campaign song is an institution of the human race, and words and music, as in other campaigns, play a part in the 1936 contest for the Presidency.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26. -- Characterizing the Roosevelt Social Security Act as "unjust, unworkable, stupidly drafted and wastefully financed," Governor Landon tonight pledged himself and the Republican party to amend it to provide old-age pensions for needy American citizens more than 65 years old financed on a commonsense, pay-as-you-go basis and large enough to give each such person a minimum income sufficient to protect him or her from want.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Sept. 24. -- Swarthmore College has started a new plan for voice and speech instruction under the supervision of Miss Beatrice Beach, director of dramatics, and Dr. Everett Hunt of the English Department.

The first complete test of the twentieth century's earth-enveloping facilities for commercial transportation will be begun this week by Leo Kieran for THE NEW YORK TIMES and the associated newspapers of the North American Newspaper Alliance.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- The Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, numbering among its members many of the world's noted scholars and scientists, will open its fourth year on Thursday. As in the past, no formal exercises will be held, the members quietly resuming studies and research which they put aside with the close of the Spring term last May.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 26. -- A light Randolph-Macon eleven for the second consecutive year held the heavy University of Richmond team to a 7-to-7 tie before 7,000 persons today.
CACERES, Spain, Sunday, Sept. 27. -- "Six hundred yards to go!" That was the dramatic message flashed from General Francisco Franco's leading Rebel column outside Toledo at midnight.

A CHRONICLE of one man's experiences during the World War, Warwick Deeping's new novel has in it little not already well known to the experienced reader. His leading character, whose journal these pages are supposed to present, is a country doctor, 35 years old.

Nine days ago Governor Lehman dismissed the charges brought by the Extraordinary Grand Jury against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn; he was "firmly convinced," he said after a hearing at Albany, that Mr. Geoghan "was an honest man."

TRUE to tradition, the week before a world series, mystery has surrounded the broadcasting plans. The radio engineers went to the Yankee Stadium and Polo Grounds to perfect their installations, but no definite announcement could be made by the stations that they would actually be on the scene for the play-by-play description.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 26. -- United States Senator A. Harry Moore of New Jersey and Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, will speak at Sunday morning services in Kirkpatrick Chapel, Rutgers University, during the current academic year, according to the list of lecturers announced today by Dr. Frazer Metzger, dean of men.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- An army of unemployed young men and women between the ages of 18 and 25 will be put to work on small conservation projects under a plan announced today by the National Youth Administration.
VIENNA, Sept. 25. -- The Austro-German peace agreement, which two short months ago was a European political sensation, has so far produced in practical results exactly nothing.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- A most representative crowd of society members of the North Shore colonies and their house guests attended the running of the Meadow Brook Cup steeplechase this morning over a course on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark.

While business continues to wrestle with the intricacies of the Patman anti-price discrimination law, the disclosure last week that Representative Patman will sponsor a new measure barring manufacturers from retailing was seen here yesterday as another "threat to the economy of large-scale distribution," an effort to "bulwark the wholesalers' position" and an advance indication that the next Congress will again be the battleground over legislation having further far-reaching effects upon both distribution and manufacturing.

At least one speaker at the conference on prisons and parole struck at the fundamental evil in our treatment of crime, corrupt politics. The speaker was Mrs. Blanche La Du, president of the American Prison Association. "It is not the theory of parole," she said, "but the administration of parole that is causing the trouble.

WITH lower railroad passenger rates there has come a great decline in the number of extra-fare trains. Today there are but nine trains in the whole country on which there is a "special service charge."

That the principal efforts of the French Government at home will be directed toward creating more favorable conditions regarding wages and earnings in farm and industrial lines is a general feeling in financial circles here. Preliminary steps already taken include the creation of a wheat board, which is to have absolute authority over the price, and exports and imports of wheat with similar bodies for coal, wine and other basic staples.

LIFE with father on the farm was a somewhat rough-hewn business, but all bespangled with the jewels of regal food. They lived simply. But -- even in a world innocent of refrigerator cars -- they ate like kings. And if father was as despotic and crochety a tyrant as ever .was managed by a level-headed and capable wife, well, he was a lovable tyrant for all that, and they had a good time.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Holy Cross opened its football season today with an easy victory over Bates, scoring 45 to 0, before 8,500 persons. The visitors were unable to make any headway against a powerful Crusader defense and registered only one first down.

More than a score of American Indians, fantastic in war paint and feathers and garbed in the ceremonial costumes of their various tribes, gathered around a council fire in the center of Long Meadow, Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon to celebrate American Indian Day.

A VISIBLE change comes over the city in these late September days, a change like the quickening of country life in April. The prospect of the best Fall business for the city in many years has nothing to do with the case, for the modulation occurs every year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Proposed changes in the official corn standards for this country were announced today by the Department of Agriculture. Officials said the changes would "tighten up regulations" on flint corn.

DEFERRED VACATION: When Harvard opens the 301st year of its existence tomorrow, its president, Dr. James Bryant Conant, will not be present, a rare situation at Cambridge. Dr. Conant has been pressed these past few months by the ceremonies attendant upon the university's tercentenary celebration, which ended eight days ago.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Willis Hudlin, dean of the Cleveland pitching staff, held the Tigers to five hits today to some his first victory on the eve of the season's end. The score was 5 to 3.

The Brooklyn Dodgers' football team, which showed speed and strength against Pittsburgh last Wednesday night despite its defeat, will attempt to break into the National League winning column this afternoon when it lines up against the Boston Redskins at Ebbets Field at 2:30 o'clock.
ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 26. -- The University of Georgia Bulldogs defeated a fighting Mercer University eleven today, 15 to 6.

RIO DE JANIERO, Sept. 26. -- The exchange market today operated without fixed rates because of the withdrawal of the Bank of Brazil from the market. Other Brazilian and foreign banks sold exchange only to cover drafts maturing today, usually at the exchange rates prevailing yesterday.

Cardinal Manuel Concalves Cerejeiva of Lisbon, Portugal, sailed for home yesterday on the Italian liner Vulcania after a six weeks' visit in this country as guest of the San Francisco archdiocese. Cardinal Cerejeiva came to the United States at the invitation of Archbishop John Mitty of San Francisco to preside at the sixth centenary celebration in honor of St. Elizabeth of Portugal.

SHE was a peasant. But she saved France. And when she stood before her judges in her hopeless trial at Rouen, they knew that she "had to be regarded as either saint or devil There was no middle course." Legends have grown up thick about her. Controversy has raged over her.
International developments in recent years have contributed mainly to unrest. World-wide political antagonisms have gone hand in hand with economic dislocations.

NEW LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The Coast Guard Academy and Wesleyan University elevens battled through sixty minutes of grand defensive football to a scoreless tie before 1,800 spectators today at Jones Field in the opening of the game season for both teams.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 26. -- Despite the fact that Coach Blaik sent his varsity and second teams to the showers after the third touchdown. Dartmouth today overwhelmed a fighting Norwich eleven, 58 to 0.

IN Part II of the sixth (and most recent) volume of Professor Chandler Rathfon Post's splendid "History of Spanish Painting," published by the Harvard University Press, the author confesses to many surprises and anomalies encountered in the course of his researches.

A JOINT international commission is now studying the desirability of a deep-water route between the Hudson and St. Lawrence Rivers. Whatever its decision may be, the present connecting waterway affords a fine cruising ground for the yachtsman.

HOOKED, braided and crocheted rugs and patchwork quilts, made by thrifty housewives of New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania, will be featured in the Domestic Arts and Crafts section of the New Jersey State Fair at Trenton, opening this afternoon.

MR. GRAY writes with a surgical deftness. But, though he has undertaken that most delicate of operations, the exposure of a human mind, there is no sickening odor of anesthesia about his novel, only a stinging, antiseptic quality.

EVERY day at this season of the year new broadcasts are introduced, but many of them from now on will be planned and rehearsed with the producer's fingers crossed because he is aware October in a Presidential campaign year gives politics the right-of-way on the air.

One hundred changes in the faculty at City College were announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president. They were authorized by the Board of Higher Education on Dr. Robinson's recommendation. These changes are to take effect on Jan. 1, 1937, except for Dr. Thomas R. Moore, who will retire at the end of the term. The list follows:

MORE and more the amateur gardener counts upon irises to supply the general color scheme for late Spring and early Summer. Indeed, by a careful selection of types, it is not difficult to have these dependable and easily cared for flowers in bloom from April to mid-July.

THIS volume, sixth in line of succession in the Whiteoak family saga, follows chronologically on the heels of "The Master of Jalna." Taken as a single novel, and not as one more chapter in a family history which promises to run on indefinitely, it is complete in itself.

FOR the first time in the history of physiological chemistry an enzyme, one of those chemical substances so vital in the processes of digestion and fermentation, actually has been observed at work and experimental proof has been provided for a theory held for more than half a century.

AMONG American Indians Malvina Hoffman is known as Mud Head. The name was given with respect. The Ainus of Japan, the Bushmen of Australia, the Zulus and Pygmies, the Shilluks and Sudanese of Africa, probably have similar names for her.

JOHANNESBURG, Union of South Africa. -- Germany is resorting to unusual methods to recapture the South African market, partly lost to her through a boycott on her goods. The boycott, though still maintained, shows signs of wearing off, and German goods are slowly finding their way back into the Union despite efforts of Great Britain to check the trend.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26. -- Led by two sensational sophomore halfbacks, the University of Pittsburgh eleven, rated a strong contender for Eastern honors, overwhelmed a game but powerless Ohio Wesleyan team, 53 to 0, at Pitt Stadium today.

BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- The Boerse responded to the devaluation of the franc with a strong upward movement today, some prices rising as much as 5 points. The move indicated that financial circles expect the mark to follow the franc sooner or later.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Plans for the publication of periodic reports showing the extent to which trading by members of Exchanges for their own account, on and off the floor, affects the total volume of trading are being perfected rapidly by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Combining vocationalized business training with the cultural aspects of a general college education, Hunter College offers this term an enlarged field of specialized business courses. These, added to the pre-medical, pre-social work and pre-journalism courses of study, mark a trend toward a curriculum that is regarded as adapted to the increasingly wide vocational field for women.

Fear that an "erroneous impression'' as to the general quality of housing in Queens had been created as the result of the recent survey which disclosed numerous violations of the Building Code was expressed yesterday by the Long Island Chamber of Commerce.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 26 (AP). -- W.H. Strang's Twilight Song won the Kentucky Futurity as the six-day grand circuit meeting got under way today. The victor lowered her own season's record for 2-year-old trotters to 2:03 1/2.

DALLAS, Sept. 26. -- Increased activity is reported for the week in all lines of business in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, with retail trade showing a sharp upward trend with the advent of cooler weather following general rains throughout the area.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 26. -- Penultimate concert of the season, by the Mexican composer and conductor, Carlos Chavez, was enthusiastically applauded by 3,000 persons who packed the Palacio de Bellas Artes to capacity last night.

ROME, Sept. 25. -- The League of Nations never has been popular in Italy, but now, since its decision not to exclude the Ethiopian delegation from the Assembly, nobody here has a single good word to say for it. "Those buffoons in Geneva," is the mildest title used when referring to it.

Claud Walck, substitute quarterback, passed and ran the Montclair State Teachers College eleven to a 12-6 victory over Brooklyn College at Lewisohn Stadium last night. Entering the game early in the first quarter in place of Neal Takala, who was injured on an end run, Walck proved an elusive foe for the Kingsmen.

GEORGE BERNARD SHAW, that inveterate letter writer whose recent invective leveled at the Hays office and the Legion of Decency seems, upon reflection and a check-up of facts, to have been misplaced, has termed all Hollywood authors "bellboys," and has declared he wants no part of the California proceedings.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26. -- The importance of the preservation of freedom of education and denunciation of religion and racial intolerance were Governor Landon's principal themes in short rear-platform talks in five Wisconsin cities as he traveled from Oshkosh to Milwaukee today.

It was just a few weeks ago that an apparently harmless little letter was delivered to the departmental desk, was pushed around for a few hours and finally, having fallen to the floor where it collected an overcoat of cigarette ashes and a few rubber-heel prints, was rescued, opened and read.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The Reds assured themselves of fifth place in the National League pennant race today by defeating Pittsburgh, 5 to 1. The defeat jolted the Pirates' hopes for third place.

The part played in everyday life and in industry by the physicist's contributions will be the theme of a combined meeting in New York of all the national physical societies Oct. 29-31, it was announced yesterday by the American Institute of Physics, which will commemorate its fifth anniversary at that time.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 26. -- A formal airing of charges of peonage growing out of the sharecropper system in the Eastern Arkansas Cotton Belt was made today as the result of investigations by a Governor's commission here and a Federal grand jury at Little Rock.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Miss Byrl J. Kellogg, chief of the Cortland (N.Y.) Free Library, was chosen today to succeed Frederic G. Melcher of Montclair, N.J., as head of the New York Library Association.

WOMEN must make up their minds to look on after-dark dressing in a new light this Autumn. There are many gradations of costume, ranging from the simplest little cocktail and dinner suit to Vionnet's backless and hoop-skirted triumph, which strips the shoulders and covers the head with a cloud of black lace.

Announcement that the French government would undertake devaluation with the assistance and cooperation of Great Britain and the United States affected the cotton market favorably yesterday. In sympathy with a sharp rise in Liverpool, strong outside markets and unfavorable weather in the cotton belt, prices moved upward to end with gains of 7 to 14 points.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Princeton University will begin its 190th academic year on Tuesday, when President Harold Willis Dodds greets the 640 entering freshmen at the traditional opening exercises in the university chapel.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Dr. Wayne W. Soper, research associate in the State Education Department, drew from dusty charts and files the conclusion today that the per capita cost of giving to Empire State youngsters an education is only slightly greater than it was a generation ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Plans to call in warehouse and private insurance experts were announced today after a meeting of the special committee named by President Roosevelt to formulate a crop insurance program for Congress.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 27. -- Fears that the Chino-Japanese crisis might pass immediately into action are subsiding further as reports come in that the Emperor is quietly carrying out his prearranged program of public engagements in the northern island of Hokkaido.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Autumn is often said to be the most delightful time of year in the Alleghenies. Now Jack Frost transforms the green of Summer leaves into warm colors.

NEW SALEM, in Illinois, for six years the home of Abraham Lincoln, revives the atmosphere of a village of the pioneers in the West in the early years of the past century. Reconstruction of the town, which passed out of existence in 1839, was begun in 1932, and has continued since with the help of the Civilian Conservation Corps under the direction of the Illinois Department of Public Works and Buildings.

IN theory the Anglo-Italian tension of last Autumn disappeared with sanctions, but in reality it has done anything but disappear. It has died away at one end of the Mediterranean only to turn up in more dangerous form at the other end. In the Spanish civil war it has raised issues whose scope is European rather than merely Mediterranean.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26. -- Reports of a highly encouraging nature were received this week on industrial activity in the Eighth Federal Reserve District. Employment of large numbers of workers and a general speeding up by large and small industries are evident.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 26. -- The news of stabilization of the French franc and of the agreement between the three great financial powers has been received with almost delirious joy in Belgium.

The record of the electoral vote for President in the last twelve elections reveals clearly the States which in past campaigns have been the real battle grounds of the parties. Though political history does not necessarily repeat itself, and this year's election may not follow previous patterns, the accompanying chart indicates a good deal about American voting habits.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Harold B. Johnson, editor and publisher of The Watertown Times, suggested in a statement today an eight-point Republican State platform based on the party's national platform.

DEMOCRATIC education does not necessarily mean mass education. It means, in the best sense, exactly the opposite. For if education is to be genuinely democratic, if it is to serve the needs of a democratic community, it must be directed away from standardization and mechanization toward individual training and development.

THE narrator through whose lips the author tells this tale is an alcoholic who has voluntarily entered a sanitarium to be cured of his craving for liquor. The sanitarium is really, as the narrator expresses it, "an expensive nuthouse."

COURSES in landscaped architecture at Columbia University, under the direction of Professor Hugh Findlay, which had been popular in recent years, will be continued this season. Laboratory work in connection with the classes will be conducted in the agricultural greenhouse at 116th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Northern New Jersey's country supper clubs, which in the past Summer attracted 50 per cent more Essex, Union, Passaic and Morris County society folk than in any previous Summer, are preparing for a continuance of their increasing popularity now that the football season is approaching.

THIS book comes as a beneficent bolt from the blue. The previously published three volumes of letters, mainly to Theo, promised to be all the autobiographical material we should have -- and they constitute, as a matter of fact, one of the most extraordinary documents in the entire realm of art.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- Nearly 40,000 persons crowded the east and west stands today, between social engagements, to see the last of the international polo matches between the Argentines and the Greentree team, which represented the United States.

CLINTON, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Students and members of the faculty at Hamilton College are now able to obtain pictures by famous masters from the library galleries, just as they draw books from the library shelves. The idea resembles that used for several years by the Hamilton Music Department, which permits the borrowing of volumes of phonograph records for use in fraternity or dormitory rooms.

OF all countries deserving of literary attention Mexico ranks well near the top. Its new accessibility, both by highway and steamship, and also a now stable government have made of it a haven for the weary traveler. The tour-loving public has been swamped with volume after volume of "Mexican Maze," "Mexican Holiday," "Mexican Adventure," and a dozen other Mexican attributes. Here is another contribution to the cause.

LOUIS D. BRANDEIS is the most important, misunderstood man of our times. Being an appointed judge instead of an elected official he has been able to maintain an economic blue print without tactical compromises and with only such deviations as his own shifts in opinion have dictated.

The latest official action looking toward permanent relief of Hunter College's chronic housing shortage -- a shortage made more acute than ever by last week's large entering class -- is contained in a memorandum now being studied by the Director of the Budget.

Still scarred from the fighting of 1932, Shanghai, world's sixth largest city, was appalled again last week by the rumble of Japanese tanks and cannon caissons, the gleam of machine guns and bayonets.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 26. -- Cancer treated in time by surgery, X-rays and radium is very often curable.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Captain Bill Craig blocked a punt in the fourth period today and Middlebury defeated Union College, 7 -- 0. John Kirk, sophomore end, fell on the ball in the end zone for the touchdown and George Anderson added a point from placement.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 26. -- Fighting desperately to ward off a goal-ward drive in the last moments, Tulane's Green Wave eked out a 7-6 victory over the University of Mississippi today before a crowd of 18,000.

CARRYING out the mandate of Parliament, Prime Minister King has appointed nine governors of a Canadian Radio Corporation to take over the supervision of the Dominion's broadcasting system on Nov. 2. The governors will replace the existing Canadian Radio Commission comprised of three members.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Programs representing widely different student interests, religious, secular and musical, have been planned for undergraduates of New Jersey College for Women during the current semester. Laymen and ministers of many denominations will speak at student assemblies and services and programs will be presented by musicians, largely members of the college faculty.

THE young author of this striking first novel is an American journalist who for some years past has worked on the staffs of English language newspapers published in China. From the knowledge and experience of the Orient thus gained he has told, with consummate interest, a story of the Fourth Estate as it exists today under British and American direction in the principal Chinese cities.

HAVANA, Sept. 26. -- The police today captured Guillermo Ara, who was a police captain during the Grau San Martin regime and is one of the leaders of the outlawed revolutionary organization Joven Cuba, together with six companions in a raid on an apartment building in the suburb of Vedado.

Both major parties in New York are awaiting the action of their State conventions this week to enter upon the final and most aggressive stage of their campaigns. The State conventions will be held tomorrow and Tuesday, the Democrats meeting at Syracuse and the Republicans at Albany.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 28. -- The Luzerne County Court has asked Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti to assign a special prosecutor to relieve District Attorney Leon Schwartz in the trial of Emerson Jennings, Wilkes-Barre civic leader, who is accused of bombing the automobile of Judge W.A. Valentine during the insurgent strike at the collieries of the Glen Alden Coal Company last year.
VIENNA, Sept. 26. -- The German eagle is once again hovering over Central Europe and the diplomatic dovecotes consequently are all aflutter.

VETERAN yet abounding in energy, Mr. Wells is a celebrity who has fairly earned his prestige. He started with nothing. He had to learn everything that he has learned. Yet he is by no means a megalomaniac when he hints that he has become a Diderot brought up to date, the encyclopedist of the twentieth century.

Except for sharp recessions in the prices of France's dollar loans on only a few sales, the market for bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was undisturbed by the overnight announcement of the proposed devaluation of the French franc.

NEARING the end of an unusually short retooling period, car manufacturers are rapidly swinging into production of 1937 models. Men are being hired by the thousands, materials and parts are being delivered to car factories in increasing volume, and the roads around Detroit soon again will be alive with new cars being trucked to distant dealers.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 26. -- After spotting P.M.C. an early lead, the Villanova eleven easily defeated the Chester cadets in the Main Line stadium today, 32 to 7.

IN many a Southwestern town there is a battle brewing over the treatment of trailer tourists, with local merchants lining up against the proprietors of tourist camps and hotels. Here in the wide-open spaces, where the distances between even small villages are great, the tourist camps and small hotels have for years been doing a profitable business.

Details of a treaty between the United States and Canada that is expected to be promulgated soon to reduce serious haddock depletion caused by methods in the fishing industry were worked out Friday at the annual meeting of the North American Council on Fishery Investigation.

A probationary patrolman, not yet provided with a uniform and the assurance it gives, in his first night on duty last night captured one man suspected of passing counterfeit coins in the Third Avenue shopping district, near 168th Street, the Bronx; aided in the arrest of another and seized fifty-five spurious 50-cent pieces.

LEADING a life of extraordinary adventure and continuous combat, a picturesque little army has been campaigning in China for a decade and still remains almost unknown. This organization, the Chinese Marine Corps, is so small, and the manner in which it has accomplished its difficult tasks has been so quietly efficient, that only recently has it been attracting attention.

HERE is the stuff of the old West. The authenticity of the material in "A Rider of the Cherokee Strip" is attested by the Cherokee Strip Cowpunchers Association and further emphasized by a professor of history, but the reader will not need to turn to these introductory pages to get the tang of reality from this cowboy's memoirs.

WHEN Major Bowes and his amateurs did not keep their rendezvous with the Sunday evening microphone for some listeners no doubt it was almost as if the sun had failed to rise on schedule. No broadcast has led the popularity polls so long; no show ever evoked such a demand for studio tickets.
FORT LARAMIE, Wyo., Sept. 26 (AP). -- The National Park Service hopes to restore crumbling Fort Laramie to a semblance of its riotous youth, as a landmark in the winning of the West.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Sept. 25. -- When future economists come to write the history of the past five years in the Irish Free State, they are likely to treat of it as a period of remarkable industrial revolution since more has happened during those few years to change the industrial life of the country than had occurred in the entire preceding century.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Luis Companys, President of the autonomous Catalonian State, announced tonight that Joseph Tarradellas had been named head of a new Cabinet organized after a government crisis.

McMURRAY, Alta., Sept. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Five months out of New York on a canoe journey to Nome, Alaska, Sheldon P. Taylor and Geoffrey W. Pope paddled down the Athabaska River today on their last lap before Winter closes navigation.

Your recent editorial discussing Newton D. Baker's article "Why We Went to War" contains the sentence: "What, then, about the manufacturers of munitions and the international bankers who, according to the later theory advanced by the Nye committee, forced or deceived our government into declaring war?"

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Long Island Sound's last of twenty-three championship regattas of the season was held today by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club, and the racing craft won their titles for the year. They are as follows:

BY a coincidence that looks almost like a dispensation of fate Clemens Krauss and Felix Weingartner have been ousted at virtually the same time from operatic jobs each was to have held for five years and that both filled for just about the same period.

In the Presidential campaign last week there was heavy firing along the agricultural front. The two leading candidates, using different tactics, pushed ahead vigorously, each trying to gain the farm vote. That vote is of vital importance since the farm States may prove decisive in the election results.
SYDNEY, Australia. POLICE descended on the Savoy Theatre here when a band of amateur players was presenting Clifford Odets's drama "Till the Day I Die" and attempted to ban the performance.

Commodities needed for reasonably assured manufacturing schedules should be purchased for three to six months ahead, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents pointed out yesterday in a report describing steady improvement in national industrial activity.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 26. -- With the opening of Smith College on Tuesday, the two new dormitories, Laura Scales House and Franklin King House, which complete the quadrangle unit, will be opened to 120 students. Over 30 per cent of the undergraduate body will then be housed in the quadrangle dormitories.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The St. Louis Post-Dispatch (independent), which supported Democratic candidates in the last five Presidential campaigns, announced tonight that it "cannot support Mr. Roosevelt for re-election to the Presidency."

The American residential subdivision so generally accepted as the proper thing in this country is a type of development little known in European lands, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, who has just completed a visitation tour of the leading housing centers in Great Britain and on the Continent.

IN these times of well-organized flower shows with special exhibits of herb gardens, and of color prints of plants and flowers in shop windows, it seems hard to realize that once such helps were generally unavailable, the only information on gardening being confined to the old herbals.
LEXINGTON, Va., Sept. 26. -- Washington and Lee, showing powerful offensive, defeated Elon College, 27 -- 0, on Wilson Field today. Wilson Sample, fullback, scored two touchdowns for the Generals.

THOSE who are fascinated by the Fall knitting styles as advanced by Paris can knit copies of some of the dresses that appeared in the season's collections.
