Graduates of the skirt-and-sweater class who feel competent to tackle intricate stitches and to follow more complicated designs will find a New York shop in possession of fifteen original models from Paris.

SOMETHING over five years ago one of this country's leading playwrights -- George Kelly is the name -- took one long, rueful glance at the theatre and shook the dust of Broadway from his feet. He had, said he, about enough.

SPICY aromas throughout the house; the sound of the chopping board in the big kitchen; kettles simmering and steaming on the wood stove, and long rows of mason jars ready to go on the shelves in the pantry.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Ernest Biegazski took his first ride this afternoon in the barrel in which he hopes to sail across the Atlantic to Europe and found it would float without leaking.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 25. --The South is divided this week in debate on Mississippi's plan, sponsored by Governor White, for attracting industries by giving cities and counties power to purchase factories to be leased, sold or donated to industrial enterprises.

A "testament of maturity" to which 212 feminine careerists contributed data about themselves, their jobs, obstacles encountered and how they overcame them is contained in the report on a survey released yesterday by Dr. Iva Lowther Peters through the National Federation of Business and Professional Women.
WE worry. We worry too much. We worry ourselves into illness and mental upheaval. And yet, if we only knew it, our trouble is not really that we worry, but that we don't worry right.

ALTHOUGH the season has hardly dawned, two new galleries have already opened on New York's art equator. Hudson D. Walker, grandson of the Minneapolis collector, has taken quarters at 38 East Fifty-seventh Street and Florence Tricker, who pioneered in the Gramercy region last year, is located at 19 West Fifty-seventh.

SEATTLE, Sept. 26. -- Still on a triumphant rampage, the University of Minnesota opened its 1936 football season today with its eighteenth consecutive victory, smashing the touted University of Washington Huskies, 14 to 7, before a capacity throng of 37,000 in Washington Stadium.
Contending Teams -- New York Yankees, champions of the American League; New York Giants, champions of the National League.

HARRISBURG, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The Dauphin County Court directed the Secretary of the Commonwealth today to accept the Royal Oak and Union party nomination papers of thirteen Philadelphia and twenty-eight Allegheny (Pittsburgh) Republican candidates for Congress and the Legislature.

LANCASTER, N.H., Sept. 26. -- There will be field trials today for fox and coon on the Lancaster estate of Sinclair Weeks, which White Mountains sportsmen will attend. The hunting season for birds and small game will open on Thursday and deer hunting on Oct. 15.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- The play-by-play description of the second match of the polo series between the United States and Argentina, contested on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today, follows:

JASPER, Ala., Sept. 26. -- Miners, farmers and other union members in the newest development of Alabama's strange school strike have threatened to picket Walker County schools that remain open Monday. Tension has been growing since two weeks ago when the school year began.

WILL DURANT set himself the difficult task of writing the story of civilization in five volumes, of which the initial one -- "Our Oriental Heritage" -- appeared last year. Simon Schuster have reprinted its first section, in essence a preface to the complete work, under the title of "The Foundations of Civilization" ($1).

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Coincidental with the return of communities operating on daylight time to standard time tomorrow, two railroads serving Chicago announced faster schedules and several new trains.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The Treasury said today that imports of cattle weighing 700 pounds or more under the Canadian trade agreement were nearing quota figures and that, effective Monday, importers would be required to deposit duties at the full tariff rate.

SOON after 6 o'clock on Tuesday morning, thirteen airplanes will roar away from Portsmouth airdrome at one-minute intervals to race to Johannesburg, 7,200 miles away, for $50,000 in prizes offered in connection with the gold city's Empire Exhibition.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 26. -- The government's scheme for reducing peasant indebtedness, published tonight, brought protests from bankers, who contend most banks will be forced to close. Big banks are already calling in credits from smaller banks which seem doomed.

THE third annual National Motor Truck Show conducted by the New Jersey Motor Truck Association will be held in Newark from Nov. 3 to 7 in Newark Center Market Building. Governor Harold G. Hoffman has designated this period as Motor Truck Transportation Week and will issue a proclamation to that effect, it is reported.

ARMONK, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The Westchester Embassy Club here will be the scene next Saturday evening of a supper dance to aid the Irvington House for Cardiac Children, Irvington-on-Hudson. Mrs. Grover A. Whalen is chairman of the benefit.

VIENNA. LUDWIG KARPATH, the eminent critic and journalist who recently died here at the age of 70, was a nephew of Karl Goldmark and, consequently, a cousin of the late American composer, Rubin Goldmark.

THE past few years have seen quite a distinct tendency toward the earlier planting of daffodils. Such plantings may hasten only a little the season of bloom in the Spring, but they enable the bulbs to make a strong root growth before freezing weather.

People who have wanted a national debate should be well pleased as they tune up their radios for the night of Oct. 1 and assure themselves that their favorite newspaper will surely be on hand for breakfast the next morning.

AT this season of the year many householders are completely doing over their houses and apartments; more, perhaps, are partly redecorating. To conserve the best of one's old furnishings is both good practice and good sense; it gives the home a continuity which it lacks when everything old is discarded.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- At the first opportunity offered today the United States made good on its pledge to protect the three-power monetary agreement between this Government and France and Great Britain, when it threw nearly $5,000,000 of its stabilization fund into the exchange market to halt what officials at first considered an attempt by Russia to drive down the pound sterling.

FROM Stuart Davis, national executive secretary of the National Executive Board of the American Artists Congress, a long communication has been received in which exception is taken to the article (appearing in these columns last Sunday) on the Federal Art Project and the selected work, done under the project, now exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26. -- The following unusual prayer was offered at the Landon meeting in the Milwaukee Auditorium tonight by the Rev. John F. Fedders, pastor of the First Lutheran Church:

The Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science (The University in Exile) will begin its fourth year of instruction tomorrow at the New School for Social Research with a program that gives evidence that these exiled scholars are "making themselves at home" with domestic as well as world problems, according to an announcement issued yesterday by the school.

KINDERHOOK, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Twenty historical, civic and fraternal organizations joined today in an endeavor to have New York State preserve Lindenwald, the 184-acre estate of Martin Van Buren here, as a permanent memorial to the nation's eighth President.
Manhattan opened the local intercollegiate football season at Randalls Island yesterday and at the same time uncovered a team of promise.

The family called him Ulysses after another wanderer, but his odyssey was ended on the night when, with frosted whiskers and snow on his back, he tapped his paw with a fine self-respect on the front door of the big, white house in New Hampshire.

The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday turmed "justifiable" $12,000,000 of the more than $37,000,000 in budget increases sought by city departments for 1937. This $12,000,000 can be provided, the commission held, and at the same time taxpayers can receive lower tax bills next year.

The stock market rallied briskly yesterday on the over-night news of the decision to devalue the franc and especially on the assurances of strong cooperation in the matter of the part of the United States and Great Britain. Word that Switzerland and Holland would follow France's lead came after the closing and occasioned no surprise.

Granville did the expected at Belmont Park yesterday when he won the forty-fourth Lawrence Realization, but he did it in such a manner before 20,000 persons that the rolling applause was his which usually goes only to the victor in a bitterly fought battle.

The financial community generally concurred in the views expressed last week by the Secretary of the Treasury, Henry Morgenthau Jr., that no serious repercussion on financial institutions here could result from the heavy imports of gold in the last two years. Mr. Morgenthau's opinions were contained in a reply to an inquiry by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan as to the possible effect on our monetary system of the gold-purchase policy of the United States Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Democratic and Republican bidding for agriculture's political support, climaxed by President Roosevelt's new plans for crop insurance, land-use laws and farm-tenant aid and by Governor Landon's pledge of Republican subsidies at Des Moines, has made the farmer the country's most "unforgotten man."

WHEN the air turns crisp and chill winds and storms bring the first hint that Winter is on the way, thousands of New Yorkers pack their new Fall suits in their old Summer bags and take the trail to the Midsouth.

Marked buying activity was noted in most departments last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Wetting Howell, Inc. Mail orders were heavy. Dress purchases stressed short-sleeved street and "bar" styles. The straight-front skirt with back fullness is newer than the all-around "swing" styles.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 26. -- Under a hot sun and before 7,000 spectators, the University of Tennessee opened its 1936 football season today by defeating Chattanooga University, 13 -- 0.
SAN ANGELO, Texas, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The threat of floods along the Rio Grande and in West Texas decreased tonight as high waters began sinking toward normal levels.
PARIS, Sept. 26. -- The French Government tonight prepared to "crack down" at the first signs of public disorder growing out of the plan to devalue the franc.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Arthur T. O'Leary, prominent Catholic layman and intimate friend of James A. Farley and Alfred E. Smith, made public today at his law offices here a letter he sent last Tuesday to Mr. Farley in which he declared he could not vote for President Roosevelt because the name of David Dubinsky, labor leader, was on the list of the Democratic Presidential electors from this State.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Five States -- Pennsylvania, Michigan, Ohio, Illinois and Indiana -- were termed by Colonel Frank Knox the "real battlefield" of 1936 politics.

TRENTON, Sept. 26. -- A more equitable distribution to municipalities of public service electric and gas company tax moneys paid to the State is sought in an application before the State Board of Tax Appeals.

Vice President John N. Garner announced yesterday that he would make his first speech of the campaign in about two weeks. The exact time and place of the address will be determined within a few days, he said after conferences with James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, and other party advisers.

A memorial to the late Simon F. Rothschild, former president of the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., will be dedicated this afternoon at 1:15 o'clock by Colonel Julius Ochs Adler, successor in that office. Walter N. Rothschild, son of the late philanthropist and clubman, will accept the memorial.

HARRY PRICE is, as an indignant Poltergeist is said to have protested, a "man who puts the kybosh on the spirits." He has been investigating psychic phenomena for thirty years, and he was the founder and director of the British National Laboratory of Psychical Research, which was absorbed by the University of London in 1934.
LONDON, Sept. 25. -- Neither Hitler, Mussolini nor Stalin is freer from internal, effective political opposition to his foreign policy than is the British Government at present.

A.J. McCarthy, vice president and general manager of the International Mercantile Marine Company, said yesterday he did not expect that a strike of Pacific Coast maritime employes would result this week from the demands submitted by the Coast unions to the ship lines.

The State convention of the Socialist party, meeting yesterday at 21 East Seventeenth Street, affirmed a full slate of State-wide candidates, headed by Dr. Harry W. Laidler, candidate for Governor, which had been nominated last June. The affirmation were unanimous.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

The calling of bonds for payment before maturity increased last week as several of the country's leading corporations announced plans for retiring large notices of bonds. Payment dates in the new notices were in distant months, leaving the total of $195,048,000 for September unchanged from a week before.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Uncertainty whether business in general would make a full seasonal gain over the high levels of August was expressed today in the weekly survey of the Department of Commerce.

NORTON, Mass., Sept. 26. -- President Edgar Park's tenth anniversary at Wheaton coincides with the opening of college and will be celebrated with a dinner given by the Faculty Club on Oct. 5, the day on which Dr. Park came to Norton to live in the "Wheaton Homestead" ten years ago.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Cornell's 1936 gridiron model featured a high-powered attack before 10,000 fans at Schoelkopf Field today in running up a 74-to-0 victory over Alfred University. Eleven touchdowns were tallied in the rout.

Despite the pleas of trade association executives, most manufacturers have not yet decided what price policy to follow in regard to extra costs resulting from the Social Security Law, it was said here yesterday. Prices can be advanced only where a market is in a strong technical position, according to comments, and where Buyers are not likely to resist such rises.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The kind of boat races that thrill-hungry crowds wait years to see produced speed, spills and accidents on the muddy, brown Potomac today and left the classic President's Cup feature in doubt for another twenty-four hours.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- Argentina completed its polo trip in a smashing success today when the blue-shirted riders from the Pampas won the second and deciding game of the Cup of the Americas series from the United States at 8 goals to 4.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, director of the old-age pension plan, was angered today when he learned that Daniel J. Tobin was permitted to broadcast an appeal for funds for the Democratic war chest Friday night in New York from station WJZ, a National Broadcasting Company station.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The constructional value represented by building permits in the first eight months of 1936 in 770 cities having a population of 10,000 or more amounted to $884,129,000, a rise of 74 per cent over the corresponding period last year, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins made known today.

BARNEGAT CITY, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Concern has been expressed over the condition of the historic Barnegat Light, reported early this week to be leaning seaward and threatened with immediate undermining by the waters of Barnegat Inlet. Barnegat residents, however, do not share this fear.

BILBAO, Spain, Sunday, Sept. 27. -- The first naval battle of the Spanish civil war appeared imminent today as five government warships were reported steaming under full speed to northern ports blockaded by Rebel vessels.

GENEVA, Sept. 26. -- Hope of an early examination of the Palestine disorders by the Mandates Commission ended today. Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden informed the Council of the League of Nations that Britain, before giving information sought by that body, must await the findings of the royal commission of inquiry and it could not begin to investigate until order was restored.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Mrs. Kirby Ramsey's Mucho Gusto, which won the Peabody Memorial Handicap, a week ago, captured the $2,500 Lincoln Handicap at Lincoln Fields today in a pouring rain. Bandalore, from the Rosedale Stable, was second and F.P. Lettelier's Billbo third.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26. -- Names of bankers and business men were included in the list of nearly 400 passengers on the Panama Pacific liner California as she sailed for New York today via Los Angeles Harbor, Acapulco, Panama and Havana.

There are six stories about Reggie Fortune in this volume. As mysteries they are both clever and ingenious, but Reggie Fortune's pose of being bored to extinction by the business of investigating crime is more than a trifle wearisome.

THIS account, in the first person singular, of Jimson Andrews's Main Street adventure is so self-consciously written and so replete with earnestly delivered cliches that it is embarrassing and unnerving.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Eighteen years ago today at dawn the American First Army started its pivotal attack which smashed the Hindenburg line on the western front and forced the imperial German command to sue for armistice.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP). -- A maniac was blamed today for the assault on Alda Deery as the New York show girl lay in a serious condition at a hospital.

FROM late September until Spring an increasing number of American motorists, who apparently are never able to stay long in any one place, restlessly cross and recross the Southwestern States of Arizona and New Mexico as they head to and from California.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The University of Southern California's Trojans scored a smashing victory over the Oregon State College Beavers, 38 to 7, today.

PAUL BAKEWELL Jr., lawyer and sometime Professor of Law, is not an economist. He views the problems of money solely as an issue of constitutional law, long since settled by Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution, a Supreme Court decision of 1827, and the Coinage Act of 1873.
ALBANY, Sept. 26. -- Storm signals are flying as the Republican clans gather here in preparation for their State convention, which will be called to order at noon on Monday.
The biggest betting series in history is forecast by Jack Doyle, veteran commissioner, for the Yankee-Giant struggle starting Wednesday at the Polo Grounds.

The New York University Division of General Education under the direction of Ned H. Dearborn has enlarged the experimental group of science courses, it was announced at the university yesterday. Fifteen new courses have been added to the five given last semester, when the series was inaugurated.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 26. -- The fortieth annual Bryn Mawr horse show closed today with Mrs. Ellsworth H. Augustus's chestnut gelding Chatter Chat adjudged the champion hunter. Mrs. Owen B. Toland's Justa Boy annexed the reserve award.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Advance applications for admission to Cornell University, which opens Monday, have been more national in character than at any time in the past five years.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, praises Professor Nelson Glenn McCrea, now entering his thirty-seventh year as Anthon Professor of the Latin Language and Literature at Columbia, as "a master interpreter of ancient Greece and Rome in terms of the intellectual and moral needs of today and tomorrow" in a foreword to "Literature and Liberalism'' by Professor McCrea, soon to be issued by the Columbia University Press.
PARIS, Sept. 24. -- Some of the new dressy hats are actual copies of officers' kepis, the front being embroidered with metal oak leaves, laurel, blades of wheat and similar motifs.

The American Academy of Opthalmology and Otolaryngology, largest medical association of specialists in the world, will open its forty-first annual convention today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. More than 2,500 eye and ear-nose-throat doctors from this country and Canada will attend meetings and clinics until Saturday, when about 100 will sail for Bermuda to play golf.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Featured on the week's social program here is a first annual puppy show, sponsored by the Asheville Kennel Club and sanctioned by the American Kennel Club. The show, which will be held on Saturday at the Tyler Building, will attract more than 150 entries from many sections of the South.

Even though H.G. Wells is accustomed to dealing with great periods of time and space he is, in writing his own obituary and even taking into account its humorous aspect, away off in his calculations. The man who can cover all time and history and embrace it in one volume certainly should not regard twenty-seven years as a long time.
HARRISBURG, Sept. 26. -- Governor Earle plans within the next two years to get Pennsylvania farmers out of the mud permanently through the expenditure of more than $50,000,000 on stabilized roads.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- Developments of the last week have shown that months of agitation, preliminary investigation and denials have failed to quiet the fears agitating some Philadelphia citizens that communistic teachings are being countenanced in the public schools.

The Manufacturers Housing Promotion Council, organized by a group of leading manufacturers of building materials and equipment to conduct a nation-wide promotional campaign for better housing, announced plans yesterday for thirty displays and housing shows in various parts of the country during the coming year to emphasize the value of "quality construction."
UNIONTOWN, Pa., Sept. 26 (AP). -- The Fayette County Court ordered the September grand jury to reconvene Tuesday to investigate the death of Frank C. Monaghan, 64, a hotel owner.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26. -- Isaac H. Clothier 3d of Gwynedd Valley, Morgan Reichner of New York and Henry Redmond, also of New York, were hosts tonight at a dance for Miss Sally Ann Chapman, debutante daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John P. Chapman of Overbrook.

A campaign to increase the enrollment in the schools conducted by the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, and thus to further the work of Catholic action and strengthen the fight against communism, was outlined yesterday at a luncheon of Catholic leaders in the Center Club, 120 Central Park South.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Sept. 27. -- An intimation that the Japanese Army intends landing forces on Chinese soil in the Yangtse Valley and possibly elsewhere was given yesterday by Major Gen. Seiichi Kita, the Japanese Military Attache.

ANDOVER, N.J., Sept. 26. -- A 900-pound mass of iron and stone, believed to be a meteorite, is presenting a perplexing problem to the 500 residents of this borough. For the last three weeks the unattractive ornament has decorated the front lawn of Roy Van Sickle and the borough officials are at a loss to know just what to do with it.

Twenty-nine German motion pictures, the first contingent of the rare films which were acquired abroad this Summer, have arrived at the Museum of Modern Art Film Library, it is announced by John Hay Whitney, president of the library.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Miss Mary Charlotte Lane of Corning, N.Y., will hold the Sarah Williston Senior Prize Scholarship at Mount Holyoke College during the present academic year. The award is given annually to the ranking senior provided she has attended the college for three years and was elected a Sarah Williston Scholar in her sophomore year.

The franc crisis dominated the markets last week. Stock prices moved indecisively until Friday when traders, appreciating that the battle to prevent devaluation of the franc was over, sold stocks in a nervous market. Yesterday, heartened by the skillful manner in which the French action was handled, the stock market regained about two-thirds of the Friday losses.

For residents of Queens who wish to take courses in the Fall session of the WPA Adult Education Program of the Board of Education, six centers have been opened for registration this week. Many centers used in the Spring and Summer sessions will be reopened and others are expected to be added in a short time.

WASHINGTON. -- Americans are drinking less tea than they did a few years ago, according to the 1936 report of the United States tea examiners, which reveals changes in the types of tea in favor with the consumer. Since 1934 green tea has shown a slow but steady decline, Oolong tea has held its own, while black tea has grown consistently in favor.

A new class of marine radio-telegraph service by which passengers on transoceanic vessels may send radiograms to all parts of the United States at rates substantially lower than for regular service was announced yesterday by the Radio-marine Corporation of America, a subsidiary of the R.C.A.

Further restoration of the American school system toward normal operation is seen by John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, in his outlook on conditions as the 1936-37 academic year begins.

WEBSTER CITY, Iowa, Sept. 26 (AP). -- David Hunter took time off from his chores today to say a young farmer should be able to run a $4.88 stake into land and equipment worth $30,000 in twenty years' time.

FORT SAM HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 26 (AP). -- War games testing the army's frontier defenses spread to a national scale today as an imaginary invading "Black" army suddenly shifted three divisions from the Gulf Coast to the Eastern seaboard to aid an assumed attack on the capital.

Cooper Union has begun its seventy-sixth year with an enrollment of about 1,800 men and women, including 501 freshmen selected competitively from 3,081 candidates. Instruction in the Institute of Technology, day engineering department, will start tomorrow with 350 students registered, 100 of whom comprise the entering class.

MR. FICKE'S observations in verse are neither subtle nor musical, but they are gracefully written and as authentic as a carefully kept diary. There are nature poems and a last "Evening Dialogue" in which Mr. Ficke regretfully refuses any faith in revealed religion.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 25. -- New vigor has been injected into the campaign for permanent registration of voters in Baltimore by the revelation that many thousands of registered voters on the poll books are actually missing, removed from the State or dead.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 25. -- The Committee for Industrial Organization, formed last November by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and a group of associates to further the cause of industrial unionism in the mass production industries, is at present involved in a storm of inter-union controversy which extends from the Atlantic to the Pacific, and which affects several important industries.

THOUGH he left half a dozen of them, should mention be made of Haydn's concerto for 'cello and orchestra, that in D may be taken for granted. Even that is not complete identification, however, for this was one of Haydn's proclivities, and another of the six is in the same key.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 26. -- The importance of the gold fields of Quebec, Canada's second ranking gold-producing province, has attracted increasing attention from the geological survey branch of the Federal Department of Mines, and official surveys were started this week in seven sections of Northwestern Quebec.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The government made public today a detailed report showing its financial operations under the $4,880,000,000 Emergency Relief Appropriation Act of 1935. The report which is a printed volume of more than 500 pages of text, graphs and tables, was prepared in the Treasury Department and was released for publication through the National Emergency Council.

The decision of the French Government to devalue the franc with the cooperation of the United States and Britain evoked a favorable response in financial circles yesterday. Leading bankers said it was an important step toward recovery from monetary chaos.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The 275th birthday celebration of Mamaroneck closed today with a parade witnessed by more than 10,000 persons, a pageant at Harbor Island and dances sponsored by the American Legion and the anniversary committee.

LONDON, Sept. 23. -- Next week's openings are these: On Monday at Covent Garden is Sir John Martin-Harvey's fortnight's revival of "Oedipus Rex." Also, at Victoria Palace is "Let's Raise the Curtain," a revue postponed because of the death of Florence Desmond's husband, the aviator, T. Campbell Black.

Mrs. Helen Lehman Buttenwieser, a niece of Governor Lehman, and wife of Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, a partner in the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Company of 52 William Street, will begin serving a clerkship tomorrow in a prominent law office downtown, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHARACTERS and scenes in this book," says Mr. Cary in his foreword, "are fictitious." His account of the women's war set going by Elizabeth, otherwise Lisbet, the Nigerian ju-ju priestess -- surely one of the most extraordinary heroines of modern fiction -- "must not," he adds, "be taken to refer in any way to the women's wars in Southern Nigeria during the last ten years."

"Oscar of the Waldorf," who was born Oscar Tschirky, will be 70 years old tomorrow. There will be a deluge of congratulatory messages from all parts of the country and Europe, as usual, but the event will not be observed with any sort of celebration if the famous host of the Waldorf-Astoria can prevent it.

AMONG those who watched the take-off of the Deutsche Lufthansa flying boat Aeolus for the Azores by way of the most powerful catapult aboard ship anywhere in the world were many representatives of American air-transport companies.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Behind the spectacular passing and running of Marty Fishbein and Jerry Bonavita, Panzer College overpowered East Stroudsburg Teachers College today, 20 to 2, at the Knights of Columbus Stadium.

HAMBURG, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Led by their pastor, the Rev. Robert P. Crouch, who for the last eight months has shed his clerical garb every week day and donned overalls to superintend building construction, about 12 members of the Hamburg Baptist Church and a few paid carpenters and masons were rushing work today to complete the new church building on the site of the original 150-year-old edifice destroyed by fire last Winter.

THE brave words spoken by Presidential candidates, even by those who aspire to be candidates, have a habit of drawing together to form a book. Some editing is usually in order; some rearrangement is not infrequent.

Harry Hamilton, who wrote that jolly good story of shantyboat people, "Banjo on My Knee," turns to the flying trapeze for the scene of his second novel. The chief performers are three youngsters born in a one-horse town in Illinois. From their German mother and Irish father they inherited -- if that's possible -- a secret yen for the dazzle, danger and thrill of an acrobat's life.

A PRIZE of $100 is being offered by the Wieniawski Association in its biennial competition for composers. The 1937 award, the donation of Adam Kuryllo, president of the association, will be given for the best work for violin and piano by an American or Polish composer.
DENVER, Sept. 26. -- Wintry weather rode into the Rocky Mountains today, heralded by the season's first snow, which ranged from a light flurry in some sections to a seven-inch downfall in Wyoming.

President Roosevelt will lay the cornerstone of the Medical Building of the Jersey City Medical Center at 11 o'clock next Friday morning. The ceremony will mark the half-way point in the program financed by Jersey City, Hudson County and the Public Works Administration and designed to make the institution the third largest medical center in the United States.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Fred Perry of England, amateur tennis champion of the world, and Donald-Budge, American star, won the right today to meet for the Pacific Southwest tennis title tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- Following is the text of the note from the Belgian Ambassador here to Secretary of State Hull pledging cooperation in the currency stabilization move:

PARIS, Sept. 26. -- Backed by American and British approval and the promise of Belgian and Swiss cooperation with the tri-power stabilization agreement, Premier Leon Blum's government does not seem likely to have any difficulty getting from Parliament, Monday, approval of lowering the gold content of the franc by between 25 and 30 per cent, which was proposed last night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26. -- A system of general examinations will be given at Yale University at the end of the senior year, starting in 1937, in the college and to certain students in the Sheffield Scientific School and the Yale School of Engineering.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Soil conservation to prevent erosion was vindicated during the severe storm of Sept. 18, according to a report issued hero by the Soil Conservation Service, a Federal agency which is demonstrating methods of soil conservation on the fields of sixty-one Monmouth County farms.

Undoubtedly Dr. FERDINAND SAUERBRUCH had the support of the majority of his auditors when he told the German Medical Congress on Monday that spiritual and intellectual freedom is essential to the development of science, at the same time boldly warning the Government that the work of the scientist can never be complete if it is merely a service to the nation.

When President Roosevelt starts the first steam shovel and breaks ground for the $58,365,000 East River Vehicular Tunnel connecting Manhattan and Queens next Friday afternoon, he will launch the Public Works Administration's largest single non-Federal undertaking.

In the rivalry between fascism, communism and democracy, need there be any anxiety as to the ultimate victor? Is it not certain that, in the long run, that form of government will prevail which is most conducive to the development of the human mind? Is not this an outcome devoutly to be wished, so that the result will be a good one, whatever form of government prevails?

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26. -- Bishop Joseph Schrembs of the Cleveland Catholic diocese today termed the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's "anti-God" reference to President Roosevelt in a Cincinnati speech "a harsh statement, not justified in my opinion by the facts."

Walter Kreusi, whose recent analysis of the cost of "First Houses" at Avenue A and Third Street drew the fire of Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, explained yesterday that his figures on the labor costs had been obtained from the published records of the WPA and its predecessor, the Works Division of the New York City Emergency Relief Bureau.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 26. -- Connecticut State opened Brown's fifty-first varsity campaign on the gridiron by administering a smashing 27-to-0 upset defeat today. Scoring twice each in the second and fourth periods, the invaders ran rough shod over the home forces in every department of the game except scoring first downs.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Queen Mary, after more than twenty-five years as mistress of Buckingham Palace, will move next week to the old home she first entered as a bride on the arm of the late King George, then Duke of York.

In the third month of their struggle to displace the Leftist government of Madrid, the Spanish Rebels pushed closer to the capital. So desperate did the Loyalists' position become last week that they blasted a dam on the Alberche River, south of Madrid, hoping that the flood would engulf the attackers.

INTEREST in color reproductions, which has been mounting for several years with the advance in the fidelity of these works, has quickened anew with the recent publication of the first of a projected series of American Art Portfolios.

JUST at the edge of this picturesque little town runs the Franco-German frontier. Walking in the wooded hills, one might cross it inadvertently and long remain unaware of the offense. For the language, like the trees and fields, is the same on both sides of this arbitrary line, and the towns and villages of Alsace and the Palatinate closely resemble one another.

WITH REBEL TROOPS NEAR TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 26. -- Rebel forces commanded by General Francisco Franco were encamped a few miles from Toledo today after a bitter engagement in which Loyalist troops seeking to bar the insurgent advance were hurled back.

THE case of Dorothy Arzner, Hollywood's lone woman director, illustrates two tenets of present-day industry. The first is that an intelligent woman can do pretty much any kind of work she sets her mind on doing, and the second is that she need not sacrifice her femininity in doing it.

Hundreds of vans drew up in front of apartment houses and private dwellings throughout the city yesterday, deposited their burden of household goods and lumbered away to pick up other loads. With the Fall season at its peak, the moving men found themselves hard pressed to keep up with calls to transfer thousands of families, and reported that their business was the heaviest in several years.

The pace of this fast-moving mystery story inspires all of its characters, and perhaps its readers, too, with a most terrific thirst. Between drinks its sleuths ferret out the baffling mystery of the murder of Ruth Brooke, a blonde butterfly of Broadway.

Senator King visited Puerto Rico this Summer and returned North on the Borinquen, on which I was a passenger. Since I am a Puerto Rican, living now in the States and keenly interested in the problems of Puerto Rico, I took the opportunity of speaking with him in order to hear his side of the question and to present one or two points on the side of Puerto Rico.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 25. -- By the end of next week there will be in Palestine a full corps of the British Army under command of General Dill, who arrived here nearly a fortnight ago.

THROUGHOUT the land, county and State fairs are now in full swing, providing the Boy Scouts with opportunities to put their training to practical use. Often they donate their services in doing the chores of the fair, or they may demonstrate various phases of scouting in booths of their own; frequently they engage in both activities.

More than thirty large organizations of women -- regional, State and national -- are identified with the program of the three "Review of the News" conferences which THE NEW YORK TIMES will hold on Oct. 6, 8 and 9 at Newark, Garden City and New Rochelle.

The discovery of an ancient hill, city and fort of the prehistoric Pueblo Indians on Black Mesa, Arizona, by the Rainbow Bridge-Monument Valley Scientific Expedition was the most significant find of the expedition, according to Dr. Charles del Norte Winning, field director, who returned recently from Arizona.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 26. -- The relief situation in New Jersey flared anew this week with the publication of a survey made by the Public Works Administration, which found flaws in this State's municipal control of relief administration, but neither the Republicans nor the Democrats are expected to make relief a major issue in the campaigns now under way.

THE journeyings of that intrepid traveler Alexandra David-Neel across the Tibetan plateau until she realized her desire to enter the forbidden city of Lhasa have been discussed in these columns on various occasions.

LONDON, Sept. 11. A NEW comedy by Ronald Jeans at Daly's Theatre makes fun of the public which insists on versatility in its celebrities, looking to film stars for religion and to Bishops for science. The comic hero of "The Composite Man" is a famous tennis player.

THE impression Governor Landon, in his campaign for the Presidency, is seeking to make on the American people is that of a plain man who, progressive in spirit, especially desires to preserve all that was good in the national past. He argues for the common-sense approach to problems and for united defense of the tradition of individualism.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 26. -- Apparently unaffected by the shower room explosion which took the lives of two of its leading players, the Purdue football team today opened the season with an impressive 47 -- 0 victory over Ohio University.

IN a certain headlong way it has, this city all of a sudden faces the prospect of two and perhaps three plays about W.S. Gilbert and Sir Arthur Sullivan. There is the Cosmo Hamilton "Gilbert Meets Sullivan," awaiting the lavish ministrations of Hassard Short.

Last Thursday night in Cincinnati Father Coughlin, in an address before a rally of the National Union for Social Justice, declared that President Roosevelt was "anti-God." He also said that he advocated the "use of bullets" should an "upstart dictator" make the ballot void.

PASADENA, Calif. CITIZENS of Pasadena are violently debating the question whether the beauty of Colorado Bridge, one of the most graceful structures in Southern California, should be marred by devices designed to prevent suicides from the 160-foot-high span.

An already difficult delivery situation in a number of major merchandise lines became more acute last week as retailers found delivery requirements of manufacturers ranged from three weeks to two to three months. This was the case in goods ranging from staples to high style merchandise, and included goods wanted for Christmas holiday selling.

IN giving consideration to the new proposed traffic regulations, which are being considered by the Board of Aldermen at the present time, it must be remembered that, although our present ordinance has been amended from time to time, it still contains many provisions which have out-lived their usefulness and should have been repealed or amended long before now.

The Merchants Association has endorsed the program for the reduction of State and local expenditures which the Restore New York Committee will present this week before the resolutions committee of the Democratic and Republican State Conventions.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- Stuart R. Janney Jr.'s aged gelding Justinian II today captured the thirty-eighth running of the historic Meadow Brook Cup before a crowd of about 5,000 which spread over the hills and dales on the estate of F. Ambrose Clark.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Research programs at the University of Rochester, which have kept many scientists in their laboratories all Summer, will receive new impetus with the opening of college classes tomorrow.

RESEARCH in high altitude flight for the benefit of its coming fleet of huge transport airplanes is to be started, probably within thirty days, by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc. This quest for greater knowledge to be utilized in connection with its aircraft of the near future is to be sought through the new experimental overweather laboratory plane.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Two girls were killed and ten other persons injured in a head-on crash of two automobiles on the Crescent Boulevard, near here, early today. Three of the injured are residents of Ithaca, N.Y. The dead are Emma Clements, 25 years old, and Ella Mosher, 24, both of Camden, N.J., who were catapulted from the rumble seat of a coupe in which they were passengers.

MONTREAL, Sept. 26. -- The governors of the National Hockey League failed to reach a decision on the dispute between the Boston Bruins and New York Americans over the ownership of two players today. They succeeded, however, in clearing up the major part of their business, which was arranging the schedule for the 1936-37 season.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The White Sox virtually assured themselves of a third place berth today when they beat the Browns, 5 to 3 and 8 to 6, in a double header.

In observance of its silver jubilee, this season, the social committees of the Hackensack Woman's Club are engrossed in preparations for a series of particularly attractive programs, to be climaxed by the anniversary celebration on Feb. 5. Among those to be heard and seen by the members in the ensuing weeks are Cosmo Hamilton, novelist; Elsa Mae Gordon, comedienne and author; Dr. Alfred Adler, psychiatrist; Dr. Arthur Kellogg and Rosamund Birchby, dancer.

PARIS. NO sooner are the Paris Winter openings ended than all eyes are turned toward Cannes and its adjacent beaches. Sports clothes launched on the Riviera offer important fashion forecasts for Palm Beach, Bermuda -- and even California.

QUITO, Ecuador. -- The long-standing boundary dispute between Ecuador and Peru is soon to be referred to President Roosevelt. If he can solve it, prestige will be added to his "good neighbor" policy in Latin America. The Ecuadorean and Peruvian commissioners will hold their first discussion on Sept. 30 in Washington in accordance with an agreement to submit the question for final arbitration to the President of the United States.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, served notice today that his forces expected to demand wage agreements throughout the industry and declared that failure of negotiations would "lie squarely on the shoulders of the operators."

Appearance of counsel for the railroads at hearings on applications by truck and omnibus operators for certificates under the Motor Carrier Law of 1935, which last week were conducted by a joint board in the Pennsylvania Hotel, illustrated the active part that railroads have assumed recently in highway transport.

MARTHA GELLHORN'S first novel, "What Mad Pursuit," was a brash, giddy, theatrical little tale -- written, however, with a certain freshness and spirit. It was very bad and very youthful, but at least it had life in it.

A TIMELY book which has just been added to the Fall list of the Oxford University Press is "The Spanish Tragedy," by E. Allison Peers. It is a description of the steps which have led up to the present trouble over a period of years, during which the author, a well-known writer on Spanish subjects and now Professor of Spanish at the University of Liverpool, has been preparing the book.

The sacrifice of all the culture that the United States has attained was predicted yesterday by the Congress of American Poets, which suggested as a remedy the creation of a Federal Department of Art to make appropriations and otherwise assist the 5,000,000 men and women now engaged in the arts.
THE loves of Louis XIV have given rise to many books, but there is room for new accounts of the great monarch's heart-adventures as new collections of letters or original chronicles are discovered.

IT is one of life's little ironies that lately so many good journalists have persisted in proving themselves poor novelists. Having written one of the really significant books of our time in "Personal History," Vincent Sheean straightway delved into olden times and came up with a novel that was exciting when it was a record, and trivial when an imaginative story was ringed around it.

The Jews of New York and the world observed Yom Kippur, their Day of Atonement, yesterday. There were services in all temples and synagogues, with the troubles of a disturbed world the topic for most of the sermons.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Traces of an Arctic expedition which perished in 1912 were asserted today to have been found in Kara Sea. The Russian hydrographic boat Toros reported to the All-Union Arctic Institute that it had discovered on a remote island in the Kara Sea traces of the lost expedition of V.A. Rusanoff.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 26. -- Mrs. George White Baxter entertained at tea this afternoon at Cherokee Cottage for her guest, Mrs. Alton Brooks Parker of New York. Assisting Mrs. Baxter at the tea table were Mrs. Stephen S. Cummins, Mrs. Clifford R. Hendrix, Mrs. A. Moore Richard and Mrs. Frederick K. Hollister.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Mrs. William Zeigler Jr.'s Esposa, the filly that has a victory over Discovery to her credit, scored another triumph today at Narragansett Park when she won the Rochambeau Handicap, at a mile and three-sixteenths for 3-year-olds and up.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- With Bill King leading the attack, White Plains High conquered Derby (Conn.) High, 19 to 6, before 3,500 spectators in Parker Stadium today in the opening engagement for both teams.

WILBRAHAM, Mass., Sept. 26.-- Wilbraham Academy will formally open for its 120th year on Tuesday with a registration of 140 boys, the largest enrollment since 1912. Nine students will be present from New York State, with three from the city itself.

THE Promenade concerts or, as they are generally called, the "Proms," are here again, their popularity as great as or even greater than ever. The attendance can no longer be reckoned by the size of the audience, for the Queen's Hall is filled to capacity every night.

CHARLES BOYER, who has passed through Manhattan many times but has never yet unpacked his trunks here, stopped over with Mrs. Boyer (Pat Patterson) last week on his return from Europe long enough to enjoy "Idiot's Delight" and to chat a few minutes before barging right off to Hollywood.

HYDE PARK, Sept. 26. -- A complaint that employers were hiring men on relief rolls at part time for low wages in the expectation that these workers would continue to receive a large part of their support from relief funds was made by Mayor La Guardia when he came here today to confer with President Roosevelt.

The American Security League, Inc., an old-age pension organization with aims similar to those of Dr. Francis E. Townsend's group but less optimistic in its demands and promises, has amended its charter and in the future will be known as the League for National Pensions, Inc., it was learned yesterday.

With the opening this week of a new school year, Lawrenceville School, at Lawrenceville, N.J., is introducing the conference system of teaching made possible by the gift of Edward S. Harkness, benefactor of Yale and Harvard Universities, which was announced last June.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- The latest contribution to New York's thrill-loving populace, Roosevelt Raceway, was thrown open to public inspection today although the official ceremonies which were to have taken place were postponed for a week.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Synthetic hormones have been used successfully by Dr. Benjamin H. Willier, Professor of Zoology at the University of Rochester, to alter the sex of female embryo chicks.

BRITISH television technicians are reported to be busy "adjusting the very complicated machinery at Alexandra Palace," which has yet to be handed over officially to the British Broadcasting Corporation by the two manufacturers, the Baird Television, Ltd., and the Electrical Musical Industries.

THE researches of American scholars have contributed so much of late years to our knowledge of English literary history that Virginia Moore's elaborate study of Emily Bronte was welcomed here with hopeful anticipation.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 26. -- After getting off to a sluggish start, the University of North Carolina eleven overcame a stubborn, scrappy Wake Forest team today to open its season with a 14-to-7 Southern Conference victory.

THIS definition is sufficiently general to cover virtually all revolutions that have occurred in history, with the exception of what are known as "palace revolutions," which involve no greater change than the overthrow of an Oriental monarch or a South American President by a rival in his own entourage.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Training of engineers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will be broadened this year to ally a program of purely cultural studies with the technical courses.

In accordance with plans approved by the Superintendent of Schools, the Police Commissioner and the president of City College, a course in "Physical and Moral Welfare of the Child" will be offered to selected teachers, beginning Oct. 5, in the Twenty-third Street building of City College.
ROME, Sept. 26. -- The devaluation of French and Swiss francs has again raised the problem of whether Italy will be able to maintain the lira at its present gold value.

Programs and progress in the fields of peace, social legislation, contemporary Jewish affairs, immigration, naturalization and social service will be discussed at the annual all-day meeting of the presidents of eighteen sections of the New Jersey branch of the National Council of Jewish Women at the Hotel Douglas in Newark on Tuesday.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The government of the Netherlands, which with France and Switzerland clung to the gold standard after other major powers had quit it, announced tonight that it could no longer maintain its "present monetary policy."

MORE favorable weather for trade pushed up sales volume in the week, although reports continued to describe rather spotty conditions through the country. Improvement made the best headway in the South and Midwest.

Earl Browder, the Communist candidate for President, has sought permission to make a speech at Catholic University in Washington to reply to attacks on communism by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen. Mgr. Sheen responded to that request with an attack upon communism as a foe of religion.

MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney gave a supper dance tonight in the recreation building of Greentree, the hence of Mr. Whitney's mother, Mrs. Payne Whitney, in honor of the Argentine polo team.

GLENVILLE, Conn., Sept. 26. -- Showing consistently throughout the day in the hunter division, the chestnut gelding Easter Morning, owned and ridden by Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby of Bedford Hills, N.Y., today was awarded the hunter championship of the fifth annual Autumn horse show of the Byram River Beagle Club, held on the club's grounds.

America's first campus colony of fine arts is being established at the University of Iowa, in Iowa City. Finishing touches are now being put on the rambling $200,000 fine arts building, and the $150,000 dramatic arts structure near by will be completed in time for the dedication ceremonies in November.

New York's war-famous "Fighting Sixty-ninth," officially the 165th Infantry, New York National Guard, will hold a regimental review and evening parade on Governors Island for the first time since its organization eighty-five years ago, next Saturday at 5:15 P.M.

WITH weekly passenger air service between San Francisco and Manila starting next month, with airplanes soaring over the Andes and along the Amazon River, crossing the jungles of Africa and skirting the Malayan coast, air travel is becoming an increasingly important factor in the world's travel program.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 (AP). -- Although he has awaited, trial for almost fifteen months in Germany, the American seaman Lawrence Simpson probably will learn his fate on an espionage charge within a single day.

ON THE TOLEDO FRONT, Sept. 26. -- The Rebels drove their advance units within the sight of Toledo today after having broken the government line along the Guadarrama River, about eight miles from the city. Fields along the line of advance were strewn with bodies of fallen fighters.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The University of Chicago football team, starting its first campaign in three seasons without the services of Jay Berwanger, overwhelmed an out-classed but valiant Lawrence College eleven of Appleton, Wis., 34 to 0, at Stagg Field today. The game was witnessed by 24,000 rain-chilled fans.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 26 (AP). -- Undaunted by South Dakota State's touchdown on the opening kick-off and outplaying its opponent by a wide margin thereafter, the University of Wisconsin football team opened its 1936 season in a drizzling rain today with a 24-to-7 victory.

IT will be through no neglect on the part of zealous commentators and historians if in the end we fail to know just about everything that is to be known about our most illustrious moderns and their work. Surely in no previous epoch has a more generous and consistent effort been made to throw light upon all phases of the careers and the achievement of an epoch's leading spirits.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- A committee representing the civic class of the East Rockaway High School will appear before the village board to petition for greater protection at Long Island railroad crossings Monday night. The committee was appointed yesterday to protest the condition which caused injury to two students earlier in the week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). -- That secrets can be kept -- even when three nations are in on them -- was generally conceded today as the story of the negotiations leading up to the tri-power monetary agreement unfolded.

Miss Claire Hillyer of Greenwich, Conn., gave a dinner last night in the garden of the Ambassador for Miss Karen de Chambaud Conze, Greenwich debutante of the season. The other guests were Miss Rosemary Boyle and Miss Ruth Macloon, James Stuart Gillespie Jr., Gerard Southwick, Raymond Ovington and Jerry Barzaghi.

The committee was appointed yesterday to protest the condition which caused injury to two students earlier in the week.

The nineteen-acre estate in Upper Nyack, Rockland County, N.Y., known as Underclyffe Manor, former homestead of the late Jean Adriance Dole, will be sold at auction on the property by Joseph P. Day next Saturday afternoon. The late Mrs. Dole was the wife of Colonel Benjamin Adriance, president of the Adriance Machine Works and the Savage Arms Company.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Delegates who attend the State Republican and Democratic Conventions this coming week will be asked to include in their platforms a plank favoring legislation to give farmers the right to make their own prices and terms in the sale of milk.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 26. -- The Naval Academy won from William and Mary by 18 to 6 today as it ushered in its 1936 football campaign, displaying flashes of good running and passing, but at most stages nullifying its gains by incurring penalties and fumbling, Nay closed strongly to win handily.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Almost every kind of automobile tragedy possible descended on Daniel J. Gentile on Memorial Drive here early this morning, sent him through enough crashes to have killed half a dozen men, and finally landed him in court with only a few scratches on his head to plead guilty to charges of drunkenness, driving while under the influence of liquor, and driving so as to endanger.

MEXICO'S capital city is girding itself to entertain the host of American tourists now moving southward over the new Pan-American Highway. Building is booming; hotels have sprouted new wings, tourist camps with every American convenience are being erected, and many private homes have responded to the request of the Federal Government that they open their doors to visitors unable to find other accommodations.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 26 (AP). -- A $5,000,000 development within this city and utilization of plans drafted previously in the upper reaches of the Genesee River have been recommended to the War Department for flood control for the stream.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- Rhode Island today is debatable territory. Two months ago the political currents all indicated a Republican victory in November, but during the last few weeks there has been a shift.

Grocery manufacturers have taken a united stand against accepting any contracts on advertising allowances offered them by distributors, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., asserted yesterday.

MEXICO, D.F. -- Reports of alarming sanitary conditions found by "health squadrons" in Mexico's drive to combat disease and to improve public health have brought an intensification of the government's campaign initiated several months ago.

DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 26. -- The hard-smashing Duke football team defeated Colgate today. The Blue Devils, playing before a gathering of 25,000 fans, comprised mostly of home-coming alumni, crossed the Northerners' goal line only once, but that once was enough.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 26. -- A lightly regarded colt, C.V. Whitney's Tatterdemalion, captured the $10,000 added Potomac Handicap from a heavily backed filly today in as exciting a finish as has been seen here in many a day, before a crowd of 22,000.

The Stepney Fresh Air Camp of the East Side Settlement House will be the beneficiary of a pre-opening performance of the new play, "Tovarich," adapted from the French of Jacques Deval, with Marta Abba and John Halliday in the leading roles, the night of Oct. 13 at the Plymouth Theatre.

The Presidential campaign, in the sense of a national debate, will actually begin this week when Franklin D. Roosevelt entrains for a political speech at Pittsburgh Thursday night. Up to this time the President's cause has been voiced by others -- the Democratic National Committee, party orators and the small minority of the national press which is supporting his claim for re-election.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Standing firmly on his original charges, George Bernard Shaw tonight replied to protests following his recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES denouncing alleged Catholic censorship of the film, "St. Joan." He was interviewed in his country home at Ayot St. Lawrence.

OUT of the thin haze over the Autumn sea comes the droning of huge engines. It is at first a mere pulsetion, the effect of terrific explosions against the atmosphere. And then, against the pale and indeterminate sky, emerges the thin outline of a wing, like an albatross, soaring in a straight line.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 26. -- The addresses on the Good Friday bombs that snuffed out the lives of Thomas Maloney, insurgent union leader, and two others here were written by Michael Fugmann, now on trial for murder, said Eldridge W. Stein, New York handwriting expert, in the Criminal Court today.

MAX MILLER, the genial coverer of the waterfront, the philosophic householder, the mosquito and iceberg expert of the Bering Sea, went to Hollywood for his latest collection of narrative essays. Following the example of Nellie Bly and other reportorial expose specialists, he had himself committed to the place -- an inmate script writer.

To a world troubled by conflict of will and confusion of purpose in many quarters, news that the three great democracies of France, Britain and the United States have agreed on a joint plan to stabilize their currencies has brought reassurance. In hard-pressed France this news is hailed by the Government as signalizing "the start of monetary peace."

WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. 26. -- Students and faculty of Wellesley College, filling the chapel to overflowing at the first assembly of the academic year, greeted their new president with enthusiasm today as she opened the college's sixty-second session, making her first formal appearance.

WASHINGTON, -- Uncle Sam's chemists have launched a drive to curb explosions in soybean processing plants. The processing of America's fastest-growing crop has been blamed for several explosions causing loss of life. In October, 1935, at Chicago, eleven workmen lost their lives and forty-five were injured in a blast that caused property damage estimated at $600,000.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 26. -- Party leaders, assembling here tonight for the Democratic State Convention, which opens Monday, voiced gratification over the assured harmony that will characterize the sessions and both publicly and privately predicted that the New Deal and Governor Lehman will carry the State in November.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- John Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, criticized Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau today for what he termed a "political broadside" in connection with the monetary agreement with France.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 26 (AP). -- J.M. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, disclosed here today that the projected transatlantic airplane service would embrace both a northern and a southern route.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 26. -- With the notable exception of the elimination of the medalists, Eugene V. Homans of New Jersey and Miss Louise Iselin of Women's National in the first round, favorites advanced to the semi-finals in the annual invitation mixed Scotch foursome golf tournament today at the Piping Rock Club.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 25. -- The challenge to Senator Harry F. Byrd's leadership of the Democratic "organization" in Virginia, which may come in the contest for the Governorship next year, is expected to involve the fiscal policies and reforms for which Mr. Byrd is largely responsible.

Construction of one-family dwellings continues active in Brooklyn, while apartment-house building has declined, according to a report on building operations prepared by the Brooklyn Real Estate Board. It indicates, however, "substantial increases" in the construction of factories and warehouses and office buildings and in structural alterations to existing buildings.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25. -- Observers here say that the program of coming political events in Allegheny County indicates that it will be a major battleground in the fight for Pennsylvania's thirty-six electoral votes.
BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- Germany, like most countries outside of Spain, centered her main interest this week on the Fall manoeuvres.

GENEVA, Sept. 26 (AP). -- The projected devaluation of the franc is the result of France's conviction that a guarantee of peace must be accompanied by prosperity of the people, Yvon Delbos, French Foreign Minister, told the League of Nations Assembly today.

THE latest household pet is the ant, to whom King Solomon so wisely urged the sluggard to go. Artificial ant nests have made their appearance in the home. They come complete, with ants already installed inside the observation nest, where between sheets of glass, the unhappy insect is obliged to labor, eat, sleep (for ants do sometimes sleep or rest inert) and carry on its family life and civic affairs.

BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- Lawrence Simpson, American seaman, will be haled before the National Socialist People's Court in Berlin on Monday to answer charges of having engaged in treasonable and seditious activities in Germany.

Its only drawback would be that an occasional irrepressible chuckle over some of its funniest passages might provoke the disapproval of fellow-passengers who hadn't thought to get a copy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The chamber of Commerce of the United States continued its attack today upon what it termed the "inequities visited upon business by the surtax upon the undistributed earnings and profits of corporations" as written into the Revenue Act of 1936.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- This season's spaniel program will open at Hot Springs with the second annual Bath County field trials on Friday and Saturday. The initial event last year developed intense competition and drew a large number of fanciers from New York and New Jersey.

On a foggy night in the outskirts of London the headless body of a man is discovered in what would have been a bonfire had the match ever been applied to it. Among the first to view the body is Ludovic Travers, who promptly advises the local authorities to call in Scotland Yard.

Columbia and Rutgers battled through two and one-half hours of football yesterday at Baker Field in an informal scrimmage and the Lions emerged victorious, 32 to 6. The coaches of both teams stood behind their charges and were quick to offer criticism at the close of each play.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27. -"In the recent currency moves the French Government is to be congratulated for its courage in taking the initiative," Dr. James Harvey Rogers of Yale University, who has been an economic adviser of the Roosevelt administration, said tonight.
OLIAS DEL REY, Spain, Sept. 27 (AP). -- From the ramparts of Toledo today could be seen one of the most spectacular air battles of the Spanish civil war.

George Antheil, composer of the "Ballet Mecanique," has been engaged to write the entire score for the Cecil B. DeMille film, "The Plainsman." Mr. Antheil writes from Hollywood that, by a coincidence he had been touring Texas, New Mexico and Arizona for several months, studying Indian music, before he received the DeMille offer or had any idea that his studies might be put to practical use.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- In a roaring, tearing, hard-driven third heat finale today John M.L. Rutherfurd, the Long Island sportsman, captured the President's Cup for 1936 by a brilliant feat of seamanship and navigation on rough, choppy river water.

Dr. Harry W. Laidler, Socialist candidate for Governor, opened his campaign at Town Hall yesterday with an indictment of the legislative records of both major parties in this State and an attack on Governor Lehman for his disposition of the charges against District Attorney Geoghan.

HYDE PARK, Sept. 27. -- In the social atmosphere of a house comfortably filled with guests, President Roosevelt and Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau talked this afternoon face to face for the first time since the United States joined the "gentlemen's agreement" with Great Britain and France not to enter a currency war.

GENEVA, Sept. 27. -- League quarters warmly welcomed devaluation of the franc because of the joint Anglo-Franco-American agreement behind it and because of the promise of action against trade barriers.

PARIS, Sept. 26. -- The financial markets here were completely dominated this week by the aggravation of the foreign exchange situation and the increased weakness of the franc. The American Football League made an auspicious start in New York yesterday as a crowd of 6,500 watched the Yankees open their circuit season with a 13-6 victory over the Syracuse Braves in the Randalls Island Stadium.

The usual sabbath calm of the Broadway theatre was broken last evening by the second of the seasonal cycle of military school plays. The entry was "Bright Honor," the work of Henry R. Misrock, which followed by only a few days Mr. Viertel's "So Proudly We Hail," leaving one more to come later on.

This Crimefile is based on an interesting idea. It is a make-believe police dossier of a crime, planned by J.G. Links, and written by Dennis Wheatley.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Lower prices for most livestock, as well as for meats, prevailed in most markets last week. Receipts of cattle and hogs were smaller and of sheep larger than in the previous week, but the run of all livestock was materially increased over a year ago.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 27. -- The largest field in the history of the women's national golf championship gathered tonight at Canoe Brook for the start at 7:30 o'clock tomorrow morning of the fortieth annual tournament.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Violent death for a steadily increasing number of motorists and pedestrians is predicted for the Fall and Winter by the National Safety Council.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Further evidence of man's existence in North America 10,000 or more years ago was offered today by Dr. Edgar B. Howard, trustee and associate in paleontology of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, who supervised new excavations this Summer in New Mexico.

TOLEDO, Spain, Monday, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Rebel troops captured this city yesterday, rescuing the besieged insurgents in the Alcazar fortress and sending the government forces fleeing in disorder with heavy losses.

ALBANY, Sept. 27. -- With all the State's major Republican leaders now on the ground for the opening of the party's State convention here tomorrow, but most of the delegates not yet arrived, the stock of Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley has taken a sudden and phenomenal jump in the race for the Governorship nomination.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Speculative interest in provisions here has not been large, with the market influenced on one hand by speculative short covering of lines put out on the recent upturn, while cash interests have been fairly persistent sellers of lard.

MADRID, Sept. 27 (Passed by the Censor). -- The Spanish Cabinet held a council meeting this afternoon, after which it issued a statement on the present situation saying that the government had been constituted with absolute legality and represented the Republicans and anti-Fascists in the country.

TOKYO, Monday. Sept. 28. -- The Japanese Government intends to lay upon the United States the onus of invoking in the naval treaty the escalator clause regarding submarines, according to the newspaper Asahi, which publishes this morning a forecast of the Japanese reply to the United States.

MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The Soviet State Bank declared early today that the statement of Henry Morgenthau Jr., United States Secretary of the Treasury, that Russia was trying to weaken the value of the pound sterling was "absolutely without foundation and a nonsensical invention."

BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- The stock market opened irregular this week and fluctuated within narrow limits until near the close, when the French decision to devaluate the franc induced a substantial recovery. Except for Aku Rayon, in which a bull market developed, industrial stocks were neglected in favor of the securities of businesses in former German colonies.

I desire to compliment you on your editorial "The Farm Vote," to which I say "Amen."

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- An attack on the surtax on undistributed corporation earnings is made by Sewell L. Avery, president of Mongomery Ward Co., in his semiannual report to stockholders of the big mail order and chain store organization.

The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, Nassau County, Inc., will be aided by a special polo game to be held on Sunday at Bostwick Field in Westbury, L.I. George H. Bostwick and his brother, Dunbar Bostwick, who have donated the use of the field, are assisting members of the benefit committee in assembling the teams.

BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- The announcement of an impending devaluation of the franc came to Berlin as a complete surprise. German bankers, indeed, had declared long ago that a collapse of the French gold standard ultimately would be inevitable, and by mid-week they considered the franc position as critical.

A few hundred yards from the great tulip tree under which Henry Hudson met in friendly conclave with peaceful Manhattan Indians in 1609, members of the Indian Confederation of America celebrated the final phase of American Indian Day yesterday afternoon.

Transatlantic ships carried 421,018 passengers between the first of the year and Sept. 16, representing a gain of 33,909 or more than 8 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago, according to records compiled by the Atlantic Passenger Conference.

A banking group composed of Paine, Webber CO., Charles D. Barney Co., Granberry Co., Reynolds Co., William Cavalier Co. and Mitchum, Tully Co. will offer to the public today by means of a prospectus 85,000 shares of common stock of Stokely Brothers Co., Inc. The stock will be priced at $17.50 a share.

VIENNA, Sept. 27. -- Devaluation of the French franc had no immediate effect on the economic situation in Eastern Europe, according to reports from all capitals. In Vienna banks exchanged 100-franc notes until 10 o'clock at the old rate and hundreds of small brokers ran from bank to bank to exchange their notes, but shortly after 1 o'clock all trade in French francs was halted.

Included in realty transactions announced over the week-end was the sale by the Central Savings Bank of the three walk-up apartment houses at 377-379 Second Avenue and 240 East Twenty-second Street, the southwest corner. The flats occupy a plot 50 by 100 feet and have been purchased by Cutler Klar for remodeling into garden suites with a landscaped court entrance.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Moulton gave a dinner for twenty-four at Oakwood this evening and Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen gave a small dinner at Wakehurst.

The Staff Association of the New York Public Library is seeking public support for its request for a larger library budget. This year New York City is spending 47 cents per capita for libraries -- Cleveland, for example, is spending almost four tames as much per capita -- and the book stock here is said to be in a desperate condition.

BERLIN, Sept. 26. -- The industrial outlook in Germany, according to most reports, has definitely improved. Nevertheless, Minister of Economics Hjalmar Schacht is said to be opposing an extension of Reich credits and bounties for increases in agricultural and raw material production. In this connection he complained this week that "too many Germans are screaming for subventions."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harrison de Sales, assisted by Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Loring, Mr. and Mrs. Earl A. Means, Mr. and Mrs. W.J. Murray and Mr. and Mrs. J. Mahlon Buck, entertained today at a twilight cocktail assembly, attended by more than 500 guests at the Greenbrier.
LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Extension of yesterday's three-power monetary agreement was widely forecast in London tonight as the logical result of the new deal among currencies of the world.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Home runs by Clyde Passeau and Morrie Arnovich gave the Phillies a 4-to-3 victory over the Bees today after the visitors had taken the first game of a double-header, 7 to 3.

The Presidential candidates on the Democratic, Republican, Union, Socialist and Communist tickets have been asked in a letter from the American Youth Congress, 55 West Forty-second Street, whether they will "make the American Youth Act a 'must' in your legislative program."

SYRACUSE, Sept. 27. -- On the eve of the opening of the Democratic State Convention here tomorrow it became more apparent than ever that the Democrats are preparing, with the New Deal as the sole issue, to fight to retain New York's forty-seven electoral votes and the control of the State government as well.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27. -Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., today defeated his famous rival, Fred Perry of England, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, to win the men's singles championship in the tenth annual Pacific southwest tennis tournament.

Much of the world has retrogressed in its devotions to tribal or racial gods, as they were in Jehu's day, and away from the conception of God as a Father to all, as taught by Christ, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the James Memorial Chapel of the seminary, Broadway and 122d Street.

A decided upturn in the volume of retail trade produced a perceptible increase in the number of open orders and reorders received last week in the wholesale apparel market here, with the bulk of activity falling in the dress field.
