Restricted production during the first half of September produced delivery difficulties in the higher-priced coat field, and unexpected consumer demand for high-colored apparel and accessories found manufacturers with stocks depleted or exhausted.
EATONTOW, N.J., Sept. 27. -The Monmouth County Country Club's Evergreen Farms squad won the Eastern Polo League title today when it defeated the Governors Island four by 8 to 7 in an overtime match.

It sometimes happens in a Presidential campaign that, toward its end, an event occurs which gives it an entirely new turn. It causes the people to forget all the political speeches that have previously been made. It leads them to throw away party platforms as documents that have been superseded by something which had never swum into the ken of their framers.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 27. -- The municipal elections held throughout Yugoslavia today show how little progress has been made toward unifying the country.

The strictly formal type of religion practiced by many people was assailed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland in his sermon at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street. More than 500 persons attended services to hear Dr. Reiland in one of his last sermons before his retirement next Sunday to become rector emeritus.

DALLAS, Texas, Sept. 27. -- Martial law was declared tonight at flood-harassed Waco, ninety miles south of here, where 2,000 persons were homeless after the Brazos River broke through a levee and inundated the eastern part of the city.

" I am going to create a housing shortage," Tenement House Commissioner Langdon Post told Local 10 of the Workers Alliance of Greater New York Tuesday night. "That is the only way to get decent homes," he explained. By "decent homes" Commissioner Post means subsidized homes.

The better teamwork of the Maccabees, soccer champions of Palestine, routed the New York State Football Association All-Stars, 6 to 0, yesterday at the Yankee Stadium. A crowd of more than 30,000 was present to welcome the visitors for the first game of their tour of the country.

Governor Lehman replied yesterday to the letter of reproof addressed to him last Friday by seventeen of the Drukman grand jurors who had asked the removal of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. 27. -Wellesley College honored its late president, Dr. Ellen Fitz Pendleton, today in a simple memorial service of thanksgiving in the college chapel.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- The Red Sox closed the American League season today as they opened it -- with a victory over the Athletics.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27. -Showing with all the nonchalance that marks an old-timer in the public eye, the Sealyham champion Wolvey Noel of Clairedale trotted into the top award this afternoon at the fourteenth annual bench show of the Westbury Kennel Association, held on the J.S. Phipps polo field.

BILBAO, Spain, Sept 27 (By warship to Saint-Jean-de-Luz, France) (AP). -- Three government warships today poured shells into Zumaya, headquarters of the Rebels marching on Bilbao, almost from dawn to dusk.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Niagara University's Purple Eagles defeated Notre Dame's B football team, 21 to 0, today for the first home victory since 1934.

Last week's foreign exchange market labored under the imminence of a devaluation in the French franc, which, when announced on Saturday, unsettled trading here and brought to a complete stop operations abroad.
Two leaders of American Jews who returned yesterday from European visits described the plight of members of their race in Eastern Europe in bitter terms.

Cotton prices held within a somewhat narrow range last week and made only small and irregular net changes. Contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week ranging from an advance of 9 points to a decline of 10 points.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 27. -- Rear Admiral Osamu Sara, Naval Attache of the Japanese Embassy in Shanghai, told this correspondent last night that the Chino-Japanese situation was rapidly growing worse. He said that two Japanese destroyer flotillas composed of eight vessels would arrive at Shanghai shortly and that a second consignment of re-enforcements of an undisclosed total were aboard transports en route to Chinese waters.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 27. -- The National Association of Fortune Tellers held its first annual convention today at the State fair grounds here and predicted that:

A mother and her ten children escaped without injury from a blazing tenement house at 1,159 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning by creeping along a narrow second-story ledge to the adjoining building. Seven other occupants were rescued by firemen after suffering burns and lacerations.

Conventions and expositions here next month are expected to attract more than 100,000 visitors, many of whom will come with the express purpose of making purchases, John R. Young, manager of the convention bureau of the Merchants Association of New York, said yesterday.

General approval of the program advocated by the New York State Economic Council to reduce the cost of State government has been given by Winthrop W. Aldrich, as president of Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, it was announced yesterday by the Restore New York Committee.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27. -- In one of the best games staged on Bostwick Field this season, the Westbury quartet of Ebby Gerry, G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, Winston F. C. Guest and Bobby Strawbridge teamed in fine style to defeat the Gauchos, composed of four members of the Argentine polo squad, 7 -- 4, today.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 27. -The Pittsfield Country Club had an "advertising ball" last night at which 200 members and guests were present. Frederick T. Francis was general chairman.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 75 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week, and the highest rate in actual tonnage since February, 1930.

Colonel Terry's champions and Professor Stengel's Dodgers pulled down the curtain on the National League season at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Giants lost, 8 -- 3, but that was only incidental and expected, with the Colonel again sending his reserves into the fray.

The Railroad Enthusiasts, Inc., are uniting to champion the cause of the steam carriers. This organization of friendly commuters, incorporated under the laws of Massachusetts, exists to defend the railroads against public criticism and to support their battles before public service commissions.

Any division of liberal elements in this country will be aid to Governor Landon and the forces of reaction, Senator Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin declared yesterday. The Senator was here for a week-end conference with local leaders of the Progressive National Committee, supporting President Roosevelt.
MADRID, Sept. 27. -- The Spanish Government, admitting Madrid was imperiled by the advancing Rebel army, issued a proclamation today appealing for reinforced defenses of the capital.

ALBANY, Sept. 27. -- William B. Bell, chairman of the national Republican finance committee, declared tonight at a dinner of United Republican Finance Committees of the State that a survey conducted by party leaders had given assurances that Governor Landon would carry the nation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Asking if the Senate campaign investigating committee will "probe for a questionable splinter while it ignores a malignant cancer in the body politic," John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, has challenged the investigators to study Republican evidence which he declares shows corruption, favoritism and intimidation by the New Deal in Pennsylvania.

MARSHFIELD, Ore., Sept. 27. -- Raging forest flames devastated the coast town of Bandon in Southwest Oregon today, taking a toll of seven dead, 1,500 homeless and estimated property damage of $1,500,000, and leaped on tonight to lick at the outskirts of three other Coos Bay cities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The radio phase of the national campaign will reach a new intensity Thursday night when there will be a series of three half-hour broadcasts over a nation-wide network by three speakers of the first importance.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- A brilliant meteor which flashed across the sky at twilight of July 16, startling many observers in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, appeared first over Livingston County, N.Y., and disappeared off the New Jersey coast after traveling a path 313 miles long, according to calculations compiled by Dr. Charles P. Olivier, director of the Flower Observatory of the University of Pennsylvania and president of the American Meteor Society.

MADRID, Sept. 26 (Passed by the Censor). -- The insurgents operating in the Tagus Valley tonight apparently were throwing most of their strength into their drive at Toledo, while government lines defending the approach to Madrid over the main highway from Talavera de la Reina were holding firm at Quismondo, a village five miles east of Maqueda.

The pending rapid transit unification proposals contemplate a new issue of approximately $110,000,000 of city corporate stock for the account of the present bondholders of the private companies. It is the contention of Judge SEABURY and Mr. BERLE that these new bonds, being self-sustaining, should be excluded from the city's debt limit, and if their plan is approved they intend to apply at once to the courts for an order directing their exclusion.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (AP). -Comment that "progress" was being made came out a joint meeting of shippers, maritime unions and Federal officials tonight as efforts were continued to prevent coast waterfront tie-ups after Wednesday, when working agreements expire.

For one brief spell in the opening period the Dodgers displayed a brand of football against the Boston Redskins that brought joy to the 15,000 Brooklynites gathered at Ebbets Field yesterday, but then the home forces collapsed completely, to wind up on the short end of a 14-3 count.

Two youths who, with a third unidentified person whom police are seeking, are accused of holding up parked motorists on Riverside Drive were seized early yesterday morning by police after Isidore Epstein, of 2,070 Clinton Avenue, the Bronx, was robbed while sitting in his car at 105th Street and Riverside Drive.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Accustomed though this market is to financial crises in France, the momentous developments at the close of this week overshadowed the financial markets, which had fully realized that definitive action on the French currency problem was impending.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- In the presence of a large group of club members from 1lew York City and Westchester, Colonel Julius Ochs Adler, president of the Century Country Club here, unveiled and dedicated today a memorial to the late Simon F. Rothschild, New York banker, who was president of the club for ten years.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- The first authoritative statement regarding Germany's attitude toward devaluation of gold currencies and her own intentions was made today by Fritz Reinhardt, State Secretary in the Finance Ministry, who said to a Storm Troop gathering near Berlin: "German currency is stable.

The Rev. Dr. I-Iarry Emerson ! Fosdick told more than /,000 memI bers of the city's police force, at-I tendihg the annual memorial service of the Police Square Club at Riverside Church yesterday afternoon, that because their duties dealt them "special temptations no less than special hazards," personal integrity was the ranking factor in the performance of i;heir duties.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa, arriving today from Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg, has on board the Right Rev. August Mararhens, Bishop of Hanover and new president of the Lutheran World Convention, who is coming here to attend an executive committee meeting.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 27. -- The Democratic State platform, to be voted on by the convention delegates Tuesday afternoon, will give enthusiastic support to the New Deal, and particularly those features that are in keeping with New York State issues, it was learned tonight as the platform committee went into session.

On Saturday evening the government pinned back the ears of that division of Broadway's precise children who will take their drama straight or not at all. For the Federal Theatre Project, after flirting with all the more archaic forms of the current theatre, from Shakespeare to Virgil Geddes, settled back and in "Horse Eats Hat" gave play which apparently didn't mean anything at all.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27. -- All the tension attendant upon a climactic finish to a thrill-packed football game came to pass today as the Pittsburgh Pirates downed the New York Giants on Forbes Field with three minutes left to play. The score was 10 to 7.

ALBANY, Sept. 27. -- The Republican State platform will contain a plank which will lay the basis for the Gubernatorial candidate to attack Governor Lehman for his handling of the ouster charges against District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn, it was made known tonight on the eve of the opening of the party's State convention.

By denying God nations that say they are seeking to establish human equality destroy those spiritual qualities without which love of neighbor cannot exist, and therefore they defeat their own purpose, the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The appropriation by the Peruvian Government in its current budget of an amount sufficient to pay interest at the rate of $5.50 for each $1,000 bond is a step in the right direction, but economic conditions in Peru warrant the appropriation of a substantially larger amount in the 1937 budget, according to Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance, in a special bulletin to be published today.

Forty-one attorneys, writers, educators and others have signed a letter asking the Democratic, Republican, Union, Socialist and Communist Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates "to make at least one public pronouncement on the issues which constitute the heart of the struggle to maintain democratic liberties in the United States."

Had Lew Lovett, in his timely and constructive letter, thought to cover ten years instead of seven, his list of important printing establishments quitting the New York area might have included the large Butterick publishing organization, which, with meager beginnings in 1863, developed into one of the most successful publishing and printing units in the country.
The season's first big week -- seven new shows and one revival are scheduled -- continues tonight with a brace of events, to wit:

Asserting that the construction industry in the United States had not played an important part yet in bringing about recovery, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York in its current issue of The Guaranty Survey, its monthly review of business and financial conditions in this country and abroad, declares that a full measure of prosperity cannot be achieved so long as such an important branch of industry as building lags.

NEW ROCHELLE, Sept. 27. -Cornelius Shields, Y.R.A. champion, today added the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club trophy to his Interclub Class laurels, while H.W. Wagner, Jesse A.B. Smith Jr., and H.M. Pitman triumphed in handicap class events as neighboring clubs here wrote "finis" to the sailing season.
GENEVA, Sept. 27. -- The Swiss Government, it is understood late tonight, plans to ask Parliament tomorrow to make the degree of devaluation of the Swiss franc about 30 per cent.

Surf fishing, at best, is a tough game, one of the toughest in all angling. So when a chap comes along who deliberately makes things more difficult for himself, purely as a sporting proposition, you have to sit up and take notice.

Freebootery, which thinned to the vanishing point during prohibition, has taken a new lease on life in New York Harbor, it was learned yesterday. River pirates who turned to liquor smuggling in the dry period are taking up their old trade.

Governor LANDON'S speech at Milwaukee on social security was the kind of address deplorably infrequent in political campaigns. It was a genuine analysis of the problem it discussed, and in the simplicity of its presentation a real contribution to public understanding of that problem.

HALEYVILLE, Ala., Sept. 27 (AP). -- Seven persons were drowned and an eighth escaped today when an automobile, out of control, rolled backward down a hill into Davis Mill Pond, six miles north of here.

It may seem rather unusual for employers to rally publicly to the defense of a union leader in their industry, but simple fairness demands that, as spokesman for the largest employing group in this industry, I join whole-heartedly in denouncing as utterly unfounded the Hearst newspapers' allegation that David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, advocates and supports communism.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27. -- A shake-up of great significance in Soviet life was announced today so unexpectedly that there had not even been a rumor it was in preparation.
PARIS, Sept. 26. -- Informed circles here were in no way surprised, late on Friday, when the government created an exchange equalization fund and decided to close all markets here temporarily.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 (AP). -- In a rain-soaked battle filled with bitter disputes over ball and strike decisions, the Cubs beat the Cardinals, 6 to 3, today and closed the National League race tied with St. Louis for second place.

Three members of the Vilna Troupe, which made Jewish theatrical history a dozen-odd years ago -- Sonia Alomis, Alexander Asro and Noah Nachbush -- got together again on Saturday night in the New School for Social Research auditorium to remind us that they are still an active force in that theatre.

The problem of advertising wines and beverages to women consumers will be one of the major topics for discussion when members of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers convene here on Oct. 13 for their annual meeting and election of officers.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- Dedicating the first 1,000 kilometers [about 620 miles] of the new double-track automobile roads that are beginning to crisscross Germany, of which 6,000 more kilometers are still to be built, Chancellor Adolf Hitler today delivered a speech in which he again emphasized that Germany must make herself independent of "the good or ill will of sources lying outside Germany."

Intending to allocate shipments in advance, producers of some light finished steel materials, especially sheets, have asked large consumers to supply estimates of their requirements for the remainder of the year, the magazine Steel says in its weekly review, out today.
COLEBROOK, N.H., Sept. 27. -Mrs. Middleton Maingault of New York gave a luncheon at Polly's Place here today for Captain and Mrs. Lewis Morris and William Benton Chase of Whitefield.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The Yankees concluded the American League season at Griffith Stadium today by establishing a new modern major league record and an American League mark, but they lost to the Senators, 10 to 5.

A large group of delegates left the Grand Central at 11 o'clock yesterday morning for the Republican State Convention at Albany. Kenneth F. Simpson, leader of New York County, already had gone to the State capital. The group departing yesterday included National Committeeman Charles D. Hilles, John R. Crews, leader of Brooklyn, and Samuel Koenig, formerly leader of New York County.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 27. -Three persons were killed today in automobile accidents in various parts of the State as Governor Harold G. Hoffman officially opened the annual New Jersey Safety Week campaign.
The highly corrosive combination of salt air and industrial fumes, part of the normal atmosphere in New York City, has damaged two sections of the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 26. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84, which compares with 84.1 the week before, 84.2 two weeks before, 83.7 three weeks before, and 83.8 four weeks before.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Sept. 28. -- Japanese plans to strip China of every vestige of independence are found to be contained in the long list of "mild general principles" submitted to Nanking by the Japanese Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Congestion in September corn contracts featured that market here again last week, with the close yesterday showing 1 1/4 cents a bushel advance, compared with the previous week. The new crop months were unsettled, with December 1/4 cent lower and May 3/8 cent higher.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27. -- Down the main three-quarter-mile straightaway of the new Roosevelt Raceway roared several racing cars for the first time today as a number of drivers entered in the 400-mile Vanderbilt Cup race slated for Columbus Day began tuning up motors for the event.
BUFFALO, Sept. 27. -- Canisius College opened its football season today by crushing the Assumption College eleven of Sandwich, Ont., 56 -- 0.

The rise of ground in Central Park at West 106th Street resounded all yesterday afternoon with a steady clank, clank, as if a dozen blacksmiths were busy at their anvils. The Knickerbocker Horseshoe Pitchers League of Greater New York held a tournament for pitchers whose average is .300 or less, a .300 horseshoe pitcher corresponding to a baseball player with a batting average of less than .220.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 27. -- The Bermuda Government plans to establish birth control clinics to check the growth of the Negro population, General Sir Reginald Hildyard, Governor since last May, said today at the opening of two dockside visitors' waiting rooms on St. David's Island.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 (AP). -The powerful Chicago Bears hauled out their aerial attack today and soared to a 17-to-0 triumph over the Philadelphia Eagles before 25,000 National Football League fans. Bill Hewitt, former Michigan performer, was on the receiving end of both scoring passes.

Only forty-six of the 187 municipal clerks in grade 1 passed promotion tests for grade 2, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission. George B. O'Gorman and Helen M. Ferris of the Water and Purchase Departments, respectively, led the winners.

BEVERLY, Mass., Sept. 27. -- One of the finest specimens of real old Colonial rooms and furnishings in the country is to be set up in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City as a result of the purchase of the "olde parlor" in the 300-year-old Burnham-Hart home on Linebrook Road in Ipswich.

Offhand, perhaps nothing looks more simple than analyzing the respective batting strength of two ball clubs. You take the weekly averages, duly note the hitting percentage of each jot down the homers and other extra base drives along with the runs-batted-in total, subtract the low from the high and there you have the answer.

Police Commissioner Valentine admitted yesterday that complaints of inadequate policing of school crossings had been received from all parts of the city. He conceded that the situation was bad but declared he was powerless to correct it without a substantial increase in his force.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Sept. 27. -- Former Governor Frank O. Lowden of Illinois today expressed approval of Governor Landon's farm program and announced that he would participate actively in the campaign by making three speeches for the Republican national ticket.

An unusually instructive correspondence has occurred between Senator VANDENBERG and Secretary MORGENTHAU regarding the causes and consequences of our huge imports of gold in recent years. Mr. VANDENBERG'S questions imply that we are getting the gold chiefly because of the "artificial price" of $35 an ounce, which the Treasury now pays for it, compared with the old rate of $20.67 an ounce.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Under its new name and management, the New Jersey State Fair opened here today for its forty-ninth annual exhibition. The fair will continue day and night through Saturday with special features arranged for each day.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, trustee under the indenture for Kreuger Toll 5 per cent secured debentures, will announce today the sale at auction of collateral underlying the debentures at 10:30 A.M. on Oct. 27 at 18 Vesey Street, New York.

Offhand, perhaps nothing looks more simple than analyzing the respective batting strength of two ball clubs. You take the weekly averages, duly note the hitting percentage of each jot down the homers and other extra base drives along with the runs-batted-in total, subtract the low from the high and there you have the answer.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company reported yesterday for August gross revenues of $6,423,053, a gain of $643,275, or 11.1 per cent, over a year before, and the highest total for the month since August, 1931. Freight revenue rose $339,299, or 10.6 per cent, and passenger revenue $238,531, or 12.2 per cent, from August, 1935.

The piano and the violin vied with the saxophone and musical bones yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park as thirty-two boys and girls competed for prizes in the finals of the Park Department's amateur musical instrument contest for juniors.

The engagement of Stella Andreva, colorature soprano from London, to join the Metropolitan Opera during the coming season became known yesterday. It was also learned that Gina Cigna, distinguished French-Italian dramatic soprano, has virtually agreed to terms for her entry into the Metropolitan singing personnel and that her signed contract is expected in a day or two.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27. -- The cotton market here was moderately active last week, so far as futures were concerned, and extremely active in the spot department. There was a lack of speculative activity, but a rather good demand in the way of trade buying and price fixing by mills, and this was virtually sufficient to absorb the volume of hedge selling usual at this season owing to the movement of the crop.

Instead of discussing the "inevitable war," men of good will should talk about "indispensable peace," the Rev. Dr. Minor Simons, the pastor, said in his sermon yesterday morning at All Souls, Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street. War can be averted by human decision, he said.

An unusually instructive correspondence has occurred between Senator VANDENBERG and Secretary MORGENTHAU regarding the causes and consequences of our huge imports of gold in recent years. Mr. VANDENBERG'S questions imply that we are getting the gold chiefly because of the "artificial price" of $35 an ounce, which the Treasury now pays for it, compared with the old rate of $20.67 an ounce.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Under its new name and management, the New Jersey State Fair opened here today for its forty-ninth annual exhibition. The fair will continue day and night through Saturday with special features arranged for each day.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, trustee under the indenture for Kreuger Toll 5 per cent secured debentures, will announce today the sale at auction of collateral underlying the debentures at 10:30 A.M. on Oct. 27 at 18 Vesey Street, New York.

Five racing shells belonging to the Waverley Boat Club were saved from destruction in the Hudson River yesterday when T. Ormond Deignan, captain of the club, dived overboard from Harman Thumhart's power boat into the wash of a Dyckman Street ferryboat.

It took football just one day of real play to establish the fact that there will be new giants for the season of 1936 and that the always present regular occurrence which was named upset in the day of its rarity and clings to this name for want of a better one will be present in its usual quantity.

The news in the decision to devalue the franc, and with it the other currencies of the gold bloc, the guilder and the Swiss franc, seems to be that the three great democracies -- and money powers -of the world are working in harmony toward the goal of general currency stabilization and the thawing out of international trade.

Animals are subject to congenital deafness and to other types of deafness from which human beings suffer, according to one of the exhibits placed on view at the opening yesterday of the convention of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27. -Members of society of the North Shore colonies and many persons from New Jersey, Westchester and the South Shore who had devoted their time to steeplechasing and polo for a week, attended today in large numbers the fourteenth annual dog show of the Westbury Kennel Association on the polo field of Westbury House, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Phipps.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 (AP). -- The Indians ended their American League season today by defeating Detroit, 9 to 1, in a game called in the sixth inning because of rain.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 27. -Going over to the Long Island shore and catching the southern breeze that sprang up yesterday afternoon. Henry H. Anderson, in his sloop Clotho won the Larchmont Yacht Club's race for the N.Y.Y.C. 32-footers around Stratford Shoal, off Bridgeport, Conn., and return, a distance of 59 1/2 miles.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27. -The annual Yale honor roll, including 145 names from Connecticut, 120 from New York and 45 from New Jersey, and containing 551 names of students in Yale College embracing the freshman year, was announced today.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Four Milwaukee home runs, two of them in extra innings, gave the Brewers their second straight victory over Buffalo in the Little World Series today, 6 to 5, in eleven innings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Discussions of importance in relation to close cooperation between the Securities and Exchange Commission and State regulatory bodies are expected to develop at the nineteenth annual convention of the National Association of Securities Commissioners in Denver, which will be addressed on Oct. 1 by Chairman James M. Landis of the SEC.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Behind the seven-hit pitching of three rookie hurlers, the Reds closed the season today with a 6-to-5 victory over Pittsburgh before a ladies' day crowd of 13,000.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- President Roosevelt spent his last day of relaxation until after the November election in rest here today.

The Harlem All Peoples party, which complained to Secretary of State Hull on Friday that the Hotel Delano, 108 West Forty-third Street, had refused accommodations to Prince Malaku Bayen, cousin of Emperor Haile Selassie, yesterday received a telegram from Mr. Hull deploring the incident but asserting that the State Department could not interfere, because the Prince was not in this country in a diplomatic capacity.

CLIFFSIDE PARK, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Representative Edward A. Kenney of the Ninth Congressional District, a resident of this borough, announced today that he would request a closer police watch on the studio of the late Charles Henry Niehaus, internationally known sculptor, whose works are exhibited in the Congressional Library, the Senate Chamber, the Capitol rotunda and numerous parks throughout the United States.

Last Winter the Cook County Democratic machine declared war against Governor HORNER. In the April primary Cook County gave a majority of 150,000 against him. He was saved by down-State. Mayor KELLY shook hands ceremonially with the Governor. Last week there was another distribution of olive branches.

Through restrictions imposed by governmental bodies, the New York Stock Exchange as a market "has suffered impairment in its functional characteristics," Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange, said in his annual report which will be mailed to members today. The report, a thirty-eight page pamphlet, covered the year ended on May 1 last, his first term of office.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Rutgers is marking time and looking ahead to 1937. The finest freshman squad to matriculate here in five years is working out under Arthur Matsu and Al Sabo, and if its scholarship is commensurate with its avoirdupois and football ability, bullish days are ahead for the Scarlet in another twelvemonth.

PARIS, Sept. 26. -- The last session of the Bourse this week ended before the Council of Ministers decided to devaluate the franc. All week the market was influenced chiefly by the foreign exchange situation and the prospects of devaluation. International and French industrial stocks therefore rose considerably.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- When the regular Fall term of Supreme Court convenes here tomorrow Supreme Court Justice Frederick D. Close in Special Terminal will be flooded with applications for writs of certiorari for reduction of assessments in Westchester County aggregating millions of dollars, it was revealed today.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- The government's bill to devalue the franc was passed by the Finance Committee of the Chamber of Deputies tonight. Tomorrow the Chamber itself will vote upon the project and every sign points to its passage by a safe majority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP). -- Regulations under which Western stockmen and ranchers will be paid an estimated $2,000,000 to $3,000,000 in soil-conservation benefit payments were announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

VIENNA, Sept. 27. -- From illegal Nazi circles this correspondent learns that leaders of the underground Nazi movement decided last week in a secret conference to issue orders to their followers throughout Austria to modify all opposition to the present regime "in view of the Communist danger."

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The devaluation of the French franc and the probable stabilization of the world's leading currencies are regarded by the grain trade here and abroad as removing one of the great hindrances to a large international trade, especially in wheat.

Most of us will accept Mr. Baker's analysis of the facts leading to our entry into the World War and his conclusion that "it was caused directly and solely by the German use of the submarine." That is, we accept the submarine as the sole direct cause.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 28. -- De Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry still can't believe it, though he beheld it with his own eyes. He saw his Brown University varsity register 17 first downs to Connecticut State's 5, gain 165 yards by rushing and pile up 114 yards in addition through the air and still lose the game on Saturday by the staggering margin of 27 -- 0.

Cold weather in many sections of the country over the week-end resulted in a sharp demand for all types of wearing apparel in the local wholesale markets yesterday. Mail orders were heavy and called for Fall goods in both men's and women's lines.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28. -- Russia's 1936 grain crop is almost all garnered now, and in advance of official estimates, which may not be available for months, the best informed foreign experts here calculate that it will fall only very slightly under last year's crop of 89,000,000 metric tons.

As a result of completing thirteen of fourteen forwards on Sunday, the Chicago Bears assumed the lead as the best passing combination in the National Football League, according to statistics announced yesterday. The Bears, in addition, retained their scoring honors with forty-seven points in two contests.
My attention has just been called to the letter entitled "Three Gold Certificates," signed by W.W. Phelps and appearing in your issue of Sept. 8, 1936.

The following triumphant cablegram from Jack Cohn, vice president of Columbia Pictures, aboard the Queen Mary, speaks for itself: "After much persuasion finally induced Mrs. Beryl Markham to sign contract appear in motion picture portraying her great achievement for Columbia."

Since no saucier craft than the Pinafore ever sailed through a stage door, all was well among the mariners last evening on both sides of the Martin Beck Theatre's footlights. The decks being manned by that peerless crew, the D'Oyly Carte Company, the Pinafore was not only saucy but palpably a beauty.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- The Boerse staged today what amounted to another devaluation boom, despite official declaration that a change in Germany currency policy was out of the question. Stocks jumped up 6 or 7 points and lesser gains were common, especially among "blue chip" issues.
Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, warned fifty striking pupils in the Bronx yesterday to attend their classes or face prosecution as truants.

HAVANA, Sept. 28. -- Re-establishment of the death penalty in Cuba is provided for in a bill unexpectedly approved as a whole tonight by the House of Representatives. The measure would cause the execution of all those in Cuban jails who have been condemned to death by various courts during the past two years.

HARRIET MONROE, who "commenced poet" in the early Nineties and made poetry her cardinal interest all her life, knew how hard it was and is for a poet to get a hearing and make a living. For twenty years or so she kept her head above water by lectures and newspaper work.

After a few local and early season experiments with the art of murder, Times Square settled back last evening to take a lesson from the British. They got it. At the end of two hours of Emlyn Williams and his "Night Must Fall," they were well within their rights to jab broom handles under the beds, to make sure he had remained at the Barrymore.

TOPEKA, Tuesday, Sept. 29. -- Arriving here early this morning after a week's campaign trip that he regards as very successful, Governor Landon in short talks at Illinois, Iowa and Missouri towns on his way from Byron, Ill., yesterday attacked the Roosevelt administration on several fronts.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Dr. Henry B. Kummel, director of the State Board of Conservation and Development, submitted a report to Governor Harold G. Hoffman today in which the board recommended that no action be taken on charges of inefficiency pending against Colonel Leonidas Coyle, State Fire Warden.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 28. -- Efforts of business groups to seek Federal and State legislation "creating a monopoly for the small concern" threaten to destroy competition, raise prices and lower the standard of living, and must be checked to avert "economic disaster" in this country, Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University, asserted in an address at the opening session today of the eighth Boston conference on distribution.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 28. -- State Senator William H. Smathers, Democratic-candidate for United States Senator, opened his campaign here tonight with an address at Convention Hall in which he assailed the legislative record of his Republican opponent, Senator W. Warren Barbour, and defended the accomplishments of the national administration.

Efforts to stabilize foreign exchange yesterday was among a series of favorable incidents, which brought about one of the most active days the cotton-textile industry has experienced in many months. In cotton gray cloths alone more than 30,000,000 yards of all types were sold, some orders covering delivery into January and February of next year, while prices advanced 1/8 of a cent on many constructions.

The Seabury-Berle transit unification plan should be promptly approved so that the city may avail itself of prevailing low money rates and other favorable conditions, it is urged upon the Transit Commission, Board of Estimate and Legislature in a report made public yesterday by the State Chamber of Commerce.

Oscar Tschirky, who, during his forty-three years as host at the Waldorf-Astoria has catered to the whims of thousands of diners, including royalty and other personages, on his seventieth birthday yesterday admitted that his favorite dish was plain boiled beef, with a bit of fat, and a boiled potato.

PARIS, Tuesday, Sept. 29. -- The first article of the government's Devaluation Bill -- the article that contains the all-important provision to reduce the value of the franc -- was voted by 343 to 252 in the Chamber of Deputies at 2:50 o'clock this morning.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Milwaukee's long-range hitters again were too much for Buffalo tonight, the Brewers taking their third straight game in the Little World Series, 3 to 1, before overflow crowd of 15,212.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Marshall Field Co. are looking toward an extensive refinancing program, although the time and details have not been determined.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 28. -- Shoe retailers of this State are headed toward their second successive year of record business, according to reports made today at the first session of the State Shoe Retailers Association convention.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, at the helm of the airship Hindenburg on her way to Lakehurst for her ninth visit of the Summer, radioed the Zeppelin offices here that the airship would land at Lakehurst around 6 o'clock this morning.

Convinced by an exhaustive study of the educational possibilities of radio that broadcasting is the greatest agency of education since the printing press, Mr. Joseph M. Sheehan, Associate Superintendent of Schools, asked the Board of Education yesterday to set aside $5,000 this Fall to finance experimental programs.

Directors of the Holly Sugar Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, in addition to the regular dividend of 50 cents. They also declared the regular payment of $1.75 on the preferred stock. All dividends are payable on Nov. 2 to stock of record of Oct. 15.

Governors Island was alive with marching men, waving flags and blaring bugles yesterday morning as the Sixteenth United States Infantry, "New York's Own," paid tribute to Major Gen. Stanley H. Ford, commanding general of the First Division, who will leave tomorrow for Omaha, Neb., to assume command of the Seventh Corps Area.

Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday a sharp drop in new cases of diphtheria in the city for the week ended last Saturday. Only six were reported with no deaths, compared with ten for the previous week. No diphtheria deaths have been reported in the last five weeks.
Alan M. Thompson has formed the investment securities firm of A.M. Thompson Co., to specialize in public utility preferred stocks, at 115 Broadway.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Senator La Follette, Wisconsin Progressive, called upon all liberals tonight to unite in seeking the re-election of President Roosevelt.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economics Minister, today convoked the central committee of the Reicbsbank, of which he is president, for Wednesday, at 4 P.M. The purpose of the meeting, according to the official announcement, is to "receive a declaration from the Reichsbank president regarding the German view respecting the currency situation." The official announcement added:

A direct result of the Robinson-Patman act, and its provisions covering advertising allowances, will be a 50 per cent increase in sales of premiums intended for distribution to consumers, Howard W. Dunk, secretary of the Premium Advertising Association of America, Inc., claimed yesterday at the opening of the second annual Atlantic Coast Premium Buyers Exposition at the Hotel Astor.

Returning on the Normandie from France yesterday, Abraham Cahan, editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, predicted that the Blum government would remain in power long enough to carry out its proposed financial, economic and social reforms and solidify the democratic elements of the nation for defense against Fascist dangers at home and abroad.
Having canceled all appointments for this week, Mayor La Guardia went at the task of cutting $37,000,000 from the 1937 budget requests yesterday with the aid of Budget Director Leo J. McDermott.

The approach of Oct. 1 produced an unusually long list of apartment rentals over the week-end and brokers and management firms anticipate heavy leasing today and tomorrow as tenants whose present contracts are expiring and who have as yet no other accommodation hasten to make last-minute selections.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Appraisers appointed by the court reported today that Alfred I. du Pont left an estate of $39,374,845.

Enrico Venturi of Italy defeated Eddie Zivic of the fighting Zivic family from Pittsburgh in a slashing ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 3,000 saw Venturi, holder of the lightweight championship of Europe, score over the Pennsylvania fighter.

TOKYO, Sept. 28. -- Japan's China policy developed rapidly today. In a statement to foreign correspondents, Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita warned China that she was at the parting of the ways leading to peace or war and must immediately make her choice.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 28. -- Sinking long putts on the last two greens for birdies, Willie Klein, Wheatley Hills pro, and his amateur club-mate, H. Matzinger, won the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association today at the Brookville Country Club.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 28. -- Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, told 700 women at a testimonial dinner to Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman tonight, that 3,500,000 women employed in industry had made great gains under the New Deal.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Closing the 100th annual session of the New Jersey Methodist Episcopal Conference today, Bishop Ernest G. Richardson, presiding officer of the Philadelphia Area, announced eighty-nine pastoral changes for the coming year.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 28. -- The government's decision temporarily to abandon the gold standard -- it is noteworthy the word "devaluation" has not been used so far -- was received calmly by the nation. The Cabinet's optimism was shown by an announcement of the reopening of the Stock Exchange tomorrow, although originally it was scheduled to be closed tomorrow as well as today.

FLINT, Mich., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Two persons were injured fatally in an explosion today which wrecked a filling station and store of the General Tire and Appliance Company and sixteen others were hurt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Max Gordon's American premiere of "St. Helena," by R.C. Sherriff and Jeanne de Casalis, took place at the National Theatre tonight. The play, sumptuously mounted, coincided with the beginning of the National's 101st season, and a near-capacity audience turned out to receive the gilt souvenir tickets.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Shivering doughboys, slicker-clad gunners and rain-soaked members of attached units of the Second Infantry Brigade won today in a game of war against the picked aerial scouts of the 97th Observation Squadron, during division manoeuvres at Pine Camp under Brig. General Perry L. Miles.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 28. -- While all eyes were kept glued on the two young marvels of the present golfing era, Miss Pam Barton of England and Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, a relatively obscure golfer from the Blue Ridge region of North Carolina not only outplayed them but every one else in the qualifying round of the fortieth women's national championship today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The nation's 1936-37 food supply per person was estimated officially today at about 3 per cent less than the amount actually used during the 1935-36 season.

GENEVA, Sept. 28. -- All political parties in Switzerland met in Berne today and accepted more or less reluctantly the government's devaluation decision. The Parliament meeting was delayed by these meetings and by the failure of the committee dealing with the devaluation law to agree on all details.

WACO, Texas, Sept. 28. -- Brazos River authorities tonight saw "a critical situation" along the stream south of here as lowland dwellers fled before the onrushing crests of two of Texas's largest rivers.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP). -- The Detroit Lions opened defense of their National Football League title tonight with a driving, 39 to 0, victory over the Chicago Cardinals.

Resolutions opposing the teachers' oath laws and condemning Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens for barring Communists from meeting in public buildings were adopted yesterday afternoon by the Brooklyn-Nassau Presbytery.

The Keppel Gallery will open the Autumn season at its new quarters, 71 East Fifty-seventh Street, today. The move to this address (one flight up) was made late last Spring. The old premises at 16 East Fifty-seventh Street have Been undergoing reconstruction since that time and will henceforth be occupied by the Valentine Gallery.

Back in the Nineties a naval lieutenant startled his superiors and upset departmental heads by a broadside of criticism against American ships, gunnery and general methods. He was still a lieutenant when he took the audacious step of addressing himself directly to President Theodore Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Heavy rains in Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas and Nebraska, which will materially improve the outlook for the Winter wheat crop in the Southwest, and highly beneficial rains in both Argentina and Australia sent the world's wheat markets into a tall spin today.

ROME, Sept. 28. -- All Italian Exchanges remained closed today on government orders and will not reopen until Thursday morning so as to prevent any undue fluctuation in securities in the present state of uncertainty about the government's monetary policy.

Kirsten Flagstad arrived yesterday on the Normandie after a vacation and operatic appearance abroad, and confirmed the report that her one new role at the Metropolitan Opera this season would be Senta in Wagner's "The Flying Dutchman."

Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers, who has presided over all the special Drukman sessions since his appointment by Governor Lehman last November, suggested yesterday that the time had come to turn over the unfinished Drukman trials to the county authorities -- even to District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan, now that he has been cleared of the Drukman charges made against him.

GENEVA, Sept. 28. -- Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, replied in the League of Nations Assembly today to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Nuremberg attacks on Russia and to the veiled overtures to the Nazi and Fascist governments made by Britain and to a less degree by France in the Assembly last week.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Mrs. E. Denemark made a quick return on a claiming investment today. Last Saturday she placed her certified check for $6,500 in the claiming box, and after Two Bob had finished out of the money in the colors of the C.V. Whitney Stable, the filly was led off to the Denemark barn.

HYDE PARK, Sept. 28. -- President Roosevelt finished tonight a speech to be delivered in Syracuse tomorrow night in which it is generally understood that he will attempt to clarify the issues of his campaign for re-election and pave the way for specific speeches later on such topics as finances, taxes, banking and agriculture.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- Retail sales in New England in 1935 amounted to more than $2,700,000,000, an increase of 27 per cent over the sales in 1933, according to figures presented here tonight by John Guernsey, distribution economist for the United States Census Bureau of the Department of Commerce, at a dinner meeting of the Retail Trade Association Executives of New England, held under the auspices of the American Retail Federation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The Lake Superior Power District Company of Ashland, Wis., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for $5,600,000 first mortgage bonds, Series A, due on Oct. 6, 1966.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Sept. 29. -- The most powerful Nazi party organ, the Voelkischer Beobachter, carries this morning a personal warning by Agriculture Minister Richard-Walther Darre to the German people to prepare for a shortage of certain foods during the coming Winter.

In a suit by the International Flight Corporation against the Movietone News and Fox Film Corporation for $100,000 for the loss of a plane on Oct. 17, 1934, the plaintiff applied in the Supreme Court yesterday to take the testimony of Laurence Stallings and other editors of Movietone News before trial.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Sept. 28. -- Coach Dick Harlow today made a sweeping cut in the Harvard football squad, picking thirty-nine players for his first string. Harlow chose almost entirely from the three teams he has been instructing right along.

Pleas for the closer cooperation of specialists in eye, ear, nose and throat diseases, neurologists and biochemists and for the better coordination of existing scientific and medical knowledge as the best way to advance this phase of medical science were made yesterday before members of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology, in convention at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 28. -- Edward F. McGovern, chief defense attorney in the Good Friday bomb murder trial of Michael Fugmann, demanded today the privilege of withdrawing as counsel so that he might eventually become a defense witness to reply to statements of two State investigators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Approval of the application of the Department of Docks for modification of the harbor lines along the Manhattan shore of the East River between Twenty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets, was announced today by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission began today an investigation of the operations of the Petroleum Corporation of America, sponsored in 1929 by Blair Co. of New York. The corporation is an investment company specializing in oil stocks.

Lieut. Col. Brehan B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, completed yesterday the task of fixing prevailing rates of pay for all WPA workers by announcing reductions of from 15 to 50 per cent in the monthly hours of work of 7,500 professional workers.

Most of the demonstrations that were expected yesterday to emphasize the dissatisfaction felt by seamen and other groups at the treatment of Lawrence Simpson, American sailor, by the German courts, failed to materialize.

MADRID, Sept. 28. -- The Spanish Government tonight ordered every available man to the civil war front. Striving to concentrate every effort toward a defense of Madrid against the insurgents, the government took the following steps:

Philip W. Barber, regional director of the WPA Federal Theatre Project, announced yesterday that he had asked the national officers of the project to curb their efforts to get publicity for the forthcoming production of "It Can't Happen Here."

SYRACUSE, Sept. 28. -- Expressing confidence in the re-election of President Roosevelt and himself, Governor Lehman in an interview here today said that the Democratic State platform would be straight-forward and honest with no promises which he and the party would not carry out.

The owners of thirty-one acres of land in Flushing meadows, which was taken over by the city for the World's Fair project, undertook yesterday to show Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn why their meadows property is worth about $800,000 instead of the $92,160 for which it is assessed.

The arbitration proceeding between the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade and the Garage Washers and Polishers Union arising from the union's demands for wage increases and shorter hours will begin today before Ben Golden, associate director of the Regional Labor Board, who was appointed arbitrator by Mayor La Guardia.

Rains in Texas, which damaged the cotton crop there, led yesterday to increased support for that staple on the Cotton Exchange here and checked hedging pressure. Buying here, combined with further foreign demand in a readjustment to the three-power monetary agreement, lifted prices to the highest levels since Sept. 18, or more than $1 a bale above the low marks of last Friday, and final quotations showed net gains of 9 to 14 points.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 28. -- M. Harvey Taylor, Republican State Chairman, said tonight he would present to Senate investigators "enough specimens of WPA political corruption and waste" in Pennsylvania to keep the committee "busy from now until the 1940 election."

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- Within a very brief period after the French devaluation bill has cleared the parliamentary hurdles, the British Government is confident that international trading readjustments will follow to improve world commerce by taking full advantage of a saner currency situation.

Belief that France's devaluation of the franc would affect commerce in the Orient, particularly with Japan, was expressed yesterday by Kenkichi Yoshizawa, member of the House of Peers of Japan and former Minister of Foreign Affairs.

Unless Marse Joe McCarthy finds himself in a state of indecision, the public will be made acquainted today with the identity of his starting pitcher when the Yankees tangle with the Giants in tomorrow's opening game of the first subway world series since 1923.

ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN, Ottumwa, Iowa, Sept. 28. -- Governor Landon is continuing to follow a "hands-off" policy in the nomination of a Republican candidate for Governor of New York, close friends said today.

ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Westchester, who, from indications tonight, is likely to become the nominee for Governor of the Republican State convention, faced a battery of cameras and a crossfire of questions from half a hundred newspaper correspondents tonight.

GENEVA, Sept. 28. -- The possibility that the Spanish Government will formally invoke the League of Nations covenant and appeal to the Council, on the ground that German and Italian aid to the Rebels menaces world peace, grew today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28. -- The first canvass of "revolts" of company unions in the steel industry since the Steel Workers' Organizing Committee was formed on June 17 will be made here tomorrow at a meeting of the committee, Philip Murray, its chairman, announced today.

New York State is more than ever this year the observed of all political observers. Its forty-seven electoral votes make it always important in Presidential elections, but this year it is absolutely critical. If the Republicans do not carry it for Governor LANDON he cannot be elected President.

One hundred years ago ANDREW JACKSON was approaching the end of his second term and his energies were concentrated on the election of MARTIN VAN BUREN as his successor. The son of a farmer and tavern-keeper at Kinderhook, N.Y., VAN BUREN had been a successful Secretary of State and had represented his country at the Court of St. James.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- The National Socialist tribunal known as the People's Court today sentenced the 34-year-old seaman, Lawrence B. Simpson of Seattle, Wash., to three years in the penitentiary after he had confessed that he had imported Communist propaganda material into Germany.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- With a cast of thirty-three members, "Stage Door," the new three-act play by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber, was presented by Sam H. Harris at its premiere here tonight at the Forrest Theatre.

Ninety-five per cent of the members of the Society of Restaurateurs, Inc., of New York are opposed to serving liquor to women at bars, Paul Henkel, president of the association, said last night at the monthly meeting of the organization at the Lobster Chop House, 145 West Forty-fifth Street.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Ab Jenkins set eight new motor car speed and endurance records today and then was forced by mechanical trouble to end a run which he had expected to bring a dozen more.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Railroads normally accounting for more than 84 per cent of total railway operating revenue had a net railway operating income in August of $56,090,777, compared to $36,333,008 in the corresponding month last year, the Association of American Railroads announced today on the basis of "advance reports" from 103 Class I railroads.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. 28. -- General Francisco Franco's 6,000 African veterans, who achieved the "impossible" by fighting all the way across hostile Spain, were resting tonight in historic Toledo preparatory to advancing on Madrid after taking the former city yesterday in bloody hand-to-hand combat.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Carding a sparkling best ball of 64, seven under par, the Essex County team of Bill Malcolm and Jim Blanchard Jr. today carried off first honors in the one-day pro-amateur golf tournament of the New Jersey P.G.A. at the Essex Fells Country Club. A field of thirty-one teams competed.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Two University of Washington oarsmen who rowed under Rusty Callow today took over the crew-coaching reins at Cornell, James Lynah, director of athletics, announcing the appointment of Harrison Sanford as head coach and Norman Sonju as his assistant.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Transcontinental Western Air today announced drastic reductions in base fares in what appeared to be the first move in a rate war among the country's transcontinental airlines.

The Seas Shipping Company, operator of the American-flag Robin Line between the United States and South Africa, last night announced increases of $1 and $3 respectively in its rates on shipments of boxed and unboxed automobiles, effective on shipments moving in October. The new rates will be $5 and $7 respectively.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- By unanimous vote the Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures today authorized its investigator, Louis R. Glavis, to continue his inquiry into charges of industrial coercion in Pennsylvania. It also voted to have Mr. Glavis investigate alleged "intimidation and other irregularities" in the administration of the WPA in that State.
JASPER, Ala., Sept. 28. -- Governor Graves and the Walker County grand jury today were drawn into an investigation of the patron "strike" of school children in that county.

A misunderstanding in some quarters that the University of Notre Dame has sold exclusive radio broadcasting rights to its five 1936 home football games was cleared up yesterday by a statement from the Rev. John F. O'Hara, president of the university.

ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- Representative James W. Wadsworth was beaten today in a contest for the chairmanship of the resolutions committee of the Republican State Convention, and the forces of William F. Bleakley, Supreme Court Justice, hailed the defeat as their victory over the supporters of Senator George R. Fearon in the first test of strength between the two rivals for the Gubernatorial nomination.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State Democratic chairman, opened his party's campaign in New Jersey last night by predicting that President Roosevelt would be re-elected by a majority greater than that of 1932.

A "hopeful outlook" for settlement of the long strife between the Lutheran Church and the Nazi government was seen yesterday by leaders of the moderate wing of the German Lutherans as they arrived here for the eight-day sessions of the executive committee of the Lutheran World Convention at the Hotel McAlpin.

SEATTLE, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Edwin S. Smith, United States Labor Relations Board examiner, refused today the offer of Hearst interests of proof that the striking Seattle chapter of the American Newspaper Guild stole telegrams exchanged by Ray Colvin, day managing editor of the strike-bound Post-Intelligencer, and Hearst executives in the East.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Hog prices rallied today after declining for three weeks. Prices advanced 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight from Friday, with some lights and pigs up 25 cents or more from the close of last week. A sharp falling off in receipts and a better demand for fresh pork incident to continued cool weather were the main influences.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- Admiral William Sowden Sims, U.S.N. (retired), commander of the United States fleet in European waters during the World War, died of a heart attack here early this evening at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Robert Hopkins. He was 77 years old.

ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- The Republican State convention opened today with a keynote speech which, in not a few of its salient points, echoed a speech delivered under Liberty League auspices earlier this year by Alfred E. Smith, and which in many quarters was looked upon as addressed fully as much to Democratic malcontents as to Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Charging that Governor Landon had definitely rejected the Social Security Act for "a dole with a means test," John G. Winant, former Republican Governor of New Hampshire, resigned today from the Social Security Board so that he would feel free to answer the Republican candidate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of a new form for the registration under the Securities Act of 1934 of securities of issuers in reorganization or of issuers who have succeeded corporations in solvency proceedings.

ONE part history, one part tract, one part fiction, Upton Sinclairs "Co-op: A Novel of Living Together" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50) appears to be one of the notable books of our depression years. As an item of literature it is ordinary or even second-rate; Mr. Sinclair has never been one for subtlety, deftness or literary charm. But as a document it is of certain importance.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- The Phillies defeated the Athletics today, 5 to 1, in a post-season game staged at Shibe Park for the benefit of the widow of Monte Cross, who played shortstop for both teams some years ago. Fewer than 1,000 attended.

The State of Virginia awarded yesterday a total of $10,019,600 of refunding bonds to a banking syndicate headed by the First National Bank of New York at a price of 100.493 for $2,769,100, due from 1937 to 1946, as 1 3/4s, and $7,250,500, due from 1947 to 1965, as 2 1/4s. The net interest cost to the State was put at 2.178 per cent.

The share market yesterday reflected the general confidence felt that the world economy will benefit measurably from devaluation of the franc and its allied currencies, in that prices were steady. Traders generally favored the side of the advance but were not very demonstrative about it; at the same time, the moderate amount of selling that came into the market was absorbed readily.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- Slight and partly deaf, Lawrence B. Simpson stood clutching a chair while he testified in People's Court today in fluent German, frequently bending forward to hear the prosecutor's questions.

An amended plan of reorganization for the Lawyers Mortgage Company was filed yesterday with James A. Martin, referee, by the creditors' committee of which Mortimer N. Buckner is chairman. The company has about $6,000,000 in cash and government bonds, the greater part of which would be paid pro rata on allowed.

The fear that ultimately the Park Department will remove the remaining seven rowing clubs from the Harlem led the Metropolitan Rowing Association at its meeting last night in the New York Athletic Club to appoint a committee to confer with Commissioner Robert Moses.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28. -- Coach Ducky Pond worked the Yale football squad more than two hours today to start the last week of practice before the opening game with Cornell next Saturday. No change in the line-up was made, but the regulars were withdrawn gradually and replaced by second and finally third-string men.

The monetary stabilization agreement of France, Britain and the United States was declared yesterday by United States Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah, in an interview in national Democratic headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel, to be "the biggest thing that has happened internationally in many years."

Holders of Chesapeake Corporation ten-year 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds, due on Dec. 1, 1944, have been notified by J.P. Morgan Co., sinking fund agents, that $650,000 of the bonds has been drawn for redemption on Dec. 1, at 105 and accrued interest, for the sinking fund. The drawn bonds may be converted by that date into common stock of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.

CAMPBELL, Ohio, Sept. 28. -- Tear gas was used by police in this suburb of Youngstown today to disperse a crowd of striking high school students who staged a demonstration around the school building to protest against the transfer of a favorite teacher.

There exists no little confusion about the reasons which precipitated the present rebellion against the government in Spain. Part of the confusion is due to ignorance concerning the history of the five months which intervened between the coming of that government into power and the outbreak of the civil war on July 18.
Buried away unnoticed among the summaries of the bobsledding results of the Winter Olympics was the line, "3d -- Great Britain (McEvoy)."

When the United States and France signed a reciprocal trade treaty a few months ago, the possibility of devaluation of the French franc was foreseen. The treaty specifically provided that either country should be free to terminate the agreement on thirty days' notice, or to propose a modification of its terms, in case it found its interests prejudiced by any sufficiently "wide variation" in the then prevailing rates of exchange.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Twenty-five hundred law enforcement agents of the Treasury Department staged a nation-wide one-day raid on internal revenue law violators today, rounding up probably more than 1,000 prisoners. Definite figures will not be available here until telegraph reports are received tomorrow from the 500 offices which participated.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 28. -- Party Spirit, 3-year-old High Time gelding owned by Arthur McDonnell of San Francisco, paid a long deferred visit to the winners' circle today as Rockingham Park opened its Fall meeting of twenty-two days. Bill Leischmann rode him to a four-lengths victory in the six-furlong White River Handicap, the inaugural feature.

EASTON, Pa., Sept. 28. -- President William Mather Lewis, speaking at the opening convocation at Lafayette College in the Colton Memorial Chapel this afternoon, outlined the duty of the American college student toward curbing un American practices and developing effective action for the benefit of society.

Mayor LA GUARDIA has gone into seclusion to wrestle with the last city budget which will go into effect during his present administration. In some ways his task is more agreeable than it has been in other years. Thanks to Fusion, Controller TAYLOR, the bankers and the business cycle, the city's financial position is greatly improved.
Various housing properties were included in the Brooklyn realty turnover reported yesterday.

By far not the least interesting phase of all the angles that one finds tossed into this forthcoming complex whirl known as a world series comes to light in comparing the rival managers -- Joseph Vincent McCarthy, head man of the Yankees, and William Harold Terry, boss of the Giants.

The public, "quite justly," is not satisfied with the practitioners the medical colleges of the United States are turning out today, Dr. Alfred C. Beck, Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the Long Island College of Medicine, declared yesterday.

The agreement to hold steady in foreign exchange the dollar and the pound sterling on the basis of the devalued franc came at a time when the three great contracting parties were ready for the contract and smaller nations would be influenced to do the same. It could not have come before the three were ready.

HITLER has kindly said that nations which think Modest they can afford democracy are welcome to it. He will not stand in their way. He might even consider democracy for the German people if he had all the colonies and raw materials to pay the high cost of democracy.

Another English melodrama opens this evening at the Fulton, "Love From a Stranger," which Frank Vosper adapted from a story by that master mind of detectives, Agatha Christie. Auriol Lee has staged it. Mr. Vosper plays the leading role and associated are Jessie Royce Landis, Minna Phillips, Olive Reeves-Smith, Leslie Austen, George Graham, A.G. Andrews and Mildred Natwick.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 28. -- Seventeen inches of wet, heavy snow, the worst September fall in the city's history, blanketed Denver tonight, disrupting traffic and communications as it blocked highways and snapped power lines under its sodden weight.

Tony Albano, a hardy baseball fan from Brooklyn, where the breed, of necessity, is hardier than any other species in the United States, is not going to miss being the first bleacherite through the turnstiles at the Polo Grounds tomorrow morning.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Professional advertisers have the most blunted sense of honor of any legitimate business, Dr. Logan Clendening of Kansas City, physician, surgeon and medical writer, told some 4,000 delegates here today at the annual convention of the American Bakers Association and allied groups.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The New Deal batteries turned their fire directly on Governor Landon, the Republican Presidential nominee, as the Democratic State Convention assembled today. A withering barrage, presaging an even more vigorous attack, was hurled in the direction of Kansas by three of President Roosevelt's lieutenants, Robert F. Wagner, Robert H. Jackson and James A. Farley.

Raymond Moulton O'Brien of 56 East Fifty-second Street, 31-year-old son of the late John Denis O'Brien of Pittsburgh and New York, has been acknowledged by the British Crown as the rightful Earl of Thomond. This was disclosed yesterday, although Mr. O'Brien's claim was accepted about two months ago.

Colonel Churchill Williams has bought the ninety-seven-acre eirbower farm on the Danboro-Point Pleasant Pike in Bucks County, Pa., from James A. Sauter. Frances Spencer, the broker, also sold to T. L. Gustin a 109-acre farm in Old York load, near Buckingham, Pa., and to the Hey. ffohn W. Hauser a thirty-two-acre estate in Landisville load. Buckingham Township, fdr Marie W. Caulk.

Dr. Robert J. Ellis, 50 years old, a retired Canadian physician, slashed his wrists with a razor blade at 8:10 A.M. yesterday and then leaped to his death from a room on the eighth floor of the Hotel York, 488 Seventh Avenue. His body struck a bakery truck parked on Thirty-sixth Street and then fell into the street.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 28. -- Following is the text of Robert H. Jackson's speech before the Democratic convention:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Cardinal Prince, pacing star of the Hotel Baker Stables, St. Charles, Ill., won the Reynolds Stake, feature of today's Grand Circuit meeting, in straight heats. He paced the first and third heats each in 1:59 1/2. He was driven by his trainer, Sep Palin.

Second Deputy Police Commissioner John J. Sullivan reserved decision in Greenwich Street police station yesterday on a complaint brought against the French Casino, midtown night club, by James A. Leftwich of 65 University Place.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Four teams carded 67s to tie for first honors in the pro-amateur best-ball competition held today at the Winged Foot Golf Club under the auspices of the Westchester Golf Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Pass defense received the chief attention of the coaches today when the Princeton football squad trotted on University Field. Two Black back fields faced the Orange backs and ends. Jim Salsich, Tom Barnicle and Karl Pettit did the passing for the Tiger scrubs, completing enough tosses to show that the varsity still has much to do before the opener with Williams Saturday.

PORTSMOUTH, England, Tuesday, Sept. 29. -- Trail-blazers of a new era in British Empire aviation, nine airplanes took off this morning in a great race across Europe and Africa to Johannesburg, 6,150 miles away, for 10,000 in prizes offered by I.W. Schlesinger of South Africa.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP). -- Soviet officials professed themselves mystified tonight at Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau's charge that Russia had attempted to disrupt the foreign exchange market after an international stabilization accord had been reached.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 28. -- Coldly confident, the Rebel conquerers of Toledo tonight massed their troops for what they hoped would be a final campaign to take Madrid, forty miles to the north, and end the Spanish civil war.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 28. -- Coldly confident, the Rebel conquerers of Toledo tonight massed their troops for what they hoped would be a final campaign to take Madrid, forty miles to the north, and end the Spanish civil war.

Marshall Field's Charing Cross, recovered only recently from bucked shins which made lumps as big as walnuts, won down Belmont Park's Widener chute yesterday to make himself a formidable competitor for the rich Futurity on Saturday.

With France placing a minimum of 5,000,000,000 francs on any outward shipment of gold, and with the United States Treasury limiting shipments of gold to those countries that maintain a fixed selling price for gold, it is evident that movements of the metal for an indeterminate time forward will cease, except for possible driblets from or to minor countries.

Sharply criticizing the tendency, particularly over the radio, to "play down" to audiences. Ira A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks-Fifth Avenue, declared yesterday that advertisers must take stock of the consuming public and decide which way to lead them "up or down."
ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- The keynote address of Martin W. Littleton at the Republican State Convention here was as follows:

Pheasant shooting on licensed game farms starts in Connecticut next Thursday. On these commercial preserves, which raise and release their own birds, the seasons are not governed by the general open dates. New York game farms have been operating since Sept. 1, and in New Jersey the opening date is Nov. 1.

The second annual U.S. Camera Salon, comprising the work of 175 outstanding American photographers, was opened last night in the Mezzanine Gallery of the R.C.A. Building, Rockefeller Center. Through Oct. 11 the show will be free to the public.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on September 23 shows an increase for the week of $89,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, decreases of $13,000,000 in time deposits and of $96,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks, and an increase of $22,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks.
To one who has intelligently followed the history of the League it must seem amazing that Great Britain and France are doing their uttermost to get Italy back in good standing.

Columbia entered its final week of pre-season football practice yesterday at Baker Field by engaging in a two-hour drill in kick formations. According to Coach Lou Little, the Lions have so many difficult games that a point here and there may make the difference between defeat and victory, and he is anxious to have the Blue letter-perfect in conversions after touchdowns.
