RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Many parcels of land owned by the Montauk Beach Development Corporation at Montauk are being advertised for sale by Suffolk County for unpaid taxes for 1935.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28. -- Columbia started a busy week. "Safari in Paradise" went before the cameras with Jean Arthur and George Beck as stars and Lionel Stander, Raymond Walburn and Henry Mollison in the cast under Al Green's direction.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra and its conductor, Serge Koussevitzky, have proposed that the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, at which they took part for the first time last month, be extended next Summer, it was announced yesterday.

The statement attributed to the so-called Loyalist government at Madrid to the effect that Germany is to be awarded the Azores, if the "Rebels" are successful in setting up a government, raises some question as to whether or not such a transfer of government would not constitute a violation of the Monroe Doctrine.

Trends of prices of bonds conflicted yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, reflecting, to some degree, the general uncertainty over repercussions of the international money situation. United States Government obligations continued in supply at receding quotations and declined from 1-32 to 7-32 point on a fairly heavy turnover.

Price changes on the local commodity futures markets yesterday were mixed, with little influence traceable to the developments abroad. In general, however, the trend was lower. On the cash markets cotton, print cloths and cocoa gained, while wheat, corn, rye, flour, rubber, antimony, butter, silk and standard tin declined.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The largest number of narcotics arrests in the Treasury's round-up today was reported in Texas, where 149 persons were taken into custody on narcotics peddling charges. A quantity of marihuana was seized at San Antonio, Texas.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 28. -- The Greenbrier, with more than 1,000 guests, is the scene of many parties.

American taste in art -- its shift from decade to decade -- may be somewhat gauged from the show arranged at the Old Print Shop and current there till Oct. 17. From each ten years beginning with 1840 a group of prints has been selected -- works that met popular approval in their times.

The statement made yesterday to foreign correspondents in Tokyo by ARITA, Minister of Foreign Affairs, gives added emphasis to the serious import of the disclosures reported in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES about the negotiations now being carried on between the Chinese Foreign Minister and the Japanese Ambassador.

MARSHFIELD, Ore., Sept. 28 (AP). -- Twenty thousand residents of Southwestern Oregon placed on the winds tonight the fate of their homes as they heard grimly that nine lives and possibly fifteen had been lost when forest fires laid waste the village of Bandon.

Mrs. Murray Whiting Ferris gave a luncheon yesterday in the Terrace Garden of the Plaza for Dr. Wu Yi-tang, president of Ginling College in China. Other guests included Dr. Tsune-chi You, Chinese Consul General in New York; Dr. and Mrs. Edward H. Hume, Miss Alba de Costa and P.N. Cheng.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- George N. Peek, former AAA Administrator, and former head of the Export-Import Bank, announced his support of Governor Landon tonight in a radio colloquy with William Hard, Republican radio commentator. Mr. Peek attacked the administration's farm record, asserting that the President had broken his pledges and that the policies pursued in dealing with the farm problem were destructive of farm income.

The partners in J.P. Morgan Co. applied to their income tax returns for 1935 a loss of about $9,000,000 incurred through a loan extended to O.P. and M.J. Van Sweringen to bolster a railroad holding structure when it became undermined by falling security prices in 1930, it was disclosed in banking circles yesterday.

The new Maritime Commission, to which the President has just made three temporary appointments, has many important tasks before it. It will be called upon immediately to allocate subsidies, to handle a difficult and strained personnel situation and to improve safety standards on ships flying the American flag.

WHEN Don Carlos Hubbell winds up and begins to fire at the Yankee bats, the ball players will have the stage pretty much to themselves until the big battles are over. But there is still a full day before the storm breaks. That provides a chance to take note or make note of some other little matters that merit attention.

Operations of the steel industry in the third quarter of this year will make a favorable comparison with the second quarter in respect to tonnage, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday on his return from Europe on the Normandie.

An issue of 20,000 shares of $2 cumulative participating preferred stock of the Darling Stores Corporation, New York, will be offered today at $28.50 a share through a prospectus by Leach Brothers, Inc. The proceeds will be used to provide additional working capital, to finance the opening of additional stores and to improve certain leaseholds.
ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- The address of Colonel Frank Knox, candidate for Vice President, before the Republican State Convention tonight was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Back at his desk from a six weeks' tour of the drought area, Rexford Guy Tugwell, the Resettlement Administrator, said that recent rains had brought considerable relief to livestock and dairy farmers who otherwise would now be calling on the government for livestock feed loans, and grants for their own subsistence.

J. Freystadt Sons, Inc., one of the city's oldest retail fur establishments, has leased the store, basement, mezzanine and part of the second floor at 240 Madison Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets, for their retail fur business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- An arrangement for coordinated use of the huge stabilization funds of the United States and Great Britain in protecting their conditional currency agreement with France was understood to be under negotiation today.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 28. -- The keynote speech of Senator Robert F. Wagner, delivered at the Democratic State Convention today, was as follows:

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 28. -- After the fortieth annual women's national golf championship had begun at the crack of dawn over the Canoe Brook Country Club course today and had failed to finish its qualifying throes when darkness descended, there were many things that were not certain, such as the scores of the last nineteen starters and who would win Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare's vacated title.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- The stock market here was in a cheerful mood today, following the collapse of the gold bloc. British Government securities fell sharply on sales by French holders, but among the industrial shares there were many bright features.

Formation of a new Atlas Corporation, with which will be consolidated the present Atlas Corporation, and three large investment companies controlled by the latter company was proposed yesterday by the directors of Atlas Corporation. At a special meeting to be held on Oct. 29 shareholders of Atlas will vote on the plan, which provides for the consolidation with Atlas of Pacific Eastern Corporation, Shenandoah Corporation and Sterling Securities Corporation.

Approach of the world series zero hour, accompanied by chilly weather and the portent of rain, found Joe McCarthy's slugging Yankees still the favorites over Colonel Bill Terry's Giants, with the odds unchanged in the book of Jack Doyle, Broadway commissioner.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Prices of wheat moved up around a cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here in the early trading today in sympathy with the markets in Winnipeg and Liverpool, but it reacted sharply and closed at the day's low level, with December unchanged and May off 1/2 cent.

The State Board of Housing now is engaged in carrying out its announced policy of restricting occupancy of low-income model housing in New York to families of comparatively modest resources, George Gove, secretary, reported yesterday.

Cotton prices here advanced further yesterday into new high ground for the movement as domestic and foreign trade buying continued and offerings were relatively light. Reports or another active day in the cotton cloth market and private advices concerning damage to the cotton crop in the Western belt as a result of the heavy week-end rains resulted in moderate commission-house purchases.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 29. -- For the last three weeks the disturbances in Palestine have been having repercussions in Transjordan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Equity Fund, Inc., Seattle, Wash., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for not in excess of 200,000 shares of common stock of 20 cents par value. The corporation is an investment company.
The public notices column of THE NEW YORK TIMES carried yesterday the following appeal:

America's greatest metropolis, having hit the jackpot in baseball's wheel of fortune this Fall, settles down today to a state of bitter civil war as Colonel Bill Terry marshals his Giants, champions of the National League, to meet the opening assault of Marse Joe McCarthy's American League juggernaut, the Yankees, at the Polo Grounds in the first game of the 1936 world series.

The middle of a very liberal week will be marked this evening by two more new plays. They are: "Stork Mad," a farce comedy by Lynn Root and Frank Fenton, at the Ambassador Theatre. The story was suggested by the current "baby derby" up in Toronto, and the players are Percy t, Dortha Duck'orth, Ann Thomas, Edward F. Nannary, Carleton Maey, Hale lorcross, ir. Root and others.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 29. -- As far as the gallery was concerned there was only one real golf match at the national championship today. When word arrived that Miss Eva Shorb, an unknown, was 1 up on the tournament favorite, little Miss Patty Berg, as early as the third hole, spectators cut across fairways and came out from late luncheons in the clubhouse to watch.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 29. -- The Commonwealth linked Michael Fugmann today to the cigar boxes from which were fashioned the mail bombs which killed Thomas Maloney, insurgent mine leader; his son, Thomas Jr., and Michael Gallagher, school director and cemetery sexton.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons, International League champions, stayed in the running in the little world series tonight by defeating the Milwaukee Brewers of the American Association, 2 to 1, for their first victory in the four games the series has gone to date.

For the last two or three years it has been the conviction of an increasing number of well-informed persons that no permanent stabilization of the world's currencies could be expected until the remaining nations in the "gold bloc " -- France, Switzerland and Holland -- had devaluated.

The level of traffic on the Illinois Central Railroad is at its highest level since 1931, L.A. Downs, president, said yesterday. He said that revenue received this year up to the second week of September exceeded $75,000,000, a total which in previous years had not been reached until the second week in October.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- The text of President Roosevelt's speech tonight to the Democratic State Convention was as follows:

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 29. -- First Selectman Oscar D. TuthilI of Patterson Avenue here died in the Ossining Hospital, Ossining, N.Y., this afternoon at 2:58 o'clock of injuries suffered in an automobile accident on Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff, Saturday night. He was 59 years old. Although funeral plans have not yet been completed, the body will be returned to his home here tomorrow morning.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons are aiding in plans for the annual two-day bazaar in behalf of the charity wards of the Knickerbocker Hospital, to be held on Oct. 6 and 7 at 2,040 Broadway. The occasion will mark the seventy-fourth anniversary of the founding of the institution.

A budding saxophone player who practices six days a week, afternoon and evening, "may be a cross between Spalding and Paderewski and still be a heartache" to his neighbors, Magistrate William O'Dwyer observed yesterday in Adolescents Court in Brooklyn.

GENEVA, Sept. 29. -- The French and British delegations agreed yesterday, it is understood, to submit a joint resolution to the League of Nations Assembly whereby it would recommend abolition of all quotas and exchange control through negotiations to be carried out by the World Bank and the League.

Commodity futures were moderately firmer as a whole yesterday in quiet trading. Old Rio coffees fell to 3 1/4 cents, a new all-time record. In the cash markets, gains appeared in cotton, corn, cocoa, silk, tin and rubber, while rye, oats, butter and lard declined.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Four thousand men and women met here tonight in Constitution Hall for the second annual mass demonstration under the auspices of the Committee on Religious Life in the Nation's Capital. Twenty-two denominations were represented in the assembly of Protestants, Catholics and Jews, whites and Negroes.

Ten minor league players, four of them from the American Association, two from the Pacific Coast League and one each from the International, Texas, Georgia-Florida Leagues and the Southern Association, were brought up to the major leagues last night in the annual draft meeting. Seven of the ten have had major league experience.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29. -- John Castle today succeeded Bill Dickens at left guard on the Yale eleven, the first change made by Coach Ducky Pond in a week. Pond said, however, that it was by no means certain Castle would start the opening game against Cornell Saturday.

PARIS, Sept. 29. -- Opposition in the Senate Finance Committee to many clauses in the franc devaluation bill as passed by the Chamber of Deputies this morning has caused delay until tomorrow of its discussion by the upper house. It has also postponed until at least Thursday the reopening of the Stock Exchange and the fixing of the value of the new "Blum franc" in respect to the pound and the dollar.

Parked just across the street from St. Francis Xavier's Church, Sixth Avenue and Carroll Street, Brooklyn, the automobile in which four youths had been "rooming" for several days seemed unobtrusive and hardly provocative of a police inquiry.

An outline of the programs for the first ten weeks of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of John Barbirolli, British conductor, was made known yesterday. The twenty-four-week season of the orchestra will officially begin on Nov. 5.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- The dry issue, which bothered both major parties in the pre-convention days of 1932, is likely to be raised this year against Governor Landon, it became known here today.

Smiling and adding words of encouragement, Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, presented medals and prizes to a large group of boys and girls yesterday afternoon at the Harvest Day celebration of the Children's Gardens, York Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Some of those attending the Southeastern electric power pool conference which meets in Washington today may find their memories dimly haunted by certain events which took place in Albany early in 1931. In his successful campaign for re-election a few months before, Air. ROOSEVELT had stressed the power issue, in which Western progressives, like Senator NORRIS, were taking such a lively interest.

Justice William F. Bleakley has been an outspoken opponent of the New Deal, especially on the spending, taxation and constitutional issues. He has attacked Governor Lehman as a "New Deal" Governor in recent speeches, and has demanded a return to economy in both Federal and State governments.

How a concession obtained by the United Fruit Company from the Guatemalan Government in 1927 has placed that corporation in a position to obtain one-third control of the International Railways of Central America was disclosed to stockholders of the shipping concern in a letter issued yesterday by John L. Simpson, chairman.

Historians of the theatre will perhaps remember the current week as the time when British actors went mad before he Broadway eye. For with only a cloudy day to separate it from "Night Must Fall," there came last evening to the Fulto Theatre Frank Vosper and his "Love From a Stranger."

Possessed of the optimism and enthusiasm of youth, in spite of his 73 years, Dr. William H. Park, director of the city's Bureau of Laboratories since 1894, will close his official connection with the New York City Health Department today. The severance of his official status, however, will not end his varied investigations into contagious diseases, he emphasized yesterday.

The accomplishments of 46,000 WPA workers on women's and professional projects were reviewed yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, as a companion piece to the "balance sheet" of engineering projects he made public a month ago.

Jack Portney of Baltimore easily outpointed Joe Pennino of East New York in the ten-round main bout of the Broadway Arena last night before a crowd of 3,500. Portney weighed 146 1/2 and Pennino 146 1/4.

The Anglo-French-American gentlemen's agreement to keep steady the pound and dollar on the basis of the franc as devalued strikingly illustrates an important political point. This is that, because of the intolerable length of Presidential campaigns in this country, the Outs must make promises at the peril of having them matched by performance before election day.
Contending Teams and Managers -- Yankees, champions of American League; Joseph V. McCarthy, manager. Giants, champions of National League; William H. Terry, manager.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- Governor Lehman addressed the Democratic State Convention here today immediately after he was renominated for the Governorship. After thanking the delegates for the confidence they reposed in him he pledged himself to serve out the full two-year term should he be re-elected.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- An order in council providing for martial law in Palestine was decreed today by King Edward and the Privy Councilors at Balmoral Castle, Scotland. It enables Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, the High Commissioner, to delegate to General J.G. Dill, commanding the Palestine forces, power to make all regulations for public safety and defense.

BUFFALO, Sept. 29. -- Colonel Ralph K. Robertson, who is named by the Republicans to run for Lieutenant Governor, is a military man and lawyer. Of old Buffalo stock, he represents the third generation of his family in the military service.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP). -- Farmers in widely separated sections of the country are experiencing a farm labor shortage for the first time in seven years.

Michael T. Cannon of 73 Main Street, Tarrytown, N.Y., a 65-year-old pioneer in the telephone business in Rockland and Westchester Counties, will retire tomorrow, after firty-one years and one month of service with the New York Telephone Company, and its predecessor, the Westchester Telephone Company.

Before Europe's political paroxysms have subsided today's history will be translated into tomorrow's mode, J. Hamilton Preston informed members of the Fashion Group yesterday. The impress of current events as "an influence" should be perceptible before long, this authority declared.
BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 29. -- A predominantly proletarian government, the first ever known in Spain, took the reins in Catalonia today and gave immediate effect to its announced program.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- In opening his active campaign for re-election to the Presidency here tonight, Franklin D. Roosevelt denied with the greatest possible emphasis that his administration had fostered a spirit of communism, and bluntly stated that the New Deal had stopped a drift toward radicalism fostered by Republican policies.

Members of the Charter Revision Commission spent yesterday in conference with Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel, and his aides perfecting plans for the appeal tomorrow afternoon to the Court of Appeals in Albany to set aside the decision of Supreme Court Justice Dodd and allow a vote on the new city charter proposal next month.

The Leslie-California Salt Company reported a net profit of $245,821 for the year ended on June 30 after deducting taxes, depreciation and other charges. This equaled $2.10 a share on 116,520 no-par shares of capital stock. In the previous year the net profit was $202,296, or $1.74 a share.

DENVER, Sept. 29 (AP). -- The death toll in the Rocky Mountain region's early season snowstorm mounted to sixteen tonight with the finding of three more bodies as thousands of relief workers started to clean up debris.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29. -- The statement that company unions in the steel industry are revolting "all along the line" and are "showing signs of independence" as a result of the campaign to organize the steel industry was made today by Philip Murray, chairman of the steel workers organizing committee.

Tony Albano, 38-year-old unemployed chauffeur from Brooklyn, who took over the No. 1 post at the Polo Grounds Eighth Avenue bleacher entrance on Sept. 18, last night was willing to consider cash in lieu of glory.

Concluding a month's investigation of the cooperative movement in this country, five executives of Finnish cooperatives yesterday expressed strong approval of the strides made by the American groups, prior to sailing last night for their homeland.

MEXICO, D.F., Sept. 29. -- How a ring manipulating narcotics worth $4,250,000 every three months has been broken up is told in a statement issued this evening by Dr. Jose Siurob, chief of Mexico's Department of Public Health.

The risks of horse racing were never more illustrated than in the Westchester Claiming Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday, in which William Ziegler Jr.'s Wha Hae was first by a half length after two horses went lame in the running. The victor was held at 7 to 2 and defeated Fraidy Cat, the favorite, which was four lengths before First Minstrel. Quel Jeu and Jair then finished as named.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President of the United States, said early today that he had appealed to President Roosevelt to help him surmount a threatened ban against a campaign speech at Terre Haute, Ind.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 29. -- The convention of New York State Shoe Retailers Association ended here today in a session marked by flurries of argument over advertising and selling practices. One argument, an address by James O. Hoyle, professions investigator for the State Education Department, urged the delegates to represent themselves only as "shoe experts" and not as "foot experts."

IN the Summer of 1917, with the war at its height, H.B. Lees Smith, who later became a member of a MacDonald Cabinet, brought into the House of Commons the case of a second lieutenant of the Royal Welsh Fusiliers. This young officer, said he, had enlisted as a private on Aug. 3, 1914. He had been wounded in France, had won the Military Cross and had been cited for conspicuous gallantry.

The Rhode Island School of Design at Providence has acquired a portrait by Gilbert Stuart of Christopher Hughes, American diplomat, from the Ehrich-Newhouse Galleries, Inc., 578 Madison Avenue. The price paid was not revealed.

At 8 o'clock tonight Leo Kieran, reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES and The North American Newspaper Alliance, will leave the Times Building to start on a trip around the world. Throughout his 22,000-mile journey he will use only scheduled and regularly established modes of travel.

The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation will offer today 40,000 shares of Series E 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock at $102 a share and accrued interest through an underwriting group comprising the First Boston Corporation, Edward B. Smith Co., Goldman, Sachs Co., W.C. Langley Co. and Sage, Rutty Steele.

The victories of Cornelius Shields and his Aileen in the Interclub Class season of sailing races and in the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy series, just completed, were confirmed yesterday by official figures from the class committee. Aileen wound up the season with six percentage points over C.B. Stuart's Ariel, and in the Bermuda series had three points on Robert McC. Shields's Canvasback.

Drs. Reynold C. Fuson and Robert F. Christ, working under a du Pont research fellowship in the Organic Chemistry Department of the University of Illinois, from which several notable discoveries have already come, report officially in the current issue of Science that they have manufactured a compound artificially in the laboratory which answers the standard chemical tests for vitamin A.
WACO, Texas, Sept. 29 (AP). -- Flood-congested rivers piled up crop losses tonight in South-Central Texas, forcing lowland residents to flee for their lives.

Buyers' Registrations Up Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed substantial increase over the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 1,018 as against 760 in the previous week and 691 in the same period last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29. -- Maritime unions tonight met a waterfront truce request of the newly created Maritime Commission by reiterating their willingness to extend present working agreements fifteen to thirty days past today's expiration date.

GENEVA, Sept. 29. -- Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Madrid's Foreign Minister, decided tonight to publish, probably tomorrow, documents containing notes to Germany, Italy and Portugal charging them with giving aid to the Rebels. Mr. Alvarez del Vayo made his decision when the opposition of Joseph A.C. Avenol, League Secretary General, to publishing them through the League of Nations stiffened today.

NAPERVILLE, Ill., Sept. 29. -- Three men and a woman, members of a flying camera crew, were killed this evening when their cabin monoplane crashed and burned two miles east of here. The accident occurred only a moment after the plane swooped less than 200 feet over the speeding Chicago, Burlington Quincy Zephyr streamlined train bound for Minneapolis.

HAVANA, Sept. 29. -- An amendment to the law re-establishing the death penalty providing that terrorists, kidnappers and gangsters condemned to death by the urgency courts created for trying such crimes shall in future be executed by a firing squad within twenty-four hours after sentence has been imposed was approved by the House of Representatives this afternoon.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Sept. 30. -- While Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, who has gone to the mountain resort of Kuling instead of proceeding to Nanking, continues to maintain silence, both China and Japan continue to await with tense anxiety some indication of his attitude toward Japan's terms.

Bear speculators against the French franc, who have been waiting many months for devaluation to bring them profits, found a good part of the fruits of their operations snatched from them yesterday when a "squeeze" developed in the foreign exchange market and the franc, instead of falling, rose about a cent above what is expected to be its new valuation.

The 900,000 railroad employes in New York State are to receive with their next pay checks admonitions to fight for the elimination of the provision in the State Constitution which prohibits the charging of tolls on the State Barge Canal, W. Kenneth Hayes, vice chairman of the Associated Railroads of New York State, announced yesterday. Fourteen railroads and the Railway Express Agency comprise the membership of the association.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 29 (AP). -- Jimmy Thomson, long hitter from Shawnee-on-the-Delaware, scored 146 to lead the field in the Philadelphia district qualifying round of the national P.G.A. tournament at the Atlantic City Country Club today.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- The text of the Democratic State platform is as follows:

ALBANY, Sept. 29. -- William F. Bleakley, Supreme Court justice, of Westchester, appeared before a cheering throng at the Republican convention tonight and as the party candidate for Governor called for a united front for victory in the State.

Revenues of utility companies selling natural and manufactured gas in July amounted to $51,593,000, compared with $49,407,800 in the same month last year, a gain of 4.4 per cent, according to the American Gas Association.
LAKEHURST, N.J., Sept. 29. -- With customary precision, the airship Hindenburg made its ninth scheduled landing at the naval air station here today with forty-four passengers and cargo.

A borough-wide search was under way yesterday by the Brooklyn police for two well-dressed hijackers, who stole a truck containing $20,000 worth of cigars and cigarettes after kidpnapping the truck driver and his helper about 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Manufacturers and wholesalers showed substantial gains in August, 1936, over the corresponding month in 1935, and small gains over July of this year, according to a survey made jointly by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce and the National Association of Credit Men, and made public today by the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The government today supported the plea of The Associated Press for a Supreme Court review of its controversy with the National Labor Relations Board in the case of Morris Watson, former employe of the news gathering association.

Attorneys for the Securities and Exchange Commission brought into the record yesterday the testimony of Norman Stern and Herbert King, formerly partners in Arnold Co., as they proceeded with hearings to determine whether these and ten other respondents should be suspended or expelled from securities exchanges for alleged manipulation of the common stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd.

With the arrest of the fifteenth lawyer yesterday on an ambulance-chasing charge, Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the new Accident Fraud Bureau's investigation, announced that there had been a general exodus of lawyers' "runners" or "steerers" sought for questioning in accident litigation.

Staging a strong finish, Eddie Brink, 139 1/2, Scranton, took the decision from Lou Fox, 135 1/2, East Side, in the feature eight-round contest at the New York Coliseum last night before 7,000 persons.

Jack Johnson, the only Negro ever to hold the world's heavy-weight boxing championship, is about to make his debut in grand opera. He will appear in "Aida" Friday night at the Hippodrome. Although he admitted yesterday that he could sing quite well, his vocal talent will not be drawn upon in the opera.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 29. -- A plea for good manners as an essential factor in the maintenance of international peace and goodwill was made here today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29. -- The Red navy's Baltic and Pacific fleets steamed to sea simultaneously today for complicated and realistic war games that will conclude the Fall manoeuvres testing every phase of military preparations in every part of the Soviet Union.

Conformity with city regulations requiring standards of physical equipment and clinical and nursing service for proprietary hospitals has been attained by sixty-two out of sixty-nine such institutions in the city, Hospital Commissioner S.S. Goldwater announced yesterday.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,030,050 barrels, compared to 3,037,000 in the preceding week, a decline of 6,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 13,400 and of 9,900 barrels respectively in California and Oklahoma and a gain of 8,900 in Texas were the important changes.

An American railroad president would be forbidden to drive a passenger express train in Germany, but Dr. Julius Dorpmueller, general director of the German Railroad Company, a position which corresponds to that of president of all American railroads, experienced such a thrill when touring this country and studying our railroads and power works.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Sept. 29. -- John Holter, a destitute man, 77 years old, is in the Ocean County jail here because no public agency would grant relief to him and his wife, Ellen, who is 53 years old.

TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 29. -- The jubilant notes of Te Deum rang out again within the age-old walls of the Alcazar today when the Archbishop of Toledo, Cardinal Goma, celebrated a solemn high mass of thanksgiving for the city's delivery.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Prices of hogs here today were steady to 15 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, with most classes sharing in the advance. Strength in fresh pork and continued light receipts of hogs were the main influences. Fresh pork loins were up 1/2 cent at 16 1/2 to 22 1/2 cents a pound wholesale.

Announcement was made yesterday by the United States Polo Association of the revision of its constitution and of the election of officers and a board of governors for the ensuing year, following the annual meeting of delegates held at the Racquet and Tennis Club last Thursday.
The directors of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation declared yesterday a cash dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable on Oct. 23 to stockholders of record of Oct. 16.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 29. -- The Bath County Hounds, which is entering its sixth season, has just issued its October card, calling for three drags and one live-fox hunt. There will be a meet tomorrow at the Yard, home of the master, Mrs. Fay Ingalls.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Squadron Leader F.R.D. Swain, Royal Air Force test pilot, established a new world altitude record for airplanes yesterday, the Air Ministry announced tonight.
ALBANY, Sept. 29. -- The text of the platform adopted today by the Republican State Convention is as follows:

August sales of reporting wholesale firms in this district averaged 10.6 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year, a smaller increase than in July, according to the monthly review issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve agent here.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Excitement over currencies subsided today on the London Stock Exchange and business became quieter, although the undertone remained firm. British Government stocks opened weak, but made a spectacular recovery in the afternoon, when early losses were converted into gains.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Ordering a slash of 60 per cent in fifteen requests for fees and expenses in connection with the reorganization of the Middle West Utilities Company under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today authorized the Middle West Corporation, successor company, to pay $380,000 for fees, and $104,000 for expenses.
WITH GOVERNMENT FORCES RETREATING ON MADRID, Sept. 29. -- "Shoot your cowards!" the government tonight ordered its military leaders, directing the retreat on Madrid.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 29. -- President William Allan Neilson, at the opening chapel of Smith College this morning, which officially started the academic year, extended greetings to 520 entering freshmen, as well as to the returning upper class men.

A $100,000 project for increasing the number of suites in a twelve-story house at 150-58 West Seventy-ninth Street was among the building plans filed yesterday. The two apartments on each floor will be converted into six units. Details of the projects were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The movement by some of the smaller Securities Exchanges to obtain unlisted trading privileges in stocks which are fully registered on other Exchanges was broadened somewhat today with the filing of applications with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the San Francisco Curb Exchange.

Within the last two months twenty-eight musicians employed in WPA orchestras in the city have left the project to accept private employment, Lee Pattison, city and State director of the WPA Federal Music Project announced yesterday. Mr. Pattison asserted that the "return of these musicians to private jobs points to the fact that musical activity and the possibilities of reemployment have improved considerably within the past few months."

While it was reported yesterday that there was some selling of American securities by Continental Europe, probably due in part to the monetary unsettlement caused there by the French situation, it was stated that England was continuing to buy American securities, which she has done on balance so far in every week this year.

For a number of reasons Judge BLEAKLEY was the strongest of the candidates for the Republican nomination for Governor. The ancient division between the friends of Senator FEARON and Mayor MARVIN of Syracuse would have made the selection of the latter an invitation to local and personal feuds; and the former's long activity in the Legislature would inevitably have exposed him to attacks.
United State Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Samuel Goldwyn, Inc., and Pioneer Pictures, Inc., became members yesterday of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., at an election held in the association offices at 28 West Forty-fourth Street. Mr. Goldwyn will represent his company, and Pioneer will be represented by Merian C. Cooper.

After having remained "dark" for three weeks, in the hands of renovators, the Temporary Galleries oft the Municipal Art Committee, at 62 West Fifty-third Street, reopens to the public today with the first in another series of group exhibitions scheduled for this season.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 29 (AP). -- In one of the most thrilling duels of the season, Mrs. Breen and Garth's Don Guzman, under a strong ride by Charley Stevenson, outfinished Beefsteak by a neck to capture the mile and a sixteenth handicap which featured the second day of the Fall meeting at Rockingham Park today. A crowd of 5,000 was on hand.
TOPEKA, Sept. 29. -- Governor Landon tonight made clear the general policy he would follow in selecting his Cabinet if he should be elected President.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Although it will not actually begin to function for almost thirty days, the new Maritime Commission sent telegrams today to West Coast union officials and shippers urging them to cooperate toward extending for sixty days labor contracts that will expire at midnight tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- A plan for reorganization of the Chicago Great Western Railroad under Section 77 of the amended Bankruptcy Act was submitted today to Federal Judge Charles E. Woodward and the Interstate Commerce Commission by Patrick H. Joyce and Luther M. Walter, co-trustees. The road filed a voluntary petition under the amended Bankruptcy Act on Feb. 28, 1935, after defaulting on bond interest payment.

An increasing demand for store space was indicated in the list of commercial leases reported by brokers yesterday. Merchants, bakers, operators of bars and grills, dry cleaning establishments and other firms and individuals requiring room on the street-level were prominent among the lessees.

Before a cheering crowd of 1,000 on the Boardwalk at the foot of West Tenth Street yesterday, police and civilians rescued four boys who had capsized a canoe 1,000 feet off shore. The boys and two of their rescuers were taken to Coney Island Hospital for treatment.

There has been continued criticism of the President on the ground that relief and unemployment funds have been wasted. But the fact has been overlooked that these funds have been spent in this country and not sent abroad, where our foreign loans, both public and private, may remain indefinitely because of the Hoover moratorium.

Jimmy Oleska, who is attached to the Detective Bureau in Brooklyn, upset a number of prominent district golfers at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday by carding both the low gross and low net scores in the final one-day amateur handicap tournament of the Long Island Golf Association.

Legislation in all States to require annual hearing teats for all school children to find early defects, as the most important step in the prevention of deafness, was proposed by physicians yesterday at a public meeting of the convention of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology in session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MADRID, Sept. 29 (Uncensored). -- The situation in Madrid has taken on a grimmer aspect. Gradually the difficulty of getting food supplies has increased and the organizing ability of the Madrid Town Council is put to even greater tests.

MARSHFIELD, Ore., Sept. 29 (AP). -- Southwestern Oregon's forest fires lost their powerful ally, a high wind, and retreated tonight before dense fog and the determined offensive of 5,000 fire-fighters, battling to save towns in their path.

Short casts: One need only glance at the calendar to realize that the hunting season soon will be on in full swing, for tomorrow marks the opening of woodcock shooting in Northern New York and the inauguration of gunning on various species of game in Maine.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 29 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, repeated today a charge which earlier in his campaign travels brought a storm of controversy -- that "the values of our savings and life insurance are endangered by inflation."

In the space of an hour six suburban housewives yesterday gave veteran advertising men and manufacturers an entirely new insight into premium merchandising, during a symposium on industry problems held in conjunction with the Atlantic Coast Premium Exposition being held at the Hotel Astor by the Premium Advertising Association of America, Inc.

Ticket speculators appear to have a grip on the world series that has not been known for years. Unconfirmed reports credited the scalpers with having acquired enough of the strips to range in value from $100,000 to $500,000.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- A picture of a party united behind Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman as its leaders was presented tonight as the Democratic State convention adjourned.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Sir John Ellerman, shipping man and industrialist who died in 1933, left the greatest fortune ever recorded in Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- John G. Winant, former Republican Governor of New Hampshire, who resigned yesterday as chairman of the Social Security Board to be free to combat Governor Landon's criticism of the Social Security Law, opened his campaign tonight with a radio speech.

The passing combination of Sid Luckman and Johnny Siegal, both sophomores, resulted in Columbia defeating Manhattan, 13 to 7, in an hour and a half scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field. The Jasper touchdown came when Joe Kovacs picked up a blocked punt and raced 50 yards to score.

A dance contest, open to all guests who desire to participate, will be one of the features of the benefit entertainment for Russian invalids of the World War, to be held tomorrow night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis. The program for the evening will include also Oriental and Tartar dances and native songs and numbers by a Russian quartet and a gypsy orchestra.

PHILADELPHIA Sept. 29. -- The Army Quartermaster Depot today awarded contracts for 815,340 yards of 56-inch, 10 1/2-ounce olive drab worsted cloth for shirting, bids on which were opened here Sept. 18 under invitation 45. The bidders were:

The realignment of the Western European currencies to workable parities with the pound and the dollar has been accompanied by the embargoing of the private movement of gold and by the requisitioning of gold stocks. This action closes the great free gold markets hitherto accessible to hoarders and currency managers.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- Attacking the Hull reciprocal trade pacts as a "program of tariff destruction," Julius Klein, who was Assistant Secretary of Commerce in the Hoover administration, told the closing session today of the eighth Boston conference on distribution that the agreements had resulted in "soaring" imports, small export gains and "outright gifts" to countries not parties to specific pacts, "without the United States getting anything whatever in return."

Mayor La Guardia combined words of advice to prospective officers of merchant ships with criticism of the government's policy of mail subsidy of ship lines in an address yesterday at the graduation of thirty-four cadets of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy in the Maritime Association Building.
AURORA, Ill., Sept. 29 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace declared today that the Roosevelt administration's "expenditures for recovery look like the best investment in history."

Those who assume that there is "no solution of the relief problem," without a change of government in Washington, or perhaps even with such a change, will find in the latest report of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration facts which justify a more optimistic view.
Dave Levin, the Jamaica butcher boy, defeated Chief Little Wolf, Navajo Indian from Albuquerque, N.M., in the feature wrestling match at Madison Square Garden last night.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29 (AP). --Rosalind, owned by Gibson White of Lexington and driven by Ben White, won the forty-fourth renewal of the Kentucky Futurity, valued at $10,000, the Grand Circuit feature today. It was Rosal ind's seventh victory in eight starts and boosted her earnings to more than $42,000.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 (AP). -- A new X-ray treatment for obscure tumors of the brain was described today before the American Roentgen Ray Society.
IT was a bystander from Boston who said that this was anybody's series, which was a gross exaggeration. Maybe he was a somnambulist who hadn't waked up to the fact that the Red Sox dream was over.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday announced that it had approved the application of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company to list 230,000 additional shares of common stock to be exchanged for the outstanding shares of the Terrabella Investment Company, a California corporation engaged in the oil business.

PARIS, Sept. 29. -- A graphic account of the rescue of forty wounded members of the crew of the Almirante Juan Ferrandiz, including the "commander," who is merely a first mate, was given to the Havas News Agency correspondent at Marseilles tonight by Captain Lelong of the steamer Koutoubia, which performed the rescue.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 29. -- Tall, talkative Dizzy Dean drawled today that he will be the first big 1937 holdout, that the Yanks will win the world series and that the Cardinals have too many bush leaguers on the team.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- President Roosevelt arrived here at 4 P.M. after a five hour ride from Hyde Park, where, just before he left his home for his special train, he received a large delegation of educators who presented to him a memorial of thanks for aid given to education by the administration.

A reply by Harry Uviller, impartial chairman of the dress industry, to the open letter criticizing local conditions sent him yesterday by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, will be forwarded within a few days, Mr. Uviller said last night.

An "assertive, militant public opinion boldly attacking the remaining small per cent of bunk and nonsense in advertising would clear up the situation overnight," according to a statement issued yesterday by the Advertising Federation of America in reply to a criticism of advertising practices made by Dr. Logan Clendening of Kansas City.

Price movements of bonds on the Stock Exchange were irregular yesterday, although trading was more active than on the previous day. Transactions amounted to $16,537,000, compared with $14,690,500. Of this total $10,047,000 was in domestic corporation issues and $4,525,500 in United States Government securities, compared respectively with $9,894,000 and $3,503,500 on Monday.

A "sit down" strike was staged early yesterday afternoon by about 135 members of the deck and engineering staff of the liners President Roosevelt of the United States Lines, Pennsylvania of the Panama Pacific Line and American Trader of the American Merchant Line, in protest against the policy of the owners of the ships in union matters.
TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. 29. -- Bit by bit, the horrors of the siege of Toledo's Alcazar came from the lips of the wasted and hysterical survivors tonight.

For two and one-half hours yesterday Father Divine, Negro cult leader of Harlem, blandly parried questions put to him at a hearing in County Court by William W. Lesselbaum, an attorney who is trying to collect $7,245 in judgments from him.
THE TIMES seems to have missed Senator Norris's position in censuring him for his outspoken criticism of the Republican party's supporters.

Laurence B. Halleran, brother of John J. Halleran, Commissioner of Public Works in Queens, was the principal witness yesterday in condemnation proceedings covering 600 acres of ground in the vicinity of Flushing Bay taken by the city for the site of a World's Fair.
GENEVA, Sept. 29. -- The Assembly of the League of Nations heard the spokesmen of three British dominions today and found them poles apart on a basic peace policy and League reform.

MIAMI, Sept. 29 (AP). -- Stevedores struck suddenly at this port today, bringing to a head differences between the steamship lines and the International Longshoremen's Union which had smoldered all Summer.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 30. -- Roaring southward over African wastes early today, Captain Stanley Halse, South African World War ace, is leading the all-British $50,000 prize air race from England to Johannesburg, South Africa, where he is expected to land at noon in the record time of thirty hours from Portsmouth.

Before the adjournment of Congress the Senate appointed a subcommittee to be on its guard, as it were, against political corruption during the Presidential campaign. This committee, of which Senator LONERGAN is chairman, has funds at its disposal and a force of investigators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Elisha Walker of Kuhn, Loeb Co. of New York, testifying today before the Securities and Exchange Commission, declared that, in his opinion, investment corporations should not be subjected to governmental regulation or restrictions greater than those applied to other types of corporations.

The stock market continued yesterday to move irregularly. Prices fluctuated narrowly for the most part as traders were constrained to operate cautiously until the immediate outlook for the markets can be more fully appraised with respect to devaluation of the franc and the other gold currencies.

A syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers won yesterday the award of $5,595,000 of refunding bonds of Cincinnati, Ohio, on a bid of 100.03 for the securities as 2 1/4s and 3 1/4s, at a net interest cost to the city of 2.382 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 29. -- The Princeton football team was placed on the goal line today, first for a defensive stand against the scrubs and then for a forty-minute offensive drive toward the final chalk mark.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- Temporarily at least, Germany proposes to stand pat on her currency, financial and economic policies, and especially her foreign trade methods, which are isolating her more and more from the world economy.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 30. -- The Chino-Japanese outlook remains critical and though no events comparable in significance to Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita's warning to China on Monday can be reported today, all indications confirm the belief that Japan is determined and prepared.
DETROIT, Sept. 29. -- All except one of the twelve men on trial for the Black Legion slaying of Charles A. Poole May 12 were found guilty of murder today.
Twelve properties, including two nine-story apartment houses on the West Side, were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auction sales yesterday, as follows:

Business failures declined in the retail and manufacturing groups but showed a slight gain in the wholesale division in the week ended Sept. 24, compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail insolvencies constituted 56 per cent of the aggregate last week, compared with 56.9 in the preceding week and 53.9 per cent a year ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29. -- Francine Larrimore, who has been waiting patiently here for a year for an opportunity, has been engaged by B.P. Schulberg for the leading feminine role in "A Man and a Woman," in which Edward Arnold is starred.

With the handing up yesterday of the Drukman grand jury's final report -- a presentment criticizing high police officials -- Hiram C. Todd announced his intention of resigning within a few days as special prosecutor in the ten-month inquiry which resulted in the convictions of three murderers and three conspirators in the reopened Drukman murder case.

ALBANY, Sept. 29. -- After nominating a ticket headed by Justice William F. Bleakley of Westchester as candidate for Governor, and adopting a platform endorsing the stand of Governor Landon, the Presidential nominee, on outstanding issues in the national campaign, the Republican State convention came to a close this evening.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Murry c. Becker of New York, counsel for William Fox in his bankruptcy proceedings here, was threatened today with a citation for contempt of court.
Several improvement projects were announced in connection with Manhattan realty sales and leases reported yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- The Boerse suffered a sharp reaction today, when the financial community finally became convinced from bonafide official declarations that Germany would not devalue the mark at this time. Losses in prices of securities ranged up to 4 and 5 points, extending throughout the list, although the turnover tended to shrink.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 29. -- The Democratic women of the State joined today for a special tribute to Mrs. Caroline O'Day when she was renominated for Representative at Large in the convention hall. They arranged for Amelia Earhart, neighbot of Mrs. O'Day in Rye, to second the renomination of New York's only woman Representative.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Swooping down on internal revenue and narcotic law violators, Treasury agents arrested 1,088 persons yesterday in one of the most dramatic raids on the underworld yet undertaken by the Federal Government. The force of about 2,500 men was engaged today in "clean up" operations.

In line with the general upturn in Great Britain, advertising volume there this year is running 30 per cent ahead of 1935, according to Frank Goldberg, head of an Australian advertising agency, who returned here this week from a three months' tour of the Continent and England.

A rush of last-minute renting kept brokerage and management firms busy yesterday as large numbers of tenants sought to obtain new accommodations before the expiration of their present leases. All classes of apartments were in demand and all sections of the city were represented in the day's activity, which included numerous renewal contracts.
Thomas T. Carter has been admitted as a general partner in Carter Co.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 29. -- The Meadow Brook Club's tournament polo came to a close this morning when a sixty-yard free hit by Earle A.S. Hopping, lofted high in the air, brought to a close an extra-period battle between the Aiken Cyclones and Old Westbury, giving the former the title in the Sixteen Goal Autumn Plate tournament. The score was 8 to 7.

Vocal tones engaged the attention of Magistrate Overton Harris for a time yesterday as he heard a hotel bill fraud case in West Side Court. First he rebuked the toothless defendant, Joseph Redding, 62 years old, of Gainesville, Fla., for speaking almost inaudibly, and then he censured Albert E. Baker, the complainant's attorney, for talking too loud.

There appears to be no concrete plan of world trade expansion that includes the specialty manufacturers with limited distribution facilities. Collectively they would contribute largely to an increase in our total exports. It is quite apparent that this problem is not production, but distribution, the cost of which is prohibitive if individual selling agencies are maintained.

Passengers sailing today for Europe on the French liner Normandie include Gertrude Michael and Sally O'Neil, screen actresses, and a delegation returning from the power conference, including Pierre Launay, Admiral Rolland Boris, Armand Mayer, Andre Genthial, Emil Pontzen and Jean Fallon.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29. -- If there is any reward for consecration to the job at hand, Harvard should have no cause for concern as to what the future holds in store for its football team.
BERLIN, Sept. 29 (AP). -- The German decree under which the standing armed forces are to be increased to 800,000 men went into effect. The decree prolongs compulsory military service to two years.

There's fun in the news even in days of doom -- if you can find it. Here's the poet D'ANNUNZIO exhorting MUSSOLINI to maintain his "placid hilarity" before Geneva. A nice Roman phrase, but not a precise description of the present temper of Rome.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 29. -- President Mary E. Woolley of Mount Holyoke College announced in chapel this morning that an anonymous donor had agreed to make gifts which eventually may amount to $1,000,000.

ROME, Sept. 29. -- An inter-Ministerial meeting, held in the Palazzo Venezia this morning, gave Premier Benito Mussolini an opportunity to consult his principal financial and economic advisers on the dilemma of devaluation or adherence to the lira's present gold value.

Scholarships for the academic year 1936-37, totaling more than $110,000, have been awarded to 322 students, it was announced by Columbia University yesterday. Among the recipients, including 304 men and eighteen women from nearly every State in the Union, are graduates of colleges, technical schools and universities in all sections of the country.
St. Michael's Monastery Church in Union City, N.J., which was restored at a cost of $700,000 after a fire in May, 1934, was rededicated yesterday.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Almost without exception the favorites in the women's national golf championship lived up to expectations in the opening round of match play on the Canoe Brook course today. Most of them paraded into the second without any great trouble, but a few had bad scares before surviving in the battle for the title Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare tossed aside after winning it for the sixth time last year.
The admission of general partners and the formation of new investment houses were among the important month-end changes announced by the following firms:

SCHOHARIE, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- A unique chapter in American railroading ended today when the only train of the Middleburgh Schoharie line puffed noisily into the station here to end operations on one of the world's smallest rail units.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Coach Dick Harlow was all smiles again today as his Harvard varsity eleven, which was playing against one of the strongest combinations that could be organized, got together as in no previous scrimmage this season.
Deflation of relief costs was asked by Louis K. Comstock yesterday in his annual report as president of the Merchants Association.

Store rentals continued to make up the larger part of the business leases as reported by brokers yesterday. Among the lessees was the G. G. Shops, which took for the fourth link in its lingerie and hosiery chain the store at 2 West Fourteenth Street.

A 4-year-old political feud moved yesterday into a new phase as Miss Natalie Couch challenged her Democratic opponent for Representative at Large, Mrs. Caroline O'Day, to a series of public debates on issues of the campaign. She said she was especially interested in starting with the Home Owners Loan Corporation as a topic.

In response to an appeal from banks here the Bank of France made available yesterday a supply of franc exchange in this market, ending the severe squeeze which on Tuesday sent the franc to about a cent above what its new value is expected to be.

PARIS, Sept. 30. -- Ambassador William C. Bullitt took over the succession from Jesse I. Straus at the United States Embassy here this morning after his arrival on the liner Washington accompanied by his daughter.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 30. -- City officials who had warned Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, that he would be jailed if he came here made good their threat today.

By a curious twist the first important example of international monetary cooperation which was called for as a result of the new turn of events in France took the form of help from the French for this market, rather than assistance from this side for the French.
The first checks issued in this city under the new Federal and State social security laws will go today to 27,448 needy men and women 65 years of age and older.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has long been known as an Independent Democratic newspaper. It has always placed chief emphasis on the word "Independent." Never having followed in blind faith any political leader or party, it has exercised the right to express its sincere convictions on all public matters without fear or favor.
TORONTO, Sept. 30. -- The acclaim of critics and the plaudits of a capacity audience greeted John Gielgud in his North American debut here tonight as Hamlet in the Guthrie McClintic production.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30. -- Yale had a driving workout at a secret drill on Anthony Thompson Field today as it reached the peak of its practice for the Elis' opening engagement with Cornell here Saturday.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The Boerse opened firm today, with the tendency remaining unchanged throughout the session, largely because of the favorable view of the currency situation and the increase in Reich revenues. Anticipation of the statement of Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Finance and president of the Reicbsbank, also provided a steadying factor, as it was widely assumed that he would reject devaluation of the mark.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- Germany will not devalue the domestic parity of the reichsmark, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank, declared today in giving the German answer to the democratic currency entente concluded by the United States, France and Great Britain.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 30. -- On one of the most dreary days in the history of the event -- marrow-chilling weather and pouring rain -- the women's national golf championship today lost one of its most interesting personalities, little red-headed Patty Berg, sensational Minneapolis girl.

Bill Hewitt, Chicago Bears' end, and Cliff Battles, Boston Redskins' halfback, are tied for the individual scoring leadership in the National Football League, according to statistics compiled yesterday. Each has tallied three touchdowns for a total of 18 points.

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- The Boston Shamrocks opened the local American League football season under the floodlights at National League Park tonight with a 7-to-0 victory over the New York Yankees. Despite the threat of rain which materialized as a drizzle by half time, more than 5,000 spectators turned out for the moonlight tilt.

Trading was fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were more active at slightly lower prices. Some steer cuts were lower and some lamb and pork cuts higher. Other classes were mostly steady. Early trading in kosher meats was slow. Beef and veal were about steady and kosher lamb lower.

MADRID, Sept. 30. -- Madrid's defenders tonight pinned their hope of stopping the Rebel surge against the capital on a bolstered line of militiamen at Aranjuez, one of the last large settlements blocking the northward drive from Toledo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- After spending fourteen hours in Washington tending to a long list of official engagements, President Roosevelt departed late tonight to make an intensive campaign swing tomorrow in West Virginia and Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Investigation by the Postoffice Department of the reported seizure and destruction by Harvard officials of pamphlets mailed to guests at the university's tercentenary celebration was requested today by three Harvard alumni, Quincy Howe, Varian Fry and Gardner Jackson.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, said yesterday that Governor Landon would not have the opportunity to carry out his promise made on Tuesday night to appoint a business man instead of his campaign manager as Postmaster General.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30. -- The Koppers Gas and Coke Company has changed its name to Koppers Company in connection with a forthcoming refunding program involving financing of between $25,000,000 and $30,000,000. Parent companies of the Koppers Gas and Coke also will change their names to avoid similarity of titles.

Madrid is now fully aware of its military plight. To cope with the mounting danger the Republican government may have popular devotion at its disposal, but obviously not very much military leadership.
DENVER, Sept. 30. -- Following is the text of Herbert Hoover's address tonight before the American Mining Congress:

The stock market was generally firm yesterday until the final half hour of business when a moderate increase in offerings eased prices somewhat. The closing was irregular, with THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks off 0.72 point on the day.

A petition asking President Roosevelt to invoke embargo quotas if necessary to check growing imports of wool felt hat bodies from Japan was taken to Washington and left at the White House yesterday by a committee representing leading manufacturers in the domestic wool felt hat body industry.
This has the makings of a good old-fashioned knock down and drag out fight:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 30 (AP). -- Earl's Spencerian, owned by Earl Shropshire of Lexington, won the sixtieth renewal of the Lexington Stake for 2-year-old trotters at the Grand Circuit meeting today. The Hanover Shoe Farm's Shirley Hanover took the second heat.

DENVER, Sept. 30. -- Former President Hoover charged here tonight that the Federal tax on undistributed corporation profits tended "to stifle honest enterprise, to lessen national assets, to help the powerful instead of the weak, to cost men jobs."

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 30. -- Elwood Sachsenmaier's Roman Soldier, running like a champion and showing utter disregard for rain and mud, outclassed seven rivals, including the A.G. Vanderbilt ace, Discovery, today in the $10,000 added Havre de Grace Handicap.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Thursday, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press). -- C.W.A. Scott, who with the late T. Campbell Black won the 1934 London-Melbourne air derby, appeared this morning to have taken a definite lead in the England-Johannesburg air race, after Captain S.S. Halse, who had been far ahead, had crashed yesterday near Salisbury, Southern Rhodesia.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Devaluation of the franc is the most important economic event since that of the dollar, nearly three years ago. If it is carried through successfully it may prove the best thing that has happened of any kind in that period.

Bookings of steel companies in September were 25 to 50 per cent greater than in August, establishing the last month as probably the best of the year, according to The Iron Age. Steel buying was spurred in recent weeks, the review said, by the realization of consumers that mills are sold out and deliveries within reasonable limits may not be easy to obtain for the remainder of the year.

Mrs. James Hope Caldwell entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for her daughter, Mrs. John D. Blanchard. The other guests were Princess Vladimir Koudacheff and Mrs. William Hutchinson. Another luncheon there was given by Mrs. Crimmins Jennings for Mrs. W. Woodward Phelps, Mrs. William F. Cogswell and Miss Janice Jennings.

Making a significant change in policy in the field of transport, the Railroad Express Agency, largest of monopolies permitted under the Federal laws, announced yesterday that it had organized a general sales department.

Charged with receiving and boarding a white child without the necessary permit from the Department of Health, Serena Alves, 36 years old, a Negress, of 136 West Twenty-eighth Street, proved in Jefferson Market Court yesterday to be the benefactress of a needy family and won the sympathy and assistance of Magistrate Louis Brodsky.

On a flying visit to New York yesterday, John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, reiterated his challenge to President Roosevelt to prove his sincerity in repudiating Communist support by causing the removal of David Dubinsky as a Democratic Presidential elector in this State.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Oct. 1. -While dispatches from Tokyo indicate steadily diminishing patience coupled with determination to use force against China if necessary, conditions in Nanking remain deadlocked.

Herbert A. Baker, vice president of the American Can Company, was elected yesterday president of the company to succeed C.E. Green, who resigned because of ill health. Mr. Green had been president since May, when he took the place of H.W. Phelps, who became chairman of the board.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 30. -- The Roosevelt administration is headed for a collectivist goal, Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, told the Republican State convention here today Mr. Mills added that the people were being bribed to entrust local affairs to a "bureacracy" in Washington.

Eighteen men, including several out-of-towners, were arrested near the Polo Grounds yesterday, accused of speculating in tickets to the world series. Five, accused of disorderly conduct, got off with fines of $10 each when arraigned before Magistrate Earl A. Smith in Washington Heights Court.

Reduction of the 10 per cent penalty on tax arrears to the former rate of 7 per cent was recommended yesterday by the taxation committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. The report, urging Mayor La Guardia and other city officials to amend the bankers' agreement and local laws to provide for the reduction, will be acted upon by the chamber at a meeting today.

On rain-soaked field and under a steady downpour that drenched spectators and combatants alike, Carl Hubbell, left-handed manipulator of an intricate piece of wrist dexterity known as the "screwball," smothered the mighty Yankees yesterday, and rolled them over in the mud in an impressive victory witnessed by a gathering of 42,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- President Roosevelt today accepted the resignation of John G. Winant as chairman of the Social Security Board, saying in a letter to the former Governor of New Hampshire that he did so "with the deepest regret" and because it would leave Mr. Winant more free "to defend the great work which you have so well begun."

For the quarter ended on Aug. 31 the Nash Motors Company reported yesterday a net profit of $177,249 after expenses, provision for State and Federal taxes and other charges. In the comparable period last year there was a net loss of $161,878.
The Republican State platform contains this striking plank:

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Oct. 1 (AP). -- A fifteen-day truce in the dispute between West Coast ship-owners and longshoremen over labor contracts was virtually assured today as Maritime Commission officials reported owners had offered an extension of present contracts for that period.

I was recently retained to bring action for one of my clients who was injured in an automobile accident, as a result of which he will undoubtedly be a hopeless cripple. His usefulness to himself, his family and society is at an end, and his care and maintenance will now devolve upon the city, the cost of which will be charged to the taxpayers, because the car which injured him is not insured.

It rained. And how it rained! The two bullpens were gleaming black lakes and the diamond was a green swamp as the first game of the world series -- from a crowd standpoint at least -- stepped off tea limping start at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
A call for a new political alignment in State and nation was issued last night by the American Labor party with the publication of its program of legislative demands.
The play-by-play description of the first game of tile World Series at the Polo Grounds, yesterday, follows:

MOSCOW, Sept. 30. -- Though it still appeared improbable today that the Soviet Union would make a diplomatic protest to the United States because of the statement by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. that he had saved the British pound from a Soviet attempt to drive it down, the Soviet revealed its choler in sarcastic editorial attacks against Mr. Morgenthau in two Moscow newspapers, Izvestia and Pravda.

Newspapers have been reporting the appearance of sunflowers in vacant lots and other open spaces. Whether this is to give publicity to the Republican party or to direct attention to the apparently common existence of this flower it is difficult to determine.

The bout between Tony Canzoneri and Jimmy McLarnin, scheduled for tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden, has been put off to Monday, it was announced yesterday, because Canzoneri suffered a cut lip in sparring. The former lightweight champion is sure that a few days will be enough for the lip to heal.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag reserved decision yesterday on the application of Frank J. Prial for a re-count of the Democratic primary ballots for President of the Board of Aldermen which, on the face of the count, Mr. Prial lost to Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens, the organization candidate, by 24,714 votes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- In a move toward pooling public and private electrical resources to attain greater economy and quicker expansion, President Roosevelt today held his first conference with power utilities officials and those in charge of Federal generating projects.

Apartment rentals reported yesterday included a lease of a floor in the cooperative house at 139 East Seventy-ninth Street to Jacob H. Shaffer of Chappaqua. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers. Other lessees were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- In the first criminal proceedings in Colorado under the Securities Act of 1933 five men have been indicted by a Federal grand jury in Denver, on a charge of conspiracy to violate the act in connection with the sale of securities of the North American Bond and Share Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The official opening today of Pinewood, film studios at Iver Heath, Buckinghamshire, Britain's latest challenge to Hollywood, was celebrated with a luncheon. More than a thousand guests were present. Leslie Burgin, parliamentary secretary of the Board of Trade, declared the studios open.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 30. -- Judgments totaling almost $38,000 have been granted against Mrs. Rosalie Jones Dill of Cold Springs Harbor, L.I., former women's suffrage leader. Justice Bonynge in Supreme Court here yesterday granted a $31,647.02 judgment against Mrs. Dill to the Bank of Hicksville and another for $6,296.99 to the Bank of Farmingdale.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (AP). -- A new machine capable of producing 1,000,000-volt X-rays with an intensity greater than all of the available radium in the world was announced today before the American Roentgen Ray Society.

Striking seamen walked off the 14,000-ton transatlantic liner President Roosevelt yesterday because of dissension within their own union, forcing officials of the United States Line to call off the sailing.

Chairman Hamilton's announcement, confirmed by Governor Landon, that in the event of Republican success he will not distribute Federal patronage from the Postoffice Department, calls for much amplifying before believers in the merit system can conclude that the Republicans have come over to them.

Advances of about $1 a bale in the prices of futures on the Cotton Exchange yesterday lifted them to around the levels touched after the Sept. 8 government crop estimate and $2.30 to $3.05 a bale above the low prices of Sept. 22. Heavy mill price fixing against continued large sales of goods, foreign demand on improvement in the monetary situation and a broader speculative demand were factors in the rise.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 30. -- Miss Elizabeth Schwarz, daughter of Mrs. Henry F. Schwarz of Fairfield Avenue, is in the Greenwich Hospital, critically injured as the result of a fall from her horse yesterday. She is on the danger list, suffering from a fractured vertebra and contusions of the head.

The International Salt Company has called for redemption $755,500 of its first and consolidated collateral-trust mortgage 5 per cent bonds, which will be delivered under the terms of the indenture on April 1, 1937. Of the total of $12,000,000 of these bonds authorized, $6,519,000 have been redeemed through operation of the sinking fund and otherwise, leaving $4,678,500 outstanding.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 30. -Mrs. Carleton H. Palmer of Fairfield, a former national president of the Junior League, was nominated today by Democrats of the Twenty-fifth Senatorial District as their candidate for the Senate. A prominent figure in New York and Connecticut society, Mrs. Palmer will oppose State Senator J. Kenneth Bradley of Westport, national chairman of the Young Republicans and a campaign aide to Governor Landon.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 30. -- Now a bankrupt, William Fox, former motion picture executive, believed he was worth approximately $100,000,000 in 1930. That was his testimony offered on the stand in the bankruptcy proceedings before Federal Referee Robert E. Steedle here today.

IN his new novel, "King Cole" (Harper, $2.50), W.R. Burnett submits the portrait of a possible American dictator. The man's name is Read Cole. He is Governor of Ohio. He is a pleasant, restrained, canny man, with few enemies, almost no intimates, many disciples, and thousands of acquaintances. He is observant, intelligent, a better listener than talker, imaginative but not sensitive, solidly realistic rather than visionary, a dictator by accident rather more than by design.

Dodd, Mead have an author on their list who daily commutes from a yacht to work here in New York City. He is Winthrop P. Moore, who has lived aboard his seventyfoot yacht Tondeteyo all the year round for the past four years. At present the yacht is off S/amford but its position may be changed at any time.

One of these days some one among the Abbotts, Dunnings, Barrys or Hechts will write a play for Perey Kilbride. It has been owed him for a long while, and when it finally comes there will be an evening. He is of the top flight of drama's comics, and yet persists in being sidetracked into such matters as last night's "Stork Mad."
BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The text of the declaration of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, President of the Reichsbank, before the bank's central committee today follows:

THE rain that began to sprinkle the world series contenders in the second inning at the Polo Grounds yesterday was a distinct surprise. Up to that moment the players and spectators had been expecting snow.

ALBANY, Sept. 30. -- William F.
