Bleakley, who will resign tomorrow as a justice of the Supreme Court to begin his campaign as Republican candidate for Governor, walked into the Capitol Building today and had a talk in the ways and means committee room with some fifty Republican candidates for the Assembly.
The Museum of Modern Art, now at 11 West Fifty-third Street, will erect a new building on the site now occupied by Nos. 9, 11, 13, 15, 17 and 19 West Fifty-third Street, it was announced last night.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Sept. 30. -- More than a thousand colonists attended "Frolics of 1936," with floor show and dance, tonight at the Greenbrier, in the Cameo Ballroom, transformed for the event as a night club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30. -- "Woman of Glamour," a film which Columbia regards as one of its better efforts of the season, was announced today. It will feature Melvyn Douglas and Virginia Bruce, who has been borrowed from Metro for the leading role, with Reginald Denny in a supporting part.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (AP). -- The Weatherhead Company, manufacturer of automotive parts, announced today the purchase of the old plant of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation and an employe profit- sharing plan based on earnings for the first six months of 1936.

An exhibition of Finnish industrial art, comprising more than 10,000 pieces, will be opened at 2:30 P.M. Saturday by Ero Jarnefeldt, Finland's Minister to Washington, and Mrs. Jarnefeldt. The exhibition will occupy the seventh floor of the Seventh Avenue Building of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and will be open to the public daily until Oct. 17.

The purchase by Arlington C. Hall of the two six-story elevator apartment houses at 53 to 59 East Ninety-sixth Street was announced yesterday by Duff Conger, Inc., broker in the deal with Wood, Dolson Company, Inc. Assessed at $260,000, the buildings occupy a plot 100 by 100 feet between Park and Madison Avenues.

New York University's varsity football squad of thirty-nine players, headed by Coach Mal Stevens, will depart tonight from Pennsylvania Station bound for its opening game of the season, with Ohio State at Columbus on Saturday. This afternoon the players will go through their final workout at Ohio Field and a drill is planned for tomorrow after the arrival.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore reported yesterday a net income of $6,499,443 for the year ended on Aug. 31 after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $4.61 each on 1,167,397 no-par common shares and compared with $6,077,025, or $4.21 a share, earned in the preceding twelve months.

The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the last month showed a slight increase over that of August. Sales in September, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 30,872,287 shares, compared to 26,564,032 in August, and 34,748,340 in September, 1935.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Testifying before the Securities and Exchange Commission in its investigation of investment trusts and investment companies, Henry M. Minton, vice president and chief executive officer of the Spencer Trask Fund, Inc., urged today that the regulations of the New York Stock Exchange be amended to cover the activities of member firms in their relationship to investment trust management and sponsorship.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, announced yesterday that the Atlas Corporation and associates had bought all the common stock of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., from the estate of Franklin Simon and from members of the Franklin Simon family.

VATICAN CITY, Sept. 30. -- Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, will sail from Naples tomorrow for New York in strictest incognito aboard the liner Conte di Savoia, on which the new Italian Ambassador to the United States, Fulvio Suvich, also will travel.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild's board of directors met yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pierre. Plans for an increased membership of the organization were outlined by Mrs. Herbert Witherspoon, secretary.

With official timers snapping stop watches. Leo Kieran, reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES and the North American Newspaper Alliance, left Times Square last night on a trip around the world. At 7:43 P.M. he stepped from the doors of the Times Building and into an American Air Lines automobile, bound for Lakehurst to board the Hindenburg.

Topeka, Sept 30. -- Following is the text of the report on the Social Security Act submitted to the Twentieth Century Fund and made public here today by Governor Landon as being the basis of his Milwaukee speech Saturday night:

On the grounds of the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L.I., this morning the thirty-fourth annual Piping Rock horse show will be opened, to continue through Saturday afternoon. Sixty-one classes will be judged during six sessions.

The vastness of the plans for the World's Fair of 1939 and its importance in expanding trade for New York were emphasized yesterday by Grover Whalen, president of the corporation directing the exposition, at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.

Although the passage of the Robinson-Patman act has stimulated interest in the competition between private brands and nationally advertised lines in the food industry, the trend toward private labels has been a well-defined movement among voluntary and cooperative groups since these organizations began to gain real strength.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. 30. -- With 2,000 warriors brought over from Morocco moving rapidly in trucks toward Toledo for the Rebel push on Madrid, General Francisco Franco, the insurgent commander-in-chief, turned his principal attention today to cleaning up along his flanks and eliminating the danger from Loyalist fighters who face his long, thin line on a fifty-mile front.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Sept. 30. -- Their nerves shattered by their terrible ordeal, many of the 1,600-odd men, women and children besieged in the Toledo Alcazar for seventy days refuse to leave the dark dank caves underneath and face the light of day, foreign news correspondents entering the ruined city discovered.

NANKING, China, Thursday, Oct. 1. -- A new basis for resumption of negotiations between Foreign Minister Chang Chun and Ambassador Kawagoe has been established, a Foreign Office spokesman admitted yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 30. -- Women members of the Republican convention hailed the nomination of Justice Bleakley for Governor today as they left for their homes.

Addressing a group of leading labor men representing both craft and industrial union organizations, Matthew Well, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, pleaded yesterday for peace in the factional conflict between the A.F. of L. and the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Dr. Walter F. Barry of the Essex County Country Club became the New Jersey senior golf champion today when he defeated Ferdinand A. Hubert of the home club by five strokes in an eighteen-hole medal play-off at the Essex Fells Country Club.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 30. -- Mrs. Henry Walters arrived from Newport this morning. Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Britton Katte of New York are newcomers.

Hollywood's second film transcription of George Kelly's Pulitzer Prize play of 1926, "Craig's Wife," will have its local premiere today at the Radio City Music Hall. First filmed By Pathe in 1928, the play has been remade by Columbia under Dorothy Arzner's direction and is played by Rosalind Russell, John Boles, Billie Burke, Jane Darwell and Dorothy Wilson.

GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia urged the League of Nations today to reopen peace negotiations with Italy to obtain a "national home" for his people in a definite settlement of the war. To this end, his delegate, Ato Lawrence Taezaz, said the Emperor was ready to make "considerable sacrifices."

TOPEKA, Sept. 30. -- Governor Landon made public today a hitherto unpublished report of the Twentieth Century Fund on the Roosevelt administration Social Security Act, on which he said he based his social security speech at Milwaukee Saturday night.

Price movements were erratic and the changes generally small in dull trading on the commodity futures market yesterday. There was further liquidation of old Rio contract coffee. On the cash markets cotton, wool tops, butter, tin and silk advanced, while all the grains and rubber eased.

The opening of December books tomorrow will find the 100-denier rayon yarn construction in a very tight position, according to reports in the local market yesterday. The 150-denier construction is also difficult to obtain, it was said. After books are opened a few days, it is expected that mills will announce they are sold up for the balance of the year.
Tenders will be considered by officials of East Orange, N.J., for a new issue of $927,000 of high school bonds, award of which will be made on Oct. 13. The bonds will be dated Oct. 1, 1936.

Bonds called for redemption in September before maturity increased slightly over the preceding month, but were much less than those called for payment in September, 1935. The figures were $195,048,000 for September, $162,978,000 for August and $350,611,000 for September, 1935.
LAKEHURST, Sept. 30. -- Her huge silver body lashed by rain, the airship Hindenburg took off at 11:17 o'clock tonight on her ninth return trip to Frankfort, carrying a full complement of passengers.

Salaries of officers and directors of eight corporations, as well as profit-sharing contracts between subsidiaries of Sterling Products, Inc., and the I.G. Farbenindustrie Aktiengesellschaft, were disclosed yesterday in annual reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Intelligent Americans more recently have realized that the turbulent political conditions in Europe would inevitably affect our own political scene. It is therefore no wonder that alien terms, like fascism and communism, have crept into our political terminology.
The New York Stock Exchange's committee on securities issued yesterday the following rulings:

All classes of bonds fared considerably better yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange despite the marked falling off in trading volume. United States Government obligations, which have reflected the uncertainty over the world monetary situation, turned strong but remained relatively quiet.

All free symphonic concerts by WPA Federal Music Project units may be eliminated, it was revealed yesterday by officials of the project. The announcement said that all outdoor concert band and dance activities as well as symphony concerts in Greater New York will terminate on Oct. 4.

BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 30. -- Important news came today from the Huesca sector. An official communication announced the capture of Mount Aragon and the defile known as Quinto Pass, with 700 prisoners and a considerable quantity of war material.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- A summary of several registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933, including one for 50,000 shares of $100 par value 7 per cent cumulative series prior preferred stock by the Celanese Corporation of America, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A style show of 100 Fall and Winter costumes was presented yesterday afternoon at Wanamaker's before nearly 1,000 spectators. Clothes for morning, afternoon and evening wear, as well as a full line of active and spectator sports clothes, hostess gowns and furs were included.

Dividends declared in September were the largest for that month since 1931. The increase was due principally to the number of extra and increased payments. More extra dividends were ordered than in any other month this year, while the number of rates raised was the largest for any month in more than ten years.

New securities offered to the public here in September made the heaviest total for a month since July. Larger bond offerings accounted principally for the increase. State and municipal financing, which was more than half of all bonds marketed, was the largest for a month since March, 1931.

Cesar Ameghino, Minister of Finance of the Province of Buenos Aires, announced yesterday that acceptances of the readjustment plan offered by the province to holders of its external dollar bonds and arrears certificates totaled more than $61,000,000, or more than 84 per cent of the amount outstanding when the offer was made on Dec. 3, 1935.

Sir Gilbert and Lady Eliott of Wolfelee, Hawick. Roxhurghshire, Scotland. have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss [ Veronica Boswell tgliott, to LandonI v T-n, Jr.. s01: of Mr. and Mrs.I L,andon I. Thorne of 740 Park AveI hue and Bay Shore. L.I.

The flight of gold from France, which started early in August, when fears for the safety of the franc were engendered by its fall in the foreign exchange market, was accelerated in September and resulted in the largest receipts of gold here in three months.

The precise amount that the Roosevelt administration has poured into this State in the form of loans, grants and insurance to promote recovery here became known for the first time last night when the National Emergency Council disclosed that New Deal benefits to New York State totaled $2,308,301,268 from President Roosevelt's inauguration on March 4, 1933, to the close of the last fiscal year on June 30, 1936.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 30 (AP). -- A massacre of elk by stampeding them over a cliff was revealed today with announcement that seven men suspected of the crime are to be ordered before a Federal grand jury. An official said the wholesale killing was kept secret for months lest 'guerrilla warfare crop out against the killers."

Can the best horse in the handicap division be a cripple or at least an ex-cripple? This question is the chief topic in racing circles following the victory yesterday in the thirty-fourth Manhattan handicap of the 7-year-old Olambala horse, Action at Belmont Park.

FRANCONIA, N.H., Sept. 30. -- Mrs. Arthur L. Hamilton of the Sugar Hill cottage colony today was principal speaker at the Green Leaves Civic Club, which held its Autumn meeting at Iron Mine Tavern, Franconia. A recent tour of Russia, illustrated by her own slides, was the topic.

Our financial pages report that substantial amounts of hoarded gold have come on the London market during the last few days from Continental sources. Some sellers apparently fear that to retain this metal might subject them to penalty taxes. Others feel that the purposes for which they held the metal have now been accomplished.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The government closed its affairs for the first quarter of the 1937 fiscal year today with a deficit of about $530,000,000 compared to more than $880,000,000 for the same period last year.

The long, lean man from Oklahoma was difficult to find yesterday after he had pitched himself to his seventeenth straight triumph under the worst weather conditions in which a world series battle has been waged.
SHANGHAI, Thursday, Oct. 1. -Japanese sailors with bayonets took over all the streets of the Hongkew area in the International Settlement today in a sudden and unexplained move.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Showing signs of uneasiness over the threatened tie-up of shipping on the Pacific Coast which would affect about 37,000 men, the Maritime Commission, after a visit to President Roosevelt at the White House today, sent new telegrams to shipping operators and union officials in a last-minute effort to prevent a strike.

David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, was guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel given by employes of the corporation and its service companies to mark his thirty years in the radio industry.

The Central Savings Bank sold to Aaron Weiss, acting for a corporation, the six-story apartment building containing twenty-four suites at 841 Jennings Street, northeast corner of Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx, on a plot 44 by 100 feet.
Protests were made yesterday by Communists, Socialists and the American Civil Liberties Union over the arrest of Earl Browder, Waldo Frank and Seymour Waldman in Terre Haute.

It is stated on the authority of The Industrial Bulletin of the late ARTHUR D. LITTLE, whose life has been extended by incorporation, that although the soya bean was discovered some 25,000 years ago, it was virtually unknown twenty years ago in this country, where now it takes fourth place among agricultural products, with wheat, corn and oats alone leading.

SALEM, N.H., Sept. 30. -- Closing with a burst of speed through the last half mile, Tugboat Frank, carrying the silks of Mrs. L.H. Ward of Boston, rushed home to capture the Revere Handicap by half a length before 8,000 persons at Rockingham Park today.

GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- The Spanish delegation published in French tonight the notes to the non-interventionist powers and the annexed notes to Germany, Italy and Portugal. Joseph A.C. Avenol, League Secretary General, had declined to publish the notes as League documents unless Madrid formally appealed for League intervention.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Douglas Jenkins, United States Consul General at Berlin, reported to the State Department today that in his opinion a fair trial was accorded Lawrence B. Simpson, the American seaman convicted Monday by the Berlin People's Court on a charge of sedition.
TOLEDO, Spain, Sept. 30. -- Much of this city is in ruins. That part lying between the main square, the Plaza de Zocodover, and the Alcazar has been razed by shells and bombs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Pronounced weakness today in the market for cash corn, which declined 3 to 8 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade, due largely to a let-up in the aggressive demand to secure the grain for delivery on September contracts resulted in a break of 1 1/2 cents a bushel in December corn contracts and 1 1/8 cents in the deferred months, with the close at the bottom.
" The series now," said Jack Doyle, Broadway commissioner whose odds on all sporting events are the last word, "is 9 to 10 and take your pick."

GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- The League of Nations Council decided today to approve Secretary General Joseph Avenol's appointment of Sean Lester, Danzig High Commissioner, as the League's Deputy Secretary General to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of Pablo de Azcarate of Spain.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Justice William F. Bleakley returned to his chambers in the Supreme Court here today after having been nominated for Governor by the Republican State Convention. He drove from Albany with State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale and Charles H. Griffiths, Republican leader of Westchester County, arriving here at 3:05 P.M.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 30 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, told an Ohio audience tonight that if Newton D. Baker of Cleveland had been the 1932 Democratic standard bearer "there would have been sound and sane government."

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Mrs. George B. St. George, chairman of the Tuxedo Autumn Ball Committee, who returned yesterday from a Summer in France, has announced plans for the ball, to be held at the club on Oct. 24.
HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 30. -- For a coach who has known the anguish of losing three of his team's mainstays through scholastic disenfranchisement, Earl Blaik is uncommonly cheerful these days.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Business was quiet and prices were irregular today on the London Stock Exchange. British Government stocks continued to improve. Heavy buying of the new bonds of the London County Council pushed the premium to 22s 6d each.

TORONTO, Sept. 30. -- To the lack of proper housing, the United States may attribute a large part of its $13,000,000,000 annual crime cost, its one-burglary-a-minute record and its prison population of 140,000, F.J. C. Dresser, district manager of the Cleveland Housing Division, said today before the Public Works Congress.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP). -- R.C. Thatcher's Fra Diavolo won the feature event at seven furlongs by one length at Lincoln Fields today.

ALBANY, Sept. 30. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in an address delivered here tonight before the State Conference of the National Youth Administration, declared it to be the duty of all persons in every community, including the young individuals themselves, to plan for the purposeful employment of youth.

RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Assemblyman John V. Burke of Middlesex County was killed here about 3:15 A.M. today when the automobile in which he was riding alone was in a collision with two trucks on the main New York-Trenton highway, near Bonhamton Junction.
President Roosevelt in his recent "fireside radio chat" made statements and inferences derogatory to those who for years have been engaged in the employment agency business.

GENEVA, Sept. 30. -- The Stock Exchange reopened in Switzerland today with a will, and there was a tremendous buying boom, in which bonds as well as stocks shot up to meet the devaluation of the Swiss franc, or hopes based on it. The day's business, according to the Tribune de Geneve, was the greatest ever known in Switzerland.

When the curtain rises on the new play at the Ritz you think for a moment that perhaps you will be seeing a sort of "Last Mile," because there on the stage before you are the dreary appurtenances of the death house, all leading toward the little green door on the right.

Extension of the official Summer season in the transatlantic passenger trade and a general increase in passenger rates will be discussed today at a meeting in Berlin of the principals of the Atlantic Passenger Conference

The committe for Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway first and refunding 4 per cent bonds, which were defaulted in 1934, and the secured 4 1/2 per cent Series A bonds due in 1952, reported yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had spent $4,968 betwen July 1, 1935, and July 30, 1936.

Interest rates for call and time loans in September were unchanged for the fourth consecutive month. Demand for loans last month showed little change, being principally for routine requirements. Available funds for loans still are in excess of demand.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 30. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, the undefending champion, said yesterday that if Miss Patty Berg was eliminated, the women's national golf championship would lose much of its color. Well, Patty has been eliminated and certainly some color, certain dramatic potentialities, have been lost.

Agents of the Department of Justice late yesterday captured in Yonkers Frank Vitolo, a small-time actor and adagio dancer with big ideas about money, and charged him with being the phantom-like crook who has terrorized four socially prominent or wealthy persons with threatening demands for money in the past four months.

With former Governor Alfred E. Smith prepared to open a series of broadcast attacks on President Roosevelt and the New Deal tonight with an address before the Independent Coalition of American Women at Carnegie Hall, the underwriters of his radio time remained anonymous yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Ecuador and Peru were encouraged to settle their long-standing boundary dispute through friendly negotiation by President Roosevelt in receiving and addressing in the Blue Room of the White House today delegations of the two republics who have come here in an effort to achieve a peaceful solution of the question.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 30. -- In Sedgwick Hall the Lenox Library Association, of which Grenville Lindall Winthrop is president, opened today its seventeenth annual exhibition. Mrs. Henry White and Giraud Foster lent palms and ferns for decorations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Good-quality hogs weighing 175 pounds or more sold at steady prices, while sows were unchanged to 10 cents higher. Underweights, however, were in slow demand and some late sales appeared to be slightly lower. Top was unchanged from yesterday at $10.45, while the day's average was up 5 cents at $9.55.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 30. -- Democratic party leaders, leaving here after the State convention, expressed the belief today that President Roosevelt's address of last night had been extremely helpful to the ticket in the State. It removed, they said, any last, lingering doubt as to where New York State's forty-seven electoral votes would be on Nov. 3.

VIENNA, Sept. 30. -- Although the Austrian authorities have so far successfully concealed the facts concerning Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg's suit for the annulment of his marriage, it is now known that the first step was taken eighteen months ago, when the action was unsuccessful, and was followed by a second attempt, the outcome of which is now about to be contested.

A marked difference of opinion developed yesterday in the discussion of a report on a new operating technique to relieve facial paralysis without facial tic or spasm offered by Dr. Joseph A. Sullivan of the Banting Institute, University of Toronto, at the convention of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Dropping slightly below the value of exports for the preceding month, United States merchandise exports in August totaled $178,249,000, while imports increased to $195,016,000, with a resulting excess of $16,767,000 in imports, Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper announced today.

Sir Lenthal Cheatle, British surgeon and authority on cancer, will sail today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others departing are H.B. Warner, film player; Lord Hunter, Major Gen. Sir Frederick Sykes, Sir Patrick Hannon, M.P.; Skeffington S. Norton, Mr. and Mrs. George D. Ali, Lieut. Col. H.A. Boyd, Dr. J.A. Giles and Professor Hans Kelsen.

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- Governor Curley tonight turned an attack upon the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, as a Supreme Court justice brought to final failure the Governor's attempt to bar from the ballots the names of Thomas C. O'Brien, his opponent in the Senatorial contest on the Coughlin ticket.

Revised estimates of the cost of preparing the Flushing Meadows site in Queens for the 1939 World's Fair indicate that New York City must pay $4,333,812 more directly on the fair than was tentatively planned last Spring when $7,000,000 was set aside for the purpose, Park Commissioner Robert Moses disclosed yesterday.

Barney Cosneck, Russian 175-pounder, triumphed over George Wagner, 182, Germany, in the feature wrestling match at the New York Coliseum last night before 3,000 spectators. Cosneck threw his rival in 27:11 with a flying tackle and body slam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The country's railroads moved today to maintain an estimated $100,000,000 of freight revenues threatened by the expiration on Dec. 31 of existing emergency surcharges. Through the Association of American Railroads the carriers announced plans for a general adjustment of the national freight rate structure.
Justice William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, announced his campaign itinerary yesterday. A few of the engagements are tentative. The schedule follows:

ELKINS, W.Va., Oct. 1. -- A pledge to continue with "vigor and singleness of purpose for the next four years" the wild life conservation program begun in his administration was made by President Roosevelt today in an address at the Mountain State Forest Festival here.

Another overabundance of water, this time all underfoot even if none of it was coming from overhead, called a temporary halt in the all-New York world series yesterday at just about the time the Giants and Yankees were tumbling out of their beds to clash in the second game.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 1. -- All passenger transportation in the city of Buenos Aires has been coordinated in a transit unification plan enacted by Congress in the closing hours of the ordinary sessions which expired last midnight.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange reflected a diminution of speculative interest as prices in general drifted aimlessly within comparatively narrow limits. While United States Government bonds were firm to slightly higher, other gilt-edged investments appeared to "mark time" and recorded little net change on the day.

Due to arrive here today at 10 A.M., President Roosevelt will take part in ceremonies in Queens and Jersey City, visit Democratic national headquarters at the Hotel Biltmore and take in the second game of the world series at the Polo Grounds before leaving for Hyde Park in the early evening.

The National Better Business Bureau yesterday recommended to producers of rayon yarns and to manufacturers and distributors of fabrics and garments made of these yarns that, in addition to any firm or trade name, the term "acetate rayon" be used to describe the fiber content of rayon yarns made by the acetate process.

Harry W. Colmery, new national commander of the American Legion, made his first visit to New York yesterday since his election last week at the Cleveland convention and disclaimed any retention on the part of the Legion to work this year for general war pensions or to attempt to silence "subversive" elements by "coercion."

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- The Middle West Corporation, successor to the Middle West Utilities Company, issued today its first financial report, showing consolidated net earnings of $199,926 for the first six months of 1936.
TOLEDO, Spain, Oct. 1. -- Telegrams were disclosed today indicating that the Madrid government never knew of Toledo's threatened downfall until it was too late to stop it.

Orders for holiday goods continue to increase in the wholesale markets here, with emphasis on toys, perfumes and toiletries and a wide variety of novelty goods. The situation was said to show marked confidence in the outlook for Christmas selling, despite the slowness which has developed in early Fall retail selling.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, renewed here tonight his assertion that the administration's financial policies left "no insurance policy secure, no savings account safe."

MADRID, Oct. 1. -- (Passed by censor) -- Little more than 100 of the 473 Deputies elected to republican Spain's Parliament last February, when the Popular Front parties triumphed at the polls, attended to day's Cortes meeting, which lasted less than an hour.
VIENNA, Oct. 1. -- Virtually repudiating the post-war Treaty of St. Germain, Austria today called 8,000 youths, aged 21, to the colors for a period of compulsory military service.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, appearing as "your friend and neighbor, Bill Bleakley of Yonkers," was officially welcomed home to Westchester tonight as the Republican candidate for Governor with a large demonstration at Memorial Park here.

Charges of maladministration made by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, against the office of William C. Dodge, District Attorney, were quashed yesterday by the September Additional New York County grand jury just before it was discharged by Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions.

Following an appeal yesterday by Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey for speedy action on the purchase of almost $1,000,000 of new snow-fighting equipment, members of the Board of Aldermen will vote on the purchase at a special meeting called for noon today in City Hall.
ROME, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Luis de Zulueta, Madrid's Ambassador to the Holy See, who has been a virtual prisoner in his embassy, slipped out tonight and took the Paris express.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- Today was moving day for Queen Mary. She left Buckingham Palace, her home for the past quarter-century as consort of the late King George V. to take up residence at Marlborough House, midway down the Mall, as the Queen Mother.

Australia offers a greater opportunity for American business men than they ever thought existed there, Frank Goldberg, governing director of the Goldberg Advertising Agency, Ltd., of Australia and New Zealand, declared last night at a meeting of the Association of Advertising Men at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Officials of the Federal Alcohol Administration revealed today that "bone dry" Kansas, home State of Governor Landon, was apparently plentifully supplied with beer, ale and malt beverages of ample alcoholic content, the sale of which neither State nor Federal authorities could prevent because of a loophole in the State dry law.
LONDON, Oct. 1. -- The London opening of Jimmy Donahue's musical show "Transatlantic Rhythm" tonight turned out to be a Roman holiday of good old Broadway temperament.
The text of former Govenor Smith's speech last night in Carnegie Hall follows:

BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. l. -- Huesca, on the Aragon front, was bombarded today after the government forces had captured Mount Aragon and Quinto Pass yesterday. The government forces, now within two miles of the city, are consolidating their positions and drawing their circle tighter.

More than $110,000 already has been spent on the revue, it was learned here yesterday from A.L. Berman, theatrical attorney, and Louis Shurr, Broadway casting agent. Originally, the production started out with a budget of $80,000. Items of expense kept mounting during a six-week rehearsal period and during the pre-London engagement in Manchester, where the show opened Sept. 12.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 1. -- President Roosevelt's share of the vote cast for major party candidates in the Sunpapers' Presidential poll of Maryland rose today to 64 per cent, a full percentage point above his majority in the contest with Herbert Hoover four years ago.

Employes of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel opened an exhibition of arts and crafts yesterday afternoon in the Empire Room of the hotel. The employes presented more than 200 objects, including oil paintings, water-colors, drawings, photographs, needlecraft, lace, radios, ship models, and wood carvings.

Realty assessments for tax purposes in Manhattan still are too high and the valuations in many cases still appear to be based upon the inflated figures of "boom" years instead of upon actual values, said Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, commenting upon the new valuations announced yesterday by the city.

A rise of $11,000,000 in brokers' loans and an increase of $46,000,000 in commercial loans were reported for the week ended on Wednesday by reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their condition statement issued yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Oct. 2. -- For the first time since the present Chino-Japanese crisis arose, more than a week ago, the Chinese population of the Chapei, North Szechuan and Hongkew districts of Shanghai are showing signs of panic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- With Big Tony Sarausky leading the touchdown parade, the New York Giants routed the College All-Stars of Washington tonight by a score of 35 -- 0. A crowd of about 8,000 saw the game.

GENEVA, Oct. 1. -- Public opinion as represented by the International Peace Campaign asked a hearing by the League of Nations Assembly and got a grudgingly-extended "unofficial" Assembly meeting today to receive its delegation.
PARIS, Oct. 1. -- (AP) -Still awaiting final passage of the franc-devaluation bill, the Bourse and foreign exchange markets here remained closed today.

The $460,000,000 rapid transit unification plan sponsored by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., after negotiation with spokesmen for the traction companies, was approved yesterday by the New York State Chamber of Commerce at its first Fall meeting at 65 Liberty Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- Asserting that "the Liberty Bell may be cracked but its message is not," Senator Vandenburg of Michigan told an audience in the Academy of Music tonight that it must choose next month "between constitutionalism and government by executive decree."

Yesterday's session of the condemnation proceedings to determine the amount to be paid for ground taken by the city for the World's Fair site was devoted mainly to testimony concerning the value of real estate holdings of Samuel Rosoff, contractor and subway builder.
PARIS, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

BERLIN, Oct. 1. -- The Boerse continued today to reflect the firm and confident tendency that developed after the statement of Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Finance, on the German monetary policy. Fractional improvements over yesterday's gains prevailed throughout the list.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 1. -- Charles W.A. Scott and Giles Guthrie landed here today to win the Portsmouth, England-Johannesburg air race, but their victory was clouded by a disaster.

In another effort to promote peace between the craft and industrial union factions in the American Federation of Labor, William Green, president of the federation, will come here next week to address the convention of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union.

Dr. Harry F. Ward, chairman of the American League Against War and Fascism, who returned to New York Tuesday from the World Peace Conference at Brussels, Belgium, reported yesterday that in Paris he had interviewed nine Spaniards, representing a cross-section of the people of Spain, and that they had strongly defended the Loyalist government.

TOPEKA, Oct. 1. -- Herbert Hoover conferred today with Governor Landon, candidate for the post he once held, discussed campaign plans with him, said he would participate in the campaign by speaking in Philadelphia and other cities and expressed a belief that the Republican cause was "making progress."

Additional records of transactions in Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., common stock on the Los Angeles and San Francisco Stock Exchanges were introduced yesterday by attorneys for the Securities and Exchange Commission in the trial of twelve brokers for alleged manipulation of the issue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The nation's relief load declined sharply during the Summer to the lowest point since 1931, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, said today in discussing his recent trip through ten Western States.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., Oct. 1. -- A morning musicale at the Mountain View House in Whitefield was given by musicians of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. Arrivals at the Mountain View are Mr. and Mrs. F.T. Fisher of Hackensack, N.J. Mr. and Mrs. Philip Montgomery and Russell Montgomery of New Haven, Conn., are at Pecketts on Sugar Hill.

The tentative assessment rolls for 1937 fix the value of taxable real estate in New York City at $16,030,706,291, an increase of $47,275,010 in the final real estate assessment for 1936. This is the second consecutive increase. There had been decreases from 1932 to 1935.

Evans Clark, executive director of the Twentieth Century Fund, sent an air-mail letter to Governor Landon last night declaring that the fund's "report" on social security made public by the Governor Wednesday was only a "tentative" one which had neither been approved nor disapproved by the Committee on Old Age Security.

MARGATE, England, Oct. 1. -- The Baldwin Cabinet's fears of doing or saying anything to antagonize Adolf Hitler were flatly disregarded today by the Conservative party conference, which demanded that the government declare that the cession of any British mandated territory is an "undiscussible question."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A grand total of 834,266 civilian employes, including temporary employes in the executive branch of the Federal Government in August, an increase of 3,644 over July, was reported today by the Civil Service Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 1. -- The Spanish motorship Cabo San Antonio, which has been barred from Brazilian and Uruguayan ports in the past several days, was anchored tonight in the Plate River forty-five miles below Buenos Aires with two Argentine cruisers standing by.

Alfred E. Smith, whom Franklin D. Roosevelt called "the happy warrior" when he nominated him for President in 1928, appeared last night before 4,500 men and women at Carnegie Hall as a disillusioned and angry Democrat urging the election of Alfred M. Landon, a Republican, "as the remedy for all the ills" that beset the United States.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 1. -- Captain and Mrs. William J. Schieffelin Jr. of New York and Leo A. Lanigan of Chicago were guests of honor tonight at a dinner attended by several hundred at the Greenbrier, which was followed by a grand ball.

Among those who entertained parties last night at the formal opening for the season of the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, were Mr. and Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller, whose dinner guests included Mr. and Mrs. Wallace K. Harrison, Mr. and Mrs. Julian Street Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. Percy L. Douglas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. today denied assertions of William Randolph Hearst that the American-British-French currency agreement violated the Johnson law, prohibiting loans to foreign powers that have not liquidated their indebtedness to the United States, and expressed keen satisfaction with the manner in which the agreement has been working out.

THE NEW YORK TIMES dispatch from Atlantic City in which Dr. Logan Clendening of Kansas City, addressing the convention of the American Bakers Association, is quoted as ridiculing "the stupendous, gorgeous, unbelievable conglomeration of bunk in the world today," directing his remarks especially to "professional advertisers who," he said, "have the most blunted sense of honor of any business."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Sharp declines in the market prices of farm products, principally livestock, fruits and vegetables, caused a fractional decline in the Labor Department's index of wholesale prices for the week ended on Sept. 26, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Seeking enactment of drivers' licensing laws in eleven States which do not have them, the Accident Prevention Conference was told today by Secretary Roper that "the Federal government may be forced to do something" unless the States act.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 2. -- The Adelphi Theatre curtain went up a half hour late at last night's premiere of James Donahue's and Felix Ferry's "Transatlantic Rhythm," but the news was that it went up at all.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Widespread treatment of cancer and tumors with ordinary X-rays in place of radium was suggested today by Dr. Eugene P. Pendergrass of Philadelphia, secretary of the American Roentgen Ray Society.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Domestic wheat markets largely ignored the strength in Winnipeg and Liverpool today. Reports by local statisticians indicating an increase of 10 to 11 per cent in the Winter wheat acreage compared with the 47,000,000 acres seeded last Fall led to considerable pressure on the July on the Board of Trade, which depressed the nearby futures to some extent.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 2. -- Eiji Amau, Foreign Office spokesman, gave a blanket denial today to reports from London that Japan's demands on China include the right to station troops in Yangtse Valley ports and recognition of North China autonomy.

Isolation for the first time in pure form of the specific substances, known as antibodies, that provide immunity against specific diseases, is reported today in Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Oct. 1 (AP). -- Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, was released today after spending twenty-six hours in jail here with four associates on vagrancy charges, and he started for New York. His attorney, David J. Bentall of Chicago, prepared charges of false arrest and false imprisonment against Mayor Sam Beecher and Police Chief James C. Yates.
PARIS, Friday, Oct. 2. -- Premier Leon Blum has won a "clipped" victory in the devaluation battle that raged for three days in Parliament.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- More than 500 clergymen and laymen of the Protestant Episcopal church Arch-Deaconries of Hudson, Ramapo, Dutchess and Ulster united today to honor Bishop William T. Manning's fifteen years of service as head of the Diocese of New York at a reception held at Wiltwyck, West Park, the former Colonel Payne estate.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- Business on the London Stock Exchange was quiet again today and prices ended generally irregular because of profit-taking. British Government stocks were firm, but dealings in industrials were slackened by the approaching end of the account.
Governor Landon criticizes the New Deal, but in talking to the farmers of the Middle West he promises them all its benefits and more besides.

Governor Lehman announced yesterday the appointment of Thomas F. Farrell, a friend of former Governor Smith, as the chairman of the independent citizens committee which will manage his campaign for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Exports and imports both increased in August, compared with August, 1935, but exports declined somewhat from July, while imports increased, the Department of Commerce announced today.
An incomplete list of assessments on classified office buildings, apartments, hotels and other structures in Manhattan follows:

Stockholders of the General Gas and Electric Corporation will meet on Oct. 27 to take action on a plan intended to eliminate most of the company's debt and to give public holders of preferred shares a new $5 dividend prior preferred stock ranking ahead of the present preferred shares.

Prices fluctuated irregularly over a range of 10 to 16 points on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Early moderate advances failed to attract renewed commission-house demand. The close showed gains of 1 to 3 points. Renewed trade buying was uncovered on a scale down.

TOLEDO, Spain, Oct. 1. -- Rebel troops under General Francisco Franco advanced tonight on three highways toward Madrid in what insurgent leaders hoped would be wedges blocking off avenues of retreat for the government forces.

A noisy crowd of several hundred demonstrators brought police reserves and an emergency squad with riot guns to Essex Market Court yesterday afternoon and led the police to insist upon an escort for Magistrate Alfred M. Lindau when he left the court.
THE TIMES quotes General Hugh S. Johnson's replies to the criticisms in Lloyd George's memoirs. One paragraph reads:

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Chicago's hustling White Sox picked up today where they left off two years ago, and with Vernon Kennedy permitting the Cubs only four hits, scored a 5-1 triumph in the opening game of the Chicago city championship series at Wrigley Field.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1. -- Those who cast the election auguries have for some time considered it possible that Pennsylvania's vote may decide the national result in November and make this Commonwealth politically, for the first time in post-bellum history, the keystone State in fact.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1. -- Standing before a cheering crowd which packed every seat and surged against police lines in the grounds of Forbes Field, President Roosevelt in a fighting speech tonight defended the deficit created by his administration as an investment in human welfare.

A four-story walk-up apartment house at 31-25 Thirty-third Street, Astoria, recently bought from the Prudential Insurance Company by Netter Netter, attorneys, has been resold to clients of Benjamin Jacobson. The structure, on a fifty-foot plot, contains fifty-eight rooms divided into twenty-eighth suites.
PARIS, Friday, Oct. 2. -- A crisis in France has been averted and the franc definitely devalued after a whole day of bargaining between the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate.

With many tenants taking over their new apartments yesterday, the traditional Fall moving day, brokers and renting agents of buildings in the city experienced a noticeable let-up in the rush for suites that has swamped them during the last few weeks.

Good old time-proven harmonica-playing, with such lilting lays as Ravel's "Bolero" and "Indian Love Call" to lure the crowd to response, won against all comers last night in the finals of the city-wide music contest for amateurs between the ages of 17 and 21, held on the Mall in Central Park.

May I compliment you on your editorial "The Farm Vote" and also the letter from Amalia E. Du Bois with the reference to the Reciprocal Tariff Law and the threat contained in the Republican platform to repeal the present trade agreements?

Pan American Airways yesterday set next Wednesday for the first flight with passengers across the Pacific between San Francisco and Manila. The party making the flight, all newspaper correspondents, will leave New York Sunday evening by United Air Lines and fly to San Francisco.

Three men, one a lawyer, pleaded not guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to charges of operating two "dummy" corporations under assumed names without registering them with the County Clerk, as required by law. Two of the defendants, Joseph Rubin and his brother, Harry, were released in $1,000 bail each.

BURGOS, Spain, Oct. 1. -- General Francisco Franco was designated dictator of Spain this morning at the headquarters of the Rebel junta here. General Miguel Cabanellas, until now head of the junta, presided at the ceremony, which was attended by Generals Emilio Mola, insurgent leader in the north, and Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, commander in the Seville area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Brien McMahon, Assistant United States Attorney General, informed William Z. Foster, chairman of the Communist campaign committee in New York, in a telgram late today that the Department of Justice would take no action in connection with the arrest of Earl Browder at Terre Haute, Ind.

It has been whimsically asserted that many countries have a form of government which can best be described as despotism tempered by assassination. Our own glorious Republic may some day be classed as a government of rugged individuals harried by vigilantes.

Mr. Duranty's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine today seems to me contrary to the truth when he states that Hitler, Mussolini, Franco and others are not fighting communism but liberalism and liberals.

When a complicated and comprehensive piece of legislation like the Social Security Act becomes the subject of partisan debate in the midst of a Presidential campaign, it is too much to hope that it will be discussed without emotion or exaggeration, or to expect any nice weighing by either side of the pros and cons of some of the special points involved.

The French franc fell further in the foreign exchange market here yesterday as the French Government continued to offer unlimited quantities of exchange at steadily declining prices in an apparent effort to prepare the market for the new reduced value of the French unit.

Statements of condition as of Sept. 30, which were issued yesterday by a number of local banks and trust companies, showed in most cases substantial gains in deposits and total resources in the third quarter. These gains were unusual since third-quarter statements of the banks normally show smaller figures than those of the mid-year statements, which are swollen by special and temporary deposits.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Sept. 30, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,475,000,000, a decrease of $4,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $5,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

An inquiry started four days ago by the September additional New York County grand jury into complaints of noxious gases from the recently opened bus lines in Manhattan led yesterday to the grand jurors' handing up a presentment to Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions urging the city authorities and the Transit Commission to remedy the situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The possibility of renewing indefinitely the existing "stand-off" agreement between the Tennessee Valley Authority and the operating companies making up the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation's system in the Southeastern States was discussed today by a group of the company's officials and government officers, as a result of President Roosevelt's White House power conference yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Six officers or directors of General Motors Corporation disposed of an aggregate of 10,034 shares of the common stock of that corporation in August. The total, however, represented but a negligible fraction of their holdings, according to a summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Prices ruled moderately lower on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with the exception of copper, and new Rio coffee superseded old Rio as the day's weak feature. On the cash markets wheat, cotton and wool tops advanced, with printcloths making a high price record.
LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The following film programs, which will be shown over the week-end, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of young persons in local private and public elementary and high schools:

Star Shadow, 4-year-old son of Man o' War and owned by Frank E. Brown, proved much the best of a small field in the Lothario Handicap, feature of the card at Belmont Park yesterday. With the aid of a well-judged ride by Eddie Yager he led home Mrs. Val Crane's Royal Fox by two and a half lengths.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday in the nation's twenty-two leading cities increased from the previous week, but fell 13.3 per cent below the total of 1935, mainly because heavy settlements in the first two days of October were included in last year's total.

While there was some decided opinion about a few stocks yesterday, there was little or none regarding the market as a whole. The character of trading was highly selective and the main body of stocks moved narrowly, selling off in the final hour, a condition which has been characteristic of the late trading on many days recently.

While the Chinese Government is trying desperately by delays and counter-proposals -- such as those suggested yesterday by the Foreign Minister -- to avoid a humiliating surrender to Japan, it is of the highest importance that the Western Powers face frankly the implications of Japan's acts in China.
The New York University football squad of thirty-nine players entrained last night from the Pennsylvania Station for Columbus, Ohio, where it will meet the Ohio State eleven tomorrow atfernoon.
JASPAR, Ala., Oct. 1 (AP). -- A "stay-away strike" of school children caused by a dispute over unionization of teachers ended today in Walker County, heart of North Alabama's coal fields.

WEST POINT, Oct. 1. -- Three hundred members of the Military Order of the World War at their annual convention today unanimously passed a resolution "noting with extreme regret" the criticism by Lloyd George, wartime Premier of Great Britain, of General Pershing as commander in chief of the American forces.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A proclamation designating the week beginning Nov. 9 as "American Education Week" was issued today by President Roosevelt, who urged its nation-wide observance. The proclamation read:

PANAMA CITY, Oct. 1. -- Dr. Juan Demostenes Arosemena took the oath of office as President of Panama and was invested with the tricolor cordon of the position by Octavo Fabrega, president of the National Assembly, this afternoon. He succeeded Dr. Harmodio Arias.

With work to start tomorrow on the $58,000,000 East River tubes. Arthur S. Tuttle, PWA director for New York State, made public a report yesterday from Wharton Green, project engineer, declaring that construction records were being made on the first PWA financed tunnel, the $37,000,000 Midtown Hudson Tube, connecting West Thirty-eighth Street with Weehawken, N.J. The tunnel, it is expected, will be opened next Fall, months ahead of schedule.

" Lend Me Your Ears!" which was to have made its bow this evening at the Mansfield, has deferred that event to next Monday night. A matter of polishing up a few scenes, one of the co-producers said yesterday. It is the second postponement, the premiere having originally been set for last evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- In a proposed transaction to replace 6 per cent preferred stock with a new issue on a lower interest basis the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a statement covering 70,300 shares of $100 par value 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

WITH GOVERNMENT FORCES, Olias del Rey, Spain, Oct. 1. -- Government forces launched a sharp counter-attack on the insurgent captors of Bargas, five miles north of Toledo, with a terrific land and air bombardment tonight.

Yesterday's postponement brought a slight change in the prices quoted by Jack Doyle on the world series, but with the Yankees still the favorites as the ultimate victors. Instead of the 9 to 10 and take your choice that prevailed yesterday morning, the Broadway commissioner later in the day made the odds 8 to 10 against the Yankees and 9 to 10 against the Giants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Oct. 19 for a public hearing on applications made by the Pittsburgh Stock Exchange for the extension of unlisted trading privileges on that Exchange to twenty-five issues of stocks and bonds that are fully registered on other Exchanges under the provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
LISBON, Portugal, Friday. Oct. 2 (AP). -- A masterpiece of the painter El Greco was reported today to have been destroyed in the fighting at Toledo, Spain.

Almost eight months after her alleged attempt to commit suicide in a Jersey City hotel, Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt, accused by California authorities of tricking her 21-year-old daughter Ann into a sterilization operation, appeared yesterday in the First Criminal Court, Jersey City.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Showing little concern for the heavy greens and the water-logged fairways that proved so troublesome to the remainder of the field, Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden posted a sparkling 86 to carry off the low gross prize at the weekly Women's Westchester Fairfield Association one-day golf competition today at Wykagyl.

The combined net operating income of 144 Class I railroads in August was $64,680,718, compared with $42,156,706 correspondingly last year, an increase of 53.4 per cent, the Bureau of Statistics of the Interstate Commerce Commission reported yesterday.

READING, Pa., Friday, Oct. 2. -- More than 200 persons were injured late last night in a riot which broke out when State police charged into a crowd of several thousand strikers and sympathizers gathered outside the main gate of the Berkshire Knitting Mills in suburban Wyomissing.
In the midst of the series excitement a deal involving the Brooklyn Club -- which would seem to have been involved enough as it is -- blossomed out after the rain.

Manhattan's football team will try for its second straight triumph tonight when it meets a strong Niagara University eleven at Ebbets Field. The game, first to be held under the new 150,000-watt lighting system at the Dodger ball park, is the opener of the Jaspers in Brooklyn, where they have played for the past four seasons.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Even the oldest citizen was beginning to believe that an American version of "White Horse Inn" was only a rumble in a producer's office. But last evening it opened for the season at the Center Theatre in a beautiful style that should endear it to the hearts of all good showgoers.

BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- After filling the chair of football at Cornell for sixteen years, the longest tenure of any coach of a major college team in the East, Gilmour Dobie has transplanted himself from the heights above blue Cayuga to University Heights near-by beautiful Chestnut Hill and looks down serenely upon the world.

Alterations for a night club to occupy the second floor of the new building on the Criterion Theatre block at 1,514-30 Broadway, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, will cost $200,000, according to plans filed yesterday by Thomas W. Lamb, Inc., architect, for the 1,514 Broadway Corporation of 20 Exchange Place.

FROM "Green Mansions" to "Green Pastures" to "Green Margins." The last is the title of a novel by E.P. O'Donnell, New Orleans-bred ex-boxing instructor and ex-steamship purser. It sells for $2.50 and is called by Houghton Mifflin, the publishers, a Fellowship Prize novel. Some time last year, that is, Houghton Mifflin announced that they would pay $1,000 to promising authors who needed financial aid while completing their books.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Marie Jean, owned by D.P. Letellier of New Orleans and ridden by J. Cowley, won the featured six-furlong race over a heavy track at Lincoln Fields today.
The New York Stock Exchange has suspended from dealings the following securities:

BOSTON, Oct. 1. -- Frederick C. Dumaine, 69-year-old managing director of the defunct Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, said today the firm never had sought government aid to prevent the closing of its huge Manchester, N.H., textile plant.

A new operation for chronic glaucoma, commonest cause of blindness in and after middle age, was reported by Dr. Otto Barkan of San Francisco at the convention of the American Academy of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology yesterday and was praised by leading eye surgeons as a notable advance over present methods and opening wide possibilities in eye surgery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Manipulation of milk-supply sources enabled distributors in the New York milk shed to buy fluid milk below prices fixed by the State Milk Control Board, and resulted in depressed prices to dairy farmers, according to a report made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Conrad, Bruce Co. of San Francisco submitted the highest bid for a new issue of $275,000 of water revenue bonds of the city of Aberdeen, Wash., offering 100.41 for 4 1/2s. The bonds are expected to be awarded within the next week, according to the announcement made by city officials.

Registering a gain of 71 per cent over last year, the cumulative total for engineering construction awards at the end of the third quarter was $1,737,659,000, according to The Engineering News-Record, which puts at $1,017,041,000 the aggregate for the corresponding period last year.

BUFFALO, Oct. 1 (AP). -- The Milwaukee Brewers of the American Association overwhelmed the Buffalo Bisons, International League champions, 8 to 3, tonight to win the little world series, four games to one.

A gala dinner dance and entertainment, marking the Autumn opening of the Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis, were given there last night as a benefit for Russian invalids of the World War. A program of special songs and dances was augmented by selections by a Russian quartet.
ON BOARD THE DIRIGIBLE HINDENBURG, Oct. 1. -- Smooth sailing, despite heavy weather, has marked the first day's progress of this reporter's around-the-world trip by commercial air transport.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Topping a field of twenty-five of the crack show hunters of the East, the bay gelding Cypress Des Beaux today gained for Mrs. John Hay Whitney her first leg on the Henry H. Dickson Memorial Challenge Trophy, one of the featured cup events of the first day of the thirty-fourth annual Piping Rock Horse Show.

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Government forces encircled 600 Rebels tonight in Fort Estrecho de Quinto, on the Huesca front, isolating them in a siege similar to that of the Toledo Alcazar, the correspondent of the Diario Noticias reported.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP). -- Greyhound, winner of the Hambletonian Purse last year, won the forty-seventh renewal of the Transylvania free-for-all trot, which had a value of $3,200, at the Grand Circuit meeting today.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- A resolution was adopted at the State National Youth Administration conference today calling upon Governor Lehman to consider youth State planning and offering the services of five members of the NYA to assist.

Justice William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, swung into his campaign yesterday with the utmost speed, making two speeches and announcing a speaking schedule calling for at least forty-one more before Oct. 30.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1. -- The completion of a year in which no national bank has failed, the first with such a record in fifty-five years, was hailed by President Roosevelt today in platform talks which marked his progress from Elkins, W. Va., to this city.

MANHASSET, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady confirmed today reports that she would be the hostess of Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, during his forthcoming visit to the United States. She will meet him when he arrives at New York next week on the liner Conte di Savoia and will take him to her Manhasset estate, Inisfada, where he will be her guest.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 1. -- Many leading dog fanciers were among the 200 guests at the field trial dinner held in the Empire Room here tonight.

Taking full advantage of government funds and WPA labor, the office of Borough President Samuel Levy has torn up the streets of Manhattan as they have never been torn up before, ripping up car tracks on various avenues and cross streets and making extensive paving repairs.

The United States liner President Roosevelt sailed yesterday at 5:15 P.M. from her pier at the foot of West Twentieth Street without passengers, but with a full crew of 235 officers and men and with 4,267 sacks of mail and 690 tons of freight.
ELKINS, W.Va., Oct. 1. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address here today at a Mountain State Forest Festival:

While trading in wool goods showed some improvement this week, the volume of new business was light, and mills for the most part are operating less machinery than at any time in the last two years, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- William E. Dodd Jr., son of the United States Ambassador in Berlin, was a witness today before the unofficial committee backed by Labor members of Parliament to ascertain whether the international agreement for non-intervention in Spain is being observed by Europe's dictators.
Arthur Krock's discussion of the two currency planks seems to me to reveal a failure to understand the real meaning of the Democratic plank.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1. -- Following was the prepared text of President Roosevelt's speech tonight at Forbes Field:

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- The market for hogs today was steady to 19 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, but the demand was small and the close virtually was unchanged. The top of $10.50 was the highest in nine days and showed 5 cents above the best figure of the previous day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1. -- Doris Dudley's work in "Portrait of a Rebel" has so intrigued RKO executives that she is being retained by the studio and will appear with Herbert Marshall in the film version of "Second Man." Previously the studio had made overtures to Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, but their disinterest in films is acute.
Four new films, three from Hollywood and one from England, will move into three Broadway theatres today.

The 53-family apartment house on a plot 125 by 100 feet at 593-601 East 141st Street, the Bronx, was bought by J. Lorber from the Manbeek Realty Corporation, represented by Kadel, Van Kirk Trencher, for cash over a first mortgage of $114,700.

By the heft of a market basket, Republican women workers at headquarters, 40 East Forty-second Street, started out yesterday to convince housewives that their dollars purchased more groceries under President Hoover than under the New Deal.

BEATRICE, Neb., Oct. 1 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace tonight linked an appeal for the re-election of Senator Norris of Nebraska, veteran independent Republican, with a statement that Governor Landon is asking a return to "1932 conditions."

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 1. -- It must be true what they say about golf in Dixie, for not since the halcyon days when Miss Alexa Stirling of Atlanta, now Mrs. W.G. Fraser of Ottawa, was the nation's toast as a woman golfer has the South made such a showing in the women's national championship as this year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1. -- In anticipation that Amherst will prove a much stronger opponent than the usual run of teams that come to Cambridge to open the stadium, Harvard's drill today specialized on a defensive against the Lord Jeff plays, and a long drill in which the coaches worked to get much more smoothness into the attack.

President Roosevelt will head a party of forty-eight when he comes into the Polo Grounds at 1 o'clock this afternoon to see the second game of the world series. The group, which will be seated near the Giant dugout, will include a number of Secret Service men and, of course, many correspondents who travel with the nation's Chief Executive.

ROME, Oct. 1. -- Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, and Fulvio Suvich, new Italian Ambassador to Washington, embarked this afternoon at Naples aboard the Conte di Savoia for New York. A crowd of friends and admirers gathered at the pier to see them both off.

Mr. HOOVER in his Denver speech night before last bore down on the emotional life a bit harder than he probably meant to do. He was discussing Federal taxes. "What I have to say," he declared, "is merely objective sociology and economics.

Edgar Prochnik, Austrian Minister to the United States, with Mrs. Prochnik and their daughter Patricia, and Dr. Karl Stroelin, Mayor of Stuttgart, are among the passengers arriving today from the Channel ports on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Acting for the first time upon its authority under the new Motor Carrier Act, the Interstate Commerce Commission threatened today to veto stock conversion plans of the Greyhound Corporation unless the corporation obtained the commission's approval to continue in control of the Pacific Greyhound Corporation through ownership of 56,000 shares of the latter's stock acquired last November.

The arrest of Earl Browder and four of his aides by Indiana authorities was praised yesterday by Messmore Kendall, president-general of the Sons of the American Revolution, as "consistent for the protection of the American government."

Formation of the American Community Theatres Corporation for the establishment of intimate motion-picture theatres in 100 cities of more than 5,000 population throughout the United States was announced yesterday by Walter Reade head of a chain of cinema houses in New York and New Jersey.

Plans for remodeling the three four-story brownstone tenements at 232,234 and 238 East Fifty-second Street were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the houses by Frank Fagnoni to the W. A. Construction Corporation, represented by A.J. Bernstein, attorney.

Irving Bluhm, 36 years old, a lawyer, of 245 East Eleventh Street, with an office at 291 Broadway, pleaded not guilty before Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions yesterday to indictments charging him with grand larceny and conspiracy in an alleged fake accident claim.

Seven novelties and revivals will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House during the coming season, which begins on Dec. 21, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday. He revealed also that ten new singers, a conductor and a stage manager had been engaged during the Summer, not counting about thirteen artists who will be carried over into the main season from the experimental four-week term last Spring.

In declining moderately in the final hour yesterday, the stock market maintained unbroken a record which has extended about two weeks. Not since Sept. 17 has the market had a good closing hour, it was pointed out yesterday. One broker remarked that its seesaw action in rising a little in the morning and declining a little in the afternoon had become boring through its repeated occurrence.

Governor Landon is leading in twenty-one States and President Roosevelt in ten in the latest report of the Literary Digest poll, it was announced yesterday. The latest total vote is Landon 438,601, Roosevelt 282,524 and Lemke 29,083.

TOPEKA, Oct. 1. -- Governor Landon, who listened at the Executive Mansion to the radio broadcast of the speech of Alfred E. Smith, expressed appreciation of the support of the former New York Governor, within a few minutes after its conclusion.

The further devaluation of the franc may or may not make for stabilization. In any case, American official approbation of it would seem to be out of place unless it be accompanied by an insistence that the interests of Americans be duly safeguarded.
MADRID, Oct. 1. -- The government tonight ordered knife-like counter-attacks on the Rebels driving for a stranglehold on Madrid.

Mayor La Guardia declared last night in a speech concerning business conditions in the City of New York that there is "a lot of bunk going around about business leaving the city for States where there are better business conditions."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- A national shortage of skilled labor in private industry was reported today to the vanguard of directors gathering for the Fall board meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Confident of starring in international sports events scheduled for the metropolitan district within a fortnight, three of Italy's leading automobile racing drivers and a half dozen of its amateur boxing aces arrived here yesterday aboard the Italian liner Rex.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc., will head a group that will offer $15,000,000 Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., 5 per cent $100 par preferred stock, with warrants, for which a registration statement was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington.

Higher livestock prices about offset decreased quotations for most of the grains and flour, and only a slight change was therefore reported for The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices, the index rising to 127.8 on Sept. 29 from 127.6 on the Tuesday previous.

The first of the monthly index numbers, compiled by Dun's Review and given out yesterday, showed a very slight fractional increase in the average during September, which was the fourth successive month to score an advance. It was the highest October index since 1929, and the highest of any month in more than six and a half years, surpassing that for every month back to Feb. 1, 1930, when it stood at $184.426.

OTTAWA, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press). -- The Bank of Canada reported today for the week ended yesterday a decrease of $6,925,003 in Dominion Government deposits and an increase of $2,740,422 in chartered bank deposits. The statement follows:

Frank E. Fehlman, New York sportsman, offers a tip to fresh-water anglers who hanker for one last thrill before the snow flies. He suggests a trip to the town of Clayton on the St. Lawrence River, an overnight ride by train from Grand Central.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (AP). -- Maritime unions and shipowners, working under a fifteen-day truce agreement, speeded up lagging waterfront operations today and cleared the way for negotiations designed to bring peace to the long-troubled industry.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 1. -- Many members of society of the North Shore attended the opening session this morning of the thirty-fourth annual Piping Rock Horse Show. Informality marked the first day.

Conferences in the twenty-two counties included in the Regional Plan Association's program for the metropolitan district will be held soon, it was decided yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 1. -- There is a very popular young lady on the Canoe Brook golf course these days, who is, incidentally, now strongly backed to take the American women's golfing title back across the Atlantic with her when she sails from these shores on the Queen Mary next Wednesday.

THE sun was shining over the Polo Grounds at high noon yesterday and hundreds of fans were walking away, shaking their heads this way and that The noble athletes had played through the rain on Wednesday and then were held in leash in fair-to-middling weather yesterday. One philosophical fan, strolling from the locked gates back toward the Subway, shrugged his shoulders and said:

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- Sympathy with the contention of the city that the act creating the New York City Charter Revision Commission is constitutional was indicated time and time again today by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals, as that court heard arguments as to whether the voters should have the opportunity this Fall to pass on the proposed new charter.

Ex-Governor SMITH had a great opportunity in his political speech on Thursday evening. It was open to him to come forward as a public-spirited citizen who was sincerely grieved by finding it his duty to break away from a party with which he had long been identified, and who was ready to give worthy and dignified reasons for his change of political faith.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The Thanksgiving turkey will be smaller this year, but tenderer and more tasteful, an authority said today.

VIENNA, Oct. 2. -- The affairs of the Austrian Heimwehr fascists and the authoritarian "leadership principle" upon which both they and the present Austrian regime base themselves approached the opera bouffe stage tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The market here for hogs was somewhat irregular today. Underweight hogs and sows were mostly 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, pigs were down 25 cents and other kinds were about steady. The top was unchanged at $10.50 while the day's average was lifted 5 cents to $9.65.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The New York Curb Exchange today entered the movement by some exchanges to seek unlisted trading privileges in securities fully registered on another exchange by filing an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the $53,000,000 issue of first mortgage bonds, Series A, sinking fund 3 1/2 per cent, due on July 1, 1965, of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The government ended the first quarter of the 1937 fiscal year with a deficit of $524,884,087, compared with $832,021,766 at the end of the first quarter of the 1936 fiscal year, a reduction in twelve months of $307,137,679, the Treasury announced today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Paving the way for more amicable Russo-Japanese relations, the Soviet Government today reached an agreement with Japan on the long-fought and bitter dispute over fishing rights in the Pacific.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area improved sharply this week, the sales volume of department stores proving the best since Labor Day. Sales for the week were estimated as running 8 to 9 per cent over the corresponding week last year.
