Loyalty Sabbath will be observed today in the synagogues and Loyalty Sunday will be observed tomorrow in the churches of the city. The observance will bring to a close the annual Loyalty Week sponsored by the National Religion and Moral Welfare Committee.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- The 1935 champions of the Big and Little Three will meet in Palmer Stadium tomorrow when the Princeton football team opens its new campaign against the Williams eleven.

The first page in another chapter of Fordham's football history will be written today when the 1936 edition of the Maroon eleven opens its season against Franklin and Marshall College at Randalls Island Stadium at 2:30 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that it would open bids on Oct. 15 at its offices here for seventy issues of securities of counties, municipalities and school districts in twenty-two States, most of which it acquired from the Public Works Administration for resale in the investment market.

What recitation did "AL" SMITH have in mind toward the end of his Carnegie Hall speech? He said, "You remember the recitation, 'Rome, thou hast been a tender friend to me.'" Mr. SMITH'S quotation did not stop there, but the remainder is not at this moment identifiable.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2. -- Commodore J. Stuart Blackton, one-time partner of the late Thomas A. Edison in the production of motion pictures, has made known his engagement to Mrs. Evangeline Russell de Rippeteau, film actress.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 2. -- Jumping in almost faultless form, showing a pleasing way of going over the outside course and all told exhibiting those qualities that combine to give an enjoyable ride to hounds, the topping big chestnut gelding Chatter Chat today carried Mrs. Cary Jackson to win the Meadow Brook Masters' Trophy at the Piping Rock Horse Show on the grounds of the Piping Rock Club.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Oct. 2. -- This town was divided into two camps today as a strange story of witchcraft, which might have gained wide credence in Colonial days, swept through the community.
BURGOS, Spain, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Insurgent military leaders reported feverish activity on all fronts today as General Francisco Franco assumed the mantle of dictatorship over the Rebels.

GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP). -- A Tour-year course in responsible citizenship as a requirement for the bachelor's degree was announced at Hobart and William Smith Colleges today by Dr. William Alfred Eddy, president of the colleges, in his inaugural address.

The Workers Alliance of America is planning an elaborate demonstration, probably in the form of a strike, of WPA workers in several States toward the end of the month, it became known yesterday. The organizers said they expected to enlist 1,000,000 workers.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 3. -- Japan's demands of China include settlement of the North China situation, and this, in turn, includes aviation facilities and probably railroad concessions and revision of China's tariff.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- An appeal for support of the American Legion's three-point peace program, calling for strengthening of the national defense, enforcement of a strict neutrality policy and immediate endorsement of a law "which will wring the profits out of war," was made tonight by Harry W. Colmery, newly elected national commander of the legion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The White Sox mixed solid base hits with walks and Cub misplays today to coast to an easy 11 -- 3 victory, their second straight in the city championship series, before 13,990 spectators at Comiskey Park.

A recent investigation of juvenile delinquency in New York City made by Dr. J.B. MALLER of Columbia University, with the cooperation of WPA, covering the last three decades (1903-36) and a quarter of a million delinquents (so classified by the Children's Court), shows that the total number of delinquents decreased from 87,948 in the first decade to 66,976 in the last decade.

PARIS, Oct. 2. -- One of the heaviest concentrations of policemen, gendarmes and Mobile Guards seen in months was ordered to patrol Paris tonight after the Interior Ministry had forbidden a demonstration by the French Social party and a counter-demonstration by Socialists and Communists.

Bonds moved up briskly yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange under the impetus of a renewed demand which spread into almost all classifications on the board. At the same time the turnover expanded to $13,722,900, compared with $11,516,500 on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- New official exchange rates governing international money order transactions and giving effect to altered currency values resulting from the recent stabilization accord were announced today by the Postoffice Department to become effective next Monday.

Football comes out of its preliminary trot and begins really to run at high speed today. Those colleges held to a late start in practice are among the ones joining the procession this afternoon as the old familiar names that have marked the story of football from its beginning open fresh chapters in their histories.

TOLEDO, Spain, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Rebel conquerors took inventory of Toledo today and found priceless works of art, museum pieces and church treasures missing. Many old paintings had been destroyed by bullets or slashed by knives. Officers said the El Greco and San Vicente Museums were virtually stripped bare.

Causing no great surprise in the process, four shows will go away from Broadway after this evening's performances. The double bill of "Cox and Box" and "H.M.S. Pinafore" is a routine departure from the Martin Beck; the other three are darker casualties: "The Golden Journey," "So Proudly We Hail" and "Stork Mad."

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 2. -- An international final, the first in women's American golf since 1913, became reality today as stocky little Pamella (Pam) Barton, present holder of the British title, won her semifinal round match in the fortieth national championship by defeating Miss Marion Miley, 24-year-old Kentucky star.

A committee of nine children representing the WPA day camps, which are under the supervision of the Board of Education, presented to Park Commissioner Robert Moses yesterday afternoon a testimonial expressing their appreciation for the use of the city parks.

Laying the cornerstone of the new Medical Building of the Jersey City Medical Center yesterday morning, President Roosevelt declared that Federal expenditures during the depression had prevented a shortage of hospital facilities in the nation from failure of municipal and private financing.

After holding hearings for weeks in Washington, Los Angeles and this city, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday concluded the presentation of evidence in its case against Charles C. Wright and other brokers charged with manipulating the common stock of Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd.

Margaret Mitchell's novel "Gone With the Wind" recently sold 44,262 copies in one day, Macmillan reports. In an effort to cope with the correspondence that has been pouring in from readers of the long book, Macmillan is preparing a pamphlet on the book and the author, in which the questions most often asked are answered.

SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Insurgent airplanes bombarded Eibar, key city in the Bilbao defense line on the Bay of Biscay coast, but failed to budge the government lines, refugees reaching here reported today.

Today's lone newcomer to Broadway is "Missing Girls," opening at the Globe. The film traces its origin to a story by Martin Mooney and has as its principal players Roger Pryor, Muriel Evans, Sidney Blackmer and Noel Madison.

PARIS, Oct. 2. -- Four thousand Mobile Guards patrolled the Paris boulevards tonight as the government's militant answer to Colonel Francois de la Rocque's assertion that "enemies of the people might unleash a civil war in France." In a letter to Premier Leon Blum, Colonel de la Rocque wrote:

After a long hearing in chambers, Federal Judge Julian W. Mack reserved decision yesterday afternoon on a motion by the Securities and Exchange Commission for a preliminary injunction to restrain Archie M. Andrews, former chairman of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, and others from alleged manipulation to raise the price of the stock of the Dictograph Products Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Extensive additions and improvements to its plant equipment are contemplated by Gulf States Steel Company of Birmingham, Ala., according to a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by that company, covering $7,000,000 of first (closed) mortgage sinking fund 4 1/2 per cent bonds, due Oct. 1, 1961, and 98,569 shares of no par value common stock.

This past week, with its almost overburdening succession of arriving entertainments, gave gratifying testimony to the fact that nocturnal fol-de-rol is fast outgrowing the stage of swaddling clothes (which covered very little flesh, incidentally) and is making the grade of first-class, intelligent entertainment.

Charles Pratt, secretary of the board of trustees of Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, announced yesterday at the annual Founder's Day exercises that the $10,234,000 endowment contributed by the family since 1887 was insufficient to carry the "most pressing" financial burden and, for the first time, the alumni were being asked to help.

Responding to a challenge of Miss Natalie Couch to debate publicly the issues of the Presidential campaign. Mrs. Caroline O'Day, Representative at Large, yesterday released a statement in which she informed her opponent she would be glad to comply, provided the topic were confined to the essential merits of the Democratic platform as against those of the Republican.

The statement of the Brooklyn Trust Company as of Sept. 30 shows total deposits of $119,240,808 and total resources of $135,163,206, compared with $118,935,287 and $135,064,015, respectively, on June 30. The bank lists cash on hand and due from the Federal Reserve and other banks of $39,336,674, against $34,776,214; holdings of United States Government securities of $31,435,535, compared with $32,274,230; call loans and bankers' acceptances of $10,475,725, against $11,558,980.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- J.L. Kraft, president of Kraft-Phenix Cheese Corp., expressed "surprise" tonight at the Federal Trade Commission complaint against the company.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 2. -- Supporters of Governor Landon here were greatly cheered today by the action of former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York in coming out definitely for the Republican Presidential candidate and urging his election.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 2 (AP). -- Denying that President Roosevelt averted revolution, Colonel Frank Knox, Republican vice presidential candidate, charged tonight that "the only revolution that ever menaced us was the one the false prophets of the New Deal have nourished and promoted."
TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 3. -- High winds and heaving seas were believed to have brought death to 124 persons today as a typhoon swept northward over the Japanese islands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Department of Commerce in a series of bulletins disclosed today that the export movements in August of tobacco, oil and gasoline, hides and skins and non-ferrous metals as a rule showed substantial increases, while declines were registered in the import volumes.

Realty activity in Manhattan yesterday was featured by the sale of the fifteen-story apartment house at 229 East Seventy-ninth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, by Frederick Brown, operator, to a syndicate formed by Alexander P. Watts, Inc. Erected in 1928 and purchased by Mr. Brown in June, 1935, the building contains eighty-nine apartments.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- President Roosevelt "stepped up to bat" at Forbes Field in Pittsburgh last night and "struck himself out," the Republican National Committee declared today in a statement issued by Arthur M. Curtis, assistant to Chairman Hamilton.

IT takes a book like Vincent O'Sullivan's "Aspects of Wilde" (Holt, $2.50) to remind us of what has happened in the past thirty or forty years. The renowned Oscar Wilde has been dead for a generation, and Beardsley, Pater, Ruskin, Morris and Whistler are gone too. The very lavender-colored dust wrapper with which Mr. O'Sullivan's publishers have appropriately swathed his book seems out of place in this day and age.

Republican leaders hailed yesterday former Governor Alfred E. Smith's endorsement of Governor Landon but James A. Farley, National Chairman, and other Democratic leaders discounted the effect of the address.

Charles Foster, manager of Jimmy McLarnin, boxer, was sued in the Supreme Court yesterday for $500,000 damages by Abe Lyman, orchestra leader, because of statements made before the State Boxing Commission following the bout between McLarnin and Barney Ross at the Polo Grounds, May 28, 1935.

Will not some one tell our hustling Mayor to stop inaugurating new nuisance ordinances and use his energy in seeing the ones already enacted are enforced? For instance, unnecessary noises; especially in the Roaring Forties west of and on Eighth Avenue. Every night there is a pandemonium of auto horns which goes on until midnight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The Federal Trade Commission undertook for the first time today the enforcement of the Robinson-Patman Price Discrimination Law. It issued complaints against five companies, one of them Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., Chicago mail order house.

Weakfish, blackfish and flounders are the big three in salt-water fishing these days. If you should drop by a dock at any of the bays and inlets on the New Jersey and Long Island coasts this week-end and watch the boats come in you probably would find these species predominate in the catches.

The Institute of International Education, under the direction of Dr. Stephen P. Duggan, announced yesterday the award of 145 fellowships to American students for study in foreign countries during the academic year 1936-37.

New bond financing this week consisted mainly of tax-exempt loans, with seven State and municipal issues accounting for $18,445,000 of the $19,501,500 new offerings. This compares with $51,763,750 last week and $15,637,000 this week a year ago.
The text of the message of Mayor La Guardia submitting the executive city budget for 1937 to the Board of Estimate follows:
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2 (AP). -- Calumet Evelyn, trotter, owned by McConnville Brothers, Ogdensburg, N.Y., lowered the world's record for a third heat to 1:59 1/2 in Grand Circuit racing today.

Stockholders of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., approved yesterday the capital readjustment plan by which dividend arrears on the present preferred stock will be paid. Following the stockholders' meeting, the directors declared a dividend of $4.50 a share on the new preferred stock, which will be exchanged for the present preferred.

BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The German War Ministry revealed today that it had completed the organization of the twelve army corps it had designated as its first rearmament goal when it announced the reintroduction of general conscription, March 16, 1935.

Dr. Frank E. Lutz, curator of entomology at the American Museum of Natural History, discoverer of the non-stinging bee that has pronounced distaste for sweets and creator of the non-stop firefly that glows steadily, sat in his office at the museum yesterday afternoon and propounded a few new facts about singing crickets.

HENDAYE, France, Oct. 2. -- The principal efforts of the Spanish Rebels in the past twenty-four hours were directed at the capture of Siguenza, seventy-five miles northeast of Madrid. Siguenza is an extremely important position, commanding a comparatively easy line of approach to the capital.

With the announced intention of becoming the "Ford" of the low-price liquor field, the American Distilling Company, wholly owned subsidiary of the American Commercial Alcohol Company, will spend $250,000 in newspaper advertising between now and the end of the year, James D. Webb, advertising manager, announced yesterday at a luncheon to the press at the Hotel Commodore.
SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 2 (AP). -- A world-wide drive to take all its needy members "off relief" was declared a success tonight by the Latter Day Saints Church.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Additional cases of identical bidding for Federal contracts were referred today by Secretary Ickes to Attorney General Cummings.

MARGATE, England, Oct. 2. -- From an almost casual phrase in a speech by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, at the end of the Conservative party conference tonight, it is reasonable to conclude that the British Government is not planning to play any major part in land fighting in any European war in which this country may participate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- A net railway operating income of $364,697,978 and a return on property investment of 2.3 per cent -- the highest since 1930 -- were claimed for Class 1 railroads of the United States on the basis of operations during the first eight months this year in an announcement today by the Association of American Railroads.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 2. -- Confident in demeanor, Michael Fugmann, Hanover township miner and German Army veteran, took the witness stand in Criminal Court this afternoon and denied that he was guilty of the bomb murder of Thomas Maloney, insurgent mine leader, on Good Friday.

BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The resolution adopted yesterday by the British Conservative party at Margate, that the cession of British mandated territories is "indiscussible," has aroused the ire of National Socialist party circles. They find this denial of German colonial ambitions especially invidious in view of the fact that "the British world empire has annexed new giant territories" since the World War.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 2. -- A distinct contrast in styles of play, physique, temperament and golfing background will be offered when Mrs. John Crews, formerly of New Jersey and now of Florida, meets Miss Pamela Barton, British champion from London, in the 36 hole final round of the women's national golf championship at Canoe Brook tomorrow.

Robert Burke, president-elect of the Columbia class of 1938 and an amateur boxer, sued the Columbia trustees in the Supreme Court yesterday for an order to compel them to admit him as a student. Burke had been refused permission to register this year because of his part in a demonstration at Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's home on May 12 against the sending by Columbia of a delegate to the Heidelberg University anniversary celebration.

The Congress Cigar Company, Inc., has declared a dividend of $2, payable on Oct. 31 to stock of record of Oct. 14. The disbursement will be in cash or, at the option of each stockholder, in bonds of the Puerto Rican-American Tobacco Company on the basis of $810 a $1,000 bond, plus $20 accrued interest.

Queens took a half holiday yesterday to celebrate the beginning of work on a new under-river traffic artery linking it more closely with midtown Manhattan and to cheer President Roosevelt, who was generally credited by speakers at the celebration with making possible the realization of a fifteen-year dream.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2. -- When Harvard starts its opening game against Amherst in the stadium tomorrow the only players in the line-up who started in the Yale game last Fall will be Captain Jim Gaffney, left tackle; Bob Jones, center, and Vernon Struck, fullback.

Many thanks for your recent editorial "Fictitious Issues." If the teachings and doings and followers of President Roosevelt make him a Communist, then the Progressives, who in 1912 denounced the Republican party as the party of reaction, greed and privilege, were indeed Communists.

The theft of a valuable violin, said by its owner to be a Stradivarius valued at $50,000, from a country antique shop in Maine by a "Raffles" who substituted for it a $12 instrument stained into an appearance of age with sulphuric acid, was solved last night by the recovery of the violin in a Bowery pawnshop.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The curtain came down with a $200 bang tonight on Leslie Rammon's dramatization of the balcony scene from "Romeo and Juliet."
{ The dollar on the local foreign i exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

Baseball's famous option system was responsible for the solving yesterday of what had seemed to be a perplexing problem. Originally President Roosevelt was to have witnessed the third game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium, but the day's postponement shifted the Presidential arrival from the third day to the second and the site from the Stadium to the Polo Grounds.

The foreign exchange market yesterday settled down to relatively normal trading with French francs officially offered here all day at about 4.66 cents, a price midway between the limits which have been fixed for its devaluation and which was thought to indicate the level of tentative stabilization.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Oct. 3. -- Pessimism has been descending on responsible Chinese and Japanese circles in Shanghai and Nanking to such an extent that Chinese language newspapers in both cities have joined in an astonishing manifesto urging the Chinese people to remain calm, stressing the dangers of China's perishing in conflict with Japan and pleading with Japan to believe the Chinese people are not anti-Japanese.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Sharp discussion arose over financial questions among delegates at the annual Central New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church here today.
Most futures were higher yesterday on the local commodity markets. On the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour and rubber advanced, while cotton, silk, tin and raw sugar declined.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2. -- A linking of X-ray technique and mathematics to provide physicians and expectant mothers with exact information regarding an unborn child was described by Dr. Paul C. Hodges before the American Roentgen Ray Society today.

For his opening exhibition of the season Julien Levy has brought from Paris a group of paintings from the collection of Jacques Bonjean, in whose galleries most of the artists represented received their first public showings. Nostalgic early work by the little group, whose members styled themselves neo-romantics, has been chosen.

After being closed for several days for installation purposes, the Whitney Museum of American Art will reopen to the public on Tuesday. The exhibition will consist of painting and sculpture for the decoration of Federal buildings -- work executed under the Treasury Department Art Program. All galleries of the Museum will be utilized.

With President Roosevelt casting a keen, critical and, beyond question, an appreciative eye on the thoroughness of the spectacle, Marse Joe McCarthy's Yankee juggernaut rolled out on the hard, smooth terrain of the Polo Grounds yesterday and put on the most amazing exhibition of devastating power in all world series history.
The text of President Roosevelt's address at the Jersey City Medical Center yesterday morning follows:

The pamphlet report of the Third Avenue Railway System for the fiscal year ended on June 30, including bus operations, shows a consolidated net loss of $128,302 after taxes, charges and allowance for full interest requirements on the 5 per cent adjustment income bonds, compared with a net loss of $168,449 on the same basis in the preceding year.

Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, in a radio speech delivered last night over a national hook-up of the Columbia Broadcasting System from Station WABC, urged the re-election of President Roosevelt on the ground that he was a strong leader and that strong leadership was vitally needed in the nation now.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- In one of the most spectacular finishes ever seen at the Temple Stadium, Pop Warner's Owls came through with a 12-to-7 victory over Mississippi tonight before 22,000 spectators.

Representatives of practically every Catholic diocese in the country will attend the Catechetical Congress, the annual convention of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, which begins here today under the patronage of Cardinal Hayes.

Rene Leon's letter to THE TIMES on the currency stabilization agreement between France, England and the United States is very hopeful. "Good-will" is to replace "the most devastating weapon of economic warfare" -- whatever that is.

City Hall split into two warring camps yesterday when the Board of Aldermen, resenting what they considered unwarranted reflections by Mayor La Guardia on their honesty, refused to accede to the purchase of about $1,000,000 of new snow-fighting equipment.

One aspect of the three-Power move toward stabilization that has received less attention than it merits is the effect on the ordinary citizen of this concert of the great creditor nations. Real or not, the united front assures him that there is capacity for cooperation among Governments, and therefore government of the course of events.
THE Yankees made two runs in the first inning, indicating either that you can't stop those hard hitters permanently or that there is only one Hubbell wearing a Giant uniform.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 2. -- Major Gen. John L. Hines, Chief of Staff, U.S.A. (retired), and Mrs. Hines entertained with tea this afternoon for several members of the early Autumn Cottage colony at their home, Rocky Gap, in this resort,

Melvin C. Eaton will remain as chairman of the Republican State Committee, it was decided yesterday, as he withdrew the resignation he tendered to Justice William F. Bleakley immediately after the Westchester jurist had been nominated for Governor at the Albany convention last Tuesday.

The National Investors group of investment trusts, consisting of the National Investors Corporation, the management company, and the Second, Third and Fourth National Investors Corporations, reported yesterday combined net assets of $41,976,706 as of Sept. 30 before reserves for taxes on unrealized profits amounting to $2,202,000.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 2. -- Dean Marjorie H. Nicolson announced the Smith College dean's list for the two upper classes for last year at the first college assembly of the year. To be on this honor list a student must maintain an average of B or better for a year.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 2. -- A 65-year-old farmer barricaded himself in a barn and blazed away with shotgun and rifle late today at neighbors who came to a constable's sale on his farm. The farmer eventually was wounded and captured.

Consolidated net income of the Remington Arms Company, Inc., including domestic subsidiaries, for the six months ended on June 30 was reported yesterday as $167,950, after expenses, depreciation, obsolescence, taxes, interest and other charges.

Displaying tremendous straight- away power and more than a little guile, Manhattan's football team made its 1936 debut in Brooklyn an auspicious occasion by routing a game, but outclassed, Niagara University eleven, 33 to 7, before 10,000 fans at Ebbets Field last night.

MADRID, Oct. 2 (Passed by the censor). -- The fifth Rebel air raid on Madrid, all but one of which were on the airdrome on the outskirts of the capital, took place tonight. All lights in the city had been extinguished since an early hour, but a bright moon shining in a clear sky offered excellent visibility for the enemy airmen.
ON BOARD THE DIRIGIBLE HINDENBURG, Oct. 2. -- This, the second night out from Times Square, brings near an end the first leg of this reporter's dash around the world.

BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The Boerse continued firm and lively today despite several fluctuations that shaped the day's best prices. This continued boom despite Germany's present refusal to devalue the mark is attributed to investments from blocked mark accounts and book profits made by German companies on the devaluation of the French, Swiss and Dutch currencies.

During the depression the capitalization of sixteen of the larger trusts in custody of endowed foundations in this country increased from $545,000,000 to $546,000,000, "under all circumstances an extraordinary record," Frederick P. Keppel, president of the Carnegie Corporation, said yesterday afternoon in an address before the Bond Club of New York at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 2. -- With every man on the squad in good physical condition, the New York University football team completed its preparations for tomorrow's game with Ohio State with a short workout this afternoon in Ohio Stadium.

It was at Pittsburgh in 1932 that President ROOSEVELT denounced the deficits of the Hoover Administration and declared that a Government "willing" to make no sacrifices at all in "spending," and failing to balance its budget after it had extended its taxes "to the limit of people's power to pay," was "on the road to bankruptcy."
Heavy details of police guarded President Roosevelt in New York yesterday from the moment his special train arrived from Pittsburgh at 10:07 A.M.

The Right Rev. August Marahrens, Lutheran Bishop of Hanover, Germany, who is here as president of the Lutheran World Convention, will make his first public appearance tomorrow morning since his arrival last Monday. He is attending a meeting of the executive committee of the world convention at the Lutheran Church House, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street.

New financing scheduled for next week includes $19,607,575 by two States and fifty-five municipalities, compared with a revised total of $18,207,189 this week. The weekly average this year is $28,217,783.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP). -- Colonel John C. H. Lee, head of the army engineers in the Philadelphia district, told the Delaware River Basin Commission tonight that the army engineers would "cooperate with State and local authorities and with commercial manufacturing and shipping interests of the Delaware Basin" in developing the river.

After Mr. ROBERT H. GREENWOOD, who as an independent candidate for Senator got 104,000 votes in the Massachusetts Democratic primary, had withdrawn for reasons as yet unexplained, Governor CURLEY, the regular Democratic candidate for that office, said that he was sure to beat Mr. HENRY CABOT LODGE Jr., the Republican nominee, by 200,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Wheeler were dinner hosts last. night in the CatS. Lounge of the Savoy-Plaza for Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin ]3. McAlpin Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Herzog, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin L. Larsen, Mrs. Moore Erwin and Robert Robertson.
BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 2. -- The dramatist Jacinto Benavente, reported killed, has been found living quietly in Valencia.

Increased hedge selling and liquidation appeared on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. The December position eased to within 4 points of the 12-cent level, while the May was 3 points below. Final prices were within 1 to 2 points of the lows for the day and 11 to 15 points under Thursday's finish.

Net farm income from farm production from 1932 to 1935 advanced from $1,758,000,000 to $3,943,000,000, an increase of 124 per cent, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. During the same period, gross farm income rose from $5,211,000.000 to $7,727,000,000, a gain of 48.2 per cent, the board states.
Partial restoration of full pay for city employes next year is provided in the 1937 executive budget submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate by Mayor La Guardia in the amount of $554,071,935.96.

In its issue of July 11 THE TIMES published an editorial, "New York's Fiscal Maze." During recent weeks this editorial has been widely reprinted and has been used in several political addresses and at least two partisan radio attacks on Governor Lehman's financial record.

GENEVA, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The Madrid government informed the League of Nations today that it had evidence Germany and Italy, despite the European non-intervention pact and previous protests, were continuing to help the Spanish insurgents in a military way.

Professor Giancarlo Vallauri, Italian scientist who has been attending the power conference at Washington and the Harvard Tercentenary, will sail today on the Italian liner Rex. Others on the ship will be Count and Countess G. Camerana, Dr. Joseph Collins, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Hafner, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Cutter and Mr. and Mrs. T.M. Beavers.

If Mayor LA GUARDIAS recommendations are adopted, next year's city budget will be $23,000,000 higher than this year's. Half of that increase is accounted for by the more liberal welfare allowances available from State and Federal funds as a result of New Deal legislation.

DEATH VALLEY, Calif., Oct. 2. -- The old gas cayuse with the 100-gallon gasoline tank in which Death Valley Scotty assures he used to travel 600 miles without stopping, has been retired from the highways, he said today.

For the first time in more than two weeks the stock market had a good final hour yesterday. Ever since Sept. 17, brokers have been noticing that the market has had a peculiar tendency to show strength in the morning and to sag just before the close.

The time has arrived for us to canvass the United States and determine the athlete of this country who, by his performance as a competitor and by his example and influence as an amateur, did most to advance the cause of sportsmanship during the year 1936, and therefore is entitled to the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy.

Acting on information supplied by the Attorney General's office, fifty uniformed policemen and detectives raided the two lower floors and basement of a three-story house at 241 East Eighteenth Street yesterday and arrested a man and a woman on charges of performing illegal operations.
Columbia will open its football season today at 2 o'clock when it meets the University of Maine eleven at Baker Field before an expected crowd of 10,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- In the first action of the kind since the Securities Exchange Act became operative, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had issued an order directing the Dolphin Paint and Varnish Company to show cause why registration of its Class A no-par value common stock, $2 cumulative dividend, and Class B common stock, no-par value, on the Detroit Stock Exchange should not be suspended or withdrawn.

PARIS, Oct. 2. -- When the Bourse reopened today for the first time since last Friday, it was faced with a situation that will take several days to regulate. During the four days spent by Parliament in voting devaluation of the franc, buying orders had piled up beyond any possibility of their satisfaction, for there were no sellers today.

In announcing the continuation of her double currency system, Germany seized another occasion to press a further claim for "equality." The statement of Dr. SCHACHT declared in effect that the Reich will not join the new triple entente for monetary stabilization until the great Powers create conditions enabling Germany to resume her place as a free and equal partner in the world economy.
BERLIN, Oct. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 30 shows the following changes from the preceding weeks in thousands of marks: ...

A "sit down" strike of the crew of the 7,500-ton passenger and freight ship American Trader of the American Merchant Line, the second of its kind to be staged during the week, was settled last night at 7 o'clock, three hours after the ship was scheduled to sail for Plymout and London with passengers, freight and mail.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 2. -- There is a strong possibility that Edward Arnold will continue his biographical career on the screen beyond his portrayal of Jim Fisk for RKO in "Robber Barons." Universal has purchased "The Life of Alfred Nobel," an unpublished novel about the Nobel Prize donor by Rolf Passer, and negotiations are under way for Arnold to star in the film.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 2. -- Bucknell romped over Lebanon Valley to win, 20 -0, tonight for its second straight victory at Memorial Stadium. Stuart Smith cracked the line for the first touchdown in the second period after a Bison drive of 71 yards.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company announced yesterday the organization of a small loan service in all of its fifty-eight offices. The new service, to be known as the personal credit department, will be under the direction of R.A. Prosswimmer and H.H. Riddleberger, assistant cashiers, and W.C. Crittenden of the bank's modernization loan department.

Official canvass figures made public yesterday by the Board of Elections show that Sheriff William F. Brunner defeated Frank J. Prial for the Democratic nomination for Aldermanic President by a 25,230-vote margin in the recent primaries.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- Delegates to the annual convention of the New York State Waterways Association went on record today as opposed to the levying of tolls on the barge canal. One speaker criticized President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman for their advocacy of the St. Lawrence ship canal, while others assailed the St. Lawrence project itself.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange was quiet and featureless today, the last day of the fortnightly account. British Government securities and most foreign bonds were undecided in trend.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- An increase of at least 7,000,000 workers in private employment at mid-September since the depth of the depression unemployment was figured today by John W. O'Leary, chairman of the committee on employment of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
The Yankees spattered a dozen marks in the log of world series history yesterday as they drove Bill Terry and his Giants to the verge of distraction.
At 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon Vernon (Lefty) Gomez slapped a new ball into his glove, preparatory to starting his warm-up, and remarked with a wry grin:

BOSTON, Oct 2 (AP). -- Murray W. Garsson, investigator for the Sabath Congressional Investigating Committee, charged today that evidence disclosed "deliberate and criminal neglect" on the part of officials of the defunct Amoskeag Manufacturing Company.
BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 2. -- The Catalan Generalidad decided today to mobolize all male citizens between the ages of 20 and 30. As a preliminary step, military camps and schools will be created.

BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- There will be no change in the policies of the North Atlantic Shipping Conference respecting cabin ships, classifications and rate schedules, it was announced today at the conclusion of a two-day session in Berlin.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Charley Caldwell is back again in the environs of his alma mater with another Williams College football team that may give Princeton every hit of the fight tomorrow its predecessor put up in Palmer Stadium last Fall.

Among the apartment rentals reported yesterday was a lease of fourteen rooms in the cooperative house at 775 Park Avenue to Miss Sarah R. Baldwin. Port Burke were the brokers. Other lessees were listed for houses on the West Side and in the Greenwich Village area, as follows:

The stock market gave yesterday its best demonstration of strength in five weeks, and the turnover on the Stock Exchange, 1,928,000 shares, was the heaviest since July 29. The closing was strong, with the leaders up 1 to 4 points, many at or near the best levels of the day.

Though still inclined to be resentful enough to contemplate court redress, Earl Browder, Communist nominee for President, took the philosophic view yesterday that his recent jailing in Terre Haute, Ind., to prevent his speechmaking there, would result in an increased vote for him.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

The Netherlands will find herself in the position of Belgium in the next European war, which, according to Dionys van Nymegen Schonegevel, a commander of a Netherlands submarine division in the World War, and now managing director of the Curacao Petroluem Industry, a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch Shell Company.

LOCUST VALLEY. L.I., Oct. 2. -- The horse show ball was held tonight at the Piping Rock Club, a feature of the thirty-fourth Piping Rock horse show. It was attended by 1,000 persons. Many dinners preceded the dance, a feature of the second day's program in the show ring of the club.

One of the greatest programs of racing offered in this country is scheduled for the getaway card today at Belmont Park, with three championship stakes in as many divisions. A crowd of 25,000 is expected to see the running of the $80,000 Futurity down the Widener chute, the Jockey Club Gold Cup and the Grand National Steeplechase Handicap.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- The farmers from the foothills of the Alleghanies eastward to the Delaware and the commuters from the counties which ring Philadelphia will have to save Pennsylvania from the Democrats this year if it is to be saved.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2. -- X-ray motion pictures of human organs in action were shown on a screen today at the annual session of the American Roentgen Ray Society. The films depicted a heart beating, a throat swallowing food, a stomach and part of the small intestine digesting food, a pair of lungs in the act of breathing and the movement of joints.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- After another day of uncertainty the curtain again went up for "Transatlantic Rhythm" at the Adelphi Theatre tonight thanks to an anonymous American backer previously unconnected with the show business, who provided the necessary extra money.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 2. -- George Gaylord Simpson of Stamford, a curator at the American Museum of Natural History, New York, filed suit for divorce in Superior Court here today against Lydia Frances Gaylord of Madison, Kan.
The play-by-play description of the second game of the World Series at the Polo Grounds yesterday follows:
Housing and business properties were included in the Bronx realty turnover reported yesterday.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Oct. 2. -- Argentina's polo expedition came to a close today under an auction tent on the field of William Post Son as gauchos led out their ponies for the last time, and they went to the highest bidders under the hammer of Auctioneer George Cheshire.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- A tired but unusually cheerful President returned to his home here tonight for a week-end of partial relaxation, following his initial campaign tour through four States whose electoral votes will play an important part in his race for reelection.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Working through voluntary farm debt adjustment committees, the Resettlement Administration cut the debts of 38,728 farmers by 25 per cent, or $30,446,610, during the year ending Sept. 1. that agency reported today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2. -- Yale and Cornell will renew football relations tomorrow in the Yale Bowl after a lapse of forty-seven years, and about 20,000 persons are expected to be present for what should be a close battle.

Opera at popular prices continues to attract large assemblages at the Hippodrome Theatre. After an absence of a month from the old Sixth Avenue House, Alfredo Salmaggi and his company returned last night and presented "Aida" to the highly enthusiastic approval of 5,000 persons.

WHEN fences, law, titles, officials, towns, nesters, a great inundation of men and mandates had come to Horseshoe Range, Arden, who had grazed the whole range and built up a vast herd, determined to regain possession.

WITH a population numbering less than that of New York City and scattered over an island continent about as large as the United States, Australia is extending a "flying doctor" system of providing medical service to remote places "back of beyond" by airplane and radio.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were more numerous and diversified than in the preceding week. The list included many small lots of municipal bonds, several large public utility and industrial issues, a large railroad loan and some small amounts of foreign bonds.

Earl Browder, Communist Presidential candidate, attacked the Republican party and the Liberty League and referred humorously to his one-day imprisonment last Wednesday on a vagrancy charge in Terre Haute, Ind., in a speech yesterday afternoon before about 750 members of the International Workers' Order in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street.

Even though obscured temporarily by the rising crescendo of the Presidential election, the wide interest of women in the ultimate fate of the minimum-wage legislation is expected to be thrown into high relief Wednesday night at the dinner planned to honor Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Pitt's Golden Panthers paraded to a 34-to-0 victory over West Virginia University's Mountaineers, gallant but impotent, as the two district rivals waged their twenty-ninth annual battle before a crowd of 21,000 today.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Trojans of Southern California aimed a double-barreled attack at the University of Oregon and came out with a 26-to-0 victory before 35,000 football fans today.

A memorial to the late Sophie Irene Loeb, social worker, "lover of children" and writer, was unveiled yesterday before several hundred persons at the opening of the redesigned Heckscher playground in Central Park.

ISELLE, Italy. THE Rome-Geneva Express was pounding along toward the Swiss frontier and it suddenly occurred to us that we must be somewhere near the region in which Robert Sherwood laid the three acts of his play of a war to come.

ONE of the most distinct "trends" of recent years in the world of gardening is that toward more planting in the Fall. The remarkable part of it is that this movement has not come sooner. For Fall planting is a common-sense garden practice in the use of materials, and in taking advantage of existing conditions -- plant-growth, soil and weather.

Lillian D. Wald, head of the Henry Street Settlement, and Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the executive committee of the Progressive National Committee, have written Governor Landon urging him to "disown and reject" attacks on David Dubinsky, labor leader and Roosevelt elector in this State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Under the title "The New Deal and Small "Enterprise," a brochure was issued today by the Democratic National Committee in an attempt to refute the arguments of the opposition that small business was injured by the NRA.

Hervey Allen, Margaret Ayer Barnes, Katherine Brush, Pearl Buck, Henry Seidel Canby and John Gunther are among the noted authors and literary critics whom their publishers have scheduled for the auditorium programs of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair, it was announced yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Harvard opened its season today by sweeping through and around Amherst for six touchdowns and a 38-to-6 victory. The Lord Jeffs were unable to stop the powerful rushes of Vernon Struck, who made many brilliant gains, with Roberts three times making a scoring plunge.
BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Retail trade made a better comparative showing this week than was the case during the early part of September. Current volume is estimated fully 15 per cent over a year ago.

Recovery in the structural steel industry in this country is coming about through the private demand for materials and construction, rather than through the extensive public works program, the American Institute of Steel Construction stated yesterday in a message sent to the fifth international conference on steel development in Berlin.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- An estimated 77,500 cases are on the rolls of the Relief Commission here. This translates into close to 200,000 individuals. And their present situation is acute.

LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Although Lowell Textile outplayed Panzer College for three periods today, the New Jersey eleven pushed over a pair of touchdowns in the final three minutes of play to win 12 -- 0.

A battle with the Nova Scotia mire that engulfed the nose of Mrs. Beryl Markham's monoplane Messenger was described here yesterday by William Fischer, director of the Major Forwarding Company of 15 Moore Street. He was employed by Lord Carberry, owner of the craft, to extricate it and return it to England.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- The Journal Officiel prints this morning a series of decrees suppressing more than 100 import quotas as of Oct. 10, reducing tariffs on many articles 15 to 20 per cent, cutting the prices of import licenses an equal amount and instituting a committee for tariff revision and control.

Extension of price lines to $1 and in some cases up to $2 by the variety goods chains is being spurred by the current improvement in retail trade and both sales and profit figures of these chains this year are expected to reveal the benefits of the move.

The scene of this story is a small island connected with the mainland by a bridge, and this bridge is swept away by a terrific storm just about the time the trouble begins. There is only one house on the island, and one of the people in it -- a guest -- is murdered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Among vital problems involving the social and economic legislation enacted under the New Deal which will come before the Supreme Court for settlement during the eight-month term starting on Monday, probably the most prominent is that involved in the test of the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

In view of the record of Canadian Provincial Governments in maintaining full service on their internal as well as external debt, considerable interest was manifested in financial circles here in the report published yesterday by a committee for holders of bonds of Alberta, headed by J.M. Macdonell of Toronto.

TO land in America and to be asked why Mussolini is against women, is one of the many stimulating experiences that await an Italian journalist on these very stimulating shores. I was so taken aback when the question was first asked of me that, for a moment, I did not fully understand its import.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Of the cotton classed in the week ended on Thursday, 59 per cent was white middling or better in grade, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics announced today. Of the cotton of this season's crop thus far, 73 per cent is in that classification.

IN recent years Benito Mussolini and Adolf Hitler have done a great deal for history aside from making it. In an effort to understand their dictatorial activities many persons have dusted off volumes long untouched on library shelves.

AMERICAN visitors to England who witness the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace and other military ceremonies are often struck by the fact that each regiment always marches past or moves off to a particular tune. The explanation is that every regiment in the British Army, like the radio orchestras, has its own "signature tune."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- It would cost more than $2,000,000,000 a year to carry out Governor Landon's farm relief plan of making "tariff equivalent" payments on the domestically consumed portion of farm products of which there is normally an exportable surplus, according to an analysis of the proposal by farm experts here.

PULLMAN, Wash., Oct. 3 (AP). -- A spectacular aerial attack, begun midway in the second period, carried Washington State to a 14-to-13 football victory over Stanford today and knocked the Indians loose from their three-year reign atop the Pacific Coast Conference.

THAT Arthur Bryant, author of "The American Ideal," is an Englishman and not an American is worth bearing in mind in approaching the book. And not because it is always gratifying to have others see us as we see ourselves.

IN the picturesque lingo of the old West, "a man to ride the river with" was one who could be trusted in any emergency. Whether Jeff Gray was such a man became a serious question when he rode into Tail Holt and tangled in a shooting affray.

A BOON to the bookies is Director Wesley Ruggles, an iron-haired gentleman who vaguely resembles his brother Charles and who dropped a tidy bit of Hollywood cash last week at Belmont while he was waiting for the world series to get started.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- The Boerse opened firm today, but soon reacted under profit-taking, and most prices finished below yesterday's levels. Domestic fixed-interest securities were strong, but foreign bonds and colonial issues were reactionary.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Retail business in department and specialty stores here was active in most lines this week, lagging, however, in men's and women's clothing, due to continued unseasonable weather. Shoes, hats and accessories were in good demand and business vas approximately 7 per cent ahead of the corresponding week of last year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 3. -- A total of $37,685 was received last year by Rutgers University from alumni, faculty and undergraduates in gifts for general and specific purposes, according to the annual report of the Rutgers University Fund Council, made public today.

The sixty-sixth anniversary of the death of Robert E. Lee will be marked by a memorial service at Stratford Hall, Stratford, Westmoreland County, Va., on the afternoon of Oct. 12. Dr. John H. Finley, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES and a member of the National Advisory Board of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation, Inc., will speak.

AMONG progressive gardeners these days of October are looked upon as "the Autumn April" -- a time of planting activity second only to that of early Spring. To any one familiar with the nursery industry, this swing to more intensive garden-making in early Fall is not surprising, for the commercial growers have long practiced Autumn planting and transplanting as one of their major operations of the year.

ON Nov. 1 Transcontinental and Western Air will put into effect the most drastic cut in passenger fares any air line has instituted since the Ludingtons were operating their every-hour-on-the-hour service between New York and Washington.

Both retail and wholesale trade in the metropolitan area picked up sharply last week. Department stores here experienced the broadest consumer demand since the start of the Fall season, with sales estimated as showing an increase of 8 to 9 per cent over the comparative 1935 period.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 3. -- Practically duplicating its feat of last year, Alabama overpowered the Clemson Tigers. 32 to 0. today. The running of Joe Kilgrow, left half, and the scoring of Blackie Caldwell, right half, were features. Caldwell counted two of the five touchdowns.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The Scarsdale Golf Club was the scene tonight of a dinner dance. A feature of the event was an exhibition of dancing. Among the hosts were Mr. and Mrs. Preston H.F. Young, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Richardson, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen McDaniel, Mr. and Mrs. C.F. Zeltner, Mr. and Mrs. C.B. Chisholm, Mr. and Mrs. W. Fiech and Mr. and Mrs. W.C. Foster.

NEW YORK CITY'S drive for safer and less congested streets is now being pushed along two related fronts -- traffic regulation and law enforcement. On the regulation side, the Traffic Committee of the Board of Aldermen has under consideration a drastically revised set of traffic ordinances which would considerably increase police control over motorist and pedestrian alike.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A picture of the Spanish rebellion in Northern Spain, seen through the eyes of an officer fighting with the insurgent forces, was furnished here today by letters received from Ramon Padilla y de Satrustegui, former second secretary of the Spanish Embassy here.
