THE newest methods of warfare are blended with the oldest in this fantastically bitter Spanish civil war. There is no uniformity of action on the part of either side, Red or White, except in the ferocity with which the struggle is waged.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The teeming East End of London was tense with anxiety tonight because Sir Oswald Mosley intends to lead one of his biggest Fascist processions into the heart of the Jewish district in Whitechapel tomorrow afternoon.

Slowly but surely, British policy on the Continent is crystallizing. The warning of the Chancellor of the Exchequer to Germany last Friday -- following that of the First Lord of the Admiralty to Italy ten days earlier about the Mediterranean -- is another important indication of a growing conviction in Britain that the time has come to destroy the prevalent impression abroad that there is neither leadership nor adequate power in the Empire.

A SURPRISING burst of activity has begun to manifest itself in the field of dance magazines, a field which has been inclined in the past to languish considerably more than seemed necessary. During September two new periodicals made their first appearance, and there is a movement afoot to inaugurate still another about the beginning of the new year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- The Democratic National Committee began a campaign here today to sell thousands of automobile plates at $1 each to advertise President Roosevelt and the New Deal. The plates are inscribed "Forward with Roosevelt," and will fit any cal'. Pamphlets describing them are to be sent out to a host of Chicagoans. The plea for purchase of plates ends with tbi sentence: "Every dollar helps to re-elect President Roosevelt."

THE opening up of spectacularly scenic new territory in the rugged Olympic Range of Washington State by a series of roads leading off from the Olympic Loop Highway (U.S. 101), and following river valleys into the interior of America's last wilderness, is probably one of the most useful projects initiated by Uncle Sam's CCC boys.

NAZI Germany's armament program is not committing the blunder of the Kaiser's Supreme Command, which had notoriously underestimated the importance of military aviation in modern warfare. Averaging 84,000,000 marks for the years 1927 to 1931, the German flying budget has been steadily climbing since, thus: 1934 -- 211,000,000 marks; 1935 -- 500,000,000 marks; 1936 -- 980,000,000 marks.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Norma Shearer became probably the richest movie actress in the world today when she was named the principal heiress to the estate, unofficially estimated at $10,000,000, of her husband, Irving Thalberg.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Social security measures and the cooperative movement were commended, teachers' oath bills were sharply criticized and abolition of child labor was urged in a report on the state of church and country which was approved at today's joint session of lay and pastoral delegates to the Central New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Dr. Karl Stroelin, Mayor of Stuttgart and president of the German Foreign Institute, is here to make the guest speech at the "German Day" celebration today in Madison Square Garden in commemoration of the first German immigration to America, 250 years ago.

WASHINGTON. MAXIMUM camping facilities at minimum cost are being developed by the National Park Service. Few camps of that sort have been available for "the rank and file of the American people whose budgets did not permit the luxury of sending their families to private camps," the service points out.

Like other Republican orators who have found that their excitement over the threatened downfall of the Constitution has failed to excite their hearers, Senator VANDENBERG tries to change the form of his dose of warning. At Philadelphia Thursday and in New York yesterday he harped upon the Philippine Constitution as "an example "of the first step the Roosevelt Admin"istration is taking in leaning toward "an absolute dictatorship in this court"try.''

TRENTON, Oct. 3. -- The State Department of Conservation and Development, which administers the 12,448-acre Stokes State Forest in the northwestern part of Sussex County, has been delving into some of the Indian lore and pioneer legends in which that section of New Jersey abounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Though nine out of ten working-class families in Boston own a radio, only one out of ten owns an automobile, according to a recent survey of family expenditures by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Fred A. Birchmore, 24 years old, brought home to the United States today a battered bicycle and a story of wheeling his way through remote, romantic corners of the world.

Experiential teaching among the city's public school children, in which the inventiveness of young minds has found full expression, is depicted graphically in a current exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Mrs. Nellie A. King, postmistress of Verplanck, near here, was dismissed from office last Thursday and was replaced by Philip A. Gallagher, Democratic district leader in that village, it was learned today. Mrs. King, who is distantly related to Postmaster James A. Farley, has been postmistress for the last twenty-six years.

The only school in the world where a young man can study practically any trade and almost any regulation school subject from first grade through college has just opened its Fall term in the Civilian Conservation Corps camps with an expanded program and more than 200,000 students.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Army defeated Washington and Lee University, 28 to 0, today as 10,000 spectators, one of the largest crowds ever to witness an opening game at West Point, looked on.

The annual fund-raising campaign of the Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement, which maintains twenty nursing centers and has 265 nurses throughout the city, will begin tomorrow with a dinner of the Bronx section at the Concourse Plaza Hotel.
BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- The Third Reich acquired its first big modern battleship today when the 26,000-ton warship Scharnhorst was launched at Wilhelmshaven at noon amid cheers from a vast throng.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Advances and declines about balanced in the reports on business volume for the week ended on Sept. 26, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey. Electric power output decreased slightly, confirming previous indications that output for September as a whole would not display the full seasonal gain over August.

OUT in Hollywood a 7-year-old child with blond curls is drawing a salary reputedly three times as large as that of the President of the United States. For looking after her health and welfare her mother is paid a sum which in itself would mean to most families luxury beyond their dreams.
PROBABLY the largest cache in the world was arranged when the government decided that a great part of Uncle Sam's gold supply should be placed in a giant storage vault at Fort Knox, Ky.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A memorandum containing the outline of a suggested neutrality pact for adoption by the Inter-American Peace Conference of the twenty-one American Republics at Buenos Aires in December is being circulated among the interested governments.

THE NEW YORK TIMES recent editorial "The Farm Vote" was most timely and the electorate would be well advised to give due regard to the facts set forth. In respect to the cessation of foreign loans being responsible for a sharp decline in our grain exports, attention is directed to the comparative wheat exports from the United States and Canada during the period 1924-34.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- Information received here from Moscow shows that Russia's share in the adventure in Spain represented an attempt by Gregory Dimitroff, the Bulgarian extremist and head of the Communist International, to retrieve the fortune of a once all-powerful organization.

THIS is the chronicle of a New England business man who grew up with a genuine passion for big-game hunting in Africa, and who established a museum in his home town of Warren, N.H., with the many curios he brought from his African trips.

CHILD of a German father and an English mother, born in 1917. Ivy Carl went to Germany, after a wandering childhood, at the age of 14. For two years she made her home with her uncle, a village pastor, in an atmosphere of pleasant country gossip and Gemutlichkeit and at 16 she went to Munich and lived on her own as a Gymnasium pupil.
Registration for the Presidential election on Nov. 3 will start tomorrow and continue until Sunday in New York City, and the leaders of both parties will scan the results with keen interest.

PORT HENRY, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Another legal move in the battle for possession of the $80,000,000 estate of Colonel Edward H.R. Green has been made by his widow, Mrs. Mabel Harlow Green of South Dartmouth, Mass.

READING, Pa., Oct. 3. -- M. Earl Schlegel, a 25-year-old employe of the Berkshire Knitting Mills, died in Reading Hospital today of a fractured skull received during strike riots outside the plant in suburban Wyomissing Thursday.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 3 (AP). -- After three quarters of erratic football, Indiana University's team went into high gear in the final period of the game against Centre College of Danville, Ky., today to pound out a 38-to-0 victory.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 3. -- Notre Dame, featuring a surprisingly robust running attack, went on parade for the first time this season today and marched through Carnegie Tech to a sparkling 21-to-7 triumph before 35,000 spectators.

JEAN CAPART, advisory curator of Egyptology of the Brooklyn Museum, has returned from Buenos Aires, where he has been lecturing. He will be in charge of installation of new accessions in the Wilbour Memorial Hall and is preparing documents and photographs for publication together with manuscript notes of the late Charles Edwin Wilbour, whose "Travels in Egypt," just published by the museum, Mr. Capart edited.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Rex Mays of Glendale, Calif., won the feature event on the Good Time Park automobile racing card today. He covered the thirty-five miles in 26 minutes 12.78 seconds.

Preliminary plans are now being made for the December Ball given each year to aid the maintenance of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House at 321 East Forty-ninth Street. The event will take place on Dec. 3. in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton and its net proceeds will help to provide the $13,000 yearly budget necessary to conduct the extensive welfare work of the settlement house.

NEW YORK'S recent National Electrical and Radio Exposition having served as the curtain raiser for the 1936-37 radio season, the industrialists are planning on a banner last quarter of 1936 and as the forerunner of a prosperous 1937.

The hundredth anniversary of Madison Avenue as a city thoroughfare will be celebrated this week. City officials, civic leaders and merchants will take part in the ceremonies. The Fifth Avenue Association, which also guards the interests of Madison Avenue, is sponsoring the celebration.

The optimism expressed by New York and New Jersey game officials regarding the prospects for the 1936 gunning season is shared by New England observers. According to reports from the commissioners of five States, the past Spring and Summer were unusually cavorable for breeding and rearing of small game and upland birds.

LONDON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The failure of the leaders in the English Football League to win today resulted in the race for the top position becoming an issue between four soccer teams. Bracketed with 11 points are Derby County, Stoke City, Portsmouth and Brentford, 1 point ahead of Everton, Chelsea, Huddersfield Town, Charlton Athletic and Grimsby Town.

Abe Zebrak furnished one of the features in scholastic football yesterday when he intercepted a forward pass and ran 98 yards for a touchdown to aid Abraham Lincoln High in scoring a 7-6 victory over Manual Training High before a crowd of 6,000 on the winner's gridiron.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2. -- To Admiral Henry A. Wiley, chairman of the new Maritime Commission, and Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, belongs the credit for delivering San Francisco and other Coast ports from an economic and social catastrophe, as Coast shipping continues to operate in spite of the almost certain prospect of stoppage that existed until nearly midnight Wednesday.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute broke a 16- game losing streak by defeating the Alfred University football team, 14-6, today, before a crowd of 4,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Morris H. Dixon, gentleman rider, was injured and the mare, Preparedness, owned by Arthur I. Meigh, broke her leg and had to be destroyed at the Huntingdon Valley Hunt Club's Fall meet over the Justa Farms track today.

NEXT Saturday China celebrates an anniversary, but it will be a celebration not unmixed with sadness. On Oct. 10, 1911, a bomb exploded in a town on the Yangtse River and another shot rang out that was heard around the world. For thus began the revolution that was to give birth to the Chinese Republic, and the Eastern Hemisphere was never to be the same again.

FROM the end of the World War until early in 1934 the peace of Europe was constantly disturbed by the antagonism between Germany and Poland. Germans bitterly attacked the provisions of the Treaty of Versailles which detached Danzig, Posen and a part of Upper Silesia from the fatherland and erected the so-called "Polish Corridor," thereby separating East Prussia from the rest of the Reich.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 3. -- Lafayette College, emphasizing the tenth year of the administration of President Lewis, is starting a campaign for $500,000 for additions to buildings and departments.

BIARRITZ, France, Oct. 3. -- The present conflict in Spain is being waged not between fascism and democracy, liberalism and obscurantism, but between all who stand for law and order, whatever their particular religious or political creed, on the one hand, and communism or anarchy on the other hand.

SILHOUETTES don't just happen -- they must have a foundation. Naturally the basic garment must provide, or help to provide, the curves referred to in the article at the top of this page. One more thing it must do; it must remove all hint of the diaphragm.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3. -- Kentucky's Wildcats lashed out with their great back-field talent on Stoll Field today and smashed V.M.I., 38 to 0, before a crowd of 11,000.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 2. -- The farthest-west township of continental United States is a heap of smoldering ashes today. All that is left of Bandon, Ore., are a few crumbling walls and several outlying structures.

Major changes in sales programs will be made this week by representatives of American manufacturers who distribute goods in France, Holland, Switzerland and a number of other markets where present currency developments place American merchandise at a competitive disadvantage.

LONDON. -- One of Oxford's most famous buildings, the Sheldonian Theatre, erected from Sir Christopher Wren's design and opened in 1669, has been found to be badly damaged by the death-watch beetle. It will be closed for six months to ascertain th6 full extent of the damage and carry out the necessary repairs.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 2. -New and firmer hope in the success of the real final objectives for which the Tennessee Valley Authority was created has been given to the people of the section by President Roosevelt's conference on the proposed power pool.

MADRID, Oct. 3. -- From the Tagus front it was reported today that government troops were advancing toward Cabanas, southwest of Madrid. The Rebels were preparing to advance on Siguenza, to the northeast, simultaneously with their march from the Tagus sector, with the object of threatening all communication with Madrid.

Leaders in Tammany Hall and the Democratic organizations of boroughs outside Manhattan appeared united yesterday in the belief that former Governor Alfred E. Smith's "walk" to the cause of Governor Landon, Republican nominee for President, would solidify, rather than weaken, Democratic support for the Roosevelt-Garner ticket.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 3. -- Every ringside parking place and all available fields and woodland about the Piping Rock Club show ground were filled to capacity this afternoon at the closing session of the thirty-fourth Piping Rock Horse Show.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Benjamin H. Roberts, president of Bird Son, Inc., has sent to the Federal Trade Commission an explanation of transactions which caused the commission to cite the firm for violation of the Robinson-Patman act.

This will be week an important for Long Island yachtsmen who have a weather eye out for cruising in 1937-1938 and subsequent years. Two hearings before United States Army engineers on Monday and Tuesday are likely to attract several hundred pleasure-boat owners as well as municipal officials, park and Chamber of Commerce officers, commercial boatmen and party fishermen.

Putting the finger on what is wrong with the theatre has become a national institution, like working out cross-word puzzles, but it has remained for Charles Washburn to come through With the real answer. To this seer the decline and fall of the theatre, particularly the road, is chargeable to the fossilized advance man.
THIS will be a week of new shows on the air, the majority presented by headliners of past seasons.

HAVANA, Oct. 3. -- Four persons were killed and two wounded in the early hours of this morning in a gun fight between police and radicals when the police attempted to raid a house in the suburb of Santo Suarez.

Governor Landon's election as President would mean virtual destruction of the Social Security Act and certain repeal of its provisions for unemployment and old-age insurance, Senator Robert F. Wagner, sponsor of the legislation, declared last night in a radio address from WEAF and a nation-wide hook-up.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 3. -- Today's trip was the most eventful so far. The airship Hindenburg battled headwinds all last night and landed at Frankfort on the Main at 3:15 P.M., Berlin time [9:15 A.M. New York time], six hours late for my connection with the airplane for Italy.

Professor Carl Gustav Jung, who was summoned from Switzerland to address the recent Harvard Tercentenary as "one of the deepest analytical psychologists of the contemporary world," revealed yesterday some of his observations on the contemporary scene, including Franklin D. Roosevelt.

J.F. ARIAS CAMPOAMOR, in his novel "La Fragata Rebelde" ("The Rebellious Frigate"), has taken as his theme an attempt to bring about a seamen's soviet. The book was published by Editorial Bergua, Madrid, at 5 pesetas.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3. -- Cool weather caused a considerable pick-up in retail sales in the Eighth Federal Reserve district this week.

IN the very short preface with which, breaking "the reticence of a lifetime," Mr. Mason opens his new novel, he draws an interesting parallel between the world as it was at the period of which he writes, and the world as it is today.

NEATH, Pa., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Senator Davis told a Republican rally today that "a depreciation of 10 per cent in government bonds, if it should come swiftly, under present conditions, might render insolvent 90 per cent of the banks of the country."

Under this heading the National Safety Council discusses a factor that is beginning to assume considerable proportions in highway traffic statistics. Last year collisions between bicycles and automobiles resulted in 350 deaths and approximately 13,000 injuries.

Park Commissioner Moses warned yesterday that proper maintenance of the city parks will be impossible if his request for $9,750,000 with which to carry out the 1937 Park Department program is reduced by more than $3,000,000. He asked the Board of Estimate for $9,754,951.

The devaluation of the franc last week completed the world-wide collapse of the gold standard. Within the past five years country after country has abandoned gold and allowed its currency to depreciate until today there is no nation in the world where the ordinary man can take his paper money and have it redeemed in gold.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Republican National Committee said today that unless the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee held open hearings, before election on charges of "New Deal corruption" in Pennsylvania, it would "stand self-convicted of being a partisan agency of the Roosevelt administration."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 3. -- Pan-Americanism has outgrown its ethereal nature and become a practical and workable application of liberty and democracy to international relations, said Spruille Braden, United States Ambassador at Large, in an address yesterday before the Argentine Institute of International Law.

A bristling spear point, on the front of a wave of horses, Pompoon yesterday thrust his way home first in the $80,150 Futurity at Belmont Park to receive the acclaim of 25, 000 persons as the champion 2-year-old. Not in years has a colt dominated the division as this son of Pompey does for J.H. Louchheim, the Philadelphia contractor.

THE outlaw gang known as The Maskers was so cleverly organized that only two or three of the band knew who their big boss was. So when Ranger Sherry Cole was sent to their corner of Texas to break up the gang he had to go under cover and get next to some of its members without arousing suspicion.

Three thousand boys and girls getting a junior college education in New York's emergency collegiate centers are to have better study conditions and more of real college life this season than ever before. For the first time practically every one of the twenty centers, organized in the past three years through government relief funds, across the State from Buffalo to Garden City, is to have a building of its own.

COLLECTORS, whether serious-minded or dilettante, find a common meeting ground at antique exhibitions. Here is a chance to browse around more different collections than could ordinarily be seen in a year and to swap bits of lore with other collectors about the hobbies of the tribe.

Headlines in a recent issue of THE TIMES read side by side, "Religious Study First" and "Scholars Favor a 'Court of Wisdom,'" said court being the Harvard Macroscope made bigger, better and permanent, ith specialized religious study so far from being in first place it is quite left out of the scheme of things.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Mrs. Sophia Holmstrom of Sioux Falls, today ended a four-year legal fight to escape serving a jail term for failure to pay a $17,500 judgment obtained against her in an alienation of affections case by a woman who is now dead.

GENEVA, Oct. 3. -- Premier Leon Blum of France ended a two-day visit here, which was crowded by important political and economic talks, by receiving the world press today and stressing orally these four points:

Two hundred and two students in New York University's Washington Square College were commended for high scholarship during the second semester of the 1935-36 school year, it was announced by Dean Milton E. Loomis of the college yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- The University of Pennsylvania has begun its 197th academic year with the most ambitious program ever planned on the campus for the assistance of students either wholly or partly self-supporting.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- The financial situation is influencing Fall millinery. Agnes shows "hoarding" hats, trimmed with gold chain bracelets, from which dangle many charms and bangles. Lemonnier's brimmed felt shapes have porte feuille or miser pouch crowns; their colored drawstrings replace bands.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 3. -- Brown came from behind with a Garrison finish to defeat the Rhode Island State eleven, 7 to 6, today. All the scoring was confined to the final period.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Justice William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, accused Governor Herbert H. Lehman tonight of having misrepresented the State's fiscal affairs. Mr. Bleakley spoke in the gymnasium of Colgate University here, bringing to a close his first full day of active campaigning. Incidental to his campaigning he sought expert information on farm problems.

ROME, Oct. 3. -- Delegates to the thirteenth assembly of the International Institute of Agriculture are arriving in Rome for the opening session, which will be held in the institute's palace tomorrow morning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- To develop undergraduate singing at Yale University, the Joseph Horne Holmes fund of $5,000 has been established by his two sons, John G. Holmes, '35, of New York City, and Joseph H. Holmes, '36, of Pittsburgh, and his brother, Nathaniel Holmes 2d, '08, of New York City.

MANILA. A SPIRIT not unlike that of the craft guilds of medieval Europe has been kept alive in the Philippines for almost three centuries in the small town of Paete, Laguna, about ninety miles south of Manila. The present wood carvers of Paete have an organization and a tradition reminiscent of those of the shoemakers of old Nuremberg.

THE Music School Settlement, directed by Melzar Chaffee, and the former Music School of Christodora House, C. Louise Arms, director, will unite their resources. The Music School Settlement will start its forty-second year tomorrow.

The Paraguayan Legation in Washington has made public a statement from the Foreign Ministry in Asuncion denying reports in foreign newspapers that the policy of the provisional government was "nourishing anti-foreign and anti- democratic propositions."

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Gil Dobie's first Boston College eleven mowed down neighboring Northeastern, 26 -- 6, today. The overpowered Huskies, however, riddled the Dobie pass defense all afternoon, gaining 142 yards via the air, paving the way to their third-period touchdown by that means.

AN amusing and interesting show of color prints, engravings and reproductions of paintings that have been popular during the last century in this country has been arranged at the Old Print Shop and will be current there until Oct. 17.

A list of preachers who are to be heard the rest of this year from the pulpit of the late Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman in Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, has been announced.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 3 (AP). -- A stray, half-grown black kitten was the only find today of more than 250 Boy Scouts, police and other searchers who combed ravines, woods, swamps and meadows of the northwestern section of the city and outskirts in a search for 9-year-old Charles Brennan, missing since Sunday.

DURING the forty years that have passed since William Morris died certain artistic and literary critics have dabbled with some few aspects of his life and works. But no scholar has treated either subject in its entirety. This is a lamentable fact, for Morris had an extraordinarily amazing career.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Two major meat packing companies, Armour and Swift, today faced a complaint by Secretary Wallace that they had engaged in "unfair trade practices" in violation of law.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- No Democratic leader in Pennsylvania wants the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures, headed by Senator Lonergan of Connecticut, to hold open hearings in its proposed investigation of the Works Progress Administration in this State.

The Phoenix Securities Corporation yesterday that its net asset value on Aug. 31, the fiscal year's end, was $10,107,665, equal to $130.75 a share on the $3 convertible preferred stock, and, after allowing for such stock at $50 a share, it was $7.49 each for the 833,769 shares of common stock.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Next week's openings are these: On Sunday at the Aldwych, Philip Leaver's "Causes Unknown" arrives, with Anthony Ireland and Leueen MacGrath. The same night at the Arts is "Time and the Hour," by Alan Kennington and William McElwee, with Alan Napier and Jack Livesey.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 3. -Charles H. Griffiths, Westchester County Republican chairman, won his spurs this week as the successor of the late William L. Ward through the nomination of Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley for Governor.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 3. -- It is highly improbable that martial law will be proclaimed in Palestine, if at all, for eight or ten days. General Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, the British High Commissioner, is pinning his hopes on an appeal to be issued by King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia and other Arab monarchs to Palestine Arabs to call off their strike and end terrorism.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The Duchess of Marlborough held a reception on Wednesday night at the New Burlington Galleries in connection with the exhibition of nineteenth century French art. Among the guests were the French and Belgian Ambassadors, Lady Cheylesmore, Lord Ivor Churchill, Lady Patricia Latham, Mr. and Mrs. Alec Rea, Lady St. John of Bletso and Mrs. Donough O'Brien.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- The world's wheat markets were strong in undertone today and closing sales generally were at the top to a fraction under. Reports of hot winds in Eastern Australia, an important producing area, and a tendency to reduce estimates on the prospective yield influenced trade sentiment.

SAILMAKERS of the Port of New York are still busy, despite the fact that the yachting season in local waters is almost at an end. For there are old saris to be mended, and new rigs to be designed for yachtsmen who send their boats south to race in the bays of Florida.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 3. -- All mining companies operating in Mexico, including foreign, should invest at least 25 per cent of their profits within the Republic, according to a resolution adopted at the recent convention of small-scale miners held in this capital.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The new form for permanent registration of holding companies abiding by provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 was promulgated today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Its application will be immediate in the cases of about sixty- five companies which have become registered temporarily through the filing of notification of registration.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 3. -- Connecticut College alumnae will return to the campus next week for the annual alumnae activities on Oct. 10, 11 and 12.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The Mall, stretching from the Capitol to the Washington Monument, is now more than 90 per cent completed according to the plan drawn up by Major L'Enfant 148 years ago, Arno B. Cammerer, Director of National Park Service, announced today.

Earnings of farm and consumer cooperatives are exempt in many instances, under both Federal and State laws, from income taxes that are paid by private business, according to a statement issued yesterday by the American Retail Federation, which has completed a study of tax exemptions as a form of subsidy by the government to cooperative organizations.

The advance in corporation bonds on the New York Stock Exchange gained momentum yesterday as prices in certain groups established new high marks in the second most active Saturday session this year. Although the secondary railroad and convertible industrial loans continued to lead the advance, trading was unusually broad for a two-hour week-end session and extended well over the entire list of domestic corporate issues.

IN our age of materialism with its arbitrarily necessary emphasis on key solutions through managed currency, cooperatives and community housing, when the very names Finland, Sweden and Denmark suggest successful contributions to the modern economic pattern, it is a relief to turn to the more enduring cool spiritual values of literature as suggested by Hans Ruin in "The Mysticism of Poetry."

WILLA CATHER'S first book -- "Alexander's Bridge" (1912), a story of London life -- was inspired by the initial impact of Europe upon her young and avid mind; but it was brittle and artificial, for she had not had time to know her new environment well enough to see below the surface.

KANSAS CITY (AP). -- The flying chief of Canada's famed "Mounties" -- in thirty days he made an 11,000 mile inspection of posts which once required three years -- declared here recently that United States prohibition repeal has turned the tables on Canada.

MADISON AVENUE dresses up in its best this week to observe its 100th anniversary. For a century this pleasant thoroughfare has been content to run beside famous Fifth Avenue as an obliging and useful small sister.

Lehman vs. Bleakley The New York State Democratic and Republican conventions last week produced no real surprises. In Syracuse Herbert H. Lehman was renominated for Governor by acclamation; for months there had been no question that he would be. In Albany, where the Republicans met, William F. Bleakley of Westchester County, justice of the Supreme Court, received the G.O.P. Gubernatorial nomination.

When Governor Landon, in a speech Sept. 26 at Milwaukee, attacked President Roosevelt's Social Security Act as "unjust, unworkable, stupidly drafted and wastefully financed," he touched off a controversy.

Representatives of local clubs in New Jersey will gather at Convention Hall, Asbury Park, on Thursday for the annual Fall conference of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs. Mrs. William P. Divine of Spring Lake and a large committee have prepared a balanced program embracing both serious business and entertainment.

Several pleasing styles of American architecture have almost disappeared, whereas many examples of bad design remain, according to a book just published by the American Society for Better Housing. The organization is an association of twenty-one members of the American Institute of Architects.

IT is quite true that if the United States can possibly be said to have a royal family, this is it. And that not alone because this family has sent two of its name to the White House -- a phenomenon which, after all has occurred more than once in our history.

LONDON. EVERY one in a picture soon to be made in England must be a teetotaler. The film will tell the story of the birth and development of the temperance movement in Great Britain, and the condition that all concerned with it must be "total abstainers" has been insisted on by Religious Films, a comparatively recently formed organization which is being financed by England's richest man, Joseph Rank, mill owner and philanthropist.

Complete harmony was evident yesterday in a conference of three leaders in Republican State headquarters at 41 East Forty-second Street. Plans for the campaign in behalf of William F. Bleakley, candidate for Governor, were discussed.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3. -- The war manoeuvres of both the Pacific and the Baltic fleets have been completed and the army and navy authorities declare that the Soviet forces have demonstrated their ability to repel an invader.

Announcing the adoption of a revised budget of $4,344,000, the largest in recent years, Samuel D. Leidesdorf, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, declared yesterday that the need by destitute and underprivileged families for private welfare services was still mounting.

GENEVA, Oct. 3. -- The League of Nations Council inaugurated yesterday its magnificent permanent Council chamber in the new League palace. As the delegates, League officials and members of the press strolled in, the usual hum of conversation died away before the picture that met their eyes. Art for once had silenced politics in Geneva.

Efforts of the large chains and mail order houses last week to buy staple cotton goods nine months ahead or for June were regarded by trade authorities as the most significant development in a "boiling" market which saw all records since 1923 shattered.

THIS is the time of the year when hundreds of Scout troops and cub packs are established. At this season also, with Summer camps closed and school under way, the troops, cub packs and sea scouts ships already organized resume their weekly indoor meetings.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 3. -- Out-classed and outmanned, a game Vermont team went down fighting before Dartmouth, 56 -- 0, in a football game today which saw the Indians make good use of the lateral pass. Eight touchdowns were rolled over the goal line.

ALL of the "pinks" (Dianthus in the catalogues) are loved by most gardeners, whether they be the spicy ones with blushing colors and the pinking-iron edges, the fluffy doubles, or the wee ones that twinkle like brilliant stars in the rock garden.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- More than 150 indignant residents of Rockland and Westchester Counties, together with a sprinkling of residents from other localities along the Hudson Valley, boarded the ferryboat Reading this afternoon and sailed to the middle of the Hudson River at Tappan Zee, where they held a protest meeting against the proposed construction of the Nyack-Tarrytown Bridge.

THE seventy-seventh annual Worcester Festival opens tomorrow night at Worcester, Mass., with a performance of Saint-Saens's "Samson and Delilah" in concert form, under the baton of Albert Stoessel, the festival's musical director and conductor.

In the first chapter of this story the malacca stick looms very large indeed. After that it is lost sight of for so long that the render is very likely to think that, like the flowers that bloom in the Spring, it has "nothing to do with the case."

Business activity in the last quarter of this year will come very close to that of 1929, when the stock market crash caused a rather abrupt cessation in activity late in November, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by advertising executives who have been checking the outlook in various markets closely.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Hugo Bezdek, storm center of alumni and student attacks over his athletic policies at the Pennsylvania State College, was removed today as director of the School of Physical Education.

The United States Government has submitted a statement to the International Labor Conference, which is scheduled to convene this week in Geneva, advocating the adoption of the three-watch system and the eight-hour day without overtime as the standard of employment of ships engaged in international trade.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 3 (AP). -- The University of Virginia defeated William and Mary today, 7 to 0, before 15,000 fans assembled to witness the dedication of the new $300,000 stadium of the Norfolk division of William and Mary.

THAT the automobile industry is bullish about the immediate future and feels that new all-time heights will be reached in car registrations in the United States is indicated by the address of C.E. Wilson, vice president of General Motors Corporation, in Detroit last week.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Drexel Tech lost a hard-fought game to St. John's of Annapolis today, 7 to 0, before 3,000 spectators.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP). -- St. Mary's Galloping Gaels marched into the national football picture in decisive fashion today with a 10-to-0 victory over the University of California's Bears.
NANKING, Oct. 3. -- "Under no conditions will Japan entertain counter-demands from the Chinese Government in connection with the current negotiations," the Japanese Embassy spokesman declared today.

FOR many years it has been possible for a casual visitor to drop into any smart gymkhana in Calcutta or Bombay, wander into the game room and idly suggest to the first resident encountered a round of "poona."

IN the Soviet Union, as in other countries, the Summer is the worst season for seeing the theatre. However, there is one respect in which the tourist is the beneficiary of the centralized control which the Soviet Government exercises over all the theatrical organizations in the Union.

ALMOST every amateur gardener is fairly familiar with the Single Early, Cottage and Darwin tulips -- indeed, in many gardens fairly representative collections of these are to be found. But outside of these classes -- which may, with no disparagement, be termed "the tulip rut" -- there are many splendid tulips little known or planted.
PARIS, Oct. 3. -- Colonel Francois de la Rocque charged tonight that the government-ordered investigation of his Social party had been undertaken "on direct orders from Moscow."

TODAY ushers in the Fall bicycle train excursion, bound for the open country where Autumn tints and crisp air gives zest to pedaling tours. The popularity, last Spring of these bicycle treks (discontinued during hot weather) encouraged the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to reinstate the service.

Two of Europe's most powerful dictators appear in this book thinly disguised as Hagen of Germany and Cafarelli of Italy. The hero of the story is our old friend Colonel Granby of the British Secret Service, and the narrator is Bob Hardcastle, one of Granby's aides.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- More than 300 delegates are expected to attend the annual meeting of the New York branch of the Women's Foreign Missionary Society of the Methodist Church, which takes place here Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.
WITH GOVERNMENT TROOPS, MORA, Spain, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Government forces tonight fought to out-flank the Fascist southern wing closing in on Madrid from Toledo.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 3. -- The Navy had no trouble stopping the running attack of Davidson this afternoon and won, 19 to 6, scoring a touchdown on the first play of the second quarter and two in the final period, one of which came just two minutes before the final whistle.

TO broaden the range of the musical life of New Haven, Conn., the New Haven Symphony Orchestra and the Civic Orchestra of New Haven have been combined under the unified civic direction of the New Haven Orchestra Association, with the cooperation of Yale University.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 3. -- With Lloyd Cardwell setting the pace with three touchdowns, the University of Nebraska opened its Bix Six Conference season today with a startling 34-to-0 victory over Iowa State.

Often stories for children about other lands inform but do not convince. The facts are there but not the spirit. Thus it is a heartening experience to discover such a book as 'The Golden Basket," which, like the magic traveling cloak of the fairy tales, carries the reader awayto the very place and the very people described in the story.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 3. -- Bushrod H. Spencer of New York and Jesse W. Pellaetrean of Jersey City took the stand as handwriting experts for the defense today and denied that the addresses on the bombs which killed Thomas Maloney, insurgent mine leader, in April were in the handwriting of Michael Fugmann, on trial in the killing.
THE new music season has begun. Carnegie Hall has had its opening concert, and the Town Hall launches a long series of programs this week, with three pianists giving recitals.

TOPEKA, Oct. 3. -- Governor Landon made public today the detailed itinerary for his next campaign trip, on which he will make major speeches at Chicago, Cleveland and Detroit and carry on a rear platform campaign in Illinois, Ohio, Michigan and Indiana.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $573,135,325 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on Oct. 1 was $40.88, compared with $40.56 at the beginning of September.

With the election only four weeks away. Democrats and Republicans began last week to turn on all their heat. The two outstanding events of the week were the opening of the President's political campaign and the announcement by A1 Smith that he would support Governor Landon.

VERSAILLES, France, Sunday, Oct. 4. -- The great palace here, where Louis XIV held his court, one of the show places of the world, was in danger from fire last night for an hour. Swift work by local firemen, aided by re-enforcements from Paris, quenched the blaze without material damage to the priceless furnishings and works of art.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Princeton picked up where it left off last year by defeating the spirited Williams football team today. The Orange and Black eleven, which went through the 1935 season triumphantly, gave evidence of greater strength for the campaign just starting by the convincing manner in which it turned back the New Englanders, who bowed by 27 to 7.

Six presidents of as many State Federations of Women's Clubs will contribute to the deliberations of the New England Conference at New Haven on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of this week. Mrs. Grace Morrison Poole, immediate past president of the General Federation, will conduct a session Friday morning, at which three of the six will be heard on phases of the main theme -- "Youth Today -- Citizens Tomorrow."

With the distribution of Fall merchandise increasing steadily and manufacturing operations in many industrial divisions at peak levels to meet the growing demand for goods, most branches of business entered the final quarter of the year this week under the most favorable conditions generally since the pre-depression period.

"AL" SMITH insists that "The Sidewalks of New York" still lives. The last straw that broke the donkey's back for him seems to have been when somebody issued orders at the Philadelphia Democratic Convention to stop playing "The Sidewalks of New York."

FOR the purpose of receiving donations toward the Gabrilowitsch Memorial Scholarship which is being established in the National Orchestral Association, a committee has been formed consisting of Richard Aldrich, Walter Damrosch, Harry Harkness Flagler, Albert Spalding, Theodore Steinway, Bruno Walter, Felix Warburg and Allen Wardwell.

CIVIL war in Spain, causing food shortages in Madrid and other centers, has had repercussions in the New York provision markets, and particularly in the groceries and restaurants that specialize in Spanish comestibles and cuisine.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Packing a punch in three of the four periods. Pennsylvania opened its sixtieth football season today by defeating Lafayette on Franklin Field easily, 35 to 0. Thirty thousand spectators saw the Red and Blue take advantage of several breaks to pile up five touchdowns and kick each goal.
ELBERFELD, Ind., Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Warfield Coal Company probably has the most contented workers of any coal mine in the world. Well they might be; they own it and manage it themselves.

Park Department plans for the development of the Flushing Meadows Park in Queens, following its use as a site for the World's Fair in 1939, call for transforming the parking areas south of Sixty-ninth Road into an arboretum devoted to native plant material, according to information released by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

WARRENTON, Va. -- Officials of the Warrenton Horse Show Association are preparing for the thirty-seventh annual Warrenton Horse Show, to be held on Friday and Saturday. Entries are coming in rapidly and there is every prospect that the show will measure up to its reputation for quality of the horses exhibited, well-filled classes, promptness and efficient management.

LONDON, Sept. 20. BRILLIANT acting by Miss Lucie Mannheim and Miss Madge Titheradge should suffice to carry off two mediocre plays presented in London this week -- "Girl Unknown," an adaptation by Miss Margaret Webster of a piece by Herr Ferenc Molnar, and "Madmoiselle," an adaptation from the French of M. Jacques Deval made by Miss Audrey Carten and Mr. Waveney Carton.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3. -- Los Angeles County closed the Summer with Federal and State government agencies supporting 26,231 fewer unemployment relief cases than a year ago, but at an expense now running around $1,400,000 a month more than at that time.

The last full week in September brought retail sales figures up sharply, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., but in many instances gains were insufficient to produce planned increases.

THROUGH the great roar and spill of the Niagara of campaign oratory the sensitive tympanums of the waiter, the hat-check girl, the porter and the maid have caught the merry high note of tinkling gold and silver. First to sight panting Prosperity as she finally negotiated the headwinds of the mythical corner, they have dusted off their palms and expect that this Fall the tips will drop as freely as Autumn leaves.

ALMOST any one may have occasion to "go on the air" today. As Mr. Dunlap puts it. "Mr. Average Speaker has a definite place on the radio." In this little book a well-known radio editor, Orrin E. Dunlap Jr. of THE NEW YORK TIMES tells Mr. and Mrs. Average Speaker what they need to know in order to broadcast effectively.

WITH its catalogue printed in the attractive little magazine called Exhibition (newly launched by the Municipal Art Committee), the opening group show of the season at the committee's Temporary Galleries got under way last week.

WEBSTER, N.Y. (AP) -- Dr. Alvah P. Maine, 90 years old, looks back on sixty-six years of practice as a country doctor and finds it good despite the fact that for many years "parlors were my operating rooms, kitchens my clinics, the kitchen range my sterilizer."

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 3. -- The Alfred M. Landons were divided over a gridiron contest today, with the Governor coming out the winner, but with Mrs. Landon commenting with a smile: "It was a good game."

The contributions of science and invention in the field of employment are given praise in a recent analysis issued by the National Industrial Conference Board. * * * New inventions do make new jobs and at the same time efficient machines cut down the number of jobs by requiring fewer men to produce a constant quantity of goods.

The reorganization situation of the Western Pacific Railroad became more complex last week when interested insurance companies filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a plan of recapitalization different from the one sponsored by the management of the road.

For the second time in two seasons, Paul Morehouse, 19 years old of 333 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn captain and left halfback of the Alexander Hamilton High School football team of the same borough was in Kings County Hospital last night in a serious condition with a possibly fractured skull and a brain concussion.

THE controversy begun a week ago by Stuart Davis, spokesman for the American Artists Congress, continues. It relates to an article appearing on this page Sept. 20 that dealt with the Federal Art Project exhibition now at the Museum of Modern Art and with the government's art program in general.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 3. -- Democratic nominees for Senator, Governor and one of nine Congressional nominees withdrew today to effect a coalition between the Democratic and Farmer-Labor parties in Minnesota and consolidate support of the latter party for President Roosevelt.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., Oct. 3. -- Several parties were given by White Mountains visitors at the Dartmouth-Vermont football game at Hanover. Lewis Parkhurst invited a group from the Mountain View House here. Noyes D. Clark and a party also attended.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Now that a field of more than 1,000 candidates is off to a good start in the race for control of Congress, one may expect to hear more and louder claims as to the outcome between now and the time the issue is finally settled on Nov. 3.

AT the instance of its aviation committee, of which Dudley Steele is national chairman, the American Legion passed strong resolutions on air defense at its recent convention, including both lighter and heavier than air. Full support from all government departments was urged toward solution of whatever problems exist in airship design, construction or operation, and it was recommended that the lighter-than-air aircraft program be resumed and very closely prosecuted.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 2. -- The ancient struggle between conflicting wet and dry forces, each with a national victory to its credit, is again being fought in Kentucky.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The attack on the reciprocal trade agreements program unleashed by Governor Landon in the farm belt has precipitated a political controversy which promises to increase in volume in the closing weeks of the campaign and go far toward determining whether the policies so completely associated with Secre tary Hull's name will stand the test of public analysis and persist after the election.

ST. HELENA -- little island * * *" This brief summary was found scribbled among the geographical notes of young Lieutenant Napoleon Bonaparte at Brienne. Thirty-odd years later the World Conqueror was to discover a great deal more about that small island off the west coast of Africa.

IT was a Summer night in 1861," Latch's band of outlaws and savages (the latter led by Satana, "a fierce and bloody chief of the Kiowas") hid in Spider Web Canyon awaiting return of the Kiowa scouts sent out to watch for any approaching wagon trains.

HANOVER, Germany, Oct. 3. -- The peasant legions who gather annually on the Bueckeberg in Central Germany for a harvest festival, the National Socialist Thanksgiving Day, converged on their meeting place tonight. In all, 190 special trains filled with peasants in traditional costumes are en route or are scheduled to leave early in the morning.

Horse cars (the kind that carry the animals) impeded traffic along the West Side in the Fifties yesterday afternoon as 524 head of stock arrived in town for the annual rodeo, which opens at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night to run until Oct. 25.

PARIS. HUNTING (like Winter sports) is attracting new crowds of novices every season. Every smart woman -- not to speak of man and child -- who can "bear arms" seems to be going in for shooting nowadays, at least over the week-ends.

AT THE BAR: Drinking habits of some women do not meet the approval of New York restaurateurs. Last week it was announced that 95 per cent of the members of the Society of Restaurateurs, Inc., would be happier if feminine feet were not placed on the brass rail, if feminine elbows were not rested on the mahogany bar.

WITHIN a few weeks that liberal old Vermont editor, Doremus Jessup, and his loyal friends will wage their fight against fascism on the stages of theatres in New York and San Francisco, in New Orleans and Seattle, while Berzelius Windrip and his fellow-conspirators are maladministering the laws in a Thespian America subdued by fear and oppression.

The flexibility of the Federal Constitution was stressed by Professor Herman A. Gray of the New York University Law School in an address yesterday at the fourteenth annual conference of the Women's Trade Union League, 247 Lexington Avenue.

Columbia's football forces spent a busy afternoon yesterday at Baker Field in defeating the University of Maine, 34 to 0, before 7,000 spectators. It was the opening game of the campaign for the Blue and White and Coach Lou Little's outfit showed flashes of offensive power in turning back the light and comparatively small team from the Pine Tree State.
ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The approach of the early Autumn season in the Southern highlands, with its accompanying tints in the mountain forests, has brought with it a new influx of vacationists.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 3. -- Michigan State's Spartans clipped the University of Michigan Wolverines' claws for the third successive year today, 21 to 7.

When the dramatic announcements last week that France, Switzerland and Holland were devaluating their currencies were accompanied by the agreement of France, Great Britain and the United States to cooperate in the "reestablishment of a lasting equilibrium" among their various economic systems, the world breathed a new hope.
The United States Government is trying to enforce in this country a Soviet decree under which Russian corporations were nationalized, it was charged in papers filed in Supreme Court here yesterday.
BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- Professional politicians themselves regard the November election in this State as anybody's battle.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2. -- The normal friendly relations between the United States and the Soviet Union were ruffled but not really damaged this week by the assertion of Secretary Morgenthau that he had thwarted an attempt by Moscow to depress the English pound by buying up 1,000,000 pounds sterling which the Soviet had dumped in Walt Street.

PROFESSOR WEST says that if an inveterate book collector is deprived of his income, he will immediately turn to something else -- possibly four-leaf clovers. Even though this seems an overstatement, there is on record the case of one collector who could not afford books, so he turned to collecting humorous misprints.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Eleven hard-charging, sure-tackling Northwestern football players demonstrated today they could stop even the super-star, Oze Simmons, when they defeated Iowa, 18 to 7, in the opening conflict of the Western Conference championship season before 30,000 spectators.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Sweeping assurances about the future of Morocco and the Balearic Islands are reported to have reached London today from General Francisco Franco, would-be dictator of Spain.

VIENNA, Oct. 3. -- The feud between Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, commander of the Fascist Heimwehr organization, and Major Emil Fey, his former deputy, whom he expelled from the organization yesterday, became more acute today.

RIDING on a secret mission of his own, Red Rochford saw a -- drygulcher shoot a cowboy. Red went after the rattlesnake as fast as his roan could travel, took a shot at him that knocked him from his horse and then found that in falling the fellow had broken his neck.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3. -- A scarlet-shirted mob of football players, their silver pants glinting in the sun as legs worked like pistons, ran amuck over New York University today and turned back the Violet, 60 -- 0.

FOR decades the daffodil, or narcissus, while popular in American gardens, was not considered a flower to get excited about. Growers who "kept up" on roses or irises or dahlias, adding the outstanding new varieties each year, were content to get along with a few old-fashioned daffodils, often left undisturbed in dense clumps for years, to struggle as best they might against the competition of other perennials, or even of thick sod.

THERE have been numerous lives of Brahms and volumes of reminiscences of him by biographers, critics and friends, in German, English and even in French. It might have been thought that all the facts of his life, all the information about his works and certainly criticism from most points of view had been made public.

One of the three large transcontinental airplane lines has announced drastic reductions in Winter rates, effective Nov. 1, which will bring the cost of travel on the airline about to the level of ordinary railroad fares.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 3. -- Led by Whitey Jaeger, sensational running back, Colgate's Red Raiders rolled up a 54-0 score against Ursinus today. A crowd of 4,000 fans saw the home team score in every quarter and completely dominate the contest.
MADRID, Oct. 3. -- Fascist attacks broke on the government's defenses north of Madrid tonight.

GIRDLING the world in twenty-one days, sleeping sometimes on airships, sometimes on airplanes, occasionally in hotels during brief stops, would have been impossible only a few years ago. But now it can be done without difficulty, entirely by air, with the exception of a two-day journey by ship.

ROSE lovers of the metropolitan area are enjoying the magnificent show of late blooms at the New York Botanical Garden, where scores of the finest varieties of hybrid teas, supplemented by other types, are responding to recent cool and moist weather.

BELMONT PARK, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Although members of society interested in horses had a full program today, they found time to attend the last day's race program at Belmont Park, many of them arriving from the Piping Rock Club for late luncheon or in time for the running of the Futurity.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Senator Vandenberg said tonight that unless the "extravaganza" of the Roosevelt administration "speedily ends, the youth of today must resign itself to perpetual perspiration."

A large committee of women prominent in society has been formed to assist in plans for the luncheon and fashion show to be held on Oct. 13 at the Versailles Restaurant for the benefit of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry. The entertainment is under the co- chairmanship of Mrs. Herbert Lee Pratt Jr. and Mrs. William R. K. Taylor Jr. Debutantes of the season will act as manikins in the fashion pageant.

In the heaviest Saturday trading since Feb. 1, the stock market yesterday continued the strong advance begun on Friday. Nearly 100 Individual issues were lifted to new high marks for the year. The closing levels approximated the best prices of the day, with leading issues up from fractions to 3 points.

WOODBURY, L.I., Oct. 3. -- Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. Robbins have offered their home. Ben Robyn Farm, in the West Hills section, again this year for the race ball next Saturday which will precede the Autumn meeting of the West Hills Racing Association on Monday on the estates of Colonel Henry L. Stimson and Thomas F. White.

COVINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Police today sought two missing keys with which they hope to trace the slayer of Miss Frances Brady, 30, shot and killed early yesterday in the doorway of her home a few feet from a table filled with gifts for her wedding, which had been set for Wednesday.

THE producers of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" are awakening to the morning after. With Max Reinhardt, the noted impresario, arriving back in the United States last week to direct "Danton, the Terror of France," and "Everyman," the bank accounts of the brothers Warner will probably again face heavy assaults from the prodigal Reinhardt hand, which last year tossed $1,350,000 into the first whole-hearted attempt to make Shakespeare pay on the screen.

Keenly responsive to the daily climaxes reflected in headlines on international affairs, members of many clubs have disrupted this week's schedule to assure attendance at the trio of "Review of the News" conferences arranged under the auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Six presidents of American colleges and universities are among the throng of scholars, alumni and guests who will come to the Williams campus in this Berkshire valley to celebrate the one hundredth anniversary of the induction into office of Mark Hopkins, the institute's most famous head.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 3. -- Five organizations of the New York State Convention of Universalists will hold their annual conventions, from Monday to Thursday, in the Betts Memorial Universalist Church of Syracuse.

Seventy-seven field trial meetings for pointers and setters have been scheduled for the current month to be contested in fields and covers all the way from Maine to the Pacific Coast and from the Canadian border down into the Southern States.

NO COMMENT: There is one New Deal worker who is keeping a political silence these days, but whose name, Rexford Guy Tugwell, is anathema to the opposition. Thus last week the Republican National Committee spoke of "men like Tugwell" who attempt "to regiment all walks of American life and remain communistic."

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 3. -- The Roosevelt Raceway, over which the 400-mile Vanderbilt Cup race, with forty-six automobiles starting, will be run on Columbus Day, Oct. 12, had its first test under competition today with a forty-mile motor-cycle race.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Howard, 5-year-old gelding which Stephen Panarella claimed for $3,200 two months ago, staged another of his blazing stretch rushes today to capture the mile-and-a-sixteenth Mount Washington Handicap by a nose from Gallant Gay before 15,000 at Rockingham Park.

VALLADOLID, Spain, Oct. 3. -- General Owen O'Duffy, leader of the outlawed Blue Shirts in the Irish Free State, today informed General Emilio Mola, Rebel commander in Northern Spain, that 9,000 Irish volunteers were ready to fight in the insurgent ranks.
The pigmy outslugged the big fellow yesterday but baseball being a most peculiar game, the result is not always what you would expect it to be.

From now on to election day the American people will have more than their fill of political speeches. Swarms of orators from both parties will be sent out to cover the land. It is to be feared that many of them will justify age-old criticisms and condemnations of political addresses.

PARIS, Oct. 2. -- Out of the political battle which had raged in Paris all week in consequence of the government's proposal to devaluate the franc, Premier Leon Blum's Popular Front government has emerged devaluated by more than the 30 per cent which it has deducted from the gold content of the national currency.

Columbia University has just acquired the extensive library on printing and the graphic arts which has been brought together in the last thirty years and maintained by the American Type Founders Company, it was announced yesterday by Dr. C.C. Williamson, director of the university libraries.

AMONG the hundreds of self-appointed guides to filmic morals, perhaps the most intelligent and realistic is the Schools Motion Picture Committee, which began its second season last week. The committee, as you may or may not be aware, was organized in New York last Fall by a group of faculty members and parents of pupils in the city's private -- and a few public -- high schools.

School officials were confronted yesterday with the necessity of chopping 5,000 or more names from a list of 15,000 high school and parochial school students applying for National Youth Administration aid here.

THE engagement of Stella Andreva for the coming season of the Metropolitan Opera Association adds another colorature soprano to its list. Miss Andreva, who was born in London of Scotch-German parentage, is the third specialist in the light florid roles that the Metropolitan has added to the company since the end of last season.

The ironic process by which a football hero rapidly slips from front-page fame to inglorious oblivion is the theme of "To the Victor.'' The author evidently feels bitter about it. Jerry Fleet was an average American lad, working his way through Cranston University to become an engineer.

HERE is an adventure picture book and a sea story that is on exactly the right level for the 5, 6 and 7 year olds. The liking for tales of the sea develops early, but up to the present time there has been no book for little children genuine enough to gratify their first longing for nautical adventure.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- In the two weeks' period ending Sept. 19, 733 certificates of registration and licenses to drive were either revoked or suspended, according to Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. Of the total number of cases 220 will require proof of financial responsibility before applications for new licenses will be considered.
