INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 2. -- Observers in Indiana believe that the arrest in Terre Haute of Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President, was the result of an effort on the part of local city officials to make political capital.

ABOUT the best activity since right before Labor Day was the report made by most centers last week on retail trade. Favorable weather led to a sharp upturn in volume, with the gains running from 7 to 25 per cent through the country. The best increases were noted in the Southwest, South and Midwest.
TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Late reports coming over Japan's crippled telegraph lines indicated today that a strong typhoon that missed Tokyo wreaked great havoc on much of the country.

AUTUMN brings an end to the regular travel season -- but not to the season of travel books. Already, tempting visions of future pleasure journeys glow before our eyes in an alluring uncertainty; and the Autumn is a good time to read books about travel.
SEATTLE, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr. listed tonight "thirteen reasons why Franklin D. Roosevelt should be ousted from the Presidency."

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 3. -- Repeating his victory of last year, the chestnut gelding Chatter Chat, owned by Mrs. Ellsworth H. Augustus of Willoughby, Ohio, and ridden in most of his flights over the outside course by Mrs. Cary Jackson of Orange, Va., today captured the grand hunter championship of the thirty-fourth annual Piping Rock Horse Show.

WHEN I agreed to discuss Mr. Dillaway's book on Emerson I looked forward to reading it with genuine pleasure. I was not disappointed. There are few American authors who have interested me more consistently than Emerson and almost none for whom I have a greater admiration.
DETROIT, Oct. 3. -- Henry Ford foresees a better day for the American farmer, through public realization that "the farm and the shop each needs what the other produces."
BURGOS, Spain, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Fascist Northern Army pressed its advance on Madrid tonight, capturing villages in the Gredos Mountains, west of the capital.

THERE is a premium on curves -- not bulges. Waistlines (the correct ones) are concave, hips and bosoms convex. Avoirdupois is on the short side of the market. Result, a silhouette that really has a contour, lines that have rhythm.

The colors of the 165th Infantry, formerly "New York's fighting Sixty-ninth," were trooped yesterday afternoon when the regiment passed in review before Major General Frank R. McCoy, its wartime commander, on the parade grounds at Governors Island.

Commodity futures were generally mixed last week in fairly active trading. Sugar and coffee futures fell sharply, while cocoa was slightly higher than the preceding week. In the cash markets, cotton, print cloths, silk and wool tops were stronger, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, coffee, butter, lard, antimony, tin and rubber were weaker.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- Resorting to almost every trick in its full-stocked armory of weapons, Yale opened its season with a 23-to-0 victory over a green but potentially strong team of Cornell sophomores today before a crowd of 20,000 in the Bowl.

ROBERT E. SHERWOOD came in from foreign parts one day last week and, of course, took whatever is the shortest route to the Shubert Theatre and his "Idiot's Delight." Being a sort of psychologist, Tecumseh had guessed that he would do exactly that.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- A warning to private citizens not to buy bonded whisky warehouse receipts for speculation was issued today by W.S. Alexander, head of the Federal Alcohol Administration.
The toil of the Giants' pennant drive, the strain of the world series and the years are catching up with one William Harold Terry, who nevertheless still remains the best first baseman in his league.

INTEREST in Oriental art, particularly Japanese is certain to be stimulated by the large loan exhibition now being held at the Boston Museum. This is composed of art treasures from Japan. selected there and sent to America.

BURGOS, Spain, Oct. 3. -- The Carlist national junta, comprising leaders of a group separate from but collaborating with the insurgent junta, recognized Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma as its leader tonight.

AUDIENCES have been known -- all too well so far as some actors are concerned -- to toss vegetables at the stage, and not in any spirit of barter, either. In such cases the producer was usually philosophic about it; he gathered up the vegetables and fired the actor.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3. -- A well-planned and highly cultivated marihuana farm, disguised to look like a cornfield, was discovered today at the eastern edge of the city by police and Federal agents, who said the leaves on plants would be worth $1,000,000 on the retail market.
The first auction sales of this season at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., will take place next Friday and Saturday afternoons.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- The Philadelphia Record prints a dispatch from a staff correspondent at Boise saying that Senator Borah "is not supporting the candidacy of Governor Landon." The dispatch states:

Labor unions affiliated with the New York State Federation of Labor are "unanimous in the opinion that there is a better attitude toward law enforcement since repeal," according to their replies to a questionnaire sent out by the New York State Liquor Authority.

DANBURY'S sixty-seventh annual fair, one of the oldest and perhaps the most widely known of American agricultural festivals, opens tomorrow with the brightest prospects this traditional celebration has enjoyed in recent years.

Devaluation of the currencies of France, Holland and Switzerland was described uniformly last week by bankers and economists here as an important step toward monetary stability. This opinion, somewhat contradictory on its face because those three currencies bad been the last ones definitely attached to gold, was based chiefly upon two considerations.

THE photograph above shows an Autostop, automatic protective device for railroad-highway grade crossings, installed last Wednesday on the Boston Post Road in Wayland, near Boston. Its main feature is a steel barrier, which rises up to nine inches from the road surface to stop a car that has failed to halt when a train approaches the crossing.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Rutgers opened its football season with a 13-to-0 victory over Marietta before 5,000 persons today. The Scarlet consistently outplayed the visitors throughout and its goal line was at no time in danger. The play of Perry and Stanowicz was outstanding.

THIS is a companion volume to Mr. Dobie's earlier book on San Francisco, and, like it, is accompanied by Mr. Suydam's drawings, which convey with great charm and authority the atmosphere of the places described. It tells the story of San Francisco's Chinatown, the first and still the foremost of Chinese communities in America.
BETHLEHEM Pa., Oct. 3. -- For the first time in years, a president of Lehigh University entered the classroom as a teacher with the opening of the college term.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Great Britain is keeping the United States informed of her views regarding the increased tension between Japan and China, and of the observations she has made to Japan in behalf of peace in the Far East, but it was said today that Washington had made no diplomatic representations.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Hotel Baker Stable's Cardinal Prince accounted for the Free for All Pace, feature of the last day of the Grand Circuit meeting today, despite the fact that the veteran J. E. Vonian was first home in the opening heat.

MANILA, P.I., Sunday, Oct. 4. -- The explosion of fifteen crudely made bombs in various parts of this city last night caused the police to believe terrorists had plotted to start a wide conflagration.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 3. -- Once the train was out of Atlanta and well on the way to the Coast, he had the porter bring his new suitcase to him.

THERE is a new best seller among oceanic post cards. The favorite mailed-upon-landing hail or farewell has a fresh pattern because a new edition of the Nantucket Lightship has taken up the dual role of greeter and God-speeder at the figurative jumping-off place of aerial and maritime travel between America and Europe.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Oct. 3. -- Presenting an array of the top flight players of the district, the Metropolitan Golf Association team took a commanding lead today as the thirtieth series of matches for the Lesley Cup began over the course of the Rockaway Hunting Club.

UPTON SINCLAIR'S Epic plans is still very much with us. Although after winning the Democratic nomination for Governor on his plan to "End Poverty in California" he failed to carry the State at the general election, he has not failed to exert his tireless spirit as a reformer to keep alive the social ideal for which he pleaded at the polls in 1934: the establishment of cooperative, self-help economies for the unemployed.

Fear that heavy repatriation of foreign funds lodged in this country would immediately follow devaluation of the erstwhile gold-bloc currencies was dispelled last week, and the stock market closed the week with a vigorous advance. Based on estimates, the last few days have witnessed greater foreign buying than selling of our securities.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 3. -- Thirty camps of the Civilian Conservation Corps will carry forward development programs in national and State parks and recreational areas of New England during the new six-month enrollment period for which recruiting is now under way, according to an announcement here at the Eastern headquarters of the National Park Service.

CURIOUSLY enough, the title story in this collection is the only one that has what might be called a natural explanation, and even that explanation is not precisely rational, since it is conditioned upon the impact of a disordered mind upon a normal one.

THE largest attendances at New York's semi-public or "proprietary" bridge clubs have always gone to those clustered around Seventy-second Street and Broadway. At times there have been as many as ten bridge clubs within a few blocks of that corner, all of them popular and the two or three leaders drawing 100 bridge players a day or more.

Scoring twice in quick succession after their Manhattan rivals had taken a 7-0 lead in the last period, the Erasmus Hall High School gridmen downed Seward Park High School, 13 -- 7, at Erasmus Field in Brooklyn yesterday.
PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- All the Berkshire resort towns are preparing for a heavy rush of visitors over the Columbus Day week-end, when the Autumn foliage should he at its peak of color.

Curtis, Manual Training and Stuyvesant gained team honors as the P.S.A.L. cross-country season got under way with the running of three group races over a new Van Cortlandt Park course yesterday. The distance was about two and four-tenths miles.

FROM what Mr. Darrah has to say, it would seem that Benito Mussolini is the ignoblest Roman of them all. It is a fair deduction from the evidence in this book. Some day, however, I hope to read an intensely prejudiced or partisan volume whose author will be sporting enough to include in an appendix a list of ably written books in which are presented viewpoints opposed to his own.

ROME, Oct. 2. -- The most disturbing point, from the Italian point of view, of the Anglo-Franco-American declaration that accompanied the devaluation of the French franc is the passage in which the three countries affirm their common purpose of working for a regime of greater liberality in the international exchange of goods and the mitigation of monetary restrictions that hamper trade.

THIS is one of the seasons when the 2,000 or more persons who pursue the hobby of bird banding in the United States are most busy. A large number of the 768 varieties of North American birds have started their annual migrations to sunny Winter quarters, and their hosts and hostesses en route, the bird banders, are entertaining them and recording their visits in reports to Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Debutantes who will assist in receiving at the tea which Mrs. William M. Benerman, with Dr. and Mrs. James H. Mendel, will give on Oct. 13 at the Philadelphia Cricket Club to introduce Miss Dorothy Hunter Mendel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mendel and granddaughter of Mrs. Benerman, will include the Misses Phyllis Huhn of New York, Julia Allen, Janet Bromley, Elizabeth Leeds Brown, Joan Bary, Leila Canby and Jessie Disston.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Delegates of the National Council of Federated Garden Clubs and of the Central Atlantic and South Atlantic Regional Garden Clubs will meet in joint convention this week at the Green Brier with the West Virginia Garden Club, representing fifty-three member associations.

In cathedral-crowned Burgos, Northern Spain, the Rebel generals last Thursday designated their commander-in-chief, Francisco Franco, as dictator of Spain. Short, dark, round-faced and back-mustached, dressed in tan army uniform with a scarlet sash, the latest of the supreme Fascist leaders said to his fellow-officers:

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- With the help of the biggest expeditionary force that hast left these shores since the World War, Great Britain set to work in earnest this week on the grim task of pacifying Palestine.
HERBERT GORMAN has informed his publishers, Farrar Rinehart, that they were mistaken in their statement that his latest novel, "The Mountain and the Plain," is the completion of a trilogy on France.

THE Mississippi Valley is still farmers' country. Even the traveler who breaks his journey by stops in cities whose hotel lobbies, shopping and financial districts grow year by year less distinguishable from New York's "Fifties" can hardly miss the point. Talk of grain and livestock prices and of how the effects of drought vary from county to county flows across university club luncheon tables in Kansas City.

Girls with broken hearts make glamorous heroines for light fiction. With a heart badly damaged in the crash of an engagement, pretty Becky Latimer starts out on a Summer of adventure in the Virginia mountains warranted to keep any lorn lady from brooding over a lost lover.

Half a million consumer tags have been issued to blouse manufacturers by the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers since the opening of the current season, in its campaign to reduce unjustified returns. According to B.H. Lerner, executive director of the association, consumer response to the tags has been excellent, and more than 750 retail stores are now displaying special counter cards referring to the tags.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3. -- The Marine Department of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce, casting up the September shipping figures, found them down in some respects, as compared to the figures of September, 1935, but up in others.

In your issue of Sept. 29 is a letter from the Rev. Joseph McSorley in which he attempts to clear away part of the confusion regarding Spain by citing figures on churches closed or destroyed, newspapers attacked and persons killed during the five months preceding the current struggle.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Strong student support of Harvard's new, drastic reorganization of graduate training in education to assure better preparation of school teachers and higher standards in educational administration was indicated tonight in registrations at the Graduate School of Education.

The members of the congregation of the People's Tabernacle, 102d Street and Madison Avenue, will celebrate today the church's forty-fourth anniversary, it was announced yesterday. At the same time the Rev. Henry M. Tyndall, who founded the tabernacle and has been its pastor ever since, will mark his own forty-fourth anniversary in service.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 3. -- Halting two thrusts deep in their territory, Tulane's Greenies battled the highly favored Auburn Tigers to a scoreless tie today before 20,000 thrilled spectators.
ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Two forward passes and a recovered fumble gave Andover Academy a 20-0 victory over the New Hampshire freshman eleven in the season's opener today.

Resorting to deftness and trickery when sheer power seemed inadequate to beat down the grim defense of the Bronxville High School eleven, a rugged Fordham Prep aggregation scored in the third period to win by 7 -- 0 yesterday at Fordham Field in the opening game of the season for both teams.

New York State is about to witness what promises to be the liveliest political campaign in many years. The State conventions of the two major parties have met and adjourned. The platforms have been adopted and the candidates named. From now until the polls open on Nov. 3 the political scene will be held by a host of campaign orators and the party standard bearers.

THE educational fever took possession of the Massachusetts Bay Colony early in its history. Scarcely a half dozen years after it was established, and two years before the arrival of a printing press, the enterprising colonists had created an institution of learning.

ANOTHER great tube is soon to be added to the many things that lie at the bottom of New York Harbor. While work is beginning on the new East River vehicular tunnel, connecting midtown Manhattan with Queens, the tube that will carry vehicles from West Thirty-eighth Street to New Jersey is fast approaching completion.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Taking full advantage of two breaks, the University of North Carolina's Southern Conference footballers turned back Tennessee's fighting Volunteers of the Southeastern Conference here today, 14 to 6.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP). -- A Black and Gold wave from the South rolled over the University of Chicago at Stagg Field today as the powerful Vanderbilt University Commodores overwhelmed the Maroons, 37 to 0, before 15,000 spectators.

JUST why the English starling, is an imported member of the bird family, should feed in our fields and gardens by day, and then return to congregate at night in great flocks to become a pest on certain estates, parks, trees and buildings, is an unsolved problem.
DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Robbing a bank in Texas today is more dangerous than drawing to a three-card flush.
A PANORAMA of German art commencing with the fifteenth century and continuing through the last quarter of the nineteenth century opens at the Pennsylvania Museum of Art, Philadelphia, tomorrow.

With enough orders on hand to keep shops running at their present rate for at least two months, the structural steel industry today is in the best position it has enjoyed since the depression started, V.G. Iden, secretary of the American Institute of Steel Construction, said here yesterday.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 3. -- Three sophomores, Bill Hendrickson, Bill Reese and Sammy Padden, sent Lehigh tumbling to defeat in its first home game and gave Dickinson a 20-to-6 triumph over the Engineers before 5,000 fans today.

The contention that both distribution and industry need to do a "better job of selling themselves to the public" received marked emphasis at the Boston Conference on Distribution last week, with ensuing comment indicating that efforts toward a more scientific and coordinated public relations policy in both the retailing and production fields will be an outstanding feature of business developments in the near future.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Recollections dating back half a century made the opening of Colgate University classes more interesting than usual this year, for it was in 1886 that the first courses in psychology were taught in the Chenango Valley institution.

What is considered by lawyers an important legal decision regarding the rights of a landlord to enter the premises of a tenant was recently handed down by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department, upholding the tenant.

A RICH jacket of brocade shot with gold or silver, or one of sparkling sequins, is considered a useful item in a wardrobe when the Fall formal season opens. It can be used to transform a simple evening gown into the proper costume for afternoon dancing or for dinner when one is told to "wear something long."

Mrs. Frank Knox, wife of the Republican Vice Presidential nominee, will be the guest of honor on Friday at an invitation tea at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. It will be one of the main events of the campaign activities of the club, and will be under the direction of Miss Alice Hill Chittenden, chairman of the campaign committee.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Nine-teen-year-old Miss Pamela Barton, chubby little London girl, made golf history today when she captured the women's American championship and started the Robert Cox Trophy on the first trip it has made to England since 1913.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The first county campaign for the control of cancer of the breast to be undertaken in the United States by the American Society for the Control of Cancer is being conducted in Westchester County by the society's local committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 3. -- Prospective voters crowded the polling places in such numbers today, the last of the Fall registration days, that it was predicted, in the absence of definite figures, that more than 900,000 Philadelphians would be qualified to vote in November.

Yet Mr. Minamoto, who is editor of Bukkyo Bijutsu and lecturer on the history of Japanese art at the Kyoto Imperial University, packs a great deal of well systematized information into this series of thumbnail notes.

An amateur night picture hunt, embracing features of the treasure hunt, will be held on the night of Oct. 20 to aid the Girls' Vacation Fund, which was organized last Spring to provide country vacations in the Summer for underprivileged girls of the lower West Side.

THERE are few finer mansions in Great Britain, few richer in works of art, and few with more fascinating history than Blickling Hall, in Norfolk, where Prime Minister Baldwin recently took a rest-cure holiday. Blickling is the ancestral home of the Marquis of Lothian, a Scot who is a Norfolk squire because an ancestress of his had the acumen to marry into the Hobart family.

This is a thoroughly satisfactory story of real life and everyday happenings for 6 to 10 year olds. The Smiths move from the city to a new home in the country, where for the first time in their lives Greg and Susan can have the pets they so much want and where there is not only a garden but a shallow pond, with an island just big enough for a tent.

VIENNA. A FEW months ago the Vienna Radio -- "Ravag" for short -- put music-lovers in its debt by discovering for them Schumann's traditionally maligned though almost 100 per cent unknown opera, "Genoveva"; and a few days past it gave them an opportunity to judge for themselves why Verdi's eighth stage work, "Alzira," has never in the ninety-one years of its existence made a noise in the world.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Many observers have learned in the last few days that they made a serious error in assuming that the line between President Roosevelt's many "non-political" tours and speeches of the last few months and his actual "political" campaign would be invisible.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Rural youth of New Jersey staged a show all of their own in competing for more than $2,000 in prize money at the State Fair here this week, and their production, in the opinion of one State farm official, "convincingly demonstrated that the future of agriculture in the Garden State is bright."
GENEVA, Oct. 2. -- The results of the League of Nations Assembly meeting to date may be divided under the heads of concrete and diplomatic peace policy and League reform.

THE first Terry in the theatre was Benjamin, born in 1818. He lived to the age of 76, was married to Sarah Ballard, an actress, and begat fourteen children, seven of whom entered the theatre, George and Charles as business men and Fred, Kate, Ellen, Marion and Florence as players.

Scoring on a 40-yard advance in the third period, the City College football team defeated Brooklyn College, 6 to 0, in the fifth game of their series yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium before a crowd of 3,000.

Increased Southern hedge-selling and week-end liquidation were absorbed at slowly declining prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. All positions except the spot October eased below the 12-cent-a-pound mark, with final prices barely steady at net losses of 6 to 8 points.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- The inauguration yesterday of William A. Eddy as president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges brings the total number of Princeton University graduates now heading American colleges to eleven, a survey made here today revealed.

President Roosevelt's recent speeches in Syracuse and Pittsburgh were not in accord with his administration's actual record in office, Colonel Henry Breckinridge, "Jeffersonian Democrat," declared last night in a radio speech assailing President Roosevelt's candidacy for re-election.

GENEVA, Oct. 3. -- Eight countries now have more persons employed in industry than in 1929, according to the International Labor Office's quarterly report, issued today. They are Britain, 107 per cent; Bulgaria, 124; Estonia, 135; Japan, 117; Latvia, 118; Sweden, 109; South Africa, 125, and Yugoslavia, 103.

The North German Lloyd Line announced yesterday that it had purchased the three-masted bark Magdalene Vinnen, which it will convert into a training school for officers and rename the Kommodore Johnson in memory of the late master of the liner Europa.
MR. NASH -- now bard of bibland -- mellows like a Milne. Time was when he could say:

The annual report on the condition of Barnard College, submitted to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University, was released yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve who pointed to the improved financial status of the students, the growing needs of Barnard, new appointments to the college faculty and the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Barnard College which will occur in 1939.

THE sport of rock climbing is not confined to any one season, although there are times when it is too hot or too cold to engage in this form of diversion with comfort. Right now the brisk days of October provide the best of weather conditions for those New Yorkers, still few and far between, who devote their week-ends to this pastime, hobby, task -- or, as some people would have it, this madness.

The record world series crowd at the Yankee Stadium yesterday was not confined to the ball park by any manner of means. It spread to the outlying districts and included in its scope thousands more who witnessed the best game of the series without benefit of ticket.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3. -- Thinking that her son had been hurt on the second play of a high school football game, Mrs. Frances Dalcherone, 47, mother of eleven children, died today a few hours after she had collapsed at sight of a player writhing in pain.

Reporting on home construction activity in New Jersey for the first eight months of the present year, George B. Underwood, associate State FHA director, states that statistics show that Bergen County leads all other counties in the State, with building and prospective building operations representing in cost between $13,000,000 and $14,000,000 for that period.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Kansans still rule trackdom's mile domain, for Jack Lovelock's attempted assault on the world's record, held by Glenn Cunningham, failed in Palmer Stadium this afternoon as the latter's Olympic teammate from the "typical prairie State," Archie San Romani, flashed across the finish line in first place.

In an atmosphere of flags, flowers and traditional formality, the New York and New Jersey State Societies of the Daughters of the American Revolution will convene their Autumn conferences this week. The New York organization returns for the occasion to Rochester, where forty-one years ago the chapters were first called together and the State association formed.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Companion event to the Fall tennis tournament, the annual Fall golf championship celebrates its twenty-fourth birthday this year. This event is probably the most "returned for" on the golf calendar.

RETURNS on the Summer status of the theatre would be incomplete without a report of what went on in the Broadway sector in the way of a new activity designed to further the drama on many stages. This was the first Summer session of the New Theatre School, and its sixth term of work.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 3. -- Paced by Rabbit Wear and Tommy Silvano, Penn State crushed a highly regarded Muhlenberg team, 45 -- 0, before a record opening-game crowd of 10,000 today.

IT is not often one finds such unanimity of opinion among critics as has prevailed among the Viennese reviewers over Flagstad. Without exception, practically, they have signalized the beauty and clarity of her tones, the effortless flow and untiring endurance of her voice, its ease in hurdling the heaviest orchestral barriers, the equalization of its scale, the chiseled perfection of the singer's diction.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- Once again today the hotels, cafes and restaurants of Paris were paralyzed by a strike, as they were in July, but this time it will all be over by tomorrow morning, when the employes will return to their jobs.

Clouds heavy with tragedy hang over Spain. For centuries they have been gathering and now they pour upon the dazed nation a rain of blood. Civil war-rages: no quarter is asked and none is given: modern weapons batter at ancient citadels.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The Poconos are now entering one of the most beautiful seasons of the year and resorts throughout the area have made special plans for observing the "Flaming Foliage Festival," which opened today and will continue until after the Columbus Day week-end.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The White Sox today made it three straight victories over their city series rivals, the Cubs, winning 4 to 2 with their veteran hurling star, Ted Lyons.
A tea and fashion revue, entitled "Fashion's Big Moments," for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop, will be held on Oct. 29 in the Corinthian Room and the main ballroom of the Pierre.

OMAHA, Oct. 2. -- The hot winds which seared the Corn Belt last Summer may have blown some permanent good that is not now readily recognized. They have put many farmers in a mood to listen to agents of the Soil Conservation Service explain alterations in tillage methods which represent the difference between conserving and wasting an insufficient moisture supply.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Voice culture fitted to the requirements of modern modes of communication is the aim of a course in "Spoken English" introduced as part of an extensively, changed program of studies this year at Simmons College.

IN the Oxford police court recently a man was charged with leaving his car unattended in the street for forty-five minutes. He admitted the offense, but explained that he was spending the time in a bookstore looking for a book for his 3-year-old daughter.

The Women's Traffic Club of Greater New York will give a dinner in the grill of the Commodore Hotel on Friday evening in honor of C.E.R. Sherrington, secretary of the Research Service in the London School of Economics, London University.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- Once again selected representatives of Germany's Agrarian Estate will assemble on the Bueckeberg, near Hamelin, town of Pied Piper fame, tomorrow to celebrate the harvest thanksgiving of the Third Reich. It will be celebrated in the now traditional style, with a huge mass meeting on the hill, with bands, a parade, folk dances and sham battles by the new army, and with speeches by Chancellor Adolf Hitler and others.

GRAND FORKS, N.D., Oct. 2 (AP). -- Representative William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, said tonight that the "present insane policies of the Department of Agriculture" had so restricted production that the country was today in the midst of a great shortage.

The average freshman of 1936 is not the wide-eyed ingenuous student with little knowledge of the ways of the world. Instead, it is revealed by a recent Hunter College questionnaire, answered by 929 of the 1,200 incoming freshmen, the modern college entrant is a versatile, vocationally minded 17-year-old with many club affiliations, a social point of view and a practical attitude toward college.
COLLEGE STATION, Texas, Oct. 3 (AP). -- A farmer's interest in odd stones has given Texas scientists what they say are the oldest known specimens of flowering plants in America.

The New York State Regents' literacy test for new voters will be held in all public school buildings designated as polling places this week. The hours are from 5 to 10:30 P.M., every day except Saturday, when tests will be given from 3:30 to 11:30 P.M. The school buildings also will be used this week for registration of voters.

MILFORD, Conn., Oct. 3. -- Pete J. Kaminski Jr., 33 years old, o Beacon Falls. a New Haven County Deputy Sheriff, was shot and killed at 1:30 A.M. today as he sat in an automobile with a woman companion and another couple, in a secluded section of Gulf Beach.

The Soviet Government has extended an official invitation to the members of the Manhattan Quartet for four concerts to be given in Leningrad and Moscow during the month of December. Following the Russian engagements, the quartet will be heard in Brussels, Holland, England, France and Italy.

THIRTY-SEVEN organizations, some of them representing a score or more stations and individuals, have filed notice with the Federal Communications Commission that they wish to testify at the informal engineering hearing on the broadcast wave band beginning tomorrow, in Washington, D.C.

THE holiday-maker who likes to bring home a few shaggy heads to add to the collection of trophies on his ancestral walls may now begin to think about adding a few royal trophies. They can be had only in Europe -- and by no means everywhere there.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- An increase in Franco-American trade was forecast by State Department officials today as a result of the French Government's reduction of customs duties on imports.

IN the course of her theatrical tours through the United States, Cornelia Otis Skinner has evidently bumped up against some very boresome people, parties and situations. In this collection of humorous sketches, she lampoons and lambastes them.

HERE is a masculine romance of love and adventure, a husky-throated narrative of understatement rendered in the first person singular, a British adaptation of the Hemingway rhythms. As a story it is for relaxation and escape only and not to be compared, except in technique and superficially, with "A Farewell to Arms."

Mark Hopkins made his contributions to the philosophy of education as a teacher rather than as a writer. To those of us who sat under him his two books, "The Outline Study of Man" and "The Law of Love and Love as a Law," are eloquent reminders of his extraordinary ability as a teacher.

HARRISBURG, Oct. 2. -- The Pennsylvania liquor monopoly is paying much bigger dividends than expected. During the fiscal year, ended May 31, according to a statement of the State Liquor Control Board made public this week, the profits were $10,577,737, or more than twice the annual profits estimated by the State budget makers only a year ago.
For the second time since it was promulgated in 1582, the Douai-Rheims edition of the New Testament, the official Catholic New Testament in English, is to be revised.

DETROIT, Oct. 2. -- Conviction of all except one of the twelve Black Legion defendants in a Wayne County court in connection with the murder of Charles A. Poole, WPA worker, is viewed quite generally as the death knell of the vigilante organization, which caused much alarm in Michigan and the rest of the country after the expose of its terrorist activities.

IN this lengthy poem, not only remarkably sustained throughout, but also at times rising to heights of poetic fervor and poetic strength, Stanton A. Coblentz scans the past and dares the future. "The Pageant of Man" is an ambitious work such as few would have the temerity to undertake.

THE turn of the century and shock of the World War produced a number of great writers in Germany and Austria. If they may be grouped together any other way the chronologically, it is through their sharp break with the German romantic tradition of the nineteenth century, through their new concern with social and psychological problems, and through their generally realistic technique.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 3. -- President Roosevelt today ran his vote in The Sun papers' Presidential poll of Maryland up to 145,535, with a lead of 64,423 over his Republican opponent, Governor Landon.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin asserted tonight that both Governor Landon and President Roosevelt were "sham-battling their way through this political campaign with sophistries and misstatements, confident that an unanalytical public will applaud their golden words and keep the American people in financial bondage."

Ulysses sailed beyond the sunset and the baths of all the western stars, wondering whether the gulfs "would wash us down" or whether "we shall touch the happy isles." Not in this spirit have three newspaper writers sallied forth to circumnavigate the globe, relying only on means of transportation available to any one who is able to pay his passage and willing to miss or catch trains, planes and steamers by margins of seconds.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Marquette University's golden avalanche relied on a brilliant passing attack today to defeat the University of Wisconsin, 12 to 6, before 32,000 fans.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Whatever Wall Street may think of him President Roosevelt deserves to be re-elected, in the opinion of Sir Walter Layton's weekly, The Economist, the most important organ of financial opinion in Britain.

LAST June The British Medical Journal commented on some measurements of the rate of growth of children in German cities, only to wonder whether we are not all getting bigger and better physically. Before that G.T. Bowles of Harvard had published a monograph -- "New Types of Old Americans at Harvard" -- which showed that Harvard's students were taller and heavier than their fathers.

IT was one and one as the Yankees and Giants went to work at the Stadium yesterday. A couple of odd fellows were nominated to pitch the odd game. Irving (Bump) Hadley, the celebrated hypnotist who won eleven straight during the season, served them up in a Yankee uniform. Fighting Fred Fitzsimmons, the Mishawaka knuckleballer, appeared on the mound for the Giants.

Why all the fuss and lack of criticism for the very mediocre Gilbert and Sullivan being presented at the Martin Beck Theatre? Two years back, when Mr. Martin Beck brought this company to New York, a very acceptable season was offered the hosts of Gilbert and Sullivan followers.
Will China now, at long last, go to war with Japan? Is she ready to stake what remains of her independence and her territory in a supreme effort at national salvation?

Alderman Joseph R. Kinsley, Bronx Democrat, renewed the Aldermanic quarrel with Mayor La Guardia yesterday over the purchase of $1,000,000 worth of snow removal machines, a proposal which the Aldermanic board rejected Friday in spite of a personal appeal by the Mayor.

Piece by piece the jigsaw of Manhattan's ultimate highway pattern emerges from the drafting board. Last week President Roosevelt officially started the East River Vehicular Tunnel and Borough President Samuel Levy revealed plans for a $28,000,000 crosstown tunnel under Thirty-seventh Street.

ARMONK, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- Dramatic incidents from Colonial and Revolutionary times will be re-enacted here next Saturday at the historical pageant which opens the bicentennial celebration of the Town of North Castle.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- The complete eradication of Jewish influence from the legal and economic sciences was held "essential to the German people's vital interests" by Dr. Hans Frank, Nazi Minister of Jurisprudence, in a declaration read at a gathering of university professors here today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 3. -- Seventy-five members of the Meadow Brook hunt met this morning at the stables of the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney for the official opening of the fox hunting season. The club has been hunting informally for about four weeks, but this morning the members were dressed in formal hunt livery, pink coats for the men and dark habits for the women.

Wholesale market conditions are expected to reflect favorably the sharp pick-up which occurred in many sections of the country last week and which retailers believe is the start of Fall period that will conclude with the best Christmas holiday season since 1929.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- While history displays in banner lines the life of a particular court favorite, history usually draws a veil of anonymity over the near relatives of the chosen friend. Rarely is this veil discreetly drawn aside, as history prefers its portrait clearly lined and without distracting background.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Oct. 3. -- More than 400 officials and representatives of four States, meeting here to outline the purpose and policy of the Delaware River Basin Commission, voted today that it should supervise the "apportionment and regulation of the flow of the river to protect communities and interests now sharing its use."

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3. -- Accident prevention experts from all parts of the United States and many Canadian Provinces are arriving here for the twenty-fifth national safety congress and exposition. About 10,000 delegates and visitors are expected to attend.

QUEBEC, Que., Oct. 3. -- The Donnacona Pulp and Paper Company has signed a contract with the Hearst newspaper syndicate by which the latter will take over Donnacona's entire output of newsprint for 1937, consisting of about 25,000 tons, and for several years thereafter.

TODAY Oriental poppies are enjoying a new popularity. Although they have always been considered ideal for certain bold effects, they were until recently little used except by gardeners who like a touch of flamboyance.

WHEN Mr. O'Donnell received a literary fellowship he did not hie off to the Riviera to get a so-called "perspective" on American life. He went, instead, to a small orange grove down Delta from New Orleans and sat down to finish this novel about the strange people who inhabit the strange country where the Mississippi meets the sea.

YOU can always depend on W.R. Burnett for a good story written in swift, clean strokes, with style, with class if you like, but without mannerism. "King Cole" is that. But most certainly it is not one of Burnett's best.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 3. -- The Nicaraguan Government, seeking to stimulate the gold mining industry, has granted a concession to Donald Neelans Spencer, an American, to explore and work mines in the regions of Agua Fria and Santa Rosa in the department of Leon.

NEWSPAPER men, Mr. Clarke suggests, acquire in the regular course of duty a great deal of confidential information which they are honor-bound to withhold in their printed stories. Barry Ross, the reporter-hero of "Confidential," seems to have a particular genius for amassing that kind of explosive information.

THE problem which shapes the course of this somber story is a case of unsubstantiated hereditary taint -- possible homicidal mania -- always a fertile subject for drama, but here worked to a conclusion with meager advantage taken of its latent capabilities.

While one Ethiopian group is maintaining a stiff front at Geneva, another contingent is sounding out persons close to the Italian Government with a view to obtaining concessions of some sort. Among the conditions suggested are: (1) giving Haile Selassie a foothold in Western or Southern Ethiopia under Italian protection, and (2) giving Haile Selassie, his family and his retainers substantial annual pensions in compensation for their losses owing to the change in sovereignty.

Former Mayor James J. Walker, in making what he termed his "first and last political appearance" since his return from Europe, announced yesterday that he would "always be a Democrat, and would rather turn my cheek than run out on the party as one man just did."

Registration at Manhattan College this Fall reached the highest peak in the seventy-three-year history of the institution, according to statistics announced yesterday by Alfred D. Donovan, registrar. The total enrollment, computed last week after the formal opening of classes, is 1,253 students.

LONDON. MOST persons probably are aware that Balmoral Castle, where Edward VIII recently took up his residence while his rooms at Buckingham Palace were being refurnished and redecorated under the direction of the one-time American actress, now Lady Mendl, was built by Queen Victoria and the Prince Consort.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Defending the New Deal's policy of "building spending power from the ground up instead of waiting for it to trickle down from the top," Secretary of Labor Perkins told a regional conference of State Democratic women here this afternoon "the result has been an improvement in every segment of the economic order under President Roosevelt."

NANKING, China (AP). -- Munitions manufacturers of Germany, Japan, Belguim and France who have been depending upon China for large supplies of cotton waste and other cotton by-products will have to turn elsewhere now that waste has been placed on the list of articles that cannot be exported except by special permission of Nanking's War Ministry.

WILHELM SPEYER, a German of Jewish extraction living in voluntary exfie in Austria, has with this story of a mid-German [ttlchy in 1805, when Napoleon was getting a stranglehold on Europe, begun what he hopes will turn out to be a series of novels depicting Germany before and after unification a n d extending to the present rdgime.

In a recent issue Arthur Krock devoted space to a personal interpretation and drastic condemnation of Colonel Frank Knox's statement as to the unsoundness of our savings banks and insurance institutions.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 3 (AP). -- One hundred and eighteen years of life have left Mrs. Anastacia Camargo sharp-eyed, sharp-witted and erect -- but regretful that "young people nowadays die fast."

SCIENTISTS have a name for the scattering flight of wild birds. They call it "explosive migration." It began weeks ago, showing unusual guests all about New York. A host of hungry nestlings had swelled the bird population of the land to several times its normal size.

Proper table manners will be taught in the city's public schools as part of the program now under way to improve the operation of the school lunchrooms, it was disclosed yesterday at the second annual food conference of the New York City High School Dietitians Association and the Greater New York Dietetic Association in the Hotel Commodore.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 3. -- In the opening game of the season for both teams, Trinity this afternoon completely overwhelmed Hamilton College to win, 27 to 0.

Evidently supporters of the theory that first impressions mean everything, Fordham's football forces served adequate notice yesterday that again they will be one of the powers of the country's gridiron fraternity.

SINCE Irving Thalberg's death, the trend of events at Metro seems to confirm the rumors which have persisted for two years concerning the strained relationship existing between the Nicholas Schenck-Louis B. Mayer faction and the Thalberg unit.

ALTHOUGH details of most of the new cars to be displayed at the National Automobile Show, opening Nov. 11 in Grand Central Palace, have not been revealed to the public, the show management reported last week that, in general, safety and comfort would be emphasized in their construction.

Without doubt, that portion of the new revenue law which governs the taxation of business transactions in this country by nonresident aliens and foreign non- resident corporations is the most important forward movement in this particular field of taxation to which any Congress has given expression in the last decade.

THE stuff of this book is what George Meredith once called "bloodlife." For those pulses which Mr. Blaker set to racing in his "Here Lies a Most Beautiful Lady" have not been retarded in its sequel. "Gentleman John" Billiter, king of the Caucasian oilfields, is dead, but long live his progeny!
OCTOBER is here with a long list of special broadcasts. This is the outstanding month of the year for big radio hook-ups.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 3. -- Bounding to the front before the echo of the starting bell had died away, Howard Bruce's Jay Jay kept his stable's old rose and white colors flying in front throughout the running of the Capital Handicap, $5,000 added feature of the inaugural program of the Maryland Fair Racing Association's meeting at the Laurel track today.

There was no hilarity in the Giants' clubhouse at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, but there was a lot of pride, and with good reason. They were proud of Freddy Fitzsimmons, who had held the vaunted Yankee power to four hits while they had collected ten off Bump Hadley, including Jim Ripple's home run.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Shrewd shopping for the family's food supplies was advised by Federal experts today, with a warning that food costs will go higher.

IT would seem unlikely that these two names -- Giotto di Bondoni and Jean Baptiste Pater -- have ever before been linked in this close fashion. Giotto, born near Florence in the latter half of the thirteenth century, and the French artist, Pater, most of whose short life belonged to the opening decades of the eighteenth century, stand poles asunder.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Holy Cross defeated Providence College, 21 to 6, in a hard-played game before a crowd of 8,500 today. The victors capitalized on a fumble early in the opening periods to put over their first touchdown.

The formal opening for the season of the newly decorated Sert Room at the Waldorf-Astoria, set for the night of Oct. 27, will aid the New York Exchange for Woman's Work. Many women of prominence in society are members of a committee of patronesses sponsoring a gala dinner and supper entertainment arranged for the benefit.

BOULDER CITY, Nev., Oct. 3 (AP). -- Pay load of electric current starts moving Wednesday from the world's largest generator, at the world's largest power plant, over the world's longest power transmission line.

Not often do we have the experience of meeting again almost a generation later a cherished book character. For nearly thirty years "Little Black Sambo" has delighted countless boys and girls who have thrilled to his tactful manipulation of the tigers and chuckled over his appetite for pancakes.

MAINLAND" is the sort of book lots of Americans will wish they had written. It is a confession of faith, of faith in this country and its people and its way of life, and a bold assertion of confidence in the future. It is a declaration of cultural independence. At the same time "Mainland" is prejudiced, argumentative, disorganized and -- brilliant.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross quickly mobilized to meet extra demands produced by emergencies during the past year in addition to carrying on all of its regular activities. Emergency accomplishments are noted in the annual report just issued.

THE necessity for organization, not only on the part of labor unions at one pole and corporations and institutions of business at the other, but of the classes of citizens sandwiched between these sections of our society, is an obvious development of modern life.

A NUMBER of sober novels by Chris Massie have appeared during the past ten years in England, but "Falcon Road." published there as "Hallelujah Chorus," is the first of his work to appear in America. No exception to his rule, this is not only a sober but a grim affair, a tale at once merciless and merciful.

When Gabriel Wells returned from Europe last week on the Normandie, he brought back a collection of unpublished letters and manuscripts of Benjamin Franklin, acquired from a descendant of the French chemist Lavoisier and totaling some 120 pages.

THE conflict between property and human rights supplies the recurring theme song in Dr. David's "History of the Haymarket Affair." A minor and supplementary note is struck skillfully when Dr. David correlates a bit of social revolution with public hysteria.

HYDE PARK, Oct. 3. -- Optimistic as a result of his first short campaign swing in the East, President Roosevelt turned today to preparing itineraries and speeches for his future trips. His next, which probably will begin next Friday from Washington, will be to Denver, with a stop in Omaha on the way eastward.

THERE was recently completed a remarkable social survey of England and Wales, a study of overcrowding which was virtually a census of the households. It showed that 341,000 families were overcrowded, by the official standard soon to become law. But if it be assumed that no living room should serve as a bedroom, then 853,000 families must be considered overcrowded.

A plan to raise $100,000 for the reproduction of 250 copies of "The Book of Kells," the famous eighth century Celtic manuscript in the library of Trinity College, Dublin, and to present them to 250 leading libraries of the world, was inaugurated last week by John Carroll Broderick in a lecture at Columbia University before the Women's Graduate Club of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP). -- A tip to airplane pilots not to dispute the right of way with birds now numerous in the lower air was given today by Dr. Frederick C. Lincoln, war-time flier and a division chief in the Biological Survey.

TOKYO, Oct 3 (AP). -- Leaving for Nanking with supplementary instructions, Kazuye Kuwashima, director of the Eastern Asiatic Bureau of the Foreign Office, declared today China must not only eradicate anti-Japanese activities but also must recognize Japan's special position in the north.

MR. WADE served throughout his war (1917-18) in e signal section of a field artillery battery that part of an army brigade. Army brigades were apt to have a rather thin time of it. When infantry divisions handed over their line on relief and trekked for lush green pastures, there to fatten for the next slaughter, they were apt to take their artillery with them.

Thousands of acres of undeveloped lowlands in New Jersey could be reclaimed inexpensively and put to work for farmers to help solve the midsummer pasture shortage of drought years, H.R. Cox, extension agronomist of New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, Rutgers University, advised the Pasture and Haylands Conference of the American Agricultural Editors Association and National Fertilizer Association meeting in New York recently.

DETROIT, Oct. 3. -- There are 16,752 welfare cases in Detroit still on direct relief. Of these, 5,500 are dependent children, 3,000 aged persons not eligible to old-age assistance checks; 2,700 employables now being absorbed by the WPA, and 4,552 miscellaneous unemployables, such as unemployed due to age, technological displacement and for social reasons, namely, alcoholism and debility.

SAINT JEAN DE LUZ, France, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Spanish Fascist radio stations reported tonight many persons had been killed in street fighting in government-held Bilbao when women, demonstrating for the surrender of the city, were attacked by anarchists.

IT was only a few weeks ago that an amateur of our acquaintance excused the dust on his idle 'cello with the explanation that having shifted his domicile he had lost touch with the group in which for several years he had been wont regularly to make music.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- The rigs and surreys of yesteryear were dusted off today for a trip down Michigan Boulevard.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- With the London Stock Exchange closed today, currency developments were the chief subject of interest in the financial district here. Francs strengthened somewhat in the morning, but news of strikes in Paris caused fresh uneasiness and the closing rate was 105 11-16 francs to the pound.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- The Syracuse football forces, opening their season today, scored a 31 -- 0 victory over a stubborn Clarkson eleven.

The Chicago Stock Exchange has begun a vigorous campaign for the listing of more securities by mid-western corporations, it was disclosed last week by Thaddeus R. Benson, president, in an address to 600 partners in firms holding membership in the Exchange. In soliciting additional issues, Mr. Benson said, the Chicago market realized that the New York Curb Exchange was its "real competitor."

Data in support of the Torrens system of land title registration are provided by Minnesota, where the system was adopted by an act of the Legislature in 1901, according to Martha Byrne, New York County Register and sponsor of the Survey of Real Estate Laws, a Works Progress Administration project.

When two people with tender consciences are very much in love but can't marry, their romance is bound to be a tearfully sentimental compromise. Ruby M. Ayres makes things as hard as possible for her frustrated lovers. Penelope is left alone in a dingy London flat with a spinster cousin while her mother gallivants off to Australia on a second honeymoon.

HERE is something really in the way of detective fiction. It is issued in the form of a complete police file on a case having to do with the supposed suicide of one of two rival leaders in the soap business.

Senator talked for quite while, and when it came time for Mrs. Hammond to put in another word she "regarded him with interest. 'Senator Townsend,' she said, 'do all the Senators think of themselves only as Democrats and Republicans ?'

MILLIONAIRES, says Mary Doyle, lightly scornful, were underfoot all the time, "and a singularly un-interesting lot they proved. Not one of the group possessed sufficient imagination to collect postage stamps."

LOVETT. Alta., Oct. 3 (Canadian Press). -- A lone policeman guarded a seven-mile stretch of abandoned railway track tonight to prevent violence as a result of efforts of "squatters" to prevent its being torn up.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- Retail trade held at a little better than last week's volume and was about 20 per cent ahead of last year with the larger department stores. Women's apparel, dress textiles and house furnishings again met a conspicuously good demand.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- Yale freshmen today won their opening game by outscoring Exeter Academy, 12 -- 7.

ALTHOUGH the theatre in Russia is an indentured servant of the State, it would be treacherous to assume that a free theatre, like that of England, France and America, is automatically celestial. Freedom of speech is the first essential of any art that really matters, for the whole truth cannot be spoken without it.

THIS novel, which won the Prix Femina for 1935 and which confers honor upon that award, is certain to be talked about. Without doubt it is too elusive in theme, too delicate and haunting in treatment, to find a very wide audience.

DECORAH, Iowa, Oct. 3 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace declared tonight that if Governor Landon was a "liberal" he should "at once renounce the support of these few powerful men who have always been the enemies of agriculture and of the general welfare."

TOPEKA, Oct. 2. -- With such ardent boosters as Arthur J. Carruth Jr., one of the owners of The Topeka State Journal, openly advising Governor Landon that he is in danger of losing Kansas, his home State, unless something is done, the results of straw-vote polls being taken throughout the State are giving to local Republican leaders a great deal of worry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- When Congress amended the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to permit an Exchange to apply for and the Securities and Exchange Commission to grant unlisted trading privileges on such Exchange to a security fully registered and listed on another Exchange, there was much difference of opinion as to how this amendment would change the picture as it then existed.

James M. Cox, the Democratic Presidential nominee in 1920, will come out unequivocally for the re-election of President Roosevelt in a radio address on Friday night, it was announced yesterday by Democratic National Chairman James A. Farley.
MADRID, Monday, Oct. 5. -- The War Ministry declared early today that government forces had recaptured the town of Maqueda, an important highway intersection forty-five miles southwest of Madrid.

Inability of injured workmen to handle lump-sum compensation payments wisely has resulted in the waste of several hundred thousand dollars a year in this State, according to a report made public yesterday by the Rehabilitation Division of the State Education Department.

Returning from the first leg of his tour of the State, Justice William F. Bleakley will confer here today with the Republican State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton; his campaign manager, Charles H. Griffiths, and other Republican candidates to map campaign policies and to coordinate the efforts of all candidates on the State ticket.

Jesse Isidor Straus, diplomat, philanthropist and merchant, died at 9:11 A.M. yesterday at his home at 720 Park Avenue after a four-day illness of pneumonia. Mr. Straus's health had been slowly failing for many months and had forced him to resign his post as Ambassador to France in August. He was 64 years old.

An attack on the persecution of Jews in the world today, and an appeal for love and sympathy between Gentile and Jew, were voiced by the Rev. Francis K. Shepherd in his sermon yesterday morning at the North Baptist Church, 232 West Eleventh Street.

BINGHAMTON, Oct. 4. -- A charge of bad faith was laid today against the Democratic administrations of New York, dating back to the Governorship of Franklin D. Roosevelt, by Justice William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor. The diversion of funds raised by taxes on gasoline to general expenses instead of specific use for highways was the basis of his charge.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Interest in the world's wheat markets has broadened to such a degree that any sharp change in prices is almost immediately reflected in all trading centers. Sentiment is more bullish probably than has ever been known other than during the World War, as old traders see it, and they are more disposed to look for higher prices.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- Out of the grim theme of future revolution, Alan Kennington and William McElwee have made a bubbling little comedy called "Time and the Hour," produced for the first time at the Arts Theatre Club tonight.
TOKYO, Oct. 4. -- A typhoon that missed Tokyo but wrought great havoc throughout much of Japan continued its sweep of death and destruction today.

TOPEKA, Oct. 4. -- Governor Landon's allegation that WPA payrolls have been kept secret and his demand that they be opened to public inspection received support today from John G. Stutz, executive director of the Kansas Emergency Relief Committee.

Carl Hubbell started his world series appearance in a rainstorm and finished it at the Yankee Stadium yesterday in a snowstorm. Delirious Yankee rooters, completely delighted by the dethronement of King Karl, covered the outer reaches of the outfield and showered the stands with a paper snowfall.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The national capital chalked up today a new high in talk -- the largest number of telephones per capita of any city in the world.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- Activity in the pig iron, steel and machinery manufacturing branches of heavy industry is reported to be extraordinarily high, and there is a shortage in basic supplies. The Iron and Steel Supervision Board has forbidden dealers to increase their stocks of pig iron, semi-finished products and rolled goods above the level of 1935.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Preferential treatment of consumers' cooperatives by the government or its agencies, whether by tax exemptions or by financial or other assistance, was opposed today in a special report of the Distribution Committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Peace overtures that may lead to an amicable solution of the bitter factional conflict between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, were made here yesterday by officials of unions affiliated with the C.I.O. and by William Green, president of the A.F. of L. in Washington.

Newbold Morris, Republican candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, announced yesterday the appointment of S. Stanley Kreutzer as his campaign manager. Mr. Kreutzer lives at 525 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, and has law offices at 32 Broadway.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 4 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin accused President Roosevelt today of a "misstatement" in the part of his speech on Thursday night dealing with the bonus.

Eleven architects' groups joined yesterday in the protest against the selection of the State Architectural Bureau of the Department of Public Works to design the proposed New York State War Memorial Building at Albany.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 4. -- At a meeting of the Young Republican leaders of the State here today United States Senator W. Warren Barbour declared the Republican party has "recaptured the dynamic crusading spirit of youth and is alive to modern conditions and modern needs, whether they be economic or social."

The Rev. Dr. Charles Francis Potter, founder and leader of the First Humanist Society of New York, rated New York City's cultural level in an address before the society yesterday at 113 West Fifty-seventh Street. He placed New York as only one-third as cultured as Cleveland, one-half as cultured as Cincinnati or Albany and about two-thirds as cultured as Boston.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 4. -- With two days to go, registration of voters in Essex County has reached an all-time high, 387,639, Elmer J. Herrmann, Commissioner of Registration, announced today. He expects the total will go over 400,000 by Tuesday, the deadline in the eight municipalities of the county where permanent registration is in effect.

James E. Finegan in an article to THE NEW YORK TIMES deplored the fact that first-grade clerks seeking promotion to second grade did not know the postal regulations and the names of certain filing systems. It is true that they should know the items referred to by Mr. Finegan.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- In local financial circles this week there has been expressed the conviction that the immediate effect of the gold-bloc devaluations will be a deterioration of Germany's foreign trade, and payments of balances in so far as trade is invoiced in foreign currencies, this last being approximately 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A large-scale housing project at Mount Vernon, N.Y., the first in the New York area under the Federal Housing Act, has been made possible through contracts signed by the Federal Housing Administration, the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York and the Chester Crests Apartments, Inc.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Lard stocks here decreased 6,427,650 pounds in September, compared with a loss of 4,877,610 pounds a year ago and 31,451,949 pounds two years ago. Total stocks of lard are 70,953,305 pounds, compared with 77,380,955 pounds on Aug. 31 and 22,362,000 at the end of September last year.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (AP). -- Officials of the International Hockey League and the Canadian-American Hockey League announced following a meeting here today that the two minor circuits would combine to form the International-American Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The Loyalist forces in Spain were pictured here tonight by Jose Gibernau, commercial agent of the Spanish Embassy, as "making a historic stand against the forces of destruction, of fear, of violence, and of ignorrance."

Robert Schumann's "Fantasia for Violin and Orchestra," Opus 131, which is practically unknown in this country, has been revised by Fritz Kreisler and will be played by the violinist on Oct. 29 with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, under Frederick Stock.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- This week's Boerse has been entirely under the influence of currency devaluations and foreign buying with blocked marks has increased. Except on Tuesday, when official denials of any move on the Reichsmark's alignment were made known and caused a reaction, stocks were active and strong.

With nine entered for the featured Raunt Purse, the two-week Fall meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club will begin this afternoon at Jamaica. The session will be the last of the season on Long Island, and will be followed by the Empire City meeting at Yonkers, which will ring down the curtain on 1936 metropolitan racing.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Support of President Roosevelt's "determination that this nation shall remain at peace" was pledged here this afternoon by Harry H. Woodring in his first speech since his recent appointment as Secretary of War.

VIENNA, Oct. 4. -- The Authoritarian Fascist leadership principle has fallen on hard times in Austria. The multitude of leaders in Fascist Austria now threaten or abuse each other or seek to curry favor from each other in various ways.

Bobby Wilson, whose gridiron exploits brought joy to Southern Methodist University rooters down in Dallas for the past several years, exhibited his ground-gaining ability in grand style before 10,000 fans at Ebbets Field last night as the Brooklyn Dodgers blanked the Philadelphia Eagles, 18 to 0.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Nineteen persons met death in automobile accidents in New Jersey during Safety Week, proclaimed by Governor Harold G. Hoffman as a time to consider reduction of accident fatalities, chiefly those that occur on the highways.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 4 (AP). -- The hard-hitting Green Bay football team smothered the Chicago Cardinals under passes and runs today to win a National League game, 24 to 0. A crowd of 12,000 turned out.

Leaders of the militant faction of the Marine Firemen's, Oilers and Watertenders Union expressed satisfaction yesterday with the ruling of Federal Judge Murray Hulbert ordering a new election to determine the choice of executive secretary, treasurer and agents of the union.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 76 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week. The percentage rate is the highest in this movement. The tonnage rate, at about 53,000,000 tons a year, is the highest since September, 1929, with the possible exception of February, 1930, when there was a bulge which was found afterward not to have rested on a secure foundation.

Nine units of the fleet of 100 new double-deck buses, with which the Fifth Avenue Coach Company will modernize its service in the next two months at a cost of $2,000,000, will be placed in operation today over the route to Jackson Heights, Queens. At the same time all of the drivers and conductors of Fifth Avenue buses will appear in smart new uniforms.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- A gain of 33 per cent over last year's registration figures has been made by the Democrats in Philadelphia in preparation for the Presidential election next month, as compared with a 3 per cent gain by the Republicans, according to nearly complete, unofficial returns compiled following yesterday's registration of voters.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 4. -- A serious hitch to the long-continued Chaco peace negotiations has been disclosed by the action of the Bolivian Ministry of Foreign Affairs in recalling Tomas Manuel Elio, Minister to Argentina and chief of the Bolivian delegation to the peace conference.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- After scenes of wild disorder, in which 64 persons were so injured that they had to be sent to hospitals, and 204 others suffered lesser hurts, the police this afternoon forced Sir Oswald Mosley to abandon a parade of 5,000 of his Blackshirted Fascists through the Jewish districts of London's East End.

HYDE PARK, Oct. 4. -- President Roosevelt worked for a time today on plans for his campaign trips later this month, but devoted most of his Sunday to the restful pursuits typical of this quiet village.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- Scoring a goal with less than three minutes of play remaining, the Maccabee soccer team, champions of Palestine, registered a splendid 1-0 victory over the Passon team of the American League at the Municipal Stadium today before 30,000 fans.

J. D. Malcolmson of the Robert Gair Company, Inc., manufacturers of paper board products, has been appointed chairman of the Simplified Practice Committee, to standardize boxboard calipers, by the United States Bureau of Standards, Department of Agriculture.
PARIS, Oct. 4. -- Communists, 100,000 strong, battled through the streets of Paris against Rightist demonstrators today and jammed into the Parc des Princes to trumpet a war cry of death to fascism.

ROME, Oct. 4. -- The general assembly of the International Agriculture Institute will hold its first session tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock in the building erected for it thirty-one years ago by King Victor Emmanuel III.

The suggested consolidation of four municipalities in Middlesex County, N.J., reported in THE TIMES, is another of those grandiose plans certain to result only in great growth of the costs of government. There have been consolidations of municipalities of various sorts in this State and elsewhere.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 4. -- Bostwick Field on the Jericho Turnpike was crowded this afternoon with members of society who attended a polo match in aid of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children of Nassau County, sponsored by a committee headed by Mrs. James H. Van Alen of Roslyn.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- In a long-drawn-out contest in a changing wind and Summer-like conditions, Cornelius Shields further demonstrated today his right to the championship of the Interclub Class on Long Island Sound. Sailing his Aileen over a triangular course of eight miles in the final contest of the season for the craft he defeated Lawrence Marx's Alberta by forty seconds.

Ralph H. Graves has resigned as manager of the Doubleday-Doran Syndicate and will open a similar agency in New York to represent a group of publishers including Dodd, Mead Co.; Charles Scribner's Sons, Farrar Rinehart, J.B. Lippincott Co.; Bobbs, Merrill Co.; Reynal Hitchcock, William Morrow Co. and the Frederick A. Stokes Company.

One man was drowned and two were rescued yesterday after a large sedan leaped the stringpiece at the foot of Columbia Place, Brooklyn, and landed, nose down, in thirty-five feet of water in Buttermilk Channel.
The resale of a Riverside Drive apartment house after an ownership of two weeks featured realty transactions announced in this city over the week-end.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- The report of the Bank of France that was made up on Friday, Sept. 25, shows a decrease of more than 2,500,000,000 francs in its gold reserve in the week and a decline in the reserve's ratio to circulation from 57.42 to 54.42 per cent, which explains the government's decision to proceed immediately with devaluation, the method of which would not seem to have been fixed definitely until then.

Warning of deep inroads into church, public school and home made by communism and irreligion, leaders of the Catholic clergy from pulpit and dais yesterday pleaded for a strong revival of Catholic instruction for children and adults at the National Catechetical Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 4. -- Holding their opponents scoreless until the last minute of play, G.H. (Pete) Bostwick's Aiken Knights rode to a 7-1 victory over Ebby Gerry's Aknusti quartet in the weekly high-goal polo match at Bostwick Field in Old Westbury today.

Carl Owen Hubbell, the seemingly matchless screwball maestro of baseball, was not quite up to perfection yesterday, and, as it already had been demonstrated that perfection itself does not always suffice to stop Marse Joe McCarthy's Yankee juggernaut, the result was really inevitable.

A registration of approximately 2,500,000 in New York City for the November election is hoped for by Democratic leaders, to insure a sufficiently large Democratic plurality here to overcome the lead the Republicans will get up-State.

At the last moment possible under laws of the State, the Democratic candidate for Governor of Minnesota has withdrawn and with him the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate. Some Congressional and local nominees of the Democratic party may remain in the field, but, in effect, the Democrats of Minnesota have blotted themselves out nationally.
The Giants and Yankees, together with players on other first division clubs in the two major leagues, will participate this year in the biggest world series financial "melon" on record.

A sharp increase in the use of premiums in 1937 was forecast here last week, when representatives of about thirty advertising agencies shopped through the lines on display at the Premium Advertising Association of America, Inc., at the Hotel Astor.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4. -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced today the names of students whose high records during the last semester gave them places of honor on the dean's list.

Makes New Attack on Twenty Aldermen Who Block Purchase of Snogo Apparatus. Mayor La Guardia, in a statement issued last night, declared that conferences with his commissioners over the week-end had disclosed no method of getting around the refusal of the Board of Aldermen to approve the purchase of Snogo snow removal equipment.

Why all the way around the earth? This question must have occurred to more than one reader following the course of our Mr. LEO KIERAN and his fellow-journalists eastward over the air routes. The earth being a globe, it is plain that the furthest point on its surface from any other point is only half-way around, or approximately.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Oct. 4. -- W. Halsted Taft of Montclair and Charles N. Hart of the home club today won the first annual best-ball invitation tournament of the Glen Ridge Country Club with a thirty-six-hole total of 137, seven under par.

Twice postponed, "Lend Me Your Ears!" gets around to its premiere tonight at the Mansfield. It is still the Philip Wood-Stewart Beach comedy about small-town politics, with Walter C. Kelly ("The Virginia Judge") as the leading participant therein. Curtain at 8:40 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A plan for cooperative procedure with State utilities commissions in the consideration of rate structures, costs, accounts, regulations and similar questions was announced today by the Federal Power Commission.
BOMBAY, India, Oct. 4. -- The eldest son of Mahatma Gandhi today offered to quit drinking as a birthday present if his 67-year-old father would embrace the religion of Islam.

Mrs. Sadie R. Keefer, 42 years old, was found burned to death on a blazing mattress at 10 o'clock last night in her apartment on the second floor of 143-18 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, Queens. How the mattress had caught fire was not determined.

ALBANY, Oct. 4. -- Reporting 3,455 new grants of State old-age pensions since Oct. 1, when the age of eligibility was reduced from 70 to 65 years, Governor Lehman today deplored the failure of the Legislature to allow for further participation by New York in the Federal Security Act's program.
