CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Backing up Bill Dietrich's six-hit pitching with a seventeen-hit attack on five hurlers, the White Sox won their third city championship today by trouncing the Cubs, 8 to 2, for a four-game sweep of the 1936 event.

Trade continued steady in the apparel and other branches of the wholesale markets last week, with retailers in all sections of the country sending in a substantial volume of reorders. Buying in all lines is expected to show a sharp upturn this week as the result of the rising trend in consumer demand for Fall merchandise.

HAMELN, Germany, Oct. 4. -- National Socialist Germany celebrated today its fourth thanksgiving day or harvest festival in the presence of 700,000 peasants gathered on the Bueckeberg, six miles from Hameln, and along roads leading to the hill.

Bishop William T. Manning was officially notified yesterday that a magnificent icon of St. John the Divine has been sent as a gift to the cathedral by Benjamin I, Ecumenical Patriarch of Istanbul and head of the Greek Orthodox Church throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Charges that President Roosevelt is deliberately dodging the question of future taxes, raised by Governor Landon, and that the Democrats are soliciting campaign funds from Federal employes were made today by the Republican National Committee and by the Republican Senatorial Committee.
October, as usual, rides in on a wave of exhibitions, well over twenty opening today and tomorrow or having opened over the week-end.

Mayor La Guardia, Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan and Captain William J. Pedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, will officiate at a ribbon-cutting ceremony at Eighty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue at 8:30 A.M. today, formally "reopening" Madison Avenue for its second century.

World series managers are peculiar fellows. After Marse Joe McCarthy's Yankees had beaten Carl Hubbell, the great Giant southpaw of whom the youthful Joe DiMaggio said, "He's not 'invisible,'" one might naturally have expected Colonel Billy Terry to be glum and McCarthy to be highly elated.

Last night's performance of Bizet's "Carmen" by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company before a large audience at the Hippodrome differed from the presentation of the same opera earlier in the season in the casting of all four of its principal roles.
Business in the foreign exchange market last week was subject to severe irregularity in anticipation of devaluation in the French franc, and the Netherlands and Swiss currencies.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- Dissolution of the so-called gold bloc of Continental European nations, although eventuating somewhat earlier than expected, has had no markedly strong reactions in the financial markets here. Indeed, they already had gone a fair way toward adjustment to the immediate effects of devaluation.
The play-by-play description of the fourth game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows:

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 4. -- Tony Miller of Toronto turned the tables on J. Lester Hillbish of Reading, Pa., today at the Roosevelt Raceway and took first place in the forty-mile motor-cycle race in a thrilling finish before a crowd of 20,000.

The Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland ended yesterday twenty-four years of service as rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, East Sixteenth Street at Stuyvesant Square. His sermon at the morning communion service contrasted the flexibility of youth and the constraint of age.

Tony Canzoneri and Jimmy McLarnin will fight again tonight. The gallant rivals who staged one of the best battles of the year last Spring will have at each other in a ten-round contest at Madison Square Garden that promises to attract a crowd of more than 15,000 persons.

ELLSWORTH, Me., Oct. 4. -- Frederick T. Labouisse, architect and etcher, shot and killed himself today at his camp on Abraham's Pond, fifteen miles from this place, after, police say, threatening to kill his wife, the former Eleanor Joyce Sewell of Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- The cost of hogs in the Stock Yards here in September averaged $9.89 a hundredweight, the lowest price for that month in six years, except last year. The average on Friday was $9.55, compared with $9.50 a week before, $10.30 a year ago and $5.95 two years ago.

GENEVA, Oct. 4. -- A ticklish month for the hopes for peace and economic recovery, which are based here on the Anglo-Franco-American monetary accord, opens tomorrow, when an effort to generalize a reduction in trade barriers will begin in the League of Nations Assembly -- a month that ends with the United States elections.

Barely a month ago deep regret was widely expressed over the resignation of JESSE ISIDOR STRAUS as American Ambassador to France. Death has now certified to his serious illness as the reason for his withdrawing from the post in which he had already represented his country with a distinction that adds new luster to the name he bore.
The executive board of the New York Teachers Guild urged Governor Lehman yesterday to seek repeal of the Ives Loyalty Oath Law for teachers, as part of his campaign for re-election.

Rowing with admirable zest but with occasional raggedness over a mile and half stretch of the glassy-green surface of the Hudson, a ten-oared crew of the Bronx division of the city's Life Saving Service yesterday afternoon won the first amateur lifeboat race for the championship of the Port of New York.

TORONTO, Oct. 4. -- Canada now has 121 gold milling plants in operation, and mining authorities expect that before the end of the year there will be 145 plants turning out gold bullion. The value of this year's gold production, on the basis of monthly returns already made, is expected to be in the neighborhood of $130,000,000.

Cotton prices fluctuated over a wide range last week on the New York Cotton Exchange, but, despite the substantial selling pressure which developed late in the period, closed the week with good-sized net gains.

Another milestone in the long professional career of A.G. Andrews of the cast of "Love From a Stranger" will be marked today. It was seventy-five years ago today that Mr. Andrews first became an actor as one of the juvenile players with Mrs. Fanny Sterling in "Masks and Faces."

AN article called "Hatrack" first made Herbert Asbury known. It was about a somewhat dim-witted girl whose informal amours made her the talk of a small Missouri town. The issue of The American Mercury that contained it was banned in Boston. H.L. Mencken hurried to Boston, hawked and vended a copy of the banned magazine while a crowd of thousands looked on.

IT looks dark for the Giants now. If they can't with Hubbell, who can hold those Yanks? The old master had one bad inning yesterday in the Stadium and the Giants are now, in the immortal words of the late Andrew Freedman, "standing on the brink of an abscess."

The remarks of our correspondent Harry Durant regarding surf fishing in general and the respective abilities of Northern and Florida casters in particular have brought rejoinders from several readers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A more emphatic trend by issuers to obtain, through the sale of securities, new money for plant equipment and improvement and to increase working capital, was indicated today by an analysis of registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933.

Nobody can doubt the zeal and energy of The Chicago Tribune in behalf of the Republican national ticket. Colonel McCORMICK has magnanimously given his benediction to Colonel KNOX as well as to Governor LANDON. The organization of The Volunteers released powerful forces whose consequences are not yet properly appreciated, even in Chicago.

Quite as important as the Anglo-American-French agreement in marking at last a reversal of the intense nationalism since the onset of the depression is the announcement from Paris of the abolition of more than a hundred import quotas and the reduction of tariffs on many articles, running from 15 to 20 per cent.

The Board of Education budget, as revised by Mayor La Guardia, "throws into the discard" the effort of school authorities to modernize the city's educational system, James Marshall, vice president of the school board, declared yesterday.

The Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Vincent Astor is acting president, will be the beneficiary of a special entertainment on the night of Oct. 14 in the new Iridium Room of the St. Regis. The fund, organized to aid unemployed musicians, has more than 3,000 of these performers on its roster.

Two United States Senators, Hugo L. Black of Alabama and Robert F. Wagner of New York, will be among the speakers who will address campaign rallies of the American Labor party in various parts of the State and city this week.

An airplane, flying low yesterday afternoon above Rockaway Boulevard close to the Jamaica Sea-Airport, swerved 180 degrees from its course and almost head on struck another plane coming in for a landing.

BOLOGNA, Italy, Oct. 4 -- This reporter having completed the first leg of his trip around the world from Lakehurst, N.J., to Frankfort, Germany, behind schedule, because of delay in the arrival of the dirigible Hindenburg, is setting forth today by automobile from Bologna to Brindisi, Italy, in an effort to connect with a scheduled flight to the East of the Imperial Airways.

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- The new "flight into real values," as expressed in the headlong rise of stocks and the demand for real estate and a reluctance to sell commodities, was the local market's reaction to the dissolution of the Continental European gold bloc.
Tribute was paid yesterday by the Fire Department to the forty-four members who died in the past year with memorial services at the Firemen's Monument, Riverside Drive and 100th Street.
VALENCIA, Spain, Oct. 4. -- It is now confirmed that the Island of Iviza in the Balearic group was captured from government militiamen about ten days ago by insurgents operating from Palma, Majorca.

Solomon Portnow, in a letter printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently, suggested that if all reference to the "living wage" in the New York Minimum Wage Law were omitted, there is a possibility that that law would successfully withstand any future constitutional assaults upon it in the Supreme Court.

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- There is always a first time. A convincing example of this was shown today when Tuffy Leemans, on his first chance to carry the ball in the game, ran it thirty-one yards through left tackle for his first touchdown of the season, thereby enabling the New York Giants to down the Boston Redskins and enter the winning column in the National Football League for the first time this year.

City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. last night assailed John D. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, for alleging that David Dubinsky, a Roosevelt elector in this State, has manifested Communist sympathies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The City of Albany, N.Y., had a gross debt of $32,584,630 at the close of its 1935 fiscal year, the Bureau of the Census reported today. The per capita debt was $251.04, as compared with $219.05 in 1934 and $117.78 in 1926, and the per capita cost of operation and maintenance of the city departments $54.46 as against $53.46 in 1934.

Avery Brundage, chairman of the American Olympic committee and successful leader in the fight to take an American contingent to the Olympic Games in Berlin over the opposition of critics of the Hitler regime, declared last night that the United States must learn a lesson from National Socialist Germany if this country wishes to preserve its institutions.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Sept. 30 at 73.6, compared with 73.5 two weeks before, 72.8 a month before, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

A version of "The Two Orphans," utterly unlike anything hitherto observed on stage or screen, was presented yesterday afternoon and evening at the Vanderbilt Theatre. It was the first offering of the seventh consecutive season of the Italian Teatro d'Arte under the direction of Commendatore Giuseppe Sterni.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4. -- The newspaper Pravda published today a lengthy analysis of the Presidential campaign in the United States by its New York correspondent, M. Olgin, describing the Republican and Democratic parties as representing big capitalists, some of whom gave financial backing to both.
Steel operations increased 1 1/2 points last week to 74 1/2 per cent of capacity, the highest level since May, 1930, the magazine Steel says in its weekly summary, issued yesterday.

In a letter to stockholders, P.W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said the plan for the rearrangement of the company's capitalization now under consideration would, if approved, avoid substantial financing expenses and underwriting commissions which would be involved in refunding the first-preferred stock.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 4. -- The national executive committee of the Labor party tonight held a controversial session lasting until midnight to decide whether to recommend to the party conference that opens tomorrow a resolution backing the British Government's policy of non-intervention in Spain.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4. -- Janet Gaynor may appear opposite Fredric March for Selznick-International in "A Star Is Born," to be filmed in Technicolor. Miss Gaynor is expected to return from a vacation this week to complete the deal. She recently declined to renew her contract with Twentieth CenturyFox after the studio had let it be known that it considered her box-office popularity on the wane.

Public hearings on the $436,000,000 transit unification plan sponsored by Mayor La Guardia's advisers, Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., will be resumed before the Transit Commission today in an atmosphere that has led observers to fear the city's negotiators are contemplating withdrawal from the proceedings.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- So far as any authoritative financial opinion has been expressed publicly here, the City entirely and emphatically approves the action of the governments of the United States and Great Britain in so promptly and effectively "pooling," as one leading financier expresses it, their vast resources of friendship, skill and gold in the service of their neighbors, and in the interest of a far wider community than is within their domestic limits.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 3. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84, which compares with 84 the week before, 84.1 two weeks before, 84.2 three weeks before and 83.7 four weeks before.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4. -- The Pittsburgh Pirates suffered their first defeat of the season in the National Football League, losing to the hard-hitting Chicago Bears, 27 -- 9, before 29,000 at Forbes Field today. The Bears passed their way to four scores, tallying one touchdown in each of the first two periods and two in the third.
BUFFALO, Oct. 4. -- Canisius College lost a hard-fought game to La Salle of Philadelphia by a score of 19 -- 14 today.

PARIS, Oct. 4. -- Any question as to who is master in Paris was settled today when government forces of police and Mobile Guards made the efforts of Colonel Francois de la Rocque's French Social party -the former Croix de Feu -- to break up a big Communist demonstration look like a series of college riots.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- For the first time in ten years, the United States imported more merchandise than it exported, although the excess amounted to only $9,000,000, in the first six months of 1936, it was disclosed in an analysis of the country's balance of international payments made public today by Amos E. Taylor, assistant chief of the Finance Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 4. -- Federal share insurance will be made available for New Jersey building and loan associations on Oct. 15 when Commissioner Carl K. Withers of the State Department of Banking and Insurance lifts the embargo that has prevented the associations from applying for membership in the Federal Saving and Loan Insurance Corporation, it was revealed here today.

Six American composers have been commissioned by the Columbia Broadcasting System to write music specifically for the radio and within time limits considered suitable for broadcasting. The commissions were granted in recognition of the growing importance of radio to music and the need for works that could he fitted into the time boundaries and broadcasting.

BERLIN, Oct. 4. -- The National Socialist Government has now reduced by a total of three school years the amount of instruction for German boys and girls who take the complete elementary and higher school courses which prepare for entrance into universities or business.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4. -- Under the slogan "Yale's response to human needs," 140 students, headed by Louis T. Stone Jr., '37, of Bronxville, N.Y., will try to raise $20,000 by university canvass in the next five days. This is believed to represent the largest organized contribution to the relief of human need of any American university.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The brainiest man the Western Hemisphere has ever known probably lived a few centuries ago in the Aleutian Islands, off the southern coast of Alaska, according to Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, curator of physical anthropology of the Smithsonian Institution.

The Right Hon. Earl Howe, famous automobile race driver and president of the British Drivers Club, is among the 1,800 passengers due today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. He is accompanied by P.G. Fairfield, also a driver, and Brian Lewis, son of Lord Essendin.
This is in reply to the letter of William Allen White published recently in THE TIMES.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Mrs. Henry Ford today announced her support of Governor Landon's candidacy.

The welcome the local Warner Brothers gentlemen are preparing for the newly wed Joan Blondell and Dick Powell tomorrow morning will not be so vociferous as those the city arranges for Cunard and French Line queens of the sea, nor so pompous as those with which it greets transatlantic fliers and Channel swimmers, but it will serve.

The distorted views of our political orators, the confused issues and the flagrant violation of ethics on the part of both major parties have served to curb rather than promote the interest of the non-thinking individual. He finds himself in a quandary as to who should be his choice.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Oct. 4. -- The Metropolitan Golf Association team of New York not only sustained yesterday's opening pace but added more power to its drive to carry off the thirtieth Lesley Cup team competition today on the seaside course of the Rockaway Hunting Club.

DANZIG, Oct. 4. -- The Danzig police made many arrests of Socialists today while National Socialists celebrated their "victory" over the League of Nations. Seventy members of the Social Democratic party were detained at a meeting of delegates of rural and local branches and put under protective custody.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- Mixing its running and passing attacks, Villanova defeated the University of Detroit at Shibe Park today, 13 to 6, before 20,000 spectators.

TALAVERA DE LA REINA, Spain, Oct. 3 (Delayed by Censor). -- The Rebels gave up their last hope that Madrid would collapse without heavy fighting after an air raid on the capital yesterday brought reports only of continued preparation for defense.

Daniel Smith, acting for St. Barnabas Hospital, brought the three-story brick house at 699 1/2 High Street, Newark, from Mrs. Louise W. Raschek through Feist Feist, Inc. The purchase gives the hospital frontages of 425 feet on High Street and 275 feet on Montgomery Street for use in its building program.

True peace in this life can be obtained only by reliance on God, the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, pastor, said in a sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel, colorful manager of the Dodgers, last night was removed from his post by unanimous agreement of the Brooklyn club officials. This was made known in a brief unsigned announcement which was handed out by Secretary John Gorman. It follows:

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 4. -- All dining rooms and clubrooms at the Homestead had private parties today. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Halsey had as their luncheon guests in the Colonial Room Mr. and Mrs. C. Maury Jones, Miss Kay Stammers and Frederick Warburg.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- Aided by a 100-yard forward-pass play, St. Joseph's College defeated Mount St. Mary's at the Hawks' Stadium today, 14 to 6.

Loadings of freight cars in the last three months of the year are expected to run about 9.7 per cent ahead of the same levels a year earlier, according to estimates by the thirteen shippers' regional advisory boards. The estimate indicates the following increases, by regions:
A drop of 55 per cent in applications for relief in the State in the current calendar year was reported yesterday by Frederick I. Daniels, chairman of the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- As an inducement to banks and bank receivers to retire as rapidly as possible the preferred stock, capital notes and debentures through which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation advanced them money in the critical days following the bank holiday of 1933, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, announced tonight a reduction in the dividend and interest rates payable on those obligations.

Although the scholastic football season is merely two weeks old, indications are that last year's leaders in at least two important areas of the metropolitan district likely will be dethroned. This view is shared by many, for both New Rochelle High and St. John's Prep of Brooklyn dropped their 1936 openers during the past week-end.

BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 4. -- The Catalan proletarian government has announced that the economic program for the reconstruction of Catalonia is considered of first importance next to unified prosecution of the war.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 4. -- The appointment of 118 undergraduates as cadet officers in the Princeton University field artillery unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps was announced here today by Lieut. Col. David E. Cain.

WINDSOR, N.C., Oct. 4 (AP). -- An apparently crazed Negro was riddled with bullets as he came screaming from his barricaded shanty here today after a six-hour siege in which he wounded fifteen persons, two seriously.

Some Democratic leaders in Pennsylvania admit truth in the charge that they are improperly trying to make use of WPA workers politically. It is not denied that in many instances these men have been asked to contribute to the party campaign fund, on the ground that they owe their jobs to a Democratic Administration.

Brown Brothers Harriman Co., private bankers, in their Sept. 30 condition statement report total deposits of $59,528,203, compared with $52,157,918 on June 30, and $41,228,461 on Sept. 30, 1935. Total resources amount to $87,460,863, against $79,757,095 three months ago and $66,900,468 a year ago.

An agreement between St. Petersburg, Fla., and the bondholders' committee for the city's bonds on a plan for refunding almost all of the outstanding bonded indebtedness of the municipality provides for payment of interest on bonds deposited with the committee at the rate of 3 per cent until the deposited bonds can be exchanged for refunding bonds.

It is becoming increasingly evident that industry in this country is traveling reasonably fast on the road to better times, foreign uncertainties and domestic politics notwithstanding. In some lines the upward trend has been established beyond peradventure of doubt.

Columbia started to bolster its defense yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its game with Army at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday. In winning from Maine last week the Lions displayed several weaknesses, and because of this and scouts' reports of a powerful Cadet eleven the Morningsiders face a strenuous week of practice.

John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, demanded last night that President Roosevelt give more than "lip service" in repudiation of communistic and radical influences in his administration and his campaign.

William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, yesterday issued a call to all State-chartered banks, trust companies and private bankers to publish reports of their condition as of Sept. 30. This notice was in conformity with Section 42 of the State Banking Law, which requires the Superintendent of Banks to call for statements of condition from the banks in his charge four times annually.
The play-by-pray description of the fifth game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows:

BOSTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox declared tonight that, while President Roosevelt repudiated Communist support, he failed "peculiarly enough" to explain "why the Communists want to see him re-elected."

The Max Gordon season opens this evening at the Lyceum Theatre, where -- and at 8:30 -- they will be putting on "St. Helena," by R.C. Sherriff and Jeanne de Casalis. The play is about the last days of the exiled Napoleon, a part played by Maurice Evans; and Percy Waram, Reginald Mason, Whitford Kane, Joseph Macaulay, Alan Wheatley, Rosamond Pinchot, Kay Strozzi, Edward Fielding and Francis Pierlot are also in it.

Women trade unionists representing labor organizations bade farewell yesterday to a "women's caravan" which departed from Times Square for a month's tour of the State for the re-election of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.

The Board of Superintendents of the city school system ruled yesterday that maintenance of student R.O.T.C. and naval reserve units was wholly legal provided that attendance was voluntary and did not conflict with regular class hours. No academic credit is given for the military drill.

Deaths from automobile accidents in New York City for the last weekend declined more than 76 per cent, compared with those in the corresponding week-end last year, although there was one more death than in the previous week-end this year, according to the report made yesterday by Harold Fowler, first deputy police commissioner, in charge of the Safety Bureau of the Police Department.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday the suspension of proposed rates filed by the Consolidated Edison Company, covering current supplied for manufacturing purposes. It will begin hearings on the proposed rates at 10 A.M. tomorrow in its offices at 80 Centre Street.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Formation of a "Democrats for Nelson" (Martin A. Nelson, Republican candidate for Governor) Club was announced today by Alric Anderson, St. Paul attorney, in a statement denouncing the withdrawal of two Democratic candidates in a fusion move, as an attempt to "destroy the Democratic party."

In the heaviest trading since April 30, the share market yesterday withstood a moderate amount of profit-taking as the aftermath of the strong markets in the closing days of last week and touched a new high level for the year. The closing was irregular. The turnover on the Stock Exchange reached 2,082,000 shares, compared with 1,928,000 on Friday.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare carried off the qualifying medal in the twenty-fourth annual Berthellyn Cup golf tournament with a card of 75 at the Huntingdon Valley Country Club today. It was her first Philadelphia district appearance since June, but she displayed rare form, recording four birdies, three on the first nine.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 5 (AP). -- Ralph Bald and Robert Madden, University of Pittsburgh's defending champions, forfeited today by default their opportunity to win the second Middle Atlantic States intercollegiate tennis tournament.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 5. -- The Chaco peace negotiations entered a serious deadlock today with a Bolivian announcement that that government would not proceed with conversations seeking a settlement of the territorial dispute as long as Paraguay occupied her present positions on the Villa Montes-Santa Cruz road.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 5. -- James A. Reed, former Democratic United States Senator from Missouri, attacked tonight the social reforms in the New Deal program as "tyrannical" measures leading to despotism, sought by its sponsors under "the communistic cry of 'Social Justice.'"

Hal Schumacher yesterday pitched himself into fame and possibly to greater fortune when he derailed the "Iron Horse" and nearly all the rest of the Yankee world series express just at the point where Marse Joe McCarthy had figured he was rolling safely into his terminal.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5. -- In a Zagreb court today twenty-nine Croat peasants went on trial, accused of participation in the slaying last April of six young Serbs suspected of being Comitadjis [members of a terrorist group] with instructions to assassinate Vladimir Matchek, leader of the Croat Peasant party.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5. -- There were no injuries in last Saturday's game with Amherst to retard the development of the Harvard eleven, so that today, while one or two players did only light work, preparation for next Saturday's game with Brown began with a rush.

Dean Detton of Philadelphia, new heavyweight wrestling champion, spotted Tiny Roebuck, the Haskell Indian, ninety-three pounds and successfully defended his title at the New York Hippodrome last night.

An increase in cooperative purchases by the consuming public throughout Europe was reported by Henry J. May, secretary general of the International Cooperative Alliance, who arrived here yesterday on the Queen Mary to attend the tenth biennial congress of the Cooperative League of the United States, beginning Thursday in Columbus, Ohio.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Last Summer's excessive heat caused so many deaths in the United States that by the end of this year accidental deaths from all causes will total 110,000, a new high figure.

Major Patrick J. Walsh was reelected president for his fourth term at a meeting of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. at the Hotel Capitol last night. Immediately after his selection, Major Walsh announced that he would be a candidate for the national presidency at the A.A.U. convention in December.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- The market for hogs had a strong undertone today, general sales being steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than on Friday, while sows were in demand and advanced 10 to 15 cents. The top of $10.50 was unchanged from the close of last week, but the day's average was up 15 cents at $9.80.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5. -- The belief that Penn will try to smother Yale next Saturday beneath a barrage of forwards led Coach Ducky Pond to devote today's drill of the week to developing a defense for passes.

Were it not that my name was mentioned in the courteous letter from Mr. Hunter, published in THE TIMES this morning, I should be interested in it only indirectly. To be sure, some of his statements are questionable, but on many other points he and I would be in substantial agreement.

Twenty-five men and ten women, who described themselves as unemployed artists and artists' models, were arrested last night in the offices of the Federal Art Project, 6 East Thirty-ninth Street, after they had staged a demonstration lasting more than five hours.
Devaluation of the Italian lira and modification of Italian tariff barriers were greeted with enthusiasm here yesterday by both exporters and importers.

So much is heard about hit-and-run drivers; about the callous carelessness of speed maniacs; and about the inability of average drivers to control their rattle-trap cars that it seems something should be said in praise of the average, careful, thoughtful driver.
It is not possible to determine the value of the dollar on the local forsign exchange market since a fixed parity for the new French franc has not been established.

The pattern of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was much the same as prevailed during the greater part of last week. The line of least resistance continued upward, particularly among the secondary railroad and convertible industrial bonds, while United States Government and other high-grade investments held within a narrow price range in limited trading.

It must have cost MUSSOLINI something to recede from the famous pledge made at Pesaro in 1927, when he fixed the value of the lira at a rate experts considered too high even then. For nine years Italians have not been allowed to forget that pledge; it has stood as a bulwark against every suggestion that the currency should be readjusted to meet changed conditions.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- In the winter of his content, with forty-one years of service behind him, Glenn Scobey (Pop) Warner looks down upon another strong football creation from his mounted platform at Temple Stadium aid watches his wing backs go criss-crossing by in geometric patterns and convolutions designed to demonstrate that a straight line is not always the surest route between two given points.

Suggestions for the improvement of community influences that touch the child were made yesterday afternoon in a symposium at the regional convention of the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The meeting will continue today.

HAVANA, Oct. 5. -- Representative Jose Grau Aguero, Nationalist, of Havana Province, was liberated at 5 o'clock this morning after having been held since Saturday night in connection with an alleged revolutionary plot said to have been discovered by the authorities, it was learned today from unofficial sources.

HYDE PARK, Oct. 5. -- President Roosevelt will make major campaign speeches in Chicago and Detroit on the nights of Oct. 14 and 15, respectively, according to tentative plans which became known today.

Farm tractors are now being equipped with radios. Agricultural specialists in Washington quite properly hail this as taking more of the drudgery out of tilling the soil. Driving a tractor, it is admitted, is much easier than holding down the handles of a horse-drawn plow.

Jimmy McLarnin turned the tables on Tony Canzoneri last night. The baby-faced Irishman, who was soundly trounced by the ex-lightweight champion last May, came back to even the score at Madison Square Garden by clearly outpointing the Brooklyn Italian in a ten-round fight.

BACK to the Polo Grounds. It was Prince Hal who pitched the series back across the river. The slim Schumacher gained a decision over two bulkier rivals, Cholly the Red Ruffing and Blubber Malone. Prince Hal put plenty of thrills in his performance and at times he was surrounded by a strong unsupporting cast. The Giants made three errors that forced Hal to work overtime for his triumph.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Secretary Morgenthau, as chairman of the board of trustees of the Red Cross endowment fund of about $12,000,000, said today that the only recommendations he had made as to the organization's investments were for the purchase of direct obligations of the government or securities wholly guaranteed by the United States as to principal and interest.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had admitted to dealings Peerless Corporation rights, when issued, and had suspended from dealings Phillips Petroleum Company rights.

MADRID, Oct. 5 (Uncensored). -- Since Premier Francisco Largo Caballero ballero took office early in September at the head of a genuine Popular Front Cabinet the civil war has been carried on under increasing pressure from the insurgent forces without and also under stress from within.

The first dinner meeting in the Visiting Nurse Service's city-wide campaign to raise $250,000, was held last night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, the Bronx. Richard Whitney, chairman of the men's division of the drive, spoke.

Professor WILLIAM JAMES would doubtless have included fire fighting in his list of occupations that furnish a moral equivalency of war. Were all the world at peace, free even from the rumors of war, there would still be need of such "fighters" as day and night guard the cities against the peril of fire.

The National Civil Service Reform League announced yesterday that it is seeking the support of all candidates for the United States Senate and House of Representatives for an amendment to the Federal Constitution embodying the merit system. The proposed amendment is cast in the following language, adapted from the New York State Constitution:

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Oct. 6. -- With the arrival of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek at Nanking yesterday afternoon by airplane from Kuling, coinciding with the arrival in Shanghai of Kazue Kuwajima as a special envoy from Japan's Foreign Office, the main actors in the great drama of Chino-Japanese relations were gathering for a momentous conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The question of suspending the International Typographical Union from membership in the American Federation of Labor because of the recent vote of the union's convention to support President C.P. Howard in joining the Committee for Industrial Organization, will be considered at the quarterly meeting of the Federation's executive council on Thursday.

Captain William A. Maher, secretary of the Associated Marine Workers of America, announced last night that a meeting of his group has been called for Sunday to consider a strike by employes of tugboats and steam lighters operated in the port of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Alleged irregularities in the conduct of the WPA in Pennsylvania where the Republican national committee charges that workers are being forced to contribute to the Democratic campaign funds, will be looked into by the Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures, Senator Lonergan, its chairman, said today, if the committee has "jurisdiction and the complaints are made in good faith."

Scheduling a 45-per cent increase in sales in 1937, the Hoover Company of North Canton, Ohio, will substantially increase its advertising budget for vacuum cleaners next year, dealers attending a sales convention yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania were told.

Debutantes of this and recent sea sons will act as manikins in the fashion revue "Fashions Around the Clock," a feature of the entertainment tonight and tomorrow night at the two-day Knickerbocker Hospital Fair in behalf of the charity wards and ambulance divisions of the hospital, to be opened formally this afternoon at 2,040 Broadway by Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The Department of Agriculture said today that cotton stocks carried over this year were a little lower in grade and somewhat shorter in length than last year's carry-over. The carry-over on July 31 was 5,409,400 bales, compared with 7,208,500 bales the year before.
ROME, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The sale of the "travel lira," offered to tourists at a discount to induce them to visit Italy, was temporarily suspended today in view of the monetary devaluation decree.

A suit alleging that the "Rockefeller group" acquired control of the Pan American Oil Petroleum and Transport Company from Edward L. Doheny and through a conspiracy involving a series of intricate financial transactions stripped the company of its surplus, and that it has yielded $1,000,000,000 income since the group obtained control, was argued yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McLaughlin.

In the Aleutian Islands a skull is dug up which once encased a brain almost as big as TURGENIEV'S -- biggest on record. Even Dr. ALES HRDLICKA, who made the measurements, cannot escape the conclusion that the extinct savage who possessed so much gray matter must have been exceptionally intelligent.

TOPEKA, Oct. 5. -- Harry Colmery, new national commander of the American Legion, at the welcoming ceremonies attended by Governor Landon here today, pledged maintenance of the nonpolitical policy of the American Legion.
With exhibits ranging from bed warmers to weather vanes, the eighth New York Antiques Exposition was opened to the public last night following a preview for collectors yesterday afternoon.

A license that would permit the sale of beer, wine and liquor in restaurants and replace existing beer licenses and wine licenses, was advocated by the State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association, which opened a two-day conference yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Oct. 5. -- Following long years of Republican training at crediting the party in power at Washington with the economic prosperity obtaining at any given time, West Virginia appears headed for an endorsement of the administration of President Roosevelt on Nov. 3 second only to the majority it gave him in 1932.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5. -- Major Lester D. Gardner arrived in Moscow at 11:18 this morning, having embarked on the dirigible Hindenburg at Lakehurst, N.J., at 11:17 Wednesday night. He completed a journey of more than 5,000 miles by commercial airlines in sixty-eight hours fifty-two minutes flying time.

The Whitney Museum of American Art will open to the public this afternoon at 1 o'clock its exhibition of work produced under the Treasury Department's art projects, which, admirably installed, fills the galleries on the first and second floors.

VAN METER, Iowa, Oct. 5 (AP). -- Bob Feller, the Iowa farm boy who set a new American League strikeout record in his first weeks of big-time baseball, found a crowd of 6,000 in his home town of 400 population when he returned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP). -- The sugar section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that 527,999 tons of sugar remained after 1936 quotas of 4,524,911 tons had been charged against off-shore quota areas.

Triad Credit Exchange, also Artleigh Products, Inc., in 1,133 Broadway; Robert H. Knobe, paper boxes, in 49 W. 24th St.; Abe Garfiel Co., dresses, additional space in 247 W. 35th St.; Etkin Banner Co., additional space in 230 W. 38th St.; Clotilde Cutrona, embroideries, Jacquard Knitting Machine Co., additional space, and Mac Konner and Abe Picheney, silks and woolens, additional space, in 270 W. 39th St.; Spear Co., brokers.

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- Realization sales forced opening quotations on the Boerse here today down 1 point all along the line, but profit-taking did not materially affect the general tendency of the market, which turned firm at the close, with early losses partly recovered.
Francisco de los Rios, newly appointed Spanish Ambassador to the United States, and his family are among the passengers due today from Europe on the French liner Ile de France.

Speeding down steep mountain grades, through tunnels and over bridges, two passenger trains and a fast freight covered the route of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad from St. Louis to New York yesterday morning in something less than one minute.

Messages of sympathy poured in yesterday to the family of Jesse Isidor Straus. From France, where he was so recently Ambassador, the President of the republic and Mme. Lebrun joined in a cable of condolence. Yvon Delbos, French Minister of Foreign Affairs, cabled separately that he would "long remember one who had labored so well in the cause of Franco-American amity."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener came to Washington today to thank government officials for their cooperation in the airship Hindenburg's "demonstration" flights here in the past few months, and to canvass possibilities for their renewal next year and the starting of permanent schedules.
Mr. Hinton's excellent article on the power situation in THE TIMES of Sept. 27 unfortunately perpetuates a very misleading statement erroneously attributed to me, as follows:

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 5 (AP). -- Ocean Roll, a Strolling Player colt owned by Cary T. Grayson, galloped to a surprise victory in the fourth race, outstanding event of the program at Laurel today. The contest, waged over the six-furlong course, drew a field of ten juveniles. A crowd of 10,000 was on hand.

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- The prospects of the five-power conference planned to devise a substitute for the now historic Locarno treaty are fast fading. Originally set for September, then reluctantly postponed by its originators until late October, the conference, it is quite evident, will not be held then.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- As the government of Premier Leon Blum banned tonight all demonstrations that might cause trouble by "action or reaction," Cabinet leaders and Mr. Blum mapped a swift court fight to wipe out the French Social party of Colonel Francois de la Rocque, whose followers battled in the streets with Communists yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- The Princeton regulars were excused from active work today as Coach Fritz Crisler started practice for the Rutgers game next Saturday with an hour's scrimmage between the scrubs and his second and third elevens.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- A poll of the Princeton University student body, showing 70 per cent of those voting in favor of the election of Governor Alf M. Landon as President, was announced this morning by The Daily Princetonian.

Declaring that America needs religion more than ever today, Cardinal Hayes, in a sermon yesterday at Holy Cross Catholic Church, 331 West Forty-second Street, warned that those who believe in God must unite in a solid front to combat growing irreligious tendencies in the nation.

Commodity futures prices were generally mixed in quiet trading yesterday. Raw sugar contracts recovered moderately, while coffee futures again were under pressure. In the cash markets, cotton, cocoa, butter, tin and silk were higher, while wheat, rye, oats, flour, rubber and hides were lower.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- John R. Hubbel, 46-year-old investment broker, of Kew Gardens, L.I., committed suicide in the Hunterdon County Jail here today by drinking poison which he had carried in a vial in his pocket.

In two European capitals, during the past two days, the authorities have had to decide what to do when rioting breaks out in the streets. London met the problem in one way, Paris in another. The Governments in both countries had a similar objective, or determination, but moved toward it each in a separate fashion.

SAINT-JEA_N-DF_LUZ, France, Oct. 5 (P). -- Spanish insurgents and government defenders on the Bay of Biscay front fought today for control of the important town of Eibar, twenty-five miles from Bilbao. The Loyalists and the insurgents both claimed victory in the fierce fighting.

The Industrial Rayon Corporation and subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 showed a net profit of $923,557 after depreciation, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. The profit equals $1.52 each on 606,500 no-par shares of capital stock.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5. -- The Soviet Government is embarking on a naval building program intended to win it power on the sea comparable to Soviet land power, attained by the creation of the largest and one of the best equipped armies in the world, it was shown today in an editorial article in the newspaper Pravda.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Trenton Central High School's new quarter-mile track, built as a WPA project, was dedicated today with Glenn Cunningham and Archie San Romani winning their events easily despite handicaps allowed their opponents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- A rank-and-file committee of seamen led by Joseph Curran of New York called at the offices of the Maritime Commission today and suggested that the commission ask President Roosevelt to suspend the labor provisions of the new Merchant Marine Subsidy Act for ninety days so that the seamen might put their views before Congress.

GENEVA, Oct. 5. -- An effort to extend the Anglo-Franco-American accord on monies into a general reduction of trade barriers began today in the Economic Committee of the League of Nations with W.S. Morrison, Financial Secretary to the British Treasury, and Finance Minister Paul Bastid of France making promises and threats to this end.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Two subordinates of Ellis H. Parker Sr., chief of Burlington County detectives, were arrested here today on charges of perjury before the Federal grand jury investigating the alleged kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Massachusetts supported New York today in demanding from the Supreme Court a reconsideration of the five-to-four decision in the Tipaldo case by which the New York Minimum Wage Law was declared unconstitutional June 1.

DENVER, Oct. 5 (AP). -- James K. Boughner, who played on Princeton's first football team sixty-seven years ago, celebrated his eighty-eighth birthday today and wishes present-day football stars were not "so grim" about the game.

Governor Lehman will be formally notified of his renomination as Democratic candidate for Governor at ceremonies at the National Democratic Club tonight. He will deliver his official speech of acceptance to an invited group of about 400 persons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Agriculture Department officals said today that retail and wholesale meat dealers in New York City would appear as government witnesses in support of charges that the Swift and Armour packing companies had violated the Packers and Stockyards Act.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., obtained the award yesterday of a new issue of $3,600,000 of bridge and park bonds of Allegheny County, Pa., on a bid of 100.638 for 2 1/4s. The bonds, which will be dated Oct. 1, 1936, and mature on Oct. 1, 1937, to 1966, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.40 to 2.25 per cent, according to maturity.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- There were excited dealings in the stock markets here today, especially in the international list, following Saturday's strength in Wall Street. Under the lead of the war loan, British funds responded to renewed investment buying.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- A brilliant 69 on the first eighteen, one below par, gave Walter Doyle, Hickory Golf Club pro, and his partner, Pat Circelli of Rockwood Hall, a lead which their fellow-professionals could not duplicate in the Westchester Scotch foursome championship today at the Old Oaks Country Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- More than 800 White Plains taxpayers appeared at a public hearing tonight and protested to the City Council against a proposed increase in the tax rate of $5.14 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation for 1937. Scores of taxpayers addressed the Council.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 5. -- The race for the George Vanderbilt Cup, which will be held on the new Roosevelt Raceway next Monday, was ordered cut from the originally planned 400 miles to 300 miles by the contest board of the American Automobile Association today.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- Republican leaders today accused the Democrats of registering at least 10,000 persons illegally in Philadelphia in anticipation of the November election.

Members of the Board of Aldermen must be praying that it doesn't snow next Winter. If it does, they are likely to be smothered in the drifts. By the time the blizzards begin to rage most people will have forgotten the charge that unless a certain gentleman was paid a large fee the local board having charge of the matter would never approve a contract for snow removal machinery desired by the city.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 5. -- Paced by the brilliant Mrs. John D. Crews of White Beeches, a formidable New Jersey team today turned back a strong aggregation representing the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, 10 -- 5, in the twelfth annual intersectional match for the Mrs. J.J. Thomson Trophy.

Newest of the Technicolor pictures, the Twentieth Century-Fox version of Helen Hunt Jackson's "Ramona," comes to the Criterion tonight with a cast that includes Loretta Young, Don Ameche, Pedro de Cordoba, Katherine de Mille, Kent Taylor and Pauline Frederick.

ROME, Oct. 5. -- The general assembly of the Institute of International Agriculture opened this morning in the presence of a large gathering that included members of the diplomatic corps, government officials and other prominent persons.

After an accumulation of hedge selling and liquidation had been absorbed at slight early declines, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday developed a steady undertone as domestic and foreign trade buying absorbed contracts and ring traders covered late in the day.

Frank S. Prial, defeated by William F. Brunner for the Democratic nomination for President of the Board of Aldermen, won a victory yesterday in his suit for a recanvass of the vote on the ground that the Brunner count was fraudulent.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 5. -- Former Prime Minister R.B. Bennett of Canada is finding many things to admire in Australia, but former Prime Minister W.M. Hughes's method of picking winning race horses by pricking a card with a pin is not among them.

One of the things that is not being figured today in cotton consumption is the effect of the Left movement in all the countries of the world toward a rising living standard. If the teeming millions of the Orient as well as the Occident are to have better wages and living conditions, the effect on cotton consumption will be tremendous.

The October meeting of the West Side Taxpayers Association will be held on Thursday evening in the Hotel McAlpin. Walter J. Millard of the Citizens Charter Campaign Committee will explain the proposed new city charter.

Madison Avenue, which in the course of a century has progressed from a rutted country cowpath to one of the leading commercial and residential thoroughfares of the city, was formally reopened for another century of progress at ceremonies yesterday in which Mayor La Guardia took part, marking the thoroughfare's centennial.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 5. -- The American press, with other publicity media, has been a "dominant factor" in arresting crime among youth, Hugh Clegg, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told the fifteenth annual newspaper institute of New Jersey Press Association at Rutgers University here today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5. -- Sir Joseph Barcroft of Cambridge University, one of the world's leading physiologists, told a Yale audience today of two perilous journeys to the twilight zone of the mind, in one of which he deliberately froze his body to the point of unconsciousness to find out what happens to the mind in the early stages of freezing to death.

A twenty-story building accommodating 108 families will be erected at the south corner of Riverside Drive and Seventy-third Street, according to plans filed yesterday with the Department of Buildings by Boak Paris, architects. The cost of construction was estimated at $800,000.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, revealed yesterday that he would not overrule the decision of Dean Herbert E. Hawkes denying reinstatement at the university of Robert Burke of Youngstown, Ohio, athlete and president-elect of the junior class.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 5 (AP). -- The Workers Council of the General Electric Company announced tonight that the company had agreed to a stabilization plan under which wages of 12,000 workers here will he maintained in line with the Federal cost of living index.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- William Hard, political commentator for the Republican National Committee, said tonight that charges of political coercion of WPA employes in Pennsylvania find "abundant support."

MADRID, Tuesday, Oct. 6. -- Insurgent Moorish cavalry yesterday charged government defenses at Navalperal, about thirty-five miles northwest of Madrid, but were repulsed with heavy losses, the government reported.

Colonel William E. Hoyer, director of the WPA investigating unit which turned up scores of bogus addresses in a survey of the welfare needs of absent relief workers last April, charged yesterday that WPA officials had hampered his efforts to continue the inquiry and said that his "self-respect" made it necessary for him to resign.

Booking more business in August than during that month in any year since 1929, the furniture industry continued to forge ahead, according to a survey of the industry issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants and auditors. New orders in August, while 15 per cent under the July "market" totals, showed an increase of 48 per cent over the corresponding month of 1935.

The convention of the cap and millinery department of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, had before it yesterday resolutions calling for peace in the conflict between the American Federation of Labor and the C.I.O. as leaders on both sides were continuing their efforts for an amicable adjustment of the controversy that threatens to split the labor movement.

The New York Telephone Company will oppose in the courts the $37,000,000 increase in the tentative assessments on its properties on the assessment rolls for 1937, it was disclosed yesterday by Victor E. Cooley, vice president of the company.

Dudley Field Malone, Assistant Secretary of State and Collector of the Port of New York under President Wilson, wrote a letter yesterday to Governor Landon, offering his support to the Republican nominee for President.

Switching from farm problems to urban questions, Justice William F. Bleakley, the Republican candidate for Governor, yesterday continued his attack upon New Deal Democracy by charging that the administration of relief under WPA is "100 per cent political in character."

TOPEKA, Oct. 5. -- Governor Landon today satisfied a delegation of Missouri wets as to his position on prohibition, declared for legislation to check lynching and discussed with Colonel Arthur W. Little, methods of winning back to the Republican party Negroes who deserted it to vote for President Roosevelt in 1932.

Baron and Baroness Raymond de Luze were dinner hosts last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Mr. and Mrs. Pierre C. Cartier, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Garreau-Dombasle, Dr. and Reginald M. Burbank, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Wildman and H. Morin de Linclays.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Oct. 5. -- Forecasts of an economic era of mass production of homes and other capital goods, and of an air-conditioned indoor life making vacations in Winter more popular than in Summer; featured today's session on "new industries" at the twenty-third annual National Business Conference at Babson Park, Wellesley Hills.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- In a communique justifying its action in permitting Communists to meet yesterday and breaking up with a tremendous show of force a counter-demonstration by Colonel Francois de la Rocque's followers, the Ministry of the Interior announced today that henceforth it would permit no meetings susceptible of provoking civic trouble.

Those British ambassadors with the portfolio of Gilbert and Sullivan pieces last evening led the faithful into the seventh program of the current Martin Beck festival of gladness. Led them, also, into the realm of "Patience," which is not too often performed along Broadway and so is welcomed more especially by the thorough students among the Savoyards.
The Presbytery of New York voted yesterday to wage a temperance campaign at the first meeting of the season in the parish house of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

More than 400 students and faculty members of Wagner Lutheran Memorial College together with guests attended a meeting last night in the college auditorium at Grynes Hill, Staten Island, which marked the start of a month's celebration of the institution's fiftieth anniversary.

Two field hockey teams from Great Britain and a trio of British auto racers arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to test their skill against American representatives this month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5. -- Tarzan is to transfer his activities from the jungle on Metro's back lot to the trees and streams of Sol Lesser's near-by studio. Lesser has purchased the rights to five of Edgar Rice Burroughs's stories and is negotiating with Metro for the services of Johnny Weissmuller to continue the series.
GENEVA, Oct. 5. -- The League of Nations took the pulse of its disarmament conference today and found it feeble and fluttering.

Matty Mazza and Ferdy Catropa, Peninsula team, posted a card of 73 -- 4 -- 69 to take top net honors in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association one-day amateur-pro Scotch foursome competition on the rolling North Hills Golf Club links in Douglaston yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- The wheat market made a firm start and an easy finish today. Strength in Liverpool resulted in a small advance at the opening of the Board of Trade here, but the upturn was short-lived, and with commission houses persistent sellers in small lots, a recession of 1 3/4 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel from the high point followed.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 6. -- THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial of Sept. 29 and a Shanghai dispatch to THE TIMES on the day before, which were repeated to Tokyo by Ambassador Hirosi Saito, elicited tonight from Eiji Amau, Foreign Office spokesman, one clear-cut denial and certain explanations of Japan's policy in China.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Bullard of Pomfret, Conn., who were wed recently, are at the Homestead. Mrs. Bullard is the former Miss Jane L. Longnecker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Parke Longnecker of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Virtually all commercially important countries participated in the revival of foreign trade during the first half of this year and nearly as many had larger imports than during the corresponding period last year, according to an analysis issued today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

In advocating the purchase of Lindenwald, Martin Van Buren's home at Kinderhook, THE TIMES omits an argument of appealing force. May I suggest stressing the point that at Lindenwald lived not only the first citizen of New York State to be elected President but also the first citizen of New York City, indeed the first American, to attain to international fame as an author?

In the ordinary course of events the United States Postoffice Department would be just an innocent bystander in so far as the world series is concerned, but the Giant victory yesterday cost the government a sizable amount in postal receipts, even though the revenue will be more than compensated for in admission taxes.

The percentage of Negroes in the administrative staff of the Emergency Relief Bureau is nearly double that in the general population, according to the first annual report of the ERB's advisory committee on Negro problems.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP). -- President P.K. Wrigley of the Cubs said tonight that while several changes would be made in the club for 1937 they would not involve Manager Charlie Grimm.

A fundamental weakness of the $436,000,000 transit unification plan sponsored by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., the Transit Commission indicated at an adjourned public hearing yesterday, is the strong probability that the $110,000,000 of city bonds to be issued as part of the purchased price of company properties cannot be exempted from the constitutional debt limit imposed by the State.

While Bishops, priests and parents listened, Catholic mothers urged last night that children of American Catholic families, to receive the best religious training in the home, should have freedom of expression and inquiry and parental example consistent with church teachings.
Mayor La Guardia asked twenty members of the Board of Aldermen yesterday to reconsider their action in blocking purchase by the city of $956,250 of new snow-fighting equipment.

Mrs. Henry McIlvain, who had the bad racing luck to claim a lame horse at Belmont Park, got the best of the turn of the wheel as Jamaica opened its Fall meeting yesterday. Her color-bearer, L.B. Wilson, trained by her husband and the most consistent winner in the stable, earned the featured Raunt Purse when most had given up hope.
BURGOS, Spain, Oct. 5. -- Fascist officers disclosed tonight that several hundred of their fellows have been besieged for more than two months in a mountain chapel in Southern Spain.

The Rev. Joseph H. Lookstein has been elected rabbi of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, 117 East Eighty-fifth Street, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan, a trustee of the congregation.
ATHENS, Greece, Oct. 5. -- Despite a dash across Europe to make up lost time, I landed here at 7:25 P.M. today, a day behind schedule in my tour around the world.

Aldo Spoldi of Italy knocked out Orvil Drouillard of Canada in 59 seconds of the fifth round at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. It was Spoldi's eleventh straight victory. He weighed 135 3/4 and Drouillard, 133 1/2.
Footsore and weary detectives continued a hunt in Prospect Park last night for three red-headed boys -- brothers -- who left their home on Sunday afternoon and did not return.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Mrs. Lucy Connell Moore, 22 years old, of Marianna, Fla., was admitted today with her husband, Henry E. Moore, to practice before the Supreme Court. Mrs. Moore is said to be the youngest woman so honored.

The failure of the nine judges of General Sessions to provide last Summer more than three parts of their courts for the trials of cases against Tombs prisoners was criticized yesterday in a report of the Prison Association of New York, made public by its general secretary, E.R. Cass.
GENEVA, Oct. 5. -- The League of Nations Council had its first business session in its new public chamber tonight and devoted it entirely to the Free City of Danzig.

A new system for two-way telephone communication over electric light or power wires was demonstrated at the auditorium of the New York Museum of Science and Industry in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, last night. The device, which is called "carrier call," is operated by one person plugging into the nearest electric light socket to talk with another plugged into a similar outlet near at hand.

HYDE PARK, Oct. 5. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, informed President Roosevelt today that he believed, as the result of a careful study, 90 per cent of the labor vote would be cast for Mr. Roosevelt in the election Nov. 3.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 5. -- The British Labor party, which opened its annual conference here today, devoted the morning session to damning the Baldwin government for its "cowardly weakness" in allowing yesterday's Fascist demonstration in the East End of London.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- On the second day of official trading, the new franc strengthened with respect to the dollar and sterling, closing at 21.40 to the dollar, against 21.45 on Friday and at 105.43 to the pound, against 105.45.
Jimmy McLarnin weighed 145, eight pounds more than Tony Canzoneri, for their fight at Madison Square Garden last night. Billy Cavanagh refereed and the judges were Abe Goldberg and Charley Lynch.

Four men, three of whom entered the water in their clothing, contributed yesterday to the rescue of Thomas Clarksen, 40 years old, after he jumped or fell into the East River at the foot of Broad Street at 1 P.M., according to the police.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 5 (AP). -- The Berkshire Fine Spinning Associates shut down one of their three Fall River mills tonight, and announced plans to liquidate or move the plant. The action followed the calling of a strike earlier in the day by the United Textile Workers Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Sept. 30 shows increases for the week of $72,000,000 in total loans and investments, $117,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $45,000,000 in time deposits, $84,000,000 in deposit balances of domestic banks, $56,000,000 in deposit balances of foreign banks, $61,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $132,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and a decline of $17,000,000 in borrowings.

The cause of world peace has arrived at absolute bankruptcy. There is no sensible and hopeful plan before the world today to avoid the tragedy of a new world war in which our country is almost certain to be involved. The only possible chance for an orderly progress of civilization rests on the taking, by the United States, of the initiative in a system of peaceful evolution.

FRANCO-SPANISH FRONTIER, Oct. 5. -- General Francisco Franco, supreme commander of the Spanish insurgents, announced today that his preparations for the siege of Madrid were complete and that a general offensive was imminent.

It seems they counted those Giants out too soon, which in itself is rather inexcusable. For they had counted out this same most extraordinary team away back in July only to see it come dashing back into a world series, and so it comes to pass that, incredible as it may appear, this same world series is still with us.

Industrial and residential property figured in New Jersey deals reported by brokers yesterday. A two-family dwelling, at 305 Fifteenth Street, West New York, was sold by Christopher Spiegel to John Buenzli, J.I. Kislak, Inc., reports. The property had been owned by Mr. Spiegel for twenty-five years.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 5. -- Seven assorted fresh and salt water anglers of varying degrees of experience, all reluctant to lay the ghost of the 1936 fishing season, came down here yesterday to look into the weakfish situation in Great South Bay and found the patient very much alive indeed.

Reflecting the combined effects of substantial reorders on apparel and increased commitments for the Christmas holiday period, trade in major wholesale markets got off to a good start for the week yesterday. Mail orders showed a sharp gain over the last few weeks and more buyers were in the markets.

Detective Thomas P. Mason of the narcotic squad, who six months ago broke up a narcotic ring preying on soldiers at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn by serving three months as a "private," was stabbed in the left side of the abdomen and seriously wounded last night as he sought to arrest an 18-year-old youth on the steps of a tenement at 244 West Sixty-second Street.

BOSTON, Oct. 5. -- By and large, the President is the issue in this election, taking the nation as a whole. But in Massachusetts two other personalities come into conflict with his own in a manner to turn the odds against Mr. Roosevelt in his effort to repeat his victory of 1932 in this State.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 5. -- Mrs. Gross R. Scruggs of Dallas, president of the National Council of Federated Garden Clubs, and Mrs. Forest Huttenlocher of Des Moines, also of the council, were principal speakers at the opening meeting of the South Atlantic Garden Club today at the Greenbrier.

ROME, Oct. 5. -- A Cabinet council lasting only a half hour -- a record for speed in view of the far-reaching consequences of its decisions -- approved today without discussion a series of decrees submitted by Premier Benito Mussolini devaluing the lira and aligning it with the dollar and the pound sterling.

Business and civic leaders met yesterday afternoon in the offices of J.P. Morgan Co. to organize the 1936 United Hospital Campaign Committee of the United Hospital Fund of New York. The committee this year will seek to raise $2,800,000 to meet the deficit of the seventy-nine recipients of the fund.

It was to be expected that the Republican National Committee would have a case of jitters over the balance sheet of this country's international payments for the first half of 1936. That balance shows a substantial increase of imports, and every Republican national committeeman knows that imports are a frightful menace, "depriving American farmers of an "honest living and American workmen "of real jobs and real wages."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- American advertising leaders were urged today by Bennett Chapple, vice president of the American Rolling Mill Company, to combine in a nation-wide movement to overcome "false statements from the many radical camps that have grown so rapidly in the United States."

By completing eighteen forward passes last Sunday, the Pittsburgh Pirates took the lead as the best passing team in the National League, according to the statistics compiled yesterday. The Pirates, who now have a record of twenty-nine successful efforts in sixty attempts are leading the New York Giants who have completed seventeen of their thirty-eight aerials.

By exercising great ingenuity the authors of "Lend Me Your Ears!" which was acted at the Mansfield last evening, have contrived to write a comedy without a sense of humor. This rare feat is sometimes accomplished in libraries, in the pages of academic journals or at steamer concerts in which the passengers perform.

The announcement yesterday morning that Italy was joining in the general "realignment" of European currencies by devaluing the lira 40.93 per cent was received with approval in the financial markets yesterday.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses wrote to Colonel Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, yesterday asking if the Federal Government would furnish relief personnel at a cost of $2,000,000 to supplement city personnel for the maintenance of the park system during the 1937 calendar year.

Peter F. Colleran, 45 years old, Mayor of Massapequa Park, L.I., and Michael J. Brady, 40, peace justice-elect of the same place, were arrested there yesterday on an indictment by the New York County grand jury, charging they defrauded a man in a real estate transaction in 1934.
FREE CITY OF DANZIG, Oct. 5. -- The arresting of Socialists continued here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- More radio channel allocations for educational and cultural programs and better time for them were urged today before the Federal Communications Commission at the opening of a two-week hearing.

Protection of night club patrons against unadvertised extra charges was promised yesterday by Second Deputy Police Commissioner John J. Sullivan in passing on a complaint brought against the French Casino by James A. Leftwich of 65 University Place, a former newspaper man.
Purchase of an uptown corner by Trinity Church featured the Manhattan and Bronx realty trading reported yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA administrator; Victor F. Ridder, his predecessor in office, and other WPA and city officials threw open to the public last night an exhibition designed to show the nature and scope of WPA white-collar projects.

Registration in the city for the November election totaled 360,478 for the first day, a tabulation at 2:30 this morning showed. This is an all-time high mark, being 85,578 above the previous record, made in 1932, when 274,900 persons qualified themselves to vote on the first day they had a chance to.

TWO recent pieces of news render Captain B. H. Liddell Hart's "The War in Outline" (Random House, $2) especially timely. One is from the papers of last Friday. In convention at West Point, 300 members of an American military organization passed a resolution "noting with extreme regret" that David Lloyd George, in the latest volume of his memoirs, had made "unwarranted criticisms" of General Pershing's conduct as commander of the American troops in France.
A number of penthouses and duplexes were among apartments reported rented yesterday. The list included the following:

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- New legislation against "provocative" demonstrations may be introduced by the government as a result of yesterday's turmoil in the East End in which 268 persons were injured in demonstrating against a planned Fascist procession.

Gene Buck appeared for examination before trial yesterday in Municipal Court. Peter J. Haberkorn, attorney for the Tyson Theatre Ticket Bureau, Inc., of 136 West Forty-sixth Street, questioned him regarding $195 worth of tickets sold by the agency, allegedly to Mr. Buck, between Oct. 21, 1929, and June 26. 1930.

For "aspersions" and "calumnies" this is the favorite month; and it would be vain to remonstrate against old custom. Still, there are depths that shouldn't be reached and subjects that shouldn't be broached. Besides, if the broaching and the depths can't be avoided, there should be some little glaze of possibility put on political romance.
Judge BLEAKLEY has already begun to chide Governor LEHMAN for his bad marksmanship in making budget estimates, and confronts him with the following record:

Five minutes after Iron Horse Lou Gehrig had collared Harry Danning's bounder, raced to first base for the final out of the 1936 world series, shoved the ball determinedly into his pocket and dashed off the field, the Yankee clubhouse was a bedlam.
Harry Tipper, executive vice president of the National Foreign Trade Association, last night declared that the devaluation of the franc would have a beneficial effect on world trade.

Reports of the race meetings at Saratoga and Aqueduct held during August and early September show the same growth in prosperity and public favor as has distinguished New York racing since the start of the racing year.

Two policemen and one alleged rioter were injured, seven persons were arrested and the office of a Home Relief Bureau at 8-12 Avenue D, near East Third Street, was virtually wrecked about 5 P.M. yesterday during a riot in and about the bureau.

Dispatches from Minnesota report that some Democrats in that State, who have been nominated for Congress or for local offices, refuse to submit to the decree that their party must be butchered to make a Farmer-Labor holiday. Not a few members of the Democratic party threaten to vote the Republican ticket if they do not find their own space on the official ballot.

During the last week speculative interest in the stock market has risen to the highest level witnessed since last February, when trading topped 4,500.000 shares on two occasions. The turnover in stocks has been rising steadily; outsiders have been crowding brokers' board rooms and the number of tips on "good buys" have multiplied.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- Among the more urgent matters new engaging German official attention, and found highly convenient for postponing such disagreeable matters as participation in the new Locarno conference, is the fast-approaching outcome in Spare.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, denied today that peace overtures had been opened by any members of the committee to settle its controversy with the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,987,800 barrels, compared to 3,030,050 in the preceding week, a drop of 42,250, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 123,800 barrels more than the calculation of 2,864,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for September.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Ruth Gordon, American actress, took the British stage by storm tonight, making her London debut in Wycherley's Restoration comedy, "The Country Wife," at the Old Vic. The play is presented by Helen Hayes in association with Gilbert Miller.
