Mrs. Martha C. Pease, 60 years old, wife of W. Albert Pease Jr., real estate broker, died at 5:10 A.M. yesterday in New York Hospital, about an hour after she had jumped or fallen from the window of her bedroom on the second floor of 417 Park Avenue.

Among those who entertained parties last night at the formal opening of the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's were Mr. and Mrs. James B. Lowell whose guests included Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Lowell and Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Baldwin. Another dinner there was given by Mrs. Barrow S. Weeks for Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin V.M. La Rue and John J. Murphy.

Madison Avenue, celebrating this week its hundredth anniversary, figured prominently in commercial rentals reported yesterday. Among new tenants were Harry F. Koopman, Boston antique dealer, who has leased the store and basement in 799 Madison Avenue, and Barnett Svec, jewelers, who leased in 559 Madison Avenue, between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- German diplomacy, though not involved, apparently approves whole-heartedly the Pan-American peace and neutrality projects recently outlined in Washington and more especially the plan to extend the United States neutrality laws to all American countries.
Registration in the city continued at a rapid pace yesterday, with crowds of would-be voters waiting outside registration booths for a chance to qualify themselves to vote in the November election.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 6. -- J.Y. Christmas's Rough Time showed excellent speed today in winning the featured Magothy Purse. The Grand Time gelding scampered to the wire two and a half lengths in front of Gay Balko, half of the favored Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt entry, with Moon Harvest third.

The chief market in New York for trailers is the business one, Captain J.L. Mifsud, president of the Vagabond Coach Sales Company, which has just opened sales rooms at 236 West Fifty-ninth Street, declared yesterday. Having sold forty trailers to one shirt company alone, with the possibility of another thirty-two, and twenty-five trailers to another shirt manufacturer, he felt that a huge market will be opened up for trailers as mobile sales rooms.

DETROIT, Oct. 6. -- M.E. Coyle, president and general manager of the Chevrolet Motor Company, announced today that $26,000,000 had been expended in retooling, new machinery and rearranging of the plants and assembly lines of the company for production of the 1937 models to be announced early in November.

It ended like an ordinary ball game. There were no extra flourishes or furbelows, but just the natural ending to any one of 154 encounters during the season. Lou Gehrig touched first base for the final out, tucked the ball in his back pocket and raced for the clubhouse.

There will be general regret that Chairman HAMILTON can stay in our town only four days on his present visit. There have been some interesting occupants of that office. There has been no other so sagacious, judicious and stimulating. His enthusiasm and energy are such that he seems to identify himself with his candidate.
For the first time since it was established the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, now has work by child artists in its permanent collection.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Although the gold bloc has collapsed and the managed currency idea has spread throughout Europe, Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, insisted tonight that the world would have to return to the gold standard in the end.

Twenty-nine worshippers of Father John Divine, Harlem's Negro "Dean of the Universe," landed in Night Court last night. Twenty-two were arrested on disorderly conduct charges for alleged blocking of registration; seven for refusing to leave the West 123d Street police station when the 22 were being booked.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6. -- At 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon the China Clipper of Pan American Airways will take off from San Francisco Bay for a 8,200 mile flight to Manila. The trip, the fifty-second crossing of the Pacific since survey flights were started last year, is the first of two final shakedown voyages before the starting of regular passenger service on Oct. 21.

I read your editorial "Fire With Fire" with keen interest, especially the opening sentences which read: "Some Democratic leaders in Pennsylvinia admit truth in the charge that they are improperly trying to make use of WPA workers politically. It is not denied that in many instances these men have been asked to contribute to the party campaign fund, on the ground that they owe their jobs to a Democratic administration.

Marcus L. Kenner, president of the National Association of the Deaf, made public yesterday replies from President Roosevelt, Governor Landon and Norman Thomas to queries as to the removal of barriers against government employment of deaf persons.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 6. -- Business and politics do not mix and the General Motors Corporation is not in politics, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the corporation, said tonight to 600 field representatives of the Olds Motor Works at their annual convention dinner in the Hotel Olds here.

EN ROUTE TO KANSAS CITY, Oct. 6. -- During the past week this correspondent has sought to cast the political horoscopes of Pennsylvania and New England with many politicians, newspaper writers and editors, labor leaders, business men, financiers, a couple of clergymen, a few women and an assortment of folk casually encountered.

Price changes were mixed in a light turnover yesterday in the markets for commodity futures here, with fluctuations narrow in range. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats, eggs, silk and cocoa advanced, the last named to a new high mark, while cotton, butter, lard, rubber and tin declined.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 6. -- Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander Second Corps Area, stationed at Governors Island, and Mrs. McCoy were guests tonight at a dinner given in their honor by Major Gen. John L. Hines, chief of staff, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Hines in their home, Rocky Gap.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler got the fourth annual National Socialist Winter relief campaign off to a noisy start tonight with a speech that again hurled defiance at bolshevism, castigated democracy for its toleration of Spanish atrocities and explained why the German people turned to National Socialism after experiments with democracy for thirteen years.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 6. -- The Aeolus, German flying boat making test flights for the Deutsche Lufthansa air lines, landed off the Manor Haven Airport here today at 2:35 P.M., completing a direct hop from Horta in the Azores in 19 hours and 25 minutes.

More than a score of American portraits, chiefly from the first third of the nineteenth century, have been placed on exhibition at the Ferargil Gallery. Director Price hag brought together canvases by Ralph Earl, Robert Feke, John Smibert, Jacob Eicholtz, Bass Otis and a number of anonymous artist, most of the paintings being from a private collection.

Mounted Patrolman John P. Morrow stood up in his stirrups in the central drive near Lookout Hill in Prospect Park just before 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, searching the browning meadows, thinning brush and dapple-shadowed bridle path for some sign of the three little Tuckers.

MANILA, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Several hundred lepers broke out of San Lazaro Hospital today, marched through Manila streets to the Presidential Palace and protested against being held as "prisoners." For hours the afflicted hundreds paraded through the streets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6. -- "The Saint in New York," a Leslie Charteris yarn about a modern Robin Hood, which RKO announced some weeks back, is to reach the nation's screens with Fredric March as the gay adventurer and with Barbara Stanwyck as the lady in distress.

The funeral service for Jesse Isidor Straus was conducted yesterday morning in Temple Emanu-El in the presence of diplomatic representatives of the governments of the United States and France, that he had linked as Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Continued private ownership and operation of the railroads is possible only if their capital stock as well as bonds are made attractive investments for the public, E.N. Brown, chairman of the board of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific, today told the Interstate Commerce Commission in support of the management's plan for the road's reorganization.

Seventeen artists "who have made advertising an art" are the current exhibitors at the Seligmann Galleries, 3 East Fifty-first Street. What they are showing, however, is not work produced for advertising purposes, but instead work produced in free moments when they can, as the catalogue puts it, "still call art their own."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Henry P. Fletcher, counsel of the Republican National Committe, revealed today that amounts already budgeted by the committee would call for expenditure of $8,636,000 in the Presidential campaign.

The Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music yesterday announced that twenty-three scholarships have been awarded to students for courses at the institute for this season. The scholarships were awarded as a result of competitive examinations held at the school during the last two weeks.

William S. Gray Jr., president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, was elected yesterday chairman of the clearing house committee of the New York Clearing House Association at the eighty-third annual meeting of that organization He succeeds James H. Perkins, chairman of the National City Bank.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 6. -- Marshal Julius Goemboes, Premier of Hungary since 1932, died today at Nymphenburg, Germany, where he had gone last month for treatment for kidney and gall-bladder ailments. He was 50 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- President Roosevelt indicated at his press conference today that, if reelected, he would ask Congress for an extension of time for the Presidential power to devalue the currency further. He is convinced that this power should be continued for use in an emergency.

GENEVA, Oct. 6. -- The "increasingly imperious necessity of finding for the immense reservoir of the Jewish population in Central and Eastern Europe other outlets" than Palestine was stressed by Poland in a discussion of mandates today in the sixth commission of the League of Nations Assembly.

P.A.S. Franklin, chairman of the board of the International Mercantile Marine Company, will sail today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Others are Major Alford J. Williams, Lucien van Hoorn, Minister for Holland to Austria; Miss Parmela Barton, Johnny Weissmuller, Herbert Marshall, actor; John McLean, Joe (John Henry) Lewis, boxer; Robert Livingston Clarkson and Thomas J. Watson.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 6. -- John Strawbridge has a chance to gain permanent possession of the Wissahickon Cup, for which four jumpers will compete, at the annual fall meeting over the Wissahickon Farms course in Whitemarsh tomorrow. Six races are carded.

Solly Krieger, 162 1/2, Williamsburg middleweight, outpointed John Anderson, 172, of Sweden in the feature ten-round bout at the Broadway arena in Brooklyn last night. A capacity crowd of 5,000 watched the Brooklynite overcome his weight handicap with a steady two-fisted attack.

GENEVA, Oct. 6. -- The French and the British delegations jointly submitted to the Second Committee of the League of Nations Assembly today a resolution calling on the League to press on with the Anglo-France-American accord, and urging all States to cooperate to this end and "in particular relax and as soon as possible abolish the present systems of quotas and exchange controls."

Interstate Department Stores, Inc., will submit to stockholders for ratification at their annual meeting on Oct. 26 compensation contracts with three members of the company's executive committee to replace previous agreements with representatives of Lehman Brothers.

The Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game has fixed Oct. 31 as the closing date for trout fishing on the fifteen streams and ponds which were kept open after the regular season ended July 15. Fishing for black bass and calico bass also will terminate at the end of this month.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $4,496,537 after all deductions for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.61 a share on 2,042,304 average number of no par common shares.

Sharp increases in orders for Italian goods as a result of the devaluation of the lira, and on some types of Czechoslovak merchandise owing to the anticipation of a change in the value of the crown, were reported here yesterday by executives of large buying groups.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Oct. 7. -- Fearing lest excessive pressure upon Nanking for acceptance of the entire group of Japanese demands cause internal explosions in China and make it impossible for the government to negotiate, Kazue Kuwashima, chief of the East Asia Bureau of the Tokyo Foreign Office, has arrived with instructions to Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe to adopt new tactics.

Fifteen Manhattan properties, including a twelve-story structure at the southwest corner of Greenwich and Warren Streets, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday, as follows:
Amateur boxing on an international scale will be held tonight at the New York Hippodrome, the program, billed as a "post-Olympic meet," being the first of a two-night stand.

The Court of Appeals in Albany removed yesterday all legal barriers to the submission to the voters of the city on Election Day of the proposed new charter drafted by the Charter Revision Commission. The court, in a unanimous decision written by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane, ruled that the act creating the Charter Commission was constitutional.

Samuel McRoberts, chairman of the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation 8 per cent preferred stockholders' protective committee, is asking holders to help the committee in working out a plan of reorganization, which must be considered, "as the time when the amount of claims filed will become ascertainable draws closer."

A small but very rewarding exhibition of paintings by old masters opened yesterday at the Arthur U. Newton Gallery. Rubens of 1611 is represented by a dark portrait of a lady in rich costume -- exquisite hands, and the filmy ruff beautifully brushed.

A variety of properties figured in deals reported in Brooklyn yesterday. A four-story apartment house at 369 St. John's Place was purchased by Loomis J. Grossman from the Institutions Securities Company. This house is built on a plot 41 by 123 feet and rents for approximately $3,500 a year.

The band of Princeton University has been rejuvenated. Yesterday afternoon at the Princeton Club, 39 East Thirty-ninth Street, W.A.G. Le Boutillier, '10, the man principally responsible for the change, told how it came about.

A recent survey made as one of the projects of the WPA and sponsored by the Board of Education has sought to find out how many adults there are in the city who are not able to read and write the English language. The round figure 250,000 is given as the estimated number in May of this year.

An increase of 23 1/2 per cent in the receipts of the New York Postoffice for the three months just ended is an indication of "the gradual restoration to normal business conditions," according to Postmaster Albert Goldman, who spoke on the relation of the postoffice to business at a luncheon of the Lions Club yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6. -- Dick Harlow evidently believes in the "survival of the fittest" in football, for today he sent his varsity regular through a long and hard session. The Crimson has been fortunate not to have had any serious injuries, and Harlow is capitalizing on this fine break and working his boys overtime.

MADRID, Oct. 6. -- The Minister of the Interior issued an order today forbidding militiamen to search houses without special permits from the Director General of Police. This order canceled the special permits issued to the militiamen by their own committees.

Six candidates of the Union Party were listed among seventeen independent candidates for various offices who filed nominating petitions last night with the Board of Elections just before the deadline at midnight. Former State Senator John A. Hastings filed as a candidate against John J. O'Connor in the Sixteenth Congressional District, listing himself as a candidate of the Loyal Party.
MULLAN, Idaho, Oct. 6. -- Ten miners plunged to their deaths early today in the Morning Mine near this place when an elevator cable snapped.

HAVANA, Oct. 6. -- Considerable agitation was noted today among civil government officials concerning the methods of the military authorities as brought to public attention by the motion approved last night in which the House of Representatives demanded that President Miguel Mariano Gomez investigate and punish the police who detained and mistreated Representative Jose Grau Aguero.

VILLAANOVA, Pa., Oct. 6. -- From the land of Brobdignagian football material Maurice J. (Clipper) Smith has come 3,000 miles to Villanova to catty on the Notre Dame system installed by Harry Stuhldreher, now at Wisconsin.

The charge of Justice William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, that administrative salaries in the WPA were too high and that political favoritism permeated the relief organization was termed "a lot of flapdoodle" yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, charged tonight that the "crew of fanatics" conducting the New Deal's re-election campaign was turning the government into "a grab-bag for organized minorities" by their policy of promising special privileges for political support.
WITH THE SPANISH REBEL ARMY, Oct. 6. -- The Spanish Rebel army smashed nine miles closer to Madrid today and announced the "final drive" to capture the Spanish capital had begun.

THE Yanks made a bad start. Frank Crosetti broke his bat hitting a pop fly to Phi Beta Kappa Whitehead. If Fred Fitzsimmons could break a Yankee bat with each pitch the Yanks would soon be reduced to desperate straits.

The number of buyers recorded in the market during the week ended yesterday dropped under the previous week's total, but was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 975 as against 1,018 in the preceding week and 559 in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The Treasury Department's official statement of expenditures from the 1935 emergency relief appropriation showed today that 4.51 per cent of the $3,424,564,516 spent during the fiscal year ending June 30 went for administrative expenses.
BURGOS, Spain, Oct. 6 (AP). -- The Rebel headquarters reported here today:

The judges of General Sessions authorized last night a statement denying responsibility on their part for the overcrowded condition of the Tombs prison, revealed Monday by the Prison Association of New York in a report by E.R. Cass, the general secretary.
One of the sights of the last game of the series, which was denied to all baseball fans present, was in the Yankee dugout, half an hour before the contest began.

Seven new attendance and financial records were written into the world series books last night as players of the two New York clubs prepared to divide their share of the greatest gross receipts in the history of the classic, according to The Associated Press.

WARSAW, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor, linked Governor Lehman and President Roosevelt tonight as neglectful New Deal compatriots who, together, created a situation in which "the forgotten man of the Roosevelt administration" became "the farmer of his home State."

The last contingent of European auto drivers, who will compete in the George Vanderbilt Cup 300-mile race at the Roosevelt Raceway next Monday, arrived yesterday when the three French aces, Jean Wimille, Raph Bethenod and Raymond Sommer stepped off the French liner Ile de France.

After all, it seems that the astute John Golden does know what his first show of the season will be. In fact, he quietly began rehearsals last Friday, and the show will venture over to Jackson Heights on Oct. 19. Although Mr. Golden was not prepared to divulge its authorship or contents, it was learned that the play is entitled "Punches and Judy."
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 6. -- Elliott Roosevelt, son of President Roosevelt, denied tonight he ever made a contract with Anthony H. G. Fokker to sell military airplanes to Russia.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6. -- Yale took to the offensive today in its preparedness program for the Penn game Saturday. The scrimmaging, however, did not take place until after more than an hour's drill in the fundamentals.

MADRID, Oct. 6. -- The government prepared tonight to fight insurgents in the streets of Madrid. Volunteer workmen feverishly dug trenches across the city's thorough-fares and built pillboxes at street intersections.
Former Secretary of State Bainbridge Colby declared last night in a radio address that President Roosevelt had betrayed his party and its principles and was receiving the support of the Communists.

Leaving the Baroness Eva von Blixen-Finecke, who expected to make the flight with him, fuming with anger on the ground, Kurt Bjorkvall, Swedish aviator, hopped off from Floyd Bennett Airport at 7:34 A.M. yesterday on a projected non-stop flight to Stockholm.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 (AP). -- William N. McNair ended his tumultuous Mayoralty career today with an unceremonious one-sentence resignation and went back to the law office from which he emerged four years ago.
Several sales of housing properties by banks and various garage and service station deals were included in the Manhattan trading reported yesterday.

An angry accusation of hostility and prejudice against the $436,000,000 transit unification plan drawn by himself and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., was hurled at the Transit Commission at a public hearing yesterday by Samuel Seabury, special counsel to the Board of Estimate.

Under a persistent flow of hedge-selling orders throughout the day, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange slowly eased yesterday from early slight advances to close at the low levels for the session. Evening up of commitments before the Census Bureau's estimate tomorrow and October liquidation added to the supply of offerings, while buyers adhered to a policy of accumulating contracts on a scale-down.

Won't you please relieve the mind of Mr. Hamilton, Governor Landon's campaign manager, who is working himself into a state of apoplexy over the fact that President Roosevelt "allows" a certain Mr. Dubinsky, a former Socialist, to be a Democratic elector in the State of New York?

Roosevelt medals, emblematic of outstanding achievement in a particular field of human endeavor, will be awarded jointly this year to Miss Helen Keller, blind-author, and Mrs. Anne Sullivan Macy, her life-long teacher, according to the announcement of James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevelt Memorial Association.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange was active again today, although profit-taking developed in the afternoon, causing an irregular price tendency. New municipal borrowing left British funds more neglected, although they were fairly steady.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The force of public opinion caused Governor Landon to change his stand on several important questions, Arthur Krock, Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told an assemblage of New Jersey clubwomen at the Mosque Theatre here today.

Public offering was made yesterday, following the official award, of a new issue of $675,000 of Kansas City, Mo., 2 1/2 per cent and 3 1/4 per cent city hall and trafficway improvement bonds by a banking group comprising Lehman Brothers, Kean, Taylor Co., Eastman, Dillon Co. and Wheelock Cummins, Inc., of Des Moines.

" Valiant is the Word for Carrie," today's new arrival at the Paramount, introduces Gladys George to screen audiences as the Carrie Snyder of Barry Bendfield's novel, from which the film derives. Miss George's supporting east includes such players as Arline Judge, Dudley Digges, Isabel Jewell, Harry Carey and John Howard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The controversy between the WPA and the Senate Campaign Funds Committee on the one hand and various Republican spokesmen, including William Hard, on the other side over alleged political activity of WPA forces in Pennsylvania took on new fervor here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- An affidavit by Anthony Fokker, airplane designer and manufacturer, that he at one time held a contract with Elliott Roosevelt for the expected sale of fifty military airplanes to Russia at a price which would have yielded a commission of $500,000 to young Roosevelt and a like amount to himself, was made public here tonight by the Senate Munitions Investigating Committee through the office of Senator Nye, its chairman.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 6. -- A nose finish in the third heat of the 2:18 pace thrilled the spectators at the Danbury Fair today. The finish was so close that the judges deliberated for some time, while horsemen and fans milled about the stand.

The Baker Taylor Company, book wholesalers, comment that Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind," is selling more than three times as well as any other book now on the market, and that one must go back to Pearl Buck's "Sons," for a sales comparison.

Price reductions ranging from 3 to 10 cents per pound, effective today, were announced last night by the acetate division of E.I. Du Pont de Nemours Co. Announcement of the reductions, in view of the strong market situation which has prevailed in rayon yarns, occasioned considerable surprise. No statement of the reason for the decline accompanied the announcement.

VIENNA, Oct. 6. -- Thirty-nine hitherto unknown songs by Hugo Wolf received the first public hearing at two recitals in the Konzerthaus tonight and last night. These songs form part of the voluminous manuscript discoveries made in Vienna last Winter and reported then in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

All the luck at the race track never goes to one man, as has been illustrated again and again since the day an English king was willing to swap his domain for a horse. J.H. Louchheim has the champion juvenile and largest money winning 2-year-old in Pompoon, but he lost recently, via the claiming route, a horse which never did much for him, but was always promising.

NANKING, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Chinese Government officials were summoned today to confer with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, recently returned dictator, who has undertaken negotiation of Japanese demands for lessening of anti-Japanese terrorism in China.

Both in Pennsylvania and in New York great heat is developing over the alleged misuse of relief-work funds by politicians. The promise to keep politics out of WPA may have been sincere. But in a campaign like the present it is impossible to keep WPA out of politics.

WESTBURY. L.I., Oct. 6. -- A polo team called the Whites defeated the Blues, 9 to 6, at the Meadow Brook Club today, with Louis Stoddard Jr. aiding the victors considerably. With the score 6 to 6 at the end of the fourth period, Stoddard put his side ahead by accounting for a brace of goals in succession.
HENDAYE, France, Oct. 6. -- Bands of amateur "executioners" have killed secretly about 3,000 persons in Madrid, reliable advices brought by refugees from the Spanish capital reported tonight.
TOPEKA, Oct. 6. -- Governor Landon declared today that the New Deal had established a "censorship of the source of news" which, he asserted, was just as bad as a censorship of news.

WATERLOO, Iowa, Oct. 6. -- Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, opened his speaking campaign for Governor Landon here tonight with an address in which he declared that the chief issue is the maintenance "in substance as well as in form" of the American scheme of government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Ten gangs of racketeers, whose members pose as "eye specialists," operating from Maine to California, have mulcted the public of $10,000,000 during the last five or ten years, the Postoffice Department said today, in announcing that fifty persons had been arrested throughout the nation for "mail fraud," in connection with a general inquiry.

Fifteen persons, five of whom were taken to St. Vincent's Hospital, were treated by three ambulance doctors yesterday afternoon when an elevator in which they were riding dropped nine floors to a sub-basement in a loft building at 130 West Thirtieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- President Roosevelt today changed the tentative schedule for his campaign tour in the Middle West by designating Omaha, instead of Denver, as the place of his first major speech on the trip. He will speak at Omaha Saturday night and in Denver probably Monday.

GENEVA, Oct. 6. -- The delegates of twenty-eight nations, possessing 82 per cent of the world's seagoing merchant tonnage, met here today at the opening of the special maritime conference of the International Labor Organization. They will discuss for three weeks, hours of work, the manning of ships, holidays with pay for seamen, protection of seamen in accident and sickness, seamen's welfare in ports and the certification of masters and watch-keeping officers.

WESTBURY, L.I. Oct. 6. -- Eight of the entrants for the 300-mile Vanderbilt Cup race which will be held on the Roosevelt Raceway next Monday, Columbus Day, took their qualifying runs over the difficult course today.

One worthy class of people who will benefit greatly by the new money devaluations on the Continent are the copy-readers on American newspapers. Ever since the war their life has been made a burden to them by the mad dance of the currencies.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- The system of central government control over all foodstuffs was further advanced today with publication of a law according to which most truck-farm and vineyard products -- that is, most vegetables, fruits and wines, both domestic and imported -- will be marketed in the future only through a special government agency created for that purpose.

Of all the planks in the Republican platform, none is less clearly understood in the East than the promise of "tariff equivalent" payments for the farmer, and none has larger possibilities for mischief. What the Republicans propose is "to make the tariff effective" from the farmer's point of view.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The Princeton back-field combinations were continually shifted today as the Orange and Black was sent through a long drill including nearly an hour of scrimmage.

MARSEILLES, France, Oct. 6. -- The Spanish Government, with its air route increasingly menaced by insurgent planes, sent the first boat shipment of gold to France today. The steamer Campillo unloaded numerous cases of the metal here, and they were reported destined for the Bank of France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The first general investigation of the Southern class freight rate structure since 1920 was proposed today in petitions filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by twenty-four organizations of shippers, manufacturers, traffic experts and State regulatory commissions.

Several large apartments were among those reported leased yesterday in a belated rush of tenants seeking accommodations. An entire floor, consisting of eleven rooms and five baths in the cooperative apartment house at 447 East Fifty-seventh Street was leased to James H Dunning for Wm. A. White Sons, agents, it was reported by Port Burke, Inc.
The following is the text of the acceptance speech of Governor Lehman delivered last night at the National Democratic Club:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 6. -- A proposal that the speed of all motor vehicles, except those used by police officers, be mechanically limited to fifty miles an hour was made here today by E.R. Hibbart at the twenty-fifth National Safety Congress and Exposition of the National Safety Council.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 6. -- Seeded favorites in the Greenbrier Autumn tennis tournament moved with ease today into the third round of the men's singles play. The gallery was divided between this event and the Middle Atlantic intercollegiate championship.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 6. -- Lightning struck a group of Lehman High School football players and their two coaches as they were practicing on Hilltop Field this afternoon, killing one player and injuring eleven others.

All of the eighteen chain-store and mail-order houses that thus far have reported sales for September and nine months have shown increases over the corresponding periods of last year. The business of twelve companies increased more than 15 per cent and fifteen had increases of 10 per cent or more for last month.

Marshal Julius Goemboes was named Premier of Hungary in September, 1932, when disarmament and economics were the chief topics of world discussion. Hungry for fame and anxious to play a role in history, he sought to be known as a leader.

Since May the pollution of New York's air by smoke has gradually decreased. In September this pollution was .03 to .39 of a ton less than that of September last year, and yet there were 1.12 tons to each cubic mile hanging over the city. Meteorological conditions, rather than any slackening of industry, were the cause.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, educational director of the National Socialist party and of the organization known as the National Socialist Cultural Chamber, announced today that this week should be known as "War Literature Week."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, playing sub-par golf against Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol, gained a 9-and-7 victory and led the way into the second round of the Berthellyn Cup golf tournament at Huntingdon Valley today.

One hundred and twenty-five clubs entered the qualifying competition for the National Challenge Cup at a meeting of the cup committee of the United States Football Association at the Hotel Cornish Arms yesterday.

Escorted by a guard of honor in Colonial costumes, an oak tree from Montpelier, the Virginia estate of President James Madison, was planted in Madison Square at 12:30 P.M. yesterday as a feature of the celebration of the 100th anniversary being conducted all this week under the auspices of the Fifth Avenue Association.
RYE, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Something different in the one-day weekly tournaments of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association took place over the Westchester Country Club course today.

Sterling weakened again yesterday as French funds were withdrawn from London and buying of American securities from London was active. The pound touched a low mark of $4.90 3/8 and closed at $4.90 1/2 for a net loss of 1 3/8 cents. On Monday it was off 1 1/4 cents.

The first two Giant players to shake the dust of New York from their feet are Jo-Jo Moore and Mel Ott, each of whom contributed a home run to a lost cause yesterday. They are on their way South today, Moore headed for Texas and Ott for Louisiana.

World-wide tributes, including a letter from President Roosevelt, to Dr. William H. Park, retired director of the city's Bureau of Laboratories, were read yesterday at the dedication of the eight-story, $700,000 William Hallock Park Laboratory, named in his honor, at the foot of East Sixteenth Street.

The gentleman who brought suit to prevent the referendum on the proposed New York City charter gave that measure some good publicity. He also helped to remove, in advance, any doubt as to the constitutionality of the rather unusual procedure invoked by the Legislature in this instance.

Walter Matis, Carbondale (Pa.) welterweight, who goes under the ring name of Wildcat O'Connor, rallied in the closing rounds to outpoint Tony Falco of Philadelphia at the New York Coliseum last night. The winner weighed 144 and Falco 147 1/2.

ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, campaign director of the American Labor party, filed with the Secretary of State tonight petitions bearing more than 60,000 signatures. This means that there will be another column on the State ballot bearing the names of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.
The play-by-play description of the sixth and final game of the world series at the Polo Grounds yesterday follows:
Reports were current in baseball circles last night that Colonel T.L. Huston, former part owner of the Yankees, had purchased the Dodgers and had chosen Babe Ruth to manage the National League club.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 6. -- The British Labor party, in annual conference in Edinburgh, declared today by a vote of approximately 3 to 1 in favor of this country's rearming because of "the threatening attitude of dictatorships."

The Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, declared the greatest need of an afflicted world is God and an awareness of religious truths in an address last night at a dinner closing the National Catechetical Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 6. -- The powers of the National Labor Relations Board apply only to companies engaged in interstate commerce and not to those in intrastate commerce, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals declared here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- Thirteen paintings and one drawing sent here from Germany to be part of the exhibition of German art opening this week at the Pennsylvania Museum of Art have been recalled by their owners, six German art museums.

Supreme Court Justice Riegelmann in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the proposed new charter for Nassau County may be submitted to the voters of that county on election day. The act of the Legis lature approving the charter and directing its submission to the people had been attacked as unconstitutional in a suit brought by Lawrence A. Burke, Long Beach lifeguard.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- In bringing the lira into line with sterling, the dollar and the new franc, Italy is held here to have redressed the overvaluation that in recent years has been one of the main impediments to her trade.
Leading clergymen and laymen representing various denominations met yesterday to begin an intensified appeal on behalf of Christian refugees from Germany.
The overpowering force behind the Yankee bludgeons, which crushed the entire American League this year, reigns supreme in the baseball universe today.

L.C. Smith and Corona Typewriters, Inc., reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a net profit of $709,279 after depreciation, interest and Federal surtax on undistributed profits, although the company's tax returns are filed on a calendar year basis.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 6. -- Mrs. Edward A. Jones of Pittsfield entertained members of the Richmond Garden Club this afternoon at the final meeting of the season. Miss Aline Kate Fox of Fairfield, Conn., treasurer of the Garden Club of America and a zone chairman, was the speaker.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 6 (AP). -- Marmara, 4-year-old gelding which runs in the silks of Leo J. Marks, closed fast through the stretch to haul down four rivals and capture the five-and-a-half-furlong feature at Rockingham Park today.

I am an old lady, 76 years old, and I live all alone excepting for my cat, but I try to take an interest in things that are going on in the world, and I often read a paper as the people living downstairs are kind to me and let me borrow theirs. I heard them talking about our President going to a baseball game yesterday and I wanted to read about it.
ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- The Court of Appeals decided today that the village of Boonville, Oneida County, shall be allowed to operate its electric-power plant at a profit.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 6. -- The third successive Presidential landslide appears to be in the making in Kentucky. In the State that went for Herbert Hoover by 177,000 in 1928 and then turned round and outdid itself to give a 186,000 majority for Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932, the only question now is the size of the vote it will pile up to help keep the latter in power at Washington for another four years.

Speaking as the guest of a group of Republican women who intend to vote Democratic this year, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt outlined yesterday her conception of women's attitude in a changing world. Curiosity toward different social groups, closer contacts and "understanding people first hand" are of first importance to women, she said.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- Appearing in Federal Circuit Court here today as counsel for minority stockholders of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, Simon H. Rifkind of New York, law partner of United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, asked permission to file a suit against the company's former officers and directors to recover between $80,000,000 and $100,000,000.

Exporters for the first time are expected this year to enter a national campaign as an organized unit to make an active drive for the election of the Republican candidates for President and Vice President. It was pointed out yesterday they were disturbed over domination of their business in Washington from "behind closed doors" by theorists with no practical experience and over the effect of the reciprocity treaties negotiated under the Roosevelt administration.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Oct. 6.-- The end of the sixth day of my dash around the world found me in Alexandria today.

Speakers from various branches of the educational field attacked last night the proposed new eligibility requirements for teaching licenses at a hearing before the Board of Education at 500 Park Avenue.

Continued demand for second-grade and convertible corporate bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange carried prices in many issues to new high levels. Sales reached $17,102,400, the heaviest turnover since July 15, and compared with $14,922,700 on Monday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Traders showed considerable indifference to bullish developments in the wheat situation today, and the failure of a broad outside business to develop on the Board of Trade here on damage reports from the Southern hemisphere led to selling by tired longs.

Marine police continued their search last night for the body of a man believed to be Charles H. Barnes, 37 years old, of 45-26 256th Street, Great Neck, L.I., who leaped 150 feet from the Williamsburg Bridge to the East River shortly before 10:30 A.M. yesterday, after abandoning his car on the south roadway of the span.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Receipts of hogs were in excess of expectations and proved to be somewhat above grade requirements. Most offerings were of medium to good quality, ranging from 160 to 210 pounds, with sales 5 to 15 cents below yesterday's market.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., Oct. 6. -- Fred McPhaul of Hillside, N.J., an aviator salesman for the Standard Oil Company with headquarters at the Newark (N.J.) Airport, was burned to death here this afternoon when his monoplane crashed from a height of about 800 feet and burst into flames as it plowed into the ground.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- Quoting from sworn statements relating to Works Progress Administration activities, William Hard, commentator for the Republican National Committee, asserted tonight in a radio broadcast that the "best and easiest" way to get a good WPA job in Pennsylvania was to be "a good, a very good, Democratic New Dealer."

A seven-ton truck and a Melrose Avenue trolley-car, with seventy-nine passengers aboard, were in collision at 5:05 P.M. yesterday in Webster Avenue between 194th and 195th Streets, the Bronx, causing slight injuries to forty-nine men, women and children on the trolley-car. There were no arrests.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 6 (AP). -- Routing the forces of Thomas P. McCoy, Blackstone Valley leader, the Democratic State organization today forced the nomination of Lieut. Gov. Robert E. Quinn for Governor in a stormy State convention.

With Harry Newman, former Michigan star, as their pilot the Brooklyn Tigers will make their debut in the American Football League in a contest With the New York Yankees at Randalls Island Stadium at 8:30 o'clock tonight.

Columbia's football squad went through one of the longest and most strenuous practice sessions of the year yesterday at Baker Field in preparation for its encounter with Army at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday. Not a single member of the Lion squad was idle during the three-hour workout.
The following observations are from your Topics of The Times, which I read with interest Sept. 27:

The Board of Aldermen again refused yesterday to approve the purchase of almost $1,000,000 of new snow-fighting equipment, after Mayor La Guardia had rallied 100 civic workers at City Hall in an effort to compel the sanctioning of his plans.
ROME, Oct. 6. -- In the light of Italy's action yesterday in devaluing the lira it cannot but be conceded that Germany has failed utterly to tie Italy to the chariot of her monetary policy.

Frank J. Prial, insurgent Democrat, announced yesterday that he would not run as an independent for the Aldermanic Presidency this Fall even if he should lose in his court fight to force a recount of the votes cast in the recent primary when he was defeated for the party nomination by 25,000 votes by Sheriff William F. Brunner.

Governor Lehman launched his campaign for re-election in an acceptance speech at the National Democratic Club last night in which he charged William F. Bleakley, his Republican opponent, with advocating a "counsel of weakness and executive futility" which would "retard progressive legislation in this State for many decades."

The Manati Sugar Company petitioned the Federal court here yesterday for an opportunity to emerge from a receivership by reorganizing under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act. It asserted that the Cuban raw sugar industry had markedly improved and that the company had been carefully managed since a receiver was appointed on Feb. 9, 1932.
